column2: Sheriff-Elect Peter J. McGuinness, who admits he has received more congratulatory messages than any other elected official in Brooklyn, amazed his Democratic colleagues yesterday by producing a humorous and friendly letter from Mayor La Guardia that revealed a long-established friendship between the Greenpoint Democratic boss and the Fusion standard bearer.

For the first time since the week of July 27 New York City's infant mortality rate rose last week in comparison with last year, according to the weekly report of the Department of Health. Officials pointed out, however, that the rate for the year to date was still only 47.8 per 1,000 live births compared to 50.6 in 1932, the previous record year.

Sixteen men faced the East yesterday afternoon in the basement of the Syrian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Nicholas, 347 State Street, Brooklyn, and in Greek and Arabic chanted the Kyrie Eleison. It was the opening of the final session at which ballots were counted electing three nominees for the office of Archbishop of the Syrian Church of New York and all North America.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today, no movements of significance taking place. The Stock Exchange appears to have definitely returned to its position as a wholly meaningless institution so far as it might be expected to give a clue to fundamental financial or economic conditions of the Reich.

John H. Shaw, Ethopian Consul General, accepted yesterday on behalf of the Ethiopian Government the first medical supplies and equipment to be sent from here to the Ethiopian Red Cross in the war zones.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- United States Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York declared today he would demand the recall of Ambassador Josephus Daniels from Mexico when Congress convened in January. Mr. Fish, ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, criticized the administration's non-intervention policy in Mexico.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 19. -- Although the Ethiopian Government, for obvious reasons, will not disclose the whereabouts of Emperior Haile Selassie or details of his sudden, although not unexpected, departure for the front, it was learned today that he took advantage of the preoccupation of newspaper correspondents, whose own caravan of motor trucks left for Dessye early this morning.

Fordham's football team yesterday moved a step further toward completing its defensive plans for the game with New York University on Thanksgiving Day. In a three-hour drill at Fordham Field the Rams were tried time and again on knocking down Violet passes.

WISE, Va., Nov. 19. -- A Cumberland Mountain jury convicted Edith Maxwell, 21-year-old school teacher, tonight. She was sentenced to twenty-five years in the State penitentiary for the death of her father, whom she hit with a slipper when he objected to her "running around" at night.
Dr. Max Einhorn, noted gastro-enterologist, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of his connection with the Lenox Hill Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- October internal revenue collections of $192,218,490 were $17,478,720 smaller than in the same month of 1934, due to a shrinkage in the collection of processing taxes, according to an analysis made public today by the Treasury Department. For the four months of the fiscal year from July 1 to Oct. 31, however, total receipts were $1,037,689,743.44 or $23,114,367.75 greater than in the same four months last year.

Harry Glaser, 56 years old, a vaudeville actor of thirty years ago, shot and killed his common-law wife, Mona Clark, 52, as she lay in bed at 10:40 A.M. yesterday in the three-room apartment they occupied at 88 Amsterdam Avenue, near Sixty-fourth Street.

BUFFALO, Nov. 19. -- A plan for reorganization of the Wickwire-Spencer Steel Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was approved today by Federal Judge John Knight. He called the plan fair and equitable and said it would mean continuance of the concern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The President's Cup, which was won in the September regatta by the Notre Dame, was presented personally by President Roosevelt to Herbert Mendelsohn, owner of the boat, at the White House today.

Indicating that he did not regard the re-election of President Roosevelt as certain, Professor Raymond Moley, former Assistant Secretary of State, editor of Today and an original member of the Roosevelt "brain trust," proposed last night a four-point program which, he said, the Democratic party should adopt as a matter of strategy as an aid to winning the 1936 election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Mayor La Guardia was characterized by Secretary Ickes today as "an exclamation point boy," eager for publicity. The Secretary declared that the PWA was running far ahead of schedule on its part of the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program.

Solly Kreiger, 160, Brooklyn, stopped Tom Chester, 158 3/4, Harlem, in 2:01 of the sixth chapter of their scheduled ten-round bout at the boxing show staged at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A gathering of 2,000 saw Referee Jack O'Sullivan stop the feature clash to save the loser from unnecessary punishment.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Three Croat terrorists, on trial for complicity in the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia, began a hunger strike tonight in protest against the disbarring of their lawyer.

The National Hotel Management Company, organized by officers of the Manufacturers Trust Company to operate hotel properties for which it is trustee, pays the New Yorker Hotel $10,000 a year rent for its offices there, although the five rooms also are used as offices by the management of the New Yorker.

Twenty-five hundred "Stakhanoffites" seem to have worked themselves into an almost religious ecstasy at their meeting in Moscow this week to spread the gospel of "Stakhanoffism." Stakhanoffism is described in the dispatches as the name given to a system of cooperative work devised by a Soviet coal miner, ALEXEI STAKHANOFF.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents...

An effort to help needy lawyers, of whom there are said to be some 6,000 in this city, with 1,800 registered with the Emergency Relief Bureau, was undertaken yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator.

World production continued to rise slowly during September, while prices of international foodstuffs and raw materials advanced sharply, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.
All-night motor patrol activities have been resumed by the Long Island Coast Guard after having been abandoned when prohibition was repealed, it was learned yesterday.

HOUSTON, Nov. 19. -- A message from President Roosevelt presented tonight before the world trade dinner of the National Foreign Trade Convention declared that world trade must be liberalized and freed from "discriminatory" practices.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 19.--A fierce battle between Italian pilots and Ethiopian land forces said to total 20,000 was described today by jubilant Fascisti, who estimated the enemy dead at about 2,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The North China crisis was discussed by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, during a half-hour's informal conversation today with William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State, but with nothing developing to indicate that any immediate concrete moves were in prospect to discourage Japan on her course in the autonomy movement.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 19. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the National Foreign Trade Convention:

The name of James Branch Cabell, which has not appeared on the title page of any publication since 1930 -- (the author has been calling himself "Branch Cabell" in an effort to demarcate his earlier books from his later ones) -- will again appear on a book which McBride announces for publication in February.

ROME, Nov. 19. -- As sanctions and counter-sanctions go into effect, Italy is quiet and pessimistic. A conversation with Premier Mussolini and a canvass of the views of representatives of sanctionist governments reveal that there is little hope anywhere for a solution of the conflict, entering a new phase with the beginning of the economic siege.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 (London Times Dispatch). -- A judgment reflecting unfavorably on the claims of German ministers that the State does not interfere with the freedom of religious conscience has just been delivered by the Essen Labor Court.
Edward F. Hutton, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, is in favor of industry "ganging up" and forming one all-powerful lobby to combat collectivism in government.
OSLO, Nov. 19. -- The Nobel committee has decided that no peace prize will be awarded this year.

The Kings County grand jury may vote indictments in the Druckman murder case before the end of the week, but it will not complete its separate inquiry into the alleged $100,000 bribe offer until next month, it was learned yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 19. -- The second day of sanctions against Italy passed uneventfully. Flags still flew from every window under a blazing sun, walls were still plastered with posters urging the population to buy nothing but Italian goods and the door-to-door collection of iron and other metals continued, but life flowed as usual.

Milton Soroka, N.Y.U. sophomore and candidate for the Violet varsity fencing team, captured the Dr. Graeme Hammond Prize by winning the individual prep foils competition at the New York Athletic Club last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address today to the United States Conference of Mayors was as follows:

Commending President Roosevelt's action to preserve American neutrality in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, the World Alliance for International Friendship through the churches urged Congress to extend the scope of the enabling legislation to cover "all potential war materials" in its annual message sent yesterday to members and branches.
Of the games still to be played on Eastern gridirons during the two remaining weeks there are two that will be watched with nation-wide interest.

The drive for its engagement with Fordham on Thanksgiving Day at the Yankee Stadium began for the New York University varsity football squad behind closed doors at Ohio Field yesterday. Undefeated and untied in seven games this season, this traditional clash with the Ram, the seventeenth in the series, will be one of the most important contests in a decade for the Violet.

The Bijou Theatre gets a play this evening, when "Satellite" descends on Forty-fifth Street. It is a farce comedy by Kerry Shaw and Joseph Mitchell, and the four chief players are these: Noel Francis, Stanley Smith, Barbara Weeks and Joyce White.

James F. Whalen and Harry J. Wheeler were elected co-captains of the 1936 Manhattan College varsity football team at a meeting of the lettermen last night. They succeed John J. (Red) Welch and Jerome E. Buckley, who shared the honor during the season which closed last Saturday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP). -- An underground retreat built by Russia's Czars 400 years ago, containing a supply of cannonballs, was discovered today by workers digging an extension of the Moscow subway.

Miss Mary Rose Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lorenzo D. Armstrong of this city and Riverside, Conn., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Junior League Club for three debutantes, the Misses Marion Stewart Durand, Anne Hoguet and Sybil King. The luncheon was served in the private dining room at several tables decorated with Autumn flowers.

A warning against an impostor who describes himself as "Commissioner Laynar of the State Tax Department" and solicits funds on a pretext of providing for needy families was issued yesterday by Jacob Manicoff, deputy commissioner in charge of the New York City office of the State Tax Commission.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Dr. M.A. Warriner, dean of Bridgeport's practicing physicians, today espoused "mercy killings" of incurable patients and confessed that forty-eight years ago he performed one, for which his conscience had never troubled him.

A complete schedule of workmen's compensation medical fees, with charges ranging from $2 for an office call to $225 for a bilateral mastoid operation, has been recommended to the State Department of Labor by Dr. Frederic E. Sondern, president of the Medical Society of the State of New York, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

J.P. Morgan, asked yesterday on his return from a vacation abroad whether he thought the recent bullish stock market would help to bring prosperity, replied that he did not think that bull markets make for prosperity.

The Marquess of Queensberry, Sir William and Lady Margaret Acland, Sir Frederick Rueter and the Baron and Baroness De Kerchove are among the passengers sailing for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others leaving on the ship for Cherbourg and Southampton include:

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Benjamin W. Cooper, 72 years old, a member of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission, who lived at Moorestown, was injured fatally today in an automobile collision on Route 25 at the intersection of Columbus Road, in Florence Township.

Louis Capone, 37 years old, part owner of a restaurant at 2,780 Stillwell Avenue, Brooklyn, surrendered himself yesterday in connection with the murder of Joseph Amberg and the latter's chauffeur, Morris Kessler, who were shot down Sept. 20 in a garage at 385 Blake Avenue, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Former President Hoover today characterized the Canadian trade treaty negotiated by President Roosevelt as "more of the abundant life -- for Canadians." It was his second attack on New Deal policies within four days.

Five hundred railroad men of all ranks, from secetion hand to president, are to dine in the Hotel Roosevelt tonight to observe the sixtieth anniversary of the beginning of Young Men's Christian Association work among railroad forces here. The hotel is on the site of the first Railroad Y. M. C. A. building.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange held again within a limited range yesterday under steady mill calling based on the December position, which was adequate to absorb long liquidation in advance of notices on Monday. The spread between December and October of the 1936 crop widened to 65 points, although each month sold at the same figure three weeks ago.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 19. -- On a muddy field surrounded by banked snow the Dartmouth varsity had its first taste of Princeton's offense today.

The discovery of an unusually extensive area containing one of the world's richest deposits of ancient sea serpents and other giant marine animals that roamed an inland sea extending from the Gulf of Mexico to the Arctic Ocean about a hundred million years ago, was announced here yesterday by Dr. Barnum Brown, curator of fossil reptiles of the American Museum of Natural History.

Earle Combs's days as a player with the Yankees ended yesterday with the announcement from the American League Club's headquarters that the Kentucky veteran will be retained next year as coach, succeeding Joey Sewell, who is destined for a minor league managerial berth.

The program of work and home relief is now a Permanent part of the nation's life and it will bankrupt the Federal and New York City administrations if it continues to expand at its present rate, Edward Corsi, Deputy Commissioner of Welfare, declared yesterday.

A nation-wide "service league" to reunite runaway boys and girls and their families was suggested yesterday as the most fitting memorial to Will Rogers by Mrs. Frances Rogers, founder of the Girls Service League and the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York City.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 19. -- Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, passed a more satisfactory day in the North Country Community Hospital here today. According to the bulletins issued by Dr. Richard Derby, her son-in-law and chief of staff of the institution, Mrs. Roosevelt's condition was slightly improved, as her heart action was stronger.

The completion of the official canvass of the vote cast in the recent election for several county offices in Manhattan, Queens and Richmond was announced yesterday by the Board of Elections. The Manhattan returns for General Sessions judge and Supreme Court justice follow:

Department store sales in the metropolitan area for the thirteen shopping days from Nov. 1 to 15 showed a decline of 4.7 per cent under the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov 19.--A plea that missionaries be sent to Civilian Conservation Corps camps to help check "the drinking, gambling and other vices found there" was made today by the Rev. H.E. Woolever, editor of The National Methodist Press, at the annual meeting of the Methodist Board of Home Missions and Church Extension.

A group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. is offering $4,600,000 of State of New York 4 per cent bonds, of which $350,000 is dated Sept. 1, 1915, and due on Sept. 1, 1965, and $4,250,000 dated Jan. 1, 1916, due on Jan. 1, 1966. The bonds are legal investment, in the opinion of the bankers, for savings banks and trust funds in New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 19. -- An immediate survey of the damage caused by the week-end storm will be started by United States Army engineers, it was announced today in a telegram sent to Bryant B. Newcomb, former Monmouth County official, by United States Senator A. Harry Moore.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19. -- Selection today of the team that will face Harvard Saturday made firmer than ever the conviction that the Blue's coaches expect one of the most strenuous battles of the season in Harvard Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, issued today a list of thirty corporations which have accepted invitations to attend the Dec. 9 conference on NRA's future. Some 5,000 invitations to labor and business leaders have been issued.

Plans for two eleven-story apartment houses of unusual type, to be erected by John D. Rockefeller Jr. on a large site in West Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, were announced yesterday by the Rockefeller interests, following the filing in Albany of a certificate of incorporation for the operating company, to be known as the 17 West Fifty-fourth Street Corporation.

A group of chefs peered and nodded their heads over an exhibition of sculpture and painting yesterday at Grand Central Palace land then, after consultation, awarded prizes. It was fitting that chefs make the awards because the sculpture was executed with sugar and pastry and the painting was done with cocoa.

A three-day bazaar, Ye Olde English Faire, under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire, will be opened officially this afternoon at the Biltmore by Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York. Features today include a fashion show and divertissements, followed by tea. Useful articles suitable for holiday gifts will be offered for sale at booths decorated with Jubilee Year colors and representing the twenty-five chapters of the organization.

Successful with brilliant masse shots, Edmund Soussa, defending champion, routed Edgar T. Appleby, who has held the title five times, 300 -- 87, as the players started their challenge round encounter for the national amateur 18.2 balkline billiards championship at the Metropolitan Billiard Club last night.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 19. -- "A direct slap at President Roosevelt" was the interpretation given here today by John H. Traynor, chairman of the Westfield Democratic Committee, to the action of the Westfield Board of Education in changing the name of the Roosevelt Junior High School here to Theodore Roosevelt Junior High School.

Regulatory measures and machinery set up by government, with the mistaken idea that spreading a net that covers the honest and the dishonest alike, are often foredoomed to failure through maladministration or lack of voluntary cooperation, H.J. Kenner, general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, declared in a talk here last night.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19. -- While the annual California-Stanford classic at Palo Alto Saturday in all probability will decide which team shall represent the West in the Rose Bowl game, official announcement will not come until Nov. 29.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Commission-house buying and short covering more than offset anything bearish in the wheat market today on the Board of Trade, and while prices fell about 1/2 cent a bushel early in sympathy with Winnipeg, the close was at net gains of 1/4 cent.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange today were less firm than yesterday, being weakened by profit-taking. Further selling sent British funds lower, mainly as a result of the prospect of a resumption of municipal borrowing. Far Eastern issues declined in the foreign department of the market due to the latest developments in the world situation. Brazilian shares went lower in the absence of support.

The report of Referee Philip J. Dunn finding that the former officers of the Exempt Firemen's Benevolent Fund had mismanaged the fund and failed to account adequately for nearly $1,500,000 paid out between 1920 and 1930 was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Torgsin, or foreign currency, shops were packed throughout the day today by excited crowds seeking to make purchases before valuta (foreign exchange value) ceases to be a medium of exchange.

Prime Minister BALDWIN, after his great victory in the election, is reported to be planning several changes in his Cabinet. Cabinet making is hard enough, but Cabinet remaking is a task which Prime Ministers have often found to be almost cruel. There are so many personal sensibilities to be considered, so many political claims to be weighed, such rivalries to be composed.

The selection of Edward J. Clark of Buffalo, assistant to Irving M. Ives, minority leader of the present Assembly, as clerk of the next Assembly seemed assured yesterday. Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, announced after a conference with a group of influential county leaders at the National Republican Club that Erie County would receive one of the four "key" Assembly positions.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- The International League today unanimously adopted its pennant playoff system again for 1936 and voted for a 154-game season, opening April 16 and closing Sept. 7. The opening day schedule:

Peter S. Duryee, roll-call chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, said yesterday that gains must be made in all divisions of the drive to raise $400,000 for the chapter's work if the goal is to be reached by Thanksgiving Day.

As Mr. KROCK summed it up yesterday, the Democratic strategy for the 1936 campaign would seem to be the acme of simplicity. Every effort will be made to retain the loyalty of Ras GEORGE W. NORRIS of the province of Nebraska, and Ras GEORGE N. PEEK, whose influence is paramount among the agricultural tribesmen of Illinois, Iowa and the Dakotas.

PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Arturo Toscanini, through his manager, today denied he intends to retire next Spring. The manager thus dismissed reports from New York that Toscanini was surrendering his directorship of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society there.

During the last few years there has been a marked trend in the field of child welfare work to administer relief through public rather than private agencies, according to Dr. C.C. Carstens, executive secretary of the Child Welfare League of America, who spoke yesterday at the Hotel Lexington at a luncheon meeting of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

The first of a series of special gifts committee meetings in connection with the current drive of the United Hospital Campaign Committee was held yesterday at the Union Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street. Walter S. Gifford urged New York's young men to enroll as members of the campaign committee.
Georges Barrere, flutist, will present a program and officiate at a discussion of his new platinum flute this afternoon at Sherry's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Receipts of $1,071,000 from the series of balls held on President Roosevelt's birthday anniversary last January for aid in fighting infantile paralysis were reported to Mr. Roosevelt today when he entertained at luncheon the members of the Commisison for Infantile paralysis Research.
PARIS, Nov. 19. -- It is understood that gold exports since last Thursday show a loss of about 1,000,000,000 francs.

Complaints were made in business and shipping circles yesterday that the teamsters', longshoremen's and allied unions had revived their picket lines, keeping trucks with non-union drivers off the steamship piers, and refusing to handle merchandise hauled by non-union trucks.
In reference to THE TIMES editorial "Air Accidents" I wish to present my theory of its probable solution.

MANILA, Nov. 19. -- A universal military service scheme aimed to provide the Philippine Commonwealth with 500,000 trained reservists by the time of complete independence in 1945 was revealed by Manuel Quezon today in his first press conference since he assumed the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Work around the clock is the order of the day at WPA headquarters, where a "wartime" rush is on to push through as many projects as possible before the 3,500,000 job deadline, Dec. 1.
The Chase National Bank prepared to deliver definitive Southern California Gas Company first mortgage and refunding bonds, 4 per cent series, due in 1965 in exchange for temporary bonds.

ROME, Nov. 19. -- It is learned here that the British Broadcasting Corporation, which at the end of the last meeting of the League of Nations Assembly refused to extend to Baron Pompeo Aloisi, the Italian delegate, facilities to permit him to make a radio speech to American listeners, now refuses to permit Marchese Guglielmo Marconi, father of wireless, to address the British public.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19. -- Blinkers, the equine rogue's badge, were worn by Transporter in the Notley Purse today, with the result that the son of The Porter improved so mightily as to overcome eight rivals in a mile and seventy yards test. Included among those that finished out of the money was Thirteen Stars, a colt which defeated Transporter in the last previous start for both last Saturday.

ON BOARD THE S.S. SANTA MARGARITA, Wednesday, Nov. 20. -- The finding of the complete skeleton of a man on Santa Cruz Indefatigable Island in Tortuga Bay in the Galapagos Islands, by an American scientist either solves or complicates the mysteries of this desert-like archipelago.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Welker Cochran, who was born in Iowa, received his first lessons in cue skill in Chicago and now resides in San Francisco, won the world's 3-cushion championship tonight.

Members of the Actors Equity Association, seeking information on whether to uphold the Equity administration or the militant and unofficial Equity group called the Actors Forum, met informally late Monday evening at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Forty-fourth Street.

Directors of music and of art have been chosen by the Board of Education with the advice of the Municipal Art Committee to organize the city's new Music and Arts High School, which will open in February at 135th Street and Convent Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman of the committee.

Without benefit of new developments of importance bearing on the financial scene, the share market moved more confidently yesterday, the degree increasing as the day progressed, culminating in a brisk advance in the last hour; the closing was strong with leading issues up 1 to 3 points, a few even more.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Full ownership of the world champion Tigers, it was announced today, will be acquired by Walter O. Briggs, Detroit industrialist and sportsman who for fifteen years was silent partner of the late Frank J. Navin in control of the club.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Reports that economic developments in Russia have made that country increasingly attractive for British investment have been followed by an announcement that British and Soviet officials had had their heads together for more than a fortnight at the British Board of Trade, seeking an increase in Russian purchases of British goods by means of increased credit facilities or by a loan.
ALBANY, Nov. 19.--Devaluation of the dollar extends to foreign debts and foreign credits, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

Arthur S. Vernay returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria from a journey to Lhasa, Tibet, with Suydam Cutting on an expedition for the American Museum of Natural History, of which both are trustees. He said they had collected more than 250 specimens of rare plants, birds and reptiles from the region around Lhasa and the Himalayas, which they had crossed.

Cardinal Hayes told an audience of 700 Roman Catholic men and women at the Waldorf-Astoria last night that the "splendid Catholic spirit" exemplified by the support for old St. Peter's Church in Barclay Street should serve as a stirring example to the people of the faith throughout the country.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $43,963,500 of Ohio Edison Company first and consolidated mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1965 by a syndicate headed by Morgan, Stanley Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc. The bonds will be priced at 100 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.971 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- With the deadline for registration by public utility holding companies rapidly approaching, it was reported today that further study was being given by the government and executives of some of the companies to determine whether any action could be taken further to assure the holding companies that they would not forfeit their constitutional or legal rights by registering.

The City Athletic Club team broke its tie with the Crescents for first place in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association last night by defeating the defending champions, 3 to 2, on the Crescent courts. The teams had been deadlocked at two victories each.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Showing the same hard drive and high spirit so evident in yesterday's practice, Princeton's football squad went through a long passing, running and kicking drill on University Field today in preparation for the important meeting with the undefeated Dartmouth eleven in Palmer Stadium Saturday.

The seventeenth volume of Dictionary of American Biography runs from SEWELL to STEVENSON. Here are fames still bright and many more that time has tarnished. SHERMAN and SHERIDAN are the mightiest of the soldiers. ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, THADDEUS STEVENS, JOHN SHERMAN, EDWIN M. STANTON are perhaps best remembered of the statesmen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Rhine-Main-Danube Corporation (Rhein-Main-Donau Aktiengesellschaft) has filed an application on Form 21 for permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $1,660,000 of 7 per cent sinking fund gold debentures, Series A, due on Sept. 1, 1950.

JOHN B. SANFORD gets excited about America, not for any ascertainable philosophical reasons, but simply because he loves its patterns and its contours. He is, to the novel, what the school of Thomas Benton or Grant Wood is to painting -- a "nativist" who takes a purely esthetic delight in the salt and savor, even in the occasional flaring brutality, of the American character.

James Gregory of 2,307 Avenue D, Brooklyn, who recently retired after operating street cars in Brooklyn for fifty-one years, will be guest of honor at a dinner to be given by several hundred employes and executives of the B.M.T. next Tuesday at the Midwood Grill, Flatbush Avenue and Clarendon Road, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Evelena Dixon Stevens, 62 years old, was killed at 5:20 P.M. yesterday when she accidentally fell from a window of a small study in her fourteen-room apartment on the eleventh floor at 405 Park Avenue. Her body landed in a courtyard on the Fifty-fourth Street side of the building.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- A sensation was caused throughout the country today by the news that Dr. Hermann Gortz, a German novelist and former flying officer, is now being held at Brixton prison, London, as an alleged spy.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 19. -- Victor Thaddeus, author of "Frederick the Great," "Julius Caesar" and other biographies, spent today helping to clean the interior of the New Castle County Workhouse. Sent to the prison for three days for refusal to pay a fine of $1 and sign a $200 peace bond, he notified Magistrate E.B. Griffenburg of Holly Oak that he would complete his jail term and would sign the bail bond when released.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19. -- Superior Judge Franklin A. Griffin, who nineteen years ago sentenced Tom Mooney to death for the Preparedness Day bombing, appeared upon the witness stand today seeking the prisoner's release on habeas corpus.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 19. -- Chief Mourner, owned by J.D. Norris, won the $2,500 Endurance Purse on the final day of the New England racing season at Narragansett Park today. About 25,000 spectators watched the card of seven events and it was estimated that $75,000 would be realized for charity as the result of the racing yesterday and today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Mayor La Guardia, who yesterday criticized "red tape" in the Public Works Administration, defended the Works Progress Administration today at the Mayors' conference.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Nov. 19. -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek, referring to the trial of the three men accused of complicity in the assassination of King Alexander, told the press today:

Loan sharks continued to fare badly in Special Sessions yesterday as James Canzoneri, money lender to postal employes of the Grand Central branch, and Louis Blumenthal, who used a restaurant in the fur district as headquarters, were found guilty by Justices Frederic Kernochan, Max Salomon and Thomas J. Brady.

Funeral services for Mrs. Bella Shedlin, who died Sunday of her injuries after being paralyzed for twelve years by a bullet fired by a rookie patrolman, were held Monday at the home of her father, Morris Dreiblatt, 1,108 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 19. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and Elizabeth Town and Country Club continued undefeated as a result of today's matches in Division B of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Retribution is facing all but eight members of the thirty-eight "Gas House Gang" Cardinals who weakened last Fall as the Cubs went on to take the National League pennant.

BATTLE CREEK, Nov. 19. -- Winning every one of the five counties in the Third Congressional District, Verner W. Main, Townsend Plan candidate, swept the primary election in a field of five candidates. His total vote was 13,419.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A list of heads of essential industries who are opposed to the New Deal program will be announced soon by Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee as the finance committee of the Republican party.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- Leslie Tower, chief test pilot for the Boeing Aircraft Company, Seattle, died in a hospital here this evening from burns and internal injuries suffered Oct. 30 in the crash of the Boeing 299, a giant bombing plane which was under test at Wright Field.

ROME, Nov. 19 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini declared a monopoly on all of Italy's gold tonight as the nation stood firm on a program of no compromise with countries applying sanctions against it because of the invasion of Ethiopia.

Twice last night the New York Rangers seemed on the threshold of their first home victory of the National Hockey League season. But each time they allowed the Detroit Red Wings to catch up with them, with the result that the sextets battled to a 2-2 overtime tie at Madison Square Garden.

Numerous gains were registered on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. The volume of trading was comparatively heavy. Only the metals, hides and cottonseed oil showed losses from the levels of the previous day. On the cash markets all the grains, rubber, eggs and wooltops advanced, while tin and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- In a letter to the publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, made public to the press, Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, took issue with a story published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday regarding the work relief load which is being carried by the several emergency agencies and setting forth some details regarding the Resettlement Administration.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

With hopes high for a victory over Brown on Saturday, Columbia engaged in a long scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field. Coach Lou Little made frequent changes in the eleven that started against the reserves, so that all members of the first two teams had an opportunity to perform with the varsity.

The Blue Ridge Corporation, control of which was obtained jointly last week by interests connected with Harrison Williams, Field, Glore Co., and J. and W. Seligman Co., through trusts sponsored by them, has offered to acquire at $43 a share its outstanding $3 dividend convertible preference stock.
The legal questions raised in your editorial of Nov. 17, "Treaty With Italy," are susceptible, I think, of ready answer.

ATHENS, Nov. 19. -- The four members of the delegation sent formally to London to invite King George to return to Greece arrived at Athens this morning. An article published in this evening's Tsaldarist newspaper Neon furnished some indication of the impressions the delegation brought direct from the King.

A year of celebrations of the centennial of the birth of Samuel L. Clemens, better known to the world as Mark Twain, came to a climax last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, attended by more than 1,000 guests devoted to the memory of one of the nation's foremost humorists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A "statement of facts" on the purchase of German steel for the Triborough Bridge in New York and the Morehead City (N.C.) ocean terminal will be presented to President Roosevelt, Secretary Ickes announced today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19. -- Dummy scrimmages against the freshman team made up the major portion of Harvard's workout today.

Directors of Remington Rand, Inc., declared yesterday two initial cash quarterly dividends of 31 1/4 cents each on the new 5 per cent prior preferred stock, payable Jan. 1 and April, 1936, to stockholders of record Dec. 10 and March 10 respectively.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Responsible Chinese reports from the North said today that North China leaders, despite a strongly worded Japanese warning, were slow to rally to the Japanese-sponsored autonomy movement.
If the nominating committee of the Long Island Golf Association heeds the advice of the executive committee of that body there will be no change in officials for 1936.

The publication today of the seventeenth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography brings that work within three volumes of completion. The remaining volumes, it is expected, will be completed by next Summer.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins opened their National Hockey League home season tonight with a 1-0 victory over the New York Americans before 10,000 fans at the Boston Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Management of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company was divorced today from that of the Commonwealth Edison Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois in the first move to break up the union of the three big local utilities that has existed fifteen years, during and since the Insull regime.
DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctic Archipelago, Nov. 18. -- We are off to try our luck in the unknown frozen wilderness of Antarctica.
The legal questions raised in your editorial of Nov. 17, "Treaty With Italy," are susceptible, I think, of ready answer.

ATHENS, Nov. 19. -- The four members of the delegation sent formally to London to invite King George to return to Greece arrived at Athens this morning. An article published in this evening's Tsaldarist newspaper Neon furnished some indication of the impressions the delegation brought direct from the King.

A year of celebrations of the centennial of the birth of Samuel L. Clemens, better known to the world as Mark Twain, came to a climax last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, attended by more than 1,000 guests devoted to the memory of one of the nation's foremost humorists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A "statement of facts" on the purchase of German steel for the Triborough Bridge in New York and the Morehead City (N.C.) ocean terminal will be presented to President Roosevelt, Secretary Ickes announced today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19. -- Dummy scrimmages against the freshman team made up the major portion of Harvard's workout today.

TOKYO, Nov. 19. -- Dispatches from China today give the North China autonomy scheme more of a Chinese aspect and less of a Japanese one than earlier reports attributed to Japanese sources had indicated. The scheme, as now outlined, appears to have been cleverly devised to meet a difficult situation without involving irreparable consequences.

The distress at Washington over the difficulties of putting the Utility Holding Company Act into operation, and the equal distress of the holding company managements over the course to be followed by them, must be traced to the source if anything is to be learned from this humiliating series of episodes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The difficulty, if not the impossibility, of making a solid partisan front on economic issues in the United States nowadays is well illustrated by the early volleys against the reciprocal treaty with Canada. Because of world changes, conflicting bands of economic thought have dropped to horizontal in this country, resting athwart both the major parties.

The negotiation of such an agreement as the new treaty of reciprocity with Canada inevitably raises in the minds of many people the old fear of foreign competition. If Canada is to be permitted to sell us more goods, will not these goods displace in our markets a corresponding amount of our own goods, with injurious consequences for both profits and employment?

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,850,600 barrels, compared with 2,802,250 in the previous week, a gain of 48,350, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 23,650 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and 18,950 in Texas were among important changes.

Memories of their old schoolhouse, still standing at 60 West Thirteenth Street, were recalled by members of the Thomas Hunter Association of Grammar School No. 35, at their thirty-ninth annual dinner and reunion at the Hotel Astor last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP). -- A "grass revolution," in the form of a permanent AAA intended to promote an era of sound farming practices, was forecast tonight by Chester C. Davis, Farm Administrator.

Dispersal of the art collection of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop began last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., with the sale of rare engravings and etchings for a total of $38,055.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The British Ambassador and Lady Lindsay, Justice and Mrs. Pierce Butler, others in official circles, and members of the younger set were guests at a farewell dance given tonight at the Mayflower Hotel by Mrs. Benjamin Plunket, who will leave Saturday for her home in Dublin, after a six weeks' visit here. Benjamin Plunket, her son, is an attache of the British Embassy.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 19. -- Figuratively "hitching his wagon" to a cosmic ray, a messenger from interstellar space, Dr. Robert A. Millikan, who won the Nobel Prize for measuring the infinitesimal charge of the electron, today presented before the National Academy of Sciences a new map of the contours of the immense, invisible ocean of magnetism wherein the earth floats like a tiny bubble in space.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market may be revoked for causes arising between the date of filing a registration application and the effective date of registration, as well as for causes arising after the effective date, according to an amendment to its ruling announced today by the commission.

THE TIMES editorial "General Welfare," which indicates that the government attorneys seek to support legislation now under attack by recourse to the Preamble of the Constitution, is predicated upon a misconception of the provisions of our organic act.

The United States must buy more foreign goods if it expects to increase its sales abroad, Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, declared yesterday in an address at the Marine Exhibition at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- President Roosevelt and his chief relief officer, Harry L. Hopkins, gave pledges today to American Mayors that there would be no "starvation," because Federal aid to the jobless would continue while necessary.

Benjamin W. Hendrickson, 45 years old, who for ten years had been employed as import buyer by R.C. Williams Co., Inc., wholesale grocers at 265 Tenth Avenue, was arrested in his home at 14 Sunny Brae Road, Bronxville, yesterday, on suspicion of the theft of $92,000 from the concern.

ERMELO, The Netherlands, Nov. 19. -- Forty moves had been made tonight in the twenty-first game of the world's chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam when, after a session lasting five hours, play was adjourned until tomorrow without a decision having been reached.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange posted yesterday on the trading floor of the Exchange the names of eighty-three members who have been suggested for the 1936 nominating committee. From this list the present committee on Dec. 16 will pick a slate of twenty-one candidates, of whom seven will be chosen by members to compose the new nominating group at an election on Jan. 13.

TRENTON, Nov. 19. -- The New Jersey waterfowl hunting season, which opens tomorrow, will be one of the best for sportsmen in many years, according to officials of the State Fish and Game Commission today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in Albany said today that the State was merely an "interested spectator" in the case here in which Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close held unconstitutional the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act.

Domestic corporation bonds continued their spirited advance yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Second-grade and the more speculative issues received most attention and moved up sharply in brisk buying. The market for high-grade investment bonds maintained a steady undertone in dull trading.
PARIS, Nov. 19. -- France in a separate note to Italy today maintained her tone of friendship toward that country while associating herself with other League of Nations powers in applying sanctions.

While business failures declined in the retail division in the five business days ended Nov. 14, compared with the previous similar period, increases were shown in both the wholesale and manufacturing trade groups, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in Albany said today that the State was merely an "interested spectator" in the case here in which Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close held unconstitutional the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act.

The overwhelming feature of the concert given by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night was the performance of the Brahms violin concerto by Fritz Kreisler. No such performance of the work has been given in this city in many years.

The minimum wage scale of $128 for members of the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Association is to be in effect this season without any reduction in the form of donations to the association, as in the last few seasons, it was announced yesterday by the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802, A.F.M.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- As a result of the armed outbreak at Limoges Saturday night, when an assembly of Croix de Feu members "defended" itself against a Leftist counter-demonstration, a Cabinet crisis threatened today, and it was avoided only by a narrow margin.

Reductions aggregating $16,930,027 in the 1936 budget were urged yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission upon the finance committee the Board of Aldermen during its first public hearing on budget cuts at City Hall.

A new issue of $30,000,000 of first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1965 of the Kansas Power and Light Company will be offered today by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds will be priced at 103 and accrued interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Of a total of $406,086,507 of issues which became effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in October, $163,011,168, or 40.1 per cent, was registered by electric light, power, gas and water companies, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Two hours of dummy scrimmaging was the sole item on the program for the New York University varsity football squad which concluded its second day of work on Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for the annual clash with Fordham on Thanksgiving Day at the Yankee Stadium.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20. -Whatever may be the uncertainty of Harvard's starting back field against Yale on Saturday, at least the Cambridge coaches have decided on their line. Dubiel, expected to be behind the line instead of at end, will be at left end at the kick-off Saturday, it was made known today.

GALLUP, N.M., Nov. 20. -- The new Super-Chief train of the Santa Fe Railway, which left Chicago at 7 P.M. yesterday for a mile a minute run to Los Angeles, was halted at Dilco, six miles west of Gallup at 7:20 o'clock (9:30 Eastern standard time) this evening when the front half of its 3,600 horsepower Diesel electric engine caught fire and was disabled.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20. -Coach Ducky Pond today continued grooming Luther Loomis and Dick Miles for the Harvard contest, as the former regulars, Al Hessberg and Clint Frank, remained with the subs. The varsity ran through a brisk contact drill against the red jerseyed scrubs in the final hard work of the week.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Two chief puzzles concerning the composition of Stanley Baldwin's new Cabinet were solved tonight when it was officially announced at 10 Downing Street that "the King has been pleased to approve that the dignity of a viscounty of the United Kingdom be conferred upon the Right Hon. Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, G. B. E., M. C., and the Right Hon. Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, G. B. E."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has been assured of the cooperation of the management of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in its investigation of the road's management and financing.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Convened this afternoon in the Hotel Ten Eyck for its annual three-day assembly, the New York State League of Women Voters at its first session heard the State chairman, Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat, conclude a report of the year's work with a recommendation for a narrowing of its field of activities that greater progress be made on fewer fronts.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 20 (AP). -- Indigo, gray racer from the Northwood Stables of Oyster Bay, L.I., scored his second straight victory in the Fall meeting of the Middleburg Racing Association today, winning the R. Penn Smith Jr. Challenge Plate, three and a half miles over timber, the feature event.

On election day the new county home rule amendment was approved by a large vote. The City of New York is vested with power to act under the amendment for the five counties of Greater New York by a local law, for which I have no present responsibility. But the amendment further directs the Legislature to provide by law alternative forms of government for the fiftyseven counties outside of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- An agreement by the New York Central Railroad to pay in cash its $15,600,000 Dec. 1 maturity to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in return for extension of its remaining $11,899,000 until July 1, 1941, and certain other considerations was announced today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC.

Denunciations of New Deal policies and a call for "permanent peace" rather than a "breathing spell" for industry were heard yesterday by more than 185 industrialists from all parts of the country at the thirty-ninth annual convention of the National Founders Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Evidence was offered yesterday in the General Sessions trial of three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company that about $17,000,000 in securities, credited in a report to the State Insurance Superintendent on Jan. 4, 1933, as among the company's resources, previously had been pledged as collateral for loans.

A prize of $4,000 was offered yesterday by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co. for the best basal textbook or textbook series in the field of social studies for the senior high school. The term "social studies" is held by the publisher to include history, economics, civics and sociology.

Columbia's plan of combat against Brown on Saturday probably will be based along the line that a good offensive is the best defensive. For the third day in succession at Baker Field the Blue and White yesterday concentrated entirely on attacking manoeuvres, with forward passing receiving most of the attention.

Edmund Soussa, national amateur 18.2 balkline billiard champion, won the second block of his challenge match with Edgar T. Appleby, 300--66, at the Metropolitan Billiard Club last night. Having taken the first of the three blocks Tuesday night by 300-7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during October at 103.8 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 93.9 in September this year and 97.1 in October last year.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Dr. John H. Finley of New York tonight achieved a distinction usually reserved for Ambassadors and the highest Ministers of State by being the guest of honor at a dinner of the Pilgrims of Great Britain.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange became firmer today as profit-taking ceased and overnight strength came from Wall Street. Business in international securities showed a large increase, Radio Corporation issues being particularly strong as a result of American and London buying based on talk of the payments of arrears on the preference dividend.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins handed down a decision yesterday on the application of American holders of debentures of the Siemens-Halski company and Siemens-Schwekertwerke, German corporations manufacturing engineering devices and electrical equipment, for the removal of the Irving Trust Company as trustee of the twenty-five-year 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold debentures.

The board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., unanimously voted yesterday on measures to complete the liquidation of open No. 1 contracts for the delivery of sugar in December. Two options were offered to members, and failure to make a choice may be deemed contrary to the best interests of the Exchange as lacking in cooperation in liquidating the position.
VATICAN CITY, Nov. 20. -- Pope Plus will hold a secret consistory Dec. 16 and a public one on Dec. 19 for the creation of twenty Cardinals.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 20. -- O. P. Van Sweringen, builder of one of the great railway systems of the world, testified today at a deposition hearing that directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, now involved in a reorganization battle, knew and approved his actions in trying to reshape its capital structure.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 20. -Three generations of Roosevelt were lying ill in North Country Community Hospital here tonight, all under the care of Dr. Richard Derby, chief of staff at the hospital and closely related to the three patients.

The second annual marine exhibit under the direction of the Maritime Association closed yesterday afternoon at the association building, 80 Broad Street. The exhibit was conducted for ten days, ship lines and other maritime agencies cooperating with displays of their products.
Interest in the foreign-exchange market yesterday centred in the ninety-day forward rates as continued uncertainty over the Italian and French situations unsettled the gold currencies.

PEIPING, Thursday, Nov. 21. --The North China autonomy proclamation has been indefinitely postponed. Chinese officials said today, after reporting that the mission of Major Gen. Kenji Doihara, chief of the Japanese Intelligence in China, had been a complete failure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- After an all-day round of conferences touching upon most of the major activities of the administration, President Roosevelt left tonight for Warm Springs, where he plans to spend more than two weeks at the foundation he established for sufferers from infantile paralysis.

Alfred E. Smith, night superintendent at the Central Park Zoo, and director of an expedition for animals for the unfilled cages of the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, revealed last night that he was ready to accept the offer of Emperor Haile Selassie to contribute four young lions and a leopard for New York menageries.

Hundreds of commuters, homeward bound on the upper deck of the Staten Island municipal ferry boat President Roosevelt, were thrown into a flurry of excitement late yesterday afternoon when a man and a woman, unknown to each other, attempted to end their lives by leaping overboard near the Statue of Liberty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Experiences in Canada and other nations with government ownership of railroads should warn any groups in the United States which advocate similar ownership in this country, Carl R. Gray of Omaha, president of the Union Pacific System, declared today in a talk before the National Industrial Traffic League.

MAKALE, Ethiopia, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Italy's strongly entrenched northern army prepared tonight for an Ethiopian counterattack. Headquarters officers said warriors of Emperor Halle Selassie were massing in southern Tigre Province and might attack at any time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Loans to railroads by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to enable them to pay taxes under the Railroad Retirement and Social Security Acts were forecast today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, who said that such advances would be made, provided the borrowers posted adequate security.

All sorts of creatures, from a pessimistic timber wolf to a Cheer Pheasant, trying to make the best of a crowded situation, are represented in the sixth annual Poultry, Pigeon, Pet and Tropical Fish show which opened yesterday morning in the basement at Madison Square Garden.

The city will collect approximately $500,000 a year in additional revenues, Assistant Corporation Counsel Joseph L. Weiner said yesterday, as a result of Tuesday's decision of the Court of Appeals upholding the city's right to exact payments from electric companies for the right to install and maintain underground transformer vaults.

The board of directors of the World's Fair to be held in 1939 and 1940 at Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, met yesterday afternoon for the first time and unanimously elected George McAneny president and named Harvey D. Gibson chairman of the finance committee.

Heavy profit-taking in the final hour of business that touched off many stop-loss orders, after early gains influenced by the optimistic tenor of the midweek trade reviews and, of course, by the now usual complement of favorable dividend actions, sent stock prices down yesterday from fractions to 3 points at the closing.
How, as some one once remarked, time does fly!

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- The right of reporters to withhold from official ears information obtained in confidence is to be determined shortly by the Court of Appeals in the case of Martin Mooney of The New York American.

Employes of the Atlas Bag and Burlap Company of Brooklyn testified yesterday at a National Labor Relations Board hearing that they were coerced and intimidated to join a company union and compelled to refrain from affiliating with the United Textile Workers, an A.F. of L. organization.

At the National Foreign Trade Convention, now meeting in Houston, it was proposed yesterday to make at least partial amends for an injustice done by Congress to the young Philippine Commonwealth. The circumstances were as follows:

AMIENS, France, Nov. 20 (AP). -Miss Zehra, the 20-year-old adopted daughter of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, President and Dictator of Turkey, died today after she had fallen or jumped from the door of an express train while en route from London to Paris.

For the first time in many years Brooklyn is leading the other four boroughs of the city in building construction, according to figures presented yesterday at a luncheon of the Brooklyn Better Housing Committee at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The Cosmopolitan Club's squash racquets team continued on its way toward metropolitan supremacy when it defeated the Rockaway Hunting Club, 4 to 1, yesterday on its home courts. Led by Miss Betty Woolsey, who defeated Mrs. John Bierwirth in four close games, the Cosmopolitan players followed their decisive victory over the Junior League last week by losing only one contest, and that went by default.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Directors of the United Gas Improvement Company decided at a special meeting today to refuse to obey provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, which Federal Judge William C. Coleman ruled unconstitutional at Baltimore on Nov. 7.

About 15,000 persons, relief workers and those employed in Home Relief Bureaus, gathered at Madison Square Garden last night to protest the discontinuance of Federal funds for home relief. The meeting also was caused by the discharge of about 1,000 home relief staff workers in recent weeks.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 20. -Disclosure that Duke scouted North Carolina with movie cameras for their game last Saturday today brought a denunciation of the tactics as "ungentlemanly and unethical" from the Tar Heel campus and the rejoinder from Coach Wallace Wade of Duke that there was no rule against it.

An array of exotic dishes prepared by some of the foremost chefs of the country was entered yesterday in the culinary art contest at the twentieth National Hotel Exposition now being held at the Grand Central Palace. Yesterday was known as "chefs' day" at the exposion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Farmers must decide whether they are better off with the exclusive possession of a poor domestic market or slightly shared possession of a good domestic market, Secretary Wallace said today in speaking of the agricultural concessions granted to Canada in the reciprocal trade agreement signed last week.

GENEVA, Nov. 20. -- Ethiopia notified the League of Nations today that she would refuse to consider peace terms by which Italy would gain anything from her aggression. This move suggests that the indication France and Great Britain will make efforts in this direction, now that the British election is over, is taken seriously enough by Ethiopia for her to seek to forestall such a development.

What brokers described as impressive resistance was displayed on the New York Stock Exchange from 2:15 P.M. to 2:45 P.M. yesterday. In this interval, scattered realizing sales suddenly increased in volume, and for a half-hour the ticker ran behind the market by a margin ranging from one to five minutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -Tentative recommendations for a ten-year agricultural program calling for substantial reductions in cotton, corn and wheat acreages from the 1929 levels were disclosed today by Oris V. Wells, acting chief of the AAA production planning section.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., Nov. 20. -- Immediate consideration of the New Jersey beach erosion problem has been requested of the National Emergency Council by President Roosevelt, it was announced in a telegram received here today by Mayor William F. Carhart from M. H. McIntyre, assistant secretary to the President.

Amendments to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange, providing for the creation of a standing committee on customers' men, were approved yesterday by the governing committee of the Exchange. The amendments will be submitted to the membership for ratification.

LIKE Harry Lehr, the subject of Edward Dean Sullivan's "The Fabulous Wilson Mizner" (Henkle, $3) lived by his wit and his wits. But unlike Lehr, he had a golden quality. He was neither out for revenge upon society nor was he impressed by his own legend. True, he didn't add very much to the creative life of the world, and the perfect society would have liquidated him or told him to shut up.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- With rentes weak and the international list advancing in the early part of today's session, there resulted a reversal of the tendency on the Bourse that brought a recovery in rentes and a decline in internationals at the closing.

The threatened disruption of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference resulting from the protest of the Black Diamond Line against the use of blocked marks for payment of freight charges on German flag lines was averted yesterday when the resignations of all the conference members were withdrawn.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 20 (AP). -- Chancellor Josiah O. Wolcott approved today the plan submitted by a committee of debenture holders for reorganization of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Law.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Reich Government has announced the revaluation of Saar municipal and other paper mark loans on the same basis as the revaluation of paper mark obligations of the Reich and its municipalities after inflation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Prices of hogs declined 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight in the early trading today, but the demand was active and the loss was fully recovered at the close, although the day's top was 5 cents lower than yesterday's at $9.55.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 20. -- Five persons were killed and thirtyfour injured in a clash between Communists and Gold Shirts this afternoon in front of the National Palace, during which more than 300 shots were fired.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Willie Hoppe of New York won a $2,000 billiard game tonight, defeating Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago, 50 to 31, in forty-three innings of a playoff for second place in the final match of the world's three-cushion championship tourney.

Sugar, coffee and cottonseed oil futures advanced and cocoa held firm in the commodity markets yesterday but other staples declined. The volume of trading was fairly heavy. On the cash markets cotton, oats and butter gained, while wheat, corn, rye, tin and rubber were lower.

The directors of the Homestake Mining Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $20 a share, payable on Dec. 5 to stock of record of Nov. 30. The company's usual payments are $1 regular and $2 a share extra each month.

In an article in THE TIMES of Oct. 27, dated Omaha and bearing the by-line of Roland M. Jones, there was a statement that the farmers "have seen their own prices doubled, tripled, quadrupled by processors and handlers even before their product gets to the consumer."

Italians are in for a hard time under sanctions, but they will at least have more fruit and vegetables to eat. Our London dispatch said that other countries are hustling to fill the vacuum of $3,000,000 worth of canned fruits which England normally buys from Italy, and the same amount in lemons.

The resignations of five physicians and surgeons, among them two division heads, have been received and accepted by the officials of the Fifth Avenue Hospital. The resignations follow the merging of Fifth Avenue with Flower Hospital, which was announced on Oct. 17.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- In an atmosphere of calm detachment and poised serenity, contrasting so sharply with the furor that caught up Columbus, Ohio, at the approach of Notre Dame, Princeton is preparing for the invasion of Dartmouth and the greatest football crowd seen here since close to 58,000 gathered for the Yale game in 1928.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Federal Reserve Advisory Council met today to discuss banking developments in the last two months. Tomorrow the council will lay before the Board of Governors of the Reserve System its recommendations on critical policies such as the control of excess reserves.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Nov. 21. -Major Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Japanese Military Attache here, said today there was a "strong possibility" that autonomy agitation would subside in North China, with the Nanking Government taking independent action to "improve conditions."
A large apartment building on West End Avenue and a theatre in Forty-first Street were among properties auctioned yesterday. The eight parcels offered in Manhattan were struck down to plaintiffs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The government will not propose a revival of NRA when representatives of industry and labor meet here Dec. 9, said George L. Berry, Coordinator of Industrial Cooperation, in a speech tonight before the Washington Society of Engineers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A national conference on land, sea and air accidents to promote a drive to relieve the present "distressed situation" will be held early in December at the suggestion of President Roosevelt.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 20. -- The Italians on their march northward have reached Sasa Baneh, where the Ethiopians, who are strongly entrenched, have repulsed them thus far, inflicting heavy losses.

Speaking about traditional rivalries, as most football commentators do at this time of the season, there's one most deserving of mention. It's the annual game between Lehigh and Lafayette. This year it will be played in Bethlehem and Saturday is the day.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 20. -- On a field of mud and in fog that blanketed the snow-surrounded gridiron, Dartmouth today went through its last strenuous workout before the Princeton game. Coach Red Blaik took the opportunity to give his replacements an opportunity to show their wares in adverse weather conditions.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- Three men who had given up hope of rescue after drifting in a yawl for four days off the North Atlantic Coast at the mercy of the northeast storm, were brought to Baltimore yesterday by the Standard Shipping Company tanker George G. Henry, which had picked them up Monday night twenty-six miles off Currituck Light.

American composers had first place on the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the leadership of Hans Lange, last night in Carnegie Hall. They were Robert McBride, whose "Prelude to a Tragedy" was given its first performance anywhere, and William Grant Still, represented on this occasion by his "Afro-American Symphony," played for the first time in New York.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 20. -- The National Foreign Trade Council concluded its three-day convention here today with the adoption of an official declaration of its views on banking, business and governmental policies affecting the revival of world trade.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The fear that the Italian conquest of Ethiopia would lead to the subjugation of Liberia, the only other independent country in Africa, was expressed to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the annual report of its corresponding secretaries today.

TOKYO, Nov. 20. -- The projected new North China regime will be detached from the rest of China only in part, Japanese officials said today. A Foreign Office spokesman compared the independence of North China with that which the Southwest already exercises, and he predicted Peiping's future relations with Nanking would be similar to Canton's.

Sporting goods and cameras, groceries and meats, aprons and house dresses, books and magazines, gift items and domestic floor coverings were the merchandise lines in local department stores which made the best showing in October, according to data available here yesterday.

For the first time since its creation, in 1863, the National Academy of Sciences meets in a Confederate State. It is not sectional differences that account for this seeming neglect of the South, but rather the limited scientific resources of States which took long to recover from the depressing intellectual effect of the Civil War.

Walter Merrill Hall of New York has been nominated to serve as president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for the third straight year, it was disclosed yesterday when the report of the association's 1935 nominating committee was issued.

-- Year ended Sept. 30: Net income, $6,098,215, after all deductions, equal after preferred dividends to 81 cents a share on 5,456,117 common shares, comparing with $6,739,839, or 93 cents a share, in preceding year.

Soon after Pellegrino Dionna, 29-year-old employe of the Department of Sanitation, had been arrested for holding up and shooting a bakery driver last evening, detectives found the body of a murdered woman in his flat at 930 Belmont Avenue, Brooklyn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20. --Cornelius Roosevelt, grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, was arrested tonight, with a companion, after, police reported, they shot a motorist with a weapon described as "an imported air rifle."

On his arrival at Chicago Mr. HOOVER was asked what he thought of the Canadian reciprocity agreement. He at once declared that it was another example of that "hasty legislation" to which the Roosevelt Administration has been all too prone. It would be harmful to many American farmers, Mr. HOOVER asserted, and then added that he supposed it could be cited as another form of the more abundant life -- in Canada.

The $9,000-a-year post of director of the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital is to go to Dr. Karl M. Bowman of Newton Centre. Mass., it was announced yesterday by James E. Finegan, President of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 20. -Dr. Myron A. Warriner reiterated today that he had put to a "mercy" death Adolphus Le Tourneau of North Brookfield, Mass., in 1887, although a North Brookfield physician and Le Tourneau's daughter were quoted as saying that Dr. Warriner had never treated the man.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 (AP). -A city-wide scare over poisoned baking soda led today to an investigation into twenty recent deaths, orders for the arrest of two men and issuance of a blanket warning to housewives who bought the deadly stuff.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Scathing references to the persecution of Jews in Germany were made by leading Anglican churchmen from the Archbishop of Canterbury down at today's meeting of the church assembly, one of the governing bodies of the Church of England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt received the Chief Justice and Associate Justices of the Supreme Court, who paid their annual official call at the White House this afternoon. They were received in the Blue Room and tea was served afterward in the Red Room.

A single rare etching by Whistler yielded $3,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the second session of the auction sale of fine prints from the collection of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

A banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $4,665,000 city of Boston various bonds, offering a rate of 100.0599 for the entire issue as 2 1/4s. Other members of the group are Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Kidder, Peabody Co.; Estabrook Co., and R.L. Day Co.
ROME, Nov. 20. -- Premier Benito Mussolini satisfied himself today that Italy can feed itself regardless of the economic siege laid down by fifty-one nations opposing his war in Ethiopia.

The State Water Power and Control Commission has just turned down New York's application to sink a number of wells on Long Island to increase the city's water supply. The reasons the commission gives for its refusal are compelling. Ground water conditions on the island have been serious for some years and have lately become critical.

The name of the Countess HaugwitzReventlow, nee Barbara Hutton, the Woolworth heiress, has been omitted from the Social Register of New York for 1936. This was disclosed yesterday when the Social Register Association began distributing the new books to its subscribers throughout the city.

Lord JELLICOE'S death in London yesterday will undoubtedly revive the controversies which raged so long over the great naval battle off Jutland. After all the official reports that have been published, together with the memoires which have come from the chief participants, German as well as British, a certain degree of "low visibility," to use JELLICOE'S own words, still hangs over that vast encounter of the most powerful ships in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Sixteen foes of the New Deal, heads of essential industries or prominent lawyers, were appointed today by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, to raise a fund for the 1936 campaign.

Aunt Molly Jackson, who has been a-singin' and a-composin' since she was a little tyke of ten, came to New York University from the mountains of Kentucky yesterday to demonstrate her art to students of "The Popular Ballad in England and America."

The apparent consumption of tin throughout the world in the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 was 133,783 long tons, compared with 119,052 in the preceding twelve months, an increase of 12.4 per cent, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20. -- Plans for a general longshoremen's strike, tying up probably 70 per cent of vessels engaged in intercoastal trade, were announced today by A. H. Peterson, international organizer for the International Longshoremen's Association.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The antiJewish "ghetto laws," the pride and symbol of Nazi Kultur in the Third Reich, are scheduled to be supplemented and completed next week by a proclamation of economic restrictions on Jews. They will be announced by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Interior Minister, and will be acquiesced in by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economic Minister.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Reports from observers in Ethiopia lay increasing stress on the difficulties suffered by the Italians in overcoming not at present the resistance of the Ethiopians but the resistance of nature. It would seem that the supply troubles that developed after the original short advance on Adowa are being renewed more extensively since the further advance on Makale and the Takkaze River.
