LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Bootlegging did not die with the end of prohibition in the United States and EuropeanAmerican liquor smugglers still contrive to run in illicit cargoes that are estimated to defraud the American taxpayers of $30,000,000 to $50,000,000 revenue annually.

A large one-man show by the Russian artist, Boris Gregoriev, opened with a private view yesterday at the Academy of Allied Arts, 349 West Eighty-sixth Street, to remain until Dec. 21. It is restrospective in scope, containing work that was done fifteen years ago and, at the other end of the gamut, work done as recently as last Summer.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- News of Earl Jellicoe's death was received here late this evening and Admiral Erich Raeder, chief of the German sea forces, issued in the name of the fleet and the seamen an expression of German respect for the former commander of the British Grand Fleet and sorrow for his passing.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- France and Britain are at last about to undertake the task conferred upon them by the League of Nations of finding a solution to the Ethiopian conflict which will be suitable to Italy, the League and Ethiopia.

Thousands of Will Rogers admirers in the South are contributing to the fund for a memorial for the humorist, Captain Frank Hawks reported yesterday from Greensboro, N.C., to Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, director of the fund.

The Kings County grand jury investigating the Druckman murder has been told by District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn that it has a free rein to inquire independently into every aspect of the case, without regard for evidence supplied by the District Attorney.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The first major job for Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin following the government election was cut out for him today by a ballot of British coal miners on the question of striking for a wage increase. The vote was 409,351 in favor of a walkout to 29,215 against.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP). -- A Denver attorney and a retired executive of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey told the Federal Trade Commission today of a $350,000 payment to the late F. G. Bonfils, made allegedly to bring about a reversal of The Denver Post's opposition to natural gas for the city.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 20 (AP). -- Running a mile and a sixteenth in 1:43, H. C. Hatch's Ariel Cross, carrying 103 pounds, with S. Young up, won the $5,000 added Fort Worth Handicap today. Prince Fox holds the track record of 1:42 1-5.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- Rumors and denials fought to a noisy 24hour draw today at the annual minor league baseball meeting.

Robert R. Wilmott, captain of the Ward liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park on Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 135 lives, rejected a suggestion made to him by his cruise director that passengers be permitted to take part in lifeboat drills as part of their recreational routine, it was testified yesterday in Federal court.
The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed agent of the Blue Ridge Corporation for accepting tenders of the optional $3 convertible preference stock of $43 a share.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 20. -- Broadcasting to the United States over a Columbia Broadcasting System network tonight Crown Prince Asfaou Wassen of Ethiopia followed his father's example two weeks ago and asked that the moral sympathy of the American people be expressed in support of League of Nations sanctions against Italy.

Samuel Mintz, a "lone wolf" among usurers, who lent substantial sums to manufacturers in the fur trade and managed to deposit from $75,000 to $100,000 monthly, and Maxwell Nathan, known as "Kitty" in the dress trade, were convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of carrying on a lending business without a license and charging usurious rates.

By defeating the Harvard Club, 3 -- 2, yesterday on the latter's courts, the New York A.C. gained undisputed possession of first place in the Class A tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League and now is the only unbeaten team in the competition.

" Abide With Me," Clare Boothe Brokaw's first play to reach production, provides the first-night festivities this evening at the Ritz. In it are Earle Larimore, James Rennie, Cecilia Loftus, Maria Ouspenskaya, Barbara Robbins, Lee Patrick and Allen Fagan.

Operators of merchant ships in the intercoastal trade were notified yesterday by the Seamen's Union, a branch of the International Seamen's Union, that its members would demand new rules in the shipping articles to protect them against situations developing from maritime strikes in Gulf and Atlantic ports.

Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, a net profit of $1,108,902 after taxes, depreciation and other charges. This was equivalent to $1.75 a share on 635,200 no-par shares of capital stock, excluding 40,812 shares in the treasury.
Headed by Donald Strachan of Philadelphia, the national champion, a team of six players sailed yesterday on board the Berengaria of the Cunard-White Star Line for a squash racquets tour of England.

Under active trade calling prior to first December notice day on Monday, prices of near months on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday until the December sold within 2 points of its recent high marks. October remained under pressure and went to a discount of 80 points.

A debt of more than $2,000 incurred as the result of an operation may have weighed on the mind of Mrs. Anne O'Shea on her way to mass at the St. Joan of Arc Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, at 7 A.M. yesterday, yet she did not yield to the temptation of keeping $4,350 which she found in the street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A fight for continued and adequate Federal appropriations for both direct and work relief was started today by the United States Conference of Mayors at the closing session of its convention.

DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctic Archipelago, Nov. 20. -- We are back at the Wyatt Earp, our base ship, after three hours and eleven minutes of flying in our attempt to span the Antarctic Continent from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Sea. In spite of ideal weather and a favorable take-off field, bad luck seems to dog us.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 20. -Whether President Roosevelt's program will receive the support of the Wisconsin Progressive delegation in the next session of Congress is tentative upon what methods the administration sponsors to meet unemployment.
Broadening demand for steel from automotive, railroad, construction and miscellaneous lines has increased the operating rate from 54 to 54 1/2 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A Justice Department investigation of Pacific Coast waterfront labor trouble brought a protest today from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Because he is the only living former President, because he polled 15,000,000 votes in the worst political year his party has recently known, and because he is clearly planning to dominate the next Republican National Convention, Herbert Hoover, though in private life, remains public property.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20. -- The B.B. Stable of Jerome Fendrick scored a double today when the former stake horse Apprentice captured the featured Cecilius Claiming Stakes, and Saintlite, a 5-year-old, got out of the maiden class in a rousing head finish.

The New York Lodge, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, announced last night through Bernard H. Sandler, a member of the committee in charge of the project, that the lodge will be host to 20,000 children at the New York-Philadelphia professional football game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, when Elks Day will be observed.

Retail credit collections during October increased 1.9 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Eighteen of the twenty stores showed increases. The highest collection percentage for the month was 66.20 and the lowest 37.41.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 20. -Two men were killed instantly and two others injured when a truck and an automobile were in head-on collision on the State highway at Aquebogue, two miles east of here, at 8 o'clock tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Howard Vincent O'Brien, columnist of The Chicago Daily News, predicted in that paper today that if Frank Knox, his editor and publisher, was nominated and elected President in 1936, he would "perforce leave undone practically all of the things he now advocates."

Some unsettlement occurred in the utility stocks soon after the announcement by United Gas Improvement Company of its intention to contest the Public Utility Holding Company Act, and earlier gains were wiped out in several instances.

ERMELO, The Netherlands, Nov. 20. -- By winning the twenty-first game of the match for the chess championship of time world, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam today tied Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, titleholder, and the totals are now 10 1/2 points for each of the contenders.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 20. -James Roosevelt, eldest son of President Roosevelt, resigned Nov. 1 as president of the National Grain Yeast Corporation of Belleville, it was disclosed at the plant here today. Frank Chambers, vice president and general manager of the corporation, said Mr. Roosevelt had been unable to give enough time to the affairs of the concern because of other interests.

The present -- stock market situation doubtless is far more complicated than that of 1929, largely because of the fact that pretty much everything in the world of finance must also be viewed in the light of political expediency.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey, who was once a United States Attorney, himself, presided yesterday at induction ceremonies for Lamar Hardy, his cousin, who was appointed to that office last week by President Roosevelt, to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation several months ago of Martin Conboy.
The 500 tons of sheet steel piling required for construction of an underpass on the Queens approach to the Triborough Bridge will be American, not German-made, it became known yesterday.
Value of Dollar in Exchange,The value oT the dollar on thelocal foreign exchange market,based on quotations for the Frenchfranc on tho days indicated, eompares as follows. Quotations arein cents:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -The American Football Institute blamed "false economy" practiced by school boards throughout the nation today as a major contributory cause of the annual toll of football fatalities and serious injuries.

New York's first venture in the public housing field -- the low-rental apartments built at Avenue A and Third Street on the lower East Side -- will be opened on Dec. 3 with dedicatory exercises in which Governor Lehman and other State officers and Federal and city officials will take part.

The mention of "Borah for President," with references to his radical views, evoked cries of "No! Never!" at a luncheon of the National Republican Builders, Inc., held yesterday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

ATHENS, Nov. 20. -- Marshal George Kondylis today completed the preparation of the Amnesty Bill which is to be signed by King George on Sunday as his first official act. Those named for pardon include the Venizelist officers imprisoned after the March revolution, peasants involved in agrarian uprisings and a Kondylis lieutenant responsible for the shooting in Parliament Sept. 9.

BELLMORE, L.I., Nov. 20. -Herman Kraus, 27 years old, of North Bellmore, a gardener employed at nurseries on Jerusalem Road here, was killed instantly about 12:30 o'clock this morning by a hit-and-run motorist at Meadowbrook Road and Willis Avenue, Merick.

Fifty-nine players were named yesterday by the American Olympic Ice Hockey Committee to participate in the tryouts scheduled for Dec. 7, 8 and 9 that are to be held for the purpose of selecting the American team to compete in the Fourth Olympic Winter Games, scheduled for Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, Feb. 6-16.

ROME, Nov. 20. -- It is realized here that military developments in Ethiopia will not be sufficiently rapid to save Italy from experiencing fully the pinch of sanctions and this is the reason why efforts are being made to place the country in the best condition possible to hold out against them.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Admiral of the Fleet Earl Jellicoe, commander of Great Britain's Grand Fleet in 1914 and the only man on either side who could "lose the World War in an afternoon," as Winston Churchill, then civil head of the Admiralty, described him, died today within three weeks of his seventysixth birthday.

Public offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., of a new issue of $22,799,000 Department of Water and Power of The City of Los Angeles electric-plant revenue 4 per cent refunding bonds of 1935.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Don, ridden by Major W. B. Bradford of the United States Army team, tonight captured the $500 military jumping stake at the royal Winter fair horse show, outjumping Cacique, ridden by Captain Enrique Franco of the Chilean Army team.
AFTER getting good look at the movies of the debated interference play in the closing minutes of the Army-Notre Dame game, the assorted experts came away saying:
SHANGHAI, Nov. 20. -- The North China autonomy declaration, first scheduled for Monday, then delayed until Wednesday, and again until Friday, seems to have met a check wholly unexpected by Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A registration statement covering the issuance of $16,500,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 4 3/4 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1950, has been filed by the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company of Cleveland, under the Securities Act of 1933.

A plea for a spiritual revival in America was voiced last night by the Rev. Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, at a rally held under the auspices of the group in the Metropolitan Opera House. Boxes and seats of the opera house were filled for the most part by persons in evening dress.
Money market was dull. The demand for funds was light, whilequotations remained unchanged orlali classes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The refusal of the United Gas Improvement Company to register under the Public Utility Act and its filing in the Federal court in Philadelphia of a suit to restrain the government from enforcing the act was accepted here as virtually ending the official hopes that there would be a serious break in the solid front of the major utility holding companies.

Joseph A. Ruddy, noted athlete and for years physical director of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, retired on a pension yesterday after the commission announced in a formal statement that it had dropped charges filed against him by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard.

Declaring that democracy based on geographical lines was largely obsolescent, Dr. Clement Clarence Williams, new president of Lehigh University, asserted last night at the Waldorf-Astoria that it might be necessary to supplement the government of the founders of the Republic by "economic organizations that disregard geographical boundaries."

Jack Leitt of De Witt Clinton High School and Tom McDermott of George Washington shattered the season's mark for the 100-yard freestyle swim yesterday in the fifth of the series of dual meets being staged by the Public Schools Athletic League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Bids on 1,500,000 yards of cotton sheeting to be made up in WPA workrooms this Winter were opened today by the Treasury Procurement Division. Bids were listed as follows:

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 20. -- Solution of one of the age-old mathematical mysteries, classed by the ancient Greeks and all mathematicians since then with such other enigmas of geometry as squaring the circle and trisecting an angle, was announced today at the closing sessions of the National Academy of Sciences at the University of Virginia.
Real estate trading in Manhattan yesterday consisted largely of sales of apartment houses in the Washington Heights and Inwood sections and leases of dwellings on the upper West Side.

Five counties, including Kalamazoo of great name, in the southwestern part of Michigan make up its Third Congress District. To the Representatives of that district Mr. JEFFERSON'S epigram that few officeholders die and none resign hasn't applied, at least since 1921. Five Representatives have died in office in the fourteen years between '21 and '35.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 20 (AP). -Slashing Ethiopian victories at the cost of hundreds of casualties were reported tonight from the southern battle front.

" Great Loves in Poetry," a series of three tableaux, was a brilliant feature of the Poetry Ball, held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night under the auspices of the Academy of American Poets. The proceeds of the ball will go to the academy, which was organized to encourage and foster the work of American poets of proved gifts and merit and to discover new poetic genius.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Senator Norris was assured today of national Democratic organization support if he decides to run for reelection next year in Nebraska.

IApartment rentals reported yes-Iterday, included a lease of a fur-Inished suite of twelve rooms andIfive baths in 1,010 Fifth Avenue toIMrs. Edward Myers through Doug-las L. Elliman Co. Robert Sher-!wood rented a fourteen-room un-4furnished suite in 120 East End zAvenue from Vincent Astor throughBeatrice L. Renwick, Inc. Otherleasees were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Foes and friends of the administration's farm program, as embodied in the Agricultural Adjustment Act with its processing taxes, carried to the Supreme Court today arguments in anticipation of the coming trial of the Hoosac Mills case Dec. 9.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- A sensation among all classes of the population was caused this morning when on the round pillars that are Berlin's billboards appeared white official placards headed, "Notice regarding enlistment classes of 1913 and 1916."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21. -Football will open 90,000 pocketbooks Saturday to loose more than a million dollars in a spending flood surging around the California-Stanford game.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21. -- The first victory of the Bowie meeting for the C. V. Whitney silks was scored by Roustabout today in a rough drive through the stretch which saw Weston disqualified after the finish. Roustabout, Weston and Chatmoss finished heads apart in the order named, Chatmoss being the 1-to-2 favorite.
In assuming to answer your editorial "Treaty With Italy," Dr. Borchard has offered a very strained interpretation of that treaty in his letter published in today's issue.

The Council of Apparel Trade Executives, at a meeting at the office of the Affiliated I)ress Manufacturers, Inc., yesterday afternoon, voted to support the efforts of Senator Frederick Van iNluys of Indiana to amend the Federal Trade Commission Act to give the commission the right to regulate the purchasing activities of chain store organizations.

Miss Vera Stretz was arraigned in Homicide Court Yesterday morning when the affidavit charging her with homicide in the death of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German financier, was dismissed, as it has been superseded by an indictment charging her with murder in the first degree.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Five Governors of New England States and a former Governor of the sixth (Vermont), together with 600 leaders of enterprise in the section, met here today for the tenth annual session of the New England Council, to plan the unified development of New England during the coming year.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 21. -Something unique in the service series, and perhaps in football generally, will be used by the Navy against the Army in their battle next week. Two teams, with different formations and plays, will alternate against the Cadets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Retail food costs declined slightly in the two weeks ended on Nov. 5, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1923-25 average, standing at 80.4, compared with 80.5 in the preceding two weeks and 75.4 in the corresponding period last year.

Joining in a public statement denouncing and condemning the campaign of terror and oppression of the Hitler regime against the Jewish people, 138 Protestant clergymen and educators demanded yesterday the withdrawal of American participation in the Olympic Games if they are held in Nazi Germany.

All industry should adopt the policy of "presenting sound basic principles" to legislators and government executives, the National Founders Association decided yesterday at the close of its thirtyninth annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Testifying yesterday before Supreme Court Referee Thomas C. T. Crain, Mrs. Blanche Marquis of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel said that despite the pleas of herself, her attorney and their physician, her husband, Leonard J. Marquis, Stock Exchange broker, had refused to return to her and give up Alvira Trabert, an actress.

The Jonker diamond, valued at $1,500,000, weighing 726 carats and said to be the largest and rarest uncut diamond in the world, will be cut into smaller pieces, its owner, Harry Winston of 620 Fifth Avenue, dealer in precious stones, said last night.

A group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., will offer today an issue of $2,566,000 of school district 4 per cent bonds of the city of Los Angeles, at prices to yield 0.50 to 3.75 per cent, according to maturity. The bonds are dated June 1, 1931, and mature from June 1, 1936 to 1956.

The Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector of St. George's Church, advised the graduating nurses of the Lenox Hill School of Nursing at commencement exercises last night in the Hotel Astor to beware of specialization.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $10,379,000 of first-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, at 101 3/4 and accrued interest, to yield more than 3.64 per cent to maturity.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Considerable importance is attached in diplomatic circles in London to the interview in Berlin today between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador. The latter had not been able to see the Fuehrer for more than three months, but his instructions from Premier Pierre Laval were to insist upon a personal interview.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- President Roosevelt is expected to issue a proclamation soon after Jan. 1, extending the life of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund through which this government has protected its international currency position since early in 1934.

By listening closely to "Abide With Me," which was acted at the Ritz last evening, you can understand the reason for Arthur Marsden's monstrosity. As a youth he squashed bugs. As a young man he tortures his wife in a great many ingenious ways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Utility holding companies which follow the lead of the United Gas Improvement Company will have effectively disposed of one of the criticisms heard in government legal circles against the non-compliance attitude of these companies toward the registration requirement of the new act.

William and Mary, one of the few Southern colleges which sends its coed athletic teams North for regular intercollegiate competition in tennis, fencing, basketball and field hockey, met defeat in the lastnamed sport yesterday as Manhattanville gained a 7-0 victory over the visiting hockey eleven at Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Charges that President Roosevelt was evidently attempting to shift the responsibility "for the failure of part of his work-relief program and for the waste involved in the mass of ludicrous projects initiated by the Works Progress Administration" were made today by the Republican National Congressional Committee.

In the radio address of Professor Ralph C. Epstein of the University of Buffalo as reported in THE TIMES, the point is emphasized that, contrary to the popular impression, the low point of the depression was reached in the Summer of 1932 and not in March, 1933. Dr. Epstein then proceeded to discuss the turning point of the depression in terms of the movement of the Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production.

HONOLULU, Nov. 21. -- An eruption from Mauna Loa, the 14,000-foot volcano on the island of Hawaii, began at 7 o'clock this evening. The glow from the river of lava was visible all over that island and could be seen late tonight from the eastern shore of Oahu, which is about 175 miles from its source.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today amended its instruction book for Form 10 to be used by seasoned corporations in applying for permanent registration of securities on Stock Exchanges, setting forth special requirements for railroad companies that do not report to the interstate Commerce Commission.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21. -Determined to put a halt Saturday to the high-scoring Dartmouth eleven's attack, Princeton's football forces went through a long defensive drill against all phases of the Green scoring threat today in practice on University Field.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -A general disposition to heed Secretary Ickes's appeal not to sell oil to Italy, in support of the President's neutrality policy, was indicated by the larger, oil companies here tonight.
Erle Reiter, one of the most promising juniors to appear in national skating circles in several years, gave his first New York performance last night at the Ice Club.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 21. -- General Wehib Pasha, chief of staff of the southern Ethiopian army, returned here for a military conference with the news that an Italian force had been repulsed with heavy loss at Sasa Baneh and with a hearty contempt for the military prowess of his opponent in the Ogaden area, General Rodolfo Graziani.
The first of a newly organized series of dinner dances took place last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. The subscription list for the dinner dances is formed by an invitation committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Chicago line of Doc Romnes, Donnie McFadyen and Paul Thompson staged another brilliant scoring exhibition tonight as the home club handed the Toronto six its first defeat of the season, 4 to 3, in the Chicago Stadium.

The volume of bankers' acceptances throughout the country increased $35,149,969 in October, the American Acceptance Council reported yesterday. Accepting banks reported a total of $362,984,286 for Oct. 31, compared with $327,834,317 on Sept. 30.
A single rare French eighteenth century color print brought $5,100 last night at the auction of the Cortlandt F. Bishop collection at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21. -- The China Clipper leaves tomorrow for the Far East carrying the first transpacific air mail.

ROME, Nov. 21. -- The War Ministry announces that large numbers of men at present under arms in Italy will be sent home under a special leave system. The importance of this step is symbolical more than material, for it is unofficially estimated that only 100,000 men out of the 1,000,000 who are under arms will benefit by it.

ATHENS, Nov. 21. -- That there would be no revolutionary movement in Greece after the restoration of King George II, even by extreme Republicans, was declared today by the only prominent leader to continue standing uncompromisingly on the republican platform, Alexander Papanastassiou, head of the Agrarian party.

Frankie Klick will meet Al Roth in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle brings together two of the foremost challengers for the world's lightweight championship, now held by Tony Canzoneri, and promises to attract a large crowd.

For the first time in five years the harsh, metallic "cronk" of the brant goose is being heard by wildfowlers on the Atlantic seaboard with a frequency that revives memories of the days when these birds were abundant on our coastline.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- Adventuring into the stratosphere in an opencockpit plane, Pilot Vladimir Kay Kokinaki, former Soviet sailor and stevedore, set a new Soviet Union altitude record yesterday, reaching a height of 42,640 feet over Moscow.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 21. -The National Labor Relations Board today broadened the scope of its operations by beginning the presentation of the first cases involving labor relations in cotton textile mills in this State. Two hearings were opened simultaneously, one in Spartanburg and the other in this city.
PRINCETON, N, J., Nov. 21. -The climax of Princeton University's Fall social season will be reached tomorrow night when 131 couples attend the annual PrinceTiger dance in the university gymnasium.

A one-story business building containing twenty-two stores and occupying the entire block front on the south side of Lydig Avenue, from Cruger to Holland Avenues, in the Pelham Parkway section, was purchased yesterday by Richard M. Lederer for the Associated Real Estate Corporation, of which he is president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Renewing an attack on four steel companies which submitted identical bids on materials for two PWA projects, Secretary Ickes charged today that there was "prima facie evidence of collusion" in both instances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 20, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,491,000,000, an increase of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $14,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Bank clearings for twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,576,438,000, compared with $4,584,949,000 in the corresponding week last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Commenting on the successive tie games involving Fordham-Pitt, Fordham-St. Mary's and Notre Dame-Army, Jimmy Crowley told the Notre Dame Club of New York the other night that he did not want to see another tie until Christmas.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Nov. 21. -- For the first time since the match for the world's chess championship between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam started early in October there was a postponement today in the schedule, which called for the twenty-second game to be contested tonight at the Monopole Building.

Secretary of Labor Perkins conferred last night with Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, on problems affecting the shipping industry which have resulted from differences between longshoremen and ship lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- An absolute denial that the constitutional rights of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted of the murder of the Lindbergh baby, were jeopardized in the court which tried his case was made today to the United States Supreme Court by David T. Wilentz, Attorney General of New Jersey.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- An effort will be begun here once more tomorrow to try to reach some formula of settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian diferences, or, rather, of the claims of Italy for Ethiopian territory as a colony for her people.

The Bank of France yesterday raised its official discount rate to 5 per cent, as against 4 a week ago and 3 between then and midsummmer. This action resulted plainly from the bank's large loss of gold during the past three weeks; it has amounted, in American values, to $117,000,000.

Possibility of a protracted music copyright wrangle and of a serious breach in the ranks of the American Society of Composer, Authors and Publishers was foreshadowed yesterday with the disclosure that Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., planned to withdraw its eleven subsidiary music publishing houses from membership in the society.

The opening performance of the Metropolitan Opera season under its new manager, Edward Johnson, will be Verdi's "Traviata" on Monday night, Dec. 16, it was announced yesterday. The three principal roles will be taken by Lucrezia Bori as Violetta, Richard Crooks as Alfredo and Lawrence Tibbett as the elder Germont.

In the current poll by The Literary Digest, the first instalment of which is published today, the people reached by it are not asked to vote for or against any candidate or political party. The question to which they are expected to answer "yes" or "no" is whether they approve of President ROOSEVELT'S policies.

President ROOSEVELT has done well to put himself at the head of the forces striving to curb the mounting and truly menacing toll of American accidents, especially on the highway. The mechanism of control will naturally continue to be State and local, but the emergency is national.

About 100 assorted dogs without pedigrees competed for prizes yesterday afternoon in a contest open only to foundlings adopted from one of the five shelters of the A.S. P.C.A. in New York. The contest was a feature of the Poultry, Pigeon, Pet and Tropical Fish Show in Madison Square Garden.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21. -Yale's football squad said farewell to its training gridiron, historic Anthony Thompson Field, today, closing a two-hour session in which Coaches Pond, Neale, Myers and Williamson sent it through calisthenics, a rehearsal of Harvard plays and the Blue's offensive, kick-offs and signals.

" Satellite," which opened at the Bijou Theatre on Wednesday at 8:40 P.M., ended its engagement there a couple of hours later. Its run of one performance sets a new record for the season, and ties that of any other season. To house this attraction the Bijou had returned to what is sometimes called "the legitimate."
Most commodity futures were firmer yesterday, with the volume of trading fairly heavy. On the cash markets wheat, rye, flour, lard, tin and rubber advanced, while corn and silk declined.

Action of the authorities of the Church of England in passing a resolution against race proscription in Germany is doubly significant. Here is no voluntary religious organization speaking. It is the Established Church. It is the representative of the British Government in the spiritual field.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $20,000,000 to a new high record of $3,070,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the system's statement, which was published yesterday. The gain for the week before was $60,000,000.

The share market regained its equilibrium yesterday under the leadership of railway and mining issues, many of the former group advancing 1 to 2 points in response to the unexpected news that the New York Central plans to pay on Dec. 1, with its own cash, its note for $15,600,000 held by the RFC, as this called attention forcibly to the improved position of the carriers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21.-- The S. B. Marks Company today was awarded an army contract for 97,087 bleached cotton bed sheets, 63 by 99 inches (torn lengths), under invitation 108, at prices less one-tenth of percent twenty days, as follows:

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a list of twentysix guaranteed stocks on sales of which members, under a rule recently adopted, are permitted to pay salesmen commissions if the stocks are actually owned by them.

For more than a month residents of the Gramercy Park section have had their drinking water flavored with synura, a microscopic organism, which gives a flavor something like cucumbers Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- Renomination of Mrs. Douglas M. Moffat of New York City to succeed herself as State chairman headlined a busy day today for delegates to the convention of the State League of Women Voters here. Election is scheduled for tomorrow.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 21. -- A whirlpool of rumors made every one dizzy at the minor league convention today but it was learned from reliable sources that:

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Captain Fred A. Ahern of the Irish Free State Army team, riding Gallow Glass, tonight captured the trophy in the military jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- An appeal involving labor difficulties at the Port of New York was put before the Court of Appeals just before adjournment today. The New York Lumber Trade Association named Martin Lacey, as president of the Transportation Council of the Port of New York; Fred England, representing Local 920 of the Longshoremen's Association, and others in appealing from a judgment of the Appellate Division permitting picketing at the piers.

Yachtsmen from all along the seaboard tendered a testimonial dinner last night in the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street, to Adrian Iselin 2d, skipper, and Edward V. Willis, crew, of the former's Star Class sloop Ace, which made a remarkable record this year in the international racing.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 22. -- Sources close to the government said Japanese militarists and opposing civilian leaders faced a showdown today over the North China situation, with the life of the Cabinet possibly in the balance.

George Silberman, wireless operator of the Andrea F. Luckenbach, a freighter, which was the first vessel to go to the rescue of the Ward liner Morro Castle when that ship burned off Asbury Park on Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 135 lives, told yesterday of having seen the steamer afire before he received her distress signals.

District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn hinted yesterday that police inefficiency in the handling of the Druckman murder case resulted in the escape of the "key witness," whose death in Chicago last month was officially confirmed yesterday by detectives sent there to investigate.
A mass demonstration against the participation of American athletes in the forthcoming Olympics at Berlin was held in Madison Square Park last night under the auspices of the Anti-Nazi Federation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- United States exports in October increased 7 per cent in value from October of last year and 12 per cent from September to $221,215,000, while imports increased 46 per cent from October of last year and 17 per cent from September to $189,688,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Declaring that representative government in the United States is menaced by subversive groups that have gained the ascendancy under the New Deal, Senator Lester J. Dickinson of Iowa called upon the nation's business leaders last night to do their part toward preserving Constitutional safeguards and guaranties.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Importance is being given here to Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet's conversation with Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Berlin today as a renewal of contact between the French and German Governments, which had been virtually abandoned since last May.

The Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness, appointed by the New York Academy of Medicine, made public a survey yesterday which praised the Sanitation Department, under Mayor La Guardia, as the "best administered" during the last fifty years and urged the Mayor to lead the city in a new crusade for cleanliness by adopting a city-wide anti-litter campaign.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP). -- "Downtown business" in the United States is picking up, with available office space decreasing markedly, says the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The intention of six companies to transfer their securities from the New York Curb Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday, foreshadows the greatest "raid" yet made by the Big Board upon the smaller market's list.

On many sides the Government is being urged to retire from the field of banking. Some thirty agencies in Washington, financed either in whole or in part by Government funds, are engaged in such operations. A few of them, like the Federal Land Banks, date back to days before the depression.

The sheep meadow in Central Park took on some of the aspects of a military encampment yesterday morning when the Park Department held its annual inspection of employes and equipment. Long lines of men in olive green and khaki uniforms were drawn up on the broad lawn, which lies east of the West Drive between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-ninth Streets.

Handicapped children of the nation will be the principal beneficiaries of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the memorial committee of the fund commission, held at 570 Lexington Avenue.

Determined to stamp out irregularities and racketeering in the WPA, although he says he does not believe they exist on a large scale, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, conferred for three hours yesterday with Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, and obtained his cooperation.

A police drive on Brooklyn loan sharks was started yesterday with the arrest of two men for usury and four of their alleged associates for vagrancy. They were arrested in the Brownsville district, where detectives said the weekly "take" is from $5,000 to $7,500 and the small loan racket is dominated by the Abe Reles-Phil (Bugsy) Goldstein gang.

Edward F. Hutton, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, issued a statement last night in explanation of his current article in The Public Utilities Fortnightly Magazine. Mr. Hutton telegraphed the statement from his Combahee River plantation in South Carolina, where he has been ill, to his secretary in New York, who made it public.
The Consolidated Gas Company and its gas and electric subsidiaries disclosed yesterday their intention to disregard the Federal Public Utility Law and to attack its constitutionality in the courts.

Life insurance company management as a stewardship is to be stressed at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Dec. 5 and 6. It is estimated that companies having more than 90 per cent of life insurance in force in the United States and Canada will be represented.
ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Hainsworth's 3-year-old Blackbirder, by Bostonian out of Xenya, today won the Will Rogers Memorial Handicap, closing-day feature at the Arlington Downs track.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Nov. 21. -- Jacob Ciemiengo, 16-year-old Burlington Township farmhand, and George H. Hildebrand, 26, of Columbus, N. J., were sentenced here this evening to die in the electric chair the week of Jan. 5 for the murder of Thomas Eilers, 63, poultry farmer of Florence Township.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Senator Borah may enter the Republican Presidential primaries in Ohio on May 19 and upset the plans of the Old Guard of that State and the Hoover group to elect delegates pledged to Representative Chester D. Bolton.
Mrs. Joseph Paterno gave a luncheon yesterday in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Alfredo de Zayas, widow of the former President of Cuba. The other guests were:

Unexpectedly small ginning figures, following another sharp advance in foreign quotations, carried prices on the Cotton Exchange above 12 cents yesterday for the first time since the middle of July. For the third successive day, an advance occurred in Egyptian cotton in Alexandria, where active buying by Italian spinners was reported recently.

The first session of the three-day convention of the International Association of Police and Fire Surgeons and Medical Directors of Civil Service Commissions opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania with addresses of welcome by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 21 (AP). -Cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Nov. 14 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 8,437,084 running bales, counting 167,159 round bales as half bales and including 9,119 bales of American-Egyptian.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company, major holding company unit of the fallen Insull network of power, was regarded as a certainty tonight after many months of wrangling as to the shares to be obtained in the new company by the various interests in the old setup.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club last night captured the Princeton Club invitation squash tennis tournament, triumphing over Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia Club in three straight games and the brief time of thirtyfour minutes.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Mrs. Edward Donnelly, daughter of Governor James M. Curiey, was robbed of jewelry valued at $12,000 to $15,000 at about the time of her wedding last June, her father revealed today.

Louisiana State was voted the strongest team faced by Manhattan this season and Gaynell Tinsley, the Tigers' great end, the best football player in a poll of the Jasper lettermen yesterday. L.S.U. fell only one vote short of being a unanimous selection as the Green's strongest opponent, Holy Cross, which was ranked second, getting the dissenting ballot.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -The faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today began an investigation of the air pistol sniping which resulted in the arrest and arraignment today of Cornelius Van S. Roosevelt and Peter de Florez, Tech students, on charges of assault and battery with a dangerous weapon.

Mrs. Harry F. Ward, 61-year-old wife of a Union Theological Seminary professor, and Miss Evelyn Preston, 36, Junior League member, of 282 West Eleventh Street, Manhattan, were arrested yesterday noon on charges of disorderly picketing in front of May's Department Store, at 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and later paroled in the custody of their attorney in Bay Ridge Court.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP). -- William Wyer, assistant treasurer and secretary of the Missouri-Pacific Transportation Company, testified today that in 1931 he intentionally furnished the Missouri Pacific Railroad's auditor in St. Louis with monthly statements which did not show the purchase by the company of approximately $4,000,000 in securities.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Construction of a $750,000 assembly plant at Wellington, N.Z., will be started immediately by the Ford Motor Company of Canada, it was announced today by Wallace R. Campbell, president of the company.

Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, estimated last night that there were 5,000,000 young persons throughout the country who could find no useful place in society and were confronted with general demoralization through idleness and loss of hope and ambition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A thorough examination of alleged banker domination of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was promised today by the Interstate Commerce Commission with the assignment for hearings on Dec. 2 of petitions of H. A. Scandrett, Walter J. Cummings and George I. Haight to become trustees of the road in bankruptcy.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21. -- The Guffey Coal Act would create worse conditions than those it purports to cure, the Mellon controlled Pittsburgh Coal Company asserted today as it asked in the Federal court for an injunction against the imposition of penalties and taxes under the act.

The City of New York, it was revealed yesterday, shares in the profits of the restaurant with the only all-night bar license in the five boroughs, the Farmers Square Restaurant in the Bronx Terminal Market.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler ordered yesterday the liquidation of the Greater New YorkSuffolk Title and Guaranty Company of 341 Madison Avenue, after the company had failed to submit affidavits in opposition to an application by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent, for authority to liquidate the company.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 0.5 point in the last week to 128.4 on Tuesday. The rise reflected chiefly higher prices for wheat and flour, butter, cotton and the textiles and gasoline.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Nov. 21. -Remarkable as was the marksmanship of some of Britain's greatest warships off Alexandria today, that demonstration was the least interesting aspect of the naval manoeuvres. Between the lines of a technical account of long-range gunnery and terrific air assault should be read the double political significance that the display was intended to impress the Egyptians and the Italians both.
Selling and leasing of dwellings on the upper east and west sides formed the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Although individual members of the Federal Reserve Advisory Council believed that action should be taken to control the excess bank reserves, the council adjourned today without laying any formal recommendations on credit control before the Reserve System's board of governors.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The cautious and hitherto rather unofficial Franco-German soundings for mutual rapprochement were raised to the dignity of official conversations today when Chancellor Adolf Hitler received Ambassador Andre Francois-Poncet for a two-hour conference.

PARIS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The Bank of France again tried today to check the flow of gold to New York by raising its discount rate. In the second advance within a week the rate was changed from 4 to 5 per cent.
Three passengers were injured, one seriously, when the Erie ferryboat Jamestown crashed into her slip at Chambers Street with a load of New Jersey commuters on their way to Manhattan offices.

An enthusiastic dinner throng of 800 persons, including Mayor La Guardia, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and leaders in philanthropic and welfare work, joined with Mrs. Rebekah Kohut, dean of Jewish communal workers, last night at the Hotel Commodore to celebrate her golden jubilee in social work in this city.

The Salmagundi Club's annual thumb-box exhibition will open with a stag at 8:30 this evening and with a ladies' afternoon reception and tea tomorrow from 3 to 6 o'clock. The exhibition will open to the public on Sunday, remaining until Dec. 15.

I read with interest your editorial "Manhattan Stock." There has been so much misinformation passed out in the last ten years about the Manhattan Railway Company that it is hard for me not to call your attention to an error in your statement. I am sorry to admit, however, that a great many people at the present time have the same impression as yourself.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York:

Charges that the Board of Education and Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, have violated the law by appointing more than 500 unqualified persons as attendance and assistant attendance officers since March, 1933, were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Association of Attendance and Assistant Attendance Officer Eligibles.

The eighteen-story skyscraper structure, main building of the rehabilitated Brooklyn State Hospital for the Insane, where reconstruction work was started early in 1933 as a result of a $2,315,000 State appropriation, was formally opened yesterday by Dr. Clarence H. Bellinger, superintendent of the institution.

Columbia will sacrifice weight and experience for speed at the tackle sectors tomorrow when it meets Brown at Baker Field. In an effort to instill more spirit and dash into the Blue and White, Coach Lou Little yesterday promoted Johnny Bateman and Sam Maroon, heretofore reserve guards, to the first-string tackle berths, replacing George Saffa and Charley Zielinski.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- The Philadelphia Electric Company today followed the lead taken yesterday by the United Gas Improvement Company, its controlling owner, in defying the Public Utility Holding Company Act as unconstitutional.

Additional evidence designed to prove coercion and intimidation of employes in compelling them to join a company union was presented by witnesses at yesterday's hearing on the complaint issued by the National Labor Relations Board against the Atlas Bag and Burlap Company of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Between 250 and 300 first line aircraft and probably 3,000 officers and men are to be added to the program expanding the British air force, bringing the total of machines to 2,190 at the end of two years, according to The Daily Telegraph.

Eight of eleven tenement houses in Manhattan offered for sale by auctioneers were bought in by savings banks yesterday. The forced selling covered a wide area, extending from the downtown district to Harlem.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Marshal George Kondylis, president of the Council, Minister of Finance and the leader in the restoration of King George II, announced tonight that he was "through with politics."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Secretary Hull struck out in a statement tonight against "partisan politicians," "lobbyists" and "specially privileged interests benefiting from excessive tariff rates" for their attacks on the reciprocal trade agreements with Canada.

In spite of virtuous declarations in political platforms, American government, municipal, State, national, has been extravagant and inefficient, War and depression only emphasize the general passion for making the money fly and running into debt. Any attempt to return to that Utopian principle of appropriations for the necessary expenses of the Government honestly administered has come to seem like a hope or an experiment.

STALIN has just urged the Russian workers to be gay. He did it in a speech of which the Pravda said. "STALIN spoke briefly, one hour." This was said in all seriousness, of course. A speech lasting only one hour is brief in Soviet Russia, as it was, for that matter, in the Russian revolutionary tradition a long way back.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21. -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals agreed today to review on petition the recent test case in which Judge William C. Coleman in Federal District Court here two weeks ago held unconstitutional the Holding Company Act passed by the last Congress.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21. -- The weeding out of persons who interfere with the development of the Stakhanoff movement, which was characterized as a step in preparing the way for advancing from "socialism to communism," was threatened by Joseph Stalin in his speech delivered at the closing session of the first All-Union Stakhanoffite Conference Sunday and made public tonight.
The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed cotransfer agent in New Jersey for common stock of the United Cigar Stores Company of America.

HARAR, Via Jibuti, Nov. 21 (Uncensored. -- Here amid soldiers hurrying southward to meet the Italian advance and amid the wounded trickling back, the feeling is unmistakable that the War Ethiopia is waging is a forlorn hope, a fight for a lost cause.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- At the start today of an investigation directed by Congress of the reorganization of and the activities of protective committees in the American real estate bond field, the Securities and Exchange Commission called as its first witnesses officers of S. W. Straus Co., one of the largest of the pre-depression realty organizations.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Bids on thirty-seven municipal bond issues having a par value of $5,339,500 that were pledged originally for construction loans from the Public Works Administration were received today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21. -Harvard, to all intents and purposes, ended its first season of football work under the coaching of Dick Harlow and his aides today.

PRINCETON defeated Cornell by 54 to 0. Dartmouth defeated Cornell by 41 to 6. Princeton defeated Harvard by 35 to 0. Dartmouth defeated Harvard by 14 to 6. As a guide to coming events, comparative scores are worth about two kopecks a long ton. Or perhaps that estimate is too liberal.

On the forenoon of Nov. 1 the Rev. F. R. Godolthin leaned from the pulpit of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, which after 228 years still stands in the centre of what is now the LaTourette public golf course on Staten Island, and preached words fitting for the observance of All Saints' Day.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, Friday, Nov. 22. -- The captain of the steamer Pasha has sent a wireless message here saying that he sighted flares on Sayer Island, off the west coast of Siam, at 10 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Pressing his proposal to sell government controlled cotton at a reduced rate to textile manufacturers, Senator Lonergan said today that approval of the plan might be postponed until after Feb. 1, when pledges on government cotton holdings expire.

Bronx University Week, which Borough President James J. Lyons devised in an effort to show that the northern borough had "more to boast about rightfully" than providing the name for a popular mixed drink and a derisive expression, opened last night at the Bronx County Building, 161st Street and Grand Concourse.
The number thirteen brought no ill luck yesterday to a thirteenpound prize-winning cat at the twenty-first annual show of the Empire Cat Club in the Park Central Hotel.

Interstate cooperation in providing adequate highway facilities and traffic control through the Port of New York Authority was hailed yesterday by Governor Hoffman of New Jersey and New York officials at a luncheon in the Hotel New Yorker, preceding an inspection of the Midtown Hudson Tunnel.

Among the passengers arriving to-I day on the Swedish American linerGripsholm is Eric Vettergren, di-rector of the National luseum inStockholm and one of Sweden'sforemost experts on industrial artand handicraft. He is accompaniedby his wife, Mme. Gertrude Wetter-gren, opera singer.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- It was entirely to satisfy Premier Laval that the British Government sent Maurice Peterson, head of the Ethiopian department of the Foreign Office, back to Paris to resume his conversations with Count Saint-Quentin at the Quai D'Orsay.

Despite a great rally by his opponent, Edmund Soussa of Egypt was successful in retaining his national amateur 18.2 balkline championship as his challenge-round match with Edgar T. Appleby of New York came to a close at the Metropolitan Billiard Club last night. The final score was 900 -- 645.

Directors of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation increased yesterday the regular quarterly dividend on the common stock from 70 to 75 cents a share, placing it on a regular $3 annual dividend basis. An extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock was also declared.

Chairman Swope of the New York State Racing Commission stated recently that no basic change was contemplated in the New York policy. This is to be regretted. I believe there are many local horse-race lovers who would patronize New York racing under other conditions, but who under the present management would rather travel a couple hundred miles to other tracks.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- Traders on the Boerse appear to have given up even the pretense of carrying on ordinary exchange activities. The list of stocks that are not quoted for days at a time is growing steadily.
Sam Langford, old-time Negro heavyweight boxer, received a letter of encouragement yesterday from Mayor La Guardia, urging him to a quick recovery from injuries suffered in a recent accident.
Money market was at a standstill in the matter of rate variations and business. Quotations were carried forward on a minimum of turnover.

Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, prominent lawyer and a leader in American Jewry, died suddenly at 9:30 o'clock last night at his home at 639 West 246th Street, the Bronx, after a brief illness.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 21. -- Anti-Semitic student demonstrations continued today despite the closing of Budapest University and the majority of the high schools and concentration of large police forces. The demonstrators succeeded in invading State music schools, which for the last fifteen years-have been undisturbed by anti-Semitic agitation.

BERLIN, Nov. 21. -- The State's Attorney requested the Berlin Criminal Court today to sentence Peter Legge, Catholic Bishop of Meissen, to five years in prison, and to fine him 90,000 marks for violation of the currency exchange laws. The same sentence was requested for the Bishop's brother, Father Theodor Legge, with a 50,000-mark fine.

When the New York Giants football team faces the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, Jim MacMurdo, former Pitt tackle, will be in the visitors' lineup, it was announced yesterday by Lud Wray, coach of the Quaker City eleven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP). -Christy Payne, retired vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, gave the Federal Trade Commission today what he termed a "sweeping denial of all charges" that he or the company participated in a "market raid" on Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line stock on June 16, 1930.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- With the $4,000,000,000 work relief program moving rapidly toward its peak, the Administration plans a vigorous defense of the undertaking against the criticism which has been leveled against it.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased $4,764,954 from the previous week, the weekly statement said today. Deposits by chartered banks declined $20,686,740.

On all fronts it became evident yesterday that the annual gridiron battle between Fordham and New York University this year again will take on the air of importance which in previous years established it as one of the football classics in the East.
ASMARA, Eritrea Nov. 21 (AP). -The defeat of Ras Seyoum's Ethiopian warriors by four Italian battalions in a mountain battle was reported today to the Italian high command.

The climax of a week of exceptionally interesting orchestral performances came last night in Carnegie Hall when the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, celebrated its fiftieth consecutive season of concerts given in New York with interpretations of Beethoven's First and Ninth Symphonies.

Burning the midnight oil in the barracks of the Sixteenth Infantry on Governors Island won for Private (first class) Arif V. Morali, bandsman and soldier of fortune, second prize for a Turkish dance he composed for the recent national music festival at Istanbul, Turkey.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- A statement that teachers should be hygienic models for their pupils was made by the Board of Examiners of the New York City Board of Education in an answer filed today to an appeal by Miss Rose Freistater from a ruling by the board barring a teacher's license to her because she weighed 182 pounds.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas rose 2 per cent for the week ended Nov. 16, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase reflects a smaller gain in retail trade than was anticipated, inasmuch as the rise in packages handled for the preceding week, in comparison with the same period in 1934, was 6 per cent.

Even though Lincoln Ellsworth was forced to turn back, his flight yesterday is one of the most important, both in length and in discovery, yet made in the Antarctic. It is second in distance only to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's flight from Little America to the South Pole and back to the foot of the Queen Maude Range, a distance of a little more than 1,100 miles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A new world record of 72,395 feet above sea level was announced today by the National Aeronautic Association as the official flight altitude achieved by Explorer II, balloon of the National Geographic Society, in the stratosphere flight of Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson on Nov. 11.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- A new world record of 72,395 feet above sea level was announced today by the National Aeronautic Association as the official flight altitude achieved by Explorer II, balloon of the National Geographic Society, in the stratosphere flight of Captains Albert W. Stevens and Orvil A. Anderson on Nov. 11.

The Princeton, Harvard and University Clubs Class A squash racquets teams continued tied at the top in the Metropolitan Association tournament last night, each squad registering its fourth victory in a row.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 21. -- The Dartmouth student body assembled in front of College Hall tonight to give the Green squad of thirty-four men an ovation as they entrained for Princeton.

That racing on the New York tracks under the jurisdiction of the Jockey Club had a prosperous season and made substantial gains was indicated by reports filed with the State Racing Commission yesterday.

A boy or girl of 10 is still a child and not too old for a new home, according to the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, which met yesterday at its headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street. Recognizing a problem in the desire of foster parents to adopt children of tender years, the committee voted to start a drive for the adoption of older children, ranging up to 12 years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Colder weather and smaller receipts stimulated the demand for hogs hero today and prices advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundred weight, with all interests good buyers. The top price was $9.70, up 15 cents from Wednesday, while the day's average was up a like amount at $9.55.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will be represented at injunction proceedings brought in Federal District Courts by utility holding companies and their subsidiaries, but officials were not ready to discuss the line they would take in meeting the complicated situation which is developing.

Dave Schriner put on a one-man show last night to lead the New York Americans to their first victory of the season. The strapping left winger for the spangled crew caged two goals in less than one minute of the overtime session to hand the Detroit Red Wings a 3-to-1 defeat at Madison Square Garden.

Two football games between Marblehead (Mass.) High School and Curtis High of Staten Island, the first to take place at Thompson's Stadium at Stapleton on Dec. 7, have been arranged, according to an announcement made yesterday by John W. Morris of Curtis.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today was restricted owing to the heavy settlement, although most groups were firm. British funds recovered further. Japanese issues improved and South Americans were supported in the foreign department.

MEMEL, Nov. 21. -- It was officially announced today by Mr. Baldszus, President of the Memel Diet and the man who headed the German party and won the greatest number of individual votes in the recent election, had definitely undertaken to form a new directory or government of the territory in conformity with its autonomy statute.

The safety of Hudson River tunnels as against the necessity of providing deeper water for large ships entering the port was debated yesterday morning at a hearing at the Army Building on a proposal of the Maritime Association that the Ambrose and Anchorage channels and the Hudson River up to Sixtieth Street be deepened to fifty feet.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discount were at the lowest.

Criticism of Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Education for their failure to remedy the "disgraceful" school conditions existing in Harlem was expressed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Teachers Union in Wadleigh High School, 215 West 114th Street.
MONTREAL, Nov. 21 (AP). -- Leroy Goldsworthy headed the Montreal Canadiens tonight in an uprising that resulted in a 2-1 victory over the world champion Maroons in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, acquired 30,000 shares of its common stock on Aug. 6, bringing his direct holdings as of Aug. 31 to 50,406 shares, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of transactions in and holdings of equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations whose securities are registered on national securities exchanges.

Reports that there had been an unusual increase in the parcel post mail from Italians and ItalianAmericans to Italy since the threat of sanctions and their enforcement against that country by the League of Nations were denied at the New York Postoffice yesterday.

DUNDEE ISLAND, Weddell Sea, Antarctica, Nov. 21. -- Another secret bas been wrested from Antarctica. Although Herbert Hollock-Kenyon and I had to turn back our plane after covering almost a third of the distance across Antarctica to the ROSS Sea, we discovered that the great mountain chain of which Graham Land is a part rises again beyond Stefansson Strait on what is probably one great Antarctic continent.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 21. -- As in the two previous Falls since he became President, Mr. Roosevelt established himself and a skeleton office staff tonight in the "Little White House," a cottage on the wooded slopes of Pine Mountain, overlooking the foundation which he set up to help rehabilitate infantile paralysis sufferers.

Net profit of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $163,299 after depreciation, depletion, Federal taxes and other charges. The profit was equivalent to 3 cents a share on 4,702,945 shares of $5 par common stock.

Securities of six companies now traded on the New York Curb Exchange will be transferred to the New York Stock Exchange if applications for listing on the latter market, announced yesterday, are approved. The six issues are among the applications of eighteen companies now pending before the Exchange's committee on stock list.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The present "substantial, strong and sustained advance of business" was contrasted with "two artificial stimulants that played so large a part in 1933" by Leslie G. McDouall of Newark, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, in an address here tonight at the annual mid-year conference of the association.

Disapproval of President Roosevelt's New Deal administration is displayed by a majority of the votes in the first returns of the new Literary Digest poll, it was announced yesterday. In 40,053 returns from five Southern and Midwestern States 46.72 per cent voted for the Roosevelt policies and 53.28 per cent against them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- An almost worldwide change in sentiment regarding the immediate trend of the wheat market occurred overnight, and prices on the Chicago Board of Trade and abroad were rushed up rapidly today as the result of general buying.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 21. -- Four children, ranging in ages from 5 to 14 years, were burned to death in an upper floor bedroom of their home at 105 Ashland Avenue tonight when fire, caused by a portable oil stove, swept the room.

Professor Oliver M. W. Sprague of Harvard, who resigned as executive assistant to the Treasury because of his disagreement with the administration's monetary policy, took an optimistic stand in regard to some administration policies last night.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 22. -- A proposal by General Chiang Kai-shek for limited autonomy in North China has isolated the Chinese separatists and, in the words of the latest Japanese dispatches, has "seriously impeded" the independence movement.
The board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange adopted yesterday a resolution providing that all December No. 1 raw sugar contracts be settled forthwith at 2.51 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- American oil producers were called upon today by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, to halt the further shipment of petroleum to Italy. As Petroleum Administrator, Mr. Ickes declared that domestic producers should "keep the spirit and letter" of the Neutrality Act by refusing to sell oil and "war materials" to Italy.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The body of Leroy Smith, 24-year-old farmer of Suffern, was found at 4 o'clock this afternoon in a field on the farm of George Brownsell, north of the local court house. After an autopsy tonight Dr. J. William Giles, Rockland County coroner, said Smith had been shot with a .38 calibre pistol and had been dead about twenty-four hours.

HONOLULU, Nov. 22. -- A combination eruption from Mauna Loa, the first since December, 1933, was under way today amid the smoke of burning forests and clouds of sulphur fumes that arose to such a height that they were visible forty miles away.

The old literary New York City was safe and cultured. I had the parlor on the ground floor at 10 East Twenty-eighth Street. For air in the sleeping room I had to open the window with never a thought of burglars climbing in. Upstairs, Richard Harding Davis and John Fox, the novelists, had rooms.

Dr. John A. Lapp, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, denied yesterday a motion to dismiss the complaint brought against the Atlas Bag and Burlap Company, Inc., of Brooklyn, under the Wagner-Connery Labor Disputes Act.

Our Government has taken another step in preventing shipment of oil to Italy. After President ROOSEVELT had set his official face against it, after Secretary HULL had specifically warned exporters of oil, Secretary ICKES came forward with an out-and-out statement that selling oil to Italy was a violation of American neutrality and must be stopped.

Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch was praised yesterday by civic leaders and officials as a public servant who had made himself a martyr to duty, a conscientious citizen and as a leader of Jewish effort in New York. Some of the tributes sent to his family follow:
The Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans will begin tomorrow the observance of his fortieth anniversary as pastor of what is now the West Park Presbyterian Church. Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

My one recreation for several years has been to attend Saturday football games. We were promised the abolition of liquor flasks if prohibition was repealed. But today they bring quart bottles of whisky, and the women match the men and then act like fools.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 22. -- A half million children are in serious need of care and protection, Francis Biddle of Philadelphia yesterday told the Indianapolis committee of the Child Welfare League, a federation of 160 units in the United States and Canada.

W.R.K. Mitchell, W.W. Taylor, W.H. Duff and David Soliday, as a committee, have sent to holders of Peoples Light and Power Corporation first lien 5 1/2 per cent bonds, Series of 1941, a letter advising that they represent a substantial amount of the obligations and have been in negotiation with representatives of other securities in an endeavor to agree on a reorganization plan.

Edward R. Rayher, chairman of the committee on domestic relations court of the New York County Lawyers Association, announced yesterday that his committee is studying the Jersey City plan for the handling of juvenile delinquency with a view to deciding whether it should be recommended for adoption in New York City.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 22 (AP). -- Decision on a motion for nonsuit in a case involving alleged underpayment to a milk producer was reserved until Monday today by Supreme Court Justice Edward N. Smith after hearing argument by attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- A policy of independence is to be observed by the United States in the North China crisis. This became clear today when some details were learned of the conversation held on Tuesday by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, with William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State.

Bowing low and with earnest faces, they assured General Mariotti through" an interpreter that they as peaceful inhabitants of Azbi had taken no part in the attack against his column and deplored it deeply. Most of their followers, they declared, had withdrawn from the neighborhood when Kassa Sebat's forces arrived and had never helped him in any way.
