The general's orders were brief and were being observed long before orderlies could reach the various commanders.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Nov. 22. -- The China Clipper, first of a fleet of giant air liners to speed the Far East trade, hopped off from here today for Manila to open transpacific air mail service amid the cheers of thousands who lined the shores and other vantage points.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 22. -- The Fall sport season at Smith College reached its climax this morning with the presentation of three All-Smith blazers and the announcement of All-Smith teams at student assembly by Miss Grace Gilkyson of Mont Clare, Pa., president of the athletic association.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- Rockland County officials said they were as mystified here tonight by the shooting of Leroy Smith, 25-year-old farmer's son, as they were yesterday afternoon, when Smith's body was found in a field at the side of New City-Haverstraw Road, a mile north of the court house here.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 23. -- Ethiopian armies are definitely on the move as a result of orders given by Emperor Haile Selassie, on his visit here, that an offensive be launched in the South.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- Retail trade in the First Federal Reserve District is currently described as somewhat disappointing. Department store sales in October showed a gain of one and a half of 1 per cent over the same month a year ago.

TO have a still further offering of poems from the fragile and agile pen of Emily Dickinson is a gift which literary America will not be slow to appreciate. The spinster of Amherst died nearly a half-century ago, and none of her poetry was published until many years after, when her sister, Lavinia, vouchsafed a carefully edited collection.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Scoring honors were well distributed among Princeton's talented set of ball-carriers in today's decisive victory over Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium. Pauk, Kaufman, LeVan and White each went across for a touchdown.

Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of Dana College, Newark, will speak on "International Situations" on Tuesday afternoon in the first of a series of three lectures to be given at the college under the auspices of the current events group of the Ruth Kohn Association.

AUSTIN, Texas. AS soon as the Texas Government completes final details for conveying titles to the United States Government a new national park will be created in the Lone Star State. It will be located in the Big Bend country along the Rio Grande River across from Mexico, and it is possible that the nation to the south may take similar action within its domain.

WHILE narrow and winding old turnpikes of New England and the Middle Atlantic States and the mud and corduroy roads of the coastal regions to the south have been transformed into straight, wide speedways to carry tourists into the land of palms and sunshine, another kind of pleasure traffic route has been built to parallel the highways on one side and the wave-beaten shore on the other.

THESE are days of preparation in Switzerland, as plans are hurried along for the activities of its pleasure resorts which are whitening beneath the first snows of the season. Travelers, home for the holidays, are studying their schedules with the skating and skiing resorts of Switzerland in view.

THIS is a lively and engrossing tale concerned chiefly with the fortunes of Kirk Carmichael, young, determined and resourceful leader of a group of ranchers in their fight to save their water rights, their lands, their homes from confiscation for the aggrandizement of a powerful and unscrupulous State Senator and his corrupt political allies.

THE Needlework Guild of America is this year celebrating its fiftieth anniversary. Started in 1885 by a small group of Philadelphia women who made garments by hand for needy families, the guild has developed into a national organization with branches in all large cities and many small communities.

ATLANTA, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Lawyers of the Southeast had in their hands today a "plan for the better organization of the bar" and giving the average practitioner a voice in the affairs of the American Bar Association.

BARCELONA, Nov. 6, 1935. BETWEEN the risk of bombs risk in Barcelona and the same risk in some other European city in the war-clouded year 1936, the Prague assembly of the International Society for Contemporary Music, overcoming its previous hesitancy, cast its vote for Barcelona.

An assurance from Aubrey W. Williams, executive director of the National Youth Administration, that "substantial sums" were available for starting relief and rehabilitation activities among jobless youth in the metropolitan area awaited Mark A. McCloskey, newly appointed NYA director for this district, as he began his duties yesterday morning.

REPERCUSSIONS of the behind-the-scenes struggle being waged in New Zealand over the offer of Pan American Airways to provide that distant dominion with air connections with the United States are being felt here.

Stimulated by a sharp rise in retail buying in various sections of the country, business in general moved at a faster pace last week. Reports from leading manufacturing centres gave indications of favorable industrial conditions, while employment in many of the major lines of business showed further gains.

Retail trade snapped back last week and stores recorded satisfactory increases in volume, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Holiday buying, the report states, has started in all departments, with early reorders indicating interest in gift merchandise at higher average prices per unit.

MILAN, Nov. 8, 1935. THE Propaganda Ministry's new measures for native opera on minor Italian stages have already borne some first fruits, for better or worse, in five novelties brought out recently or scheduled for early production.

I have just read Mr. Kingsley's interesting piece in yesterday's paper, and it seems to me that it contains two important statements which merit further discussion. The first statement is: "Thoughts turn to the theatre of our day -- a theatre unshackled by formula, heir to the great and golden ages, yet strangely pallid and flavorless."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 23. -- The annual charity ball at Smith College will be held in Scott Gymnasium on Dec. 7. Ever since its inauguration in 1932 this event has increased in popularity until it is now second only to the junior promenade. Besides this it has the advantage of admitting members of all four classes while the promenade is open only to members of the upper two.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Undergraduate journalistic work is claiming the attention of more University of Pennsylvania students this year than any other extracurricular activity with the exception of athletics.

Italy will never be able to assert "her legitimate rights to life and expansion" while she follows her present role in international life, declared Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, on his arrival here yesterday.

HONOLULU, Nov. 23. -- The huge flying boat China Clipper, with the first Pacific air mail, alighted in Pearl Harbor at 10:21 this morning [3:51 P.M. in New York] 21 hours and 5 minutes after taking off from Alameda, Calif.

The appointment of Marshal Pietro Badoglio to chief command of the Italian armies in Ethiopia, although foreshadowed early in the campaign when he went to the front on a tour of investigation, has supported the belief that the Facisti are having a much more difficult time than they had anticipated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22. -- As they prepare to conclude their presentation of evidence early next week, Thomas J. Mooney's lawyers profess confidence that the eight weeks of hearings before A.E. Shaw, State Supreme Court referee, have amply proved their contention that he was convicted of the 1916 Preparedness Day bombing by perjured testimony, known to be such by Charles M. Fickert, then District Attorney.

ONE rainy night Van, who is "by way of being a doctor one of these days," is tramping New York streets in an effort to lessen the shock of his father's death. When a girl accosts him he rebukes her, then relents and takes her to his apartment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23. -- The business of transporting Pacific Coast fruit, both refrigerated and canned, together with other foodstuffs harvested during the season just closing, is keeping whole fleets of ocean carriers engaged in a manner that is thoroughly in keeping with the brisk upturn in all lines of trade on the Western slope.

Industrial, financial and other groups responding to a recent questionaire sent out to 1,600 establishments by the Bronx Board of Trade have revealed that there is "solid ground for optimism over local business conditions," it was reported yesterday by Fred Berry, president of the Bronx Board of Trade.

IN his "First Book of Irish Literature" Aodh Sandrach de Blacam, the Gaelic scholar, poet and story-teller whose name is invoked on the dedication page of "Stand and Give Challenge," says of Donnacha MacConmara, the hero of this quasi-biographical novel, that he "possessed, perhaps, the best creative mind among Gaelic singers of his age."

Fascist and anti-Fascist sympathizers clashed at a meeting of needleworkers at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon and hundreds of astonished hotel patrons in the lobby looked on while the police escorted the disputants out of the building.

Officers of the American General Corporation, which represents the consolidation of eight investment companies of the United Founders group, yesterday announced plans to amend its charter to provide for the creation of a convertible feature on its preferred stock.

At the tenth annual session of the New England Council last week no political discussion was the promise, impossible to be kept. People will talk politics, now so intimately blended with economic and industrial matters. Dr. GLENN FRANK, that industrious itinerant orator who has himself been "mentioned" as a possible Republican candidate for President, spoke of freedom and the perils of centralized government, sure to bring "a new and tragic enslavement of the masses."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Improvement in the national employment situation was indicated here today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the Bureau of Appointments and Student Employment at Princeton University, in making public the results of a survey which reveals that only one-tenth of the members of last year's graduating class are involuntary victims of unemployment.

THE Metropolitan Opera has confirmed the story that "Traviata" will be the opening-night opera three weeks from tomorrow. Lucrezia Bori, Richard Crooks and Lawrence Tibbett will have the leading roles and Ettore Panizza will conduct. Jonel Jorgulesco has designed new sets as well as plates for new costumes.

THAT large and hardy perennial, the Carnegie International, comes in for exhaustive discussion in two of the leading American publications dealing with art in their November issues. Forbes Watson, of the Section of Painting and Sculpture of the United States Treasury Department, considers its purpose and other aspects, with considerable attention to the products of and contrasts among the different nations in The American Magazine of Art (including Creative Art).

IN the case of so highly personal and moving a narrative as this autobiography to date by Mr. Harold Stearns of Harvard, Greenwich Village, The Chicago Dial, Montparnasse and The Paris Tribune, not to mention the Longchamp race course, it is exceptionally difficult to review in anything but a personal, and even, an egotistic manner.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- An extension of the League of Nations sanctions against Italy to ban shipments of oil, iron and coal was discussed today in conversations Premier Pierre Laval had with Vittorio Cerruti, the Italian Ambassador, and Sir George Clerk, the British Ambassador.

Just a notch below their winning performance of last year, the De Witt Clinton High School riflemen handily defeated eighteen other combinations in the competition for the New York Stock Exchange Rifle Trophy yesterday. The Clinton total of 1,010 led in the tenth annual event at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club's range in Brooklyn.

The share market responded yesterday to the reassuring statement by Governor Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board that the board sees no need for applying the brakes on the advance in the near future by halting its profit-taking decline of the day before having a brisk rally which carried many issues up 1 to 5 points during the half-day trading.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov 22. -- Notwithstanding protests made in the name of agriculture against the Canadian tariff treaty, the Corn Belt farmer has not shown a disposition to become much excited about it.

Man must turn to athletics and other forms of physical activity to protect himself from the social ills prevalent today, Dr. Jesse F. Williams, Professor of Education of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared in a survey, "The Challenge to Health," made public yesterday.

KEANSBURG, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Four men were captured with nearly 2,000 gallons of smuggled alcohol here early this morning after two Federal agents were held prisoners by smugglers, who thought they were hijackers, following one of the most serious gun battles between government officials and bootleggers since the repeal of prohibition.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Retail trade this week swept forward under a combination of cold weather and early Christmas shopping to the best sales totals this Fall. State Street department store sales averaged between 15 and 20 per cent above last year compared with gains of around 10 per cent early in November.
ATLANTA, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Georgia Tech defeated Florida, 39 to 6, today in a game that brought out about all the tricks of football, including an 82-yard run for a touchdown.

The amateur economist we have always with us. But where once he was an isolated crank, now he comes in droves. He would scarcely venture to set up his opinion against that of the professional engineer, doctor or chemist in his particular field, but when it comes to economics he has no such qualms.

President Roosevelt told the United States Conference of Mayors last week that taxes in this country had "grown up like Topsy" and that it was about time for the localities, States and Federal Government to seek a revision in "the general tax situation" so as to stop "stepping on one another's toes."

REPORTS of the "passing of the old East," taken home by many travelers from Europe and the United States, appear premature by several centuries, at least to the visitor who travels the road from Alexandria to Beirut with an eye to the life and customs of the natives.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 23. -- Although the prohibition amendment to the State constitution has been repealed and a State Liquor Sale and Control Law passed by a special session of the Legislature, there is a strong probability that more than two-thirds of Texas will continue to be dry.

ESCANABA, Mich., Nov. 22. -- While the automotive, furniture and other manufacturing industries of the Lower Peninsula express optimism over the prospects for an increased volume of business in Canada under the new reciprocal trade agreement, Michigan agriculture feels it has been discriminated against.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- An assertion that Pennsylvania will be carried by President Roosevelt next year was made tonight by Senator Guffey, chairman of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Agitation for revision of the football rules cropped up again last week.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The price of gold fell here today to 140s 10d an ounce, with sales 286,000. Silver went down to 29 3-16d an ounce for spot and to 28 13-16d for forward delivery, with prices adjusted to the lower level of the dollar, although there was some forward selling on Indian account.

IT is almost hundred since a years Tennyson published "Locksley Hall," and nobody reads it nowadays. But there is a line in "Locksley Hall," "And I doubt not through the ages one increasing purpose runs," that the world might still remember and believe in with profit.

MUCH sound argument and many illuminating points of view distinguish "Art Education Today," an annual devoted to the problems of art education, edited by members of the fine arts staff of Teachers College, Columbia University.
New York had its first snowfall of the season yesterday that served as a warning of approaching Winter weather.

PARIS. SUITS will be more popular than ever this coming Spring, for all times of day. The suit silhouette is in the same transitional state that marks other fashion outlines, at the moment; this has a rather agreeable influence on the mode, since it fosters a great many different types of costume.

THE 1936 model of American trotting horse, stream-lined by more than a century of careful breeding, will draw the light-harness turfmen of the nation to New York City this week. For it is "Old Glory Sale" time and the country's leading stud farms are sending up their best yearlings to go under the auctioneer's hammer.

A sharp break in the price of Dec. 3 sugar contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was the feature of yesterday's commodity futures markets here. The December contract fell 12 points to 2.27 cents, with tomorrow, the notice day, indicating virtual elimination of any prospects of a squeeze.

Eight round-table discussions will be held simultaneously tomorrow morning at the opening meeting of the Montclair League of Woman Voters, to be held at the Friends Meeting House in Upper Montclair. The general theme of the discussions will be "The League at Work."

WHILE recording the many large and significant exhibitions of the work of masters of art from other countries that are the outcome of other civilizations, other surroundings and customs, it is a deep satisfaction to be able to look forward to a celebration, unique in character, of a truly great American painter, Winslow Homer.

THE Museum of Modern Art Film Library, at 485 Madison Avenue, which was founded in May to make a record of noteworthy motion pictures produced here and abroad since 1889, announced last week the titles and dates of the old films which will compose its first two series of programs.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22. -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King, having made a trade treaty with the United States before going on a holiday, will be greeted on his return by the news that the Dominion has settled its trade feud with Japan. Next in line for revision will then be Canada's trade relations with Great Britain.

More than 500,000 extra employes will be hired by retailers during this month and December to take care of a Christmas business expected to exceed that of last year by from 10 to 15 per cent, according to the results of a survey issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

New Jersey yachtsmen, always canal-minded, are now ambitious enough to hope for not one but three government-operated canals as connections between the State's various waterways. Most interesting of all the projects is the one to turn over to Federal authorities the abandoned Delaware and Raritan Canal, which crosses New Jersey from New Brunswick to Bordentown.

HAVANA, Nov. 23. -- Secretary of the Interior Maximiliano Smith, designated to contact all political parties to bring about an agreement so that the elections set for Dec. 15 may be held, asserted following a Cabinet meeting this afternoon that the government would not reform the electoral code.

LONDON, Nov. 7, 1935. THE Autumn season is now in full swing and all the three London orchestras have given concerts which sought to attract the public by some feature of unusual interest. The quest for novelties has not revealed a masterpiece nor has it brought forth an unknown performer of exceptional gifts.

Strong support was accorded to the French franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday. This was given not only by the arbitrage operations of leading banks in connection with purchases of gold in Paris but also, it was assumed, by the British and the United States stabilization funds.

CHICAGO. -- The Marshall Field mansion on Prairie Avenue, which for sixty years has been a Chicago landmark and showplace, is being stripped of its furnishings and is soon to be razed. The first Marshall Field built the twenty-five-room stone and brick house in the first flush of his success as Chicago's leading merchant prince.
ROME, Nov. 23. -- Italy claimed tonight to have added the rich Ogaden Province in Southeastern Ethiopia to the large areas under her control in that nation.

Alumnae Day will be observed at Hunter College on Wednesday this year in conjunction with the Thanksgiving Day festivities. In accordance with custom, alumnae will return to visit their former professors and attend their old classes.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP). -- The motor car industry will produce this year close to 4,000,000 cars and trucks if the remaining weeks of the year show no unexpected slump. Moreover, its assemblies are prepared for any volume of output which consumer demand may place upon them next year.
MOGADISCIO, Italian Somaliland, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Italians faced heavy difficulties in terrain, weather and enemy concentrations today in their advance into Ethiopia from Somaliland.

A racket in which recipients of old-age security relief are the victims was revealed yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare. More than fifty elderly persons have been victimized, he estimated.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Upsala College defeated the Panzer College eleven, 20 -- 14, at Ashland Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- Rallying in the last half, Villanova swept on to a thrilling 21-14 victory over Temple in the Owls' stadium today before a chilled crowd of 30,000. Snow fell throughout the game, making the field wet and slippery.

HOLLYWOOD. OUTRAGED by the lack of support given the film industry by the State Department, a condition emphasized by the controversy in Spain over "The Devil Is a Woman" and by the Turkish protests over "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh," the studios are uniting in an effort to compel Washington to give the picture business the same protection afforded steel, oil and similar industries.

Undaunted by the dispatches from Rome and from Addis Ababa, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, founder and honorary president, has issued the summons for the eleventh annual Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, to be held in Washington from Jan. 21 to 24 inclusive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Justification of "boondoggling" is made the subject of an essay by Charles Michelson, director of publicity of the Democratic National Committee, in answering the Republican Congressional Committee and other Republican spokesmen.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman, president of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., wrote to the Better Business Bureau of New York, Inc., yesterday disavowing any official connection with the Grand National Treasure Hunt contest.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Nov. 22. -- Twelve hundred miles out over the Pacific and drilling through the black void of the night the China Clipper is in close contact with all points of the compass after eight hours of steady flying through layers of clouds above and below.

IT was to have been expected that the jacket blurb would characterize this story of medieval England as a lusty and romantic tale. Its action is laid in the days of Richard the Lion-Hearted in and about the troubled city of York. The characters are barons and knights and men-at-arms in leather jerkins, wandering lay clerks and holy hermits and maidens in distress.

The reaction of the country to the trade agreement between the United States and Canada has been overwhelmingly favorable. I have noted a number of protests, confined almost entirely to professional partisan politicians or to some of the specially privileged individuals benefiting from excessive tariff rates, with a notable division of opinion, however, among the latter.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. GAME courts resembling the ball courts of the ancient Mayans were built by the Pueblo III Indians of Northern Arizona 800 years ago, as shown by excavations carried on by John C. McGregor, instructor in archaeology in the Arizona State Teachers College here and curator of Dendro-chronology of the Museum of Northern Arizona.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP). -- An alert Western Maryland College eleven tallied two touchdowns in the second quarter today to hand North Dakota its first defeat of the 1935 season, 13 to 7. Five thousand fans braved cold weather for the intersectional game.

MANY of Mr. Thurber's characters spend their lively existence in a state of mania. Haunted by hallucinations, they bound distractedly between the monstrous and the absurd. In this book you will encounter Mr. Bidwell, who infuriated his wife by holding his breath at parties, and the eminent author in search of a box to hide in, and Jad Peters, who collected bulky remembrances of catastrophes past, and Elliot Vereker, a walking museum of psychoses.

With the hearings before the Federal Trade Commission throwing into bold contrast the retailers' and manufacturers' divergent contentions on the voluntary pacts now before the commission, the first indication of what the commission's policy will be is being awaited with keen interest in both camps.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23. -- After winding a tortuous way through his field, the Macaw-Beaming colt, Bright Plumage, at last ran to his promise when he captured the $3,675 Endurance Handicap before 10,000 chilled spectators at Bowie today.

In September, 1931, Japanese military action in Manchuria began. The army did not move until there had been a proper "incident." Tokyo charged that Chinese soldiers and bandits had torn up tracks of the South Manchuria Railroad near Mukden. The following March saw Manchukuo created.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Unqualified approval of the League of Nations' sanctions against Italy was expressed today by Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff to Baron Arone di Valentino, the Italian Ambassador.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Dispatches from London to the French press, notably to the Liberte, this evening announce as certain that next week the British Government will begin in Berlin and Paris active negotiations with the view to a conference of Great Britain, France and Germany on the establishment of a basis for a combined policy of armaments limitation.

The soccer teams of James Monroe and New Utrecht fought to a scoreless tie in the match for the P.S.A.L. championship yesterday at Monroe Field in the Bronx. Last year after the rivals deadlocked in the final Monroe triumphed in the extra game.

Feathered aristocracy held sway at the sixth annual pet show at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the fourth day of the five-day exhibition by fanciers throughout the country. Gold and silver medals and cups were awarded to owners of champions in the caged-bird division of the display.

THE purpose of the Composers' Forum Laboratory of the Federal music project is not only to create interest in the composer and his work but to develop a closer relationship between the composer and his audience.

A simple solution of all economic evils is offered by Dr. Franz Oppenheimer, German sociologist and economist, who is to be guest of honor this evening at a dinner under the sponsorship of Professor Albert Einstein, Felix Frankfurter, Ludwig Lewisohn, Professor Henry Pratt Fairchild, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, Professor Horace M. Kallen, Professor Harry A. Overstreet and other leading thinkers.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Six thousand broadloom weavers who have been on strike for almost a month have no hopes of soon returning to work under a general union contract. They have encountered a deadlock in which large scale manufacturers, commission weavers who employ a little outside help, and 270 family shops are involved.
ST. PAUL. Nov. 23 (AP). -- Ray Murphy, national commander of the American Legion, in an address prepared for delivery tonight, warned against a "fumble" or overconfidence in the bonus fight.

THIRTY years ago New Zealand was much in the eye of those interested in social welfare and social justice. They call her the great social laboratory of the world and the most advanced, the most promising and the most interesting of all lands.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 23. -- An alert Massachusetts State College eleven defeated an old rival, Tufts College, 19 to 13, today. The victory was the first under Taube mentorship and the first triumph over the Jumbos since 1925.

A hope that this year's subscription sales at the Metropolitan Opera House will exceed that of last year by 35 per cent, was expressed by Earle R. Lewis, treasurer of the Metropolitan, last night. Mr. Lewis, who has been treasurer for the last twenty-seven years, added that if the 35 per cent was reached, it would set "an all-time record for a single year sales" for the Metropolitan.

Dr. Arthur E. Bestor, president of the Chautauqua Institution, has been elected president of the board of trustees of the League for Political Education and the Town Hall, Inc., to succeed Henry W. Taft, it was announced yesterday. He was chosen at the first Fall meeting of the board of trustees of the league.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- A new move to speed work relief employment coincided today with statistical indications that the Federal dole would continue beyond Dec. 1.

VERY seldom are we privileged to see an exhibition of the art of India so extensive as the one now on at the Heermaneck Galleries, 724 Fifth Avenue. The sculptures and miniatures have been arranged for display in two large rooms.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 23. -- The four games in the Southeast section field hockey tournament played on the snow sprinkled field of the Montclair Athletic Club today served to reaffirm the team and individual supremacy of the Philadelphia players, but also to demonstrate convincingly the great improvement of the newer association teams.

The library of the late John W. Masury of this city, together with items from the collection of Kent Alien of Los Angeles, Calif., and other properties, will be dispersed at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons.

Buying was resumed over a broad front in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Under the leadership of railroad issues, prices were carried upward sharply in the heaviest trading for a two-hour session since Jan. 12. 1935. Activity was confined largely to trading in domestic corporation bonds, the turnover in which amounted to $8,943,000, the largest since Feb. 3, 1934.

Tallying once in the third period, the High School of Commerce football team downed its traditional foe, De Witt Clinton High, 6 -- 0, in the thirty-second struggle between the schools at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The clash featured a scholastic twin bill.

Alfred E. Smith demonstrated last night a sure-thing method of gambling. Returning to the church he attended as a boy for an annual bazaar, the former Governor went from booth to booth betting nickels or dimes on every number of the board. When the wheel spun, no matter where it stopped, he won.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Four armed robbers, two of them carrying sawed-off shotguns, held up a pool room here tonight and escaped with about $6,000 in cash, after lining up twenty-five or more customers.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 23. -- The presidentcy of the world champion Detroit Tigers was assumed today by Walter O. Briggs, industrialist and for fifteen years silent partner of the late Frank J. Navin in the American League Baseball Club.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- District Attorney George V. Dorsey announced tonight that he was convinced Leroy Smith, 25-year-old farmer's son, had been murdered. Smith's body, with a gunshot wound through the heart, was found in a field near here Thursday.

ONE day in the year 1774 the British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs received a pleasant social call from a gentleman whom he had known in Madrid when he was British Ambassador there, and for whose brilliance, charm, culture, knowledge of the world, and talents as poet, playwright and musician, he had the greatest respect.

IN a land in which more than 160,000 divorces are granted every year, but wherein nobody but a specially versed lawyer knows what constitutes a legal divorce, it was surely time for such an explanatory book as this by Mr. Apstein, who can speak on the subject with a good deal of authority.

THE first award of the Limited Edition Club's Gold Medal will be made on Nov. 26 at a breakfast to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria. This medal is to be awarded annually to the American author who, in the opinion of the selecting committee, has written during the year the work most likely to become an American classic.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 23. -- Having rested for three days, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, today was reported to have recovered from the indisposition which caused postponement of the twenty-second game of his title match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, originally scheduled for Zandvoort last Thursday.

EVERY one -- well, seven or eight press agents anyway -- was making a to-do last week over Lionel Barrymore's twenty-fifth anniversary on the screen. You might have thought that Mr. Barrymore would have been a little excited about it, if only to please the bright young men who were sending out the bulletins on the subject. But he wasn't; not a bit.

As next Thursday is Thanksgiving pastors will today preach sermons reciting our nation's blessings and injecting a plea for peace among nations. There will be Thanksgiving pageants and cantatas in the evening. A number of churches will have annual homecoming services for former members.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 23. -- John Rodemeyer, editor of The Greenwich Daily News and Graphic for twenty-two years, and dean of newspaper men in Connecticut as he enters upon his sixtieth year in journalism, received a surprise testimonial dinner here tonight.

I am an American woman, and a mother who believes in morality and a high standard of thought which in no wise narrows my outlook on life or makes me less appreciative of its various phases. But resentment is aroused toward some of the present-day authors and their manner of writing, and toward the publishers who accept their work and place them before the public as examples of good literature.

A field of fifteen teams, including outstanding riders from Italy, France, Belgium, Germany, Canada and Australia as well as this country, has been lined up by Manage John Chapman for New York's fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race, which starts at Madison Square Garden next Sunday night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22. -- Incredulous, half amused and perhaps a little concerned, Philadelphians watched this week while City Controller S. Davis Wilson showed them something new in the way of a Mayor-elect in action.

A NEW type of tire, said to be able to stop a car, in an emergency, in 25 to 30 per cent shorter distance than conventional tires, and to do so without permitting the car to swerve from its course, has been developed by the General Tire and Rubber Company.

AN international bridge game played between teams 6,000 miles apart, at Schenectady, N.Y., and Buenos Aires, Argentina, will be on the air tomorrow night beginning at 8 o'clock over W2XAF, 9,530 kilocycles, and LSX, 10,350 kilocycles.

According to latest advices from Glasgow, the de luxe Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is being pushed toward completion and will be ready to proceed down the River Clyde early in May on her way to Southampton and undergo her trials before sailing for New York on her maiden voyage May 27.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- A difference of opinion between Irenee du Pont and the University of Pennsylvania trustees on the question of rewards for scientific research has resulted in the separation of the cancer research department from the university.

AS Governor of Kansas, Alf M. Landon, 48-year-old business man and independent oil producer, has come into the spotlight because of his record of administrative economy during the last two and three-quarter years -- and because this record has been acclaimed as exemplifying the things which seekers of Republican Presidential candidates believe they will have to stress in offering opposition to the New Deal in the coming campaign.
