Baldwin, 43, ibis man, ager, both of 20 Commerce i Street, were held in 500 bail each l Yesterday n Jeffers0n Market Court i to await extradition to New Mexico. They were charged with violating Section 1,301 Of the Penal LaW, relating to bringing stolen property into the city.

WASHINGTON. -- The works program is shifting into high gear. So much attention is attracted to its more obvious aspects that in many instances its fundamental purpose is entirely overlooked -- that of providing employment opportunities suited to the skills of the workers on projects of public usefulness.

A drive to raise $250,000, primarily among non-Jews, for the relief of German political refugees was initiated yesterday with the announcement that Dr. Frank Bohn, writer and lecturer, had accepted the chairmanship of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Political Refugees from Nazism.

Playing in New York City's first snowfall of the season, the New York University girls' field hockey team gave one of its best exhibitions to defeat William and Mary College, 3 -- 1, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Columbia scored its first victory of the season over a major rival yesterday. The Lions turned back an admittedly inferior Brown eleven on the snow and wind-swept gridiron at Baker Field by the score of 18 to 0.

FOR the third time in his administration President Roosevelt has transferred executive offices to the remote pine-clad hills of Warm Springs -- of all his temporary homes the one closest to the President's heart, and here, as at Hyde Park and wherever he travels by land and sea, is found a highly developed example of businesslike organization and modern communication.

MAGALLANES, that little city in Chile whose principal claim to fame has rested in the fact that it was "the southernmost city in the world," is about to take its place on the maps as an important airport.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Society danced tonight for the benefit of Irene Castle McLaughlin's stray dogs at her annual "pooch ball."

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Nov. 23. -- Nation-wide attention is being given to a circular letter issued by Archbishop Kaila of Finland, exhorting the clergy to pray for world peace, which he holds is now seriously threatened as a result of humanity's growing sinfulness.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Ethel Leginska tonight became the first woman in history to write and conduct an opera in a major opera house.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Dr. Peter Legge, Bishop of Meissen, was sentenced today in the Fourth Criminal Chamber of the Berlin Appellate Court to pay a fine of 100,000 marks, of which 40,000 marks was canceled by his imprisonment pending trial. In default of payment of the remaining 60,000 marks he must remain in prison three months longer.

"IT is nothing but beastely fury and extreme violence, where of procedeth hurt," Sir Thomas Eyot wrote of football in 1531. He probably would merely repeat himself could he be present at Madison Square Garden on a hockey night.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- In the final home game of Army's season the Cadets won today from the University of Vermont, 34 -- 0.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Sterling rose above 75 francs and the dollar to 15.19 1/4 francs in the foreign exchange trading on the Bourse today, while French rentes slumped once more, the 3 per cents closing at 72.40.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Despite indications that it will receive only one cent on each $42, the United States is preparing to go through the motions of telling twelve nations that their semi-annual war debt payments are about due.

Drunken driving has increased by 45 per cent since the end of prohibition, and the intoxicated motorist is the greatest danger on the highway today, Dr. Theron Wendell Kilmer, police surgeon of Hempstead, L.I., said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD. THE waves slapped the sand and the fog rolled in around the rotting piers, but it wasn't cool on the San Francisco waterfront. In fact, it was hot, hotter than Needles in July at high noon, hotter than tabasco sauce.

IN its present seething state, when more and more people are beginning to think that they will achieve happiness if only they can seize some State largess which they have not had to earn, society seems to need such a corrective as is afforded by this serene, practical, thoughtful book about happiness, its nature and the means by which man secure it.

An illustrated travel talk on British India will be given by Mrs. Hugh Black, president of the British Woman's Club of Montclair, N.J., at the meeting on Friday of the Queen Anne Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, in the home of Mrs. Royal Toner, in Garden City.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Winter shut down with a cold, wet hand over football today but failed utterly to quench the flame that has blazed so often in Yale-Harvard games.

With Bob McCullough, shifty quarterback, giving his customary excellent performances, the Boys High School football machine conquered New Utrecht High, 7 -- 0, yesterday at Erasmus Field, as the two formidable Brooklyn rivals brought their regular seasons to an end.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The five Vassar students who survived the automobile accident of last night which took three lives were said to be out of danger day.

TWENTY-FIVE years have passed since the press announced that Tolstoy was dead. The writings of my father had been translated into sixty languages, his name was everywhere a household word, and his death was a world-wide sensation.
BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Trading on the Boerse was mixed and listless today. Heavy industrial issues were slightly weaker, Mannesmann and Hoesch each losing 7/8 point. Machine shares were well regarded.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- Great Britain now proposes to stop crying over the spilt milk on its old but declining manufacturing activities and enter a new phase of developing hitherto secondary industries, with the object of recapturing its former status of "the world's workshop."

OF the estimated 22,000,000 young people in this country between the ages of 16 and 25 years, probably one-quarter, or 5,500,000, are wholly unoccupied at the present time. And of these nearly 3,000,000 have been forced to the extremity of going on the relief rolls.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23. -- General business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District is running 20 per cent ahead of last year. Gains are particularly noticeable in lumber, sales of stoves and, recently, automobile sales.

The M.D. after the author's name should be a guarantee that the medical details in this story are correct. And that guarantee is necessary, for two of the murders here recorded are committed in a hospital and by methods with which no layman would be likely to be familiar.

Plans for the first birthday party in its history are being completed by the National Life Conservation Society, which is rounding out its first decade. Mrs. Sturges S. Dunham is chairman of arrangements for the fete, which will take the form of an anniversary luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Dec. 5.

The discovery in Egypt of a fragment of the Gospel of St. John xviii. 31-33, adds nothing to the history of the gospel so far as the text is concerned. The place of discovery, the texture of the fragment and the Character of the writing, however, may go quite a long way toward determining the age of the fragment.

Two ambitious detectives "played hookey" from sergeants' school yesterday afternoon to capture James Mattera, 28 years old, a suspect wanted for several important crimes. They shot and seriously wounded him on the roof of a tenement at 111 Goerck Street, near Rivington Street.

READING, Pa., Nov. 23. -- Albright turned back Franklin and Marshall by a 9-to-6 score today to provide one of the season's upsets. More than 10,000 saw the game, in which Johnny Muller, Hillside, N.J., kicked a field goal early in the first period. This was followed by Dick Riffle's touchdown, climaxing a 45-yard drive, giving the Red and White a lead the Eastern Conference champions were unable to overcome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Senator Borah bluntly asserted today that should he receive the "unexpected and great honor" of being President he would veto as unconstitutional such legislation as the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill.

IN the first part of his autobiography Mr. Fay tells of his years in Dublin before the beginnings of the Irish Dramatic Movement in 1899. As we can now realize, these were years of unconscious preparation for a mission, for the Fays were dedicated men.

To commemorate the last scheduled mail flight made in the United States in an open cockpit plane, a ceremony will be held Tuesday afternoon in the sunken plaza at Rockefeller Center at which Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, general manager of Eastern Air Lines, will retire the plane from service.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Brewers estimated today that the beer output here this year will be almost 50 per cent greater than that in the last year before the prohibition era.

In Europe a nation-wide war against noise is being waged in many countries. High officers are taking part in it, distinguished medical men and scientists are identified with it and laws and regulations are being made in regard to it.

As reconstructed by scientists, those terrible and mysterious animals which roamed the earth during the dim eras of its evolution seem almost too fantastic to be credible to the mind outside the classroom or the museum.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- H. Richard Segoine, '08, chairman of the Rutgers University Alumni Council, named eight standing committees of the council today. J. Provost Stout, '95, of Lakewood, was appointed chairman of the committee on secondary schools and Bryce I. MacDonald, '14, of Westfield, was named chairman of the committee on undergraduate activity.

ATHENS, Greece, Nov. 23. -- A general shift in the naval forces in the Mediterranean, in view of the lessening tension, has been made feasible by King George's restoration and is now understood to be the subject of three-cornered talks among Great Britain, Italy and Greece.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Gorton High School's powerful football team still faces a chance for the W.I.A.A. championship by crushing Theodore Roosevelt High, an intra-city rival, under a 27-7 count today. Employing a strong ground offensive, the winners marked up their third triumph in four tournament starts.

THIS is the Odyssey of a man and two horses who made the almost incredible journey from Buenos Aires to New York. It took two and a half years to accomplish this tremendous task, and those years were filled with a multitude of adventures and dangers.

THERE are proverbs in many languages which suggest the idea that "he that has an ill name is half hanged." This idea is taken as the general text for Mr. Payson's dramatic novel about a girl who lives under a shadow after her mother is convicted of murder and executed at the opening of the story.

THE ferryboat Kalakala, recently put into commission on the run between Seattle and Bremerton, Wash., and still under adaptation tests, is radically different from any ship of her type anywhere in the world. Outwardly she looks like a giant wingless hydroplane; her interior is like the lounge of a luxurious hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Abnormal increases in the quantities of commodities exported to Italy or Ethiopia will force upon this government the conclusion that those items are prime essential war materials, Secretary of State Hull indicated at his press conference today.
The long-standing feud between Dr. S.S. Goldwater, City Hospitals Commissioner, and Dr. Menas S. Gregory, former head of the Bellevue Hospital Psychiatric Division, ended yesterday.

A SUBSTITUTE for the double-feature program, which exhibitors continue to use despite the pleas and threats of the studios, was offered this week by Edward Small, head of Reliance Pictures. To supplement his regular schedule for United Artists, Mr. Small announced plans to produce a series of 4,000-foot pictures based on short stories and novelettes which ordinarily would not contain sufficient plot material for full-length films.

Anthony Trantacosta, proprietor of the Innovation Luggage Stores, Inc., at 8 East Forty-eighth Street, was shot in the right arm with his own revolver while grappling with one of two hold-up men who entered the store shortly before noon yesterday. He was taken to the Metroplitan Hospital and after receiving treatment for the wound went home.
The speech made by ex-President Hoover before the Ohio Society on Nov. 16 has been acclaimed by party followers as a campaign keynote, charged with high-powered anti-New Deal ammunition for 1936.

Again you want to ask him what the magic secret is that has given his life such power, authority and ease, and made all the brutal struggle, pain and ugliness of life, the fury, hunger and the wandering seem so far away, and you think he is going to tell you -- to give this magic secret to you -- but he tells you nothing.

CALIFORNIA is developing a new type of fisherman. He is the operator of the "floating fish factory" which has invaded the sardine industry and which, according to officials of the State Fish and Game Commission, threatens to sweep the West Coast clear of this tiny fish.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Nov. 23 (AP). -- High school football players volunteered today to furnish blood for their coach, R.S. Killen, near death from a bullet wound allegedly inflicted by the father of a student he dismissed from the squad.

MANY novelists in recent years have concerned themselves with countries whose depths have been stirred by strong nationalist movements, but Mr. Knittel would seem to be the first to have turned his attention to Egypt.

Italy felt last week the first effects of the League's sanctions, and the action taken by the Fascist Government plainly showed that its most immediate concern is the conservation of a precious supply of gold and foreign currencies. It was with this end in view that steps were taken during the week to declare a governmental monopoly of gold, to block the export of foreign money and to check the importation of Italian lire.

IN "Cape Cod Yesterdays" Joseph C. Lincoln tells of the Cape as it was in his boyhood, before the universal automobile had brought the present-day flood of visitors and tourists, and with them that standardization which, on the surface at least, has been doing away with local differences and characteristics that in the past gave so much of salt and savor.

EVERY Times Square corner has had its self-appointed committee to find a vehicle for Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper, but the winner is a gentleman from out of town. It is Lee Ephraim of Hopkinsville, Ky. (and, since 1909, of London, England), who has arranged the next Merivale-Cooper appearance hereabout.

GENEVA, Nov. 23. -- Now that all four League of Nations sanctions against the Italian Government are in force, how loyally are they being observed? How effective are they proving or seem likely to provd?

Upton Sinclair will give the first of a series of lectures tomorrow night, sponsored by the Westchester Society for Ethical Culture, in the auditorium of the Daniel Webster School, New Rochelle. The speaker, who has chosen as his subject, "What Lies Ahead for America?" will be introduced by Representative Caroline O'Day of Rye.
Coincident with President Roosevelt's drive to reduce accidents, school officials here have formulated standard rules for the extension of safety patrols at street intersections throughout the city.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23. -- A battling New York American hockey team lost a close decision to the Canadiens tonight in a National League game that saw the Canadiens score twice in the second period and hold a desperate New York third-period attack to one goal to win, 2 -- 1.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 23. -- The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation asked the Federal District Court today to declare the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 unconstitutional and to enjoin Federal officials from attempting to compel compliance with or to enforce the act; from instituting criminal proceedings based on alleged violations of the act, and from excluding any property, communications or securities of the corporation from the mails.

THE story goes that in the lean years of her obscurity Gertrude Stein sent one of her typical verbigerative manuscripts, thousands of pages long, to a friend in this country to find a publisher. This person sent portions of the manuscript to this one and that, but without success.

THANKSGIVING dinner comes again this week, and with it that hardy American perennial of the national menu, turkey and cranberry sauce. Modern variations and additions have only slightly affected the old-fashioned family dinner.

AFTER a week's rest, Otto Klemperer will resume his leadership of the Philharmonic-Symphony Thursday evening. His program for this concert, which will be repeated on Friday afternoon and Saturday evening, will consist of Handel's Water Music Suite; Alban Berg's suite from the opera "Lulu" with Agnes Davis as soprano soloist, and Brahms's Symphony No. 2 in D.

The first of the Thanksgiving turkey shoots was held at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The usual weekly program was decided, with birds offered as prizes in all events. In the scratch shoot, J.H. Wantling had the first pick with a card of 96 out of a possible 100 targets. T.H. Lawrence, S.B. Masten, P. Garino and J.J. VanGonsic also won turkeys.

ORANGE, Va., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Navarino, owned and ridden by Noel Laing, captured the Madison Plate at the annual Montpelier Hunt Club's races today at Montpelier, Mrs. Dupont Somerville's estate near here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Harvard University gave $715,010.91 financial aid last year to students in the college and the twelve graduate schools, according to figures made public here tonight. There were 7,729 students in the university, the average distribution thus having been slightly more than $92.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Bringing to a climax a long fight between industrial and craft unionism within the ranks of the American Federation of Labor, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, resigned today as vice-president of the federation.

SCHOLARSHIPS in New York University's graduate department of fine arts have been awarded to twenty-six staff members of museums and other organizations in the field of fine arts, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Presenting a powerful Attack featured by highly efficient ground work, the undefeated New Rochelle eleven downed A.B. Davis High School of Mount Vernon, 19 to 13, before 10,000 persons at Senior High Field today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The vote-getting power of the Townsend old-age pension plan, shown in the primary election held this week in the Third Michigan Congressional District, is being carefully analyzed by leaders of both parties. Its surprising strength in this conservative district convinced the political leaders that it must be reckoned with.

HOWARD CHANDLER CHRISTY last week enlivened the local art scene with his first one-man show in years. It is a large affair, imposingly installed in the marble and velvet Fifth Avenue palace of the Grand Central Galleries.

Elimination of the Canadian duty on American periodicals led magazine publishers last week to hope for a return of the huge sales volume which they enjoyed prior to the tariff which has just been abrogated. In the last full year before the Canadian tax on magazines was imposed in 1931 American publishers sent a total of about 48,000,000 copies into Canada, which this year has dwindled to only a fraction of that amount.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Yale won an aerial duel from Harvard today with forward passes supplying either direct or indirect momentum to each of the three touchdowns. A bitterly fought first half was productive of no points whatsoever, all three tallies coming in the last two quarters.

THROUGHOUT the country Scout troops are indebted for meeting places, leadership, encouragement, opportunities to go to Summer camp and sponsorship in other activities to various community groups -- schools, churches, American Legion posts, parent-teachers associations and service clubs.

ANDREW CARNEGIE'S birthday centennial will be observed tomorrow night in the hall named after him. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the Oratorio Society will join in a program that will commemorate not only the anniversary of Carnegie's birth but the opening of Carnegie Hall in an elaborate festival May 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9, 1891.

THAT preoccupation with the beach, toiling fishermen, long flat surfaces leading out to infinity, and a far horizon which scarcely demarcates sea and sky still remains the dominant note in the paintings of the Russo-French painter Leonid.

Steps taken in New York City and throughout the country to expand the scope of education through the use of films, art objects and new methods of evaluating a student's work were among the topics considered yesterday by discussion groups at the final sessions of the regional conference of the Progressive Education Association.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Robert E. Clements, the co-founder and national secretary of the Townsend old age pension plan, was caught in transit through Chicago on the day the newspapers reported the Townsend candidate's victory in a Battle Creek Republican primary.

THE vast chaparral regions of Texas and Northern Mexico may soon yield a rich commercial harvest if capital is found to carry out the recommendations of a survey, made recently for the Texas Planning Board, of the possibilities that lie dormant in these millions of waste acres bordering the Rio Grande.

Go near any munitions factory today and you will notice great activity. Huge chimneys belch towering columns of smoke; from inside the plant comes a ceaseless hum; machines pounding, lathes whirling as skilled workmen, many of them unemployed a short time ago, now busily manufacture instruments of destruction.

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- The French Parliament will begin next Thursday its Autumn session, which is supposed to be given over to the business of passing next year's budget. But, as is unfortunately usual or nearly so, the prospects of political quiet while attention is being given to the serious business of finance are far from promising.

CANBERRA, Nov. 22. -- Australia's interest in the Pacific was quickened by the announcement of the Pan American Airways agreement with New Zealand and also by the proclamation of the independence of the Philippines.

DETROIT. IF automotive circles the trade agreement recently completed with Canada has aroused considerable interest and will continue to furnish a topic for discussion until the results can he gauged more definitely.

We stood in a road in the centre of the 900-acre tract near Clinton that was purchased a year ago by the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission for a public hunting grounds. The property is rented to a tenant farmer.

PHILADELPHIA. -- The prospect of having hot dogs and soda pop sold in Valley Forge Park has set Pennsylvania patriotic societies agog. Many of their spokesmen profess to see in it a "Democratic plot" to "desecrate" a historic shrine with a "political money-raising scheme."

MR. GINSBERG, who is Professor of Sociology in the University of London, essayed a difficult task when he undertook to present his specialty in one of the small, compact volumes of the Home University Library. For their limits are not elastic and sociology is a science so new that there is still a lack of certainty and order as to some of its boundaries and content.

MR. BAKER'S fifth volume, covering approximately the fifteen months immediately following the outbreak of the World War, deals with a phase of Wilson's career which, more than any other, must be turned to for an understanding of his character, his intellectual processes, and his ability and methods as a politician and statesman.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 23 (AP). -- On the field where Red Grange first galloped to fame ten years ago Captain Jay Berwanger of Chicago climaxed his amazing football career today with a personal victory over Illinois in the final game of the season. The score was 7 to 6.

CHICAGO. -- As a step in the program to replenish the shelves of the Chicago Public Library, Chief Librarian Carl B. Roden has placed an order for 62,000 new volumes, which will cost $63,256. Within the next few months the library expects to have 175,000 new hooks on its shelves, he said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Bonding difficulties involving the construction of the Majestic Apartments, Central Park West, New York, and high-pressure salesmanship orders to salesmen of S.W. Straus Co. in an effort to speed up the sale of Majestic securities were a feature of today's investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the Straus Company, now in receivership.

Just three hours after the first of the three murders in this book has been reported to the police, Lieutenant Peter Quint arrests the murderer. Five minutes more suffice for Quint's explanation of how he solved the mystery of three almost identical murders.

IT is Kent Murdock, news photographer on a Boston newspaper, who supplies the pictures that go with the murders in this story of men and women most of whose morals are conspicuous by their absence. Murdock does not pretend to be a detective.

"Planned transportation" is the solution to the railroad problem, according to T.W. Van Metre, Professor of Transportation at Columbia University. Professor Van Metre holds that the railroads will be in "a bad way" if duplication of service and concomitant waste is not reduced.

BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- It is estimated now that the total fines placed on Catholic charitable and monastic orders on the basis of exchange smuggling charges total about 5,000,000 marks. About 10 per cent of the German orders have been affected directly and, in all, one-third of the orders will feel the financial effects of these fines, directly or indirectly.

Andre Stegfried, French political scientist and author, will give three lectures on French political life and politics at the New School for Social Research, beginning Dec. 2 at 5 P.M. The lectures will be devoted to a discussion of the psychological and social basis of French political life and politics, the outlook for the formation of political parties and recent developments in French political life.

ONLY three new films are bound for the Broadway sector this week. That, at least, is the forecast at present, although a few additional candidates will probably slip quietly into town and bolster the schedule. These are the Thanksgiving Day arrivals:

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Hager gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of their marriage. Their guests were: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Dauphinot, Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion, Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Von Elm, Mr. and Mrs. John Kienle, Mr. and Mrs. Steward Wagner and Mr. and Mrs. James E. Power.

WORKING in secrecy, engineers of the Radio Corporation of America and National Broadcasting Company are reported to be dismantling the old television equipment atop the Empire State Building preparatory to installing modern apparatus.
ATHENS, Nov. 22. -- When King George II arrives here Sunday to resume his throne he will find multifold troubles awaiting him.

FALL planting need not end with the first frost. In fact this period really marks the beginning of one of the best seasons for setting out a class of plants that is quite as important to the property owner as his lawns and shrubbery -- the deciduous shade trees.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The wheat market showed a strong undertone in North American markets today. While selling attributed to New York operators caused an early dip, the offerings were readily absorbed and the market started upward later in sympathy with strength in the Northwest and Southwest.

It is related that during the war a number of British and American newspaper photographers were given authority to "shoot" General Foch in his room at the Ministry of War. The news photographers found no maps upon the wails. Foch explained that he did not keep maps on the walls of his room but in the cartographer's department upstairs.

LITURGICAL Arts (second quarter, 1935) contains the following articles "Aestheticism and the Liturgy," by the Rev. Gerald B. Phelan; "St. Patrick's Church, Racine, Wis.," by Maurice Lavanoux; "The Great Altar-Piece of Veit Stoss (Wit Stwosz) at Krakow," by Earl Morse Wilbur; "The Liturgical Directions of St. Charles Borromeo," by the Rev. Michael Andrew Chapman -- these in addition to the editorials and special departments.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 23. -- Premier Andrew Tocheff today tendered his resignation to King Boris who accepted it, after which he entrusted to the outgoing Foreign Minister Kiosseivanoff the task of forming a new government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Asserting the Northwest was "up in arms" over the lumber tariff reduction in the Canadian-American trade treaty, Senator McNary of Oregon, the Republican leader, arrived today to file a protest at the White House and State Department.

RETAIL trade quickened in the week under the influence of more favorable weather in different sections of the country. Where the warm spell persisted consumer buying, started on holiday gift merchandise, was fairly well maintained on home furnishings but lagged in the apparel departments.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 23. -- Duke University won the Southern Conference championship and gained the top rung on the State football ladder today when Ace Parker, stellar Blue Devil back, raced 40 yards to score against North Carolina State College and the Dukes threw forward a stonewall defense to stop the Wolfpack twice on the 5-yard line.

The Scott Paper Company has declared a stock dividend of 50 per cent on the common stock, and an extra dividend of 20 cents a share in cash in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share in cash.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 23. -- Stanford's mighty football men today shattered the championship dreams of the greatest University of California team in years and probably clinched the Rose Bowl bid by conquering the Golden Bears, 13 to 0.

Arrangements are being completed for the second annual retriever trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association, which will be conducted on Saturday and Sunday, Dec. 7 and 8. The meeting will be held on the estate of Charles L. Lawrance in East Islip, L.I.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Staging a last-ditch rally in the final quarter, during which the elusive Tony Di Yeso tallied twice, the White Plains eleven, defending champions, defeated Yonkers Central, 20 -- 18, today at Parker Stadium in their final Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association contest.

LIFE being a grave and serious pursuit, Billy Rose has supplied the antidote of a circus. "Jumbo" is a whirligig of circus acts. To give it the proper splendor of theatre showmanship, Albert Johnson has transformed the old Hippodrome into an inviting amphitheatre of blue, red and gold, with steeply rising banks of seats and an idealized atmosphere of innocent festivity.

ATHENS, Nov. 23. -- Great disappointment was evident in Athens when it was announced that King George's departure from Brindisi was postponed. The city was filled with all kinds of rumors until a cable was received from the admiral commanding the flagship that storms raging over the Adriatic delayed the departure of the King and the Greek warships.

In Squadron A Armory, at Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, next Tuesday morning the forty-first annual Old Glory sale of light-harness horses will get under way, to continue through Thursday afternoon. There will be two sessions each day, starting promptly at 10:30 A.M. and continuing in the afternoon until the last of the number allotted for the day is disposed of.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Bennett Y. Ryan, Harvard '37, son of a New York magazine publisher, was found guilty in a municipal court today of assault and battery on Frank Foster, 67-year-old janitor of Dunster House, Harvard dormitory.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 23. -- Bishop Mathieu of Aire and Dax, France, in a lecture given in Brussels this week under the auspices of the Cardinal Mercier Lecture Association and in the presence of Cardinal Archbishop Van Roey and Premier Paul Zeeland, bitterly attacked certain tendencies in American films.

ACCORDING to a survey made recently by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, safety glass windshields are being offered now as standard equipment on practically all makes of cars. Safety glass in windows is being included in regular equipment by four out of five manufacturers, as compared with one out of two last year.

MUNICIPAL pride, if nothing else, should cause G. Stanley Cochrane and Potsy Clark to send sharp notes to the stout Jack Adams, who manages and coaches the Detroit Red Wings of the hockey circuit. He isn't doing right by their fair city.

The quota of the women's committee in the United Hospital campaign to raise $2,000,000 has been set at $800,000, it was announced last night by Mrs. William Woodward, the chairman. The group leaders and team captains will report the progress of more than 1,300 women workers at a meeting Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. at the Hotel St. Regis.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Antiques and Indian relics bearing upon the history of Westchester County will be exhibited at the County Centre from Dec. 3 to 7 in connection with the second annual Southern New York and Connecticut Antiques Exposition.

The sale of the Cortlandt F. Bishop art collection was completed yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, realizing a total of $276,145. The lots sold at the final session brought $77,332.50.

WE are prone to think of "seasons" in the garden -- a season for this, that or the other thing to be done at a special time. The result is that often those things which can be done at any time never are accomplished.

Prices were steadied yesterday on the Cotton Exchange by a statement by the manager of the cotton pool that 600,000 bales of spot cotton would not be made available to the trade until after growers had marketed most of this year's crop.

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 23. -- Discussion in the Finnish, Swedish and German press about the possible refortifications of the Aland Archipelago as a consequence of the new strategical position of the Baltic region met with the most vigorous protests on the part of the population of the islands.

FROM overseas comes news of the book Mr. Eric Blom has compiled, of sayings by a great many people upon the subject of music. This volume should amuse, instruct and entertain. Aphorisms coined by minds as far apart as those of Euripides and H.G. Wells adorn its pages.

An important, perhaps even a decisive issue in next year's Presidential campaign will be that which spokesmen for the Roosevelt administration describe as "agricultural parity," "a balanced agriculture" or "the ever-normal granary" and which Republican critics describe as "the economy of scarcity," or, in Mr. Hoover's recent phrase, "the more abundant life -- without bacon."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The Army Air Corps, prescribed by the 1925 Morrow Board to become "second to none" within five years, has not obtained one combat plane for sixteen months and fewer than 250 "serviceable" and modern craft will be assembled Dec. 1 along the Florida coast for the first mass manoeuvres of the General Headquarters Air Force.

MINEOLA. L.I., Nov. 23. -- After deliberating more than six hours, a jury in the county court here at the trial of Patrolman Joseph M. Dampf of the Nassau County police force, for extortion, reported to County Judge Cortland A. Johnson at 3:20 A.M. today that it was unable to agree.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Texas Christian University let loose amazing aerial and ground formations today to smother Rice Institute, 27 to 6, and remain one of the few unbeaten teams in the country.

PARIS, Oct. 30. WE have had a whole sheaf of new plays in the last fortnight, and among them are several which have been warmly praised by the critics, and several others -- not always the same -- which show signs of establishing themselves with the public.

THE new system of applying fines for parking violations, to be put in effect in this city soon, is expected to simplify the process of paying the penalties, saving time and trouble to the majority of parkers who only infrequently break the parking rules.
ROSEBORO, N.C., Nov. 23 (AP). -- A year ago a young aviator walked into a Winston-Salem newspaper office late at night, slung his hat on a chair, sat down to a typewriter and began:
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The Bonnie Briar Country Club here will be the scene on Thanksgiving eve of a barn dance.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Federal Judge John D. Martin held today that a newspaper is "quasi priviledged" in quoting police officers in the investigation of a crime, in an opinion dismissing a $15,000 libel suit brought against The Memphis Commercial Appeal.

Mrs. Christian R. Holmes will give a tea on Tuesday at her home, 1,107 Fifth Avenue, for members of the Sustaining Membership Committee of the National Music League who are aiding actively in the sale of boxes and seats for a recital by Mme. Kirsten Flagstad of the Metropolitan Opera the night of Dec. 11 at Carnegie Hall.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Although disappointment was written in the face of every member of the Dartmouth squad as the men walked back to their dressing room after the defeat at the hands of Princeton today, the coach of the Green, Earl Blaik, formerly of West Point, took matters philosophically.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- In the presence of high officials of the government, diplomatic representatives of twenty-three foreign countries and delegates from more than 200 colleges and universities, the Rev. Dr. Arthur O'Leary, S.J., was inaugurated tonight as president of Georgetown University, succeeding the Rev. Dr. Coleman Nevils, S.J., now rector of St. Ignatius Church in New York City.

Eighteenth and early nineteenth century American and English furniture and decorations, together with early American and Georgian silver, paintings, engravings, Oriental rugs, porcelains, and early American glass, will be offered for sale at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 23. -- The youth concert audience which filled the Rivoli Theatre here this morning was composed almost entirely of music lovers less than 18 years old. This is the first of a series of four youth concerts, arranged by the Nassau Philharmonic Society this season.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 23. -- Halting a 65-yard advance by the Nittany Lions in the closing moments of the game, Bucknell won its sixth straight game over Penn State, 2 to 0, today. A crowd of 8,500 shivering fans sat in the cold to witness the twenty-fourth meeting of the teams.

IT is in the nature of hunting never to be entirely satisfied with what you have got; far away bigger game beckons. Hence the unfulfilled wish of many a humble duck and rabbit gunner for a hunt in Africa. Or, if not Africa, possibly Northwest Canada, the Yukon and Alaska. But even these sections prove inconveniently far from home.

In his earlier book, "The Deadly Dowager," Mr. Greenwood presented a murder story that was deliriously funny. "The Fair Devil" is not like that. It has its moments of comedy, it is true, but they are soon forgotten in the contemplation of the unbelievable depravity of the woman whose character is clearly indicated in the title.

TO the modern grandeurs of ancient Rome Premier Benito Mussolini has added another, the new University City, which brings into one grouping the hitherto scattered activities of the University of Rome. One-seventh of the forty-acre site is occupied by buildings; the remainder by courts, avenues, gardens and sports fields.

HAVANA. -- Personalities, not issues, will be the deciding factors in the Cuban general elections set for Dec. 15. On that date the thirty-three-year old republic will elect a President from among various candidates for the first time in eleven years.

THE LOW-DOWN: Before a gathering of couples he had bound in wedlock, the Rev. Ivan H. Hagedorn, pastor of the Bethel (Pa.) Lutheran Church, answered last week his own question: What's the trouble with men and women in modern marriage?

Continued improvement in business conditions is assured through the Winter months, in the opinion of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, which made public its appraisal of November business yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23. -- Convincing proof that business is on the rise on the Pacific Coast came from a number of sources during the Past week. The earnings report of the Emporium-Capwell Company, among the largest of the department stores here, shows net profit of over $200,000 for nine months, against a loss of $33,000 for the first six months.

JAPAN'S conviction of "manifest destiny" was thus rationalized in a pamphlet recently published by the army: "When the Mediterranean was the centre of civilization the world's leaders were Greece and Rome. The scene shifted to the Atlantic and England became the leader.

Promulgation of the Canadian reciprocal trade agreement last week has served to consolidate opposition to the administration's entire reciprocal trade program, a check among foreign traders and domestic interests revealed yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The Essex Club and the Montclair Athletic Club emerged winners in the opening day's play of the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets League today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The consumer is the subject of increasing governmental attention. His problems are being studied by fourteen Federal bureaus. Paramount is the problem of the rising cost of living.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP). -- It is thirty-two years since President Roosevelt was an editor of the Harvard Crimson, but the editors of The Yale News appropriated a celebrated coup of his today.

EXCEPT for its sharpness of observation and its delicate humor, there is little to connect the author of "National Velvet" with this informal diary, written when Miss Bagnold was 19. For reasons which now seem incomprehensible, the publication of "A Diary Without Dates" produced a flurry in wartime England and caused Miss Bagnold's dismissal from the military hospital where she was working as a V.A.D.

The Giants, though still shrouding in deep mystery that big deal with the Cardinals which is not to be announced until Dec. 10, relented yesterday sufficiently to let a palpitating public in on at least two other player transactions which Manager Bill Terry has just completed.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Nov. 23. -- Nova Herculis -- the star that rose from oblivion to the season's celestial sensation last Winter -- burst forth today with the most direct evidence yet discovered in support of the theory that the universe is exploding.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Six Rutgers University fraternities held dances and house parties tonight.

Observance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Ruskin Club of Elizabeth, N.J., will be a luncheon meeting tomorrow at the home of Mrs. A.A. Baekey at 822 Colonia Road. All former members of the organization have been invited to participate in the silver jubilee.
DRAWINGS occupy a fairly prominent niche in the current exhibition panorama. Of freshly opened shows in which they play an important role -- or, indeed, encounter no opposition -- there are several.

THE announcement last week that the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing has become the Department of Nursing in the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons marks a significant advance in nurse training.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23. -- Of the seven Presidents from Roosevelt to Roosevelt, Calvin Coolidge is described as the "greatest kidder of them all" by Richard L. Jervis, former chief of Secret Service detail at the White House.

BEHIND the temporary order of the Bureau of Air Commerce barring "intentional" use of the airways and airports of the Federal system in bad weather by other than airline planes, which caused protests from airmen recently and led to a long conference in Washington among all parties at interest, lies a good deal that does not meet the casual eye.

LINDEN, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Andrew Thur of Linden was killed tonight when he was struck by an automobile on State Route No. 25 near the Seven Gables Inn here. The car is alleged to have been operated by Kenneth Thomas of 257 Maple Avenue, Rahway, N.J. He was arrested on a charge of "reckless driving resulting in death."

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The first large-scale revolt against the rising trend of steel prices behind the National Government's new tariff wall has been organized by a group of automobile interests headed by Sir Herbert Austin, an automobile manufacturer.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Little Bobby Wilson desperately pumped magic from his hands and nimble feet today and Southern Methodist's undefeated Sky Raiders rolled on with a 10-0 triumph over Baylor's stubborn Bears.

ABOARD THE WYATT EARP, Dundee Island, Weddell Sea, Antarctica, Nov. 23. -- Lincoln Ellsworth and the airplane Polar Star, with Herbert Hollick-Kenyon as pilot, are somewhere over the Antarctic Continent but out of touch with Ellsworth's base here.

FOLK ART generally has a directness of purpose and a lack of self-consciousness which the professional designer of today might well envy. American furniture of the early Pilgrim or Puritan settlements tended toward an uncompromising simplicity, and even more austere was the work of the Shakers.

GENEVA, Nov. 23 (AP). -- Italy announced her refusal today to attend an international maritime conference opening Monday under auspices of the International Labor Office. Observers in Geneva attributed the action to Italy's resentment over sanctions and said it indicated she would not attend meetings here as long as an economic siege is in force against her.

TORONTO, Nov. 23. -- Ontario's thirty-six producing gold mines set a new high monthly production record in the history of the Province in October, when bullion production was valued at $6,702,129, compared with $6,187,556 in September and $6,643,130 in June of this year, the previous record month.

With two of their injured players back on the available list, the New York Rangers will be seeking their first home triumph of the National Hockey League season tonight, when they oppose the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

Welcoming a chance to disport on their home turf after an absence of three weeks, the New York Giants will resume their drive to remain at the top of the Eastern Division of the National Football League this afternoon at the Polo Grounds, where they will face the Philadelphia Eagles, starting at 2:15 P.M. This will be Elks Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- A nation-wide organization to cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission in working out regulations for over-the-counter transactions and other investment problems was completed today by the Investment Bankers' Conference Committee of which B. Howell Griswold is chairman and Frank L. Scheffey is director.

As he talked last week to a visitor in his office in the Palazzo Venezia (a building made cold by League of Nations sanctions), Premier Mussolini sipped hot milk. His visitor was Anne O'Hare McCormick of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Here is Mrs. McCormick's picture of the man who, single-handed, has presented the world with its most dangerous crisis since the great war:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Turkeys will cost more money this Thanksgiving. The crop is the smallest in eight years, and there are enough consumers with better buying power to bid up the price. Government economists say so.

MANILA, Nov. 23. -- After Manuel Quezon's first week as President of the Commonwealth it is increasingly clear that the Philippines are moving rapidly toward a "one-man government." The majority caucus this afternoon chose Gil Montilla as Speaker of the Assembly rather than Quintin Paredes, the previous Speaker, who had declared for strong legislative leadership, or Manuel Roxas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Present and prospective increases in population are important factors in the economic recovery now under way, say government economists. Already there are 5,000,000 more persons to feed, clothe, house, educate and entertain than at the beginning of the depression.

IN his collections of short stories, such as "A Sage of the Sea," "A Saga of the Sword," "The Red Flag," , Mr. Austin invariably used an integrating theme; but none of these works can be regarded as in any way foreshadowing his latest, more ambitious launching out into this full-grown novel.

More than 500 members of the Foreign Policy Association, attending a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor, heard Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, and Felix Morley, editor of The Washington Post, discuss the position the United States should take to maintain world peace in times of foreign wars.

Donald R. Lash, compactly built Indiana University junior, captured the senior national A.A.U. cross-country title for the second successive year yesterday, coming home at the head of a crack field of sixty harriers who braved wintry blasts and snow flurries to compete in the thirty-ninth annual classic over the beaten trails of Van Cortlandt Park.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- A wet but happy group of Princeton football players gathered in the University Field House after their victory over Dartmouth today, slapping each other on the back and listening to the congratulations of Head Coach Fritz Crisler as they dressed.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 23 (AP). -- An Ethiopian attempt to invade Italian-occupied territory was repulsed today. Italian officers expressed the belief there were many enemy losses.

IN a recent film plants were pictured which were said to devour small animals and reptiles. While most plant fanciers have no ardent desire to own such monsters, one is reminded that there are varieties of plants, somewhat akin to those in question, although of less ferocious tastes, which repay cultivation with both beauty and novelty.

THE music of Ludwig von Beethoven and Maurice Ravel will make up the 200th broadcast by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony over WABC's network on Dec. 1 from 3 to 5 o'clock. In a nation-wide poll among the Sunday afternoon radio audience these two composers ranked high as favorites, although Jan Sibelius, Finnish composer, topped them in the voting by a slight margin.

"A bunch of bums and loafers; they don't want to work." I heard the remark made by a man standing at the curb on Twenty-third Street as he watched a gang of WPA men tearing up the tracks on Fourth Avenue. To be sure, they were not working hard, they couldn't, whether they wanted to or not.

TORONTO, Nov. 23. -- While the heads of many branches of Canadian industry are still unwilling to commit themselves as to the possible effects of the Canada-United States trade pact, the prevailing opinion seems to be that Canadian industries are apt to lose, directly; but that, through increased purchasing power on the part of Canadian farmers, they stand a good chance to offset the direct loss, if not actually improve their position.

THE Mark Twain Centennial speechmaking or memorial committees aren't going to listen to the likes of me, although Cyril Clemens, president of the International Mark Twain Society, is a friend of mine and I won honorable mention for a theme entitled "Why We Should Revere Mark Twain" in the 4A grade at North School, Hannibal, Mo.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Paris bottiers are reviving bronze kid slippers of former dancing school days. They consider this the only tone that will harmonize equally well with the smart plum, prune, brown and wine tones. It is also lovely with green.

THAT small group of green mountains known as Tahiti, climbing upward out of the vast sweep of the blue Pacific 3,600 miles southwest of San Francisco, has inspired a quantity of literature out of all proportion to its geographical prominence.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, forecasting President Roosevelt's re-election next year, tonight gave as one of his reasons that "you cannot beat somebody with nobody -- and the Republican party has nobody."

Pushing across two touchdowns in the second quarter in quick succession, a hardy band of gridiron warriors from the New York Military Academy triumphed over an aggressive Admiral Farragut Naval Academy team yesterday at the Polo Grounds in the second edition of their annual "little army-navy" series.

WELL might the gaunt ebony-cane-bearing Sherlock Holmes himself have tried through his boundless ingenuity to extract from William Gillette a few of his impressions on the portrayal of the role of the famous detective on the air.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 23. -- Competitions for turkeys occupied the gunners at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The regular 16-yard shoot was to have been a registered event, but on account of the weather and the small field it was postponed until later in the season.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 23. -- Ohio State's Scarlet Tide rolled relentlessly over Michigan's hapless Wolverines, 38 to 0, today, clinching a share in the Western Conference football championship.

A CRUDE first novel in the hard-boiled manner, this story is concocted of murder, infidelity, greed and debauchery, pictured without sentiment or heroics, in a wide open, post-war copper mining town of the West. The young assistant foreman of the locality's richest mine, Mark Broderick, a copper king's only son, is slain while at work by the blade of a pick-hammer driven into his skull.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 23. -- Minnesota uncorked the fury of its unbeaten gridiron machine today to flatten Wisconsin, 33 to 7, for a share of the Western Conference title and clinch national recognition for the second consecutive year. About 45,000 persons saw the final game of the season.

With the partition it has dreaded since 1900 about to begin (the loss of five northern provinces has been postponed, but only postponed) China confronts the most serious threat to its national existence in modern times. The Chinese as a people may be as one in their resentment at the transfer of the five provinces to Japanese control, but for practical purposes of resistance they are not a nation.

Large copper cents used for the small coinage in this country more than a century ago aroused the keenest bidding at the sale of several fine coin collections held yesterday afternoon by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.
UNTIL now grousers have been reviled by all and sundry, but in Bulgaria people may not only grumble to their heart's content, but may take their complaints to an official whose duty it is to listen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- New York's Boulevard Gardens, with every one of its 958 apartments occupied and many applicants awaiting the first vacancies, is offered by PWA officials here as conclusive proof of a legitimate demand for modern, low-rent urban homes.
NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 23. -- A powerful Boston College eleven ran roughshod over Boston University today on Alumni Field in the annual game between the two teams, winnig, 25 -- 6.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 23. -- The unexpected showed no signs of happening on Taylor Field today and a gallant Lafayette eleven went down before Lehigh by the overwhelming count of 48 to 0 while a crowd of 12,000 shouted its almost complete approval.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Coach Dick Harlow of Harvard was one of the first to congratulate Ducky Pond and Kim Whitehead of Yale on their victory. Later, at the Dillon Field House, the Harvard mentor had the following to say:

BERLIN, Nov. 22. -- Any new manoeuvring in Memel or any development in the Chino-Japanese situation that might contain the germ of an entanglement for Russia seems, as if by reflex, to turn the eyes of the world toward Germany.

NANKING, Sunday, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek with the conclusion of the fifth Kuomintang Congress turned his attention today toward the North China crisis, having accomplished substantial moves in the direction of national unification.

APPEARANCE of the 1935 Christmas Seals has stimulated activity among philatelists, who thus have an opportunity to add to their collections of charity stamps and seals -- which may contain up to 3,200 varieties.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- In a bleak, wintry setting Dartmouth's championship hopes were buried under a canopy of falling snow today by one of the most powerful football teams turned loose on an Eastern gridiron in years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Pressing his campaign for a liberal Republican party, while letting his decision to enter the Presidential primaries depend upon "events," Senator Borah said today that he would make a series of political speeches over the radio beginning Dec. 7.

THE aquarium fad seems to be constantly growing in popularity and to have become a real and permanent interest among people of many sorts. All of them will find this cyclopedic book extremely helpful and interesting. It includes not only the aquarium of its title but also the garden pool and the terrarium, and its questions and answers are concerned with fresh, brackish and salt water toy fish.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- New England, which for a century has held that a high protective tariff is the first duty of a national administration, has discovered, somewhat to its own surprise, that it rather likes the new reciprocal trade agreement with Canada.

STRATEGICALLY spotted within a few hours of New York City, Philadelphia and Washington and equally available to the millions who live in the smaller places between, Atlantic City counts heavily for its patronage on the short four-day vacations made possible by holidays like Thanksgiving.

THE laws of duplicate contract bridge, which have been in preparation for eight months, will be published early next month. The delay in their release is due to the disagreement of the legislators as to whether or not honors should be scored in duplicate contests.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 23. -- West Virginia closed its home football schedule for 1935 with a 51-0 victory over Washington and Jefferson today. It was the largest score ever made against the Presidents by the Mountaineers.
A smokeless blaze threatening a rickety five-story tenement with a saloon on the first floor drew an imposing turnout of fire apparatus to Madison Square Garden shortly after 5 P.M. yesterday.

A true picture of present-day Germany could not help but stress the continuous struggle in progress, beneath an outwardly smooth surface, among the various groups and factions assembled in the National Socialist party, the sole political organization permitted in the Reich.

THIS is the story of the Mormon schism called Strangites and of their prophet king, the irrepressible James J. Strang. Written with clarity, wit and great charm, the book is surely one of the few rare best in its general field.

Aerial rum patrols thunder high above the Canadian border, soar over the Rio Grande. At sea, on dirty nights, unlighted rum craft slide past Coast Guard cutters that plunge and pitch in angry spume along 10,000 miles of coastline. Deep in the pine woods of New Jersey thousands of gallons of molasses mash bubble and boil in giant vats.

THE years after the World War saw the German theatre in a period of a great flowering. We had more great actors than at any other time. There were quite a number of prominent regisseurs, or directors, such as Reinhardt, Jessner, Engel, and so on, who competed sharply and interestingly with one another.

IN many communities parlor games, those amiable social pursuits of a group in a home, are experiencing a revival. Both types of parlor games -- those played with cards, a board, or a table, or other mechanical equipment, and those played without any special equipment according to spoken instructions from the leader of the group -- are gaining in popularity.

LONDON, Oct. 31. IT can hardly be doubted that Dodie Smith has once again achieved a popular play. "Call It a Day," which was presented by an accomplished cast at the Globe Theatre last night, lacks the irresistible sentimental appeal of "Autumn Crocus," but its sham realism and easy comedy may well be more generally palatable than the sham Ibsenism and easy comedy of "Touch Wood."

Thanksgiving morning will find 1,000 delegates and approximately as many visitors thronging the Hotel Cleveland at Cleveland for the opening session of the joint national convention of Hadassah and Junior Hadassah, the first in six years. It will be the twenty-first annual meeting of the senior and the twelfth assembly of the junior group.
HONOLULU, Nov. 23. -- The silver-winged China Clipper brought America's first Pacific air mail to Hawaii today into a harbor ringing with the cheers of a "melting pot" population.
A veteran Long Island University quintet routed Cooper Union, 56 -- 13, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night. It was the opening contest of the campaign for both teams.

MANY vivid, impressive interests strike the reader from Mrs. Woodward's pages, but the most impressive of them all is its honest, realistic, wholly sincere portrayal of child life, and of adult life as seen through childish eyes, on the lower East Side during the last decade of the nineteenth century.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 23. -- Concurrently with a renewal of the conflict between the government and elements opposed to socialistic education in various parts of the country, twenty-five persons have been arrested and held incommunicado in this capital.

Dean John T. Madden of the New York University School of Commerce declared yesterday that the capitalistic system was being undermined by the breakdown of international trade and that unless commerce between nations was restored there would inevitably be further disintegration.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 23. -- Another crisis and one that may prove to be as serious as the general textile strike of September, 1934, is rapidly approaching in the relations between Southern textile-mill owners and their employes.

With all branches of the drug industry confused by the recent court decisions dealing with the New York State fair-trade law, a nationwide movement got under way last week to seek support for national legislation which would lead to the strengthening of the rules to control resale prices through contracts, which are now in effect in several States.

The revision of Federal legislation enacted nineteen years ago will he sought by shipping men at the next Congress in an effort to place American ship lines on a par wish foreign lines in international freight conferences.

WINTER'S warning of cars that will not start, or of cars that start with difficulty and operate far below a reasonable standard of efficiency, already is sounding through the cold, crisp air of Autumn.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 23. -- To the last exciting split second 50,000 spectators, half frozen by the blasts of a wintry November afternoon, but glowing in admiration for one of the grandest squads of fighting men ever to wear the Gold and Blue, watched Notre Dame end its greatest season since the Rockne era today with a typical comeback that defeated Southern California, 20 to 13.

There has been a large subscription for the pre-opening performance of "Weep for the Virgins" tomorrow night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, which has been taken over by the Neighborhood Playhouse Associates to augment its scholarship fund. Proceeds will be used in aiding talented young persons to obtain training in all the theatre arts.

THE long-promised rebuilding of Newark Airport is to get under way. With $3,000,000 in Federal aid and nearly another million to be furnished by the city, the present inadequate field is to be enlarged and generally refurbished and the time is not far distant when this Eastern terminal, which in some respects is the busiest airport in the whole world, will have a physical development worthy of its importance.

Pending the issuance by Consolidated Gas Company of New York or other intrastate holding companies of an explanation of their reasons for determining not to register or to apply for exemption under the Public Utility Act of 1935, counsel conversant with the problem indicates that there is no absolute right of exemption in the act, although its terms seemingly would allow such corporations to be exempted.

Brooklyn detectives arrested five more men in a drive on loan sharks which began Wednesday with the arrest of six men. Two of yesterday's prisoners were charged with usury and the others with vagrancy.

THE School of Fine Arts of the American Academy in Rome has announced its annual competition for the Prix de Rome in composition. The award consists of a fellowship in musical composition with a stipend of $1,250 a year.

THE amazing gifts to education made by Andrew Carnegie, whose centenary is celebrated tomorrow, are usually thought of in three categories -- those for libraries, those for research and those for teachers' pensions. Yet in his lifetime the little, rubicund, bearded ironmaster handed out some $20,000,000 to individual American colleges, often in the course of personal visits.

CANTON, Nov. 23. -- The American delegation arrived at Hongkong on the President Jefferson yesterday morning and forty-one, including six Senators and seven Representatives, made the rail journey to Canton for their first view of the interior of China.

New York will join tomorrow with communities throughout the world in celebrating the 100th anniversary of the birth of Andrew Carnegie, born Nov. 25, 1835, at Dunfermline, Scotland. Observances, which are to continue throughout the week, will take place also in other parts of the United States, in Canada, Scotland, England, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand and in British insular possessions that have benefited from the widely spread Carnegie philanthropies.

What is described as a unique collection of objects connected with the history of religion since its beginning will be opened to public view Tuesday in the Low Memorial Library at Columbia University.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 23. -- President Roosevelt today handled a large bulk of routine work, including the signing of two official commissions, in early morning and late afternoon shifts so that he could enjoy out of doors an ideal, bracing Fall day.

One of the season's dual meet records was bettered, another equaled, at the sixth series of engagements for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school swimming championship of the P.S.A.L. in the De Witt Clinton twenty-five-yard pool yesterday.

Well-known members of the Players Committee of the New York Junior League will take part in the first of a series of weekly broadcasts for children next Wednesday afternoon over station WOR. The sketch to be presented is entitled "The Topaz Room," and was written and directed by Mrs. Winthrop C. Neilson Jr.

RADIO in Europe is bottled up and tightly corked as far as freedom of speech to America is concerned, according to Max Jordan, European director of the National Broadcasting Company now visiting in New York. America, he finds, might happily add a few words to "The Star-Spangled Banner," and along with "land of the free" sing of "air of the free."

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIP PER, Nov. 23. -- Flight units of the size of the China Clipper, twenty-five tons gross, function at the highest efficiency through the application of broad principles of marine operation routine. Throughout the night the navigation department has obtained seven celestial sights and received forty-one radio directive bearings.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- It was confirmed today that the League of National German Jews, a nationalist German organization which advocated the assimilation of Jews and urged an understanding of national socialism, was dissolved by the Secret State Police on the ground that its program violated National Socialist principles.
THE Angel whipped the bandage from O. Henry's eyes and zoomed upward out of Times Square, barely missing a jutting neon sign on the Claridge.

Although December cotton futures are at a premium of 40 points over May and 80 points over Next October, Harriss Vose, members of the New York Cotton Exchange, in their weekly letter state that this is not an unduly large premium, as spot cotton is at a premium above December contracts.

USUALLY to gain the distinction of occupying an entire thin volume of its own -- at a dollar per copy -- it would seem that a short story should be something more striking, permanent and substantial than the slight creation here in hand.

IT was not the lure of famous and fabulous Lhasa which drew Harrison Forman, American, into forbidden Tibet, but that of a mountain, practically unknown. Reported to be "higher than Everest," the "Mystery Mountain," Amniyi Machen, is somewhere in Northeastern Tibet, in the district of the Ngolok, fiercest of bandit tribesmen, ruled by a robber queen.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- The problem of whether Italy will continue as a member of the League of Nations is again being discussed here. The term "premature" was applied in official quarters today to reports that Italy would withdraw from the League if oil, iron and steel were added to the list of raw materials that may not be exported to Italy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23. -- Warm praise for Harvard's fine playing came from Ducky Pond, Yale coach, in the dressing room after the game today. "Harvard played inspired football," he said, "and I have nothing but commendation for them."

Dr. Adolph Lorenz, 81-year-old Viennese surgeon, who is noted for his "bloodless surgery," said on his arrival on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg yesterday that he had completed his autobiography and had named it "The Missing Glove."

Retail trade in the metropolitan area showed improvement last week, with executives reporting favorable development of early Christmas shopping. Department stores here had gains ranging up to 10 per cent for the period, but it was pointed out that the comparison was with an extremely warm week last year, when most stores had poor sales figures.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23. -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court will consider here Monday an issue which in the last few weeks has aroused freedom of the press committees of several associations of publishers and editors.

Some interesting remarks made recently at a banquet in London describing Queen Victoria's first ride in a train would, I feel sure, interest your readers, reflecting as they do the public opposition aroused by the introduction of the "steam horse."

WHATEVER sound literature exists in the Balkans deals with the soil and the people that dwell on it. The important authors, almost without exception, are those who, even though they may have been educated abroad and may have never followed the path of the plow, stay close to the oxen and fraternize with the donkeys.
GILEAD, Conn., Nov. 23. -- Once a prosperous community, Gay City -- Connecticut's ghost town -- is slowly returning to the forest from which it was hewn.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- Premier Benito Mussolini and the British Ambassador, Sir Eric Drummond, held another conference at the close of a day that saw Italian resistance to sanctions swell to new proportions. The conversation lasted for about twenty minutes.

The Greyjackets of the Seventhi Regiment, with the assistance ofI many young women, are now completing plans for their annual Fall Military Ball, which will take place on Dec. 7 in the regiment's armory tat Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 23. -- Indiana University's Fighting Hoosiers, scoring on an aerial thrust that gained 53 yards late in the third period, whipped Purdue, 7 to 0, in their annual football battle today.

CAMP ROOSEVELT, Ocala, Fla., Nov. 21. -- Etching a 195-mile canal diagonally across Florida's surface to connect the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, United States engineers are transforming most of the peninsula into an island and creating what is perhaps the most opulent single symbol of the New Deal.

WILFORD S. CONROW has brought out, in mimeograph form, his scholarly treatise on "The Pentagon Pose -- Feminine Symmetry," with which is combined a "Summary of the Ratios of Feminine Symmetry" by William Churchill, whose system of ratios Mr. Conrow has translated into decimals.

Mr. HOOVER'S mistake consisted in putting too many epigrams into his speech. There were more the a dozen, and naturally Mr. HOOVER'S critics seized upon the least successful in the lot. As a matter of fact, some of the aphorisms were very good.

PORTLAND, ORE. AS the first snow flurries strike the Western ranges homesteaders and ranchers oil their rifles, unleash their hounds and trail the beast which annually destroys scores of their sheep and calves.

WEST AUSTRALIAN wheat farmers recently asked the government to lend them machine guns to combat droves of emus that had invaded the wheat-growing areas. In one district alone between 500 and 1,000 of the ungainly looking birds arrived in a day, and they threaten even more damage than they accomplished three years ago, when they destroyed hundreds of acres of crops.
Since last Spring the stock market has been pushing upward; in the last month with especial speed. From March 13 to Nov. 13 the Federal Reserve Board's index of 421 stocks rose from 63.1 to 93.3.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov 23. -- Princeton's varsity and freshman soccer teams triumphed over visiting Pennsylvania booters today. The Tiger varsity staged a late drive to win by 3 -- 2 while the cub players downed the Red and Blue yearlings, 2 -- 0.

BERMUDA . . . Nassau . . . Havana . . . Port au Prince . . . Cartagena . . . Magic names! In them is the lure of romance, past and present. The very sound of them conjures vibrant colors, a burning sun, golden sands, waving palms, brown skins and flashing teeth, the tinkle of ice in tall glasses, lazy hours in a deck chair.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 23 (AP). -- The orange-shirted Plainsmen of Auburn, propelled by superb line play, crushed Georgia's red-shirted Bulldogs by 19 to 7 today before 15,000.

Two young men, whose names were recorded at the West Thirtieth Street police station as Ross Updegaff, 26 years old, of 19 Benedict Place, Greenwich, Conn., and Carl Smalaheer, 33, of the Greenwich Y.M.C.A., were injured about 8 P.M. last night in a fight before the Seventh Avenue entrance to the Pennsylvania Station.

The statement issued in Washington on Friday by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, indicating that the Federal Reserve authorities saw no occasion at this time for checking the rise in the stock market, was received yesterday in Wall Street with mixed feelings.

THE National Academy of Sciences held its midwinter session at the University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va., last week. As usual, the scientists swept over the vast universe and touched nearly everything. Brains and drugs, receding nebulae and centrifugal machines that not only defied but conquered gravity, psychology and the more recondite phases of organic chemistry -- all were illuminated by a small, bright, if not all-embracing, light.

The question whether the low point in the recent depression occurred in the middle of 1932 or in the late Spring of 1933 -- whether, in other words, the upturn really began in the one year or in the other -- is one of those matters of dispute that in history are frequent. If the different "indices of industrial activity" are used to test the question, contradictory evidence can often be produced.

Mrs. Robert C. Ream will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at her home, 770 Park Avenue, in behalf of the forthcoming performance of "The Eternal Road," a new play by Franz Werfel, the night of Dec. 26 at the Manhattan Opera House, which has been taken over by the directors of the New York Exchange for Women's Work, to raise funds for carrying on the philanthropic activities of that organization.

The last letter written by Father Damien, the Catholic priest who died a victim of leprosy at the leper colony of Molokai in the Hawaiian Islands after devoting his life to the service of the sick, has found its way to New York. This was learned just as news came that the body of the priest is to be brought to New York on a United States Army transport en route to his native Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The foreign trade program of the United States may be said to have reached a stage where it will have a definite effect on world economy. The cumulative effects of concessions granted and obtained under most-favored-nation conditions will soon begin to cause changes in trade relations of foreign countries with one another as well as with us.

At the final report luncheon of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies in the campaign to raise $650,000 toward the deficit, tomorrow, at the Hotel Commodore, Mayor La Guardia will address the 500 delegates.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Vastly superior in ground-gaining ability, an alert and smooth-functioning Colgate football squad, which scored in the first two minutes via a blocked punt, swept to a 27-to-0 victory over Rutgers in the face of a driving snowstorm on Neilson Field today.

THE British Navy is back in Alexandria harbor, and Egypt is again the core of the British Empire. An ominous forest of gray masts and funnels fills the western harbor of Alexandria, and incoming Italian steamers whose captains forget to dip their ensigns are stopped by British picket-boats and made to go outside and come in as they should.

Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., United States Minister to Norway, and three other former officers of the bankrupt Sonora Products Company were directed by Judge Robert P. Patterson in Federal Court yesterday to pay $2,098,755.49 to the Irving Trust Company.

With resentment against Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law steadily growing in practically all sections of the country, credit men, lawyers and others plan an intensive drive for elimination of the section at the next session of Congress and a broadening of Section 12 to carry out the aims of the corporate reorganization provision, it was learned here yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 22. -- It is much too soon to guess what the economic siege now beginning will do to the Italian people. The last six months have wrought great changes in the spirit of the country; the next six months may work another transformation.

UNFORGETABLE pictures of the snow on the White Mountains are carried away by all who go there to ski in Winter. This year, because of the work of the Civilian Conservation Corps, it is predicted that more people than ever before will remember the ranges with the snow on them.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A report tending to strengthen the belief held by some explorers that land exists northwest of Wrangel Island in the Arctic Ocean was delivered to the government today by a Soviet pilot, V.S. Molokoff.
