Miss Rebecca Shapiro, vocational guidance counselor of the Manhattan Industrial High School for Girls, presented a plea for understanding of the social and human values of job placement work yesterday morning at the Third Metropolitan Conference on Employment and Guidance Procedure at the Hotel Astor.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 23 (AP). -- Neither Iowa's wraith-like Negro, Oze Simmons, nor Northwestern's husky blond, Don Heap -- nor any one else for that matter -- could shake loose today and the Hawkeyes and Wildcats fought to a scoreless draw in a stirring Western Conference football final.

The Japanese Anemone, a Fall-blooming perennial, supplements the many kinds of anemones found growing in our gardens and in the woods. The opinion that no other variety can equal it for sheer loveliness of flower is widely held. When to the abundance of bloom put forth by a well-established plant is added its airy gracefulness no more need be said to recommend at least a trial of it.

A nation-wide home building program contemplating the construction of 8,000,000 low and moderate cost homes during the next ten years, with private capital doing 85 per cent of the job, has been submitted to President Roosevelt by the Committee of Economic Recovery, Inc.

IN reviewing A.P. Herbert's latest book, "What a Word!" (Methuen) -- a lively exposure of many current misuses of the English language -- Harold Nicolson applies to its author the remark that age cannot stale his infinite variety.

H.G. WELLS, novelist, historian, prophet and -- most recently -- script writer, will leave for Hollywood in a few days to continue his study of film-making. Plagued for interviews, he decided last week to kill all the birds with one stone and did it most effectively in a group interview arranged by United Artists and attended by about fifty newspaper men.

ANY cook knows that the average kitchenette is no place to prepare a large Thanksgiving dinner. New Yorkers tied to an apartment over the holiday need not give up the idea of having the traditional feast simply because they have not the facilities for cooking it.

ROME, Nov. 23. -- The United States considered making representations to Italy tonight because of a demonstration against two physicians and their wives in which American flags were torn from an automobile.
Mr. and Mrs. Otto Sampter will celebrate their sixtieth wedding anniversary today -- and with three-score years of marital happiness behind, they see ten -- "even twenty" -- more years ahead.

The election of Charles H.C. Pearsall as national president of the Propeller Club of the United States was announced yesterday. Mr. Pearsall succeeds Arthur M. Tode, who had directed the work of the club the last nine years. Mr. Tode has been designated honorary national president.
Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch, who died suddenly at his Bronx home Thursday evening, will be buried today with an impressive ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Bill Guckeyson, Maryland's back-field flash, tallied twice on long runs, to day, to give Maryland a 12-6 victory over Georgetown before a crowd of 9,000.

WHEN Vicky Gray lost her job as secretary in a business firm, she faced the depression bravely. She wouldn't take the easy course, which would have been to marry Jimmy because she didn't love him. She reluctantly sublet her beloved little apartment and put an ad in the paper for work as governess or companion.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22. -- Again the eyes of the world are turned eastward, with Japan's announcement that five of China's northern provinces, two of which hem in the Soviet Union's sister State of Outer Mongolia, are determined to separate from Nanking and form an autonomous independent government.

Earnings of white-collar workers in the retail stores of the Soviet Union are reported as rising steadily as the result of larger purchases by the masses of the people and a new system of payment provided for in a blanket agreement recently concluded between the "Glavtorg" (the State trading authority) and the Commercial Employes Union.

AT a moment when Europe is disturbed by the activities of dictators who have a wild look in their eyes and seem to move nations by a kind of magic, Britain has chosen the leadership of a man who is reassuringly normal -- one might almost say extraordinarily normal -- and quite lacks the hypnotic powers which sometimes are so effective, and so dangerous, in politics.

VISITORS who drop into the Imperial Theatre to see "Jubilee" will be surprised to find an entirely transformed Albertina Rasch evident in the dance arrangements. Nowhere during the whole evening is there to be seen a single group of those svelte duchesses who used to people her ensembles in the days before "The Great Waltz" and her Hollywood interlude.

THE jacket subtitles this book "Four Peculiar Stories and a Preface." Coming from Mr. Tarkington, peculiar and unexpected seem fitting adjectives to apply to these stories. He has ranged far afield from the juvenile humors of Little Orvie and Penrod, from the adolescent problems of Seventeen or Alice Adams.

THIS descriptive story of the Eskimo people of Northern Greenland is by the author of "Eskimo," which, turned over to the movies, was a screen success a few years ago, one in which the author appeared as an actor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Industrial output in the first half of November has resisted seasonal forces, with some industries showing further gains over October and others overcoming the usual tendency to decline, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly report on domestic business conditions.
Mayor La Guardia and Secretary Ickes traded punctuation-mark punches last week in one of the oddest public controversies those veteran public controvertists ever got into.

If there has been any maintenance of prices in the steel industry, it has been the maintenance of prices at too low a level, according to T.M. Girdler, chairman and president of the Republic Steel Corporation.

FROM now on until next May we are going to hear a great deal about book auctions in this country. Except for a brief interval around the holidays the major galleries have undertaken their heaviest schedule in years, and the market is now teeming with unprecedented activity.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors:

CAIRO, Nov. 22. -- It is generally admitted that Sir Samuel Hoare's Guildhall speech has aroused the Egyptians to such a pitch of wrath against the British Government that many fear a repetition of the trouble of 1919, when the Egyptians revolted against the British protectorate.

The Works Progress Administration for New York City will add 11,000 more persons to its quota, bringing the total for the city to 235,000, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, who explained that he had received authorization for the increase.
HONOLULU, Nov. 23. -- Mauna Loa continued in eruption today. Lava is pouring out Unabated at the source, 11,600 feet up the north slope of the volcano.

Federal regulation of the live poultry industry in New York City and Jersey City will become effective tomorrow. Beginning then, handlers of live poultry in these cities must have licenses from the Department of Agriculture. Thus far more than 400 applications have been filed at the Barge Office with the local headquarters of the Packers and Stockyards Division of the Department of Agriculture.

TWO or three years ago Mr. Holmes wrote "Abraham Lincoln Traveled This Way" and a good many persons enjoyed reading it, while some of them found it useful as a companionable guide along the same roads.

Thanksgiving turkeys are plentiful, but much higher than last year, it was reported yesterday by Mrs. Frances F. Gannon, Deputy Commissioner of Markets in charge of the Consumers Service Division, at the same time that chain stores announced that the average retail price would be 37 cents a pound.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 22. -- Cheered by the public enthusiasm over the arrival of the President and by the prospect that the greatest crowd ever assembled in the State will hear his address in the football stadium of Georgia Tech. next Friday, leaders of the Roosevelt wing of the Democratic party will resort to an unprecedented coup to break the grip of Governor Talmadge on the State political machinery.

THE world this week pays grateful tribute to the memory of Andrew Carnegie, born 100 years ago tomorrow -- Carnegie, who made one of the mightiest fortunes in history and then, while he lived, gave it away almost entirely.

IN "The Great White Gods" Mr. Stucken evinced a considerable talent for expanding a single historical incident into a living romance. He has now chosen a larger canvas to work on. "The Dissolute Years" is a panoramic study of the reign of James I of England, the first of the ill-fated Stuart dynasty.

ONE YEAR OFF: America's erstwhile infant prodigy of the violin is approaching his nineteenth birthday. Off and on, Yehudi Menuhin has been giving concerts as a soloist since the age of 7: critics agree that for several years he has ranked with the top virtuosi, regardless of age.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The complaint that the present-day college graduate emerges into an unfriendly world in which there is no place for her is disputed by Miss Fredericka Belknap, director of the personnel bureau at New Jersey College for Women, in her annual report to Dean Margaret T. Corwin, made public today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The new Middle West Corporation of Delaware, authorized to acquire all the properties of the Middle West Utilities Company, under the pending plan for reorganization of the former key holding company of the old Insull system, was licensed today to do business in Illinois.

It will sound very heretical, but in the interest of clear thinking I offer some observations regarding the Texas lynching not wholly in accordance with the general reaction. You say editorially that the county prosecutor and the county judge have "by their extraordinary language added their quota of disgrace to the whole affair," and most people will think so.

Called bonds last week were more numerous and embraced a wider selection of industries. Not only were definite calls larger, but there also was a sharp increase in proposed refundings, particularly in the public utility field. Bonds called for payment in November now total $217,684,000, compared with $370,101,000 in October, and $127,733,000 in November, 1934, for corresponding weeks.

Foreign exchanges were thrown into a maelstrom of wide price movements and feverish activity last week. The projecting forces were the advance in the French Bank rate to 5 per cent from 4, which followed apprehension over the continued drain of gold, and the crisis which developed in the Italian situation where a monopoly on gold was ordered, together with the seizure of funds of English banks.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 24. -Stanford's football team for the third consecutive year appeared today to be knocking at the Rose Bowl portals.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Nov. 24. -- Like a waterfront scene in the old days of sailing vessels, when clipper ships had to be loaded in a mad rush to enable them to sail with the tide, the marine runway of the Pan American Airways ocean air base at Pearl Harbor, Honolulu, was a busy scene early this morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- A few of the "public enemies" in Alcatraz, thwarted in crime, have turned to the higher life.

Until a few years ago "planning" was commonly used in a somewhat restricted sense. It was directed at the physical needs of a community, and embraced chiefly such factors as traffic, transportation, the distribution of population, and the location of industry, commerce, business, residence and recreation.

HONOLULU, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The China Clipper pressed on today with its transpacific air mail burden, leaving Honolulu at 6:35 A. M. [12:05 P.M. Eastern standard time] for Midway Islands. It carried twenty-one persons, the largest number ever to fly over the Pacific in an airplane.

Harvard will be three hundred years old next September. It is a respectable age, however infantine compared with that of Paris or Bologna. A dignified ceremonial worthy of the pieties of such a commemoration is to be expected; and on an anniversary of the Genial Mother's birthday she would be well pleased to see the children bring gifts back to the old home.

Competition in the fifth annual swimming tournament of the Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association started yesterday with St. Francis Prep, the defending titleholder, and Brooklyn Prep triumphing in their initial engagements.
LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The British and the French Governments reached an agreement today to urge postponement of the discussion of an oil embargo against Italy.

Traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's system increased by 215,015 passengers, or 0.23 per cent, during October, as compared with the same month in 1934, according to a report submitted to Federal Judge Julian W. Mack by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, and made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Standardization of airplane procurement methods for the army, navy, Coast Guard and Bureau of Air Commerce, leaving to each branch control over only the technical details peculiar to its service, is under serious consideration.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP). -- With Bill Karr on the receiving end of three touchdown passes, the Chicago Bears battled the Detroit Lions to a 20-20 tie on Wrigley Field today after the visitors had taken the lead three times in a National Football League encounter.

Twoscore exhibitions on the local calendar, opening today or tomorrow or already opened over the week-end, attest that the local field has no fear of holiday weeks. The attractions include old masters and modern Bulgarian art, several exhibitions of sculpture, painting from the American Midwest and bronzes from Africa, objects of art from the Far East and etchings by our own craftsmen.

In extending by a year the term of ROBERT LINCOLN O'BRIEN, Chairman of the Tariff Commission, President ROOSEVELT has recognized a man who has been doing real public service. Appointed originally as a Republican, Mr. O'BRIEN never surrendered his convictions about tariff taxation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Sentiment in the world's wheat market is regarded as in favor of higher prices based on the broader demand for cash wheat and the lack of selling pressure from holders who have accumulated stocks in expectation of the demand improving as the season advances.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- Following a meeting between Premier Pierre Laval and the British Ambassador, Sir George Clerk, here today it is understood it has been agreed that the meeting of the sanctions coordination committee scheduled for Friday at Geneva should be postponed.

When the Boston Bruins come to town to play the New York Rangers local fans are generally sure of a ??eming hockey battle, a rousing exhibition of fist swinging, or both. Last night at Madison Square Garden the Bruins gave a crowd of 14,000 the whole program before they bowed to Lester Patrick's warriors by the count of 1 to 0.

" Mickey Montefiore," a solid black female cat kept by the Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx for the amusement of patients in the children's ward, won a silver cup as best cat in the show yesterday at the close of the sixth annual Poultry, Pigeon, Pet and Tropical Fish Show in Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- Premier Pierre Laval's government of "national union," which was formed last June and received power to act by decree for "defense of the franc," is not expected, at least by its opponents, to survive this coming week.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24. -- Over a snow-covered steppe in below zero weather, 200 Soviet writers made a solemn 100-mile pilgrimage to Yasnaya Polyana yesterday to the grave of Leo Tolstoy, Russia's great novelist, mystic and pacifist.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 24. -- While there is still no concerted Ethiopian offensive on either front, it is increasingly apparent that Emperor Haile Selassie has given orders to stiffen resistance and make every foot of Italian gains as costly as possible in life and equipment.

Mrs. Tesla C. Nicola, whose husband is a physician attached to the Seventh Day Adventist mission at Addis Ababa and personal surgeon to Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, arrived yesterday via Hamburg on the liner President Roosevelt with her three children.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 24. -- Gabredarre, just north of Gorahai, which was originally abandoned in panic, is semi-officially reported to have been retaken by Fitaurari Shefara's soldiers.

From the first, the debate about commodities that might be considered "implements of war" has been specific. The articles always mentioned were copper and cotton, oil and scrap-iron, steel and tractors. Little by little the State Department has taken up one after the other.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- A nationwide campaign seeking to reduce automobile accidents at least 35 per cent by 1941, thus preserving 38,000 lives, was announced tonight by the National Safety Council. The five-year drive will open Jan. 1.
You referred in an editorial to the war neurosis now prevalent in Italy, but since the nature of this fearful disease is so little understood, a brief analysis of it may not be out of place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -State Department officials received with an interest approaching real concern today reports that an autonomous government had been proclaimed in Eastern Hopei Province in North China.

Next to God, the love of friends in and out of the church whom he had served had made possible his "long and happy career" in the metropolis, the Rev. Dr. A. H. Evans declared in a sermon yesterday morning in the West Park Presbyterian Church.

The principal development in the cotton futures market last week, from the standpoint of prices, was a further widening of discounts on the most distant deliveries. On the New York Cotton Exchange, deliveries from January to March showed little net changes, but the later deliveries recorded declines ranging up to 18 points on the October position.

Tentative plans for the formal dedication on Saturday of the Will Rogers-Wiley Post Memorial Airway Beacon on the George Washington Bridge have been completed, it was announced yesterday by State Senator A. Spencer Feld, chairman of the New York State Aviation Commission.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Nov. 24. -The New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League opened today with the Racquets Club of Short Hills decisively defeating the Morristown Squash Club here, 4 -- 1.

The general improvement in business activity, noted during the past four months, continued through October and the first half of November, according to the regular monthly survey yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin charged today that the United States made a "semi-secret" pact with the League of Nations in 1933 to support sanctions.

There can be no lasting national recovery without a moral recovery, the responsibility for which lies with every man and woman in the United States, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Definite signs of recovery were hailed on three fronts in Washington today as representatives of capital and labor, as well as the government, viewed the record of the past few months and appraised the substance of the business upturn which has been sustained now for more than a year.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The Marquess of Londonderry's exclusion from the new Cabinet has been followed by the abandonment of a brilliant reception at Londonderry House usually held on the eve of every new session of Parliament.
A thin coating of ice on streets and sidewalks was blamed by police yesterday for auto accidents.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 24. -Winter dinghy sailors apparently are not the hardy mariners they used to be. With a snow-covered shore for the first time this season, only twenty-two ventured forth today in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- As expected, the report of the Bank of France on Nov. 15 disclosed a further recession in the gold reserve amounting to 933,000,000 francs and already it is regarded as certain that the next return on Nov. 22 will show an equal or even greater decrease.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (Monday). -Elmer Rice's experimental satirical comedy, "Not for Children," had its first performance on any stage tonight at the Fortune Theatre as the season's first offering of the Stage Society.

While some of the apparel departments experienced only a fair demand for merchandise last week, there was an active call in other divisions of the wholesale markets here for all types of holiday items for immediate delivery. Fur departments were busy and orders for formal apparel gained steadily.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 24. -- The Brazilian Government, it was officially announced tonight, has ordered troops, naval units and army planes rushed to the northeastern part of the country to suppress a revolt assertedly aided by Communists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- New rules defining what types of securities are suitable for investment of current funds of registered holding companies and their subsidiaries were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with a view to conserving investors' equities under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The stock markets here are beset by conflicting events, movements consequently being erratic. The good effect of the national government's success at the election quickly evaporated under the influence of renewed conflict between China and Japan, the disturbances in Egypt and the beginning of active sanctions against Italy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- Lower prices for lard futures here last week were due mainly to commission-house selling and an indifferent demand and to the irregular movement of hogs, which sold at lower prices. A decline in corn prices also was a factor affecting hog values at times.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- All indications point to a further intensification of the anti-Catholic drive now in progress throughout Germany. According to well-authenticated information current today, all grants of State funds to Catholic private schools are to be withdrawn, orders to this end having already been framed.
TIENTSIN, Monday, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Serious disturbances broke out in Tientsin today and autonomist agitators seized several municipal buildings.

William F. Peterson, 52-year-old securities dealer, indicted as the promoter of a "get-rich-quick" investment scheme involving more than $450,000, has been sought on a bench warrant unsuccessfully, it became known last night.

PARIS, Nov. 23. -- Gold which left France this week went to England and the United States. Some bullion also was shipped to Amsterdam because the Dutch exchange had risen above the gold-import point on repurchasing by bear sellers of the florin.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 24. -A reception and tea dance in honor of their daughters, the Misses Nancy and Nita Easley, will be given by Mr. and Mrs. George Albert Easley of Three Gables Farm, Loantaka Road, on Thursday afternoon at their estate.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 24. -Jap, an 8,219-pound 50-year-old elephant, rested quietly tonight with a bale of hay for companionship in a local garage after being upset -- literally and figuratively -- on the streets of East Orange.

A free-for-all fight which broke out when there was only a minute left to play climaxed the amateur hockey contest between the New York Rovers and the Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The movement of hogs here last week was materially larger than in the previous week, and that of cattle was smaller. Deliveries of all livestock except sheep were materially smaller than a year ago, hogs being decidedly under last year.

The optimistic analysis of business conditions throughout the country as contained in the November bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board follows a statement made on Friday in Washington by Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, to the effect that the recent rise in the prices of securities is healthful and that the Federal Reserve Board had not interfered because cash and not credit is being used to buy securities.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,945,998,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest bearing discount bills.

Possibly the governor of the Federal Reserve was not altogether wise in giving to the advance of stocks so public a blessing, and in assuring the public that the Reserve Board has no present intention of applying "brakes" such as higher margins or higher bank reserve requirements.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Although no additional official measures have been made necessary by the application of economic sanctions against Italy, the Reich Ministries of Economics and Foreign Affairs are watching developments closely from the points of view of Germany's commercial and diplomatic interests.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine contained an article by Howard Lee McBain in which were certain comments on the matter of American States Public Service Company in which case Judge William C. Coleman held that the Public Utility Act of 1935 was unconstitutional in its entirety.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 24. -- A general paring of the budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1936, to reduce the anticipated Federal deficit for that year to not more than $500,000,000, was strongly indicated today by Chairman Buchanan of the House Appropriations Committee on his arrival here for a series of conferences with President Roosevelt.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 24. -- The "forbidden lines" of the spectrum, something fantastic almost beyond belief, have appeared in Nova Herculis, the new star which blazed forth last December, like the Star of Bethlehem.

In the snow-swept horseshoe of Palmer Stadium and the sundrenched oval of Stanford University, football's lowering curtain fell upon the championship hopes of two more of the dwindling band of unbeaten and untied elevens on Saturday.

Prices were mainly weaker last week on commodity futures markets here, although coffee, sugar and cocoa were fairly steady and recovered from their depressed spells in fairly large transactions. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, lard, quicksilver and steel billets gained.

When the issue of "industrial" versus "craft" unionism was fought out in the convention at Atlantic City of the American Federation of Labor last month, the advocates of industrial unionism, led by JOHN L. LEWIS of the United Mine Workers, were defeated by a vote of 18,000 to 11,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Throughout Westchester County today special services with extra musical programs were held in all churches in celebration of Thanksgiving. At Christ's Church on the Shore Road, Pelham Manor, the rite of confirmation was conferred on a large class by Suffragan Bishop Charles K. Gilbert.

One of the programs and concerts which will be remembered as a conspicuous pleasure of this season was given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Hans Lange conducting, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The soloist was Jose Iturbi, and he played a work for which he is ideally equipped, the beautiful Mozart concerto in E flat, numbered 482 in Koechel's catalogue.

To reduce costs and increase convenience for regular users of air transportation, the air transport operators who have recently opened joint headquarters in Chicago announced yesterday, through their public affairs committee, a plan of scrip books and travel cards good on virtually every airline in the United States.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Ishbel MacDonald has decided to become the proprietress of a 300-year-old country inn near Chequers, the country estate where her father spent his happiest days as Prime Minister.

In "this age of despair and blasted hopes," the most puzzling question one can be asked is: "How can I keep a tranquil heart?" the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Jefferson, honorary minister of the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, said in his annual sermon at the church yesterday morning.
MANILA, Monday, Nov. 25 AP). -President Manuel Quezon proposed to the National Assembly today compulsory military training for all male Filipinos in defense of the new Commonwealth.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 24. -North Jersey's shore municipalities split into two camps over the weekend as a result of the plans of the Central Railroad of New Jersey and Pennsylvania Railroad to abolish the present graduated commutation rate for tickets from New York to the shore and substitute a flat monthly rate.

Only the fundamental spirit of righteousness acquired from a belief in God can bring about an equitable distribution of the benefits from scientific progress, and only faith is a sure light in the world's darkness, the Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 25. -- The attitude of the United States Government and American public opinion "may have an important effect in helping shorten the Italo-Ethiopian war," The Times says editorially today.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry K. Hadley gave a reception and buffet supper last night in their studio, 15 West Sixty-seventh Street, for Miss Jerry Bergh, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bergh, who will be introduced formally at a tea dance on Dec. 13 at the Savoy-Plaza.

In response to numerous requests from sportsmen regarding the locations of shooting preserves in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, a list of licensed game farms has been compiled by More Game Birds in America, Inc.

LOOKOUT MOUNTAIN, Tenn., Nov. 24. -- Oratorical echoes of the battle that opened up the way for Sherman's march to the sea rang over this historic shrine this afternoon in commemoration of the seventy-second anniversary of its capture by Federal forces in the war between the States.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov 24. -The tenth anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires as Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island was commemorated here this morning at a service in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

For some time to come BAKER will no doubt be quoted for and against BAKER in the revived debate on neutrality, and entanglement, and how we got into the war, and how we could or could not have stayed out.

Dr. Franz Oppenheimer, German sociologist and economist, was guest of honor last night at a dinner sponsored by the New York Zionist Club at the Hotel Park Central. Speakers, who included Dr. Albert Einstein, praised Dr. Oppenheimer for his contributions to economic science and to the movement for rebuilding a Jewish national home in Palestine.

Benjamin Kotlowitz, 111-year-old resident of the Bialystoker Home for the Aged, 228 East Broadway, entered a hospital yesterday afternoon for the first time in more years than he can remember, but he did not go in as a patient.

VIENNA, Nov. 24. -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, Vice Chancellor, and other Fascist Heimwehr leaders attended today a meeting of Styrian Heimwehr members at Leoben, Upper Styria, the centre of the industrial district and the cradle of the Heimwehr movement.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- Midnight tonight marks the end of the first week of sanctions and finds the Italian nation still unshaken in its determination to resist to the utmost. Italy is, indeed, at present at the apex of a period of patriotic exaltation that makes all sacrifices appear light and surrounds hardships with a glamourous halo of self-sacrifice that makes them easy to bear.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Nov. 25.--Yin Ju-keng, Administrative Commissioner of the North China demilitarized zone, abruptly revived the movement for an autonomous North China yesterday by proclaiming the independence of a large area of Eastern Hopei Province.
BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Unlike the Ministry of Economics, which comments pessimistically on the outlook for foreign trade, the banks are inclined to expect an export surplus next year.

ATLANTA, Nov. 24. -- Efforts of textile mill employes to bargain collectively with their employers in many Southern textile centres have resulted in a "battle of petitions," according to officials of the Regional Labor Board here, whose jurisdiction covers the Carolinas, Georgia and Northern Alabama.
CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP). -- The Rev. Dr. Charles Anson Ingraham, 83, died in the pulpit of the Presbyterian Church here today, halfway through a service he was conducting for a friend.

The calendar congestion in the courts in this city and in other parts of the State has been a vexatious problem for a generation or two. Despite the earnest efforts of both bench and bar, it still remains completely unsolved. The complexities of our economic and social conditions have produced an ever-increasing amount of litigation.

With four inches of snow covering some parts of the city, the Department of Sanitation yesterday assigned 5,200 of its regular employes to the task of sweeping and sanding the principal traffic arteries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- In a new challenge, to the administration, the American Liberty League said today that until business and industry were assured of a more conservative trend in government it was idle for President Roosevelt to expect private enterprise to absorb the unemployment any more rapidly than at present.
ROME, Nov. 22. -- Although the volume of business is small, the Stock Exchange here is firm and application of sanctions has not given rise to any striking oscillations.

MANILA, Nov. 24 (AP). -- George C. Butte, an American justice of the Philippine Supreme Court, married Angela Papa, widow of a member of the Manila Municipal Board, today. The first Mrs. Butte obtained a divorce in Reno two years ago.
Prize winners in the Hayden Planetarium Poster Contest for the most inspiring and instructive posters were announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24. -- With the Eastern racing season beginning its final week at Bowie tomorrow, it was clear today that a greater number of thoroughbreds than ever before will be campaigned at Winter courses in quest of more than $1,500,000 which will be distributed in purses between Thanksgiving Day and next Spring.

In connection with the campaign of the United Hospital Fund for the wherewithal to eliminate, or at least substantially reduce, the operating deficits of voluntary hospitals, it is important to note certain unfriendly tendencies which must be taken into consideration while we are trying to balance the accounts of charitable institutions.

The New York Giants still hold the undisputed lead in the Eastern Division of the National Football League. At the Polo Grounds yesterday they slipped and slid through icy black mud to a 10-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles and increased their margin to a full game over the Dodgers, whom the Giants meet at Ebbets Field on Thanksgiving Day.

Berta Ochsner, one of the leaders in the Middle Western dance field, made her New York debut in a solo recital at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon. In making any estimate of her work, it is necessary to look through, rather than at, her program, for it was made up largely, though not exclusively, of dances of slight content and fairly familiar approach.

Referring to the letter of Whidden Graham in re Dunlap v. United States (19 SCR 319) that if a right depended upon regulations to be issued by the Secretary of the Treasury and no regulation has been issued, the right did not exist, it is interesting to examine the decision in Pigeon River, , v. Cox (54 SCR 361) where at page 367 the court said:

An offering to the public will be made today of a new issue of $25,000,000 New York Queens Electric Light Power Company first and consolidated mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1965, by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.
HILO, Hawaii, Nov. 24 (AP). -Mauna Loa cracked under the pressure of a new upheaval today, sending a cascade of lava down toward Hilo.

The greatest danger facing America is not communism or fascism but that the people will forget God, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, said yesterday at a joint Thanksgiving service for the patriotic societies of New York in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Federal fingerprint experts have discovered ex-criminals applying for police beats, army assignments, gun permits, hotel jobs and taxi-driving cards.

About 80 of the 700 couples married in the last twenty-six years by the Rev. Dr. Paul Mansfield Spencer at the Church of the Strangers, 309 West Fifty-seventh Street, gathered last night at the church for a "homecoming." Dr. Spencer hopes the event will be repeated as an annual function.

PARIS, Nov. 24. -- Fifteen hundred wine growers and sympathizers under the leadership of the Royalist Henry Dorgeres, who during the past year has been trying to organize a kind of peasant-Fascist party, were involved in a battle with police and mounted Mobile Guards this evening at Montpellier.

DUNFERMLINE, Scotland, Nov. 24 (AP). -- Everything is in readiness in this little city, where the success story of Andrew Carnegie had its humble beginning, for the observance tomorrow of the centenary of the birth of the famous philanthropist.

AT the moment the more perfervid champions of big business, scenting an opportunity to checkmate Jim Farley and go back to Republican rule, are industriously spreading the gospel that Franklin D. Roosevelt is "fomenting class strife" with his New Deal and that one of his trusted lieutenants, Rexford Tugwell, is a sansculotte who has merely forgotten to remove his breeches.

Arthur Judson, manager of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, was urged yesterday by Jacob Rosenberg, secretary of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, to rescind his endorsement of the policy of exacting admission charges for WPA concerts.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- The greatest danger facing the United States at present is the influential leaders who assume that as economic conditions improve industry should be allowed to carry on without governmental or other restriction, it was said here tonight by the Most Rev. John A. Ryan of Catholic University, Washington, D.C.

Declaring that for the entire holiday season and extending into February, business will continue to show the upward trend currently in evidence, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, pointed out yesterday in his monthly review of business that heavy governmental expenditures of the past several weeks and currently are a bolster for the months immediately ahead.
Deals involving housing properties formed the bulk of real estate trading reported in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn over the weekend.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24. -- National production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 55 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week and equal to the previous high point of the year, reached in the two weeks ended on Feb. 9.

Hope Farm will be the beneficiary of the Inter-School and College Dance to be held the night of Dec. 21 at the Biltmore. Younger members of society who are taking an active interest in the arrangements include the Misses Suzanne W. Murray, Lucy Saunders, Mary Schley, Beatrice Butler, Mary Alice Amory, Jane Rovensky, Phyllis Gillespie, Ruth Mary Ruxton, Doris Terhune, Lydia Hadden, Virginia French, Faith Locke, Hope Gatins and Caroline Miller.

The Catholic Church's teachings on capital and labor, morality, education and such topics as birth control, divorce and interracial relations offer the soundest remedy for communism, the Rev. William I. Lonergan, associate editor of America, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24. -- The shopping spree of the Soviet Union's new heroes -- the Stakhanoffites -during which they bought perfumes, kid gloves, silk lingerie and fur cloaks, before returning to the coal mines, textile mills and beet fields, was featured throughout the country by the press today.

The recently announced campaign of the government to hasten the transfer of unemployed workers from public to private payrolls is hailed by the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey, as "the most constructive approach to the problem of recovery that the government has yet taken."
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 (AP). -Pittsburgh's Pirates were eliminated today from the National Football League championship race as they bowed to the ponderous Green Bay Packers, 34 to 14.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- In the recent ocean travel season, which extended later in the year than in any recent year, American ships "more than held their own," according to a statement made here today by James Craig Peacock, director of the Shipping Board Bureau, in which he disclosed results of a survey of the travel year.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the old-age revolving pension movement, said today that he "did not expect" to join forces with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, radio priest.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, 1935, have reported a net operating profit of $1,071,157 after all charges including interest, amortization and depreciation but before Federal income taxes, in contrast with an operating loss of $2,530,514 for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 25, 1934, and a loss of $6,291,748 for that ended on Aug. 26, 1933.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24. -Plans to establish a 300th anniversary fund at Harvard University this year for the awarding of large annual prize scholarships to boys in each State of the Union were announced tonight by Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, in letters sent to 65,000 Harvard alumni.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 24 (AP) -Officials of the Catholic Church declined today to comment on the arrests of twelve Catholics in the State of Jalisco on the charge that prominent Catholics were supporting a revolutionary movement there.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- With an oil embargo threatened, experts said tonight that Italy had reduced petroleum consumption to the point where the nation believed it could carry on at home and in Africa for one year without running short.

A lessening of the intensity of land usage in this city by limiting the height of skyscrapers and spreading business and residential populations over large areas is recommended in a report on drastic revision of the zoning laws just adopted by the Merchants Association.

THE only doubt now about that Princeton team is whether or not it can go on ice. It went well through the snow on Saturday. It traveled fast on hard ground earlier in the season. Just an all-weather, sure-footed football team, and a trifle too powerful for the Dartmouth tribe that tried to halt it in the snow-covered jungle.

Twelve detectives beat six alleged master burglars into submission at 2 A.M. yesterday in the dark corridors of 80-82 Bowery, a six-story building housing some seventy offices and cubby holes of gem merchants and dealers in old gold, as well as about $2,000,000 worth of precious metals and stones.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 24. -Two bed-ridden women patients of the Christian Sanitarium on Goffle Hill Road in Wyckoff, near here, were killed by smoke early today when fire swept through one of the five buildings of the institution. Nurses, heroically risking their lives, rescued thirty-six women patients quartered in the building, a two-and-a-half-story brick structure.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP). -Governor Earle has asked the heads of three Federal agencies to aid Pennsylvania's investigation of the Associated Gas and Electric Company system by opening the organization's books "for the purpose of tracing the charges already developed and other charges that may appear upon further investigation."

Outstanding work by American photographers will be shown at the 1935 photographic exhibition of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue next Sunday and Monday, it was announced yesterday.

The first returns in the national plebiscite on war and peace conducted by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches, 287 Fourth Avenue, favor a smaller army and navy, control of the munitions industry by the government and national isolation through strict neutrality legislation, it was announced yesterday.

ON BOARD MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Nov. 24. -- Lincoln Ellsworth, who with his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, started yesterday from Dundee Island on a flight to the Ross Sea, 2,140 miles away, is still out of communication with his base here at Dundee Island.

Elks Day was celebrated at the Polo Grounds yesterday by more than 10,000 small boys with impromptu snowball barrages between halves of the New YorkPhiladelphia professional football game. The boys were guests of New York Lodge 1 at the game.

American shipyards are working at only one-half of their capacity, according to a survey made by the National Council of American Shipbuilders. Fifty sea-going vessels are under construction, including forty-six vessels for the United States Navy and four sea-going tankers for private interests.

Governor Lehman stepped into the controversial Druckman murder case last night by sending identic telegrams to Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, asking them to come to his home in this city on Wednesday to discuss the case and "all the alleged crimes connected with it."

LIMA, Nov. 24. -- Overseas trade of Peru in the first eight months of this year amounted to 309,355,426 soles, against 300,097,416 in the same period in 1934. Exports fell off to the extent of 2,292,934 soles, whereas imports increased from 103,549,398 to 115,100,342.

ATHENS, Nov. 24. -- King George II, saw Greece shortly after dawn today for the first time since his exile as the cruiser Helle approached Corfu from the north. The King was plainly visible, waving from the bridge to the crowds lining the shore, as the cruiser steamed at quarter speed 150 yards off shore.

Juvenile delinquency is the high road to adult crime. For that reason any promising experiment in the handling of the youthful offender is watched with interest by all those studying the crime problem. A Committee of the New York County Lawyers Association has just made a report on such an experiment which has been conducted across the river in Jersey City for four years, apparently with success.

Recommending vigorous opposition to any new attempt on the part of the Federal Government to regulate industrial wages and hours, the report of the committee on relation of government to industry of the National Association of Manufacturers opposes restriction of production, either in industry or agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -President Roosevelt today summoned "the serious consideration of every one" to the annual Christmas seal drive by the National Tuberculosis Association.

Pity the poor radio sponsor! He has been the victim of gibes which have no legitimate basis. The self-appointed sages bemoan that a great singer is put on the air at a fabulous salary and then forced to sing "claptrap," losing the privilege of "expressing himself."

Tonight brings the first of this week's scheduled trio of doubleheaders. There have not been many such crowded evenings this season, but now the producers are looking toward the holiday season -- trying to get their shows "set" for that festive time.

Communism and the Russian system will be conquered "only when Christians put into practice Christ's ideals of justice and brotherhood," the Rev. Dr. H. W. B. Donegan, the rector, said in his sermon yesterday morning at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP). -- The Boston Redskins lost their eighth straight National Football League contest today, when Bill Smith, former Washington end, placepicked the Chicago Cardinals to a 6-0 victory before a shivering crowd of 5,000 at Fenway Park.

A group of Roman Catholic men and women who have been studying papal encyclicals on labor in a Social Action Conference conducted for the last two years in Brooklyn were advised last night by the Rev. Wilfrid Parsons, editor of America, a Catholic magazine, to consider ways in which they could begin to bring about reforms in industry and in municipal administration of public affairs.
Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch was buried with full civil honors in Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, yesterday after a service in Temple Emanu-El attended by more than 2,500 persons.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The Board of Trade's index of British industrial activity for the third quarter, based on 1930 as 100, stands at 110.8, compared with 111.5 for the June quarter and 103.2 for the third quarter in 1934. The slight decline from the second quarter was seasonal, but the expansion over last year's figure was attributed to a definite trade recovery which is shared by all industrial groups.

BELGRADE, Nov. 24. -- The annual conference of the chiefs of staffs of the three Little Entente States started here today. It was stated officially that the aim of the meeting mainly was to exchange views regarding the recent Autumn manoeuvres.

Norman Armitage, the national saber champion, gave characteristically superb performance yesterday on his home strips at the Fencers Club, turning back Miguel A. de Capriles of the University Fencers Club in a fence-off to triumph in the first of a series of tests with this weapon staged by the Amateur Fencers League of America to select the Olympic sword team.

King Football rounded into the homestretch in the metropolitan scholastic ranks during the past week-end, as numerous elevens concluded their campaigns. Actually activity was just about half normal, because many other teams were idle awaiting their season's closers on Thanksgiving Day, but perusal of the results discloses the usual run of surprises, including a few upset and some unexpected large scores.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- The gold purchases of the Bank of England this week amounted to 651,359, making the amount bought this year 5,035,039. No information was vouchsafed concerning the source of these purchases but it is generally understood that the exchange fund was the seller.

DETROIT, Nov. 25. -- The mystery surrounding a sensational "baby mix-up" case of twelve years ago was believed solved today by the confession of Alphonse Vlemminck that he threw the body of one of the babies in the Detroit River after it smothered to death.
Phil Baker came down from Stardford, Conn., to the St. Nicholas Palace last night to score a distinct upset in one of the greatest ring bouts seen at a local fight club in years.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25. -- In the city where he found the opportunity that awaited his energy and initiative, tribute was paid today on the centenary of Andrew Carnegie's birth to his distribution of vast wealth for social advancement. Accompanying the tribute was a warning that the occasion was a challenge to the American people on the issue of whether it is wise to set limits by governmental policies on the holders of great fortunes.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Paul Thompson, star wingman for the Chicago Black Hawks, leads the individual scorers in the first weekly statistics of the National Hockey League, issued tonight by President Frank Calder.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The Ethiopian Government asserted tonight that two victories on the northern front had turned the tide of the war in that sector to Ethiopia. An official announcement said Dedjasmatch Wores, leading a detachment of Ras Seyoum's warriors, had triumphed in two engagements within three days.

The home-building program of the "Committee for Economic Recovery" may be a trifle ambitious, but it is good to see business men turning their attention to this neglected field, and a number of the points they make are well taken. Private initiative will have to carry most of the load here, as it has even in the much-publicized British venture.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 25. -- The cost of county government for 1936 in Nassau County will increase $1,457,216 over the 1935 budgetary requirements under estimates made public for the first time today at a budget hearing before the Board of Supervisors.

Ogden L. Mills, who was Secretary of the Treasury under former President Hoover, and Lewis W. Douglas, who became one of the Roosevelt administration's severest critics after his resignation as Director of the Budget, made common cause against the New Deal last night at a dinner of the New York State Economic Council in the Hotel Biltmore.

The weekly football forum, which has been a feature of Monday luncheons at the Downtown Athletic Club all Fall, was concluded yesterday with John W. Heisman answering a barrage of questions asked by the fifty business men present.

After a three-hour hearing in the Bay Ridge Court yesterday, Mrs. Daisy Ward, 61 years old, of Palisades, N.J., wife of Professor Harry F. Ward of the Union Theological Seminary, and Miss Evelyn Preston, 36, of 282 West Eleventh Street, Manhattan, a Junior League member, were found guilty of disorderly conduct by Magistrate Sweeney.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The policy of the United States of discouraging exports of oil and other essential war materials to Italy and Ethiopia is expected to stand unchanged by the postponement of further sanctions action by the League of Nations.

The rumor was general in Wall Street yesterday that Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, planned to "interpret" his statement of Friday afternoon in which he held that the recent stock market activities were relatively safe and healthful and that Washington had no intention of applying any "brakes" in the near future.

ATHENS, Nov. 25. -- King George II of Greece today became the first of the monarchs who lost their thrones as the result of the World War to experience restoration when he ended his twelve-year exile at 10:05 this morning by setting foot on the soil of Greece.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The dollar volume of sales of stocks and bonds in October on the nation's securities exchanges, aggregating $2,214,379,595, was an increase of 31.9 per cent over September and 161.2 per cent more than in October, 1934, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25. -- Found guilty of murdering her 13-year-old stepson, Peter Parfenoff, who had betrayed his grandmother to the authorities when she stole from a collective farm. Christina Parvenova, a peasant woman, was sentenced to death before a Soviet firing squad by the Supreme Court of the White Russian Republic at Sekno.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The stock markets here generally were firm today although quiet, with continued uncertainty in the Continental European stock markets due to the political situation, although the foreign exchanges were quieter. British funds gained on renewed investment demand.

The fact of substantial and sustained business recovery is now so unanimously recognized that it is timely to ask how far we have got toward normal conditions. At New Orleans, a fortnight ago, the Bankers Convention's resolutions cited business sentiment as entertaining positive "conviction that recovery is making vigorous progress."

ROME, Nov. 25. -- Postponement sine die of the meeting of the Committee of Eighteen at Geneva that was to approve the addition of oil, coal and steel to the list of articles the exportation of which to Italy is prohibited, has been welcomed in Italy with relief so heartfelt that no effort is made to disguise it.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Jap, the elephant who has found reason to distrust trucks, has proved to her truck driver-keeper that elephants have memories. Her memory and her obstinacy, however, deprived the 50-year-old elephant of a ride and tonight she and the truck driver -- temporarily turned mahout -- limped home to end a seven-hour twenty-mile walk.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- A modern story in an ancient setting will be the feature of the forty-seventh annual production of the Princeton University Triangle Club, undergraduate musical comedy organization, according to an announcement by Walter H. Smith, '36, of Pelham, N.Y., its president.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25. -- For the third successive season Stanford was named today to represent the West in the annual Rose Bowl football game at Pasadena New Year's Day.

New Yorkers have no choice but to care for their own sick, as there are no Federal or State provisions for voluntary hospitals in either regular or emergency funds, Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury and chairman of the professional committee in the United Hospital campaign, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of that committee at the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street.

MADRID, Nov. 25. -- More than a year after his arrest and imprisonment here, Francisco Largo Caballero, 63-year-old Socialist Deputy and leader of the militant revolutionary factions of his party, went on trial today before the Supreme Court on charges of having helped to direct the revolt in October, 1934.
DUNFERMLINE, Scotland, Nov. 25. -- America and Scotland joined today in paying tribute to the great Scottish American, Andrew Carnegie, in the town where he was born 100 years ago today.

Publication of a special list of 1,500 dry goods wholesalers for the guidance of mills desiring to do business with concerns falling within its definition of a wholesaler, was announced yesterday by the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute.

Controller Frank J. Taylor, in a report made public yesterday, completely exonerated Willets H. Shotwell, personal representative of Borough President Ingersoll in charge of the demolition of buildings on the Brooklyn Bridge Plaza site, in his handling of the sale of materials taken from the first three demolished buildings.

GENEVA, Nov. 25. -- The movement toward extending the raw materials embargo against Italy to include oil, coal and steel gained force today in the wake of mounting United States responsibility in the matter. Russia and Rumania, who are Italy's chief suppliers of oil, led in informing Geneva this afternoon that they were ready to make this extension whenever all the other producers, League of Nations members and non-members, did the same.
Detectives recovered $75,000 worth of stolen furs yesterday and charged three men with receiving stolen goods in connection with a hijacking on Nov. 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Tenders for two series of Treasury bills aggregating approximately $100,000,000 were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today, Secretary Morgenthau announced. The tenders were made on Nov. 22, and the bills are to be dated Nov. 27.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Forgetting for the time being their sensational victory last Saturday over Dartmouth, Princeton's football hosts today turned their attention toward their meeting with Yale at New Haven Saturday, determined to gain revenge for the 7-0 upset achieved by the Elis last year.

In his "Journal of Autumn," Henry D. Thoreau declares: "I must be out of doors enough to get experience of wholesome reality, as a ballast to thought and sentiment. Health requires this relaxation. * * * I keep out of doors for the sake of the mineral, vegetable and animal in me."

DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctic Ocean, Nov. 25. -- There is still no word from Lincoln Ellsworth, who with his pilot, Herbert Hollock-Kenyon, left Dundee Island, at the head of the Weddell Sea, Saturday to fly across Antarctica. It is hoped that by this time he is safely encamped at the Bay of Whales.

Any lingering doubt that the city is faced with a typical big game this Thursday is very easily dispelled by one visit to New York University and Ohio Field. On the field itself, wet and slippery and muddy yesterday, there is an attitude visible on the part of both players and coaches that point certainly to more than usually important happenings near at hand.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, of 14 Wall Street, established by John Markle, coal operator, to "promote the advancement and diffusion of knowledge among the people of the United States and to promote the general good of mankind," receives cash and securities worth about $8,692,155, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- While the Supreme Court action today directly affected a comparatively small sum, some legal observers contended that it served to tighten for the present lower court orders impounding $125,000,000 to $150,000,000 of taxes pending a high court ruling on the AAA's constitutionality.

Being a midget actor Mr. Truex needs a midget comedy. For the past two seasons he has had difficulty in finding the sort of miniature lark his acting requires. Milton Lazarus's "Whatever Goes Up," which opened at the Biltmore last evening, is at least half a step in the right direction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Apparent evidence that "people are drinking more" was seen today in Public Health Service estimates that 3,665 persons died of alcoholism during 1934.

With the receipt of the report of its representative, Alden Calkins, who made a tour of the Pacific Coast, the Trotting Horse Club of America has decided to work on the extension of the Grand Circuit to the Far West, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization in the Prince George Hotel.

The charge that L.L. Balleisen, industrial secretary of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, sought by threat to bring pressure upon her to dismiss the complaint of the National Labor Relations Board against the Atlas Bag and Burlap Company of Brooklyn for violation of the National Labor Disputes Act was made yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board.

Great South Bay's race week, blue-ribbon sailing event of the South Shore of Long Island, will comprise six racing days next season instead of the usual five, it was decided last night at the annual meeting of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association at the Downtown A.C.

The theft of three large medals that had belonged to the late Henry Fairfield Osborn from the guarded gem room of the American Museum of Natural History, some time between the afternoon of Nov. 15 and the morning of Nov. 16, was made known last night.

Mutual savings banks in Massachusetts, New York, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Maine have organized to determine the procedure they will follow in the receivership of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. A committee has been named to operate as a single unit representing the mutual institutions in the six States, and is composed of the following:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25. -- Organized labor's ability to cooperate with management in a constructive way is about to be put to the test by the Tennessee Valley Authority in carrying out its new employe relationship policy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors voted today to inquire why New York City is getting VVPA funds for materials and supplies on relief projects while in counties outside of the city these costs must be borne by the municipalities.

Efforts of Russian women to garb themselves fashionably, despite such obstacles as waiting six months for the services of a dressmaker, were described yesterday at the November luncheon of the Fashion Group in the Hotel Biltmore.

Light harness horsemen from all over the United States and Canada, with a sprinkling of representatives of foreign breeders, will gather in the Squadron A Armory, at Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, at 10:30 o'clock this morning for the opening session of the forty-first annual Old Glory horse auction.
ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- Governor Lehman issued his annual Thanksgiving proclamation today, as follows:

The Metropolitan Water District of California will enter the market on Dec. 13 with a new issue of $12,096,000 bonds. The district has specified a fixed interest rate of 5 per cent. Further details of the financing will be announced later.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- Prices on the Boerse weakened slightly at the opening today, but became firmer at the close. Activity was limited and the price changes were not significant. Most sales continued to be made outside of the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Montana-Dakota Utilities Company of Minneapolis, a small holding company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a notification of registration under the Public Utility Act. It has subsidiaries operating in Montana, Wyoming and North and South Dakota. C.C. Yawky is president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Government collection of processing taxes from eight Louisiana rice millers under the Agricultural Adjustment Act was ordered suspended by the Supreme Court today until it shall decide whether court injunctions to prevent such collections in the first instance are legally obtainable.
Sotal Fenn on. The'South Penn oil Company has declared a .quarterly dividend of 40 cents[ Three months ago the dividend was increased from 30 cents to 3,5 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Overwhelming opposition to recent Federal legislative trends was registered in the referendum taken by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States among its constituent bodies, the results of which were made public here today.

Columbia moved into the final week of its football season yesterday at Baker Field by engaging in a long but comparatively light drill in preparation for its game with Dartmouth here on Saturday. It was cold and windy, and Baker Field was covered with snow when the Lions reported to Coach Lou Little, but the elements did not deter the Blue from an enthusiastic workout.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The Wagner Labor Act was condemned as an unconstitutional interference with commerce and praised as an instrument for industrial peace as attorneys argued here today its first legal test in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Unsafe ocean-going vessels carrying passengers under the American flag are being quietly required to be remodeled for safety, it was disclosed today at the Department of Commerce. Officials declined to estimate how many ships had been found unsafe, but said that not one ship owner had refused to comply with the "suggestions" offered by the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection.

Esky Clark of Harvard does not assume his new job of director of athletics at Lafayette until Jan. 1, but already he has received eighty-five applications for the position of head football coach. . . . He told Asa Bushnell, Princeton graduate manager, about it, remarking that not even one candidate hailed from Old Nassau.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Primo Carnera, former world s heavyweight champion, outpointed Ford Smith of Missoula, Mont., in a 10-round-bout at the Arena tonight before 7,000 fans. The Italian weighed 267 1/2 pounds, Smith 209.

Baron Eberhard von Schroetter, commander of the Stahlhelm in the United States and Canada, issued an order here yesterday to his followers, all former German soldiers in the World War, announcing that he would continue the organization under its old name and its old constitution on his own responsibility, although the Stahlhelm was dissolved in Germany by Hitler on Nov. 7.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has no intention of entering into any fight on President Green of the American Federation of Labor or those members of the executive council opposed to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, who is leading a faction demanding industrial unionism for the mass-production industries.
PARIS, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Half of the twenty best-dressed women in the world are Americans, in the opinion of the leading Paris dressmakers, a poll showed today.

The Kings County grand jury is expected to hand up indictments today in the murder of Samuel Druckman, on the eve of a conference tomorrow to which Governor Lehman has summoned District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 25. -- As the new autonomous State proclaimed yesterday by Yin Ju-keng appealed today to Japan to send troops to "purge the area of Communists," an attempted coup by autonomists in this city collapsed after a mob outbreak.

A concert was given in Carnegie Hall last night in the presence of a very distinguished audience in commemoration of the centenary of the birth of the man who gave its most celebrated concert auditorium to New York and to America -- Andrew Carnegie.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- Dr. Luther Gulick, in his first public address since his appointment to direct the Regents' inquiry into the cost and nature of public education, told the State Teachers Association at its dinner here tonight that the time had come "for a rethinking of our educational objectives and programs."

A proposal for an oceanfront park at Sea Girt, N.J., linked to a forty-mile highway which eventually would end at Atlantic City, connecting with direct routes to New York City at Rahway, was made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association, Inc.

In the hope that Lincoln Ellsworth can receive radio messages, a member of Admiral Byrd's second Antarctic expedition has sent to the Ellsworth expedition headquarters on Dundee Island information that may help the explorer and his pilot reach safety at Little America.

Once more the theatre's attention goes to the Music Box, where the new Katharine Dayton-George S. Kaufman show will be suitably installed this evening. Call it "First Lady" and say that it deals with Washington's upper strata social life. In it, as is probably pretty well known by now, is Jane Cowl, and among her drawing room company are Lily Cahill, Stanley Ridges, Jessie Busley, Oswald Yorke, Helen Brooks and Ethel Wilson.

At a special meeting in City Hall yesterday the Board of Estimate voted to increase relief appropriations for November and December from the original amount of $14,800,000 to $16,532,000, making the change to take advantage of an increased return from the State.

Although the preparation of the Maroon defense was believed finished last week, the Fordham squad returned to that phase of the game yesterday and spent about three hours in putting the finishing touches on it for the battle with New York University on Thursday.
Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, announced yesterday that a reorganized staff at Gouverneur Hospital would be ready to take over the clinical work of the institution on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Built around the sturdiest part of Minnesota's mighty squad, five Gophers, two players each from Northwestern and Ohio State, Iowa's Oze Simmons and Chicago's John Jacob Berwanger were named today on The Associated Press Big Ten all-star team for 1935.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today warned John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, and six associated executives of other industrial unions that their forming of a committee within the federation to promote industrial as distinct from craft unionism might "create a line of cleavage" with "grave consequences."

The chances of two men forcing their way through from the point at which Lincoln Ellsworth's plane was last heard from to the Antarctic Coast and perfect safety are 90 per cent good, according to Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson, noted polar explorer.

PARIS, Nov. 25. -- For the third time within twelve days, the regents of the Bank of France raised today the discount and interest rates by a full point in following out their policy of protection for the franc.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Charles R. Fairey told THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent tonight that he had withdrawn his challenge for the America's Cup because he did not wish to press his suggestion regarding the type of yacht to be used, which he had heard privately was unacceptable to the New York Yacht Club.

A circus performance will be given on the Mall in Central Park again this Thanksgiving, it was announced yesterday. In addition, there will be a second performance Thursday afternoon in the music grove in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
Barnum's museum has been reconstructed on the sixth floor at Gimbels and may be inspected there daily -- adults, 15 cents, children a dime.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 25. -- In the privacy of the Little White House here, President Roosevelt met today with his chief associates concerned with the budget and began studies of how to pare Federal expenditures to bring them closer to the level of the national income.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- An agreement this week between the utility holding companies and the Securities and Exchange Commission on procedure to be followed in bringing a test of the Public Utility Act before the Supreme Court appeared probable today on the basis of information from utility and government circles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A strictly legal, as contrasted with a broad constitutional question was the issue before the Supreme Court in the rice millers' suit today. Therefore no clue was afforded as to the attitude of the court toward the validity of the processing taxes and other contested aspects of the President's farm-relief legislation.

The New York Curb Exchange admitted to listing yesterday securities of five companies, accorded full listing to the securities of four concerns formerly in the unlisted department and removed from unlisted trading the issues of four corporations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 25. -- Indication that the Palm Beach season, now opening, will eclipse previous ones is given by the unusually large numbers of colonists established in villas and the early opening dates of clubs and hotels. During the Summer nearly forty new homes have been completed, many of them now occupied by owners.

An underwriting group headed by Hayden, Stone Co., sold yesterday at par and interest $12,000,000 of ten-year 4 per cent convertible debentures of the International Cement Company. Other members of the offering group were Blyth Co., Inc., the First Boston Corporation, the Lee Higginson Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co.; Field, Glore Co. and White, Weld Co.

An exhibition of articles representing the craftsmanship of patients in ten city hospitals was opened yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. All of the exhibits were for sale and it was announced that the proceeds will be placed in a fund for the benefit of the patients.

PHILADELPIA, Nov. 25. -- Bids were opened at the quartermaster's depot today on 566,970 cotton huck towels for the Civilian Conservation Corps, under invitation 115. Inasmuch as Controller General McCarl has ruled that the CCC is a relief organization, and, consequently, the cotton processing tax is waivable, bids were submitted with and without the addition of this tax. They were as follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Two hours of dummy scrimmage opened Yale's practice for next Saturday's game with Princeton here. The two varsity elevens faced their scrub rivals in a rehearsal of Yale's most effective attacking plays.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today reversed the order issued in February by the Grain Futures Administration, headed by Henry A. Wallace Secretary of Agriculture, suspending Arthur W. Cutten from trading on the country's grain exchanges for two years.
HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 25. -- The commander-in-chief of Ethiopta's southern battlefront is a man who cannot read a military map, who cannot draw a plan, who knows nothing of staff work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Evidence before the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that when the real estate bonding house of S.W. Straus Co., with subsidiaries or affiliated units in almost every State, began to totter in the late Winter of 1931, the corporation, in a last desperate effort to ward off the impending collapse, organized 235 bondholders' protective committees all of whose members were executives of the Straus organization.

Colossal cauliflowers of blue-brown smoke merging into a milky cirrus far above the normal clouds hang over Mauna Loa. Rocks are blown out. Lava flows down the slope in a fuming river with the consistency of molasses. Forty miles distant lies Hilo, a town of 20,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The New York State Superintendent of Banking, aided by representatives of 32,000 investors, lost today in the Supreme Court in an attempt to regain control of the Prudence Company, Inc., one of the largest guaranteed mortgage investment firms.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman handed down a decision yesterday declaring unconstitutional the Fair Trade Law passed by the last Legislature as a curb on price cutting in the sale of nationally advertised merchandise. The decision was made in a suit brought by Coty, Inc., to prevent the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., from selling Coty products at prices lower than those fixed in an agreement with retailers.

Dore Strauch, who with Dr. Friedrich Ritter, a Berlin physician, left Germany in 1929 to live a primitive life in Galapagos, has written a book telling the full history of the experiment. Dr. Ritter died last year. Harper will publish the book early in the Spring under the title, "Satan Came to Eden."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Princeton students, many of them members of the University Rowing Association, gathered on the shores of Lake Carnegie here this afternoon to honor the 100th birthday of the man who built a lake out of a muddy creek for the benefit of Princeton undergraduates.

Mayor La Guardia's policy of retiring city employes more than 70 years old received a rude jolt yesterday when Democratic members of the Board of Estimate joined with Fusion members in extending the service of thirty-three employes who have passed retirement age.

For the third successive first-notice day of an active trading position none was circulated yesterday, and prices on the Cotton Exchange improved during morning trading. Mills called cotton and a persistently strong basis on better grades in the South caused at one time a 17-point rise in October.

The State Supreme Court will not interfere with the decrees of the Federal Court relating to bankrupt corporations, if a ruling made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black stands. Justice Black dismissed a suit involving $2,000,000 against Wise Shoe, Inc., which went into bankruptcy and was reorganized as the Wise Shoe Company, after paying creditors of the bankrupt company 40 per cent in cash and 20 per cent in four notes.

The Brown Shoe Company and its subsidiary reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $1,108,124 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equal, after 7 per cent preferred dividends, to $3.59 a share on 247,000 no-par shares of common stock.
