Rear Admiral Fabian Tamm, commander of the Swedish Navy, who is spending his annual period of leave in studying the American Navy, visited the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday preparatory to a trip today to Washington to meet officials of the Navy Department.

The Beethoven Association opened its eighteenth season at the Town Hall last night with Ria Ginster, soprano, and the American Society of Ancient Instruments as guest artists. The members of the society were Jo Brodo, Ben Stad, Josef Smit, Maurice Stad and Flora Stad; their instruments included the quinton, the viole d'amour, viole de gambe, basse de viole and harpsichord.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25. -- Martial law for sixty days was voted by Congress tonight at the request of President Getulio Vargas and the Cabinet, while Federal army, naval and air forces battled revolutionists in the States of Pernambuco and Rio Grande do Norte.

"By having a devil of a fight" Chairman BUCHANAN of the House Appropriations Committee believes the Federal deficit can be pared for the fiscal year to begin July 1 next to not more than $500,000,000. Just how much of a fight it would be can be recognized from the analysis of the budget by LEWIS W. DOUGLAS in the current Atlantic.

Two dozen inmates of Alcatraz prison near San Francisco, which shelters the most desperate criminals in Federal custody, are pursuing correspondence courses with the University of California. The head of the United States Prison Bureau at Washington says there is no objection to such extracurricular activities at Alcatraz, provided the prisoners do it on their own time.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Pennsylvania's graduated income tax law, passed at the last session of the Legislature to lighten the burden on real estate, was declared unconstitutional today by the State Supreme Court in a unanimous decision.

The Consolidated Gas Company of New York and four of its subsidiary gas and electric corporations began suit yesterday in the United States District Court to test the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, which was approved by the President Aug. 25.

Automobile accidents declined in New York City last week-end 23 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, figures of the Police Department showed yesterday. Fatalities resulting from such accidents showed a decline of 5.27 per cent.

BOSTON, Tuesday, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The Globe, in a copyrighted story, says that investigators, seeking new evidence in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted kidnapper of the Linbergh baby, have discovered, in Massachusetts, wood they believe is identical with that from which the kidnap ladder was constructed and handwriting samples they believe match the ransom notes.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25. -- Bancroft Hall, where the middies live, burst forth today with the pep slogans which bloom during the week before the Army game. The words "Beat Army," worked out in electric globes of blue and gold, top the main entrance, while Tecumseh, "the god of 2.5," has been given an artistic coat of war paint with the same colors predominating.

WAKE ISLAND, Tuesday, Nov. 26. -- Again with the first daylight yesterday the China Clipper was on her way westward, bound for another stretch of her 8,000-mile hurdle of the Pacific, a third of the distance around the globe, to speed the first United States air mail to the Philippines.

Reports yesterday on new charge and instalment accounts being opened confirm the expectation of retail executives here that credit sales are playing no small part in the development of Christmas trade. One store manager stated that more than three times as many charge accounts are being opened at this time in comparison with the same period last year.

The Short Hills Club team captured its second match in a row in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association tournament when it shut out the Princeton Club, 5 -- 0, yesterday on the latter's courts. Only two other teams, the Columbia Club and the City A.C., remain unbeaten.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 25 (AP). -- In honor of the centenary of the birth of Andrew Carnegie, a special "peace exhibition" was opened today in the Palace of Peace of the World Court.

The campaign of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies to raise $365,000 for the federation's ninety-one affiliated institutions entered its final stage yesterday with the announcement that $292,930 had been raised.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 25. -- Six of fifty Ethiopian deserters from the Italian forces, twenty-eight of whom arrived here yesterday after terrible sufferings on the journey, died of thirst and disease in the Danakil Desert.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- British acquiescence in the French demand for a postponement at Geneva of action on oil sanctions against Italy has already aroused the first rumblings of the inevitable criticism that the Baldwin government, safely returned to power, is now prepared to sell out the League of Nations.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 (AP). -- Proportional representation -- a plan to insure an equitable voice in government for all citizens -- received approval today from two champions of political reform.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of $65,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due in 1965, by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, N. J., was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25. -- President Getulio Vargas, with the backing of his Senate and Chamber, placed all of Brazil in a state of siege tonight to crush a Leftist uprising. The Senate, in an emergency session, approved a sixty-day state of siege by a vote of 25 to 3 and the President quickly put the measure into force.

Dean Willard C. Rappleye of the Columbia Medical School, in his annual report to the trustees, made public yesterday, asserted that physicians and hospitals that provide medical service for the unemployed should be paid by the community through taxation, philanthropy and hospital insurance.

Lady Leslie gave a dinner last night at the Plaza. Among her guests were Mr. and Mrs. J. Fred Pierson, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Grover, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ludlum, Mrs. M. Bernard Philipp, Miss Thelma Mays, Mrs. Dorothy L. Norris, Lawrence Smith Butler, Bryn Strandines, Albert H. Clayburgh and A. James Sheldon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Captain John F. Milliken of New York, president of the United Licensed Officers' Association, today charged that government-owned merchant vessels were openly violating the safety sections of the navigation laws and suggested that Secretary of Commerce Roper, who has been designated by President Roosevelt as chairman of a conference on safety, "straighten out the government fleet before requesting the private operators to do anything."

The Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation has called for redemption its first and refunding mortgage and other 5 per cent bonds. The aggregate principal amount is $37,182,000, which will call for a disbursement of $40,162,771 with premiums and interest.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The British Parliament was completed today, with the announcement in late returns of the election of three members for the combined Scottish universities. One of the men elected, at least technically, according to the count of the ballots, was Noel Skelton, who died last Friday.

ATHENS, Nov. 25. -- King George's landing at Phaleron was marked by an unrecorded mutiny. Mutineers were a score of international newspaper men who found themselves prisoners aboard one of the escorting destroyers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Chicago is no longer the crime centre of the world, that distinction having moved to New York, said Frank J. Loesch, president of the Crime Commission, in a talk before members of the Union League Club today.

A bill to increase the license fees for hunting, fishing and trapping will be introduced before the 1936 Legislature, it was predicted yesterday by Thomas E. Brady of White Plains on his return from the annual convention of the New York State Conservation Council at Albany.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The distinguished diplomat, Lord Tyrrell, former British Ambassador to Paris, today was unanimously elected as the new British film censor succeeding the late Edward Shortt, who had been President of the board since 1929.

If the Constitution is not to fail in the purpose for which it was written, it must be flexible and adaptable enough to meet fundamental social and economic changes, asserts Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper in an article entitled, "Forward With the Constitution," in the December Current History.

WEST POINT, Nov. 25. -- Army, going into the stretch in its preparation for the Navy game in Philadelphia next Saturday, staged a long drill on the Plains gridiron today. Gar Davidson had his entire squad working, all hands being in top physical condition.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The Misses Helen Dorothy Brownhill, 75, and Isabelle Clark, 62, inseparable friends for thirty years, ended their lives together today by agreement in the apartment they had shared for sixteen years.

HAVANA, Nov. 25. -- The government strove today to conciliate political parties so that the general elections set for Dec. 15 can be held. The Cabinet meeting scheduled for this afternoon to consider the situation was postponed until tomorrow to give further time to the various factions to formulate a solution of the problem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Testimony that practical television "is still quite a distance in the future" was received today at a Federal Communications Commission hearing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- Despite the runaway race of the Smith brothers, Phil and Dannie, of Rutgers, the Alfred University team from upper New York State finished in a bunch to beat the favored Scarlet, 32 to 33, at Buccleuch Park today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25. -- In his first winning performance since being acquired by A.C. Compton, the Dodge colt Dartle today electrified his admirers when he survived a nose finish in the featured Edward Andros Handicap to return $17.60 for $2.

In one of the stormiest and most critical meetings in its history, the Actors Equity Association stood by its administrative officers yesterday afternoon and hurled back the challenge of the Actors Forum, insurgent group within Equity.
The birthday anniversary of Andrew Carnegie, who was born 100 years ago yesterday in Dunfermline, Scotland, was commemorated last night with a concert at Carnegie Hall.

Builders in many of the active home development centres in and adjacent to Queens Borough report the demand for medium-priced dwellings is much keener at this time than has been the case for four or five years. This well-sustained demand is leading to the completion of plans for considerable Winter building, and in many of the communities building sites are being purchased by prospective home owners for early residential improvement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP). -- Attorneys for the Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Massachusetts asked the Supreme Court today to allow a jury to decide on its $15,000,000 anti-trust damage claim against Radio Corporation of America.
Just how an America's Cup challenge is handled was shown in the report of the cup committee of the New York Yacht Club made public yesterday. The report in port was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- By selling a $2,288,000 block of debentures of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation to the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York for $1,844,104.72, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today took itself out of the public utility business.

Out of 1,500 etchings submitted by artists from forty-four States, 263 have been accepted for the twentieth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, and cash prizes have been awarded to five, with two honorable mentions. The show is to be open to the public tomorrow, following a private view today, at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

THE nice thing about ice hockey is that old feuds never die. Somebody always steps in to keep the pot boiling. The Rangers Just finished a stirring session with their ancient enemies, the Boston Bruins, and now the star-spangled Americans are ready to take a slash or two at M'sieu Lestairre Patrick's Blue Shirts in the first battle of the Winter series for metropolitan supremacy.

TOKYO, Nov. 25. -- Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, today sharply warned Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, financial expert of the British Foreign Office, who is now in China, not to interfere with the autonomy movement in Northern China.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Unexpectedly strong cables from Liverpool lifted the prices of domestic and Canadian wheat fractionally at the opening of the markets today, but selling pressure immediately appeared from houses with Eastern connections and disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

Thomas F. Maguire, a clerk in the office of District Attorney William C. Dodge, testified yesterday in the loan shark prosecutions in Special Sessions, that he had borrowed $50 from Edward Libman in the entrance to the Department of Health Building at 139 Centre Street, in November, 1934, and still owed it the following March. The District Attorney's office is at 137 Centre Street.

We have read with interest your editorial "More Meters Needed," in which you propound the question, "Why has New York failed to adopt universal metering?" You believe that the installation of water meters would "prevent waste, reduce costs and free every thrifty householder from the financial burden of having to pay for his shiftless neighbor's leaky faucets."

A prediction that the proposed transit unification plan recently completed would bring to the city treasury $9,000,000 more a year than is being received under the present system was made last night by City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., who with Samuel Seabury conducted the negotiations with the rapid transit companies.
Prices of commodity futures were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. In the cash market, rye, butter and tin were higher, while wheat, corn, eggs, silk and rubber were lower.
ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP). -- The up-State Works Progress Administration machinery slipped into high gear tonight in an effort to extend its job-giving program to all employable men and women by Dec. 1.

Alfred E. Smith praised the "great work" of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Barclay and Church Streets, at an entertainment program at the Waldorf-Astoria last night that closed an eight-day period of festivities celebrating the sesquicentennial of the parish.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25. -- The Liberal Government, led by Premier L.A. Taschereau, was returned to power in today's provincial election by the slimmest majority in the history of Quebec. At 10:30 P.M. the returns indicated forty-eight government supporters had been returned.

Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, declared upon his return from Europe last night that American gasoline was prolonging the Italian-Ethiopian War and that "the United States is becoming a major base of supply for Italy."

The prosecution closed its evidence in General Sessions yesterday in the trial of three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company, charged with publishing a false statement, on Jan. 13, 1933, of the company's financial condition as of the preceding Dec. 31.

Three triple-headers and one doubleheader constitute the first organized program of scholastic basketball games to be played in Madison Square Garden this Winter, according to an announcement made yesterday at the Gridiron Club by Ned Irish, director of basketball activities in the Garden.

Marion Kerby presented a program of "Negro exaltations" and Kentucky mountain songs at the Town Hall last night. Under "Negro exaltations" were listed: "Yo' Must Come in by de Do'," "I'm So Glad Dat Trouble Don't Las' Always," "Jonah's Band," "Rock de Cradle, Mary," and "Dry Bones."

GENEVA, Nov. 25. -- The International Labor Organization's preparatory maritime conference began a two weeks' session here today with 50,000,000 of the world's 63,000,000 tons of merchant marine represented by government, employer and labor delegates.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The demand for hogs here today was less aggressive, especially from the East, as purchases made today would not arrive there in time to be killed on Wednesday and with a holiday on Thursday it would necessitate carrying them over.

BUFFALO, Nov. 25. -- Between seven and eight hundred WPA workers who have been on strike here to enforce the prevailing rate of wages agreed this afternoon to call off their strike and return to work tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25. -- The listing committee of the San Francisco Stock Exchange today announced it had approved the application of the General Motors Corporation to list both its common and preferred stock.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries report for the year ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net income of $8,754,885 after all deductions, equal to $5.84 a share on 1,499,478 shares of $6 dividend preferred stock, compared with $8,152,716, or $5.44 a share, in the preceding year.

Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis 3d, the former Grace Vanderbilt, who returned on the Europa last night with her mother, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, after a visit of about six weeks abroad, declined to discuss a published report that she will seek a divorce from her husband.

The proposal of the Department of Docks that the harbor lines on the westerly side of the East River be altered to provide park space adjoining the proposed East Side express highway was attacked yesterday by Eugene F. Moran, chairman of the rivers, harbors and piers committee of the Maritime Association.

As an enthusiastic motorist who has driven some thirty thousand miles over American roads during the past year, solely for recreation, I have followed with considerable interest your editorial and epistolary comments upon the hazards of motoring and remedial suggestions.

Desirous of illustrating what the modern State has done and is doing in the realm of mural art, both at home and abroad, the Cosmopolitan Club organized an exhibition, which opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the clubhouse, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.

WAKE ISLAND, Tuesday, Nov. 26. -- With 5,000 miles of the Pacific Ocean behind her, the China Clipper landed here at 1:40 P.M. today (9:40 P.M. Monday, Eastern standard time) after a fast flight from Midway Island.

The twelve-story Hotel Embassy at the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventieth Street and five three-story taxpayers at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twentieth Street were among the Manhattan parcels bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:

Doris Wacker, a young dancing teacher, told a jury in Federal court yesterday about her experiences aboard the Ward liner Morro Castle when that vessel was burning off Asbury Park, N.J., on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Tiny spores of plant diseases spread by winds, of which millions representing seven types of fungi were carried to 72,395 feet by the stratosphere balloon recently, can survive atmospheric conditions under which a human would perish, results of tests announced today showed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of 101 leading cities on Nov. 20 shows no change for the week in total loans and investments, an increase of $99,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $20,000,000 in time deposits and of 944,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 25. -- The Italian advance northward along the Fafan Valley has collapsed with the Ethiopian reoccupation of Gabredarre, north of Gorahai, and the apparent recapture of Gorahai itself. This and other factors have caused a resurgence of Ethiopian confidence and a complete relaxation of the tension so evident a few days ago.

Looking forward to their Thanksgiving Day battle at Ebbets Field which is likely to decide the Easttern division race in the National Football League, the New York Giants find themselves nearer full strength than at any other time this season, while the Brooklyn Dodgers bemoan the probable loss of Stan Kostka, fullback, recuperating from a broken rib.

Members of the Board of Aldermen clashed yesterday with a group of pedagogues over the question of whether formal education was desirable as a prerequisite for admission or promotion in the city civil service system.

If WPA officials insist upon charging admission to concerts by unemployed musicians Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians will demand payment of the union scale of wages, and, if necessary, will call a strike on Dec. 5 to enforce payment of union rates.

It is not true that the League of Nations has abruptly given up the plan to deprive Italy of oil. It has postponed action on it for "some days," owing to the urgent request of the French Government that action be delayed. Premier LAVAL is in political and financial difficulties at home, and evidently fears that his position would be further imperiled if an added and drastic sanction were applied to Italy.

The theatre picked up another careless stranger last evening and carted him home to the Fulton. Let the name be "The Ragged Edge" and say at once that such minor satisfaction as may accrue should go to Al Woods. Sitting in his rooms in radio's newest showplace, he may find pleasure in the fact that he has done the impossible, politely speaking.

After a special meeting of the New York Yacht Club yesterday afternoon, it was announced that the challenge of the Royal London Yacht Club for the America's Cup on behalf of Charles R. Fairey had been withdrawn. Details of the negotiations between the two organizations, replete with apologies and thanks, were given out at the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The international military jump, over a course that required skilled manoeuvring of mounts on short turns and criss-cross jumps, was won by Wampum of the United States Army team, ridden by Captain C.C. Jadwin, in the feature event tonight of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Continuation of substantial gains in employment, with nearly 250,000 workers returned to jobs in private industry in October and an increase of $8,200,000 in weekly payrolls, was reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

So far Young Republicans, 1935 style, have seemed to live in peace and amity with one another. They have scarcely a harsh word to throw at the reactionaries and the Old Guard. Indeed, some meetings of these signs and harbingers of Republican rejuvenation have an air, doubtless false, of being inspired and prompted by older and therefore more malign heads.

Judge Charles C. Nott in General Sessions forfeited yesterday afternoon the $15,000 cash bail furnished last August for William F. Peterson, 52 years old, on two grand jury indictments arising from his promotion of an alleged "get-rich-quick" investment scheme.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Marshall Field Co. today announced a sweeping reorganization of its wholesale department, which now is to be known as the manufacturing division. It will deal in goods manufactured or imported by the company and will cease to operate as a jobber of products manufactured by others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Andrew Carnegie was described by Secretary Hull today as "an apostle of peace who deserves to be known as a great citizen of the Americas" in an address as chairman of the Governing Board of the Pan American Union at a ceremony commemorating the hundredth anniversary of the philanthropist's birth.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 25. -- Salaam, 5-year-old gelding owned by C.E. Davison, captured the $800 Alamo claiming purse, feature of today's program at Epsom Downs.

PARIS, Nov. 26. -- Premier Pierre Laval's chances of carrying his government beyond its first encounter with the Chamber of Deputies Thursday have considerably improved during the past forty-eight hours. Tonight in a broadcast address to the country he showed that he himself had recovered from the depression from which he was suffering some days ago when he announced to his friends that he would be glad to be defeated.

WEST POINT, Nov. 26. -- Army's final preparations were badly disrupted today when Lieutenant Moe Daly, line coach, was suddenly stricken with appendicitis in Lieutenant Gar Davidson's office while outlining a defense against Navy's spread formations, and was rushed to the post hospital for an emergency operation.

Under the official tumult of life in Washington the authors of "First Lady" have perceived the snarls and screams of a backstairs catfight. Jane Cowl has conspired with them to make a brilliant comedy out of it for patrons of the Music Box, where it opened last evening.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 26. -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, sounded a warning tonight against increasing Federal influence in city government. He spoke at the final session of the convention of the National Municipal League, of which he is president.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- From official sources it was learned today that Walther Schulze, better known as Schulze-Wechsungen, director of the provincial office for Berlin, Brandenburg and Kurmark of the Propaganda Ministry, had been relieved of all his duties on account of financial irregularities and that he faced trial.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a bill of complaint in the Federal court here yesterday against the Electric Bond and Share Company and five affiliated holding companies, in an effort to reduce the number of injunctions which utility companies are seeking against the Public Utility Act.

In the last issue of "Bird Lore," published by the National Association of Audubon Societies, its editor, William Vogt, writes entertainingly of his experiences as unofficial observer on an aerial survey of duck breeding grounds conducted in the prairie regions of Canada last August.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26. -- The Central Asian Soviet Republics have for the first time filled their cotton quotas ahead of schedule by delivering 1,500,000 tons to the State warehouse by Nov. 25.
BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The Boerse was almost totally inactive today, showing some signs of weakness around the opening and some evidence of firmness toward the close.
Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share and a stock dividend of 3 per cent.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Between orders for a ham on rye and a cup of coffee the mystery of the spectator who suddenly joined the Dartmouth football squad last Saturday in an effort to hold off the oncoming Princeton Tigers was solved today from behind the counter of a dining car lunch wagon on Farrell Place here.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Nov. 26. -- At Ewing's Landing, on the shores of Okanagan Lake, thirty miles from Vernon, B.C., sit members of a British family, carrying on with their daily tasks and outwardly showing nothing of the strain of waiting, which takes their minds and hearts to the icy wastes of Antarctica.

The Class I railroads reported yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission that for the first time this year they earned in September a balance above their interest charges, Returns by 149 roads showed that in September they had a net income of $13,542,934, contrasted with a net loss of $2,267,477 in the preceding month and a net loss of $1,179,163 in September, 1934.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press). -- A big brown gelding, Blarney Castle, of the Irish Free State Army team, with Commandant J. G. O'Dwyer up, defeated an international field tonight in the featured military touch-and-out stake at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

The Musical Art Quartet, which has an honorable record as a purveyor of chamber music, began its tenth subscription season at the Town Hall last night. The ensemble, consisting of Sascha Jacobsen, Paul Bernard, Louis Kievman and Marie Roemaet-Rosanoff, was augmented by a visiting violist, William Hymanson, for the Mozart quintet in G minor, Koechel No. 516.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26. -- Another prize of the waning Eastern season fell to C.V. Whitney today at Bowie when the sulky colt, Rough Diamond, by the moody Mad Hatter, came from last place to be first at the wire in the Mayor Howard Jackson trophy race.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan and Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas, two prospective candidates for the Republican nomination for President, have been invited to speak at the annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club, it was learned yesterday.

READING, Pa., Nov. 26. -- In an address delivered here tonight R.V. Fletcher, general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, recommended that the railroads of the country be permitted to govern themselves, to consolidate without supervision and to have less rigid direction by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Among the passengers arriving on the French liner Champlain are Lady Mendl, also known as Elsie de Wolfe; Mme. Ganna-Wralska, Serge Rovinsky, Russian painter; Raymond Lavondes, newly appointed Minister from France to Central America; Clifford C. Fischer, Bernard Boutet de Monvel, French portrait painter; Elissa Landi, actress, and

The City Athletic Club, Bayside Tennis Club and Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club teams were victorious in the second series of matches in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group II tournament last night. All three teams won by the same score, 3 to 2.

Whether Johnny Woods, the "stimulated" twin of the recent experiment in infantile behavior patterns, is superior to Jimmy, the un-stimulated twin, is problematical, but the value of "stimulation," per se, remains unimpaired, according to Dr. Myrtle B. McGraw, research psychologist who superintended the experiment.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- John Howeson, one-time dictator of the world's tin industry, was among three business men who appeared at the Mansion House Court today on criminal charges arising from the pepper crash of last Winter.

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- The house of delegates of the State Teachers Association adopted a resolution this afternoon without debate advocating "that sort of academic freedom which permits the teacher the complete liberty of political conduct and thought to which he is entitled as an American citizen."

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange remained dull and restricted today because of the uncertainty of the situation in France. The exception was the operations in British funds following a successful start.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The Prince of Wales, presiding at a dinner of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, said tonight he was happy to take advantage of the presence of Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador, to request him to convey thanks to the Carnegie Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation for making possible the publication of two volumes of the Survey of British Commonwealth Relations.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday for listing the securities of seven companies previously traded on other Exchanges. Of these companies five were traded on the New York Curb Exchange, one on the San Francisco Stock Exchange and one on the Chicago Stock Exchange.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 26. -- The man whom Emperor Haile Selassie feared most, Lij Yasu, deposed King of Ethiopia, is dead. It was announced officially that he had died of "general paralysis" in the luxurious prison at Mount Cara Mouleta, where he had been confined for three years.
Top price for the opening day of the forty-first annual Old Glory sale of light harness horses, which began yesterday morning in Squadron A Armory, was $7,000.

The second International Exhibition of Leica Photographs opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in the Mezzanine Galleries of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. Approximately 300 camera studies are on display, including work by many widely known American photographers.

Selected as the book published in the last three years, most likely to become an American classic, "An Almanac for Moderns," won for its author, Donald Culross Peattie, a gold medal yesterday. The award was made by the Limited Editions Club at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria, which was attended by 100 authors, editors and publishers.

Creation by private enterprise of a low-cost housing industry which should have potential annual sales of "two or three times those of the automobile industry" and a truce in the "mud-battle" between business and government "in order to do something for the average man" were urged yesterday by Professor Raymond Moley, editor of Today and formerly Under-Secretary of State.
Total cash dividend payments in 1935 by the companies composing the Standard Oil group are estimated at $170,078,682, compared with $169,092,529 in 1934, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here, selling being influenced by weakness in Liverpool and also in Minneapolis. While buying against bids brought about some recovery from the low point, the finish was at net losses of 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel.

The first diphtheria death in six weeks in the city occurred last week in Queens, the Department of Health reported yesterday. The total for the year to date is fifty-six, compared with ninety-five during the corresponding period last year.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The opinion is gaining ground among government officials here that Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, government financial expert, should be urged to leave China without delay before he does serious harm to Britain's political interests in the Far East.

A tribute to the memory of Andrew Carnegie as the man who more than any other of his time "transformed giving from an ill-developed art into a well-regulated science" was paid last night by Sir James Irvine, principal and vice chancellor of St. Andrew's University of Fife, Scotland.

Details of the remodeling of the Manhattan Opera House, which will play host to Max Reinhardt's spectacle, "The Eternal Road," next January (instead of Dec. 23), were made available yesterday by Norman Bel Geddes, who is designing the scenery; Franz Werfel, author of "The Eternal Road"; Meyer W. Weisgal, its producer, and Mr. Reinhardt.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2.839,950 barrels, compared with 2,850,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 10,650, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 14,850 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and of 7,400 in California were partly offset by a gain of 11,750 in Texas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Labor bodies all over the country are being notified of the drive for industrial unions, as against craft unions, in letters sent out this week by the Committee for Industrial Organization.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- The coming Winter Olympics at Garmish-Partenkirchen received today official recognition as a Nazi propaganda undertaking by the appointment of Councilor Wilfred Bade of the Reich Propaganda Ministry to the organization committee for the Winter Olympics.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 26. -- Thomas Peter Jr., 17 years old, of Bruce Park Avenue, died this afternoon in the Stamford Hospital after a three-car collision on the Boston Post Road in Stamford last night. Nine persons were injured, five of whom are in the Stamford Hospital The condition of three is serious.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Nash Beadleston gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. L. Loomis White, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon T. Coleman, Mr. and Mrs. F.N. Fanshawe White, Mrs. M. Lawrence Keene, Miss. Jessie J. Fanshawe and William F. White.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The Elizabeth Town and Country Club took the lead in Division B of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets Association when it defeated the Montclair Athletic Club, with which it had previously shared the lead, today, by 3 -- 2.

Contributions totaling $527,000 in cash and signed pledges have been collected by the United Hospital Campaign Committee, including a donation from Mayor La Guardia, who became the first city employe to contribute to the fund, it was announced yesterday.

The governors of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York yesterday elected as president Robert R. Piper to succeed Charles H.C. Pearsall, who resigned to accept the presidency of the national organization. Mr. Piper is treasurer of the United Dry Docks, Inc., and has served as vice president of the Propeller Club of New York.

The Emergency Relief Bureau announced yesterday that no more applications for home relief, except dire cases, would be considered pending disposal of 25,000 cases now awaiting investigation. This indicated that no new cases would be taken for at least a month.

Beaming with happiness at the prospect of a dream she was sure would come true, a black-garbed, bespectacled grandmother from the banks of the Wabash arrived in New York yesterday. She had no eyes for the city's sights, no ears for its hubbub, though she encountered them for the first time.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Trustees oil the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company announced today that on Dec. 1, E.M. Durham Jr. will become chief executive officer, with jurisdiction over all departments. They said the appointment was made "with the hearty approval of James E. Gorman, who remains with the system as president of the company and as trustee under appointment of the United States District Court."

Price movements in yesterday's stock market were dictated by a steady stream of profit-taking sales on the one hand and by cautious buying on the other. The net result was a slowing down of the trading pace, with a heavy tone prevalent virtually all day.
The formal opening of Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, took place yesterday with the arrival of Big Rosie, the Hippodrome elephant, at the very door of the shop, laden with merchandise.
TIENTSIN, Nov. 26. -- The Japanese military extended its activities to the Tientsin civil airport today, nearly causing an international incident.

Cathedrals, churches and synagogues throughout the city will hold Thanksgiving services tomorrow morning. Virtually all the houses of worship on the main thoroughfares of Manhattan will have individual services. Some of the churches and synagogues on the East and West Sides and in the Fort Washington section will hold union worship.

It becomes increasingly apparent that only bad weather will prevent the sixty or seventy thousand who go to the Fordham-N.Y.U. game at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow from seeing one of the most wide-open football contests ever played in this section.

Benjamin F. Spellman, lawyer, of 115 Broadway, was appointed referee yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy to conduct hearings and determine whether the operation of pin games in amusement centres was a violation of the Esquirol act.

The sale of the three six-story flats with stores at the northwest corner of Hudson and Leroy Streets in the commercial and industrial centre of lower Manhattan was one of the interesting deals reported by brokers yesterday.

I was greatly pleased with your editorial on organized medical research in which you praise "team-work." It so happens that I have been working on the problem of the prolongation of life under grants of foundations that feature the prima-donna "genius" and also with some of the smaller teams that have been forming spontaneously at the universities and at some progressive hospitals.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 26. -- Three of the most important British journalists here have made strong oral protests to their consul against what they describe as the virtual taking over of the British Consulate, on a mountainside overlooking Harar, by two American correspondents.
LONDON, Nov. 26. -- C.R. Attlee and Sir Archibald Sinclair were elected leaders today respectively of the Labor and Liberal Oppositions in the new Parliament.
BERLIN, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Nov. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

THE TIMES published recently a statement by the Rev. H.E. Woolever, editor of The National Methodist Press, to the effect that "missionaries should be sent to CCC camps to help check the drinking, gambling and other vices found there."

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Nov. 27. -- Spurred to action by autonomy developments in North China, the Nanking Government yesterday sent General Chang Chun, Governor of Hupeh Province, and Tang Yu-jen, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, to Shanghai to discuss a settlement of the Chino-Japanese relations and a reorganization of the Central Government with Ambassador Akira Ariyoshi of Japan and General Rensuke Isogai, the Japanese Military Attache.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- A cash payment of $1,636,363.74 will be made to the creditors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York on or soon after Friday, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

GUAM, Wednesday, Nov. 27. -- Forty-nine minutes ahead of schedule and with a thirty-mile tail wind stepping up her speed to almost 170 miles an hour for the last two hours, the Pan American Airways flagship China Clipper thundered down the coast of Guam this afternoon with the first ocean air mail for this island, en route to the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The Shipping Board Bureau Terminal in Brooklyn will be kept in operation from tomorrow, when the present lessee terminates his contract, until Jan. 1, when it is hoped a new tenant will take it over, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The determination of the administration to maintain its neutrality policy in the East African controversy independently and undeterred by what the League of Nations or other governments might do was emphatically asserted today on high official authority.

Formation of Harris, Hall Co. to carry on the investment business in the underwriting of corporate securities done by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, was announced yesterday by Albert W. Harris, chairman of the bank, in a letter to stockholders.

With the America's Cup challenge of the Royal London Yacht Club for Charles R. Fairey withdrawn and the way clear for T.O.M. Sopwith to challenge for a match in 1937, which he had hoped to do, the wheels of negotiation were set in motion yesterday for an international contest among 12-meter sloops on this side of the Atlantic next Summer.

BERLIN, Nov. 26. -- An appeal addressed to all nations to open their gates to Jews forced to emigrate from Germany was published today all across the front page of the Jewish Review, the Zionist newspaper published in Berlin.

VIENNA, Nov. 26. -- A striking indication of the current progress in cultural relations between Soviet Russia and the Czechoslovak republic was furnished on Saturday night by the first performance in Central Europe of Dimitri Shostakovich's sensational propagandistic opera "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk" at the National Theatre in Bratislava.

RED BANK, N. J., Nov. 26. -- The prosecuting authorities of Monmouth County were working on the theory tonight that a woman shot and killed John H. Blanford, 40-year-old gardener and war veteran, whose body was found under mysterious circumstances late last night in the small house he occupied on the estate of Mrs. J. Amory Haskell, elderly widow of a former vice president of the General Motors Corporation.

Two of the most famous college football classes of recent years shared the national spotlight on Saturday at Princeton and Palo Alto as the Tigers won general acclaim as the best team in the East and Stanford wrecked California's Rose Bowl hopes.

New York has a number of private hospitals, operated for profit, which care only for those who can pay the full cost. It has also twenty-six municipal hospitals, operated solely for relief of the destitute. In between stand ninety-eight philanthropically supported hospitals, "privately run, non-profit in- ''stitutions, serving all classes and all "conditions of people, but predomi- "nantly the great middle class, which "must rely on them for its sole protec- "tion, and the poor."

The eleven music publishing houses controlled by Warner Brothers Pictures resigned late yesterday afternoon from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers because of dissatisfaction with the amount of royalties collected by the society from radio broadcasting stations.

Thomas Frank Hoey, who became keeper of the Central Park Zoo bears when the sheepfold became the Tavern-on-the-Green, went home early yesterday to spend the day nursing a badly bitten right index finger and pondering the differences between bears and sheep.

The spokesmen of union labor in the maritime trade indicated yesterday that they considered the acceptance of freight destined for Italy a matter to be decided upon by the ship lines and that they were prepared to accept employment wherever it was offered as long as wage and working contracts were maintained.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The contention that the Guffey Act comes under the commerce clause of the Constitution and is a valid exercise of Congressional power was made before Justice Jesse C. Adkins in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today by John Dickinson, Assistant Attorney General, in the government's defense of the act against the attack on its constitutionality by James W. Carter, president of the Carter Coal Company.

Everything went, and no holds barred, as the Rangers subdued the Americans in the first meeting of the season between New York's hockey teams at Madison Square Garden last night. The victory was scored by the slimmest possible margin, 1 to 0, and the goal that decided the issue was scored by Butch Keeling, spare left forward on Lester Patrick's sextet.
Business failures declined in all trade groups in the week ended Nov. 21 compared with the five business days ended Nov. 14, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- With many former Red and Blue stars on the sidelines, the Penn varsity today held its last hard practice before the forty-second game with Cornell. There was no contact work.

Ernest Lee Jahncke, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and one of three American members of the International Olympic Committee, informed European Olympic officials yesterday that he would oppose American participation in the 1936 games in Berlin.

CORNING, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Completion of the 200-inch glass eye for the world's largest telescope, announced today at the Corning Glass Works, means that in about five years man will see four times further into space than ever before.
Turkey costs about eight cents more a pound than at the corresponding time last year, but there will be no lack of it tomorrow on the Thanksgiving Day festive boards of this city.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- An epidemic of colds, the result of exposure last Saturday on the snowy turf of Palmer Stadium, struck the Princeton football squad today. Steve Cullinan and Johnny Weller, first-string linemen, spent the day in the infirmary, while no less than nine others who played against Dartmouth are suffering from slight attacks.

Four Manhattan properties and five Bronx parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Among the Manhattan offerings was the ten-story Schlegel Building at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Twenty-second Street, taken over by the Seamen's Bank for Savings on a $100,000 bid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- An attack on the South's farm tenant problem, involving removal of 1,000 tenants on to small farms of their own, was revealed today by Rexford G. Tugwell.

The Supreme Court decision, suspending payment of processing taxes, caused a number of dry goods buyers yesterday to hold off on future commitments, as various interpretations were put on the ruling. Many professed to see in the decision an augury that the processing taxes themselves would be held unconstitutional, while others regarded the ruling merely as a technical clarification of the status of the collection of the taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Eleven offering sheets of various oil interests were received by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the week ended on Nov. 23. The commission again cautioned that the act of filing does not give to a security its approval or indicate that the commission has passed on its merits or that the matter filed is correct. A list of the filings follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Commenting on the suit brought in New York against the Electric Bond and Share Company and five subsidiaries to force compliance with the Public Utility Act of 1935, the SEC expressed belief today that it would afford an opportunity for a speedy determination of the constitutionality of the act, and indicated that if any other suits were brought, they would be few.
The long vigil on old Rose Hill has begun. Quietly, but determinedly, word was spread on the Fordham campus yesterday that the Maroon mascot will not be kidnapped.

Sam Langford, the "Boston Tar Baby" who boxed the best of them between 1902 and 1923, called at City Hall yesterday at Mayor La Guardia's invitation, confessed that he was broke, and went away with a job.

RIO DE JANERIO, Wednesday, Nov. 27. -- Bitter fighting between loyal vigilantes and seditious, communistic soldiers was reported early today in dispatches from the revolt-torn State of Rio Grande do Norte.
A mortgage for $35,000 on 178-80 West Brohvay. held by Pauline Cohen. from the Concourse .sttes Corp., has been reduced to $25,000 and the interest rate reduced from 6 to 5 per cent.

The number of visiting buyers registered here during the week ended yesterday was slightly under the figures for the preceding week and also below the corresponding week of last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 683, as against 697 in the previous week and 715 in the same period last year.

Conflicting influences resulted in rather confused trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Reactionary tendencies dominated many of the recently favored issues, particularly in the industrial group, while railroad liens lacked the buoyancy that had characterized them recently.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 26. -- Behind the newly formulated employe relationship policy of the Tennessee Valley Authority lie two years of experiment in that field during which there has not been a single strike among the 17,000 employes.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 26. -- An Ethiopian communique late tonight confirmed reports of an Italian rout on the southern front. It was stated the invaders were repulsed in confusion, abandoning tanks, armored cars and loaded trucks.

"Boy Meets Girl," which is a saga about a couple of mad gentlemen in Hollywood, will open at the Cort Theatre. Bella and Samuel Spewack wrote it, and in the company are Joyce Arling, Jerome Cowan, Allyn Joslyn, Royal Beal, James MacColl and Charles McClelland.

The Brillo Manufacturing Company, Inc., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $99,698 after depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on 25,394 shares of $2 Class A stock, the earnings equal 38 cents a share on 160,000 shares of common stock. In the first nine months of last year the company had a net profit of $114,573, or 47 cents a common share.

The campaign for a Will Rogers memorial was extended yesterday across the Atlantic to include the American humorist's many friends in London and continental Europe. Wilson Cross, president of the American Club in London, was named chairman of the committee to receive contributions in that city and on the Continent.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 26. -- Ras Nasibu, commanding the Ethiopian forces at Jijiga, telephoned to Emperor Halle Selassie tonight that couriers arriving at Jijiga today brought the news that the Italians were retreating in the south.

NANKING, Wednesday, Nov. 27 (AP). -- A high government official told The Associated Press today that the Chinese Government had determined to meet with force any move to impose the autonomy program on the territory south of the borders of Hopei and Chahar Provinces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Rights by custom, long recognized by English law, do not exist in the State of New York, Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley ruled today in a long decision which cited many authorities.
Three medals were presented last night by the American Geographical Society at a monthly meeting held at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The British Cabinet will meet tomorrow and discuss the whole Ethiopian problem. It will be particularly concerned with the question whether Britain shall press for sanctions in oil against Italy. The next indication of policy may be expected in the Address from the Throne at the opening of the new Parliament next Tuesday.

A copy of the rare earliest issue of Thomas Gray's "An Elegy Wrote in a Country Church Yard," issued in 1751 at the price of six pence, was sold last night for $2,100 at the Rains Galleries at the auction of the library of William D. Breaker of Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- The only personal opposition to the proposed minimum wage for women and minors in hotels and restaurants appeared at the hearing conducted by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, today. He was Moses L. Kove of the Hotel Men's Association of Sullivan, Ulster and Greene Counties.

A new issue of $11,710,900 Metropolitan Edison Company first mortgage, series G, 4 per cent bonds, due on May 1, 1965, will be placed on the market today by a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 102 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield more than 3.85 per cent.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Gathered once again in special session to grapple with the perplexing financial difficulties of the Boston Braves, the club owners of the National League yesterday by unanimous vote declared the Boston franchise forfeited to the league.

A special meeting of stockholders of the American General Corporation was called yesterday for Dec. 30 by the directors to take action on a charter amendment by which all series of the company's preferred stock would be made convertible into common stock at the ratio of two common shares for one of preferred.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Contending that the Public Utility Act of 1935 is unconstitutional, the North American Company filed an equity suit in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia today to enjoin the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Attorney General and the Postmaster General from seeking to enforce the act, which, the company declares, threatens its personnel and management and endangers the interests of its 72,000 stockholders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26. -- Bennett Y. Ryan, Harvard junior and son of a New York magazine publisher, was dismissed from college today by a vote of the college administrative board. He will not be allowed to return to Harvard at any later date.

The Kings County grand jury indicted Meyer and Morris Luckman, cousins, and others not yet in custody for the murder of Sam Druckman, and handed up a presentment yesterday to County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn, asking permission to continue their investigation into charges of malfeasance against police and other officials connected with the ease.

Reports that Prime Minister BALDWIN is now hesitant about complete support of the League of Nations and going through decisively with sanctions under Article XVI of the Covenant must be gratuitous. He may be in doubt just at what date to proceed with his program, but his intent to proceed cannot well be questioned.

Representatives of fifteen important wholesale dry goods buying offices, meeting yesterday at the office of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, formed a new organization to be known as the Association of Dry Goods Wholesalers New York Representatives.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 26. -- Stone Webster, Inc., and a group of its subsidiaries, including the Engineers Public Service Company, joined today in the growing offensive against the Public Utility Holding Company Act. They filed a bill of complaint in the Federal District Court here asking for an injunction against the Securities and Exchange Commission and other Federal officials restraining them from enforcing provisions of the law pending final determination of its constitutionality.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- The Governors of nine States and motor vehicle commissioners, safety directors and other high officials of twenty-two States today pledged their support of the National Safety Council's five-year campaign to attain a reduction of at least 35 per cent in automobile deaths throughout the country by the end of 1940.

A record group of records -- 292 in all -- will be presented to the Amateur Athletic Union for consideration at its forty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Commodore on Dec. 6, 7 and 8, it was announced yesterday by Edwin F. Schaefer, chairman of the record committee, through Secretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Prices of hogs declined 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight today, but there was a brisk demand at the lower level from local packers and a quick clearance was effected. As most of the receipts are of the new crop and show little difference in weight, the spread on sales is narrow.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 26 (AP). -- The atomic weight scale, yardstick of chemistry, was threatened today by a reported discovery that oxygen is heavier in air than in water.

The estate of Mrs. Anna Thalmann, who died April 24, 1934, was appraised yesterday at $4,573,618 gross and $4,165,899 net, of which $2,332,176 was in securities and $2,141,332,761 in cash. Mrs. Thalmann was the widow of Ernst Thalmann, senior member of the banking firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., who died in 1912.

The drunken automobile driver looms bigger and bigger in the routine death roll which quotes the price paid by the American people for its week-end holidays. It is stated before a meeting of police and fire surgeons that the drunken drivers have increased 45 per cent since repeal.

More than $180,000,000 of defaulted Straus real estate mortgages could have been reorganized for the benefit of the bondholders three years ago, according to testimony received yesterday by a joint legislative committee from the mortgage trustee.
Nearly 2,500 officers and patrolmen were assigned yesterday to hold crowds in check and control traffic along the four-mile route of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade.

Some people have an idea that civil service examinations are only suited to clerks and others in the lower brackets of the city or Federal service. That is not true. Under the modern system of examinations, designed to test not merely a candidate's knowledge, but his aptitude, experience and general capacity, men have successfully been selected for higher positions.

Mussolini was praised yesterday as "a man of courage in a world of pussyfooters" by Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, in an address before the Italian Chamber of Commerce at the Biltmore.

The flight of gold from the franc continued unabated yesterday as the time drew nearer for a decision upon France's political and monetary crisis with the reconvening tomorrow of the Chamber of Deputies. An additional $29,929,000 of gold was engaged in Paris for shipment here, following the engagement of $33,946,000 on Monday.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during October, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compares as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1934. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Preliminary experiments with national radio broadcasts for the purpose of rounding up criminals have been "very encouraging," J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Bureau of Investigation, announced today.

If the Social Security Act is declared unconstitutional, some form of legislation embodying its principles will be substituted, because the program has received so large a degree of public approbation, Thomas E. Shearer, editor of the Prentice-Hall Labor and Unemployment Insurance Service, told the New York Trade Association Executives at their monthly luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (AP). -- The Maroons blasted Chicago out of the National Hockey League's unbeaten class tonight as they sped to a 4-1 triumph in a wild game that saw fourteen penalties meted out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The New Deal's price controversy with big steel companies was renewed by Secretary Ickes today with an assertion that there was "prima facie evidence of collusion" in identical bids on a Florida public works project.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 26. -- Outplayed by Dr. Max Euwe of this city, representative of The Netherlands in the world's chess championship match which was resumed here tonight, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the titleholder, finished the first session of five hours with a pawn minus in the twenty-third game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Mrs. Roosevelt is receiving these days many more cheerful letters and few, if any, "really desperate pleas," a circumstance which she regards as at least a hopeful indication of returning prosperity.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 26. -- The government declared tonight that it had broken the backbone of the radical revolt in Northern Brazil.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26. -- Soviet audiences are becoming increasingly Shakespeare-conscious, it was apparent today with the opening of a three-day Shakespeare conference in Moscow's Masters of Arts Club, with more than 100 leading critics, playwrights, poets and theatrical directors participating.

Following a personal inspection yesterday of the House of Detention for Women at 10 Greenwich Avenue, Mayor La Guardia wrote three letters listing changes that he considers desirable at the institution.

Abe Davis, one of twenty-two defendants charged with usury by Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, has been busy making new small loans since he was released on bail, Jacob J. Rosenblum, one of Mr. Dewey's chief assistants, yesterday told the justices of Special Sessions who are trying the loan shark cases.

ATHENS, Nov. 26. -- King George II signaled the first full day of his leadership of the nation by shaking off "suggestions" by Marshal George Kondylis as to the future of the government -- which eliminated every eventuality but continuance of the marshal as Premier -- and began the task of choosing a leader from among the ample supply of candidates, with only Prince Paul, his brother, as his trusted adviser.

Mrs. Richard Roberts gave a luncheon yesterday at the St. Regis for her debutante daughter, Miss Priscilla Kent Roberts. The party was in the King Cole Room at several tables decorated with yellow snapdragons and pompom chrysanthemums.

Actions by utility holding companies to test the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act, jammed through Congress at the eleventh hour of the last session, were slow in getting under way, but the torrent was swelling visibly yesterday, and today's crop of court actions is expected to include even more companies.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 26. -- Pruning of $400,000,000 from appropriation requests of the regular government departments for the next fiscal year was announced today by President Roosevelt, after he and his fiscal aides had completed work on their budgets.

Willard Van Der Veer, camera man on Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's last two polar expeditions, will talk on "Film Making at the North and South Poles" on Friday night at 159 West Forty-ninth Street, under the auspices of the New Film Alliance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made an amendment to Rule JB4 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to broaden its scope in regard to incorporation by reference of data required for registration of a security on the Exchanges.

Seldom has a crown been surrendered to a rival with such good grace as the Chicago Crime Commission has just exhibited. The head of that body says that Chicago's eminence as "crime centre of the world" is departed and the title now belongs to New York.

ROME, Nov. 26. -- Prudent optimism, with strong emphasis on the "prudent," continues to be the Italian outlook on the European situation since the postponement of the Committee of Eighteen's meeting at Geneva.

Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan soprano, and Harold Bauer, pianist, will appear in a joint recital tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria in aid of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind and its auxiliaries, the Community Workers, the Vacation Camp and Dormitory, and the Junior League of the Guild.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- The size and impressiveness of the naval delegations now preparing to descend upon London have darkened the prospect of next month's naval conference still further until it is impossible for observers here to see the slightest hope of its success.

A fair example of "Words, Words, Words," if not "Symbols, Symbols, Symbols," mentioned in a letter in THE TIMES is to be found on the very next page in an article by William L. Laurence reporting the closing sessions of the National Academy of Sciences at the University of Virginia.

Columbia tested its defensive and offensive tactics against a third-string combination yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for the game with Dartmouth here on Saturday. With the contest against the Green the final opportunity for the Lions to salvage an outstanding major victory for the season, Coach Lou Little left nothing undone in his attempt to bring the Blue to the peak of its ability.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- Toronto broke a three-game losing streak tonight by beating Boston, 2 -- 1, before 12,000 at the Garden. After thirty-six scoreless minutes Harvey Jackson put the Maple Leafs in front by completing a combination play with Charlie Conacher and Red Horner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- For ways that are dark and tricks that are vain, diplomats are peculiar, and the same has been maintained by many historians of their craft. But on the surface, what State Department officials had to say at their long press conference today about the present status of our neutrality policy seemed straightforward enough.

With the known deposits of copper ore estimated to have a content sufficient for only 40 years at the 1929 rate of consumption of 2,000,000 tons, the copper industry again is on a sound basis, according to a review by Hornblower Weeks, and with any further business recovery "will again enter a period of prosperity."

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Over the Pacific, Wednesday, Nov. 27 (by Wireless). -- As the China Clipper speeds along on the fourth lap of the air mail route from California to the Orient -- the 1,500-mile stretch from Wake Island to Guam -- we are checking back on the plane's performance.

A new wage contract was signed yesterday by the Black Diamond Steamship Company and the United Licensed Officers Association, covering salaries and working conditions of officers employed on the company's ships. It was the first agreement reached by a dry cargo or passenger line operating in the Western ocean trade with the officers' group.

DUNDEE ISLAND, Antarctic Ocean, Nov. 26. -- Nothing has been heard from Lincoln Ellsworth since his radio faded during his flight across Antarctica on Nov. 23. From the day of his departure until this morning the weather here has been unsuitable for flying, but today is ideal, affording an opportunity, if needed, for Mr. Ellsworth to return.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann, in his death house cell at State prison, called upon Dr. John F. (Jafsie) Condon today to make a "full confession" in the kidnapping and murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., for which Hauptmann was convicted at Flemington last February.

SO Stanford will appear as the defendant in the Rose Bowl again. Bob Grayson, Monk Moscrip and Bones Hamilton, Stanford stars, lived up to their open pledge to beat Southern California three years in succession. It is understood, however, that these fellows have no pledge to lose the Rose Bowl game three years in succession. Columbia and Alabama put two strikes on them.

Any profits realized by the Home Owners Loan Corporation on the sale of homes on which it has foreclosed, will be turned over to the home owners who lost their money and property through the foreclosure, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Application was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935. Another application by the corporation asked the commission for an order declaring that it was not a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company or the United Corporation.

There has been a Liberal Government in the Province of Quebec for thirty-eight years. The Province seemed to be as permanently Liberal as Vermont is Republican. In '31 the Liberal representation in the Legislature was all but ten times as large as that of the Conservatives.

An unobstructed view of the west facade of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was afforded yesterday for the first time when the iron scaffolding surrounding the entrance to the edifice on Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street was taken down.

The centenary of ANDREW CARNEGIE'S birth, celebrated as it has been in such a variety of ways and in so many places, is that of a great man of business, but also of an even greater philanthropist. He devoted his later years to giving away on a princely scale the money which he had made in his earlier life.

With a bow to former Mayor Walker, a passing reference to his troubles in the Board of Estimate and a birdseye survey of a multitude of municipal problems, Mayor La Guardia dedicated yesterday the new $4,550,000 white granite building on Foley Square, which will be occupied by the Health, Hospital and Sanitation Departments.

C. 3'. llewin, Inc., fourth floor in 319 Broadway, through Horn Horn, Inc.; Paragon Slipper Co., in 115-17 Wooster St.; Durabilt Fibre Box Co., in 97-101 leade St.; Garner Products, Inc., in 912-20 Broadway; Hercules Leather Goods Co., represented by Holmes Douglas, and A. { T. Manufacturing Furrier, in 122-30 W. 27th St.; Gregory Beauty Parlor, in 173 I Broadway, from Dr. Haines Dentist, Inc.; Charles F. l%Toyes Co., brokers.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday under the influence of unsettling events in France and the list ended 1 to 6 points lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The Italian Government is likely to protest the action of the United States in preventing the sailing of the American tanker Ulysses with oil to Italy, if it has not already done so.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and Wholesale prices in New York.

Arthur G. Schaffner, 49 years old, of 128 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, sought by the police for some time for trying to swindle two job-seekers, was arrested on charges of attempted grand larceny shortly after noon yesterday outside of 64 Wall Street.

DUBLIN, Wednesday, Nov. 27. -- The appointment of Malcolm MacDonald as Minister of Dominions in the British Cabinet has been quickly followed by a remarkable story, featured by the Irish Independent this morning, giving what purport to be proposals for settlement of the Anglo-Irish dispute.

Vladimir Drozdoff, who once held a professorship at the St. Petersburg Conservatory of Music and who has been absent from the concert stage for the last few years, last night appeared in a piano recital at Aeolian Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP). -- A housing shortage "greater than any government is prepared to meet" was predicted today by Peter Grimm, assistant to Secretary Morgenthau, as he noted a "perceptible" loosening of private cash in the building field.
Miss Martha Berry, volunteer educator of the inhabitants of the hill country in Georgia, was honored last night at a Tranksgiving dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt by 850 of her admirers in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals issued an order today temporarily enjoining the Securities and Exchange Commission from disclosing to the public "trade secrets" of manufacturing and industrial corporations.

The Book of the Month Club has made a dual selection for January. Its choices are "If I Had Four Apples." by Josephine Lawrence, author of "Years Are So Long," which Stokes will publish, and "The Next Hundred Years: The Unfinished Business of Science," which Reynal Hitchcock will bring out.

It was most startling to read the remarks of the Rev. H.E. Woolever, editor of The National Methodist Press, to the effect that vice conditions in the camps of the CCC were deplorable; that there existed a great need for missionaries to be "sent" to these places to protect the morals of the 470,000 young men of "Sunday school age," 17 to 25 years.

New York University's undefeated and untied football team went through its final drill yesterday at Ohio Field in preparation for its seventeenth meeting with Fordham tomorrow afternoon at the Yankee Stadium. Coach Mal Stevens drove the squad until dark.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- A 5-year-old girl was drowned here tonight in a bathtub by her mother, who later took poison, according to the Bloomfield police.

A syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago won yesterday the award of a new issue of $875,000 of highway improvement refunding 3 per cent bonds of Sussex County, Del., on a bid of 102.22. Other members of the group are Graham, Parsons Co.; Francis I. du Pont Co. and Battles Co. The bonds are dated Sept. 1, 1935, and mature serially from 1937 to 1967.
A new group show of paintings by American artists has opened at the Milch Galleries, 108 West Fifty-seventh Street, to remain through the Christmas holidays.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman appealed last night for continued private support for philanthropic and social agencies in addition to the aid already being extended by State and Federal bureaus. He was the principal speaker at the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the National Urban League at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26. -- After more than a week of secret practice at the Naval Academy, the gates were opened late today and the midshipmen and officers were allowed to see the team in action. This procedure will be continued tomorrow and Thursday, the final days of practice at the academy for the Army game at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, on Saturday.

A sharp rally in coffee futures was a feature of the trading in the commodity markets here yesterday. Other staples generally were lower. In the cash market corn moved up, while wheat, rye, oats, refined sugar, lard, silk and wool tops were lower.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd declared today that he saw no reason to worry over the fate of Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, who is unreported on his flight across the Antarctic continent, first explored by Byrd. From the facts at hand, declared Admiral Byrd, it seems a "reasonable" conclusion that Ellsworth is either at or near Little America.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Reginald Parnell, City Director of Revenue and Finance, returned to the Public Works Administration today a check for $121,080, which had been advanced to the city toward construction of the new city hospital.
VIENNA, Nov. 26. -- Austria's chief trouble is that no one -- either Austrian or foreign -- seems able to realize that Vienna no longer is the capital of a great European confederacy.

Leaders of the steel industry will not participate in the industry-labor conference called by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, it was announced yesterday. The conference is to be held in Washington on Dec. 9.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 27. -- As a new crisis in Chino-Japanese relations approached today on the heels of increased tension in North China, a high official of the Chinese Government declared that "a definite break must come sooner or later."

Transcontinental and Western Air has decided to operate passenger service from Floyd Bennett Field as well as from Newark next Spring, whether or not New York's municipal airport gets a designation as an airmail terminal, it was announced yesterday.

Six men, three charged with homicide and having deadly weapons and three with suspicion of burglary, were held by police yesterday in connection with the seizure of a small arsenal at 57 Vermilyea Avenue.

Some shadowy proprietary right of property in Mr. LINCOLN seems to belong to the National Republican Club here. Lincoln Day is there regarded as a national Republican festival. If any new Lincolns are to arise they must come from the West. To the club dinner on Feb. 12 two Republican hopes, prospects or probationers have been invited.

In bringing suit against the Electric Bond and Share Company to force compliance with the Public Utility Act of 1935, the Government has chosen its ground carefully. This company, if any, is subject to the controls set up in that statute. It is one of the largest of the holding companies, serving small communities in all parts of the country.

John Kirkol, 49 years old, of 539 West Forty-ninth Street, who had been unemployed until three weeks ago, when he found a part-time job in a poultry market, was shot and killed there last night by one of three hold-up men who escaped with $327.

America has no time immemorial. So a justice of the State Supreme Court has ruled at White Plains, in denying the residents of Mamaroneck access to a strip of beach which they have used for fifty years.

KHARTOUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, Nov. 27. -- "Sanctions day" finds Anglo-Egyptian Sudan far more tranquil than seven or eight weeks ago when Italo-British relations appeared so threatening and British defenses in the Mediterranean were being strengthened.

Proclamations by the President and the several Governors were not needed to convince Americans that they have much for which to be thankful. They already had ample evidence of this. They have seen the clouds of depression breaking and lifting. More men are finding work. The tall chimneys are smoking again, the dynamos are emitting their low hum, machinery is turning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Roosevelt administration still is opposed to the immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus, Secretary Morgenthau said today. The Secretary has just returned from Warm Springs, where he went over the government's 1936-37 budget with President Roosevelt.

Henry S. Guinness, London banker, is sailing tonight for England on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, accompanied by Mrs. Guinness. Also sailing are Mr. and Mrs. Axel Wenner-Gren, William K. Howard, motion picture director; Senator H.W. Laird of Montreal, and:
