PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 27. -- One of the largest events of the early season here was the buffet dinner for sixty, followed by cards and dancing which Mr. and Mrs. Carl Furman Mabee of Lake Forest, Ill., gave tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Ernst F.S. Hanfstaengl has arrived from Berlin to testify in his libel action against The Daily Express, which will be tried before Lord Chief Justice Hewart and a jury on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Wholesale prices, continuing their upward trend, advanced fractionally, in the week ended on Nov. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index rose to 80.6 from 80.4, a week earlier, and compared with 76.3 a year ago.

The Rev. Simon Wigishoff, former Procurator-General of the Fathers of Mercy in Rome, will arrive in New York on Dec. 14 to assume the pastorate of the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame, 114th Street and Morningside Drive, it was announced yesterday.

A first folio of Shakespeare brought $7,400 last night at the Rains Galleries at the auction of the library of William D. Breaker of Brooklyn. Gabriel Wells was the purchaser of this copy of the 1623 edition of "Mr. William Shakespeare's Comedies, Histories Tragedies.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27. -- Racing's wheel of fortune whirled rapidly today at Bowie, crowding accidents, upsets and good and bad racing luck into one program, culminating with the victory of a filly, Genie Palatine, an obscure racer even at the half-mile tracks, which returned 230 to 1 to backers when she dashed home first in the third race.

Although it does not involve a trip either to the Rose or Sugar Bowls, there is a game scheduled to be played in the metropolitan area today that, based on present indications, will lure a record throng away from their Thanksgiving turkeys.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- With the remark that "there can be no question that we are out of the depression," Secretary Roper today revealed that pre-Christmas trade in the principal retail centres was running from 5 to 25 per cent ahead of 1934.

" Wimpy the Barber," specializing in streamline haircuts, is advertising the opening of a tonsorial parlor at City College. Wimpy is Milton Gerber, a senior, who with the aid of a pair of clippers, shears and a comb has been working his way through college giving haircuts "at rates which will meet every student's pocketbook."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Washington Newspaper Guild decided tonight by a vote of 30 to 16 to refuse admission to General Hugh Johnson, former Administrator of the National Recovery Administration, who is now author of a syndicated newspaper column.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 27 (AP). -- Dr. John F. Condon, chief witness against Bruno Richard Hauptmann, condemned kidnapper and murderer of the Lindbergh baby, reaffirmed tonight his testimony and said he was on the trail of additional supporting evidence.

The Greene Cananea Copper Company declared yesterday a special dividend of $1 and a quarterly dividend of 75 cents on the common stock. The quarterly dividend places the stock on a $3 annual basis, compared with $2 previously paid.

The Inland Steel Company has sold an issue of serial bonds to Kuhn, Loeb Co., it was learned yesterday. The issue is part of the program, approved on Tuesday by the directors, for refunding Inland Steel's first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds.

Reports of the prevalence of drinking, gambling and other vices in Civilian Conservation Corps camps were declared yesterday by those associated with or having direct knowledge of the camps in this area to be without foundation.

With less disturbing news from France and a recovery in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed resistance yesterday and ended with a gain of 6 points to a loss of 2 points. Strength in both near positions and an advance in December in New Orleans over New York influenced later deliveries.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

BOSTON, Nov. 27. -- Shore leave in the Coast Guard service in New England will be denied tomorrow despite the holiday, and all hands will be on guard to prevent any attempt to smuggle alcohol into the coves and nooks along the coast.

HAVANA, Nov. 27. -- The general elections scheduled for Dec. 15 were indefinitely postponed this afternoon by President Carlos Mendieta when the government failed to conciliate the political parties who have been deadlocked in the controversy over the Supreme Electoral Tribunal.

Improvement in sales training methods both in schools and commercial organizations will be one of the major objectives of the National Federation of Sales Executives, for which a constitution and program of activities has just been drawn by a committee on organization.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 27 -- Ethiopian optimism is growing as a result of repeated reports of successes on both war fronts.

Indications that the Federal Government of Brazil is in the way completely to suppress the revolt in two or three of the States in the North will be regarded as good news by most Americans. This is not because they are against any change in the Government of Rio de Janeiro, but they would wish it, if it must come, to be by orderly and lawful means.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- With only seventy-two hours to go, WPA officials expressed confidence today that the goal of 3,500,000 employed on the $4,000,000,000 work-relief program would be reached Dec. 1. A last-minute drive was under way to meet the third deadline set for the program.

Net operating income for October of the first forty railroads to report for that month was $44,767,000, against $27,623,000 in October, 1934, an increase of 62 per cent, and against $32,860,000 in October, 1933, an advance of 36.2 per cent. Their income in September was $33,663,000, against $23,340,000 in September, 1934, a rise of 44.2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Receipts of hogs here today fell below trade expectations, and with a brisk demand prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight, with weights under 180 pounds showing the most strength. A small lot of 205-pound averages sold at $9.80 but the practical top price was $9.75, or 15 cents above Tuesday's level, while the average of $9.60 was also 15 cents higher.
Housing deals on the upper west side of Manhattan and a Brooklyn industrial sale featured the urban realty activity reported yesterday.

The women's squash racquets team of the Cosmopolitan Club finished its Fall interclub match schedule yesterday by scoring a 3-2 victory over the Heights Casino players on its home court. It thus earned the distinction of being the only unbeaten Metropolitan team in the primary league.
GENEVA, Nov. 27. -- The League of Nations published today a detailed table reflecting the legislative application of all sanctions against Italy, including messages received down to 6 P.M. yesterday.

Counsel fees totaling $565,424 have been collected to date by the law firm of Wise, Shepard Houghton in connection with $180,000,000 of defaulted Straus real estate mortgages that could have been reorganized for the benefit of the bondholders at last three years ago, according to testimony given to a jonit legislative committee yesterday by lawyers to whom the fees were paid.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today and prices were mixed in result. Most deals in securities continue to be made independent of the official exchange, where quotations are still completely under government supervision.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27. -- Faced with a problem the difficulty of which every player appreciates, the Yale football squad is making the most of every moment to be ready for Princeton Saturday.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 27. -- Declaring this city faced a financial crisis, Councilman John J. McDonnell announced today he would introduce a resolution at the next meeting of the City Council to abolish his own salary of $2,500 a year and the same pay for two other Councilmen, Theodore Ornstein and Percy I. Elias.
One of the most exciting experiences that can befall a big-game hunter -- that of being "charged" by an animal -- provided a rare thrill for a Maine guide last week.

Lady Mendl, the former Elsie de Wolfe, who was named recently by Parisian dressmakers as the best-dressed woman in the world, was unimpressed by her laurels when she arrived here yesterday on the French liner Champlain. She even declined to accept the designation and suggested her own candidate for the honor.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Cornell, still looking for its first football victory of the season, meets Pennsylvania in the forty-second game of the series on Franklin Field tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- That the real estate bond house of S.W. Straus Co., with offices in most of the States of the Union and which sponsored bond issues of which approximately $468,000,000 are said to be in default, continued to sell bonds to its customers at par when the issues were in default, was alleged today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed transfer of the membership of William C. Cooke to John G. Bates and the actual transfer of that of William Schatzkin to Alfred Poole Duffy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27. -- With the Princeton football squad back at full strength after five men had spent the night in the infirmary, Coach Fritz Crisler today gave the players a long practice on University Field in which blocking and pass offensive and defensive were stressed.

At 1:30 this afternoon on the surface of the Yankee Stadium the football teams of Fordham and New York University will meet in their annual game, which this season has attracted more attention than any of their meetings in recent years.

Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel reserved decision yesterday on an application by thirty-one physicians on the civil service eligible list to compel the Board of Education to discontinue the appointment of three "provisional" physicians and to have their places filled from the eligible list.
BOSTON, Nov. 27. -- Miss Margaret Torbert, young debutante of Marlboro Street, literally made a flying entrance into society tonight.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Agreement was reached this morning at a conference between Premier Pierre Laval and the British Ambassador, Sir George Clerk, that the postponed meeting of the League of Nations committee of eighteen for the extension of sanctions against Italy should be held on Dec. 5 at Geneva subject, of course, to Mr. Laval's being able to attend.

BROWN vs. Colgate -- A treacherous affair, this guessing game. With a show of great friendliness Mr. J. Francis (Chick) Meehan confided that Rice would conquer Texas Christian and Mr. Lou Little promised faithfully that Penn would wallop Michigan. In the light of what happened it is odd to find no mention of Mr. Meehan or Mr. Little in that comprehensive volume by Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars entitled "Snakes of the World."

The Reynolds Spring Company in the first nine months of this year had a net profit of $263,365 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equal to $1.81 a share on 145,000 shares of $1-par capital stock, excluding 3,566 shares in the treasury.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- On his way to Washington after a ten-day trip through twenty-three States, Postmaster General Farley reported here today that he had found the "same confidence and solidarity" behind President Roosevelt. The "much-heralded 'slipping of Roose velt,'" he said, exists only in Republican newspapers.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, took issue last night with the theory that brakes should be put upon the increase of scientific research and knowledge. He spoke at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, ending the centenary celebration of Andrew Carnegie's birthday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27. -- That the Soviet Union is not alone interested in Japan's creation of a new North China autonomous State is stressed in an editorial in the official Red Army newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, which points out that the United States and Great Britain also are "extremely disturbed by the growing Japanese activity in China."

Governor Cross should hop down from Hartford this morning and start carving the little holiday item at the Lyceum. The sovereign State of Connecticut has been libeled. Let Westport and Old Lyme, New Milford and Danbury, hear that at Sweetwater they talk of nothing but babies. No discussions of art, politics, insurance or hats; babies, just babies.

SEVERAL years before his death George Moore invited Charles Morgan, author of "The Fountain," to "study with him to be his biographer." Morgan accepted the honor, but was told that no true biography could be written without access to "a certain series of letters" addressed by Moore to a "single correspondent." During Moore's last days the recipient of the letters refused to turn them over to Morgan.
Arthur Krock remarked in THE TIMES that the probabilities that the 1936 election would be fought on Western agricultural plains were very good in the opinions of astute political commentators.

GUAM, Thursday, Nov. 28. -- After a day of resting at her buoy at the Pan American Airways ocean air base off Shumay Point across Apra Harbor, the China Clipper was ready tonight to depart at daylight Friday on the final leg of her flight across the Pacific with the first United States ocean air mail to the Philippines.
TOKYO, Nov. 27. -- If Japanese military intrigue in North China was behind the autonomy government, it has evidently been short-circuited by diplomacy.

GENEVA, Nov. 27. -- Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois arrived here today from Italy and gave a statement interpreting to Europe the United States policy regarding sanctions, opposing United States support of the League of Nations' proposed embargo on oil, coal and steel sought by Italy and criticizing the League's method of applying sanctions as liable to embarrass the United States and hurt its trade.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Japanese sources reported today that an Outer Mongolia-Manchukuo conference, in session for months in an effort to settle a border conflict, had ended in an atmosphere of hostility.

Mayor La Guardia is given power to close any store or commercial establishment where labor trouble results in danger to the pubic under a proposed local law introduced yesterday by Alderman Samuel Feingold in the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly.

Two more loan sharks were convicted in Special Sessions yesterday, bringing the total of those who have been found guilty or have pleaded guilty to nineteen. Tomorrow fourteen are due to be sentenced and the remaining two of the twenty-two recently arrested will be tried.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The reorganized British Cabinet met today for consideration of the material which at the government's suggestion King George will put in his address from the throne to the new Parliament next Tuesday. The address will reaffirm the government's League of Nations policy of endeavoring to shorten the war against Ethiopia by sanctions against Italy.

Social adjustment rather than social reform legislation should be the aim of those engaged in social work, according to Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, president of the National Conference of Social Work, who addressed the annual conference of the National Urban League at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Parkside, 18 Gramercy Park South.

With practically all the magnates vanished from the scene, having disappeared as swiftly as they had arrived, President Ford C. Frick yesterday set to work picking up the loose ends of the latest developments in the effort to rehabilitate the financially harassed Boston Braves.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27. -- The Brazilian Government was in complete control of the revolt situation tonight after uprisings by two rebellious military forces in Rio de Janeiro during the day had been suppressed in hard fighting and the rebels who set up a communistic regime in the northern city of Natal had fled from that port.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., of New York filed suit in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today to enjoin the Securities and Exchange Commission, Attorney General Cummings and Postmaster General Farley from enforcing the Public Utility Act of 1935.

A tea dance was given yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Eugene Gray Jr. at their home, 320 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss Jane Gray. The hostess, in a gown of leaf-green transparent velvet and the debutante in a gown of white silk net over satin, received before a large mirror flanked with chrysanthemums and ferns.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 27. -- Overcoming the disadvantage of a pawn minus, which existed when play was adjourned last night in the twenty-third game of the world chess championship match, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, title-holder, today earned a draw with Dr. Max Euwe, the challenger.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler handed down a decision yesterday by which the investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company gained a sum estimated at almost $500,000.

WILMINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Suits attacking the Utility Holding Company Act as unconstitutional were filed in Federal court today by the Standard Power and Light Corporation, American Gas and Power Company, Louisville Gas and Electric Company and Standard Gas.

PARIS, Nov. 27. -- What will happen tomorrow when Premier Laval's government goes once more before the Chamber of Deputies after nearly five months of liberty to govern without parliamentary criticism is still uncertain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Fifty of the capital's debutantes and a few from other cities were in the line at the fifth annual Black and White Ball tonight at the Mayflower Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Charging that "he broke up my home," Louis Sapp entered a hospital room here today and shot to death Harold Bourg, 39, who was recovering from an operation. The victim was an electrician employed at the Illinois Central Hospital, where the shooting occurred.

It is almost traditional that the security and commodity markets are dull on the day before a holiday, and yesterday's trading proved to be no exception. The stock volume on "the big board," 1,850,000 shares, was the smallest for a full day since Nov. 4; the turnover in the listed bond market dropped about $600,000 from the preceding day to $14,339,300; the grain and cotton markets, too, reflected the holiday spirit.

The Health, Hospital and Sanitation Departments can take just pride and satisfaction in their handsome new building on Foley Square. The headquarters staffs of these departments deserve spacious accommodations of this kind, so superior to those to which they were accustomed in the old days.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Justice Jesse C. Adkins of the District of Columbia Supreme Court ruled tonight that the Guffey Act through which Congress sought to regulate the vast bituminous coal industry was in part constitutional and in part invalid.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare was belatedly appointed today as a member of the British delegation to the naval conference convening here early next month, although he is still immersed in the Ethiopian crisis and had hoped he would not need to take an active part in the conference.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 27. -- The White Plains (N.Y.) High School football team hopes to avenge the 13-to-0 setback received last year when it tackles the Central High eleven on School Field tomorrow morning in the third intersectional gridiron meeting between the teams within a four-year period.

Hrs. William Lafayette Burton 2d gave a luncheon yesterday at the Colony Club for two debutantes, her half-sister, Miss Julia E. Donahue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Donahue, and Miss Dorothy Pratt Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herschel V. Williams.
Relief workers owe a vote of thanks to William H. Matthews, whose letter appeared in THE TIMES of Nov. 24.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 27. -- A Japanese troop train of seventeen cars carrying about 3,000 soldiers arrived here today from Shanhaikwan, at the eastern end of the Great Wall. On its way it had dropped off reinforcements for the Japanese garrisons at Chinwangtao and Tangku, in Hopei Province.

One of the large debutante parties this season in town took place last night at the Ritz-Carlton where Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Procter gave a supper dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Hope Procter. The ballroom was transformed to represent a tropical garden with rare tropical plants and fruits.

An unusual sense of civic duty which kept him on the job seven days a week to learn how to build better roads for his home county was the official explanation given by Raymond G. Pollard, Assistant Public Works Commissioner of Queens, for two trips to Georgia this year in a city car, it was disclosed yesterday by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard.

Five years litigation over the estate of Abraham L. Erlanger, which began soon after his death on March 7, 1930, when Miss Charlotte Fixel filed objections to the probate of his will on the grounds that she was his common law wife, ended yesterday with the signing of an order by Surrogate James A. Delehanty admitting the will to probate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The possibility of a second Presidential veto of a cash bonus bill in as many years was forecast in Congressional quarters here today. Representative Buchanan, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, just back from a Warm Springs, Ga., budget conference with President Roosevelt, said:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (AP). -- George Sisler, once considered the best first baseman in baseball, tonight confirmed reports he and a group of local business men and sportsmen planned to purchase the St. Louis Browns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Reasons for the increase of the American delegation to the London Naval Conference to twenty persons from a smaller number, and for the decision to send to London for a time William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State, were given for the first time by officials today after they read a London dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning discussing these points.

Mayor La Guardia told 163 Sanitation Department employes whom he promoted yesterday that their department was no haven for "drunks and shirkers" and promised them no political interference if they brought charges against such employes.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Stralem gave a supper party last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw, Mr. and Mrs. Octavio Prochet, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Hirsch, Mr. and Mrs. David C. Moss, Mrs. Alfred Wagstaff 3d and Henry R. Ikelheimer.

For more than sixteen hours yesterday the safety of Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot somewhere in the frozen wastes of Antarctica seemed assured with reports that a radio message bearing the call letters of the Ellsworth plane had been picked up off New Zealand.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Army is about through with its preparations for the Navy game. Today the coaches had all hands out and drove them through a lengthy practice session. There was a final glimpse of the Annapolis attack as demonstrated by the plebes and then followed a rehearsal of the Cadets' own offensive tactics which lasted until mess call.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 27. -- Simon Minor, 37 years old, a Negro, who was pardoned recently by Governor Talmadge of Georgia after Minor had escaped from a chain gang three times, came home here this afternoon to a tumultuous welcome by dozens of friends.

ABOARD THE M.S. WYATT EARP, Nov. 27. -- The Wyatt Earp moved to Deception Island today with the hope that from here there might be a better chance of hearing the emergency wireless at the Bay of Whales, the goal of Lincoln Ellsworth's flight in the Polar Star.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- The European situation again took a very grave turn today when it became known the Italian Government, disturbed by "the atmosphere of restlessness" brought about by the proposal to place an embargo on oil exports to Italy, had ordered certain troop movements whose nature was not disposed.

ATLANTA, Nov. 27. -- Governor Talmadge challenged President Roosevelt today to defend the AAA, the Bankhead Act, lack of denominational churches at Norris, Tenn., and the relief payroll of Rexford Tugwell.

The city of Boston, Mass., yesterday made the award of a new issue of $2,500,000 of short-term notes to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtaining a price of par plus a premium of $35 for 0.82 per cent notes. The notes are dated Dec. 2, 1935, and are payable on Nov. 2, 1936.

ELKTON, Md., Nov. 27. -- Ghaffar Djalal, Minister from Iran (Persia), was handcuffed to a constable for a time here today following an argument on Main Street where his chauffeur was stopped for speeding.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Financial circles in Germany, both foreign and domestic, are puzzling their heads these days to solve what is known as a great gold mystery in Germany. It involves the disappearance from official records within a year of no less than 100,000,000 marks worth of gold which should be there but isn't.

The establishment of a high school of music and art, advocated by Mayor La Guardia, was formally approved by the Board of Education last night after the board, in executive session, had heard parental protests that the new school might cause overcrowding in the Wadleigh High School Annex, 135th Street and Convent Avenue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Trading in wheat today on the Chicago Board of Trade was of a pre-holiday character and consisted considerably in changing between the December and the deferred deliveries. Weakness in the December future in Minneapolis, where local professionals were said to be liquidating their holdings, had some effect here, but toward the last the evening up by shorts and the firmness in Winnipeg made closing trades unchanged to 1/4 cent lower.

A high appreciation of Will Rogers as a serious and keen observer of international affairs was received from President Roosevelt yesterday by the national headquarters of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission. The message telegraphed by the President read:

MADRID, Nov. 27. -- The trial of Francisco Largo Caballero, militant revolutionary leader of the Spanish Socialist party, accused of being one of the chief directors of the October, 1934, rebellion, closed today before the Supreme Court with a dramatic denunciation of the defendant by the Attorney General.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- The Bank of Italy is paying a 25 per cent premium on gold to increase its gold reserves for Italy's purchases abroad. It is buying gold at 15.45 lire per gram. Its rate was 12.35 lire per gram.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Testimony that Mrs. Ella Hoover Thacher, 85 years old, head of the Florence (N.J.) Thread Works and former president of the New Jersey W.C.T.U., was possessed by a mania for speed was given today before a lunacy commission and a jury here.

Miss Angela Scoville Dunham made her debut last night at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Dunham 3d, at the Pierre. The party was in the Corinthian Room, the debutant receiving with her parents near the entrance against a background of cybotium ferns and tall baskets of Autumn flowers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- President Roosevelt will not ask Congress for more than $1,000,000,000 to finance further direct relief for the unemployed, Chairman Buchanan of the House Appropriations Committee predicted today as he returned from a conference with the President at Warm Springs.

Max Mason, president of the Rockefeller Foundation since 1929, announced yesterday that he would retire soon to devote himself more closely to research work in his own fields of mathematics and mathematical physics. He is now engaged on a special scientific study on which he hopes to concentrate for some time, he said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Much of a $332,342 fund due employes in navy yards and shore stations for overtime between March 21, 1878, and Sept. 22, 1882, is lying in the Treasury unclaimed, it was disclosed today.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrived yesterday with 459 passengers from the Channel ports twenty-four hours late because of continuous storms virtually from Cherbourg Breakwater to the Ambrose Lightship.
An article in THE TIMES of Nov. 24, by Barron C. Watson, entitled "Down the Long Sea Highway," states:

Local gourmets who must have their turkey hot off the gridiron have real cause for thanksgiving today. Nowhere else the country over does the holiday menu provide so delectable a dish as will be served up within five cents' fare of New Yorkers' homes.
The Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to cancel water rates against forty-six religious and charitable institutions. More than $8,000 was involved.

Employment-creating provisions inserted in the law establishing the post of Federal Coordinator of Transportation, which is occupied by Joseph B. Eastman, have prevented the railroads from effecting economies which they otherwise would have brought about, M.J. Gormley, executive assistant to J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said at a luncheon given yesterday by the Transportation Association of America.

BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- Three more nuns were convicted of exchange-law violations today in the Nazi regime's war of attrition against the Catholic Church. The nuns, officials of the Order of the Gray Sisters of St. Elizabeth, received prison sentences and were fined.

ATHENS, Thursday, Nov. 28. -- A serious conflict between King George and the Kondylis Cabinet developed last night over the question of an amnesty for participants in the Republican revolt of last March, and the issue is now deadlocked.

The boatswain of the Ward liner Morro Castle, who should have been in command of the deck crew, was intoxicated when that vessel burned off Asbury Park on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 135 lives, it was testified yesterday in Federal court at the trial for criminal negligence of two officers of the ship and an official of the line.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 27. -- One change marked the Dartmouth practice today. Bill Cole, who reported late in the season, was promoted to a varsity guard position over Fran Schildgren, while the veteran Latta McCray was dropped to the third team.

Amicable settlement of the law suit brought by the Chilean Government against the Chilean Electric Company, Ltd., subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., was virtually assured through an agreement reached yesterday by the government and the company, according to private advices from Chile.
PIRAEUS, Greece, Nov. 27. -- Thousands of tangerines dotted the waters of the harbor here as the first sanctions were forcibly applied against a schooner arriving from the Italian Dodecanese Islands.

The Interstate Commerce Commission gave out yesterday the complete statement of Class I railways for September. The railways had reported that last September their total net income, for the first time in 1935, had exceeded the month's proportion of such charges as rental of leased lines and interest on funded debt.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27. -- Furthering their campaign for a defense fund for Edith Maxwell, the young Virginia school teacher convicted of killing her father, four members of the Knoxville Business and Professional Women's Club left here today for Wise, Va., where they will offer their services to the prisoner.

Paul Stefan has completed an account of the career of Arturo Toscanini, conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, and the book will be brought out on Jan. 20 by Viking Press, to coincide with Toscanini's first appearance with the Philharmonic this season.
BUFFALO, Nov. 27. -- Spokesmen for leading business and civic organizations who hold divergent views both defended and condemned the administration of direct and work relief in Buffalo today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- As legal actions growing out of the Public Utilities Act multiply, with the SEC and other government agents both defendants and plaintiffs, it may be useful to review the court status of these twenty suits and to recall their political background.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Dr. Hermann Gortz, former German air force officer, was accused before a Magistrate yesterday of two offenses under the Official Secrets Act. He was remanded for a week and then will be formally committed to trial in Old Bailey.
A long, grueling scrimmage, with the assistant coaches getting into actual combat, featured Columbia's session yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Dartmouth here Saturday.
Mr. Hitler has dissolved the Stahlhelm, but Baron yon Schroetter says that the Stahlhelm will not be dissolved on this continent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- New York's share of the billions spent by the Federal Government for relief was estimated today by the Relief Administration at $374,205,774 up to Oct 31.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- A large part of the estate of James Reuel Smith, Yonkers historian and writer, who died Nov. 12, was left to the United States Government, in care of the Attorney General, "to be applied toward redemption of Liberty bonds issued in 1918," according to his will filed for probate here today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 27. -- According to the interpretation given a letter received today from John G. Winant, chairman of the Social Security Board at Washington, Connecticut must hold a special session of the Legislature before Jan. 1 or fail to obtain Federal funds under the Social Security Act in 1936.

Miss Elizabeth M. Sturgis was introduced to society last night by her parents at a supper dance in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. The debutante, who attended the Lawrence School and the Shipley School, received with her parents. The guests included:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Initial rules for applying 1935 banking act controls to the flow of bank credit were issued tonight by the Federal Reserve Board.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27. -- A new device enabling the development of from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 pounds of pressure per square inch, which will bring forth an ice hotter than boiling water and transform soft graphite into matter capable of imposing scratches on the hardest steel, was announced today at Harvard University by Professor Percy W. Bridgman.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP). -- Deaths on American highways reached a new high mark in the first ten months of the year, the National Safety Council disclosed today.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 27 -- Official dispatches to Addis Ababa stat-

A complete reinvestigation of the disappearance of Joseph Force Crater, the Supreme Court Justice who dropped from sight more than five years ago, has been started by the Police Department, it was discovered yesterday.
The movement in opposition to American participation in the Olympic Games in Berlin next year was joined yesterday by Zack Farmer, managing director of the 1932 games in Los Angeles.

African Negro sculpture, and that of more or less closely related cultures, occupied a prominent place in last season's exhibition program here in New York. We had the remarkable display arranged by James Johnson Sweeney at the Museum of Modern Art, supplemented by smaller groups at the Pierre Matisse and the Valentine.

America's traditional festival will be observed again today with reunions and merry-making in the nation's homes, while charity and good-will toward all the unfortunate and needy will be manifest in hospitals, settlement houses and welfare organizations.

The Cunard White Star Line will withdraw the liner Majestic, the largest commercial vessel afloat until the French liner Normandie entered the service, and will retain the Berengaria in its transatlantic passenger service, it was learned yesterday.

The crisis in the franc showed signs of abating yesterday. Banking circles here received word from Paris that Premier Laval was likely to be supported by the Chamber of Deputies, which meets today to consider his financial decrees and the question of next year's budget.
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Representatives of government departments were questioned about the arms trade before the Royal Commission on Arms today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 27. -- Brazil's big guns and bayonets wiped out two reckless revolts in the heart of her capital defenses today.
Four recipients of old-age pensions in the city were Mayor La Guardia's guests at luncheon in City Hall yesterday.

MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 27. -- Two men were arrested for arson at 9:30 o'clock tonight outside a tailor shop in a two-story brick store and apartment building at 3,377 Northern Boulevard, Munsey Park, near here, where a device for setting the place afire had already been lighted.

The four American musicians who make up the Manhattan String Quartet, returned home yesterday on the French liner Champlain, willing to forget the incident in Rome two weeks ago when they were attacked by blackshirts because they had not given the Roman salute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Efforts of the Maine Central Railroad to procure a private underwriting of proposed refunding bonds in connection with its plan for a $20,000,000 exchange and readjustment "have been unavailing" and there is no present prospect of success, the Interstate Commerce Commission was advised today by Edward W. Wheeler, vice president and general counsel of the road.

With reference to John Heisman's remarks at the concluding session of the Downtown Athletic Club's "Football Forum," this writer, who has had some experience of American football and a very great deal of Rugby, would like to correct the impression that might be caused by Mr. Heisman's comparison of the training methods of American and Rugby footballers.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 27. -- Fickle Chance, 5-to-1 shot, drove home ahead of a fine field of sprinters to capture the $1,000 William B. Travis Purse, the feature event at Epsom Downs today.

The swimming teams of De Witt Clinton and George Washington High Schools continued tied for the lead in the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond division of the P.S.A.L. championship race after yesterday's dual meets. The rivals have seven victories, no ties and no defeats for a total of 14 points each.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- The Middle West Utilities Company, the huge system built up and dominated by Samuel Insull until his fall in 1932, was put back on its feet today and was told to try standing after three and one-half years of receivership and bankruptcy reorganization proceedings.

Pressure for quick deliveries on holiday merchandise has increased as reorders on these goods have gained in volume in the markets here. Deliveries on toys continue particularly backward, but supplies of lingerie, handkerchiefs, a varied list of home electrical appliances and handbags available for quick delivery are limited.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27. -- The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority are willing to extend a share in the management of that vast undertaking to their 17,000 employes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Problems of the East African war and the Japanese occupation of North China were discussed today by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, in separate conferences with B. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, and Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, chief of the Far Eastern Division of the State Department.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27. -- The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority are willing to extend a share in the management of that vast undertaking to their 17,000 employes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Problems of the East African war and the Japanese occupation of North China were discussed today by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, in separate conferences with B. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, and Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, chief of the Far Eastern Division of the State Department.

Geoffrey Toye, director of the Covent Garden Opera Company in London, sails for home tonight after a fortnight's visit here. During his stay he conferred a number of times with Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera House, and sought to engage certain artists for the international season in London next May and June.

More than 20,000 Communists and Left Wing Socialists fraternized in Madison Square Garden last night, where a debate was staged on the merits of their respective doctrines by Earl Browder, Communist chieftain, and Norman Thomas, Socialist leader. Mr. Browder returned recently from Moscow, where he attended the congress of the Communist International.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Temple University closes its season with Bucknell here tomorrow in the ninth annual game between the institutions' football teams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP). -- A suggestion that industries enjoying governmental favors be required to adjust prices and production promises "in the light of the general welfare" was made today by Secretary Wallace.

Eight leading business organizations began yesterday the active work of organizing a citizens committee of 500 to oppose Mayor La Guardia's plan for construction and operation of a municipal "yardstick" power plant.

This evening's major event finds itself being introduced by the strangely vague appellation of "How Beautiful With Shoes," the same being a play in three acts by Wilbur Daniel Steele and Anthony Brown, opening at the Booth Theatre.

At full strength for the first time this season, the New York Rangers hockey team will face the powerful Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League contest tonight, starting at 8:45 o'clock.

Warner Brothers Pictures issued another statement yesterday setting forth further facts that led their music-publishing companies to sever their connection with the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. There was also another statement from the society.

Renewal of many traditional Thanksgiving Day rivalries, along with a few intersectional contests, are among the sixty-five metropolitan district games scheduled for today -- the last big day of the 1935 scholastic football campaign.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- State police at the Keyport barracks received information tonight that an automobile bearing Pennsylvania license plates, with a man at the wheel and another person slouched in the seat beside him, was seen leaving the Middletown Township estate of Mrs. J. Amory Haskell on Saturday night shortly before John H. Blandford, gardener and World War veteran, was shot and killed in his home on the estate.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The British Government possesses information that Marshal Pietro Badoglio, the new Italian commander, intends immediately to launch a concentrated attack along the line of the frontier between Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Ethiopia, so as to reach the city of Gondar and Lake Tana.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 27. -- While the members of the colony here joined today in preparations for tomorrow evening, when President Roosevelt, the "founder," will preside again as host at a Thanksgiving feast to be attended alike by sufferers from infantile paralysis and friends of the foundation, the President withdrew into the privacy of his intimate circle to write, the highly important speech he will deliver at Atlanta on Friday.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 27. -- Happy "Pilgrims" from far and near thronged this historic town tonight while final preparations were made for a day of thanksgiving tomorrow, the renewal of a custom started here in 1621.

Auctioneers conducted sixteen foreclosure sales of properties in Manhattan yesterday. The sales involved twenty-three buildings, all of which were bought in by the plaintiffs in the foreclosure proceedings.
All security and commodity exchanges in the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Canadian and European markets will be open as usual.

New jobs for 3,800 women will be created by the WPA, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. He said that 1,300 women would be put to work cleaning and repairing uniforms of the New York National Guard and 2,500 jobs on cleaning and repairing school books.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the transfer of the regular membership of G. William McAndrews to John A. Ludlow of Peter R. Lawson Co. George H. Logan of Lamborn, Hutchings Co., was elected to associate membership.

PRAGUE, Nov. 27. -- President Thomas G. Masaryk's forthcoming resignation, mention of which has hitherto been prohibited in the Czechoslovak press, is now openly discussed. Its actual date depends on the result of tomorrow's conference here among leaders of the governmental coalition parties.

Despite expectations that a general advance in finished steel prices would be announced this month, several producers have opened their books for the first quarter of 1936 with unchanged prices, according to Iron Age's weekly summary, issued yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- Former President Hoover declared today that "imported social philosophies of government" are being used as a camouflage for the violation of true American liberalism. He condemned regimentation and coercion by government bureaus as hampering a real return to American ideals.
The twenty-ninth annual Christmas seal campaign of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association will be officially opened today by Mayor La Guardia.

PEIPING, Nov. 27. -- To make certain that North China's railways would not be stripped of their rolling stock, the Japanese military, after seizing Changyimen Station, 300 yards from Peiping's southwest gate, in addition to Fengtai, announced today that for every car and locomotive going south across the Yellow River another must come north.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- The City Commission acted quickly today to recover the $121,080 check from the Public Works Administration which Reginald Parnell, City Director of Revenue and Finance, returned yesterday to Washington. The check was an advance on a $1,390,909 PWA grant for construction of a new city hospital.

The Electric Bond and Share Company made public yesterday the changes in personnel of its affiliated holding companies pursuant to the announcement on Tuesday of the severance of interlocking relationships.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The Irish Free State Army team, riding sensationally, tonight won the international military officers' team challenge trophy, feature event of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show, before a crowd of 12,000.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine lost no time yesterday in complying with a demand from Governor Lehman for all the available data in the Druckman murder case.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 28. -- As soon as the royal birth was announced this morning sirens carried the tidings over the city, and the news was broadcast to the empire by a national radio network.

Paul Bowser of Lexington, Mass., wrestling promoter and owner of one of the leading racing stables in the country, yesterday afternoon paid $7,5000 for the yearling bay colt De Sota, the highest price of the second day of the forty-first annual Old Glory auction sale of light-harness horses, held in Squadron A armory.

Two more major industries, petroleum and chemical, announced yesterday that they would not participate in the industry-labor conference called by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, to meet in Washington on Dec. 9.

Bonds were generally firmer in undertone in the trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While a pre-holiday atmosphere marked some sections and tended to curtail fresh commitments, an upward trend was resumed over a fairly broad front led by second-grade railroad bonds.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The Irish Free State Army team, riding sensationally, tonight won the international military officers' team challenge trophy, feature event of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show, before a crowd of 12,000.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine lost no time yesterday in complying with a demand from Governor Lehman for all the available data in the Druckman murder case.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 28. -- As soon as the royal birth was announced this morning sirens carried the tidings over the city, and the news was broadcast to the empire by a national radio network.

Paul Bowser of Lexington, Mass., wrestling promoter and owner of one of the leading racing stables in the country, yesterday afternoon paid $7,5000 for the yearling bay colt De Sota, the highest price of the second day of the forty-first annual Old Glory auction sale of light-harness horses, held in Squadron A armory.

Two more major industries, petroleum and chemical, announced yesterday that they would not participate in the industry-labor conference called by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, to meet in Washington on Dec. 9.

ABOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Friday, Nov. 29. -- A few farspaced lights showed against the dark mountains, massive in the graying light of dawn and holding back the first glints of the rising sun, as the China Clipper climbed out of Apra Harbor, Guam, at 8:06 P.M. Thursday, Greenwich mean time (6:06 A.M. Friday, Guam time, and 3:06 P.M. Thursday in New York.

CHRISTMAS, Fla., Nov. 28. -Without a reindeer or a flake of snow, this community is claiming notice once more for the only "Christmas" postmark in the world. From far places cards and packages already are coming here to be stamped and mailed again by "Mrs. Santa Claus."

George Hiram Mann, attorney, of 79 Wall Street, who led the fight to get $332,342 from the last Congress to pay navy yard workers for overtime worked between March 21, 1878, and Sept. 22, 1882, said yesterday he was going before the next Congress with a demand for payment of $1,000 each to the eight surviving members of the group who did not file claims.
While Governor Lehman studied records in the Druckman murder case yesterday, the Citizens Union called upon him in a letter to supersede District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn.

Pointing out that government expenditures today take more than 25 per cent of the national income, the report of the committee on government finance of the National Association of Manufacturers says these expenditures have been accompanied by a substantially similar increase in public employees.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The British Government instructed its embassy in Tokyo today to inquire into Japan's intentions in view of recent events in North China and to remind her of the existence of the Nine Power Pacific treaty.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions, with a defense as brilliant as their offense, routed the Chicago Bears and gained a tie for the Western group lead in the National Football League race today.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, has instructed all civil servants that he "expects them to free for their children the pathway to enrolment in the Hitler Youth and other National Socialist party youth organizations."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- At the end of the Chicago dispatch narrating in today's TIMES Postmaster General Farley's claim of seventeen States already in the President's re-election bag appears the modest statement that W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, has been en tour with Mr. Farley.

Thanksgiving sermons in pulpits throughout the city divided yesterday between earnest consideration of the problem of today and expressions of relief that on such a day the problem need not be considered.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 28. -- Climaxing a game of thrills, Nebraska staged a 67-yard fourth-quarter touchdown march today to defeat Oregon State by 26 to 20 before 25,000 spectators.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The Chicago Cardinals scored their third victory of the season over the Green Bay Packers, 9 to 7, today in a bitterly contested football game at Wrigley Field.

Silver King, 2:01 3/4, a dark gray 3-year-old by Mr. McElwyn, 1:59 1/4, and out of Fay Worthy M., 2:14 1/4, by Favonian, 2:01 3/4, brought the top price of $7,100 at the forty-first annual Old Glory auction sale of light harness horses, which was concluded yesterday afternoon in Squadron A Armory.

Some philosophers hold that the English are as much attached to the cooking of their country as to its climate. The weather is often bad, the cooking usually -- or should we say always? The strong of heart and stomach have a just pride in surviving. One feels that there is something highbrow and artificial in the efforts of the Food and Wine Society and the Saintsbury Club.

Rolling up its largest score since 1928, the Curtis High School juggernaut crushed Benjamin Franklin High of New York under a 54-0 count yesterday at Thompson's Stadium, Stapleton, S.I., to remain among the few unbeaten and untied schoolboy elevens in the Metropolitan area.

Art education in the city's public schools "ignores the vital fields of artistic training," stresses commercial art and is generally "fundamentally unsound and misleading," in the opinion of Austin Purves, director of the art schools of Cooper Union.

TORONTO, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The mining market of the Toronto Exchange staged a base metals session today, virtually all issues of that group advancing on heavy volume. Several issues touched new high prices for a year or longer.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 28. -Mrs. Anna Blandford, widow of John H. Blandford, slain World War veteran, whose body was found on the estate of Mrs. J. Amory Haskell, near Red Bank, N.J., Monday will go to the scene of the crime after the funeral of her husband tomorrow morning.

Paavo Kauppinen of the Finnish A. C. led home a field of sixty-four in the twenty-fifth annual walking race from City Hall to Coney Island, held under the auspices of the Walkers Club of America, yesterday. He started with a sixteen-minute handicap and had an actual time of 1:33:14 for the ten-and-a half-mile course.

NEWARK, Nov. 28. -- Characters from Mother Goose and other fairy tales, the Arabian Nights and Alice in Wonderland took the place of the Tony Sarg balloon animals and monsters in the fourth annual Thanksgiving Day parade staged here today by L. Bamberger Co.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today, with business increased in spite of the near approach of the end of the account, although British funds were somewhat easier and New Zealand issues were lower as a result of the election.

SCHUYLERVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Through the activities of the Works Progress Administration Stark's Knob, New York State's only extinct volcano, is to be made more accessible to the public. The WPA has allocated $1,024 for improving the grounds around it.

The second performance in New York and the first performance by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of excerpts from Alban Berg's opera, "Lulu," was given last night in Carnegie Hall under the direction of Otto Klemperer. The performance was one of surpassing vividness and technical brilliancy.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 28. -- The Virginia Polytechnic Institute eleven scored a 12 to 6 victory over the Cadets of Virginia Military Institute today. The game was played in a steady downpour of rain before a crowd of 12,000.

WARSAW, Nov. 28. -- Several leaders and prominent members of illegal anti-Semitic and Nationalist organizations, mostly students and young university graduates, were arrested today in an attempt to end rioting in colleges and the growing anti-Jewish propaganda.

Postmaster General James A. Farley returned yesterday to New York from a tour similar to those he made in 1932, and announced that the sentiment of the country is for the re-election of President Roosevelt in 1936.
CALLANDER, Ont., Nov. 28. -Yvonne Dionne, one of the sisters you've heard so much about, sat down to her breakfast table this morning and found her cereal, fruit and milk all in new dishes.

With hopeful notions about that mural space left vacant by the directed departure of Diego Rivera from the halls of Rockefeller Center, the thirty-five artists and craftsmen who banded together last January in a cooperative move to keep off the relief rolls prepared yesterday for an exhibition of their work, scheduled to open Dec. 2 in their penthouse studio at 289 Fourth Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- There was such a disagreeable drizzling rain in Paris this afternoon that all the elaborate precautions which had been taken for protection of Parliament on its opening day were not in the least needed.
United States Senator A. Harry Moore and Mrs. Moore were hosts to a group of friends at a Thanksgiving dinner in the Senator's cabin in Hunterdon County.
LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Plans for a new series of imperial air services are under active consideration by commercial interests in Great Britain.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28. -- Through a driving rain, and before 20,000 persons, the largest crowd of the meeting, the bay colt Tweedledee was up in a driving finish to take the Thanksgiving Handicap today as Only One finished in the ruck. The banner crowd, which wagered approximately $500,000 on the entire program, drove Only One into odds-on favoritism at 3 to 5, only to see him run fourth in a fivehorse race.

WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 28. -Wheat futures did not get out of fractional range today and prices ended 1/8 to 3/8 cent lower. Trading was entirely local and dealings were exceptionally quiet, with little pressure in evidence. Export business was negligible.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28. -- Gradually, through the opening day's play in the national field hockey tournament today on the Laurel School field, it became apparent that, although the East still holds its accustomed position of supremacy in the country's ranking, the Western teams have made great strides during the last year.

A double-barreled Thanksgiving Day circus, with elephants, clowns, apes, trained dogs and ponies in twinkling harness, was presented yesterday to about 40,000 spectators in Manhattan and Brooklyn by the Hearn department store. The first performance was given in the morning on the Central Park Mall and the second in the afternoon in Prospect Park's Music Grove, where the bandstand had been converted into a circus arena and surrounding trees were decorated with bunting.

The Juilliard School of Music yesterday announced that "Impressions From a Greek Tragedy," by Albert Elkus, was adjudged the best work in the recent competition for publication of orchestral works by American composers. The school conducts the competition once a year and also defrays the expenses of publication.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 28. -Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained today with a Thanksgiving dinner at Casa Del Pastor. Tables were placed on the terrace.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- It is authoritatively stated in official quarters today that the fact that the Bank of Italy is buying gold from private citizens at a 25 per cent premium over the standard price laid down in the law fixing the lira's gold content is not to be interpreted as evidence that the lira's present gold parity is about to be abandoned.

BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 28 (AP). -Robert Rankine, Preston (Ont.) shoe-cutter, became a three-time winner in Berwick's Thanksgiving marathon today, negotiating the rugged Briar Creek course of 9 miles 385 yards in the record time of 47 minutes 35 seconds.

VIENNA, Nov. 28. -- Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg in a discussion of Austria's foreign policy before the Federal Diet today said Austria would not "make use of the special stand we are taking in order to accumulate war profits" in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.
The rival captains went to the centre of the field for the toss, which was won by Captain Joe Maniaci of Fordham. The Maroon elected to kick off with N.Y.U. defending the west goal.
HANNIBAL, Mo., Nov. 28 (AP). -Nearly a year-long Mark Twain centennial celebration in his boyhood home will close with a dinner Saturday night on the 100th anniversary of his birth.
A new book by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, relating the imaginary visit of a boy and girl to Washington, D.C., and the White House, is published today by the Dodge Publishing Company.

THE TIMES published recently a letter on rural school centralization from W. W. Christman of Delanson, N.Y., from which one might conclude that the people who oppose centralization are a lot of back numbers who do not know what is best for modern boys and girls.

Twenty-four stutterers have shown marked improvement, even to a complete cessation of stuttering, when they spoke while moving on all fours. This phenomenon, for which no explanation has been discovered so far, is reported in the issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, published today.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 28. -Led by Don Jackson, North Carolina's great halfback, whose passing, running and punting figured largely in a Thanksgiving touchdown parade, the Tar Heels went on a scoring spree today to trounce Virginia, 61 to 0, in the South's oldest Turkey Day classic.
Discovery of a substance which makes the dentist's drill a painless instrument, something millions of persons the world over have been hoping for, was announced here yesterday by Columbia University.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- A spokesman for the Propaganda Ministry declared today the main charge against Mgr. Banasch, Catholic prelate arrested in Berlin last week, was based on possession of copies of secret documents and government reports.

An option to purchase four-fifths of the voting common stock of the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company will be exercised by the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company before the end of this year, according to plans of the management of the latter company.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28. -- Pittsburgh and Carnegie Tech played to an 0-to-0 tie in their annual intracity Thanksgiving struggle at Pitt Stadium today.

~[ORRISTOU/I~, 1~. J., Nov. 28,The W~isses Nancy and Nita Easley,twin daughters of Mr. and ~rrs.George Albert Easley, made theird~buts this afternoon at a tea dancegiven by their parents at theirhome, Three Gables Farm, here.Miss Nancy Easley attended MissPorter's School, was graduatedfrom Mount Vernon Seminary,Washington, and at present is astudent at William and Mary College, Williamsburg, Va. ~Iiss NitaEasley attended Chatham Hall,Chatham, Va., and is a senior atthe Finch School, New York.

BUFFALO, Nov. 28. -- Mayor George J. Zimmermann of Buffalo interrupted Thanksgiving Day festivities at his home today to defend the relief administration of his city against criticism which, for the most part, he holds unjustified.

The United Hospital Campaign Committee has raised approximately $557,000 to date and is striving to raise at least an additional $1,500,000 to save the city's voluntary hospitals from curtailment of operation, it was announced yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 28. -- Decisions expected to be reached within the next two or three days will determine whether the centre of the newest Chino-Japanese crisis will be confined to the area north of the Yellow River or whether compromise is impossible, a Japanese Embassy spokesman said here today.

Peter Fleming, author of "Brazilian Adventure" and "One's Company," has just completed what he calls "a successful essay in traveling light" from Peking to India, by way of Manchuria, Mongolia, the interior of China, Northern Tibet, Sinkiang and Kashmir.

The premiere of "Weep for the Virgins," scheduled for tonight at the Forty-sixth Street, has been set back twenty-four hours. It will open there tomorrow evening, the explanation for the delay being that an outdoor scene is being made into an indoor scene -- which, of course, takes time....

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (AP). -S. J. Morley's Fire Advance, a 26to-1 shot in the mutuels, captured the Thanksgiving Handicap, feature of the opening of the Winter racing program at the Fair Grounds today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28. -- The Amen Boys of the Grand Street Boys Association, led by their honorary president general, Albert Morgan, 94-year-old Civil War veteran, arrived here today for their annual four-day jamboree at the Ritz Carlton Hotel.

Dr. James H. Breasted, director of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago and one of the world's foremost authorities on the ancient civilizations of Egypt and the Near East, became ill last Tuesday aboard the Conte di Savoia, on which he was returning to the United States from a trip of inspection of the various expeditions of the institute.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 28. -- Two women and nine men, all Catholics, arrested last Saturday on a charge of aiding a seditious movement against the government of the State of Jalisco, were removed from police headquarters today to the city penitentiary and placed at the disposition of the Federal Attorney General.
Galloping around the outdoor circuit:

h)0*0*0*iOCritical for France, and perhaps even more so for the rest of Europe, was the decided vote of the Chamber of Deputies yesterday, to continue the Laval Cabinet in office. Defeat for the Premier would have plunged everything into confusion both at home and abroad.

New York money market closed for holiday. Wednesday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans, three-quarters of 1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans, 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, three-quarters of 1 per cent.
ROME, Nov. 28. -- Responsible persons with high connections said tonight that a war that might be a world war would be certain to result if the League of Nations placed an oil embargo upon Italy.

PRAGUE, Nov. 28. -- Sergei Kozimoff, a clerk in the Soviet Legation here, was arrested today by detectives in Hirschberg as the plunderer of the Soviet Legation yesterday who escaped with all the cash in the safe.
The annual R. H. Macy Co. Thanksgiving Day parade crawled along Broadway yesterday under threatening skies and finished in a downpour at Thirty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Americans here celebrated Thanksgiving tonight at the annual dinner of the American Society. Ambassador Robert W. Bingham presided, while addresses were made by Lord Hewart, Lord Chief Justice, and Professor Kenneth Murdock of Harvard.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- In front for approximately four-fifths of the race, Ray Trail, ace of the Mont Pleasant High School squad of Schenectady, scored an impressive triumph in the tenth annual national interscholastic cross-country championship, contested over the Branch Brook Park course this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Presidential approval of a highway, road and street program for New York State to be carried out with $10,546,377 in work relief funds previously allotted by Secretary Wallace was announced today by the Division of Applications and Information.

Holiday traffic, made doubly dangerous by wet streets in the afternoon and evening, took four lives and brought injuries to eleven persons in Queens yesterday. There also were three serious crashes in New Jersey communities during the day, a baby being killed and nineteen persons being hurt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Members of the Civilian Conservation Corps, now numbering nearly 600,000, have been of great assistance to the national park service in controlling forest fires, fighting insect pests and preventing soil erosion, Arno B. Cammerer, director of the National Park Service, stated today in a report to Robert Fechner, CCC director.
Residential properties figured in most of the real estate transactions reported yesterday as the Thanksgiving holiday kept trading belowh)0*0*0*inormal.

The Columbia University Glee Club will hold its twelfth annual Thanksgiving concert and dance tonight in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. More than 300 undergraduates and their guests are expected to attend, according to W. Emerson Buckley, '36, of New York, manager of the club.

The Manhattan Acmes from Fifty-ninth Street Playground defeated a Queens team drawn from the College Point Arrows and the Astoria Maple Leafs by three goals to one yesterday afternoon in the finals of the Park Department's interborough roller hockey tournament at Roosevelt Playground on the lower East Side.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -Superior man-power that packed speed and deception paved the way to New Rochelle High School's 32-19 triumph over the Charles E. Gorton High School today before 8,000 persons on the losers' gridiron.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- In the absence of any clear indication of British and French intentions regarding the embargo on exports to Italy of oil, coal and copper the European situation must still be regarded as extremely grave.
The Hershey Hockey Club moved into the lead in the Eastern Amateur League yesterday afternoon by downing the previously unbeaten New York Rovers, 5 to 2, at Madison Square Garden before 3,500 fans.
For Fordham on Thanksgiving Day there came the realization that it has one of the truly fine football teams of the country.

Early and favorable action by the PWA on the recent request of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel Authority for a grant of $11,250,000 is asked of Harold L. Ickes, Federal Public Works Administrator, by the Fifth Avenue Association in a letter made public yesterday.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Six persons died and eleven were injured in a fire which destroyed a two-story frame apartment building here today following a gas explosion.

Sir James Colquhoun Irvine, vice chancellor of the University of St. Andrews, Scotland, will be the principal speaker this afternoon at the National Interfraternity Conference, which will continue at the Roosevelt Hotel sessions that began on Wednesday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP). -Army and Navy came to town in the rain tonight for their annual football battle Saturday.
Leasing of store space for restaurants featured the business rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Three such establishments on Broadway and Eighth Avenue were involved in the leasing contracts.

Early in January the Municipal Art Committee, appointed last Winter by Mayor La Guardia, will open temporary exhibition galleries at 62 West Fifty-third Street in a fivestory building provided for the purpose by Mr. La Guardia and the Board of Transportation, it was announced yesterday.

A confusion in the current discussion of the neutrality issue needs to be corrected. The choice is frequently made to appear to be between an elastic policy which would enable this government to cooperate with other nations in preventing war, and an inelastic policy which would isolate the United States from all international efforts for peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Conditions in the building industry, where 5,000,000 persons are estimated to have been unemployed during the low point of the depression, continue to improve rapidly, according to a report today by the Department of Labor.
BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Two tales of local revolt against the Nazi regime became public here today.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- A further step toward the conversion of Germany into "a nation in arms" was announced today with the publication of a law providing for the creation of trained reserves and their maintenance at a high level of efficiency through annual training exercises.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The expectation was voiced here today by lawyers for both sides that the Supreme Court would decide the two main AAA cases now pending, by Jan. 13, or ten days after Congress convenes.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 28. -- The funeral of former Emperor Lij Yasu was held secretly yesterday at the monastery of Debre Libanos, 100 miles north of Addis Ababa, the only mourner being the aged priest Amba Hanna, who was the imprisoned ruler's constant companion for nineteen years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- An amendment to the Federal Trade Commission law to protect the public from unfair or deceptive commercial practices is recommended by the Federal Trade Commission in its report for the year ended June 30.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 28. -Displaying their best brand of football of the season, the University of Kentucky Wildcats today rolled over the University of Tennessee Volunteers by 27 to 0, which equaled the worst defeat either team has taken in this traditional series started in 1899.

More than 200 artists, representing twenty States, have accepted the call to the American Artists Congress to be held in New York on Feb. 14-16. Among them are seventeen with work entered in the 1935 Carnegie International, according to Stuart Davis, who is acting as secretary to the congress.

For the text of "How Beautiful With Shoes" which was played at the Booth last evening, Wilbur Daniel Steele and Anthony Brown have gone to a verse in the song of Solomon, "How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O Prince's daughter."

To introduce their daughter, MissMarie Louise Kaufman, Mr. and~l~[rs. Louis Graveraet l/[aufman,i gave a supper dance last night at~their home, 625 l~ark Avenue. Thedance was preceded by a dinner forthe d~butante and some of herfriends.
WASI-HNGTON, Nov. 28.--l~earAdmiral and Mrs. Adolphus Andrews, held a reception this afternoon in their home to introducetheir daughter, Miss Frances Andrews, to society.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -Johnny Kelley of Arlington, Mass., who captured the grueling Boston marathon earlier this year, ran another brilliant race today to take the revival of the Yonkers marathon, held under the auspices of the Chippewa Club, in 2 hours 38 minutes 43 seconds.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- With Parliament opening under uncertain conditions, the Bourse today was inactive, and, despite yesterday's rally, was irregular throughout. Most shares, including rentes, closed slightly below yesterday's levels.

TORONTO, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Dixiana Farm of Lexington, Ky., won first, second and third places in the $1,000 Irwin three-gaited saddle stake, one of the feature events of the closing program at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight.

A frankly tentative trial marriage was celebrated in Madison Square Garden the other night between the Communist party and the Left Wing Socialists under the leadership of NORMAN THOMAS. Twice the standardbearer of the Socialist party in national elections, Mr. THOMAS now speaks for the majority in the national Socialist organization, which is in favor of trying out a united front with the Communists.

New York City celebrated Thanksgiving Day yesterday in its usual hearty fashion. There was hardly a person among all the city's million's who did not enjoy a turkey or chicken dinner with all the fixings, along with the sense of wellbeing and thankfulness for the bounties of nature which is traditional of the holiday.

The New York Giants burned their Brooklyn bridges behind them yesterday and left the Dodgers stranded, two games behind them in the race for the championship of the Eastern Division in the National Football League.

It is now nine months since the bodyh)0*0*0*iof SAM DRUCKMAN was found in a Brooklyn garage. In the interval the case has burst the bonds of an ordinary murder mystery and come to involve the good repute of the District Attorney of Kings County as well as the integrity of certain police officers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 28 (AP). -Professor Charles Swain Thomas of Harvard University believes a requirement for an English teacher's preparation "should be a stiff course of logic, or at least a demonstrated ability to think clearly and to express thought accurately."
ROME, Nov. 28. -- Official Italian dispatches said tonight that Daggah Bur, Ethiopia's "hold-out" fortress on the southern front, was demolished by an air bombardment.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Pennsylvania's mystery team wound up its season with the most decisive victory it has scored over Cornell since 1928 in the forty-second holding of their Thanksgiving Day classic at Franklin Field.
A cold wave heading eastward from the Great Lakes and the Ohio Valley is due to arrive in New York City late today, according to officials of the Weather Bureau.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Brazilian Government announced the complete suppression of the leftist revolt today and said that 138 persons had been killed in the four days of fighting. The nation was rapidly returning to normalcy, although a "state of siege" was in existence.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Many members of the American colony here attended a Thanksgiving dinner tonight at which Ambassador William E. Dodd was guest of honor and chief speaker. He discussed the problems confronting the postwar world, especially in their bearing on current international relations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Thanksgiving Day dinners were served at all the Westchester County institutions at Eastview today, and in all the municipalities of the country service clubs, charity organizations and individuals distributed baskets of holiday food to the poor.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Times of London will devote its chief editorial tomorrow morning to an explanation of United States neutrality, declaring that the recasting of American conceptions of neutrality now in progress is of immediate and direct concern to Britain.

The volume of orders for fabricated structural steel booked in October was 12 per cent greater than the monthly average for 1935, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction. The shipments were about equal to the monthly average of the year.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the week ended on Wednesday, amounted to $5,472,471,000, against $4,174,354,000 for the corresponding week last year, a gain of 31 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt and Vice President and Mrs. Garner, both on this year's absentee list from the capital, ate their Thanksgiving dinners miles apart this year, the President heading a holiday party at Warm Springs, Ga., and Vice President Garner an offical group homeward bound from the Philippines and due to arrive about Dec. 13.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased $5,179,059 from the previous week, the bank weekly statement said today. Time deposits by chartered banks increased $1,368,958.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP). -- Additional Work Relief projects aggregating $5,050,558.65 have been approved by the allocation board of the New York State Works Progress Administration, Up-State Administrator Lester W. Herzog announced today.

Sal Ferrara, speedy right halfback, led the St. John's Prep eleven to victory and an undefeated season -- the first in the school's history -- as the Red and White conquered its traditional rival, Brooklyn Prep, in the seventeenth meeting between the teams at Boys High Field yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28. -- Governor George H. Earle, acting through the State Emergency Relief Administration, late last night ordered all cash State relief to be cut off from 34,000 Pittsburgh relief cases. The move followed Mayor William N. McNair's refusal to provide city money to cooperate with the Federal WPA work relief program.

TIENTSIN, Nov. 28. -- In a sudden switch of sentiment, diplomatic, press and army circles, in Tientsin have become convinced that a Chino-Japanese armed conflict over autonomy is highly unlikely.
