As a result, although, the Japanese continue preparing an air field here, still hold planes ready to transport troops and are sending two destroyers here, there is little evidence of tension in the foreign and Chinese communities.

The melancholy Dane said to Ophelia, "Be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape calumny." But what would the unlucky Prince have said if he knew that there are at least two kinds of hot ice? Professor PERCY BRIDGMAN at Harvard has discovered two new ice varieties, making seven all told.

Two goals by Lynn Patrick gave the New York Rangers another triumph last night. The crafty blue-jerseyed sextet turned back a favored Chicago Black Hawk team at Madison Square Garden by the score of 2 to 1 to register their third straight triumph and to move into exclusive possession of first place in the American Division of the National Hockey League.

Jock McAvoy, who holds the middleweight and light heavyweight championships of the British Empire, will be seen in action in an American ring for the first time tonight when he faces Al McCoy, hardpunching French-Canadian from Boston, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

ON BOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Deception Island, Antarctica, Nov. 28. -- Another day of constant listening has failed to reveal the position of Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, who are somewhere on the Antarctic Continent between the Weddell and the Ross Seas.

JUST to keep the record straight M'sieu Gerard Debaets, who had parked his bicycle outside, said that he was born in Antwerp, Belgium, thirty-five years ago. He is 5 feet 10 inches in height, weighs about 180 pounds and is covered with more scars than those gathered in six-day bike races. He is one of eight boys in the Debaets family and six of them became professional bike riders.

ATHENS, Nov. 28. -- The unyielding attitude of the Kondylis government today obliged King George to take steps to form a neutral Cabinet before issuing the general amnesty for civilians and pardons for those interned desired by the King himself.

An increase of 15.3 per cent in the sales of wholesale firms in this district, the largest advance recorded since last December, featured the report on October trade, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain was particularly marked in the case of shoes, which showed a rise in sales of 49.4 per cent over the same month last year.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 28. -Getting off to a flying start as a result of making a fumble and a blocked punt count for touchdowns, South Bend Central High's football team scored a 27-14 victory over the invading White Plains (N.Y.) High School eleven this morning before a shivering crowd of 7,500.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28. -- Appeals to Jews for a closer unity as a means of sponsoring causes to combat intolerance, anti-Semitism and totalitarianism, "the ugly outgrowth of fascism," marked the opening here today of the joint annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, and Junior Hadassah.

The strong Hampton Institute eleven displayed a diversified attack at the Polo Grounds yesterday and defeated its time-honored rival, Virginia Union University of Richmond, 15 to 7, in a hard-fought contest staged before 6,000.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Five Cleveland families received Thanksgiving greetings today in the form of checks totaling $90.60 from Joseph Russell, who is serving fiftyfive years in Ohio penitentiary.
MANILA, Friday, Nov. 29. -- The China Clipper, bearing the first transpacific air mail from Alameda, Calif., appeared over Manila Bay at 3 P.M. [2 A.M., Eastern standard time] today.
HELENA, Mont., Nov. 28 (AP). -Earth shocks as intense as the major tremors of a few weeks ago jolted Helena today, but the city escaped serious damage.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Nov. 28. -President Roosevelt celebrated Thanksgiving Day by presiding, as he has done for many years, at a dinner for patients and members of the Warm Springs Foundation, which he established for sufferers from infantile paralysis.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 28. -The victorious Labor party is expected to hold a caucus Monday to select Cabinet members, to whom Joseph Savage, who will become Prime Minister, will give portfolios.

Sir Norman Angell, Nobel Peace Prize winner, headed a panel of speakers last night with a statement of facts which, he said, "a good many pacifists do not face," in a symposium on "Is Peace Possible Without World Organization?" at the Town Hall.

The years were turned back yesterday. Like a flashback to the days of Chick Meehan and his touchdown cannon, the FordhamN.Y.U. game once again had the place of importance in the public eye which it held half a decade ago.

GENEVA, Nov. 28. -- The League of Nations committee of experts that is considering the way in which governments are applying sanctions against Italy tightened the financial sanction with a stricter interpretation today.

GENEVA, Nov. 28. -- Ronald Garrett, British ship owners' delegate, announced today that he would refuse to participate further in discussions by the preparatory maritime conference of the International Labor organization regarding the manning of ships and the hours worked except as they relate to the general economic aspect.

At the suggestion of the Merchants Association, a Citizens Committee of Five Hundred is now being organized to oppose Mayor LA GUARDIA'S efforts to establish a "yardstick" electric light plant in this city. The Mayor will probably denounce the five hundred as tools of the "Power Trust," even if no utility companies are directly represented.

There was a round of parties yesterday for debutantes, the largest being the dinner dance last night at the Pierre given by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie to introduce their daughter, Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie. It was similar to the party that Mr. and Mrs. Gillespie gave two years ago for the debut of their eldest daughter, Miss Eileen Gillespie.
In your editorial "Efficiency and Welfare" you misconstrued the approach of those of us upholding the possibility of "an economy of abundance." May I try to make our position clear?

Legislation will be sought at the next session of Congress to extend admiralty jurisdiction to cover damage done by vessels to docks, piers and other land structures, it was announced yesterday in a report published by the Committee on Admiralty of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A warning that the administration must proceed cautiously in any move to strengthen present neutrality laws was sounded today by Senator Borah, senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

h)0*0*0*iODispatches of the past week from Warm Springs, Ga., where Mr. ROOSEVELT has been wrestling with the Executive budget for 1936-37, have represented him as "cold" to proposals to include soldiers' bonus. This is easily intelligible. A President struggling for economy in the budget could not be anything but extremely frigid to plans which would add something like 60 per cent to the regular expenditures.

A tea dance was given yesterday at Sherry's by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson to introduce their daughter, Miss Dorothy Nelson. The debutante, who attended the Fermata School in Aiken and Miss Porter's School, Farmington, Conn., received with her mother.

Ghaffar Khan Djalal, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, who has handled the affairs of his native Iran (Persia) in Washington for the last two and a half years, told yesterday his version of how he was arrested and handcuffed Wednesday in a smalltown speed trap.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28. -- The Governor of the State of Rio Grande do Norte reported today that the liner Santos, on which 500 rebels had fled from Natal after having held the city for several days, had returned to the port because of lack of fuel and the rebels had been taken prisoner.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 28. -- The question of resumption of payment of Chile's foreign debt obligations once again was discussed in the press today as a result of recent statements made by Salvarino Gallardo, prominent lawyer, in the course of defense of a member of the local directorate of the Chilean Electric Light Company, accused of violating the exchange control laws.
BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- Prices on the Boerse were weak in inactive trading today. Heavy industrial issues continued stagnant. Machine stocks were slightly stronger, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 3/4 point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -A large question mark tonight shadowed the eventual status of United States troops in North Chinah)0*0*0*iin view of Japanese military concentrations there and the seizure by Japanese soldiery of control over railway lines in Eastern Hopei Province.

Aylmer Vallance, editor of The London News Chronicle, arrived last night on the Manhattan of the United States Lines for his first visit to America. He said he would spend a month here to study newspaper methods in New York and other cities.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- With a long forward pass and Walter Dobie's drop kick in the opening period, Bucknell gained a surprise 7-to-6 victory over Temple in the Owls' Stadium today before a crowd of 13,000 spectators.
PARIS, Nov. 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -Plans for a permanent organization of business and labor leaders, under the government's wing, to give continuous attention to industrial problems are being developed by George L. Berry, the President's coordinator for industrial cooperation.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 28. -Winding up the most unsuccessful season in his ten years of coaching at Brown, Tuss McLaughry today saw his Bruins suffer a 33-0 defeat against Andy Kerr's Colgate Red Raiders before the smallest crowd in the history of their Thanksgiving Day series.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 28. -Playing inspired football, Vanderbilt defeated Alabama, 14 to 6, before a crowd of 18,000 in Vanderbilt Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Craft unions have failed in the crucial task of organizing the great massproduction industries and the only way workers in these industries can achieve industrial freedom is through organization by industries, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, asserted tonight in a radio broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Liquidation of the twelve governmentowned Regional Agricultural Credit Corporations has proceeded to the point at which less than $48,000,000 remains of the total loans of $304,000,000 now outstanding, W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The East Orange eleven came back after a four-year victory lapse to down Barringer's team 19-12, today in the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the oldest high school rivalry in New Jersey. More than 10,000 spectators saw East Orange pass its way to victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Guffey Coal Act headed toward Supreme Court review tonight as tests of an even dozen New Deal measures before the high tribunal were projected within the next year.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- University of Maryland and Syracuse University fought to a scoreless tie in the rain and mud as some 4,000 hardy football fans huddled in the Stadium today.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Nov. 28. -- An 11-months-old child was killed and its parents and another couple, all of Schenectady, N.Y., were injured today when their automobile was in collision with a truck on the Hamburg Turnpike here.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 28. -Thousands of present-day Pilgrims flocked to old Plymouth today for a Thanksgiving Day celebration which was gay and happy despite leaden skies and bursts of rain.

Evidence of new progress in the conquest of radio fading, one of the principal obstacles in effective short-wave communication, was presented yesterday in the current issue of Science by Dr. Harry Rowe Mimno of Cruft Laboratory, Harvard University.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28. -Bloomfield High School's powerful gridiron squad ended its season undefeated, untied and unscored upon today with an impressive 12-to-0 victory over Montclair High as a crowd of 15,000-looked on.
Fat, a brown, rotund monkey that stands some eighteen inches high, went hitch-hiking yesterday morning and he picked the West Side Express Highway to do it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- With traditional ceremony, in the matter of rank and decorations, Thanksgiving Day was celebrated in Washington with the Navy Relief Ball at the Willard Hotel. Flags provided the customary color note, and the Navy and Marine Corps Bands, the music.
ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 28 (AP). -Emperor Haile Selassie left today for Dessie to take command of his warriors attempting to repel the Italian invasion.

HAVANA, Friday, Nov. 29. -- Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, has been invited by the Cuban Government to come to Cuba to act as technical adviser to the government on modification of the electoral code with a view to settlement of the controversy among the political parties which has caused an indefinite postponement of elections.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28. -The swiftness and efficiency with which military forces have dominated the Communist elements, as well as the irrepressible hostility of the civil population to charlatans, has shown once again how extremist doctrines and their methods of bloody violence constitute the antithesis of the Brazilian soul and feeling.

PEIPING, Nov. 28. -- In view of the tremendous Japanese pressure being exerted here, an important announcement is expected hourly from General Sung Cheh-yuan, commander of the Peiping-Tientsin garrison. Japanese sources quote General Sung as saying that he rejected Nanking's appointment as Pacification Commissioner for Hopei and Chahar Provinces because it came too late, for the situation had reached a point where he could do little if he accepted.

ROME, Nov. 28. -- Financial experts said today sanctions and patriotism had solved Italy's gold problem. The gold drain, it was said, had been halted by public offerings so great that before the end of the year Italy might increase her reserve by 50 per cent.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28. -- Uncensored telephone messages from Rio de Janeiro indicate that the federal government has the situation well in hand. The revolt in the northern States had collapsed Tuesday night before the outbreak of yesterday's abortive attempt to spread the uprising to troops in Rio de Janeiro.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Nov. 28. -- Death penalties for two 15-yearold Edwardsville boys will be asked by State's Attorney Lester Geers in the Madison County Circuit Court here, he said today, after they admitted a part in the killing of John C. Higgins, Deputy County Treasurer, early Tuesday morning and brutally beating Margie, 7-year-old daughter of Higgins.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP). -Further support for Senator Borah of Idaho as the Republican Presidential nominee in 1936 came today from Representative Fish of New York, himself known as a "liberal" and a possible seeker of the nomination.
CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 28. -- Penn Military College kept its six-year home record clean by defeating Ursinus in a hard-fought game today, 6 to 0.

As Marshal Pietro Badoglio takes command of the Italian forces in Ethiopia, the situation is obscure because of conflicting claims put out on behalf of the rival armies. It is evident, however, from accounts on both sides that the Italians have met with unforeseen troubles in the north as well as the south.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29. -- The financial report of the Harvard Athletic Association for the twelve months ending June 30, 1935, incorporated in the annual report of Henry L. Shattuck, treasurer of Harvard College, showed an excess of income over expenses of $2,306.18.

The new Walker Gallery, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street, opened its doors a few weeks ago with an exhibition made up of work by six Americans, three belonging to an earlier generation (Winslow Homer, Thomas Eakins and Albert P. Ryder) and three contemporary -- Thomas Benton, Grant Wood and John Steuart Curry.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- Two French newspapers and, following their lead, a British newspaper published today a sensational version of the interviews Premier Pierre Laval had three days ago with Sir George Clerk, the British Ambassador, and Vittorio Cerruti, the Italian Ambassador.

Mr. and Mrs. Mason Huntington Bigelow gave a small dinner dance last night at their home, 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Katharine Huntington Bigelow. The members of the party then attended a supper dance given for Miss Elizabeth Merrill and Miss Cornelia Dickerman.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Nov. 30. -- Chinese, Japanese and foreign circles here were astounded to hear this morning that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, flying from Nanking, had arrived at Chungking late yesterday afternoon.

William P. Earle 3d, 19 years old, a Princeton sophomore, was injured fatally early yesterday morning in a collision of automobiles on the depressed highway in Jersey City. The youth, who was the son of William B. Earle of 120 Willow Street, Brooklyn, suffered a fractured skull and died at the Medical Center at 5:30 A.M., several hours after the accident, in which four other persons were injured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Drastic reductions in railroad freight rates on citrus fruits from Florida to New York City and other Atlantic ports were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The ruling establishes a precedent in rate-making which is intended to enable the roads to compete more effectively with truck and water transportation.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The reserve ratio for the New York bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- A recommendation that the Federal Reserve Banks allow some of their holdings of short-term government securities to run off at maturity, thus reducing excess bank reserves and the threat of credit inflation, has been laid before the Open Market Committee of the Reserve System by the Federal Reserve Advisory Council, it was learned here today.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 29. -- "Pay dirt" has been discovered in Constable Hook, in the midst of oil tanks and pipe lines, on the site of the old International Nickel Company property here. Prospectors by the score, with sieves, spades and shovels, are flocking to the plant, assured of fairly good wages every day they work.

New York will have its final football game of the year this afternoon when Columbia and Dartmouth meet at Baker Field, starting at 1:30 o'clock. Morningside officials expect a capacity crowd of 32,000 if the weather is favorable.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S speech at Atlanta yesterday was heralded in advance as the beginning of his campaign for reelection. It was not quite that. Speaking to his good friends and neighbors in Georgia, the President naturally began with expressions of friendship and indebtedness, a little effusive perhaps, but pardonable in a public man.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29 (AP). -- Duke's champion Blue Devils placed three members on the All-Southern Conference football team chosen for The Associated Press today by coaches and sports writers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP). -- The Federal Reserve Board placed tonight restrictive regulations upon borrowings by officers of member banks from their own institutions. The orders supplemented those of a few days ago by which the board established technical machinery for increasing reserve requirements as a means of checking what it might consider an unhealthful pyramiding of bank credit.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29. -- In spite of a cold, biting snow storm that turned the carefully nurtured greensward of the Laurel School field into a treacherously slippery and slow playing surface, the well organized field hockey teams from the East showed to even greater advantage than yesterday against their Western opponents in the second round of the national round-robin tournament today.

ROME, Nov. 29 (AP). -- After yesterday's aerial assault on Daggah Bur, small forces of Ethiopians were believed to be gathering today to block again the projected Italian march into the heart of their empire.

The reorganization plan of the Ohio Water Service Company, a subsidiary of the Federal Water Service Corporation, has been approved by the Northern District Federal Court in Ohio in proceedings under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

The United States Coast Guard has asked the City of New York to deed a part of its airport at Floyd Bennett Field to the Treasury Department for the establishment of a large air base for the New York division, it was learned yesterday. The request was filed with John McKenzie, Commissioner of Docks, late in October, but no reply to the letter had been received up to yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- The Boerse was quiet but firmish today, most transactions continuing to be made outside the official Exchange.
A sharp break in cotton in Alexandria influenced prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, and the list ended at losses of 3 to 7 points.

From the point of view of the enthusiastic New Dealer, today's figures in The Literary Digest poll must be still less satisfying than those which were published a week ago. For one thing, the percentage of straw-voters who express their disapproval of "the acts and policies" of the Roosevelt Administration has increased from slightly more than 53 per cent to nearly 56 per cent of the total cast.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- Facing 50,000 cheering Georgians at a "home-coming" celebration here today, President Roosevelt declared that the depth of the depression had passed and, with it, the peak of Federal appropriations.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- The text of the address prepared for delivery here today by President Roosevelt was as follows:

A rising tide of opposition to President Roosevelt's policies is disclosed in the new returns of the Literary Digest poll, it was announced yesterday. With 167,000 additional ballots tabulated, the totals showed 91,351 votes for the President and his policies and 115,736 against them.
NANKING, Nov. 29 (AP). -- China's central government openly indicted the Japanese Army today for "conniving" to create an autonomous State in North China.

One week ago this morning this hebdomadal column ventured to predict that the nocturnal event of the ensuing seven days would be the opening of the classy New Montmartre on Wednesday evening, with Beatrice Lillie and trimmings. Well, this column -- in all innocence -- was wrong.

George E. Hegarty, for twenty-one years an employe of the composing room of THE NEW YORK TIMES and for the past six years assistant night foreman, was killed accidentally by illuminating gas Thanksgiving evening at his home at 242-14 Ninetieth Avenue, Bellerose, Queens. He was 38 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- American manufacture of arms and munitions and the export of these war supplies came directly under control of the government as legislation passed by Congress last August automatically became effective today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Miss Diana Mary Douglass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Graham Dun Douglass of Douglaston, Queens, was presented yesterday afternoon at a reception for several hundred guests at the home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dun Douglass of Llewellyn Park.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- With a zeal and determination reminiscent of the last whirlwind days of the campaign for national enfranchisement, women from all parts of the country are arriving here tonight for the National Woman's party conference called to plan and organize a final drive for adoption by Congress of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

ATHENS, Nov. 29. -- Constantine Demertzis at King George's request prepared tonight a proposed Cabinet of neutral persons, chosen to satisfy the King's insistence for a complete amnesty as well as former Premier Panazoti Tsaldaris's demand that the National Assembly be convoked.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Acquisition of all plots in the seven-acre site for New York City's $4,700,000 Harlem River low-cost housing and slum clearance program was announced today by Secretary Ickes.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York has adopted a lower dividend scale for 1936 because of the reduced return on its investments, it was announced yesterday. While the exact amount can not be determined until the close of this year, the total will approximate $23,900,000, or about 85 per cent of the amount set aside for dividends this year.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Bedford Hills, N.Y., made an excellent start in the hunter division at the fifth annual Peekskill Horse Show, which opened this afternoon in the new State Armory.

Miss Cornelia Dickerman and Miss Elizabeth Merrill, who attended the Brearley School together and from which they were graduated last Spring, made their debuts jointly last night at the Pierre, where their parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman and Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Merrill, gave a supper dance for them.

The English idea of the small college as a social unit within the university that has recently been adopted at Harvard and Yale was discussed in an address by Sir James Colquhoun Irvine, vice chancellor and principal of the University of St. Andrews, Scotland, at yesterday afternoon's session of the National Interfraternity Conference in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Mayor La Guardia has been sued by Charles Shankroff, a Brooklyn real estate man, for $50,000 damages for calling him a "bum" and "faker" at a Board of Estimate meeting on Oct. 18.The suit was disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Wasservogel denied an application by Shankroff for permission to examine John H. Schwarting and Manus A. O'Donnell, stenographers for the Board of Estimate, concerning the language said to have been used by the Mayor.

Jock McAvoy, from the Lancashire mill districts of England, impressed fight fans at Madison Square Garden last night as he hammered his way to the decision over Al McCoy, Boston light-heavyweight, in a bitterly waged ten-round battle.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP). -- Employment, payrolls, orders and prospects showed big increases in factories wholesale houses and retail establishments of up-State New York, the Marine Midland banking group reported today as the result of a survey.

Although new bond financing this week dropped off sharply from the preceding week, two public utility issues brought the total to $58,531,900, against $22,110,000 offered in the corresponding period of last year and $177,549,000 last week.

The weekly Federal Reserve reports, issued yesterday, showed that member-bank reserves had risen $7,000,000 further in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high level of $5,789,000,000, but that the excess of reserves over legal requirements had in the same period declined $10,000,000 to about $3,060,000,000.
Deputy Chief Inspector Michael A. Lyons and ten other police officers will be promoted by Commissioner Valentine in the presence of Mayor La Guardia at a ceremony at City Hall at 10 A.M. Monday.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Stewart Durand and Dr. and Mrs. Harris Fenton Brownlee jointly gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the home of the former, 35 East Sixty-third Street, to introduce their daughters, Miss Marion Stewart Durand and Miss Adelaide Dennis Brownlee.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 30. -- The Cabinet approved today the largest army and navy appropriations in the history of the Japanese empire, constituting 46.8 per cent of the total estimated expenditures for the coming fiscal year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29. -- Subsidizing athletes in many of our higher institutions of learning continues secretly while the college authorities openly say that no athlete scholarships are being granted, according to Dr. Wilson Farrand, secretary of Princeton University.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- With a pained expression on his face Dr. Ernst Hanfstaengl, chief of the Nazi foreign press bureau, told a British court under oath today that he never swore against Oxford professors and never uttered a threat attributed to him -- "I will send some of our swine to burn down their Oxford."

GENEVA, Nov. 29. -- Disregarding the refusal of British shipowners to participate in the discussion, the International Labor Organization's preparatory maritime conference took up in private today detailed technical work on the proposed convention for internationally regulating the manning of ships.

Editors of newspapers in twenty-five Eastern and Southern colleges, meeting at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, for a three-day conference, were urged by two speakers to devote more editorial space to a discussion of social and economic problems of the day.

Although the stock market has been declining fairly steadily since Nov. 20, when the highest level for the year was established by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, it appears likely that this index will show a net gain for November after today's month-end session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Federal dole, which has cost the government $3,694,000,000 since May, 1933, was ended today. The FERA announced that the twenty-two States not already cut off the direct relief list had received their final payments for direct relief.

TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Nov. 29 (AP). -- A trail of violence which followed Douglas Van Vlack across the Far West was newly evidenced today when the crushed and bullet-pierced body of his divorced wife, Mildred Hook, was found near here.

Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge introduced their nieces, Miss Margaret Dodge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Dodge of Beirut, Syria, and Miss Ruth Rea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Childs Rea of Pittsburgh, last night at a small dinner dance at their home Greystone, Riverdale, N.Y. Both debutantes, who are spending the holiday with host and hostess and their grandmother, Mrs. Cleveland H. Dodge, are sophomores at Vassar College.

ON BOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Deception Island, Antarctica, Nov. 29. -- No wireless signals from Lincoln Ellsworth, wherever he might be on the Antarctic Continent, have been heard since his signals faded Saturday when he was virtually half way between the Weddell and Ross Seas on his projected flight over Antarctica.

The Engineers Public Service Company reports for the year ended Oct. 31 total revenue of $1,108,568, compared with $620,929 in the preceding year, and net income of $960,536, against $454,404 the year before, with preferred dividend requirements $2,323,537 for the period.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 29 (AP). -- Federal Judge John P. Nields refused today to rule summarily on the constitutionality of the Utilities Holding Company Act and dismissed the petition which requested the opinion.

The Blue Ridge Corporation has declared a dividend of one-tenth of a share of Central States Electric Corporation on each outstanding share of Blue Ridge common stock, payable on Dec. 17 to holders of record on Dec. 6, thus leaving the corporation with less than 10 per cent of the stock of this company.

The officers and members of the council of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers were cleared yesterday of charges of malfeasance, misfeasance and non-feasance made by John Parker, a member, on the ground that they had wasted funds of the society in publishing The Engineering Index, a resume of engineering progress throughout the world.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29. -- The Eastern racing season will end here tomorrow, when seven races will he run, featured by the $5,000 Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap, for which nine have been named. The mile-and-three-sixteenths test will be notable for the return to competition Walter M. Jeffords's Firethorn, beaten favorite in the Riggs Handicap, but before that the victor in the Lawrence Realization and Jockey Club Gold Cup.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES criticizing the amateur economist is unfair to that individual. Can THE TIMES name any issue outside of the Smoot-Hawley tariff which 1,000 economists are willing to support? The fact that professional economists never agree is sufficient proof that theirs is no true science, and this explains the existence of amateur economists.

Miss Vera Stretz, charged with the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt in the Beekman Tower, 3 Beckman Place, on Nov. 12, said yesterday that she believed that "any decent person would do the same thing under the circumstances." She was interviewed in the Women's Detention prison, with her attorney, Samuel Leibowitz, at her side.

With the share market currently supersensitive to day-to-day developments bearing on the financial scene, in contrast with the more confident feeling in evidence not many months ago when prices were appreciably lower than they are now, any attempt to produce a seismographic record of this or that influence, marketwise, would result in a confused picture.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on five European members of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at a special university convocation yesterday noon in the Low Memorial Library.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Rishi, a useful campaigner from H. Hagen's stable, came through with a victory in his first start at the Fair Grounds today when he led a field of claimers over six furlongs in the feature race.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29. -- A change in terms of the Rockefeller Foundation grant will give the Harvard University Committee on Research in the Social Sciences $300,000 to finance its activities for five years. Of the amount $200,000 is given unconditionally, while $100,000 is subject to the dollar-for-dollar matching terms of the Rockefeller Foundation.

The Royton Realty Corporation, which acquired the northwest corner of Hudson and Leroy Streets last week, enlarged its holdings yesterday by purchasing three adjoining buildings from Trinity Church. The corporation, a syndicate recently organized by George Robinson, attorney, now owns the block front on the west side of Hudson Street between Leroy and Morton Streets. All the properties were bought through William S. Sussman, Inc.

BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- The National Socialist Winter propaganda campaign, designed to allay growing unrest and to fortify the supporters of the regime, was inaugurated by Chancellor Hitler himself tonight with a speech before some 20,000 persons that packed the new and imposing German Hall erected on the outskirts of Berlin as a rallying centre for Nazi mass demonstrations.

Jackie Merkle, the 7-year-old "mind reader" who has been amazing the public in general and city officials in particular with his mental feats, shifted his scene of activity from City Hall over to the Hall of Records yesterday and gave Surrogate James A Foley a few pointers about surrogate law.

Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Reid gave a dinner dance last evening at their home, 15 East Eighty-fourth Street, for Miss M. Thayer Gibbons, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Gibbons. Miss Gibbons was graduated last June from Miss Hewitt's School, having previously attended for three years Rosemary Hall in Greenwich, Conn.

Sixteen Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Savings banks were plaintiffs in half of the actions. A Broadway skating rink was included in the parcels taken over to protect liens, as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the risk of being characterized "constitutional termites," to borrow President Hoover's recent words, we hasten to the defense of THE TIMES editorial "General Welfare," which Mr. Jansen in his letter printed Nov. 20, held to have conveyed an erroneous impression to your readers.

The annual campaign of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association is so well established in the goodwill of this community, and reaches so close to its homes and firesides, that no extended notice of the appeal would seem to be needed. It goes straight to every heart and should unloose the strings of every purse.

There was a census in Turkey the other day. Since this enumeration, usually for purposes of taxation, comes from the East, it is just that the Turks should be subject to it. A mere and straight count was all that KEMAL ATATURK asked of his people. While the walls were covered with posters, one trait of the day brings us back to the Arabian Nights.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Diplomatic activities between London and Paris are at fever heat just now. In a few days probably an official announcement will be given out on a forthcoming meeting in one or the other capital of representatives of the British and French Governments.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29. -- The University of Miami eleven continued its victorious march tonight at the expense of the Boston University Terriers, winning by 17 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Louis Stark wrote interestingly in THE NEW YORK TIMES about the troubles of the anthracite industry. He failed, however, to bring out fundamental difficulties which the industry has not yet succeeded in o ercoming.

Three Midwest thugs robbed Frances Faye, night-club entertainer, and her escort, Joseph Eichenbaum, of rings valued at $6,200 and $160 in cash on Fifty-second Street near Seventh Avenue at 3 A.M. yesterday. Two suspects were wounded and captured and one escaped during a swift chase that ended in a smash-up at Ninth Avenue and Sixty-third Street.

William C. Coyle, Jr. made short work of the final of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association's annual tournament at the New York A.C. last night, defeating George A. Phelps of the Yale Club in three straight games, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Active buying of wheat futures which the trade attributed to short covering for an Eastern operator carried prices up sharply today, and while the best figures were not maintained, because of selling against offers, the close on the Board of Trade showed net gains of 1 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel with the December leading.

In the old days, Broadway producers shied away from Saturday night openings. No reason in particular, just one of those things. But now they bob up quite frequently, and this evening will set a new high record of two. They are:

Dispatches describing the Italian Government's measures designed to draw into the public treasury gold holdings of the people are not altogether clear as to the mechanism employed. It is stated, explicitly enough, that the national bank is offering for such gold 15.25 lire per gram, instead of the statutory price of 12.63.

Serge Jaroff and his Don Cossack Russian Male Chorus last night made their appearance at Carnegie Hall in a recital which was labeled as the 3,000th performance. That the popularity and appeal of these Russian choristers, garbed in the characteristic fashion of the Cossack uniform, is still undiminished was evidenced by an audience that filled every seat.

MANILA, Nov. 29. -- As the rugged hills of the Philippines appeared over the port bow today the crew of the China Clipper came to a realization of the significance of this achievement for American aviation -- a history-making 8,000-mile flight in a four-motored transport plane bearing the first transpacific mail from Alameda, Calif., to Manila.

To introduce their daughters, the Misses Helen Coolidge Adams and Nancy Montgomery Adams, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Safford Adams gave a dinner dance last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre. Both debutantes wore gowns of ice blue satin and carried ostrich feather fans.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29. -- The Knoxville Business and Professional Women's Club today withdrew from the movement to raise a defense fund for Edith Maxwell, the Virginia school teacher convicted of murdering her father, and announced that it would return the more than $200 in contributions secured after it started the movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- With hotels for miles around filled to the eaves and the vanguard of the season's most brilliant gathering of notables pouring into the city, Philadelphia was in the throes of excitement and revelry on the eve of football's most dazzling spectacle.

Efforts of laymen and legislators to impose loyalty oaths on educators, dictate educational policy and thus to "lynch" ideas and render teaching "sterile" were condemned by speakers at day and evening sessions yesterday of the National Council for the Social Studies in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 29. -- As a preliminary to the Yale-Princeton land battle at New Haven tomorrow, there was a sea one this afternoon off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club here, and in line with what the bookmakers might offer in the way of odds on the terra firma struggle, Princeton won.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the Schechter case invalidating child labor provisions of the industrial codes has reduced national safeguards for children to where they were three years ago, according to the annual report of the National Child Labor Committee.

Mila Kocova, "dramatic colorature" soprano of the Prague National Theatre, made her first New York appearance last night at the Town Hall in a recital for the benefit of the Town Hall Endowment Fund. This was the first time that a foreign artist had made a debut at a concert of the endowment series, and the event brought out a large and responsive audience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- A registration statement covering the issuance of 150,000 shares of $100 par 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock has been filed by the Schenley Distillers Corporation of New York City under provisions of the Securities Act of 1933.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 29. -- Reliable sources state that eight Japanese troop trains are scheduled to make three trips from Shanhaikwan, at the eastern end of the Great Wall, to Tientsin, and that the first is due here tomorrow morning.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- The Mortgage Commission of the State of New York has the power to mortgage properties under its jurisdiction to raise money for necessary improvements, as well as for the payment of taxes and interest, Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley ruled today.

The French liner Champlain, departing today for Plymouth and Havre, will have among her passengers Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, World War ace and chairman of the contest board of the American Automobile Association; Captain Pierre Clave, Captain Antoni Nobili and Captain Andre Jousseaume, French cavalry officers who took part in the National Horse Show, and:

A 15-year-old schoolgirl whose life was imperiled after swallowing an open safety pin was transferred from a Long Island Sound steamer to a plane yesterday afternoon and rushed thirty-five miles to New York City for prompt medical attention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Bank of Silesian Landowners Association of Breslau (Schlesische Landschaftliche Bank Zu Breslau) has filed an application with the SEC on Form 21, for the registration of $1,190,000 of first mortgage collateral 6 per cent sinking fund gold bonds due on Aug. 1, 1947, on the New York and Boston Stock Exchanges.
Europe is living on the brink of war and any untoward incident or accident suddenly may throw the whole world into another great conflict, according to James Truslow Adams, historian.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- As football fans scoured the city today in quest of tickets for the annual Army-Navy game at Philadelphia tomorrow, it was disclosed again that the best way to obtain them was by paying "scalper" prices about the Capitol and office buildings.
VIENNA, Nov. 29. -- Italian troops are being withdrawn in large numbers from the South Tyrol area. This movement began last Sunday and is still going on.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Sale of $10,000,000 of ten-year 3 per cent first mortgage bonds of Series C to Kuhn, Loeb Co. was announced officially today by L.E. Block, chairman of the board of the Inland Steel Company.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents

To the Editor of The New York Times: Publication on Nov. 13 of Secretary Baker's admirable letter "Our Entry Into the War" and your editorial endorsement of it constitute a public service. Candor, however, forces the impartial student of the relevant documents to ask why both completely ignore Secretary Lansing's recent memoirs, and the facts apparently established as to Colonel House's mission to Europe in the Autumn of 1915.
BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- Secret political police confiscated the funds of the Confessional Church and Confessional Synods, consisting of voluntary contributions from Protestants throughout the Reich.

Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, will "raise no questions and make no suggestions" at the Washington conference with business men on Dec. 9, he informed S.L. Hoffman, president of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, in a letter which the latter made public yesterday at a luncheon of trade association executives held at 1,350 Broadway.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The British Government confirmed tonight the report that Premier Pierre Laval had renewed the assurance that France would aid Great Britain in the event of an Italian attack on this country and that the French Premier had notified Ambassador Vittorio Cerruti that any warlike measures by his country against Britain would be considered as hostility to all League of Nations States, including France.

Labor conditions on American coastal vessels were attacked as unfair to employes and conducive to accidents at sea in a brief filed yesterday by Silas Blake Axtell, 80 Broad Street, with the United States Steamboat Inspection Service.

A cold spell began to set in last night as fresh westerly winds carried freezing weather eastward from the Great Lakes, the Ohio Valley and the Appalachian region. New Yorkers probably would arise this morning to a 28-degree temperature, next to the coldest of the year, the Weather Bureau said last night.
Canvases by Max Weber, all of them painted in 1934 and 1935, constitute a one-man show at J.B. Neumann's New Art Circle, 509 Madison Avenue, which will be on until Dec. 21.

The American Cigar Company declared yesterday a stock dividend of one-twentieth of a share of commond B stock of American Tobacco for each share of American Cigar common and a quarterly dividend of $3 on the common.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- "The American consumer can reasonably expect the cost of living to have soared to a point about twice as high as its present level when the depression ends and the world scramble for gold subsides," Professor Edwin Kemmerer of Princeton University asserted here tonight at a meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

In the nineteenth game of the world chess championship match, contested at Zeist in Holland and the last to he won by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine from his challenger, Dr. Max Euwe, the former was at the top of his form and outmanoeuvred his rival on the queen's side of the board, according to the detailed score which was received yesterday.
Auctioneers were kept busy yesterday wtih a long list of foreclosure sales in Manhattan. They conducted eighteen foreclosures, including the sale of a twenty-story loft building on Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Activities of the real estate bond units of S.W. Straus Co. in the months immediately preceding the collapse of the Straus organization in 1933 were under fire at today's inquiry into the operations of that concern by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Nov. 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, a decrease of $17,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and an increase of $10,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 29. -- Two cities only thirty-four miles apart are in the grip of a football frenzy unprecedented in this section as the time approaches for tomorrow's game between the Texas Christian University Horned Frogs of Fort Worth and the Southern Methodist University Mustangs of Dallas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Based on a population of 7,154,300 as of July 1, 1933, the per capita cost of operation and maintenance of the general departments of New York City for the fiscal year ending Dec. 31, 1934, was $71.34, according to a survey by the Bureau of the Census, announced today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 29. -- Jesse L. Livermore Jr., 16-year-old son of the stock market operator, lay near death in the Cottage Hospital here tonight from a bullet wound which the authorities said was inflicted at 1:30 o'clock this morning by his mother, Mrs. Dorothea Wendt Livermore, during a drunken argument in their suburban home.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area forged ahead during the week, with the consensus indicating that early Christmas shopping is off to a favorable start. Average gains of department stores were estimated at about 5 per cent for the period, although several individual stores were credited with an increase running well ahead of this figure.

The Harvard Club's triumph over Yale, coupled with a Princeton defeat at the hands of the Crescents in the Class B squash tennis circuit of the Metropolitan League last night sent the Crimson into first place with four victories and one loss.

Narrow and mixed price movements characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A general lack of interest, together with the absence of many traders from their desks resulted in prices in some sections drifting to moderately lower levels.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP). -- William May Garland, eldest of America's three representatives in the International Olympic Federation, joined Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill tonight in condemning a proposed American boycott of Germany's 1936 Olympic Games. His statement broke the deadlock existing among the American officials.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29. -- A statement that "there can be no permanent recovery as long as the nation depends on palliative legislation inside the capitalistic system" is made in a letter sent to President Roosevelt today by forty- five members of the executive board of the National Religion and Labor Foundation.

Indicating that too high hopes should not be held for the immediate solution of pressing naval problems, Norman H. Davis, Ambassador-at-Large, and seven members of the United States delegation to the London naval conference sailed last midnight for the British Capital and the difficult task of discussing the rationalization of naval armaments at a time when most League nations are bristling with distrust and trouble.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Hogs were in urgent demand today, with the East taking 50 per cent of the arrivals after deducting shipments direct to packers. Prices as a result moved up 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with several loads of livestock show rejects selling at $9.95, or at $12.20 with the processing tax of $2.25 a 100 pounds included.
No change was apparent in any section of the money market so far as quotations or business were concerned.

The demand for a few miscellaneous cuts were active in the wholesale markets. Trading in a general way was only fair to slow, however. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to strong, veal and calf cuts mostly unchanged. Lamb carcasses and most of the cuts were higher. Fresh pork cuts were generally steady with Wednesday.

Mrs. Helen Moran Fahnestock, 34 years old, of 164 East Seventy-second Street, divorced wife of Colonel Snowden A. Fahnestock, the banker, died at 9:40 P.M. last night at New York Hospital of injuries she received Thanksgiving Day when she Jumped or fell from the third floor of 158 East Sixty-fourth Street to the street.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- The main points of President Roosevelt's address at Grant Field today included:

Wall Street bankers generally were inclined to skepticism yesterday concerning President Roosevelt's reference to the extent to which the public debt could expand without impairing the nation's credit. A majority of the "great Wall Street bankers" reached last night refused to comment on the President's statement, but it was apparent that each of them wondered privately where such an impression was gathered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On page 23 of THE TIMES this morning I read of a new $4,550,000 health structure dedicated by Mayor La Guardia to house an imposing staff of politicians, scientists, doctors, laboratory workers, nurses, , paid for with the city's money.
BERLIN, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler served terse notice on the world tonight that "the German people will furnish their own protection."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29. -- This "generation of Jews" was urged to make Palestine the homeland for hundreds of thousands of Jews who are being crowded out of many countries in an address by Rabbi Barnett R. Brickner of the Euclid Avenue Temple tonight before the National Convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, asked Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, yesterday to supply 10,000 laborers today for WPA projects. There are 228,000 at work now.

A new book by Carl Van Doren is announced by Harpers for publication in the Spring. The title will be "Three Worlds," and it is described as the biography of a man and the history of a family in the three worlds called "Pre-War," Post-War" and "Depression."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Regret that Ghaffar Khan Djalal, Minister from Persia, was arrested and handcuffed in a tilt with Elkton officers over a speeding charge was expressed today by Governor Harry W. Nice.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 29. -- The 1936 budget providing for total expenditures of $9,878,049.89, an increase of $1,509,871.01 over the 1935 total, was adopted today by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors at a special meeting in the County Court Building.

Prices were slightly lower in yesterday's fresh produce market, due to a sharp falling off in demand following Thanksgiving Day, according to the City's Consumers' Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets. Meats were unchanged in price.

A youth identified as Arthur Heslin, 20 years old, of 1,927 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, died at 12:20 this morning in Madison Park Hospital, Brooklyn, of a bullet wound received about midnight when Detectives Walter Lourie and Francis Griffiths fired on him and another youthful prowler in the rear yard of a house at 2,402 Avenue P, corner of East Twenty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

His manifold duties as head of a New York publishing firm have forced Thomas H. Beck to relinquish membership in the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, of which he had been chairman since 1931. Governor Cross regretfully accepted Mr. Beck's resignation this week and appointed in his place Oliver Ellsworth, Hartford sportsman.

Even with the salvos of the Asiatic Fleet of the United States Navy booming acclaim of her accomplishment and giving it a thunderous reality, there remains a magic quality, difficult to dispel, about the flight of Pan American Airways' giant China Clipper from California to Manila.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- Dr. Augusto de Vasconcellos convoked the committee of eighteen today for Dec. 12, when the chief question is expected to be extension of the League of Nations war material sanctions to cut off Italy from oil. This extension then seems very probable, in view of the attitude of the United States.

MANILA, Nov. 29. -- The extravagant enthusiasm which greeted the landing of the China Clipper this afternoon endangered the craft and almost caused serious damage, which was averted by the quick action of newspaper men.

Reports to date indicate that the railroads of the country earned a net income of about $32,000,000 in October, which would be the best result for any October since 1930. This would compare with a net income of $13,542,000 in September, $5,716,000 in October, 1934, and $13,913,000 in October, 1933.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29. -- President James Rowland Angell of Yale University, in an article written for the Yale-Princeton program, appearing tomorrow, claims that commercialization in football has assumed a position of prime importance in over 70 per cent of the nation's colleges.

The increase in lumber production last week was more than seasonal and the adjusted index, which is a component of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, advanced to 77.2 from 75.6 in the previous week. It compares with 57.4 for the week ended Nov. 24, 1934.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Eritrea's new High Commissioner; Marshal Pietro Badoglio, announced today a "rather strict" censorship on news dispatches from the northern African war front.
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Operations in the London Stock Exchange were quiet and somewhat dull today, the last day of the account. Further selling weakened British funds.

Price movements on commodity futures yesterday were mixed. A number of leading staples advanced briskly in active trading. On the cash markets, where corn made a new low, lard, cotton and wool tops also declined, while wheat, cocoa, silk and rubber advanced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee tonight characterized the President's speech promising a smaller deficit next year as "sheer propaganda," and as on a "par with the promises of a balanced budget which he made during the 1932 campaign."

Prayers are asked "for the suffering Lutheran churches in Russia" and "brotherly and intercessory sympathy for other Lutheran churches in the world which are proclaiming the gospel with great difficulty" in an official communication from the third Lutheran World Convention. This will be read

The entire estate of Bernard S. Deutsch, late president of the Board of Aldermen, in a will filed for probate in Bronx Surrogates Court yesterday is bequeathed to Mrs. Frances W. Deutsch, the widow. The estate itself is estimated at not more than $10,000, but the testament indicates that provision was made for the couple's two daughters and others before Mr. Deutsch's death.

Penitentiary sentences ranging to four years in one instance were imposed yesterday on eight usurers by Special Sessions Justices Kernochan, Salomon and Brady. Three others got off with suspended terms. Another trio was to have been disposed of, but these sentences were postponed until Monday.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The British Government announced today that it will not interfere with next Wednesday's Anglo-German soccer match in London, although Chancellor Hitler personally agreed to call it off if the authorities here so desired.

Mike Mesco, the hamburger-hurling athlete of Rahway, N.J., whose Horatian gesture in Dartmouth's defense won him national notoriety during the Princeton Dartmouth football game last Saturday, will occupy a seat of honor in the Yale Bowl when Princeton and Yale clash at New Haven today.

The New York Americans will play the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight, one day ahead of the usual hockey date, in order to make room for the six-day bicycle race. This will be the second meeting of the teams, the Bruins having edged out the Americans in their first engagement at Boston, 1 to 0.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

A widening call for Winter merchandise and the auspicious start of holiday gift buying pushed retail sales ahead this week at the fastest pace recorded in more than six weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $18,997,629, compared with the revised total of $17,573,253 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $25,887,891.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29. -- The Yale junior varsity eleven today won from the Princeton reserves, 13 -- 0, in opening the week-end of Tiger-Bulldog football events.

Governor Lehman was believed to have acted yesterday to speed up the office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County in preparing the minutes of the November grand jury in the Samuel Druckman murder case for the Governor's use in his investigation.

THE sugar-coaters of science need a new technique. At present many of these guides through the temples are trying to be both reverent and flip. They talk over-anxiously and in exaggerated terms of how great is the contribution of this man or that, and then attempt to conclude their remarks with a wisecrack for "reader interest."

The heavy movement of foreign funds to this country in the last month were for investment in securities or deposit in banks, while the movement earlier this year reflected largely a return of American capital, including repayments of foreign indebtedness to this country, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29. -- This city tonight was like an armed camp on the eve of invasion from a decidedly grim foe, but by no means was the situation considered hopeless.

ADDIS ABABA, Nov. 29. -- The Ethiopian Government thus far has been unable to confirm the report that Ras Seyoum has recaptured Makale. Nor has it received further details of a report from Harar that Ras Nasibu had retaken Ualual. Telegrams were sent to both generals tonight seeking information.

ROME, Nov. 29. -- Premier Pierre Laval's victory in the French Chamber yesterday, which was more convincing than most persons here had expected, helped to ease the international tension. Hard words were being hurled at France only a few weeks ago when she failed to prevent the application of sanctions against Italy.

DETROIT, Nov. 29. -- "That boy can't take it," said Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the New York Republican State Central Committee, today referring to President Roosevelt. Mr. Eaton also predicted that Mr. Roosevelt would not be a candidate for renomination in 1936.
Charles Laughton will have the title ro1e in Metro's "Goodbye, Mr. Chips."

TOKYO, Nov. 29 (AP). -- Efforts by Western diplomats in Tokyo to learn the future Japan proposes for North China, authoritative sources said today, have met a barrier of Eastern evasiveness that has only befogged the situation further.

WITH the opening of the Metropolitan Opera season but two weeks off, the prospects for a successful year, at least financially, are understood to be good. The Metropolitan Opera Guild has revived interest in the Metropolitan in certain circles and there has been an increase in subscriptions as a result of its activities.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Dispatches from the Far East, saying the autonomy of North China was about to be declared, confirmed every fear of the British Government that Japan would take advantage of the present crisis in Europe to seize another gigantic slice of the Asiatic mainland.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- If cooperative investigation and planning can stimulate prosperity in this conservative corner of the United States, New England should move ahead handsomely. Its physical resources are being measured and charted. Its agricultural and industrial assets and liabilities are being weighed and balanced.

It is noticeable that, when interviewed, British radio executives manifest little enthusiasm for the stop-watch method of American studios as contrasted with their more leisurely system of broadcasting. Increasingly the reasons become evident to judicious American listeners.

SARAH LOUISA SWEENY has chosen for the background of her first novel a period of American history which has seldom been adequately portrayed in fiction. Most of the action of "Harvest of the Wind" takes place in Kansas during the dramatic period between the passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Bill and the outbreak of the Civil War.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30. -- The convention of Hadassah, women's Zionist movement in America, today honored Miss Henrietta Szold, its founder, who now lives in Palestine. Miss Szold, who will be 75 on Dec. 21, will return to this country for a month of celebration and tribute to be given her by Jewish groups throughout the country in honor of her life-long activity for Hadassah.

We have been told over and over again that the adoption and enforcement of economic sanctions by the League of Nations against Italy is "the first of its kind in history," "the first great effort ever made to penalize a war-making nation by bloodless means."

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The glories of thirty-five centuries of Chinese art were seen in the greatest exhibition ever assembled outside of Asia at an exhibition at the Royal Academy's Burlington House Galleries.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Nearly all the Paramount Publix motion-picture houses in the Chicago suburbs were closed tonight by a mysterious strike of union motion-picture operators that lasted less than two hours.

THE first thing which strikes one in reading "The Vision of Piers Plowman," here most excellently rendered into modern speech, is the intense modernity of this fourteenth century English poem. William Langland, to accept the view of the translator of single authorship and not Professor Manley's theory of several collaborators, was by no means so great a poet as his great contemporary Chaucer; he could neither create nor depict characters; he was no raconteur.
I have been instructed to forward the following resolution, which was passed at a recent meeting of the Motion Picture Council for Brooklyn:

In his article "Eyes of Germany Turned on Russia" published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 24, Frederick T. Birchall says that in Czechoslovakia Konrad Henlein "has not only definitely consolidated all Germans in the country into one group hut has made it the biggest in the country."

PRINTS always brighten the scenery. They bring fresh life to clothes, what with their colors and their fanciful patterns. At this time of the year they have two functions: One is to go South, where they add to the general decorative picture; the other is to brighten the atmosphere of the chill North.
Gold bullion on the open London market, in terms of British currency, unchanged at 141s 1/2d per fine ounce. Price before British suspension of gold payments on Sept. 21, 1931, was 84s 9 3/4d.

Current inventories of dry goods jobbers throughout the country are 5 to 10 per cent below those carried a year ago, it was reported yesterday by those houses which check up on their stocks at this period of the year. This condition is not uniform throughout the country, some houses carrying more and others less, but the figures were regarded as a broad average.

Gold received here in November was $92,611,300 less than the import volume in the preceding month, despite the increase in shipments from France. The total of $205,090,700 compared with $297,702,000 for October and with $112,912,700 in November, 1934.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 30. -- The first news in some time of the whereabouts of the Italian column that left Mount Mussa Ali, crossing the Danakil Desert toward the Ethiopian plateau, was received here today.

By the accident of death Fusion has lost its majority in New York City's Board of Estimate, but it is the Democratic party rather than Tammany which has gained control. That is the opinion of those who follow city politics closely, for Tammany, meaning by that name the regular Democratic organization of Manhattan, has only five of the nine Democratic votes in the board.

Although Mark Twain found Australia full of fine literary material, his remarks when he visited that country in 1895 were not always flattering, D. M. Dow, official secretary for Australia to the United States, told a group of thirty persons yesterday afternoon at National Poetry Centre in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

CONSERVATION and forestry projects were among the first large-scale community good turns undertaken by the Boy Scouts in the early stages of their movement in this country, and the work is now going on intensively in practically every State.

Three men charged with the possession and sale of narcotics were arrested early yesterday by three policemen after a mile-and-a-half chase through the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn. The prisoners described themselves as Joseph Naporano, 35 years old, of 286 Nineteenth Street; Michael Maranchino, 38, of 229 High Street, and Daniel McCabe, 40, of 43 Fulton Street, all of Brooklyn.

LONDON is taking things more easily this week, the cable reports. Tonight, Wyndham's 1930 Players are giving "The Farm of Three Echoes," with Sybil Thorndike, Jessica Tandy, Ursula Jeans and others. Noel Langley, who wrote last year's play about Dante and Beatrice, is the author.

The first government-owned and government-constructed postoffice station in New York City, the Kensington Station, McDonald Avenue, near Church Avenue, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday at 3 P.M About 1,000 persons were present.

Pacifism as "good, selfish business for nations to practice" was stressed by Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, in an interview yesterday. The interview followed his receipt Friday of the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Columbia University for his services in behalf of peace and international understanding.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing Prison says that work on a new educational building now being constructed where studies now taught will be expanded and classes enlarged will be completed in forty or fifty days.

With the month-end coinciding with the end of the week, the volume of business done in November in stocks and bonds is to be scrutinized for what light it may shed on what lies ahead, now that the market is in its ninth successive month of advancing prices.

From the attitude taken by Administration spokesmen and, on Friday, by the President himself in speaking on public policies at Atlanta, it is pretty plainly indicated what will happen in next year's political contest. The Democratic party will largely impute to Administration policies the present business recovery.

PRAISE FROM THE DUKE: When he dedicated the new Health Building last week -- it's in Foley Square and it cost $4,500,000 -- Mayor La Guardia said kind things about Jimmy Walker, who recently returned to New York from an extended stay abroad. Said Mr. La Guardia: "In the construction of a public building most of the difficulty is in getting it authorized and started.

Fifteen educators have been appointed by the National Education Association to draw up a long-term plan for American education, it was announced yesterday by the association and its department of superintendence in its journal.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Murtha Lawrence and his Brooklyn Prep cross-country teammates closed their season in a blaze of glory today by winning the first national Catholic school championship run conducted by Seton Hall College for their third respective individual and team titles of the Fall campaign.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 30. -- Held fairly well by a desperate and courageous Tulane defense in the first half, the Louisiana Tigers hit their stride in the second half and turned the annual gridiron classic into something of a rout at Tulane Stadium today before 35,000 fans, the largest crowd ever gathered for a sports event in this State.

The New York Football Giants are coming down the stretch in first place with an excellent chance of finishing in that spot. With a two-game lead over the Dodgers, they need only a tie or victory in one of their remaining games to clinch their group title.

LIKE musical stock companies everywhere, those of Second Avenue have their standard parts -- lovers and ingenues, comedians and the rest. Without prejudice to the players in the other categories, many of whom have devoted followings, the talk here will be only of some outstanding comics.
This is a book that should be cordially welcomed by households where family singing is still the custom and by teachers who are looking for simple songs that are fresh and interesting.

THIS year marks the hundredth anniversary of the birth of the first great American orchestral conductor, one more influential than any other musician of his period in developing American taste and knowledge of symphonic music. He was Theodore Thomas, born the son of a "Stadtpfeifer" in Eseno, East Friesland, Oct. 11, 1835.

ATHENS, Nov. 30. -- Amid universal expressions of satisfaction with King George's firmness in the matter of a general amnesty for political offenders and his triumph over Marshal George Kondylis, former Premier, and Panayoti Tsaldaris, his predecessor in the office, the public learned today that Constantine Demerdjis's "amnesty Cabinet," consisting of permanent officials, had taken the oath of office this afternoon.

AFTER more than three-quarters of a century of effort on the part of institutions to offer higher education to Negroes, the aims and ideals remain not clearly defined; and if integration of those trained into the social and economic pattern is regarded as the chief criterion, the results have not been entirely satisfactory.

The names of 118 undergraduates who have received promotions in the R.O.T.C. unit of City College were announced yesterday by Colonel Oliver P. Robinson, head of the Department of Military Science and Tactics. Raphael L. Uffner leads the list as cadet first sergeant.

Last week's opening debates in the French Chamber of Deputies, which had been awaited as being of crucial importance to the future of the French currency, appeared to bankers here to indicate that the franc would emerge unscathed from the current crisis, like other recent crises, but that French politicians were approaching a realization that devaluation was inevitable.

WHY are we having so many bad accidents involving youngsters of high school age?" asked a motor vehicle administrator at a recent conference of Eastern States Commissioners; "how can we reach the younger drivers?"
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Secretary Swanson's annual report showed, in the following tables, the status of the Navy as of June 30 in respect to categories of vessels limited by treaties:

There is a man out in Cincinnati JIM FARLEY ought to look up, or HENRY FLETCHER, or the editor of The Literary Digest. His name is KENNETH DORIS, and he works for The Enquirer as their "P.R. expert," i.e., their authority on the intricate workings of the system of proportional representation which is -- or at least has been, since there is now talk of repeal -- that city's boast.

BACK in 1929 the Canadian Government decided to import a herd of reindeer for the Eskimo people of the north Mackenzie country, who were being starved out by the gradual extinction of the once great herds of caribou that roamed the Arctic country.

THERE is something refreshingly original in the conception which lies behind these seven short dramatic poems by Audrey Wurdemann. The seven deadly sins are known to all. They are: avarice, gluttony, pride, anger, lust, envy and sloth.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 30. -- The University of Mexico lost its sixteenth international football game since 1929, when it bowed to Westmoorland University of San Antonio, Texas, by 31 -- 7 today. The Texans showed daring and skill with forward passes and plenty of power once they neared the goal line.
An extra dividend of $1 and the regular quarterly dividend of $1 were declared yesterday by the South West Pennsylvania Pipe Lines Company.

GENEVA. THE world's radio listeners now number 200,000,000, or one in ten of mankind, according to an estimate in Radiodiffusion, new semi-annual publication of the International Broadcasting Union just issued at the headquarters.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 30. (AP). -- The University of California at Los Angeles defeated the University of Idaho, 13 to 6, today to earn a tie with Stanford and California for the Pacific Coast Conference football title.

At the meeting point of the New York-Montreal and New York-Boston airways -- the Manhattan tower of the George Washington Bridge -- an airway beacon of 1,800,000 candlepower was dedicated yesterday to the memory of Wiley Post and Will Rogers.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Twin forces of debt and unemployment have obscured, temporarily, plans of Premier Aberhart to develop a system of social credit in Alberta. Government reforms to make possible the payment of basic dividends await the arrival from England of Major C.H. Douglas, founder of Social Credit.

TIENTSIN, Sunday, Dec. 1. -- The Japanese military today requested General Liu Yuh-su, public safety commissioner, to provide accommodation in Tientsin for portions of three divisions of Japanese troops within two days.

One of the strongest arguments for public support of the city's voluntary hospitals in the current campaign for the United Hospital Fund is the inadequate provision for maternity cases in the crowded tenement districts on the West Side.

Business activity made substantial gains in every section of the country last week, as cooler weather and holiday shopping spurred retail trade and sent stores back into the wholesale markets for merchandise. Not only did consumer goods move ahead, but the heavy industries, such as automobiles, construction, steel and machine tools, continued their recent excellent showings.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 30 (AP). -- George H. Norris, key figure in an attempt to defeat Senator George W. Norris, veteran Nebraska Independent Republican, by a duplicate filing in the 1930 Nebraska primary, will go to trial here Monday in Federal District Court on a perjury indictment.
The effort to place 10,000 more persons in WPA work relief jobs as laborers was practically completed yesterday, bringing the total on such jobs in the city to nearly 238,000.

MADRID, Nov. 30. -- Francisco Largo Caballero, former Minister of Labor and now Cortes deputy, chairman of the Socialist party's executive committee and secretary of the General Labor Union, was acquitted today by the Supreme Court on charges of having been one of the leaders of the revolt in October, 1934.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- A financial guarantee sufficiently large to induce Democratic leaders to bring the party's national convention to this city in 1936 will be sought by a committee to be formed here next week by Senator Joseph F. Guffey and his associates.

ONE of the greatest countryside road-building programs in the nation's history proceeds apace in the shadow of a tall question mark. The annual auto accident toll, rising steadily since 1925, reached a peak last year with 36,000 dead and more than 800,000 injured.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- John H. Dumbrell, 59 years old, a banker and broker, was shot to death in his home here today and his widow, Amy, was arrested.
