THIS is a strange book. Real people flit across its pages more ghostlike than creations of purest fancy. Out of old sketch-books, faded letters and long-remembered conversations the author has conjured up the lives of two women of the last century, women who stirred her own life deeply because they were her mother and her "golden" aunt.

An increase of 33 per cent over last year in the number of students joining sororities of Hunter College was announced last week by Miss Selma Goldstone, chairman of the Pan-Hellenic Association. The thirty sororities of the college have pledged more than 150 students this semester.

Charles Schumacher, 65 years old, of 139-24 Fifty-eighth Street, Flushing, Queens, was struck by an automobile and killed about 5:15 P.M. yesterday. The accident occurred on Main Street, Flushing, between Fifty-eighth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Road.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Lady of Lexington, 9-year-old chestnut mare owned by Roger A. Young of Bronxville, N.Y., captured the three-gaited saddle horse championship of the fifth annual Peekskill Horse Show, which was concluded tonight in the armory of the Service Battery of the 156th Field Artillery.

AS the time approaches for "Tobacco Road" to enter upon its third year on Broadway, I find that my once comfortable fireside chair is becoming more and more uncomfortable. My uneasiness is undoubtedly due to the fact that I am anxious to be up and on my way to Georgia for my yearly visit.

Delegates from eighteen major art societies of the Fine Arts Federation of the City of New York have adopted a resolution urging that the entire World's Fair project in 1939 be the result of a single, coordinated vision and that it be created by men of outstanding ability, skill and distinction in the fine arts.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (Canadian Press). -- Victorious in English cup battles, twenty-eight soccer teams today eagerly waited the draw for the second round of the historic competition and twelve others who emerged with honors even made preparations for replays this week.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- The question of whether the Philippines should be invited to cooperate on sanctions was raised today in the committee of experts studying their application. This came in connection with the consideration of such protectorates as Morocco, Tunis, Sudan, , and because the islands produce rubber.

ONCE more the name of James Branch Cabell is to appear on the title page of a book. Since 1930 the "James" part of his name has been in temporary eclipse and he has been signing himself simply "Branch Cabell."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- Yale closed its soccer season undefeated by subduing Princeton, 2 to 1, today in a morning prelude to the varsity football battle between the rival universities.

ALWAYS good friends and good neighbors, those old ranchers, Lem Floyd and Pop Jennings, quarreled violently when Floyd learned that his daughter Mary had run away from the school in Walla Walla, to which he had sent her, and joined a traveling rodeo show.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30. -- Price-fixing and other governmental trade regulations were attacked here today at the closing session of the annual convention of the American Marketing Society at the Claridge Hotel.

The crisis in which the League of Nations finds itself in the war between Italy and Ethiopia is masked in the public opinion of the world by illusions and fallacies which defeat a proper understanding of the problem, Sir Norman Angell, English statesman and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1933, declared yesterday at the Town Hall.

A resolution "demanding" that the United States cease from participating in the world armament race and that the millions spent in war preparedness be diverted toward improving social conditions was among several resolutions adopted yesterday at a Conference for Peace and Economic Equality for Women.

ONE of the few strictly indigenous American folk arts is scrimshaw -- craft work done by the sailors of New England whaling ships in their spare time at sea. Using whalebone, ivory and wood, these seamen made many a picturesquely carved box, miniature clock case and purely ornamental souvenir.

Not all the opposition to the Social Security Act has come from conservatives who are opposed to the principle of old-age and unemployment insurance itself. In the current Harper's, ABRAHAM EPSTEIN, once research director of the Pennsylvania Commission for Old-Age Pensions and for the last eight years executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security, launches a blistering attack upon the measure.

FORGOTTEN youth is having its turn at both commercial and artistic recognition in New York this week. And incidentally the public schools are demonstrating the practical dollar-and-cents value of their teaching.

The falling birth rate will cause a drop in high school enrolment in this country after 1937, Rufus D. Smith, provost of New York University, who has just completed an extended study on population trends and their effect on education, predicted yesterday.

Dr. Arthur Wright, director of the third surgical division of Bellevue Hospital, extracted an open safety pin one and a half inches long last night from the upper abdomen of Lillian Lennehan, 15 years old, of Ramsey, N.J. After the delicate operation, which required only one-half hour, a bulletin at Bellevue said the girl's condition was "good."

Improved business conditions, together with wider operation of the Corporate Reorganization Act, will reduce the total of commercial failures for the third consecutive year and bring them to the lowest level since 1920, according to estimates here yesterday.

The Long Island University varsity quintet defeated the Alumni five, 46 to 23, last night at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium. The victory, L.I.U.'s second of the season, was witnessed by 1,200. Four former captains and four ex-varsity players faced the undergraduates.
"Democracy and Irresponsibility" is the subject of a lecture which Louis K. Anspacher will give tomorrow morning at the Bronxville Women's Club, under the auspices of the current events section.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Nearly perfect football weather welcomed the vast crowd of 79,000 notables and mere football fans alike to Franklin Field today for the greatest of America's football spectacles, Army against Navy.

A broadside of criticism against both the custom house and the United States Appraiser's Stores, branches of the local customs service, was loosed yesterday by importers as the rush of Christmas imports brought fresh complaints of delays and harassments attendant upon bringing foreign goods into this port.

Faced with the momentous question of deciding whether to vote for or against American participation in the 1936 Olympic Games, the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, largest sports governing body in the world, will stage its forty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Commodore on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday.

AN inundation of English music is promised when Sir Thomas Beecham takes over the baton of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in January, according to a report which has just seeped through. His fourteen concerts will, it is claimed, take the form of a festival of English compositions.

WITH no fanfare whatever, but considerable promise of success, a new ballet organization has slipped into the American field with Philadelphia as its centre and Catherine Littlefield as its director. Though it came into official existence no longer ago than Oct. 25 witch a modest suburban performance, it is already worthy of attention for several reasons.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 39. -Business leaders and public officials here were unable to explain with certainty today why the marked pickup in local industrial payrolls brought no decrease in relief rolls.

WICKENBURG, Ariz. HENCEFORTH travelers in this section will find, near the point where Highway 60 crosses the Colorado River, a reminder of the days when camels were tried as a solution to the problem of Western desert travel, for recently Jim Edwards of the State Highway Department erected there a stone pyramid topped by the copper figure of a camel in memory of Hadji Ali, Arab camel driver, and the experiment that he represented.
A dinner with dancing was given by Mr. and Mrs. Allen S. H. Bristow last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Burges Bristow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The curt, one-sentence resignation of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, from the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, has focused attention on the conflict within the federation between advocates of industrial unionism and those favoring craft unionism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Agricultural Departmental experts declared today that in October farmers received less than half of the amount the consumer paid for ten principal foods used by a "typical American family."

FOURTEEN years ago the world hailed, as opening a new chapter in history, the signing of the Treaty of Washington which ended, men hoped, the dangers of naval competition. This week a small group of admirals and statesmen will meet in London to try to salvage the wreckage of that dream.

THIS little book had its origin in an enterprise of the British Broadcasting Company, which invited ten eminent and representative men to take part in a series of talks on the "Causes of War," each one to discuss the subject from a particular point of view.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 30. -- Southern Methodist University's stampeding band of wild Mustangs romped to a 20-to-14 triumph over the Horned Frogs of Texas Christian University before a capacity crowd estimated at better than 40,000 today.

JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Nov. 30. -- Dr. Robert W. Hockman, the American surgeon, who has just returned from Daggah Bur, says that town is being bombed every day by Italian planes. Yesterday, he reported, nine bombers and four reconnoissance planes came over and dropped two huge bombs, 6 feet 2 inches in length, only one of which exploded.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 (AP). -- F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of America, asserted today a two-year survey indicated the probable return of prohibition by 1945. His prediction, he said, was based on a study of the effect of repeal in forty-four States.

LABOR LEADER: A couple of months ago, when George Lansbury resigned as leader of the British Laborites because he could not condone League sanctions enforced by arms, his party selected Clement R. Attlee to succeed him.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP). -- Trial of three civil actions against partners of J.S. Bache Co., brokers, involving claims and interest aggregating $1,250,000 and resulting from the failure of the State bank of Binghamton five years ago, will begin here Monday before Justice Ely W. Personius in Supreme Court.

THE day of the expeditionary picture is over. There never will be another "Chang," "Grass" or "Four Feathers." Better jungle films can be concocted in Hollywood than in the heart of Africa. Thus does Ernest B. Schoedsack lament at the memory of the far reaches that brought him fame.

SUDBURY, Mass., Nov. 30. -- A new "tale of the Wayside Inn" went on State police blotters today when James A. Murphy, a New York lawyer, reported that $3,000 in jewels and clothing had been stolen from his car in the parking space of Henry Ford's 249-year-old hostelry.
I read with interest Mr. Downes's review of the concert of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Hans Lunge on Monday, Nov. 11, 1935. I think his enthusiasm was entirely justified.
An obedience test, with two classes, is to be added to the program for the annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club, which will be held in Mechanics Building, Boston, Feb. 21 and 22.

IT seems that there's always some anniversary being celebrated in the Walt Disney Studios. If it isn't Mickey Mouse's birthday, it's Minnie's and, when they happen to be idle, there generally is a party somewhere for young Donald Duck or Harry Horse or one of the others.
PHILADELPHIA. -- Next year will usher in a new deal for Philadelphia's policemen and firemen. Final provision has been made to assure them a day off each week.

After forty years of "mushing" dog teams through the wastelands in a successful effort to bring the Church to the last frontier of America, the Right Rev. Peter Trimble Rowe, Bishop of Alaska, officiated at a special service yesterday in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, in observance of the anniversary of his consecration there Nov. 30, 1895.
IN the Foreword to his first Antarctic book. "Little America," Admiral Byrd wrote:
ROME, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio's first communique to the Rome government today said:

Progress made by the city in bettering conditions in the so-called "jungle" district of Brooklyn was praised yesterday by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities in a letter to Mayor La Guardia. At the same time the Mayor made public a report submitted by Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, outlining the action that has been taken in the district.

A delightful concert was given by Felix Salmond, 'cellist, and Ernest Hutcheson, pianist, yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. The program consisted of the piano and 'cello sonatas of Beethoven. Few in the audience, probably, had heard all these compositions, for it is the natural tendency of artists and audiences to interest themselves in a composer's most effective scores and to let the others remain in obscurity.

Organized industry will make known its attitude toward the proposed revival of NRA in permanent form this week when manufacturers from all over the country gather here for annual meetings and conventions. Delegates at the meetings also will formulate an industrial program for recovery and discuss New Deal legislation affecting business and industry, including the Social Security Act, the Wagner Labor Disputes Act, the reciprocity treaties and the new tax law.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November was the heaviest of any month since July, 1933, and the largest turnover for a November since 1929. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 57,462,895 shares, compared with 46,662,841 in October, and 20,868,401 in the corresponding month a year ago.

OF outstanding significance in Scandinavian publishing circles is the elaborate project now under way to bring out the old Icelandic sagas and other vellum manuscripts in facsimile reproductions by means of the process of photo-lithography, which provides completely satisfactory full-sized substitutes for the use of scholars who may not happen to have access to the originals in the libraries of Scandinavia.

DALLAS, Texas. -- Following court decisions upholding the validity of the Texas Cigarette Tax Law, a drive has been instituted to stop sales and consumption of cigarettes that do not bear the State's tax stamp.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 30. -- Application of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Law, Section 77, made before Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the Federal court here, revealed a corporate deficit of $45,000,000 which has been accumulating for twenty-three years.

Stockholders of two public utility companies obtained temporary injunctions yesterday in Federal Court restraining the companies from filing registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utilities Act of 1935.

Enactment of legislation to prevent the "vacationing" of material crime witnesses, such as those who sunned themselves in Miami during the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer murder investigation recently in Newark, was recommended yesterday in a statement read by Attorney General John J. Bennett at an executive session of the Interstate Commission on Crime.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- The molecular structure of ice so "heavy" it sinks like iron in water was described today at the closing session of the American Physical Society.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 30 (AP). -- Frankly admitting the difficulties confronting them, AAA officials today set about starting control of potato production, one of the most bitterly fought of government crop regulation programs.

IT would be difficult to find a more outstanding and complete example of single-mindedness, of unselfish, long-continuous devotion to one conviction and purpose, than is afforded by the life story of General Richard Henry Pratt as told in this volume by Elaine Goodale Eastman.

Stationed on skyscrapers instead of mountain peaks and sending messages across the rooftops of central Manhattan instead of a wooded ravine, sixteen Boy Scouts of Troop 472 staged an exhibition of semaphore flag signaling yesterday morning in a contest which announced the approaching end of the Silver Jubilee year of the Boy Scout movement in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). Receivers for the Hoosac Mills Corporation of Massachusetts today described as a "fraud" the AAA amendments with which Congress attempted to insure the constitutionality of processing taxes.

SOME travelers are like those engaging insects which go skating around pools of water without seeming even to get their feet wet. Mr. A.G. MacDonell is one of them. One would not wish to carry the insect comparison further, for Mr. MacDonell is manifestly a pleasant young man, socially gifted, intelligent if not inquisitive, and endowed with a neat sense of humor.

One of the major club programs in Central Queens this week will be the "Christmas in Iceland" celebration to be given by the Colony Club of Queens as a feature of its December meeting. The event will be held Thursday afternoon at the Hollis Unitarian Church.

The varied contributions of world nations to America's Christmas Day have been reaching port in recent weeks in the form of toys and novelties and the table delicacies that make Christmas dinner the final word in gastronomic delight.

WEATHER conditions turned more favorable to retail trade in the week and sales volume mounted in most sections. The increases in the Middle West were very sharp. In this section business ran 5 to 7 per cent ahead of last year.

SYDNEY. THE first country in the world to do so, Australia has approved postoffice proposals for the use of airplanes to fly mails at ordinary letter rates. This move by the federal government represents the first step in conquering the great distances which separate the capitals of the different States of this Commonwealth and will be the greatest help that interstate communications have ever received.

IT was indeed a "heroic task of selection" which faced the authors of this work when they sat down to select from the world's great, near-great and alleged great the "500 Indispensables" that would cover the needs of most of its users.

PADRAIC COLUM'S Saint Columba is sufficient to convince us that the lives of the early saints should be written by poets and that an Irish poet is pre-eminently the one to retell for young people the lovely legends, half fairy, lore and half holy record, that have gathered around the names of Colum-cille and Patrick, those great figures of early Christianity in Ireland.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard geologist, remained steadfast today in his refusal to subscribe to any teachers' oath except his own.

LONDON. WHEN Max Reinhardt's film version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" was shown at the Adelphi Theatre here, simultaneously with its presentation in New York, it was the talk of the town for at least eight hours.

WITH the development of the iron mike and the radio compass, automatic protection has been provided to ships at sea. Modern transport planes are guided at incredible speeds by gyro-pilots which exceed in accuracy the hand of the most skilled aviator.

THE highway program for the current fiscal year, calling for expenditure of more than a billion dollars in Federal and State funds, soon will be at its highest mark, it is disclosed in a checkup of operations throughout the country made by the American Road Builders Association.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 30. -- The Rice Institute Owls lost their third Southwestern Conference football game of the season today, bowing to the surprising Baylor Bears of Waco, 8 to 0. Fourteen veterans of the Blue and Gray, who brought national recognition to Rice football, played their last game.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Although the outcome of Premier Benito Mussolini's war and even the fate of the League of Nations may conceivably depend on the amount of oil Italy receives from abroad between now and April, when the rains in Ethiopia will begin again, Italy is still getting oil from nations that condemned her aggression, banned arms and credits and boycotted her goods.

Engineering students of Stevens Institute of Technology and Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute will debate the question, "Resolved, that engineering should be a closed profession," on Wednesday evening in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The debate is being sponsored by the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers as a feature of its thirty-first annual meeting.

LONDON. -- The victory in the Canadian elections of Mackenzie King and the Liberals has stimulated the search by imperialists in London for a practical means of strengthening the bonds of the British Empire, and in influential quarters the view is being advanced that the League of Nations can be used as an instrument for imperial unity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- In a riotous display of power, deception and passing skill, Army sank Navy with a scoring jamboree that piled up four touchdowns in the first eighteen minutes of play today to gain the most decisive victory recorded in this service football classic since 1903.
TELEVISION in England is no longer a pale shadow, but is rapidly moving toward reality.

THIS is the life story of a woman who was born in South Africa in 1862 and has lived there all her life. She has been a part of the wars and development of the country, the gold rushes and the diamond craze, and has either seen or known nearly all the men whose names are connected with the tumultuous political and economic growth of the region.

MISS ELIZABETH DILLINGHAM HART, who is known as a book reviewer and has won some distinction as a poet and short-story writer, is in this, her first published book, introduced as a novelist. Actually, it is too short to be called a novel, and the word "novelette," as it is described on the wrapper, sounds rather frivolous when applied to the sacred theme which Miss Hart has chosen for her first effort.

TOKYO, Nov. 30. -- The promises made by General Sadao Araki while he was Minister of War in 1932, that the army's extraordinary expenditures would cease in two years from 1933, were jettisoned in the new budget adopted this morning, as were forecasts that army expenditures in Manchuria would sink to 70,000,000 yen annually.

LITERARY caravans are very very very much the fashion, but Mr. Schwarz's collection of "great stories of twenty-five centuries" has a singular claim to the title. A caravan implies a journey; it implies a group of men traveling through alien lands, often through deserts; it implies the visioning of mirages, the delights of resting in oases; yes, all this, and a great deal more.

PROBLEMS which vitally concern the immediate future of American aviation await solution by the aircraft industry at a meeting of the governors of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, to be held in Washington on Dec. 9, Thomas A. Morgan, president of the chamber, said last week.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The Racquets Club of Short Hills, defending champion, scored its second consecutive sweep when it defeated the Plainfield Country Club in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets League today.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 30. -- Georgia Tech's Golden Tornado triumphed over its ancient rival, the University of Georgia, by 19 -- 7 today before a crowd of 30,000.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Nov. 30. -- Jesse Livermore Jr., 16, who was shot early yesterday by his mother, Dorothea Livermore, after a drinking bout, was slightly improved today, but doctors declared that he must go through a "critical stage" within the next twelve hours.

Police Commissioner Valentine went to the unusual extent of a general order yesterday to members of the department, extolling the police career of Third Deputy John A. Leach, whose retirement, because of age, became effective at midnight.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 30. -- Weekend buying, combined with the first Christmas shopping, lifted retail sales here 15 per cent above the corresponding week of last year, while bank clearings and bank debits of the Ninth Federal Reserve District and auto sales continued to show startling increases over the same period.

More than 100 photographs dramatizing the work of the ninety-one affiliated agencies of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies went on exhibition yesterday at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue.

A suspected automobile thief who identified himself to the police as Adolph Kiesla, 34 years old, of Weirton, W.Va., was shot three times early yesterday morning by a patrolman who joined in a short chase in the vicinity of Sixth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

IN all the tumultuous history of the Actors Equity Association no one could remember anything quite like this. There on the rostrum of the Hotel Astor's Grand Ballroom, last Monday afternoon, stood a dignified ex-actor fighting for his official life.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Igor I. Sikorsky has plans for ships eight times as large as the China clippers.

TORONTO, Nov. 30. -- Canada's exports of silver bullion in October were more than double in both volume and value those of the same month of 1934, while exports of gold bullion declined, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported. The exports of silver were 1,265,102 ounces, valued at $825,759, against 603,176 ounces at $298,072 in October, 1934.

CHICAGO. -- Wilbur Glenn Voliva, successor to John Alexander Dowie as theocratic dictator in the city of Zion, Ill., has run into trouble. Last Spring for the first time in his dictatorship the voters of Zion took the municipal government from his ticket, and elected an anti-Voliva administration.

MRS. THOMAS'S book of reminiscences draws its interest from her memories of the multitudes of men and women she has met who at one time or another have been much in the public eye. But she has made it endlessly entertaining by the light but vitalizing touch, the underlying sense of humor and the zestful enjoyment with which she has recreated her contacts with them and the scenes and occasions of the background.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 30. -- News of the recent revolt is slowly deserting the front pages of the newspapers, which throughout the nation are demanding severe legislation to curb communism.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- With the large American contingent already on the water and sixty-one Japanese now in Berlin on their way to London, the personnel of the British delegation to the London naval conference was completed tonight.

UNIVERSITY, Miss., Nov. 30. -- Scoring in the first and last quarters, the University of Mississippi defeated Mississippi State College, 14 to 6, today in the thirty-third football game between the institutions.
FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City THE NEW YORK TIMES today makes its twenty-fourth annual appeal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Increased Federal revenue and diminishing lawlessness were credited by J.M. Doran, Administrator of the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., to repeal of the Prohibition Amendment, in a statement issued today. Forty States are helping their treasuries by liquor control taxation, he said.

THE Gordon Musical Association, Inc., recently formed at Canaan, Conn., has given a fresh impetus to the activities at Music Mountain, the Summer music school and music centre opened at Falls River, in that State, five years ago, with Jacques Gordon of the Gordon String Quartet and former concert master of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, as its moving spirit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Plans for building up the navy to the strength permitted under the Washington and London Naval treaties should be continued without change, despite the London Naval Conference which is to meet within a week, Secretary Swanson declared in his annual report today to President Roosevelt.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. Nov. 30. -- A brief legislative program for the next session of Congress, stripped down to non-controversial essentials, was studied by President Roosevelt today as an immediate sequel to his speech at Atlanta yesterday when he indicated that he had no further plans involving new experiments and stated that "the peak of appropriations has passed."

For the first time in seven years a mass meeting to permit public expression of opinion on birth control has been scheduled for tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall by the American Birth Control League, of which Mrs. Francis N. Bangs is president.

Members of the New Jersey Committee on the Cause and Cure of War face a crowded program at their annual leadership institute from Monday to Thursday of this week in Newark. Sessions of the institute will not start until Wednesday morning at the Newark Y.W.C.A., but social events in connection with it will begin tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 30. -- The State Conference of Mayors, which opposed limiting real estate taxes, was assailed by Justice George H. Pratt of Coming, secretary of the State Committee for Tax Limitations, at the Winter business meeting of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York here today.

The reopening in recent weeks of about a dozen wool goods mills, which have been closed for several years, led executives in the local market to fear that overproduction may again return to plague the field. The remarkable revival of the industry this year, as attested to by a 91-per-cent jump in wool consumption, is the magnet that has drawn these old mills back into the field.

First-person experiences at the controls of a plane during at least two transoceanic hops will be related Thursday evening at the Central branch of the Y.W.C.A. at 610 Lexington Avenue when Amelia Earhart will talk on "Adventures in Flying."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- About 2,500 representatives of industry and labor will attend the industry conference here on Dec. 9, George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, estimated today. Cards of admission are being sent to all who have accepted Mr. Berry's invitation to meet in an endeavor to find a way to revive at least some of the objectives of the National Recovery Administration.

IF one needed any proof that life, and particularly the life of young people, is today in no whit different in a Japanese village than it is in Topeka, Birmingham or Minsk, this lightly sketched, delicate little novel should furnish it.

In addition to another sharp break in the Alexandria market, which made a decline there of $4 a bale since Wednesday, prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday felt the effects of increasing pressure from Bombay in Liverpool and the list closed with losses of 6 to 9 points and at the lowest levels of the week.

Harry A. Schultz, chairman of the steel and iron division of the commerce and industry committee in the United Hospital campaign, reported yesterday that the division had raised 60 per cent of its quota of $24,000. Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the committee, said the division was the first so pass the half-way mark.
Seven trust funds or bequests, established to benefit the Hundred Neediest Cases, have been added during the last twelve months to the increasingly lengthening roster of such gifts.

Presenting a line-up which included only one veteran from last season's first team, City College opened its 1935-36 basketball campaign at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night by conquering the St. Francis College five of Brooklyn by 38 to 24.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Nov. 30 (Reuters). -- Whatever troops Premier Benito Mussolini may order to Libya, talk of an invasion of Egypt is no longer regarded here very seriously. Not a single Egyptian authority is anxious about the outcome of a possible attack from Libya.
AN innovation in the field of dental education has been inaugurated in the School of Dentistry of the University of Louisville -- the introduction of honors work for outstanding students.

City Hall was picketed for a few minutes yesterday morning by a score of crippled relief workers, members of the group which stood siege for several days a few weeks ago in the Welfare Department offices at 902 Broadway.

Reflecting the improved earnings in business this year, dividends declared in November were the largest for any month since June, 1931, and the largest for a November since 1930. The total was $401,523,897 for 827 corporations, compared with $166,625,453 for 757 companies the month before and $347,246,152 for 675 corporations in November, 1934.

Within the same week the University of Pennsylvania and Mr. IRENEE DU PONT amicably decide to part because he wishes his Biochemical Foundation to patent its medical discoveries and use the profits for research, and Columbia University gratefully accepts the patent of Dr. LEROY L. HARTMAN for a "desensitizer" which makes it possible to drill and fill teeth painlessly.

AT the Brooklyn Museum the "Humor in Art" exhibition is less amusing than interesting, thus corresponding to similar exhibitions at other periods and in other countries which show the tendencies of their time with the definiteness and enhanced significance of art plus irony or caricature.

NEITHER wind nor storm nor hail can stop hikers. Every Sunday morning hundreds of them pour out of the big cities into ferries, special trains and buses, seeking hillsides and woodland trails. At an hour when the Sunday sky is still shaking off the gray of dawn, men and women in waterproof boots and forestry cloth breeches stride through the still city streets to conveyances that will take them to near-by wildernesses.

PRESUMABLY this novel is based upon a true story of seventeenth-century Iceland. One gathers, indeed, that much of it survives in documentary form and that the principal actors have not altogether lost their place in national history.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 30. -- Roy Campbell's accurate southpaw passes carried Western Maryland from imminent defeat to a 14-to-10 victory over Georgetown today. In the most thrilling encounter of a Stadium football season which has offered considerable excitement this year, the Terrors humbled an opponent that was twice as strong along the ground.

BEFORE Eliot was 30 he had written "Prufrock." Before Pound was 27 he had produced, among other things, "Night Litany," "Sea-Farer," "The Return," and "Altaforte." Hart Crane was no older when "White Buildings" was published.

The Long Island chapter of the Adelphi College Alumnae Association, of which Mrs. Oliver Le Compte is president, will have as the main speakers for the supper meeting of Thursday evening at the college in Garden City Mrs. F.C. Dietz, Nassau representative of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs, and Miss Signe Hagelthorne, the college dean.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29. -- Brazil this week has passed through her sixth major revolution within fifteen years.

In 1933 Commissioner of Motor Vehicles Harold G. Hoffman, now Governor of New Jersey, had a happy thought. He wished to diminish the perils of the highways under his jurisdiction, and when the outdoor advertisers suggested a direct appeal to motorists on billboards the commissioner walked into the trap.

FOR those who missed some of the choicer representatives of English literature in the Breaker sale at the Rains last week the American Art-Anderson Galleries has graciously provided an opportunity to make a quick recovery.

Timely discovery of a fire in the basement of the Symphony Theatre, a motion-picture house at 2,531 Broadway, at the southwest corner of Ninety-fifth Street, enabled 600 men, women and children who had been watching a film showing in the theatre to file to the street without difficulty at 6:22 o'clock last night.

The crisis which the Italo-Ethiopian conflict has created, and the League's determination to apply sanctions against Italy, has brought the United States face to face with the' necessity of deciding upon such policy as may be in keeping with its own interests and the interests of world peace to which we are committed by the Briand-Kellogg treaty. The United States has decided on a policy of neutrality.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- The Yale Dramatic Association tonight launched a mystery farce, "The Whispering Gallery," as a feature of the entertainment for the Princeton-Yale football game visitors. It will be repeated here Monday night.

Five days from San Francisco to Manila; China in less than a week! It savors of necromancy and flying carpets. Now that the China Clipper has translated this dream into actuality, it still does not seem true, even to those who have watched the rapid development of the large flying boat.

I AM quoting from a fifteenth-century book, the famous "Utopia" of Sir Thomas More. Examine the quotation carefully: for, although it is an angry comment on a black and bitter period in English history four hundred years ago, it is also a pertinent exposition of "Let Freedom Ring."

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 30. -- The activities of Vaughan Glaser, an American actor alleged to have been brought into Canada under a special immigration permit to participate in an election campaign broadcast on behalf of the Conservative party, have led to a government investigation and the decision to ban such radio propaganda in the future.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Army's football squad was giving a lot of credit tonight to Line Coach Moe Daly for the victory over Navy -- even though Daly wasn't within a hundred miles of the scene of battle on Franklin Field.

EVERYBODY, it is said, has one good book in him if only he will write it. Lord Howard of Penrith -- better known at Washington as Sir Esme Howard when he was recently British Ambassador -- has realized his opportunity.
A new chemical pain-killer, which may make the dentist's chair almost as terrorless as the barber's chair, was announced the day after Thanksgiving at Columbia University.

It has frequently been said within the past two or three weeks that the peace of Europe is today in more danger of being broken than at any time since the Great War. This is not an irresponsible opinion, and there is undoubtedly some warrant for it. European sentiment is undeniably in a condition of great tension, and an accident might lead to an explosion.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 29. -- Last Nov. 12 and Nov. 22 were red-letter days in the history of the new Turkey. Two railway lines, important for industrial development and national defense, were opened on those dates -- the Irmak-Filios and Fevzipasha-Diarbekr lines.

RICHMOND, Nov. 30. -- October and early November witnessed more improvement in business in the Fifth district than any other six weeks in several years, the Richmond Bank reports. Business men in general were able to carry on their activities without calling on banks for assistance, it was stated.

FOR instance, take the "happy ending." If you happen to be of a realistic temper, the insistence of the popular cinema on joining the principals in the mechanically ecstatic fadeout, often in defiance of their obvious unfitness for each other, must often cause you grave concern.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 30 (AP). -- Representative Fred J. Sisson attacked the United States Chamber of Commerce poll on New Deal policies today, asserting that the questions were so constructed as to make a "yes" or "no" answer impossible.

By breaking 99 out of 100 targets, F.A. Cauchois annexed the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. It was the best score in a field of twenty-four gunners. The second prize went to C.W. Phellis, with 96. In the handicap shoot, the winner was F.B. Jacobs, the second cup going to G.E. Churchill.

As a spectator of the continuous fight our language makes to retain its title, my attention was arrested by your recent editorial "English at Bay." The article is still before me, for my first thought was to write you that I was not aware of English being at bay, except in THE TIMES. Elsewhere it is in retreat.

Until the adoption of the Revenue Act of 1935, corporations were not as a general rule permitted to take credit for contributions to charitable institutions for income-tax purposes. Prior to the enactment of the Revenue Act of 1928, which act expressly confined the allowance of such deductions to individuals, Federal revenue statutes dealing with the deductability of contributions made no mention of corporations.

TOO long has the shrub border been a neglected aspect of garden planning. Succession of bloom in perennial beds is ever a lively subject of discussion; planting a shade tree without careful thought is not considered; but the line of shrubbery that marks off the garden plot or forms a boundary demarcation receives but scant attention.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- Reptiles and batrachia are the latest victims of Paris fashions. Their skins make many chic accessories. Preciosa is the first bottler to show shoes in suede python. The scales give its velvety surface a ghostly moire undertone. A suede finish has also been successfully given to chameleons by skin tanners.

FOR almost fifteen years J. Raymond McCarl has been depicted as an official ogre who takes a fierce delight in chiseling pennies off lowly charwomen, clerks and laborers employed by Uncle Sam. It is for such exploits that he has become headline news.

THIS attractively made book devotes almost half its space to beautifully reproduced page plates on heavy paper illustrating artistic snuff boxes in a great variety of forms, designs and periods. Many of them are from the private collection of the author, who has long been an enthusiast on this subject.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30. -- Sparks from a cigarette which he was smoking while listening to the radio started a fire and brought death today to Theodore L. Wright, 50, of 397 Courtland Avenue, a WPA supervising engineer, whose body was found by firemen in the ruins of his home.

The world divides into two groups: those to whom Winter, with its ice and its snow and its cold, comes as a joy; and those who only look and long for the advent of the new Spring. Daniel Whitehead Hicky is a poet for the latter rather than the former.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Industrial output in November has not undergone the usual seasonal recession, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic business situation. Steel, automobile and electric power production have continued to expand, while the recessions in industries for which current data are available have been mainly of a seasonal character.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The three-month-old United States-Japan agreement by which the Japanese agreed to limit exports to the Philippines of their cotton textiles to 45,000,000 square meters a year has already encountered difficulties, officials disclosed today.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Harriers wearing the colors of the Chippewa Club today monopolized the team honors in the tenth annual cross-country championships conducted by the Westchester Recreation Commission over three new courses at Tibbetts Brook Park.

WISE, Va., Nov. 30 (AP). -- Abram Falin, 16 years old, charged with slaying his mountaineer father in a family fight, was confined in the same jail today with Edith Maxwell, who is under a twenty-five-year sentence in an almost identical case.

The documents to be housed in the new $12,000,000 National Archives Building in Washington will make available "the facts upon which the written history of American life and civilization will be based," Dorsey W. Hyde Jr., director of the archival service of the National Archives, told the twenty-third conference of Eastern College Librarians as it convened yesterday morning at Columbia University.

LONDON, Nov. 23. COINCIDENCE," a first play by Byers Robertson, presented at the St. Martin's Theatre, breaks a great many rules, but gets there just the same. We can hardly ever tell what will happen next, but when it happens we are bound to sit up and take notice.

Senorita Amelia del Rio, who is an archaeologist and official cus todian of the Monte-Alban treasure in the National Museum of Mexico, has made a very complete collection of old Mexican tales from Toltec, Aztec and Spanish sources.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 29. -- North Carolina gets far less money from the Federal Government, in comparison with the Federal taxes it pays, than any other State.

The twenty-ninth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Thursday and Friday, will produce reports on special surveys vitally affecting the life insurance companies. Leaders in banking, education and government will be among the speakers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Suit for an injunction to restrain the SEC from interfering with the $11,000,000 American Utilities Service Corporation was filed today in Federal court. The company, a holding organization for fifteen subsidiaries, has not registered with the SEC.

VERY often the home gardener can take a profitable tip from the commercial grower. The handling of low wet spots, or areas of very heavy soil, which are likely to keep the impatient planter waiting days, or even weeks, before he can begin to "work" them in the Spring, furnishes a good example.

Leaving behind him a record that his commanding officer described as one "of which every enlisted officer might well be proud," Technical Sergeant Jeremiah Courtney retired yesterday as a member of the guard company of the disciplinary barracks on Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- With a final, last-minute rush, following weeks of three-shift, twenty-four-hours-a-day sifting of hundreds of thousands of projects, the WPA today brings to a close its campaign to end the Federal dole and put 3,500,000 unemployed on public jobs at subsistence wages.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 30. -- Catching the Eagles off guard in the opening period the Crusaders from Holy Cross scored three touchdowns before Boston College was able to catch its breath and defeated the Maroon and Gold eleven on Alumni Field today, 20 to 6, in the annual game between the Jesuit rivals.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- One of the greatest teams that ever wore the Orange and Black of Princeton closed its season undefeated with a victory over Yale in the Bowl today, 38 to 7.

The undefeated Brooklyn College soccer team won the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference crown for the second successive year as the title drive came to a close with a double-header being staged at Hawthorne Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 30. -- Litigation involving about $3,000,000 and in which the Mellon-controlled Aluminum Company of America was charged with having a monopoly on aluminum ingots and with violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, has been settled out of court.
A very interesting news item was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 24 entitled "Jellicoe in a Letter to Chicago Woman Made Analysis of the Battle of Jutland."

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- A spirited defense of capitalism, capital stock companies and private initiative was delivered today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, before the Academy for German Law, created to transform Roman law into German law according to National Socialist ideology.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- A round of luncheons, teas and dinners, with the Naval Academy alumni dinner dance as a climax, supplemented the major event of the day in this city.
TORONTO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs turned on a sweeping offensive tonight to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 8 -- 3, in a National League hockey game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Vigorous protests over being arrested and handcuffed at Elkton, Md., were expressed to Secretary Hull today by Ghaffar Khan Djalal, the Minister of Iran (Persia).

Thirty of the foremost bicycle riders of the world, constituting the traditional field of fifteen teams, will get under way in New York's fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race tonight in Madison Square Garden. At 9 P.M., Pat O'Brien, screen star, will fire the gun that sends the teams off on a grind that will not end until Saturday night at 11 o'clock.

MASSAUA, Eritrea. -- Massaua, revisited, gives more than ever the impression of a superhuman accomplishment. The things that were done here, particularly during the terrible months of July and August, literally beggar description. No one who has observed the changes in this Red Sea port and who knows the conditions under which they were made can have any hesitation in saying that the greatest heroes of Italy's Ethiopian campaign are right here in Massaua.

IN October, 1931, Arnold Lunn, a convinced theist, challenged Dr. Haldane, a skeptic in religious matters, to a debate by mail on the subject of Christianity, each party to the argument to defend his own creed and to attack his opponent's.

THE preparation of the garden for its Winter rest is a task which is all too often slighted, for, when the weather becomes chilly and raw and the last bit of color is gone from the borders, enthusiasm for outdoor work usually falls to its lowest ebb.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Twenty-nine States had placed personal income tax laws on their statute books before Pennsylvania got around to it last Spring. Previous attempts to impose such a tax in this Commonwealth had been successfully resisted.

New York's annual festival of the fine arts, the ever-spectacular Beaux-Arts Ball, with its complement of color, gayety and artistry, will be held in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday night and into the early hours of Saturday morning.

Large redemptions by public utility corporations were a feature of last week's announcements of bonds called for payment before maturity. Aside from these calls, the new retirements were principally for small lots of municipal and industrial loans.

MILAN, Nov. 12, 1935. AT the Teatro Comunale of Ferrara, the Propaganda Ministry has encouraged the production of a new one-act opera by a local musician, Carlo Ratta. His "Marfisa d'Este" is a lyric legend sketched about the tale of the beauteous and wicked princess of that name, supposed to have committed numerous misdeeds in Ferrara's ducal castle.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 30. -- A statement made by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, that "mass production" of college graduates had made negligible the face value of a college degree was the basis of a symposium which The Chattanooga Times will print tomorrow.

Anguish bit into his very soul yesterday afternoon and his frame fairly bulged in sympathetic gesture as Princeton piled score on score on the hapless Yale football team at New Haven, but the Twelfth Man exercised heroic self-restraint. He sat on the edge of his seat, but did not leave it and suffered silently, majestically and with due thought to the readiness of press and camera to fasten on him at the slightest aggressive gesture.

SO stimulating is the recently published treatise, "The Modern Band," by Stanislao Gallo, that many a symphonic composer, after its careful perusal, might easily be tempted to try his hand at creating an opus for the too generally underrated medium of expression with which the new volume concerns itself.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Liquidation by holders of December grain contracts carried prices sharply lower in all North American markets today, with the close around the bottom. Wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade lost 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents, in Winnipeg 1 1/2 to 1 5/8, in Kansas City 1 to 1 1/8 and in Minneapolis 1 3/8 to 1 3/4.

THE recommendations of the New Jersey State Planning Board recently announced are likely, in the opinion of highway authorities, to have a far-reaching effect on future road construction not only in that State but in others.

GEORGE HENRY PAYNE, Federal Communications Commissioner, is crusading for a higher standard of radio programs. In recent speeches at Harvard, Cornell and Columbia Universities he pointed out that culture should dominate as one of the keynotes in American broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- George N. Peek said today that he was reducing to "simple language" what has been termed a "supercritical" report to President Roosevelt on possible effects of the Canadian-American trade pact. It will be submitted to the President on his return from Warm Springs.

An active demand for gift accessories, toiletries, toys and men's and boys' furnishings featured the week in the wholesale markets here, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.
ALWAYS, take off the lid, and the spirit of man will bound upward like a steel spring. There is nothing more reassuring as to man's inherent spirit than this invariable manifestation.

The First and Second District Dental Societies of the State of New York will open their eleventh annual Greater New York December meeting tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The meeting, attended by nearly 10,000 dentists, will continue throughout the week.

Within the last two days, it was revealed yesterday by Commissioner Valentine, two policemen have been dismissed for drunkenness, three others have been marked for dismissal, three have been suspended and three other cases have been disposed of on similar charges in one way or another.

Pictorial reproductions of noted tropical resorts will lend an appropriate touch of color to the Tropical Ball on Dec. 12 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Bermuda, Nassau and other Winter rendezvous -- particularly in South and Central America -- will be represented by scenic displays in a decorative scheme employing also airplanes and models of cruise ships.

In the Corinthian Room of the Pierre last night, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boardman gave a dinner dance for their debutante daughter, Miss Clarinda Starbuck Boardman. The debutante received with her parents before a bower of palms and ferns at the stairway leading to the dining room, which was decorated with masses of yellow chrysanthemums on the window ledges.

Rare American glass of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries collected by Alfred B. Maclay of this city, together with the collection of early blue Staffordshire ware and Currier Ives lithographs of Mrs. John Canfield Tomlinson Jr. of Northampton, Mass., will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., next Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Call and time money rates in November stayed at the level to which they had been raised in October. There was a lack of interest as to new loans at the prevailing quotations, borrowing being almost entirely for replacements of expiring obligations.

Early Christmas shopping began to set a faster pace during the week, and retail trade in the metropolitan area showed gains over the corresponding week last year. For department stores the increase over 1934 for the week was estimated to average around 5 per cent, although substantially larger gains were made by individual stores.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Two inland and two seashore golfers will see action in the semi-final round of the thirteenth annual Eastern States Thanksgiving tournament as the result of the first and second round matches today over the Wildwood Golf Club links.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- New excavations in Dura, the Pompeii of the Euphrates, made by the combined Yale University and French Academy of Inscriptions expedition, have resulted in these notable finds:

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- Premier Laval's success in the Chamber of Deputies was marked by a vigorous response on the Bourse today, and the end-of-the-month settlement was made considerably easier by the belief that the government would last.

The Madison chapter of the American Association of University Women will have Dr. George M. Priest, Professor of German at Princeton University, as the principal speaker on its annual guest night program on Friday at the home of Mrs. Dwight Morss on Woodland road.

The future relations of government to business, the regulation of competition and the development of the National Labor Relations Board and of the New York State unemployment insurance system will be among the problems on the discussion program for the second annual conference of the Federated Management Societies, Thursday and Friday at the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The District Court in Koeslin granted a farmer a divorce today because his wife refused to bear children. The court held the farmers were the mainspring of German blood, which wives must help to perpetuate.
Relative to your recent article concerning the Presidential cheeses, I would add a correction and supplementary information.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30. -- Once again the field hockey players from the Southeast have emerged with a clean score sheet from the round-robin games of the annual national tournament. The matches on the snow-laden field of the Laurel School today proved their continued superiority beyond the shadow of a doubt.

Sponsors of oaths and other instruments affecting freedom of teaching were denounced and defended yesterday by teachers at the closing session of the annual meeting of the National Council for the Social Studies in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Programs as diverse as the purpose of the clubs that hold them will characterize the current week among women's organizations. Holiday activities will engulf them all in another seven days. Just now the calendar reflects that variety credited with being the spice of life.

Trading in bonds was narrow on the New York Stock Exchange in a typically dull week-end session yesterday. Prices generally maintained a firm undertone, with most of the swings worthy of note being on the up side. Trading was selective, with the sharp advances scored in a few individual issues reflecting merely specific circumstances affecting those bonds rather than any broad market influence.

WASHINGTON. THE National Park Trust Fund, created by Congress in July, has recently received its first donation -- a $5,000 check from the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Distributing Corporation, in recognition of the facilities placed at the disposal of the company in making a film in Sequoia National Park, California.

SOME rather staggering news came through from Washington last week. It had to do with reported activities of the New Deal's art department at Boulder Dam. According to this dispatch, artists are now at work not only painting the machinery in "harmonious colors" but also covering the walls of the power house with lightning and the floor with "lizards, plumed serpents and birds."

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 30. -- Edward Hay, one-time Minister of Communications and until recently Mexican Consul General at Paris, today was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs by President Lazaro Cardenas, thus completing the Cabinet which was reorganized last June following the political crisis which resulted in the disappearance from public life of former President Plutarco Elias Calles.

Independent Royal Arch Lodge No. 2, F. and A.M., which is affectionately known as "Old Number Two," will celebrate its 175th anniversary at a service at 3 o'clock this afternoon at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

RADIO men proved last week that contract bridge can be made a source of entertainment to radio listeners and also to spectators. Incidentally, a United States team led by Ely Culbertson outplayed an Argentine team and won the international match by 1,030 points, but the result of the competition was not nearly so important as the successful result of the scientific experiment.

The first of the Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The guests, who included former debutantes and many of their men friends, were received by several members of the committee headed by Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow. Other members of the committee are:

WITH coffee, some one brings out the portable radio and there, in a far-away corner of the world, with the open tent-flap carrying the vision out toward the tropical stars and the deep, dark void below, the plaintive strains of Lucienne Boyer singing "Parlez-moi d'amour" bring instant silence, and the air becomes pregnant with nostalgia.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30. -- Auburn's Plainsmen broke a long-standing jinx with a 27-to-6 victory over the University of Florida Gators at Miami Stadium today.

British department stores missed an opportunity to take advantage of the great housing boom in England, whereas furniture chains there selling on the installment plan experienced a sharp growth coincident with the increase in residential building, according to data analyzed yesterday by H.I. Kleinhaus, director of the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- In the matter of crime, things are better in Chicago. Certainly automobiles are safer from theft and stripping than they used to be, and, if police statistics can be relied upon, murders, robberies and burglaries are fewer.

The popularity of Will Rogers in the places which he visited in his lifetime as an aerial traveler is being reflected daily in contributions being received for the Will Rogers Memorial Fund, it was disclosed yesterday at national headquarters of the fund campaign.

One hundred and fifty-nine men and women students of Brooklyn College were named on the first honor list issued by the deans of the college for outstanding scholastic achievement during the semester ended in June, 1935. The honor list was made public yesterday by Deans Adele Bildersee and Mario E. Cosenza.

A tribute from Lieut. Gen. Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt, Governor of Bermuda, will mark the Bicycle Breakfast to be held today at Le Coq Rouge for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation. A floral bicycle will be presented to Miss Hope Gatins, chairman of the debutante committee for the benefit, on behalf of the charity, as the Bermuda Governor's tribute to the occasion.

MOUNT KISKO, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- The fourth annual Goldens Bridge Hounds Hunt ball was held here tonight at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club. Mrs. Marion T. Gibson, M. F.H., headed the committee in charge of the event. She was assisted by Mrs. William Browning, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, Mrs. W. Watson, Mrs. Arthur Choate and Mrs. J.C. Smith, James Butler, Joseph Dixon, William Browning, Frederick Warfield, Frederick Godwin and Edward Munro.

Bond issues marketed here in November were larger and stocks smaller than in the preceding month. Both types of securities were larger than a year ago for the corresponding month. New issues offered to the public aggregated $338,618,000, of which $334,139,000 represented fifty-four bond offerings and $4,479,000 two stock issues, compared with $301,323,000 for fifty-five bond flotations and $35,097,000 for eight stock offerings in October.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- A new NRA bill was reported authoritatively today to be ready for swift submission to Congress, should business show signs of wanting it.
MILD confusion reigns along the Rialto this week, with the cinema's advance agents uncertain whether five or just three new pictures will open.

Censorship of the college press by university administrations was attacked yesterday by speakers at the second-day sessions of the conference of Eastern and Southern college editors at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

ONCE in a while, even if it is not a family custom, nearly every woman plans a buffet supper, checks off the list of guests against the available forks, and wonders what she will place on the menu. The buffet supper solves the problem of serving a maximum of guests with a minimum of fuss, and for Sunday night or week-end entertaining is becoming more popular every year.

IN his able and suggestive article entitled "Musicians and Critics" in THE TIMES of Nov. 24, Mr. Downes quotes d'Indy's remark, "I consider criticism absolutely useless." It may or may not be absolutely useless -- there will be different opinions about that -- but it is absolutely inevitable.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- "Sure it's tough to take it on the chin," said Lieutenant Tom Hamilton, as he stood against the wall in the steaming Navy dressing rom a few minutes after his gallant midshipmen had left the field, the losers of the game they wanted most in all the world to win.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The "big five" of the naval world are about to foregather once more to seek a new formula for controlling the expansion of their floating armaments.

This year's all-America football team, though it must inevitably draw criticism from certain sections of the country and from certain institutions whose candidates have been overlooked or filed away in favor of others, compares favorably for balance, speed and strength with the best of recent years.

THIS sheaf of poems out of England comes to the American reader with two introductions, one by Hilaire Belloc and the other by John Masefield. Seldom does one find a book so doubly endorsed. Nor is it, on examination, that Ruth Pitter needs to fear the reception of the garland of her Mad Lady.

The most advanced developments in streamlining of commercial ships will be carried out in the construction of the new flagship of the Holland-America Line, which will be ready for service in 1937. Models of the ship have been completed, indicating the use of streamline effects in her hull and funnels.

ROME, Nov. 29. -- Oil has become the principal centre around which the fight between Italy and the League of Nations is being fought ever since the proposal was seriously made to add it, with coal, copper and other essential raw materials, to the list of goods to whose export to Italy sanctions are to apply.
ST. JAMES, L.I., Nov. 30. -- The first Smithtown Hunt ball since 1931 was held this evening at the country home of Lawrence Smith Butler in this village. More than 300 persons attended.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The announcement was made today that all persons enjoying diplomatic privileges in embassies, legations and consulates would not be affected by paragraph three of the Nuremberg laws which, as amended, forbid Jews to employ non-Jewish women servants under 35 years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Two years after repeal the two sides of the question are marshaling forces again for new battles over prohibition. With pledge-signing campaigns and social activities temperance leaders are directing their efforts now mainly to educating young people against "the dangers of drinking."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- George N. Peek has tendered to President Roosevelt his resignation as president of the Export-Import Bank and Foreign Trade Adviser and is expected with a few days to sever all connections with the administration with which he has been identified since the beginning.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 30. -- The 1936 Nassau County budget showing an increase of $1,457,216.80 was not thoroughly and publicly discussed before adoption "because there were things in it a little difficult to explain," according to a charge made today by Benjamin L. Barondess, president of the Civic League of Nassau County and vice president of the Nassau County Taxpayers Association.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Honduran political exiles in Costa Rica hail with delight the recent declarations of the Honduran Minister in Washington, former President Dr. Miguel Paz Barrajona, deprecating the intention of President Caries to remain in office for another term, contrary to the Constitution.

Although completing one of the most active months since July, 1935, and a week wherein prices worked lower, stocks moved narrowly yesterday in the slowest Saturday trading since Sept. 28. The half day's business on the Stock Exchange amounted to 670,000 shares; the closing was steady, with the railway group showing up to a little better advantage than the industrial.

IN its text, in the wood engravings which are a living part of that text, and as a piece of book-making, this new volume by Clare Leighton is a beautiful thing. Nothing with more distinction comes from the presses this Autumn.

WITH the best motives in the world, Feather told a white lie to blacken the reputation of a dead man. When the dead man proved to be very much alive, she found that her good intentions had let her in for an infernal mix-up.

IT is significant of the popular interest in detective fiction that the choice of the Book Society for the current month should have fallen upon "Gaudy Night" (Gollancz), the latest work of Dorothy L. Sayers. This is a detective story with an imaginary women's college at Oxford as a background.

ABOUT this time each year the printmakers begin their mass manoeuvres. Last week the Society of American Etchers, Inc. (formerly the Brooklyn Society of Etchers), opened its annual exhibition at the National Arts Club, to remain current through December.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Professor James W. Garner of the University of Illinois told the Academy of German Law today the old distinction between neutrality of the State, as such, and neutrality of its citizens should be abolished as "illogical, if not immoral."

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 (Canadian Press). -- The peoples of Canada and the United States require no treaty to bind upon them the principle of the undefended frontier and resort to arms by either of them against the other is both "unnecessary and unthinkable," Norman Armour, American Minister to Canada, declared today before the Canadian Club.

THE extravagant, ostentatious youth of Alcibiades when as the rich young ward of Pericles he flaunted his beauty in the Athenian streets is the period chosen by Vincenz Brun for his carefully detailed novel. Opening with the celebration of the great Athenian festival, the Panathenaea, it closes with the departure of the still youthful Alcibiades for Sicily.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Joy was unconfined in Army's dressing quarters after the game, Head Coach Gar Davidson being overwhelmed by former Army players and rooters as a result of the Cadet's brilliant victory over the Navy.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Pelican, former handicap performer for J.E. Widener, came through with a smashing victory today in the silks of E. Sigman in the six-furlong Baton Rouge Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

SHANGHAI. -- A long time before the establishment of the new government in Manchuria, the Japanese were in a position to know the locations of the principal gold-bearing regions in the country. These areas were carefully set aside. When the Manchukuo Government was established they were designated as State mining property, thereby creating one of the first of the Manchukuo monopolies.
THE factors of plant material, of supplementary foliage and of harmony between these and the container in which they appear, are rapidly increasing in significance.

The theory that a child who cannot make normal progress in reading is below normal in general intelligence has been disproved by a remedial project in the city's public schools in which problem children have made gains as much as five times greater than those in average classrooms.

We like this book of more or less random verses because of its closeness to nature. The author -- the book comes from a mountain press -- evidently lives among the fields and the hills. She loves the smell of new-mown hay. The birds and the bees and the flowers are all her friends.

NOVA HERCULIS blazed forth again last week, but only in Associated Press dispatches. This means not that astronomers have been neglecting the star but that the studies made for nearly a year have now received the attention that they deserve as news.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- Behind the pomp and circumstance of Georgia's tumultuous home-coming welcome to President Roosevelt in this city today, a battle of practical politics was being waged for control of the State.

The collection of furniture, early American silver and other objects of art, including the property of the late Chandler R. Clifford, founder of the American Association of Interior Decorators, which was auctioned yesterday and Friday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, brought $44,421.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30. -- While the stove and foundry industry continues to hold the spotlight in the industrial field of the Eighth Federal Reserve District, certain indices show a general betterment in this line.

Wildlife enthusiasts were delighted to learn recently that the National Association of Audubon Societies had arranged to establish the Todd Wildlife Sanctuary on a beautiful little island lying a short distance off the Maine shore in Muscongue Bay, between Damariscotta and Waldoboro.

Roy Worters, diminutive goalie for the New York Americans, gave one of the finest performances of his career last night when his team defeated the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden, 2 to 1. The star-spangled net guardians, practically single-handed, held off the raging skaters from the hub in a dynamic final session that thrilled a gathering of 8,000 fans.

THE Romantic Movement has had many and conflicting explanations, but it has remained for Peter Quennell, in his brilliant study of Byron and his background before the fall, to add to the customary romantic notes -- sensibility to nature, medievalism, melancholy and the like -- the note of plain racial, not to say sexual, snobbery.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- When it rained in Paris Thursday, everybody in authority, especially the Minister of the Interior and the Prefect of Police, heaved vast sighs of relief. That fortunate drizzle was, they knew, far more likely to prove effective in keeping the streets free from demonstrators than all their police and Republican Guards.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 30. -- While the city administration looked on with misgivings, the local WPA organization made a last-minute drive today to complete the transfer of about 6,000 to work relief in the liquidation of direct relief by the Federal Government by Monday morning.

The Middle West Utilities Company, which, as the top holding company of Samuel Insull's once-mighty system, had investments valued at more than $1,000,000,000 before it went into bankruptcy in April, 1932, was reincarnated last Wednesday. Its new name is the Middle West Corporation.

Appointments of vice presidents by the dozen and committeemen by the score at last week's annual meeting of the American Power Boat Association's council marked, in reality the close of one motor-boating year and the launching of another.

WINDMILLS all at once began to turn picturesque and archaic arms in the landscape of American public consciousness recently when Cape Cod's collective voice was heard through the land. The native and Summer residents on the cape were concerned over the sale to friends of Henry Ford of one of their ancient windmills for preservation in his Early America Museum in Dearborn, Mich.

A new course in statistical research has been added to the Barnard College curriculum this year, it has been announced by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve. This is an advanced course to bring students into contact with organizations dealing with business and social research in the city, and also give the students an opportunity to carry out projects of their own.

ATHENS, Nov. 28. -- King George of Greece, it is known, had no illusions that he was returning to a bed of roses, but he can hardly have anticipated the violent conflict into which he was immediately thrown with King-maker Kondylis, the former Regent.

FUR farming -- an idea which burst on a Canadian trapper who had penned up a young fox to wait until its fur matured -- is rapidly attaining the status of big business in the Dominion. Statistics collected by the Canadian Government list a total of 6,437 fur farms, with a capital investment of $14,000,000.

The antagonism of executives of the Association of American Railroads toward the office of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, flared again last week, thus carrying on a campaign which has been waged increasingly in the open since early in the year.

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season -- one of a series of three dances of importance to debutantes this Winter -- will be held on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event, with its heritage of formality carried through several decades, will bring together most of the debutantes of this season and many of their young men friends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- A representation of 100 per cent on the part of A.F. of L. unions at the industrial conference was predicted today at the headquarters of George L. Berry, Industrial Recovery Coordinator. This followed reports in labor circles here that the carpenters' union, the second largest in the federation, had at first declined an invitation.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30. -- The suggestion of Senator McNary that Canada should ask the United Kingdom to accord to United States timber the same preference as granted Canada in the 1932 trade agreements went without comment from officials here.

FOR the first time in history grown-ups who feel the need of going back to college for a few weeks are to have a building of their own on a university campus. Out at the University of Minnesota preparations are under way for the start this month of a $275,000 Adult Education Building, financed in part by PWA.

Consolidated Railroads of Cuba, controlled by the Cuba Company, reported yesterday for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a net loss of $4,271 after taxes, interest and other charges, compared with a net loss of $5,434 in the corresponding period the year before.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- Italy's Cabinet rushed through measures to strengthen the nation's war machine today. In two and one-half hours the Cabinet, dominated by Premier Benito Mussolini, approved eighty-eight defense, economic and financial decrees.

IN the December number of Harpers Magazine, Samuel Baron sings a thoughtful dirge over "The Dying Theatre." The funeral strain is not in itself exceptional, for criticism of the theatre always wears the widow's weeds. You will remember Mr. McCurdle's rococo lament: "

In a new code for duplicate contract bridge, agreed upon yesterday by the American Bridge League, the American Whist League and the United States Bridge Association, the count of honors in match point play is eliminated. The new laws will go into effect tomorrow and will be adhered to in the tournament of the American Bridge League in Chicago.

JANE ADDAMS is dead. It is difficult to write these words or to have faith in their meaning, for even the most hardened skeptic and unbeliever knows that Jane Addams is alive. Today, with a world made heartsick once more with reports of air raids and pillage, of gas attacks and civilian suffering, her militant spirit, dedicated to the cause of peace and mediation, is guiding the thinking of millions of peace lovers.
