Mr. Judson must not blame the free concerts entirely for the lack of patronage of the Philharmonic. The type of program given last year is largely responsible for the falling off of membership. I sat through many numbers which bored me, and I did not go to several of the concerts which advertised modern music.

GENEVA, Nov. 30. -- Emigration of 200,000 Jews from Germany must be expected in the next few years if present conditions there continue, experts studying reorganization of the League of Nations refugee work have been told by the delegation headed by Heinrich Mann and George Bernhard, representing all German refugees in France.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Three Army backs shared scoring honors in the first-half touchdown parade staged against the Navy on Franklin Field today. Grove was the pace-setter, crossing twice in the first period. True also tallied in the opening quarter, while Grohs went over in the second.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Roosevelt four-generation Christmas celebration will be minus a ball for young people this year because there is no one to give it for. The Christmas calendar was made public today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

IN the continuing crisis of unemployment which requires our governments, local, State and Federal, to assist the destitute on a scale unprecedented in our history, the need for private charitable work is undiminished.
The first municipally built, owned and managed housing project in the United States will be publicly opened in New York on Tuesday. It is appropriately called First Houses.

The latest developments in the engineering field will be discussed here this week when more than 2,000 engineers from every State and from Canada gather at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. The sessions will open tomorrow afternoon with the business meeting and will close Thursday afternoon.
Without waiting for an invitation, the Rambling Correspondent dropped into a chair and said he had read the story of the world's twenty best-dressed women with much satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Adoption of a resolution by the Republican National Committee suggesting the writing of a platform by the national convention that will appeal to "all classes, irrespective of previous political affiliations" will be urged by R.B. Creager, National Committeeman from Texas, when the committee meets here Dec. 16.

Washington, the States, the cities all watch the figures of business improvement closely, but no other figure do they watch with quite the interest as that of unemployment. Apart from the indication that it gives of human distress and demoralization, it is pivotal in determining political and economic policies.

EVEN if Alexander Pope, as he declared, "lisp'd in numbers, for the numbers came," as an infant prodigy our own Isaiah Thomas has him beaten a mile. For to the small Alexander numbers came, without effort on his part.

How wise and cautious elephants are was demonstrated the other day by the refusal of an aged pachyderm to re-enter a truck which had broken down with her on the road. She left the conveyance at East Orange, N.J., and insisted on walking twenty miles to her home.

MANILA. -- A Filipino columnist writing in the highly nationalistic Philippines Herald has broached a topic about which Americans here have hesitated to speak. That is the decline in quality of the teaching of English in Philippine schools. Under the caption "Who Is to Blame," he writes:

BROADCASTERS are now planning their shows under the 1936 calendar. The entertainment card for 1935 is booked full and within a few weeks the curtain will drop on the year's radio cavalcade. Millions of words and countless melodies have been flashed into the emptiness of space for another 365 days to vanish in less than a second after they were impinged upon the "mike."

EARLY last January the President of the United States pressed a golden key in the White House and thereby caused a light to shine from a tall tower on a hill beside the Mississippi River. The hill was Cardiff Hill, overlooking the little city of Hannibal, in Missouri; the tower was the Mark Twain Memorial Lighthouse.

THE importance of these memoirs lies in the character of the man who wrote them and in the peculiar intimacy of his connection with Napoleon. His duties as Master of Horse kept him close to the side of the Emperor from the moment when the die was cast and 600,000 men were sent across the frontier into Russia in January, 1812.

PARIS. THE Fall midseason collections in which the styles for next Spring are shown indicate, as usual at this epoch, a distinct reaction toward a simple, informal mode -- a reaction, specially acute this season, because it comes after the run of supersumptuous renaissance fashions, willed to us by the late Italian exposition.

WHEN, several weeks ago, Eugene L. Vidal, director of air commerce, issued orders restricting the use of regular airways and limiting the use of airports for fliers not engaged in regular air-line service there was a squawk that echoed from Mines Field, Los Angeles to Roosevelt Field, L.I.

Distillers, rectifiers, importers, jobbers and retailers in the liquor industry are looking forward with some misgivings to Jan. 1, when the 50 per cent tariff reduction on whiskies aged four years or more becomes effective. A period of price unsettlement, which will he aggravated by the usual post-holiday decline in whisky sales, is bound to follow the change in rates, whisky dealers point out.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP). -- New impetus for a move to link North America with Europe by a commercial airline will be sought at a conference next Wednesday between American and British experts.
OTTAWA, Nov. 28. -- Few of Canada's recent elections have produced more surprising results than that of last Monday in the ancient Province of Quebec.

The successful operation of the bid depository established three months ago by the American Institute of Steel Construction may lead to the adoption of similar depositories by the wholesale lumber and allied construction trades, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Retail trade was abnormally heavy for the season, with gains of the individual stores running 15 to 40 per cent ahead of last year. A heavy advertised week-end sale by one Loop store brought out a shopping crowd on Friday that taxed elevator and escalator capacity.

The French Chamber of Deputies reconvened last week, after a recess of five months, in the midst of a new crisis for the franc. Its first debate, therefore, was not concerned with the nation's critical relationship to Italy, Germany or England, nor with the domestic problem posed by the Croix de Feu armed veterans' organization, but with the question, Is it worth while struggling to keep the franc at its present gold value?

Decoration of the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is in the hands of a group of British artists selected with a view to displaying "the best of British artistry and craftsmanship of the present day," it was announced yesterday at the New York office of the line.

Today is the first Sunday in Advent. In Baptist churches the annual Education Day will be celebrated. The purpose is "to stimulate the zeal of Baptist boys and girls in going to college and to create a new interest in the Baptist schools."

YOU will look long in the history books for a Prime Minister who, within a month after he led his party into office with the largest majority it ever gained, has achieved a trade treaty which his country had vainly sought for the greater part of seventy years. These things Mackenzie King has done, however.

Like every writing man, the President of the United States sometimes has trouble getting started. Early last week, for instance, he sat down to write a speech and ran into difficulty; the ideas didn't come right. Succeeding at last in getting two pages finished, he read them over -- and tore them up.

A group of seventy-five reservists in the Italian Army who have been residing in the United States departed yesterday for their homeland, ready to go to the Ethiopian front. They paraded along the Italian Line pier at West Eighteenth Street singing and shouting, and then boarded the Conte di Savoia's third-class gangway for the voyage to Genoa.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 30. -- Baldwin High School's undefeated and untied football team will go South next week for its second post-season game in as many years with Petersburg (Va.) High School. The contest is to be played next Saturday at Petersburg, according to an announcement made today by George Craig, Baldwin coach.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP). -- The Federal dole ended in up-State New York today, but the Works Progress Administration, to which municipal officials look for help in shouldering the relief burden, gave assurance that it had jobs for all relief recipients who would take them.
An exhibition of Staffordshire and American box lids will be held this month, beginning tomorrow, by the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

ROME, Nov. 30. -- Further easing of international tension has occurred in the last twenty-four hours, and Italians are now beginning to look forward to the meeting of the League Committee of Eighteen with greater equanimity than hitherto.

THE Japanese invasion has altered many Chinese customs and the new youth of China have discarded many of their ancestors' habits, but some of the older generation still walk in the paths of tradition. In Peiping, for instance, pompous middle-aged gentlemen may still be seen airing their caged thrushes or skylarks in the bright morning sunshine.

IF there is any failure on the part of the present or future population to understand music, it will not be the fault of the musical popularizers or their publishers. For years now there has been a stream of explanatory and instructive manuals issued from the press, and they seem to be coming at closer intervals than ever.

MAJOR ALBERT WARNER took time off the other day to outline the plans of his company and its affiliates -- Cosmopolitan and First National Pictures -- for the first six months of the new year. After the annual festivities are over, the Warner cameras will start turning on six new productions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 30. -- Concentrated effort to stem the rising tide of discrimination against women and to achieve and safeguard by constitutional amendment and by treaties their equality with men in status and opportunity was urged and pledged at the opening session here today of the biennial conference of the National Woman's Party.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The naval conference, scheduled to open a week from Monday, represents an attempt to pick up whatever bits and pieces can be salvaged from the wreckage of the Washington and London treaties.

FRANCESCO GEMINIANI'S "XII Sonata a Violine e Cembalo'' has been made available to students and instrumentalists in an edition in modern notation, prep ared by Ross Lee Finney. This volume, the first of the series of annual publications of early and rare music to be put forth by the Smith College Archives, is a most commendable achievement, representing much research and labor.

THE problem of finding a Christmas gift for a man need not cause confusion in feminine heads. Women who refuse to allow themselves to be unnerved by memories of past gifts, which were slyly hid away a few days after New Year's, stand a chance of hitting upon a present that will serve its recipient well.

Declines of a point or two predominated in the local commodity futures market yesterday, although some of the metals were firmer. In the cash markets, rubber gained, while declines occurred in all the grains, cotton, lard and wool tops.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 30. -- Francisco C. Rosas, an oil field worker, is being sought, according to the Vera Cruz State authorities, for the murder of James Brown, American production foreman for the British-owned Eagle Oil Company at its Agua Dulce camp.

A concerted nation-wide effort to translate six recognized fraternity ideals into action was urged by speakers at the final session yesterday morning of the National Interfraternity Conference, which held its annual two-day meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

MEXICO, D.F., Nov. 30. -- Francisco C. Rosas, an oil field worker, is being sought, according to the Vera Cruz State authorities, for the murder of James Brown, American production foreman for the British-owned Eagle Oil Company at its Agua Dulce camp.

A concerted nation-wide effort to translate six recognized fraternity ideals into action was urged by speakers at the final session yesterday morning of the National Interfraternity Conference, which held its annual two-day meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The organization by Mrs. Gladys Gordon Fry, ornithologist, of a party of bird students for a five-week trip to study bird life in British Guiana in January, the first student group of its kind to visit the wilds of that country under professional guidance, was announced yesterday.

We celebrate this year the hundredth anniversary of Mark Twain's birth. Much has been written in appreciation of the man and of his work. Critics and reviewers give just praise to his description of the life of the Middle West in the country town where Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer were born and of life on the Mississippi.

STATION SPW, Warsaw, Poland, is a new ten-kilowatt broadcaster in the short-wave roster. The channel is 13,635 kilocycles (22 meters). Programs are on the air daily from about 11:30 A. M. to 12:30 P. M., New York time. Identification may be difficult until it is learned that "Radio Warszawa" is pronounced "Rawdeo Varshava."

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 30. -- Mayor Henry Mitchell of Elkton said today that there was "some pretty hot stuff" in the Elkton Town Council's report on the "runin" which the Iranian Minister had with the Elkton police.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20. -- Russell T. Sharpe, secretary of the student employment at Harvard University, said today that the current belief that every boy or girl, regardless of ability, has the right to a college education must be corrected.

BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- The trial of Bishop Peter Legge of the Catholic Diocese of Meissen before the Berlin Criminal Court on charges of exchange smuggling has been followed by a new outburst of Nazi defiance of the Catholic church.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30. -- Artificial growth of large and optically perfect lithium fluoride crystals, which, because they transmit light over a wider range of wave lengths than any known optical material, hold promise of extending the horizon of atomic research, has been accomplished in the Department of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it was revealed here today.

OMAHA, Nov. 29. -- After a month of special session effort under the insistent prodding of Governor Cochran, the Nebraska Legislature finally evolved a series of social welfare laws to match the national administration's program.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP). -- An undefeated team will be invited by Stanford for the Rose Bowl game here on New Year's Day, Alfred Masters, Indians' graduate manager, said tonight.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29. -- Nation-wide interest has been aroused in the case of 21-year-old Edith Maxwell, the school teacher who was sentenced to twenty-five years in the penitentiary after conviction by a jury in the little Virginia mountain town of Wise.

GENEVA, Nov. 29. -- Judging from what one reads from outside, particularly from the United States, a good many persons are wondering whether Great Britain runs the League of Nations. The answer given here is no.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Enactment by the next Congress of a bill for the immediate cash payment of a soldiers' bonus over a Presidential veto was predicted today by Senator McNary, minority leader.

Things took a nasty turn abroad last week. Mussolini found himself face to face with the possibility that his supplies of oil might soon be shut off. It was a threat that stirred him to action -- and the action was not peaceful.

ANY foreigner attempting to get from fiction some idea of American village life might well go quietly mad if he read through the interpretations of the past twenty years. Imagine, for example, the mental state of one who followed, in sequence, life in Gopher Prairie; Friendship Village; Spoon River; Winesburg, Ohio; Arlington, Vt.; Kinston, Miss.

EACH reprinting of a book means a service stripe, for it indicates that it has satisfied the needs of a good many people and that it contains something of proven beauty, interest or helpfulness. Therefore it is often wiser to look among the reprints for Christmas presents than among the new books.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The Boerse was quiet today and without any important transactions or significant changes, as the real business in securities is still done privately and transactions on the floor are entirely official in character.

LARGE-LEAVED begonias, bryophyllum, sanseveria or snake plant, the crassula and other common fleshy leaved succulents, root quickly and easily from their leaves. To propagate the large-leaved begonias, of which the Rex type is widely admired, the gardener chooses large mature leaves.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- The mountaineer moonshiners of the Blue Grass State have lost their 100-year war with the Federal Government. The last stronghold of the clan has been penetrated to the innermost recesses of the hitherto impenetrable hills.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Seven times as much Japanese cotton cloth entered the United States in October as was imported in the corresponding month last year, but its value was only five times as great, the Department of Commerce reported today.

PROCESSIONS have been the delight of mankind ever since the first captain marched home his conquering warriors and his captives, ever since the first chieftain was borne in solemn pomp to his grave or pyre, ever since the first high priest led the people out to sacrifice to the dim gods of the twilight.

DOG dietitians and eat caterers doing business on a large scale are a recent development of industry. No boondoggling this, even though some of its promoters are recruits from occupations that have languished.

JUST why the "border" carnations, so extensively grown in England, have never become more popular in this country it is difficult to understand. Many of them are perfectly hardy, their culture offers no great difficulties, and in addition to other desirable qualities they have to recommend them their unique fragrance.
The $10,000,000 Annex Postoffice Building at Ninth Avenue, between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets, will be dedicated by Postmaster General James A. Farley at noon Thursday.

Tomorrow's activities at the Carroll Club will include a dinner for the Right Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Philosophy and Religion at Catholic University in Washington, and the first of a series of three lectures by him. "Political and Social Conditions at the Time of Christ" will be his initial topic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- Pacific Coast business showed no unusual development during the past week, most indices recording a steady improvement. Moderate to good gains were reported by both wholesale and retail merchants and there was a seasonal increase in the number of employed in these lines.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30. -- Yale fought grimly and gamely against the inevitable today. The Elis were crushed by the Princeton powerhouse but never routed.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Vassar College is going to have an opportunity to study crime in a program that will extend through the rest of the college year.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Nov. 30. -- Emperor Haile Selassie established Ethiopia's military headquarters at Dessye today, after telling his subjects that, if necessary, he would "join the warriors in the trenches."

In correcting James P. Welsh's article on "The Old Spanish Trail" Miss Ellen E. Bailey herself fell into errors caused no doubt, by a similarity of names. Her statement that General Braxton Bragg was killed in a duel on the steps of the postoffice at Mobile is one. General Bragg died in Galveston, Texas, Sept. 27, 1876, and was buried in the Confederate Rest in Magnolia Cemetery, Mobile.

THREE operas will be given in concert form by the B.B.C. Orchestra in London this season. They are Purcell's "King Arthur,'' Darius Milhaud's "Christopher Columbus" and Shostakovich's "Lady Macbeth of Mzinsk."

Marjorie Hope Nicolson, dean of Smith College, will be the speaker Friday at a joint meeting of the Smith College clubs of Summit, the Oranges and Montclair at the Montclair Art Museum. In addition, the committee, which comprises representatives of the three organizations, will present Edith Bennett, soprano, who will be accompanied by Rodney Saylor at the piano.

DETROIT. SEVEN hundred thousand units appear to be the probable output of the automobile industry for the months of November and December. Production, with Ford and Chevrolet setting the pace, is holding steadily around 90,000 a week.

HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Sir Emerson, 2-year-old Valdina Farms entry, with only one previous victory to his credit, romped away from keen competition today in the $5,000 added Ed Hussion Memorial Handicap at Epsom Downs, covering the mile and sixteenth route in 1:45 2-5.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Weather cloudy, track sloppy. Army was first on the field. Navy came tumbling after.

Columbia's football team, working with almost mechanical perfection, closed its season with colors flying high yesterday at Baker Field. The Lions from Morningside Heights, underdogs because of a mediocre record for the 1935 campaign, conquered the heavy Dartmouth eleven by the score of 13 to 7 in a dazzling battle that had a crowd of 20,000 spellbound until the final whistle.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Seniors at New Jersey College for Women who have been outstanding in their studies and in service to the college will be honored in the traditional Christmas ceremony preceding the holiday recess. Twenty-eight seniors will have places on the "senior stairs" at the ceremony Dec. 20 in the Elizabeth Rodman Voorhees Chapel, it was announced today by Dean Margaret T. Corwin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Hubbard Gold Medal, highest award of the National Geographic Society for geographic achievements, will be presented on Dec. 11 to Captain Albert W. Stevens and Captain Orvil A. Anderson, commander and pilot of the record-breaking stratosphere balloon, Explorer II, it was announced today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

ON BOARD S.S. WYATT EARP, Antarctica, Nov. 30 (By Wireless). -- Lincoln Ellsworth's supply ship is once more breaking through the waves on her way to Magallanes, where she will refuel, pick up an airplane and turn south again to lay food depots on her way to the Ross Sea.

DUBLIN, NOV. 5. DUBLIN is having quite a season of religious, or morality, drama, and reveling in it. For three weeks the Gate Theatre played Henri Gheon's "The Marriage of St. Francis" to packed houses. Artistically the production was something of sheer visual joy.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 1. -- After night-long conferences General Sung Cheh-yuan, commander of the Peiping-Tientsin area, sent two telegrams to Nanking yesterday, the first jointly addressed to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, Finance Minister H.H. Kung and War Minister Ho Ying-ching, declaring the autonomy movement in Hopei and Chahar was now beyond the local authorities' control and asking Nanking's instructions.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP). -- Washington State's Cougars came from behind to tie the favored St. Mary's Gaels, 7 to 7, in their football game today before 16,000 fans.

DUBLIN, Nov. 30. -- Since the return of the Baldwin government in Great Britain and Malcolm MacDonald's appointment to the Dominions' Office, Dublin has been full of peace rumors. On this side of the channel J.H. Thomas's removal as Dominions Secretary is regarded as definitely opening up fresh prospects of initiating negotiations with Britain with a view to quick peace.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Orange High School finished its season today with a 25-to-6 triumph over the East Side High School eleven of Newark, The East Siders ended their season, failing to win and losing ten games. Orange won seven, lost one and tied one.

PAT O'BRIEN is slightly more Irish than Paddy's well-known pig. It comes, we suspect, of being born in Milwaukee, which -- as any one knows -- is 72 per cent German and 27 per cent breweries. The 1 per cent is Irish, and, when you have a minority as small as that, it has to be a loud and enthusiastic minority if it expects to get anywhere at all.

MR. DAMON'S word, a "Chronicle," very fairly describes the character of his work. A part from some excellent set pieces on her heredity and environment, it is mainly a chronicling of Miss Lowell's activities week by week, without critical or (unless rarely ) interpretative interference.

WATER-COLORS have been commanding their full share of the public's attention since the present art season got under way. The Pennsylvania Academy's thirty-third annual is still on and will remain current in Philadelphia until Dec. 8.

A SENTEMENTALIST here and there may tip the cup on Thursday to Repeal. But most Americans, unless their memories are jogged, will hardly recall that exactly two years before, on Dec. 5, 1933, a delegate in Utah put the finishing "aye" to what had been variously described as a return to the dark ages of the swinging door and as the rebirth of prosperity, liberalism and individual liberty.

A renewal of business interest in the Federal Trade Commission and a greater willingness on the part of industry to adopt voluntary codes under the commission's rule were predicted here yesterday by association lawyers, if the proposed amendments to the Trade Commission and Clayton Acts are enacted into law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The solid front maintained by large utility holding companies against governmental efforts to compel their registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission was held virtually intact today on the eve of the deadline set by Congress for compliance with the registration provision of the 1935 Utilities Act.

THE struggle of a spontaneously romantic family against the austere and domineering head of the house is the theme of Norma Patterson's new novel. Stuart Progress as a young man had set himself the task of building up a solid fortune to provide for the physical needs of his family, a younger brother and sister, an orphaned niece and nephew.

A FAMOUS old port of South Africa will benefit by the confusion of international affairs in the Mediterranean. The Hapag Lloyd Line, which will send out the Reliance on a world cruise of 139 days, starting Jan. 9, has scheduled Mossel Bay for a call en route, having diverted the ship from the Mediterranean to the Cape of Good Hope route to avoid possible trouble.

THREE weeks from next Wednesday -- unless all signs fail -- will be Christmas Day. It should be celebrated this year with the pleased giving and receiving of the most interesting collection of new books that have appeared in a long time.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov 30. -- "This Princeton team that beat Yale today is the strongest playing combination which has worn the Orange and Black during my Yale athlettic career," said Raymond (Ducky) Pond, Yale head coach, after today's game.

HOLLYWOOD. THE once substantial army of stunt men that took all the chances for the lovely stars of both sexes is diminishing. Accidents and the increases use of process and trick shots have taken their toll.

ANOTHER bimillenary festival has come out of Italy this year. Five years ago it was Virgil whose 2,000th birthday was observed not only in Italy but all through the Western World, wherever Latin has retained more than a school-room vitality.

MADRID, Nov. 30. -- A daylight payroll robbery in which five Spanish hold-up men used machine guns in the most effective gangster manner resulted today in one death and in the Madrid Municipal Government's losing about $204,750.

When Orla V.E. Nielsen, 50-year-old cab driver of 24 Moylan Place, saw three hold-up men escaping in an automobile last March, he did not hesitate to risk his life by pursuing them, picking up a policeman and helping in their capture.

Undismayed by two unfavorable decisions in the lower courts, attorneys for drug and book-publishing interests tomorrow will carry their fight for the right to maintain resale prices on standard articles, as provided for under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, to the Court of Appeals in Albany.
MADRID, Nov. 30. -- A parliamentary commission was appointed today to investigate Spain's latest political scandal -- another of the series this country seems to be in for.

IN this latest of his long list of books Mr. Pitkin, who for a good many years has illuminated current life by way of both the printed page and his Chair of Journalism in Columbia University, endeavors to find, define and discuss what he calls "The Easy Way of Life."

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, addressing the 179th annual dinner meeting of St. Andrew's Society last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, declared the time has come for Americans to realize that the American Constitution guarantees the right of men to do they please with their earnings.

HIS first exhibition in some time reveals Ernest Lawson as still one of our very interesting colorists. In these recent landscapes at the Ferargil Galleries (till Dec. 8) the scored emphasis of line seems less prominent than in some of the older work in duller palette, and his color patterns and rhythms have gained in richness with the years.

In presenting again its annual appeal for the Neediest Cases in New York, THE TIMES is gratified to have the special endorsement of the heads of the public relief agencies in this city. They unite in testifying that the desirability and usefulness of private charity remain as great as ever.

DALLAS, Nov. 30. -- Favorable shopping weather throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District for the current week has brought out an unusually large number of early Christmas shoppers, and their buying is reflected in encouraging reports from retailers all over the district.

THE notable increase during the last few years of books dealing with the arrangement of cut flowers in the home has given convincing evidence of the growth of a new artistic interest in the American public. In his foreword Mr. Ames notes this development and thinks it due to the rapidly increasing garden clubs; but the authors see it rather as one of the results of the recent developments in art as applied to living.

JUDGING by both the internal and the external evidence, one must say that the cause of peace has never been half so well pleaded as the cause of war. Somehow or other the right argument has never been hit on in just the right way at the right time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Troops of the United States Army's "Can Do" regiment stand guard in North China over American lives and interests.

Fur items have been coming to the fore as good-selling Christmas merchandise, according to the report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Tobe, merchandising consultant and style authority. Short-hooded capes, "taxi hoods" of white lapin to be worn with long black velvet capes or wraps, already have sold extremely well, she reports.

PEIPING, Nov. 30 (AP). -- North China's unrest cropped out tonight in the Province of Shantung, where large bodies of well-armed men were pillaging eastern villages, said dispatches from Chefoo. Telegraph lines were severed and bus schedules were disrupted, said the reports, which quoted authorities as expressing the opinion the movement was political.
Interest in the development of orchestral music and its presentation leads me to address a query to you which may have been in other musicians' minds as well.

BUFFALO, Nov. 30. -- Proposed rules which would tend to curb freedom of the press by gagging attorneys and barring newspaper photographers from court rooms were assailed at a session of the Judicial Council of the State of New York today.

BUFFALO, Nov. 30. -- Rallying around Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle of the Erie County Republican organization and his six local members in the 1936 Assembly, Republican chairmen and members of the lower house from seven Western New York counties reached unanimous agreement today to wage a finish fight for adequate recognition at the legislative session convening Jan. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- To add to the troubles of shipping men here, a new waterfront labor upheaval broke out yesterday, when captains of ten tugboats and 200 bargemen walked out in a demand for increased pay and "better conditions."

FROM this vantage point of the first day, it would seem that December will be a pretty busy month in the theatre. They can't be added up until New Year's, of course, but the indications are that there will be almost as many shows as last December -- the number then being twenty-one, revivals excepted.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Summoned to Washington last August for one day to act as a consultant for the National Youth Administration, Professor George A. Graham of the Princeton University Department of Politics, was informed that although he would not receive a salary, he would be reimbursed for all the expenses of his short trip by Uncle Sam.

MANILA, Nov. 30. -- A continual recurrence of what ostensibly are the merest of trifles is serving gradually to bring to a head the vital issue of the exact position of American sovereignty toward the Philippines.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Tailless Tom, pet cat of the 102d Medical Regiment in the State armory at White Plains, mingled with the feline aristocracy of several nations today when the third annual show of the Westchester Cat Club opened at the county centre.

Joseph A. Solovei, attorney for Meyer Luckman, garage owner who was indicted by the Kings County grand jury last Tuesday for the murder of Samuel Druckman, obtained a writ of habeas corpus yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel in Brooklyn, calling for Luckman's appearance in court on Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- John Masefield, British Poet Laureate, who has had much experience on rivers and seas, wants Londoners to erect a memorial to Mark Twain on the Thames, with special reference to the American author's association with the greatest river in his own country.

NOTICES have been sent out to motorists of Pennsylvania that special license tags with initials or favorite number combinations will no longer be granted. The ruling is effective for all license plates for 1936.
The Anglo-French offer submitted to Italy last August and immediately refused by Premier Benito Mussolini, but now revived again in Paris, covered the following:
ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- The month of December was proclaimed today by Governor Lehman as the season for the annual sale of Christmas seals.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Monday, Dec. 2. -- The flying boat, China Clipper, after two days of rest and reservicing in Manila and with 1,000 pounds of the first Philippine air mail loaded aboard, set out on the return trip over the Pacific early this morning, with Guam as the first stop.

The conclusion of racing in Maryland, which also marked the end of the Eastern season, showed once more that the sport is definitely on the upturn. An estimate of receipts and expenditures last night showed that Maryland tracks enjoyed almost 10 per cent more business than in 1934, which in turn was an improvement over 1933.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 1. -- The set-up for man's first experiments with a ray fourteen times more lethal than X-rays, so powerful that approach is unsafe in any direction at less than fifty feet, is ready for work at the University of California.

A contract for the sale of two apartment houses in the Dyckman section and deals involving various other housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced over the week-end. Most of the buying was for investment purposes.
Sales of housing properties formed the bulk of realty trading reported in New Jersey over the week-end. Included in the turnover were deals for a factory in West New York and a taxpayer in Bayonne.

The centennial of the first publication of Hans Christian Andersen's Fairy Tales was celebrated yesterday morning in the studios of the National Broadcasting Company, where addresses were given by eight speakers including Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- Trading in the cotton futures market was in decidedly moderate volume last week. This was due partly to the Thanksgiving holiday and partly to expectation of the government's final crop estimate due on Dec. 8.

An overwhelming sentiment for national isolation through strict neutrality legislation and government control of the munitions industry was shown yesterday in additional returns in the nation-wide plebiscite on war and peace conducted by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Increases in personnel to man the full treaty navy at war strength were urged today in the annual report of Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of the Bureau of Navigation. In the 1935 fiscal year the navy was substantially undermanned, in officers and enlisted forces, he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The deadline for compliance with the Public Utility Act was reached at midnight tonight with the major holding company groups maintaining virtually a solid front in their fight against the act.

Offering will be made today to the public of a new issue of $1,775,000 of city of Atlanta 3 per cent bonds, issued for sewer, storm-water sewer and school purposes, by a banking group headed by the Chase National Bank. The bonds, which are to be dated Jan. 1, 1936, and will mature from Jan. 1, 1937 to 1966, inclusive, are offered at prices to yield 0.60 to 2.55 per cent, according to maturity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1. -- Complete equality of rights was demanded and all present or proposed legislation, State, national or international, discriminating against women or unequally limiting their activities was condemned at the closing session here today of the biennial conference of the National Woman's Party.

While about 15,000 spectators drowned the echo of his pistol shot, Pat O'Brien, screen star, last night started the fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden, sending fifteen hardy cyclists off on a grind that will not end until 11 o'clock next Saturday night.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Employable men and women now on relief and unemployed are the responsibility of the Federal Government, it was said here today by Governor Harold G. Hoffman in the latest exchange of telegrams with the Federal Government on its refusal to grant additional funds for direct relief.

American pacifists should band together and advocate the most common principle of the peace groups if they wish to keep the United States out of the threatened European conflict or any other war, the Rev. Leon Rosser Land, assistant pastor of the Community Church, declared yesterday at Town Hall.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1. -- Checks and pledges for $75,000 for the Rothschild Hadassah University Hospital to be built in Palestine wee given today at the final meetting of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America. The hospital, to cost nearly $700,000, will be built by Hadassah and the American Jewish Physicians Committee.

A call for books to be submitted for inclusion in the Fifty Books of the Year Exhibition for 1936 has just been sent out by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, Grand Central Palace Building. Frederic G. Melcher is chairman of the Fifty Books committee for this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Active bidding for hogs on Friday advanced prices 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight for the day, reaching the top price of $9.95, the highest since Oct. 23, and making a new high for November in eight years.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 2.--The critical stage between Japan and China will come in Nanking tomorrow when Ambassador Akira Ariyoshi has a second interview with General Chiang Kai-shek, the Central Government leader. The latest Japanese news from China indicates that the autonomy movement has been effectively frustrated for the time being, pending this interview.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- Tightness has increased in the money market, the resources of which have decreased as a consequence of payment to the Bank of France of gold withdrawn. This condition was coincident with and aggravated by the usual larger demand for the end-of-November expansion.

Nineteen large oil concerns were asked to state their policy concerning sales during the Italo-Ethiopian conflict in a letter sent to them yesterday by Henry Pratt Fairchild of the People's League for Economic Security and Professor of Sociology at New York University.

Usurers have taken advantage of the distress of many small home owners in this city, it was charged yesterday by James N. MacLean, general chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners.

With Christmas business getting off to a good start, retailers throughout the country placed last-minute orders for large quantities of gift items in the local wholesale markets last week. At the same time, the cool weather spurred the demand for fur coats, while activity in formal evening wear broadened.

So far as regards the industrial picture, last week was made up mostly of declarations, from responsible quarters, that not only is recovery genuine and emphatic, but that it will continue. On both points published declarations of the Federal Reserve, of the American Federation of Labor and of the Federal Housing Administration were in entire agreement.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Extreme ease continues to prevail in the money market here. The crisis in France and the generally disturbed international political situation is causing a steady influx of foreign capital to London. Much of this money is being turned into gold in which there have been active dealings, but a relatively moderate turnover indicating that those holding gold have no immediate intention of selling.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., Dec. 1. -- Southern Methodist University was chosen tonight as Stanford's opponent in the New Year's Day Rose Bowl football classic and the undefeated Mustangs immediately accepted the bid.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1. -- A slight further delay in the declaration of autonomy in Hopei and Chahar Provinces by General Sung Cheh-yuan, commander of the Peiping-Tientsin garrison, appeared likely as War Minister Ho Ying-ching conferred today in Tsinan with Governor Han Fu-chu and other Shantung leaders.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Two masked gunmen were beaten off in a wild gun battle early today after they had attempted to rob two Chicago merchants.

PARIS, Nov. 30. -- There are in the foreign-exchange market here some who have interpreted the premium paid to Italian citizens on gold to be sold to the State as a measure implying official currency devaluation.

The British Admiralty has called a large group of officers and engineers from the British merchant marine to report at once at Portsmouth, England, for duty in the Royal Naval Reserve, it became known here last night.

Several thousands of schoolboy football players throughout the metropolitan district will be busy this week storing away their togs, unless they are among the early birds who have already done so, for with fewer than a half-dozen exceptions the gridiron wars are over.
With time turned back 2,000 years, the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History added the Star of Bethlehem yesterday to its man-made firmament.

Members of the salt water angling fraternity will follow with unusual interest the reports that emanate this Winter from Bermuda, where a serious effort is under way to develop the island as a resort for rod-and-reel enthusiasts.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 1. -- The greatest part of the arms, munitions and war materials captured by the Italian forces in their advance on the Somaliland front were of British manufacture, it was stated today in a communique on the Somaliland operations.

Using as a text, "The way of the sinners is made plain with stories" the Rev. Dr. Willard L. Sperry, Dean of the Harvard Divinity School, in his sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, asserted: "The way of the Italian Army across Ethiopia is made plain with stones."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Republic of Haiti has filed an application on Form 18 with the Securities and Exchange Commission for permanent registration of $8,441,538 of customs and general-revenue external thirty-year sinking-fund 6 per cent gold bonds, Series A, on the New York Stock Exchange.

The three grand jury stenographers who recorded the testimony of witnesses before the reopened investigation into the murder of Sam Druckman worked all day yesterday transcribing the minutes which Governor Herbert H. Lehman has called upon District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn to submit to him.

PEIPING, Monday, Dec. 2. -North China leaders who oppose the autonomy movement were elated yesterday by reports that War Minister Ho Ying-ching would arrive here this morning with proposals from Nanking. Their elation turned to dismay when General Ho, after conferences in Tsinan, delayed coming north immediately.

THE TIMES reports that final approval of Mayor La Guardia's sponsored high school of music has been given by the Board of Education. As a cultural institution, it is to be welcomed. As an institution which is to set up high standards for the music teaching profession, every music lover in the city will applaud the Mayor for advocating such a school.

Forty-one American educators, presidents of colleges in twenty-seven States, made public a request yesterday to the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States and to the American Olympic Committee to withdraw from participation in the 1936 games in Germany.

In a setting of tropical plants, with the scent of orange blossoms in the air, the Florida Fair will be opened at 12:30 today in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. Designed to bring the tropical beauties and attractions of Florida as a resort to Winter-bound New York and to display its industrial and agricultural products, the exhibit will continue three months.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- Trailing by 14 -- 0 in the second quarter through a fumble and a pass thrown half the length of the field, the New York Giants rallied to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 21 -- 14, at Baker Bowl today. They thus clinched the right to represent the East in the play-off for the championship of the National Football League.

Some sportsmen may grumble at Commissioner OSBORNE'S proposal to increase the fees for fishing, hunting and trapping licenses in this State; but if they want better sport, that is probably the only way to obtain it. Certainly that is true of fishing. Deer are still plentiful in the woods, but trout are not, and, as Mr. OSBORNE himself has publicly admitted, the present outlook is that they will grow scarcer and scarcer.

ROME, Dec. 1. -- Italy's determination to fight sanctions was again confirmed today when Premier Benito Mussolini received at the Palazzo Venezia ninety-four committees of mothers and widows of men who lost their lives in the World War.
Frank S. Righeimer of Chicago, former intercollegiate champion while a student at Yale, led the contestants in the second of the series of pre-Olympic epee tryouts at the Fencers Club last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Eviction was threatened today for 30,000 persons on relief in this city. The Chicago Real Estate Board decreed that relief workers would be put out if they could not pay their December rent.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 1. -- The condition of Jesse Livermore Jr., 16, who was shot by his mother, Mrs. Dorothea Wendt Livermore, in a Thanksgiving Day quarrel, remained grave tonight, although he showed slight improvement.

Yvonne Georgi was welcomed back to New York after an absence of four or five seasons in the first of two recitals at the Guild Theatre last night. It was, in certain respects, a very different Georgi from the one who used to dance with Harald Kreutzberg and to seem, in contrast with him, a serious and even a solemn young woman.

Motor vehicle registration this year will aggregate approximately 26,150,000 cars, a gain of about 5 per cent over 1934, according to a compilation by the Travelers Insurance Company, based on reports from more than forty States. The company estimates that gasoline consumption this year will exceed last year's by about 6 per cent.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries, other than the Crown Willamette Paper Company and its subsidiaries, have reported for the six months ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $1,192,560 after depreciation, depletion, interest and taxes.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- Recent reports from Ethiopia have done little to illumine the situation on the two fronts beyond bringing further confirmation of the difficulties the Italians are suffering on their communications through an excess of force and a deficiency of experience, aggravated unexpectedly by bad weather.

To the Editor of The New York Times:Within two weeks of each other Mr. Roper and Mr. Tugwell made speeches. Both gentlemen have the confidence of the President, but of the two Mr. Tugwell appears to enjoy the greater degree.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP). -- The Chicago Cardinals pushed over a touchdown in the fourth period today to gain a 7-7 tie with their home-town rivals, the Bears, and cling to a slender chance of getting into the National Football League championship play-off.

Tomorrow is Dickinson Day in Kansas City. If this festival has not been formally and officially proclaimed in Missouri, that is because Missouri, following fashion, has a Democratic Governor. To Missouri Republicans of good-will, to the Republicans of Kansas City, Rome of national conventions and sitter upon seventy-seven hills, tomorrow is marked by red letters and a white stone and the presence of the senior Senator from Iowa.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 (AP). -- "Liquor is in the saddle at Washington and its apologists are riding whip and spur through all the States," Bishop W.N. Ainsworth of the Southern Methodist Church charged today, saying that an "unrestrained" program of the liquor interests was "both the indictment and peril of an administration that has done many things of genuine merit."

Further details of plans for a a series of regional conferences by the American Bankers Association designed to preserve "the public's newly recovered confidence in banks" are presented by Robert V. Fleming, president of the Riggs National Bank, Washington, and newly elected president of the association, in an article in the current issue of Banking, the association's publication.

This year will close with more genuine confidence in the outlook for the coming year than there has been at any time since the depression started, the National City Bank declares in its December bulletin, published today.

The New York Relief Society for Socialist Prisoners and Exiles in Soviet Russia, of which Mrs. Manya Gordon Strunsky is secretary, made public yesterday a letter from Russian Socialists reporting the imprisonment and exile of many Socialists in Soviet Russia, most of them without trial.

Conditions in Europe can best be described as "threatening," the Right Rev. James Maroni, Lutheran Bishop of Agder, Norway, declared yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Eva Le Gallienne, content to pay Broadway an annual visit, begins another one tonight at the Shubert Theatre. "Rosmersholm," in a new translation by herself, launches a fortnight of repertory which will go on to include "Camille" and a double-bill of comedies by the Quinteros, "A Sunny Morning" and "The Women Have Their Way."

Colder weather, with below-freezing temperatures, is forecast for today. Weather Bureau officials said last night that a cold wave moving from the West would probably hold down temperatures for the next few days.

Atheism is the direct culmination of a philosophy of life constructed to justify wrong conduct, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Although Italian affairs again are contributing to the unsettlement of the financial markets, there is no loss of confidence, which has been growing steadily in the last month. The critical French situation, similarly disturbing, is not being overrated.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 1. -- The rebel campaign, which for several months has been causing anxiety within the State of Jalisco and, indeed, the entire republic, has been quashed, according to an official War Department announcement.

The Right Rev. Peter Trimble Rowe, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Alaska, received yesterday from Bishop William T. Manning, a pectoral cross made of Alaskan gold. The presentation was made at a special service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, commemorating the fortieth anniversary of Bishop Rowe's consecration.

After a radio debate with Norman Thomas over Station WOR last nights Dr. F.E. Townsend, Californian exponent of universal old-age pensions, assailed the logic of his opponent in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker.

DETROIT, Dec. 1. -- The Detroit Lions took undisputed possession of first place in the Western Division of the National Football League today by crushing the Brooklyn Dodgers, 28 to 0. Detroit scored in every period but the first, tallying three touchdowns, three extra points, a field goal and two safeties as 12,000 looked on in freezing weather.

Tributes were paid to Bernard S. Deutsch, late President of the Board of Aldermen, at a memorial service held in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning under the joint auspices of the Free Synagogue and the American Jewish Congress. Mr. Deutsch was a former president of the congress.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- A radical $17,400,000 tax program which would relieve manufacturing and real estate by shifting part of their tax load to 200,000 additional small-wage earners, public utilities, retail stores, certain types of insurance companies and some classes of investments as well as racing promoters and games of skill and chance, was unanimously recommended by a special legislative committee whose report was made public today.

Fear that migratory game waterfowl may become extinct within a few years unless drastic steps are taken by conservation authorities was expressed yesterday by Dr. William T. Hornaday, militant protector of wild life and for thirty years, until 1926, director of the New York Zoological Park.

An investigation of the complaint of the Seas Shipping Company, Inc., operator of the Robin Line, against the member lines of the United States-South Africa Conference that conference membership has been denied it and that the conference lines have cut their freight rates to embarrass the Robin Line, will be opened this morning by the Shipping Board bureau of the Department of Commerce, at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Stret.

P. Garino and A.L. Burns each broke 99 out of 100 targets in the contest for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, Burns yielding the trophy to Garino without a shoot-off. In the handicap event, three gunners tied with full cards, Slingerland finally winning first prize, P. Sleppy the second and J. Mercadante the third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The public debt of the United States will pass the $30,000,000,000 mark for the first time in history as the result of a $1,318,000,000 Treasury financing operation, including the borrowing of $900,000,000 in cash and the refunding of $418,000,000 in maturing obligations, announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Senator Borah's name will be entered in the Presidential primaries in Illinois by a group of progressive Republicans of the old Ickes faction, unless the Idaho Senator definitely forbids such action.

Friedrich Schorr, Metropolitan Opera baritone; Ruggiero Ricci, boy violinist, and Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, appeared in joint recital at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of the Jewish National Fund. A large audience turned out for the occasion and greeted the artists with profuse applause.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,996,113,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest bearing discount bills.

Now that December is here, the Group Theatre has resumed its public activities with "Weep For the Virgins," which was put on Saturday evening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. It is Nellise Child's drama domestic life among the fish packers of the San Diego canneries, and it is about as aimless as drama has any right to be.
A tie-up of all WPA music performances in this city was scheduled yesterday for Thursday after a strike vote by the membership of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.

Frederick Hazlitt Brennan is a man of ideas. It is no journeyman enterprise that conceives the schemes of "Stick-In-the-Mud," which opened Saturday night at the Forty-eighth Street. He is not at the moment a finished playwright, however, and his saga of community life aboard the grounded Dixie Belle aches for the blue pencil.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- An attempt to enlist John D. Rockefeller Jr. in the fight being made by local residents against the construction of a PWA-financed airport here will be made by the Valhalla Community Council, it was announced today.

A united Palestine appeal, with Zionist and non-Zionist elements joining in an effort to raise $2,500,000 next year to finance the work of the Palestine Foundation Fund and the Jewish National Fund in the upbuilding of Palestine, was authorized yesterday by 1,500 persons at a national conference at the Hotel Biltmore.

It is said that if the Industrial Commissioner adopts the recommendations of his Hotel and Restaurant Wage Board, it will require an increase in labor costs for about three-fourths of the employers, and will mean wage increases for nearly 60 per cent of the 60,000 women and minor employes in hotels and restaurants in New York State.

MOUNT EPHRAIM, N.J., Dec. 1. -- A section of a grand stand collapsed here today during a football game, throwing 500 persons to the ground and injuring three seriously enough to require hospital treatment. Two others were treated at the scene and several more were bruised.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1. -- With his sire, Champion Rockefeller's Ace, as his closest rival for the top award, Elyria Easter Parade, striking entry belonging to Dr. O.M. Deems of Springfield, Mass., was named the best dog in show at the first specialty exhibition of the Newark Boston Terrier Club at the Essex House today.

ATHENS, Dec. 1. -- The Demerdzis Cabinet tonight signed an amnesty pardoning 758 rebels imprisoned following the March revolution and annulling the sentences against 400 fugitives now living in France, Italy, Turkey and Bulgaria.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 1. -- WPA will come into its own here tomorrow when it takes over the TERA burden of supplying work for the employable thousands on relief. With the shift, WPA inherits a great deal of trouble.

It is nearly a year since President ROOSEVELT insisted in a message to Congress that "the Federal Government must and shall quit this business of relief." At least, for the moment, that goal has now been achieved. On Saturday the Government made to the States the last grants they will receive so long as the present work-relief program remains in operation.

In a report of a survey made public yesterday the American Association for Social Security declared that constitutional obstacles of many kinds would make it difficult if not impossible for most States to establish unemployment insurance by complying with the chief provisions of the Federal Social Security Act.

With rubber, coffee and the metals stronger last week in the market here for commodity futures, sugar, silk and hides lost ground somewhat, with trading rising in volume at the approach of the year-end. In the cash markets, all grains declined with cotton, lard, wool tops and silk, while mess pork, cocoa, tin and rubber gained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Existing regimentation of the farmers of the United States "constitutes a definite challenge to the American form of government," the American Liberty League asserted today in an analysis of the AAA Act. Control of agriculture under the system, it charged, is a "vicious combination of fascism, socialism and communism."

The National Economy League made public yesterday an increasingly vigorous exchange of letters with Colonel Frank Knox, active candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1936, revealing the "quandary" in which the Economy League found itself when Colonel Knox declared himself two weeks ago for the immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Increased receipts of corn at primary markets, with a shading of cash premiums at times, and the weakness in wheat, led to selling by holders of December corn here last week. Several large pit operators who deemed prices too high forced a lower level, with the close at almost the bottom for December corn at 57 5/8 cents a bushel, or 2 3/8 cents under the previous week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The first contract bridge national championship tournament held here in six years by the American Bridge League will start tomorrow. More than 1,000 players will participate in the championship contests, which will accord the winners national honors.

Kenneth Lynch, the 32-year-old Long Island armorer and metal craftsman, will open his first one-man show this morning in the galleries of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street. The exhibition is made up of various work done during the last five years and it is dominated by two life-size figures of fully armored knights, holding fourteen-foot lances and sitting on armored and caparisoned horses.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 1. -President Roosevelt began the final week of his visit to the Little White House here today with every indication that he would devote himself to relaxation as much as possible in preparation for the arduous schedule which he must enter upon immediately upon returning to Washington.

The past Summer has brought to a successful conclusion two years of experimentation with social dancing at night by large groups in the city's parks. The results have been so satisfactory that the use of park buildings for indoor dancing during the Winter has been decided on.

The Little Mothers Aid Association, of which Mrs. Frank Oliver Hall is president, will be the beneficiary of a card party and Christmas sale this afternoon in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis. The association maintains a day nursery at 236 Second Avenue, where children whose mothers are employed during the day are cared for, and also a vacation home for mothers and children.

Concerning resignations, as concerning personal taste, there can be no real dispute. JEFFERSON said that few Federal officials die and none resign. But apparently Mr. GEORGE PEEK has resolved to be the great exception. Some may wonder that he did not resign before.
PEIPING, Monday, Dec. 2. -- Chinese semi-official sources said today that two Japanese advocating North China autonomy had been slain by Chinese village residents east of Tientsin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- An estimate that the number of unemployed decreased by 3,000,000 in the first two years of the Roosevelt administration was made today in a government pamphlet of statistical charts on the relief situation.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm J. MacLeod, retired pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, preaching in that church yesterday morning, declared that mankind had lost its sense of brotherhood.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The British Government does not pursue the aim of ruining Italy or inflicting a smarting defeat on Premier Benito Mussolini himself. The members of the Cabinet will meet in extraordinary session tomorrow guided by a desire to maintain a nice balance between two objectives, first, to indicate the authority of the League of Nations Covenant; second, to bring about a settlement of the Ethiopian dispute by amicable means.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Loyola University of Los Angeles defeated the University of Santa Clara, 7 to 0, today in an upset that brought lusty cheering from the 12,000 spectators. It was Loyola's first football victory over the Broncos.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, replying this afternoon to criticism of his recent attack on some of the major policies of the Roosevelt administration, declared that "it is not my purpose to destroy, but perfect the New Deal."

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--Prosperity is coming back both into the building and loan and real estate fields throughout the country, according to H.F. Cellarius, secretary-treasurer of the United States Building and Loan League, who has completed a survey covering forty-one States, the District of Columbia and Hawaii.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1. -- After being held to a scoreless tie in a first period of remarkably even play, the 1935 United States field hockey first team scored twice in the second half to defeat the reserves, 2 -- 0, today on the Laurel School Field.

A police raid on an apartment on West 159th Street, given as the address of a man captured in a frustrated jewel robbery in Westchester, resulted last night in the discovery of an arsenal of firearms and ammunition and a large quantity of assorted jewelry from which the gold had been removed.

The International Hydro-Electric System, a subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company, announced yesterday that it had relinquished voting control of its $400,000,000 New England Power Association in order to obtain exemption from the holding company provisions of the Public Utility Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- State Representative John J. Finnerty made public tonight a letter from Alfred E. Smith describing as unauthorized a movement started here to boom him for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1. -- An electric sound "camera" which automatically, and in a few seconds, makes a picture record of the quality of tones and sounds within most of the range of human hearing has been built at the Cruft Laboratory of Electric Communication Engineering, Harvard University, Dr. Harry H. Hall, instructor in physics, announced tonight.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 1. -- Turbaned priests of the Ethiopian church are telling their congregations that the Italians will not acquire any Ethiopian territory. Many are speculating whether the war will produce a "black Luther."

Lillian Lennehan, 15 years old, of Ramsey, N.J., who accidentally swallowed an open safety pin, was convalescing yesterday at Bellevue Hospital after the pin had been removed from her abdomen by an operation.

For more than forty years I have watched budget making and I have listened to promises by many candidates that if elected they would reduce the city budget. It has been done from time to time a little, but it is a difficult process. It is easy to promise and very hard to perform.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Announcement of the Treasury's December security offerings of $900,000,000 in notes and bonds, aside from a note-refunding operation, again shifts the capital's financial spotlight toward the nation's banks, the chief source of funds to meet the Federal deficit.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 56 per cent of capacity, a rise of 1 point in the week and of 2 points in two weeks. The rate was the highest of the year, passing the previous high level, set in the two weeks ended on Feb. 9.

Warning that New York is losing business to other ports because of the refusal of union workers at the piers here to handle merchandise delivered or called for by non-union truck drivers, six commercial organizations have appealed to Mayor La Guardia to intervene.

The annual sale for the benefit of the Cenacle of St. Regis will be held tomorrow in the ballroom of the Plaza. A variety of useful and decorative articles suitable for Christmas gifts will be offered for sale. Luncheon and tea will be served. The funds raised will further the many charitable activities of the Cenacle of St. Regis at 628 West 140th Street.
ROME, Dec. 1 -- The text of Premier Benito Mussolini's speech today to World War widows and Gold Star mothers follows:
ROME, Nov. 29. -- The market for stocks and State securities here shows no change.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- For the month ended on Nov. 19, The Bankers Magazine reports an appreciation of 233,500,000 in the market value of 365 representative securities which, following a smaller rise in the month before, virtually wipes out the heavy loss of the two previous months.

" A national preaching mission" will be conducted by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, it was announced yesterday at the council's headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street. This will be the first time the council has carried on such a campaign.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 1. -- A detective and two Negroes were shot here this afternoon in a pistol battle which followed two early morning hold-ups during one of which a third Negro was shot.

The new production which was mounted at the Second Avenue Theatre on Saturday night is virtually a one-man show. That is not to say that the house has dispensed with its usual company, chorines and orchestra, but that it has presented young Leo Fuchs, a newcomer from abroad, and Mr. Fuchs is every inch a one-man show.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 1.--After five hours of thrilling play tonight in the twenty-fifth game of the series for the world chess championship, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the challenger, held a slight advantage over Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, the titleholder.

Delegates from Eastern and Southern college newspapers, attending the final session yesterday of the National Student Federation's conference on problems of the college press, voted against the United States taking part in the 1936 Olympics if the game are held in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- While announcement was being awaited today from Warm Springs, Ga., of the President's reluctant acceptance of the resignation of George N. Peek as head of the Export-Import Bank, friends of the farm leader were attributing to him a determined effort to influence the course of the administration's foreign trade policy through the medium of the National Democratic Convention and the platform pledges it may adopt.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Grain traders throughout the world seem to be viewing the markets with unusual indifference. This was the situation last week particularly, and it is the belief of many that there is no prospect of a radical change for the better in the near future.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Traders in provisions here say that while there is fair new buying of lard futures coming into the market prices did not follow the sharp advance in hogs last week, thus disappointing the speculative interest. The price of lard was influenced by the fluctuations in corn, cottonseed oil and cotton. Sentiment, however, remains fairly bullish.
The Hundred Neediest Cases Fund started its twenty-fourth year yesterday with seventy-two contributions, totaling $4,165.74.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- Boston's sadly battered Redskins completed their national pro league home season today by making a brilliant fourth-period rally to score a 13-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates and end an 8-game losing streak.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Woodrow Wilson Stromberg, who played right end against Navy yesterday, was elected captain of the Army football team for 1936 while the players were journeying back to West Point by special train today.

The decision of steel makers not to raise prices for the first quarter of next year has caused a relaxation of the pressure for delivery of finished steel before the beginning of the year, according to the weekly summary by the magazine Steel. Nevertheless, steel operations last week were increased 1 1/2 points, and at 56 per cent of capacity were the highest of the year to date, the magazine said.

BERLIN, Dec. 1.--The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, the most widely known of the independent Protestant pastors, publicly charged the government today with aiding and abetting the introduction of heresy into the teachings of the German Protestant church.

In the night of Nov. 23 the dispatch from Asmara mentioned the Ethiopians' old guns as French Etiennes of the Eighteen Seventies and French Legrasses of an earlier period. Also in the "Valley Inferno March" Herbert L. Matthews's very interesting article was marred by the statement that the "Walde Gabriel band is armed with French Legras rifles used in the war of 1870."
CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The range of grain prices here last week with the closings, compared with those of the previous week, was as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- A census of business in 1935, intended to provide an up-to-date chart of the entire economic structure of the nation, has been started as a $7,784,000 work-relief project.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Two sweeps were registered in the New Jersey group of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League today.

The names of ten police officers, selected by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine for promotion to higher ranks at exercises to be held in the presence of Mayor F.H. La Guardia at City Hall at 10 A.M. today, were made public yesterday at headquarters.

Public charges in the city's voluntary hospitals have increased 109.7 per cent during the last five years, according to results of a study made public yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the United Hospital campaign to raise at least $2,000,000 for the work of those institutions among the sick poor.

Including exhibitions opening over the week-end, forty new attractions await the visitor to art galleries this week. They are scarcely less numerous than varied -- old masters and work about and primarily for children; water-colors, pastels, ceramics, textile designs, murals and armor and thumb-box sketches are all to be found on the calendar.

PARIS, Dec. 1.--The next three weeks admittedly are going to be a difficult time for Europe, yet the best opinion is that--always barring an "incident," which might upset the applecart--Europe will come through them unscathed and at peace.

In the night of Nov. 23 the dispatch from Asmara mentioned the Ethiopians' old guns as French Etiennes of the Eighteen Seventies and French Legrasses of an earlier period. Also in the "Valley Inferno March" Herbert L. Matthews's very interesting article was marred by the statement that the "Walde Gabriel band is armed with French Legras rifles used in the war of 1870."
CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The range of grain prices here last week with the closings, compared with those of the previous week, was as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP). -- A census of business in 1935, intended to provide an up-to-date chart of the entire economic structure of the nation, has been started as a $7,784,000 work-relief project.
This annual appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund is a cry for help from those most sorely distressed in all the city.

The recent passing of Judge Charles B. Wheeler of Buffalo removes from the roll of distinguished citizens of the State of New York one of the most brilliant lawyers and versatile scholars of the period covered by his record.

Arthur Loesser concluded his series of three historical concerts with a recital devoted to twentieth century piano music which brought a large audience to the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The gifted artist failed to reach the heights scaled at the second recital of the series, but, as always, played with keen understanding, accuracy and admirable grasp of the task in hand.

Trading in the cotton futures market last week was of moderate proportions and fluctuations stayed within a narrow range. At the close on Saturday quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were only 5 to 17 points lower on the week.

The Rev. Cornelius J. Drew of the New York Apostolate Fathers, a band of mission preachers of the archdiocese, preached the Advent sermon yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. His topic was the "Justice of Judgment."

CALDWELL, N.J., Dec. 1. -- A fast low-winged, long-range monoplane is being prepared here for a possible flight over Antarctica to search for Lincoln Ellsworth. The machine, an all-metal Northrup monoplane similar in type and performance to the plane in which Ellsworth was exploring the South Polar region, was flown here yesterday from Roosevelt Field by Russell W. Thaw, in whose name it is registered.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 1. -- The Canadian Government in a statement issued tonight by the Minister of Justice, E.A. Lapointe, disowned responsibility for having initiated the proposal to add oil to the list of products, the export of which to Italy has been embargoed by the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Most processors have not absorbed the taxes laid upon them by the AAA to finance benefits to farmers, but in the main have passed them on to the consumer, or farmers have received a lower price for their produce than if there had been no tax, the annual report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics asserted today.
Fifty-seven assorted cyclists pedaled down Fifth Avenue in the sleet yesterday in the preliminary to the first 200-yard bike sprints ever held in Fifty-sixth Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

JIJIGA, Ethiopian Field Headquarters, Dec. 1. -- Although gratified by the retirement of the Italians from the Fafan River Valley, Ethiopian leaders are aware that the whole Southern Italian campaign is possibly a feint to draw the Ethiopians away while the Italians concentrate for a more serious effort in the North.
BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- Non-Nazi theologians viewed apprehensively today the declaration of a Hitlerite student leader that the Christian, Marxist and Nazi philosophies are involved in a death struggle.

Signor MARCONI has again been refused permission to speak over the British radio in defense of his country's Ethiopian adventure. Perhaps it is not too frivolous to suggest that there is something rather delightful in MARCONI being excluded from the wireless waves.

A near-record performance by Miss Erna Kompa and the discovery of a possible Olympic freestyle prospect in Miss Toni Redfern, 16-year-old novice, were features of the women's open A.A.U. handicap swimming carnival in the 75-foot pool of the Women's Swimming Association yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- Financial interest here this week was concentrated on the activity in the market for dollar bonds of the so-called certificated class, for which proof of German ownership is required before a specified date.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The texts of the Treasury's new offerings of 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 1/2 per cent notes, made public today, were as follows:
