While the old guard of the Socialist party in this State and city was pushing its plans yesterday for purging the party of Communist and pro-Communist elements, Louis Waldman, State chairman, issued a statement demanding the resignation of Leo Krzycki of Milwaukee as National Chairman of the party for participating in last week's demonstration in Madison Square Garden for a united front between Socialists and Communists.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1. -- George S. Kemp and associates controlling the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation were challenged today by senior shareholders seeking their overthrow and the restoration of the former management, to seek proxies for the special meeting of stockholders here on Dec. 17, provided these proxies are voted and not withheld to prevent a legal quorum.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The Boston Bruins broke a three-game losing streak by inflicting a 2-0 shutout on the New York Rangers in a fast and exciting hockey clash before 10,000 tonight at the Boston Garden. It was the first Sunday National League affair in Boston's history.

A new free art school for underprivileged students has been established here under the Federal art project of the Works Progress Administration, according to announcement by Mrs. Frances Pollock, district supervisor of art teaching under the WPA.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan readvertised for bids yesterday for the construction of the link of the West Side Elevated Highway from Forty-sixth to Fifty-ninth Streets. The advertisement calls for bids based on the use of foreign steel and cement as well as domestic steel and cement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- "The patient is very restless in his isolation ward," remarked this column, Nov. 18, of George N. Peek. Next day the patient broke out and went to the White House to tell the President some fretful things he had heard among the farmers during the Summer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- If any American League club obtains Jimmy Foxx, the Athletics' hard-hitting first baseman, by trade or purchase this year, as has been mentioned in various player deals, his contract will have to be revised, with the salary sent sharply upward.

For the first time since 1918, New York is about to see Alia Nazimova in an Ibsen play. On Thursday night of next week she will begin a limited engagement in "Ghosts" at the Empire Theatre, under the management of Luther Greene, with McKay Morris, Harry Ellerbe and Ona Munson in her supporting cast.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2. -Spear in hand, George Vanderbilt, honeymooning American, went out on a reef at the height of a tropical tornado and speared crabs for food for his bride and himself when they were marooned recently on uninhabited Lady Musgrave Island, many miles off the Queensland coast.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, Dec. 2. -- Persons who have arrived here from Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland, by airplane say the attitude of the Italian Somali troops appears to be giving the high command more concern than the recent movements of Ras Desta Demut's Ethiopian flanking force.

Mayor La Guardia let it be known yesterday that he would intervene in the threatened strike of 700 musicians employed on music and dance projects of the WPA. The strike, scheduled for Thursday, has been ordered by the Musicians Union in protest against working conditions affecting the rate of pay promulgated by Nikolai Sokoloff, director of the Federal music project in Washington.

A startled horse slightly injured eight persons early yesterday afternoon when the wagon it was drawing was side-wiped by a United States Mail truck. The animal reared and wheeled in the stream of pedestrians crossing Thirty-ninth Street at Seventh Avenue.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec.2. -- A resentful conviction that Dr. Walter A. Riddell had allowed Great Britain's Geneva representatives to use him to pull Britain's chestnuts out of the fire is understood to have inspired the action of the Canadian Government yesterday in repudiating initiative for the oil embargo against Italy, which Dr. Riddell had proposed.

Three men in ten-gallon hats paused yesterday afternoon under the three gilt globes that identify the establishment of Weisenberger Son at 781 Eighth Avenue, gazed at the assortment of musical instruments, jewels and nickel-plated revolvers, and then walked in and announced that they had some diamond teeth to offer as security for a loan.

The 1936 budget was adopted yesterday by the Board of Aldermen at a total of $545,541,842.56 after the Democratic majority on the Finance Committee had criticized the La Guardia administration for failing to keep its campaign pledge to cut the budget by at least $50,000,000.

JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Dec. 2. -- Important Ethiopian advances through Italian Somaliland are reported here by sources that are considered reliable, although they are not officially confirmed. Two forces are said to have placed themselves in a position to cut off the army under General Rodolfo Graziani, which has been operating in Ogaden.

MUSSOLINI'S threat of war against sanctions as should bring one interesting development. There is a certain Power, which all the nations are in the habit of describing as superior to themselves, and that Power seems to be lined up against MUSSOLINI in Ethiopia.

A demand that birth-control information be provided for mothers of families on relief was made last night by more than 2,500 persons at a meeting in Carnegie Hail under the auspices of the American Birth Control League. It was the league's first public meeting in New York City since 1928.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- With increased knowledge, man could go on increasing his life span indefinitely, until he reached the great age, sometimes discussed by scientists, at which he would be "all scars from an accumulation of accidents," Dr. William Marias Malisoff, editor of Philosophy of Science, said tonight in an address at Rutgers University.

Sixteen nations have been formally notified by MUSSOLINI that if they declare an oil embargo against Italy he will regard it as an "unfriendly act." This is a phrase of the old diplomacy, usually tantamount to a threat of war. One Government did not use it in communicating with another unless it was prepared to back up its resentment by force of arms.

New York of the past and present, from its parades and toys to its gala ball gowns and military costumes, is evoked by four special exhibitions and two new permanent ones which the Museum of the City of New York will open to the public tomorrow.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Eighty-six persons were indicted by the Saratoga County grand jury today in the Attorney General's investigation of race track tipster racketeering. The indictments were handed up in twenty-five sealed presentments.

The Kings County grand jury which indicted four suspects in the murder of Sam Druckman and was continued in office to pursue its inquiry further into charges of bungling in the investigation and prosecution of the case suspended its activity yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- Although no formal resolution was adopted on the subject in a session here today, the Republican State Central and Executive Committees indicated that they are opposed to the renomination of former President Hoover.

The New York State Banking Department announced yesterday its annual list of bonds legal for investment by savings banks and trust funds in this State. A total of 117 issues has been removed from the list, including the obligations of eighteen municipalities, forty-four railroads and fifty-five public utilities, many of the latter because of retirements.

The cost of work relief in this city, dispensed by the Federal government under the WPA, will be $5,515,000 a week when the army of WPA employes reaches the total of 242,000 within a few days, it was disclosed yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, in a report presenting a detailed account of the situation.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 2. -President Roosevelt made today his first inspection of a resettlement project, hailing it as "a dream coming true," and urging in an impromptu speech that counties throughout the United States carry on this work beyond the point where Federal expenditures must cease.

Fight fans who expect Joe Louis to have a walkaway when he battles Pauline Uzcudun in Madison Square Garden Dec. 13 for The New York American's Christmas Fund are in for a surprise, according to Lou Brix, who is directing the Basque's fistic affairs.
ROME, Dec. 2. -- Italy has begun to feel the pressure of League of Nations economic sanctions, business leaders said tonight, and is faced with solving unemployment and credit problems.

The mailbag these days bulges with missives from doleful duck hunters. Expressions of opinion range from demands for a closed season to bitter denunciation of the current restrictions. Here are a few excerpts:
A survey to determine the extent to which radio might aid in the education of city school children was undertaken yesterday by the Board of Education.

In the face of a clash with the National Economy League on payment of the soldiers' bonus, Colonel Frank Knox, prominently mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for President, reaffirmed his position for payment last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mickey Walker's comeback campaign met with a sharp setback last night at the St. Nicholas Palace. The former middleweight and welterweight champion of the world was knocked out by Eric Seelig, German battler, in the seventh round of a scheduled 10-round bout.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2. -Complimenting their house guest, Joseph J. Cavanagh of Chicago, Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Hayes gave a dinner tonight at Charmae followed by contract.

In anticipation of an early announcement of cotton acreage plans for 1936, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and ended with gains of 4 to 7 points. The plans were made known late in the day in Washington.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs since last February failed today to have any material effect on the market and prices were generally about steady as compared with Friday's levels. Most of the offerings consisted of 190 to 230 pound averages with the spread between the top and the average price of 10 cents the smallest on record with one exception.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Controller General McCarl released funds today to the New York State WPA with which the administrator, Lester W. Herzog, will be permitted to start work on projects selected from an approved list totaling $27,101,740.

Harris Eckstein, a wholesale and retail dry-goods merchant whose store is at 68 Orchard Street, was robbed of more than $7,500 late yesterday afternoon by two youths who knocked him down on the sidewalk of Grand Street, near Eldridge Street, and fled with the package containing checks and cash.

Use of WPA funds for razing of the old Consumers Brewery at Sutton Place and East Fifty-fourth Street and for other demolition work such as has been carried out under the sponsorship of the New York City Housing Authority was criticized yesterday by the Albert A. Volk Company, building wreckers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The Prince of Wales won the first prize in the breeding short-horn division at the International Livestock Exposition today with his 2-year-old bull Bapton Orator, so called because of his resounding bellow. Cruggleton Wellington, shown by Imperial Oil, Ltd., of Toronto, won second award and Milky Way Prince, shown by Milky Way Farm, Pulaski, Tenn., the third.
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The Japanese delegation, twenty-nine strong, arrived in London today for the Naval Conference after a tiring journey cross Siberia.

Created by students in high schools here, a group of prize-winning prints entered in a contest sponsored by the International Silk Guild, which have been reproduced in silk fabrics for Spring by manufacturers, features an exhibit of designs opened yesterday in the exhibition gallery at Rockefeller Center.

Errors of fact considerably spoil the validity of the strong opinions against school consolidation in the letter of F.H. Selden in THE TIMES of Nov. 29. An outstanding item is the statement that "centralization has been tried and practically abandoned by some States." There is not even one case in point which could be cited.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Total assets of the Bank of Montreal amount to $792,800,000, compared with $759,100,000 a year ago, Jackson Dodds, joint general manager, announced today at the bank's 118th annual meeting. W.A. Bog is associate general manager.

The mad riding in the fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden claimed four cyclists as victims last night when the grind spun past its first twenty-four hours. Thrills were crowded one upon another as the sizzling pace continued to the cheering of 10,000 spectators.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 2. -Printers' ink has yet to touch the pasteboard that will be Rose Bowl football tickets, but the opinion prevailed today that Stanford and Southern Methodist will play to a capacity audience of 89,000 New Year's afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today exemption from registration to the Richmond and the Wheeling Stock Exchanges, subject, however, to the condition that they come under the anti-manipulative provisions of the Securities Exchange Act and certain rules promulgated by the commission to insure fair dealing and afford adequate protection to investors.
PEIPING, Tuesday, Dec. 3. -- Speculation is widespread in North China regarding War Minister Ho Ying-ching's plans for curbing the autonomy movement.
Money market was quiet, with demand limited to routine requirements. Quotations were unchanged for all classifications.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 2 (AP). -- Countess Marie-Anne von Wurmbrand-Stuppach, the former Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., was married secretly a fortnight ago to her childhood sweetheart, Count Paul Palffy, officials disclosed today.
THE HAGUE, Dec. 2. -- Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, challenger, today defeated Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, the titleholder, in the twenty-fifth game of their series for the world chess championship.

Four young men entered the office of Dr. Alex Paigen, dentist, at 58 West Seventy-second Street, at Columbus Avenue, shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday, read magazines until a patient left, then held up the dentist and his assistant, binding them to chairs with twine and escaping with $195.

ROME, Dec. 2. -- As the second crisis is followed by a second breathing spell -- supposing that this uneasy delay in applying further sanctions can be described as a breathing spell -- one fact standing out in clear relief is that the policy of the United States is recognized on both sides of the Alps as a factor of decisive importance in the European situation.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, OVER THE PACIFIC, Tuesday, Dec. 3. -- Leaving Guam behind, the China Clipper is rapidly eating up the miles on the second leg of the homeward journey from Manila. We left the waters of Apra Harbor at 20:11 Greenwich mean time [3:11 P.M., Monday in New York] for Wake Island, which we are scheduled to reach in thirteen and a half hours.

New York University dedicateo the Elmer Ellsworth Brown House for English Studies on the Univer sity Heights campus yesterday anc presented the honorary degree o] Doctor of Laws to Sir James Colquhoun Irvine, principal and vice chancellor of the University of St. Andrews, Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The purchase for $5,000 of a servicing corporation which had on its books assets approximating $190,000, in addition to an expectancy of fees estimated to exceed $500,000, all of it paid by, or to be paid by, the "all-Straus" bondholders' protective committees, was the high spot in today's investigation of the affairs of S.W. Straus. Co. by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2. -Lawrence Morgan Kelley of Williamsport, Pa., tonight was elected captain of the Yale football team for the 1936 season. According to Eli tradition, the choice was announced as unanimous.
The bashful courtroom demeanor of the woman president of a glove union local provoked Supreme Court Justice Wenzel in Brooklyn yesterday to some observations from the bench.

An archaeologist is supposed to be a savant who digs up relics of the past, deciphers inscriptions and delivers learned discourses on the rise and fall of vanished peoples. To the late Professor JAMES H. BREASTED an intimate acquaintance with ancient folkways, acquired by patient excavation and study, was of little use unless it could be applied to contemporary life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- As a step to make the most effective social use of the nation's scientific services, creation of a permanent and politically untrammeled science advisory board was recommended to President Roosevelt today by the Temporary Science Advisory Board in the report of its chairman, Dr. Karl T. Compton.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on Dec. 11, for a new issue of $3,555,000 of refunding bonds of the Orleans Levy District, La. The bonds will be dated Jan. 1, 1936, and mature serially on Jan. 1, 1946 to 1975. Bidders are asked to name an interest rate not exceeding 5 per cent.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The Soviet Academy of Sciences announced tonight it had discovered definite signs that the earth's pulling power -- gravity -- was undergoing alterations.

Defense motions for dismissal of an indictment accusing three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company of publishing a false statement on its financial condition in 1933 were denied, with two exceptions, yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi at the resumption of their four-week trial.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Swastika flags fluttered from the windows of the chartered air liner that brought a German football team to Croydon Airfield today for Wednesday's match with an English team. The German players, whose average age is between 22 and 23 years, came in one plane and their friends and officials came in two others.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 2 (AP). -Four stars from Southern Methodist, four from Texas Christian and three from Rice were selected today by sports writers and coaches for the 1935 Associated Press All-Southwest Conference football team. The three teams that contributed paced the championship race and easily offered the greatest array of outstanding players.

The first in the series of Musical Morning for this season, which were organized four decades ago by Albert Morris Bagby, took place yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the three hundred and eighty-first Musical Morning in the series.

Several hundred officers of national trade associations and State manufacturers' associations retired behind closed doors at the Hotel Commodore yesterday to decide whether their opposition to the government conference of industry and labor, opening in Washington next Monday, should be made more emphatic by refusing to attend at all.

David V., the young rabbi of Case 7; Dorothy G. of Case 2, who asks only for "a chance of happiness," and others of the Neediest whose mute appeals for help were printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday were among those aided yesterday by the ninety-five contributions received in the first day's mail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- President Roosevelt proclaimed today the reciprocal trade agreements with Canada and Brazil, to become effective on Jan. 1, in whole or in part.
Princeton, as the East's only unbeaten and untied contender for championship football honors this year, monopolizes The Associated Press all-Eastern selections, compiled yesterday.

As a somewhat recent student in New York high schools, I have followed with no little interest the attacks of Mayor La Guardia upon the custodial system used in the city's schools. On Nov. 21 there appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES a summary of an article from the current issue of the Public Education Association's bulletin.

Two youths, inmates of the death house at Sing Sing, under sentence to die soon in the electric chair in the slaying of Patrolman James M.J. Killion last Jan. 18 in a luggage shop hold-up at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, testified as State witnesses yesterday in the General Sessions trial of 63-year-old Nelson B. Clark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- A challenge to President Roosevelt to reveal the names of the bankers who, the President said in his Atlanta speech, had told him that the national debt could be expanded to between $55,000,000,000 and $70,000,000,000, was issued tonight by Representative Hamilton Fish of New York.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP). -- More than 2,000 employes of the Jewel Tea Company in eighty-three cities of forty-three States will participate in a $150,000 bonus voted today by the directors.

AT his worst, and it must be admitted that he occasionally puts his worst foot foremost, Alexander Woollcott is something of an intellectual crooner, bearing about the same relationship to literary criticism that Rudy Vallee or Kate Smith bears to music. At his best, he is an invaluable connoisseur of minor key perfection -- which is the sort of perfection whose existence many people of supposed catholic tastes are constantly forgetting.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- After spending ten days of imprisonment in a railroad refrigerator car, Glenn Boldan, a Minnesota farm boy of 14, was rescued today in Baltimore and taken to a hospital, where his condition is described as critical. His feet were frozen and his hands frost-bitten.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press). -- While the fight for individual honors in the National Hockey League scoring race centred around the first lines of the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks, the weekly statistics issued tonight by President Frank Calder showed the International group of the league outscoring the American section by almost two to one.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 2. -- As Jesse L. Livermore Jr., 16-year-old son of the widely known market operator, continued to battle for life at Cottage Hospital against incipient pneumonia and shock, his mother, Mrs. Dorothea Livermore Longcope, was arraigned today in the justice court of Ernest Wagner on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon with intent to commit murder.

Virtually no change from 1934 in the regulations governing the valuation of securities held by life insurance companies for their year-end statements will be made this year, it was announced yesterday. The decision was reached at an executive meeting of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

Bradley Lewis of the Salem Crescent A.C. knocked out Don Stevens of Rochester in the first round of the featured intercity special bout at the bi-monthly amateur boxing carnival of the New York Athletic Club last night. After two minutes and fifty-four seconds of even battling, Lewis floored his opponent for the count with a right to the jaw.

WESTWOOD, N. J., Dec. 2.--Eyes bulged today when proceedings in Common Pleas Court disclosed that Ellen J. Ackerman, mysterious little old woman in black bombazine, had left more than $200,000 in and around her weather-beaten house at 70 Elm Street when she died there on the night of Nov. 21.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- Germany's struggle between the totalitarian State and the Protestant Church took a dramatic turn today when Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, undertook to paralyze the opposition to his regime. He decreed the suppression of all groups that in the future attempt to interfere with State control of the Protestant Church through the new government-appointed church directorates.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 2 (AP). -Jeers from Midwestern college professors greeted today's Cambridge dictum about accent.

Samuel Spiers, driver of a United States Mail truck in Queens, reported to police of the Newtown precinct that he had been held up by two men at about 10 o'clock last night. The two escaped with a pouch from the truck, but no value could be placed upon their loot, the police said.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook reserved decision yesterday on the application by Mayor La Guardia to dismiss the $50,000 slander suit brought against him by Charles Shankroff, real estate broker of 771 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, after hearing a lively discussion by the attorneys as to the legal meaning of the word "bum."

Florence Vickland, soprano, who made her debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall under the auspices of the Naumburg Foundation, has a fresh voice, distinguished by its color and emotional capacity. Her equipment is uneven, and her vocal methods still in need of development.

A period of prosperity is assured over the coming two years, Roger W. Babson, economist, told members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., in the course of a speech yesterday before the group's regular luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 2 (AP). -Ethiopia will soon hurl an army of 400,000 warriors against Italians entrenched in the north, it was indicated today. Unofficial reports said the first major offensive might take place at dawn tomorrow, the monthly day of the patron St. George.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -Five thousand enthusiastic undergraduates and townspeople paid tribute tonight to Princeton's undefeated and untied football team, the second champion eleven in three years, with the traditional victory bonfire on the green behind historic Nassau Hall.
Additional accounting details of funds received from the President's Birthday Ball last January were made public yesterday by Carl Byoir, general director of the national committee.

Yielding to the persistent pleas of her grandmother, Miss Natalie E. Carr, 21 years old, member of an old New York family and recently a novice in the convent of the Sisters of the Presentation of Mary at St. Hyacinth, Que., has left the cloister temporarily and will re-enter college.
HARTFORD, Dec. 2. -- Connecticut, normally a Republican State and one of the six that gave their vote to President Hoover in 1932, seems virtually certain to remain in the Republican column in 1936.

Excellent retail trade yesterday and at the week-end confirmed previous appraisals by retail executives here of the early trend in Christmas shopping. They noted an active demand for better merchandise, a rise in the size of the average sales check and a better ratio of sales to store attendance, in comparison with the conditions last year at this time.

A $20,000,000 investment by the Southern Pacific Company in the control of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway appeared yesterday to be in jeopardy because it seemed certain that the latter company would be unable to meet interest payments due on Jan. 1.

Mail fraud involving the sale of stock of a corporation that purchased gold mine properties from Robert L. Owen, former Senator from Oklahoma, who was co-author of the Federal Reserve Act, was charged yesterday in an indictment against nine individuals and two companies handed up to Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The British Cabinet held its regular eve of Parliament session today to put the finishing touches on the King's address, to be delivered in the House of Lords and the House of Commons tomorrow by the Lord Chancellor.
ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The State Works Progress Administration plans to continue hiring workers even if the quota of 134,400 jobs is reached, Lester W. Herzog, administrator, said today.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Closing of some of New Jersey's normal schools may be recommended to the 1936 Legislature by the budget advisory committee, which is seeking to make funds available for emergency relief.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- Two cases involving decisions denying the validity of the State Fair Trade Practice Act, enacted by the 1935 Legislature to curb price-cutting on nationally advertised merchandise, were argued today in the Court of Appeals.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- On the basis of reports from all parts of the country, presented in executive session to the biennial conference held here by the National Woman's Party, early adoption by Congress of the Equal Rights Amendment was confidently predicted today by Mrs. Harvey W. Wiley, vice chairman.

The thirteenth annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind, held under the auspices of the New York State Commission for the Blind in cooperation with churches and clubs of New York City, opened yesterday at 475 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-first Street.
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Settlement of Dr. Ernst F.S. Hanfstaengl's libel action against The Daily Express was announced before Justice Swift and a jury in King's Bench Court today.

As '36 nears what are our Republican friends doing to make it auspicious to their cause? Are they smoothing differences, composing quarrels, broadening friendships, breathing harmony? No, they're in their killing clothes. Their knives are out. Young Republicans mass in mutiny against the Old Guard.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2. -- A Middle Western accent is scientifically little different from the noise made by a vacuum cleaner, a Harvard physics instructor stated today.

A relaxing of tension from the French political situation found ready reflection yesterday in the foreign exchange market here and gold-bloc currencies rallied. The franc rose 3/8 point to 6.59 1/8 cents, or above the gold-export point, and only $5,854,000 of gold was engaged in Paris for shipment to this country.

The common stock of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., of no-par value, was admitted yesterday to the list by the New York Stock Exchange and was removed from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange at the same time. The Curb also suspended dealings in the common and preferred stocks of the Holly Sugar Corporation, also admitted to the Stock Exchange, and in the 5 per cent bonds of Southern California Edison Company, Ltd.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 3. -- Further straining of Chino-Japanese relations became evident today as the Japanese displayed their asperity over the new delay in the North China autonomy program. One indication of Japanese anger was Ambassador Akira Ariyoshi's postponement, this time indefinitely, of his projected conference at Nanking with General Chiang Kaishek, leader of the National Government.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- Under the glow of century-old gold candelabra, eighty debutantes, including a score or more from New York, Philadelphia, New England, Washington and the South, were formally presented to society tonight at the first Monday German of the Bachelors Cotillion at the Lyric.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Most futures were slightly lower in quiet trading on the local commodity markets yesterday, Coffee was firm. On the cash markets cotton and tin advanced, while declines occurred in all the grains, hides and lard.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 net sales of $121,670,572, an increase of 22 per cent over the preceding fiscal year. The net profit was $5,649,146 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges.

Judge John C. Knox, senior jurist of the United States District Court, where calendars are clogged with bankruptcy cases, suffered a fracture of the collar bone early yesterday in his home at 430 West 110th Street, but he went to his chambers in the Woolworth Building at the usual hour and worked all day there and in court.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- With Albany's home relief case load absorbed 100 per cent by WPA today, Mayor John Boyd Thacher declared that he was very much disturbed by the mounting number of applications for home relief. The Mayor was unable to say whether the WPA would serve to reduce the city's relief expenditures next year when he observed the unexplained rise in the applications for relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The letters FERA were officially removed today from the New Deal recovery alphabet, coincident with an announcement that the Federal Emergency Relief Administration which they designate had spent $3,041,647,691 since May, 1933.

In the annual report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr. A.G. BLACK, the bureau's chief, presents the results of studies made of the effects of processing taxes, particularly in relation to wheat, cotton and hogs. "Briefly, the findings are that proces "sors in general have not absorbed the "taxes, but that they have been passed "on to the consumer or have tended to "lower prices to farmers."

WEST ORAiGE, N. J., Dec. 2.-The appreciation of Japan for the benefits given to mankind by the late Thomas Alva Edison was manifested here today when two stone memorial lanterns were presented to the inventor's family by Renzo Sawada, Consul General for Japan in the United States.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2. -- The nation's Drys today started a campaign of song against "Demon Rum."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Yale and Syracuse will compete against Massachusetts Institute of Technology crews in a new intercollegiate Henley regatta on Lake Quinsigamond, Worcester, on April 25, the Technology Athletic Association announced tonight.

An investigation of charges that the United States-South African Freight Conference had cut freight rates deliberately to injure the Robin Line after having refused to accept the latter as a conference member was started yesterday morning by the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

Liam O'Flaherty, from whose book the motion picture, "The Informer," was made, has written a novel which is construed in England, where it has been published, as a violent attack on persons in Hollywood and their methods. The title is "Hollywood Cemetery."
Recognition of the part Will Rogers played in the development of lay interest in aviation is being reflected in donations to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund from professional aviation organizations.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The visible and invisible "Verboten" sign's that have always loomed large in Germany are further extended by new directions issued to the German police for maintaining law and order. These directions, published in the official police periodical, are based on court verdicts.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2. -- Woodlander, 6-to-5 favorite, carried top weight of 116 pounds and the colors of Boots Hernandez of New Orleans to victory in the Audubon Handicap, mile and seventy-yard race, which topped the Fair Grounds program today.

Two purchases by Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty brokerage firm bearing his name, were among the investment deals reported yesterday. From Frederick Brown, operator, Mr. Noyes acquired a three-story building at 406 Eighth Avenue, fifty feet north of Thirtieth Street.

The reckless driver will probably not be deterred from traveling at excessively high speeds by news that it will involve him in considerably higher gasoline bills. Still, the figures are interesting. Quoted in Sunday's TIMES, they come from the United States Bureau of Standards, which is accustomed to speak with authority on such matters.

Preferred and common stocks of the public utility holding companies in general were easier on the local securities markets yesterday, due to a widespread belief that it may be many months before the issue raised in threescore suits against the Public Utility Act's provisions is settled, and that, meanwhile, the utilities may be hampered in a number of their essential programs.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- The Cornell Daily Sun today asserted editorially of Cornell's sport program that "among the several immediate problems that must be solved in the very near future is the question of the coaching personnel for football."

With buyer attendance described as the largest on record, price advances averaging 15 per cent were announced by shoe manufacturers at the Spring opening being held at the Hotel New Yorker under the auspices of the National Volume Shoe Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Disclosure today of a three months' delay by President Roosevelt in appointing the three public members of the commission to investigate facts pertinent to an adequate railroad pension system revealed apprehension in Congressional circles lest the delay bar the possibility of further legislation to perfect the Retirement Act at the forthcoming session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Further gains in business were reported today by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and the heads of three of the country's important railroads, the Southern, the Union Pacific and the Northern Pacific.

Mrs. Allan M. Pope gave a luncheon at the Mascotte yesterday for Mrs. Frederick H. Cone, Mrs. William P. Palmer, Mrs. Ernest Harrah, Mrs. William B. Belden and Mrs. Gustavus T. Kirby. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. Sosthenes Behn for Mrs. Lewis J. Proctor, Mrs. Dudley Davis and Mrs. Charles A. Russell.

Following the submission of a stipulation by drug and cosmetic manufacturers to Mayor La Guardia agreeing to Federal supervision of their products, the Mayor did not hold the public hearing scheduled for yesterday in City Hall at which local control of these products was to be discussed.

Anthony Streeter, 23 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Fay Streeter, 21, denied all knowledge in the police lineup yesterday of eleven pistols, a shotgun and a rifle found in their apartment at 555 West 159th Street on Sunday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP). -- Swift concentration of the general headquarters air force in South Florida today convinced its commander he could mass the fast fighting ships anywhere in the United States within twenty-four hours.

PARIS, Dec. 2. -- The expectation is entertained here that the proposed meeting here Saturday between Premier Pierre Laval and Sir Samuel Hoare, the British Foreign Secretary, may bring some progress toward establishing a basis for settling the Italo-Ethiopian quarrel that will avert the necessity of coal and oil sanctions against Italy.

With the various European political factions adopting a more conciliatory attitude with respect to the Italo-Ethiopian situation, and with domestic trade news giving further assurance, the share market yesterday showed mild rallying tendencies early in the day, only to turn heavy in the final hour when it became apparent that there was nothing of especial note in the day's news which would influence trading to any extent.

The passenger list of the Manhattan of the United States Lines, leaving today for the Channel ports, includes several diplomatic and consular representatives, American Olympic athletes and members of delegations going to attend conferences in Europe.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- Wheat traders appeared today to pay little or no attention to news, regardless of its character. Scattered liquidation by longs and a little pressure from houses with Eastern connections resulted in the market on the Board of Trade opening lower and at no time did it show a pronounced tendency to rally.

Ernest Schelling, conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's concerts for children and young people, will open a series of concerts in high school auditoriums of the five boroughs this afternoon at Evander Childs High School. The concerts are under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee, with which the Board of Education and the National Music League are cooperating.

A dispute over the ownership of art works valued at more than $100,000, including three paintings attributed to Rubens, ended in the Supreme Court yesterday when a jury before Justice Lloyd Church gave a verdict for Frederick Silberman, art expert, in a replevin suit brought by Edmund J. Horvath, head of a firm of accountants.

Two circumstances have forced the Treasury to go into the market for more money. An outstanding obligation of $418,000,000 in notes matures on Dec. 15 and must be refunded. Meantime, current expenditures have drawn heavily on the Treasury's "working balance."

Amid varicolored tropical plants, orange blossoms, waving palms and dioramas showing sun-drenched stretches of beach, Dave Sholtz, Governor of Florida, opened the Florida Fair at 12:30 P.M. yesterday in the International Building, Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ratified the appoinments of Howard S. Palmer, James Lee Loomis and W.M. Daniels as trustees in bankruptcy of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company.

The Associated Utilities Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, paid in full last week the balance of $2,900,000 due on notes of the Penn Southern Power Company held by the New York Trust Company. It also arranged for a new note with the Chemical Bank and Trust Company to cover $450,000 due to that bank from Penn Southern Power.

The International Longshoremen's Association declared a boycott yesterday of the piers of about twenty-five ship lines operating to and from New York, and serving also ports in the Gulf district. Effective at midnight, the withdrawal of the members of the association was ordered as a blow at lines which have refused to recognize the association as the official spokesman of their longshoremen at ports in the Gulf.

More than 300 photographs taken by persons living within fifty miles of Columbus Circle were placed on exhibition last night at the American Museum of Natural History as the Metropolitan Salon of Photography. The public will be admitted to the show beginning today and continuing through Dec. 15.

Edward C. McDonald, sitting as special master in the Federal court in Brooklyn, concluded yesterday the hearings on the petition of the Prudence Bondholders Protective Association for permission to intervene in reorganization proceedings involving the Prudence Company, Inc., and the Prudence Bond Corporation.
Without a hitch, 462 prisoners were transferred yesterday from the Correction Hospital on Welfare Island to the new Rikers Island Penitentiary.

The local professional football season will end Sunday when the Pittsburgh Pirates come to the Polo Grounds to meet the Giants, winners of Eastern Division honors in the National League for the third straight year, and the Boston Redskins invade Ebbets Field to face the Brooklyn Dodgers.

Juvenile delinquency, crime prevention and kindred problems were discussed last night at a dinner conference of social workers at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street. Byrnes MacDonald, director of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, who was the principal speaker, announced that he had just obtained Mayor La Guardia's approval for a plan to rent empty buildings in parts of the city where delinquency was high to provide recreation centres.

The ninth annual exhibition of etchings, lithographs and woodcuts by members of American Print Makers opened to the public yesterday at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street. It will continue until Dec. 28.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Mayor La Guardia took sharp issue with the statement that New York is now the nation's crime capital, when he supervised the promotion of ten officers of the Police Department in City Hall yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 2. -- With Jan. 1 the deadline when registration must become effective, brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets continue to file applications with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The SEC asked for thirty days in which to pass upon such requests but hopes to complete this task in regard to all that are now on file.

One distinction ought to be kept in mind about the aim and working of the Neediest Cases Fund. It differs from the agencies for relief, Federal, State and municipal, in that it looks beyond mere immediate help. It contemplates rehabilitation rather than temporary relief.

Frederick Hussey, who died Nov. 13, 1934, a resident of East Orange, N.J., left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,165,016 gross and $2,026,729 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $1,665,009. The only property taxable in New York was $352,500 in real estate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The resignation of George N. Peek as president and trustee of the Export-Import Banks and as a special adviser to President Roosevelt on Foreign Trade was officially announced at a meeting today of the trustees of the Export-Import Banks, who promptly voted to offer the offices of president and trustee to Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC.
May I compliment you on the excellent analysis of the hospital situation in your editorial "Hospitals Need Help"?

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The stock markets here were unsettled today and further restricted by the foreign political situation and the undecided tendency of the French franc. Further declines in British funds were attributed to the current discussions of sanctions.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (AP). -- The $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, to be run here Feb. 22, may be worth more to the winner than last Winter's record $108,400 purse, it appeared today as nominations of thoroughbreds reached seventy-six.

CAIRO, Dec. 2. -- Although calmed since the violent anti-British riots of a fortnight ago, Egyptian students are still demonstrating under the slightest pretext, but the demonstrations are not confined to attacks on Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Creation of a vast railroad empire in the Southwest to be dominated by the Missouri Pacific and to be formed by a consolidation of that line and subsidiaries with the St. Louis-San Francisco and the Missouri-Kansas-Texas was recommended in a Reconstruction Finance Corporation examiners' report made public today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- In its efforts to balance the economic interests of farmers and consumers, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced plans today which are intended to increase hog production 30 per cent over this year in 1936, but to hold cotton at about the present restricted crop.

SEATTLE, Dec. 2. -- Schools of economics were compared today by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, at a luncheon of business organizations of Seattle. Although recognizing the virtues of the newer schools of thought, Mr. Gay sided with the older and more orthodox groups of economists, declaring "the State should refrain from trying to supply power for the [economic] machine."

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The first session of the bridge championship tournament events of the American Bridge League was held this afternoon at the Stevens Hotel, with a national championship for women's teams of four.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Applications for registration by three more small utility holding companies, the Mission Oil Company of Kansas City, Mo.; the Citizens Utilities Company of Minneapolis, with seven subsidiaries, and the Northern Paper Mills Company of Wisconsin, with one subsidiary, were received in the mails today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

JIJIGA, Ethiopia, Dec. 2. -- In the past fortnight 5,000 Ethiopians have moved south from Jijiga. This movement has accelerated in the past four days, during which 2,500 men have been sent as evidence of the decision of Ras Nasibu to fill the gaps in the Southern front preparatory to a general advance.

The need for recognition by corporate wealth of its continued responsibility in supporting private charity even in economic crises when governments become the major support of the indigent was emphasized at a group discussion of the campaign problem confronting the United Hospital Fund at the Union Club last night.

Four more loan sharks received penitentiary sentences yesterday, and the last defendant among the twenty-two seized by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of racketeers in New York County, was tried and convicted by Special Sessions Justices Kernochan, Saloman and Brady.

A complete international exchange of scientific knowledge in order to minimize the evils of war was advocated last night by Sir James Colquhoun Irvine, principal and vice chancellor of the University of St. Andrews, Scotland. He spoke at a dinner given for him at the Hotel Plaza by the Pilgrims of the United States, of whom Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler is president.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 3. -- Princess Victoria, elder of King George's two surviving sisters and known by virtue of her untiring work for the sick and needy as "the unselfish Princess," died early today at her home, the Coppins, Iver, Buckinghamshire.

Uniform legislation to tighten the laws on extradition of criminals and to provide for the interstate supervision of paroled persons were among the model statutes approved yesterday at the concluding executive session of the Interstate Commission on Crime.

Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton will confer today with ten Republican county leaders and seek to work out the basis for distribution of the patronage and important posts that will go with Republican control of the Assembly in January.

The Metropolitan Opera House was alive with activity yesterday. Rehearsals of every description -- orchestra, ensemble, solo, chorus and ballet -- were under way in various parts of the house and even outside of it in preparation for the new season which is to begin in a fortnight. With the exception of chorus and ballet, all rehearsals began yesterday.
A match in which all three games went to extra points and a sweep by the Columbia University Club quintet featured last night's contests in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

We are a wonderfully consistent nation, punctured full of inconsistencies. For example, we impose a tariff on imported articles to promote prosperity among our own people, and then, a little later, we abolish it for the same reason

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Nov. 27 shows an increase for the week of $142,000,000 in total loans and investments, and increase of $199,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, a decrease of $94,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and an increase of $57,000,000 in deposit balances of foreign banks.

A resolution pointing out that many persons cannot afford to pay for adequate dental service and urging organized dentistry to seek some plan to extend such service without jeopardizing the livelihood of dentists was adopted last night at a meeting of the First District Dental Society.

WITH the football roar subsiding, Farmer Frank Frisch was sought out on his New Rochelle acres. There have been reports of an important trade between the St. Louis Cardinals and the New York Giants. As manager of the Cardinals, Farmer Frank should know something about it if it had taken place.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2. -- Unless there is a last-minute upset, Louisiana State University and Fordham University apparently will meet in Louisiana's Sugar Bowl here on New Year's Day.

Two of New York's Neediest Cases -- 72-year-old Maggie and her paralyzed "baby brother" of Case 5 and the war veteran and his wife of Case 8 -- were removed from the list of the Neediest yesterday by two designated contributions, which were included in the 206 gifts received.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, leader of a strong-arm group, which terrorized fresh water fish dealers at Peck Slip, received the heaviest prison term ever imposed here in an anti-trust case, when he and fifty-seven other defendants were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3. -- Running a front race all the way, Fair Time, Clyde Troutt's gelding, carried off the Hammond Purse, the mile and seventy-yard event which featured today's events at the Fair Grounds. It was the second straight victory of the meeting for the winner.
DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Members of the freshman football squad at Southern Methodist University figured today they could make the round trip to the Rose Bowl for $2.50 each.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- In an atmosphere of fever and at times of tumult, debate was begun today in the Chamber of Deputies on the attitude of the government toward the quasi-military leagues, which acknowledge no allegiance except to their leaders and which in the eyes of many are a constant threat to the Republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Unsettled world conditions have prompted the Treasury to accumulate a large cash reserve and put its financial operations on a 24-hour basis, Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today when he announced that the government's $900,000,000 cash loan offered yesterday was over-subscribed four times.

OTTAWA, Dec. 3. -- A storm of considerable proportions has blown up in Canada over the Dominion Government's repudiation of responsibility for the proposal made by its League of Nations representative, Dr. W.A. Riddell, for a coal, iron and oil embargo against Italy.

Yesterday's rise in stocks was regarded by observers as a clear-cut example of a spontaneous advance following steady improvement in the technical position of the market during the last two weeks. Aside from such continuing influences as the improvement in trade and expectations of an inflationary trend, there was no news to account for the rise.

The declining trend of commodity prices in November accentuated a recession which had its inception in October, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and as a result, Dun's index number of wholesale commodity prices on Dec. 1 fell below the level of the month preceding for the first time since September.
Apartment house investment deals and purchase of a housing site featured the Bronx activity reported yesterday.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 3. -- William D. Euler, Minister of Trade and Commerce, announced tonight the reorganization of the Canadian Wheat Board, with the following personnel:

THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases receives a bequest of $1,000 in the will of Joseph Bulova, late president of the Bulova Watch Company, which was fried for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Bulova died on Nov. 18, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $10,000."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Early American antiques and objects of historic value filled the auditorium of the County Centre today at the opening of the second Southern New York and Connecticut Antiques Exposition and Historical Exhibit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Twenty-two additional offering sheets of various oil interests were filed last week as follows, the Securities and Exchange Commission anounced today:

Frederic J. Fuller, president of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company, gave direct testimony for the second day yesterday in his defense in the General Sessions trial of himself and two other officers of the company on a charge that they issued a false statement on its financial condition in January, 1933.

Net profit of the Food Machinery Corporation for the year ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $1,025,037 after providing for Federal income taxes, but before deduction of preferred dividends. This is after writing off all development expenses and setting up the usual reserve for depreciation, inventory obsolescence and adjustment of bad-debt reserves.
A rise in new cases and deaths from diphtheria last week caused Health Commissioner Rice yesterday to urge all parents to have their children under 6 years immunized at once.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The failure of many manufacturers and distributers of arms and other implements of war to register with the State Department as required under the neutrality resolution led Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to issue a warning that if they did not register within a reasonable time he would refer their names to Attorney General Homer Cummings for action.

It is refreshing to see the Republican county chairmen of this State deliberating earnestly at the National Republican Club on the organization of the Assembly, made Republican, no doubt, mainly by their skill and genius. The geographical and personal elements and the considerations of political justice that decide the distribution of honors and patronage and chairmanships of committees are matters too subtle, difficult and momentous for laymen to give an opinion on.
Directors of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York declared yesterday the usual extra dividend of 15 cents and the regular quarterly dividend of 37 1/2 cents on the capital stock.

ATLANTA, Dec. 3 (AP). -- An assertion by Frank Lane, Big Ten football official, that the game as played this season was "glorified basketball" and that the "slow whistle" and attendant lateral passing had made blocking a "lost art" has stirred debate among Southern coaches, favorable and otherwise.
BOSTON, Dec. 3. -- Three men are dead tonight after the worst jail break in the history of Massachusetts.

ROME, Dec. 3. -- The Italian Cabinet met again this morning under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship and approved several important measures aimed at increasing and preserving Italy's slender stocks of raw materials in view of the strain being put on them by League of Nations sanctions.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Nov. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3. -- James Roosevelt arrived today by airplane from Warm Springs, Ga., where he has been with his father, to be a guest of Joseph P. Kennedy. Mr. Kennedy, accompanied by Edward Small Moore of New York and Jack Kennedy of London, flew down this morning.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Louisiana State University and Texas Christian University were selected tonight as the teams to play in the annual Sugar Bowl football game here on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- While the Securities and Exchange Commission today studied future procedure in its legal battle with utilities to test the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935, another holding company, Tennessee Electric Power, a subsidiary of Commonwealth and Southern, filed suit in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia to enjoin the commission from requiring it to comply with the act.

MONTREAL, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press). -- An interim injunction prohibiting appearance in theatres owned by the Confederation Amusements, Ltd., of any persons purporting to be winners of contests held by Major Edward Bowes of New York was issued in Superior Court today. At the same time an action for damages against the theatre company for $4,500 was brought by Major Bowes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Following is the State Department announcement today concerning the registration of arms concerns, with a list of those registered:

A survey of children in New York City between the ages of 2 and 6 has revealed that 73 per cent of those examined have decayed or diseased teeth, it was reported last night at the eleventh annual convention of the First and Second District Dental Societies at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The eighteen-story store and loft structure at 150-54 West Twenty-eighth Street, in the Penn zone business district, has been sold by the Savings Bank Trust Company to an investing group to be known as the 150 West Twenty-eighth Street Corporation, of which Samuel Bergman is president.

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, denied yesterday reports published here and in London to the effect that an Italian subsidiary of his company had agreed to supply to Italy all petroleum required in the event of an embargo of oil by the League of Nations.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Vivian Dixon are active in behalf of the dinner and entertainment for the benefit of the Invalids of the Russian Imperial Army and their destitute dependents now in this country tonight in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis.
Two announcements from the administrative office at Fordham University yesterday brought to a sudden halt a flood of rumors regarding football on Rose Hill.

As a result of a conversation accidentally overheard in a telephone booth yesterday afternoon, detectives assigned to the Attorney General's Anti-Racket Bureau here were on their way last night to Ballston Spa with three of the eighty-six persons indicted by the Saratoga County grand jury for race track tipster racketeering.

Reaching the highest mark of this year and revealing an increase of $53,691,568 for November, total net borrowings on collateral of New York Stock Exchange members aggregated $846,113,137 on Nov. 30, it was reported yesterday. At the end of October the total was $792,421,569.

Commissioner POST and the other members of the Housing Authority had a fine, brisk day for the dedication of the first Government-built and operated low-rental housing development in the city. The sun shone, the bands played, the school children waved their flags. A block front of old-law tenements on the lower East Side had given way to more light and airy dwellings, with a playground and a row of trees thrown in for good measure.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The Elizabeth Town and Country Club continued undefeated in division B of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League today, scoring a sweep over the Plainfield Country Club.

Most futures were moderately higher on the local commodity markets yesterday. Crude rubber futures dropped 40 to 44 points on the announcement by the International Rubber Regulation Committee in London of an increase in the Netherlands Indies basic quotas for 1936 to 1938.

The first dinner dance for this season in the series of Yorkville benefits for the Community Association took place last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Receiving with Mrs. Dexter Fales, active chairman of the dance committee, and Mrs. A. Mansfield Patterson, honorary chairman, were Mrs. Lea Hudson and Mrs. Alexander M. Orr.

A letter to President Roosevelt from the official heads of twenty-five Protestant denominations, supporting his efforts to keep the United States from becoming involved in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, was made public yesterday by Dr. Walter W. Van Kirk of the Federal Council of Churches.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- Howard Benton Lewis, special master for the Federal District Court here, gave his approval today to the plan of reorganization of the capital structure of the Baldwin Locomotive Works under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
Two relief workers were held in $1,000 bail each yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on a complaint charging that they solicited and accepted a bribe of $50.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The State's highest court denied to Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt today the right to carry to the Court of Appeals her legal fight for custody of her 12-year-old daughter, Gloria.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- London today is the centre of surmise and curiosity for the rest of Europe, because Europe's fate in the coming months depends upon the why, the what and the whither of British policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the operations of the S.W. Straus Co. chain of realty bonding houses and affiliated units ended today. Investigation of the American Bond and Mortgage Company will begin tomorrow.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 3. -- After commanding officers of the army conferred today with War Minister Joao Gomes Ribiero on measures to expel undesirable radicals from the ranks, President Getulio Vargas disbanded three infantry regiments that participated in last week's rebellion.

A great field for missionary work remains in this country, particularly among the Navajo Indians, whose reservation constitutes the last big stronghold of paganism in the United States, the Right Rev. Frederick B. Howden, Bishop of New Mexico, said yesterday at the Advent meeting of the Women's Missionary Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New York in Synod Hall, adjacent to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

With a total market value of $44, 950,590,351, there were 1,175 stock issues, aggregating 1,308,858,205 shares, listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 1, it was reported yesterday. A month ago the market value of 1,168 issues, consisting of 1,307,139,275 shares, was $43,002,018,069.

A general improvement in bonds was seen on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The marked success of the Treasury's December financing and the quick closing of the books on the cash offering put new life into the market for government obligations and that group scored its best gains since Oct. 21.
PARIS, Dec. 3. -- Following a kidnapping case at Marseilles which has taken French justice by surprise, the government moved today to prevent such crimes from spreading in France.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Remuneration of officers and directors of the General Motors Corporation and other employes receiving in excess of $20,000 annually approximated $5,000,000 for 1934, according to a report by the company made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- There would have been little need of Federal intervention in the financial world had the precept "beware of false profits" been the guide in the "rainbow decade," George L. Tirrell, chief examiner of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, said here tonight.

Efforts to settle the threatened strike of musicians employed on WPA music and dance projects failed yesterday, and it appeared that the strike would go into effect as scheduled tomorrow morning. About 700 musicians are involved. The strike was ordered by the Musicians Union, of which the 700 are members, in support of demands for the prevailing rate of wages and modification of working conditions.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway reserved decision yesterday in the habeas corpus proceedings designed to save Meyer Luckman from standing trial for the murder of Sam Druckman, one of his employes in a trucking firm which enjoyed a virtual monopoly in the shipping of foodstuffs in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- Eight proposals to be studied in connection with the new legislative session were urged upon the executive committee of the State Federation of Labor today by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The Port of New York Authority will consider bids next Wednesday for a new issue of $16,500,000 of general and refunding bonds, it was announced last night by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman, after a meeting of the board.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Over the Pacific, Wednesday, Dec. 4. -- After the strenuous thirteen-hour flight from Guam to Wake yesterday, the China Clipper had comparatively smooth and easy sailing today winging toward her mid-ocean air base at the Midway Islands.

Don't look now, but sooner or later Tom Sopwith will be hauling over the SSE horizon, probably edging up from "the still-vext Bermoothes" on 'longshore beat with Endeavour II for another go at America's Cup. Or perhaps with the same Endeavour that trailed Rainbow in last year's encounters off Newport. Skipper Tom will make up his mind about that later.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Outstanding in the trading today on the London Stock Exchange was the sharp advance in British funds following the announcement of the new government loans, which were favorably received. Quotations were generally firm after a quiet opening.

Insisting that Chicago has more crime than New York, Mayor La Guardia sent an invitation yesterday to First Assistant State Attorney Wilbert Crowley of Chicago to come here and satisfy himself that the figures quoted by the Mayor were correct.

Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Phelan Beale, Mr. and Mrs. Will R. Gregg, Dr. and Mrs. John Winston Fowlkes, Mr. and Mrs. Williana J. Murray, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lipscomb, Mrs. David Lawrence and Leroy Campbell.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Pledging the British Government to "firm support of the League of Nations" and to the building up of her defenses for safeguarding of the empire, an address by King George today opened the ninth Parliament of his reign.

Formation of a State mortgage bank or banks operating under drastic restrictions and supervision as the best means of re-establishing the real estate investment market was proposed yesterday to the joint legislative committee investigating the situation as to guaranteed real estate mortgage bonds.

A defense of the rate policies of the United States-South African Freight Conference was presented by conference officials yesterday at the second and closing session of the Shipping Board's investigation of charges of unfair practices on the part of conference lines.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- Flags flew at half-staff everywhere throughout Great Britain today because of the death of the King's sister, Princess Victoria. The news of her death early this morning was broken to the King and Queen at an early hour in Buckingham Palace, and messages of condolence soon began to pour into the palace from over the world.

In Great Britain the King's speech defines the policy of the Government. It is a far better indication of coming action and legislation than is a party platform in this country. At the opening of the new Parliament yesterday, the Baldwin Cabinet, speaking through King GEORGE, announced the stand which it is determined to take in foreign affairs, particularly with reference to the war between Italy and Ethiopia.

OTTAWA, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Savings deposits in Canadian chartered banks on Oct. 31 were $1,465,301,708, almost $100, 000,000 more than a year before, according to the monthly statement of the banks to the Department of Finance, made public today. There was a $21,000,000 increase in October.

RACING, to most people, means Saratoga or Belmont Park, with the jockeys hunched up over the horses' heads like so many monkeys perched on sticks. But there is another kind of racing that goes on in the back country of New England and New York -- the sulky racing that this department used to enjoy, even in all its absolute ignorance of horseflesh, at the Sage Park track outside of Windsor, Conn.

The St. Louis Southwestern Railway, which has been a pawn in consolidation moves for a decade and for which the Southern Pacific Company paid $20,000,000 a few years ago, announced yesterday that it would default on $584,362 of obligations on Jan. 1.

Details of the cotton control plan for next year, calling for a 5 per cent greater acreage reduction than last Spring, created more activity yesterday on the cotton Exchanges here and in New Orleans and Liverpool than had been witnessed in some time. With a possible yield of only 11,500,000 to 12,000,000 bales indicated under favorable growing conditions, buying centred in the October, 1936, delivery, which had been selling at a heavy discount.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- The arrival of 25,000 head of hogs here today, the largest since the middle of January led packers to take a more bearish attitude on the market and while early prices were steady to 5 cents a hundred weight lower the close showed losses of 10 to 15 cents. A top price of $9.90, the same as Monday, was paid early, but later $9.75 was the price quoted.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Borough President Harvey of Queens warned today that relief expenditures must be curtailed eventually "or it is going to run away with us all," and joined other delegates in criticizing the Federal work-relief system at a meeting of officials of villages and cities in Yonkers City Hall.

Seven Manhattan properties and eleven in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan offerings included the twelve-story Girard Building at 198 Broadway and various apartment houses, as follows: ...

PEIPING, Wednesday, Dec. 4. -- The mere fact that General Ho Ying-ching, the Chinese War Minister, arrived here last evening has stiffened the stand of the leaders opposed to the North China autonomy movement, for it had been feared that incidents might arise to block his arrival.

Bequests of $150,000 to educational and religious institutions are contained in the will of Charles Millard Pratt, philanthropist, former director of the Standard Oil Company and former president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 3. -- Large forces of Ethiopians marching on Makale in Northern Ethiopia have been sighted by Italian advance patrols, it was announced today. The Italians believe the major battle they have sought ever since their African campaign started is now near.

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- Erich Koch, head of the National Socialist government in East Prussia and provincial party leader, was suspended by General Hermann Goering, Prussian Premier, several days ago for having physically chastised a subordinate party member in his Koenigsberg office, but has been reinstated by Chancellor Adolf Hitler, it became known today.

A city-wide survey will be made, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday, to determine whether it is true that business concerns have moved out of the city because of high taxation and high operating costs.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks lengthened their lead in the American division of the National Hockey League by coming from behind tonight to out-skate the Bruins for a 3-1 victory before 12,000 at the Garden.
LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The United States has undertaken preliminary work for a reciprocal trade agreement with her greatest foreign customer, Great Britain, an authoritative source disclosed tonight.

Louise Astor Van Alen, daughter of Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen of this city and Newport and former wife of the late Alexis Mdivani, will be married within the next few weeks to Serge Mdivani, brother of Alexis, according to reliable information received here yesterday from Newport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A Treasury regulation requiring every taxpayer to file two copies of his Federal income tax return next March will be announced within the next few days. The additional copy will be made available to State and local tax collectors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Secretary Ickes aligned himself with the government's policy of discouraging "excessive" commerce with warring Italy and Ethiopia today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3. -- All of Yale's seven varsity and jayvee coaches were reappointed today. No contracts were announced but they were named for one-year terms.

Deputy Sheriff Hugh Breslin, who says that he fought Johnny Kilbane for the featherweight championship of the world twenty years ago, and half a dozen assistants were unable to dislodge Mrs. Josephine Kosmowski from her home at 260 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, so that WPA laborers could demolish the place in accordance with plans for the $12,000,000 Williamsburg housing project.
Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, said yesterday that his office would continue to seek out and punish loan sharks. He has assigned two assistants to this work.

The Southern Women's National Democratic Organization of New York is sponsoring an exhibition that will open at the Barnard Club, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, next Saturday afternoon with a reception. This show is made up of work by artists of Southern birth who now reside in New York. Those participating are:
J. Ebb Weir, president of the Long Island Golf Association, has announced that the organization's amateur-pro competitions will be discontinued in 1936.

A national campaign for abolition of slums and for increased Federal aid to promote low-cost housing was started yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Public Housing Conference in the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, declared here tonight that Olympic athletes were meeting the "un-American boycott offensive with historic American action."
The City A.C. players scored their fourth straight triumph in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group I team matches last night.

Two more inmates of the death house at Sing Sing, doomed to die on Jan. 9 for killing a policeman, gave damaging evidence for the State in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of 63-year-old Nelson B. Clark as their accomplice in a hold-up.

The John Fritz Medal, highest honor in the engineering profession in the United States, was presented last night to Dr. William F. Durand, Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Leland Stanford Jr. University, for notable achievement "as authority in hydrodynamic and aerodynamic science, and its practical application," and for being an "outstanding leader in research and in engineering education."

The attitude of industry toward government during the coming Presidential campaign year was defined for industry, "and more especially the voter," yesterday at the Hotel Commodore by several hundred officers of regional manufacturers' associations and trade associations.

The American Superpower Corporation has disposed of its large stock interests in the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and in the Italian Superpower Corporation, it developed yesterday, thus leaving it without ownership of more than 10 per cent in the stock of any public utility holding company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The Southwestern Gas and Electric Company has filed with the SEC an amendment to its registration statement for the issuance of $16,000,000 first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series D, due on Nov. 1, 1960, and $4,500,000 of 4 per cent serial debentures, Series A, due serially from Nov. 1, 1936, to Nov. 1, 1945, changing the offering date from Nov. 20 to Dec. 10.

An order requiring Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, and four other Cabinet members who compose the National Munitions Control Board to show cause next Tuesday why they should not be restrained from extending the board's restrictions on exports to Italy to oil, cotton, scrap iron and copper, was signed last night by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- There was a noticeable lack of selling pressure in the North American wheat markets today which failed to be affected to any extent by sharp declines in Liverpool and Buenos Aires. Prices on the Chicago Board of Trade held within a range of around 1 cent bushel and closed at the top with gains of 1/4 to 3/8 cent.

Five persons were injured slightly about 9:30 o'clock last night in an explosion in an old-fashioned wood-burning stove in the Nantucket Social Club on the second floor of a five-story loft building at 201 Sullivan Street, at the northeast corner of Bleecker Street.

Keeping the voluntary hospitals open through contributions will be much more economical in the long run than would taxation to keep them going. Governor Lehman said in a letter indorsing the United Hospital Campaign which was made public here yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The text of King George's address, read in his behalf at the opening of Parliament today, was as follows:

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 3. -- President Roosevelt told newspaper correspondents today that he had ample material on which he based the statement in his speech at Atlanta last Friday that bankers told him in 1933, when banks and industry were seeking financial aid from the government, that "the country could safely stand a national debt of between $55,000,000,000 and $70,000,000,000."
