WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Charges that the Agricultural Adjustment Act is unconstitutional, nullifies the division of power between State and nation, and extends almost unlimited Federal power over local affairs were made today in a Supreme Court brief of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- The legality of the dismissal of William R. Hayward by the New York City Board of Education on May 31 from the position of principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School was challenged at a hearing today before Dr. Ernest E. Cole, Assistant Commissioner of Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A summary of stock transactions and holdings of officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations with securities registered on national securities Exchanges, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed a continuation of gifts of considerable value in October and disclosed for the first time gifts in other months that had not been revealed in earlier summaries.

Mrs. Lisa Shaw, dancer known as Lisa Parnova, appeared yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McGeehan and a jury as her own attorney in defending a divorce suit by Hollis B. Shaw, artist and nephew of the late Simeon Ford, in which the plaintiff's cousin, Ellsworth Ford, also an artist, and son of the late hotel man and after dinner speaker, is named as corespondent.

IS it not about time that Uncle Sam stopped his Little Jack Horner attitude and realized that without unity among the civilized nations of the earth civilization as we know it cannot continue another fifty years? Are we going to enter the ark of safety called the League of Nations now, when our membership would be so helpful; or are we going to wait until we are driven in as a matter of sheer self-defense?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Capitol Hill sources close to the Senate Munitions Committee reported today that the drafting of a new and more stringent neutrality bill already was under way, with its submission intended for early in January.
The six-story office building with stores at 31 West Fifteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been sold by the estate of Amos Enos to the labor group representing the garment workers.

Finland recently announced her intention to pay the instalment due this month on her war debt to the United States. It is safe to say that the Treasury expects no other payment. Interest is due semi-annually on these obligations. In June of last year, again in December and again last June, Finland was the only nation to pay anything whatever.
First Houses, New York City's experiment in slum clearance with government funds and relief labor, were formally dedicated at Avenue A and East Third Street yesterday morning.

Growing sentiment for restoring goal posts to the goal line may develop into an organized demand by football coaches at the rules committee meeting in February, Chick Meehan, Manhattan mentor, said yesterday.

Vigorously attacking those "unfair critics" who "seek to discredit advertising without regard to the truth," the National Better Business Bureau declared yesterday that reputable publishers sacrifice millions of dollars annually in rejected advertising copy which fails to measure up to the standards they have set for the protection of their readers.

Another jam in which four women were hurt occurred yesterday when 5,000 WPA applicants, all of them white-collar workers, and including many women, waited for hours in front of the WPA intake office, Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. None suffered serious injuries.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- An assertion that Westminster Theological Seminary, founded several years ago by Presbyterian Fundamentalists, was "committing suicide" in identifying itself with the independent board for Presbyterian foreign missions is contained in a letter to the seminary's board of trustees, published in this month's issue of Christianity Today.

Shareholders of the Bank of the Manhattan Company held yesterday their 137th annual meeting. From J. Stewart Baker, chairman, they received a detailed report which showed that earnings for this year, estimated at $3,733,000, had fallen below the $4,950,000 earned last year, but were still $733,000 in excess of dividend requirements.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 3. -- Dr. Frantisek Spina, Minister of Health, who is the German agrarian representative in the Czech coalition Cabinet, sharply criticized in a speech at Bruex the policy adopted by Konrad Henlein's German Nationalist party.

Cardinal Hayes presided and spoke yesterday morning at the annual service celebrating the feast of St. Francis Xavier, patron saint of the missions, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and 131st Street. The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, auxiliary bishop of the archdiocese; Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General, and the Most Rev. Francis X. Ford, Vicar Apostolic of Kaying, China, also were present.

A full dress performance of Verdi's "Traviata" was presented last night at Carnegie Hall as a tribute to Max Rabinoff on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the beginning of his career as an impresario. The proceeds were to go to the Los Angeles Free Sanatorium.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Gertrude Atherton, 78-year-old author advocate of scientific rejuvenation, staked what she said was her own experience against opinions of medical doubters tonight.

More general use of direct-mail advertising by insurance companies and a more generous use of "paer, ink and force" to keep their message before potential buyers, was urged yesterday by Philip J. Kelly, executive vice president of I. Harry Latz Service, Inc., in a speech at the mid-year session of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

New York City will soon have its own official anthem. Mayor La Guardia wrote to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers yesterday asking that it conduct a contest among anthem-writers to produce a hymn that Father Knickerbocker can call his own. He took the step after conferring with Gene Buck, president of the society, and other leaders in the musical world.

A mounted restoration of a Scarrittia, a herbivorous animal native to South America 30,000,000 years ago, was shown at the Museum of Natural History yesterday preliminary to going on public view in the main lobby tomorrow.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association tonight named Bloomfield and Phillipsburg as joint holders of the 1935 football championship for North Jersey Group IV high schools. Bloomfield was unbeaten, untied and unscored in in nine games, while Phillipsburg was unbeaten and untied in ten.
The National Youth Administration sent yesterday to school and college heads in the metropolitan district a bulletin disclaiming liability for injuries suffered by students working on NYA projects.

Colonel Henry L. Doherty, chairman of the National Committee for the 1936 Birthday Ball for the President, announced yesterday plans for the benefit parties to be held on President Roosevelt's fifty-fourth birthday, Jan. 30. He also made public the names of the members of the national committee.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 3. -- Regardless of the heretofore open opposition of Senators Glass and Byrd to some of the basic policies of the New Deal, Virginia seems to have accepted the proposition that President Roosevelt will be renominated and re-elected. With this assumption, the Old Dominion has settled itself down to enjoy a degree of prosperity not experienced since 1929.

Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick of the Department of Correction declared yesterday that the Tombs, the Brooklyn city prison and the Queens prison were antiquated "disgraces" that should be replaced. He spoke before an audience of 200 at the League for Political Education at Town Hall.

Another "kibitzer" prize committee was established formally yesterday when the motion picture critics of New York emerged from one of their star chamber proceedings, bestowed upon themselves a title and announced that they would, in the near future, designate what they considered the best picture released during the year, the best male performance, the best female performance and the best director.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- A team of four women from as many States, assembled at the last minute, won the national women's team-of-four championship and the Charles E. Coffin Trophy in the American Bridge League's annual Winter tournament today. The winning team was composed of Mrs. Robert B. Fuller of New York, Miss Helen White of Los Angeles, Miss Florence Stratford of Cleveland and Mrs. L. G. Quigley of Chicago.

ARTURO TOSCANINI was resting between halves of a Vienna concert when he was informed that ex-King FERDINAND of Bulgaria wished to offer his congratulations in person. The maestro replied that he could see no one during a concert. FERDINAND assumed that TOSCANINI had failed to understand who the visitor was, and sent to inquire a second time.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3. -- Stanford University's Rose Bowl-bound football team placed five players on The Associated Press all-Pacific Coast varsity eleven for 1935.

When Japan sends us cotton cloth, when France sends us cement, when the barriers are somewhat lowered in trade between the United States and Canada, there are always certain to be plenty of commentators around to view the situation with alarm. In nation after nation statesmen sit up late nights to devise ingenious methods of reducing imports into their country.

Building activity in Brooklyn for the last eleven months is far ahead of the same period last year, according to a report made public yesterday by Edwin L. Thatcher, Brooklyn Building Commissioner. The report showed plans filed for 1,908 structures this year at an estimated cost of $36,793,620, an increase of $24,000,000 over the total for the same period last year when plans were filed for 1,348 buildings at a cost of $12,533,486.

ATHENS, Dec. 3. -- Most of the rebels who took part in the March uprising began returning to their homes yesterday. Only a few were detained on charges of plundering Macedonian and Cretan banks. Telegrams were sent by the relatives of fugitives informing them it was safe for them to return.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey ruled here yesterday that the government was entitled to an injunction against the International Business Machines Corporation and Remington-Rand, Inc., restraining them from carrying out a "tying up" agreement between themselves and from enforcing provisions in their leases to renters of machines which prohibit the renters in most cases from using any cards except those manufactured by the maker of the machines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Secretary Ickes's explanation today that he did not mean recently to advocate the stoppage to belligerents of all exports of oil provides another illustration of the difficulty of effectively combining the "peace-at-any-price" policy of Congress, the war-shortening program of the State Department and the administration's broad business recovery drive.

Wendell L. Willkie, head of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, utility holding company, asserted here yesterday that "a personal representative" of President Roosevelt had solicited a $5,000 campaign contribution for the 1932 expenses of the Democratic National Committee.

College football turnstiles, registering a steady upturn since the depression low of 1932, clicked off substantial increases in attendance for the 1935 season. The gains ranged as high as 40 per cent in some instances, but the increase for the country as a whole probably, did not exceed 10 per cent.

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- Prices weakened on the Boerse today, with the usual little activity in operations being recorded. The softness of the market was attributed by financial observers simply to lack of takers resulting from the public indifference toward trading on the official exchange.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Dec. 3. -- Forceful play by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam in his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris for the chess championship of the world made the twenty-sixth game, begun tonight, highly interesting and often exciting.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon at the Jewish Day of the thirteenth annual Christmas Blind Sale, now being held under the auspices of the New York State Commission for the Blind at 475 Fifth Avenue. The sale, which includes only materials manufactured by the sightless, opened on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The sale of $8,800,000 of Louisiana and New Orleans highway and sewerage bonds at a premium of $675,000 was announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 4. -- A decision by Melbourne seamen to strike against the recent federal shipping award, following similar action in Sydney, makes paralysis of Australian coastal shipping inevitable unless the men can be induced to listen to reason.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Mayor La Guardia joined last night with Alfred J. Lill, member of the American Olympic Committee; Eric Seelig, former amateur light-heavyweight boxing champion of Germany, and others, in urging American withdrawal from the Olympic Games in Berlin next year.
MONTREAL, Dec. 3 (AP). -- The Maroons evened their series with the Canadiens tonight when they won a National League hockey game, 3-2.

Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, who has been put forward as a possible Republican candidate for President, met with Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, and a dozen leading Republicans of the State yesterday.

Ratings for the indoor polo season which opens this month were announced yesterday by Thomas Brady, chairman of the handicap committee. The changes were few, this first handicap committee meeting confining itself largely to the acceptance of eighty-nine new members.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- The New York squash racquets team, which last year won the triangular interteam series of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, began the defense of its sectional title by defeating the Westchester players, four matches to three, on the Sleepy Hollow Country Club courts this afternoon.

Mrs. Hilda Peterson, 39 years old, wife of William F. Peterson, fugitive "investment broker," both of whom have been indicted with two others on grand larceny charges growing out of Peterson's manipulation of his Isco Service Corporation heard herself denounced by the prosecutor yesterday in General Sessions as "the lure" for her husband's alleged victims.

While returning from a school playground shortly before 5 P.M. yesterday, Gloria Jackson, 13 years old, a Puerto Rican orphan, of 35 West 114th Street, was lured into a hallway, criminally assaulted and flung from a second story window. She died shortly after midnight in Harlem Hospital.

MIDWAY ISLAND, Pan American Airways Ocean Air Base, Dec. 3. -- In a leisurely flight of nine hours the China Clipper took a third long stride eastward across the Pacific 1,252 miles from her ocean air base on Wake Island to land here late this afternoon [at 11:50 P.M., Eastern standard time].

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- A strongly worded warning that the Federal Reserve System should "eliminate or at least greatly reduce" the $3,000,000,000 excess reserves now held by banks lest the idle reserves force dangerous credit inflation and "a new wave of speculation such as preceded the market collapse of 1929," has been laid before the board of governors and the open market committee of the Reserve System by its advisory council, it was learned today.

With the arrival of Robin Lee, 16-year-old national champion, from Minneapolis this week, the roster of figure skaters who are practicing at the Ice Club for the national championships and Olympic tryouts the end of this month is now complete.

Contributions to community chests in 133 cities have been 5 per cent higher than last year, but less than the 12 per cent increase sought, according to preliminary reports announced yesterday by Allen T. Burns, executive vice president of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., of 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

While our own Government was successfully floating a new loan of $900,000,000 to cover emergency expenditures in the near future, the British Government was offering investors in that country two new issues aggregating 300,000,000. Funds raised through the sale of these securities will be used exclusively for the purpose of refunding outstanding obligations.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3. -- Seventy-five of the country's finest thoroughbreds had been named today for the Santa Anita $100,000 added handicap to be run Feb. 22. The chances were good that the list would grow to eighty.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- An appeal to householders throughout the nation to revolt against potato control under the Agricultural Adjustment Administration by planting potatoes in their back yards next year has been made by Mrs. Walter M. Newkirk, a Philadelphia clubwoman living in Radnor, a suburb.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has been requested to advocate a "buy at retail" policy in a letter sent to her by Sidney A. Haas, president of the Retail Manufacturing Furriers, Inc., following reports in the trade press that Mrs. Roosevelt recently had purchased furs from a manufacturer here.
The Film and Photo League will show "The Brothers Karamazov" on Saturday night at 7 and 9:30 o'clock at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Twelve teams of the original field of fifteen were riding furiously last night before one of the largest Tuesday night crowds in the history of the event as the fifty-ninth international six-day race passed its forty-eighth hour in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will confer within two weeks with a committee representing the investment trusts to discuss a questionnaire which will be sent out in preparation for a sweeping investigation on the basis of which the commission must report to Congress by Jan. 4, 1937, whether it deems legislation advisable for Federal control of investment trust activities.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 3. -- The Ecuadorean Government sped relief workers today into the Andes area where a slide buried the village of Verde Cocha and its fifty inhabitants, rolling over a front of nearly two miles.

With the franc once more above its gold-shipping point, the flow of gold from Paris to the United States, which had been almost uninterrupted since Sept. 9, came to a halt yesterday. No fresh engagements of bullion in Paris were reported, the amount taken abroad for shipment being limited to $585, 000 engaged in India.

"Tobacco Road" is two years old tonight and ceremonies are in order as the play enters the charmed circle of long-enduring Broadway shows. The ceremonies will take place at midnight at the Hotel Astor, where Sam H. Grisman, Jack Kirkland and Harry H. Oshrin will be hosts to the cast, executive staff and stage crew, each of whom is entitled to bring a guest.
CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 3. -- A swirling snowstorm which greeted a company from Hollywood who stepped off the train here today to take pictures of the Dionne quintuplets was hailed with enthusiasm.

Many reservations have been made for the performance of "Whispering Gallery" by members of the Yale Dramatic Association, which will take place tonight at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of Yale-in-China. Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm heads the group in charge of the sale of seats for the benefit.

Business failures increased in the retail and wholesale divisions but declined in the manufacturing branch in the five business days ended Nov. 28, compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail defaults showed an increase from 114 to 148.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Assertions that if the Bankhead Cotton Control Law is upheld Federal power will be virutlaly unlimited, the dual system of government end and constitutional nullification "accomplished by a mere act of Congress" were made by attorneys for Leo Moor, Texas cotton producer, in a brief filed today with the Supreme Court preparatory to arguments on the act next week.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 3 (AP). - District leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association said today that more than a dozen steamship lines had agreed to negotiate for new contracts with the union and expressed confidence that the strike of longshoremen would be settled soon.

ROSLYN, L.I., Dec. 3. -- "The Tulips Are Blooming," a play by Elizabeth Armstrong, had its first production on any stage tonight in the Theatre of the Four Seasons, an opening that was postponed from last night. Charles Hopkins and Grant Tierney offered the play as the final production of their Autumn season.
Among the humanitarian works which have been made possible through Andrew Carnegie's generosity are some unknown to the general public because they affect but a small proportion of the population.

A suit for separation brought by Mrs. Gloria D. Spreckels against Adolph Spreckels, one of the heirs to the Spreckels sugar fortune, whom she married on Sept. 6 last at Baltimore, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday. Justice Bernard L. Shientag appointed Mrs. May Debevoise, Mrs. Spreckels's mother, guardian to prosecute the suit because Mrs. Spreckels is only 18 years old.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Authority was given to officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen today to call a strike of 1,700 employes of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad unless there is a satisfactory settlement of a dispute over the union's demand that a fireman be assigned to each of the streamline trains and electric switch engines operated by the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- As subcommittees of the House Appropriations Committee opened today hearings on future appropriations, returning members of Congress voiced the belief that some sort of bonus legislation would become law at the coming session of Congress, expressed doubt that appropriations could be reduced to the extent the administration contemplated and predicted that Congress would stay in session until June.

In a letter to THE TIMES Mrs. Florence Brewer Boeckel contributed a noteworthy justification of mandatory neutrality legislation as a guarantee of our neutrality in future wars. She offers this policy as "a sound basis -- at present the only politically practical basis -- for cooperation by this government with the League in measures for world peace."

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- The confessional Protestant synods challenged the Nazi totalitarian State's authority today by a demonstrative public breach of the decree extending State supremacy issued by Hanns Kerrl, the Minister for Church Affairs, yesterday.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 3. -- The Commonwealth government is consulting Sir Douglas Mawson, polar explorer, regarding its participation in the search for Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, as he is well acquainted with Antarctic conditions.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
DENVER, Dec. 3 (AP). -- Two of the greatest backs who ever raced to touchdowns in the Rockies dominate The Associated Press All-Mountain Conference team for 1935.
There is no "overhead" as far as the Neediest are concerned. Your gift to them goes whole and unimpaired direct to the persons you elect to help; there are no deductions for any purpose.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Dorothea Wendt Livermore, accused of attempting to kill her 16-year-old son, Jesse Livermore Jr., suffered a nervous breakdown today.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Dec. 3. -- Five heavily armed prisoners escaped from the City-Federal jail today, leaving a confederate dead and a detective chief wounded critically. Tonight they were believed to be trapped near Clayton.

Due to the holiday during the past week the number of buyers registered in the market was well below the preceding week. However, the total was practically the same as in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The average fresh-water angler probably entertains the belief that it is only necessary to keep a stream well stocked in order to provide good fishing. If the solution of the problem were as simple as that, our fish and game departments would have little to worry about.

Increasing indifference on the part of the general public toward safeguarding the fruits of its repeal victory, a definite growth in dry sentiment and more strenuous efforts by certain elements in the liquor industry to circumvent or modify the control laws -- these are among the chief trends since prohibition was repealed two years ago tomorrow, in the opinion of Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, came out yesterday in opposition to a recent proposal for replacing the single hospital commissioner with a board of trustees for the city hospitals. The commissioner was recounting the progress of his administration before the annual meeting of the State Charities Aid Association at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, speaking yesterday afternoon at a luncheon of the Lions Club of New York at the Hotel Astor, revealed that the question of water supply in the State was "getting to be a pretty serious one."

The Actors Equity Association announced yesterday a campaign to abolish the WPA ruling that all but 25 per cent of the workers on the Federal theatre project must have been on the relief rolls before Nov. 1.

Government science surveyed and directed by a small group of the best scientific minds which are to be appointed by the National Academy of Sciences and which are to serve without compensation, all on the theory that "we have now reached a point where "science and the research which has "discovered and released its powers "cannot be left to accidental applica"tion " -- such is the proposal that comes from the Science Advisory Board.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4. -- Banking, investment and industry, three handmaidens of economic well-being, together with civic service, were represented tonight at a dinner in the Palace Hotel for Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and three specialists in trading who make up his party.
Plaintiffs bought in the seven properties offered at auction stands in Manhattan yesterday. Except for three loft buildings on the lower East Side, all of the offerings were housing properties.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- In connection with the proposed oil embargo against Italy, attention here has been drawn to Great Britain's own dependence on overseas sources for oil, cotton and other raw materials, and to the fact that the American neutrality policy, if logically applied, would work against Britain when she was involved in war just as it works against Italy today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The brief filed with the Supreme Court by the Mountain States Beet Growers Marketing Association and the National Beet Growers Association offered this defense for the AAA:

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- One hundred and eighty delegates of the Berlin-Brandenburg Confessional Synod, one of the most influential opposition groups in the Protestant Church, voted unanimously today to make no compromise with Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, and his State supremacy decree issued Monday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4. -- Insomnia, 15 to 1, a filly formerly owned by the Greentree Stable, scored a half length victory at the Fair Grounds today largely through racing luck. The daughter of John P. Grier, now the property of Mose Goldblatt, was trailing Moratorium, the odds-on favorite, when the gelding bolted and ran out at the stretch turn.

City officials joined with industrial and civic leaders yesterday in starting a plan for a permanent safety council to integrate the municipality's efforts to cut the toll of accidents on the streets, in homes and in industry.

Broadening tendencies marked trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was the heaviest since last March 6. Domestic corporation bonds were carried much higher, the combined average for that group reaching a new high level for the year at 83.63, compared with the previous high point of 83.62, made on Jan. 26.

Holding an alumni team to one field goal and one foul in the first half, the St. John's University five recorded its second victory of the season in a one-sided game, 52 to 18, in the De Gray gymnasium last night.

Since it was selected nine days ago as the recently published book by an American author most likely to become a classic, "An Almanac for Moderns," by Donald Culross Peattie, has sold 1,309 copies, Putnam reports. This book received the gold medal of the Limited Editions Club at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria last week.

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Sibley Dow gave a dinner last night in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis. Their guests were General and Mrs.William Ottman, Mr. and Mrs. Chapin Marcus, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hammitt, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hungerford, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stevenson, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lounsbury, Mrs. Crawford Pope, Mrs. Baldwin H. Voss, Mrs. Walter Ford, John Morris, Colonel Edward Janche and Harry Gaines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Nineteen building trades unions which have been divided into two rival camps for two years have settled their differences and have agreed also upon a plan that will provide for continuance of building trades operations in cases where jurisdictional disputes occur.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the Congress of American Industry, declared that the widespread fears of economic collapse had spent themselves and had been succeeded by "the healing influences of world economic recovery."

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reiterated yesterday that the published report of an alleged agreement between the Italian Government and the Societa Italo Americana del Petrolio, the Italian subsidiary of his company, "is absolutely false in every respect."

Befitting this year of jubilee, the 1936 edition of the British Who's Who, which Macmillan will publish here on Dec. 10, opens on four pages rather than the customary two, devoted to the King and Queen and with the Duke and Duchess of Kent left out of the small portrait section to allow two pages for the Prince of Wales.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 4. -- The students and faculty of Swarthmore College, at the weekly assembly today, sat in silence as a "tribute of affection and respect" to Miss Ella Louise Kirk, a senior, who ended her life last night by throwing herself under a Pennsylvania Railroad train near the campus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, told the tri-district convention of anthracite miners today that he hoped for a new agreement with the hard coal operators by April 1, when the present contract covering the wages and terms of employment of 100,000 miners expires.

The last of the interclub team matches of the women's New York Primary Squash Racguets League went to Heights Casino yesterday on its home courts with a 4-1 victory over the Rockaway Hunting Club. The Cosmopolitan Club last week won the series, with a record of three successful matches and no defeats.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Secretary Wallace pictured the AAA today as a permanent institution regardless of the stand the Supreme Court may take on the constitutionality of its present structure.

The Woman's Christian Temperance Union of the State of New York will begin today a new war against cocktails and highballs on the "social drinking" front. The first assault will be in the form of advertisements in newspapers here and in Utica, Syracuse and Watertown.

"Ginger," with Jane Withers and Jackie Searle, will be shown, starting tomorrow and continuing through Sunday, on the children's matinee film program at the Lenox Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.

Public offering win be made today of a new issue of $6,000,000 of Marine Parkway Authority 4 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A, dated Dec. 1, 1935, and maturing on Dec. 1, 1960, by a banking group headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. The bonds win be priced at 99 1/2 and accrued interest.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Two mounted policemen with a number of foot constables on traffic duty, as far as this writer could see, constituted the whole force provided outside the Tottenham Hot Spur Club's soccer ground this afternoon to protect 10,000 German Nazis who, braving the warnings of the British Trades Union Council and other Laborite bodies, came to London to cheer their national soccer team at grips with England.
The leading forward passer in the National Football League is still Ed Danowski, one of the back-field mainstays of the New York Giants, according to official statistics released yesterday.

The Neediest Cases of New York City, for whom this appeal is made, can be helped effectively only by private charity. Their problems are so acute, their distress so severe, that they must have the helping hand, neighborly care, trained guidance, skilled medical attention and special service which only the private organizations can give.
ROME, Dec. 4. -- A royal decree masked Italy's financial situation with official secrecy tonight.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 5. -- Although the Chinese Government will not tolerate violations of the sovereign rights of the five northern provinces, local conditions and the wishes of the people are certain to play a large part in influencing the policies of the special administration to be established in Peiping by War Minister Ho Ying-ching as Nanking's representative.

On the second anniversary of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment the chairman of the State Liquor Authority, Mr. MULROONEY, has painted a picture of present conditions which will strike many observers as an accurate one. He finds a marked decline in bootlegging.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 (AP). -- The all-Southeastern football team for 1935, compiled by The Associated Press from the opinions of coaches and sports writers, presents an entirely new set of stars for this year's honor roll.

DAVID LAMSON'S "We Who Are About to Die" (Scribner's, $2.50) has been praised by no less an authority than Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing. It is a book about Condemned Row in California's San Quentin penitentiary, written by a sensitive person who lived in that row for thirteen months under sentence of death. Oddly enough, in view of the circumstances attendant upon Lamson's incarceration, it is an un-Dostoevskian, completely objective chronicle.

One of the letters accompanying a contribution to the Hundred Neediest Cases expressed the donors gratitude to THE NEW YORK TIMES for making it possible for her still to give a memory Christmas present to her father and mother. Were they living, she would at this season have given something to them in filial devotion.

Not without ferocious words or thoughts did many of us fill out that infamous "pink slip" early this year. All of us, that is the few of us, the select or proscribed scanty millions of the Income Tax Club, were tickled when the provision for this form of publicity, this titbit for snoopers, was yanked out of the Revenue Act of 1934.

Postponed from earlier in the week, "May Wine" opens tonight at the St. James Theatre, restoring Laurence Schwab to Broadway as a musical showman for the first time in three years. A musical play this one is called, with a score by Sigmund Romberg (but no chorus), lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d and a book adapted by Frank Mandel from "The Happy Alienist," a novel by Wallace Smith and Eric von Stroheim.

The Soviet American Securities Corporation announced yesterday the receipt from the Bank of Foreign Trade of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics of serial numbers drawn for redeeming at par 10 per cent of the 10 per cent Soviet Government Bond issue due in 1942, of which 1,000,000 gold rubles was issued in the United States.

The reported advocacy by President Roosevelt of interest rates as low as 3 1/2 per cent on farm mortgages was received with mixed feelings yesterday by executives of insurance companies which hold the obligations, according to The Associated Press.

An old prayer-book held the centre of attention last night when rare-book dealers and collectors assembled at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., to bid on first editions of many of the most famous books in English literature and other rarities collected by the late Seth Sprague Terry and his son, Ward E. Terry.

The Black Diamond Steamship Corporation tendered its resignation yesterday as a member of the American Steamship Owners Association on the ground that the association had failed to achieve anything in the form of a ship subsidy program and had been lax in its efforts in support of lines operating in the unprotected trades.
Residential properties made up the bulk of the Bronx realty turnover reported yesterday.

Andrew Ponzi, world champion pocket billiard player, got an order yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Shientag requiring the National Billiard Association of America and the New York Hotels Statler Company to show cause tomorrow why they should not be restrained from conducting a championship tournament at the Hotel Pennsylvania from Dec. 9 to Dec. 21.

Following negotiations covering several months between the Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, and the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., both parties will announce today a comprehensive readjustment plan proposed to the holders of $69,372,900 of dollar bonds of the province, offering to those holders readjustment bonds with lower interest rates but with improved security in place of their present bonds.

While police of eight States were watching railroad and bus terminals last night for a mother, who with two children, both stricken with scarlet fever, had disappeared from St. Barnabas House, 304 Mulberry Street, during the afternoon, all three were found sitting in the Midtown Bus Terminal, 143 West Forty-third Street, where they had been for more than five hours.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4 (AP). -- Bloomfield High School's football team, undefeated, untied and un-scored-on in nine contests this Fall, again ranks as the champion of champions of New Jersey school-boys.

Buying interest in railway shares yesterday eclipsed that in other sections of the stock list, with the market having its busiest day in more than a week. The demand reached its climax in the final hour, when the demonstration in railway issues probably was the greatest in several years.

Pig iron production in November, according to The Iron Age, totaled 2,065,913 tons, or 68,864 tons a day, compared with 1,978,411 tons, or 63,820 tons daily, in October. The gain, in terms of daily rate, was 7.9 per cent. Furnaces in blast on Dec. 1 numbered 122, as against 116 NOV. 1, a net increase of 6.

BALDWIN, L.I., Dec. 4. -- Baldwin High School's football squad participated in its last workout on Church Street Field today prior to its departure tomorrow morning for Petersburg, Vs., where Coach George Craig's forces will face Petersburg High on Saturday in the second post-season gridiron encounter between the schools.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The British Government has received from Secretary Hull the semi-annual reminder of the war debt installment, due Dec. 15, with a demand for payment. The customary reply will be sent within a few days, to the effect that under the circumstances the British Government will not pay.

From Sheepshead Bay to Manasquan, ninety miles down the Jersey coast, word is being spread that the codfish is on in earnest, and those hardy individuals who revel in the rough going and who scorn the biting wintry winds are making the most of it.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

SO James Emory Foxx, the Maryland melon magnate, served notice that any ball club owner who bought him from Connie Mack could add in a salary argument with James to come later. That's as good a way as any to help discourage the sale. Maybe James wants to stay in Shibe Park. And maybe he will have to.

The action of the rails in rising yesterday to new high levels for the year, while industrial stocks were lagging, led brokers to ponder on the outlook for the market as a whole. If the industrials had shown more vigor in rallying from their recent decline, the market experts would have concluded that the downward movement had run its course.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4. -- The first award of the Columbia Lion, an honor which is to be conferred annually by the Affiliated Columbia University Alumni Clubs of New Jersey, was made at the Newark Athletic Club tonight, when a bronze sculpture of the university's lion was presented to Dr. Harold Clayton Urey, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia.

The first week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning Dec. 16, will mark the debut not only of the new management headed by Edward Johnson but of eleven new singers and of the American Ballet and its ballet master, George Balanchine, as members of the company.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association will not be officially represented at the industrial conference called for next Monday in Washington by Major George L. Berry, although the board of the organization has taken no action on the question, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the association.
Performing in a fashion which bespoke potential power, the Fordham University basketball team turned back an alumni quintet, 36 to 20, last night in the college gymnasium.

There was a large and brilliant assemblage at the reception and private view of the exhibition of modern Peruvian art by Elena and Victoria Izcue, and of pre-Inca textiles and ceramics, in the galleries of the Fuller Building, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- According to persons who have talked with President Roosevelt, a budget of about $5,000,000,000 for the 1936-1937 fiscal years is now considered the "limit" that he will suggest to Congress.

Officials of the Winter Olympic Games state that there will be entries from twenty-one different countries in the figure skating championships. This means that with most of the entries consisting of full teams of four-men singles skaters, four-women singles, and two pair, the largest number of figure skaters ever to meet in competition will gather in Garmisch-Partenkirchen in February.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has devoted considerable space to reporting the trials and convictions of those usurers who prey upon the needy. Little has been said, however, with respect to the outstanding usurer in the city today, our city government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- At 5:32 P.M. tomorrow, Eastern standard time, residents of the United States will mark the beginning of the third year of relegalized liquor. The anniversary finds the drys diligently working to bring back prohibition, while government tax receipts record a steadily growing consumption of alcoholic drinks.

Five letters alleged to have been sent by Mrs. Hilda Peterson, wife of the fugitive William F. Peterson, fake broker, to a woman who later lost about $5,000 in Peterson's "get-rich-quick" stock promotion scheme were read in General Sessions yesterday at the trial of Mrs. Peterson and two men on a larceny indictment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The United States delegation to the London naval conference has instructions dealing only with technical naval questions and not with political problems. Should political issues, such as those involving international relationships in the Far East, be injected into the conference, this government would have to reach decisions that have not been considered.

The Albany-New York motor boat marathon, the grueling 129 3/4-mile grind on the Hudson River, will be staged next year on Sunday, May 10, it was announced last night at the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association in the Hotel Lexington.

Dry goods mills were considerably cheered this week by reports of the low stocks in the hands of wholesalers. A year ago, they pointed out, heavy jobber stocks of cold-weather goods tied up capital and prevented the wholesalers from operating on Spring lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Caught in a thirty-mile cross wind after reducing speed for a glide into Bolling Field, Major George E. Rice and Lieutenant Harry H. Geoffrey of Mitchel Field, L.I., were killed this morning when their observation plane crashed into a ravine on the edge of the field.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Charges that agents of the Securities and Exchange Commission "threatened and browbeat" witnesses in their quest for evidence were made by attorneys for Michael J. Meehan, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Curb Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, at a hearing today on charges that he, with others, created a "false activity" on the New York Curb in Bellanca Aircraft stocks.
College students, business and professional men and women, rich and poor, contributed $11,178.45 yesterday for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases.

Coincident with the announcement by the Fashion Originators Guild of America that it plans to issue shortly more detailed pledges for retailer signatures, Albert M. Post, executive director, declared yesterday that the guild has nothing to do with retail price-fixing or the establishing of retail markups.

ROME, Dec. 4. -- The proposed embargo on oil exports to Italy still is the chief topic of conversation here, but much of the tenseness has been taken out of the situation by the declaration by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes that he had not banned oil exports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Total expenditures of $65,640,619 in October were listed in the monthly report to Congress issued today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. This compared with expenditures of $54,118,581 in the preceding month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The intense interest being displayed by all sorts of people in the time and place of the Republican National Convention of 1936 is a surprise even to the party managers. The Rhode Island by-election last August, certain indicated trends at the November polls and straw ballots now in progress are partly responsible.

PARIS, Dec. 4. -- Premier Pierre Laval's chances for surviving the debate on the Fascist leagues, which will be resumed tomorrow and possibly continued until Friday, were given by experts of the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon as at best slight.

A large upper Manhattan housing property was acquired yesterday by Frederick Brown, who purchased the six-story elevator building at the northeast corner of 215th Street and Indian Hill Road. The house is on a plot 150 by 100 feet, near Seaman Avenue, and overlooks Baker Field and the Harlem River.

The committee for $244,000,000 of Missouri Pacific Railroad first and refunding 5 per cent bonds, headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, announced yesterday in a letter to holders of these securities that it would press court action to end a situation which gives J.P. Morgan Co. power to veto any plan of reorganization put forward for the company.

Plans to rush emergency rations to Antarctica for Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollock-Kenyon, his pilot, whose radio failed on their transantarctic flight Nov. 23 and who have not been heard from since, were announced last night by F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History.
The will of Mrs. Helen Richards Stetson, widow of the Rev. Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The proponents of better housing have won national attention. America is calling for a national housing policy. There is no issue at all as to whether the Federal Government can act. The issue is how should it act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Thomas N. McCarter, head of the Edison Electric Institute, took the stand today as the first witness against two former Internal Revenue Bureau officials and a New York tax consultant, charged with conspiring to divulge income tax information.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 4. -- A new autonomy outbreak, the fourth of its kind here, is likely tomorrow, and the authorities will not suppress it "if it is found to be genuine and unsupported by Japanese influence," it was learned on the highest authority tonight.

ATHENS, Dec. 4. -- Full settlement of the long-standing feud which made Crete anti-monarchist because the majority of the population is Venizelist seems near as a result of King George's amnesty to the rebels of the March outbreak and the declaration by former Premier Eleutherios Venizelos that he would return to Crete promptly.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Smaller receipts of hogs brought all classes of buyers into the market here today, and prices were steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher, compared with the general trade yesterday, with some sales regarded as up 15 cents.

Influenced by easier foreign markets and the sale of January contracts for between 10,000 and 15,000 bales by houses doing government business, prices on the Cotton Exchange here were set back yesterday and closed with losses of 9 to 19 points.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Starting a "new crusade" for prohibition, the Anti-Saloon League of America called upon President Roosevelt tonight to abolish the use of intoxicants at all White House and public functions and, as leader of the repeal movement which promised the saloon would not return, to condemn "publicly and emphatically the violation of this pledge."

MIDWAY ISLANDS, Dec. 4. -- Homeward bound on the last quarter of her history-making flight across the Pacific Ocean and back again within fifteen days, the China Clipper left the Pan American Airways ocean airbase here for Honolulu en route to Alameda, Calif., at 6:12 A.M. [1:12 P.M., Eastern standard time].

Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, referred to the needs of the voluntary hospitals of this city as "a great civic problem" in a radio address delivered last night in behalf of the campaign for $2,000,000 being conducted by the United Hospitals Campaign Committee.

Charles Shankroff, the realty man who has a $50,000 slander suit pending against Mayor La Guardia on the charge that the Mayor called him a "bum," appeared yesterday at a hearing of the Public Service Commission into the rates charged by the Jamaica Water Supply Company and was rebuffed by the commissioner and company officials when he repeatedly asserted his right as an individual to investigate the company's books.

Miss Dorothy Forbes of the Broadwood A.C., Philadelphia, and a Middle Atlantic A.A.U. champion, featured the swimming meet in the London Terrace pool last night by scoring in the women's 100-yard back-stroke event. She won from Miss Jean Kolinski, W.S.A. entrant, Miss Jeanne Laupheimer of the Dragon Club finishing third.

In a setting reminiscent of old-time regimental festivities of the Russian Imperial Guards, a dinner dance and entertainment was held last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis to aid the invalids of the Russian Imperial Army and their destitute dependents now living in this country.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were stimulated today by the quick closing of the two big government loans, which were heavily subscribed. British funds were particularly strong, gaining further. In the foreign section a fresh outbreak occurred in speculative activity in Mexican bonds following the British committee's advice to Mexican bondholders not to sell.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4. -- Frank P. Walsh of New York, veteran of Thomas J. Mooney's legal staff and chief of counsel in the present habeas corpus hearing here, washed his hands today of further responsibility in the hearing, throwing the proceedings into confusion.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4. -- Mrs. Margaret Emerson was hostess to twelve persons informally for luncheon today at her villa and to fourteen persons tonight at dinner.

Reductions in automobile deaths in eighty-six cities of the country over a four-week period and a fifty-two-week period, as compared with a year ago, were reported yesterday by the Bureau of the Census of the United States Department of Commerce.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4. -- Calling for a 50 per cent increase in Soviet grain production within the next three or four years in view of the growth in population -- estimated at 3,000,000 annually -- Joseph Stalin addressed the congress of the country's combine operators in Moscow last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- An appropriation to establish a transatlantic air mail service will be asked of Congress at the next session, Postmaster General Farley announced today. He said that he hoped there would be an American air line across the Atlantic to match the Pan American service now operating over the Pacific.
A song-conscious city pondered yesterday the probability that a municipal melody with words to match would soon grace the official archives and bring glory to a possibly obscure bard.

A new social frontier, "an effective equivalent of the old physical frontier" with its golden opportunities, "lies ready at our hands for our occupation, development and enjoyment," according to Ralph E. Flanders, retiring president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, in his presidential address at the annual dinner of the society, held at the Hotel Astor last night.

Nelson B. Clark, 63 years old, former Massachusetts politician and chemical manufacturer, spent most of yesterday on the witness stand in General Sessions in his defense on the charge that he helped four gunmen, now in the death house at Sing Sing for a hold-up murder, to prepare for another hold-up last Dec. 15.
HULL, Que., Dec. 4 (AP). -- A helpless bank employe, bound and gagged, was slain today by robbers who then escaped with $15,000 in bills of the Banque Provinciale du Canada.

ALBANY, Dec. 4. -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education, decided today that eight continuation school teachers in New York City were entitled to become "administrative assistants" in positions which they have been holding as "unassigned teachers."

The Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of York, is due tonight from England on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by Mrs. Temple. He will make a five-week tour in this country. The liner, delayed by storms, may not dock until tomorrow.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Germany, in effect, repudiated today her Reichsmark notes circulating abroad by prohibiting their reimportation into Germany and their use within Germany except under certain strict limitations that reduce the notes to a small fraction of their value.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Attacking the low "service charges" of the Erie and the Pennsylvania Railways for truck freight delivery in New York City, the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to compel the rail carriers to submit evidence as to the costs.
Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney investigating racketeering in Manhattan, caused the seizure yesterday of books and records of the Flour Truckmen's Association, Inc.

An English loan to Italy, sufficient in size to clear up present Italian exchange difficulties and relieve her of other pressing financial problems, is a prime consideration in current peace negotiations, according to information disclosed yesterday by bankers, exporters and credit men attending the regular monthly round-table discussion of foreign credit and exchange problems sponsored by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 4. -- An indication that the administration might again put agricultural legislation before Congress at the coming session was given here today after President Roosevelt conferred for an hour with a delegation of farmers from Meriwether County, where this town is situated, and from adjacent Pike County.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 4 (AP). -- The Three Musketeers of Nebraska's crack back field -- Lloyd Cardwell, Sam Francis and Jerry LaNoue -- travel together on The Associated Press Big Six Conference all-star football team, selected by coaches, sports writers and other authorities.

DETROIT, Dec. 4. -- Speaking on "What of Tomorrow?" before the Town Hall today Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, declared that those who opposed the policies of the administration had no alternative proposals except a return to the old order, and that inevitable disaster lay in that direction.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The turning point in the Italo-Ethiopian dispute was reached today, London learns, when Premier Laval of France communicated to Ambassador Vittorio Cerruti the principal points in a proposal for settlement of the conflict in Africa.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Four men, one a close political associate of the late Senator Huey P. Long, and two officials of a quarry company which did a large business with the Louisiana Highway Department, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for alleged conspiracy to defeat income-tax payments.

In the development of aviation and chemistry for national defense this country is on a parity with, if not superior to, other nations, according to testimony yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hotel before the Congressional committee studying the operation of patent laws.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- In a jovial mood as he greeted more than fifty reporters crowded around his desk today in the Postoffice Department, Chairman Farley said he was "thoroughly in accord with the President's views" on Senator Norris, Republican, of Nebraska.

ON BOARD THE CHINA CLIPPER, Dec. 4. -- The flying boat China Clipper made the flight from Midway Islands to Honolulu today in exactly nine hours and forty-five minutes, or at an average speed of 141 miles an hour. We are now at Honolulu in forty-six hours nineteen minutes' flying time out of Manila, and are scheduled to depart for San Francisco in twenty-four hours.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Admiral Osamu Nagano, Japan's chief delegate to the international naval conference opening next week, said today his country wanted to economize on naval armaments and expressed the belief that large offensive-type cruisers should be abolished.

The dextrous hand of Mike Jacobs, premier boxing promoter of the post-prosperity era, appeared yesterday in the arrangements for the forthcoming international title bridge match -- to the vast astonishment of the French team that arrived Tuesday night after earning the right to oppose America's Four Aces by its victory in the European championship play at Brussels last June.
Mrs. Hollis B. Shaw, who as a dancer is known professionally as Lisa Parnova, stepped out of her role as a Portia yesterday, after losing a divorce case in which she had appeared as her own lawyer.
With six clubs competing, Group 2 play started in the New York division of the Metropolitan League's Class C squash racquets tournament last night.

For some time we have been hearing about a semi-official but quite secret estimate of unemployment that various Federal agencies have been using for their own guidance. This estimate, originally prepared for the President's "Committee on Economic Security," and since continued, has now been made public.

COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Dec. 4. -- A rising urge to score an upset of upsets Saturday by checking the Rose Bowl-bound Southern Methodist University football machine was encouraged tonight at Texas A. and M. College.

All insurance companies licensed to do business in more than three States should be examined through the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners, with proper representation for the States concerned, it was decided yesterday at the closing sessions of the midyear meeting of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list Anaconda Copper Mining Company 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due on Oct. 1, 1950.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Regional WPA Director John Buckley Bryan at White Plains instructed Ray K. Masters, Rockland County WPA head, today, to conduct an investigation to learn why skilled brickyard workers now on WPA payrolls refuse to go to work for the De Noyelles Brick Company here at wages double those of the WPA.

The Bronx Zoo let it be known yesterday that it is being imposed upon. By pairs and by platoons, baldpates, pintails, mallards and just plain black ducks are flying to the open lakes of the park and bringing their friends with them. There were about 1,400 visiting ducks yesterday afternoon, and there are more now.

Frigid winds sweeping east from the Mississippi Valley struck New York yesterday and forced the mercury here down to 15 degrees above zero at 7 P.M. This is five degrees above the low record for the day set in 1906.

Miss Marion Lloyd defeated Miss Dorothy Locke in a fence-off for premier honors in the women's invitation fencing competition held last night at the Salle d'Arms Vines. The score was 5 -- 3. Both are from the home club.

It became known yesterday that Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh has just purchased, for its permanent collection, a painting in the Carnegie International Exhibition, which closes next Sunday. The canvas thus honored is by the wellknown New York artist, Leon Kroll.
Three suggestions entirely new in the conduct of racing by the New York Yacht Club were embodied in the report of the race committee which was received yesterday by club members.

IMPERIAL ETHIOPIAN HEADQUARTERS, Dessye, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Emperor Halle Selassie, a close adviser said today, will leave Dessye within a few days, going overland to the north or flying back to Addis Ababa. In any case, it was learned, he will not proceed more than fifty miles toward the northern battle front, probably going to Magdala to meet his three northern commanders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- More than half of the Business Advisory Council, made up of leading business men from all parts of the country, resigned today under a plan of "rotating personnel" announced by Secretary Roper at the close of the council's final meeting of the year.

Over the protests of the Fifth Avenue Association, the Retail Dry Goods Association and other business groups, Mayor La Guardia signed four bills yesterday extending the city's emergency relief taxes from the end of this year to June 30, 1936.
HERSHEY Pa., Dec. 4 (AP). -- The New York Rovers tied Hershey for first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight, winning their game, 3 to 2.

ROME, Dec. 4. -- King Victor Emmanuel canceled today the traditional New Year's reception to diplomats and governmental officials. He thus will avoid shaking hands with the Ambassadors of sanctionist countries. Fascists construed this and the donation of the royal wedding rings as a definite effort to show the public that the King approves the invasion of Ethiopia and Italy's defense against League of Nations penalties.

Thirteen additional department stores have joined in the efforts of the WPA in this city to transfer as many WPA employes as possible to jobs in private industry and business, Major Wilfred E. Boughton, head of the WPA industrial employment bureau, announced yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 4. -- Ethiopia is ready with her peace formula whenever a request for it comes through the proper channels. It was worked out mainly by Lidj Sirouk Herrouy, son of the Foreign Minister, and himself a Foreign Office assistant, and was tentatively approved by the Emperor before his departure for the front.

The National Labor Relations Board served a complaint yesterday on The Associated Press alleging violation of the National Labor Relations Act because of the discharge by the news agency of Morris Watson, vice president of the American Newspaper Guild.

Eben S. Abbott, chief engineer of the Ward Liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 135 lives, got into a life-boat while passengers were wandering about the vessel not knowing what to do or where to go, it was testified yesterday in Federal court.

As a result of the improvement in operations, employment in the steel industry in October showed a gain of more than 55,000 persons over the total for October, 1934, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- There apparently are now two plans in the field for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian war.
Two investment trusts, the Lehman Corporation and Selected Industries, Inc., declared yesterday larger distributions for shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The $27,000,000 work relief fine arts program, designed to provide jobs for unemployed musicians, actors, artists and writers, will not come to a peak until January, and the remainder of the white-collar program, which is expected to employ about 600,000 persons, probably will not get fully under way until later.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Dec. 4. -- Success once more rewarded the efforts of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, challenger for the world championship at chess, when he finished the twenty-sixth game of his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris today and defeated the champion for the second time in a row.

The National Association of Manufacturers, the outstanding body in formulating industrial policy in this country, opened its annual convention at the Commodore Hotel yesterday with an all-day series of addresses, declaring industry is now in politics to rid the United States of the New Deal.

Secretary HULL denied with emphasis yesterday that the policy of our Government in the matter of neutrality had been "inconsistent." This seemingly refers to the inability of the press correspondents last week to "understand" what Secretary ICKES said about oil and its possible embargo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Figures indicating Japan had passed the United States in October trade with China met with various interpretations today in government circles.

Franco Georgetti, popular Italian cyclist, last night withdrew from the fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden, reducing the field of surviving teams to eleven. Fifteen got off the starting mark last Sunday night.

The Railroad Credit Corporation received $881,115 of loan repayments in November, bringing cash receipts for the month to $910,586. The corporation distributed a liquidating dividend of $2,207,655 -- its twenty-second -- to the loan pool contributors on Nov. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- Clearing the way for the increased control that the new Federal Reserve Board will assume on Feb. 1, the present Board of Governors today limited the reappointment of chairmen and deputy chairmen of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks to two-month terms.

Efforts of "certain outside interests to capture the management and control of Consumers Research, Inc., for the dissemination of political propaganda" were charged yesterday by Edward Garfield of 25 West Forty-fourth Street, counsel for the concern, to be "at the bottom of the so-called strike" at the Consumers Research plant, situated near Washington, N.J.

Steel production has continued to improve and is now at 57 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from last week. The Iron Age said yesterday in its weekly summary. The rate is the highest since the third week in June, 1934, when production was artificially stimulated by forward buying, prior to the effective date of a price increase.

The General Sessions trial of three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company for publishing an alleged false statement of the company's assets in January, 1933, continued yesterday with one of the defendants, Frederic J. Fuller, on the stand for the third day. Mr. Fuller was president of the company for about eight months before its collapse in August, 1933.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Louis Haddad and Mrs. Eliot Evans of Chicago won the national mixed pair championship in the American Bridge League's Winter tournament today, outdistancing the field of forty-five teams and leading the runners-up by more than 30 match points.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- The Voelkischer Beobachter, the Nazi party's official organ, carries a bitter attack on Father Assmann, an American Jesuit priest, declaring that he was recently expelled from Germany.

Colonel A. Pearson Hoover of the contracting firm of G. Richard Davis will discuss "Tax Limitation on Real Estate" at a luncheon meeting of the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York today at 12:30 P.M. in the Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Bids were requested today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on sixty-eight municipal security issues including twenty-two issues of New York City having a principal amount of $6,154,000. The issues offered cover municipalities in fifteen States and involve a total principal amount of $13,037,100.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- With another Presidential campaign year only twenty-seven days away, Chairman James A. Farley today called the Democratic National Committee to meet here the second week in January, either the 7th or 8th, to choose the place for the party's next national convention.

Douglas Vought, member of the Roosevelt committee representing holders of $77,000,000 of defaulted S.W. Straus Co bonds, denied yesterday that his committee had been dilatory in reorganizing the forty-seven properties it controlled or that it had refused arbitrarily to consider plans put forward by trustees.

ELKTON, Md., Dec. 4 (AP). -- Two police officers, who participated in the arrest and resultant handcuffing of Ghaffar Khan Djalal, Iranian Minister to the United States, were fined $25 and costs each tonight on a charge of common assault.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. Dec. 4. -- Rhode Island, which brought the Republican elephant back to life by an unexpected victory at a special Congressional election in August, continues to show a marked anti-New Deal trend, in the opinion of most impartial observers.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 4. -- Gerlogubi in addition to Gorahai has been evacuated by the Italians but the Ethiopians have not occupied the towns, according to a report from Ras Nasibu, commander in that area.

Sweeping through five matches with the Bayside Tennis Club the New York Athletic Club registered a 5-0 victory on the Winged Foot courts last night and remained the only unbeaten team in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 4. -- More skirmishes were reported today in the Tembein region and in front of Makale, showing that unusual activity, probably leading toward a decisive battle, continues unabated.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee expended $2,654,500 for the relief of the Jews of Germany and Eastern Europe from the Spring of 1933 to September, 1935, it was revealed in the committee's 1934 report made public yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 4. -- The Italo-Ethiopian war has reached a virtual stalemate, it appears here. After penetrating the fog of the conflicting communiques from Rome and Addis Ababa the situation seems to be about the same as it was at the beginning of the war, with firm Italian positions at Adowa and Ualual.

The threatened strike of 700 musicians employed on the WPA music project in this city was settled yesterday and the action ratified by the membership of Local 802 of the Musicians Union, which issued the strike order. The strike was to have gone into effect this morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP). -- A constitutional amendment to permit the setting up of a new and more extensive NRA was urged today in a joint statement signed by more than 100 Catholic leaders.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 (AP). -- The Catholic Review, official organ of the Archdiocese of Baltimore, says that Catholics are expressing "deep regret" that the University of Notre Dame is preparing to give President Roosevelt an honorary degree.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Announcement late yesterday by the Canadian Government that it would attempt to dispose of part of its exportable surplus of wheat started today a selling movement in North American markets, which carried the near-by deliveries to new low marks on the current downturn.

Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing has been associated with Theodore Epstein, racing magazine publisher who was arrested Tuesday in connection with the State's drive on tipster racketeering, in the publication of a magazine called Prison Life Stories, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Preliminary consideration was given today by Secretary Hull, at a conference with a number of his advisers in the State Department, to the formulation of neutrality legislation that would be recommended to Congress this Winter.

Zlatko Balokovic, the Croatian violinist who attracted attention at his debut here eleven years ago by giving sixteen consecutive recitals, returned to the local concert platform last night in Carnegie Hall after an absence of seven seasons. His reappearance was hailed by a large audience which applauded him lustily after every number.

Prices of futures were generally higher in the commodity markets here yesterday, with interest centred in cocoa. Rye, eggs and rubber advanced in the cash market, with wheat, corn, oats, tin, cotton and raw sugar lower. Raw sugar lost 30 points to close at 3.10 cents a pound, the lowest cash price since March 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The total of unemployed persons was 10,915,000 in the United States in September, according to figures made public today by Robert R. Nathan, formerly consultant on unemployment statistics for the Committee on Economic Security.

The way to a man's heart may be through his stomach, but the way to his money, the Police Department says, is through a subway seat. This information is contained in a list of nineteen suggestions issued yesterday to men and women for safeguarding their money in public during the Christmas rush.

With even greater enthusiasm than his original appointment was received three years ago on Rose Hill, the students of Fordham yesterday hailed the news that Jimmy Crowley had been retained as head football coach of the Maroon for another three-year term.

Mayor LA GUARDIA wants an official anthem for New York City and has suggested a prize competition. There are enough gifted musicians and librettists, employed and unemployed, to provide the city with a fine hymn, but in all candor it must be stated that the usual result of anthem competitions is pretty awful.
BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Prices on the Boerse became slightly firmer today after a weak opening. Activity was again limited, however.

I am afraid that Austin Purves, director of the Art School of Cooper Union, who recently pronounced the art teaching in our city high schools "fundamentally unsound," based his conclusions upon insufficient evidence, for he visited, according to Forest Grant, director of art in the high schools, only three of nearly half a hundred schools.

John F. Patterson, 22-year-old New York University student, leaped to his death from a window of Washington Square College, 100 Washington Square East, shortly after 2 P.M. yesterday. The youth's body was impaled on the pickets of an iron fence in the rear court.

Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, who is investigating racketeering in Manhattan, made a new thrust yesterday against unlicensed loan sharks charging usurious interest rates. This time he corralled six prisoners, who were held in an aggregate of $44,000 bail by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

A general recovery in earnings is reflected in a report on railroad operations for October and the first ten months of the year issued by the Association of American Railroads yesterday. The statement is based on returns by 145 Class I railroads operating 237,757 miles of line.

The $100,000,000 of convertible bonds which the Great Northern Railway proposes to issue to refund a 105,800,000 bond maturity on next July 1 would be offered to stockholders in She ratio of one $1,000 bond for each twenty-five shares held, according to plans under consideration by the company's directors.

Problems affecting the automobile owner, operator and pedestrian were presented yesterday from many angles at the first of a series of public hearings to be conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Automobile Insurance and Safety, in the Bronx County building, 161st Street and Grand Concourse.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Viscount Monsell of Evesham, First Lord of the British Admiralty, will preside at the naval conference opening Monday, it was disclosed today.

There would be general support in England for a real attempt to review colonial mandates, according to Aylmer Vallance, editor of The London News Chronicle, who spoke yesterday on "The British Position in the Ethiopian Crisis" at a luncheon of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents at the Hotel Lombardy.

Colleges throughout the country have welcomed increased interest in football this year, especially as reflected in mounting box-office receipts, but the problem of confining spectators' enthusiasm to the stands has become an acute and critical issue.

The Roosevelt administration "has not only saved the country from an utter collapse but it has brought the country well along the road to recovery and prosperity," James A. Farley, Postmaster General, said yesterday at the dedication of the new $11,500,000 postoffice annex on Ninth Avenue between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP). -- If First-Baseman Jimmy Foxx has been sold to the Chicago White Sox by the Athletics, it's all news to Manager Jimmy Dykes of the Chicago team.

Some brokers are advising their clients to take profits on stocks this year, on the ground that income taxes are likely to be higher in the future than they ever have been. This advice may result in heavy realizing sales before the end of the month.

A toy shortage this holiday season, due to delayed buying and a rush of eleventh-hour orders which manufacturers cannot fill, was reported yesterday by W.A. Coventry, head of the Grey Iron Casting Company and president of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States of America, at the opening of the organization's annual convention at the Hotel McAlpin.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities in the United States in the five days ended on Wednesday totaled $5,441,745,000, compared with $4,511,624,000 in the same week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The increase was 20.6 per cent, compared with one of 31 per cent in the preceding week.
A plan for the healing of the century-old schism in the Methodist Episcopal Church has finally been approved by accredited representatives of the three great divisions, it was learned here yesterday.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed a rise of 17 per cent for the week ended Nov. 30, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is the largest since the week ended Sept. 28, when there was an increase of 20 per cent.
