The political tactics to be followed by industry in the 1936 Presidential campaign to defeat "the new economic order proclaimed by President Roosevelt," were outlined here yesterday before 1,000 leading industrialists at the annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Assessments paid by banks to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation may be deducted as ordinary and necessary business expenses for Federal income tax purposes, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Fall and Winter seasons, when baseball players go hunting, are no holiday for Branch Rickey, general manager of the Cardinals and their farm "chain."

When a rare copy of that landmark of literature, Milton's "Paradise Lost," came up at auction last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., the bidding reached $17,500 before the volume passed into the hands of a new owner, Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach.

The new three-story Georgian building of the American Federation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, was formally opened yesterday afternoon when President Roosevelt, who is honorary president of the foundation, telephoned his best wishes from Warm Springs, Ga.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 5. -- A general manufacturers sales tax to displace the processing taxes of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, if the Supreme Court should hold the latter unconstitutional, was discussed as a possibility today by Senator George in a talk with newspaper men, following a conference with President Roosevelt which lasted more than an hour.

W.A. Kimbel of Ardsley, defending titleholder, gained the fianl round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association veterans championship at the Heights Casino yesterday, along with H.E. Mills of the University Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Secretary Morgenthau today characterized the $4,520,000,000 cash subscriptions to the Treasury's offering of $900,000,000 in bonds and notes to be issued on Dec. 15 as indicative of the high credit standing of the government and as entirely satisfactory to his department.

William F. Peterson, 53-year-old fugitice bogus stock broker, deposited $156,000 in four months early this year in the Guaranty Trust Company's Fifth Avenue branch, it was brought out yesterday at the General Sessions trial of his wife, Hilda, 38, and two men on a larceny indictment.

A dissenting voice was raised yesterday to the University of California proposal that it play its Madison Square Garden game with New York University on Dec. 18 without a centre tap. The Golden Bears, blithely ignoring national rules, have been engaging in court contests on the Coast for several seasons without a jump ball.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The text of those portions of Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare's speech in the House of Commons today covering both the African and Asiatic situations is as follows:

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, departing tonight for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremerhaven, will have among her passengers Dr. Erich von Prittwitz und Gaffron, brother of the former German Ambassador here, who is returning to Germany after attending the Carnegie celebrations; the Baroness Antonia Hatvany, Herman Winckler, German industrialist, and the following others:
The Marx Brothers' new picture, "A Night at the Opera," starts an engagement today at the Capitol.

Walter Duranty, whose book "I Write As I Please" is just going into its sixth edition with a total of 30,000 copies printed, is calling the novel on which he is now at work "Mud and Blood." Simon Schuster expect to be the publishers.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 5. -- War Minister Ho Ying-ching, Nanking's emissary who has been attempting negotiations to avert the autonomy or independence of North China, was brusquely told this afternoon by the Japanese military to leave Peiping immediately.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 5. -- The Australian Government has informed President Roosevelt that the Commonwealth is cooperating with Great Britain in preparing an expedition to the Antarctic to search for Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, pilot of the plane in which the two men flew into the unknown on Nov. 23.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- More than half of 4,700 religious leaders of the country who replied to a questionnaire sent out by the National Religion and Labor Foundation early in 1935 pledged themselves to work for social ownership of public utilities and basic industries, Dr. Willard E. Uphaus, executive secretary, announced today.
Here's the sequel to the story of the shaving customer who laughed so hard at the barber's jokes that he grabbed the razor and cut himself.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange held firm today under the influence of the success of the new government loans, in which dealings started. The improved international outlook also added to the more optimistic views.

GENEVA, Dec. 5. -- Strong recommendations from all sides that the League of Nations integrate permanently all refugee work were made to the committee of experts which concluded yesterday its hearings on this subject. The committee will draft recommendations, hoping to have them ready for the January meeting of the League council.

The 1935 volume of Butler Brothers, largest wholesale house in the country, will amount to about $68,000,000, an approximate gain of 50 per cent over the 1932 figure, it was made known yesterday in connection with a statement issued by F.S. Cunningham, president.

The Giants, with two of the finest centres in the National Football, League in Mel Hein of Washington State and Johnny Del Isola of Fordham fame, will split their great combination Sunday in order to make the most possible use of these two great linemen.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in directing the Chase National Bank as depository of twelve mortgages for which certificates were sold by the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Company to deliver the mortgages to the Mortgage Commission upheld yesterday the constitutionality of an important section of the Mortgage Commisison Law.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5. -- The New York Americans upset the mighty Maroons of Montreal tonight in a somewhat ragged National Hockey League game that saw the Americans stand off a closing Maroon drive to win, 2 -- 1, and go into a third place tie with the Canadiens in the International Group.

Three men were wounded, two seriously, in a shooting affray led by a former policeman yesterday afternoon at Morningside Avenue and 123d Street. A patrolman returning home off duty wounded the fleeing former policeman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Moving to ease some of the drastic provisions of the new Potato Control Law, the AAA increased the growers' automatic tax-free allotment today from five to fifty bushels.

The program given last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was one of the most interesting, and in point of performance most exciting that Mr. Klemperer has provided his audience this season. It was a curiously assorted list, which worked out surprisingly well, with the assistance of Mme. Lotte Lehmann as soloist.

The Harlem Market Company, Ltd., of 1,190 First Avenue, applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction to prevent city officials from continuing an alleged conspiracy to compel produce merchants to move from Harlem Market to the municipally owned Bronx Terminal Market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Democratic leaders are concerned over the effect of reports that Philadelphia has been agreed upon as the site of the 1936 national convention. They are fearful that Chicago, Cleveland, St. Louis and Kansas City, the other contenders, may be deterred from making serious efforts to obtain the convention.
The city of Denver will enter the market on Dec. 17 with a new issue of $750,000 of public works bonds, maturing from 1946 to 1975. Bidders are to name interest not exceeding 3 per cent.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 (AP). -- Tulane University entered the market for a new football coach today.

President Roosevelt and his New Deal policies have made a slight gain in the latest returns in the nation-wide poll of The Literary Digest, but they still trail in thirteen States and are getting a majority of votes in only five, it was announced yesterday.
Despite a late rally by Eastern forces, intersectional honors for the 1935 football season belong to the Middle West and Southwest.
LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 5. -- Nebraskans, 300,000 of them, have taken literally President Roosevelt's advice to attempt to keep George W. Norris in the Senate, George W. Kline said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Two of its outstanding relay events, the Harvard-Yale and Andover-Exeter team races, will be missing from the famous Boston A. A. track and field meet Feb. 8.

A policy of "self-regulation" for industry in conformance with definite standards authorized by permissive rather than prohibitory legislation by Congress was urged last night by Nelson Gaskill, former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.
The platform on which organized industry proposes to work politically during the coming campaign for the defeat of "President Roosevelt's new economic order" was finally adopted yesterday.

A warning against promiscuous bank chartering, or, as he termed it, "failure chartering," was sounded yesterday by Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association and of the Riggs National Bank of Washington, D.C., at the monthly meeting of the New York Chamber of Commerce.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings scored their second victory of the season in eight starts tonight, defeating the Boston Bruins, 2 to 1. It was Boston's sixth setback in eight games.

Most commodity futures were slightly higher in quiet trading on the local markets yesterday. Only coffee and sugar were lower. On the cash markets corn and rubber advanced, while cotton, wheat, rye, oats and tin lost ground.

A widespread educational campaign, particularly among children, on the needs of dental care as a sound foundation for general health was urged yesterday by Dr. Frank J. Houghton of the Jersey City Board of Education in an address before the eleventh annual convention of the First and Second District Dental Societies at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The franc weakened further yesterday as reports from Paris indicated that Premier Laval was facing a critical situation in the Chamber of Deputies. The French currency unit dipped to 6.58 3/8 cents, which was below the gold-shipping point, and closed at 6.58% cents, off 1/8 point.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- All national and State banks were cautioned today in an open letter by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, against too rapidly retiring that agency's investment in their preferred stock, capital notes and debentures at the risk of seriously depleting their working capital.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The next year is likely to be a boom one for naval construction, Francis McMurtrie, the new editor of Jane's Fighting Ships, the authoritative year book of the world's war fleets, which will be published tomorrow, writes in the foreword.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Possibility that the national capital may overflow into Baltimore or some other city near by was foreseen today by Secretary Ickes, who declared in a statement that with the creation of more governmental agencies by the last Congress there was not sufficient space in Washington to house the government.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Secrets of the new fleet of flying boats and airliners now being built for the transatlantic and British Empire air routes were revealed today at the Empire Airways Exhibition, which Viscount Swinton of Masham, Air Minister, opened at the Science Museum.

Mayor La Guardia played fireman for a few minutes at City Hall yesterday to advertise the repeat performance of "The Midnight Alarm," a Fire Department show which will be held in Madison Square Garden on the afternoon and evening of Saturday, Dec. 21.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 5. -- On the eve of the nation's independence day Finland's Gas Defense League, in collaboration with the air force, artillery, infantry, Civic Guards, Fire Brigades, Boy Scouts and women's organizations staged simultaneously in twenty-one cities the largest manoeuvres ever held in order to demonstrate efficient measures to protect the population against gas attacks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Supplementing earlier announcement by the SEC and the Attorney General that criminal proceedings would not be brought at this time against utility holding companies that failed to register, Postmaster General Farley notified postmasters today that the department did not intend to bar such companies from use of the mails.
BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The government today threatened to bring two leaders of the rebellious Protestant confessional synods before the People's Tribunal on a charge of treason.
Sixteen squash racquet stars will take part in the eighth annual Gold Racquet tournament to be staged at the Rockaway Hunting Club, Cedarhurst, L.I., beginning tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today salaries paid by several companies which i the coapanies had called confiden-4 tial. Among them were the followLug:

Ralph Greenleaf of New York City will not compete in the world pocket billiard championship which will start on Monday and end on Dec. 21 at the Pennsylvania Hotel Roof Garden because of illness, it was announced last night by C.A. Storer, president of the National Billiard Association of America.
TOKYO, Dec. 5. -- Reports were received here today to the effect that the Japanese naval authorities would advocate the abolition of submarines at the forthcoming naval conference at London.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
To assuage your correspondent's grievance against the old Fifth Avenue buses, I would suggest that he take a trip in one of the new buses, at any hour.

"How Beautiful With Shoes" had its last performance on Wednesday night at the Booth. Having opened Thanksgiving night, that gave it an engagement of exactly eight performances. (Technical note: rehearsal expense money for the second and third weeks is deducted from the players' two-week salary guarantee.)
Generally regarded as the underdog, Paulino Uzcudun blithely continues his training routine for his fifteen-round bout with Joe Louis, whom he meets at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight.

ROME, Dec. 5. -- Italy's African army proposes to untangle the European crisis by forcing a decisive battle with Ethiopia and then confronting Geneva with a war settlement signed by Emperor Haile Selassie, informed circles reported tonight.

With a few parting shots at the Fusion administration for having failed to redeem its campaign pledges of economy, the Tammany-controlled Board of Aldermen finally adopted the recommended city budget for 1936 without change. It stands, in round numbers and with all expenditures included, at $613,000,000 as compared with $620,000,000 this year, $611,000,000 last year and $588,000,000 in 1933.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government de.posits with the Bank of Canada decreased $3,728,318 in the week ended yesterday, the bank said today in its weekly statement. Deposits by chartered banks increased $4,797,09-8. The statement follows:

The Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives will make an appeal for the "rights of small-unit industries" -- those in which a moderate sized volume of business is distributed among a large number of comparatively small firms -- at the industrial conference in Washington on Monday, called by Major George L. Berry.

Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, asked the Federal Government yesterday for an additional $30,000,000 to finance WPA jobs in this city. The request was addressed to Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A decision to sustain the power of Congress laid down by the Tennessee Valley Authority would change "the form of the Federal Government and the social organization of the American people," James M. Beck, former Solicitor General, and Forney Johnston, attorney for the Alabama Power Company, declared in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today.
President Roosevelt has "done daring things, and will continue to do so -- perhaps even more daring things," Postmaster General Farley said last night in an address at the Hotel Astor.

The New Jersey Board of Pardons will be asked by Governor Harold G. Hoffman to grant Bruno Richard Hauptmann a personal interview if the man convicted of the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. seeks commutation of his death sentence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A proposal for a Federal system of unemployment insurance for transportation employes, instead of their inclusion in the separate systems, was adopted today by the Association of Railway Labor Executive, representing the twenty-one standard railway unions.

PALM BEACH, Dec. 5. -- With present reservations indicating the largest season in many years, the Breakers Hotel opened informally today. Its formal launching, following tradition, is scheduled for Christmas Eve. The first guests were Mr. and Mrs. Otto Stahl of Stamford, Conn.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- While every effort is being made to prevent it, it is very possible that Premier Pierre Laval's Cabinet will be defeated tomorrow evening on the conclusion of the debate on the issue of the patriotic leagues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A drive for legislation looking to permanent long-range slum clearance and low-cost housing divorced from emergency considerations and backed by a first appropriation of not less than $800,000,000 will be sponsored by Senator Wagner at the coming session of Congress.

A halt of unlimited free storage incoming freight on piers in the New York port district was urged trade groups and ship lines yesterday at a hearing conducted by the Shipping Board bureau of the Department of Commerce at the Maritime Association Building, 80 Road Street.

The memory of Duncan Phyfe, American master cabinet-maker in the early days of the republic, will be jointly honored this afternoon at a lecture and tea in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where many pieces of his furniture form part of the permanent collection.

The establishment of mortgage banks operating under strict State regulation and supervision was advocated yesterday at a public hearing of the joint legislative committee on guaranteed real estate mortgages in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- Louis de Florez, New York engineer, took the role of a target in court today to prove that his son and Cornelius V. Roosevelt could do no harm with air pistols used for alleged sniping from a fraternity house at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- With $900,000,000 increase in revenue and indications of a decline in bootlegging and smuggling, the Treasury viewed with satisfaction the second anniversary of repeal of the Prohibition Amendment today.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 5 (AP). -- Approval of revisions in plans for extension of rural electric lines in the territory of several operating companies of the Associated Gas and Electric System was announced today by the Public Service Commission.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 6 (AP). -- Colonel Edward M. House, confidential adviser to President Wilson in the wartime period, warned in The London Daily Mail today of new disasters in Europe "unless the imperial urge of Mussolini has an opportunity to spend itself on African soil."

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The threat that "Germany will have to reopen the question of treatment of its Jews unless anti-German agitation by international Jewry ceases" was voiced today by the newspaper Angriff, which is published by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own publishing house.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 6 (AP). -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the statement by Secretary Hull calling upon all nations to respect existing treaties "impresses me as a reiteration of principle of international law by the United States."

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 5. -- The Italian front in Northern Ethiopia is not a solid line such as the armies held in Europe during the World War. That means it is virtually impossible to prevent small bands of Ethiopians from slipping through and attacking isolated posts and columns.

The hope that New York City can be made the greatest centre of music and art in the world was expressed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in a letter to Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The letter was read at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor by Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association.

Siluan F. Baldin, a 60-year-old engineer in the office of the Borough President of Manhattan, submitted the first entry yesterday for the $2,000 cash prize in the contest inaugurated by Mayor La Guardia for the composition of a city anthem.

FRANKLIN, Ohio, Dec. 5 (AP). -- A determined village marshal and a bank cashier thwarted a bank hold-up and killed one of the robbers today, but two other members of the robber gang, one of them wounded, eluded pursuers tonight after a wild dash for freedom in which they abducted two women and later two men.

Superior power and accuracy enabled Joseph De Raismes of the Elizabeth Town and Country Club to triumph over Edward P. Field Jr. of the Princeton Club in the final of the Class B and C squash tennis tournament last night at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, Brooklyn.
Selling and leasing of dwellings and apartment buildings in Manhattan yesterday indicate a continuance of the demand for housing properties in the city.

Hosiery shipments from American mills in October of this year amounted to what probably was a record of 12,164,000 dozen pairs, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday. Demand was nearly 2,500,000 dozen pairs above the corresponding month of 1934 and 1,347,000 dozen pairs higher than last September.

Solution of a modern zoological mystery, the hitherto unaccounted for mass-migration of the gray squirrels of New England to Southern climates, is offered in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
As a critical situation again arose in North China simultaneous warnings came from the United States and Britain against Japanese attempts to alter the status there.

In his speech on Wednesday at Detroit, Secretary ICKES neatly disposed of all "opponents of the Administration." They have nothing to offer except on the one hand disaster and on the other danger. Having got this dilemma before his audience and before the country, it might have been thought that the Secretary would be content to stand and smile pityingly at the Republican party taking to the woods.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5. -- Slashing three strokes from par with a deadly short game, Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., today snatched the lead in the first round of the $2,000 Orlando open golf tournament with a 68 for the 18 holes. He was out in 33 and back in 35.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The Chicago Board of Trade today was drawn into the controversy between the Farmers National Grain Dealers Association and the Farmers National Grain Corporation over the latter's alleged short operations in the wheat market.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 5 (Canadian Press). -- Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, who had given up attending any one but the Dionne quintuplets, sat tonight beside a new patient, Jean Hersholt, character actor, who came from Hollywood to play the title role in "The Country Doctor," a film starring the five sisters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A declaration that the United States was adhering to the fundamental principles of its traditional policy and was "closely observing what is happening" in North China was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in a public statement that was tantamount to a warning against any impairment of American rights and interests in that region.

Life insurance presidents from all parts of the United States and Canada, meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, heard criticisms of certain government trends as a "threat to savings," and a counter-warning that insurance companies must rid themselves of wasteful competitive expenditures, and might face a "Federal code" unless a few "nefarious enterprises" were eliminated.

The Electric Bond and Share Company, which has held important interests in numerous public utility companies since it was formed by a merger with the Electric Bond and Share Securities Corporation in March, 1929, and acquired Electric Investors, Inc., in October, 1929, has reduced its holdings in all utility companies excepting the six former "client" holding companies to small fractions, it was ascertained yesterday.

THE NEW YORK TIMES published a dispatch from San Jose, Costa Rica, in which the Government of Honduras, presided over by General Tiburcio Carias Audino, was accused of committing unconstitutional acts.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 5. -- President Lazaro Cardenas promised today that Mexico's 16,000 rural school teachers would receive arms to protect their lives as they spread socialistic education throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Tentative approval for early operation of scheduled transatlantic air service, which will virtually assure round-the-world air travel, was given today at a conference attended by British, Irish Free State, Canadian and United States aviation officials at the State Department.

Subscription books were closed yesterday on an offering of 100,000 shares, or more than one-third, of the Virginian Railway's $27,955,000 of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. Until the sale of this stock, all the outstanding preferred was held in a voting trust controlled by the estate of the late H.H. Rogers and four heirs.
PARIS, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The Naval Ministry revealed today that the keel of a new 35,000-ton French battleship has been laid secretly at Brest.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 5. -- While Yvonne, Annette, Emilie, Cecilie and Marie took inquisitively at the movie camera, which is the first scene in "The Country Doctor," Mr. and Mrs. Oliva Dionne talk bitterly of the film-making as they sit around the hot stove in the kitchen of their frame farmhouse, 100 yards away.

There has been no lack of tragedy in the news, but nothing sadder than the boy of 16 in a California hospital recovering from a gunshot that was expected to prove fatal. Through his doctors he has issued a statement: "I don't want to see either my father or my mother.

The Empire Bond and Mortgage Company divested itself of $1,386,165 of assets in January, 1932, six months before it went into receivership, according to testimony presented yesterday at a hearing in the State Office Building before the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Bondholders', Stockholders' and Creditors' Committees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A decline between 1933 and 1934 of more than 30 per cent in the number of persons with net incomes of $1,000,000 or more was revealed today by the Treasury on the basis of income tax returns.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- Last month's municipal election campaign cost the Republican and Democratic parties and the candidates $700,000, according to accountings fried today with the Clerk of Quarter Sessions.

The dedication of the houses at Third Street and Avenue A, reconstructed by the Municipal Housing Authority, is a great event in the history of the city. Houses on Manhattan Island, well planned and equipped, and renting at an average of approximately $6 per month per room, mark an important milestone in the long and slow road that we are traveling toward the provision of satisfactory housing for the lower income groups.

A decline in prices of cotton in Alexandria and a break in New Orleans unsettled quotations on the Cotton Exchange here at one time yesterday, but a closing recovery left the list at losses of only 1 to 6 points on the day.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- A warning to Japan that her movements in Northeastern China were arousing world suspicion at a most unpropitious moment and an admission that attempts to reconcile Italy, Ethiopia and the League of Nations might prove "a hopeless task" were made today by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare in the House of Commons.

Nelson B. Clark, 63 years old, former Boston chemical manufacturer and Bull Moose candidate for Governor of Massachusetts in 1915, was found guilty of first-degree robbery late yesterday afternoon by a jury in General Sessions. He had been tried before Judge Morris Koenig as the accomplice of three of four youths, all now in the death house at Sing Sing, in a Sixth Avenue luggage shop hold-up on Dec. 15, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Anthracite operators will be asked to substitute the six-hour day and the five-day week for the eight-hour day and six-day week, when the present agreement expires in April, if the tri-district convention of anthracite miners tomorrow ratifies the proposal made by the wage-scale committee at the session of the miners tonight.

At the annual meeting of the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County yesterday at 42 West Forty-fourth Street, Lee Thompson Smith, foreman of the March, 1935, grand jury which resulted in the Dewey racket investigation, was elected president of the association to succeed Robert Appleton, who was elected honorary president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The $4,000,000,000 work-relief program will, for the most part, be finished by July 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The following is the text of Secretary of State Hull's statement today on the North China situation:

Elmer Ripley, former basketball coach at Yale, will inaugurate his first year in a similar position at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club tomorrow night when the New Mooners launch their 1935-36 campaign against the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. on the Central court.
Following is the text of the "Platform for American Industry" finally adopted yesterday at the close of the session of the National Association of Manufacturers: ...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Both wholesale prices and retail food prices increased in recent weeks, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted was at the lowest. The ratio of reserve for the New York Bank also reached a new high point for the year.

MADRID, Dec. 5. -- Another Cabinet crisis may result from a denunciation by Antonio Nombela, former Inspector General of Colonies, who asserts he was dismissed because he blocked a $1,000,000 raid on the Spanish Treasury last Summer.

The discovery of the existence in the brain fluids of human beings suffering from high blood pressure of a highly active substance which raises the blood pressure in experimental animals is announced in the current issue of Science by Dr. Irvine H. Page of the Hospital of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

The blunt declaration that management "can and does effectively destroy the right of self-organization among workmen" was made to an audience of 1,000 of the leading industrialists of the country here yesterday by J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

A committee of five executives of leading investment trusts will go to Washington next week to discuss with the Securities and Exchange Commission the form of questionnaire that the commission will send to the trusts throughout the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- Flanked by two of his three attorneys, but conducting his own case, Thomas J. Mooney steered his habeas corpus hearing today into a jury-tampering channel, which had been opposed by his counsel, and won only indifferent results. He elicited testimony, but after he had done so it was ruled inadmissible.

RENO, Nev., Dec. 5. -- Arturo Peralta Ramos, husband of Millicent Rogers Ramos, is expected to file a suit for divorce here tomorrow, although pending negotiations may delay the action for a day or two. The trial of the case will take place behind closed doors.

On the ground that the word "bum" does not import a crime or punishable offense, and the word "faker" has never been held slanderous, Supreme Court Justice McCook dismissed yesterday a $50,000 slander suit brought against Mayor La Guardia by Charles Shankroff, Brooklyn real estate man.

With victory on the Olympic question anticipated by both sides, a close fight loomed last night over American participation in the games in Berlin next year as the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States made ready for its forty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Commodore today, tomorrow and Sunday.

The Rev. Leon Rosser Land, assistant pastor of the Community Church, said in his sermon last Sunday that American pacifists must cooperate with labor and other groups working for a cooperative society in which the economic roots of war would be eliminated.

Two young men, both former students of the University of California at Los Angeles, according to the police, were held for the Westchester County grand jury yesterday following their arrest in Scarsdale, N.Y., on charges of burglary. A young married woman, described by one of the prisoners as his intended wife, was held as a material witness.

Supreme Court Justice Lauer ruled yesterday that the estate of Arnold Rothstein, murdered gambler, was liable for $76,000 to the New York Indemnity Company on a promise by Rothstein to pay a debt of the Ray Miller orchestras, in which Rothstein was interested.

Unalterable opposition to resurrection of the NIRA and "government regimentation" was expressed by more than three-quarters of the trade and industrial groups in the country in a survey released yesterday by Trade-Ways, Inc., despite the fact that about half of them admitted deriving certain beneficial results from the Recovery Act.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The D.M.W. Contracting Company, Inc., of Brooklyn today submitted a low bid of $439,000 for construction of the Madison Square Postoffice substation in New York City.

Convinced that the time is now "ripe for a definite forward move," Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College announced plans yesterday for the purchase of a plot of land on Riverside Drive between 119th and 120th Streets as a site for a new building for the college.
The Harvard and University Club squash racquets teams continued in a tie last night for the Class A leadership in the metropolitan league race by scoring their fifth consecutive victories.

Directors of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock. The quarterly dividend places the stock on an annual basis of $1.60, against $1 previously paid.

In Today Mr. THEODORE JOSLIN, sometime secretary to Mr. HOOVER, paints lovingly and in detail a portrait of him in his present state of will and feeling. It is good to know that, freed from his almost excessive official industry, he is full of cheerfulness. He is now the real Mr. HOOVER. What is done is done and he isn't worrying about it.

The schism in the Socialist party in this city, marked by the secession on Wednesday evening of a minority group of left wing delegates to the party's central committee, assumed wider proportions yesterday as the secessionists completed formation of an independent organization, with offices at 21 East Seventeenth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Hogs were in good demand again today with prices steady to 10 cents a hundred-weight higher than yesterday. The top price was lifted 10 cents to $10, without including the processing tax of $2.25. If the tax is taken into consideration, today's best sale would figure in packers costs sheets as $12.25, the highest price for December in ten years.

Emphasizing that it has followed to the best of its ability a policy on oil shipments to Italy in line with the pronouncements of President Roosevelt and the State Department, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in a statement yesterday said that with one exception "no Standard Oil of New Jersey interest has made shipments of what might he termed war business'' to Italy.

PEIPING, Dec. 5. -- After Colonel Tan Takahashi had asked War Minister Ho Ying-ching to leave North China a representative of Major Gen. Hayao Tada, Japanese military chief in North China, transmitted suggestions to the same effect from the Japanese commander.
Vincent M. McCann, formerly with Brown, W'heeloek, ttarrls Co., is now soclated with Williams Co.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- With the United States an importer of good quality Spring wheat for milling purposes, the action of foreign markets has considerable effect on the domestic price. An unexpected recession in Liverpool today was reflected in scattered liquidation and commission house selling on the Board of Trade here, which carried near-by deliveries to new low marks on the current downturn.

A gift of $50,000, equaling the largest received in this year's drive, was announced yesterday by the managers of the United Hospital Fund campaign. The donation came from the Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A heavy demand for "small change" to meet the nation-wide requirements for Christmas spending, sales taxes and other purposes was shown by Treasury Department figures today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5. -- No longer the rock-ribbed Republican State it was before the depression, Pennsylvania must be classified for the present, at least, in the doubtful column in next year's Presidential election.
The presentation of two new trophies featured the annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday morning.
PARIS, Dec. 5 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The most serious spill of the fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden occurred at 11:40 o'clock last night, reducing to ten the number of surviving teams in the grind which started last Sunday night. When the the endurance test opened, fifteen teams, representing the best riders of America and Europe, pedaled off in the struggle on wheels which will not end until Saturday night.
A recent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES revived the perennial controversy over the relative merits of amateur versus professional economists.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Trading on the Boerse today was largely inactive again, with no transactions of even limited significance being recorded. Quotations continue to have a purely official character and they attract little attention in the business community.

Charges that Eugene Vidal, chief of the Bureau of Air Commerce, and "all of the Department of Commerce," as well as army air officials, had been "influenced" by the Manufacturers Aircraft Association to reject improvements in aviation were made yesterday by Brig. Gen. William Mitchell before the Congressional committee studying patent laws in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5. -- Recommendations for periodical physical, mental and psychological examinations for motorists and permanent revocation of the licenses of convicted drunken drivers were incorporated in resolutions adopted by the New Jersey State Grange, closing its sixty-third annual convention here tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Rishi and Neverfade scored repeat victories today in the best races on the Fair Grounds program which was given over entirely to events including the claiming clause. Rishi, a son of Ladkin, carried the colors of A.W. Moseley and became the first three-time winner of the meeting when he finished the six-furlong route in front.

Eighty-two major letters, minor insignia and class numerals have been awarded to members of the 1935 varsity and jayvee football squads at City College, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, director of athletics.

TRENTON, Dec. 5. -- Arthur Magee, Acting Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today that motor accident fatalities in New Jersey for the first ten months of 1935 totaled 956, or 13 more than in the comparable 1934 period, but expressed "hope" that the 1935 twelve-month total would be less than last year.
ATHENS, Dec. 5. -- Foreign press correspondents were warmly greeted in a formal audience today by King George II, recently restored to the throne of Greece.

Writing from his home in Des Moines, Jay N. Darling assures this department that his resignation as chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey does not mean he has retired from activity in the field of wild life. This will be welcome news to the nation's sportsmen, who feel that the country can ill afford to lose so valiant a fighter for the cause as the famous "Ding."

A modernization job will be undertaken in the Bronx as the result of the sale by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of the two five-story apartment houses at 292-294 Brook Avenue. The property has been acquired by the Me-Har Corporation through John J. Reynolds, broker.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 5. -- Federal Judge Judge John P. is sued a temporary restraining order today prohibiting the Central Public Utility Corporation and its subsidiary, the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company, from registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Threats that Howard C. Hopson of the Associated Gas and Electric Company may be cited for contempt of the House of Representatives unless he supplies certain information to the Rules Committee by Dec. 16 are contained in a letter to Mr. Hopson from Chairman O'Connor. The letter was made public today.
ROME, Dec. 5. -- Italy is displaying a strange lack of enthusiasm toward the optimistic forecasts of an early solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy that are being made abroad.

Displaying a hesitant tone during most of the day, the share market moved narrowly yesterday and closed irregular. Metal issues and many of the specialty group showed about the best strength of the list at the closing; the advantage gained on the day before by railway stocks was not pursued, save perhaps at the opening.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- Horses owned by Audrey's Choice Stable and the Greyholme Stables captured a good share of the honors as the eighth annual 110th Cavalry Horse Show opened tonight in the Commonwealth Armory. The show well continue through Sunday evening.

A convoy, the first assigned in New York Harbor in recent years, met the North German Lloyd liner Bremen at Ambrose Lightship last night, escorted her to Quarantine and established an all-night patrol about the huge liner that is not to be relaxed until she reaches her dock at 7:45 o'clock this morning.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5. -- The famous "Gift of God" baby, claimed by two women as their own, was declared today by Rush H. Limbaugh, special commissioner, to be the child of Miss Anna Ware, 19, unwed servant girl, of Newton, Pa.
The first round in the battle to keep Meyer Luckman in jail pending his trial for the murder of Sam Druckman went yesterday to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The suggestion that Britain join in cutting Italy's communications with Africa if economic pressure fails to end the war was made in a resolution adopted by the general council of the League of Nations Union today.

The names of those whose brief biographies are published under "The Neediest Cases" are not revealed, nor are their addresses known except to those who go to them from one or another of the organizations ministering to their needs. They are anonymous fellow-beings in deepest want.

IT was Mr. James J. Johnston, fight impresario of Madison Square Garden, who said: "You could have knocked me down with a crowbar." He was referring to his dazed state when he heard that Mr. Mike Jacobs, a rival pugilistic entrepreneur, was preparing to stage the final round of an international catch-as-catch-can contract bridge tournament in the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- A new offering of $100,000,000 of 3 per cent Federal Land Bank bonds to refund a $62,000,000 issue outstanding at 4 1/2 per cent will be made by the Farm Credit Administration on next Tuesday, William I. Myers, governor, announced today.
Two hundred and thirty-six contributors added $11,092.62 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the total received to date to $43,431.21.

Francis George Mautte, a junior, was elected captain of Fordham University's football team for 1936 at a meeting of the letter men yesterday. The new leader, who succeeds Joe Maniaci, has been on the varsity squad for two years. During the recent campaign he held down the right halfback post and in 1934 was a substitute fullback.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Raymond J. Funkhouser of Harrison, manufacturer and Democrat, who defeated Benjamin I. Taylor, veteran Harrison Republican, for membership on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, was declared disqualified for office in a decision today by Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The foursome composed of L.J. Welch, Walter Pray, Joseph Cain and E.T. Wood of Indianapolis came from behind tonight in the third and final session of the team-of-four event to win the 1935 championship in the contract bridge tournament of the American Bridge League.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The foursome composed of L.J. Welch, Walter Pray, Joseph Cain and E.T. Wood of Indianapolis came from behind tonight in the third and final session of the team-of-four event to win the 1935 championship in the contract bridge tournament of the American Bridge League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- There are two reasons why both the more practical men among the New Dealers and the more socially minded ones, in rare combination, have had little faith in the duration of the truce between the administration and certain types of large industries, the truce called "the breathing-spell."

The recommendations submitted lately to the Federal Reserve by its Advisory Council, and published this week, approach from two different angles the question whether the present member bank reserves should not be regulated. That the "surplus reserve" of these private institutions, which recently passed $3,000,000,000, is superfluously and abnormally large is a matter of common knowledge.

Francis W.H. Adams, special prosecutor, attempted to show yesterday that William F. Warms, master of the Ward liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934, with a loss of 135 lives, was fifty minutes late in receiving word of the outbreak of the fire.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Four of the six newcomers on the 1936 football schedule of Army will be renewing old relations when they meet the Cadets. According to the complete list of dates announced today, Army is slated to face nine rivals next season.

Eight positive cases of scarlet fever were reported in Willard Parke Hospital yesterday with four more children under observation. All of the cases came from St. Barnabas House, a shelter operated by the New York Protestant Episcopal Mission Society at 304 Mulberry Street, where about thirty more children and a group of adults were quarantined.

Robert V. Miller, alias Count Victor Lustig, described by Federal agents as the most expert competitor the United States Government has ever had in the issuance of money, interrupted his own trial for counterfeiting yesterday by pleading guilty.

A heated discussion on methods for determining costs of power distribution, participated in by a number of nationally known engineers, disturbed the usual serenity of the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, being held this week at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Monetary gold stocks of the United States rose $135,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a high record of $10,009,000,000, according to the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. As a result of this gain in gold, the reserves of member banks of the system increased $116,000,000 to a new high mark of $5,905,000,000 and the excess of reserves over legal requirements rose $120,000,000 to the unprecedented figure of $3,180,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 4, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,475,000,000, practically unchanged from the preceding week and $16,000,000 above the corresponding week in 1934.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, guest of honor last night at a dinner in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, held an audience of 1,200 for two hours after the dinner with the story of his last Antarctic expedition illustrated by motion pictures.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley today dismissed a suit by Marselis C. Parsons, former president of the Rye National Bank, to recover substantial contributions made to reopen the institution following the banking "holiday" in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Unpaid balances on 130,910 shares of common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation which were allotted to officers, and directors under the management stock ownership plan of Jan. 31, 1930, amounted ot $11,114,569 on Dec. 31, 1934, according to confidential data filed by the corporation in registering its securities on the Stock Exchanges, which the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt tonight appointed the investigating commission provided for in the Railroad Retirement Act to make a study of retirement, annuity and similar technical problems under the new law. Walter H. Pollak of New York was designated chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Executors of the estate of Mary R. Diaz-Albertini -- Lewis L. Clark and Henry H. Anderson of New York City -- today applied to the Board of Tax Appeals for redetermination of a tax deficiency of $309,681 levied by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 6. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman's interest in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, it developed here today, is based upon a belief held by Ellis H. Parker, Burlington County detective, that the prisoner in the death house here is not "entirely responsible" for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.
Capturing the trophy for the second year in a row, William A. Kimbel of Ardsley won the veterans championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association again last night at the Heights Casino.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- An authoritative prediction that the Home Owners Loan Corporation will adopt a sterner attitude toward delinquent borrowers was made today.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Radiating a measured degree of optimism, the precise depth of which it is probably undesirable to probe, the United States delegation to the forthcoming naval conference landed from the liner Aquitania at Southampton today, and tonight the members already housed the members and unpacking at Claridge's Hotel.

Undismayed by the fact that his $45,000 slander suit against Mayor La Guardia was recently dismissed, Charles Shankroff, Brooklyn taxpayer, was again present at yesterday's Board of Estimate meeting to spread his views on the record.
Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark, is sailing today to her post at Copenhagen on the Frederik VIII of the Scandinavian-American Line. Others sailing on the ship include:

Fritz Kreisler again received the homage and the unstinted enthusiasm justly due a virtuoso when he appeared for the third time this season at Carnegie Hall last night in a recital. The proof of the violinist's magnetic power was decidedly clear when, fully half an hour before the concert, every available seat was already filled and rows of auditors were standing in the rear of the hall.

Mrs. Hattie F., "broken at 28"; Jonathan, 80 years old, who could not leave the house because he had no shoes; Tom and Caroline L. and 2-year-old Jane were among the Neediest in all New York who were helped yesterday by the 210 contributions received for the Fund.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6. -- S. Paul Skahem of St. Paul was elected president of the National Association of Securities Commissioners at the closing session of their annual convention in the Miami Btltmore Hotel tonight. Mr. Skahem succeeds Harold K. Bradford, former Securities Commissioner of Vest Virginia and now a member of the! Securities Exchange Commission.

With all its traditional glamour and festive spirit, marked this year by many striking and colorful innovations, the annual Beaux-Arts Ball was held last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Framed in a setting flashing with the spangled trappings of a circus "big top" and the baroque motif of East Indian decoration, the event was given under the auspices of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects to further that organization's extensive educational program.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 6. -- Champion Skipper Bob, owned, trained and handled by Harry T. Conklin of Amagansett, L.I., was the winner today of the open all-age stake at the annual field meeting of the American Chesapeake Club.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Dec. 6. -- Coming back from the other side of the world today, I was impressed for the first time by the tremendous distance we covered in the China Clipper.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- An oil embargo against Italy was recommended by the student model council of the League of Nations at its opening session at Elmira College today. The council also "warned" Japan that its troop movements in Northern China were likely to disturb the peace of the world.

A complete revision of the patent system, which has remained virtually unchanged since the birth of the nation, was urged upon a Congressional committee yesterday to extinguish "scarecrow" and "shotgun" rackets allegedly employed by big corporations to stave off competition.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, was one of the first witnesses yesterday in the suit brought by James J. Donovan against nine officers and directors of the Atlas Corporation and the Securities-Allied Corporation for $14,896,032 damages in behalf of the latter corporation on the ground that the defendants had misappropriated and diverted its assets.

The diversion of import freight from rival ports on the Atlantic Coast to the piers of New York as a result of the practice of granting unlimited free storage piers throughout the New York port district was described yesterday at the resumption of the Shipping Board investigation of New York pier practices.

The performance of the share market yesterday was chiefly a repetition of the hesitant attitude of the day before; prices fluctuated within comparatively narrow limits throughout and closed irregular. Some of the lower-priced petroleum issues firmed up, as did various specialty stocks, but as a rule movements were not in terms of groups.

The two rival groups in the Socialist party will hold separate meetings tomorrow night to thresh out the problems presented by the breakaway of Norman Thomas and his "left wing" members from the so-called "old guard."

HAVANA, Saturday, Dec. 7. -- The Cuban Government unqualifiedly accepted yesterday afternoon a formula presented by Professor Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, for a solution of election problems and set general elections for Jan. 10 next.

In his letter to THE TIMES, Kimberly Cheney speaks of the "subversive attempts on the part of the administration to bend the Constitution to its purposes" and says that this attitude "transgresses all conceptions of Presidential honesty."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission appointed today Abraham N. Davis of Brooklyn, a former Assistant Attorney General of New York, who has wide experience in securities fraud cases, as assistant director of the trading and exchange division of which David Saperstein is director.

William Tannenbaum, 333 Robling Street, Washington, D.C., testified yesterday in Federal court that when the Ward liner Morro Castle was afire on Sept. 8, 1934, off Asbury Park, he did not know what his duties were, although he was a seaman.

Although it is still some distance off, it appears likely that next season will find Katharine Cornell back in the realm of the moderns. For Maxwell Anderson has written a new play and Miss Cornell is, in the language of the street, all for it.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- Stern measures designed to force compliance by public and private schools and colleges with the new Teachers' Oath Law were outlined tonight by Attorney General Paul A. Dever, acting at the request of Governor James M. Curley.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6. -- Preparations for a strike of the 105,000 garment workers in New York City wore authorized today at a meeting here of the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union. At the same time, it was said, however, that authorization of a strike does not necessarily mean that one will take place, since employers have expressed willingness to negotiate before the present union contract expires on Jan. 31.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, after a conference here today, issued a call to 1,700 members of the union employed by the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad to go on strike at 6 P.M. Monday unless the Burlington agreed to use two men in the cabs of its Diesel electric locomotives on the "Zephyr" trains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Assured of the joint cooperation of the United States, Canada, the Irish Free State and Great Britain toward early establishment of transatlantic air service, the principal operators today began a series of conferences to determine who would get the "biggest batch" of the anticipated over-ocean air travel.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 6. -- Emperor Haile Selassie had a narrow escape today when nine Italian planes dropped nearly 1,000 explosive and incendiary bombs on Dessye, where the imperial field headquarters has been established.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- Bob Quinn, business manager of the Dodgers and for many years owner of the Boston Red Sox, will become the new owner of the Boston Braves if the National League at its meeting in Chicago Tuesday accepts his offer, it was learned here tonight in authoritative baseball circles.

The first of the Junior Assemblies of the season last night at the Ritz-Carlton was in a Winter outdoor garden -- appropriate to the freezing weather -- of evergreens, sprinkled with white chrysanthemums, simulating snowballs. These fir trees were grouped in the corners and balconies of the ballroom, and chrysanthemums resembling snowbanks were massed at the base of the mirrors on the side walls, which were arched with silvered and green smilax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The Tri-District Convention of Anthracite Mine Workers today approved a report of the scale committee under the terms of which the coal operators will be served with twenty-seven specific demands for inclusion in a new wage contract to replace the five-year agreement expiring on April 1.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6. -- It is now hoped that the exploration ship Discovery II, which is going to join the search of Antarctica for Lincoln Ellsworth, missing American explorer, will be able to leave for the Bay of Whales before Christmas, thus enabling it to reach the pack ice at the Ross Sea entrance about the middle of January, which is usually the best season.

The Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering Award for chemical engineering achievement was presented to the organic chemicals department of E.I. duPont de Nemours Co. at a dinner at the University Club last night, held in conjunction with the fifteenth national exposition of chemical industries, at Grand Central Palace.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 6. -- Young Republicans, meeting here for their third biennial convention, were planning today to endorse Governor Alf M. Landon for the Republican nomination for President next year, but received no encouragement from Mr. Landon himself.

Governor LEHMAN'S action in superseding the District Attorney of Kings County in the Druckman case has a wide scope. He was not solely interested in the murder, though that was apparently a sordid and ghastly business. The alleged murderers have finally been indicted, and their trial alone would not have moved Governor LEHMAN to set aside District Attorney GEOGHAN.

A total of $17,519,103 of Christmas Club savings will be released for Christmas shopping this year by the savings banks of this State. The total, which represents a new record for Christmas Club savings in the State, is $1,800,000, or 11.85 per cent, above last year's Christmas savings.
President Roosevelt will formally open the 1936 Democratic campaign at the Jackson Day dinner in Washington on Jan. 8, Postmaster General James A. Farley announced last night.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc on the days inducated, com-pares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
James Forbes, mendicancy expert who died Nov. 26, was a pioneer in the borderland between social and police work.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen came up the harbor to her West Forty-sixth Street dock yesterday with the eyes of Coast Guards and special police watching her closely as the result of a report to the police and Federal officials that a Communist group had planned to damage her as a demonstration against Nazi Germany.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Viscount Swinton of Masham, Air Minister, expressed Great Britain's sympathy today in the loss of Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The Nationalist student organization known as the Kyffhaueser Student Bund has refused to amalgamate with the Nazi Student League on the ground that the latter is an anti-Christian organization.

The approaching holiday season -- which is always the best in the night spots is responsible for the accelerating activity to be noted around the laugh-and-play resorts. The last week marked a perceptible rise in stocks on the nocturnal market.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP). -- Lighthouse Harry Cooper of Chicago shot to the front at the halfway mark in the $2,000 Orlando open golf tournament today with a 69 that duplicated his first round score and left him two strokes to the good at 138.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Two more attacks on the AAA, its methods, principles and constitutionality were filed in the Supreme Court today, one by John W. Davis, Nathan Miller and William R. Perkins in the rice processing tax case and another by John E. Hughes of Cleveland in the Hoosac Mills case.

The volume of production of steel ingots in the United States last month was at a new high level for the year at 3,153,247 gross tons, slightly more than the total of 3,146,446 tons produced in October, and the highest output recorded since May, 1934, and with that exception, the highest since the start of the depression.

When the trustees of the will of Robert Schaikenbaeh and the Robert Schalkenbach Foundation, Inc., sold to Eric Coupey, 125 IV. 12th St., the foundation took back a purchase money mortgage for $42,750, subJect to a first mortgage for $110,000 held by the Young Women'B Christian Association Retirement Fund.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Prices of hogs suffered a sharp setback here today as the result of the refusal of leading packers to pay prevailing levels in view of the declining tendency in lard and the failure of fresh meats to fully reflect the recent advance in hogs.

Holiday trade made notably favorable progress in department stores in the metropolitan area during the week. Sharp increases over a year ago were noted for the forepart of the week. However, sales figures for yesterday and today will compare with those of the extremely large volume registered on the corresponding days last year, when customers bought heavily to escape the 2 per cent city sales tax, which went into effect on Dec. 10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Secretary of State Hull refused today to elaborate his statement of last night on the North China crisis and refrained from comment on foreign reactions to it. When his attention was called to the comment of the Foreign Office spokesman in Tokyo and to the enthusiasm manifested in Nanking he refrained from discussing them.
LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were generally quieter than yesterday, although again there were numerous firm features.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Indictments charging conspiracy to steal more than 6,000,000 gallons of gasoline valued at about $300,000 have been handed up against seventeen men and a corporation, it was disclosed here today at the arraignment in Quarter Sessions Court of twelve of the men.

When the income tax return figures were published a year ago they revealed some paradoxical results. Incomes in the lower brackets had declined in 1933 as compared with 1932, while those in the higher brackets rose. There was a fall in the total income of those reporting incomes of less than $5,000 and, in fact, of all classes reporting incomes of less than $25,000.

The Harvard Club continued its drive toward championship honors among the Class B teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League when it halted the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club representatives by 4 -- 1 last night.

Phyllis Bentley has cabled to Hill Peters, the literary agency which represents her here, a protest against the intended publication here by Hillman-Curl of her novel, "Environment." This was Miss Bentley's first novel, begun before 1918 and published in England in 1922.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 6. -- Continued Soviet press attacks against Finland for its alleged aspirations to seize North Russian territory and its intention to conclude a military treaty with Poland and Germany were met by two protests launched tonight in Parliament by Premier T.M. Kivimaeki and seconded by Foreign Minister A.V. Hackzell.

PEIPING, Saturday, Dec. 7. -- Optimism over the Nanking Government's efforts to prevent the establishment of an autonomous regime in North China was revived today by General Ho Ying-ching, War Minister, who said he had received many protests against autonomy since his arrival here to confer with North China leaders.

MOSCOW, Dec. 6. -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, presented to each of 100 brightly costumed natives of Tadjikistan and Turkomanistan -- cotton-picking and cotton-growing champions -- a gold watch and a phonograph and records on the occasion of their call at the Kremlin yesterday.

Opposition to the proposed schedule of fees for physicians in workmen's compensation cases was expressed yesterday on behalf of employers by Alfred Rothschild, chairman of the legislative committee of the Insurance Buyers of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Following a conference with representatives of religious organizations, President Roosevelt has instructed the army and navy to make no comments on any civilian organization or its policies without his specific consent, it was deeclared today by the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

The more than 1,200,000 Roman Catholics under the spiritual jurisdiction of Cardinal Hayes will be asked to take a pledge, repeating it line by line after the priest, tomorrow at mass not to attend any motion picture which has not the approval of the Legion of Decency.

TORONTO, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press). -- The Ontario Government tonight proclaimed its Power Act, canceling power purchase contracts with four Quebec companies, after a conference with representatives of the companies had failed to produce an agreement.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., and wholly or substantially wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the third quarter of this year estimated net earnings of $737,791 after expenses, estimated Federal income taxes and interest on the company's debentures.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Maurice Maschke, Cleveland political leader, and his partner, G.W. Parratt, were leading a field of ninety-two pairs for the open pair championship in the American Bridge League's contract bridge tournament here today.

An opportunity to try their blades on the first outdoor ice of the season was welcomed yesterday by five of the nation's leading skaters, who will be competitors for the national figure-skating championships and places on the United States Olympic team, when they staged a drill on the outdoor rink at Park Avenue and Sixty-first Street.

Team and individual prizes won during the 1935 cricket season were formally awarded last night at a buffet supper dance held at the Hotel George Washington by the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association. Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General and honorary president of the Cricket Association, who was expected to be present, could not attend because of the death of Princess Victoria.

It is a very definite as well as a very important pledge which the president of the Merchants Association has taken to the cause of grand opera in New York. Mr. COMSTOCK said at a luncheon in behalf of the Metropolitan Opera, "We shall have in New York one of these days the best house for opera in the world, and the business men will build it."

An advance of 0.5 point for the week carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 129.9 on Tuesday, within 0.3 point of the Oct. 8 five-year high point of 130.2. Steers, hogs, cotton, meats, butter, cocoa and tin made gains.

Twenty persons were injured, six of them so badly that they needed hospital treatment, in a collision about 8:30 o'clock last night between a crosstown trolley car, with forty passengers aboard, and a fully loaded five-ton truck at Thirty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6. -- After two defeats here at the Fair Grounds, Mrs. J.R. Gregory's Thomasville ran a powerful race in the featured event today to score by four lengths in easy fashion. The 4-year-old Supremus gelding was handled by the apprentice G. Smith and was going easily at the end of the mile and an eighth to turn back Cristate and Lady Federal, which finished as named.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Dec. 6. -- Dan T. Heady, leader of the six prisoners who broke from jail here Tuesday, was shot to death by a posse when he was trapped in a farm house near Weathers, Okla., today and had refused to surrender. With him was Dewey Gilmore who was wounded and captured.

Two major trade groups, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and the Cotton-Textile Institute, Inc., yesterday were added to the score or more of other industrial organizations which have refused to participate in the industry conference to be held in Washington Monday by Major George L. Berry, coordinator for industrial cooperation.

THE dear old dean of football linesmen, Dean Watkeys of Syracuse, scanned a few lines that appeared in this sector recently and sent them back augmented with decorative and illuminating comment of his own. The lines were:

State and municipal loans to the number of 130, scheduled for next week, reach a total of $64,178,415, one of the most active periods from the standpoint of the number of individual sales to be experienced by municipal bond houses in some time.

A suggestion that speed governors be put on cars of persons convicted of reckless driving was among the recommendations made yesterday at the second of a series of hearings conducted by the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Automobile Insurance and Safety in the Bronx County Building, Grand Concourse and 161st Street.

Rapid progress in obtaining consents for the reorganization of the C-2 series of guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, under the plan approved by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, was reported yesterday by the reorganization department of the State Mortgage Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- The Assembly Ball took place tonight at the Bellevue Stratford. Guests were received in the foyer of the ballroom by Mrs. Charles Edward Ingersoll, Mrs. Leonard Tillinghast Beale, Mrs. Henry Sandwith Drinker Jr., Mrs. Arthur Emlen Newbold Jr., Mrs. Frederick Rogers Drayton and Mrs. Charles Eustis Bohlen. Nearly a thousand persons were present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Senator Norris today declared that he would not seek renomination next year. His announcement was made in a brief statement in which he pledged his active support to President Roosevelt and said that he could be more effective if not a candidate himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Industry's political planks for its war on the New Deal will drive organized labor and its friends as well as all liberal forces in the country to the support of the Roosevelt administration, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6. -- Premier Aberhart of Alberta, first of the provincial leaders to arrive in Ottawa for next week's Dominion-Provincial Conference, revealed today that he had asked American, British and Canadian holders of $160,000,000 worth of Alberta bonds to accept a voluntary reduction of interest.

The Synagogue Council of America, representing practically all shades of Jewish religious thought in this country, appealed yesterday "to the moral forces of the world" to defend the rights of religious minorities in Germany against the forces that seek to destroy them.

The discussion that has been going on for some weeks over the advisability of action by the Federal Reserve System to reduce member bank excess reserves has produced as a side issue consideration of the question of Federal Reserve Bank earnings. Even with their large holdings of government securities the Federal Reserve Banks have shown small earnings in recent years and many of them have earned nothing.

The Right Honorable and Most Rev. William Temple, Lord Archbishop of York, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for a visit of five weeks in this country, during which he will speak at several universities and preach in a number of American cities.

It is all very well, this gay and offhand talk, some of it in verse, about dashing off an "anthem" for New York. But it is a serious matter to get an anthem -- for a composition that is bound to be very secular -- that will fix itself in the hearts and throats of the people, and last, and roll down the ages.

Frank Bailey, board chairman of New York Investors, Inc., testified yesterday at a continued hearing into the affairs of the Prudence Company, Inc., which is in reorganization under Section 77b. The hearing was before Adolph C. Kiendl, special master, in the Federal Building in Brooklyn.

Norman Hill, San Jose (Calif.) rider, last night was forced out of the fifty-ninth international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden as the endurance test approached the close of its fifth day.

Eager to fight James J. Braddock for the heavyweight championship of the world, or, in lieu of that, willing to take on Joe Louis in an elimination bout, Max Schmeling arrived yesterday from his native Germany aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line.

New bond financing this week amounted to $26,299,000, the smallest since the week ended on Oct. 11, when only $19,740,000 in new bonds were placed on the market. This compares with $58,531,900 last week and with $25,476,000 in the corresponding period last year.

The approximate status of the municipal bend market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The fight by holders of Missouri Pacific Railroad first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds against the road's plan of reorganization was directed today against income estimates recently submitted by William Wyer, secretary-treasurer of the trusteed carrier.
Marblehead (Mass.) High School's football squad arrived here by boat yesterday eager to end the all-winning march of Curtis High when the two teams meet this afternoon at Thompson's Stadium.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6. -- Miami University's Hurricanes triumphed by 21 to 13 over the Oglethorpe Petrels in their final game of the season at Miami Stadium tonight.
Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia announced yesterday the launching of a drive in the South to block re-election of President Roosevelt in 1936.

As in past years, the Beaux-Arts Ball was preceded by many dinner parties and other festive celebrations given by committee members and subscribers to the ball. In the main these fetes were costume parties, the hosts and hostesses and their guests being in their Beaux-Art fancy dress.

Governor Lehman announced in Albany yesterday that he would supersede District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County in the investigation of the murder last March of Samuel Druckman, a shipping clerk, in a Brooklyn garage and in an inquiry into allegations of bribery or attempted bribery.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 6. -- A Japanese Army spokesman said today that Secretary Hull's statement on the Far Eastern situation yesterday represented the natural American view, and that Mr. Hull sought to allay uneasiness concerning North China.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, British Foreign Secretary, is expected by airplane tomorrow to have with Premier Pierre Laval what may be for Europe as a whole as well as for the Ethiopian conflict a decisive interview.
Charles R. Fairey, whose challenge for the America's Cup was withdrawn upon his request to the New York Yacht Club, yesterday sent the following cablegram from London to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

About 1,000 persons attended a debate last night in the Bronx County Building, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, in which students from N.Y.U., Manhattan College, Fordham, Hunter College and Mount St. Vincent's argued the relative advantages of a college education in institutions located in large and small communities.

PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 7. -- With dramatic suddenness, the dangerous situation created by the parliamentary debate on the armed political leagues in France was dispelled yesterday morning, the Laval government was saved, Parliament and the country were delivered from a haunting although perhaps exaggerated dread, government 3 per cent bonds rose with a bound and the franc recovered against the dollar and sterling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Authority to issue $8,176,000 of new first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds to replace a like amount of 5 1/2s now outstanding was asked today by the Fort Worth Denver City Railway of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The La Salle Academy basketball team registered its fourth victory in as many starts this season by defeating Cathedral Prep of Brooklyn, 19 to 15, at Goddard's Gymnasium in one of the several school contests waged on Manhattan courts yesterday.

Two more men were arrested yesterday in the State's drive on racetrack tipster racketeering, bringing total arrests here and in Saratoga County, where eighty-six indictments have been handed up, to seven.
