The new Gallery of Medieval Art at the Brooklyn Museum, with 225 exhibits representing more than a thousand years of history, was opened yesterday at 3 P.M. with a reception and private view for museum members and guests.

NANKING, Saturday, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The reported imminent appointment of General Chiang Kai-shek, chief of China's armed forces, as chairman of China's Executive Yuan, observers said today, would mean his assumption of the full responsibilities of a virtual dictatorship.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Wheat prices managed to finish a fraction higher today on the Board of Trade here in the face of a further recession in Winnipeg, where the Wheat Board was reported a persistent seller of the May delivery at and above 87 3/4 cents a bushel.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 6. -- Ben Lucien Burman, author of "Steamboat Round the Bend," one of the last pictures in which Will Rogers appeared, paid a tribute to Will Rogers at a memorial luncheon for the humorist given by the Connecticut branch of the League of American Pen Women this afternoon at the Pickwick Arms.

The Foundation for the Blind, whose new building was dedicated on Thursday, is a national institution that has made it its chosen duty to assist all local agencies in meeting their problems and carrying forward their work for the blind. It is not to assume the functions of these local associations.

A hearing on the charge of grand larceny against Richard Brophy, 40 years old, former business manager of the first ByrdAntarctic Expedition, was continued until next Monday yesterday when he was arraigned before Magistrate Aurelio in the West Side Court.

Speaking last night over station WLWL, the Rev. Father Ignatius W. Cox, S.J. Professor of Ethics of Fordham University, assailed the proponents of birth control who spoke at Carnegie Hall during the birth-control mass meeting last Monday evening.
Governor Hill McAlister of Tennessee was guest of honor last night at the thirtieth annual smoker of the Tennessee Society in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6. -- Charging that the recent voluntary bankruptcy of Fox West Coast Theatres resulted from a $25,000,000 conspiracy involving the Chase National Bank of New York and other financial organizations, T.L. Tally and L.L. Bard, local theatre owners, today petitioned the United States District Court to void the bankruptcy.

Frances Jenkins, a youthful and comely contralto from Denver, made her first New York appearance in a recital last night at Town Hall. Although previously unheard in the East, Miss Jenkins has sung in Canada and the Middle West and has had operatic experience abroad, where her first role was Carmen at the Grand Opera of Geneva.

In 1937 ends the term of Mr. MARCUS ALLEN COOLIDGE, junior Senator from Massachusetts. He is a quiet and useful Roman. Perhaps he is a little slow for these giddy-paced times. Tuesday Governor CURLEY said that he was going to run for the Senate next year. He told the world the same thing last February.

Using its influence with creditor supply houses to obtain a bankruptcy petition, the United Hotels Securities Corporation attempted early this year to throw the Manhattan Towers Hotel into a 77B proceeding to obtain the management of the hotel, according to testimony yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Bondholders, Stockholders and Creditors Committees.

The national outdoor track and field championships next year will not be coincidental with the final Olympic tryouts, but will be an independent meet. This is the committee recommendation that will come on the floor today for consideration at the forty-seventh annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, which opened a three-day session yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The Chicago Board of Trade contributed $8,700 toward the expense of the special survey of grain marketing issued last Summer by the Farmers National Grain Dealers Association, Robert P. Boylan, president of the Board of Trade, said today.

BISMARCK, N.D., Dec. 6 (AP). -- A directed verdict acquitting former Governor William Langer of perjury charges today cleared away some of the legal difficulties which have beset him since he lost his office eighteen months ago.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 6. -- Japan will not permit the Chinese Government to extend its silver nationalization and its new currency program to the five northern provinces, Shantung, Hopei, Shansi, Suiyuan and Chahar.

GENEVA, Dec. 6. -- The Preparatory Maritime Conference called by the International Labor Organization ended today with the prospects better than at its beginning for a final conference next November to adopt a convention on the manning of ships and the hours worked.

Directors of the Acme Steel Company voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to an increased quarterly dividend of 62 1/2 cents. This places the stock on an annual basis of $2.50, against $2 previously paid. In the preceding three quarters the company paid extras of 12 1/2 cents.
TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 7. -- A young Japanese, Hideyuki Kikuchi, has invented a new method of smelting that will revolutionize metallurgy, according to the Tokyo newspaper Nichi Nichi.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 6. -- With Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam two points ahead in the score and with four contests remaining, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and the Netherlands' representative resumed play tonight in their match for the chess championship of the world and placed on record forty moves of the twenty-seventh game of the series.

The application by Andrew Ponzi, world pocket billiard champion, to restrain the National Billiard Association and the Hotel Pennsylvania from holding a tournament at the hotel was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McCook.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 6. -- A non-committal statement today that the courts must decide the issue in the "strike" of utility holding companies against registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission constituted the first comment by President Roosevelt in reference to this new test of his administration's policies.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Substantial spurts in many lines of business marked a new series of pre-Christmas reports today.

Following is the text of a resolution given out last night by the executive committee of the National Amateur Athletic Association as the position which opponents of American participation in the Olympic Games will ask the annual athletic convention to take finally today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The salaries of America's top-ranking corporate executives have risen generally from their depression low levels, but their total compensations were revealed today as still far below the $1,000,000 high marks of 1929.

In appreciation of his work in the restoration of Williamsburg, Colonial capital of Virginia, the Society of the Virginians presented a bronze medal and paid tribute to John D. Rockefeller Jr. at the society's annual dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The requests by counsel for Michael J. Meehan of New York that the hearing on allegations that he violated the anti-manipulative sections of the Securities Exchange Act of 1935 be transferred from Washington to New York and a more complete bill of particulars supplied were denied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which thereupon began to complete plans for a hearing at its offices here next Wednesday.

A week ago, desiring to know what the weather predictions were for Boston, I telephoned the local Weather Bureau. Getting no response, I called your office and was told that the Weather Bureau was sometimes very slow in answering the telephone. I tried again, with no response.

The Rev. William Butler Sperry, a deacon of the Episcopal communion, will be advanced to the priesthood this morning at 10:30 o'clock at a public ceremony in Grace Episcopal Chapel, 414 East Fourteenth Street, of which he has been the vicar since last May.

The prosecution continued to submit evidence yesterday in General Sessions in the trial of Mrs. Hilda Peterson and two officers of the Isco Service Corporation, accused of fraud in connection with stock transactions by her husband, William F. Peterson, fugitive, in which about $465,000 was lost to investors, many of them women.

The French franc rallied strongly yesterday in the foreign exchange market following the vote of confidence given to Premier Laval in the Chamber of Deputies. It rose to 6.61 1/2 cents, the highest price since Aug. 29, and closed at 6.60 3/4 cents, up 2 1/8 points net.

Warnings against "wild-eyed pied pipers" who would scrap the "American system," a call for balanced budgets for States and cities, and a plea for freeing life insurance companies from "burdening" taxes, marked the closing sessions yesterday of the annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Plans for the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League, which forms the backbone of the preliminary season in the sport each Winter, were announced yesterday following a meeting of the schedule committee of the league.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The British Government has received an intimation that China is seriously considering the advisability of following Ethiopia's example by appealing to the League of Nations to have Japan declared an aggressor because of her invasion of Chinese territory.

Seven leading clergymen of the city spoke in eulogy of the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans at a dinner last night at the Hotel Empire, Broadway and Sixty-third Street, given by the officers and members as part of the two-week celebration of his fortieth anniversary as pastor of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- Trading on the Boerse was quiet today, with prices mixed at the finish. Transactions had little significance, as the real securities market continues to con-i sist of private deals made entirely outside of the official exchanges.

The general public cannot realize how hard the professional classes, and particularly the engineers, have been hit during this depression. People think that because of the large amount of PWA construction work going on in the city, the engineering profession was well taken care of.

Mystifying tricks and novelties with light, sound, electricity and radio were shown yesterday afternoon at a preview of the House of Magic in the General Electric Building, Fifty-first Street and Lexington Avenue.

A group of holiday cards made by artists for their own use will be on view in the Fifth Avenue entrance lobby of the New York Public Library for the two weeks preceding Christmas, beginning Wednesday. Among the artists represented are John Taylor Arms, Glintenkamp, Balcom and Ruzicka.

Although the United States birth rate in 1934 was 17.1 per 1,000 population in 1934, as compared with 16.6 in 1933, there was no world-wide rise, reports the Statistical Bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. In twenty of the thirty-four countries whose 1934 rates have thus far been available, says the bulletin, "the declining tendency" was "still in evidence."

An interesting squash racquets experiment had a friendly outcome when a picked class B men's team played a women's metropolitan team to a 3-3 tie at the Junior League courts last night. The seventh match was left undecided when Mrs. Henry C. Brunie defaulted to George A. Phelps, No. 2 on the Yale Club B team.

M. LAVAL'S vote of confidence in the French Chamber yesterday came on a proposal for action directed against the quasi-military leagues which have flourished with hard times in France. The largest of them is Croix de Feu, claiming 700,000 members, philosophically opposed to the French "Left," but somewhat vague as to its immediate political purposes and methods.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Republican principles were applauded, but the practice of leaders in excluding women from the councils of the party was condemned at the annual luncheon meeting here today of the League of Republican Women.
Apartment-house deals by investors and operators featured the Manhattan and Bronx trading reported yesterday.

Backed by a grant of $1,752,000 from WPA funds, work was begun this week to convert the abandoned army post at Fort Schuyler, Throgs Neck, the Bronx, into a permanent home and training base for the New York State Merchant Marine Academy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A mild lecture by Secretary Hull to foreign envoys against abusing the international privilege of diplomatic immunity coincided today with an expression of regret from the United States Government to Ghaffar Khan Djalal over the Iranian (Persian) Minister's recent arrest in Maryland on a traffic charge.

Angered yesterday by a remark he thought had been made by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, Mayor La Guardia threatened in a Board of Estimate meeting to call of the plans for the World's Fair in Flushing in 1939. He dropped the subject, however, when he realized he had misunderstood what was said.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 6. -- Nine powerful trimotored Italian battle planes raided this field headquarters of Emperor Haile Selassie today, strewing the streets with dead and wounded. They bombed the American Hospital, Red Cross tents and the imperial residence.

After having lost on Thursday virtually all the improvement made on the announcement of plans for acreage control of the next crop and then steadying around 11 1/2 cents a pound for the March delivery, prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange recovered slightly to end at gains of 1 to 4 points.

With cocoa futures joining copper and sugar in a downward movement, other staples were generally firmer in fairly good volume on the local commodity futures markets. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, cocoa, rubber and silk advanced, while lard and tin declined.

ROME, Dec. 6. -- Premier Benito Mussolini, speaking in the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow, will personally reply to the friendly appeal made by the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare, in the House of Commons yesterday. At the same time he will set forth in detail the Italian position in the light of developments of the past few weeks.

President Roosevelt was the choice of 43 per cent of the Columbia College students who voted in a poll on current events conducted by The Columbia Spectator. Although the Columbia enrolment is 1,600, only 282 students voted.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Dec 6. -- Texas A. and M. and powerful Southern Methodist, Rose Bowl nominee, were primed tonight for their annual football battle tomorrow.
Money market was at a standstill, ] and on light demand /or funds] quotations were carried forward without chge.

A painting by the modern Dutch artist Vincent Van Gogh brought $15,000 last night, the highest price at an auction of paintings by American and European artists at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The sale comprised the collection of J.K. Newman of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The bombing by Italian planes today of Dessye, Ethiopia, and the hospital there of the American Seventh Day Adventist Mission aroused widespread criticism here on humanitarian grounds because of the reported wounding of non-combatants, including women and children.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec 6. -- The Ethiopian Government announced today Italian air bombing activities on the northern front were increasing, two Ethiopian soldiers having been killed and two wounded yesterday in raids by eleven planes.

GENEVA, Dec. 6. -- The Ethiopian Emperor charged Italy with violating Red Cross conventions by bombarding hospitals, including the American Hospital at Dessye today, in a personal telegram to the League of Nations.

Complete organization for the Will Rogers Memorial Fund in Alaska, where the cowboy humorist was flying when he met his death, was reported yesterday to the headquarters of the fund campaign by R.J. McKenna, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Fairbanks. "

HAMBURG, Dec. 6. -- Carrying on the speaking campaign in which various Nazi leaders are now engaged, General Hermann Goering, Reich Air Minister and Prussian Premier, spoke here tonight. His speech again demonstrated that the government is not at present interested in making any further revelations as to its policy.
LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 6. -- Dr. John A. Schaeffer was inducted this morning as president of Franklin and Marshall College at special ceremonies.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- Massachusetts, carried by the last two Democratic Presidential candidates, Alfred E. Smith in 1928 and Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932, should be a political battleground next year, with a strong possibility that the State may return to its old-time Republican allegiance.

Reports from New Jersey upland gunners indicate that the season, which will close in another week, has produced better than average shooting. On one score there is general agreement -- rabbits never have been so plentiful.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- Vassar College will have an addition to its library building which will double the present capacity of 200,000 books. The construction, estimated to cost $150,000, will begin as soon as preliminary details are complete.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP). -- Senator McNary of Oregon, Republican leader in the Senate, announced today that he would introduce on the opening day of Congress a three-point farm relief bill as a basis for a "natural transition from the AAA of a long-time program."
TOKYO, Dec. 6. -- Japan evidently desires it to be understood abroad that the Nine-Power Treaty is obsolete if it is invoked in connection with North China.

In a move to facilitate the reorganization of the Postal Telegraph Cable Corporation, now in bankruptcy, both the Lehman and Stewart bondholders committees will make a joint application in Federal court today for the appointment of trustees for the corporation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt feels that the only way for the United States to keep out of war is to have no war anywhere, he told an Albany churchman in a letter made public here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Notable increases in exports to the United Kingdom, Canada, Italy, France and Germany were features in the foreign trade of the United States during October. Revised figures on trade with individual countries and grand divisions released by the Department of Commerce today placed the total of October exports at $221,237,929 and imports at $189,239,865, with a resulting favorable balance of $31,998,000.
Gaumont-British has arranged for an interchange of players, writers and directors with Twentieth Century-Fox.

THE most recent writings on Arnold Bennett are reminiscent of that divine who once said from his pulpit that he was going to offer up not a prayer but an explanation. When Bennett died, the picture of him for the public mind was set as he had apparently wanted it to be. It was a little glassy, a little hard, but quite complete.

Ways of reducing substantially the number of Fourth of July accidents, including the extension of State and local legislation and Federal control over the fireworks industry, were urged by speakers yesterday at a luncheon conference in the Hotel Commodore.

Prizes for last Winter's competition in the Skate Sailing Association of America were awarded last night at a dinner in the Hotel Buckingham, 101 West Fifty-seventh Street. In the gathering, which was a social one arranged by William J. Stuebe, vice commodore of the local division of the association, were fifty devotees of the sport of gliding on the ice carrying a sail to catch the wind.

The 1935 college football season, one of the most spectacular of post-war years, has produced an all-America team qualified in nearly every respect to take its place among the most accomplished in the gridiron hall of fame.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 6. -- The warm and typically Southern hospitality freely extended to the undefeated and untied Baldwin High School football squad will be temporarily discontinued on Cameron Field tomorrow, when the Long Islanders participate in their second post-season clash with Petersburg High in two years, scheduled for 2 P.M.
In regard to the editorial "Medical Patents" it seems to me that the author overlooked a few salient facts.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 6. -- The Duke Power Company has received approval of the North Carolina Utilities Commission for its plan to refinance a major part of its outstanding bonds and short-term notes in order to reduce interest charges, it was announced here today.

A resolution against American participation in the Olympic Games will be placed "without recommendation" before the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States today at a general session of its annual convention in the Hotel Commodore as a result of a tie vote on the issue yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee.

In a move to facilitate the reorganization of the Postal Telegraph Cable Corporation, now in bankruptcy, both the Lehman and Stewart bondholders committees will make a joint application in Federal court today for the appointment of trustees for the corporation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- President Roosevelt feels that the only way for the United States to keep out of war is to have no war anywhere, he told an Albany churchman in a letter made public here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Honeybrook Big Parade, young champion, owned, bred and handled by Willard R. Van Dyck of Upper Darby, Pa., was named the best in show at the annual fixture of the Collie Club of America, which was staged at the Westchester County Centre today.

RADIO, as operated by the United States Navy, has had a busy year, according to a report to President Roosevelt by Secretary of the Navy, Claude A. Swanson. It is estimated that 127,031,726 words were transmitted over the naval-shore radio system, saving the Federal Government more than $3,250,000, figured at commercial rates.

The Harlem evening schools have reached the saturation point in registration as a result of the eagerness of Father Divine's flock for learning. A descent from the "kingdom" to the levels of worldly wisdom started a year ago. Now classes are "packed," but adherents of the Divine cult are still flocking to school at the rate of 150 a week.

An "epochal transition" in banking in this State, in common with the entire American banking system, involving changes in the character of bank assets and deposits such that "our commercial banks have taken on something of the nature of investment trusts" is described in a detailed study of banking developments in this State between 1923 and 1934 published yesterday by the New York State Bankers Association.

The Long Island University quintet vanquished the University of Newark five, 53 to 35, last night for its third victory of the season. The contest was played in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium before 1,200 spectators.

The New York Junior League Players will present their first production of the season, "The Siege at Christmas," a children's play by James Gardner Hellman, this week at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

ONLY recently have the unique merits of the saintpaulias -- generally known as African Violets -- been recognized. They are particularly valuable for indoor gardens that receive little sunshine, as they will bloom in any light window, even though it looks to the north.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Business in Puerto Rico improved during the fiscal year 1935, despite the lowest trade balance in several years, Governor Blanton Winship said in his annual report made public here today.

THERE is a kind of homely, appealing charm in the Negro themes by Henry Botkin, which were on view until Saturday at the Marie Harriman Gallery. As previously related, Mr. Botkin journeyed down to the "Porgy and Bess" country with George Gershwin, whose opera is having a run at the Alvin Theatre.

IF the product of the publishers' presses is a good indication, there is a renewed and active interest in the study of musical history. And this is not only in elementary treatment for beginners but in a more detailed fashion, needing the attention of musically educated readers.

THE TIMES published recently a dispatch that "the bodies of 400 Chinese will be exhumed and sent to China." As a former manager of the Pacific Mail and Toyo Kisen Kaisha at Hongkong, I would give the interesting information that these will arrive in Hongkong and Shanghai manifested as "fish bones," which is sacred custom from the days of the Yankee clipper ships.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7. -- The 15,000 banks of the United States are the hardy survivors of the 30,000 banks of the pre-depression days, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said tonight in an address before Group V of the California Bankers Association.

THE translator quotes Prince Buelow's appraisal of Gustav Stresemann: "He is the most notable figure of the new Parliamentary Germany, and as Foreign Minister has shown qualities that have extorted the respect of the foreigner."

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- Gerald Albouy is creating a furor with his novel evening headdresses, which are individually designed for leading Parisian elegantes. One is a flowered coiffure of multi-colored forget-me-nots that rests on top of the head; a lace veil falls down the back -- this is very Spring-like.
Sets of the works of famous authors, rare color-plate books and other items will be offered at auction at the American Art Associaton Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Saturday afternoon.

HELPED by favorable weather in most sections, retail business in the week enjoyed a combination of seasonal and holiday trade that sent sales totals ahead in a very satisfactory manner. Cold weather needs were required and volume gift buying started up earlier than usual.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7. -- Film executives groaned today when they learned that Emilie and Yvonne Dionne, of the quintuplets, have cut new teeth during the filming of their first feature-length picture at Callander, Ont.

THERE comes a time in collaborations when, as the fellow says, enough is enough. Though this is my first experience, I believe that ordinarily this point is reached just before the New York opening which climaxes the weeks of casting, rehearsals, try-outs and drug-store coffee. Anyhow, I've reached it.
OTTAWA, Dec. 6. -- Prime Minister MacKenzie King returned from his southern holiday this week to find, as one so often finds after holidays, that trouble was awaiting him.

FIRST LADY: While the President was in Georgia last week Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited New York and took in the play "First Lady." She was much amused by its picture of Washington intrigue and went backstage afterward to talk it over with Jane Cowl, the leading lady.

ROME, Dec. 7. -- Premier Mussolini spoke for twelve minutes in his address to the Chamber of Deputies today, reading a manuscript. His free right hand moved constantly for emphasis. When he assailed the League of Nations his clenched fist was raised and his face contorted with emotion.

The sum of $24,017 was obtained for the collection of postage stamps with many original drawings owned by the late Beverly S. King at the auction last week by George B. Sloane at 116 Nassau Street. Mr. King was killed by an automobile in Washington last March.

PEIPING, Dec 7. -- Although use of the word "autonomy" is studiously avoided, the provinces of Hopei and Chahar and the cities of Peiping and Tientsin are expected to be included in a virtually autonomous area early next week under the "North China Political Affairs Council."

AT least two of the Metropolitan Opera's important newcomers have just cause to be impatient with a multi-lingual world. Having mastered sizable repertoires in one language, they must now proceed to learn them in another. It is not an easy task to replace a new set of words for a group that has always been associated with a certain melodic line.

Tracy H. Lewis captured the principal prizes in the New York Athletic Club shoot at Travers Island yesterday, first taking the High Scratch Cup, with 94 out of 100 targets. Then he took the doubles scratch trophy, getting 25 in 15 pairs of doubles.

THE two photographs above show the present stage of construction of the Henry Hudson Parkway, for which an allotment of $1,450,000 was recently granted by the Federal Government, as part of $10,546,000 for New York State.

ROME, Dec. 6. -- The League of Nations' sanctions, now in their third week, although their pinch is being increasingly felt, have so far failed either to halt the war in East Africa or to weaken the Italian determination to conquer Ethiopia.
TORONTO, Dec. 7 (AP). -- The Maple Leafs gained a 2-1 overtime victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The muddled political situation among Colgate University students which has split the student body into "secessionists" and "standpatters" seems nearer settlement than at any time this Fall.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Roosevelt farm program will be brought before the Supreme Court of the United States tomorrow in the long-awaited test of the constitutionality of AAA. By coincidence, the President himself has chosen the same day to speak before the American Farm Bureau Federation in defense of the farm policies of his administration.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 7. -- Undeterred by the State Supreme Court's ruling that his board of managers of the Highway Department are "trespassers" and without authority, Governor Olin D. Johnston held on grimly to the road offices today.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- The advent of colder weather has stimulated the demand both at retail and wholesale for Winter merchandise. Particularly marked has been the pick-up in sales of both men's and women's apparel. Local department stores report a heavy movement of Christmas goods. Nearly all merchants expect this will be the best holiday season for several years.

Stimulated by cold weather and Christmas shopping, trade and industrial activity in practically all sections of the nation established five-year records last week. Retail volume soared, manufacturing ran counter to seasonal trends, auto sales registered substantial gains and employment in stores and factories broadened sharply.

BACK in the season of 1917-18, under the tutelage of Arthur Hopkins, there ran at the Plymouth Theatre a play called "The Gipsy Trail," by one Robert Housum. One hundred and eleven performances. Today, the road all playwrights come, the same Mr. Housum is knocking at the gate again with a play for the same Mr. Hopkins.
WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- Japan's challenge to the industrial nations took a wider sweep this month with the arrival in Southern waters of the first whaling fleet to sail from Nippon to the South.

ALL over this country young men trained for foreign trade have been working in department stores, or selling insurance, electric appliances, books or even stocks and bonds, patiently waiting till there are jobs again in American foreign trade.
Joe Louis, sensational undefeated Brown Bomber, and Paulino Uzcudun, Basque Woodehopper, will battle fifteen rounds or less Friday night in Madison Square Garden in the interests of charity.

Premier honors in the national four-wall handball singles ranking for 1935 have been awarded to the present titleholder, Joseph P. Platak of Chicago, according to the listing announced yesterday by the National A.A.U. handball committee. Sam Atcheson of Memphis, Tenn., runner-up to Platak and champion in 1933 and 1934, has been ranked No. 2.

The United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net income of $1,463,766 after all deductions, equivalent to $2.43 a share earned on 600,000 no-par shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock, compared with $885,866, or $1.47 a share on the same stock in the preceding twelve months.
DUBLIN, Dec. 6. -- This week President Eamon de Valera and his Ministers had to render an account of their stewardship before the annual convention of the Fianna Fall party here.

In their last game of the regular scheduled season, the Giants, defending National Football League champions, will clash with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. The contest will start at 2 o'clock, fifteen minutes earlier than usual.

A dinner with dancing was given last night by Mr. and Mrs. L. Stuart Wing in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis to introduce to society Miss Beatrce Kunhardt, debutante daughter of Mrs. Wing. Miss Kunhardt wore a gown of iridescent metal cloth and carried a muff of orchids, and Mrs. Wing was in pale blue satin with a corsage of orchids.

ALONG about the first of the year Metro hopes to have a sizable fraction of the movie-going public looking at the world through rose (and blue) colored glasses. Seeking a novelty to charm its fickle audiences, the company has revived the stereoscopic film which first was tried publicly about eleven years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -Fast-moving political events are shaping the destiny of former President Hoover and, political observers assert, swelling sentiment for Senator Borah as the Republican standard-bearer in 1936.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Thirty-two pairs who survived yesterday's elimination round of the open pair championship of the American Bridge League's contract bridge tournament entered the final round here today with a Chicago pair leading.

WHATEVER the outcome of the effort on the part of the Bureau of Air Commerce to secure an airplane of unusually safe flying characteristics which can be produced in quantity at a cost of from $700 to $1,000, there can be no doubt that it has stimulated design and production of some small planes of interest and novelty.

Many cities throughout the United States will soon follow the example of New York City and initiate anti-noise campaigns, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday. The Mayor based his prediction on the flood of requests for information as to the local campaign which have been sent in by officials and civic groups in other communities.

A NEW type of school for peasant women, designed to fit them for more effective life on the soil, has been inaugurated in Germany. The "Bauerliche Frauenschule" (peasant women's school) is comparable to the American junior college in that it may either serve as a connecting link between secondary school and college, or as a terminal institution.

Gloom reached a high point here last month with less sunshine than has been recorded in the city during November for more than twenty-four years, according to David R. Morris, meteorologist at the New York Meteorological Observatory, operated in Central Park under the Federal Weather Bureau.

Formation of the Gerster-Gardini Club is announced by Mrs. Edgar Stillman-Kelly, former head of the National Federation of Music Clubs, with which the new group has already affiliated, as it has with the Metropolitan Opera Guild. A reception in honor of the vocal educator, Mme. Berta Gerster-Gardini, for whom the club was named, will be held next Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Counsel for the defense and prosecution in the case of Nick Montana, indicted for compulsory prostitution, completed their arguments at 10:30 o'clock last night before Judge Cornelius F. Collins and a jury in the Court of General Sessions.

ALL through the holiday season heavy shipments of citrus fruits come to Eastern markets from California, Florida and the sunny Southwest. This week again they are speeding North and East by the hundred car lots, by train and truck -- once the golden apples of legend, now fruit for the table, taken for granted in Winter-bound city and country alike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Supreme Court was generally presumed to have reached a decision late today on whether to grant Bruno Richard Hauptmann's request for review of his conviction of kidnapping and murdering the Lindbergh baby.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 7. -- Addressing the Kansas Young Republican Club here tonight, Governor Alf M. Landon declared that the 1936 election, confronting the voters with an issue transcending a choice between parties, would decide "whether the American people want to strengthen democratic institutions or to accept more centralization of power."

NINE hundred Japanese girls sat on the matted floor, their feet tucked under them, while an old gentleman addressed them on "Mutual Love." The sermon over, a younger man-in shirt-sleeves, for it was noon and hot -- recited sentences from their scriptures.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, who are passing the season on their yacht, Coconut, will open Casa Beata tomorrow morning for a large informal party similar to those which they gave there Sundays in previous Winters.

The first of a series of regional conferences planned by the American Bankers Association will be held in Philadelphia on Jan. 23 and 24, it was announced yesterday by the association. The meeting, which will be held at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, will cover the Eastern States. Subsequent meetings will be held in other sections of the country for bankers in those districts.
Fanfare attendant upon the production of "This 'n' That" at the Mutual Benefit Auditorium, Newark, on Friday and Saturday by members of the Newark Junior League, would do credit to Barnum himself.

In THE TIMES of Nov. 17 you print a letter by Mr. Nicholas Haz attacking the two articles by Lewis Jacobs (issues of Oct. 20 and Oct. 27, respectively), in which the latter attempted to appraise American film directors since Griffith. Heaven knows I have no particular reason to leap to the defense of Mr. Jacobs.

The business conduct committee of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that members carrying international arbitrage accounts for non-member foreign correspondents who are registered with and approved by the committee on foreign business need not apply to such accounts the requirements applicable to margin accounts set forth in Circulars C-5221 and C-5262.

After an hour's conference yesterday morning at his home at 820 Park Avenue with Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Governor Lehman announced he would issue in Albany tomorrow the formal order directing Mr. Bennett to supersede District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County in the investigation of the murder of Samuel Druckman, garage worker.

PHILADELPHIA. -- Intermittent criticism of the structure of Philadelphia's public school system during the last few years is about to result in a survey of the city's educational methods by a group of outside experts.
The appointment of 111 students to the staff of the "Violet" yearbook of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance was announced yesterday by Associate Dean George R. Collins.

New Rochelle High School's powerful football team, winner of the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association championship, placed four men on the county's annual all-scholastic eleven, according to the selections announced yesterday. Coaches of the twenty-nine major teams in Westchester and twelve sports writers collaborated in picking the squad.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh are firmly convinced that Bruno Richard Hauptmann is the kidnapper and murderer of their son. Sources close to the couple made that plain on their behalf in Englewood yesterday while in several cities matters pertaining to the famous case were being advanced, often through a maze of controversy.

The primal desire to slay birds and beasts stirs the pot hunters of New York City these days even though they are far outside the law. Recent arrests show that their tribe does not decrease. Legally they have no leg on which to stand.
DETROIT. ALMOST six months after the NRA was declared legally dead by the Supreme Court, the automobile industry is still observing the regulations that were designed far rapid economic recovery.

THE grand old game of politics is about to begin. The players are trotting up and down, flexing their vocal cords. The coaches are bellowing instructions. The fans -- 125 millions of them -- are gathering, and paying, to see the quadrennial combat. Presently there will be shin-kicking, gouging, black eyes and cauliflower ears, to say nothing of cauliflower reputations, and the fans will love it.

The foreigner has a wine for every mood. Conan Doyle knew this and made his famous character, the war-scarred Napoleonic veteran, Brigadier Etienne Gerard, begin each of his cafe reminiscences in this fashion: "Gentlemen, I will have a wine of Auvergne tonight."

Two hundred and twenty-three more friends of New York's Neediest Cases came to the help of those in greatest distress in all the city yesterday, as the first week of the appeal ended with a grand total of 854,804.62 on hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Every person in the country will figuratively shoulder an indebtedness of over $240 on Dec. 16 as his share of the debts owed by the Federal Government. On that date the Federal debt will reach about $30,500,000,000, the highest total in the history of the country.

PROBABLY there are more human beings on the face of the earth who want what the title of this book indicates -- zest for life, enjoyment of life, or, more briefly, happiness -- than who want anything else that could be offered them.
" You bum! Throw him out if he opens his mouth again. I will treat you the same as you were treated in the Surrogate's Court, you faker."

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Italian Embassy, in a statement issued tonight based on information from Rome on the bombing of Dessye, denied the American Hospital or Gondar has been bombed. It said the use of incendiary bombs was a reprisal against Ethiopians' use of dumdum bullets.

WINTER cruise itineraries will this year undergo one of the most radical changes ever made in their history. The Italo-Ethiopian war is both directly and indirectly responsible for this wide alteration in schedules.

ADVENTURERS and trailsmen of the Far West watched Idaho last month as an expedition sponsored by the National Geographic Society explored one of the wildest river canyons on the North American continent. Starting at Salmon City, the party navigated the 350-mile stretch of the Salmon River gorge to Lewiston, in the northwest section of the State.

A survey of safety in world shipping by Lloyd's Register of Shipping as reflected by tonnage lost at sea indicates that the degree of safety on American ships is more than twice as great as that of the average commercial shipping afloat.

Five firemen were overcome and eleven others injured last night while companies summoned on two alarms fought a smoky blaze in the basement of the fifteen-story apartment building at 255 West Eighty-eighth Street, at the northwest corner of Broadway.

IN 1775 not only were the English in America being forced to decide between the King and the Colonies but the necessary decision was tearing the Indian peoples apart. In Dr. Eleazar Wheelock's school for Indians at Hanover feeling ran high, and young Philip Brewster, in whose veins ran English and French as well as Indian blood, found the choice a painfully difficult one.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7. -- The United States Olympic hockey team candidates opened their preliminary try-out series tonight by defeating Yale in the New Haven arena, 3 -- 1.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 20. STRINDBERG as a triumphant public success is the decidedly novel phenomenon of the season here with "A Dream Play" running night after night while the red lanterns glow outside the Royal Dramatic to indicate that the house is filled to capacity.

On the eve of the President's address before the American Farm Bureau Federation at Chicago and of the argument to be made before the Supreme Court in the test case of both of which events are scheduled for tomorrow -- Secretary WALLACE has suggested various alternatives which the Government might pursue in case the processing tax is held to be unconstitutional.

THE appeal of contract bridge as a public spectacle will receive its first real test when, according to announcement last week, French and American teams will play the finals of their international tournament on Dec. 23 at Madison Square Garden.

Industry's "lack of a plan" for voluntary or semi-government control of business is the chief reason why so many groups have decided to boycott the conference with Major Berry in Washington tomorrow, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by several trade association executives.

CHRISTMAS this year brings with it not only lots of cheer (times are better) but plenty of enchanting novelties for gifts. Shopping should not be difficult with so much to choose from. From far and wide articles have poured onto the counters.

GENEVA, Dec. 7. -- After a four-day deadlock the five experts advising the council on reorganizing refugee work renounced late tonight trying further to reach a unanimous agreement. The British, French, Czechoslovak and Norwegian experts drew up a majority report to the League of Nations Council, and the Italian Ambassador, Giuseppi de Michelis, drew up a minority report. Both reports were withheld.
One of the earliest of the month's Yule frolics is the old-fashioned Ohio Christmas party to be held tomorrow on the Hotel St. Regis roof by the Daughters of Ohio. Daniel Frohman will be a guest.

A Winter bouquet show, to be held Tuesday from 3 until 9 in the Casino, will feature the program of the Garden City-Hempstead Community Club this week. It will be under the direction of the garden department.

New State and municipal bond issues reported as having been approved by the voters of 437 communities in thirty-eight States during November amount to $118,809,719. This total compares with $43,767,739 in October, and with a total of $168,325,950 in November, 1934.

ATLANTIC CITY. N.J., Dec. 7. -- A.S Johnson of Rutgers University was elected president of the Association of University and College Business Officers of the Eastern States at the close of its sixteenth annual convention here today.
I have been interested in the letters which have appeared in THE TIMES during the last few months on the subject of rural schools.

The placing in a voting trust of the International Hydro-Electric System's 88 per cent interest in the New England Power Association does little beyond creating a legal separation of interests, since operations of the New England group have been virtually autonomous for several years.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Fog cast a gloomy pall over English soccer today and four matches, three of them in London, were either postponed or abandoned.

A man who could maintain a regime of communal living and could execute bold and unorthodox experiments in social and industrial life in this country for a space of forty years in the nineteenth century must have possessed the rare attributes of genius.

An exhilarating buzz and radiance that begins to seep into every phase of existence along about this time of year is conspicuous these days in the Christmas sales of handiwork, at which members of many organizations are preparing to make the holidays more enjoyable for the less privileged.

A sparkling 100-yard free-style performance by Tom McDermott of George Washington High School, who won in 0:53.2, enlivened the eighth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school team championship of the Public Schools Athletic League, conducted in the seventy-five-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School yesterday.

THE new management at the Metropolitan Opera intends to keep things moving, at least during the opening week. While there is nothing astonishing in the repertoire for the first six days -- "Traviata," "Walkuere," "Faust," Hansel and Gretel," "Aida," "Lohengrin" and "Boheme" -- there will be a series of new faces.

THERE is range and depth and variety in these essays by the former Canon of Worcester. Although none of them is more than a few pages in length, and although many are written in a more or less discursive and conversational style, still all contain some solid nucleus of thought, whether their subject be literary criticism, religious rumination, historical commentary or general observations concerning modern life and civilization.

PRINTS may now be seen in abundance, with more to come as the season advances. Of the large exhibition (twentieth annual) presented by the Society of American Etchers, Inc., at the National Arts Club, we have already spoken. This will be current through Dec. 26.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- When President Roosevelt's train comes into the Union Station next week, he will have rounded out 50,000 miles of travel since he became resident of the White House.

Diplomatic endeavors to arrange some sort of settlement of the Ethiopian conflict last week were overshadowed by a piece of real war news. Italian airmen dropped 1,000 bombs on Dessye, headquarters of Emperor Haile Selassie. The Emperor grabbed a machine gun and opened up on his attackers, apparently without scoring a hit. He, too, escaped harm.
PASTEL came prominently into play last week, with three exihibitions devoted largely or altogether to work in this medium.

GENEVA, Dec. 6. -- When Baron Aloisi of Italy pleaded with the League of Nations powers not to give against Italy a verdict of guilty of making war in disregard of the covenant, which automatically requires the judges to apply sanctions, he stressed that the nations had not done this to Japan.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6. -- The Anti-Saloon League of America, meeting in annual convention in St. Louis this week, served fair warning that it will attempt to return prohibition to the Constitution, and fixed the date at 1945, when league leaders believe at least forty States will have voted favorably on another dry amendment.

Continued improvement in general business conditions next year is indicated by the upward trend of the machine tool industry, C.J. Stilwell, vice president of the Warner Swasey Company of Cleveland, said yesterday.

Two hours after a hit-and-run driver had struck and killed Areta Korneaktos, 9 years old, of 11-36 Forty-fourth Drive, Long Island City, last night, a few blocks from her home, a 17-year-old errand boy, who, the police said, had no license and could not handle a car, gave himself up four miles away from the scene.

With ample stocks in all departments, retailers obtained full benefit of the cold snap last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby Block Co. Business in Winter goods, coupled with early Christmas shopping, brought figures of stores throughout the country to 10 to 15 per cent larger than a year ago.

THIS intelligent study of the changing philosophy of literary leaders in England is a book of wide view, searching understanding and suggestive conclusions, even if these conclusions may not always be in agreement with a reader's own. In method, the book is unsatisfactory, not to say annoying.

A PASSENGER on Northwest Air Lines flying westward on the airway to the Northern Pacific Coast of the United States sees rolling dairy country, rich and populous towns and cities, great barns and lakes and forests between Chicago and the Twin Cities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Retail trade continued at the exceptionally active pace set immediately after Thanksgiving. Crowds at times taxed the capacity of the elevators and escalators in the larger department stores. Sales in dollars are probably averaging close to 15 per cent ahead of last year along State Street, with some of the stores exceeding this increase and others falling a little below it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP). -- For the last year wages and salaries of government workers alone have cost more a month than it cost to operate the entire government, including the army and navy, for any year before the Civil War.

Eighty-two per cent of more than 10,000 manufacturers throughout the country have voted "No" to the question, "Do you favor legislation continuing in any form the principles and policies of the NIRA?" it was disclosed yesterday.

New Yorkers will see by television within five years, according to David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America. As far as the immediate future is concerned, Mr. Sarnoff confesses the pessimists now have a little the better of the argument.

WHETHER it be a palm tree of the South Seas or a sturdy northern oak, woodcraft or seacraft, animal lore or Indian lore, there is hardly a phase of Scouting that is not illustrated on the postage stamps of the world's nations.

As the reader may guess from the title, this is neither an outline nor a theory but just a breezy series of anecdotal chats on the subject of mental health, which the layman can read lazily and perhaps profitably. There seems to be very little structure to this book.

The radio equipment of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will be sufficiently powerful to permit her passengers to speak to any part of the world, officials of the line announce. The giant ship will use thirty-two radio wave lengths in maintaining contact with other ships and with land.

Neutrality legislation designed to keep the United States out of war, an absorbing discussion theme among the larger groups of women of the country, has been named as one of the "big three" items on which the National League of Women Voters will concentrate in the coming session of Congress.

Have at you, sir! In your columns of Nov. 30 you refer to a major in the United States Army whose evening at "Pride and Prejudice" was spoiled by the discovery that the officer in the play wears an American scabbard for his sword.

ROBERT ANTHONY EDEN is 37 and the world's first Minister for League of Nations Affairs. This post was especially created for him by the British Government, Introduced to Geneva in 1932 by Sir John Simon. former Foreign Secretary, he was taken at first by his foreign colleagues and League officials for only another of the young aristocrats from the British Foreign Office.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 7. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, today reduced the lead of the challenger, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, by winning the twenty-seventh game of their title match, which was adjourned last night after 40 moves had been made.

THE London cable, getting right down to business, reports the following events of the current week: Tonight the Aldwych Repertory Players are doing H.M. Harwood's satire of ancient Greece, "These Mortals," with Frank Vosper and Isabel Jeans.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 7. -- Captain Henry, a sturdy Chesapeake Bay dog owned by Mrs. F.J. Frank of Madison, N.J., and handled in the field by William Gladwin, was judged the victor today in the non-winners stake, opening event of the retriever meeting of the Brook Haven Game Protective Association, on the estate of Gerald B. Hollins.

SOCIAL agencies in New York City that are engaged with the problem of juvenile delinquency are keenly interested in the report on the Jersey City plan recently submitted by Edward R. Rayher, chairman of the Committee on Domestic Relations of the New York County Lawyers Association.

Lynn Garrow of "Buckaroo" and "The Mounted Falcon" figures again as heroine in "The House of Many Tongues." Lynn is still in Prague, helping with plans for the 20,000 students of the Czech and German universities who, in the face of intolerable living conditions and an almost total lack of resources, are struggling to go on with their education.

Leaders of the "regular" Socialist party moved yesterday to prevent a threatened disruption of the citywide organization. Admitting that at least thirty-nine delegates to the City Central Committee, representing twenty-eight branches, had bolted at a party meeting last Wednesday and had set up an independent organization, the "regulars'' declared they had worked out a plan to retain control in all branches.

IT might represent the performance of a real service were some Learned Society to sift the problem of abstract sculpture. One of the first questions posed in its ratiocination ought to be: Why are abstract theses so much more "difficult" when carved or modeled by a sculptor, "in the round," than when painted on what Gertrude Stein so acutely describes as a "flat surface"?

The general convention of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States at the Hotel Commodore received and tabled yesterday a resolution "calling upon" American athletes to stay away from the Olympic Games in Germany.

In 1783 the first balloon, built by the Montgolfier brothers, had an ascension at Versailles, witnessed by the King of France, Queen Marie Antoinette and Benjamin Franklin. Marjorie Flack tells the story of this momentous event not from the viewpoint of the assembled court of France but from that of the first living creatures to make an ascent into the air -- a cock, a duck and a sheep from an unknown French farm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Suggestions for a Federal budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1936, which would show a net surplus of $264,617,000 instead of a predicted net deficit of $3,272,075,589 if the present governmental spending policies are continued, were made public here today by the National Economy League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- More than 3,000 representatives of industry and labor will he assembled to discuss common problems when the industry conference called by George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, meets here Monday.

THE movement to establish a chain of International Youth Hostels in the United States, where the young travelers of the world may meet on common terms and find accommodations at moderate rates, has been given a long push ahead with the dedication recently at Northfield, Mass., of American International Youth Headquarters.

The United States Lines received a bid of $11,600,000 yesterday on its proposed new cabin liner which will serve the New York-Hamburg trade with the Manhattan and Washington. The bid, by the Newport News Shipbuilding Corporation, was the only "firm offer" received from four yards invited to submit figures.

LONDON, Dec 7. -- Japan announced flatly today she demanded absolute naval parity with the United States and Great Britain. The announcement threw even more gloom about the international conference opening Monday.

General Charles H. Sherrill, member of the International Olympic Committee, who favors American participation in the 1936 Olympic Games, scheduled to be held in Germany, made public last night a letter he had received, following a protest by him to Cardinal Hayes against an article in a Roman Catholic publication.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 7. -- On May 2 next the world may look over the shoulder of a Wellesley student to learn what she sees and studies on her way to a bachelor's degree. On that day classes and laboratories will be thrown open to the public.

BEN ARONIN has availed himself in his second novel of a curious device for telling a story of the persecution of the Jews under the Spanish Inquisition. The device, while curious, is not exactly unusual. Nor does Mr. Aronin go to any trouble to make it convincing, as a novelist of the pseudo-scientific school would certainly have done.
General James G. Harbord of Rye will be the guest of honor and speaker before members of the Manor Club of Pelham Manor and their guests on Friday evening.

Among the parties last night for debutantes was the dinner dance that Mr. and Mrs. James Madison Austin gave at the Pierre to introduce to society Miss Barbara West, daughter of the hostess. It was held in the roof garden at several tables on which were pink snapdragons, roses and lilies.

In a sea chopped into whitecaps by a wind that rode slightly in advance of oncoming darkness, a twenty-month-old baby and his young mother were transferred at Ambrose Lightship late yesterday afternoon from a seaplane to a small sea yawl, thence to the pilot boat and finally through a wide-swung, light-filled port of the Swedish liner Gripsholm, outward bound.

JEAN SIBELIUS celebrates his seventieth birthday today in Finland, and the world pays homage to his genius. It was not always so. Thirty-five years ago the present acknowledged master was virtually unknown in America. When Theodoro Thomas in Chicago and Wilhelm Gericke in Boston introduced Sibelius's Second symphony in the year 1904, the music brought scarcely a flutter of applause.

AFTER a prodigal beginning the Winter film season bogged down a trifle during November. There were diamonds, to be sure, among the perishable stuffs that briefly warmed the Broadway screens. In the English-speaking cinema the month earned a place in the history of the film year because of "Mutiny on the Bounty" and the delightful, if somewhat neglected, romantic comedy called "Hands Across the Table."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A famous American fighting unit, the Fifteenth Infantry, the "Can Do" regiment, stands guard over American citizens at Tientsin, metropolis of North China. At its present post since 1912, the regiment carries on its colors the figure of a Chinese dragon in gold on a blue field with the words "Can Do" -- an eloquent expression in pidgin English of the ability to deliver the goods.

THE Wyndham sisters, blonde and brunette, middle-class New York beauties, discontented with the narrow circumstances of their lives, are ambitious to better themselves by contriving wealthy marriages. Laura works as a stenographer, Lotty as a mannequin, and the former's intimacy with her boss is abruptly stopped when his wife objects to the affair, in consequence of which he discharges Laura with a liberal bonus to ease the girl's loss of her job and his love.

DUBLIN, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Victorious, 17 -- 9. in one of the most thrilling matches of its British Isles tour, New Zealand recorded its third triumph over Ireland in international rugby today. In a game marked by numerous penalties which led to nearly half of the points the All Blacks won by taking advantage of opportunities when in their opponents' territory.

Surviving accidents and a burning pace, the team of Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel, German cyclists making their debut here, last night rode to victory in the fifty-ninth international six-day race in Madison Square Garden, while a crowd of about 11,000 set up a deafening roar.

This is the third novel in which Mr. Downing has used Mexico as a background. The principal characters, however, are Americans, and the detective in this book, as in the two earlier ones, is Hugh Rennert, an agent of the Customs Bureau of the United States Treasury Department, although he is not acting in his official capacity.

Taking advantage of the good-will prevailing during the holiday season, racketeers have set up fake charities, it was disclosed yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, in a warning to the public against their solicitations. The Welfare Department solicitation unit has already received inquiries about apparently spurious charity organizations.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- More than 100 persons will participate, in "Frolics of 1935," a musical revue to be presented by the New Rochelle League for Service on Friday and Saturday evenings in the auditorium of the New Rochelle High School.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange crossed the 1,000,000-share mark in November for the first time in almost two years. The total was 1,032,788 shares, a rise of 102,569 from the 930,219 in October.

That complete stoppage of the flow of oil to Italy would throttle Italian efforts to beat Ethiopia is abundantly plain. The League of Nations' Sanctions Committee is to start formal deliberations on the question of an oil embargo on Thursday.

FORTUNE smiled upon George Moore when he made himself free of other men's lives for the matter of his books, but when he sought to name his own official biographer, she was perverse, perhaps avengeful.

IN the Fourteenth Annual of Advertising Art, M.F. Agha, who writes the foreword, explains the efforts of the Art Directors Club to make the yearly exhibitions representative of the best advertising art of the period, stripped of sales appeal and typographical aids or drawbacks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Henry G. Alsberg, director of the WPA's writers' division, today appealed to the public to cooperate with the 3,000 unemployed newspaper men, photographers and research workers now compiling material for The American Guide.

Creation of State mortgage banks as substitutes for the "outworn and discredited" mortgage guarantee companies is being considered by the State Mortgage Commission, Wendell P. Barker, the commission's chairman, told a national conference on debtor relief laws yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Alfred B. Maclay's collection of early American glass realized $24, 064 when auctioned Thursday, Friday and yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. The final session yesterday afternoon brought $11,682, or almost as much as the combined total of the two previous sessions, $12,382.

New York City's WPA, which was believed to have attained its full stature last Nov. 1, has suddenly begun to grow again, nourished by new quotas from Washington. The latest goal -- likely to be reached within the next fortnight -- is 255,000 workers, an increase of approximately 12 per cent over the quota reached a month ago.

The Pennsylvania and Erie railroad companies were charged with violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in separate suits filed by the Merchants Refrigerating Company and the Union Terminal Cold Storage Company, Inc., in Federal court Friday, it was learned yesterday.

Tomorrow night at 8:30 o'clock in the roof garden of the Pennsylvania Hotel two of the world's leading pocket billiard players will step to the table to start the first of forty-five games in a thirteen-day tournament from which a new world champion is expected to emerge.

THE Founding Fathers, and John Jay belongs to them, with Washington, Adams, Jefferson and Hamilton, have suffered variously at the hands of their biographers. With the exception of Jay, these leaders have been frequent subjects for analysis and tribute, from the time of Parson Weems to the present, but none has yet, a century and more after he finished his work, been portrayed to general satisfaction.

THE solemn purpose of this artless tale is to demonstrate the fatal capacity of circumstantial evidence to effect the erroneous conviction and execution of an innocent man tried for murder. But the substantiating details of that premise are aligned in a fashion so dull and wooden as never to exert any hold whatever upon the read er's sympathy or imagination in following the case, before and after the crime, of the unfortunate Renolds.

Criticism of lawyers who resort to "sensational publicity and ballyhoo'' in handling their cases was expressed last night by Harold R. medina, Associate professor of Law at Columbia University. He spoke at the fifty-eighth annual dinner of the Hudson County, N.J., Bar Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MOST books on science intended for the reading of laymen deal with the achievements of science, the problems it it has solved -- its battles with ignorance and its triumphs. But this new book by A.W. Haslett, the British scientist connected with King's College, Cambridge University, whose "Radio Round the World" was published in this country not long ago, looks to the future for possible triumphs yet to come.

The franc reacted slightly yesterday following its sharp rally on Friday, but quotations continued above the gold-shipping point. The net loss was 1/8 point, the close being 6.60 5/8 cents, up 1 7/8 points on the week. Netherlands guilders fell 7 points to 67.85 cents, and Swiss francs were off 1 1/2 points to 32.45 1/2 cents.

ANOTHER of the great dreams of aviation moved toward realization last week when British, Canadian and Irish Free State authorities in civil aviation met at Washington with the American body bearing the long title.

American furniture and decorations of the Colonial and early Federal periods, dating from the seventeenth to the early nineteenth century, together with English Queen Anne and Georgian furniture, porcelains and other items, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Moving swiftly to conciliate local importers who complained last week of delays in getting merchandise through the United States Appraiser's Stores, the Treasury Department was in a position yesterday to announce that merchandise examinations have been brought up to date.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- An allotment of $668,000 made a month ago by the WPA for development of an airport in central Westchester County was canceled today. The airport was to have been the first owned and operated by the county.

A fake magazine salesman, charged by the police with having swindled Catholic priests out of thousands of dollars over a period of seventeen years by selling bogus magazine subscriptions, was arraigned before Magistrate William A. Farrell in Yorkville Court yesterday and held in $1,500 bail for trial in Special Sessions.

THE former Mrs. Gustav Mahler, who previous to her first marriage was the composer Alma Schindler, is now in New York with her husband, Franz Werfel. He is superintending the preparations now being made in the Manhattan Opera House for the forthcoming production of his drama "The Eternal Road," music by Kurt Weill.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Lafayette threw a real scare into Pennsylvania in the opening basketball game at the Palestra tonight, the Red and Blue not winning until an extra period. Then Jim Bradford, football end, accounted for six points, the final score being 41 to 37.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The sum of $25,000,000 annually will have to be spent in the construction of the $143,000,000 trans-Florida ship canal if it is to be completed with "economical speed," the Army Engineer Corps has declared in a formal report to Frank C. Walker, director of the work-relief Division of Applications and Information.

Expanded Christmas shopping and purchasing of Winter apparel and accessories featured retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. Department stores here were not able to report gains over the corresponding period a year ago, due mainly to the difficulty of meeting 1934 sales figures swollen by the rush of buying just prior to the effective date of the municipal 2 per cent sales tax on Dec. 10.

Today being the annual Bible Sunday under the auspices of the American Bible Society and the New York Bible Society, virtually every pastor will preach a sermon on the history of the Bible marking the culmination of the celebration of the four hundredth anniversary of the printing of the first Bible in English.

VERY efficiently has the editor of The American Forests Magazine done the important and interesting job comprised in this book. In the first place, it is a handsome volume, well made and thoroughly illustrated.

One of the easiest forms of nature study is that of trees. The specimens are large and prominent as compared with mosses, ferns or wildflowers, and there are a number of conspicuous characteristics to judge by -- bark, leaves, fruit and general shape.

For the different viewpoints expressed in various "letters to the editor" regarding THE TIMES'S editorial remarks, a fortnight ago, on "Amateur Economists," there are evidently several reasons. None of the writers was rash enough to assert confidence in the "amateur economist" as a class. But they agreed in expressing doubt as to whether trained economists are always in agreement, or can always be safely followed when putting economic principles into law.

A GENTLE remonstrance has been received from the Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes for a statement appearing here last month in our notice of the Newberry Library exhibition of early Bibles. The assertion which is challenged was to the effect that Greek manuscripts of the whole Bible are extant as far back as the second century.

THE not very startling central theme of this book is that President Roosevelt does not think or act like a Marxian Socialist. He thinks and acts, as Mr. Hallgren sees him, like an opportunist who has courage, intelligence and good-will but cannot see beyond the end of the profit system's nose.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 7. -- Yesterday's bombing of Dessye is described by officials here as purely a military action. Since there is a state of war between Italy and Ethiopia, they hold, it was natural that the heaviest concentration of the enemy's forces yet gathered should be bombed, particularly as the Emperor and his son were known to be present. To miss such an opportunity, as they see it, would have been military folly.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 7. -- Sweeping aside a two-stroke edge Johnny Revolta held over him, Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., today tied the P.G.A. champion for the Orlando open golf championship with 280 for the seventy-two holes.

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- An advisory board authorized by Chapter 300 of the laws of this year was named by Governor Lehman today to make classifications by trades or occupations of laborers, workmen and mechanics required to perform public work. The board is authorized to examine into proposed public work projects and determine the laborers that are skilled, semi-skilled or unskilled.

Fate has decreed that Sir CHARLES KINGSFORD-SMITH, acknowledged by fliers themselves to have been their knight of the air, without fear and without reproach, should have met his end in the cockpit, his hands on the controls, as the China Clipper made her historic voyage from San Francisco to Manila and return.

Some 200 girls, eager to finance Christmas festivities for the orphaned and blind children they have unofficially "adopted" through the Little Flower League, will sponsor a benefit bridge Wednesday evening at the Catholic Young Women's Club, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

MODERN languages are studded with a host of curious words owing their origins to the names of persons and places. One of the newest arrivals is "blaginist," coined by the Soviet to stigmatize the folly which prompted Pilot Nikolai Blagin to stunt his monoplane around the giant airliner Maxim Gorky until a crash hurled both machines to the ground.

DESPITE the magic of modern wireless, radio always celebrates Marconi Day, Dec. 12, with greater amazement from year to year. The march of science reveals that it was a triumph of the first magnitude to pick up the sputter of the first transatlantic signal in 1901.

THE last that Jane Addams did before her death was to write the final pages of her book "My Friend, Julia Lathrop." Never did a title more successfully give the essence of the contents of a book. Pride there is in the relationship of author to subject, as well as affection and respect.

FOR her latest romance Maysie Greig has chosen pretty, dark-haired Sally, an Indiana farm girl, for her heroine. On her first vacation from drudgery, duty and religion Sally met a carefree, liberty-loving young artist. Within a week they were madly in love, and Rex, filled with the confidence of young love, persuaded Sally to marry him then and there.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Driving home four goals in the final period, the Princeton hockey team inaugurated its season this afternoon by defeating a spirited but outclassed M.I.T. sextet, 7 -- 1, in the Baker Memorial Rink.

HOLIDAY decorations for the home now follow a carefully thought-out pattern in which a dominating color may form a background for contrasting accents. To the traditional wreaths of holly are added novel forms of adornment and sparkling new materials.

By its own reckoning, the National Association of Manufacturers represents 75,000 business enterprises employing 12,000,000 to 15,000,000 workers. On the word of its official spokesman, the purposes of the NAM are (1) to study the relations between government and industry; (2) to promote and define the best interests of industry; and (3) to give its findings to the public and to industry as a whole.

HIGHWAYS apt to be troublesome at times in Winter because of slippery hills, ice or drifting snow have been listed by Earnest B. Bearnarth, travel director of the Automobile Club of New York, as follows:

A large audience had the good fortune yesterday afternoon to hear Joseph Szigeti in an inspired mood play in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Szigeti was assisted by an excellent musician and pianist, Nikita Magaloff, in the performance of the greatest of the Beethoven piano and violin sonatas, the Opus 96, and in other compositions by Schubert, Weber-Szigeti and various transcriptions and originals of new and old compositions built on a smaller scale.
WHAT are Winter travelers going to do now that the earth is frozen below the depth of tree roots and the lime-colored sun is no longer warm at noon?

An average net loss is sustained each day by New York's voluntary hospitals on all classes of bed patients, according to a survey of hospital costs made in connection with the current campaign to raise $2,000,000 for the United Hospital Fund.

SIDNEY LANFIELD admits he is one of those Hollywood accidents you read about. Things just happen to him. If he had been an actor and had appeared in the silent films, there would have been a subtitle reading "A pawn of fate" before he made his entrance.

ATLANTA, Dec. 7. -- Establishment of a charitable fund from a fortune which had its nucleus in a boom in coca-cola stock was revealed today with the announcement of provisions in the will of Joseph B. Whitehead Jr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- That the Bankhead act is constitutional was maintained by the government today in a brief filed in the Supreme Court by Stanley Reed, Solicitor General.

Staving off a thrilling, last-minute rally by Brooking College which produced two field goals in the last fifteen seconds, City College's basketball team passed its first crucial test of the season on its home court with flying colors last night. It conquered the Brooklynites by a 29-28 score to register its second triumph of the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 (AP). -- Aleta Freel, 28 years old, former New York actress and wife of Ross Alexander, film leading man, committed suicide by shooting herself through the temple, police reported today. Her husband said she was disappointed in her career.

The Rev. Ralph Drisko corrects your statement that the famous cheese presented to Thomas Jefferson by Elder John Leland weighed 1,235 pounds. However, you are right and he is wrong. I have the original letter sent to Jefferson by the people of Cheshire as well as Jefferson's gracious letter of thanks.

Two solenodons -- rare and curious little animals from Haiti -- have been purchased by the New York Zoological Park and are expected to arrive here tomorrow on the Porto Rico liner Borinquen, it was announced yesterday by Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the park.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- The Boerse was inactive today, with some signs of increasing weakness. So few stocks registered any quotable changes, however, and so many were not quoted at all that little importance can be attached to the market's tendency.
