LONDON, Dec. 6. -- At the moment when Italy has challenged British seapower in the Mediterranean, when reamed Germany is raising her head across the North Sea, and when Japan is carving out an empire on the mainland of Asia, the delegates of the five chief naval powers will meet in London on Monday, In an attempt to salvage something from the system of naval limitation created by the Washington and London naval treaties.
NEWARK N.J., Dec. 7. -- For a half hour before sunrise this morning, nature provided a glowing spectacle of color in the eastern sky for early risers here.

BRITAIN'S all-empire "Great Family" broadcast, which attracted international attention for the past two years, will be staged again this season, with King George at the London microphone on Christmas morning. The program is scheduled to begin at 9:25 A.M., E.S.T., with bells ringing in Bethlehem.

AMERICAN teachers have determined to pull themselves out of a rut by hitching their wagon to a star. Last week their largest professional organization, the National Education Association, appointed a commission of fifteen school men and women, so to speak, to choose that star -- to chart the ideal direction for our schools in the modern age.

Replying to statements by employers that the all-inclusive occupational disease amendment to the Workmen's Compensation Law had resulted in throwing thousands of persons out of work. Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, has issued a statement asserting that labor statistics showed that employment was on the increase.

LAST week Dr. Karl T. Compton submitted to the President the second and final report of the Science Advisory Board of which he is chairman and which includes among its members such academic celebrities as Dr. R. A. Millikan, Dr. Simon Flexner and Dr. Frank R. Lillie and such directors of industrial research laboratories as Dr. Frank B. Jewett and Charles F. Kettering.

Earle R. Lewis, box-office treasurer of the Metropolitan Opera House, yesterday disclosed that there would be 28 per cent more new subscribers by the time the new season opens next Monday night than the highest total recorded in the last sixteen years. Figures prior to 1919 were not available, he added.

CANTON, China, -- Recently, when seven Japanese warships swung at anchor in the open roadstead at Swatow, an ominous threat to the Chinese authorities in that northeastern Kwangtung city, officials of Kwangtung province were even frankly worried. But not Liu Chiwen, the Mayor of Canton, capital of the province.

MADRID, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Sweeping changes in the Spanish Constitution that would relax some prohibitions affecting the Catholic Church will be proposed by the parliamentary committee on constitutional reform, it was disclosed today.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 8 (AP). -- The police arrested several hundred leaders of the Omoto-kyo religious sect today in a round-up supervised by the Home Ministry. Charges against those arrested were not revealed, but newspapers said it was understood that some of the tenets of the cult had been adjudged disrespectful to the imperial family.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 7. -- Resignation of Frank C. Walker of New York as executive director of the National Emergency Council and the Work Relief Division of Applications and Information may be expected early in January, according to friends.

The race-track tipster, commonest species of wriggler along Broadway's main stem, squirmed under Attorney General John J. Bennett's microscope last week. Eighty-six specimens were isolated for indictment in what was described as a $3,000,000 racket.

PROBABLY the world's longest and loneliest police beat is that patrolled by Constable T. Reid, who is stationed at Newcastle Waters in the Northern Territory of Australia. From his station Constable Reid's beat reaches out 120 miles north, 180 miles south, 140 miles east and 112 miles west.

A new record for automobile production in November, far surpassing previous figures, was disclosed by the Automobile Manufacturers' Association yesterday. The high output was held to be further evidence not only of what is being accomplished under the Fall model announcement plan, but of the strides toward recovery being made by the industry in general.

BELIEVING that youth has a right to be heard and that the problems of youth can best be solved by the cooperation of youth itself, a group of young people has launched a monthly magazine called Voice of Youth.

IT is no mere accident that Havelock Ellis should have become a leading interpreter of that lesser stream of French literature which comes under the general head of romanticism. For there are important factors in his own psychological history (which he as a doctor loves to investigate in other writers) which place him deeply in sympathy with Rousseau and his followers.

WHEN the winds blow and the seas pound, the Coast Guard goes into action. The Winter gales bring trouble to the Atlantic shores, and the men on patrol along the windswept beaches and those who go out to sea on the cutters are always ready for the fight.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Emily Tuckerman will assist at the tea table at the Christmas bazaar tomorrow at the Pierre in behalf of the Art Workers Club. Serving with Miss Tuckerman will be the Misses Marguerite Decroix, Margaret Clinton, Elise Merrill and Sonia Lie.
BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- What will be done with the Massachusetts educators who refuse to take the teachers' oath without qualification or explanatory comment?

Standards of higher education have been lowered through the efforts of colleges to maintain the size of their student bodies at pre-depression levels, Frank Bowles, acting director of admissions in Columbia University, asserted in his annual report to the trustees of the university made public yesterday.

EQUIPPED with a trick umbrella and a Hapsburg lip, the Baron von Kaz leaves his native Vienna, where he has been unfortunate enough to ally himself with the wrong political party, and comes to America to see if there is an opening for a detective of European reputation.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- Instead of producing a general movement of pacification, yesterday's debate in the Chamber of Deputies and the bills against the armed leagues as they were passed after much amendment last night have produced resentment and resistance.

Having had their preliminary tune-up at the recent minor league sessions in Dayton, the magnates of professional baseball's two major leagues will advance upon Chicago in a body this week to attend their annual Winter conclaves.

IN the words of the editor, the seven books of Tibetan yoga herein given to the Western World provide "a more or less comprehensive and unified expression of the most important tenets of Mahayana (or Northern) Buddhism."

A splendidly trained Marblehead (Mass.) High School football team handed Curtis High School a decisive and wholly unlooked-for setback at Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, yesterday. The alert New Englanders took the previously undefeated Curtis eleven by storm to roll up a 29-to-0 triumph, while a crowd of 10,000 persons looked on.

AN ebb tide recently stranded 194 black pilot whales on a small sand spit at Tatlow's Beach, Tasmania. Along this coast the sight of whales left high and dry is not uncommon, but they have never been seen in such large numbers.

THE quarterly review Modern Music, published by the League of Composers, has just issued an index of its first twelve volumes, from November, 1924, to June, 1935. The index is in three parts, the first consisting of a catalogue of subjects; the second, of authors and articles, and the third, of illustrations.

WITH the advent of colder weather, and with windows less frequently opened, plants in the house are almost sure to be subjected to a closer atmosphere than they have had during the Autumn. The experienced indoor gardener knows that these altered conditions mean that he must be more keenly on the alert than ever to detect the first sign of possible plant enemies, such as aphis, mealy bug, scale and white fly.

BIRD lovers of Europe are protesting against the growing traffic in feathered creatures from British and Portuguese East Africa to their own continent. Portuguese officials, it is reported, have expressed willingness to cooperate in stemming the flourishing trade in small birds between Mombasa and Beira.

Prices held fairly steady in dull and uneventful trading on the commodity futures markets here yesterday, with rubber slightly easier and copper and hides moderately firmer. On the cash markets corn and oats advanced, while wheat and rye declined.

The man whom the police call Blackshirt is a "gentleman crook," not a common, low thief. He steals not because he needs or wants the money that might be realized by selling his loot but because he likes excitement. The police, callously ignoring such subtle distinctions, would like to lay their hands on Blackshirt, and it is quite possible that they would, if they could catch him, treat him like an ordinary malefactor.

Uncertainty over the future of the AAA processing taxes, spreading throughout the food trades as the date for a Supreme Court decision on the validity of the imposts approaches, is having a depressing effect upon prices in some divisions of the industry, according to reports here yesterday.

President CONANT'S speech at the dinner given by the Carnegie Corporation made skillful use of ANDREW CARNEGIE'S expressed purpose in the foundation of the Carnegie Institution, to seek the exceptional man and never to interfere with his freedom of action. That principle applies not only to business and philanthropy but to all human affairs.

HERE you have a hardboiled newspaper man's story, laid on the Pacific Coast, involving a lot of heavy-drinking reporters, , and several unconventional love affairs, winding up as a more or less technical detective yarn.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 6. -- The most puzzling question in Virginia politics today is whether Lieut. Gov. James H. Price, the anti-Byrd candidate for Governor in 1937, has too long a start for the Byrd candidate, Representative Thomas G. Burch, to be able to catch him.
The superb art collection of Henry Clay Frick is about to be turned over to the public to whom the steel and coke pioneer willed it sixteen years ago.
FOR the Neediest of all in New York City -- those helpless victims of circumstance whose want cannot be met by public relief -- the appeal is renewed today.

GOVERNMENT radio services have been expanded greatly in recent years. Every Federal department has a "radio contact" man who will supply scripts and speakers upon request by broadcasting stations. By the end of this year 500 government officials -- the President, Cabinet officials, Senators, Congressmen, administrators, scientists and economists -- will have appeared upon the networks.

IN "The Decline of American Capitalism" Mr. Corey undertook to show that capitalism in this country must in due time precipitate a new revolution out of which, through the aggressive action of the proletariat, a Communist State will emerge. The same expectation caps the argument and historical exposition of the present book, save that, until near the end, the term socialism rather than communism is used to describe the new order.

If this book contained nothing but the Haders' delightful picture, one would still have a very good conception of the charms of Jamaican life. Black women stride majestically along, balancing on their turbaned heads bunches of jade-green bananas or crates of chickens, small boys play along the roadside in the gray-green shadows of the tropic "bush," while pigs and chickens scatter helterskelter before the onrush of tourists' cars.

JACKSON, Wyo., Dec. 6. -- The wapiti are beginning their annual trek from the mountainous regions and game refuges of Northwestern Wyoming down into the Jackson Hole country, where Winter rations of cottonseed and hay await them. What the wapiti, or elk, do not know is that a death warrant, signed by the Wyoming State Game Commission, awaits 1,000 of their number.

LONDON. NOW that the Worshipful Company of Newspaper Makers has merged itself with the Worshipful Company of Stationers, the historic Stationers' Hall in the shadow of St. Paul's Cathedral is to be enlarged at a cost of $350,000. Like many another London building which has been the scene of interesting doings in the past, it is more widely known by name than by sight.

WHILE the exhibition of paintings by Renoir at the Bignou Gallery (remaining through this month) is not large and was not arranged as in any sense a comprehensive display, it yet serves to illustrate several distinct phases of this great nineteenth - century French artist's work.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Attilio Rossi, a 35-year-old laborer of 86 Hillside Avenue, who suffered a shock to his nervous system about a year ago which resulted in paralysis of the left side from his shoulder to his feet, is a cured man today from what he describes as a "miracle."
OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Sing Sing was on the verge of another hit tonight, it hoped, after 2,000 inmates witnessed a preview in the chapel today of the institution's annual "Follies."

Mr. and Mrs. Roger Howson gave a reception yesterday at their home, 327 East Fiftieth Street, for their debutante daughter, Miss Joan Howson. The guests included older friends of the family as well as young friends of the debutante, who is a sophomore at Bryn Mawr.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Women's activities on the University of Pennsylvania campus will assume unusual significance next week.

CHICAGO. -- The contest for supremacy between the horse and mule on one side and the tractor and truck on the other, with the nation's farms and highways as the arena, is still undecided, according to members of the Horse and Mule Association of America, but the horse is again moving toward his former proud place in the scheme of things.

THE ninety-second edition of the "Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue" with its 1.123 pages and listings of more than 90,000 stamp varieties sharply illustrates the enormous growth and progress of philately, as the hobby of stamp collecting is now scientifically and popularly known.

COMBINATION of favorable circumstances, some of them supplied by adversity, have made it possible for Brooklyn College, maintained by the City of New York, to plan, and begin work on, a complete and modern group of college buildings and campus.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The text of Senator Borah's address tonight was as follows:...

SOME day Huey Long will be a historic figure. At the moment he is just one more dead man. A meteor that flashed across our political horizon, he seemed to many an omen of things to come, but like a meteor that has disappeared, once gone, the light that he shed is difficult to remember.

Nine persons were injured, one of them seriously, when a fire engine struck a truck at Columbia and Stanton Streets shortly before 4 P.M. yesterday, causing the truck to mount the southeast curb and knock down two pedestrians.

A mass meeting to protest against the asserted maladministration of the Federal Neutrality Act of 1935, and the danger to continued cordial relations between the United States and Italy as a result of imposing sanctions, was held last night in Lexington Hall at 109 East 116th Street.

IN connection with the proposed embargo on Italy's oil supplies, Premier Laval of France, at the request of Great Britain, has just told Mussolini that if he made war on Britain he would have to fight France also. Laval had already said this to Britain, but the British Government thought it advisable that he say it once more -- this time directly to Mussolini.

That "music hath charms" to soothe the hurried commuter into immobility -- temporarily at least -- was shown yesterday afternoon as the Manhattan Concert Band, a WPA unit of almost sixty pieces, held the attention of a rapt audience of suburban residents, red caps, trainmen and passersby in Grand Central Terminal.

THE year 1935 has been a stirring one for teachers. A New York teacher has been judged too fat to teach; one Massachusetts teacher has given up marriage to hold her job, and, after forty years, another is in trouble about not saluting the flag.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Canadian trade agreement was denounced today as violative of President Roosevelt's campaign pledge not to lower agriculture tariffs and as a general tariff reduction unauthorized by Congress in a report by George N. Peek that made complete his break with the administration over its agrarian and commercial policies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- New low prices for wheat on the current downturn were reached early today on the Board of Trade here as the result of scattered liquidation and local pressure due to a sharp recession in Liverpool. The break, however, brought in buying against bids and on resting orders, causing a good rally in the distant deliveries, based on the strength in Winnipeg.

Debutantes had another busy day yesterday with receptions, luncheons, dinners and dances. One of the largest parties of the night was the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Rovensky at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Jane Ewing Rovensky.

ROME, Dec. 7. -- Premier Benito Mussolini delivered his widely heralded speech on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis in the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon in an electric atmosphere, amid scenes of enthusiasm such as the oldest parliamentary reporters have seldom witnessed.

The United Textile Workers of America will begin immediately an intensive campaign in all parts of the country to gain support for the National Textile Act in Congress, according to an announcement by the executive council of the union in authorizing the campaign.

MRS. JAMES ROOSEVELT has erected a playhouse on the grounds of her Hyde Park home for her great-grandchildren, who are the grandchildren of the President of the United States. But despite the fact that the little house is fully equipped for home-making, it represents no subtle effort at education in the business of living.

In THE TIMES for Nov. 17 Mr. Nicholas Haz took exception to the sort of criticism Lewis Jacobs offered in some articles on American directors which you published, and exception to Lewis Jacobs himself for offering it. Such a completely misleading and unjustifiable broadside calls for some answer on the part of a serious medium which is winning wider recognition every day.

INDIANAPOLIS. Dec. 7 (AP). -- First to receive the death penalty under a new Federal law, George W. Barrett, 50-year-old crippled Kentucky mountaineer, was found guilty today of first degree murder by a Federal court jury in the slaying of a Federal officer. The verdict carries a mandatory sentence of death by hanging.

ALTHOUGH "The New Gulliver" is the first of his animations to be widely distributed outside of Russia, the director and editor-in-chief of the multiplicationists who made it, in Moscow, has filmed other satirical dolls before this.

The share market endeavored yesterday to shake off some of the lethargy that has characterized it for several days, succeeding to the extent that the trading volume was almost double that of the Saturday before and that prices worked moderately higher.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7. -- The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Nov. 30 shows the following changes in the month, in paper pesos:

ATHENS, Dec. 7. -- Scattered armed clashes in Crete between the Tsaldarists and Venizelists resulted this afternoon in one death and about a dozen wounded before federal troops could restore order. Three villages were affected by the disturbances.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 7. -- The Short Hills Club held is lead in the New Jersey group of the Class B Squash Tennis League when it defeated the Montclair Athletic Club today, 4 to 1, E.L. Winpenny's straight-game victory over George Lewis provided Montclair's lone point.

A city-wide recreation system, ultimately supported by municipal and State funds in a manner similar to the financing of public education, was proposed yesterday in a plan adopted at the closing session of a conference on recreational problems at New York University.

HAVANA, Sunday, Dec. 8. -- Former President Mario G. Menocal, the Presidential candidate of the Democratic party, withdrew early this morning from participation in the general elections set for Jan. 10 and demanded the immediate resignation of President Carlos Mendieta.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7. -- Despite maritime strike talk and a pessimistic view by lumber and other interests in the Northwest over the Canadian trade treaty, both travel and commerce movements through Pacific Coast ports are gaining in volume.

MASTERS'S book tells us so much of Lindsay because it speaks so well and eloquently -- and bitterly, too, on occasion -- of the American scene into which Lindsay was born. The ancestry, the man, and the moment are here inseparable, for Lindsay was an authentic inspiration, though an erratic person.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Representatives of the International Red Cross dispatched a formal protest to the League of Nations today of the second bombing in as many days of Dessye, war headquarters of Emperor Haile Selassie.

LONG ago the Assyrians, Babylonians and Egyptians passed on into oblivion, but the Chinese, who began in equal antiquity, are still among the history-making nations of the world, and despite the powerful destructive forces working toward their downfall they seem destined to continue an immortal life.

IN their final game of the regular pro football season, the Giants will be merely playing for exercise at the Polo Grounds today. But the Pirates, their opponents, are on a treasure hunt. If the Boston Redskins can defeat the Kelly-Topping outfit over at Ebbets Field and the Pirates can throw the Giants for a loss, the visitors from Pittsburgh will cut in on the second place slice of the play-off melon.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 7. -- The University of Florida football team, after a scoreless first half today, became the "Fighting Gators" in the last two periods, scoring three touchdowns and a safety to defeat the University of South Carolina, 22 to 0. It was the final game for both universities.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- In Premier Pierre Laval's study at the Quai D'Orsay he and the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare, sat down this evening perhaps in closer agreement than they had ever before been. They sought to "determine bases that might be proposed for a friendly settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Twenty-three electrical engineers of prominent New Jersey and New York industrial firms will act as advisers to Rutgers University students of the College of Engineering under an "industrial adviser" plan adopted this week.

EXTREMELY long novels have become popular of late. Which is perhaps the reason why Esther Morgan McCullough has seen fit to spin out her account of the life of her not particularly interesting heroine, Sebastian Dale, until it covers no less than 789 pages.

Because it is believed in many quarters that an oil embargo against Italy, if enforced drastically, probably would make that country almost powerless to continue its war more than a few months, the question arises as to the reasons for the hesitation of the various governments in putting such an embargo into effect when they are interested in stopping the Ethiopian hostilities.

IMAGINATION and ingenuity have been employed by the toy-makers in the production of this year's new playthings. Judging from the excitement of the little boys and girls who have been taken early to see the Santa Clauses and their wares in the stores, the children are going to be immensely thrilled when some of these toys become their own on Christmas morning.

THE modern sociologist has little use for the genius. "I have not made events," Lincoln once said, "events have made me." The heroes of military exploits, the bards who sing immortal songs, the painters who make landscape and men live on canvas, the technicians who invent railways, automobiles and telephones are but creatures of their time.

WITH the cinema engaged in a cycle of yarns based upon historical figures and events, producers are bordering a state of mild frenzy. Individuals viewed by their contemporaries as deep-dyed villains have assumed, in their descendants' eyes, virtues the originals might have hesitated to claim.

THE Thirty-seventh Attack Squadron of Langley Field, Va., sent six ships to the Aberdeen proving ground recently. Aberdeen was the gathering point of the Ordnance Department, members of the Society of Mechanical Engineers and their guests in order to witness a demonstration of equipment.

Mrs. Dexter Fales gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce her daughter, Miss Ellen D. Fales. Miss Fales, who is a daughter of Hallburton Fales, attended the Chapin School in this city and the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 7. -- The nature of a "grave incident" in Peiping which aroused Japanese army heads in North China recently proves to have been a case of a propaganda effort failing.

In this new story about Captain North of the Army Intelligence Mr. Mason pictures a Washington overrun with spies and traffickers in stolen government secrets. As the story opens, a bill has been introduced in Congress giving the authorities more power to deal with such offenders.

John Marshall, defending champion, and Douglas advanced to the final round of the annual P.S.A.L. junior high school basketball championship for the second consecutive year by registering hardfought victories yesterday in the semi-final round.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Ten per cent of the members of the senior class of Princeton University have already obtained employment starting after June graduation, it was announced here today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the Bureau of Appointments and Student Employment.

FOR a third time Mr. Philip Ainsworth Means has enriched historical archives with a scholarly volume. In "Ancient Civilizations of the Andes," published in 1931, and in "Fall of the Inca Empire" in the following year it was apparent that he not only possessed an exhaustive knowledge of the early Spanish sources but that he was also especially well equipped to condense that knowledge into a readable narrative

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 7 (AP). -- Gus Nicholas, 45, unemployed until a few days ago since he lost a $63,000 fortune, wrote to his wife and daughter in New York City this week telling them he had landed a job. But his letters went to the wrong address.

Former Governor John G. Winant of New Hampshire will preside on Tuesday, at the thirty-sixth annual luncheon of the National Consumers League at the Hotel Delmonico in his capacity as president of the organization. Speakers for the occasion will be Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, L. Metcalfe Walling, Rhode Island Commissioner of Labor, and Miss Elizabeth S. Magee, secretary of the Consumers League of Ohio.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 7. -- District Attorney Martin W. Littleton will start an investigation of the acts of the WPA administration in Nassau County before the Nassau County relief grand jury on Monday. Although Mr. Littleton refused to say what the specific nature of the inquiry would be, it was understood from a reliable source that one phase would relate to the question of whether public funds were being wasted by the WPA administration here.
RALEIGH, N.C. -- North Carolina approaches with considerable misgiving its first lethal gas execution on Dec. 13.

THE Mather Library, a collection of 2,000 volumes of the writings of Richard, Increase and Cotton Mather and their descendants, has passed from the possession of William Gwinn Mather of Cleveland, who assembled it, into the important accumulations of Americana owned by Tracy W. MacGregor of Washington.

Soviet purchases in the United States for the first eleven months of this year reached a total of $36, 500,000, more than two and one-half times the figure for all of 1934 and three times greater than that for 1933, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- An attack on the basic philosophy of the New Deal as well as one on the 1929 brand of prosperity and government participation in it were made by Senator Borah in a radio speech over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight.
After that momentous scientific discovery at Colgate University, said the Rambling Correspondent, he was expecting any day the return of the rocking-chair.

The Nine-Power Treaty, already somewhat tattered at the edges, is being invoked again in the Far East. The American Government definitely and the British Government by inference have called Japan's attention to its treaty obligations in connection with the so-called autonomy movement under way in North China.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 7. -- The tradition that a Harvard man usually wins the Gold Racquet tournament was kept alive today as the four semi-finalist in the classic squash racquets tourney proved to be past or present Cambridge stars.

George E. MacDonald, writing of "the continuous fight our language makes to retain its title," expresses regret that THE TIMES should have quoted Professor Weekley's sentence "he should be left alone," because "left alone" "means abandonment to solitude, whereas 'let alone' signifies abstention from interference," the meaning intended.

BRIELLE, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Mayor William H. Borden, who would have completed his second three-year term on Jan. 1, was found dead this afternoon on the floor of his gas-filled bedroom by his wife and daughter when they returned home from a visit to New York.

IN his reminiscences of a Princeton he never knew, Donald Ogden Stewart recalled that in those days there were four hundred-odd undergraduates. And five, he added, who were not so odd. These, he said, clubbed together and became Big Bill Edwards.
An entertainment, "A Polar Night," will be held Thursday night at the home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street, for the benefit of the Studio Guild.

CHARLES BROCKDEN BROWN was a breaker of new trails. He was among the first American authors to cease slavishly following British models and to deal with American life. In the preface to his novel, "Edgar Huntley," he urged his fellow-countrymen to stop writing of "puerile superstitions and exploded manners, Gothic castles and chimeras" and to use instead "the incidents of Indian hostility, and the perils of the Western wilderness."

MOSCOW, Dec. 7. -- A new beauty salon was opened in the heart of Moscow today -- one in a chain of cosmetic shops opening throughout the Soviet Union as a result of a vast government campaign to popularize the use of cosmetics.

The demands of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union may be so "prohibitive" that they will not represent a "fair price for peace" in the garment industry, it was declared by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, in a statement yesterday.

OMAHA, Dec. 6. -- The Corn Belt was somewhat diverted this week to note that the minds of Secretary Wallace and Smith W. Brookhart, former Iowa Senator and late Russian trade adviser of the AAA, had been running simultaneously on the same subject but in different directions. It may have been mere coincidence, but it sounded a lot like planned coincidence on somebody's part.
WITH mixed feelings of wonder, admiration and trepidation one reads the headline in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Sunday, Aug. 18, Section No. 2: "WPA to Spend $3,000,000 for Revival of the Drama."
A SQUARE-JAWED, jocular admiral, who carries his diplomacy from the conference tables to the golf links, is helping to present the American case at the naval parley in London.

Charging that propaganda was being exerted against conservative artists, Charles R. Knight, portrait painter and muralist, who has done many paintings for the American Museum of Natural History, yesterday afternoon assailed modern painting and advised conservative painters to be more assertive against oranges that are drawn to look like green squares, and other distortions.

With its potential market being steadily cut away at the top by the increasing inroads of specialty shops and at the bottom by the standardized chain systems, the typical department store, with few exceptions, appears destined to contract and diminish as the major factor in the merchandising picture, according to views expressed yesterday by I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. FIRST-NIGHTERS were subjected to no dilemma of choice this week in Philadelphia, as they have been in past weeks, because Gilbert Miller's production of the English courtroom drama, "Libel!" by Edward Wooll, disclosed Monday night at the Chestnut Street Opera House for the first time in America, supplied the only note of novelty.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7. -- Holiday buying has extended to record-breaking proportions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. Retail stores report not only a heavy demand for ordinary goods but a marked increase in sales of high-priced products.

EDUCATING child craftsmen and at the same time child recipients of their products, the Westchester Workshop, a centre of arts and crafts, assumes a special role each year at this season. It becomes "Santa Claus" to some 2,000 underprivileged children and, by organizing and supervising a toy-repair shop in which cast-off playthings are transformed into seemingly new Christmas gifts, expands its diversified community program in leisure-time education.

Preliminaries to today's meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association took place last night at the Paramount Hotel. The officers and committees of the association gathered for the annual dinner and following this there were closed meetings of the rules and executive committees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Another batch of confidential reports made by corporations in registering securities on Stock Exchanges, to which the Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled the public is entitled, was issued today. Among them was a statement dated April 1, 1935, which gave the compensation of officials of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the fiscal year as follows:
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Miss Mary McElroy revealed today her foremost ambition to make "normal, acceptable citizens" of three men who two and a half years ago kidnapped her for $30,000 ransom.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Miss M. Carey Thomas, president-emeritus of Bryn Mawr College, made the college the chief ultimate beneficiary of her estate in a ninety-three page will, filed for probate here today.

DON BASIN, U.S.S.R., Dec. 5. -- Today I talked with Alexei Gregory Stakhanoff, the coal miner whose name in three months has become a Soviet household word along with Stalin's, Voroshiloff's and Kalinin's.

MILAN, Nov. 27, 1935. THE most noticeable effects of sanctions on Italian musical and theatrical life thus far have been two: first, the elimination from bills and programs of artists from sanctionist countries; second, the enforcing of economy in electric light consumption.

The usual week-end influences failed to check the advance among the more speculative domestic corporation bonds and prices were carried to new high levels during the two-hour trading period yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Meanwhile, high grade investment issues maintained a firm undertone in dull trading.

MOUNT VERNON, Iowa, Dec. 7. -- Miss Enola Brandt of the Milwaukee State Teachers College has won first place in a nation-wide contest for college students in the translation of poetry by Horace, it was announced today by Professor Mark E. Hutchinson of Cornell College here.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Princeton's basketball team opened its season tonight, downing Drexel Institute of Philadelphia, 39 -- 25. Bill Tilden, Tiger guard, was the high scorer, getting six baskets and two foul shots for 14 points.
If you are a skeet fan and suffer perpetual torment because you can't break better than 15, don't blame your eyesight or you frazzled nerves.

Japanese inroads in China have gone about as far as they will go, in the opinion of General Chen Wu-fang, 45-year-old military leader in North China, who arrived here yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa. General Fang said that in his opinion China had the courage and power to drive out Japan without the aid of the League of Nations.

The announcement by the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway that it would default on $500,000 of interest on Jan. 1 served last week to show the new light in which the importance of "key lines" has been considered in financial circles in recent years.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Unless the world buys more German goods Germany will have to reduce her debt payments even more than she has reduced them already, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, announced today in a speech in Munich.

Delegates to the American Kennel Club will hold their quarterly meeting on Tuesday at the headquarters of the governing body at 2 P.M. At 11 A.M. the A.K.C. directors will hold their monthly meeting, which will be followed by the customary luncheon.

THE world continues to be Mr. Halliburton's oyster, and the oyster continues to yield its pearls to this indefatigable epicure. True enough, the gems are cultivated, but they are none the less spectacular for that. Priceless, in effect, are the conception and achievement of crossing the Alps, a la Hannibal, on the back of an elephant imported for the occasion from a Paris zoo.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 8. -- Under the new regime in Hopei and Chahar an area of 154,000 square miles with more than 40,000,000 persons will come under the military, economic and political domination of Japan and Manchuria.

When Charles F. Murphy was leader of Tammany Hall (there has not been one like him since) he had a stock answer to the stock question that was asked him every campaign year. The question: Whom have you picked for the nomination? The answer: The convention will decide.

ONE important garden "chore" which can be attended to after the surface of the ground freezes is the tucking in for the Winter of many hardy plants and shrubs. Protection even for bulb beds and perennials is best applied only after the soil freezes or is about to freeze, so that mice will not be tempted to seek shelter in the inviting covering.

The end of the 1935 field hockey season, unlike most other years, leaves the players with a definite sense of expectation. Usually there is nothing but an eight-month lull to look forward to, until hockey camp or club activities begin again. But 1936 is to be an unusually full year.

Under attack by both smaller competitors and some sources of supply, the large national wholesale houses, of which only four remain, are consolidating their positions through the establishment of regional branches and specialized departments, according to opinions hero yesterday by well-informed observers.

IT would seem to be quite as much the doctor's as the patient's dilemma. For Dr. Tannenbaum and Mr. Branden are stern and definitive in the way they point out to the medical profession the parting of the ways to which it has come and challenge it to make the choice which they suggest.

In THE TIMES (Nov. 24) weekly review, under the heading "J.P. Morgan Says" --, Article XVI of the League covenant is misquoted. The article says that League members agreed automatically to boycott a covenant-breaker by "severance of all trade or financial relations, the prohibition of intercourse between their nationals and the nationals of the covenant-breaking State, and the nationals of any other State, whether a member of the League or not."

Christmas trees, the traditional symbol of the yule season, will be in great demand this year, according to C.S. York, freight agent in charge of the New York Central Railroad's freight yards at Thirty-third Street and Eleventh Avenue.
With fluctuations limited and business light, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday unchanged to 3 points higher.

New Utrecht ended the three-year reign of James Monroe High as city P.S.A.L. soccer champion yesterday when the Green and White substitute centre forward, Bernie Emil, caged the goal in the second half of a bitterly fought contest that enabled his team to win, 1 to 0, at Ulmer Park in Brooklyn.

Humanity today is at a philosophical and religious crisis that may prove to be one of the turning points of history unless the great mass of people in the world awaken to the danger of that possibility, Michael Williams, editor of The Commonweal, declared yesterday morning at the twelfth annual communion breakfast of the New York Circle of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

HENRY BURTON SHARMAN has specialized for many years in the one subject of the teachings of Jesus and his life as a setting for them. He has taught this theme by a method he has himself developed, combining scientific inquiry with critically keen discussion, to classes in the University of Chicago, the University of Toronto, Yenching University at Peking and elsewhere.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7. -- The Broadside gelding Biff, which was a formidable handicap competitor on Western tracks, reeled off his best six furlongs and one of the fastest in the history of the Fair Grounds when he was timed in 1:11 2-5 in winning the Gulf Coast Handicap today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 7. -- Byron Haines added another weird chapter to the 1935 football season today when he accounted for all the scoring as Washington defeated Southern California, 6 to 2, before 35,000 persons.

Temperance education sponsored by the State has begun in New York under the auspices of the State Liquor Authority, with several other departments of the government at Albany cooperating. Leaflets, booklets and posters have appeared and official speakers are addressing civic groups, all in the interest of temperance in the use of alcoholic beverages.

Several receptions were given yesterday afternoon for debutantes. One of the largest was that given by Mr. and Mrs. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer in the ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce Miss Lorraine Graves, daughter of the hostess. The debutante wore a gown of pale blue velvet and carried yellow orchids.

COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Dec. 7. -- The powerful Southern Methodist Mustangs, Rose Bowl nominees, kept intact their perfect football record for the season when they defeated a strong Texas A. and M. team today, 24 -- 0.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 7. -- A 58-year-old butcher, who was one of Kearny's best-known and best-liked tradesmen, was shot dead in his shop here tonight by a robber, who fired a sawed-off shotgun at him at close range when he refused to raise his hands.

THIS is Leigh Carder's third novel about assorted outlaws of the Texas border country. He is fertile in the invention of new and strange and interest-compelling plots, and in this tale he has surpassed his previous efforts in that line in "Outlaw Justice" and "Border Guns."

Important advances in medicine and surgery for the prevention of blindness and the conservation and restoration of sight were described by Dr. LeGrand H. Hardy, director of Eye Service, Fifth Avenue Hospital, in a paper he presented yesterday morning at the closing session of the conference of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, at Rockefeller Center.

Piling up a big lead in the first half and then coasting through the second chapter, the Fordham basketball team scored its second victory of the season last night, turning back the Cooper Union quintet, 38 to 14, in the Maroon Gymnasium.
ATLANTA, Dec. 7. -- Georgia's old anti-sedition statute of 1866, under which Angelo Herndon, Negro Communist, was sentenced to eighteen to twenty years in prison, was held unconstitutional today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7. -- The general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today approved the objectives of the committee on industrial organization of the American Federation of Labor "as long as it adheres to the purposes originally outlined by it."

Underprivileged children who are aided by the Catholic Big Sisters of the Ladies of Charity will be the beneficiaries of a luncheon to be held by that organization on Dec. 16 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis. The benefit has been arranged by a group of women headed by Mrs. Kimball G. Colby.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The administration, which has defined its foreign policy as "a good neighbor policy," is now testing the effectiveness of its program on four major foreign issues -- the naval conference, the Japanese invasion of China, neutrality in the Italo-Ethiopian war and trade treaties with various countries.

A strike of electric light and power employes that may darken Queens this week unless Mayor La Guardia intervenes was forecast last night by William J. Kennedy, national president of the Brotherhood of Utility Employes.

Edward Saltoft, noted Danish artist, who has painted many prominent European personages, including crowned heads and dictators, is to paint a portrait of President Roosevelt. The sittings for the President's portrait will be held in the White House, beginning this week.

RUSSIA is building a St. Moritz of her own high up in the Caucasus to meet the public demand for improved Winter sports facilities and as an attraction to visitors from abroad. The site of the resort is Bakuriani, which lies in a mountain valley in the Georgian Caucasus within sight of the peaks of Elbrus and Kasbeck.

With one possible exception, major colleges in the metropolitan district face a basketball season with stronger prospects and higher hopes than ever before in history. Individually some may have had better teams, but as a whole the outlook was never better.

THAT improperly washed dishes and silverware may cause the spread of common colds and other respiratory diseases was emphasized by Dr. James G. Cumming, chief of the Bureau of Preventable Diseases of the Health Department of the District of Columbia, following a series of experiments in forty-six restaurants in Washington, where his examiners found that the usual methods of dishwashing left from 50,000 to 100,000 bacteria on the average spoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared tonight that he would reject any such offer as that made in a letter sent to him today by John L. Lewis proposing that he leave his present office to head the Lewis group's campaign for industrial unionism.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- Two Princeton backs and a Yale end have accepted invitations to play with the All-East team against an All-West eleven in the annual game in San Francisco New Year's Day, Coach Andy Kerr of Colgate announced tonight.

A MODERN man's intricate journey through the worlds of thought and feeling and desire; his passionate search for truth; his need to correlate the primitive in his own nature and the highly complex mental processes that distinguish him from creatures of a different order are resolved, here, into the utmost simplicity by means of a logical and provocative allegory.

CALDWELL, N.J., Dec. 7. -- With Brownsville, Texas, their first objective and Magallanes, 9,500 air miles away near the tip of Chile, as their goal on a five-day flight, Russell W. Thaw, racing pilot, and William H. Klenke Jr., radio man and engine mechanic, took off at 10:07 A.M. today from the Caldwell-Wright Airport on an expedition to find and bring succor to Lincoln Ellsworth in the Antarctic.

Members of the Seventh Regiment gave their annual Fall Military Ball last night in the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. More than 2,000 persons attended the event, which, as in recent years, was set in fantastic surroundings.

THIS is history of music of a very different kind from the elementary books, lately appearing in such large numbers, that sketch the development of the art for beginners. It is a stiff and detailed course, made for those who can walk alone and who are expected to be able to traverse all the wide domain of music unaided, and who need not be helped over every stile they come across on the way.

Scoring almost at will, Manhattan opened its seventh basketball season under the leadership of Neil Cohalan with an impressive 46 to 19 victory over an Alumni five before a crowd of 1,000 persons at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Eighteen Italian airplanes today bombed the Ethiopian town of Dessye and an encampment near by. The aviators brought back word they believed Emperor Haile Selassie had escaped unscathed.

WITH its eye, as always, on the welfare and budgets of its clients, this column has been looking into the matter of New Year's Eve -- specifically, the matter of its box-office prices. In general, they tilt upward that night, the managers figuring that ready cash should be in circulation then if ever.

CORNING, N.Y., Dec. 7 (AP). -- With the care accorded by a court jeweler to an exquisite crown gem, picked workmen of the Corning Glass Works tomorrow will remove from its annealing oven the world's largest piece of glass, the 200-inch mirror, or "eye," for the world's largest telescope.

THE alert and efficient-looking camera hobbyist of today, with his entire photographic outfit lightly suspended from a strap over his shoulder, or perhaps concealed in a coat or sweater pocket, offers a striking contrast to his predecessor of only a few years ago.

Mrs. Edward Palmer York gave a dinner last night at the Savoy-Plaza for Miss Winifred D. Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey V.W. Gould, and her fiance, Clifford Coddington. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Harvey. Mr. and Mrs. Oliver R. Grace, Miss Clarinda York, Miss June York, William E. Palmer, Andrew Coddington and Paul Saurel.

VERNON, Mich. -- Michigan may be the next great gold producing State. Deposits opened here recently on the banks of the Shiawassee River show assay values equal to the quality of the best Klondike finds.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (AP). -- Texas Christian defeated Santa Clara by 10 to 6 today in a thrill-a-minute game.
The annual Columbia College "Dean's Drag" will take place Saturday night in John Jay Hall, on the campus. The proceeds from the dance will go to the dean's fund for needy students.

THE How-to-Make-It Club of the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania enters its third year at Christmas time. Formed to give a larger group of young students an intimate knowledge and appreciation of museum exhibits, the organization now has 1,000 members, mostly boys and girls between 7 and 14, scattered through the United States.

IF one of the older New York galleries be correct in its belief that a snow scene in the window is the best bid for the attention of passers-by, then the Roerich Museum's present show should prove its most popular exhibition to date.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6. -- Kentucky's $70,000,000 tobacco crop began this week its movement to market, but not at prices the growers expected. Despite production control, prices are below par.

THE most photographed city in the world is one of the most difficult and dangerous to picture. A close-up of a tall building, for instance, is likely to make the structure appear to be tilting at a precarious angle, while flying too low over the fascinating views the city offers involves considerable hazard and violates Federal regulations.
IN the Rio Grande pueblos of Santo Domingo and San Felipe, twenty-five miles south of Santa Fe, Christmas Eve is celebrated with a pagan dance in a Christian church.

ADOPTION of permanent license plates was urged last week by Michael A. Connor, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of Connecticut. Not only would this bring an annual saving estimated at $125,000 but it would greatly simplify the progress of car registration every year, he asserted.

THE approach of Christmas is heralded by Columbia with one of the largest and most substantial lists we can remember. In addition to six album sets are half a dozen seasonal disks, carols or hymns, and a loose record release of seven.

KURT SCHINDLER, who died the 16th of last month, had had excellent training in music. He was eclectic in his tastes and his musical understanding. He could write an admirable introductory note to the first performance of a Schoenberg string quartet, and go into ecstacies over Mendelssohn's "Reformation" symphony.

Richard P. Terhune, who has been wearing the insignia of lieutenant commander of the New York Power Squadron, is the indicated new commander of this important unit of the United States Power Squadrons for next year and in line for promotion at the annual meeting and elections tomorrow night.

NORMA MILES, pretty, talented and young, lived with her spinster aunt in a cottage overlooking the Tred Avon River. On the Eastern Shore sailing and fishing were quite as important as any land occupations. But fishermen belonged to a lower social caste than the old landed families, even when they had lost their lands.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7. -- Storming the enemy defense for two touchdowns and a field goal in the fourth quarter, the University of Maryland captured the State football championship by beating Western Maryland College, 22 to 7, today at the Stadium.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 7. -- Baldwin High School's football forces stormed onto Cameron Field full of determination today and scored a notable 14-to-7 victory over Petersburg High in the second post-season gridiron game in as many years between the schools.

While a delegation of five presented to Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, demands for relief, some 200 relief workers representing the Workers Alliance of Greater New York held a demonstration yesterday morning in front of the offices of the WPA in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

The annual meeting of the Students International Union will be held Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-first Street, it was announced yesterday. Sir Norman Angell, Nobel Prize winner, will be the chief speaker and Mrs. Alexander H. Hadden, a vice president, will preside.

ONE reads Mr. Schlink's new book with the growing conviction that it would be much easier and wiser just to lie down and die and be done with it than to try to carry on an inevitably losing struggle against the poisons that, according to the author, are being fed to the American people in almost all kinds of their food.

The annual bazaar to raise funds for the Barat Settlement will take place Wednesday at the Plaza. A feature of the bazaar will be a tea room, where luncheon and tea will be served by members of the junior auxiliary of the settlement.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 7. -- A considerable dampening of enthusiasm for President Roosevelt and his New Deal policies, particularly the latter, has been noted in North Carolina, but it has not been such as to cause any observer here to entertain the slightest serious thought that the State might repeat is performance of 1928 and go Republican next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- In its first major strategy since joining the issue with utility concerns over the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935, the government today moved to have the question decided by the Supreme Court exclusively on the basis of the suit brought in New York by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Electric Bond and Share Company and five of its subsidiaries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- The wind that sweeps north and west from the prairies into Lake Michigan will have important tidings for Franklin D. Roosevelt Monday if he can read the message of the wind. It comes from areas vital to him in his quest for reelection, the farms and cities of the Midwest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7. -- Less favorable weather reduced shopping activity to some small extent as the week closed, but it is generally reported that Christmas purchasing got off to an unusually early start and has been in most satisfactory volume.

First Houses -- New York City's initial experiment in slum clearance -- have been formally dedicated, and within the next few weeks 120 carefully selected families will move into the 1.37-acre development of garden apartments at Avenue A and East Third Street.

TOKYO, Dec. 7 -- The mission of Lieut. Col. Muto, who left for China last evening, is to arrange for an increase in Japan's permanent garrison in North China, the newspaper Asahi reports. He will discuss organization details with Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of Japan's forces in North China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In approaching my task of coordinating the cooperative efforts of industry and the government to accelerate recovery, re-employ the jobless and establish a greater measure of permanent economic stability, I have sought first to ascertain industry's point of view.

The Congressional, crack flier of the Pennsylvania Railroad between New York and Washington, rounded out fifty years of service yesterday. The train in the last half century has traveled 8,212,500 miles and carried 7,000,000 passengers between the two cities.

This is a story of straight detective work by the Police Department of the City of New York under the direction of Police Commissioner Thatcher Colt, whom you may have met in other stories by Anthony Abbot. If so, you will remember that Colt likes to take an active part in solving such crime puzzles as seem to present extraordinary difficulties.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 7. -- President Roosevelt spent the last full day of his semi-vacation at the "Little White House" here concentrating on two speeches which he will deliver before widely differing forums on Monday. He will start for those engagements on a special train leaving before noon tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7. -- Speaking before the Connecticut Council of Churches today, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, declared that the "next twenty years would determine if there is a satisfactory method of stopping the continually disintegrating effect of pressure groups and building up a stronger sense of the general welfare without sacrificing any essential liberty to democratic process and the essential spiritual sacredness of the individual as an individual."

Recommendations of proposals to be brought before the annual meeting in February were approved at the quarterly meeting of the executive committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association at the Hotel Vanderbilt yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The key to the new rebellion against the totalitarian State that flared up in the German Protestant Church ten days ago and became more intense this week, is the question of whether the National Socialist regime is worthy of Protestant confidence.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Faculty members of the Harvard Law School today scoffed at the threat made by Attorney General Paul Dever that he would take away the charters of educational institutions whose faculties did not comply with the Teachers' Oath Law.

WITH the substantial completion of his vast WPA recruiting campaign Relief Administrator Harry L. Hopkins ended the first stage of an effort comparable only with the mobilization of the A.E.F. in 1917. The 3,500,000 men whom he has actually put to work fall only half a million short of the total strength of the army and navy at their World War peak.

IT is quite certain that irrespective of the decisions of Mr. Toscanini the Philharmonic-Symphony season of 1936-37 will be shorter than this one. Whenever Mr. Toscanini, who obviously cannot be replaced, elects to terminate his appearances with the New York orchestra, the management has in view a policy which would represent a considerable departure from the past.

WASHINGTON'S Farewell Address urged his fellow-countrymen always to observe good faith with all nations. With equal reason, we expect them to observe good faith with us. This was the essential point of Secretary HULL'S careful statement on conditions in North China. He spoke on this subject at the very time when the British Foreign Secretary, Sir SAMUEL HOARE, was dealing with it in his long address in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON'S Farewell Address urged his fellow-countrymen always to observe good faith with all nations. With equal reason, we expect them to observe good faith with us. This was the essential point of Secretary HULL'S careful statement on conditions in North China. He spoke on this subject at the very time when the British Foreign Secretary, Sir SAMUEL HOARE, was dealing with it in his long address in the House of Commons.

RATHER than have an argument with the composing room we have permitted the title of this book and the names of its author, illustrator and publishers to be printed in the usual manner with capital letters and punctuation marks according to the rules.

HOLLYWOOD. A WESTERN UNION messenger delivered a large envelope and extended a pad for signature. Breaking the seal, a booklet 10 by 13 inches was unveiled, bound in blue stock and tied with a blue silk cord with tassels.

THE current (December) Prints, edited by Aline Kistler, continues the excellent impression made by the previous issue, which was the first after the magazine's reorganization. There are included Kerr Eby's explanation of his "War" group of etching and drawings, recently exhibited at Keppel's, with a number of reproductions.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 7. -- On the eve of Jean Sibelius's seventieth birthday tomorrow, as civic committees in nearly every town in the country busily completed last details of elaborate programs honoring him, a correspondent found the composer today peacefully at work in his beautiful house at Tusual, fifteen miles inland from Helsingfors.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The advisory committee of the New York State Conference of Mayors at a meeting here today came out for "reduction and limitation of the tax burden on real estate."

The annual Winter Gambol, dinner and ball of the Lambs was held last night and during the early hours of this morning in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, with more than 1,400 persons present.

HERE and there the quality of the enthusiasm for "First Lady" is strained. To some of the hedonists who prowl around our theatre the new comedy by Katharine Dayton and George S. Kaufman lacks bite. But that merely goes to show that, after all, there is no accounting for personal taste.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- A continuation of the favorable industrial trend which had been noted in recent months was reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

HOLLYWOOD. SAMUEL GOLDWYN lost a David and Goliath battle this week and changed the title of the new Eddie Cantor film from "Shoot the Chutes" to "Strike Me Pink." For a reason known only to himself, Sidney Skolsky, Hollywood columnist, liked the "Pink" title and persisted in referring to the film by that name in his column.
WITH proposals and counter-proposals for controlling vehicles in the interests of safety, the role of the speed governor has become a lively topic of discussion.

AT the Arden Gallery through December Nura is having a "show" -- one so simple, so subtle, so various and so completely one thing that you are almost as badly off trying to describe it as if making some foolhardy attempt to copy it.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 8. -- Whitecairne Wendy of Wingan, Labrador retriever owned by Jay F. Carlisle of East Islip, L.I., and handled in the field by David Elliott, was the best performer in the Open All-Age Stake at the field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association, concluded here today.

More than a score of new exhibitions await the gallery visitor who has not yet been worn out by the early season rush of shows. Oils, water-colors, prints, sculpture and craft work are included in numbers and variety to appeal to an unusually wide diversity of tastes.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 8. -- Four Italian planes bombed today an Ethiopian encampment north of Dessye in the third aerial raid in three days. The results of the bombardment were not announced.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The world's chief naval powers, the United States, Great Britain, Japan, France and Italy, will meet in conference here tomorrow in the hope of concluding "a new international treaty for the limitation of naval armaments.

PEIPING, Dec. 8. -- With the formal announcement of the powers and the personnel of the new Administrative Council for Hopei and Chahar expected tomorrow or Tuesday, signs of discord are already being shown.

Aroused by the recent movement to have birth control information provided for the mothers of families on relief, Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, occupied the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral at pontifical high mass at 11 o'clock yesterday morning to voice his "measured, deliberate and emphatic condemnation of the effrontery" of its proponents.

TORONTO, Dec. 7 -- Canada's output of copper in 1934 was the greatest on record, in both amount and value, according to a report just issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. It was 364,761,062 pounds, valued at $26,671,438, against 299,982,448 pounds at $21,634,853 in 1933.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Marymount College celebrated today its twenty-eighth birthday anniversary. The day was one of festivity for students and faculty, friends and alumnae.
May I congratulate and correct you on your editorial relative to minimum wages for waitresses in hotels and restaurants?

CORNING, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- The success of man's most ambitious effort to build a "tower to infinity" was assured here today, after more than a year of anxious waiting, when the giant mirror-disk for the 200-inch telescope was taken out of its annealing oven and declared to be the world's mightiest astronomical eye to be used for the discovery of stars and universes yet unknown.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The entire gunnery system of the 20,150-ton British battleship Royal Oak has been put out of action by what is suspected to have been an act of sabotage.

MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- An unconscious 76-year-old farm hand was rescued here this morning in a spectacular fire on the estate of John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, which destroyed a private indoor polo field, stable and grand stand valued at more than $200,000.

Four burglary suspects were arrested shortly after midnight yesterday on the top floor of a six-story drug warehouse at 54 Fulton Street. According to the police, the men were attempting to enter the offices of E.J. Barry, Inc., and steal a valuable supply of narcotics and perfumes.

Using tools owned by their victims, burglars early yesterday smashed open two safes belonging to the Moylan Supply Corporation at 523 West 125th Street and got away with $500 found in the safes and a quantity of electric appliances.

In THE TIMES of Dec. 2 I noticed some interesting comment from the Uhlmann Grain Company on the wheat situation; that they see a likelihood of a carryover of 150,000,000 bushels of United States wheat into the 1936 crop year; and, "with a normal crop in 1936," that the United States would again be an exporter of the bread grain.

Herman Katims, pianist, appeared in recital last night at Carnegie Hall in an all-Beethoven program. He played four of the sonatas: Op. 10, No. 1; Op. 57, the "Appassionata"; Op. 27, No. 2, and the last of the thirty-two, Op. 111. There was a good-sized audience which was demonstrative after each of the pianist's interpretations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Livestock interests are giving more attention to raising, feeding and marketing cattle, hogs and sheep than at any previous time. The expansion in the attendance of farmers who raise stock at the annual stock show here was greater than in recent years.

A buoyancy unusual for December is being shown by the steel industry, according to the weekly review of the magazine Steel. The rate of operations rose 1 point last week to 57 per cent of capacity, the high mark for this year; prices are firm and the active demand for lighter steel products is about to be reinforced by larger requirements for structural and railroad materials, the magazine says.

Schedules of varsity teams for the Winter and Spring seasons were announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics at C.C.N.Y. Sixty-eight contests are listed, the baseball team topping all the squads with nineteen games carded.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8. -- Francis B. Stevenson, a former Nassau County (N.Y.) policeman, seized a guard's pistol in the Anne Arundel County jail today, shot a young woman whose testimony had helped to convict him of larceny, and turned the weapon upon himself, inflicting a serious wound.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 57 per cent of capacity, representing the fourth weekly increase of 1 point. Tonnage is up 70 per cent from the average in July, the low month of the year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade here were erratio last week with a lower close. Prices follow:

With a dramatic change of venue, so to speak, the Teatro d'Arte crossed Forty-eighth Street from the Longacre Theatre to the Ritz Theatre yesterday and presented in afternoon and evening the Italian version of Louis N. Parker's "The Cardinal," calling this four-act drama with more precision "Il Cardinale Giovanni de Medici."

The annual Christmas bazaar of the Near East Industries will open at the headquarters of the Near East Foundation, 2 West Forty-sixth Street, today, continuing through Saturday daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The proceeds of the sale of the handiwork of refugee women will be devoted to their maintenance and to that of their dependent children.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 8. -- Steps were taken today with the publication of a decree signed by the High Commissioner to ease the almost unbearable strain that is being placed on roads and vehicles here and in Northern Ethiopia.

JULIUS CAESAR, observes MONTAIGNE in one of the best known of his essays, won fifty-two pitched battles, and every time against superior forces. The secret of his unbroken success was a combination of valor, genius and luck.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- A feature of the oats trade here last week was a steady accumulation of near-by futures by processors and the changing of spreads on the part of Northwestern interests, the December being bought and the May sold. The open interest is not large, and the movement is fair.

A torn piece of papyrus containing parts of verses of the eighteenth chapter of the Gospel of St. JOHN has come to light, proving "beyond all doubt," according to the highest authority, Sir FREDERIC KENYON, that this Gospel was in circulation in the first half of the second century.

With an expansive gesture patriarchal Tobias Wildstein whipped out a $1 note yesterday afternoon, ignited one end of it, and started to light the 109 candles on his three-foot birthday cake, set up on a table in the basement of the home of the Sons and Daughters of Israel, 232 East Tenth Street.

Local and national business organizations, according to the Merchants Association of New York, have joined in a campaign to bring about the repeal of that part of the Federal Revenue Act of 1934 which provides that the salaries paid in 1934 to all corporation employes receiving more than $15,000 a year may be made public in 1936.

In a unique occasion at the Metropolitan Opera House more than 1,200 members of the newly formed Metropolitan Opera Guild last night attended a reception at which they mingled with the artists and staff of the opera company.

CAIRO, Dec. 8. -- Two trolley cars and a motor bus were burned by students in anti-British rioting here today, and many policemen, including a Briton, were injured. About sixty students suffered powder burns as a result of shots fired by the police.

A heavy "pea-soup" fog enveloped the city early this morning, accompanied by a sharp change to warmer from the temperature of the last few days. Starting at about 10 o'clock last night, the fog gathered in thick smoke-like billows that were rolling heavily over the city by midnight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Definite progress toward a greatly improved army marked the fiscal year which ended in June, Secretary Dern said in his annual report today, adding that the year was "in many respects one of the most important in the peace-time history of the War Department."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8.--Although the general repair and upkeep of battleships continued to improve during the 1935 fiscal year, in spite of the ships' increasing age, Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations, called attention in his annual report issued today to major improvements that must be made if the vessels are to keep pace with the other craft of the fleet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The radio speech of Senator Borah last night, in which he attacked by indirection the plan of the conservative wing of the Republican party to align itself with big business and collect from industry a vast campaign fund, was viewed here today as evidence of a purpose by the Progressive wing to array itself against the Eastern Republicans.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- A campaign to raise $3,500,000 in 1936 to be expended by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for the "reconstruction, emigration aid and emergency service" among European Jews was voted here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Clark Hinkle, former Bucknell University star, kicked two field goals, made a touchdown and added the extra point to give the Green Bay Packers a 13-to-6 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National League game today.

ROME, Dec. 8. -- The speech on the Italo-Ethiopian crisis that Premier Benito Mussolini delivered in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday has caused a widespread feeling of optimism throughout Italy. It is felt that it touched exactly the right note for, though showing no sign of retreat, Italy has left every possible door open for future negotiations.

CEDARHUST, L.I., Dec. 8. -- The miniature gold racquet, emblematic of victory, was presented to Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club today as the blue ribbon squash racquets event ended at the Rockaway Hunting Club. He thus became the first player to win the gold racquet tournament for the third time, his previous conquests being scored in 1931 and 1933.

Contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund dropped to $1,892.50 yesterday, the smallest amount received on any one day since the twenty-fourth annual appeal for those in deepest distress in all New York opened a week ago yesterday.

The establishment of a registration centre and control calendar for dates of public meetings, dinners and benefits was announced yesterday by the Town Hall Club at 123 West Forty-third Street. The aim, it was said, was to reduce the number of conflicting dates for events which are of interest to the same groups.

Three men, each accused of having left the scene of an accident after his automobile had seriously injured a person, were held by the police yesterday at Newark, N.J., after citizens had aided in their capture.

At their second of two evenings of instrumental and vocal chamber music at the David Mannes Music School, Ann Dick, soprano, and Yella Pessl, harpsichordist and pianist, presented last night the entire song cycle of Schubert's "Die Schoene Muellerin."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8. -- The Englewood Field Club held undisputed possession of first place in the New Jersey group of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League today as a result of its victory over the previously undefeated Plainfield Country Club, 3-2.

The general convention of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States closed at the Hotel Commodore yesterday with a rejection of all attempts to keep American athletes out of the Olympic Games in Germany.
The Bronxville F.C. defeated Ardsley, 4 to 3, while Apawamis and Sleepy Hollow registered one-sided victories in Westchester Division Metropolitan Squash Racquets League team matches yesterday.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Search for Paul Redfern, United States flier who vanished eight years ago, began in earnest today when a single-engined flying boat left the tiny village of Wanotoba, near the junction of Brazil and the Dutch and British Guianas.

The Normandie's vibration troubles will be removed before the huge liner resumes service from Havre to New York in March, Henri Cangardel, managing director of the French line, said yesterday in a statement issued from the company's headquarters in Paris.
HOUSTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- One death and more than $1,000,000 property damage were caused by flood waters tonight which continued to spread over 100,000 acres.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL, EN ROUTE TO CHICAGO, Dec. 8.--With his holiday at Warm Springs, Ga., concluded, President Roosevelt tonight traveled toward the Middle West, where tomorrow he will make two speeches, each expected to be significant as sequels to the militant defense of his administration, which he delivered at Atlanta, Ga., on Nov. 29.

The eighth anniversary of the Church Army, an evangelical organization of laymen in the Protestant Episcopal Church, was observed yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. The group is made up largely of young men and women between the ages of 20 and 30.

BERLIN, Dec. 8. -- The Nazi government and the opposition clergy of the Confessional Synod avoided today making too sharp an issue of the present crisis in the struggle between the church and the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The lawyers committee of the American Liberty League, in its second attack upon a New Deal act, branded today as unconstitutional on four points the Guffey Bituminous Coal Conservation Act. It also defended the right of its members as lawyers to express opinions publicly on the constitutionality of legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Efforts of the Democratic committee of Lancaster County, Pa., to influence farmers receiving AAA benefits to support the party ticket were revealed in a letter sent to the voters last month and made public by the Republican National Committee tonight.

Secure in the knowledge that a tie would assure them of second place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League, the Brooklyn Dodgers adopted cautious methods against the Boston Redskins yesterday at Ebbets Field and the final whistle found both elevens in a scoreless deadlock.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8. -- Soviet Russia demonstrated its determination to stamp out opposition to the Stakhanoffite movement for increased production with two death sentences and numerous prison terms today.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Conditions which enabled the British Government this week to issue loans amounting to 300,000,000 at an average cost of only 2 1/4 per cent were such as could scarcely fail to give a strong stimulus to the security markets.

Two recommendations will be made to the basketball rules committee as a result of a meeting to interpret the code last night at the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A., at which most of the leading coaches and officials in the metropolitan district were present.
