A new first mortgage of $300,000 at 5 per cent interest for five years has been arranged by Samuel Kronsky, Inc., as broker, for the Empire-Sixth Avenue Corporation on the twenty-story Lefcourt-Empire Building at 989-991 Sixth Avenue. The building was bid in at auction by the Empire-Sixth Avenue Corporation about a week ago.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.1 on Dec. 4, compared with 71.3 a fortnight before, 71 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

DALLAS, Dec. 8. -- Coach Claude (Tiny) Thornhill of Stanford started back to the Pacific Coast today to prepare his football warriors "for everything imaginable" in the Rose Bowl after scouting Southern Methodist in the Mustangs' final and impressive regular season victory yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- In a prediction concerning the Senatorial elections next year in which twenty Democratic and thirteen Republican seats are at stake, Senator Joseph F. Guffey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial committee, today declared that President Roosevelt's policies would be vindicated by his re-election and the re-election of "all our Democratic Senators."

When the world gets tired of murdering itself for greed there still will be many people who are peace-loving, quiet, and who can rejoice in the superiority of their rivals, Professor William Lyon Phelps said yesterday in a sermon at the Community Church in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

BALDWIN, L.I., Dec. 8. -- Despite the rain, 300 persons were at the station to greet Baldwin High School's victorious football team upon its arrival late today from its successful invasion of Virginia. At Petersburg yesterday Coach George Craig's charges registered a well-earned 14-to-7 triumph over Peters-burg High.

ADDINGTON, Surrey, England, Dec. 8. -- Golfers who believe that the modern golf ball goes too far, thus spoiling the game for the average player and making some old championship courses look ridiculously short, organized a friendly test here today with a new-type light ball, which even the hardest hitters cannot drive much over 250 yards.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP). -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels mowed down the University of Oregon eleven, 18 to 0, today in a football game witnessed by 16,000 fans.

In its report on patents the Science Advisory Board lays its finger on a defect that has long called for correction. Some 90,000 patents are granted every year. If the number were only 10,000 there would still be reason to doubt the quality of the inventions disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Of $159,352,843.24 reported spent between July 1 and Sept. 30, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration paid out to farmers cooperating in its six programs $133,387,288.72, according to the monthly report of the AAA Controller made public today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8. -- Although half a dozen attempts to show the joys of socialism through the classic ballet have failed, the Bolshoi Theatre has presented another of Dmitri Shostakovich's ballets, "The Limpid Stream."

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 8. -- The seventieth anniversary today of the birth of Jean Sibelius, celebrated Finnish composer, was observed in this country with a nation-wide festival. Flags were hoisted in all the towns and from every part of Finland citizens sent deputations to pay homage to the nation's greatest composer.

BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 8 (AP). -- France's giant seaplane, the Lieutenant-de-Vaisseau-Paris, took off today for Dakar, Senegal, on its way across the South Atlantic to celebrate the three hundredth year of French rule in Guiana and the West Indies isles of Guadeloupe and Martinique.
Approval of a long list of championship awards for 1936 was among the routine business disposed of at the closing session of the A.A.U. convention at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Under the signature of Ellis A. Gimbel, department store executive, a legal notice will appear in newspapers tomorrow morning announcing that he intends to dissolve as of Dec. 31 the business of Gimbel Brothers Bankers, "a partnership which was organized to conduct a private banking bush s."
" It is by the goodness of God that in our country we have three unspeakably precious things -- free speech, freedom of conscience and the prudence never to practice either of them."

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The report of the Bank of France, published on Thursday, was compiled on Nov. 29, and refers to the week in which the largest exodus of gold from the bank took place. At the same time the figures show that the usual month-end expansion occurred.

With Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland and Marcel Camp of Detroit ready for the opening match, play in the world's pocket billiard championship will get under way tonight in the Roof Garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania. Ten of the country's leading cue experts will compete for title honors in the thirteen-day tournament.

GENEVA, Dec. 8. -- Some wealthy German Jews are seeking to have a bank established to liquidate the property of Jews in Germany so as to solve the transfer problem for refugees and reduce the loss now suffered in leaving the country, according to reports here.

MADRID, Dec. 8. -- Two administrative scandals have failed to produce a dissolution of parliament so earnestly desired by the Socialists and their Left wing allies who believe they can regain control of the government if another general election is held now.

Norman Armitage, national champion, topped twenty-eight candidates yesterday in the second of the series of saber tests being conducted by the Amateur Fencers League of America to help determine the composition of the American Olympic sword team. Armitage triumphed on his home strips at the Fencers Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- So many new factors have come into the grain trade recently that the majority of operators are uncertain which side of the market to take, so that most of the speculative operations are professional and daily fluctuations are confined to a moderate range.

In our work at the Legal Aid Bureau of the Educational Alliance we are frequently consulted by employes who have assigned their wages under instalment contracts for the purchase of merchandise without knowing that they have done so. Many of the cases are, pitiful, since the poor employe is left with nothing to live on when such assignments are enforced.

A demand for a legislative investigation of Governor Harold G. Hoffman's interview with Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the New Jersey prison death house was made last night by Assemblyman Crawford Jamieson, a Democrat, of Mercer County.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin called on his National Union for Social Justice today to mobilize by Congressional districts "for the purpose of driving from public office those who support the system of private money control."

Mr. PEEK, now on the outside looking in, has fired his first shell against the Administration. The chief point scored by the former foreign trade adviser is that Mr. ROOSEVELT, in one speech of his 1932 campaign, promised not to lower agricultural tariffs. This is regrettably true, but it seems odd of Mr. PEEK to concentrate all his attention on this particular broken pledge.

The halt in the stock market, which occurred toward the end of November, continued last week; prices changed little. This was again that market's quite familiar action on occasions when the best of a run of good industrial news has become public property, and when prices on the Stock Exchange had foreshadowed the news beforehand.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Plans for a central airport for Westchester County, to be situated at Croton Point, on the Hudson River, will be revived tomorrow at the meeting of the Westchester Board of Supervisors. The Croton Point site had been discarded in favor of a location at Valhalla, in Mount Pleasant, because of the necessity of filling in acres of lowland.

Two brief series of recitals were brought to their conclusion last night when Yvonne Georgi danced her second performance at the Guild Theatre and Angna Enters gave her third program of "Episodes" at the Masque.

" Life With Father," by Clarence Day, has been gaining momentum in the sales race recently, and is now in second place here in New York. The day after Thanksgiving, Alfred A. Knopf received orders for 2,200 copies of this book -- setting a "Life With Father" record -- and during the following week orders for 9,000 copies came in.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8. -- Although the Soviet Union is harvesting the biggest flax crop in its history today, the export organization predicts that sales abroad will be less than those of last year.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The recovery in United States markets has not been taken into account here, although, at any other time, such an upward movement would have been counted as a favorable element in the general situation and an encouragement to the European markets.
The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States adopted yesterday the following resolution, drawn up by Gustavus T. Kirby, former president of the Amateur Athletic Union:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Release of $14,112,442 by Controller General McCarl for thirteen projects designed to provide relief jobs for white collar workers was announced today.

The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in his sermon at the Cathedral yesterday morning, criticized Bible societies for what he called their lack of "common honesty" in expurgating the Coverdale Bible.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Although there was an increase of 4,222,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England this week, compared with an increase of 5,760,000 in the corresponding week last year, total circulation was raised to 405,600,000, which was 20,120,000 over the figure in 1934.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 8. -- On the eve of a grand jury investigation of the WPA administration in Nassau County, Harold P.C. Howe, Nassau-Suffolk WPA director, announced tonight that he would have 795 men on the sites of county projects tomorrow morning and that it is up to the county to supply tools.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8.--Good deliveries of cash corn on December contracts started a selling movement and a sharp decline here last week, followed by a rally, so that all futures closed around the best price of the week, with net gains of 7/8 cent on December, 5/8 cent on May and 1/2 cent on July.

MUSSOLINI'S speech on Saturday was not so thunderous and threatening as was indicated in advance. It is true that he took the firmest tone against the League of Nations, and vehemently asserted Italy's ability to press on to her great objective, sanctions or no sanctions.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity continued in large volume and embraced a wide selection of loans. Those added to the current month's list were composed of industrial, foreign and municipal refundings, while those for later months were more diversified, with the largest a block of Federal Lank Bank bonds.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Waldo Himmer of 254 Boulevard, Mountain Lakes, is faced tonight with the problem of a crane which, like the snake in Aesop's fable, strikes at the man who saved its life. The crane only nibbled at Himmer, but it struck hard enough at his father, Vitalis, to knock a pipe from his mouth.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 8. -- Ohio, always a pivotal State in national elections, is very much fed up with the New Deal and is showing decided pro-Republican tendencies today.

Movements were erratic in the commodity futures markets here last week. Coffee and sugar eased persistently and recurrent weakness brought rubber lower for the week. Hides and cocoa ended with gains. Copper was strong.

In a Michigan Congress District, illuminated by all the intellectual and moral influences that radiate from Kalamazoo, the Republican primary for Representative was won by a devout partisan of Dr. TOWNSEND with a majority over all competitors and a plurality of 8,000 over the closest rival.

A recapitulation of the motor vehicle accidents for November showed a decrease of 24 per cent in accidents, 10 per cent in fatalities and 24 1/2 per cent in the number of persons injured, figures released yesterday by the Police, Department showed.

It was not without special design that the appeal for the Neediest Cases was originally planned to be issued just before Christmas. That is the time when we think of our friends and relatives with sympathy and affection. It is the time when, if ever, the heart overflows with pity for the unfortunate and miserable who are forced to live outside of a circle of Christmas friendship.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Ephraim E. Di Kahble, Princeton freshman, who last week advertised in the personal columns of New York newspapers for an orange and black guinea pig, was exposed tonight as the ingenious creation of five other members of the class of '39 at Princeton University, whose ultimate aim was to elect their imaginary character treasurer of the freshman class.

By breaking 94 out of 100 targets, T.H. Lawrence led a field of twenty-four gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. There was a tie for the handicap prize between J. Mercadante and M.B. Kaesche, each returning a full card.

MANILA, Dec. 2. -- Laying the foundation for adequate national defense, establishing complete domestic order and attacking the problem of tenant labor in the Philippines are the major matters with which President Manuel L. Quezon proposes to occupy himself in the first year of his administration.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- A fresh obstacle confronted the London naval conference tonight on the eve of its opening tomorrow, as French, Italian and American delegations engaged in a last-minute exchange of viewpoints with the British.

The proposal to tax motor cars capable of fifty miles per hour or more as suggested by Francis MacDonald does not take into consideration the wide differences in driving conditions in various parts of the country. On Long Island and in the metropolitan district fifty miles may be reasonable as a top speed on dry roads, but certainly not on wet, slippery pavements.

Morris Davis of the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A. created a new metropolitan record in capturing the twenty-five-mile Metropolitan A.A.U. walking championship held under the auspices of the Finnish A.C. in Brooklyn yesterday. Davis's time through the streets of Bay Ridge was 3 hours 43 minutes 34 seconds, supplanting the old mark of 4 hours 3 minutes, established by Charles Eschenbach of the New York A.C. in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8.--Only one person in the United States had a net taxable income of more than $5,000,000 in 1934, and his was between $6,000,000 and $9,000,000, Internal Revenue Bureau figures showed today.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 8. -- Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., today won an eighteen-hole play-off to take first prize money from Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee, in the $2,000 Orlando Open golf tourney. They were tied after the regular seventy-two holes yesterday with totals of 280.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP). -- A revenue problem bearing earmarks of an incipient taxpayers' revolt confronted California officials today struggling with a record-breaking $426,000,000 biennial budget.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.6, which compares with 84.5 the week before, 84.3 two weeks before, 85 three weeks before and 85 four weeks before.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 8. -- Whatever other virtues Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, may claim for the capitalistic system, defended by him in his recent address before the Academy of Law, its application to railways as a medium of national transportation was rejected by Chancellor Adolf Hitler today in an enthusiastic eulogy of the German Government-owned railways.
MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 9. -- The ice avalanche that buried community dwellings at Kirovsk, at the foot of Mount Yuxpor, overturned a railroad locomotive.

TOKYO, Dec. 8. -- Japan's fundamental policy at the London naval conferences was described by Navy Minister Mineo Osumi in a statement to the press tonight as "thoroughgoing disarmament by creating a situation of non-aggression and non-menace and establishing a common upper limit of naval tonnage."

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 8. -- A new attempt at a serious revolt by Estonian Front Soldiers and Fascist elements was disclosed late last night when Estonian political police arrested twenty persons taking part in a secret meeting near Reval. Among those detained were General Anders Larka, Colonel Seimann and many other leaders of the Front Soldiers societies.

Hospital workers themselves are leading in the employe group subscriptions which are just beginning to come in volume to the United Hospital Campaign Fund, it was reported yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the campaign, in making public the latest list of contributors.

The announcement by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration of its production restriction program for 1936 and the continued selling of futures by houses which were believed to be acting for the Producers Pool were the chief price influences in the cotton market here last week.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- There was a sudden change in business on the Bourse yesterday following the theatrical events that had occurred in the Chamber of Deputies that same morning and which were interpreted as a general reconciliation of the various parties and as a political event of great importance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Leading industrialists who had previously accepted an invitation to attend were reported tonight to be ready to bolt the conference called by Major George L. Berry, coordinator for industrial cooperation, when it is convened here tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Successful treatment for arthritis with great doses of Vitamin D was described today by Dr. C.I. Reed, of the University of Illinois College of Medicine.

Replying to charges by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, declared yesterday that 100,000 dressmakers affiliated with his organization were not seeking to "plunge the New York dress industry into a war for the mere fun of striking."

Formation of a New York Safety Council comes at an opportune time. The public seems to be aroused, as it has not been in years, to the menace of accidents, especially those on the highway. The National Safety Council has done splendid work in this field, and much can be expected of a local agency acting along similar lines.

RIGA, Latvia, Dec. 8. -- The Foreign Ministers of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania will meet in Riga tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday. The conference will be the third since the "Baltic Entente" was formed last year. Karlis Ulmanis, Premier and Foreign Minister of Latvia, will take part for the first time.
DETROIT, Dec. 8. -- The Red Wings played their fifth tie of the young National Hockey League season tonight, deadlocking 1-all with the Americans in a rough game.

A strike involving 5,000 motion-picture studio employes on the Pacific Coast and 30,000 film stagehands all over the United States and Canada was threatened yesterday by the International Alliance of Theatre and Stagehand Employes.
In these days of Christmas giving the advice of the philosopher Seneca, who lived in the time of the Roman Empire, seems of much present value. He said:

The New York State Committee of the Socialist party yesterday proclaimed the Left Wing group which bolted the central committee of the party's local organization last week an "outlaw organization" without standing in the party.

The American Car and Foundry Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries have reported for the six months ended on Oct. 31 a net loss of $1,731,318 after all charges, including $828,284 for depreciation. For the first six months of the preceding fiscal year the net loss was $330,753.

The list of Metropolitan Opera boxholders for the 1935-1936 season, opening next Monday evening, Dec. 16, the first season under the new management of Edward Johnson, successor to Giulio Gatti-Casazza, was made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here last week was much smaller than in the preceding week and almost 50 per cent less than a year ago. The turnover of corn, however, was more than 10,000,000 bushels, more than the week before.

Merchants and others subject to the city sales tax have until Jan. 15, 1936, to make their payments without being subject to penalties, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. The tax, covering the period from September to December, inclusive, is actually due on Jan. 1, but the law allows fifteen days of grace.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company will begin today, at public hearings before the Transit Commission, its drive to establish by next May a comprehensive 5-cent fare bus system operating a fleet of more than 600 motor vehicles over routes once dedicated to street car travel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today the completion of the liquidation of thirteen receiverships and the restoration of one receivership to solvency in November, making 173 receiverships closed or restored to solvency since his annual report to Congress dated Oct. 31, 1934.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Chicago's Bears conquered the Chicago Cardinals, 13 to 0, today to deprive their home-town rivals of a tie for first place in the Western division of the National Football League and give the Detroit Lions the right to meet the New York Giants, leaders of the Eastern section, in the championship play-off.

Construction of the 38th Street-East River tunnel in time for the world's fair opening at Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, in 1939. was advocated last evening by United States Senator Robert F. Wagner as providing "the key to the proper handling of motorists."

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Dr. Louis Mark of Columbus, Ohio, and Lewis Bernard of Cincinnati led a field of sixteen paired teams to win the president's trophy in the final event of the American bridge tournament today.
Performances of "Victoria legina," a new play with Helen Hayes in the leading rJle, have been taken over to raise funds for various charitable organizations.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- This week's decree prohibiting the import of reichsmark notes, or their domestic acceptance for the settlement of foreigners' debts, constituted a formal repudiation of part of the Reichsbank's currency issue. The financial markets were not affected, however, because the measure had been foreseen.
That the United States will have a formidable hockey team at the Winter Olympics in Germany early next year became clearly evident yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The dismemberment of Ethiopia, with the cession of almost half her territory to Italy, will be proposed by the British and French Governments this week in a last despairing effort to make Premier Benito Mussolini abandon his war in Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 8. -- The first .Junior Dinner Dance of the season is to take place on Friday in the ellevue Stratford. Cibotium fern and Southern smilax interspersed with red roses and poinsettia will be used as decorations.

Foreweek trading in the foreign exchange market was a repetition of the sagging tendency in the franc and the gold bloc noted in previous week, contrasted with a firm undertone in sterling. The reaction in the franc was predicated on apprehension over the meeting of the French Chamber on Thursday, and the belief that the reactionary parties' vote would be against Premier Laval.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Aided by the limit time allowance of five and a half minutes, Joseph Battito, 18-year-old Irish-American A.C. runner, captured the third annual A.A.U. six-mile handicap road race staged under the auspices of the 312th Infantry today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Supreme Court will convene tomorrow and hear the initial arguments on the constitutionality of the processing taxes of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, a keystone of the New Deal's reform-recovery structure.

By the sweet quality of his light lyric voice in softer work, his clean-cut diction and ingratiating manner of getting his songs across the footlights, William Robyn, in his recital last night at the Alvin Theatre, quickly won the approval of his audience.

HONOLULU, Dec. 8. Welcomed by a swarm of army planes, the Congressional party headed by Vice President John N. Garner arrived this morning from Manila, where the delegation attended the inauguration of the first Philippine President.

Larger orders for Spring apparel, preparations for special promotions and last-minute calls for holiday merchandise created greater activity In the local wholesale markets last week. Demand for formal ready-to-wear continued to broaden. In the coat division dressy cloth styles for promotions were sought, fur types continued active, while requests started to come in for Spring swagger numbers.

Christians must endure hardship and fight courageously against sin and for the world's salvation, the Right Rev. James Maroni, Lutheran Bishop of Adger, Norway, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

Only by sharing with others can we approach the God-like ideal of peace and brotherhood in this world, the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared yesterday in his first sermon as pastor-elect of Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street. The Rev. Mr. Speers, who comes to New York from the First Presbyterian Church of Utica, will assume his duties here Feb. 5, 1936.
The Gourmet Society luncheon at the Hotel Lafayette yesterday was unprecedented in that the guest of honor did not eat a bite.

New York's Neediest Cases, for whom the twenty-fourth annual appeal was renewed yesterday by the publication of typical cases from the second hundred of the Neediest, are deserving unfortunates, whose only hope for salvation is the trained help of private charity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- After failure to agree to plans for the restoration of the Connecticut Power Company's 66,000-volt interstate transmission lines without placing the corporation under the Wheeler-Rayburn Act, the Federal Power Commission today addressed joint letters to the utilities commissions of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York, urging these commissions to act on the dispute.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP). -- Tommy Cook's goal, thirty-five seconds from the final whistle, tonight gave the Black Hawks a 1-to-0 decision over the Boston Bruins in a rough hockey battle.

Two new phases of social dancing were brought out yesterday in a discussion of the trends of that amusement at the December meeting at the Hotel Astor of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc. One is a revival among the younger devotees of the ballroom of the square dances of the 1890's such as the lancers, quadrilles and other formal figures whose restoration has long been advocated by Henry Ford.

One of this column's volunteer scouts relays a tale of two duck hunters who woke up one day last week to find themselves marooned in the ice-locked stretches of Barnegat Bay. How they escaped from their predicament provides a picture of the hardships occasionally experienced by members of the brotherhood of wildfowlers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The world's most urgent need, "now that it is welded by the scientific conquest of distance into a single community, is a single and universally accepted standard of moral judgment by which all nations agree that their actions shall be approved or condemned," the Right Honorable and Most Rev. William Temple, Lord Archbishop of York, said in two sermons delivered here today.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Following is in brief what is wanted by each of the five powers attending the naval conference that opens here tomorrow:

Clifford Odets, Group Theatre Hero No. 1, returns to Broadway and playwriting tonight with "Paradise Lost," opening at the Longacre Theatre. In it will be seen regulars of the Group's acting company, such as Elia Kazan, Morris Carnovsky, Stella and Luther Adler, Roman Bohnen, and a few from the outside, such as Blanche Gladstone, Frieda Altman and Joan Madison.
The text of the sermon preached yesterday by Cardinal Hayes in St. Patrick's Cathedral follows:

Traffic experts were wondering yesterday whether the Anchor liner Caledonia, due from Glasgow this afternoon with 24,665 cases of Scotch whisky in her hold, would set a new low breakage record for her bottled cargo.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, preaching yesterday morning at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church. Park Avenue and East Sixtieth Street, declared the world was in the grip of an epidemic of fear.

The Maroons of Montreal got a quick jump on the Rangers last night when they scored two goals in the first five minutes of play. But the New Yorkers fought back grimly, retrieved those two tallies and then went into the lead.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- Lard futures were sold here last week on hard spots by packers and speculative holders, with offerings well taken on declines. Specialists say hog and lard prices are not working in unison as they should do, resulting in an unsettled feeling.

The letter from Grete Stencel deplores the fact that she could find, after several hours of search in various toy departments, practically no toys made elsewhere than in Japan, and evidently assumed that these Japanese toys had forced the American-made articles from our markets, to the detriment of 10, 000,000 unemployed Americans who might be put to work making toys for American children.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 8. -- Bryce Kirk, a youngster of 4, won in Class A, and Egbert Moxham, considerably older than Kirk but still the youngest skipper out in Class B, scored in that division in the dinghy races on Manhasset Bay today.

Bishop William T. Manning has joined with the Right Rev. Alexander Mann, Bishop of Pittsburgh, and the Right Rev. John C. Ward, Bishop of Erie, Pa., in a letter to the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in America, protesting against the conferring of the title of "Right Reverend" upon John William Charles Torok by the Bishop of Eau Claire, Wis.

In a cold, slippery setting before about 7,000 spectators, including five American Legion bands, the New York Giants ended their regular football season with a 13-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 8. -- The alleged threat of communism in the strike of between 4,000 and 5,000 oil workers at Barrancas and Bermeja has aroused government and public opinion here.

THE report from the old Schuyler mansion at Pompton Lakes is that Shufflin' Joe Louis has now grown up to 204 pounds or thereabout, which makes him a heavier sleeper than ever. Except in the ring. The Dark Destroyer is always wide awake inside those ropes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 7. -- It was announced last night that the Cabinet had voted this afternoon to ask Congress to rush measures adequate to curb communism. It is believed that Congress will pass emergency bills Monday giving the government what will amount to a free hand.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,996,086,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The "Power Trust," through tactics followed by holding companies in attacking the Utility Act of 1935, is giving "another demonstration" that it is "bigger than the government," Senator Norris charged today.

The recital that Elisabeth Rethberg gave yesterday afternoon in Town Hall showed the conspicuous growth of an artist long famous for her mastery of singing, now an interpreter who makes the voice the vehicle of poetical or dramatic expression.

MOSCOW, Monday, Dec. 9.--Eighty-eight persons were killed and forty-four injured when an avalanche of ice swept down Thursday upon Kirovsk, Soviet city beyond the Arctic Circle on the Kola Peninsula, according to a communique issued here today. Kirovsk is the location of the world's largest deposits of apatite, a mineral fertilizer, and all the adult inhabitants are employed in the mining industry there.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- Within the next twenty-four hours, if possible, what must be considered as a final effort by France and Britain jointly to meet Premier Mussolini's demands in Ethiopia will be presented to Rome. It is in every sense a joint plan. This time at least there will be no French reservations; there is no difference of interpretation; there is no ambiguity.

As another major step in the city's crime prevention campaign, juvenile community centres to reduce delinquency among local boys and girls will be established soon throughout the city by the Juvenile Aid and Crime Prevention Bureau of the New York Police Department.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 8. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, title-holder, again outplayed the challenger, Dr. Max Euwe of this city, in the twenty-eighth game of their chess match for the championship of the world tonight, and held the advantage when the contest was adjourned after forty moves.

Gold stars in memory of the four New York policemen who lost their lives in the performance of duty this year were placed on the gold-star flag of the Police Honor Legion yesterday at the Shubert Theatre at memorial services honoring these men and the twenty-four other legion members who have died since the 1934 memorial.

Increased efficiency and economy of operation have placed the railroads of the United States in a position to improve their financial standing with any substantial increase in the volume of their business, according to James J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

Those who know how research is conducted and how pharmaceutical products are made will hardly agree with Mr. Palmer's objections to medical patents. Insulin is sold at a profit of only 10 per cent throughout the British Empire. If the profit were abolished entirely the product would still be too expensive for many poor diabetics.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Six young men and women students of New York State colleges and high schools cherished prizes today as a result of their participation in a contest in translating the verses of Horace, held in connection with the poet's bimillennium.

A nation-wide survey conducted by the General Foods Corporation has disclosed a widespread belief that large companies are not altogether good for the country, although they pay higher wages than do smaller companies, C.M. Chester, president of General Foods, announced yesterday.

Leaving no stone unturned in his campaign to guide the New York Giants to their second successive National Football League championship. Coach Steve Owen yesterday sent the local squad through its first Monday drill of the season at the Polo Grounds.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- The decision of the American Amateur Athletic Union to participate in the Berlin Olympics next year was reported by the German press with great satisfaction, but the papers did not reveal the closeness of the vote.

The individual seat sale for the opening night performance at the Metropolitan Opera House next Monday night was opened and closed yesterday. At the end of the day's business the inaugural presentation of "Traviata" was assured of a sold-out house. Only standing room remains and these admissions will not go on sale until the day of the performance.

The triangular business plot at the northwest corner of Fulton and Church Streets brought $76,000, or about one-third more than the city's upset price of $58,000, at an auction by the Board of Transportation yesterday. The sale was the first of a series planned to restore to the tax rolls real estate bought for subway purposes and no longer needed.

Dropping 5/8 cent an ounce here and 7-16d in London as a result of the action of the United States Treasury in lowering its bid, quotations for silver reached yesterday the lowest point since April 10 in the market here and since March 26 in Great Britain.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors approved today the so-called Sonn tract in Mount Pleasant as the site for the county's first municipal airport. It made an appropriation of $140,000 for purchase of the necessary land which becomes effective "only after a definite allotment or grant has been made by the Federal Government."

Bertha Bykow, 10 years old, a fifth-grade student at Public School 71, 188 East Seventh Street, tried to end her life by drinking poison yesterday when she learned that her father, who has been wasting away with consumption in a sanitarium, would not even be able to return home to die.

The Winter travel season will this month with movements by water and rail to exceed those of any recent year, according to a survey made by the American Express Company. Special cruises will be combined with rail movements of vacationists and travelers on their way home for the holidays.

Following the most successful season of their history, more than 100 members of the New York Power Squadron, one of the most powerful units of the United States Power Squadrons, Inc., held their annual meeting in Caruso's Restaurant last night and elected Richard P. Terhune as commander for 1936.

The rift in the Socialist party arising from the bolt of a minority left wing group from the central committee of the New York organization continued to widen yesterday as both sides were hurrying preparations for the final struggle to determine control of the party in the State and nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 4 shows a decrease for the week of $114,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $135,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, decreases of $107,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $29,000,000 in time deposits and $22,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $169,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.
Money market was dull with business confined to routine requirements. Quotations were unchanged for all classifications.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 9. -- Blue Day, A.G. Tarn's 7-year-old horse, won the fourth and feature race at Epsom Downs today in a fine field of sprinters, chalking up his third victory of the meeting.

It was commonly anticipated that the Supreme Court of the United States would decide, as it did yesterday, that the convicted kidnapper, HAUPTMANN, is not entitled to a new trial. This decision, of course, does not undertake to say whether he is actually guilty or not.

A sustained attack of cyclonic proportions paid dividends for Joseph Furlin, Middletown, N.Y., boxer, last night in the semi-finals of the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s inter-city amateur tournament before about 4,000 fans in Madison Square Garden.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Princeton's varsity, freshman and junior varsity Winter sports teams will engage in 144 contests during the coming season, according to the schedule released today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- A sharp falling off in the movement of hogs today was largely responsible for an advance of 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight in the local market, compared with Friday. Numerous leads sold at the top price of $10, or 10 cents above Friday's best level, while the day's average was up 15 cents at $9.85.
In thirty minutes yesterday afternoon a General Sessions jury convicted Nicholas (Nicky) Montana, 37 years old, ex-convict vice overlord, on a compulsory prostitution indictment.

Mrs. George F. Chandler gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Alton B. Parker, Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. Louis W. Stotesbury, Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby, Mrs. Charles C. Griswold, Mrs. Charles Rockhill, Mrs. George Brodhead and Mrs. Harold Lyford.

Mail orders were again heavy in the market here yesterday, marking what is believed to be the final rush for gift merchandise for quick delivery. Reports yesterday indicated that Christmas shopping at the week-end was heavy in practically all sections of the country.

The Census Bureau's reduction of 407,000 bales in its estimate of this year's cotton crop, issued yesterday, was about twice as much as operators had been looking for, and prices on the Cotton Exchange declined instead of advancing. Selling orders poured in from both foreign and domestic sources, carrying the list off $1 a bale and leaving closing losses of 13 to 20 points.

The Inroads which the liquor traffic, motion pictures and radio broadcasts have made on the "once highly reverenced" Sabbath were assailed in resolutions adopted yesterday, morning at the annual meeting of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States, held in the chapel of the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- New York City may dump "sludge," or chemically treated garbage that is 90 per cent water, at sea without violating the Supreme Court's 1933 order against dumping refuse off New Jersey's shores, the court unanimously decreed in an opinion by Justice Butler today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- A learned decision, mellow with the philosophy of his three-score years and ten, was handed down here today by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph Morschauser in a case having to do with paperhanging and the art of pipe-tamping.

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $100,000,000 of Federal Land Bank 3 per cent consolidated Federal farm loan bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1956, and not redeemable before Jan. 1, 1946. The bonds, which represent the first borrowing by the Land Banks since 1930 for other than refunding purposes, are priced at 98 3/4 and interest, to yield about 3.08 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Catcher Bob O'Farrell, who aided the Cardinals to win a pennant in 1926, managed the team in 1927 and who returned last year as third-string catcher, today was given his unconditional release.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9. -- Two assassins tonight shot and killed Walter Liggett, crusading publisher of The Midwest American, as the veteran newspaper man arrived at his home with his wife and daughter from a shopping tour.

Hiram C. Todd, appointed special attorney general in the Druckman case, has had wide experience as special prosecutor. A native of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., he was admitted to the bar there in 1900 after his graduation from Union College in 1897.

The threatened strike of 30,000 stagehands throughout the United States and Canada and of 5,000 studio employes on the Pacific Coast was averted yesterday by an agreement between the International Alliance of Theatre and Stagehand Employes and representatives of leading motion-picture producers and companies.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (Canadian Press). -- The keen race between Paul Thompson of the Black Hawks and Charlie Conacher of the Maple Leafs for the leadership in National Hockey League scoring swung in favor of the Chicago left wing during the past week, in which the Hawks took part in three games, while Toronto had only one contest.

Merger of the Institute of Medicine Manufacturers and the United Medicine Manufacturers, which will result in an organization with a total membership of more than three hundred producers and distributers situated in all sections of the country, was effected at a meeting of representatives of the two groups at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

RENO, Nev., Dec. 9 (AP). -- An answer and cross-complaint to the divorce suit of Arturo de Peralta-Ramos was filed here today by attorneys for Mrs. Millicent Rogers de Peralta-Ramos, daughter of the late Standard Oil officer, Henry Huddleston Rogers 2d.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- Friday's optimism on the Bourse, following the dramatic reconciliation between the Right and Left in the Chamber of Deputies has not been long lived. What happened subsequently on that day when the Left amended the bill on the armed legions in a fashion to which the Right objected had already on Saturday the effect of moderating opinion on the Bourse.

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association and fourteen of its members yesterday filed a joint complaint in the United States District Court against Local Union 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, charging conspiracy to ruin the business of the association's members in the metropolitan area.

Avery Brundage, chairman of the American Olympic Committee and new president of the Amateur Athletic Union, said here yesterday at his office that the next battle over participation would begin immediately in the campaign for funds to send the American Olympic team to Germany.

Yesterday the Supreme Court of the United States handed down a decision which, though of no vital importance in itself, involves principles which may later have a wide application. A section of the Home Loan Act was declared invalid. It was the part which authorized the taking over by the Federal authorities of building and loan associations chartered by a State.

The Manufacturers Trust Company will pay on Jan. 2 a special dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, Harvey D. Gibson, president, announced yesterday. The dividends will go to holders of stock of record of Dec. 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Rudy Vallee, tone of the stars in George White's "Scandals," was missing at the final curtain tonight at the National Theatre. Mr. Vallee, well received throughout the show, had sung a snatch from the Maine Stein Song only a few minutes before in a novelty number, after which the entire company began to file on the stage for the closing song.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Serious damage to the propelling machinery of the new cruiser Quincy developed during a trial of the equipment on Saturday at the Fore River Yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company, officials revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Eddie (Babe) Risko, middleweight champion of the world, won a close decision from his outstanding North American rival, Frankie Battaglia, tonight, but was booed by 7,000 fans at the Arena for the tactics he adopted in the non-title bout.

Berkeley Bell of Austin, Texas, seventh ranking player of the nation in 1934, joined the ranks of professional tennis stars yesterday. He signed a contract for a tour of the country next year under the auspices of Bill O'Brien, sports promoter.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9. -- Mrs. Alfred D. Bell entertained tonight with a dinner followed by contract at her villa on Sea Spray in celebration of the birthday of Sidney Homer. Other guests included Mme. Louise Homer, Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. Joel White Massie and Dr. Edmund Le Roy Dow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The texts of the two addresses delivered today in this area by President Roosevelt are given below, the first before the American Farm Bureau here, and the second at Notre Dame University, South Bend.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The election of Thomas William Montgomery of Wheeling, W. Va., as captain of the 1936 Princeton football team was announced tonight at the annual dinner to the team given by Edward D. Duffield, '92, of South Orange, N.J., and Colonel Franklin D'Olier, '98, of Morristown, N.J.

John K. Weeks, the defending champion and seeded No. 1, defeated George V. Coe of the Union League Club in straight game as the second annual Class B singles invitation squash racquets tournament got under way at the Squash Club yesterday. The event attracted forty-one entries, nine more than last year.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 9. -- As every school child knows, the imperial State of Wisconsin was dowered by nature with every conceivable treasure, responds eagerly to idealism enforced by practical politics, is owned by its people, and operated by a family dynasty, now in its second generation.

The Standard Gas Light Company, subsidiary of the Consolidated Gas Company, lost yesterday its fight against the utilities tax when Supreme Court Justice Callaban denied an application by the Standard to compel the City Tax Collector to deduct $25,854 from the city franchise tax levied against it because of payments of that sum made by the company since 1933 under the utilities levy.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 9. -- James Lephakis, proprietor of a luncheonette and ice cream parlor here, was released without bail today in Patchogue Police Court for trial next Monday night on a charge of refusing to serve three Negroes in his establishment.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The Japanese reaction to President Roosevelt's suggestion of an all-around cut in naval strengths amounting to 20 per cent if that is obtainable but otherwise to any lesser percentage is distinctly unfavorable. The Japanese reject the suggestion as quite impossible upon existing levels because it would merely prolong the ratio system, which has become intolerable to Japan.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 9. -- After spending most of the day dodging rapier thrusts from the sharp beak of an angry crane whose life they saved, Mr. and Mrs. Vitalis Himmer, offended by the lack of courtesy and appreciation shown them, are now wishing that their son, Waldo, had not been so enthusiastic about risking his life on flimsy ice to rescue the frozen bird from the lake yesterday afternoon.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9. -- The Soviet Union indicated again today its intention to resist any military incursion by Japan into Outer Mongolia. In an outspoken editorial in the Communist party newspaper Pravda, Japan was warned that any adventure in that region "may prove dangerous."

HAVANA, Dec. 9. -- President Carlos Mendieta in a manifesto to the public today reiterated the determination of his government to hold elections and emphatically asserted there would be no change in the government's policy.

The dynamic response of several stocks recently to announcements of split-ups or stock dividends is reminiscent of 1929, when the high prices of many issues made it seem desirable to increase the number of shares outstanding with a view to decreasing the selling price.

The 1,467 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $42,232,388,273 par value as of Dec. 1, had a total market value of $38,464,704,863, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Nov. l, there were 1,483 issues, aggregating $42,298,955,051 par value, which had a total market value of $38,170,537,291.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 9. -- The Lincoln Ellsworth rescue plane which left Caldwell, N.J., Saturday on the first lap of a projected 9,500-mile flight to Magallanes, Chile, crashed near Atlanta Airport early today in an attempted take-off. The pilot, Russell W. Thaw, and a mechanic, William Henry Klenke Jr., escaped injury.

A. and C. Boni report that the 2,500 boxed sets of "The Illiterate Digest," and "Letters of a Self-Made Diplomat," by Will Rogers, already are sold after less than one week on the market. A second edition of 3,000 sets is being bound.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers, Field, Glore Co. and Hayden, Stone Co. will offer today a new issue of $16,500,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 4 3/4 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1950, of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company. The bonds are priced at 101 and accrued interest from Nov. 1, 1935.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. had ordered the dismissal of Court Attendant Morris Gottlieb in Brooklyn, after fixing upon him the responsibility for the escape of two prisoners from a Brooklyn court last month.

Education of lower court judges to assure more effective enforcement of labor laws was urged by Miss Dorothy Kenyon, New York attorney, at the thirty-sixth annual meeting yesterday of the National Consumers League at Allerton House, 130 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight champion, plans a visit to the State Athletic Commission today where, it is expected, he will file a formal challenge to James J. Braddock, world titleholder.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A new national research program to be carried on with a $12,000,000 allotment from the Works Progress Administration, to collect "information essential to the factual guidance of administrative policy and action," was announced today by Corrington Gill, Assistant Administrator.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association will conduct its thirtieth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Dec. 26, 27 and 28, it was announced yesterday. As in the past, it will be held in conjunction with the conclave of the Football Coaches, the Physical Education Association, the Student Health Association and the Track Coaches Association.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 9. -- Stanford tacked the "Sold Out" sign on the Rose Bowl gates today.

ATLANTA, Dec. 9. -- Charles J. Haden, former Georgia chairman of the Federal Government's efforts to refinance farm debts, asserted here today that 40,000 Georgia farmers had been driven out of cotton planting by an estimated 30 per cent reduction in acreage since 1932.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Wine will be served at the White House this season as usual, following the practice resumed upon repeal of prohibition, despite the Anti-Saloon League's demand that the President's family set an example of total abstinence.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The text of the opening address of Norman H. Davis, chairman of the United States delegation to the naval conference that convened today, follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Irving Wexler (Waxey Gordon) of New York appealed to the Supreme Court today from the ten-year sentence for violating income tax laws imposed upon him by Judge John C. Knox in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Unofficial judgments by such groups as the Lawyers' Committee of the American Liberty League have no weight and will be utterly disregarded in administration of the Coal Conservation Act, the Bituminous Coal Commission said tonight in reply to a statement of the Lawyers' Committee that the law is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- The government lost in the Supreme Court today in its effort to end litigation over tax refund claims of more than $10,000,000 by heirs of William Waldorf Astor. The court refused to review a ruling by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals which denied a government request for an order to end the cases.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9. -- Declaring that the balancing of the budget is "the keystone of a sound recovery program," Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, presented a four-point indictment against "spending our way to prosperity" in an address here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Disorderly scenes marked the delivery of an address today by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, before an industry-labor round table conference here when spokesmen for industrial groups attempted to question the coordinator as to his program for setting up an industrial council.

The first $1,000,000 has been subscribed in the 1935 United Hospital Campaign to raise $2,000,000 to meet the financial crisis confronting the voluntary hospitals of the city, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the campaign.

The two ten-story and penthouse apartment buildings which John D. Rockefeller Jr. will build just north of Rockefeller Center will be of unusual design, it was learned yesterday when plans for the structures were filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 9. -- Against the background of a special convocation, the third in the history of Notre Dame University, over which a Cardinal of the Catholic Church presided, President Roosevelt today received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws in recognition of his achievements as President and particularly for his part in granting independence to the Philippine Islands.

CAIRO, Dec. 9. -- Although intended to quiet the situation here, the government's proclamation yesterday warning the public against demonstrations and authorizing the police to shoot hag had a contrary result.

The Columbia University Club and the City A.C. continued in their tie for the lead in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis race as a result of victories registered yesterday. Each has three triumphs without a defeat.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 9 (AP). -- Southern Methodist University, which meets Stanford in the annual Rose Bowl game at Pasadena, Calif., on New Year's Day, today was ranked as national collegiate football champion under the system originated by Dr. Frank G. Dickinson of the University of Illinois.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- To avoid the risk of a possible defeat of Premier Pierre Laval's Cabinet in the middle of the efforts to end the Ethiopian War the Senate has adjourned the debate that was to have been held tomorrow on bills dissolving the armed leagues.

Eighteen women employes of the Golden Brand Nut Products Company, confectioners, occupying the fourth and fifth floors of the building at 201 Fulton Street, near Church Street, were affected by carbon monoxide poisoning at 10:05 yesterday morning.

A large audience attended Mr. Bagby's 382d Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Mme. Eide Norena and Richard Crooks of the Metropolitan Opera, and Roman Totenberg, violinist. The accompanists were Arthur Balsam, Frank La Forge and Pierre Luboschutz.

Two inquisitive, earnest little rodents from Haiti arrived yesterday afternoon at the Bronx Zoo. They made themselves at home at once, encouraging Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the zoo, to hope that they will live considerably longer than their predecessors of twenty-five years ago, which died after a few days.

Members of the Graham Alumnae Association will hold a card party this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Lewis Mercer Borden, 40 West Seventy-fourth Street, to aid the educational work of that organization. In charge of the arrangements are:

Because of difficulty in devising new projects to provide jobs for the increased quota of WPA employes granted by Washington for this city, Victor F. Ridder, works progress administrator, requested the public yesterday to make suggestions for projects.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Striking employes of Consumers Research, Inc., filed a $500,000 libel suit against the corporation, its officers and directors in the Warren County court here this afternoon. Sheriff E.C. Tigar said that he would serve the complaint tomorrow.

The report of Governor WINSHIP of Puerto Rico for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1935, is a pro-consular document that is at least encouraging. Shortly after the close of the period covered by the report there was a celebration of the thirty-seventh anniversary of the landing of the first American troops in Puerto Rico, on the shores of Guanica Bay.
BEING in the secret pay of Santa Claus, I suppose it would be ungracious for me to forget the annual Christmas recommendations. So here goes --

Weakness was noted in gold-bloc currency quotations again yesterday as foreign exchange bankers expressed the opinion that the franc had experienced "too theatrical" a rise last week. Although keeping above the gold export point, the French currency unit lost a point and closed at 6.59 5/8 cents.

Mayor La Guardia took on some extra work yesterday afternoon after finishing his official duties at City Hall. As one of some seventy-five judges at the exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York, Mr. La Guardia paid a late afternoon call at Mezzanine Gallery No. 3, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, where the show is to be opened to the public this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- As soon as possible after the naval conference reassembles tomorrow the British will bring up their plan for a pooling of building programs in place of the old ratio system which Japan refuses to accept any longer.

Whatever exception may be taken to some of the declarations in the "platform" adopted last week by the National Association of Manufacturers, a growing number of thoughtful persons, after the experiences of the last few years, will be willing to subscribe to the following paragraph:

The plan for reorganization of the New York Athletic Club under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, as proposed by the club, was approved yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox. Two per cent interest will be paid to holders of the first mortgage bonds as of Dec. 1, with the probability that six months' arrears also will be paid.

After receiving a formal offer of a $2,000 prize for New York City's anthem, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that a conference on the anthem contest would be held at City Hall at 3 P.M. on Friday.

Fourteen bus routes in Manhattan will carry 114,806,840 passengers in their first year of operation, according to estimates presented to the Transit Commission yesterday. The figures are exclusive of traffic on the Madison and Eighth and Ninth Avenue lines now in operation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- While the British-Irish Free State-Canadian air mission was continuing conversations today with American operators and government officials to work out details for transatlantic air service, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America today was partly reorganized. Leighton W. Rogers was elected to succeed Thomas A. Morgan as president and nineteen air-mail operators withdrew membership to conform to the new air-mail act.

BASLE, Dec. 9. -- The monthly two-day meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements ended here tonight with European central bankers apparently generally hopeful that there would be no further hard monetary strain before Spring, although making, of course, the usual reservation of bankers.
May I reply to the very interesting letter from Professor D.F. Fleming, which you published in answer to an earlier one from me on mandatory neutrality?

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Apart from activity in international issues following strong week-end advices from Wall Street, the stock markets here were quiet today but generally firm, awaiting further developments in the international situation.
Among your letters to the editor on Dec. 5 there appeared one signed by Stanley Isaacs, president of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc.

Robert V. Miller, alias "Count" Victor Lustig, master counterfeiter and swindler with a record of thirty-seven arrests and no previous convictions in this country, was sentenced yesterday to twenty years in a Federal penitentiary. Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe fixed a sentence of fifteen years and a fine of $1,000 for possessing and passing counterfeit bills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Supreme Court, changing its mind for the first time this term, agreed today to pass upon a dispute over patents on radio receiving sets, which it had refused on Oct. 14 to review.

The sale of guaranteed mortgage certificates by private companies should be permitted under strict State regulation and supervision, the joint legislative committee on guaranteed real estate mortgage certificates was told yesterday at its third public hearing in the Bar Association Buliding, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The text of the opening address of Admiral Osamu Nagano, head of the Japanese delegation to the Naval Conference, follows:

With the adoption of a new code for cleaners and dyers in New Jersey, it was disclosed yesterday that rugged individualism in business had lost one of its most militant advocates, Jacob Maged, Jersey City tailor, who in the days of the NRA became a symbol of competition's last stand when he served three days in jail for cutting the NRA prices for pressing suits 5 cents.

MADRID, Dec. 9. -- The Spanish Cabinet resigned today because the Conservative Catholic party withdrew its support of Premier Joaquin Chapaprieta's 1936 budget bill and because he, in turn, flatly refused to extend the 1935 budget for three months.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, was seen in railroad circles here yesterday as the most probable successor to the late Charles H. Ewing as president of the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- A plan of reorganization of the Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., of Passaic, which has been in receivership since March 28, 1932, and in the hands of reorganization trustees since Sept. 12, 1935, was submitted today to Federal Judge Guy L. Fake by Merritt Lane, counsel to the company.

The city of Chattanooga, Tenn., will be in the market on Dec. 23 with a new issue of $677,000 of public improvement bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1935, and maturing from Dec. 1, 1940 to 1949. The bonds will carry a 4 per cent interest rate.

With gift shopping now entering its final two weeks before Christmas, reports were unanimous yesterday in retail, wholesale and jobbing circles that the total retail trade for the holiday period will easily be the best since 1930, with indications already manifest that in some sections it may eclipse the 1929 figures.

Pleading for more attention by banks to the needs of small business for credit, William H. Pouch, chairman of the industrial advisory committee of the Second Federal Reserve District, said last night that this was no time for banks or other credit sources to be "jittery" about making loans.

When the President spoke to the farmers of the country yesterday, through the American Farm Bureau Federation at Chicago, he was addressing a more satisfied audience than he would have found in the Corn Belt or the cotton country in the early days of his Administration.

There was a generally firmer tone yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, although the rubber and the metal futures were slightly lower. The turnover was moderate in most instances. On the cash markets, rye, hides and silk rose, while declines appeared in wheat, flour, butter, lard, wool-tops, tin, rubber and cocoa.

A Christmas sale of useful articles suitable for holiday gifts will be held today, tomorrow and Thursday at the Nearly New Shop, 913 Eighth Avenue. Miss Louise Edgar heads the group in charge of the sale and her aides are Mrs. Francis Robert Masters, Miss Julia E. Smith, Mrs. Peter Grimm, Mrs. Sidney E. Budd, Mrs. Henry Hopkins and Mrs. Ernest B. Davies.

A woman witness for the State in the General Sessions trial of Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, wife of the fugitive fake broker, William F. Peterson, and two men on a theft indictment, arising from Peterson's mythical "get-rich-quick" stock schemes, told Judge Nott and the jury yesterday how she lost $101,499.45 to Peterson in eight months.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Replying aggressively to critics of the administration's agricultural program, President Roosevelt in an address here today forecast further Federal regulation to make permanent "a more stable economic life" by perpetuating a "fair balance" between industry, agriculture and the other producing factors of the nation.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 (AP). -- Motor Products Corporation, manufacturers of automobile parts and fittings, declared a 100 per cent stock dividend today payable on Feb. 1 to stockholders of record of Dec. 20.
The Dieppe Corporation, operators of the Central Park Casino restaurant, filed a petition in Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP). -- In two emphatic opinions the Supreme Court today gave to Congress and the administration new warnings against encroachment on rights reserved to the States by the Constitution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Wheat traders who had been anticipating a higher level of prices as the result of Broomhall's unexpected small estimate on the Argentine exportable surplus from the new crop were greatly disappointed by the action of today's market.
John Barrymore will appear as Mercutio in Metro's film of "Romeo and Juliet." The title roles will be played by Leslie Howard and Norma Shearer. It will be directed by George Cukor.

Trade news over the week-end, the more conciliatory attitude being adopted generally with respect to the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, President Roosevelt's address to the American Farm Bureau Federation convention in Chicago, the hasty adjournment of the opening session of the Industrial Conference in Washington, the Supreme Court's decisions, and announcements of several favorable dividend actions, failed yesterday to invest the stock market with much spirit.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- The Boerse was almost entirely inactive today, with scattered signs of weakness as traders continued slowly to liquidate their small holdings. Most of the usual public was absent from the Exchange, and few quotations were made.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- A code of regulations for the cleaning and dyeing trade governing minimum prices for staple services, graded minimum wages, maximum working hours and working conditions in the more than 4,500 plants and retail outlets in this State was adopted today by the State Cleaning and Dyeing Board.

Paul Mooney, Columbia coach, thinks that last Sunday's basketball clinic of coaches and officials at the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A. will have far-reaching effects on intercollegiate basketball conditions in the East, for three particular reasons:

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The formal opening this morning of the five-power conference which hopes to supersede the treaties of Washington and London with a new agreement for the limitation of naval armaments provided three outstanding features.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The 1935 cotton crop was estimated at 10,734,000 bales by the Department of Agriculture today in its final forecast for the year. The revised figure was 407,000 bales, or 3.7 per cent below the estimate of Nov. 1, and was 1,098,000 bales larger than the actual crop of 1934.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Informed tonight that part of the "mystery deal" closed between the Giants and the Cardinals three weeks ago had leaked out of St. Louis, Horace Stoneham, representing his father at the major league meetings here, confirmed the transaction in full.

Hiram C. Todd will investigate, as special prosecutor, the murder last March 3 of Samuel Druckman, Brooklyn garage worker, and the charges of bribery that have been made, in consequence of that crime, against members of the Police Department and, presumably, of the District Attorney's staff in Kings County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A dramatic identification by James W. Ives, former Olympic Games champion, of a court-room spectator as the man who tried to get him to drop the prosecution of Representative John H. Hoeppel of California and his son, Charles J. Hoeppel, on charges of conspiracy to solicit a bribe, featured the opening today of their trial in the District Supreme Court.

Having written two dynamic dramas, Clifford Odets is entitled to his Chekhov interlude, "Paradise Lost," which the Group Theatre put on at the Longacre last evening. For Mr. Odets has discovered that the contemporary middle class in America faces the same blank wall that stood before the futilitarians whom Chekhov was describing at the beginning of the century, and he has consciously aped the centrifugal Chekhov technique.

Harold Samuel, who is a unique interpreter of Bach, gave his one New York recital of the season last night in Town Hall. His performances were superlatively in the vein, and this fact tinged the pleasure in his performance with regret the keener, that he is to be heard here no more this Winter.

MANILA, Dec. 9. -- Efforts of the Filipinos to raise funds for the Quezon-MacArthur defense program, which would require 16,000,000 pesos annually, resulted today in the introduction of a bill by Assemblyman Agaton Yaranon for an increase in income taxes that would be retroactive to 1920.
Birth control advocates replied yesterday to the criticism voiced by Cardinal Hayes in St. Patrick's Cathedral Sunday morning.

PEIPING, Dec. 9. -- While Chinese leaders here continued conferences today to settle problems of the new autonomous regime projected in Hopei and Chahar Provinces, more than 2,000 students staged anti-Japanese demonstrations in which they demanded immediate military mobilization for war on Japan.

Clicking off points with a finesse that amazed a capacity gallery of 600 persons in the Roof Garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, the veteran Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland won his opening match in the world pocket billiards championship, defeating Marcel Camp of Detroit.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Reports from all parts of Germany indicate the secret police are carrying on nationwide raids in Catholic diocesan offices and in headquarters of Catholic institutions. Two more vicars general of Catholic dioceses have been arrested.

HELSINGFORS, Dec. 9. -- An attempted military coup to upset the dictatorial regime of the Estonian Republic, disclosed with dramatic suddenness early yesterday, has resulted in the arrest of fourteen of the chief Opposition leaders and about eighty other persons, according to today's reports.

Frank A. Sieverman Jr. of the New York Athletic Club went into the quarter-final round, one bracket ahead of the field, yesterday when he defeated Lawrence H. Sonneborn of the Yale Club, in the National Association December squash tennis scratch tournament. The score was 15 -- 7, 17 -- 14. The tourney is being held at the N.Y.A.C.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 9 (AP). --Fourteen Virginia and West Virginia bituminous coal producers asked Federal District Judge John Paul today to restrain the Federal Government from collecting taxes under the Guffey act pending a determination of the measure's constitutionality.

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- Fifteen up-State Republican leaders met State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton at a luncheon today and discussed proposals which will be whipped into shape by a committee for a larger gathering of the party here on Dec. 18.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The text of the speech of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin of Great Britain, opening the naval conference today, follows:

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 9. -- A sensational 67, four under par, gave Alvin Krueger of Beloit, Wis., the lead in the first round of the $2,000 Sarasota open golf tournament today as low scoring featured the play.

Cleto Locatelli, Italian welterweight, outpunched Izzy Jannazzo to win the decision in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. While a capacity crowd of more than 4,000 looked on, the rivals waged a vicious battle.

The General Electric Company will continue after Dec. 31 its pension plan for all employes on the payroll at that time who now are participants in the additional pension plan, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. The company has operated a pension plan since 1912, and since 1928 it has been on a contributory basis, known as the "additional" pension plan.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Heinrich Sahm resigned today his office of Oberburgermeister (Chief Mayor) of Berlin. A National Socialist party court recently expelled him from the party for buying from Jewish firms, but he was reinstated by Fuehrer Adolf Hitler.

Debutantes of this season, headed by Miss Lucy G. Hutchinson, are aiding the annual Christmas Seal Campaign in behalf of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, now in progress, which will continue until Christmas Day. Thomas W. Lamont is treasurer of the association, which was founded to fight tuberculosis and other communicable diseases.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 9. -- Although neither Chinese nor Japanese express optimism over the effectiveness or duration of the new autonomy arrangement in Hopei and Chahar Provinces, Chinese Government quarters anticipate a brief breathing spell, for they believe serious Japanese pressure will not be renewed until after the London naval conference.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

In spite of the acres of blue-prints Director CLAS talks about, and his vigorous efforts to translate them into brick and stone, it is now widely admitted that the Federal housing program, as administered through the PWA, has largely failed to accomplish its objectives. "

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The report from Paris that Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare of Britain and Premier Pierre Laval of France had agreed on terms for a settlement of the Ethiopian war whereby Italy would receive 150,000 square miles of Ethiopian territory will be followed by an uproar of protests in the British Parliament tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- President Roosevelt indicated today his personal interest in plans to rescue Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon from Antarctica, the State Department said in making known that the department had been active in aiding rescue efforts.

GENEVA, Dec. 9. -- The Council of the League of Nations was called today to meet Dec. 17. The only question on the agenda is the one of settling Assyrian refugees in Iraq and League officials deny the move has any connection with the Ethiopian war.

The Toronto Maple Leafs will meet the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The spangled sextet, off to a shaky start, has improved considerably of late and has picked up 5 points out of a possible 6 in its last three games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- In the new Supreme Court Building, the New Deal farm program went on trial today as arguments opened in the Hoosac Mills case involving the validity of the processing taxes levied by the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the constitutionality of the entire measure.

There must be many among those in need, for whom help is asked at this season, in whose behalf no such appeal would have had to be made in days gone by. In normal times when the bread-winner of a family dies, or is incapacitated, relatives or friends will rally to the aid of those among the survivors who are incapable of self-support.
In association with Lee Ephraim, the Theatre Guild's fourth New York production of this season will be "Call It a Day," by Dodie Smith, with Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper in the leading roles.

Mrs. OSSIE DRIMMER, 24, of Los Angeles, had lived only two months in the United States and, as the event showed, did not like it. But the manner of her departure from this country was so thoroughly American that it deserved to make the first page of the newspapers last Sunday, as it did.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 9. -- All the once-famous White Star liners, including the Majestic, will be retired from the Cunard White Star's express transatlantic service next Spring if a provisional schedule issued tonight is adhered to.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- Expectation that Premier Benito Mussolini will accept the basis for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict prepared yesterday by Premier Pierre Laval and Sir Samuel Hoare is general in France. Indeed it is currently believed that a good deal of what Sir Samuel agreed to had been already arranged between Mr. Laval and the Italian Ambassador, Vittorio Cerruti.
