Proposals for the construction of the Weehawken land sections and plaza of the new Midtown Hudson Tunnel will be received by the Port of New York Authority Dec. 19, as part of the program to bring the project to completion within two years.

The man in whose ancestral home, Hoghton Tower, near Preston, Lancashire, England, the loin of beef was dubbed "Sir Loin" by King James I in 1611, arrived yesterday on the Anchor liner Caledonia on his way to join a freighter, he owns, the Cape York, at San Pedro for a voyage to the Southern Seas that will last till April, 1936.

OTTAWA, Dec. 9. -- A dominion provincial conference, ranked as the most important administrative gathering since Canada's confederation in 1867, convened in the Parliament buildings here today to deal with the connected problems of unemployment, debt taxation and constitutional revision.

A girl and a young man, living at 62 South Portland Avenue, Brooklyn, confessed yesterday they had committed more than thirty robberies in Brooklyn and Queens within a year, according to police. The girl, Anna Stenzel, 18 years old, who had been missing from her home at 70-28 Seventy-third Street, Glendale, Queens, since last December, told the police she had acted as a decoy for her companion, Joseph Lecce, 22.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 9. -- The Long Island Golf Association decided during its annual meeting held at the Garden City Hotel today to go ahead with its program in 1936 regardless of the ultimatum delivered by the Long Island P.G.A.

A net income of $188,500 was earned in November by the New York Central Railroad, according to an estimate filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. Gross revenues were estimated at $25,880,200. The figures would indicate a net loss of about $4,500,000 for 1935, against a net loss of $7,682,334 in 1934.

Surprised while ransacking an apartment at 542 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, a youthful burglar became so frightened early last night that he grasped a chandelier, swung himself into the air and vaulted through an open window to a court about twenty feet below.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Dec. 9. -- The first court case in a drive instituted recently by the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce to keep student fliers from carrying passengers resulted here today in the conviction of Walter Campbell of Merrick Road, Wantagh, L.I., on a charge of violating the State Business Law.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- State milk-control boards should discontinue price fixing and act merely as "umpires" for the industry, Arthur M. Woodward of Trenton told milk-control executives of fourteen States and Canada at a conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Formal supervision of activities on the over-the-counter market by the Securities and Exchange Commission, will begin on Jan. 1, when it is probable that the registration of about 5,000 brokers and dealers will become effective.

My compliments to the writer of the item "Classicists Celebrate" on the first page of the editorial section of THE TIMES today for calling attention to the fact that if the Latin poet Horace was born Dec. 8, 65 B.C., this is the 1,999th anniversary of his birth, not the 2,000th.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, pioneer suffrage leader who will be 77 years old on Jan. 9, announced at her home here today her choice of the ten outstanding women of the country for 1935.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 9. -- Playing an uphill game and constantly nullifying the best efforts of his determined opponent, Dr. Max Euwe of this city was successful tonight in drawing the twenty-eighth game of the series with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in their match for the chess championship of the world.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The respect of Joel Louis for his opponent, Paulino Uzcudun, next Friday night in Madison Square Garden is indicated by his unusually complete preparation. Louis thus far has been witnessed in fifty-two rounds of boxing since starting serious training on Dec. 1.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- Miss Alice Marlman's brown gelding Oican won the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds today, defeating Vesee and Wilco, which finished behind the leader in that order. Chortle, the favorite, came in sixth.

Now that the general upland game season is over in this State, with the exception of Long Island, many New York sportsmen are making flying trips to Maryland, where grouse, quail and pheasants may be hunted until Dec. 31.

A $5,000 gift to the Neediest Cases Fund from "A Friend," who gave the same amount last year, removed seven cases from the list of the Neediest yesterday and was sufficient to help materially five other cases of those in greatest distress in all New York.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9. -- Expenditure of $7,700 for new furniture and draperies for the "little white house," the Sea Girt Summer home of New Jersey's Governors, was suggested by Mrs. Harold G. Hoffman, wife of the present Chief Executive of the State, the Budget Advisory Committee was told today by Quartermaster General Stephen H. Barlow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann's plea for a review of the trial as a result of which he was sentenced to die for the kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby was refused by the Supreme Court today in one unexplained typewritten line.

Sales of cars of the General Motors Corporation last month were the largest for a November since the corporation was founded, it was announced yesterday. Three times as many cars were sold by the corporation to its dealers as were sold in November, 1934, while twice as many cars were sold by the dealers to consumers as the year before.

The central tower of Lincoln Cathedral, the highest in the country and perhaps the most beautiful in the world, has stood for centuries as a monument of religion, devotion and architectural skill. Today, through the munificient aid of your fellow-countrymen, it has renewed its strength and it stands also as a symbol of that spiritual unity of the Anglo-Saxon race on which in my humble judgment the future welfare of the world depends.

NOT so long after the turn of the century, about the time the Cotton Palace came to Waco and the Great Emancipator was established first in the thoughts of the nation's tender youth as the figurehead on the copper coin of the realm, a barefoot boy found himself on the gridiron of Baylor University and came down with a hopeless case of kick-and-buck fever.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 10. -- The newspaper El Mercurio in an editorial today declares that Argentina, in her foreign policy, is systematically endeavoring to block the intensification of trade between Chile and Peru, thereby creating an atmosphere of distrust among the Latin-American republics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- When the weather is hot human beings are more prone to commit murder and other crimes of violence. J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Division of Investigation of the Department of Justice, declared in a report on crime conditions made public today.

John Collins, 26 years old, awaiting a death sentence in the Queens County jail, obtained a marriage license yesterday from Deputy County Clerk William Zimmerman, to marry Miss Anna Downey, 18, of 227 East Thirty-third Street, Manhattan.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Ex-Druggst," in a recent letter to THE TIMES, complained that he was unable to obtain calamus root at thirtyeight drug stores in Brooklyn.

The withdrawal of union longshoremen from Atlantic and Pacific Coast ships operated by ship lines which refused to meet the terms of the International Longshoremen's Association at Gulf ports was ended yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the longshoremen's association.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- A breathing spell in internal politics and hopes aroused by the Ethiopian peace plan permitted tho Bourse to recover somewhat today. The Senate's action in deferring discussion of the League's stand will permit Premier Pierre Laval to go to Geneva and allow the forces for moderation to act in the meantime, it is held here.

TRENTON, Dec. 10. -- Quartermaster General Stephen H. Barlow of the New Jersey National Guard assumed today full responsibility for the expenditure of nearly $7,500 this year in refurnishing the "Little White House" at Sea Girt, the State's Summer Executive mansion.

The basketball season a year ago ended just five seconds too late for Paul Mooney. His Columbia quintet had the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League won until Captain Bob Freeman of Penn hit the cords with a prodigious heave from beyond midcourt just before the end of the play-off game.
Housing properties made up the bulk of the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

America's currency devaluation process, coupled with our reciprocal treaty program, has placed the products of this country on the bargain counters of international trade in an idealistic endeavor to save the world, Captain F.X.A. Eble, managing director of the American Match Institute, declared here last night.

Aid for the Neediest is aid for those who most require it. It is food for the hungry, clothes for the ragged, warmth for the cold, hope for the hopeless. It is succor for those unfortunates whom government aid cannot effectively help; it is private charity at its best.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Legal technicalities whose nature was not made public halted an inquiry today into the connection of George Trinistach, George Washington University football player, with the case of Representative John H. Hoeppel of California, who, with his son, Charles J. Hoeppel, is on trial in the District of Columbia Supreme Court on charges of conspiracy to solicit a bribe.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The constitutionality of the Resettlement Administration, of which Rexford Guy Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, is administrator was attacked in a suit filed in Federal court here today by Merritt Lane, counsel for the Township of Franklin in Somerset County, N.J., and four property owners of that township, seeking to halt the "Bound Brook project" under the Resettlement Administration.

Thirteen men and women who have devoted much of their lives to the perfection and appreciation of the spoken word made five-minute talks last night at the fifteenth anniversary dinner of the National Association for American Speech at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A meeting to consider a strike against the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company will be held this evening by the Queens local of the Brotherhood of Utility Employes at its headquarters, 40-11 Main St., Flushing.

No gold was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here and the foreign exchange market was quiet, with the franc up 1/8 point at 6.59 3/4 cents and the pound sterling unchanged at $4.93. Receipts of gold totaling $18,495,900 were reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, however.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The desire of Mrs. Garnet McCabe to return to New York County from Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane to stand trial for the murder of her husband, Evert McCabe, vice president of the United Parcel Service, was granted in a decision today by Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Sixteen more offering sheets of various oil interests were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission during the week ended Dec. 7. The list follows:

The Central Savings Bank, plaintiff in six foreclosure actions against the Louis J. Ehret Holding Corporation, bid in the six parcels of realty at an auction yesterday conducted by Thomas F. Burchill.
Rudy Vallee will not appear in George White's "Scandals" in New York, Mr. White informed THE NEW YORK TIMES last night by telephone from Washington.

A survey by the Iron and Steel Institute shows that nine out of every ten high executives of leading steel companies started at "the bottom of the ladder" and worked their way up, it was announced yesterday.

A "Title Sweepstakes" in which prizes will be awarded in connection with a fine arts exhibit was announced yesterday by the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus from their headquarters at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- As a result of requests by several issuers, the Securities and Exchange Commission has amended its rules so that a statement which must be published on the front page of prospectuses offering for sale securities registered under the Securities Act of 1935 now reads as follows:
" Your Uncle Dudley," with Edward Everett Horton, Alan Dinehart and Marjorie Gateson, starts a week's run this morning at the Center Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The PWA now is expected to ignore the Dec. 15 "deadline" for completing all heavy construction work relief contracts, a spokesman indicated today. He remarked that "we won't have any figures on contracts until a week or two after that date."

" The first edition" of the Bible "designed solely for pleasurable reading" is being issued this month by the Limited Editions Club to members. The club directors say that the finest prose of the English language is to be found in the King James Version, and that it should be read for pleasure.

The British Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs referred in Paris yesterday to the "wild rumors" about the peace terms to be offered to Italy. He declared that most of them were "positively absurd." What the exact proposals are we shall not know until they are published, but both in London and in Geneva reports and alleged "leaks" concerning them produced something like a furor.

The name of Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, was added to the list of contributors to the Will Rogers Memorial Fund yesterday, it was announced at the campaign headquarters. Secretary Roper's check for $25 was sent from his office in Washington.

Governor Lehman yesterday afternoon named Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers, Hudson Falls Republican, to preside over a special term in Brooklyn starting Jan. 6 in an investigation into the murder of Samuel Druckman, who was beaten and strangled the night of March 3, last, in a garage at 225 Moore Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Final touches were put on the budget estimates of the Government's "ordinary" expenditures for the next fiscal year, it was believed, at a conference at the White House today between President Roosevelt and the acting budget director, D. W. Bell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Silence greeted all questions at the Treasury today relative to the government's silver policy, as a result of the silver collapse, but nevertheless some experts expressed the belief that the United States had decided to do some "horse trading" in buying the metal rather than to buy it at any price fixed in the international market.

A toast to the President of the United States, proposed last night at the "Better Light -- Better Sight" dinner at the Biltmore by the toastmaster, Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey and of the Edison Electric Institute, was greeted with general laughter by the audience of 500 executives of the electrical and optical industries who attended the dinner.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- A plan to install 40,000 additional seats in the Municipal Stadium in South Philadelphia and have the ArmyNavy football game played there next year was announced today by Mayor-elect S. Davis Wilson. The total seating capacity of the stadium, he said, would be brought to 120,000, or 40,000 more than Franklin Field, scene of this year's game.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Baseball men today figured that Tom Yawkey had spent more than $3,500,000 since 1932 when he purchased the Boston Red Sox. Reputedly a multimillionaire, most of his wealth inherited from his foster father, Yawkey, unofficial but reliable records show, spent huge sums as follows:

Four hundred and twenty-two contributors -- the greatest number so far in any one day to the 1935 appeal for the Neediest of all New York -- sent their gifts yesterday to help care for those who are more than unemployed and who receive no help from public relief agencies.

By unanimous vote of the sixtythree Aldermen present, the Board of Aldermen adopted an amendment to the Code of Ordinances yesterday requiring that an American flag at least thirty-six by fortyeight inches must be displayed at all public gatherings where political or public questions are discussed.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- The acceptance by the British Cabinet of the HoareLaval plan as a basis for negotiations has inspired the French Government with confidence that the Ethiopian conflict is nearing a solution. It is even being forecast here in official circles that a settlement will now be possible without any further recourse to Geneva sanctions.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 11. -Ice forming on the wings of a Belgian air liner as it neared Croydon air field at dusk yesterday was believed to have thrown it into a headlong dive into a garden in which its eleven occupants, seven passengers and a crew of four, were instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Apparently determined to maintain its final plan of railroad consolidation intact, the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today as "prima facie impracticable" a stockholders' plan for reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway, which involved consolidation of that road with the St. Louis-San Francisco and the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railways.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 10. -- The Ethiopian Government asserted today that the Italians were retreating from their main front lines in the Makale region following successes by the defenders, who had cut the invaders' communications.
BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The number of registered unemployed in Germany increased by 156,000 in November and now totals 1,985,000, it was announced today.

Directors of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association (California), which is 99.64 per cent owned by the Transamerica Corporation, declared yesterday an extra dividend of $1,000,000 in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $1,250,000.

A photograph widely used in the recent national drive for safer motoring won first prize in the spot news division of tho photograph exhibition of the Press Photographers Association, which was opened to the public yesterday in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

No longer does any team hold terror for the New York Americans, not even the vaunted Toronto Maple Leafs. Last night at Madison Square Garden Red Dutton's surprising stick-wielders handled the sextet from the North with apparent ease, defeating it by 4 to 2, to the complete satisfaction of a crowd of 10,000.

Members of fraternities at Columbia College have attained, for the first time on record, a scholastic average higher than the general college average, it was announced yesterday. The report was based on the academic records for 1934-35.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Another group of reports filed as confidential by corporations, which the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today after deciding that no harm would be done the issuer and that the public was entiled to the information, showed few that paid compensation in the last fiscal year in excess of $50,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is gratifying to read that Senator Wagner has at last boiled the housing problem down to its fundamental issues. No housing on a large scale is going to be successful until we come to grips with three basic points and decide whether we are for or against them. They are:

Both Wall Street and Washington are attaching great importance to the hearings scheduled for today before the Securities and Exchange Commission in the capital of the charges against Michael J. Meehan, a member of the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, of violation of the anti-manipulative section of the Securities Exchange Act.

A marked increase last week in children's diseases for which statistics are kept was reported yesterday by the Health Department. Diphtheria cases rose to a weekly high for the year of 45. Three deaths from this disease were reported.

ALBANY, Dec. 1O. -- Seasonal declines in industry from the middle of October to the middle of November decreased the number of factory employes in the State 1 per cent and pushed payrolls down 2.7 per cent, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- While labor groups were meeting today and naming representatives to sit in the industrial council proposed by Major George L. Berry, Coordinator for Industrial Cooperation, some of the industry groups met again and divided as they did yesterday, with one wing favoring cooperation and the other opposing further action under the coordinator's auspices.

New York University's football team will open its season next Fall against Ohio State University, it was announced yesterday by the Violet's board of athletic control through Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. The contest will be played on Oct. 3 in Columbus, Ohio.

There was a meeting of the Republican State Central Committee of Iowa in Des Moines. At first everything went happily and hopefully. Former Representative MACLAFFERTY of California, representative of the Republican National Committee, blew through the war trumpet a note, a keynote, of high resolve and valor.

Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott of Brooklyn issued a warning yesterday against the sending of liquor through the mails. Persons who wrap-up bottles of wine and whisky for Christmas presents and seek to have them delivered by the United States Post Office are liable to a $1,000 fine, two years in prison or both, he pointed out.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 10. -- New Hampshire, Republican in Presidential elections since the Civil War except in 1912 and 1916, gives every indication of electing Republican Presidential electors next year.

The Gdynia-America liner Pilsudski arrived yesterday at her Hoboken pier a day behind schedule, as the result of severe Atlantic storms. Captain Eustazy Borkowski, master of the ship in place of Captain Mamert Stankiewicz, who is on vacation, said that the storm had reached hurricane force on several occasions and that he was on the bridge virtually without sleep for three days and two nights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Final technical and regulatory details for the proposed transatlantic air mail service to be started jointly next Spring by Pan-American Airways and Imperial Airways were worked out today with the hope that "a perfectly harmonious" report can be made to the Inter-Department Committee on Civil International Aviation tomorrow, when the British, Irish Free State and Canadian missions expect to complete their work.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Dec. 10. -Three members of the Army Air Corps at France Field are missing, believed drowned in the crash of a bomber twelve miles from Colon last night. Two others, Lieutenant John A. Samford and Private Ronald Dufor, after struggling all night long in shark-infested waters managed to reach Rogage Key at daybreak and were rescued.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 10 (AP). -A. B. Chandler, 37-year-old veteran of some of Kentucky's bitterest political wars, became Chief Executive of the Commonwealth today amid the cheers of thousands.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel upheld yesterday the right of the Board of Education to ignore the Municipal Civil Service Commission in continuing Dr. Morris O'Shea, son of William J. O'Shea, former Superintendent of Schools, and Drs. Louis L. Shapiro and Emeline P. Hayward under provisional appointments as school medical inspectors.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10. -Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow was host to members of the Men's Tuesday Club today for luncheon and cards at Casa Pequena. Attending were Bernard Henry Kroger, Frank B. McQuesten, William Theodore Hoops, Homer E. Sawyer, Nathan D. Bill and Ward Ames.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- A redistribution of national income either through increased per capita consumption and higher living standards or by heavy public expenditures for farm and unemployment relief is inevitable, Secretary Wallace said today in his annual report.

CAIRO, Dec. 10. -- Unless there is a change in the British Foreign Office policy regarding Egypt's return to the 1923 Constitution before 10 o'clock tomorrow morning, the Egyptian Cabinet will resign.
Among those sailing tonight for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam on the Holiand-American liner Volendam are:
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 10 (AP). -William Randolph Hearst sized up Governor Alf M. Landon today and hailed him as a man who could rout the Roosevelt forces in 1936.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- There will not be the slightest sign of compromise in the explanations of the "common upper limit" which the Japanese will submit to the naval conference tomorrow, but details will be lacking.

Further evidence of the widespread interest in property close to the site of the proposed World's Fair in the Flushing meadows was given yesterday in the announcement by officials of the Arrowbrook Golf and Country Club that their 108-acre property had been placed on the market.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 10. -President Alfonso Lopez called attention to the necessity of settling the problem of Colombia's foreign debts in a speech here yesterday to a conference of Governors called to study the question of States' rights and organization under the proposed new Constitution.

William Boyle, 48 years old, of 869 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, a former clerk in the Department of Health, was held yesterday for the Queens grand jury in $1,000 bail on charges of grand larceny in Rockaway Beach court, Queens, by Magistrate Giorgio.
Mayor La Guardia hinted yesterday that banks might see the wisdom of cutting their interest rates on mortgages to 4 per cent if they faced the alternative of a city tax on banks.

Many women interested in the work of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association attended the luncheon and fashion show yesterday in the Louis XVI Restaurant of the Park Lane for the benefit of that organization. Debutantes acting as manikins were the Misses Charmion Kineon, Ruth Mary Ruxton, Rosalyn Crosby, Barbara Hoge and Beatrice Kunhardt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are indications that the automobile buying public may be in the mood to consider other advantages in lieu of high speed. The decrease in motor car advertising of emphasis on speed since the wide publication of "Sudden Death" suggests that manufacturers already recognize a change in attitude.

A new record for forward passing efficiency was set by Ed Danowski, back field star of the New York Giants, during the past season, according to the final individual statistics of the National Football League, released yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- Union dock workers in New York City obtained a decision in the Court of Appeals today when the high court affirmed the removal of an injunction against them and fifty-six steamship companies by the New York Lumber Trade Association.
DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP). -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today that the incomes of automotive workers in 1935 will be at least 30 per cent higher than in 1934.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Bringing to a dramatic halt the second day of argument in the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the Bankhead Cotton Control Law, Solicitor General Stanley Reed faltered this afternoon and sat down, physically unable to continue.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Faced with the alternatives of repudiating either its Foreign Secretary, Sir Samuel Hoare, or its pre-election pledges concerning the League of Nations and the Ethiopian War, the British Government has evidently chosen the latter course as the simpler way out of the worst international snarl any Cabinet has been entangled in for a long time.
U. S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Three debutantes were honored at luncheons yesterday. Mrs. Robert Hawthorne Wylie gave one at the Pierre for Miss Winnie V. Wylie, her debutante daughter, and Miss Frances Murdock, debutante niece of Mrs. Alonzo Potter. Mrs. Wilber Bloodgood entertained in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Cariton for Miss Le Brun Cruger Rhinelander, debutante daughter of Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander.

GENEVA, Dec. 10. -- The Ethiopian peace offer made to Premier Mussolini of Italy by Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare of Great Britain and Premier Laval of France created an extremely bad impression in League of Nations circles, arousing a mixture of indignation, bewilderment and gloomy speculation.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- For the first time since the early days of the World War, when a moratorium was declared, no price for silver was fixed today in the London market.
W. F. G. Swann, director of the Bartol Scientific Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute, will talk on "Music as an Avocation" this afternoon at the Hotel Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Former Vice President Curtis will return to active politics as chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- Well-informed Catholic spokesmen here report that the Italian Government is negotiating with the Vatican and with German Catholic Bishops to have the Peter's pence, collected in Germany during the last Holy Year, turned over to Premier Benito Mussolini's agents as a war loan.

MANILA, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Roy W. Howard, chairman of the board of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, said today there was "evidence aplenty" that the Philippine Republic would "never materialize." He predicted that Congress would be asked to make the present Commonwealth form of government permanent "on a territorial basis."

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- On "Friday the thirteenth" the First National Bank of Chicago will announce formally its return to a dividend basis for the first time since the close of 1932, it has become known. At the same time arrangements will be completed for retirement of $10,000,000 of the $25,000,000 of preferred stock held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

PEIPING, Dec. 10. -- A Japanese spokesman today characterized yesterday's student demonstrations against Japan as part Communist and part Kuomintang (Nationalist party) in source. He announced that he had received a satisfactory reply to a formal protest to the Peiping authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Lord Moyniham, noted surgeon, presided at the first public meeting tonight of the Voluntary Euthanasia (easy death legislation) Society which is proposing to introduce a bill into Parliament on the following lines:

For the first time since he assumed his post as Works Progress Administrator for this city, Victor F. Ridder struck yesterday at what he termed "fly-by-night" organizations that devote themselves to constant criticism of the administration of relief and to stirring up trouble and discontent among the unemployed and relief clients.

W. B. Eddy, of the Rochester Germicide Company, Rochester, N. Y., was elected president of the National Association of Insecticide and Disinfectant Manufacturers at the closing session yesterday of the association's twenty-second annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TWICKENHAM, England, Dec. 10. -- Oxford and Cambridge battled to a scoreless draw in the annual university Rugby classic before 40,000 spectators today. The game, a grim struggle between two wellbalanced teams, was played in cold, windy weather.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Colonel Leonard P. Ayres business stattistician and vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today that 1935 had been "by far the best of the three recovery years of the depression" and predicted "modest progress" along the recovery trail for 1936.

Efforts to strengthen their hold upon the party organization in this city were being made yesterday by both warring factions in the Socialist party as various branches in the Assembly districts reported their stand in the situation.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10. -- Peace was restored to Pacific Coast waterfronts at 6 o'clock last night when the International Longshoremen's Association removed its forty-day boycott on so-called Gulf hot cargo, coincident with ending of the two months' longshoremen's strike at Gulf ports.

Although a generous gift from an anonymous "Friend," reported yesterday, removed seven cases from the list of the Neediest and helped materially five others, the total amount of contributions this year has fallen somewhat behind that of last year for the same day. It is gratifying to note, however, that the number of contributors is greater.

Postmaster Albert Goldman, as chairman of the Federal employees division in this area, urged the cooperation of his associates with the United Hospital Campaign Committee at a luncheon yesterday of members of this group at the Bankers Club.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Handel's "Messiah," composed in 1741 and generally recognized as one of the world's finest oratorios, cannot be sung in the auditorium of Washington Junior High School by the Mount Vernon Choral Society because the Board of Education regards it as "sectarian."

Affiliation of the Mail Order Association of America with the American Retail Federation was announced yesterday by Colonel C. O. Sherrill, president of the federation, following a meeting of that organization at the Hotel New Yorker.

George Kelly of Philadelphia, national titleholder now seeking the world's professional pocket billiard championship, came through his first-round match in grand style yesterday afternoon, staving off a late rally by Joe Procita of Gloversville, N.Y., to win by the score of 125 to 99, in the Roof Garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- Three amendments to the State Constitution passed at the November election, were officially canvassed today at a meeting of the State Board of Canvassers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- A solution to the manifold problems of the financially, harassed Boston Braves and confirmation of two player transactions suspected of having been completed some time ago and reputed to involve rather fabulous sums stood out at the close of the first sessions of the two major league conclaves today.

Having recaptured the Assembly, the Republicans are preparing to take their modest place in the sun again at Albany. Their leaders are already busy with the agenda for a meeting to be held next week, at which the party program will be announced in advance, in an attempt to steal some of Governor LEHMAN'S thunder.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Final subscription and allotment figures were issued today on the Treasury's offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds of 1945-47 and of 1 1/2 per cent notes of 1940.

Dick Merrill, crack pilot for the Eastern Air Lines, has been engaged to pilot the new Northrop Gamma monoplane which has been chartered to fly to the rescue of Lincoln Ellsworth, lost in Antarctica since Nov. 23, it was announced here yesterday by Commander Frank M. Hawks, speed flier, through whom the rescue plane has been obtained from the Texas Company.

PARIS, Dec. 10. -- In accordance with a decision of the Cabinet, Finance Minister Marcel Regnier today asked the French Parliament to adopt a special procedure to get the budget voted before the new year.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet again today pending developments in the peace negotiations, although the market was fairly cheerful. British funds became firmer after early dullness. Among the foreign bonds uncertainty prevailed regarding the German list owing to the statements by Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Finance, regarding the debt payments.

The famous Arlberg skiing technique was introduced for what was said to be the first time in the United States yesterday when Otto Lang, first assistant instructor at the Hannes Schneider School on the Arlberg at St. Anton, Austria, opened his ski school at B. Altman Co.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP). -Unless a larger share of the benefits of industry is given to the workingman, he is likely to take radical steps to obtain such a share, the Most Rev. John A. Dully, Bishop of Syracuse, said in the opening session of a two-day Catholic industrial conference here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP). -- Declaring that college football is a major "racket," Professor George Owen Sr. of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today advocated the hiring of star athletes on a day laborer's basis.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Chester C. Davis, Administrator of the AAA, declared here today that if the Supreme Court holds the Farm Adjustment Act unconstitutional Congress can enact new legislation to carry on the New Deal farm program in conformity with the holdings of the court.

ROME, Dec. 10. -- The AngloFrench proposals for a solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, which it had been expected would be submitted to Premier Benito Mussolini today, have not yet been received in Rome. No communication about them had arrived at a late hour tonight from the Italian Embassy in London or Paris, nor had either the French or the British Ambassador to Rome asked to be received by Mussolini tomorrow.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well above the preceding week. However, the total was less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

HAVANA, Wednesday, Dec. 11. -President Carlos Mendieta last night presented his resignation to the Cabinet and the Council of State at a joint session after his government had failed to effect a conciliation of the political parties preparatory to holding the general elections set for Jan. 10.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The Prince of Wales recited a jingle today at the annual meeting of the Travel and Industrial Development Association of Great Britain and Ireland, which he urged be supported in every way possible so that it might "continue to raise its voice louder and louder."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 10. -Hoffman Philip, the new United States Ambassador to Chile, was the guest of honor today at a luncheon given by the Chile-American Association, which was attended by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance and Trade and many persons prominent in political and commercial circles.

TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 10. -- An astonishing trend of moderation in the Japanese Army's "strong" North China policy was revealed by Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of Japan's forces in North China, in an interview today. General Tada's refrain was regret that recent events had caused a belief that Japan had territorial ambitions in China.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was appointed yesterday a temporary trustee for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe. Postal is being reorganized under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act and application for trustees was made jointly by the Lehman and Stewart bondholders' committees with the approval of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which controls Postal.

Domestic corporation bonds were subjected to moderate profit-taking on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and reactionary tendencies predominated over a fairly broad list of issues. The market for secondary bonds proved most vulnerable to the selling.
Governor Herbert H. Lehman has sent to the committee for the Tropical Ball his acceptance to serve as an honorary patron of the ball and his best wishes for the success of the event.

Secretary WALLACES annual reports are by no means the dry-as-dust documents that issue from most Washington offices at this season of the year. Into them he puts a good deal of hard thinking and a refreshing amount of candor. His report for 1935, which is published this morning, conforms in this respect to the pattern of its predecessors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The city of Copenhagen, Denmark, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Form 18 for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $15,000,000 of twenty-five-year 5 per cent gold bonds, due on June 1, 1952, and $12,000,000 of twenty-fiveyear 4 1/2 per cent gold bonds, due on May 1, 1953.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- About 175,000 new homes will be constructed in the United States next year, Steward McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, estimated today in announcing that the volume of business done by the FHA has passed the $500,000,000 mark.
The United States Treasury, which for months has been "pegging" the world price of silver, withdrew its support yesterday and allowed the foreign market to collapse.

The Automobile Club of New York and its parent organization, the American Automobile Association, went on record yesterday in opposition to compulsory automobile insurance and in favor of State inspection of motor vehicles.
ROME, Dec. 10. -- Commanders of Italy's northern and southern armies in Ethiopia were reported today to anticipate much stiffer resistance soon from the defending warriors of Emperor Halle Selassie.

Announcement was made last night by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians that it will demand the expulsion from the international body of the union of Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, director of the Federal Music Project, with offices in Washington.

In a unanimous report submitted to Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College Columbia University, a faculty-student committee appointed by him to investigate the ease of four workers dismissed from the college cafeteria found that the men had not been rehired because of their "union membership and activity."

Two upsets marked the thirdround play of the National Association December squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night, when both Rowland B. Haines, No. 2, and Edward G. McLaughlin, No. 4 in the national ranking, were eliminated.

The feature of the concert given by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was the solitary and grimly fantastical Fourth symphony of Sibelius. This work was played in honor of the composer's seventieth birthday, celebrated in most places of the Western world last Sunday.

Articles of agreement for a fifteenround heavyweight championship elimination next June between Max Schmeling, German boxer who formerly held the title, and Joe Louis, famed Detroit bomber, yesterday were signed by Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 10. -- Just Fun, a 10-to-1 shot in the mutuel wagering, captured the Rice Institute, feature event today at Epsom Downs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is regrettable as Louis A. Stone contends in a letter to THE TIMES that the ignorance or innocence of instalment purchasers frequently results in the signing of papers, the legal consequences of which are unknown to the signers. I can appreciate Mr. Stone's indignation against the unscrupulous seller who beguiles his customers into believing that the papers to be signed have little or no effect.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Despite the colder weather and smaller receipts prior to hogs dropped 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight here today. A slower movement of fresh pork was given as the chief cause of lack of interest shown by packers. Smaller packers who operate almost exclusively on fresh pork paid the top price of $9.90, or 10 cents under yesterday's best mark, while the day's average was down 15 cents at $9.70.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- On the very first day it has gone to work the five-power naval conference has come to grips with the supreme issue before it -- the Japanese demand for parity in sea strength with Great Britain and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Filing of eleven additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, involving proposed issues of $13,185,380, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Southern Railway estimated that it would earn a net income of $3,851,706 in 1936 in a report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. The estimate excluded provisions for the payment of $1,199,471 under the railway pension law and $415,962 under the social security law.

Christmas spirit is beginning to pervade the galleries of New York. Several have definitely arranged gift displays. For example, there is the American Folk Art Gallery at 113 West Thirteenth Street, its two rooms stocked respectively with grouped items that are considered of museum stature and with material priced for the holidays, from $50 down.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Club owners of the American Association tonight postponed until tomorrow the election of a successor to Thomas J. Hickey as president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- On the ground that thousands of people both within and without the American Federation of Labor consider the Committee for Industrial Organization "dual in character and purpose," President William Green of the federation declined today to become associated with the organization sponsored by John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers of America and seven other labor unions.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 10 (AP). -Further steps by the authorities in the assassination of Walter Liggett, publisher of The Midwest American, who was shot down at his own door last night, await the identification by his widow of Isadore Blumenfeld, alias Kid Cann, who is held by the police.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- "Arousers of the people," are more numerous in these parts than is previously recalled by the oldest inhabitants. They are sounding their tocsins to arouse the people to the perils that lie in continued government spending and in legislative and social projects "subversive of the Constitution."
Directors of the General Foods Corporation yesterday accepted the resignation of Edward F. Hutton as chairman of the board.

Few spectacles could be more ironic than that of Dr. SCHACHT, Germany's economic dictator, complaining that world trade, which had increased tenfold between 1850 and 1910, has since then been wrecked by "force and shortsighted politicians." No country in the world within the last few years has shown half as much ingenuity in devising new methods of blocking the free flow of world trade as Germany.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- George W. Olvany Jr., 23, son of ex-Judge Olvany, former Tammany chieftain, shot himself twice in the head early this morning in a lonely section on lower Saranac Lake, about a mile from this village.

After a lively chase in which one of two radio car policemen fired six unheeded warning shots in the air, a 17-year-old youth ran a small 1935 sedan into a moving van at Seventy-second Street and First Avenue shortly before 9 o'clock last night, damaged the sedan, suffered a minor scalp wound and found himself a prisoner charged with stealing the car.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz awaited today the arrival of official notification from the Supreme Court in Washington of its refusal to review the verdict of guilty in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, awaiting execution in the State's prison here for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 10. -Variety was a feature of the Winter bouquet show of the Garden CityHempstead Community Club today in the Garden City Casino, when Winter flowers, greens and shrubs were displayed. There were wreaths, table settings and miniature arrangements as well.

It is not because he was an editor, but because he was the victim of foul murder by public enemies, that the case of Mr. LIGGETT attracts national attention. He had been for a long time exposing and fighting vice conditions in Minneapolis. Whatever may be said of his methods, they were at least effective in rousing the hatred of the racketeers who lived off this despicable form of money-making.

Asserting that its 136 years in business entitled it to the exclusive use of the word "Manhattan" for banking purposes, the Manhattan Company, which operates the Bank of the Manhattan Company at 42 Wall Street, brought suit yesterday in Federal Court to restrain the First Manhattan Corporation of 20 Pine Street from any use of "Manhattan" in its name or advertising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP). -Aside from the extent of territory to be acquired, Italy probably would gain little in accepting a reported Franco-British suggestion that there be ceded to her the southeastern portion of Ethiopia.

ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- The elevenmonth total of new corporations formed in this State is 16,946, the Corporations Bureau of the Secretary of State's office reported today. The aggregate is 112 short of a year ago, when up to Dec. 1, 17,058 new concerns had been chartered.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Following the disposition of the tangled affairs of the Braves the club owners of the National League continued their session today, re-elected Ford C. Frick president and went on record favoring the appointment of world series umpires by the advisory council instead of by the two major league presidents as practiced heretofore.

Another group of composers whose scores are seldom heard came briefly to life last night at the Town Hall under the ministrations of Hans Lange and the PhilharmonicSymphony Chamber Orchestra. Of the five men represented on the second program of the series of five for the benefit of the Bennington College Scholarship fund, only Johann Sebastian Bach is known to concert goers with comparative thoroughness.

Another advance in the cost of living of wage-earners was reported yesterday in a survey of the National Industrial Conference Board. The increase reported was 0.5 per cent from October to November. The most substantial increase was in food prices.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

An unusual lot of United States gold coins aroused spirited bidding at the sale of two well-known Canadian collections yesterday by the J. C. Morgenthau Company at 1 West Forty-seventh Street. The highest price was $140, paid for a fine specimen of the $10 gold coin, 1883, from the New Orleans mint.

The four-day trial in Special Sessions of Bernard P. Fisher, an officer and general manager of the New American Furniture Industries Credit Bureau, Inc., which shares offices at 381 Fourth Avenue with Fisher's National Furniture Mercantile Agency, ended yesterday in Fisher's conviction on a charge of commercial bribery under Section 439 of the Penal Law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Senator Lonergan plans to introduce a resolution at the next Congressional session to create a constitutional legislative court or commission to act in an advisory capacity to Congress and the President.

About 500 druggists heard themselves criticized last night for falling prey to commercial ventures which tend to make of them merely "sandwich men" with little or no standing as professional druggists.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Dec. 10 -- The Himmer family here spent an eventful eight hours today tending to the wants of the unappreciative crane saved from freezing last Saturday by Waldo Himmer. A partial list of their activities follows:

At the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club held yesterday the following clubs were elected to membership: Keeshond Club, Lehigh Valley Kennel Club, Birmingham Kennel Club and the Bull-Mastiff Club of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- A public statement by Philip H. Gadsden, chairman of the Committee of Public Utility Executives, suggesting that the major holding company groups and the commission get together and select suits brought by three or four typical companies and expedite them to the Supreme Court, was ignored today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

About 500 druggists heard themselves criticized last night for falling prey to commercial ventures which tend to make of them merely "sandwich men" with little or no standing as professional druggists.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Dec. 10 -- The Himmer family here spent an eventful eight hours today tending to the wants of the unappreciative crane saved from freezing last Saturday by Waldo Himmer. A partial list of their activities follows:

At the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club held yesterday the following clubs were elected to membership: Keeshond Club, Lehigh Valley Kennel Club, Birmingham Kennel Club and the Bull-Mastiff Club of America.

Further testimony was given yesterday in General Sessions in the trial of Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson and two men co-defendants on the indictment charging they abetted her husband, the missing Wililam F. Peterson, in his fraudulent stock deals in which investors lost $465,000.

Sixty to seventy tons of granite boulders and rock forming a promontory in the Palisades at Mountain Road, Jersey City, crashed into the rear yard of the L.O. Koven Company, boiler manufacturers, early yesterday morning. An annual occurrence, according to officials of the plant, yesterday's avalanche was the worst in twentyfive years.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,785,300 barrels, as compared with 2,820,450 in the preceding week, a drop of 35,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 26,150 barrels in Oklahoma and a gain of 19,800 barrels in California were the most important changes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP). -California's four big universities agreed today to withdraw from competition in the 1936 Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships to revive their own conference meet after a lapse of a decade.

HAVANA, Dec. 10. -- The military authorities today ordered the newspapers to refrain from carrying news of the kidnapping of Nicolas Castano Padilla, wealthy sugar mill owner who was kidnapped yesterday morning in the Vedado residential section and for whom a ransom of $300,000 has been demanded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Appreciation of nearly thirty-eight years of efficient service as Consul and Consul General was expressed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a message today to Edwin S. Cunningham, Consul General at Shanghai, who is retiring for age.

Voluntary adoption of a standard form of apartment house lease without recourse to legislation was among the recommendations submitted to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York by its committee on law reform at a stated meeting at the home of the association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, last night.

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 10. -Streaking over the Bobby Jones links in a rare exhibition, Alvin Krueger of Beloit, Wis., today shattered par by five strokes and took a commanding lead at the half-way point of the $2,000 Sarasola open golf tournament.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 10. -- The Constituent Assembly has approved a measure to increase to 33,000,000 soles the 6 per cent bond issue of 18,000,000 soles authorized under a law of Feb. 14, 1930. The bonds are to be offered at par to creditors of the State in payment of the sums owing to them on Dec. 31, 1934.

I'LL fight this bomber. I think my style will bother him." Thus spake Max Schmeling, without provocation or solicitation and entirely of his own volition, and Camera, Levinsky, Baer and Paulino moved over to make room for another recruit to the unprotected and benevolent order of incorrigible optimists.

As the ranks of fishermen and hunters grow ever larger, while facilities for the pursuit of their sport diminish, the trend to the development of commercial fish and game preserves, catering to sportsmen on a fee basis, becomes more pronounced.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Every player on the rival teams, including the goalies, joined in a general fist fight tonight when the Bruins downed the world champion Maroons, 2 -- 0, before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.
ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Dec. 10. -A large crowd was impressed today by the work of Paulino Uzcudun in his final boxing drill before meeting Joe Louis in Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The problem of pegging, fixing or stabilizing the price of a security being distributed by underwriters will be taken up again by the Securities and Exchange Commission as soon as the commission has formulated more definitely its program for administration of the Public Utility Act of 1935 and the legal actions involved.
City Hall took on a musical atmosphere yesterday while numerous persons racked their brains for a city anthem, and Mayor La Guardia listened to the strains of several Christmas carols.

Rugged individualism in the theatre is almost dead and only the success of the WPA theatre project can assure a future for the theatre in the United States, according to Elmer Rice, regional director of the Federal project. He addressed a luncheon meeting of the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday.

The State of Rhode Island yesterday accepted three separate tenders submitted for three new bond issues aggregating $1,772,000. A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and including Kidder, Peabody Co. and F. S. Moseley Co., won the award of $872,000 of 3 per cent public works bonds due on Sept. 1, 1956 to 1963, on a bid of 109.339.

BERLIN, Dec. 10. -- The Boerse for all practical purposes was totally inactive today. No movement developed that could be regarded as a price tendency. The small volume of offers that depressed the market slightly yesterday had evidently been exhausted today.

Jose R. de Capriles, former New York University star, representing the University Fencers Club, won premier honors in a junior foils competition sponsored by the Amateur Fencing League of America on the strips of the New York Athletic Club last night.

A demand for a declaratory judgment recognizing him as the son of Putnam Bradlee Strong, son of the late Mayor William L. Strong, and May Yohe, former actress, now Mrs. John Smuts, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Robert E. Thomas.

HONOLULU, Dec. 10. -- Head winds encountered most of the way from Alameda, Calif., retarded the arrival of the Philippine Clipper on her first air mail cruise across the Pacific until 9:01 A.M. today (2:37 P.M., New York time).

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10. --Establishment of a Graduate School of Public Administration at Harvard University, through a gift of $2,000,000 from Lucius Nathan Littauer, glove manufacturer and former Representative in Congress, was announced here today by President Conant.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10. -- The lightly - weighted filly. Exotude, owned and trained by F. P. Letellier, was a driving winner of the Golden Rod Purse, feature event today on the Fair Grounds program. A half length was the margin at the end of the mile and seventy yards and the victor had the favorite, Neverfade, behind her.

John K. Weeks, Princeton Club, defending champion in the Squash Club's second annual Class B singles invitation squash racquets tourney, advanced to the third round yesterday at the expense of G. Acheson of the Sleepy Hollow Club. Despite Acheson's tenacious efforts in the rallies, Weeks prevailed, 15 -- 13, 15 -- 8 and 15 -- 8.

CHICAGO, Dee. 10. -- American wheat markets showed today a disposition to follow strenghh in Buenos Aires rather than the dragging tendency in Winnipeg, sending prices at the end on the Chicago Board of Trade 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel higher on the old crop deliveries.

A vigorous, attractive young woman, 26 years old, stood in front of Brentano's book store at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street at 1:30 on a sunny and unusually mild December afternoon in 1910, waved good-bye to a former college classmate with whom she had been chatting and then was swallowed up in the crowd of passers-by.

The proceedings of the National Manufacturers Association convention here last week brought some comfort to Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, she indicated in an address before the National Consumers League at the Hotel Delmonico yesterday.

Tonight's opening is the same as last night's, that having been postponed because of certain mechanical adjustments with the scenery. It is still "This Our House," the play about Beatrice Cenci, and the theatre remains the Fifty-eighth Street. It seems that about 2 o'clock yesterday morning the authorities in charge decided another twenty-four hours would be needed to get everything in shape: they took them.

iMEXICO, D. F., Dec. 10.Peasants and workmen will be armed,if 'necessary, to guarantee the distribution of land within Wrexico, todefend the peasants' enjoyment oft and to improve the working classes economically, said PresidentLazaro Cardenas in an address toworkers in the agricultural schoolat Tenerta, Strife of rexico, at theconclusion of a week-end tour."

Though yesterday had no such official title, it was a more or less official John Jacob (Jay) Berwanger Day in New York City's football circles. It was an exciting holiday, during which honors were heaped on his head, for the big back and captain of the University of Chicago team who has received widespread recognition as one of the outstanding football players of the past season.

Jose R. de Capriles, former New York University star, representing the University Fencers Club, won premier honors in a junior foils competition sponsored by the Amateur Fencing League of America on the strips of the New York Athletic Club last night.

A demand for a declaratory judgment recognizing him as the son of Putnam Bradlee Strong, son of the late Mayor William L. Strong, and May Yohe, former actress, now Mrs. John Smuts, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Robert E. Thomas.

HONOLULU, Dec. 10. -- Head winds encountered most of the way from Alameda, Calif., retarded the arrival of the Philippine Clipper on her first air mail cruise across the Pacific until 9:01 A.M. today (2:37 P.M., New York time).
The Park Department will post this morning in its borough offices and on all WPA construction projects "a message to park workers" from Abraham Lincoln.

France retained her crown as dictator of feminine fashion in a "beauty contest and fashion display by the junior belles of Hell's Kitchen," staged last evening at the Marjorie Post Hutton Free Food Centre for Women and Children, a Salvation Army unit, which recently moved from the West Side zone to 30 East Twenty-ninth Street.

It was "clean-up day" on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with 101 issues being stricken from the list. While the dropping of these securities excited no interest since all had previously been suspended from dealing for a variety of reasons, two of the issues revived memories of a former era -- in Wall Street and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave the first offical dinner of the season, entertaining in honor of members of the Cabinet, with a musicale afterward to which additional guests were invited.

MANILA, Dec. 11. -- Roy Howard's statement that the "independence dream was dying" ricocheted through Filipino and American communities alike, monopolizing discussion and reviving old issues and creating new hopes.
Reports of continued improvement in the real estate market were made by real estate and mortgage experts at a meeting of the Long Island Real Estate Board yesterday in the Jackson Heights clubhouse.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. ll. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, women's national golf champion from Philadelphia, disclosed today that she plans to compete next year in the British women's championship, an event in which she was runner-up to Miss Joyce Wethered in 1929 and to Miss Diana Fishwick in 1930.
WITH THE ITALIAN TROOPS AT ADIGRAT, Ethiopia, Dec. 11. (AP). -- Italy's big push toward the heart of Ethiopia from the north has been halted until lines of supply can be set up for the next drive.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Samuel Mandell, 40 years old, of 382 Buffalo Avenue, this city, described by the police as the "sugar king" of the alcohol racket in Northern New Jersey, was fatally shot last night by a gunman as he fled in Paterson Street from the home of a woman he had been visiting.

ROME Dec. 11. -- The Franco-British proposals for solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy were delivered to Premier Benito Mussolini today by Count Charles de Chambrun, the French Ambassador, and Sir Eric Drummond, the British envoy, at 5 and 5:30 P.M., respectively.

Seeded players encountered stiff opposition as the Squash Club's second annual Class B squash racquets invitation tourney went into the quarter-finals on the home courts yesterday. John K. Weeks of Princeton, defending champion, was carried to four games before he defeated Peter Vischer, Squash Club president, who bowed by 15 -- 9, 15 -- 11, 13 -- 15 and 15 -- 6.
The woman who for years has been helping the Neediest Cases Fund with an annual gift of a $1,000 note brought her contribution to the Times Square office of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- More than 300 guests, including several who came in after the Cabinet dinner and musicale at the White House, attended tonight the ball given at the Sulgrave Club by Dr. and Mrs. William Holland Wilmer for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Miriam Scott, daughter of Mrs. Russell Sard, who was Miss Rebekah Wilmer.
Continuing its victory pace against its third opponent of the season, the Fordham basketball team scored a 44-16 triumph over Wagner College last night in the Maroon gymnasium.

An injunction suit to restrain Robert P. Levis from acting as Republican leader of the Eleventh Assembly district was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Daniel J. Riesner, lawyer, who contested the leadership of the district with Mr. Levis at the primary election.

When Will Rogers was Cherokee Bill he saved a little girl, who was to become May Wirth, circus equestrienne, from a spanking. The story was told yesterday by Nellie Revell, theatrical writer and radio raconteur.

WARSAW, Dec. 11. -- New anti-Jewish riots were reported from West Poland. In Wiecbork, near the German border, Jewish traders' stalls were demolished in the market place, shop windows were smashed and several were beaten. Many arrests were made.

Thirty persons were injured, one seriously, at 10:02 o'clock last night when a four-car passenger train, with about 200 aboard, entering the 125th Street station of the Third Avenue elevated line, rammed the rear end of a supply train which had stopped at the station.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Orders for 10,000 freight cars to cost about $25,000,000 were placed today by the Pennsylvania Railroad, which asked also for bids by next Monday from banking houses on $18,420,000 of equipment trust certificates to help finance the building program.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 11. -- Mrs. Edith Liggett telegraphed Attorney General Cummings tonight asking a Department of Justice investigation into the murder of her husband, Walter Liggett, publisher of a crusading weekly newspaper here, who was shot by two gunmen at the door of his home Monday.

For the first time in the history of Columbia varsity shows, women students will appear in the annual undergraduate production. This ends a tradition that has existed since 1894 when the first Columbia show was produced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Federal Government, while it has been defending the validity of the Bankhead Cotton Control Act, was disclosed today as doing so in the face of an opinion expressed in a memorandum to Secretary Wallace that the measure was "probably unconstitutional."

With the tension with respect to the silver market noticeably relaxed, the share market firmed up moderately yesterday although it by no means recovered from the setback of the day before. The Volume of trading was diminished, the day's business on the Stock Exchange amounting to 2,130,000 shares, against 2,341,000 on Tuesday.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- A collection of former Notre Dame football stars gave 10,000 spectators a demonstration of the indoor game tonight by defeating a group of hastily assembled collegians, 10 -- 9, in the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange turned dull today after a firm opening, with British Government stocks leading the downward procession. Little selling was in evidence and quotations in most departments slumped from lack of business.

Mrs. Hildred Gude believes that a reconciliation with her husband, Oscar J. Gude, son of the late outdoor advertising executive of that name, is "spiritually and physically impossible," it was said in the Supreme Court yesterday in Mrs. Gude's suit to set aside a separation agreement and give her the custody of their two sons.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Ethiopia will not accept Italian domination or cede territory that has been taken by force, Wolde Mariam Ayelu, Ethiopian Minister, said today after learning details of the Franco-British proposals on a visit to Premier Pierre Laval.

An indication that Italy was pleased by the France-British plan for settlement of the Ethiopian controversy was given yesterday by Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States, in an address at the annual meeting of the New York Board of Trade at the Commodore.

ATLANTA, Dec. 11. -- The national attention attracted by the attacks of Governor Eugene Talmadge upon President Roosevelt and his policies has induced the hope among some business leaders of this section that he might be used as a spear-head for a split in the Democratic party that would turn the administration out of power in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A pointblank denial that he had conspired with his son, Charles J. Hoeppel, to sell an appointment to West Point for $1,000 was voiced from the witness stand in District Supreme Court today by Representative Hoeppel of California.
The Harvard, Princeton, Yale and University Club teams were winners last night as the group one Class C teams of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association swung into action for the first time.

Chicago was favored as the meeting place of the Republican National Convention at a session of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee held yesterday at the National Republican Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Convinced that they had remained in the background long enough, the Yankees stepped to the fore today by transacting the only player deal to enliven an afternoon otherwise given to purely legislative matters as the two major leagues concluded the second day of their annual Winter conclaves.

The 1,500-ton destroyer Cummings, built for the United States Navy, was launched at Mariners Harbor, Staten Island, yesterday in the presence of about 500 guests, representatives of the navy and of United Drydocks, Inc., the builder.
Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan came to the aid of the police street safety campaign yesterday and at the same time revealed himself to be a versifier.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 11. -- Sir Sidney Barton and Paul Bodard, the British and French Ministers to Ethiopia, received messages today detailing the Paris peace proposals, and as joint action was indicated they must confer before offering advice to Emperor Haile Selassie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Attorney General Cummings will appear in the District of Columbia Supreme Court tomorrow to argue for a stay of proceedings in seven actions brought by utility holding companies to enjoin enforcement of Title I of the Public Utility Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- With the same formality with which it decrees wheat and cotton production, the AAA announced today that China might ship one and one-tenth bushels of potatoes into the United States in the coming year without paying a tax under the new Potato Control Law.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Harvard's varsity and freshman basketball teams got off to a fine start tonight, scoring impressive triumphs over Boston University quintets in the opening games of the season in the athletic building.

Charging the United States with "playing the coward" in world affairs, Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland proposed last night that this country take the lead in an international conference to seek world-wide readjustment of trade, drastic disarmament, stabilization of currency and settlement of war debts.

Commodity, futures generally were lower yesterday, although no severe declines appeared in the markets here. A slightly better tone developed in coffee futures after early weakness and rubber was higher. On the cash markets corn, butter and rubber advanced, while wheat, oats, flour, eggs, lard, tin, cotton and silk declined.
PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Ethiopia answered a French appeal for a "conciliatory spirit" tonight with flat resistance to any "premium for the Italian aggressor."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Making a belated request to the law division of the State Education Department for a ruling on whether Handel's "Messiah" and Christmas carols could be sung in schools outside school hours. Mount Vernon's Board of Education was notified today that such programs were permissible.

GENEVA, Dec. 11. -- The League Committee of Eighteen, convoked mainly to fix the day for cutting off Italy's oil supply, will meet in private here tomorrow afternoon, with the probabilities favoring a delay. The only thing yet definitely on the agenda is a report by experts, analyzing how sanctions are being applied legislatively.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11. -- Providence College defeated Yale, 48 to 24, tonight in the opening basketball game of the season. The visitors displayed superior passing, more accuracy in basket shooting and a defense that held Yale at bay throughout.

QUINCY, Mass., Dec. 11. -- The largest group of guards ever assembled for a launching at the Bethlehem Fore River shipyards at Quincy, kept watch over a usually small number of visitors today as the new destroyer Moffet slid down the ways here.

If ever the irreverent have scoffed at the labors of Congressional campaign committees or either branch of them for either party, now is the time for apologies and regrets. From Washington comes news of the transfusion of new blood and energy and youthful fire into the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee.

In an interview yesterday after his return from a speaking tour in the Middle West, Norman Thomas, leader of the left wing of the Socialist party, read the "Old Guard" out of the party and announced that the fight against them would be pursued to a finish.

It was a French economist, BASTIAT, we believe, who described the approach to a taxpayer of a government boasting of its leniency in raising revenue. He said it was like going politely into the poultry yard and asking the fowls with what sauce they would like to be served up.

Captain Einar Sundstrom, who was master of the Morgan liner Dixie when it went aground on a Southern reef last September, was host at luncheon yesterday to 170 of the 234 passengers who shared that experience with him. The passengers were welcomed by the captain to a rebuilt and redecorated liner, ready to sail again after spending the last two and one-half months in drydock.
The New York A.C. Class A squash tennis team traveled to Brooklyn yesterday, but returned last night still the undefeated leader in the metropolitan league matches.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Still advocating the out-and-out payment of college athletes, Professor George Owen Sr. of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology apologized today to the president of Notre Dame "if any statement of mine is untrue."

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Bankers were advised today by G. Munro Hubbard of New York, president of Doremus Co., in a talk before the Chicago Financial Advertisers in the Hamilton Club to explain their place in the economic world so that the man in the street understands it.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 11. -- Australian High Commisioner Stanley Bruce, in London has cabled the Australian Government that the United States Government advised Sir Herbert Wilkins, aboard the motorship Wyatt Earp at Magallanes, Chile, to suggest that the British research ship Discovery II approach the Bay of Whales as soon as ice permits and to try to pick up wireless signals from Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Storm centre of the Massachusetts teachers oath "rebellion," Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard University Professor of Geology, reversed his position tonight and signed an unconditional oath -- to pave the way for a fight on "this un-American legislation."

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- New York City real estate is bequeathed to Mrs. Frances Sacket I De V.]in w-@g in the will of her I mother, Mrs. Eliza Ross Sacker De Valin of Cape Vincent, on file here today. Mrs. De VRliB died here Nov. 27.

Holiday trade in the metropolitan area has continued to go ahead nicely thus far this week, with the expectation that sales at the week-end will easily be the best of the shopping period thus far. Gains over a year ago have been noted by most stores here on every day this week, with the declining sales curve at this time last year tending to emphasize the extent of the increases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A decrease in expenditures for Federal relief after this fiscal year ends June 30 was forecast today by President Roosevelt and some leading members of Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Dismissal of suits brought by the United Gas Improvement Company and the Philadelphia Electric Company to challenge the Public Utility Act was asked in the Federal Distract Court here today in motions by Attorney General Cummings and other officials.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- A warning against vast expenditures for monumental buildings, in the construction of which Nazi organizations land leaders are vying with each other to enhance Nazi prestige, was seen today in a speech by Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, Finance Minister.

With the prospect of international racing in the 12-meter class next Summer, interest in the twelves has had an impetus, and announcement was made yesterday through the brokerage department of Sparkman Stephens that two of the one-design sloops had been sold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The petition to the Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia, signed by Chairman J. Warren Madden of the National Labor Relations Board, marks the first case in which the board, following the requirements of the National Labor Relations Act, has on its own motion asked the Circuit Court of Appeals for an order supporting its findings.

Murray Patrick, son of the Rangers' manager, knocked out Howard Langraf, Baltimore, who had a record of eleven consecutive knockouts, in the outstanding bout on the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s inter-city boxing card last night at Madison Square Garden.

" In Person," Ginger Rogers's first starring picture for RKO Radio, starts a week's engagement today at the Radio City Music Hall. The cast also includes George Brent, Alan Mowbray, Grant Mitchell and Joan Breslau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission began today to present evidence with which it hopes to drive from the brokerage business Michael J. Meehan, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a foremost speculator.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- The American Farm Bureau Federation approves and will defend the Agricultural Adjustment Administration Act, it was established here today when seventeen resolutions were adopted at the closing session of the annual meeting.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 11. -Nearly a thousand persons, including many notables of the State, heard Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank of New York, deliver the principal address tonight at the annual dinner of the Houston Chamber of Commerce.
