VIENNA, Dec. 11. -- Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, Austria's powerful Vice Chancellor, in a speech tonight called for Austrian leadership of the Germanic nations in a startling challenge to Adolf Hitler.

The swimming carnival at the New York Athletic Club last night was featured by Lester Kaplan's fast time in the 100-yard breaststroke event. Kaplan, Dragon Club representative, defeated Paul Friesel, a clubmate, in 1:05.7.

SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. ll. -- Johnny Revolta P.G.A. titleholder, blazed down the stretch in a champion's finish today to break the Bobby Jones Club course record with a 65 and take first money in the Sarasota open golf tournament.
BUFFALO, Dec. 11. -- Judge John Knight in the Federal court today denied the petition of three Mexicans for citizenship because they have a strain of Indian blood.

VIENNA, Dec. 11. -- In an adroit speech tonight Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, the Vice Chancellor, while preserving the form of adherence to the house of Hapsburg, succeeded in intimating that he would tolerate no actual restoration propaganda. He subordinated entirely the question of whether or not Austria should be a monarchy to his determination to make it a 100 per cent Fascist State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- The wheat markets continued on the down-grade today. On the Chicago Board of Trade the erratic action of the December delivery stood out in the trading. Notices were issued around midday of intention to deliver about 1,900,000 bushels of cash grain on future contracts, the first so far this month, and in the scramble to liquidate holdings by scattered interests the current month dropped to 1/4 cent under the May.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 11. -- Two employes of the Ethyl Gasoline Company of Newark were killed late today when their testing airplane crashed near Nunda, fifty miles southwest of here:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Strange as it may seem, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin again implied in Parliament today that the policy of the British Government was still that any proposals for peace in the African conflict must be satisfactory to Italy, Ethiopia and the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Hubbard Gold Medal of the National Geographic Society was presented by General Pershing tonight to Captain Albert W. Stevens and Captain Orvil A. Anderson of the Army Air Corps, in recognition of their ascent into the stratosphere on Nov. 11, when they reached an official altitude of 72,395 feet.

In the cloudy Surrey hills not far from Croydon, London's airport, the eleven passengers and the crew of a Belgian airliner met a tragic end. Ice had formed on the craft's wings. The perfect streamlined form for which the designer strives was destroyed, with the result that the resistance -- "drag" in technical parlance -- was increased beyond the margin of safety.

Saying he was appalled at the thought that the racketeer "take" in this city equaled in a few days the amount sought by the United Hospital Fund in one year, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor investigating rackets, urged volunteer workers yesterday to greater effort as the fund soared past the half-way mark with a total of $1,304,551.

Remarkable precision and almost perfect position play enabled Erwin Rudolph to win his second match in the world's pocket billiard championship yesterday. He defeated the veteran Bennie Allen of Kansas City, 125 to 11, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Events have demonstrated again the inherent folly of the Government's silver policy. On Tuesday the United States Treasury, which for months has been "pegging" the world price of silver, withdrew its support and the market collapsed. In London the bullion brokers were unable to fix a price for the metal for the first time since war days.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that 101 securities, all of which already have been suspended from dealings, would be stricken from the list on Dec. 31. Many of these issues have either matured, have been redeemed or have gone out of existence, and in many cases other securities of the same company remain listed on the Exchange unaffected by this action.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Great Britain put oil sanctions temporarily on the shelf and turned to Geneva for action on the new Anglo-French peace plan in the face of undisguised press disapproval and suspicion tonight.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange or partners in the firms will be required henceforth to approve personally the opening of all new accounts under a series of amendments adopted yesterday by the governing committee of the Exchange.

Columbia's basketball team flashed a powerful second-half attack last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium to defeat Brooklyn Poly Tech, 38 to 13. It was the opening game of the season for the veteran Blue and White outfit and it marked the first defeat in three starts for the Engineers.

While Hiram C. Todd was being sworn in yesterday as special prosecutor in the Druckman murder case and its ramifications, the Kings County November grand jury issued a statement indicating sharp resentment at Governor Lehman's action in superseding them in the midst of their inquiry into the case.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Increased receipts of hogs here today carried prices off 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight. The arrivals of 25,000 head were the largest for a Wednesday since January. There was an active demand on the decline, with all interests good buyers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Representatives of four governments combined today to remove one of the principal obstacles to early inauguration of regular transatlantic air service for passengers and mail.

John Collins, 26 years old, who will be sentenced to death in the electric chair tomorrow for the murder of a Queens civic worker last June, was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Anna Downs of 227 East Thirty-third Street, Manhattan.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., to hold a public hearing on a proposal to transfer part of Chisholm Park at College Point, Queens, for use as a terminal for the College Point ferry.

THE cables bring definite word from Melbourne that the Australian Lawn Tennis Council, which means Norman Brookes, is filing its Davis Cup entry for 1936 in the American zone. Having tried these many years to qualify for the challenge round the hard way, in the European sector, the Antipodeans are now horning in on the good thing Uncle Sam's nephews have had all to themselves.

Auction selling in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the offering of the twenty-story Clarendon Building at 215 Fourth Avenue, southeast corner of Eighteenth Street, which was bought in by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, on a bid of $800,000.
I read with a great deal of interest in THE TIMES of Dec. 9 the sermon on the subject of birth control by Cardinal Hayes.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 11. -- About 500 Mexican communities with 5,000 or more inhabitants have no physicians, Dr. Jose Siurob, Minister of Public Health, said yesterday in announcing that one of his principal subordinates would tour the republic to establish cooperation by State Governors in a plan to improve health conditions.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 11 (AP). -- A Reuters [British] News Agency dispatch from Peiping today said Manchurian troops, who yesterday occupied Kuyuan, in Southeastern Chahar Province, had also entered near-by Paochang.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The labor apparel group, representing about 750,000 employes, met today and decided to press for Federal legislation dealing with the apparel industries along the lines applied to the coal industry in the Guffey Law.

A plan to coordinate public and private property improvements, described as a "cellular conception" of city planning, was outlined to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects at a luncheon in the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

Six men, alleged by Thomas E. Dewey, special racket prosecutor, to be members of a loan sharks ring which lent more than $250,000 a year to 2,500 clients, were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions, where two of them pleaded guilty and four others not guilty.

The recent marked demand for private houses in the Carnegie Hill section of Manhattan continued yesterday with the sale by Simeon M. Barber of the four-story residence at 12 East Ninety-third Street. The house has been acquired by a client of Maurice tour. Wyckoff, attorney, for altering.

CAIRO, Dec. 11. -- At a meeting today the Egyptian Cabinet unanimously decided to resign. Since King Fuad was unable to receive Premier Tewfik Pasha Nessim, submission of the resignation was postponed until noon tomorrow.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 11. -- Any one who has been perplexed on reading "and/or" in insurance policies or legal papers should be heartened. The Wisconsin Supreme Court cannot figure it out either.

OTTAWA, Ill., Dec. ll. -- A captain of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, assisted by Department of Justice agents, captured two suspects in the kidnapping of John S. Labatt, Canadian brewer, after a street chase here today.

Bondholders' committees in real estate reorganizations were asked last night by the Streit Joint Legislative Committee, which has been investigating the activities of such protective groups, to adopt forthwith a new procedure for the better protection of bondholders.

Judge James M. Barrett, normally a slow but crisp speaker, talked very rapidly for a few moments in Bronx County Court yesterday to a quietly weeping youth and a crowd of men and women anxious to learn what was to become of the boy, who was convicted recently of killing his father with an axe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is willing to advance $15,000,000 toward winding up the receivership of the Union Trust Company of Cleveland if a like amount can be obtained from depositors and stockholders, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, announced tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The British Government announced today that it would order seven new destroyers immediately, in addition to the flotilla leader and eight destroyers now building under the 1935 naval program.

Many native Southerners of prominence attended the fiftieth annual dinner of the New York Southern Society last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland spoke. The dinner was followed by dancing.

The Port of New York Authority awarded yesterday a new issue of $16,500,000 of general and refunding bonds due in 1965 to a banking syndicate headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., at a price of 97.111 for 3 3/4s. The bid represents a net interest cost to maturity to the Port Authority of 3.8463 per cent.
Slight though it be, some consolation may be gained by New York hunters from the knowledge that conditions about which they are prone to complain are not peculiar to this region.

The rarity of a capacity fight crowd in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night was forecast by Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday for the fifteen-round bout between Joe Louis, Detroit's heavyweight title threat, and the veteran Paulino Uzcudun, rugged Basque.
BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- The Boerse was quiet again today, developing no tendency either way. The only change of importance was in Siemens Electric shares, which lost 2 3/4 points.

Alla Nazimova, who long ago made theatrical history in Ibsen roles, comes to the Empire tonight in "Ghosts." She, of course, is Mrs. Alving, with a supporting cast which includes McKay Morris, Harry Ellerbe. Ona Munson and Raymond O'Brien.

As the site for a taxpayer, the southwest corner of Lydig and Cruger Avenues, the Bronx, was sold by the Bronx Heights Development Corporation to the Associated Real Estate Corporation, Richard M. Lederer, president. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., were the brokers.

Construction contracts in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains last month totaled $188,115,000, which was below the October figure of $200,595,700 but 85 per cent above the $111,691,500 reported for November, 1934, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

Led by Irving Terjesen, the New York University varsity basketball team opened its season last night, when it defeated an Alumni five, 48 to 22, in the University Heights Gymnasium before a crowd of more than 1,000. Terjesen tallied three field goals and four fouls, for a total of 10 points.

The directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., declared yesterday a special distribution of 50 cents a share on the outstanding preference stock, in accordance with the recapitalization plan approved on Tuesday by stockholders. The dividend is payable upon delivery of the present stock in exchange for new preference stock.

When the Four Aces contract bridge team sits down tonight at Essex House to start its 300-hand world championship match against a team of French players which in June won the championship of Europe, Oswald Jacoby, who organized the Aces' team two years ago, will not be in the line-up.

PRAGUE, Dec. 12. -- The opposition of Right-wing parties in Czechoslovakia to the proposed election of Dr. Eduard Benes as President of the republic resulted in a Cabinet and State crisis today. Premier Milan Hodza tendered the Cabinet's resignation to President Masaryk, which the President refused to accept.

TRENTON, Dec. 11. -- Senator-elect Lester H. Clee of Newark, chairman of the Budget Advisory Committee, indicated at a hearing by the committee today that the Legislature might be asked to abolish the jobs of 159 motor vehicle inspectors and at the same time increase the personnel of the State Police Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, retired, who was appointed chairman of the American Red Cross to succeed Judge John Barton Payne when the latter died last January, was reappointed to that office today by President Roosevelt.

Cash and pledged contributions totaling $44,500 were received yesterday, the first day of a drive to raise $150,000 by the Artists Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

Another break in silver futures in Montreal unsettled prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and the market fell 25 to 31 points under the heaviest liquidation since the improvement started more than two months ago.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The Princeton basketball team won its second encounter tonight, downing the Lafayette five by 30 -- 21 in the University gym.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- A new "battle of the stork" has been initiated by the National Socialist regime to raise the German birth rate in conformity with Chancellor Adolf Hitler's dictum that only the numerically strong races will rule the world.

A change in the spirit of American colleges affecting student bodies as well as presidents of institutions was noted yesterday by Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, in his annual report.

Fear and uncertainty again dominated the world market for silver yesterday as bankers, bullion brokers and speculators strove to understand what new turn in the United States Government's silver policy underlay Tuesday's abrupt cessation of buying and the consequent collapse in the price of silver.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The 28-year-old Lord de Clifford, twenty-sixth baron in a line dating back to 1299, will face trial for manslaughter tomorrow in the House of Lords, kneeling on a velvet cushion and flanked by a crimson-robed tribunal of his peers of the realm.

TOKYO, Dec. 11. -- Officials realize that if Japan refuses at the London Naval Conference to discuss concrete details until her principle of naval parity is recognized, and if the Americans refuse to concede parity until they know the concrete terms, such a situation will mean that Japan will incur the blame for converting the conference into a hen and egg discussion.

Safety propaganda, graphic posters and articles like "Sudden Death and How to Avoid It," should do a great deal to instill carefulness and caution in the minds of automobile drivers, but such material can accomplish only so much. There is a basic factor in accident causation which such things cannot possibly influence, and that is the competence of drivers.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Dec. 11. -- After boxing seven rounds with five of his sparring partners today Joe Louis called a halt on training for his bout with Paulino Uzcudun. Bob Moody and Lew Poster each traveled two rounds with the Detroit heavyweight, while Paul Cavalier, Roy Williams and Vincent Parille went in the ring to take their last pummeling from the fists of the Bomber.

From century to century the observation has been made: "With how little wisdom the world is governed!" Dean INGE in quoting this from the past has recently given it a somewhat different interpretation:

More than 2,000 persons braved the chill of the Newark Bay waterfront yesterday afternoon to attend the breaking of ground for Jersey City's $1,250,000 sports stadium on a ten-acre site at Droyer's Point.

It would not have been hard to fortell the immense crowd and the demonstration that accompanied Kirsten Flagstad's first song in recital in New York last night in Carnegie Hall. The fame of the finest singer of certain Wagnerian parts that this city has seen in many years had preceded her.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 11 (AP). -- The heads, of all three American missions in Ethiopia and other members of the American colony presented a signed statement to Cornelius Van H. Engert, United States Charge d'Affaires, today, protecting the Italian bombardment of Dessye.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- For two hours this afternoon the five-power naval conference, sitting in committee, listened to an exposition by the Japanese of their naval position in response to questions put to them yesterday. The session was private, but as far as can be learned tonight the amount of precise information gleaned was not large.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Serious doubt as to the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Act was expressed here today by Federal Judge John Paul as he granted a preliminary injunction to fourteen Virginia and West Virginia coal producers, restraining the government from collecting a penalty tax for their refusal to accept the coal code.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. ll. -- Charging that Miss Rosa Christoph, a maid in their Montclair home, "unduly, illegally and fraudulently influenced" Edwin M. Rine in the making of a will under which the maid received the income of a $100,000 trust fund for life, Mrs. Cisca Miller Rine, the widow, contested today the will of the railroad executive.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- The Cuban public, stunned by the sudden resignation of President Carlos Mendieta today, waited anxiously for the action of the Council of State and the Cabinet to designate a Provisional President to preside over the coming general elections set for Jan. 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- The National Labor Relations Board petitioned the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today to enforce an order it had made against the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., and the Pennsylvania Greyhound Management Company, to engage in collective bargaining with its employes.

Stricter enforcement of the traffic law, with stiffer penalties for reckless and drunken drivers, was urged by Charles A. Harnett, New York State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, at the hearing yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Compulsory Automobile Insurance and Safety.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Democrats in the Midwest, where the Gettysburg of 1936 will probably be fought, are suffering from Governor trouble. Republicans are afflicted with ex-Governor trouble. The national results in several of the key States will be influenced by these political maladies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Albert Meyer, "defender of the Swiss franc," today was elected President of Switzerland for 1936. Giuseppe Motta, who has served as President four times, was named Vice President.

Martin W. (Buggsy) Goldstein, Brownsville gangster, boarded a train in Grand Central station at 4:53 P.M. yesterday bound for either Chicago or Boston, while a silent detective looked on to make certain that he did not change his mind at the last minute.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11. -- Rain and a sloppy track somewhat disturbed form at the Fair Grounds today, Bald Crest, winner of the feature, being among the outsiders to score. This chestnut color-bearer, owned by Mrs. C.C. Winters, led practically all the way of the six furlongs to score by a neck in a driving finish, and pay $18.60 for $2.

It hurts to find in the news of a single day specimens of careless English in the Prince of WALES among the living and in ABRAHAM LINCOLN among the honored dead. The heir to the British throne at a business men's meeting recited a jingle of which the final couplet runs:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Anglo-French proposal to stop the Italo-Ethiopian war by partitioning Ethiopia was described today as "incredible" by Senator Borah, ranking Republican member of the Foreign Relations Committee. He added that he believed it could not be put through to a successful conclusion, as the small nations of Europe would see its precedent "aimed at their hearts like a dagger."

MIAMI, Dec. 11. -- While 160-odd army planes, with mass manoeuvres just completed, were idle here today in advance of the start of the annual Miami air races tomorrow, a civilian flier set two world records here this afternoon.

Otto Schlaaff and Robert Riotte, who made their last appearance at the Town Hall a little more than eight months ago, returned last night in a concert for two pianos. The program consisted of the Mozart-Reinecke sonata in F, the Schumann-Debussy "Three Etudes in Canon Form," Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Haydn, Franck's prelude, fugue and variation, Debussy's "En Blanc et Noir," Casella's "Pupazzetti" and Ravel's "La Valse."

To carry out a notice served two weeks ago on Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, the State Mortgage Commission announced yesterday that on Jan. 1 it would take over control of the servicing of "all certificated mortgages issued or guaranteed by the Lawyers Mortgages Company coming within jurisdiction of the mortgage commission."

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Advisory Committee on Airports, will confer in Washington today with Postmaster General James A. Farley to obtain the approval of the Postoffice Department of Floyd Bennett Field as an air-mail terminal.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $44,000,000 Southwestern Bell Telephone Company first and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Dec. 1, 1964, by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The bonds will be priced at 102 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.35 per cent to 1961, the first year in which they will be callable at par.
WASHINGTON, Dec. ll. -- Rudy Vallee has reached no final decision as to when he will leave the cast of George White's "Scandals," he told THE NEW YORK TIMES late today.
Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, turned over yesterday to Thomas E. Dewey, special vice and rackets prosecutor, evidence on job-selling in the WPA organization.

With the Neediest Cases Fund lagging somewhat behind last year, it is timely to recall the method pursued in behalf of this charity. There is absolutely no personal solicitation. No individual receives a letter requesting a contribution on or before a certain date.

ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- Counsel for Miss Rose Freistater, New York City school teacher who failed to get a license in 1931 because she was overweight, told the State Education Department today that she is now down to the specified 150 pounds and therefore entitled to a teaching permit.

With the exception of a single month, the most pronounced gain in chain store sales this year occurred in November, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Hammons Co., Inc., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Great Britain notified the United States today that she would default on her war-debt payment on Dec. 15 through a note to Secretary Hull from Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador.

Rummaging around among the enormities and infamies of the Cenci family, Joel W. Schenker and Allan Fleming have salvaged the fustian and dubbed it "This Our House," which was played intensely at the Fifty-eighth Street Theatre last evening.

The opera department of the Juilliard School of Music ushered in its season of performances with a presentation of Mozart's "Magic Flute" last night in the school's concert hall. This opera, Mozart's last, and to many his greatest work for the stage, remains one of the most difficult in the entire repertoire.
While wealth is a prime requisite to the building of a great art collection, it is by no means the only one.

A special sale of useful articles will be held today at the West Side Thrift Shop, 640 Columbus Avenue, corner of Ninety-first Street, to celebrate the hundredth anniversary of the founding of the Half Orphan Home, one of the charitable organizations aided by the sale of articles at the shop.

The United States liner Washington is due today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Among her 645 passengers are William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to Soviet Russia; Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois and Mrs. Lewis Efrem Zimbalist and Jascha Heifetz, violinists, and Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong. Others are:
ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 11. -- An air raid alarm was raised here this morning at 4 o'clock when the rumor spread that Italian planes had been seen at Dessye making for Addis Ababa.

Testimony yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, 38 years old, and two men on a charge that they aided her missing husband, William F. Peterson, to defraud many persons in fake stock deals, revealed that in eighteen months Peterson obtained $516,743 from his victims.
A smoothly functioning Manhattan basketball team found little difficulty in overwhelming the Cooper Union quintet, 43 to 20, before a crowd of 1,000 at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

Motor-truck operators and intercoastal ship lines which are planning new tariffs in conformance with recently enacted Federal legislation will be asked to consider the views of shippers in the metropolitan district in fixing such rates, it was announced yesterday.

The gray stone mansion which the late Henry Clay Frick built in Fifth Avenue between Seventieth and Seventy-first Streets began its career as a public art museum yesterday afternoon when some 700 invited guests followed a carefully arranged course through the large and sumptuously furnished rooms hung with a fortune in art.
The body of a 70-year-old man who died in Bellevue Hospital Satudray of arterio-sclerosis was identified yesterday as that of William H. Foss, once a wealthy real estate broker here.
The new telephone book, which is as recurrent as Winter, but covers a far wider range of possibilities, will appear today.

Philip Guedalla, who has just returned to the British Isles after a visit to Russia, is finishing a panoramic history which will be published here next Fall by Doubleday, Doran under the title, "The Hundred Years." It will attempt to give the "high lights" of the last century, starting with the enthronement of Queen Victoria in 1837 and carrying through to the present.

The Board of Transportation still has about $75,000,000 worth of real estate on its hands and hopes to dispose of it soon in an improved real estate market, John H. Delaney, chairman of the board, told the Sinking Fund Commission yesterday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Robert V. Fleming, recently elected president of the American Bankers Association, in an address before the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking here last night in the Roosevelt Hotel urged bankers who are seeking employment for their funds to consider taking over some of the government lending operations.

Are Democrats more fickle or have they more desire for travel than Republicans? In the choice of cities for national conventions Republicans have been steadier than their opponents. On the whole, in spite of all temptations, Chicago has been Republican first choice.

Last August I visited New York as one of the leaders of a group of Boy Scouts from San Francisco. The boys and the leaders had a most wonderful time in your city and the numerous courtesies shown us, particularly by the police in directing and keeping us out of trouble, will never be forgotten.
James L. Bailey and John W. Freeman have been elected directors of Montague Gold Mines, Ltd., which controls the Montague gold district of Nova Scotia.

Most of yesterday's reality offerings at auctioneers' stands were taken over by savings banks. Six properties in Manhattan and ten in the Bronx comprised the forced selling for these two boroughs. Tenement houses dominated the list of foreclosed properties, all of which were struck down to the plaintiffs.

Improvement in the outlook for the railroads was expressed in a symposium, drawn from the railroad and banking field, presented to the New York Railroad Club at a dinner in the Hotel Commodore last night.

With trade practices of various branches of the food industry under investigation by Federal officials, the recently organized national food and grocery conference committee will take immediate steps to formulate a set of rules designed to correct the evils, it was announced here yesterday.

Probably Ibsen wrote "Ghosts" for Nazimova. Or, if not for her specifically, at least for a great actress, which is the measure of her Mrs. Alving in the performance that reached the Empire last evening. "Great" is a word for sparing use; it paralyzes linotype machines toward midnight.

Production of wool fabrics continues to average more than 3,000,000 linear yards weekly and no signs of a letdown are apparent in either weaving or spinning mills, according to the weekly survey issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Concluding their annual three-day Winter conclave with a joint session before Commissioner K. M. Landis today, the club owners of the National and American Leagues touched off a mild bombshell by flatly rejecting a request for a $20,000 appropriation to help in selecting and sending a team to represent the United States in the Berlin Olympic games.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Television may bring with it "sound-conditioning" apparatus capable of throwing a shroud of silence about homes, factories and other buildings, a Department of Commerce executive said at a meeting of engineers here tonight.

John J. Kemp, 51 years old, an insurance broker whose clients included the late Will Rogers and other theatrical stars, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions of the theft of more than $12,000 from two actors. Judge Donnellan remanded him to the Tombs for sentence Jan. 7.

Collier's Weekly yesterday announced its annual all-America football team for 1935, naming three players each from the Southwest and Middle West, two each from the South and Far West and one from the East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -The Federal Trade Commission today heard a charge and a denial that interests associated with the Cities Service Company had bolstered that company's stock to stimulate its sale to the public.

An order that "slackers and loafers" must go was issued yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, with the discharge of ten foremen and one general superintendent employed on WPA projects. Mr. Ridder said they were dismissed because they failed to exercise the proper discipline over their men.

PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Mrs. William Wiener of New York was fatally injured and her husband was badly hurt in an automobile accident near Cosne, Tuesday. Mrs. Wiener died yesterday in the hospital at Cosne, where it was said today her husband's condition was satisfactory.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Tommy Thevenow, versatile Pirates' infielder, was sold today to the Cincinnati Reds for an unnamed sum. Thevenow, a dependable fielder, can play at second, third and short.

Investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates new in default won an important point yesterday against the mortgage companies and the State Superintendent of Insurance as liquidator of more than a score of them when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler held that the companies must make good immediately any money withheld from the income of the mortgaged properties against which the certificates were sold.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 12. -- A royal rescript reinstating the 1923 Constitution was signed by King Fuad today, and the Cabinet of Premier Tewfik Nessim Pasha is remaining in office until after parliamentary elections after its note of resignation and an accompanying letter were all ready, except for signatures, to submit to the King.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 12. -- A speech in London by Alexander Shaw, president of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, expressing apprehension for British shipping in the Pacific owing to American subsidized competition, is prominently displayed in Australian newspapers today.

The Mack utility investigating committee, holding a public hearing yesterday at its headquarters at 10 East Fortieth Street, delved deep into the affairs of the Long Island Lighting Company, of which Ellis L. Phillips is the directing head, and put into its record the following evidence:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Representative John H. Hoeppel and his son, Charles, were convicted tonight by a District of Columbia Supreme Court jury on charges of conspiracy to sell a West Point appointment for $1,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -A denial that American Catholics planned reprisals against President Roosevelt for his refusal to intervene in the Mexican situation, as suggested by them, was formally issued tonight from the national offices of the Knights of Columbus in this city under the signature of Martin H. Carmody, Supreme Knight.

The world market for silver recovered slightly yesterday from the panic which had overtaken it on Tuesday when the United States Treasury suddenly withdrew its bid for silver in London, allowing the price to collapse. Despite Secretary Morgenthau's statement yesterday that the Treasury was still a buyer and was spreading its orders over other markets as well as London, bankers, bullion brokers, foreign exchange dealers and others concerned with silver continued bewildered.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Dec. 12 (AP). -The New York State Grange, by an overwhelming majority, voted disapproval of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration plan of production control.
WISE, Va., Dec. 12 (AP). -- Judge H. A. W. Skeen denied a new trial today for Edith Maxwell, 21-yearold school teacher sentenced to twenty-five years for the murder of her father.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,480,000,000, an increase of $5,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $8,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Berlin's new institute for rewriting history lives up to its name. There has been only one lecture, by a professor of "political pedagogy," but already the best friend of history would fail to recognize it.
Next Thursday evening the Metropolitan League's Class A team squash racquets championship will be decided between the University and Harvard Clubs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A study to determine for the first time what the American people want, and how and for what the rich as well as the poor spend their money, will be undertaken within five weeks by the Department of Labor under the National Research Program, to which $12,000,000 has been allotted by the Works Administration.

Mayor La Guardia expressed the city's welcome at City Hall yesterday to four leading members of the Matica Slovenska, Czechoslovakia's academy of history, art and science, as they arrived here to begin a five-month lecture tour in American universities and cities.

Two distinguished violinists, Mischa Elman and Efrem Zimbalist, yesterday returned on the Washington of the United States Lines after extensive concert tours abroad. Mr. Elman has been giving concerts for two months in Egypt and Palestine and Mr. Zimbalist made an eight-month tour of China, Japan, Russia and Europe.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 12. -- Owing to defective radio transmission of instructions from Paris, the French Minister, Paul Bodard, was unable to join the British Minister, Sir Sidney Barton, today as expected in placing the Anglo-French peace proposals before the Ethiopian Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- "Not expansion but reduction of navies is the Japanese proposal," declares Captain Tamon Yamaguchi, Japanese naval attache at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Costs of government, Federal, State and local, equal one-third of the current national income, the taxation committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, headed by Fred H. Claussen of Horicon, Wis., said in a report accompanying a questionnaire sent today to its 1,500 member organizations.

Once more the British Government has notified the United States that it will make no payment on its war debt. An installment of $117,000,000 is due on Dec. 15. This is in addition to $465,000,000 which has accumulated in arrears. A note handed to Secretary HULL by Sir RONALD LINDSAY simply states that there has been no change in the situation since the British Government defined its position in June, 1934.

A rise of $31,000,000 in brokers' loans, the third successive rise of about this amount, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement published yesterday.

The Christmas issue of the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee report, commonly referred to as the Catholic White List, has been made public. For this issue the juvenile section is featured. G. K. Chesterton is represented by two books, "The Well and the Shadows" and "The Scandal of Father Brown."

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- December wheat developed independent strength today on the Board of Trade here as the result of deliveries of only 20,000 bushels on future contracts, following the issuance of notices on 2,243,000 bushels yesterday.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 net income of $240,422 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. The income is equivalent to 47 cents a share on 512,631 shares of $5 par capital stock and compares with $439,547, or 86 cents a share, in the preceding year.

Effects of social security legislation on retail operations, the potentialities of the expanding housing movement and "the challenge of manufacturers so-called fair trade practice rules" submitted to the Federal Trade Commission for approval, will be the major topics dealing with national problems which retailers will debate at the silver anniversary convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania from Jan. 20 to 24, according to announcement made yesterday by the association.

In a verdant setting suggestive of Southern Winter resorts, the Tropical Ball was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House. A throng of several hundred persons, including many debutantes and other young people of society, participated in general dancing, a multitude of carnival attractions and divertissements throughout the evening.

A sharp exchange of telegrams between Governor Lehman and the Kings County November grand jury took place yesterday as the grand jury continued to show its resentment at having the investigation of the Druckman murder case and its ramifications taken out of its hands.

Emerson George Spies, 21-yearold senior of Hobart College, Geneva, N.Y., and Howard M. Wiedermann, 22, a graduate of the University of Buffalo, were picked last night as the candidates from New York State for the award of Rhodes scholarships to Oxford University, England.

Letters in the scrawled penmanship of children, letters typewritten on formal business stationery, some only a single sentence, others pages long -- all expressing compassion and hopefulness for New York's Neediest Cases -- brought 268 gifts totaling $13,052.57 to the Fund yesterday.

Victory by a membership vote of three to one against the secessionist left wing group led by Norman Thomas in the Socialist party was predicted yesterday by Algernon Lee, city chairman, in reply to Mr. Thomas's declaration of the day before that the old guard would be "read out of the party" shortly.

Commodity futures were moderately lower in light trading on the local markets yesterday. Sugar futures were slightly higher. On the cash markets all the grains advanced and gasoline rose to a new high, while lard made a new low and tin and silk declined.

SIR PHILIP GIBBS is a man of fine sympathies who hates ugliness, noise, pain and all the cruder contacts of a vicious world. He wishes the whole of England could be like Surrey and Sussex, with no "blighted areas," no "black country," no screaming cities. He would like everything to be a garden, with homes in the architectural tradition of the Tudor and Stuart Kings dotting the pleasant landscape.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- Der Angriff, the Labor Front's official organ, contains a vitriolic attack on Pastor Gerhard Jacobi, chairman of the Berlin-Brandenburg Confessional Synod. The paper asserts he is of Jewish origin on his mother's side and declares:

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin promised Opposition leaders in the House of Commons today that he would keep next Thursday's parliamentary calendar clear and, if expedient, on that day grant an opportunity for debate on the Italo-Ethiopian War.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 12. -- The reaction in Canadian Government circles to the Franco-British plan for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict has been highly unfavorable. One influential member of the Mackenzie King Ministry privately admitted he considered it "a shameless betrayal of the League."

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list McKesson Robbins, Inc., preference stock $3 series cumulative, convertible, without par value. McKesson Robbins, Inc., 7 per cent convertible preference stock, Series A, $50par, has been suspended from dealings.

For a few days the leadership of Great Britain, the prestige of France, the ambitions of Italy were at the front of the news. Suddenly there was a shift. It was seen that the big question was what would become of the League of Nations. Could it be saved? Under the appeals and guidance of Anglo-French representatives it had shown signs of coming back to full life.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- President Roosevelt's chances of carrying Ohio next year as he did in 1932 are materially weakened by the Federal administration's fight with Governor Martin L. Davey over relief policies and by dissension among State Democrats over the Davey administration policies, according to well informed observers here and in Cleveland.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 12. -- Caustic comments on the latest phase of the United States Treasury's silver buying program were made by a highly placed government spokesman.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Society yesterday announced that Arturo Toscanini will make his first appearance at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening, Jan. 23, when he will direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Tickets for the thirty-four concerts which Mr. Toscanini will conduct at Carnegie Hall will go on sale this Sunday.

After a conference with Park Commissioner Moses, Borough President Harvey of Queens said yesterday that he and Mr. Moses had agreed to oppose the proposal to transfer a part of Chisholm Park at College Point, Queens, for use as a terminal for the College Point Ferry.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- It is hoped here that the restoration of Egypt's 1923 Constitution will put an end to the discontent that has flared up so menacingly in recent weeks and that has given such anxiety to the British Government

The official representatives of the seventy-seven teacher associations affiliated with the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations agreed last night to conduct a State-wide campaign to combat "organized attempts now being made to cripple government service, especially public education, by limiting local income through a decrease in State aid."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- The government issued a decree tonight fixing 90 cents a bushel as the minimum price for this season's wheat crop. The ruling price at the close of trading this afternoon was 78 1/4 cents. The decree also establishes a minimum price for flaxseed equivalent to $1.16 3/4 a bushel.

Refinancing of certificated mortgages to enable investors in real estate securities to obtain ready cash was advocated yesterday at the fourth public hearing of the joint legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.

An appeal to take advantage of the tax exemption up to 15 per cent of income allowed by the Federal Government for gifts to churches, synagogues, colleges, character building institutions and private charities was issued last night by the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery after a meeting at the Yale Club attended by representatives of welfare and religious organizations.

PEIPING, Dec. 12 (AP). -- General Sung Cheh-yuan, head of the new semi-autonomous regime in North China, told newspaper men tonight that establishment of the HopeiChahar Political Council "marks an end to secret diplomacy in North China."

Weakness in Liverpool yesterday dropped prices on the Cotton Exchange here fo the lowest level of the movement at one time, but the market showed resistance as the May approached the recent mark, and last-hour covering left the list 3 to 11 points net higher on the day.

A memorial service for Mrs. Mary Cadwalader Jones, long a social leader here and who died in London on Sept. 22 at the age of 84, was held yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock in the Church of the Ascension.

MONTREAL, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens and Boston Bruins, cellar-dwellers of the National Hockey League's two divisions, struggled through seventy minutes of ice warfare tonight to a 1-1 tie that failed to alter the position of either.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Money stocks in the United States reached the new high record of $16,260,836,196 on Nov. 30, the Treasury announced today. This was almost twice the amount of money on hand on Aug. 31, 1929, when the nation was at the approximate peak of its prosperity.

MIAMI, Dec. 12. -- In one minute this noon all the modern combat striking units of the air defense of the continental United States swept by the official reviewing stand above the white-capped waters of Biscayne Bay to provide the opening feature of the annual air races here.

Charging "malicious" intent "to discriminate," Carlos G. Garcia, president of the Garcia Sugar Corporation, 99 Wall Street, brought suit yesterday for $39,642 damages against the New York Sugar and Coffee Exchange and four brokerage houses that are members of the Exchange as a result of the Exchange on Nov. 21 ordering liquidation of the "December No. 1" sugar contracts at a specified price, which Mr. Garcia alleges was lower than the value of the contracts.

A performance of Mahler's "Resurrection" symphony, which was sheer tonal drama, overwhelming in its intensity and sweep of vision, was given by Otto Klemperer, conductor of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, the chorus of the Schola Cantorum, and Susanne Fisher and Enid Szantho, solo singers, last night in Carnegie Hall.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 12. -- Dismissal for government employes and members of the military services participating in a revolt and penal servitude are the penalties provided by the new National Security Act, which was passed by Congress last night.

Major letters have been awarded to twenty-four members of the Fordham University varsity football team, it was announced by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey yesterday. The presentation of the insignia will be made next Spring at the annual Fordham Block F dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Grover A. Whalen, chairman, and other members of Mayor La Guardia's committee on airport development appeared this morning before Postmaster General Farley to urge once more the designation of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn as an air mail terminal.
The value of the dollar on the local forein exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotatlons are in cents:

The Franco-British peace proposals in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, if territorial concessions to Italy are embodied, would constitute a "betrayal" of the League of Nations, Sir Norman Angell, recipient of the Nobel Prize for Peace, declared yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Commodore.

The remarks of Observer on "Language" are most amusing, but they do hot go far enough. New Yorkers have achieved a certain ludicrous reputation for their ignorance of geography, but they are even better known for their misuse of the King's English.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Announcement of a sixteen-hour daily passenger service between Chicago and Denver, to start early in June, was made jointly today by Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, and Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago Northwestern.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The following were designated today by the war Department to be examined March 3 for admission to West Point at the term beginning July 1:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- An injunction suit brought by Fred Waring, leader of Waring's Pennsylvanians, against the WDAS Broadcasting Company on the ground that the company, by playing his records for public entertainment without paying him for the privilege, has been depriving him of profits to which he is entitled, was taken under advisement by President Judge Harry S. McDevitt in Common Pleas Court No. 1 today.

New York faced definitely last night the prospect of a strike of its light and power services when the Queens local of the Brotherhood of Utility Employes voted through its emergency committee to declare a walkout against the Queens Light and Power Company.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12. -- Pittsburgh's football team, usually successful enough in other climes, proposes to end its California losing streak Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Wholesale prices in the first week of December continued to advance, the Bureau of Labor statistics announced today. The index on Dec. 7, based on 1926 averages, was 80.9, compared with 80.8 on Nov. 30 and 76.7 on Dec. 8 the year before.

Placing human beings in a state of suspended animation for long periods of time, thus making possible the stretching out of a normal life span over a period of centuries, may become one of "the realities of tomorrow," it was predicted last night by Dr. Alexis Carrel, Nobel Prize winning biologist of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

The American Civil Liberties Union, in letters sent last night to Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine, charged two uniformed patrolmen with entering a private home "without authority" on Wednesday afternoon to break up an orderly meeting of Stuyvesant High School students.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Confronted with a decrease in tolls and with a continuing yearly decline in collections through alleged "manipulation" of tonnage computations of ships using the waterway, Colonel J. L. Schley, Governor of the Panama Canal, in his annual report today for the fiscal year 1935 urged that legislation be enacted to provide a single unit system based on the Panama Canal rules of tonnage measurements.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended Dec. 7 showed an increase of 13 per cent over the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain compares with a rise of 17 per cent for the week concluding Nov. 30.

Trenton, N.J., will be in the market within the next two weeks with two new issues of bonds aggregating $1,903,000. On Dec. 23 the city will consider bids for a new issue of $903,000 of water, street and public works bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1935, and maturing on Dec. 1, 1936 to 1975.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -Princeton University's intercollegiate sports program was operated at a loss of $16,445.51 during the fiscal year ending last June 30, the annual financial report of the Princeton Athletic Association, released today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager, reveals.

CARNERA was through with the sixth round. Baer had enough by the third and the referee stepped in to save the petrified Levinsky before the first three minutes were up. Actually, all three were licked before Joe Louis had laid a glove on them. The Detroit Disintegrator withered them where they stood in their corner.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 12. -- A voluntary petition in bankruptcy, under the amended Bankruptcy Act, admitting inability to meet $24,958,992 in matured and maturing obligations, was filed in Federal court today by the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway.
Selling of apartment houses in scattered sections of Manhattan and the Bronx featured realty activity in the city yesterday.

I read with close attention your editorial on the recommended minimum wage schedules and regulations for waitresses and Grier Bartol's letter of comment published Dec. 9. Mr. Bartol was of assistance to the Wage Board in its study of conditions in the hotel and restaurant industries.

The world's most powerful atomsmashing "gun," which will hurl atomic projectiles with energies of 15,000,000 volts, and will be capable of building up voltages as high as 20,000,000, will be installed tomorrow in the Columbia University physics laboratories.

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- Reaffirming his belief in universal fingerprinting, Governor Lehman allowed his own prints to be taken today in the presence of Walter N. Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction.

Directors of the Midland Steel Products Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents on the common and another of 50 cents on the $2 non-cumulative stock. This is the first dividend on either stock since Jan. 1, 1932, when 75 cents was paid on the common shares and 50 cents on the $2 issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Regular airplane passenger and mail service calling for four round trips a week between the United States, Ireland and London, with connections at London for complete roundthe-world flights, will begin in the Summer of 1937 and possibly some months earlier, under plans developed during a week's conversations which closed today.

John Murray, 36 years old, son of Thomas F. Murray, former Deputy Controller and until recently Tammany leader in the upper West Harlem district, was lodged in the Tombs yesterday on an indictment specifically charging that he defrauded a woman of $200 by pretending he would obtain a concession for her in Jones Beach State Park from Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

In the Caprice Room of the Weylin last night the third of a series of Thursday dinner dances was held under the direction of Miss Aurelie Murchison and her committee of members of the younger set. Committee members and their friends were hosts and hostesses at several dinner parties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Frank B. McElhill, New York tax consultant, and two former officials of the Bureau of Internal Revenue were convicted by a jury in District Supreme Court today on an indictment charging them with conspiracy to defraud the government.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- The Chamber of Deputies and the Senate adopted exceptional procedure today to permit the Laval government to rush discussion of the budget in the hope of getting it voted on before the new year.

The share market displayed a sagging tendency throughout the entire trading period yesterday. Pressure was not especially insistent, although the volume on the Stock Exchange remained above 2,000,000 shares; the closing was steady, with the setbacks ranging from small fractions to a point or two.

GENEVA, Dec. 12. -- Anthony Eden of Great Britain proposed today, and his proposal was adopted, that the League of Nations Council be called next Wednesday to hear "a full statement' of the Hoare-Laval peace plan and "determine as and when it sees fit what course it would wish to pursue in the light of the situation thus created."

In a setting of ermine, orchids and the severe black and white of evening dress the much-heralded Franco-American international bridge match between the Four Aces team and a French quartet which holds the European championship got under way amid great confusion last night at Essex House.

The Earl of Carnarvon, C. S. Forester, author; Raymond Massey, actor; Miss Mary Ellis, actress; Mr. and Mrs. W. T. Whalen and Dr. and Mrs. J. H. Jones are among the passengers due today from England and France on the CunardWhite Star liner Aquitania.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet today, but the undertone was firm. British funds were scarcely altered. Japanese and German issues were better in the foreign group. International securities recovered as a result of advices from the United States, but they weakened later from profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Striking back at critics of the reciprocal trade agreement with Canada, Secretary Hull declared in a letter to Senator Costigan made public today that when misapprehensions were cleared away it would be evident that "wise, prudent, and well-considered action" had been taken.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Raymond B. Fosdick, attorney, identified for many years with Rockefeller interests, has been elected president of the Rockefeller Foundation and of the General Education Board, it was announced yesterday at the foundation's offices.

For several months Victor Koussow had gone about his menial tasks in the School of Dental and Oral Surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, stoopshouldered, glaring malevolently at his superiors from behind his goldrimmed glasses.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 12 (AP). -A Federal Court jury tonight convicted "Grocer" George W. Norris of Alva, Okla., of perjury, after deliberating six and one-half hours. The maximum penalty is five years' confinement and a $2,000 fine.

Announcement of a thirty-sixgame schedule for the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League was made yesterday, the league action starting Saturday night, Dec. 21, and continuing through Feb. 22, with games each Saturday night in both Squadron A Armory in Manhattan and Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn.

William J. Ehrich, 32 years old, a broker, who lived at 125 East Seventysecond Street, leaped to his death late yesterday afternoon from a room on the fifteenth floor of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, where he had registered yesterday morning.

MADRID, Dec. 12. -- President Niceto Alcala Zamora put himself in an embarrassing position today. He is Leftist and his political sympathies apparently influenced him to act contrary to his constitutional prerogatives when he charged Miguel Maura, an extreme Left Wing politician, to form a national union government to conduct the general election.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The market for hogs showed an easy undertone here today, the decline of around one-half cent a pound in fresh pork loins in the local market in the last week greatly curtailing purchases by smaller packers who operate heavily in fresh meats.

Holiday item: Lucienne Boyer is coming in from the road, bringing another "Continental Varieties" to the Masque on Dec. 26. There she will remain at least a week, accompanied by Georges Andre Martin, master of ceremonies; Pils and Tabet, singers; Helen Gray, comedienne and dancer; Paal and Lief Rocky (Les Rocky) and Iza Volpin's Continental Quartet.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The experiences of American business men under the New Deal were described before an audience of British business men yesterday by H. Gordon Selfridge, American-born owner of a London department store, who returned last month from a visit to his native land.

Plans are under way among members of the New York Yacht Club to form a new one-design class to take the place of the famous thirtyfooters in the future. The start may be made this Winter, with some of the craft in the water and racing next Summer.

Aldo Nadi, called by European experts the virtuoso of the sword, a marvel of speed, grace and precision, made his American debut last night before a capacity attendance in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. Throughout his performance with the foil and saber, applause resounded for the efforts of this member of a famous Italian fencing family.

The Rangers trailed their New York rivals, the Americans, well into the third period of their game at Madison Square Garden last night. Then Cecil Dillon brought about a tie to send the teams into overtime and in the extra session the Blue Shirts whipped three fast scores past Roy Worters to gain a generally unlooked for 5-to-2 triumph.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 12. -Committees in twenty-four States today interviewed candidates for nominations to Rhodes scholarships, with each State committee nominating two men. The committees of the remaining States will meet tomorrow and Saturday to complete the list of nominations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission tried with little success today to link up the stock transactions of two important Wall Street men with the operations of Michael J. Meehan, who is defending himself against an SEC action to debar him from trading on the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade on charges of illegal manipulation of stocks.

Rough drafts of the new form of the Securities and Exchange Commission intended for the use of listed companies in filing periodical information have been received by several houses in Wall Street, and in almost every case complaint has been voiced as to the involved questionnaire incorporated in the form.

ROME, Dec. 12. -- Premier Mussolini spent almost the entire day wrestling with the Franco-British peace proposals submitted to him yesterday. He has not yet sought the advice of any other member of the Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A candidate for President and a full Congressional ticket will be put in the field next year by the leaders of the Townsend old-age pension movement.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 12. -- After an interval of three days, play was resumed in the chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam at the Military Casino tonight.

Conversation over the coffee cups at luncheon eventually drifted around to the subject of Pennsylvania's three-day season on antlerless deer which opened yesterday morning. Four of the five sportsmen at the table discussed the topic from numerous angles while the fifth, a man of long experience in the field, listened thoughtfully.

Both room rentals and restaurant sales continued to improve in local hotels last month, Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., accountants and auditors, reported yesterday. Room rentals showed a gain of 12.49 per cent and restaurant sales an increase of 17.14 per cent, compared with November, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Abandoning the policy of buying silver largely in London, the Treasury has transferred its purchasing operations to a number of other markets, Secretary Morgenthau revealed today.

Trailing by fifty-four points at the end of the fifteenth inning, Erwin Rudolph staged a slow, uphill battle, in which strategy played an important part, and turned back the challenge of Charles Seaback in the world's pocket billiard championship at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -The Yale swimming team, regarded as the strongest in Yale history and most formidable in the East, next week will begin its season without league affiliation.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Nearly 100 peers in scarlet and ermine robes acquitted on a charge of manslaughter their young fellow-peer Lord de Clifford.
Universal's film of E. Phillips Oppenheim's "The Great Impersonation" opens today at the Roxy. Edmund Lowe, Valerie Hobson and Wera Engels are its principal players.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- An agreement between the government and utility holding companies on a few cases to be fought out in obtaining a rapid determination of the constitutionality of the Public Utility Act of 1935 appeared remote today after Attorney General Cummings said he thought "such negotiations would be entirely futile."
Joe Louis's campaign for the world's heavyweight title tonight heads into boxing's immovable object, Paulino Uzcudun.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- Winning favorites were hard to find at the Fair Grounds today, where a heavy track prevailed, the victory of Speed Limit in the featured Onyx Purse marking the fifth consecutive defeat of a public choice. Carrying the colors of W. J. Miller, Speed Limit scored by a length and a half under the handling of G. Miller, and returned $27.20 for $2 in the mutuels.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -Scoring two goals in the overtime period, Princeton's sextet gained its second straight victory tonight, downing the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, 6 -- 4, at Baker Rink.

ROME, Dec. 12. -- Premier Mussolini, intent on driving a good bargain for Ethiopian peace, was represented in responsible quarters tonight as satisfied with the main outlines of the Franco-British proposal to end the conflict.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- In another blast at college football this afternoon, Professor George Owen, naval architect of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, branded the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena, Calif., "a racket" in which the $1,000,000 gate goes in the hands of a few promoters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The formal plan for the proposed union of the Methodist Episcopal Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church South, and the Methodist Protestant Church into a consolidated "Methodist Church" with a membership of more than 7,200,000 was made public here today by Rev. Dr. Harry E. Woolever, secretary of a joint commission representing the three major branches of Methodism.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The Japanese thesis of a "common upper limit" was torn to tatters in the five-power naval conference today. Nothing is left of it but a vague outline, and already there is a tendency, to which even the Japanese are adapting themselves, to seek some other solution.

Formation of the National Institute of Wine and Spirits Distributers, Inc., a federation of State and city wholesale associations, was announced here yesterday by Joseph Triner, president of the Illinois Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association and president of the new group.

TORONTO, Dec. 12. -- Sir Francis Floud, British High Commissioner to Canada, warned Canadians tonight that the Dominion "is in serious danger of permanently losing the British and European grain markets if the present situation is not put right."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The State of Louisiana defended before the Supreme Court today its 2 per cent tax on the gross income of larger newspapers from advertising, which Senator Long jammed through the Legislature in July, 1934.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 12. -- Governor Floyd B. Olson, the subject of many attacks in the weekly paper of the murdered Walter W. Liggett, today asked the Department of Justice to cooperate in the investigation of the crusading editor's death.

ATHENS, Dec. 12. -- Major Nicholas Zezas, Director of Secret Police, who personally arrested Republican leaders under the regency of Marshal George Kondylis and who reported many anti-monarchists for deportation, today was removed from his post.

The scrapping of the stall starting gate on New York tracks looms as a possibility for 1936 as the result of action taken by the Jockey Club yesterday in appointing a committee of stewards and members "to consider the method of starting." The committee is under the chairmanship of Joseph E. Widener, one of the stewards, and includes his fellow-stewards, John E. Cowdin and George H. Bull.

Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, widow of Reginald C. Vanderbilt, will not apply for maintenance and support of her 11-year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, according to her attorney, who announced yesterday that Mrs. Vanderbilt planned to give up her house here and take an apartment near her shop in East Fifty-fourth Street.

Opposition to the New Deal having become more vocal and violent with every hour that brings nearer the voters' referendum in 1936, the President's surprise at the warmth of the greeting he received from Cardinal Mundelein on Monday must have been an unusually pleasant one.

Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois declared on his return from Russia yesterday that the Soviets had unquestionably dishonored explicit pledges made during recognition of negotiations two years ago and the subsequent debt discussions which fell through.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12. -- At his Via Vizcaya home, Maurice Fatio was host tonight to a small group for dinner, guests including Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C. P. Wichfeld, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Mrs. Quentin F. Feitner and J. Cordon Douglas.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased $3,287,136 from the previous week, said the bank's weekly statement today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $2,925,720. The statement follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Several millions of $1 silver certificates of the new type authorized by the Treasury are being distributed to banks throughout the United States through the Federal Reserve and will be available to the public next Wednesday, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Discrepancies in statements by the motorman of the Third Avenue elevated train and the flagman of the work train into which it crashed Wednesday night at the 125th Street station caused Miles M. O'Brien, Assistant District Attorney, to order the arrest of both on manslaughter charges yesterday.

An extra police detail of 1,252 men has been assigned to duty in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden and in Harlem for the Louis-Paulino bout tonight. This number is exclusive of detectives and traffic patrolmen.
TORONTO, Dec. 12. -- Amid a cross-fire of college yells the University of Toronto defeated Yale in an international hockey game at Varsity Stadium tonight, 7 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings, taking advantage of scoring chances and playing a great defensive game, dealt the Chicago Black Hawks their first defeat of the National Hockey League season on home ice, 3 to 1, tonight, before a crowd of 8,500 in the Chicago Stadium.
Aldous Huxley is calling his new novel "Eyeless in Gaza." It is now announced for publication here next Spring by Harper.

The regulation in the New York traffic ordinances which gives to policemen on duty at points where there are traffic lights the right to direct traffic contrary to the lights is a direct means of educating drivers into contempt for the signals.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- No pretense of activity appeared on the floor of the Boerse today. The total stagnation that has been characteristic of the market for several weeks is being continued, with no evidence even of passing interest in the rare quotations that are made.

Bank clearings of twenty-two leading cities in the country for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., were $5,136,378,000. This compares with $4,769,049,000 a year ago, an increase of 7.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Escorted by five admirals, Secretary Claude A. Swanson of the Navy conducted a complicated manoeuvre in President Roosevelt's office today in an effort to obtain larger allowances for the naval reserve, so as to put reservists on a pay basis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -Cottonseed crushed from Aug. 1 to Nov. 30, was reported today by the Census Bureau as 1,956,763 tons, compared with 1,768,296 in the corresponding four months a year ago. Cottonseed on hand at mills on Nov. 30 amounted to 886,804 tons, compared with 1,237,720 the year before.

The real estate division set up by the State Insurance Department to handle the sale of properties for title and mortgage companies under its supervision has made eightyfour sales for an amount aggregating about $3,000,000, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, reported yesterday ata meeting of the brokerage division of the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

Conflicting price trends among the more active speculative issues characterized bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Those interested in the strictly high-grade investment bonds, in the meantime, were more concerned with the heavy supply of new offerings than with listed issues with the result that United States Government and other giltedged issues moved within a narrow price range in light volume.

At holiday large families seem often to be blessed with abundant joy. When the children are small there is all the fun of the tree and the Santa Claus legend. When the youngsters grow up, there is the happiness of reunion from separate homes. It is easy to understand the strength of family loyalty and love when one reads the story of many of the Neediest Cases.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The brilliant young actress, Flora Robson, added another fine portrait to her distinguished gallery of stage interpretations tonight in the title role of Wilfred Grantham's "Mary Tudor."
Engagements of $2,202,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday, of which $1,044,000 was taken in England and $1,158,000 in Canada.

The final Government estimate places the 1935 cotton crop at 10,734,000 bales. This is a reduction of 407,000 bales below the estimate for Nov. 1, and of 1,064,000 bales below that for Aug. 1. The 1935 crop on this basis will still be 1,098,000 bales larger than the actual crop of 1934, but with that exception it is the smallest in twelve years.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 12. -- Helen Hayes returned after four years to Gilbert Miller's management tonight in the first American performance of "Victoria Regina," Laurence Housman's play based on the reign of Queen Victoria. The first-night audience taxed the capacity of the Auditorium Theatre to see the play, which goes to Washington next week and is due in New York on Dec. 26.

Mrs. George F. Breen gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Her guests were Mrs. Matthew J. Carney, Mrs. Bradford Ellsworth, Mrs. Ralph R. Browning, Mrs. Raymond De Voe, Mrs. James McKenna, Mrs. Frank Heller, Mrs. Joseph Higgins and Mrs. Frederick Fisher.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $3,397,823 after all deductions. This was equivalent to 53 cents a share on 6,399,002 common shares.

Two new exhibitions open today at the Brooklyn Museum -- one of modern European woodcuts, the other of school research work executed by visiting classes in the museum galleries and work rooms as background studies in school subjects.

The city will begin next year a systematic campaign to close "forever" all old-law tenements not complying with the stringent amendments to the multiple dwelling law, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, announced yesterday at the midWinter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A $125,000 Bronx housing project was included in the building plans filed yesterday, as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The fifty-sixth annual Charity Ball presented a pageant of "Yesteryear -a Touch of the Past" tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford. Participants in the chorus and specialty dances were all members of the younger social set and the four beneficiaries included the Babies' Hospital, Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Jefferson Hospital and the University of Pennsylvania Hospital.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of New Jersey, criticized yesterday the Democratic Nations Committee, of which he is vice chairman, for its lackadaisical support of President Roosevelt in the face of a barrage of criticism by political opponents.
A $125,000 Bronx housing project was included in the building plans filed yesterday, as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The fifty-sixth annual Charity Ball presented a pageant of "Yesteryear -a Touch of the Past" tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford. Participants in the chorus and specialty dances were all members of the younger social set and the four beneficiaries included the Babies' Hospital, Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Jefferson Hospital and the University of Pennsylvania Hospital.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of New Jersey, criticized yesterday the Democratic Nations Committee, of which he is vice chairman, for its lackadaisical support of President Roosevelt in the face of a barrage of criticism by political opponents.

The second in a series of subscription dances was held last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was featured by a special program of entertainment. Several dinners were given by young married couples, debutantes of former years and their friends.

Rudy Vallee will appear in George White's "Scandals" when that revue opens at the New Amsterdam Theatre here on Christmas night, it was determined yesterday at a conference of Mr. Vallee, Hymen Bushel, his lawyer, and A. L. Berman, attorney for Mr. White.

In a competition which included several widely known interior decorators, Miss Mary L. Faithorn, of Sunnyside, Queens, a 28-year-old receptionist at Rockefeller Center, received the first prize for the bestdecorated Christmas tree in the annual Christmas show of the Gardens of the Nations yesterday at Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

A stubborn two-alarm blaze early yesterday morning in a Bowery building occupied by diamond dealers caused tie-ups of the Third Avenue elevated and trolley line and impeded traffic to and from the Manhattan Bridge. A special police guard was thrown around the structure, which houses gems valued at between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann, convicted of the murder of the Lindbergh baby, was sentenced to death today for the second time. The execution was set for the week of Jan. 13.

The United States liner Washington had loaded 21,500 sacks of mail yesterday at 4:30 P.M. in preparation for her sailing today noon, and with the volume of Christmas mail that generally reaches an American mail ship of her size prior to her departure, a new record for transatlantic carryings was expected last night.
