Following the successful experiment of last Summer, when the women's and men's national outdoor tennis championships were combined in one tournament at Forest Hills, the United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday that the same procedure will be followed for the indoor championships.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 13. -- With the chess championship of the world almost within his grasp, Dr. Max Euwe of this city attained a total of 15 points in his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the titleholder, when he succeeded in drawing the twenty-ninth and semi-final game of their long match at the Military Casino today.

Brooklyn Local, 102, of the Brotherhood of Utility Employes prepared last night at a meeting of some 500 members at 307 Washington Street to support the threatened strike of electric light and power employes in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Additional corporation reports, filed as confidential with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which, after hearings, the commission made public today, included that of the Standard Oil Company of California, showing aggregate remuneration of officers and directors in the last fiscal year.

Ignoring the objections of two members of the Board of Estimate, Park Commissioner Moses, the Park Association and numerous civic groups, Mayor La Guardia caused the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly to adopt a local bill yesterday which would put a ferry approach through the middle of Chisholm Park in Queens.

Because of the form in which the question has been put, the most interesting aspect of the straw vote now being taken by The Literary Digest is a comparison between the present poll and a similar one taken in March and April, 1934. On that earlier occasion voters were asked whether they "approved on the whole" the policies of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S first year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Princeton University conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws upon the Right Honorable and Most Reverend William Temple, Archbishop of York and Primate of England, in a special convocation this afternoon in the Princeton University chapel.

Organized labor is represented on the reorganized employe complaint appeals board of the Works Progress Administration, it was announced yesterday by Daniel S. Ring, Assistant WPA Administrator for New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Through a New York financier and a Chicago referee in bankruptcy, the government sought at the SEC hearing today to show that Michael J. Meehan, Wall Street trader, engineered an artificial rise in Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock last Spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today reports of salaries of officers and directors of companies registered with it. About 200 companies have filed certain information, arguing that it should be held "confidential" Overruling this plea, the commission is now making it public.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 13. -- The complication of football rivalry with the latest dramatic production of Paul Green, Pulitzer Prize winner, has started a sharp controversy in this State. Mr. Green's play, "The Enchanted Maze," had its premiere at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill last week before an audience of 1,100, and dissent over its quality and propriety began before the final curtain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Still trying to construct a chain of circumstantial evidence againch Michael J. Meehan, whom it hopes to force from trading on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade, the Securities and Exchange Commission today introduced the list of transactions in Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Controller of the Currency announced today that agreements had been reached out of court whereby four suits involving the right of the government to priority over other depositors in withdrawing funds from banks in receivership will be dropped.

TSINGTAO, Dec. 13. -- "Everything is quiet at present in Tsingtao and we expect to remain quiet if Governor Han Fu-chu makes a wise decision. We anticipate he will decide shortly after the new year to have Shantung join the Northern autonomy movement.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, issued a statement yesterday regarding reports that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York had protested to President Roosevelt against his appointment because of his connection with the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company.

The weight of real estate taxes was denounced as a danger to schools and essential government services, and a coming labor shortage was predicted yesterday at the closing sessions of the midwinter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mrs. Madeline Roetger, 50 years old, widow of Richard C. Roetger, former banker and music patron, was found dead of illuminating gas poisoning in the kitchen of the three-room apartment she occupied with her son, Russell Roetger, at 1 Bank Street, at 1:30 P.M. yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- The Franco-British proposals for solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, made public in Rome late this evening, created an excellent impression on Italian public opinion. Although they follow the lines every one expected, they are considered rather more favorable to Italy than it was generally believed they would be.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mich., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Flying Cadet Maxwell H. Crowell, 22, a pilot in the Ninety-fourth Pursuit Squadron of the Army Air Corps, was killed in the crash of his pursuit plane near here this afternoon after the plane had clipped the roof of a Grand Trunk caboose and hurled him from the cockpit.
MONTREAL, Dec. 13. -- McGill University defeated Yale, 10 -- 0, at hockey tonight. The Redmen scored two goals in the first period, four in the second and four in the fourth.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Lord de Clifford, acquitted on a charge of manslaughter by his peers in the House of Lords yesterday, will be put on trial in Old Bailey in January on a charge of dangerous driving. The peer was tried by his fellow-peers only for manslaughter, which is a felony.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The government has nearly $30,000,000 worth of postoffices and other Federal buildings under construction in New York State, Treasury figures showed today. Contracts for $10,000,000 more will be awarded soon.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Cornell's sharp-shooting basketball team overpowered the University of Toronto five, 54-29, in opening its 1935-36 campaign in the Drill Hall today.

Moderate advances were made by most commodity futures in light trading on the local markets yesterday. Only silk and cocoa futures were lower. On the cash markets, all the grains, cotton, butter tin rose, while cocoa silk and lard declined, the latter to a new low.

A memorial service for Dr. Clement C. Moore, author of the immortal children's poem, "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 434 West Twentieth Street, near Ninth Avenue, where he was the first secretary and clerk of the vestry.

Senator Borah, it appears, is terribly afraid of what he thinks is likely to happen to Ethiopia. "If the proposed plan to dismember Ethiopia is consummated," he says, "it leaves Mussolini the most powerful figure in Europe. He will have brought Great Britain and France to his terms -- securing more than he in the beginning asked.

The historical marker recently erected in City Hall Park states "old Dutch Vlagte (flat), or pasture, later called the Common." Where can one find in any authoritative history this place referred to as "Common"? Part of the property was owned by the commonalty, but in all books and other historical printings I have always seen this property designated as the Fields.

"Broadway Hostess," latest of the Warner-First National musical films, begins a run this morning at the Strand. Winifred Shaw has the leading role, assisted by Lyle Talbot, Allen Jenkins and Spring Byington.
In the first tax sale held by Jersey City since 1928 the city bought in yesterday all except seventy of 600 parcels offered at the sale held in the Assembly Chamber in the City Hall.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 13. -- Following another mishap to a De Havilland-86 airliner in Australia, the Commonwealth government suspended tonight certificates of air worthiness for the remaining seven machines of that type in the country pending an investigation.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13. -- Lucky Turn made her fifth start at the Fair Grounds track today a winning one when she came on toward the end of the Maryland Purse with a surprising burst of speed to score by five lengths at the handsome odds of $33 for $2 in the mutuels.
The Spelman Fund of New York made grants aggregating $537,250 for activities in public administration during 1934, according to a report made public yesterday.

KALGAN, Chahar Province, Saturday, Dec. 14. -- The populace and Chinese soldiery of this gateway to China's Northwest gaped in silent wonderment today as a small detachment of Japanese troops peacefully invaded the city.

"I recently sent a dollar to your Fund out of my allowance. However, I have been ill this week and the money which I was to have spent on lunches remains unspent. Since your Fund is behind that of other years, I should like to add my bit again."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Civil aircraft is leading in value the exports from the United States of arms, ammunition and implements of war, if the character of licenses granted for this business from Oct. 10 to Nov. 30 inclusive is to be taken as a criterion.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- The naval conference decided today before adjourning over the week-end to change the method of its deliberations. The Japanese demand for naval parity, which is the crucial matter with which the conference has to deal, is now before it and has been dissected from every angle.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13. -- As wheat prices jumped here today the quotations on flaxseed soared 13 3/4 cents as a result of the government's unexpected decree last night establishing minimum prices of 10 and 14 pesos a quintal respectively. The market experienced the wildest day in many months.

MIAMI, Dec. 13. -- Glimpses of the immediate future in both civil and military aviation were given here today at the annual air races at the Municipal Airport and the airline maintenance conference of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, held concurrently and closing today.

Displaying the best form that it has shown this season, the St. John's University five registered its fourth straight victory by turning back the Savage School quintet, 48 -- 12, in the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

An Associated Press dispatch from Anchorage, Alaska, described, the other day, some of the difficulties encountered by pilots who undertake to fill shopping orders by airplane for dwellers in the far interior. The town of Fairbanks, however, appears to be very much in the swim.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The physical wealth of the nation will be increased at least $5,000,000,000 as the result of the construction now being carried out under the Work Relief program, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, estimated today.

The unbeaten La Salle Academy quintet brought to an end the winning streak of the St. Peter's High team of Staten Island, scoring by 23 -- 21, at the Goddard Gymnasium in the tone Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. contest yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The desirability of cooperation between the Federal Government and the States in enforcing uniform legislation dealing with reorganizations, particularly in the real estate field, was stressed today by Saul S. Streit, chairman of the New York State Legislative Committee, who came here to discuss the problem with William O. Douglas, director of the protective committee study of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec 13. -- An unexpected over-night announcement that the Argentine Government would buy all the new crop wheat offered by growers in that country at a price equal to 89 1/2 cents a bushel, figured at current rates of exchange, threw the world's markets into a turmoil today.

BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- John F. Condon, "Jafsie" of the Lindbergh case, declared today that though he has declined offers of from $10,000 to $250,000 to intercede for Bruno Richard Hauptmann he still does not want to see the German carpenter go to the electric chair.

Harlem branch of the Socialist party has aligned itself with the Norman Thomas left-wing group, it was announced yesterday by the City Central Committee backed by the Thomas faction. The announcement said that Frank R. Crosswaith, Negro leader, made the motion which put the branch on record behind Mr. Thomas.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13. -- As the third year of the second five-year plan draws to a close all indications are that the Soviet Union has not only overfulfilled its annual industrial program but is well on the way to carrying out this five-year plan in four years.

THE HISTORY OF AMERICAN SAILING SHIPS" (Norton, $7.50) was seemingly designed for professional experts and post-graduate hobbyists only. The author, Howard D. Chappelle, is a naval architect. His book is authoritative, complete, a monument of research. It is filled with building plans and the exact measurements of long-rotted ships. There is hardly a "charm line" in it.

TRENTON, Dec. 13. -- Leaders of the Republican majority in the Senate and Assembly decided in conference with Governor Hoffman today that a special session of the 1935 Legislature was not necessary at this time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Denial that the Tennessee Valley Authority is a government yardstick to which all privately owned hydroelectric utilities must by mandate conform was set forth in a brief presented by Attorney Genera Cummings to the Supreme Court today in advance of next Thursday's argument on the TVA.

Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, former colonel in the Ethiopian Army and known here as "Harlem's Black Eagle," returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania and told reporters on board the ship that he had shaken the dust of Ethiopia off his feet forever.

The public will have its first opportunity today to see the altar piece by Filippo Lippi which the Metropolitan Museum of Art purchased from the collection of J.P. Morgan. Temporarily the painting by the fifteenth-century Florentine artist will hang in the museum's room of recent accessions.

George Graham, alias Guy Adams, who, it is charged, collected $30,000 from more than 100 persons in 1931 for a vacation in the West, and then disappeared with the money, has been arrested by the police of Cincinnati and is being returned to New York, it was disclosed yesterday.

The preservation of "a liberal civilization" is dependent upon the work of social organizations in opposition to the forces of communism and fascism, according to the Rev. Dr. J.V. Moldenhawer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, who addressed the directors and several hundred sponsors of the Young Women's Christian Association yesterday at a luncheon in Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The liquidation of Jewish-owned property in Germany continues at an increasing pace, and every issue of a Jewish paper here contains lists of Jewish enterprises that have gone over to "German" hands.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Carlos Ortiz Basualdo, wealthy Argentine, who broke up the dancing team of Maurice and Hughes when he wed Leonora Hughes in 1925, was drowned last night.

Yorkville Haberdashers, Inc., has leased a twelve-foot store in the building under construction on the former theatre site in Times Square, between Fort-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets. The reserved rentals total about $250,000, the Wood, Dolson Company, the broker, reports. The Broadway frontage of the strt/cture has been rented with the i exception of forty-one feet.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 13. -- A warning to the cotton planters of the South not to jeopardize the future of the AAA program by passing the hardships and inconveniences of crop control on to the backs of their tenants and sharecroppers has been issued here by Oscar Johnston, manager of the Federal Cotton Pool and special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury in matters of farm finance.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 13. -- Former President Plutarco Elias Calles suddenly returned to the Mexican capital this afternoon, arriving from Los Angeles by plane at 4:43.

Testifying before a special committee of the New York State Legislature this week, ARTHUR BALLANTINE, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, made out a strong case for the compulsory automobile compensation plan with which his name has long been connected.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Dec. 13. -- Open defiance of the AAA's potato allotment law by shippers and farmers of the lower Rio Grande Valley was threaten today as efforts to obtain stamps and containers to move the Fall potato crop under the law's provisions proved of no avail.

Outspoken criticism of the type advanced by Professor Owen will help to remove the wall of hypocrisy surrounding what he aptly terms the college football "racket." So patent are the facts of the situation that denial of Professor Owen's charge of general athletic commercialism seems to constitute a self-accusation of insincerity or incredible naivete.

The popularity of the New Deal shows a further decline in the fourth report of The Literary Digest's nation-wide poll. With a total of 642,711 votes in twenty-six States, 274,830 votes, or 42.76 per cent, are for the New Deal. There are 367,881, or 57.24 per cent, against it.

The Long Island University quintet accounted for its fifth straight victory of the season by crushing Dickinson College, 60 -- 25, last night. A capacity crowd of 1,500 watched the clash at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

MADRID, Dec. 13. -- Spain has been without a Cabinet for five days and nothing has happened to relieve President Niceto Alcala Zamora's problem because his Leftist sympathies restrain him from asking Jose Maria Gil Robles, leader of the Catholic Popular Action party, the strongest party in Parliament, to form a government.
BANGOR, Dec. 13. -- There seems to be no doubt that Maine is strongly against the New Deal, and will go Republican at the Presidential election next year.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Louis weighed 200 1/2 pounds and Paulino 207. The referee was Arthur Donovan and the judges Marty Monroe and Charlie Lynch. The fight by rounds follows:

Mrs. Antoinette Ptacek, 55 years old, was shot in the right forearm at 2:50 P.M. yesterday when she refused to hand over the day's meager receipts of her small candy store at 1,383 York Avenue, near Seventy-third Street, to two adolescent robbers.

The primary news this morning is of farewells -- not of hails. Three from the current list of attractions are scheduled to make their departures after this evening's performances, they being "A Touch of Brimstono." from the Golden Theatre; Eva Le Gallienne's repertory troupe, from the Shubert Theatre, and "Abide With Me," from the Ritz.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- Operations on the Boerse continued completely stagnant today. Mannesmann rose 1/8 point in the quiet industrial list. The weakness in the potash group lowered Westergeln 1 1/2 points and Aschesleben 1 point.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Damage to the new $10,000,000 Post-office Building, a section of which was swept by fire early today, was estimated by the National Parks Service, custodians of the structure, at $60,000. Other estimates ran almost ten times that high, but it will probably be weeks before the real extent of the damage to walls, floors and ceiling will be determined.

Charles H. George, 62 years old, a lawyer with about forty years' experience, took the stand in General Sessions yesterday in his own defense against a charge that he helped William F. Peterson, fugitive stock "expert," defraud investors in Peterson's deals to the extent of $516,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 13. -- Following the refusal of Attorney General Cummings today to assume charge of the investigation of the murder of Walter Liggett, crusading weekly newspaper publisher and editor, the State Attorney General's office late this afternoon took over direct supervision of the case.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- For two days a "Silver Jubilee in Regent Street" is being held at Hannah Penn House. At this annual holiday market, silver trinkets and fine linens are being offered. The proceeds will fill hundreds of Christmas baskets for the needy in this city The enterprise closes today.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bristol Turner gave a dinner last night in the Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stewart 3d, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Hasslacher, Mr. and Mrs. G. Griswold Frelinghuysen, Princess Daria Obolensky, Miss Muriel Smith, Burton Liese and Andre V. de Smolianinoff.

The wheat markets of the world yesterday furnished the thrills for speculators. Following the overnight announcement from Argentina that an agency there similar to the AAA in this country had lifted the price that it would pay farmers for wheat 37 cents a bushel to about 90 cents, the United States markets advanced their limit of 5 cents a bushel.

A gift of $500,000 in trust has been made by an anonymous donor jointly to the American Institute of Arts and Letters and to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, affiliated organizations located at 633 West 155th Street.

Nikita Balieff still makes friends and regiments of them were in the Continental Room of the Hotel St. Moritz on Thursday night to see the good-humored old boy unfold the latest incarnation of his "Chauve Souris" revue. Since he has cast numerous shows in the mold, there is reason to expect amusement from him -- and expectation is not in vain.

With the help of a sparkling 51-point run in the seventh frame James Caras of Wilmington, Del., won a close match from the veteran Bennie Allen of Kansas City, 125 to 96, in thirteen innings, at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday and jumped into the lead in the world's pocket billiard championship.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Victor Koussow, Russian laboratory worker who killed two professors, wounded a third and then committed suicide Thursday at the School of Dental and Oral Surgery, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, was examined by a lunacy commission in 1927 and pronounced sane, it was disclosed yesterday.

"This will never do," said JEFFREY. It will be said by millions of people in Europe and South America and the United States when they read the terms of peace suggested to Italy by Great Britain and France. These would treat Ethiopia as if she were already a conquered and prostrate country.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 13. -- The conference of Dominion and Provincial Prime Ministers closed today after coming to two important conclusions and failing of agreement on a more important issue.

Seven Atlantic liners will sail today for European ports carrying more than 4,500 passengers who will spend the Christmas holidays abroad. Seven other ships will sail with another 1,500 passengers for Southern and Pacific ports.

New business of all classes of insurance written by the forty-two companies having 83 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all United States legal-reserve companies was $700,059,000 in November, compared with $676,757,000 in the corresponding month last year, an increase of 3.4 per cent, according to a report filed yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents with the Department of Commerce.

The second metropolitan women's team vs. men's B team squash racquets match, held at the Junior League last night, resulted in a 4-3 victory for the women players, who were again profiting from a plus eight handicap. The event proved popular with a well-filled gallery.

HAVANA, Dec. 13. -- Jose A. Barnet, ad interim President since the resignation of Colonel Carlos Mendieta Wednesday, was sworn as Provisional President of this island republic at 12:40 P.M. today. Chief Justice Federico Edelman administered the oath in the presence of all members of the Supreme Court.

I was interested recently to read letter a THE NEW YORK TIMES written by Admiral Phelps under the caption of "Neutrality and Article XVI." This was apparently written as a criticism of Judge Manton's suggestion of "Neutrality as a Measure of Cooperation."

ALBANY, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Official confirmation that' Assemblyman-elect Philip J. Casey of Troy will be listed as a Democrat in the 1936 Legislature stirred speculation today as to whether the Democrats will invite him to join their caucus when the House is organized Jan. 1.

Fred (Firpo) Marberry, for twelve years a successful right hand pitcher in the American League and for part of the recent season an umpire in the same circuit, will wear a New York Giant uniform in 1936.

The address which the chairman of the Chase National Bank delivered at Houston covered a wide range of subjects. Mr. ALDRICH expressed satisfaction over certain aspects of the Banking Act of 1935, but for the most part his discussion of New Deal measures was highly critical.

Brooklyn Tech's sextet, holder of the title for the past three years, met with a stunning 1 -- 0 setback at the hands of New Utrecht as competition in the annual City Public Schools Athletic League championship hockey tournament got under way last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The first election to determine employe representation held under the direction of the National Labor Relations Board at the Wayne Knitting Mills, Fort Wayne, Ind., has resulted in 516 votes for the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, an A.F. of L. union, and 401 votes for the "Association for Employes for Representation of Employes Only."

The world silver markets continued yesterday to adjust themselves to the new policy of the United States Treasury which, in practice, appears to involve the purchase at declining prices of a small part of the silver offered for sale in London together with small purchases in New York and other markets.

The Winter season for errata hunters and others who delight in searching out queer quirks in monumental works opened officially yesterday with the issuance of the Manhattan Telephone Directory, Winter 1935-36.

The Harvard Club strengthened its hold on first place in the race for championship honors among the Class B teams in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by defeating the New York Athletic Club, 5 -- 0, on the latter's courts last night.
Since Nov. 26, 65,000 copies of Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient" have been printed, bringing the total to 185,000 copies. Translation rights have been sold in Sweden, Japan and Holland.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A reply to critics of Cardinal Hayes on the birth control issue was given last night from Station WLWL, the Paulist Radio Station, by the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bergh gave a reception with dancing yesterday afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza to introduce their daughter, Miss Jerry Bergh, to their lqew York friends. Miss Bergh had a preliminary coming out party, a dinner dance! last September in San Francisco, given by her grandmother, Mrs. Joseph Civelli, who with Mr. Civelli came to New York for the party yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Colonel James Joseph Meade, commander of the First Brigade of the Marine Force at Quantico, Va., and Colonel John Colt Beaumont, commander of the Fourth Regiment at Shanghai, were selected today for promotion to brigadier generals of the line in the Marine Corps. Colonel Russell B. Putnam, assistant paymaster, was selected for promotion to brigadier general in the Paymaster's Department.

A substantial falling off in the number of enrolled Republicans for this year as compared with 1934 and a slight increase in the Democratic enrollment were shown in the official figures for Manhattan and the Bronx made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Progress in negotiations for construction of a ship to replace the Leviathan was reported to President Roosevelt today by Secretary Roper.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Following the revolt of public opinion in Great Britain and elsewhere against the Hoare-Laval proposal for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian dispute, a similar strong reaction has begun in France.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13. -- Pittsburgh will attempt to square an old football debt tomorrow when its eleven meets Southern California at Memorial Coliseum.

Calm and quiet -- disturbed only by the appearance on schedule of Mike Mesko, the Rahway counterman who bolstered up the Dartmouth line in its failing moments against Princeton a few weeks back -- prevailed yesterday afternoon at the resumption at Essex House of the bridge match between the French team that holds the European championship and the Four Aces of the United States.

A committee representing holders of a mortgage certificate issued on the modern nine-story apartment house at 310 West Eighty-fifth Street have sold the building to an investing syndicate, it was announced yesterday. The new owners acquired the property for all cash, free and clear of mortgages.

Turf figures from many racing fronts arrived in New York yesterday, passed through, or departed, leaving in their wake much interesting information for discussion. As a result the probability for 1936 is that the Eastern racing season will get under way at Bowie on April 1, with the New York season to start at Jamaica on April 23.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- While butcher hogs generally sold at steady prices here today, the demand for lard types were slow because of the decline in the price of lard and sales were made at losses of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. It was reported that numerous heavy sows were carried over unsold.

Preliminary plans for the construction of a $50,000,000 free port in Jersey City were announced yesterday afternoon by a committee of the Foreign-Trade Zones Associates, a group of New York and New Jersey business and professional men, with offices at 74 Trinity Place.

A plea for modification of tariffs on Latin American goods and extension of foreign trade agreements to encourage exchange of products between the United States and the Latin American republics was made last night by D. Stewart Iglehart, president of W.R. Grace Co.

The Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts, the Reich Government agency that handles payments on German foreign obligations under the moratorium restrictions now in effect, announced here yesterday an offering to holders of certain maturing German dollar bonds to exchange their securities for new bonds or to receive payment in the form of "blocked" reichsmarks, which are restricted as to use and which can be converted into dollars only at a heavy discount.

Due largely to the unusual activity in the market for new tax-exempt securities, bond financing this week reached a total of $205,536,000, the fourth largest week of the year in dollar volume. This compares with $26,299,000 last week, and $22,512,400 a year ago.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $28,711,380, to be represented by 128 separate loans, compared with the revised total of $63,171,415 for this week. The weekly average for the year to date now stands at $26,657,757.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A mural painting in the McKinley High School library, opened for public inspection today, shows Senator Huey P. Long, with a halo over his head, in the center of a legislative group including Vice President Garner, Senator Borah, Speaker Byrns and Representative Snell.

A note of optimism was sounded in a talk on "New Trends in Women's Work" at Hunter College yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, Professor of Economics at the Connecticut College for Women, who made the first report on the WPA research project in which she has been engaged for six years for the Institute of Women's Professional Relations, of which she is director.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 13. -- In the series between tennis stars from Mexico and Texas for the cup donated by former President Abelardo Rodriguez, the local team took a 6-2 lead today.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 13. -- High Japanese officers formulated at a conference today their policy toward North China, involving an increase of Japanese Army forces in this area and close collaboration with the new semi-autonomous regime.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Under the title, "This'n That," the Newark Junior League presented their annual entertainment, for the benefit of the Colored Day Nursery, tonight at the Mutual Benefit Auditorium here. The show, which included the presentation of "Thirty-nine Steps," a British feature film several Walt Disney comedies and chorus numbers by members and children of members, will be repeated tomorrow afternoon and evening.

Directors of the Chicago River Indiana Railroad declared yesterday a distribution of $3,000,000 out of accumulated funds of the last four or five years. This is the first payment since 1929, when $2,500,000 was distributed. The New York Central owns all of the railroad's stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The administration is considering plans to raise the strength of the Naval Reserve to about 150,000, compared with the present total of 20,000 to 25,000 men, President Roosevelt made known today.

Ernest Schelling, who has conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts for children and young people for the last eleven years, yesterday disclosed the general outline for the six Saturday morning concerts for this season at Carnegie Hall.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Resolutions supporting the St. Lawrence seaway and power development project and opposing the Federal Potato Control Act and trade treaty with Canada were adopted tonight at closing sessions of the New York State Grange.
Mayor La Guardia was criticized yesterday by Norman Thomas and other liberals for planning to appear at an Italian-American mass meeting in Madison Square Garden tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- For failure to file reports with the State Tax Commission in the last three years some 37,000 stock corporations face the loss of their charters unless they comply within six months with rules and regulations of the corporation bureau of the Secretary of State's office.

A supper dance with tickets at bargain prices and some 200 subscribers garbed in depression-inspired costumes was held last night at the Sherry-Netherland. In the words of Alexander Auchmuty Phillips, organizer and chairman, the entertainment was given principally for the benefit of fun and was entitled "The Starving Four Hundred Party."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- Drama by Henrik Ibsen, music by Jean Sibelius and a stage design inspired by Rockwell Kent's Arctic color combine to make a Norse holiday in the Experimental Theatre at Vassar College this week-end.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Criticism and support were expressed in the West and Southwest tonight on the Southeastern Conference decision to give its college athletes direct financial aid.

Joe Louis, Detroit's sensational Brown Bomber of the ring, battered Paulino Uzcudun, rugged Basque woodchopper of another day, into a technical knockout defeat last night in the fourth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden before an overflow crowd of 20,000 fight enthusiasts, who paid gross receipts of $128,394 for the show.

TIENTSIN, Saturday, Dec. 14. -- Japanese action to open a new rail gateway from Manchuria to North China was reported last night by a reliable source. It was said the Japanese had already begun the construction of an entirely new line from Jehol City to Tungchow, the capital of Yin Ju-keng's autonomous area of Hopei Province, which is only twelve miles from Peiping.

GENEVA, Dec. 13. -- Excerpts from the Ethiopian note, signed by Wolde Mariam, Ethiopian Minister to France, in reply to the Hoare-Laval peace proposal for the settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy, follow:

Your correspondent G.M. Dillard, referring to incomes in 1934, presents a subject vital to wealth, capital, business, and practically all of 125,000,000 people that are employed by them. The depletion your correspondent refers to is particularly that of the Roosevelt administration, but he is also mindful of the fact that it did not originate with NRA.

The opportunity so generously provided by Mr. Roosevelt to aspirants for the Republican Presidential nomination is evidently making them a little careless. Colonel Knox and Hamilton Fish have assured Western farmers that they would be quite as well treated by the Republican party as by President Roosevelt.

Sweeping all the first places in the free-style events, including the 400-yard relay which concluded the program and determined the eventual victor, Fordham University's varsity swimming team opened its 1935-36 schedule at the C.C.N.Y. pool last night by conquering City College in their annual dual meet, 41 to 30.
Fifty sportsmen, members of the Wilderness Club, assembled the other night to pay a distinctive tribute to one of their number, Fred G. Carnochan of New City, N.Y.

With consumers showing the greatest willingness to spend that has been witnessed in any holiday season in the past five years, retail sales figures rose sharply throughout the country last week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The 100th anniversary of the birth of Phillips Brooks was observed yesterday at the Hall of Fame on the uptown campus of New York University at exercises participated in by Bishop William T. Manning of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on a motion by Henry Ward Beer, representing the State Banking Department, to dismiss a petition by the Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company of Mineola, L.I., seeking reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

GENEVA, Dec. 13. -- The following is the text of the letter of Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Premier Pierre Laval of France to Joseph A. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, forwarding the Fraco-British peace proposals:

A declaration that policy gambling is widespread among hospital attaches, patients and PWA workers on Welfare Island was made yesterday by Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson, who appeared as the prosecutor in one of the cases tried in Special Sessions Court.

Apropos your editorial "Health Through the Ages," one might add that Moses not only was a public heath administrator of the very first rank but in addition he was the originator of personal, family and public hygiene and sanitation.

Joe Louis weighed more last night than in any of his previous major ring encounters. The Detroit Bomber tipped the scales at 200 1/2 pounds, six and one-half pounds lighter than Paulino Uzcudun, who weighed 207.
LONDON, Dec. 13. -- In an editorial condemning the Hoare-Laval plan for Ethiopian peace The London Times says:

Differences arising from the resentment of the Kings County November grand jury over Governor Lehman's order superseding it in the investigation of the murder of Samuel Druckman were well on the way to being ironed out yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Twenty-two football stars, drawn from nine States, will represent the West in the annual East-West charity game here New Year's Day.

VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- That Nazis in Tyrol still administer their own system of courts in defiance of the Austrian Government was revealed in an Innsbruck court yesterday when two Tyrolese girls and a Tyrolese student were convicted of complicity in the murder of a Nazi turncoat last August.

The courts have been laying out so lustily against tyrannies and usurpations that sooner or later they were bound to run foul of that inflated nuisance, "and/or." The blow has fallen in Wisconsin, where a justice of the Supreme Court pays his compliments to "and/or" in no uncertain terms.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 13. -- Colonel James J. Meade was a major of Marines and a colonel in the Haitian Gendarmerie when he became to his fellow Marines "the man who was behind the wall at Grande Riviere."

Dues must be paid or the owner of a yacht cannot race. That drastic order, announced yesterday, was in the form of a decision by the executive committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union, ruling body of yachting in this country and Canada.

DETROIT, Dec. 13. -- Nine members of the New York Giants who are to battle the Detroit Lions in the play-off for the National Football League championship on Sunday arrived here today somewhat surprised to discover they were running second choices in the betting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Most of the holiday liquor consumed in the United States this year will be strictly legal, Treasury Department officials said today, because a vigilant Coast Guard and treaties with foreign countries have virtually stamped out smuggling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Thirty New York artists, nearly all of New York City, are among the nineteen sculptors and forty-four painters designated today by the Treasury Department's Section of Painting and Sculpture to execute work for Federal buildings throughout the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Having earlier in the season snagged a football victory from Harvard, Princeton now seems bent on destroying Cambridge's most illustrious alumnus. Subject: The Roosevelt. Opportunity: The Triangle Club's forty-seventh annual production, called "What a Relief."

A Petrus Guarnerius 'cello, fashioned by one of the celebrated family of violin makers of Cremona, was back in the hands of its owner, Miss Elsa Hilger, yesterday as she appeared on the platform of the Academy of Music in Philadelphia as a member of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

The Architectural League of New York, whose clubhouse is at 115 East Fortieth Street, announces that its fiftieth exhibition will be held in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, in February. The exhibition will strive to reveal the progress of a half century in architecture and the allied arts.
ATLANTA, Dec. 13. -- The Southeastern Conference voted overwhelmingly today to recognize athletic ability in the assignment of financial aid to students.
The power in Joe Louis's punch was so great as to drive one of Paulino's teeth clean through his upper lip.

PRAGUE, Dec. 13. -- The resignation of President Masaryk was again postponed today, but the Czechoslovak press, after being forbidden for weeks to refer to this subject of common gossip, was allowed to announce officially that the resignation would take place tomorrow. Premier Milan Hodza will broadcast a speech on the subject tomorrow night.

TOKYO, Dec. 13. -- The attitude of officials today made the conclusion logically inevitable that the naval parity Japan seeks is parity with the United States fleet, and that naval limitation is for Japan a question of reducing the American fleet to or near the Japanese level.
Mervin Sacks's letter to THE TIMES is directly illustrative of present-day efforts exerted by truck-fleet operators throughout the country to promote safety on the highways.

Included in the variety of building plans filed here yesterday, in addition to the $700,000 bank edifice of the Dry Dock Savings Institution on Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, were the plans for eighty-four small residences to go up in the Springfield, Winfield and Bayside communities in Queens.

Net profit of F.E. Myers Bro. Company, manufacturer of pumps and water systems, for the year ended on Oct. 31 was reported yesterday as $659,860 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent after deducting $7,500 dividends paid on the 6 per cent preferred stock, now retired, to $3.26 a share on 200,000 share of no par common stock.

SANTIAGO, Chile. Dec. 13. -- A plea will be made for reconsideration by the Chilean Supreme Court of the decision against the local board of directors of companies composing the so-called Chilean Electric Corporation. The court verdict, reached Wednesday, imposed fines of about $7,000,000 upon the American and British directors and ordered them to serve twenty-one days' imprisonment.

Joe, the imperious male sea lion at the Central Park Zoo, was banished to Brooklyn yesterday. Wearied by the constant flow of complaints from apartment houses across Fifth Avenue and a little bored themselves at the recurrent barking under their windows, park officials in the Arsenal decided to see if the removal of the master would not have a quieting effect on the four females in the "seal" pool.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- When the whole truth comes out about the decision of the British Government to back the Hoare-Laval agreement, it will be found that the naval situation in the Mediterranean has played an important part in shaping the attitude of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and his colleagues.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Jack Kasley, Western Conference and intercollegiate breast-stroke champion, swimming the new "butterfly" stroke, bettered the American short-course record for the 100 yards by a full second tonight in an Olympic benefit meet conducted by the University of Michigan.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- The directors of the First National Bank of Chicago voted today to retire $10,000,000 of its $25,000,000 preferred stock on or before Dec. 31 and to resume regular dividends on the common stock on Jan. 2 with the payment of $1 a share to place the stock on a $4 annual basis.

The order of the Federal Communications Commission requiring a uniform accounts system for telephone companies, effective on Jan. 1, was assailed as arbitrary and unconstitutional before a Federal statutory court yesterday by attorneys for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which is suing for an interlocutory injunction.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area reflected the mounting increase in volume of Christmas shopping during the week. Increases over the same period a year ago were noted for every day of the week, with the average gain for department stores for the period being estimated at 5 to 7 per cent.
Stimulated by an advance in wheat here and a recovery in cotton in Liverpool, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange improved further yesterday and closed with gains of 11 to 18 points.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- More than 200 awards were made to Colgate athletes tonight at the annual Varsity C dinner. The football team received special praise for its comeback after losing three games.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama cheeks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

IT looks like a hard, full Summer ahead for Bill Terry. The man who would give up his place in the sun for a seat in the dugout in baseball's strange anomaly finds himself apparently without any takers.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The secret political police have been brought to a temporary pause in their preparations for the treason trial of Mgr. Bannasch by the discovery that he received his instructions from Cardinal Michael von Faulhaber of Munich.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14. -- With county and State law-enforcing officials today refusing to accept direct responsibility for the investigation into the murder on Monday of Walter Liggett, crusading editor and publisher of a weekly newspaper, the Hennepin County chapter of the Minnesota Law and Order League, comprising a group of Minneapolis business men, issued a statement demanding that some constituted authority take over active direction of the hunt for the slayers.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Dec. 14. -- Entries for the 1936 Winter Olympics are more than double those for any previous Winter games since their introduction in 1924. The official entry list of the various nations for the nineteen competitions which was completed today shows a total of approximately 1,000 entrants.

The elite of the bird world met in competition yesterday at the beginning of the seventh annual national open show given by the Empire Cage Bird Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Fanciers from several cities brought more than 1,000 canaries, wild birds, parrots and many other varieties for the two-day event.

IT is interesting to know the exciting history interwoven with the wanderings of that commonplace bean, coffee; the wars, the naval battles, the commercial struggles that were fought over it; its translation from drug store to coffee house and its bitter rivalry with beer, wine and hard liquor; the millionaires it has made and ruined.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Mrs. Eleanor De Santos, a night club hostess, 28 years old, was under arrest here today, after being implicated by two hold-up men in thirty or more robberies of gasoline service stations and other places in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

MEXICO, D.F. SANTA CLAUS was officially banished from Mexico in 1930. In his stead was placed Quetzalcohuatl, the serpent with plumes, god of the ancient Aztecs, whose grinning statue may be seen in Teotihuacan, region of the pyramids, not far from Mexico, D.F.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Ambassador Hirosi Saito of Japan conferred today with Assistant Secretary of State Francis B. Sayre concerning an anticipated adjustment of the "gentlemen's agreement" limiting Japanese exports of textiles to the Philippines.

Government assistance to housing should be given only in return for reliable assurances that "discredited building and finance practices will be abandoned," the National Association of Housing Officials was told yesterday by its executive director, Coleman Woodbury.

College basketball, which advanced with one gigantic stride when it moved into Madison Square Garden a year ago, will take a second step in the same direction on Wednesday night, when the first of ten college court double-headers is staged on the new board floor of the Garden.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press). -- South Africa failed against strong Australian bowling today in the opening day's play of the first of five test cricket matches between the two countries, being dismissed for 248 runs.

The appointment of 117 New York University students to the editorial boards of the three downtown students' papers was announced yesterday by Harold Voorhis, university secretary. The appointments follow:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Mrs. Walter W. Gosling of Red Bank, president of the Associate Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women, announced today a program of vocational guidance for high school girls, arranged by the association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Syracuse and Penn staged another one of their thrilling basketball games tonight in Archbold Gymnasium with the Orange's greater speed bringing the home team victory, 39 -- 30. It was Syracuse's first victory over Penn since the 1932-33 season and brought the series standing to 17 -- 15 in favor of Syracuse.

Two well-mounted Squadron C teams opened the New York indoor polo season in victorious fashion at their home armory in Brooklyn last night, one routing the Blind Brook trio, 11 to 4, and the other overpowering the First Division, 15 to 5 1/2, before a good-sized gallery of spectators. Both were exhibition matches.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Critics of the Anglo-French peace formula received a new shock with the publication of an official document today disclosing unexplained discrepancies in the manner in which the plan was broached to Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia.

Early arrivals at a dinner party the other night in one of those sedate brownstone front houses in the West Seventies were observing the usual amenities. In due time the hors d'oeuvres appeared, and above the patter of polite conversation was heard the voice of our host, Thomas J. Regan, sportsman.

Plans for a municipal art center and auditorium will be revealed by Mayor La Guardia tomorrow afternoon at City Hall when representatives of leading civic organizations assemble there at a meeting to be held under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee of One Hundred.

THE Metropolitan Opera will go on the air for the fifth season as a Saturday matinee, but as an unsponsored performance. Neither cigarette nor mouthwash will be affiliated with the ethereal productions from the Golden Horseshoe this year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Princeton's basketball team came from behind in the opening minutes of the second half, scoring 13 points while holding Rutgers to a single basket to take a hotly contested game tonight in the university gym, 32 -- 29. The losers held a 16-10 advantage at half time.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "Die Walkuere," with Kirsten Flagstad, Gertrude Kappel, Lauritz Melchior, Friedrich Schorr and Emanuel List in the leading roles, the afternoon of Jan. 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

HAVANA, Dec. 14. -- Cuba's seventh Provisional President since the fall of the Machado dictatorship, Jose A. Barnet, has been inaugurated, but the problems of the island are still far from a solution.

Rome and the power of Rome, particularly as regards the Eastern imperium, are pictured with an elaboration of detail that brings the period in question -- the first century A.D. when Tiberius was Emperor -- very vividly before our eyes.

The collapse this week in the silver market, with our government holding the bag, should call attention to a lesson of history nearly half a century ago when we tried to "do something for silver" with painful consequences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Secretary Perkins has invited representatives of twenty-six national labor, social welfare and religious organizations to meet here Tuesday to discuss with officials of the Department of Labor closer cooperation for the improvement of American labor standards.

Bonds of public utility corporations and industrial enterprises predominated last week in the announcements of securities called for payment before maturity. The calls were principally for later months, with additions for December consisting entirely of small lots of municipal obligations.

A plan for furthering peace education among the children of New York materialized yesterday with the formation of a children's leaders commission at a conference of leaders in juvenile work called by the American League Against War and Fascism. The meeting was held in the Community Church, 550 West 110th Street.

The administration's agricultural policy, which the President credits with having been an important factor in increasing the income of our farmers by $3,000,000,000 since he took office, was examined, attacked and defended last week on three fronts -- in the Supreme Court at Washington, in Chicago's Union Stockyards amphitheatre, and in Atlanta, nerve center of the Cotton Belt.

Early in November the Belgian delegate to the League of Nations made a suggestion which caused skeptics to snort. The League, for the first time in history, had just voted to impose sanctions; at the fag-end of that momentous session the Belgian representative proposed that, as a gesture of good-will, France and Britain be authorized to carry on negotiations to settle the conflict between Italy and Ethiopia.

Ten years ago tonight professional hockey was introduced into Madison Square Garden, when the New York Americans faced the Canadiens of Montreal. Tonight the Americans will celebrate the anniversary on the Garden ice by opposing the Chicago Black Hawks, leaders in the American Division of the National Hockey League.

STREAMLINED is the word for the 1935 version of the perennially popular toy train. From headlight to observation platform, it has undergone changes as revolutionary as those exhibited by the most modern of transcontinental flyers.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 14. -- Ernest Gruening, Administrator of Reconstruction, met the protest that his agency was employing too many mainland Americans by pointing out that nineteen Americans and more than 13,000 Puerto Ricans were on the payrolls. Mr. Gruening's answer was given to the bar association committee which called following the association's adopting of resolutions condemning the appointment to the legal department of "imported American lawyers."

WARSAW, Dec. 14. -- Cross-examination of more than eighty witnesses in the trial of the Ukrainians who are alleged to have organized the assassination of Bronislaw Pieracki, Minister of the Interior, in June, 1934, was concluded yesterday in the fourth week of the hearing.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 14 (AP). -- A treasure trove of unique value went up in smoke one day in Keokuk, Iowa, when Mark Twain's letters to his mother, almost four trunks of them, were destroyed, as requested by the humorist himself.

To meet the problem of individual differences, an enlarged program of social and moral guidance has been introduced at Hunter College by Dean Hannah M. Egan, in conjunction with the vocational and educational guidance plans set up this semester by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college.

CHILDREN'S toys have a way of holding up the mirror to society, as any one versed in playthings will tell you. The record goes back to the little sculptured chariots of ancient Greece, and its latest entry may be a sputtering mechanical devise. Yet never, perhaps, has the reflection been so true as in this Yuletide season.

THE New Jersey Orchestra, conducted by Rene Pollain, will open its thirteenth season tomorrow night at the Orange High School, and repeat the program Tuesday night at the Mount Hebron Junior High School in Montclair.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -The shadow of secret diplomatic manoeuvres fell tonight across the week-old naval conference, struggling to extricate itself from the complications of Japanese parity demands.

The place of foreign languages in the changing educational field was discussed by more than 750 foreign language teachers in the metropolitan area at the second Foreign Language Conference yesterday at the New York University School of Education.

GENEVA, Dec. 14. -- Egypt has taken the position that the Kellogg anti-war pact not only justifies her in applying League of Nations sanctions against Italy but also no longer obliges her not to resort to war against the aggressor. This position was taken in a note drafted by the Egyptian Cabinet when it agreed to sanctions and was communicated to the League in a letter dated Nov. 5, which was published only today.

Plans for fighting from the outset any attempt by the Anti-Saloon League, Women's Christian Temperance Union or other dry agencies to revive prohibition are under consideration in all divisions of the liquor industry.
HELP for the needy? Of course, you say; the government helps, the State helps, the city helps, we all help; that's why taxes are so high -- of course we must all do our part, and we are doing it.

HOBART, Okla., Dec. 14 (AP). -- With an entire county under strict quarantine, the health authorities worked tonight to halt an outbreak of meningitis that has caused one known death and possibly several more.
Word of the upturn has apparently reached far-off Goteborg (Gothenborg) on the swift-flowing Cattegat in Sweden, even if there are doubters here in the homeland.

LIVING in the country" is no longer limited to the Summer months. Better roads, improved transportation, more efficient and less bothersome systems of heating, have all been factors in creating a new type of year-round country home.

WORK is being pushed on five large steel bridges on the coast of Southern Oregon, which, when completed, will afford a continuous through route from the month of the Columbia River at Astoria to San Francisco Bay.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has closed a contract with the Russian oil trust for the kerosene the former will require in the Near East for 1936. The amount involved probably will be about 500,000 barrels at a price of $1,000,000, depending upon the quotation at the time of delivery.

DALLAS, Dec. 13. -- Retail sales throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District for the last week have been such that accountants are forced to go back to 1929 to find like volume for the corresponding week of any year. The wave of holiday-gift buying that began some four weeks ago has increased steadily and retailers have found it difficult to replenish depleted stock.

HERE are two novels dealing directly with industrial unrest in the South, both by writers who have put their trust in Communist doctrine. As creative literature, neither is likely to survive beyond its season, although in the case of Fielding Burke we have to do with a writer of distinguished gifts.

Difficulties which will beset dry goods wholesalers when they start operating on Fall goods next month started many of them to make early plans last week and to be prepared for any of the numerous contingencies which may arise, they declared here yesterday.
AURORA, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Students at Wells College, in the country village of Aurora, have their Christmas season tuned to sleighbells.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The country's 28,000,000 wage earners may receive social security "numbers" under an identification plan now receiving careful scrutiny by officials of the Social Security Board as a possible solution to one of the vast administrative problems before them.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Unless there is some further but now unforeseen deviation from the Ethiopian policy which the electorate had expected would be pursued, the British Government will not especially exert itself in Geneva next week to have the League of Nations approve the Hoare-Laval plan for the dismemberment of Ethiopia.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The naval conference is quiescent over the week-end while the various delegations consider the temporary impasse created by the Japanese demand for a "common upper limit" -- which is merely naval parity in disguise -- and what compromise can successfully be brought forward to meet it.

LONDON. -- The Italo-Ethiopian war has greatly influenced the toy market this Christmas season. It is estimated that some 1,000,000 will be spent in London on toys and that nearly half of them are replicas of such instruments of war as are being used in East Africa or capable of being used in a European conflict.

Week-end influences tended to curtail interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and prices generally maintained a steady to firm undertone in light trading. Except for a few broad upswings in selected industrial loans, the domestic corporation group lacked a definite trend and closed the two-hour period with only minor price changes.

AS Christmas approaches the mind of the hostess turns to her holiday decorations, especially for the board which is to groan with the family dinner -- and later offer good cheer to successive groups of guests throughout Christmastide.
Having finished one of the most successful years in its history, the New York State Golf Association yesterday put its house in order for next season.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Members of the Committee of One Hundred who will entertain friends at the opening of the horse-racing season at Tropical Park tomorrow, will meet at their clubhouse in Michigan Avenue, Miami Beach, on Tuesday night for an address by Charles G. Batchelder of New York, a former United States trade commissioner.

AIKEN, S.C. -- Aiken resort activities have not yet begun in earnest, but members of the colony and other Winter visitors now here are finding plenty of sport. Bird hunting is now popular, and both the dove and quail seasons are open. From now until the first of the year, when the dove season closes one month earlier than usual, there will be shoots almost every day.

TO stimulate increased interest in opera in this country, a new organization is being formed to be known as the American Opera Guild. It is the plan of the guild to bring to production operatic works by composers of every nationality.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 13. -- Edith Maxwell, the school teacher who was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison on a charge of murdering her father, a Wise County blacksmith, failing to get a new trial from Judge H.A.W. Skeen, will now appeal.

In presenting the statistics of registration in American universities and colleges for 1935 Dr. RAYMOND WALTERS, president of the University of Cincinnati, upon whom we have become accustomed to rely for this annual review, makes the initial statement:

A half-million dollars, from 350,000 contributors, has been raised to date in the metropolitan area for the work of the Italian Red Cross in Africa, it was announced last night at a meeting in Madison Square Garden.

A Chippendale shell-carved mahogany claw-and-ball-foot lowboy made in Philadelphia in the eighteenth century and formerly a part of the furnishings of the Chase Mansion in Annapolis, Md., was sold for $1,300 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the Francis Shaw collection of furniture and decorations.

EDUCATING men for the public service will receive new impetus when the Graduate School of Public Administration opens its doors within a year at Harvard University. Last week President Conant of Harvard announced a gift of $2,000,000 from Lucius Nathan Littauer for the establishment of this school and the appointment of a commission to report "on university education for public service and to recommend plans for the organization of the new school."

IN General Grant Park, California, about sixty-five miles east rein Fresno and at an altitude of 6,000 feet above sea level, a host of mighty Sequoia gigantea are congregated in solemn congress that has lasted through unnumbered centuries.

ONCE, for about three hours, the man on the train addressed us to the text that within ten years, if some one did not look out, the British Empire would resolve itself into nothing more than a group of insignificant islands off the coast of Europe.

So remarkably sustained is the general average of art in the Frick Gallery that it is difficult to say that this picture or that one is better or best. Still, there are several in which the glorious attribute of personality makes itself especially felt and which, therefore, to me seem to stand out from all the others as bestowing a special privilege.

For many years the Neediest Cases Fund, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, has had wide recognition outside of this city. Indeed, it has had some imitations. Other newspapers in other cities have undertaken a similar form of charitable appeal. But evidence continues to come that the work here is not only appreciated and sympathized with but is watched attentively by distant readers.

HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The Democratic party gained control of the local government here tonight with the resignation of Benjamin I. Taylor, supervisor of Harrison for twenty-eight Years and former Representative to Congress.

WARSAW, Dec. 14. -- Anti-Jewish riots in the Fall may become a tradition in Warsaw colleges. New students just out of high schools still drunk with their newly won freedom are easy prey to nationalist anti-Semitic propaganda. Clashes with Jews and attempts to drive them out of classes or at least to separate them in the work rooms are regarded as an inevitable evil.

The bright lights of Broadway soon will be brighter as the result of the signing of a lease on roof space in Times Square for the erection of what was described as "the world's largest" electric advertising sign.
Your informative article on the Solenodon paradoxus repeatedly refers to that very rare, almost unique insectivore as a rodent.
THE approach of the Christmas holidays has brought little change in the production program of Detroit automobile companies.

HOLLYWOOD. WITHOUT the aid or blessing of Mae West, "Little Lord Fauntleroy" and the Selznick International concern are well under way. Miss West's connection with the venture is most remote; other elements in the making of the film are far more vital.

DETROIT, Dec. 14. -- This bustling metropolis which only a short two months ago was throwing itself into an unprecedented turmoil acclaiming its first world series baseball triumph, and which takes great civic pride in the doings of its fistic marvel, Joe Louis, is all aflutter again tonight on the eve of what it expects will be the acquisition of another world title for this city.

On Long Island this week, presidents' day programs and holiday festivities will share the attention of women's organizations, with a combined observance of the two in at least one instance. The members of Queen Anne chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, will impart a Christmas atmosphere to the event of Thursday, at the home of Mrs. John R. Miller of Garden City, in honor of the various executives who will be special guests.

ROME, Dec. 14. -- Italy views the prospect of peace today as calmly and with as little outward evidence of excitement as she stood on the threshold of war slightly more than two months ago. Just as the outbreak of hostilities was accepted with deadly seriousness and an absence of popular enthusiasm usually associated with martial endeavor, so the prospect of an early settlement failed to give rise to any public explosions of joy.

A richly merited success was scored by Winifred Cecil, soprano, who appeared in recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The youthful New York vocalist, known on the radio as Virginia Lee, has appeared here before as recitalist, and also on occasion has been heard as soloist with the Dessoff Choirs.

THE man who had lost an arm in an automobile accident looked over the safety posters in a downtown store window. He saw a sketch of John Barleycorn riding in the back seat of a speeding roadster. He saw an anguished driver holding the body of a child in his arms.

A basic change in the Federal regulations covering the $200,000,000 grade-crossing elimination program, which will permit the allocation of a larger proportion of the fund to steel, eoncrete and other materials, and a smaller proportion for the direct employment of labor than originally was contemplated, is explained by Rexford G. Tugwell, Under Secretary of Agriculture, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

STARTING from Plum Blossom Village the road winds through the beautiful semitropical countryside of Southern China. In the fields, on either side of the highway, whole families of peasants are busy cultivating rice, cane, beans and mulberry trees.

THE Supreme Court of the United States is preparing to pass on some of the most vital of the New Deal laws. The circumstances of the convening of the present session are of peculiar symbolic and realistic interest. The judges, beginning one of the most fateful chapters in the history of the court, met for the first time in the magnificent new $10,000,000 building completed under the New Deal.

Somewhere on the high seas today a ship from Palestine is bearing homeward Miss Henrietta Szold, designated by many as "the foremost Jewish woman of contemporary times." On Saturday, her seventy-fifth birthday, a nationwide celebration of the anniversary will be launched, to last thirty days under the auspices of the 300 chapters of Hadassah, of which she is founder.
COPENHAGEN. -- Despite the rise of dictatorships in Europe, democracy still stands firm in the three Scandinavian countries -- Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

ARCHITECTURAL sculpture by C. Paul Jennewein, together with a group of his drawings and small paintings, was placed on view last week in the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries. This exhibition will remain through Dec. 28.

Bruno Richard Hauptmann was told, in his Trenton death house cell yesterday, that the new date set for his execution was the week of Jan. 13. He shrugged and replied that he still felt something would "turn up" to save him from the electric chair.

The kindness of an undertaker, a stranger, saved William Larowin of 39 First Avenue yesterday from the prospect of having to Bury his 17-year-old daughter, Olga, in potter's field. But Larowin, alone now in the third-floor rear flat which, some years ago, housed a happy family of four, is still beset by trouble.

Mayor La Guardia was called upon yesterday in a resolution made public by the Newspaper Guild of New York to veto the city ordinance requiring the display of American flags at indoor meetings adopted earlier in the week by the Board of Aldermen and now before him for signature.

Last week Dr. TOWNSEND decided that his followers should name candidates for President and Vice President and in every State a ticket of Presidential electors. Candidates for Representative in Congress will be nominated in every district where neither major party will accept the Doctor's recipe.

A contribution of $25,000 to the United Hospital Campaign Committee from Edward S. Harkness was disclosed yesterday in the week-end report of new contributors to the fund. Three large anonymous gifts were also disclosed in this latest listing of contributors, one for $15,000, one for $5,000 and another for $3,000.

THIS is another history of the cat and the mouse. Those who read "A Warning to Wantons" will be surprised to find few similarities -- aside from the author's ability adroitly to impale her characters -- in this, Miss Mitchell's second novel.

FOR the memory of great men, monuments, in these days, are not enough. It is on the slopes of mountains that, gigantic, their countenances must be carved. From such an elevation, Albert of Belgium -- first in war, first in peace and first in the hearts of his countrymen -- here gazes at an enduring fame.

MADRID, Dec. 14. -- Spain breathed easier today when Manuel Portela Valladares, former Interior Minister and politically a moderate independent, who commands the respect of all parties, announced the formation of a Cabinet that would conduct "scrupulously impartial elections" not later than March 4.

AT last the great Frick Collection, one of the finest in the country, is prepared to reveal its treasures to the public. There was an official opening on Wednesday afternoon, and beginning tomorrow -- in conformity with the directions set down in the will of the late Henry Clay Frick -- these magnificent works of art become dedicated to "the use and benefit of all persons whomsoever."

The Grand Opera Artists' Association of America, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, charged yesterday afternoon that Erno Rapee, musical director of Radio City Music Hall, had failed to abide by the union's regulations that members could not work free on broadcasting programs.

TRANSATLANTIC flight on schedule, linking New York with Paris in twelve hours was predicted the other day before the aeronautical section of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers by Professor Albert Caquot, until recently director of the technical section of the French Air Ministry.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Prime Minister Gendun and War Minister Demid of the Republic of Outer Mongolia, which, Soviet accounts said, has been threatened by a Japanese-Manchukuoan invasion, had a long conference today with Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff at the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Heavily increased holdings of government obligations, enormous increases in deposits, great resources, but substantially decreased loans and discounts, were shown by national banks at the date of the last "call" of condition on Nov. 1, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

La Salle Military Academy's sextet tallied its second victory in as many starts by blanking the Alumni, 7-0, while Boys High and Lynbrook played a 3 -- all tie in non-league hockey games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

TO investigate the "many garbled and distorted reports" being received in the United States regarding European television, Andrew W. Cruse, chief of the Electrical Division, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, made an inspection trip for "first-hand, unbiased information."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- A private school and three Masonic lodges are among beneficiaries of two large estates disposed of by wills filed for probate today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office.

Activity in the wholesale markets here continued brisk last week, with many buyers present, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Last-minute accessory orders were for large quantities, despite the short time to Christmas.

The sixth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship, the first important fixture of the season, opens at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, Atlantic City, tomorrow and lasts through Wednesday. Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia will defend the title which she has held for the last two years.

Contracts for construction of the Harlem and Williamsburg housing projects, the two most important local developments in the Federal housing program, have been awarded, Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday by A.R. Clas, director of housing in the Federal Housing Administration.

Allow me, please, to answer the Messrs. Bond and Stern, who take issue with me because I don't want to believe that Griffith and von Sternberg are the only good directors and Mr. Lewis Jacobs the critic of critics of the American film.

The application of owners of defaulted mortgage certificates in Series Q-1 sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, acquiesced in by the New York State Mortgage Commission, for the appointment of trustees to administer the properties securing the issue was approved in a decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

IN Wall Street's lofty counting houses the ticker pipes a cheerier tune. Its sullen, halting clack, which through the dreary years since 1929 had droned out remorselessly the tale of falling prices, has turned into a swifter, brighter song.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT by the year end will have made eighteen broadcasts over WEAF-WJZ networks, compared to twenty in 1934. He broadcast only one "fireside chat" in 1935 and that was on April 28. His three-year record since inauguration totals fifty-six major network broadcasts, according to National Broadcasting Company's statistics.

The Women's Conference Against the High Cost of Living was assured yesterday by Donald E. Montgomery, consumers' counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, that it could look forward to lower commodity prices next Summer.

The best book for a Christmas gift is one that provides fresh and continued delight all through the year. Such a book is this lovely volume containing thirty-four carols of all seasons and all ages, adapted from English, French, German and Czech tunes, for the most part new arrangements of traditional airs.

One more stage has been completed in Japan's forward march on the Asiatic Continent. It might be more accurately described as a split stage.
