With Japanese generals presenting ultimatums and Japanese troops converging on them, two provinces of North China have become "autonomous" instead of the five that Japan insisted on.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 14. -- The schedule for the Williams College Glee Club includes twelve concerts and an Easter vacation cruise to Nassau and Bermuda. Plans for the season call for a joint engagement with Paul Whiteman and his band together with the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra.

MISS GREIG'S innocuous novels of romantic young love now total over twenty issued in the last few years, the quality and quantity of that output easily ranking her one of England's -- and America's -- leading dispensers of popular sentimental fiction active in the trade today.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) . -- Edward Drake, Arsenal center-forward, served notice on his critics today that he is the Gunners' most dangerous forward, backing it up with the amazing feat of scoring all the goals by which the Londoners whippsd Aston Villa at Villa Park, 7 -- 1.

MIAMI, Dec. 14. -- Under a lowering gray sky the annual all-American air manoeuvres and races closed this afternoon at the Municipal Airport here on an impressive military note. The attack planes of the planes the war mission of which is destruction close to the ground, took wing in weather which ideally suited their tactics of prowling at 180 miles an hour.

RICHMOND, Dec. 14. -- The Richmond Citizens Service Exchange, a self- help cooperative agency praised last Tuesday by Secretary Morgenthau as "the finest thing I have seen or heard about in the nation," was evolved from the old barter idea and started functioning on Jan. 10, 1933.

H.J. Starke of the Squash Club and John Holbrook of the Yale Club will meet in the final of the Squash Club's annual Class B squash racquets invitation tournament tomorrow as the result of winning matches played in the semi-final round yesterday. Starke provided the sensation of the tourney when he eliminated last season's winner, J.K. Weeks of the Princeton Club, 15 -- 12, 12 -- 15, 18 -- 17, 15 -- 13.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 14. -- A plane left this afternoon for Diredawa to bring here the body of Dr. Robert W. Hockman, 28-year-old medical missionary in charge of American Red Cross unit No. 1 on the Ogaden front, who was killed yesterday while examining an unexploded Italian bomb at Daggah Bur.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- It is unfortunately no exaggeration to say that the events of last week have brought the British Government's prestige both at home and abroad to the lowest ebb it has reached in many years.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 14. -- Williams College alumni in various parts of the country are assuming a share of the institution's student-aid burden, it was evidenced last night when the establishment of regional scholarships in Toledo, Cleveland, Chicago and Cincinnati was announced.
ALFRED HITCHCOCK is the first national institution, along with the "Cheshire Cheese" and the Savoy Grill, that itinerant American journalists demand to see.

HOLIDAY parties for children -- both at home and at school -- bring together collections of frocks as gay as the young folk who wear them. For dressy occasions there are gowns of velvet and lace, fluffy beribboned things of lace-trimmed and embroidered voile, and simple tailored dresses of silk or taffeta.

Radio programs for children show "distinct evidence of efforts to improve the radio's offerings along the lines demanded by an increasingly informed public," the radio committee of the Child Study Association of America reported yesterday.

IN this indefinite "in-between" season, with hard freezing for a few days, succeeded perhaps by a mild spell, there are not many things which one can attempt to do out-of-doors. An important job that many gardeners will undertake in the course of the next few weeks, however, is that of putting all their trees and shrubs into shape.

THE League of Composers will open its thirteenth season's activities with a musicale and reception in honor of Kurt Weill, the renowned German composer, Dec. 17, at the Cosmopolitan Club. This occasion will mark the first New York appearance of Lotte Lenja, chanteuse, who will be assisted by a group of artists in a program of excerpts from Mr. Weill's operas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Strained relations between the Roosevelt administration and organized business passed the breaking point recently when the National Association of Manufacturers declared that industry was now in politics to rid the nation of the New Deal.

Prominent persons are subscribing to the premiere performance of "The Eternal Road," a new play by Franz Werfel under the direction of Max Reinhardt, the night of Jan. 14 at the Manhattan Opera House, which has been taken over by the directors of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work in behalf of that organization.

Sharp changes in taxation methods in the State to restrict governmental expenditures and to reduce the burden on real estate will be proposed by the State Tax Limitation Committee at the forthcoming legislative sessions in Albany.

TSINAN, China, Dec. 14. -- Japanese efforts to spur autonomy in North China are gravely complicated because 5,000,000 of Shantung Province's 37,000,000 population are homeless, Yellow River floods having submerged ten populous counties and parts of three others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Nine States and the District of Columbia, for which unemployment compensation laws have already been enacted, contain workers who receive 35 per cent of the entire payroll of the country, and States which are expected to enact such laws within the next few months will bring this total to more than 50 per cent, according to A.J. Altmeyer, member of the Social Security Board.

AN exhibition of photographs of New York shop windows, ranging from those of stores on upper Fifth Avenue to those on the lower East Side, has been placed on view at the Museum of the City of New York. Some of the photographs were made at night others in the daytime.

WHEN Noel Coward, in "The Scoundrel," was asked how he liked Proust, he replied: "I'm polite to him." That is a fairly accurate summation of the cinema's attitude to grand opera. For months now we have been drenched in sopranos, tenors, baritones and hasty fragments of operatic music.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- "The common belief that Phi Beta Kappa men in our colleges are generally social bores has no basis in fact," Dr. Clarence W. Young, assistant professor of psychology at Colgate University, stated today after announcing results of tests conducted over a period of years.

The joint legislative Committee on Taxicab Operation and Fares, seeking to lay a foundation for public hearings to begin soon, has sent questionnaires to every cab owner in the city, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr. of Brooklyn, Democrat, who heads the committee.

THE word "Riviera" has become almost synonymous with "playtime country" for most Americans -- a utopian land where people only bask in the sunshine and dream. But there is another side to the Riviera, a working side which sends comforts and necessities out into less romantic parts of the world, and adds materially to that stream of money which its playtime visitors bring.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 14. -- A public service of penitence and indignation will be held tomorrow afternoon to crystallize Tampa's sentiment against the death by flogging of Joseph Shoemaker. No one has been arrested for the death.

Candid appraisals of their own fields of activity in the arts brought both optimistic and pessimistic votes from men and women speakers yesterday before the New York League of Business and Professional Women, on the opportunities open to women.

If the members of the vast organizations of women in New York State realized that the average item on their dinner -- or breakfast -- tables travels 1,500 miles to feed their families, transportation problems would have a new meaning for them, believes Miss Dorothy Straus, only woman appointed by Governor Lehman to the newly formed State Planning Council.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- The New Haven Railroad's streamlined Comet will take 160 member of the science class of the Hamden High School tomorrow for a speedy spin in what is believed to be the first use of such a train for purely educational purposes.

While the Federal tax on both workers and employers to provide for old-age pensions does not go into effect until 1937, the tax on payrolls to provide for unemployment insurance becomes effective a few weeks from now. In an article in the current Annalist, H. MAYNARD REES has made an interesting calculation of what the total annual cost of social security is likely to be.

TSINAN, Dec. 14. -- General Han Fu-chu, Governor of Shantung Province, is inacessible, immured in his country home in the foot-hills, but Japanese authorities in Tsinan express the conviction that he will certainly join the autonomy movement or declare Shantung's separate autonomy as soon as General Yen Hsi-shan is convinced of the success of the movement in Hopei and Chahar and flings Shansi Province's lot with the autonomists.

In view of the Federal investigations into the activities of bondholders' protective committees, the Independent Bondholders Committee for the Republic of Colombia, through its secretary, L.E. de S. Hoover, discloses, in a statement just issued, the committee's methods of operation and financing.

The Christmas song festival and dance of the People's Chorus of New York will be held Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Miss Eleanor Wendell, acting chairman of the junior committee during the illness of Mrs. Leonard Tyson Scully, will give a reception and dinner at the York Club for members and friends of the committee immediately before the concert.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Moore of New York, who are at the Everglades Club, were honor guests at a tea given today by Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. at their home.

For the first nine months of this year Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., reported a net income of $436,288 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $4.58 a share on 95,176 shares of $100-par 7 per cent preferred stock on which there is an accumulation of unpaid dividends.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Alone among the foreign debtors of the United States, Finland is ready to meet the payments due Monday (as Dec. 15 falls on Sunday) under the funding, and moratorium agreements.

The United States Treasury did not bid for silver yesterday either here or in London. Consequently no business was done in the British market and only a nominal quotation of 26 7-16d an ounce, unchanged from the previous day, was posted. In view of the nominal character of that market, Handy Harman, leading bullion brokers here, announced that there was no official New York quotation for foreign silver.

CAPABLE painters, etchers and engravers have this season improved the quality of the Christmas card. They thought it time to restore to it some of the spiritual and joyous character commercialism had been robbing it of.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Members of Congress, especially those from the Far and Middle West, are returning to Washington genuinely worried over the rapid spread of the Townsend movement.

JOHN COURNOS'S autobiography is an achievement of which he may well be proud. It is distinguished by integrity, by outstanding individualism and by a prose style that is invariably lucid and adequate and that, at times, achieves sparse, driving beauty.

Exquisite lithographs by Kurt Wiese of kittens, puppies, lambs, rabbits, colts and other baby animals, ending with a chapter about a little girl called Baby Susan. The simple text by Dorothy Kunhardt tells things about these little creatures that children like to know, often using the words that a child himself would choose to describe them.

TRENTON, Dec. 14. -- Carl K. Withers, State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, has announced that after months of negotiating by the liquidation division of his department with bondholders protective committees in several South Western and Midwestern States, approval has been given by the Court of Chancery to a plan of compromise wherein claims against the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company, aggregating more than $6,000,000, will be allowed at $2,425,000.

The prices bid and asked in the speculators' market for the season's opening performance tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House were reminiscent yesterday of the boom days of the late 1920s. One unauthorized trader said that $100 had been offered for a $10 orchestra seat, but there is none to be had.

BERLIN. FIRST steps on the part of the frugal and economically minded German authorities to recoup themselves as far as possible for the extremely large sums being spent on preparations for the Olympic Games are seen in the issue of special stamps and postal cards to mark the Winter sports, preliminary to the greater games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Delegations from Chicago and Kansas City, in efforts to obtain the 1936 Republican National Convention for their respective cities, each today offered $150,000 toward the expenses of the gathering. The Republican National Committee meets here on Monday to select the convention city.

Directors of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York have taken over the performance of the Jooss European Ballet the night of Jan. 21 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the organization.

Government counsel asked a Federal statutory court yesterday to deny an interlocutory injunction sought by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company against the order of the Federal Communications Commission for a uniform system of accounts for telephone companies, effective on Jan. 1, next.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during November was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 507,836 bales of lint and 59,549 of linters, compared with 552,187 and 67,106 for October this year, and 480,081 and 51,035 for November last year. Cotton on hand Nov. 30 was reported held as follows:

CAIRO, Dec. 14. -- Like many of the countries of Europe whose destinies are now shaped by youth, Egypt through her young students accomplished this week what only two years ago would have been regarded as a miracle.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Joy and sorrow are expected to intermingle in Pope Pius's allocution to the College of Cardinals Monday.

THE first edition of "Who's Who in American Art," published by the American Federation of Arts, has now made its appearance. It contains up-to-date biographical information on living American artists -- painters, sculptors, illustrators, cartoonists, graphic artists and craftsmen, as well as lecturers on art.

LONGWOOD, the historic old house on the island of St. Helena in which Napoleon spent the last days of his exile, has been attacked by termites and an expedition sent out by the French Government is now engaged in a battle to exterminate the insects and to restore once more the much-abused shrine.

The Brotherhood of Utility Employes yesterday wrote a letter to twenty-three hospitals in Queens advising them to make immediate preparations for the use of emergency lighting services in anticipation of the strike authorized by Queens Local 103.

THE first modern woman, Samuel Putnam calls Marguerite, Queen of Navarre. Sister of Francois I, mother of Jeanne d'Albret, grandmother of Henri IV, author of the "Heptameron" and much poetry, friend of authors, scholars, great men without number, she was the most cultured and learned woman of her period and for long afterward.

WHATEVER may be the course of his fame, Arnold Bennett must go down in history as among the most colorful of literary personalities. He was one of those in the world of the arts about whom traditions form.

It is gratifying to hear that the New York film critics have formed an association to give an award for the best performances of the year. I am but one of the many who feel that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences award often has gone to the wrong person.

PALM BEACH. -- Never before has Palm Beach received her Winter visitors so early or in such large numbers as this year. Her parks, avenues, patios and gardens have seen the stream of October arrivals swell to such dimensions that three-fourths of the colony is now here, with others coming soon for holiday house parties.

Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday that he would continue to advocate the 2 per cent city tax on retail sales, regardless of political consequences to himself, as long as it remained in his judgment the best method of raising money needed for unemployment relief.

WATER-COLORS and small sculpture by Jose de Creeft are being shown simultaneously at Georgette Passadoit's Gallery in the French Institute Building, 22 East Sixtieth Street. The water-colors are a decided innovation for Mr. de Creeft and further the impression already gained of his vigorous and versatile talents.

AT this season the markets of New York receive their quota of game. Haunches of venison and braces of hare hang from the racks; in the stalls are partridge, duck and pheasant, grouse and ptarmigan and plover. Even reindeer and bear meat are available.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 14 (AP). -- A scene without modern precedent in Federal court was enacted today as George W. Barrett, gray-haired former Kentucky feudist, was wheeled before the bar of Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell and sentenced to be hanged some time before sunrise, March 24, 1936.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13. -- Kentucky s "Boy Governor," Albert Benjamin Chandler, whom the whole State knows as "Happy," assumed office this week at an inauguration which broke all records for crowds, just as his election exceeded all previous marks for vote and majority.

FILLING STATIONS," is what motorists call them, but the men in the oil business never use that term; they title them "service" stations, and for good and sufficient reasons. Whatever name is employed to designate the units of this vast American institution, the stations are increasing in number.

THE schooner Cimba, 35 feet long, which sailed from New York in November. 1933, on a leisurely voyage around the world, has been wrecked on a coral reef off Suva, in the Fiji Islands. A letter from the Cimba's 25-year-old skipper, Richard H. Maury, just received by his parents in Darien, Conn., tells the story of the wrack and the salvaging operations.

A warning that boys under 12 years of age should be barred from competitive school sports because of "too high a price in physical strain" is contained in a report submitted by the Athletic Association of Private Schools of New York City to Frank S. Hacker, president of the association and headmaster of Riverdale Country School.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of fourteen persons to important city posts, including four places in the local courts. It was the largest number of appointments announced in a single day by the Mayor since the early days of his administration.

IN his "Primitive Culture in Greece" and his "Handbook of Greek Mythology" H.J. Rose has already given us some estimable discussions of early Greek life and literature and a new volume from his pen, consequently, will be welcomed by students of classical lore.

The five-day deer-hunting season in New Jersey, which opens on Tuesday, has inspired a group of prominent young persons to arrange a benefit unique in the annals of philanthropic endeavor. Ten members of a committee of arrangements will leave the city tomorrow to participate in the hunting in the densely wooded areas of Burlington and Ocean Counties on the opening day of the deer season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The government defended the AAA amendments today as barring the possible "unjust enrichment of a small class of private citizens at the expense of a vastly larger class."

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, is "talking through his hat" when he says that Roosevelt will not run again for the Presidency, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York told members of the Flatbush Republican Club last night at their annual dinner in their headquarters, 2,431 Church Avenue.

The opening tomorrow night of the 1935-36 season of Metropolitan Opera will bring to the Opera House a brilliant assembly of members of society, following a first-night tradition for several decades. With one of the Metropolitan's "greatest seasons" in prospect, as foreseen by officials of the Metropolitan Opera Association, the gala premiere will be the most auspicious event of the early social season in this city.

WITH radio retailers noticing what they describe as "a big swing" to combination radio-phonograph machines, Christmas business is reported to be considerably ahead of last season. One prominent New York retailer in reference to the final quarter of 1935 said the early Autumn sales were good but a slight slump occurred in November, which is blamed on "unseasonable weather."
GENEVA, Dec. 14. -- Where does the Paris deal leave the League of Nations?
CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- R.E. Clements, national secretary, asserted in an interview tonight that "Townsend-plan" followers already hold the balance of power in the 1936 elections.

Funds for the maintenance of its various philanthropies will be raised Tuesday by the Infants Welfare League, at the annual bridge fashion show and tea to be held at the Hotel Pierre. Mrs. Harry Marrits is the founder and president of the organization, which for the last fourteen years has devoted its energies to supplying prenatal and postnatal care for mothers and their children not aided by city agencies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- The problem of insuring peace is the most vital issue confronting America today, according to a poll taken of the three upper classes of Rutgers University, the results of which appeared in The Targum, campus newspaper, today.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 14. -- The autonomous reform council, which probably will formally assume office on Monday or Tuesday, will not bring to North China sorely needed peace and prosperity and a cessation of uncertainty as to its future status.

THERE has long been needed a definitive life of Washington Irving. Shortly after his death there appeared the "Life and Letters" by his nephew, Pierre M. Irving. This was necessarily a partisan and biased book. It is detailed and accurate but evasive and a great deal less than frank in many matters.

Members of the Society of Stoopnocracy, more or less officially known as "stoopnocrats," are planning another entertainment in the interests of charity which will be given on Saturday afternoon at the Biltmore, where the society makes its headquarters.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13. -- As Winter fastens its grip on the Soviet land, creating a fortress of snow and ice, which no enemies have ever successfully besieged, Moscow is assuming an increasingly outspoken attitude toward Tokyo.

ON the 7th of June, 1776, Richard Henry Lee went from the home of his brother-in-law, Dr. William Shippen, to the meeting of the Continental Congress a few blocks away, to introduce his resolution, "That these united Colonies are, and of right ought to be, free and independent States."

THE music department of Smith College, under Werner Josten, will give next Spring the first performance in America of the famous opera of Johann Fux (or Fuchs), "Costanza e fortezza," which was an outstanding music drama of the first half of the eighteenth century, as Cesti's "Pomo d'oro" was in the second half of the seventeenth.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Five Senators who were prominent factors in the political machine of former President Plutarco Elias Calles were ousted from the Senate today, one day after the return of the one-time "Iron Man" from Los Angeles after six months of voluntary exile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Withdrawal of United States Treasury support from the London silver market during the past week and the resultant collapse of prices focuses attention on the fact that America has two silver policies and that in following one she frequently trips over the other.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Heavy profit-taking developed today in the world's wheat markets and brought about sizable reactions from yesterday's finish. A rush of buying by mills and cash interests and the changing over of hedges from the December into the May sent the current delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade almost 2 cents above Friday's finish and the highest mark since the middle of October.

Exuberant, manly singing with rousing vitality in it was put forth last night at Town Hall by the New York University Glee Club which was assisted by the university's Faculty Glee Club and Alumni Glee Club. The large choral aggregation threw itself zealously into its work and met with a sturdy response from its hearers.

VIENNA, NOV. 21, 1935. FUR -- conductors' fur -- has been flying at the Staatsoper these past few days. Some of the reasons are still too obscure and too befogged with gossip to be exposed before they crystallize a little more solidly. But one of the clear-cut issues has been -- of all things -- "Tannhaeuser."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Mayor-elect S. Davis Wilson attacked the Fairmount Park Commission today as "autocratic, like a European monarchy," and urged before a House investigating committee that it be abolished.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 14. -- Prompt full payment of the veterans' bonus was advocated and predicted tonight before nearly 200 members of the American Veterans Association, which is opposed to the pre-payment. The addresses were at the fourth annual dinner of the association, held at the Hotel Statler in connection with the annual national conference.

FRENCH and American teams, now engaged in a match at the Essex House, have their playing room outfitted with rows of seats banked around the players and officials in their ring. This method of exhibition was initiated in the contract bridge duel between the Culbertsons and the Simses at Crockford's Club last Spring; but the present match offers conventional-type tickets of admission for sale, the ringside "top" being $3.30.

NOTHING that A.P. Herbert ever wrote in the pages of Punch or elsewhere is so richly humorous as his election to represent Oxford in the new House of Commons. Whether his participation in the debates contributes to the gayety of Parliament or not, his success at the polls has certainly contributed to the gayety of the country at large.

DRS. J.C. HOSTETTER and G.V. McCauley, not to mention the executives of the Corning Glass Works, kept their fingers crossed last Sunday. And so did a gathering of invited press men and other guests. The 200-inch pancake of glass which had been poured with much ceremony on Dec. 2, 1934, and which had been cooling for a year, was to be removed from its annealing oven.

Value of Dollar in Exchange. The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

In response to a suggestion from President Roosevelt I have called a conference in Washington of widely known individuals and representatives of important groups to work out plans for making accident prevention more effective in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- While the public mind has been riveted on more sensational events elsewhere the naval conference has been grappling courageously this week with problems that will affect the taxpayers of every great nation for years to come.

Professor Julius Tandler, one-time Minister of Public Health of the former Austrian Republic and Commissioner of Public Health and Welfare of the City of Vienna during the Social-Democratic administration there, is now in this city en route to China, where the government has invited him to help organize the new State Medical School at Nanking.

THEY met for the first time when Lily Tennant, movie star, driving her high-powered roadster from Carson toward Reno, suddenly found her way blocked by young Tom Sebastian, rancher, who was driving his cattle herd across the highway.

The Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of York and Primate of England, will spend today and tomorrow in this city. He will preach three times today, and tomorrow he will attend a series of gatherings in his honor. He is accompanied by his wife.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Russell G. Dunmore, once a majority leader in the New York State Assembly and a central figure in the Macy Old Guard fight that disrupted the State Republican organization in 1934, was found shot to death in his home late today. He was 51.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP). -- The State's war agains take race track tip services moved forward today with arraignment of fourteen men and two women among the eighty-six persons recently indicted by a Saratoga County grand jury.

Stripped of its verbiage, Judge Manton's recent letter simply advocates that the United States immediately place an embargo upon coal, oil, cotton, , destined for shipment to Italy, for he says in the last paragraph: "Our policy of neutrality would then shut off practically all commerce with the aggressor."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14 (AP). -- The home-town contingent of Marion Talley's debut audience at the Metropolitan is expected to be greatly surpassed by the one that New Haven will send to New York next Thursday night to honor a native son.

Purchasing and production plans of the great majority of dress firms for the Spring season are not being shaped in a manner dictated by the likelihood of a strike, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc., said last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14. -- The Princeton hockey team encountered unexpected resistance from a hard-fighting Boston University hockey sextet in the Hobey Baker Rink today, but finally emerged victorious, 5-4. It was the Tigers' third victory of the season in as many starts.

ASMARA, Nov. 30. -- It is one of the interesting developments of the warfare in Ethiopia that more and more reliance is coming to be placed on the pack animal instead of the modern truck. The development is more than merely interesting -- it is highly significant.

Facing a situation that less than 10 per cent of the half a million men and women arraigned in magistrates' courts each year are criminals, a group of women active in social welfare have decided to establish a "social service bureau," to function in cooperation with the courts.

OMAHA, Dec. 13. -- When the President speaks on the farm question he has, of course, an attentive audience in the Corn Belt. Most of it is a sympathetic one. And even the dissenting section of it is inclined to agree that he "has his best foot forward when he speaks in defense of his farm program."

The Canadian Pacific Line announced yesterday the appointment of Captain R.G. Latta, known to thousands of travelers as Jock, to succeed Captain James Gillies, C.B.E., as general manager of the line with offices in London.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Fordham overtook Yale after three minutes of play in tonight's basketball game and was never headed thereafter, winning by 38 to 20. The Rams had a 20-15 advantage at the intermission and allowed the Blue only five points in the second half.

By breaking 98 out of 100 targets, A.L. Burns won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He led in a field of thirty-one gunners. The second trophy went to Z.G. Simmons, who had 96. Burns also won the distance prize, breaking 24 out of 25 targets, shooting from the 21-yard mark.

SWITZERLAND is waiting a bit anxiously for the Winter sports season to begin. It looks like a record season as far as numbers of visitors go, for most of the rooms in the big resorts were booked months ago. But will it be a good frosty season, with plenty of snow, so that this Winter's visitors will all want to return to the same resorts next Winter?

A warning to lawyers that they must "organize and govern" their profession or face the dangers of a socialized profession in a socialized State was voiced last night by William L. Ransom, president of the American Bar Association, at the annual dinner of the New York County Lawyers Association.

Carols and traditional holiday melodies echo resoundingly through the meetings of New Jersey organizations, and pageantry is the order of the day in the concerts and dramatic presentations of the month and week.

The fourth annual interschool and college dance will be held Saturday night in the Cascades of the Biltmore. Net proceeds from the event, which will be attended by many younger members of society at home from schools and colleges for the holidays, will be given to Hope Farm in Dutchess County, N.Y., which provides a community home with advantages of educational and occupational training for 200 dependent boys and girls.

Plans for the construction with Federal funds of two 304-foot radio towers for WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, at the foot of Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, on the site of the old Greenpoint ferry terminal, have been approved by Frederick J.H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, it was announced yesterday.

What is expected to be the most important art exhibition ever held in the Southwest is being arranged by Dr. Robert B. Harshe, director of the Art Institute of Chicago, who has come to New York to arrange for loans of paintings and sculpture from private collectors and museums.

Next month's National Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace is going to be unique in more ways than one. For the first time since the first exhibit was held in the original Madison Square Garden thirty-one, years ago Gar Wood is to be present for several days.

Eighty-six undergraduates have been named to twelve City College fraternities, Emanuel Seidman, president of the inter-fraternity council, announces. Delta Pi Epsilon and Theta Kappa Phi head the list with eighteen and eleven pledges respectively.

The location of the Republican party Presidential convention will be determined at a meeting of the national committee in Washington on Dec. 16; that of the Democrats at a meeting early in January. These quadrennial political conclaves, because of their special drawing power and publicity value, are the grand prizes in the convention quest being carried on all the time by the allied go-getters of commercial club promotion bureaus, auditorium managements, hotel and restaurant associations.

More than 85 per cent of the American exporters having commercial balances tied up in Brazil will be able to get their money in full shortly after the first of the year, according to assurances given yesterday to the National Foreign Trade Council, which has been active in arranging a settlement agreement to free $30,000,000 held up there by exchange restrictions.

Marital relations between men and women are their own concern, and neither Church nor State can "dictate whether the ritual of love should be enacted for its own sake or for reproduction alone," it was said yesterday by Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg in his sermon before the Mount Neboh Congregation at 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

PRAGUE, Dec. 14. -- The Presidential standard slowly was hauled down at 1 o'clock this afternoon from the tower of Lany Castle as the signal that Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, founder of the Czechoslovak Republic, had resigned the Presidential office he had held for seventeen years.

A press report states that the full-length portrait of George Washington by Gilbert Stuart owned by the State of Connecticut and hanging in the State Library at Hartford has been appraised as possessing a monetary value of $250,000, and that insurance underwriters have accepted this figure.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14. -- The Supremus gelding Thomasville, carrying the colors of Mrs. J.R. Gregory and trained by Mr. Gregory, made it two in a row at the Fair Grounds when he captured the New Orleans A.C. Handicap today. Favored in a field of nine, the 4-year-old came from well behind in a race for horses of all ages and was drawing away at the finish.

The twenty-fourth annual appeal for New York's Neediest Cases ends its second week today with the total subscribed to the Fund to date -- $110,657.64 -- lagging somewhat behind the total as of the same date last year.

BY the perfume she uses shall you know her. Yes, it's true if she is careful about selecting it. She must know her type, and choose scents accordingly. More than that, she must be careful about how and when she sprays herself with the tell-tale perfume.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Dec. 14. -- Accident and sickness insurance is being offered to students of Vassar College under a unique group policy in what is believed to be the first such step in this country.

A holiday atmosphere prevailed yesterday in so far as the share market was concerned. Prices drifted irregularly within a narrow trading range to close firm, and mixed; the business done on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 666,000 shares, or about half the volume of the Saturday before.

Centralization of government in the United States has been the outcome of the economic depression, just as it grew out of the World War in Germany, Dr. Gotthilf Bronisch, Obermagistratsrat of Berlin, declared here yesterday on the completion of a three-month study of municipal affairs in this country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Next to the public highway, the home is about the most dangerous place frequented by the people of the United States.

Commemorating the sixty-fifth anniversary of its founding, the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York has published a limited numbered edition of a book entitled "Sixty-five Years of Progress and a Record of New York City Banks," Compiled by Jaffray Peterson, for many years associated with the bank, it contains, in addition to a brief history of the Continental, a complete record of New York City banks, from 1784 to Oct. 1. 1935.

A year ago in Italian streets, shops, cafes, public vehicles and private houses the talk was all of taxation. It was not very pleasant talk and had to be stopped. Nobody now talks of taxation, only of war, the inevitable producer of more taxation.

THE first picture of record that Henry Clay Frick ever bought was painted by Luis Jimenez, a minor Spanish artist of the nineteenth century. The last was a Vermeer. In between the two lay dreams and strivings, industrial warfare, battles between financial giants, success snatched out of defeat.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Dr. Robert William Hockman was the son of Dr. William H. Hockman of Wheaton, Ill., former missionary, now on the faculty of Moody Bible Institute in Chicago. His parents, two brothers and a sister survive him.

FRIEDRICH SCHORR is a superb Wotan. He has the voice, bearing, musicianship and profound interpretative instinct that are requisite for a genuine command of the role. Moreover, he has had such experience as few men may assimilate in an artistic career.

Swimmers of George Washington High School shattered the season's record for the 200-yard relay at the ninth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school team championship of the Public School Athletic League, conducted in the 75-foot pool of De Witt Clinton High School yesterday.

At least half a year will be required to investigate the murder of Samuel Druckman and the circumstances surrounding that crime, it was estimated yesterday by Hiram C. Todd, special assistant attorney general who has superseded District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County in the case.

IN this year of no Nobel Prize award for literature, a year of sanctions, apparently not because there is a lack of idealism in current literary production but because the Nobel Library here in Stockholm needs replenishing, there has been an increasingly insistent emphasis, at least among the reading public, on F.E. Sillanpaa, leading Finnish novelist, as the logical candidate, due to his idealistic vision of the sublime in human struggle.

Although Christmas is a week and a half off, many of the churches will today have pre-Christmas services. Especially will this be so in the chapels of universities and theological seminaries because by next Sunday they will be closed for the holidays

MANY modern designers of textiles and ceramics have gone for their source back to the primitive work of the early peoples of America. Indian blankets, pottery and basketry have served as inspirations, along with the craft work of the modern Mexican and his Aztec predecessors.

Editors of trade papers throughout the United States, spokesmen for the industries and professions their journals represent, report substantial gains for the year now ending and forecast, almost unanimously, even more spectacular advances for 1936. All fields, from machine tools to retail clothing, reflect increasing optimism.

At first glance it might seem an exaggeration to connect an East African peace plan with the capture of a city in China. One is on one side of the world and the other is on the opposite side. But fundamentally there is a relation, even if indirect.

PROTESTS against compulsory military training in colleges have attained large enough volume to be deemed worthy of comment by the Secretary of War. In his annual report, published last week, Secretary Dern scored such protests as "based upon the fallacy that such training instills a spirit of militarism in the youth of America."

In the extensive covers of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L.I., next Saturday and Sunday the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club will conduct its annual meeting for all retrievers. This competition will complete the field-trial season in the metropolitan district.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Chattanooga physicians attending Mrs. Leo N. Vick have suggested that some charitable person might offer her three weeks more of life as a New Year's gift. She is suffering from aplastic anemia, a starvation of the red blood cells.

THE problem of taking people off relief rolls has two distinctly different aspects; one is the urban, the other the rural. On June 1, 1935, there were approximately 3,100,000 relief cases on the Federal rolls which were classed as urban. They consisted of people who live in towns and cities of more than 2,500 population -- day laborers, semiskilled and factory workers, white collar employes, and others.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The German Olympic authorities have adopted an attitude of frank indifference toward the anti-Olympic demonstrations that arose in connection with the meeting of the American Amateur Athletic Union in New York.

Officers, trustees and foreign representatives of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace hailed as partly accomplished the aims of its founder at a meeting commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization held yesterday morning at the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

An example to industry in safeguarding health was seen by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in the establishment of the Union Health Center, industrial clinic of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, at the opening of the center's new headquarters, 275 Seventh Avenue.
KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 14.-- Rhode Island State College defeated Harvard tonight, 44 -- 28. A crowd of 1,200 watched the game.

POPE PIUS XI assisted recently at the memorial mass celebrated annually in the Sistine Chapel for the Cardinals who have died during the year. Around him that morning were grouped most of the living Cardinals of the Curia.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Coldly turned down by the leaders of his party, Governor Henry Horner declares "I am still a candidate and will be until after the election. I have not changed my mind at all."

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- A slight note of pessimism crept into the reports presented today at the final 1935 meeting of the German Olympic committee responsible for the preparation of next year's German team.

The plans for an impressive memorial being studied by the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation to honor the late inventor and electrical genius include a building for permanent preservation of Mr. Edison's personal scientific library and records, and a place to house the originals or reproductions of each of the more than 1,000 inventions he perfected, it was learned yesterday.

Displaying marked superiority in every phase of the game, Manhattan's undefeated basketball team increased its string of victories to three by conquering St. Peter's College, 45 to 18, before a crowd of 1,000 at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of November: Total imports, 71,450,000; exports of British products, 39,390,000; re-exports, 4,570,000; total exports, 43,960,000.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- Three hundred years ago the Antilles became French colonies. The celebration of this event, it is believed, will influence Summer styles. Already Madame Agnes is showing huge straw brims mounted on flowered Madras handkerchiefs.
BUCHAREST, Dec. 14. -- Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu denies that there were any negotiations with Soviet Russia for a treaty which would give Russian troops the right to march across Rumania.

THE conflict between the code of honor of Maryland aristocrats and that of lumber and oil millionaires from the West is the basis of this novel. To the Goodloes, whose ancestors had come to America with Lord Calvert, their standards of easy living, hard riding and social superiority were symbolized by the 300-year-old boxwood hedge which surrounded Goodloe's Choice.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Detective Lieutenant George McCartney of the New York City Police Department was injured recently when a fulminating cap on a bomb discovered in a Newark shipment of henna leaves exploded in New York police headquarters, it was disclosed here tonight by the local police.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Growing evils and several recommendations for the conduct of intercollegiate sports were pointed out by Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the Board of Athletic Control of New York University, who spoke today before members of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Association.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 14. -- From Aroostook's expansive wilderness comes the startling tale of a buck deer carrying heavy antlers upon a massive head set upon an immense body, but unable to more than waddle away when alarmed, because its legs are no longer than a pig's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend predicted today that the third-party movement for his pension plan would obtain support from Progressives, Farmer-Laborites, Non-Partisan Leaguers and the American Commonwealth Federation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Experts of several Federal departments have been going through the record of public utterances by Herbert Hoover to discover possible inconsistencies to discredit his attacks on New Deal principles and, by that device, the arguments of other Republican spokesmen as well.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14. -- A slender, quiet golfer, Ted Turner of Pine Valley, N.J., came blazing unheralded through the dusk today to post 68, three under par, for the first round of the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament and seize medalist honors.

AN elaborate series of events is scheduled for the fifty-seventh meeting of the Music Teachers National Association, to be held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the National Association of Schools of Music, Dec. 27-31, at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Townsend Old-Age Revolving Pension Plan movement is on the upswing again. Last Spring the plan was thrown out of Congress, battered by uncomfortable sessions with the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees, and trampled in a House of Representatives test vote, in which it mustered a bare sixty supporters.

As Henry Woodhouse suggests in the questions in his letter to THE TIMES, the preamble may lay obligations of a sort on Congress, but it surely does not grant power, and it is the taxing power of Congress that is before the court today for adjudication.

TRADE moved toward its holiday peak during the week, with reports from most centers agreeing that it would be the best since 1930. In some areas it was indicated that even the 1929 totals would be exceeded. The trend toward better qualities was emphasized.

IF it is true that half the world is in ignorance of how the other half lives, it can be said with no exaggeration nor any intent to alarm that 99 99-100 per cent of the 120,000,000 inhabitants of these United States has not the faintest conception of how the other 1-100 per cent plays.

AT a recent breakfast given by the Limited Editions Club the food was prepared from recipes in Alexandre Dumas's famous cookery book, "Petit Dictionnaire de la Cuisine." It was a nice touch to have the title page and the recipes reproduced in facsimile and bound with the menu.

Musical programs appropriate to the Christmas season will feature many of the meetings of the women's clubs of Westchester during the next seven days. This evening the Bronxville Woman's Club will have a Christmas candlelight musicale.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- A capacity audience in the Academy of Music looked on in amazement tonight when Saul Caston, a member of the clarinet section of the Philadelphia Orchestra, took Leopold Stokowski's place on the podium and conducted the orchestra in the playing of Borodin's "On the Steppes in Central Asia."

Barnard College will celebrate Christmas in the last week before vacation with a number of parties to be given by the college and the clubs. The festivities of the week will center around the Christmas assembly Tuesday, which will be broadcast over WEAF at 1 o'clock.

Last week in the security markets was one of uncertainty; hesitant movements in stocks resulted in the widest decline of any week since that ended on July 28, with THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks down 3.68 points, against 5.26 for the final week in July; the November advance has been wiped out. Corporate bonds averaged lower, although the new offerings of all classifications, totaling more than $200,000,000, were well received.

Announcement by the New York Central and Union Pacific railways of the construction of more streamlined trains, made last week, served to round out a year of progress in the improvement of passenger equipment.

FOR the benefit of reviewers of an earlier book who, perhaps, may review this one. Mr. Seldes thinks it well to state that he nurses no grudge against either Mussolini or fascism because of his expulsion from Italy in 1925. On the contrary, he believes that he owes the Duce "a note of thanks."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Early December continued to reflect the favorable trend of recent months, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of the domestic business situation.

After making a courageous, uphill fight against infantile paralysis for more than two years, a 14-year-old girl, who only last Monday had been overjoyed at receiving assurances of treatment at Warm Springs, Ga., died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital of the effects of a heavy cold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Anti-New Deal publishers and lawyers sizzled on the pan of satire tonight at the semi-annual dinner of the Gridiron Club, which was attended by notables of all political complexions from President Roosevelt on down.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- Gifford Pinchot seldom falls to start speculation when he comes out of the Pike County woods after temporary retirement and fires a blast at Mellonism, the "special interests," the Republican organization or the Democrats.

Staging a brilliant drive in the closing half, the Frederick Douglass Junior High School basketball team of Manhattan vanquished the John Marshall five of Brooklyn, 24 -- 10, yesterday in the final of the ananual tournament for the P.S.A.L. junior high schools title on the court of Stuyvesant High School.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- Syracuse University this week became the center of a friendly debate concerning the teaching role of women in higher education. A poll showed that a preponderant number of faculty and administrative officials favor more women in teaching, although the dissenters have a strong following.

A letter to the Business News Editor, which refers to comment upon the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, from Iser P. Cohen, president of the Cohen Brothers Corporation, leading manufacturer of sportswear, contains the following:

THE BOX OF DELIGHTS" is well named, for the reader will find in it a content as varied and enchanting as Kay Harker found when he turned the knob of the polished oval box left in his keeping by Cole Hollings, the gentle, mysterious Punch and Judy man.

Unfavorable repercussions to industry in general, following the breakdown of the greatly heralded conference between Major Berry and business men last week, were predicted here yesterday by association heads and executives who attended the meeting and who devoted considerable thought to its implications during the week.

An accident in which two private automobiles, a fire engine and a bus were involved caused slight injuries to seven persons and attracted a large crowd at the intersection of Broadway and Ninety-sixth Street shortly before 7 o'clock last night.

Exhibitions by the figure skaters who are preparing for the national championships and Olympic try-outs the end of this month will feature the sixth annual New York American Christmas and relief fund charity carnival at the Ice Club Wednesday night.

Holiday trade in the metropolitan area forged ahead last week, with crowded stores giving evidence of the accelerated pace expected to feature shopping during the eight business days remaining before Christmas. Average gains of 5 to 7 per cent for the week in comparison with 1934 were estimated for leading department stores, with indications being that the peak of holiday buying would see these figures increased to around 10 per cent.

SINCE William Lyon Phelps became a syndicated colomnist a multitude of readers has enjoyed daily his printed conversations with them, to their own great entertainment, information and interest, and, doubtless, their increased civilization and enjoyment of life.

IN spite of the hurried manner in which a naval board disposed of the crash of the Macon last February, indicating to some observers that the skeptics on the question of lighter-than-air craft in the navy meant to get rid of airships once and for all, it appears now as if the navy is not altogether of one mind on the matter.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, National League professional football team, slithered through a morass of mud today to a 14-0 victory over a college allstar team.

MRS. MORGAN may be congratulated on the high degree of sympathetic intelligence which she has brought to the problem of mass civilization in the future. It is a subject, of course, which has engaged the attention of many distinguished minds, but it is also one over which distinguished scholars and philosophers find it remarkably easy to lose their tempers and forget their facts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks reserved decision today on the request of the New York Westchester Railroad for the appointment as trustees under the recent reorganization petition of Howard S. Palmer, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad; James Lee Loomis of Granby, representing Hartford insurance companies and Professor Winthrop M. Daniels of Yale University.

BOTH his intimate knowledge of the ancient Roman world and the persuasive eloquence with which he can write about it Grant Showerman, Professor of Classics in the University of Wisconsin, proved long ago with his "Eternal Rome," "Rome and the Romans," "Horace and His Influence" and other books.

LONDON, NOV. 21. GEORGE MUNRO is a well-known Fleet Street crime reporter, and in "Murder Gang," a play written in collaboration with Basil Dean, he has turned to account a professional experience which appears to have revolted him.

DEL RIO, Texas. -- While Texas cigarette smokers await court decision on the provision of the law that requires the user to pay the tax on cigarettes bought from dealers who refuse to pay it, cigarette peddlers and bootleggers continue to profit and the State continues to lose revenue.

THE United States radio industry is not likely to benefit greatly from the new reciprocal trade treaty between this country and Canada, according to opinions received from both American and Canadian manufacturers by Bond Geddes, executive vice president of the Radio Manufacturers Association.

The postoffice reported last night that Christmas mail from the United States to Europe had broken two records this year. The total of mail sent during the week was 59,697 sacks, more than 15,000 bags more than the figure for last year.

THE inside story of the events in Germany which led to the outbreak of the World War is told in Theodor Wolff's book, "The Eve of 1914," which Alfred A. Knopf will publish in January. Dr. Wolff was editor of the Berliner Tageblatt from 1906 to 1933, a position which enabled him to meet the foremost rulers and diplomats of Continental Europe.

Madame Emily Spade, a successful concert soprano in England and Australia thirty years ago, lies seriously ill and virtually penniless in a two-room flat at 32 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, within half a mile of her early home from which she went forth as a child to achieve fame in the musical world.

With one of his characteristically brilliant exhibitions, Harry F. Wolf, national squash tennis champion, gained the final round of the December scratch tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

CHRISTMAS trees are piling up on West Street. By train and by truck they are rolling into the city for distribution by florists and greengrocers, and, in the more densely crowded quarters of the city, by sidewalk vendors -- little fir trees that soon will be all alight, festooned with tinsel and roped with pop-corn.

WE are told from time to time that the theatre is dying; from other quarters come passionate announcements that the theatre is being reborn. Both the wail and the announcement are untrue; both are uttered without any exact knowledge of the nature of things and therefore of the nature of this thing.

IT is just one hundred years since a young Frenchman, Alexis de Tocqueville, brought out the first two volumes of a philosophical treatise which he called "Democracy in America." It was a large and learned work, designed neither to catch the fancy of Americans who resented all criticism nor of Frenchmen who resented democracy.

Day camps for children in the city's parks, which were started as vacation centers for nature study and recreation, now have become outdoor schools with courses in history, geography and social science correlated with classroom work.

THE Frick Collection will be open to the public, without charge, weekdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. The galleries will be closed on legal holidays; also from July 16 to Aug. 15 inclusive, and at such other times as may be found necessary for the care of the building and its contents and for the welfare of visitors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The merging of the Oak Ridge Golf Club of Tuckahoe and the Progress Country Club of Purchase, two of Westchester's better-known golf clubs, was disclosed this week when Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close signed a certificate of incorporation for the Old Oaks Country Club, Inc.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- No matter what the League of Nations decides next week, the Hoare-Laval plan will be imposed on Ethiopia in the end, in the opinion of J.L. Garvin, editor of The Sunday Observer.

SHY young girls of 17, living old-fashioned, sequestered lives, cling to the hopeful theory that romance will some day come their way. When they are lucky enough to be heroines in a Ruby M. Ayres novel, it is safe to predict that the blissful "Some Day" will arrive fairly soon -- some time before page 300.

THE newly completed section of New Jersey's Route 2 extending from the West Saddle River Road to its intersection with the Franklin Turnpike, in the vicinity of Ramsey, was scheduled to be opened to traffic yesterday. It is more than six miles in length, has two one-way lanes separated by a strip of grass in the centre, and represents an expenditure of $798,000, part of which was paid by the Federal Government.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 14. -- The Bryn Mawr College Choir of nearly eighty voices will set a precedent tomorrow and Monday evenings by appearing jointly with another college choir. With the Princeton University Choir it will sing Handel's "Messiah," giving one performance at Princeton and the other here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Forty-seven of the fifty PWA low-cost housing and slum clearance projects are under contract, and buildings on nine of these are under actual construction, A.R. Clas, director of the organization's housing division, said today.

TOLD in the first person singular by one of its leading characters, this tale has several other features that differentiate it from the common run of Western thrillers. Ward West, who has been working in Chicago, goes back to Colorado for the Summer to visit his boyhood chum, Harper Wallace, foster son to old Mike Higginson, owner of a big horse ranch halfway to timberline, and runs into a baffling mystery.

HEN auk eggs, said to be the most valuable in the world, each worth its weight in gold, recently arrived at Harvard University. This collection was the bequest of the late Colonel J.E. Thayer, and is now being made ready for study by the curator of ornithology, as each of these rarities has a most interesting history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14. -- Three of the large Matson freighters arrived from the Hawaiian Islands all within three hours and began unloading what is believed to be a record cargo of sugar and molasses.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C. PAUL GREEN'S drama about American university life, "The Enchanted Maze," which may be produced in New York later this season, had its first production here a week ago by the Carolina Playmakers of the University of North Carolina, the troupe with which he started his playwriting career.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- The Hamden High School, which was opened this Fall, today defeated the Yale freshmen at hockey, 5 -- 4, in the New Haven arena. Jerry Grace, Hugh Young and Roger Benton figured in the Hamden scoring and excelled in all-around play.
BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- A New York dramatic success, "The Children's Hour," was added tonight to the long list of plays banned in Boston as indecent.

Ten years ago this month, in the Foreign Office at London, the Treaty of Locarno was signed. Throughout Europe and the world the event was hailed as a turning point in Franco-German history; the peace of the Old World seemed more secure. Today France and Germany glare at each other across the Rhine; the Treaty of Locarno seems to have become a dead document.

TORONTO, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press). -- David Croll, Welfare Minister, said today that a "Quintuplet tie-up racket" is in operation in New York and Toronto. Promoters, he said, assert that they are agents of the Ontario Government and are undertaking to obtain rights to use the Dionne quintuplets' names and photographs in connection with advertising.

IN her "Portrait Done at Home" Dorothy Cheston Bennett tells with complete candor the story of her life with Arnold Bennett. At no point in the narrative does she permit any hint of sensationalism to creep into her pages. Nor is she ever denunciatory.

Jack Altman, secretary of Local New York of the Socialist party, said last night in a statement that the voting in the party branches had resulted in a repudiation of delegates who had voted with the Old Guard faction at a meeting of the City Central Committee.

THAT group which started out nearly a year ago to be the Stage Associates, and then didn't bother to be much of anything, is getting serious. They have been holding conferences, reading plays, and what they are looking forward to now is an acting unit something like the Group Theatre. Twenty members, say.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- An attempt to halt liquor "traffic" across the Connecticut border into Westchester County was disclosed today with the arrest of two persons, one of whom was seized late yesterday and the other today on the complaint of the Westchester County Liquor Dealers Association.

With a strong group of thirty-two competitors, representing many of the clubs in the metropolitan district entered, play in the second annual Long Island squash racquets championship started on the courts of the Bayside Tennis Club in Bayside yesterday.

Peak figures for the depression period in wholesale and retail trade continued to be marked up in most sections of the country last week as holiday shopping gained momentum. As crop revenues expanded farmers' buying power and as workers found new Jobs opening up, numerous indications pointed to the best Christmas business since 1930 and in several instances coming close to the 1929 figure.

CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Dr. Robert W. Hockman had joined Christmas greetings with a description of the dangerous situation in Ethiopia in letters he wrote to relatives here from Addis Ababa on Sept. 22 before hostilities began.

A CHORAL meeting will be held in the County Center, White Plains, on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, under the auspices of the Westchester Music Festival Association. Dr. Laurence Redway, president of the association, announces that the meeting will be under the direction of Caroline B. Fry, choral chairman of the association.

The article in today's drama section on the background of the present production of "Ghosts" with Mme. Nazimova is incomplete. The impression I gather from the article is that Nazimova, appearing in the Middle West in "The Simpleton of the Unexpected Isles," was suddenly persuaded upon her arrival in Detroit to appear also in "Ghosts."

DEALING with the history and duties of the American metropolitan police, this volume, by two experienced newspaper men, is rather comprehensive in the ground it covers. While it is largely concerned with police work in New York City, it includes, the authors say, organization and methods in other large cities also, although these are rarely differentiated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Straw votes have the same fascination for the human race that fortune tellers have, and for the same reason. Next to his unquenchable search for faith or proof that there is life beyond the grave comes man's attempt to discover what he will do in the immediate future. But the trial polls have this advantage over clairvoyance. They depend for their accuracy on visible evidence instead of on second-sight.

LEAVING the Mesa Verde, where he has been working as a forest ranger, Wade McAllister goes down into Texas to take over a ranch he has never seen but has just inherited from an uncle he had fairly forgotten, and runs into one of the worst dust storms ever known on the Bucklin.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Three discoveries which promise to cast new light on phases of Asiatic history have been made by Dr. Muhammad A. Simsar, a young Persian Orientalist, while cataloguing and translating the John Frederick Lewis collection of more than 150 Oriental manuscripts.

PARIS. HEARTS and fans, rather than "Hearts and Flowers," might be a title for the style ballad inspired by the Paris midseason mode. Hearts of fur or fabric are among the most amusing trimmings featured by Schiaparelli. Fans appear in pleats and are variously used on dresses and wraps.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- The German Government confirmed today that a conference was held yesterday between Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, and Sir Eric Phipps, the British Ambassador, regarding the limitatton of armaments by issuing the following communique:

ALBANIA has undertaken a campaign to attract tourist traffic despite the fact that it lacks that most valuable of assets -- passenger railways. The little country on the Adriatic, bounded by Yugoslavia and Greece, has been called the least-known corner of Europe.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Giving a first-class demonstration of horsemanship, Major J.H. Thompson of the West Point horse show team tonight won the individual military jumping championship of the twelfth annual military horse show sponsored by Troop F of the 102d Cavalry, held in the Essex troop armory.
Reorganization of the Works Progress Administration for New York City, designed to decentralize control of the organization, was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Reports circulated here tonight, without official confirmation, that at least two members of the present Federal Reserve Board would not be chosen for the new Board of Governors for the system, which will take office on Feb. 1.

THIS newest tale by the veteran Canadian novelist who has published all his works under the pseudonym of Ralph Connor falls, technically at least, into the classification of historical romance. On the whole, however, there is more romance than history in "The Rebel Loyalist."

Off to a fine start with a run of 62 in the third inning, Joe Procita of Gloversville, N.Y., accounted for the first major upset of the tournament by defeating Edwin Rudolph of Cleveland, top-heavy favorite, in the world's pocket billiard championship last night in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Trailing by three points early in the second half, C.C.N.Y. put on a spirited rally to defeat Dickinson College, 41 -- 26, on the Beavers' home basketball court last night. It was the third straight victory for the Lavender and the second defeat on successive nights for the Red Devils, who lost to L.I.U. on Friday.
ROME, Dec. 14. -- The first Italian criticisms of the Franco-British plan for the solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy began to make their appearance today.

If I were a critic, I'd be a happy man this week. A play has come to town, and I can use my adjectives again. I can see myself set ting down: "Mr. Clifford Odets's new play, 'Paradise Lost,' opened Monday night at the Longacre. It is stirring, hard, mocking, bitter and eloquent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14. -- The University of California at Los Angeles carved the final chapter of its greatest football season into the turf of Kezar Stadium today with a 13-to-7 victory over a favored St. Mary's College eleven.
A correspondent asks the meaning of the passage "The wind bloweth where it listeth," John iii, 8. That question has been asked many times.

MR. HOWARD'S biography of Stephen Collins Foster ("Stephen Foster, America's Troubadour," 1934) may well stand as the definitive life. He has now accomplished a like task for Ethelbert Nevin, that American composer whose melodious, lilting, graceful piano pieces and charming songs won a popularity unprecedented in the annals of American music.

Establishment of a ferry terminal in Chisholm Park, Queens, would be illegal, Borough President Harvey and Park Commissioner Moses declared yesterday, in protest against the local bill by which the Board of Estimate on Friday sanctioned the terminal plan.

NO one will deny that all over the world today life is changing for better or worse for millions of human beings. Such changes have taken place before in history; and in each place where it has happened life has been a hell for the artist trying to express that time.

The dance given by the Language League at the Roerich Museum last night inaugurated a busy social season for City College clubs, fraternities and the sophomore, junior and senior classes. Ten affairs are scheduled to be held within the next few weeks.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14. -- Pittsburgh had Hub Randour on its side today and his presence meant the football game won by the Panthers from the University of Southern California, 12 to 7.

SINCE the two harum-scarum rogues who operate in "Boy Meets Girl" are Hollywood staff writers, the new comedy at the Cort is bound to be known as Hollywood satire; and, of course, it is. It tumbles and grimaces over the movie lots like a derisive buffoon.

THE encouraging interest manifested by the public in the opening of the Metropolitan Opera season of 1936-37, which takes place tomorrow night, is local evidence of a fact that need never have been doubted -- namely, the everlasting vitality and interest for artists and audiences of this form of art.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Yale University today announced the award for the current year of scholarship and beneficiary aid totaling $319,053 to 713 undergraduates. Additional awards to graduate and professional school students, together with supplementary employment for needy students, were estimated at about $1,050,000 for the year.

The sensational Joe Louis left this city yesterday for his home in Detroit, unconcerned about his twenty-sixth straight professional ring victory, his twenty-second knockout triumph with Paulino Uzcudun the victim, and richer by some $36,878 for one of the easiest fights of his career.

AMONG the forces mobilized throughout nation in various safety campaigns, the Boy Scouts are doing their share. Observance of common rules for safety in the home, at camp and for every phase of scouting is a cardinal Scout principle.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- With the Stock Exchange closed here today money remained plentiful in Lombard Street. Week-end loans were available at one-half of 1 per cent and less, while the three-month bill rate was steady at three-quarters of 1 per cent.

THERE'S nothing like a dash of Dwight Franklin to tone down one's respect for the cinema's accuracy. Mr. Franklin, who has done several other things, may be identified this once as a composite technical adviser-art director for the screen.

ATLANTA, Dec. 13. -- When it seemed that the last avenue of legal escape from an eighteen-year sentence to a Georgia chain-gang had been closed to Angelo Herndon, a habeas corpus ruling by Judge Hugh M. Dorsey reopened the case of the youthful Negro Communist.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Even in France, which has had a long succession of astute statesmen and politicians from the days of Richelieu and Mazarin to Thiers and Briand, Pierre Laval seems likely, on the present showing, to have a niche to himself.
SIDNEY. WHEN the last foot of 1936 film is "in the can" the infant Australian movie industry fully expects to have attained world recognition that will signify the passing of its fledgling days.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14. -- Yale University today announced the award for the current year of scholarship and beneficiary aid totaling $319,053 to 713 undergraduates. Additional awards to graduate and professional school students, together with supplementary employment for needy students, were estimated at about $1,050,000 for the year.

The sensational Joe Louis left this city yesterday for his home in Detroit, unconcerned about his twenty-sixth straight professional ring victory, his twenty-second knockout triumph with Paulino Uzcudun the victim, and richer by some $36,878 for one of the easiest fights of his career.

AMONG the forces mobilized throughout nation in various safety campaigns, the Boy Scouts are doing their share. Observance of common rules for safety in the home, at camp and for every phase of scouting is a cardinal Scout principle.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- With the Stock Exchange closed here today money remained plentiful in Lombard Street. Week-end loans were available at one-half of 1 per cent and less, while the three-month bill rate was steady at three-quarters of 1 per cent.

THERE'S nothing like a dash of Dwight Franklin to tone down one's respect for the cinema's accuracy. Mr. Franklin, who has done several other things, may be identified this once as a composite technical adviser-art director for the screen.

ATLANTA, Dec. 13. -- When it seemed that the last avenue of legal escape from an eighteen-year sentence to a Georgia chain-gang had been closed to Angelo Herndon, a habeas corpus ruling by Judge Hugh M. Dorsey reopened the case of the youthful Negro Communist.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Giving a first-class demonstration of horsemanship, Major J.H. Thompson of the West Point horse show team tonight won the individual military jumping championship of the twelfth annual military horse show sponsored by Troop F of the 102d Cavalry, held in the Essex troop armory.
Reorganization of the Works Progress Administration for New York City, designed to decentralize control of the organization, was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Reports circulated here tonight, without official confirmation, that at least two members of the present Federal Reserve Board would not be chosen for the new Board of Governors for the system, which will take office on Feb. 1.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 14. -- Alabama is said by competent observers to be still too dependent upon the Federal Government for relief and other assistance to pay serious attention to the attacks of her larger business men and smaller tenant farmers on the New Deal.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey and Captain Dan D. Casement of Manhattan, Kan., president of the Farmers Independence Council, condemned President Roosevelt's New Deal yesterday as a threat to American institutions.

In connection with the 100th anniversary of the great fire of 1835, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition contemporary paintings, prints, maps, data and paraphernalia of that memorable event.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 14. -- The national champion court tennis team of Ogden Phipps and William Rand, representing New York, was upset by the Van Alert brothers, James and William, today on the Greentree estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- The first girls' boarding school to be established here by the government will be opened within a few weeks at 5,123 South Park Way under the Works Progress Administration. About 130 girls between the ages of 16 and 25 will be selected from relief and WPA families throughout the State to take three months' residence courses in "community leadership."
The time, the place, the prosecutor and the judge for Governor Lehman's special investigation of the Druckman murder case were selected last week.

American prints by Currier Ives and other lithographers will be offered at auction on Wednesday evening at the Plaza Art Galleries. They ate the property of Mrs. Sanford Clement, Alfred Naumberg and other collectors.
VACATIONISTS who come to Florida for diversion and relaxation during the North's frigid months have begun a season that is expected to be unusually varied in its characteristics.

WITH the fear of English competition growing, the generous attitude and enthusiastic pledges of cooperation extended toward Michael Balcon, head of Gaumont-British, a few months ago were noticeably lacking during his recent visit.
MASSILLON, Ohio, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Andrew Merrell, superintendent of Massillon's waste collection department, formally announced today that the joke was on the jokesters.
