A ROAD project which has received little public attention in the States, but is considered important by territorial Americans, is the proposal to build a motor highway across the Isthmus of Panama. Ships, airplanes and railroad trains now cross the Isthmus, but need for a highway is stressed by residents of the Canal Zone.

With prices for seats in the galleries drastically cut, the Franco-American international bridge match between the Four Aces of the United States and the Parisian team that won the European championship last June continued yesterday at Essex House before a sizable crowd.

PLASTIC surgery, or, as its practitioners prefer to call it, reconstructive surgery, is so new a branch of surgery and, as Dr. Maliniak deplores often and bitterly throughout its pages, has already been so misrepresented and mishandled by chariatans and cosmeticians as to make the general public distrustful of its possibilities even in the hands of competent surgeons.

THE autonomy movement in North China, with its threat to the Central (or Nanking) Government dominated by Chiang Kai-shek, focuses attention on the Chinese soldier and particularly on Chiang's own army. Outside the bandit organizations, there are some 3,000,000 soldiers in Chitin; Chiang's force numbers 250.000, and of all the Chinese armies it rates highest in discipline, spirit and military efficiency.

BROADWAY, for all its studied cynicism, is a street upon which enthusiasms flourish like the proverbial green-bay tree. Yesterday's reigning sensation may have been a torch-singer wailing her heart out or a big-bosomed, wise-cracking blonde.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The fate of the New Deal's program for the control of agricultural production now rests in the hands of the Supreme Court of the United States. The important issue of the constitutionality of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the Cotton Control Act awaits the decision of that court.

There is a pause in the Italo-Ethiopian matter until the meeting of the League of Nations early this week. But it is not an interval of silence. Never, perhaps, has a proposed treaty of peace been so freely and widely discussed in advance of formal action upon it.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14. -- The New York Rangers tonight gave the finest display of inside blue line hockey seen here this season to defeat the Stanley Cup holders, the Montreal Maroons, 6 -- 2, in a National Hockey League contest that saw the champions open up to the limit in a vain attempt to match the New Yorkers' four-goal lead established in the first period.

At the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street, an event of the week will be the lecture to be given on Friday afternoon by Kenneth Chorley, director of the Restoration of Colonial Williamsburg, Va. The speaker will utilize colored slides to depict the work being done, under the guidance of John D. Rockefeller Jr., at Williamsburg, one of the oldest and most historic towns in the United States.

American socialism has come to a definite split, largely on the question of when -- if ever -- a resort to violence should be employed to put its program into effect. The dispute is between "left wingers" and "Old Guards." Its result, according to spokesmen for both factions, probably will be the creation of two rival parties, each claiming to be the true repository of the faith and each seeking control of the movement.

SOME twenty-three years ago Miss Henrietta Szold, a native of Baltimore, introduced a medical service in Palestine, then a raw pioneer country. Since then that servce has become a pillar of modern Palestine, ministering to the health of the people, irrespective of race or creed.

A Columbia quintet that shows more class and promise than any Lion team in years deftly hurdled over Colgate at the Morningside gymnasium last night, 28 to 17. It was not the mere victory that impressed as much as the manner in which it was scored.

That the night skies of thousands of years ago can be recovered seems a scientific miracle as startling as the appearance of a strange star must have been to ancient wise men who were, with the shepherds, the first students of the stars. As has been announced, the Planetarium has made possible this crossing of "the dark backward and abysm of time."

After deliberating three and a half hours, a verdict of not guilty was returned last night by the jury in the Court of General Sessions before whom the three officers of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company went on trial five weeks ago charged with publishing a false statement of its cash assets in January, 1933.

Mrs. Fletcher M. Johnson of Irvington-on-Hudson, formerly dean of women at Wesleyan College in Macon, Ga., will be a speaker this afternoon at a tea at Beekman Tower given by the New York Alumnae of Phi Mu, national fraternity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Although it was stalled almost at inception by the depression, Interstate Commerce Commission spokesmen said today that their six-year-old railroad consolidation plan still is a potential weapon against high-cost carrier operation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Armed with a smuggled revolver, Edward Metelski, 26 years old, who was to have gone on trial for his life Monday for the murder of a State trooper, seized the Middlesex County Jail here at 5:30 P.M. today, locked an assistant warden in a cell and then forced another prisoner to flee with him.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 14. -- State committees today completed their task of interviewing candidates and choosing nominees for the Rhodes scholarship competition. The nominees, two from each State except in rare instances where only one was chosen, will appear before the district committees on Monday for final interviews.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 14. -- President Arturo Alessandri sent a communication to Finance Minister Gustavo Ross this afternoon indicating his approval of the recent agreement reached by the Minister with C.E. Calder, vice president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, on the proposed reorganization of the so-called Chilean Electric Corporation.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. l4. -- St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, Manhattan, is bequeathed the principal of the residuary estate left by James A. Hayden of Huntington, after the death of the latter's widow, Elizabeth Bruce Gwynne Hayden, who lives at the Hotel Gotham, Manhattan, according to Mr. Hayden's will and codicil.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The Thursday Club will sponsor a supper dance Saturday evening at the Ardsley Country Club here. The proceeds will be used for its philanthropic fund. Mrs. Kenyon B. Conger Jr. will serve as chairman.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 13. -- The assassination of Walter Liggett last Monday, presumably because of violent attacks on commercialized racketeering and corrupt politics in his Mid-West American Weekly, has shocked the city and State as few events have done in many years.

RARE is the traveler who returns home with luggage that does not bulge with mementoes of his peregrinations. Primitive man, when he traveled, collected rocks arid shells, twigs and flowers, birds and beasts, scalps and slaves.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 13. -- "Not even a legitimist government could carry out Archduke Otto's restoration under present conditions," it was emphasized a few days ago by Minister of the Interior Nicholas Kozma in the Hungarian Parliament in the course of a noisy debate among the legitimists and anti-legitimists.

The first of a series of conferences by which it is hoped to avert the threatened strike of 105,000 workers in the dress industry here will be held on Tuesday evening at the Hotel Astor by representatives of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union and the National Dress Manufacturers Association.

Formation here last week of the National Institute of Wine and Spirits Distributors, Inc., national organization for liquor wholesalers, concludes more than a year of bickering among jobbers as to the need for a new organization to represent their interests.

With final reports still to be received from many of the 2,727 local committees organized throughout the United States and Alaska to solicit subscriptions to perpetuate the memory of America's cowboy humorist, the Will Rogers Memorial Fund campaign was closed formally yesterday.

TWO unusual and reliable foliage plants which appear far too little in the indoor garden are the polypodium fern (P. aureum mandaianum) and the aralia (A. elegantissima). Both thrive under ordinary house conditions and both are of interesting and arresting form.

A SERVICE in memory of Clement C. Moore, who wrote "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," will be held today in St. Peter's Church, Chelsea. It was Moore who gave the land on which St. Peter's stands and who, with other old New York citizens, organized the Chelsea parish it serves.
BOSTON, Dec. 13. -- William Robinson Pattangall, once a Republican, then for more than half a long lifetime a Democrat, has become once more a Republican.

Government control of the munitions industry has received an overwhelmingly favorable vote in the poll on war and peace being conducted by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches. Harold O. Hatcher, research director of the Council, said that the vote passed the 100,000 mark last week and that reports from 1,303 churches had been tabulated.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The imposition of sanctions against Italy last month had no appreciable effect on British foreign trade, according to the Board of Trade returns published today.

Ivan Boyeff, head of the Amtorg Trading Corporation here, who sailed for Europe at noon yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, carried with him for submission to the Soviet authorities in Moscow definite proposals for the settlement of some major debts and claims held by United States citizens and corporations against the Soviet Government.

THE majority of universities throughout the world have manifested the most inexcusable academism in their persistent neglect of psychical research. In the last fifty years masses of data have been compiled from outside sources making it imperative for the Psychology Professor either to bring discredit scientifically to such testimony or to carry on this investigation in his own laboratory.

An unusual prospective event is the representation of Winter sports teams who will assemble for the first time in the annals of skating in this country the night of Dec. 30 at the Madison Square Garden for the final Olympic tryouts and national championships for figure skating.

That there are no longer any separate women's problems but that all the world is woman's province is the contention of Mrs Chase Going Woodhouse, director of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations at New London, Conn. "Women are in the economical and political world to stay -- in thee United States.

EDITOR SLAIN: In Minneapolis last week gunmen disposed of their most insistent editorial enemy -- Walter Liggett, publisher of The Midwest American. Liggett was shot down as his wife and young daughter looked on.
Trends of prices were mixed yesterday in the brief trading session in futures in the commodity markets here. In the cash markets, rubber was higher and grain and cotton moved lower.

TAKING a short breath before the holidays, the cinema will deposit four brightly wrapped packages at as many first-run theatres in the midtown sector this week. One of them will remain through the Christmas season, while the others will pass quietly out of the running.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- California today witnesses the curious spectacle of conservative Governor Merriam's State Relief Commission standing with the radical Upton Sinclair wing of the Democratic party against Harry Hopkins and the Roosevelt administration on the issue of self-help for the unemployed.
HAWKSHEAD, Lancashire, Eng., Dec. 14. -- The mystery of 7-year-old Frank Atkinson, who "vibrates" when he sleeps and whose body produces strange "knockings," has been solved -- in principle at least.

Formation here last week of the National Institute of Wine and Spirits Distributors, Inc., national organization for liquor wholesalers, concludes more than a year of bickering among jobbers as to the need for a new organization to represent their interests.

With final reports still to be received from many of the 2,727 local committees organized throughout the United States and Alaska to solicit subscriptions to perpetuate the memory of America's cowboy humorist, the Will Rogers Memorial Fund campaign was closed formally yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Prices for grain futures here last week had a liberal range and with the exception of a fractional loss in December corn all futures closed higher than the previous week. Quotations follow:

Eight million unemployed, 800,000 in New York City alone, one in every three in need -- these figures impress the average New Yorker by their magnitude in a statistically detached way. And, of course, they are overwhelming.

The United Hospital Committee, under the chairmanship of Mr. McGARRAH set a goal of $2,000,000 for its campaign, which is to end in three days. This word is but a reminder to those who have purposed giving that they should send their contribution or pledge at once.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- Conditions in the money market here this week remained extremely tight. Call money is being lent at the rate of 5 per cent, but one-month loans only are obtainable at the Bank of France.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The selection of a convention city and a change of the rules to allow basing the size of the State delegations on the 1928 Presidential vote, the immediate questions which will confront the Republican National Committee meeting tomorrow, were subordinated in preliminary conferences today to the complicated situation facing the party as to a standard bearer an platform for 1936.

Mayor La Guardia, acting on protests against placing a terminal for the College Point ferry in Chisholm Park, Queens, has ordered a survey to determine the availability of Tallman's Island as an alternative site, it was made known yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 15 (AP). -- President Lazaro Cardenas struck swiftly today to gain the upper hand over the newly returned Plutarco Elias Calles in what appeared to be a rapidly approaching showdown over whether he or the former President will rule the political destinies of Mexico.

The former Heller handkerchief factory at 3,421-3,425 Hudson Boulevard, northwest corner of Lincoln Street, Jersey City, has been sold by the Paulus Hook Corporation to Vincent J. Curcio, distributor of barber and beauty parlor supplies. This is a modern four-story structure having 44,000 square feet of working space.

Except for the upward surge in the French franc to the highest level since late August at 6.62 cents, a reflection of the lessened tension in the French political situation, and the plunge downward to new lows for the Chinese currencies an aftermath of the unsettled silver market, other descriptions moved narrowly and at no important change from the preceding week.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 15. -- While the Westchester County Liquor Dealers Association laid plans for wholesale arrests of persons transporting liquor from Connecticut into the county, attorneys for Mrs. Frank D. Potter of Rye who was arrested on the complaint of the association Friday, announced today that the case may be taken to the United States Supreme Court.

Miss Laura Hampton Hover of Santa Monica, Calif., eloped to Armonk, N.Y., with Homer Leslie Loomis Jr. of 470 Park Avenue early last Thursday morning and they were married there before a justice of the peace, according to village records which were made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Winter wheat conditions are fair to good ever a large part of the area, particularly in the Middle West and the eastern two-thirds of the Southwestern territory. Throughout the extreme western area of Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma rains have been insufficient and the crop is doing only fairly well.
The German-American League for Culture, formed recently of non-Nazi groups, observed German Day yesterday afternoon with a meeting at St. Nicholas Palace, West Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue.
A reply to Cardinal Hayes's address on birth control last Sunday was issued jointly yesterday by thirteen clergymen of Protestant and Jewish faiths.

More than 700 attended the thirty-ninth annual dinner of the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, Findlay Avenue and 167th Street, the Bronx, last night at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. Peter J. Schweitzer, who has served for ten years as president of the home, was the guest of honor.

TORONTO, Dec. 15. -- A new monthly record was established in the production of gold in Canada in October, at 301,712 ounces, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reports. In the same month last year, 265,709 ounces were produced.

The long heralded opening of the Frick Collection to the public, which occurs today, overshadows the events of the week in the local field of exhibitions. The preview and private showing were held on Wednesday of last week and extensive reviews and comment were published on the art pages of The Times yesterday, together with many reproductions in the Rotogravure Section.
LONDON, Dec. 15. -- An editorial to be published tomorrow in The Times, London, under the heading, "A Corridor for Camels," makes a further revelation about the Hoare-Laval peace proposals.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15. -- A fight, the arrest of two alleged robbers and the rescue of a woman and five children from a burning house took place at 2:30 o'clock this morning at a fire at 114 South Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- More than 8,000 musicians who were on relief have received jobs in the music projects of the Works Progress Administration, Dr. Nikolni Sokoloff, director of the music projects, announced today.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 15 (AP). -- Ben Allen, secretary to former President Hoover, said tonight that Mr. Hoover, here en route to St. Louis, definitely viewed the address he will make there tomorrow night as an answer to the Atlanta address by President Roosevelt.

CAIRO, Dec. 15. -- If Premier Tewfik Nessim Pasha thought a royal rescript restoring the 1923 Constitution would be sufficient to placate Egyptian public opinion he was mistaken. At a meeting today of leaders of all political parties it was decided to urge Nessim Pasha to make immediate preparations for Parliamentary elections.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 (AP). -- A United States aviator, Charles J. Wellstead, was questioned tonight by authorities in connection with the kidnapping last week of Nicholas Castano for $500,000 ransom. Cuban officials said Wellstead lacked entry papers as well as a pilot's license and a license for his plane.

The fifty-first annual report of Swift Co., covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 26, given out today, showed earnings of $14,767,302 after allowing for depreciation, depletion, taxes, provision for doubtful accounts, interest, write-offs and other charges.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15. -- With Horton Smith, tall, blond pro from Oak Park, Ill., showing the way at 139 strokes for the first thirty-six holes, sixty-two top-flight golf professionals and eleven amateurs paraded today into the last two rounds of the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open.

TOKYO, Dec. 15. -- In arranging their program for the coming week at the London Naval Conference, the Japanese delegation has decided not to refuse to discuss other proposals simultaneously with the Japanese demand for a common upper limit, according to Japanese correspondents in London.

The New York Chamber Music Society gave the first concert of its eleventh season of Sunday "salons" at the Hotel Plaza last night. As has been the custom in the past, this organization, founded and headed by Carolyn Beebe, devoted its attention, in good part, to music that is not current in most concert halls.

ROME, Dec. 15. -- Premier Benito Mussolini is still studying the Franco-British peace proposals and is preparing his reply to them. He does not reveal his decisions before they are taken, so it is very difficult to guess what is going on in his mind and to foretell what his action will be.

La Argentina gave the second of the three recitals which are scheduled for her this season at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. It is no longer necessary to report that the audience was large and enthusiastic and that the dancer was at the top of her form.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- A mounting public interest in the use of the fingerprint files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for purposes apart from the capture and punishment of criminals was noted by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the bureau, today in announcing that 6,121 personal-identification fingerprint cards had been received at the bureau in the month of November.

Dr. Max Euwe, a native of Amsterdam, is in his thirty-fifth year, having been born on May 20, 1901. He is nine years younger than Dr. Alexandre Alekhine. In 1918 he became a student of mathematics at the University of Amsterdam, in which respect he followed in the footsteps of Dr. Emanuel Lasker, who held the world championship for twenty-seven years.

Thirty-six New York University football players are included among the recipients of eighty-two awards approved by the board of athletic control and the undergraduate athletic board, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. The members of the varsity and freshman cross-country teams and the yearling football squad also were honored.

All four seeded players survived as the second day of competition in the second annual Long Island championship squash racquets tournament was completed yesterday at the Baysides Tennis Club, Bayside, L.I.

CARNEGIE, Okla., Dec. 15 (AP).-- Six persons were burned to death today in the four-room farm home of George Bailey eighteen miles west of here. Bailey, who rented the house and worked as a farm hand, was badly burned. A defective flue apparently caused the blaze.

ROME, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini called on Italy again tonight to fly the flags of defiance from every housetop Wednesday -- "Faith Day" in Fascist Italy -- and he threw more cold water on the peace proposals through his inspired press.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- No darker prospect in European politics or indeed in world affairs has formed since the tragic years of the World War than that which opens this week before Christmas twenty years later. The pessimists have it all their own way, for disillusion and deadlock are on every hand, tending inevitably toward that new and greater conflagration that is the world's nightmare.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 15. -- A $40,000,000 improvement and expansion program for the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, involving one of the most important new private financing projects since 1929, was disclosed today in a letter to stockholders.

The three American members of the International Olympic Committee, and Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, were urged yesterday in an open letter by the Rev. Dr. Charles S. MacFarland, general secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches, to read "The National Socialist Concept of Physical Training" by Dr. Bruno Malitz, published last year in Germany.
Covici, Friede say that they are selling 40 per cent more books this season than they did in the Fall of 1934.

TIENTSIN, China, Monday, Dec. 16 (AP). -- The seizure of Tangku followed closely upon the arrest of the Chinese commissioner in the Tangku area by the Japanese military because of his alleged refusal to lease certain wharves to the Japanese Army for military purposes. His refusal was based on the vigorous opposition of the present occupants of the wharves.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Corny Shields had a field day in the Larchmont Yacht Club dinghy racing today. After taking three morning events of the tuning-up sort in his Class B one-design boat Prudence, he came back in the real competition after lunch and won five straight contests.
DETROIT, Dec. 15. -- As a notable addition to its rapidly growing list of triumphs, gained in a banner year, Detroit moved into full possession of top honors in professional football today.

The outlook for settlement of the labor dispute between the Grand Opera Artists Association of America, a union, and Erno Rapee, musical director of Radio City Music Hall, became brighter yesterday afternoon when the latter agreed to confer with union representatives this week.
Christ came to save "by awakening the best that there is in men," said Chaplain Raymond C. Knox yesterday morning in his annual Christmas sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Evidently supporters of the belief that the first impression means everything, the Baltimore Orioles made their local debut of the season yesterday and performed in a fashion which bespoke their potential strength.

BOSTON, Dec. 15. -- over-riding a small minority led by Past National Commander Charles M. Kinsolving, the American Veterans Association at its annual conference today voted three to 1 in favor of continuing its policy of opposition to immediate cash payment of the soldiers' bonus.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Subpoenas were served today on Phelps Smith, principal owner of the Paul Smiths Light and Power Company, following his refusal to open his books to the joint legislative committee investigating public utilities.

Following closely upon the heels of Erwin Rudolph's unexpected setback the previous night, the current world's pocket billiard championship tournament produced another great surprise last night as James Caras of Wilmington, Del., hitherto unbeaten, bowed to the veteran Frank Taberski of Schenectady, N.Y., 125 to 71, In fifteen innings at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Shooting in a driving rainstorm, L.F. Sanman broke 97 out of a possible 100 targets to win the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. R. Walsh took an extra string from P. Garino to annex the handicap prize.
SEATTLE, Dec. 15 (AP). -- Vice President Garner returned to the United States today from a two-month trip to the Orient. He had "nothing to say," but was loaded with wise-cracks.

Dan O'Mahoney, the Irish Free State soldier who is regarded as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, will risk his title against Ed Don George at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout will be promoted by Jack Curley, and a part of the proceeds will be donated to The New York American and Evening Journal Christmas Fund.

JACK BLACKBURN'S wave of the hand gave him the signal. Taking his cue from his astute handler, Shufflin' Joe uncoupled his obnoxious left from Paulino's face, where it had persistently found parking space, and shifted his portside attack to the body.

By tradition this pre-Christmas week is a quiet one on Broadway -- the silence that precedes the festive uproar of the holidays. Next week, though less active than some Christmas weeks of the past, will nevertheless see a few packages dropped down the Times Square chimneys.

An unidentified boy, about 8 years old, was killed yesterday by contact with the third rail of the southbound tracks at the East Twenty-third Street station of the Third Avenue elevated line. His death occurred, the police believed, while he was crossing the tracks from one platform to the other in an effort to save the nickel this transfer would otherwise have cost him.

Although steel ingot production has declined 2 1/2 points to 54 1.2 per cent of capacity, the demand for iron and steel is unusually resistant to the customary year-end curtailment, according to the weekly summary issued by the magazine Steel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- The decline in suicides has paralleled business improvement since 1932, Professor William Fielding Ogburn said today in tracing the course of suicides and commercial failures from 1915 to 1935.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,995,937,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15. -- It is perhaps no accident that the Japanese occupation of Kalgan, ancient capital of the Chinese province of Chahar, coincided almost exactly with the arrival in Moscow of the Prime Minister and the War Minister of the People's Republic of Outer Mongolia, which stands in the same relation to the Soviet Government as the Philippine Islands now stand to the United States -- or closer.

A Bible that survived a trip on a torpedoed vessel during the World War was exhibited as proof of "the indestructibility of the Book" by the Rev. Lincoln Caswell during his sermon yesterday morning at the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventy-sixth Street and Second Avenue.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15. -- The Supreme Court of Ontario in Toronto will be asked on Friday to issue an order approving the sale of the Great Lakes Paper Company's assets to John E. Gefaell and Lyon E. Aldrich. Notice to this effect is being given by the National Trust Company, as receiver and manager of the company, to meet the requirements of the United States Securities Act of 1933 and amendments.

Poetry is decidedly looking up, if one may judge from its frequency in the day's news. This is all the more striking because one of the main sources of poetry in the papers has been cut off with the elimination of breach of promise suits.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- There is a strong possibility that when the naval conference meets in the strictest privacy, tomorrow afternoon with only the heads of the delegations present it may decline to discuss the Japanese "common upper limit" proposal in principle without knowing what it means in practice, and invite the Japanese to come down to figures.

The Metropolitan Opera House will open its doors for its Winter season as it has done for half a century. The auspices appear to be more favorable than for the last few years. There was a time when they were always favorable; but auspices have changed for many things besides opera.

DETROIT, Dee. 15. -- The Detroit Red Wings gained undisputed possession of the first place in the American Group of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the New York Rangers, 4 to 2, before a crowd of 9,000.

GENEVA, Dec. 15. -- It seemed tonight that both the Little Entente and Scandinavia might figure in the vanguard of the nations opposing the France-British plan to obtain peace by territorial concessions to Italy. The plan is to be discussed Wednesday by the League of Nations Council.

Topics of The Times' amusing excursion into, philology apropos the history of "sirloin" falls just short of complete explanation. Yarns, however fictitious, die hard, if only they be good yarns. The trained philologist, like the historian and the scientist, is prone to take the joy out of life in his debunking of such cherry tree masterpieces as the royal knighting of a loin of beef.

Plans for the construction, with government funds, of two huge ocean liners, greater in size and speed than the French liner Normandie or the new British ship, Queen Mary, now being built, were announced yesterday by Paul W. Chapman, banker and former president of the United States Lines.

With retail sales of holiday merchandise reaching new high levels for the depression, last-minute rush orders for gift items flooded the local wholesale markets last week and found many manufacturers unable to fill the demand. At the same time a substantial amount of business was placed on goods for January promotional events, including both apparel and house furnishings.

The work of removing the overhead structure extending from the Brooklyn Bridge across Park Row into City Hall Park is progressing so rapidly that officials of the Department of Plant and Structures hope to have the task completed by the end of the year, it was announced yesterday.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he had sent invitations to attend his conference on crime conditions in the borough to Police Commissioner Valentine, Presiding Justice of Special Sessions Frederic Kernochan, Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman, County Judge Martin and Louis C. Wills, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Corn traders here are puzzled by the action of the market, the bulges bringing out selling orders, while offerings tend to disappear on breaks. Early last week offerings from the country were moderate, but later they increased.

"Religion meets the test of presenting the highest standards in social welfare goals," the Rev. Dr. Roy Ewing Vale of Detroit said yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 15. -- Everett A. Colson, Emperor Haile Selassie's adviser, has not yet returned from Dessye, where he has had long consultations with the Emperor since Friday. He was joined there by Parato Teswai Tegan, Director of Foreign Affairs, who also traveled by air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Governor Talmadge, foe of the New Deal, would be willing to become the Democratic candidate for President in 1936 if the party membership "had the courage to refuse to renominate Roosevelt," he declared today in an interview.

TIENTSIN, China, Monday, Dec. 16. -- Forces of the recently proclaimed autonomous State in Eastern Hopei Province seized Tangku. Tientsin's seaport, eighteen miles east of the city, after a clash yesterday with troops of General Shang Chen's garrison.

The fondness of a Brooklyn resident for swimming regardless of weather, and the failure of the Police Department to include rowboats in the equipment of emergency trucks, gave strollers on the Brighton Beach Boardwalk a chance to observe an old-fashioned rescue yesterday forenoon.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Money is in heavy demand here for quarterly income-tax payments and Christmas spending. Day loans yesterday were at the rate of 3 1/8-3 3/8 per cent, up slightly from a week before, when the rate was 3-3 1/4 per cent. Bank acceptances were sold to raise cash and the market for Reich paper and promissory notes was inert.

In Indiana forefathers are turning in their graves. Chains are clanking audibly. Liberty is on her last legs. Some time ago the State Committees on Governmental Economy recommended that townships be consolidated and certain offices abolished. Governor McNUTT, once thought a loyal Democrat, has been uttering perverted opinions.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP). -- Responsibility for the flogging to death of Joseph Shoemaker was laid at the door of public officials today by Tampa ministers in a service of public penitence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Harold Riegelmann, New York attorney, has resigned as special counsel to the Treasury Department, effective today.

In his Houston, Texas, address Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, repeated an exploded fallacy in the meaningless words: "The tax bill of 1935 * * * must drive a great deal of capital into tax-exempt securities, which means into non-productive uses."

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club defeated the Ardsley Country Club, 5 to 2, in the only one of three scheduled team matches in the Westchester Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association played yesterday. The encounter took place on the losers' court.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has done admirable service in bringing to the attention of its readers through its recent editorial the basic principles and necessities for minimum wage legislation. I should, however, like to clarify one impression that might have been gained from your editorial and to take definite issue with the letter from Grier Bartol regarding the proposed minimum wage for women and minors in hotels and restaurants.

In three messages delivered in this city yesterday, the Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of York, Primate of England, brought greetings from the clergy and people of old York to those of New York.

What's there, Georgine Wunderlich! What's the sense of asking "what dictionary is the New Yorker's authority for saying 'harass', locate', il'lustrate and in'quiry'?" Haven't you ever discovered that a dictionary is a record of actual usage, not a book of linguistic etiquette?

Helen Teschner Tas, violinist, who had not been heard here in two seasons, gave a recital last evening at Town Hall. Her austerely serious program consisted of the concerto in E minor, by Nardini; the Brahms sonata in D minor, the Bach sonata in A minor, Chausson's "Poems" and the Stravinsky suite on themes of Pergolesi.

"YOU were brought up in a rose garden," Thomas Wells, editor of Harper's Magazine, told Mary Heaton Vorse in 1918, "and then you lived by the sea. Why don't you write about rose gardens? Why don't you write about the sea?" But Mary Heaton Vorse had a lively curiosity and a conscience that insisted upon taking her out into the danger zones in a world of war, industrial conflicts and revolutions.

Edgar V. Tait, a junior in New York University's College of Engineering and captain-elect of the Violet harrier combination, scored a brilliant victory to take the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior four-mile cross-country title yesterday. Running unattached, Tait led a field of fifty-three starters at Victory Field, Forest Park, L.I.

Services yesterday morning in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, were given over to a memorial to the Rev. Dr. H. Percy Silver, it sixth rector. He died a year ago. The sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. Howard C. Robbins, a professor in the General Episcopal Theological Seminary.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84, which compares with 84.6 the week before, 84.5 two weeks before, 84.3 three weeks before and 85 four weeks before.

In the belief that the city school system wastes $12,000,000 annually through "teaching that does not take," the Board of Education is considering establishment of a "laboratory" to analyze teaching methods and curricula, James Marshall, Fusion member of the board, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Pork loins have declined 50 cents a 100 pounds in this territory within a little more than a week and have lost from $1 to $2 in the East. This break checked the buying of hogs last week and brought the price of loins down to 17 to 20 cents, compared with 18 1/4 to 23 cents a month ago.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15. -- For divers excellent reasons Soviet opinion has been coy in expressing itself about the European situation in general and the Laval-Hoare proposals in particular.

Many persons reading the Neediest Cases (to which others were added in yesterday's stories of those who still wait for rescue) must say to themselves, "But for the grace of GOD these might be the biographies of ourselves." Especially must this be startlingly felt when one sees one's own "given" name given to one of the anonymous cases.
An unusual jury reached a verdict of guilty yesterday on the stage of the Ambassador Theatre.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Although the Republican-controlled Board of Supervisors has voted to lay out a central airport near Valhalla at a cost of $1,000,000 if the Federal Government votes the appropriation, it wins reported today that the Democrats on the board would endeavor to reopen the airport question tomorrow when Miss Margaret Mayo of Croton, a playwright, would submit petitions favoring an airport at Croton Point.

The tenth annual Christmas sale of the Opportunity Shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street will open today. The proceeds will be devoted to the tuberculosis committee of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. Old French prints, postage stamps, Russian brocades, old glass and old silver are among the articles to be sold.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- Although he is Minister of State in Premier Pierre Laval's Cabinet, Edouard Herriot spoke today at Montbeliard as president of the Radical Socialist party in reply to those who constantly attack the policy of sanctions as certain to lead to war.

A 21-year-old girl who "hates" policemen but flirted with guards in the Middlesex Country jail at New Brunswick, N.J., was held as a material witness late last night in the escape of two prisoners from the jail on the previous evening.

Mr. HOPKINS, WPA Administrator, estimates that the physical wealth of the nation will be increased at least $5,000,000,000 as the result of the construction now being carried out under the work-relief program. "This," he declares, "demonstrates the value of "work relief as opposed to the waste of "direct relief."

ASMARA, Eritrea, Nov. 30. -- Once again the lowly can of food has come into its own. Not since the World War, with millions of men eating "bully beef" and "goldfish" (canned salmon), has so much reliance been placed upon tinned food.

In spite of the bullish crop estimate last week by the Department of Agriculture, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 32 to 53 points. Factors in the decline were uncertainty over the constitutionality of the Bank-head act and the drop in the price of silver.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 15. -- Pasquale Miele, 54 years old, a former inspector for the State Liquor Authority, shot and killed his wife and himself and seriously wounded his 10-year-old daughter in his home here tonight.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 15. -- A mass meeting here today of more than 300 Iowa labor and unemployed delegates voted a State-wide strike on Works Progress Administration projects to take effect Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Secretary Ickes, in his annual report today, presented a colorful picture of the myriad activities of the Department of the Interior, ranging from the discovery of a prehistoric titan-othere's skull in Death Valley to manufacture of helium gas for stratosphere flights.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- The action of lard prices here last week was influenced by the markets for grains and cotton, with selling on all hard spots attributed to liquidating and profit-taking sales, and by the price of hogs as well as that of the demand and prices for the cured product.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- If it were not for internal politics and the Ethiopian question and if confidence returned, the financial and economic situation here certainly would improve. In certain industries, particularly textiles, recovery is actually occurring.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP). -- How Samuel Insull obtained a $2,000,000 loan on his reputation was disclosed today in the records of the Federal Master in Chancery, Jacob I. Grossman.
C.V. Whitney's Red Rain was the best 2-year-old of the 1935 racing season according to official ratings of the juveniles by John B. Campbell, handicapper of the Jockey Club.

Brooklyn Prep defeated St. John's Prep, 58 to 17, and St. Augustine's High halted St. Michael's High, 45 to 30, in Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming meets at the Columbus Council, K. of C., pool yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- A process server in white tie and tails "crashed" the Gridiron Club banquet attended by President Roosevelt last night and presented Henry L. Doherty, utilities president, with fourteen subpoenas.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 15. -- College enrollment in the United States in 1935 increased 6.6 per cent over 1934, which in turn exceeded 1933 by 5 per cent, according to the annual survey made by Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati.
BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins defeated the Canadiens, 2 -- 1, tonight when the National Hockey League last-place clubs waged a listless hockey battle before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The New Deal's trial by Constitution continues tomorrow with the Supreme Court hearing arguments on amendments intended to strengthen the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- Wholesale prices in France rose in November, the index for the month being 353, compared with 350 in October, and 349 in November of last year. The retail price index last month was 446, compared with 453 in October and 472 in November, 1934.

Consolation came yesterday for William Larowin of 39 First Avenue on the eve of the burial of his 17-year-old daughter, Olga. Her death had shorn the penniless widower of his sole companion for the last two months and faithful housekeeper since his wife died five years ago.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 15. -- As much as the Ohio farmers dislike the Roosevelt spending program and relief policies, they like the AAA more, in the opinion of well-informed political observers.

The first financing offered to the public for the Seaboard Finance Corporation (operating a system of nine personal loan offices in Virginia and Tennessee) in the form of new issues of 30,000 shares of $2 cumulative preferred stock, with warrants, and 22,500 shares of common stock, will be made today by Leach Brothers, Inc., and James M. Johnston Co., Washington.

Hope Hampton, motion picture actress, was injured slightly and three others were hurt at 6:30 P.M. yesterday when two automobiles were in collision at Queens Boulevard and Yellowstone Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. Miss Hampton, who lives at 1,145 Park Avenue, suffered contusions of the back and chest and went home.

A two-alarm fire shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday almost destroyed a four-story brick store and tenement building at 338 East 115th Street. The fire spread rapidly through the wooden interior of the building, and when it finally was brought under control after three-quarters of an hour of fighting, only part of the outer brick wall remained.
These days require a religion to keep the individual character intact, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP). -- With many borrowers paying up past due indebtedness, officials of the Home Owners Loan Corporation reported today that repayments were being made at the rate of $17,000,000 a month.

RAWALPINDI, India, Nov. 30. -- Sixty miles from Rawalpindi, our temporary expedition headquarters, where the great Indus River breaks through the Himalayan foothills, Early Man has left a pictorial record of his life. On the sunbaked plain we found scattered huge blocks of rock covered with petroglyphs representing crudely drawn isolated figures of people hunting, fishing and riding the already then domesticated horse.
Real estate activity reported in the metropolitan area over the week-end was featured by deals for building sites in Queens.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 15. -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris who won the world chess championship in Buenos Aires eight years ago, lost it today to Dr. Max Euwe of this city.

From a man nearly 91 years old would be expected something of the despondency and pessimism natural to such a weight of age. But Mr. ROOT continues to believe that there is a soul of goodness in things evil, would men observingly distill it out. Making his own observation point, as it were, a mountain peak of his long experience, he sees the international scene steadily, and sees it whole.

The substitution of busses for street cars on Eighth and Ninth Avenues, although in effect only since Nov. 12, has already cut into the business of the city's Eighth Avenue subway line, it was indicated yesterday by the Transit Commission.

Your publication of the description of a sunrise was a fine compliment to a real reporter. It raises the question, What is news? answered overwhelmingly by the report of some criminal running amuck, some sensational gossip of ones in high places or other outbreak in social irregularity.

PRAGUE, Dec. 15. -- The Prague newspaper Montag will publish tomorrow an interesting interview with Dr. Roetter, a Prussian barrister and former naval officer decorated in the war with the Iron Cross, first class, who took up the defense of the parliamentary leader of the German Communist party, Ernst Thaelmann.

The attorneys for Bruno Richard Hauptmann will confer today in Somerville, N.J., to decide what their next step will be in an effort to save Hauptmann's life or delay his execution beyond the date set.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $275,000 of 3.40 per cent bonds of the towns of Perinton and Pittsford, N.Y., Union Free School District No. 13, by the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company, Buffalo; Sage, Rutty Steele, Rochester, and George D.B. Bonbright Co., Rochester.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- In an unusual declaration from the pulpit of Manchester Cathedral tonight Dean Garfield Williams demanded that the government tell the whole truth in the House of Commons Thursday concerning the Hoare-Laval proposal for the settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP). -- William J. Cameron, speaking for the Ford Motor Company, said tonight that industry alone cannot provide employment for "the 11,000,000 persons whom Washington says are unemployed."

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Penn T. Kimball 2d, '37, of New Britain, Conn., has been elected chairman of The Daily Prince-tonian undergraduate newspaper, to succeed William A. Carlile Jr., '36, of Columbus, Ohio. Announcement was made here today of the complete staff of members of the junior class who will take over contro of the paper for one year, beginning Feb. 6.

Members of the Glee Club of the Junior League will begin their annual Christmas tour to the hospitals of the city this afternoon, giving a program of Christmas carols and bringing holiday cheer to the patients.

Many reservations have been made for the luncheon in behalf of the underprivileged children aided by the Catholic Big Sisters, which will be held today in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis under the auspices of that organization. The guest of honor will be Lady Armstrong, who is in this country to pass the holidays and who long has taken an active interest in the work of the Catholic Big Sisters.

Caleb Milne 4th, 24 years old, grandson of Caleb Milne Jr., retired textile manufacturer of Germantown, Pa., was reported missing here yesterday by his brother Frederic, 18 years old, with whom he lived at 157 East Thirty-seventh Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 15. -- Florida'-s racing season will start tomorrow at Tropical Park, with the Coral Gables Handicap as the feature of the program, which will usher in a long schedule of racing events that will extend almost to the opening of the Eastern campaign next April.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Consolidation of the 108 different regional divisions of the country used by Federal agencies, and development of a series of common centers for the government's field activities are recommended by a subcommittee of regional planning of the National Resources Committee.

The romance of a young couple, which was to have culminated in marriage within a few weeks, ended tragically in Brooklyn yesterday when the bride-to-be discovered her fiance and his father had been killed accidentally by illuminating gas.

The appearance of four of America's leading dancers -- Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Tamiris and Charles Weidman -- and a rising young group known as the Dance Unit of the New Dance League, at Carnegie Hall last night, proved to be a sufficiently strong attraction to more than offset the unpleasant weather, and the audience that assembled for it filled the hall from floor to dome and included a mass of standees in addition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- The wheat markets of the world have been thrown into a position that traders believe will result in prices being regulated by the governments in Argentina, Australia, Canada and probably other countries, and it would not be surprising to see the United States drawn into the most unusual situation before the end of the present crop season.

he five-day open season on deer in New Jersey starts tomorrow morning, and according to reports received by the State Fish and Game Commission an unprecedented number of gunners was encamped in the woodlands last night.

The romance of a young couple, which was to have culminated in marriage within a few weeks, ended tragically in Brooklyn yesterday when the bride-to-be discovered her fiance and his father had been killed accidentally by illuminating gas.

The appearance of four of America's leading dancers -- Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Tamiris and Charles Weidman -- and a rising young group known as the Dance Unit of the New Dance League, at Carnegie Hall last night, proved to be a sufficiently strong attraction to more than offset the unpleasant weather, and the audience that assembled for it filled the hall from floor to dome and included a mass of standees in addition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- The wheat markets of the world have been thrown into a position that traders believe will result in prices being regulated by the governments in Argentina, Australia, Canada and probably other countries, and it would not be surprising to see the United States drawn into the most unusual situation before the end of the present crop season.
PARIS, Dec. 15. -- Premier Pierre Laval returned to Paris today to find dissatisfaction with the Franco-British peace plan spreading in Parliament and endangering his government.

The Brotherhood of Utility Employes, which has set a strike for "an early date" against the Queens Light and Power Company, will hold "a council of war" at the office of its Queens local, 40-11 Main Street, Flushing, tonight, when definite strike action may be taken.

American ship operators in the intercoastal trade will oppose the proposal to provide a single basis for measurement of tonnage in the Panama Canal transit, submitted by Colonel J.L. Schley, Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, in his annual report, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here as 56 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week, but otherwise as high a rate as has been seen this year. The last three weeks have averaged an annual rate slightly above 39,000,000 tons, 17 per cent above the average of the first eleven months of the year and one-half greater than actual production in 1934.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMIES AT DOLO, Ethiopian-Somaliland Frontier, Dec. 15. -- Ras Desta Demtu, Emperor Haile Selassie's son-in-law, was reported converging today with three main columns of 40,000 Ethiopians on a front thirty miles from Dolo, where a big Ethiopian attack has been expected momentarily since last Tuesday.

A memorial service for Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, who died Nov. 21, was held yesterday morning at the Montefiore Synagogue, Hewitt and Macy Places, the Bronx, under the auspices of the Bronx County Bar Association.

Miss Priscilla Godwin gave a buffet supper last night at her home, 210 East Sixty-eighth Street. Miss Godwin, accompanied by her sister, Miss Jacqueline Godwin, is sailing Jan. 16 to pass the remainder of the Winter in Honolulu.

An appeal to the people of New York to adopt as a slogan, "Hospitals Now!" was made yesterday by Mayor La Guardia on behalf of the United Hospital Campaign. The need for immediate giving to aid the voluntary hospitals, which will conclude their annual joint drive to raise at least $2,000,000 on Wednesday, was stressed by the Mayor.

Garnering a two-goal advantage in the first period, the New York Americans scored a notable victory at Madison Square Garden last night. They defeated the Chicago Black Hawks by the score of 3 to 0 in a closely fought National Hockey League battle before 13,000 persons.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 15. -- The three leaders bettered their positions as a result of today's play in the New Jersey group of the Metropolitan Class B Squash Racquets League.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin led his National Union for Social Justice into the 1936 Congress elections today with a call to "20.000 selected workers" to drive "rubber-stamp Congressmen" from office in an effort to obtain reform of the nation's monetary system.

The re-establishment of harmony within the Russian Orthodox Church after almost ten years of internal strife was celebrated yesterday by the Metropolitan of the church in the United States, Canada, and Alaska, two Archbishops, and two Bishops at a cermony in which they took the sacrament together at the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Virgin Protection, 105 East Houston Street.

The new season of the Metropolitan Opera Association will open tonight with Edward Johnson at the head of a reorganized management. The inaugural opera will be "La Traviata," with Lucrezia Bori, Richard Crooks and Lawrence Tibbett in leading roles and Ettore Panizza conducting. A capacity house is assured.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Hard-working David Windsor, Britain's seventeenth Prince of Wales, may dream of retiring from the exhausting duties of an heir apparent to his ranch in the Canadian Rockies -- and often he has hinted at such a desire.

Stocks and cotton in the United States on Nov. 30, including the unpicked part of the crop, were 13,274,000 bales, according to the Yew York Cotton Exchange Service. On the corresponding date last year, stocks were 13,614,000 bales, two years ago 15,335,000 and three years ago 17,378,000.
The La Guardia Charter Revision Commission has agreed on the basic outlines of a revised New York City government, and on many details of the proposed charter as well.
The Neediest Cases Fund enters the third week of the appeal today with many of the old, the suffering, the crippled, the dying and the abandoned still unhelped.

Philip Newbury, successful concert tenor and teacher of the turn of the century who today is living on home relief in a two-room flat at 32 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, learned yesterday that new pupils would be coming to him in the near future.

If God had redeemed man right after Adam's fall, man never would have realized that "human power without divine grace is insufficient," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street east of Broadway.
MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 15. -- The annual Payne Whitney Memorial intercity court tennis doubles tournament came to a close in the Whitney court at Greentree today with New York once again triumphant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Establishment of the first "seasonal agency" of a national bank under an amendment to the Banking Act of 1935 was announced by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency. Under the amendment, which permits seasonal branches in resort areas, Mr. O'Connor authorized the Ocean County National Bank of Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., to operate an office in near-by Bay Head from May 1 to Nov. 1 of each year.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- England's sudden change of policy on the Ethiopian peace problem has had a most unfavorable effect on business opinion here. Trading on the Boerse declined in volume almost to the minimum, and stock prices fell sharply on four days this week.

Women with vulgar and uncouth-sounding voices are more likely to succeed as radio speakers than women with well-cultivated and refined voices, according to a survey by Dr. Gordon Allport of Harvard and Dr. Hadley Cantril of Teachers College, Columbia University.

Maurice P. Davidson, organizer and first chairman of the City Fusion party, revealed yesterday that he might resign in the near future as Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity to begin preparations for a Fusion campaign in 1937 with the implied object of re-electing Mayor La Guardia.

Servel, Inc., manufacturer of gas and kerosene operated refrigerators, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net profit of $2,111,518, after bond interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. After allowing for dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the profit is equal to $1.16 a share on 1,781,426 shares of common stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Seven additional registration statements for issues of $8,762,073 have been filed under the Securities Act of 1933 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Five are issues of commercial and industrial concerns for $6,073,073.60; one an investment trust issue of $2,500,000, and the seventh is for certificates of deposit of $189,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16. -- Young Ted Turner smacked them straight down the middle of the Miami Biltmore golf course to forge ahead in the $10,000 open today, shattering with a 66 for the par-71 links the tournament record Willie Macfarlane set in 1933.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16. -- John A. Vietor entertained his house guests, John Preston, Robert W. Ebling Jr. and George DeG. Wyeth, all schoolmates at Yale; Miss Virginia Hall, Edmund K. Sheedy, Thomas Ward and E.D.E. Walden at luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club.

Figures compiled yesterday by the Police Department on automobile accidents over the week-end continued to show a substantial decrease from those of the corresponding period of last year, although there was no reduction in the number of deaths.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 16. -- As a result of the victory of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam in the world championship chess match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, the question of how the title is to be played for in the future is occupying the attention of the International Chess Federation, with headquarters here.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- After hearing arguments Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis, in Chancery Court here, reserved decision today on an application for an order restraining the Republic Steel Corporation from paying an initial dividend of $1.50 a share on its new cumulative prior preference series A stock on Jan. 2.

Commodity futures generally were lower on the local markets yesterday, although coffee futures made slight gains. On the cash markets rye, cocoa and butter advanced, while declines occurred in wheat, corn, oats, flour, cotton, silk and rubber.

THERE are some strange possibilities lying before the world of college sport in the perhaps not so distant future, put there by the highly interesting decision of the Southeast Conference to permit athletic scholarships in the future. It is even possible that the worries of a father will be completely reversed, set upsidedown.

A total of 2,783 entries was received for eleven prominent stake events next year, seven to be renewed in 1937 and two in 1938 at Belmont Park, according to the closing list announced by the Westchester Racing Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The filing of an application by the Dominion of Canada for permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of $316,000,000 of its bonds which now have that privilege temporarily was accepted by the Securities and Exchange Commission today as another indication that virtually all of the foreign nations would take similar action before the deadline on March 31.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- Across the Mississippi River here today automobiles and trains moved as more than 12,000 persons witnessed the dedication and formal opening of the new $13,000,000 Huey P. Long bridge. Public officials of the city and State and financial and industrial leaders joined in the dedicatory program, marked by a pageant depicting the history of transportation from the Indian runner days to the air-minded present.

Whether boxers and wrestlers are manual or non-manual workers is a question that is engaging the attention of the best brains of the State Department of Labor. This was disclosed last night by Glenn A. Bowers, director of the Division of Unemployment Insurance of the department, speaking on the new State Unemployment Insurance Act over WHN.

After some months of silence, during which it was revising its previous figures, the American Federation of Labor has emerged with an estimate that 11,650,000 persons were unemployed in October. This, it remarks, compares with unemployment of 15,470,000 in March, 1933.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16. -- Building, of course, is the first and easiest test of a nation's prosperity. The more it builds the more prosperous is a nation. You can see that today in London and there is no doubt of the answer -- Britain is recovering from the depression.

An appeal for the preservation of liberalism as taught by the Christian religion and as it has grown among English-speaking peoples was made last night by the Most Rev. William Temple, Archbishop of York, Primate of England, to 1,000 persons who attended a dinner given in his honor by the Church Club of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Eleven husbands and one bachelor were impaneled as a jury in Queens County Court yesterday afternoon to try Mrs. Etta Reisman, 35 years old, held on a second-degree murder indictment for slaying her husband's 23-year-old secretary.

Henry Sanderson, financier and director of public utility corporations, who died March 26, 1934, left an estate appraised yesterday at $836,271 gross and $573,747 net, which included securities worth $565,929.

Edwin R. Dibrell, vice president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the last six and one-half years, yesterday announced his resignation of that post. In presenting his resignation to the board of the corporation, Mr. Dibrell said he will enter business for himself and is forming the firm of E.R. Dibrell Associates, to serve as consultants in merchandising, sales promotion arid public relations.

A bequest estimated at more than $1,000,000 was offered to Yale University yesterday in the will of the late Charles Howard Warren with the explanation that he wished the fund to become a memorial to his son and to the Anglo-Saxon race.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 16 (AP). -- The battle over the Townsend old-age pension plan raged unabated today as the Third Michigan district prepared to choose a member of Congress tomorrow.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Bernard L. Lamb, New Jersey State Finance Commissioner, failed to "amaze" the State Budget Advisory Committee today by a report on savings made in his department, but did show economies of $1,675,680 in less than a year and offered a plan to save the State more than $6,000,000 in the next five years.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16. -- Following is the text of the address delivered this evening by Herbert Hoover before the John Marshall Republican Club of St. Louis:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 16. -- While 12,000 fans looked on at Tropical Park the 5-year-old mare Advising Anna, in the Western silks of Haughton and West, gamely held on to win the Coral Gables Handicap, banner attraction of the Florida turf season's inaugural program today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16. -- The Federal court at Seattle was ordered by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to enjoin Radio Station KVOS of Bellingham, Wash., from pirating news gathered by The Associated Press.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- Before he leaves for Geneva tomorrow Premier Pierre Laval will begin the debate on the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, which will later continue in Geneva and London, by making a statement in the Chamber of Deputies on the situation that has developed since he and Sir Samuel Hoare, the British Foreign Secretary, eight days ago produced their much-discussed basis of settlement.

Weakness in the cotton market at Liverpool, uncertainty over the United States Supreme Court's decisions, unfavorable European news and the current silver situation combined yesterday to depress prices on the Cotton Exchange here.

Today when New York is recalling the one hundredth anniversary of the great fire, which, on Dec. 16, 1835, destroyed twenty-two blocks of lower New York, we may also recall that there is at least one bell still in use which rang out the alarm for that fire.

The Beethoven Association's second concert of the season last night at the Town Hall was of marked distinction. It can hardly be remembered when the association failed to assemble artists of note or a program of high standard. Last night's recital brought forth not only artists of deep musicianship but a program of superb music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- President Roosevelt today tackled one of the knottiest problems confronting his administration when he began budget conferences on relief expenditures for the next fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- At a meeting of representatives of virtually all States with members of the Social Security Board, which continued through yesterday, the administration was assured that the various local governments would submit estimates about Jan. 1 of the amounts they plan to spend as their shares of the joint Federal-State old-age pensions.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- A housing movement that would "put 4,000,000 men back to work" was described today by Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill as the next step toward prosperity.

Colonel A.A. Anderson, 86-year-old artist whose studio is atop the Beaux Arts Studios Building at 80 West Fortieth Street, has presented to the Washington Cathedral a large religious painting by himself portraying the story of Mary Magdalen.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16. -- Three men were killed outright, a fourth died in the hospital, two others are not expected to live, and a seventh was severely wounded this afternoon when a discharged Federal relief worker, in a maniacal rage, opened fire with a rifle upon a large group of employes engaged in constructing the big WPA sewer here.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16. -- Thelma Todd was born thirty years ago in Lawrence, Mass. She stepped from school teacher to film prominence in a few months and had eight years of consistent success.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- After running third in his two previous starts, Mrs. F.C. Dunn's Thistle Jock came from off the pace today to account for his first victory of the Fair Grounds meeting. He won the one and one-sixteenth mile feature, covering the distance in 1:46 3-5.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 16. -- Wesley Andersoh today named Isadore Blumenfeld, alias Kid Cann, as the slayer of Walter Liggett, newspaper publisher. This identification corroborated that of Mrs. Liggett. Cann has been a prisoner since a few hours after the slaying a week ago today.

From its wealth of marvelous material the Pierpont Morgan Library, in East Thirty-sixth Street, has generously selected examples of old manuscript illumination and drawings to form an exhibition that serves to dramatize for us "The Christmas Festival."

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 16. -- Acceptance of the Hoare-Laval peace plan would be "cowardice," declared the Emperor, following long consultations at his field headquarters here with his American adviser, Everett A. Colson. In a formal statement addressed to Teswai Tegan, Director of Foreign Affairs, and all military leaders, he said:

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 16. -- When an inquiry primarily designed to find out whether the Canadian public is paying too much for automobiles opened before the Tariff Board here today, those American companies which serve the Canadian market from branch plants in this country launched a counter-offensive.

The A. Cressy Morrison Prize, awarded annually by the New York Academy of Sciences, will go this year to Arthur David Howard of New York University, it was announced last night at the annual dinner meeting of that organization at the American Museum of Natural History.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The stock markets here were generally dull and quiet today. British funds were affected by the political uncertainties and moved lower on absence of support. Far Eastern and European issues eased in the foreign market, but German issues improved.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, Transit Commissioners William G. Fullen, Leon G. Godley and Reuben L. Haskell participated yesterday morning in the ceremonies that marked the beginning of work on the elimination of the grade crossing at Seventy-ninth Street and Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The National Lumber Manufacturers Association, which has criticized sharply the reciprocal trade agreement with Canada, declared its intention today to cooperate with the government.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 16. -- Attorneys for the Securities and Exchange Commission elicited today from James F. McConnochie a picture of his trading role as they pursued their inquiry into the activities of his partner, M.J. Meehan, in Bellanca Aircraft stock on the New York Curb Exchange last Summer.

Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals was re-elected president of Congregation Emanu-El last night at the annual meeting in the Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. He has been president of the congregation since 1929.

Postmaster General James A. Farley directed yesterday the issuance of a call for a meeting of the Democratic National Committee at the New Willard Hotel in Washington on Jan. 9. The time and place of the Democratic National Convention will be fixed at the meeting.

Albert Bein's "Let Freedom Ring," which closed at the Broadhurst Nov. 30, comes to life again tonight, this time at the Civic Repertory Theatre in Fourteenth Street. The new management is the Theatre Union, and the prices too have changed -- $1.50 on Saturday night, $1 on other nights -- but the cast remains as it was: Norma Chambers, Shepperd Strudwick, Robert Williams, William Geer, Paula Bauersmith and Rose Kean in important roles.

The Connecticut-New York liquor dealers' controversy, which led to the arrest of two persons for transporting liquor from Greenwich to Westchester, approached a showdown yesterday with the announcement by District Attorney Walter A. Ferris of Westchester that he would prosecute the cases.

At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the doors of the Frick Art Collection were opened at 1 East Seventieth Street, and the public had its first opportunity to see the magnificent legacy it received from Henry Clay Frick, coke and steel pioneer.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16. -- Maryland's 1936 racing season will open at Bowie on Wednesday, April 1, and the Spring campaign will end at Pimlico on Saturday, May 16. The feature will be the renewal of the rich Preakness States for 3-year-olds on May 16.

A fireman who disappeared yesterday with $2,134 which he had obtained by cashing eighteen checks for the half-month's salary of himself and seventeen fellow-firemen was being sought by the police, who sent out a general teletype alarm for the man.

If William F. Peterson, fugitive broker, had bought 75,000 shares of Silver King stock late last February, as he pretended, he would have made a profit of $825,000 in the next three months, it was asserted yesterday at the trial in General Sessions of his wife and two men accused of stock frauds as Peterson's confederates.
ST LOUIS, Dec. 16. -- Herbert Hoover, in a caustic indictment of the New Deal, demanded tonight the removal of relief into a decentralized set-up based on "the voluntary spirit of human service."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- In a surprising change of program, the Supreme Court disclosed today that it will return from its holiday recess Jan. 6 instead of Jan. 13, in time to hand down decisions on the AAA, TVA and Bankhead Cotton Control Act three days after Congress assembles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Review by the Supreme Court of the constitutionality of a price differential of one cent a quart between advertised and unadvertised brands of milk in favor of the latter under the New York Milk Control Law was assured today.

The Guffey act, which was signed by the President last Aug. 30, and was passed by Congress to stabilize the bituminous industry, was attacked yesterday in suits filed in United States District Court by two coal-producing corporations, which seek to have it declared unconstitutional.
The list of the American Farmer of the American Merchant Lines, due today from London, includes:
The first of the season's Coffee Dances took place last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. There were many dinners before the dance. Some of the guests came after attending the opera.

SALERNO, Italy, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Giuseppe (Big Mike) Spinelli was sentenced today to thirty years' imprisonment for "premeditated homicide" in the slaying of the three Volpe brothers at Pittsburgh, Pa., in 1932.

For the first time in twenty-five years the Metropolitan season began last night with another opera than "Aida." Presumably the change was intended to signalize the end of the Gatti-Casazza era and the beginning of a new epoch.
With only eight days left before Christmas, the Neediest Cases Fund is entering upon the most crucial period of the annual appeal for those in greatest distress in all New York.

Mayor La Guardia's plan for a municipal art center assumed more definite form yesterday when he told members of the Municipal Art Committee at City Hall how the plan has progressed since he first announced it last January.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Lacking the international character that featured the play last year, the sixth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship for women got under way on the courts of Chalfonte-Haddon today. All four seeded stars moved into the second round.

Leasing of stores and entire floors in the midtown district and in several other sections of Manhattan was reported active yesterday despite the approach of the Christmas holidays. There were several rentals in Fifth Avenue Buildings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--Federal Reserve Bank governors, meeting here tomorrow, will discuss the increasingly pressing problem of what to do with the enormous volume of excess reserves piled up by the banks. These reserves now exceed $3,000,000,000.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday for the ten months ended on Oct. 31, a net income of $18,174,176, after taxes and charges, equal to $1.38 a share on the 13,167,696 shares of $50-par capital stock, compared with $18,312,670, or $1.39 a share, in the corresponding period of 1934. In October the road had a net income of $3,838,574, against $3,273,261 in October last year.

There has been a tendency lately among those accustomed to large giving to concentrate, if not on the immediate present, then on the near future. Although hard times may have accelerated it, the trend began before the depression. The late JULIUS ROSENWALD set the fashion when he directed the trustees of the fund which bears his name to expend both income and principal within twenty-five years of his death.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Dec. 16.--Thousands of hunters from New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware, as well as from other parts of New Jersey, arrived in the southern part of the State today to get an early start for the opening tomorrow morning of the five-day deer shooting season.

The Associated Gas and Electric System has acquired from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, through an exchange of securities, all of the bank's holdings of common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company. The stock, representing about one-third of the common shares, was acquired by the bank at auction pursuant to a default on a note held by the bank.

Poor old "and/or"! To be called a bastard son of Indolence and/or Ignorance out of Dubiety by a learned jurist and/or a politician ought to be enough to damn its being and/or its soul into oblivion by reason of such forceful derogation and/or anathema.
