In an afternoon of play featured more by duffer bridge than by expert play, the European championship contract bridge team cut the lead of the American Four Aces to a mere 40 points yesterday at the end of ninety-two hands of the 300-hand international match sponsored by Mike Jacobs at Essex House.

The donor of the largest gift by an individual to the United Hospital Campaign, which is seeking to raise $2,000,000 to meet the financial emergency confronting the voluntary hospitals of the city and which closes tomorrow, was announced yesterday as Mrs. Kate Macy Ladd of Far Hills, N.J.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 16. -- Republicans will have a $12,500,000 building and more than 250,000 square feet of floor space, if they need it, in which to nominate a candidate for President in June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Disclosing that $178,718,250 of baby bonds, with a maturity value of $238,291,000, were sold between March 1 and Nov. 30, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that a new series of the United States Savings Bonds would be issued for sale through the Postal Service on Jan. 1.
Motorists speeding through the Midtown Hudson Tunnel will travel under the largest glass ceiling in the world, it became known yesterday.

Elmer Rice, regional director of the Federal theatre project, yesterday named for the first time the productions of three of his major units and several of the smaller ones. Each group will be in rehearsal within a week, he said, although specific opening dates remain subject to cutting the red tape which has hampered the project thus far.

For his services since 1912 in the development of the Palisades Interstate Park, Major William A. Welch, its general manager and chief engineer, received last night the 1935 Cornelius Amory Pugsley gold medal "for meritorius services in the cause of furthering the development of the parks of America," given by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 16. -- What Japan expects to gain through the founding of the autonomous regime in Hopei and Chahar Provinces was set forth in detail today by Lieut. Col. Y. Ishii, the official spokesman of General Hayao Tada, commander of the Japanese forces in North China.

A new era in the history of the Metropolitan Opera House began last night as the institution opened its doors for its fifty-third year. The first change in management in twenty-seven Winters introduced Edward Johnson as director, and he chose to launch his regime with Verdi's appealing old opera, "La Traviata."

The Columbia University Club and the City A.C. each won its fourth straight match yesterday to continue in a tie for the lead in the Metropolitan Class C squash tennis race. The Blue and White routed the Harvard Club, 4 to 1, while the City combination conquered the Elizabeth team, 3 to 2.

Leonard del Genio, Harlem lightweight, outlasted Lou Lombardi of Jersey City to gain the decision in a furiously fought ten-round encounter featuring the weekly boxing show at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

If the State Mortgage Commission goes through with its plan to take over the servicing of the certificated mortgages of the Lawyers Mortgage Company on Jan. 1, it will virtually put an end to the hope that the company, one of the title and guaranty concerns in rehabilitation by the State, can be reorganized, Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink, who is head of the Mortgage Rehabilitation Bureau at 160 Broadway, said last night.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- An emergency meeting of the British Cabinet has been called for tomorrow morning, when Foreign Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare, who returned from Switzerland tonight, will give his account of what happened a week ago between him and Premier Pierre Laval in Paris to bring about the Ethiopian peace proposals that have put the Baldwin Government on the defensive against virtually the entire British public and Parliament.

A special committee of traffic experts having membership in the Shippers Conference of Greater New York yesterday submitted a list of ten questions to be placed before transportation men at a "town meeting" summoned to consider the operation of the new Federal motor-truck legislation.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16.--Thelma Todd, motion picture actress, was found dead today in her automobile, and tonight it was announced that she had died of carbon monoxide fumes "that she breathed accidentally."

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- The Boerse appeared completely paralyzed today. This week opened as last week closed. There were few offers made and as few taken. For the practical purposes of market regulation, the official Boerse has ceased to exist.

I noted with interest your editorial "Gold and Stabilization" in which, commenting on the address of Mr. Aldrich, it was stated that perhaps two years ago a majority of business leaders believed that the adoption of codes in which they might fix prices for their goods represented a solution for one of their chief problems.
Tonight will be another night of hockey celebration in Madison Square Garden.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Fine bowling and fielding is slowing up the first cricket test match between South Africa and Australia. After the Springboks had taken the whole of Saturday to score 248 runs, the second day's play ended today with the tourists' total at 280 for four wickets.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, which has paid dividends continuously since 1861, declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share, payable on Dec. 28 to holders of record of Dec. 19. This is the first dividend declared this year.

A letter threatening death to Caleb Milne 4th, 24 years old, of 157 East Thirty-seventh Street, who vanished Saturday morning, was received in the mail yesterday by his grandfather, Caleb Milne Jr., 74 years old, at his home in Germantown, Pa.

The Federal Government, which already has begun a criminal investigation under the mail fraud statutes of the $700,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company, developed by Howard C. Hopson, who has waged a fight against the Utility Holding Company Bill, struck out again at that corporation yesterday.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 of short term notes of the city of Pittsburgh, Pa., on a bid of 100,065 for 1s. The notes are dated Oct. 1, 1935, and will become payable on Oct. 1, 1938.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Selling of wheat futures by the Canadian Wheat Board in Winnipeg was strongly in evidence on the Board of Trade here today. While the general run of the news was in favor of higher prices, the pressure on the Canadian market was sufficient to put a damper on operations on the bull side.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 16. -- The Mexican Senate removed the Governors of the States of Sonora, Sinaloa, Guanajuato and Durango today after unanimous approval of a committee report charging them with seditious activity in behalf of former President Plutarco Elias Calles.

The public was warned yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters to avoid Christmas fires and injuries often resulting in death. "Of all misfortunes," said the announcement, "none is worse than the fire which not only destroys the family fireside but all too often takes toll of life and inflicts painful burns on helpless children and others."

Magistrate William O'Dwyer, sitting yesterday in the Brooklyn Traffic Court, in a determined effort to stop the evasion of traffic violation summonses, sent out a squad of ten uniformed policemen, armed with warrants demanding appearance of 280 in the court this morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Gleaming with white paint, tempered with pale green, and shining stainless steel, the new White House kitchen was shown to the press today for the first and last time.

For the first time on record the country's supply of money has risen above $16,000,000,000. This is almost double the amount we had in the Autumn of 1929, at the peak of the pre-depression boom. The enormous increase since then is to be explained partly by heavy imports of gold and silver and partly by devaluation of the dollar.

Approximately 600 men, members of the Laundry Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, Local 810, affiliated with the A.F. of L., went on strike in upper Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, affecting about fifty establishments. About 350 men struck in Manhattan and the rest in the Bronx.

Governor TALMADGE may seem to prejudiced critics a specimen of a common order of politicians, cultivators of oddity, seekers of conspicuity. Such a view is unjust to a solitary patriot. He calls himself a Jeffersonian Democrat. If he is right he should keep in hiding or be accompanied by a bodyguard.

An offering of $15,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Schenley Distillers Corporation will be made today by Lehman Brothers. The offering consists of 150,000 shares at $100 a share.

Wizened old women from out of town and quick-fingered fashion sketchers from Fifth Avenue pressed cold noses against the panes of the Thirty-ninth Street entrance to the Metropolitan Opera House last night as another opening went into history.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Prices of hogs were on the downgrade here today. While a few sales were made early at about steady prices the undertone was weak, and at the last the market was quoted as 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight lower with butcher hogs and sows weighing over 275 pounds showing the most recession.
Dan O'Mahoney, the husky young Celt from County Cork, last night triumphed in the hardest wrestling match he has had since annexing the world's heavyweight championship.
Penitentiary terms were imposed yesterday on two loan sharks by Justices Kernochan, Salomon and Brady in Special Sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- A field goal from mid court by Al Greenberg, New York boy, gave Temple University a sensational 32-30 victory over St. Joseph's in the second game of the season's opening college basketball doubleheader at the Arena tonight.

The Neediest, whose stories have been told on these pages and who are waiting for the relief you can provide, are not mendicants. They are self-respecting men and women and helpless children who have come to grief through no fault of their own and can struggle forward no longer without outside help.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 16. -- Rhodes scholars who will enter Oxford University next Fall were chosen today by committees in eight districts, each of which was entitled to four scholarships.

A signed contract for the construction by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of a new passenger and freight ship for the United States Lines at a cost of $11,900,000 was placed in the hands of Secretary Roper yesterday in Washington.

Seven members of a gang of fake charity solicitors, who used names of public officials, judges, lawyers and business men in pleas over telephones for subscriptions to mythical hospitals and orphanages, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to conspiring to defraud the public, a rarely used law.
Crownless as far as the boxing world is concerned, Joe Louis stands acclaimed by the nation's sports experts as the outstanding athlete of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Supreme Court received an unexpected visit today from one Harris Tzotis, who was apparently under the impression that he was Diogenes in search of truth or something, and dressed to fit the part.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Political cleavage divided Capitol Hill's comment tonight on Herbert Hoover's address at St. Louis.

Remarking that it had become necessary to deal sternly with persons who risk the lives of others by driving automobiles while under the influence of liquor, Judge Lester W. Patterson in the Bronx County Court yesterday gave a former Department of Sanitation truck driver an indeterminate sentence in the penitentiary for manslaughter.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Paul Thompson, Chicago Black Hawks' wingman, with eight goals and six assists for 14 points, still leads the individual scoring list in the National Hockey League, according to the statistics announced tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Arthur Henderson, who started life as an iron molder, left an estate of approximately 24,000, it was revealed today, thus establishing a record among prominent Laborite leaders in the House of Commons who have died.

Joe Louis's next ring engagement may be his scheduled battle against Charley Retzlaff in Chicago Jan. 17, according to an announcement made yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs, who has the Detroit Bomber under exclusive contract.

For the first time the chess champion of the world is a Dutchman. In the closest of all the matches which passed the title, Dr. MAX EUWE of Holland triumphed over Dr. ALEXANDRE ALEKHINE, Russian resident of Paris, by a score of 15 1/2 to 14 1/2. He won nine games, lost eight, and thirteen were drawn.

Mr. HOOVER replied at St. Louis last night to President ROOSEVELT'S Atlanta speech. He produced one interesting and effective comparison. It was that between the methods of relief which he himself adopted when President and those which have been followed by Mr. ROOSEVELT.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16.The 1936 budget for Westchester County, as finally prepared by the budget committee and submitted today to the Board of Supervisors for adoption at the meeting next Monday, provides for an estimated tax rate of $3.97 for each $1,000 assessed valuation, an increase of 18 cents over the rate for 1935.

Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland and George Kelly of Philadelphia joined James Caras of Wilmington, Del., in a three-cornered deadlock for first place in the world's professional pocket billiard championship tournament at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

President Roosevelt has invited the Lincoln Cathedral Choir, an "a cappella" organization from Lincoln, Neb., to participate in the ceremonies of lighting the National Community Christmas Tree on Christmas Eve in Washington, it was announced yesterday by Walter Anderson, manager of the group, at the choir's national headquarters at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Gathering up some loose ends in the outdoor field:

Columbia University paid tribute yesterday to the memory of Associate Dean Arthur T. Rowe and Dr. Paul Wiberg of the university School of Dental and Oral Surgery, who were slain last Thursday by Victor Koussow, a deranged laboratory worker.
PEIPING, Tuesday, Dec. 17. -- A night of rioting against "Japanese aggression" left sixty student patriots wounded today and drew warnings from the Japanese military.

Judge George W. Martin of Kings County Court acquiesced yesterday morning to the request of the November grand jury that it be dismissed. It had found four murder indictments in the beating and strangling of Samuel Druckman on the night of March 3 last in the garage in which he was employed at 225 Moore Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a public hearing for Thursday morning to consider a request by Southwestern Gas and Electric Company of Shreveport, La., an operating subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, which registered under the Public Utility Act of 1935 as a holding company, for permission to market $20,500,000 of bonds and debentures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- If the local forecasters are correct, the Third Michigan Congressional District tomorrow will elect overwhelmingly, in the Republican nominee, a pledged adherent of the Townsend plan, the Old Age Revolving Pension, the OARP. Should this happen, the event may prove a blessing in disguise by putting responsible and patriotic leaders of American thought on timely notice that they must unite to avert this threat of the destruction of our economic system.

Business interests of the city will be asked tonight to assist Controller Frank J. Taylor in determining whether trade amounting to millions of dollars a year is being driven out of the city because of local taxation.

Mayor La Guardia administered oaths of office yesterday to Magistrate Alvah W. Burlingame, promoted to Special Sessions Court; Charles Solomon, who succeeds Mr. Burlingame as magistrate, and Ellsworth H. Buck as member of the Board of Education.

Appointment of Sidney J. Kennedy, former collector of customs at Puerto Rico and active in the customs service since 1917, as administrative assistant to Thomas M. Lynch, United States Appraiser here, was announced yesterday by Collector Harry M. Durning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The government failed today in its effort to collect $21,000,000 as taxes on distilled spirits alleged to have been diverted during national prohibition from industrial use to beverage purposes.

If further proof were needed of the popularity of buses, it would be furnished by the experience of the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation. It is now barely a month since operations began on Eighth and Ninth Avenues, but according to the Transit Commission's announcement traffic has already risen 70 per cent over last year.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the names of twenty-one candidates for places on the nominating committee that will select candidates for office to be voted on at the annual election of officers and governors on May 11, 1936.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A decision to hold the Republican National Convention in Cleveland June 9 was reached today by the party's national committee in an atmosphere filled with revived hopes of defeating the New Deal in 1936.

There was resignation yesterday on the part of followers of the share market to the fact that holiday and year-end influences, and the present state of politics, domestic and foreign, make for uncertainties, marketwise; lacking important developments, stocks drifted irregularly and closed heavy, with leading issues down from fractions to 2 1/2 points.

HAVANA, Tuesday, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Cuban police announced early today that three prisoners taken in connection with the kidnapping of Nicolas Castano had been killed in an armed clash near the suburban town of Calvario.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Mrs. A.M. Creech's veteran racer, Noah's Pride, won the featured mile event today at Epsom Downs, defeating a smart field of 3-year-olds and up.

Another token of supremacy in the sport went to Harry F. Wolf yesterday as the national champion received the silver bowl as winner of the December scratch squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 11 shows an increase for the week of $130,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $181,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $47,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

One of the most intensive man hunts ever conducted by the police forces of New Jersey was under way last night for the two prisoners who escaped Saturday night from the Middlesex County jail at New Brunswick. Since their escape the men have held up an inn, broken into a boarding house and wrecked two stolen automobiles in their efforts to evade the tightening police cordon.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The naval i conference decided today again to !change its tactics. In the intimate atmosphere resulting from confining its deliberations to the heads of delegations it discussed anew the Japanese proposal for a-"common upper limit" and found it was mere]y traveling in a circle getting nowhere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Dealers in securities were warned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they must establish carefully that the initial purchaser of an issue which had been sold "privately" took over the issue with the intent of holding it for investment before they distributed any part of such an initial issue to the public without registration under the Securities Act of 1933.

A driver who is accused of having struck and seriously injured a cripple in a wheelchair, then driven away, was held in a total of $5,500 bail on three charges by Magistrate Malbin in Brooklyn Homicide Court yesterday. The magistrate said that if the evidence was correct, the case was "one of the most vicious" ever to come to his attention.

ROME, Dec. 16. -- Within forty-eight hours Premier Benito Mussolini will obtain from the Fascist Grand Council approval of the tenor of the reply he wishes to make to the Franco-British peace proposals and on Thursday morning he will probably communicate it to the French and British Ambassadors.

The secessionist group in the Socialist party, headed by Norman Thomas, issued a statement yesterday from its headquarters, 21 East Seventeenth Street, assailing the acceptance by Charles Solomon, Old Guard Socialist leader, of the appointment by Mayor La Guardia to be a magistrate.

From his cell in the death house of the New Jersey State prison at Trenton, Bruno Richard Hauptmann, sentenced to die Jan. 13 for the Lindbergh baby murder, has offered to submit to tests with the "lie detector" and "truth serum" used recently in Chicago.
Eleven Manhattan parcels and eight in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. A sheriff's sale also was held in the Bronx.

Although discussion of Assembly appointments at the Republican legislative conference at Albany tomorrow has been tabooed by State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton, it is expected that the selection of a majority leader, clerk and chairman of the Ways and Means Committee will receive informal consideration in talks before and after the conference.

The theft of fifty-four revolvers, eight rifles and a large quantity of ammunition from a police equipment store directly across a narlow alleyway from police headquarters and uncomfortably close to Commissioner Valentine's own office became known yesterday after the police had succeeded in keeping it a secret for almost two weeks.

President Roosevelt will get as many electoral votes in 1936 as he won in 1932, Postmaster General James A. Farley, National Democratic Chairman, assured Brooklyn Democrats last night. Mr. Farley spoke at a dinner given by Frank J. Quayle Jr., retiring Sheriff of Kings County, to associates and political allies at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn.
The office of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau at 80 Centre Street was stampeded yesterday morning at 9 o'clock when the doors were opened for the sale of 1936 automobile license plates.

The board of managers of the Adams Express Company declared yesterday a dividend of 10 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 10 to stockholders of record of Dec. 27. It was stated that this action was in line with the policy of the board to declare dividends when conditions warranted, without regard to fixed periods.

The decline in the price of silver continued yesterday. In London the United States Treasury purchased only 5 per cent of the silver offered and the quotation was reduced to 26d an ounce, the lowest price since Feb. 28. This was a drop of d from last Friday and was equal to about 57.70 cents an ounce.

Disregarding the crisp night air and the warning of three bandits who had stripped him of his trousers and $31, Sidney Weiss, collector for a Jersey City macaroni manufacturer, trailed the trio to an address six blocks from time scene o the robbery last night and had them arrested.

The City Affairs Committee, of which John Haynes Holmes is chairman, made public yesterday a letter to Thomas D. Thacher, chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, protesting against parts of its tentative plan.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- Money for carryover purposes in today's midmonth settlement reached the astonishing rate of 8 per cent and caused considerable concern on the Bourse. On Nov. 30 the rate was 6 per cent, and it was believed that sufficient liquid capital would be found at that rate to permit it being retained and even lowered.

PLUTARCH made SOLON say that to salute as happy one who is still in the midst of life and hazard is as little safe and conclusive as to crown and proclaim as victorious the wrestler that is still in the ring. But the world need not await the death of MASARYK to proclaim him victor.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 16. -- Pope Plus XI in a secret consistory held in Consistorial Hall this morning created twenty new Cardinals, as follows:

There were two aspects of last night's concert of the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall to lend extra interest to the proceedings. Firstly, Joseph Schuster, former first 'cellist of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, made his initial appearance as soloist with the orchestra here on this occasion.

The Federal Reserve open market committee will hold today its last statutory meeting of the year in Washington. Some historical interest attaches to the occasion, for it may also be the last gathering of the open market committee as at present constituted.

Deals involving changes in ownership for buildings in the midtown East Side and in Chrystie Street, and the purchase of a plot in the Bronx for the erection of a new apartment house, were reported yesterday.

While hundreds of holiday shoppers passed, two robbers with drawn pistols approached Charles Glickman, Bronx dealer in old gold, as he was about to enter his car at Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue shortly after noon yesterday and forced him to drive them to Forty-third Street near Second Avenue, where they robbed him of $3,452 and left him in the car bound and gagged.

PEIPING, Dec. 16. -- Scenes of brutality characterized efforts of Peiping policemen, soldiers and gendarmes to break up an immense student demonstration against autonomy for North China today after the firing of three volleys from rifles over the heads of the students had failed to disperse the marchers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Representative John J. O'Connor, chairman of the House Rules Committee, who has been seeking information on the income of Howard C. Hopson, said tonight that he did not believe his inquiry would be affected by the tax lien filed in New York against the Associated Gas and Electric Company.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Community Councils of Queens and the entire city joined yesterday with the New York City Park Association, Queens Borough and city officials and civic leaders of College Point in opposing the city's proposal to locate a new terminal slip for the College Point-Bronx ferry in Chisholm Park.

Sixteen families have moved into First Houses, the New York City Housing Authority's first experiment in model low-rental tenements, at Avenue A and Third Street, the Housing Authority announced last night. Many of them are enjoying this week for the first time the advantages of mechanical refrigeration, ample closet space and other modern conveniences.

The New York Rangers tried hard celebrate their 500th game with a victory but after seventy minutes of play had to be content with a 1-to-1 tie against the Canadiens of Montreal last night. The visiting sextet played cautiously all the way through and rarely opened up, with the result that the game held few thrills for the crowd of 10,000 persons on hand at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Governors of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks met today as the open-market committee for the system with virtually their entire attention centered on the problem of the $3,300,000,000 of excess reserves that members of the system have in the banks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Ray Murphy, Commander of the American Legion, today delivered personally to President Roosevelt that organization's request for full and immediate payment of the bonus.

Mrs. Winifred Ovitte, fashion editor of Women's Wear, was greeted yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore as the new president of the Fashion Group of New York. Her election for a term of two years beginning Feb. 1 was announced at the luncheon. Miss Dorothy Shaver, vice president of Lord Taylor and chairman of the board of governors of the organization, presided.

Encountering unexpectedly stiff opposition from a fighting Seton Hall quintet, Manhattan's basketball team cut loose with a brilliant display of scoring power last night to maintain its undefeated status in a wide-open battle at the Manhattan gymnasium.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The war in Ethiopia is at present overshadowed by the conflict over the provisional peace proposals. This relegation of the battlefront to the background had contributory causes in apparent army movements and the curtailment of news.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- The Metropolitan Opera Company presented Puccini's "Tosca" before a socially distinguished audience at the Academy of Music tonight.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 17. -- America paid homage to four of its pioneers of aviation today and received a hint of aerial accomplishments to come.

TUNGCHOW, China, Wednesday, Dec. 18. -- A frank admission that the autonomists are not satisfied merely with Hopei and Chahar, but aim at ultimate expansion in other provinces, has been given by Yin Ju-keng, chairman of the East Hopei autonomy council.

In a letter to President Roosevelt yesterday the New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association asked that the government announce a "clear cut, understandable housing program" which will permit private industry to proceed with confidence in developing the potential housing market.

While business failures increased in both the retail and wholesale divisions in the week ended Dec. 12, as compared with the previous week, the manufacturing branch showed a slight decline, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Renovation of various Manhattan housing properties is projected in connection with deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -Heinie Manush, a former batting champion of the American League who slumped badly last season, today was traded by Washington to the Boston Red Sox for two other outfielders, Roy Johnson and Carl Reynolds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Active preparations for the session of Congress which will open Jan. 3 will start on Thursday, when Vice President Garner, Speaker Byrns and other Congressional leaders reach Washington on their return from the inauguration of the Philippine Commonwealth in Manila.

Price movements were mixed in light trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. On the cash markets corn, rye and lard declined, the latter to a new low price, while wheat, cotton, rubber and wooltops advanced. Refined sugar prices were restored to the 5-cents-a-pound level.

The Franco-American international contract bridge match, scheduled for 300 hands with a grand finale at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, proceeded through its 140th hand yesterday at Essex House with the American Four Aces leading the European champions from Paris by 2,850 points.

Although, as Chairman THACHER makes it clear, the Charter Commission has reached no final decisions, it has apparently proceeded far enough in its deliberations for the public to catch their general drift. It is in the direction of improvement and adaptation rather than fundamental change.

The Squash Club went into the lead in the Class B Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association team race last night in Group I. By defeating the Harvard Club, the Squash Club remained unbeaten in two matches.

The variety of properties figuring in yesterday's active dealings included two large taxpayers and an apartment house in the Bainbridge Avenue section of the Bronx and a multi-family building in Queens.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Dec. 17. -Dr. F. E. Townsend, here for a physical check-up by Mayo Clinic physicians, tonight asserted that the triumph of Verner W. Main, who bore endorsement of the Townsend Club organization in his race

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 17. -- A survey of ten typical New Hampshire towns was reported by the New Hampshire Foundation today to show that the Compulsory spendings by persons 60 years of age and older under the Townsend plan would amount to twice the retail purchases of all the residents.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 17. -- Police tonight awaited word from New York City concerning a 19-year-old girl who says she is Betty I. Bush, daughter of a New York broker and banker, and a man held with her who says he is Harold McConnaghy, 35, alias John Metz, alias Harold McCann.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 17. -- Demands are coming to government officials from all sides for a complete "purge" of associates of General Plutarco Calles, former President, who returned here last Friday after a self-imposed exile in Los Angeles, Calif.

Charging that the National Dress Manufacturers Association had failed to comply with the union agreement which expires Jan. 31, officials of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union presented last night to the association provisions for better enforcement which the union demands in the new agreement now being negotiated.

Yesterday the American Legion formally submitted to Mr. ROOSEVELT its demand for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus. No statement was forthcoming as to the answer given by the President, but Secretary MORGENTHAU asserted recently that the Administration is still opposed to the demand for payment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A Federal Workmen's Compensation Law for workers in interstate commerce was favored today at a meeting of welfare organizations and trade union representatives held under the auspices of the United States Department of Labor.

A fire of unknown origin caused damage estimated at from $70,000 to $100,000 yesterday morning in the six-story factory and warehouse building of the Horowitz-Margareten Company, noodle and matzoth manufacturers, at 179-183 Lewis Street.

A Christmas party for the children attending the Anne Brown Alumnae Free Nursery School will be held Friday morning at the headquarters of the nursery in the New York Kindergarten Building, 524 West Forty-second Street.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, joined yesterday in the appeal for support of the United Hospital Fund drive as the campaign neared its close today. New additions to groups soliciting in the professions were announced in an effort to put the fund over the top.

The art of ceramic has come into some prominence this week, with a selected group of work from the fourth national Robineau memorial ceramic exhibition at the Ferargil Galleries and a one-man show of ceramic sculpture, pottery and enamels on copper by Russell Barnett Aitken at the Walker Gal]eries -the former to continue until Dec. 28, the latter until Jan. 4.

United States ports have won back part of the trade in Canadian grain exported to other parts of the British Empire despite a "whispering campaign" intended to discredit such export by ports other than those of Canada, according to the Port of New York Authority.

About 130 members of the Knickerbocker Greys, crack cadet battalion of New York boys, marched yesterday afternoon in an annual Christmas review before former members of their ranks. The review was staged in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

HAVANA, Dec. 17. -- Three persons were killed and one gravely wounded in a gun battle near the corner of Infanta and San Lazaro Streets tonight between police and the occupants of a car suspected of containing the main members of the gang which kidnaped Nicolas Castano, released by military authorities last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Attorneys for the Securities and Exchange Commission, who are seeking to obtain the suspension or expulsion of Michael J. Meehan from major Exchanges because of alleged manipulation of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock, battered all through today's session on Matthew Frank, who described himself as a New York City betting commissioner and an "intimate" friend of Mr. Meehan.

A 5 per cent reduction in the number of civil service employes on the city payroll for the ultimate good of the civil service system is advocated by Harold Riegelman, attorney for the Citizens Budget Commission, in an article in the January issue of The Answer, a national civil service magazine.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17. -- Dr. Charles Warren Dubois, 33, former interne in Bellevue Hospital, New York, was shot in the head and killed today while he and an unidentified man apparently were preparing for a duck-hunting expedition.

PARIS, Dec. 17. --During two extremely dramatic sessions today the French Chamber of Deputies discussed and decided its attitude with regard to the Italo-Ethtopian dispute and the course that should be followed by France's representatives at Geneva.

Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney, urged General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins yesterday to impose sentence immediately on Nicholas Montana, vice overlord, on his conviction last month on a compulsory prostitution indictment.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- Bishop Erwin Kreuzer of the Old Catholic Church, a sectarian body on a more or less nationalist basis developing from a schism with Rome in the last century, today took the oath of loyalty to the Third Reich.

,17/, P. I., Dec. 17.TheAmerican community is exercisedover the terms of a bill creating anew intermediate court of appealswhich has been submitted to theAssembly and recommended byPresident Manuel Quezon.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17. -- That Soviet Russia will throw its full weight and influence against the HoareLaval program at Geneva was indicated clearly today by the Journal de Moscou, a French-language newspaper published under semiofficial auspices.

Hank Greenberg of Detroit has the distinction of having swung his bat more effectively by far with men on bases than any other player in the American League, during the 1935 season, according to the official figures released today.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- Once again the executioner in evening clothes swung the headsman's axe in the dawn's dim light in Berlin today and another head rolled in the sand of the Third Reich. The head belonged to Rudolf Claus, leader in the Communist uprising in Saxony in 1920.

Awarding medals for meritorious service to Major WILLIAM A. WELCH, general manager of the Palisades Interstate Park; WILLIAM E. CARSON, former director of the Virginia Department of Conservation and Development, and PHILIP W. AYERS, forester for the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests, is indicative of the growing public interest in the furtherance of the development of parks in America.

The St. Ann's Academy basketball team, playing on its own court, captured its opening contest yesterday when it defeated the Power Memorial Academy quintet, 31 to 11, in a C.H.S.A.A. contest. The first half was close with the victors enjoying a 12-to-7 lead at half time.

A delegation from Local 119 of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, which charges that fifty of its members were locked out of the Central Park Casino on Monday, will call on Park Commissioner Moses today in an attempt to enlist his aid in their cause, officials of the union announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Increasing indications that major veterans' organizations were driving to solidify their strength behind a single bonus bill in the approaching Congress brought a forecast from a Democratic House leader today that a cash payment bill would be shoved through, no matter what the Presidential attitude.

Declaring that any substantial hardening in money rates appears unlikely for some time to come, Allan M. Pope, president of the First Boston Corporation, told those gathered at a dinner of the Savings Bank Officers Forum, Group 4, of the Savings Bank Association, last night in the Hotel Astor, that the argument for an "increase or maintenance of present prices of highgrade interest-bearing securities outweighs the known factors against this increase in price."

CATSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 17 (AP). -Officials hurried into the Catskill Mountains here tonight after receiving an anonymous tip that they "would find something interesting" regarding the disappearance of Caleb Milne 4th at a two-story stucco house on the Wood Road, between West Saugerties and Palenville.

Four hundred members and guests of the Sunshine League for Orphans of the City of New York held their sixth annual benefit luncheon and entertainment yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Contributions amounted to $5,000, which was apportioned to twelve Jewish orphan homes to buy coal, clothes and other Winter necessities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., of New York City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for the issuance of $9,200,000 of first mortgage 4 1/4 per cent sinking fund bonds due on Jan. 1, 1956.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 17. -Sir Douglas Mawson, widely regarded as the most experienced of all Antarctic explorers, disclosed tonight that he had offered his services to accompany the British Royal Research Society vessel Discovery II on a search for Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, his pilot, lost since Nov. 23, when they started on a transantarctic flight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- President Roosevelt's statement on the public works fund today was the first intimation of what the New Deal proposes for the unemployed after next July. The Chief Executive nevertheless withheld any hint of the total to be asked for relief of all kinds.

Insisting that American goods are not objects of discrimination by the Argentine authorities, L. C. Ball, president of Ault Wiborg Argentine Company, Buenos Aires, told the Export Managers Club of New York at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday that this country is getting its full share of exchange allotment from the Argentine Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Republican party now has a convention city, a convention hall, $150,000 for expenses and a date to assemble its Presidential nominating forces. It still lacks anything approaching agreement on a candidate and a platform, as was manifest in what was said privately by members of the Republican National Committee which met here this week.
PEIPING, Wednesday, Dec. 18. -A wide area of North China assumed a semi-autonomous status today with the formal inauguration of the new Political Council for Hopei and Chahar Provinces.

MIDLAND PARK, N.J., Dec. 17. -- A new method of picketing plants where strikes are in force and where a court order prevents demonstrations has been evolved by the local union of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers. The union has purchased a plot of land fifty feet from the plant against which it is acting and defies the police to prevent picketing on that land.
Christmas trade and income-tax payments offered combined evidence yesterday that in the city and throughout the country Americans have more money to spend this year.

GENEVA, Dec. 17. -- The trend here tonight in small power and League of Nations Secretariat circles seems to favor confining the meeting of the Council tomorrow on the Anglo-French proposals for Italo-Ethiopian peace to declarations by Premier Pierre Laval of France and Anthony Eden, British Minister for League affairs and adjourning until Friday.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- After weathering a furious barrage during a scoreless opening period, the Boston Bruins gave the Detroit Red Wings a 4-1 trouncing tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden.

LIKE all selective lists, the one printed last week in this column for the benefit of the Christmas book-giver had its errors of omission. Some correspondents have been quick to resent the absence of their particular favorites among the books of 1935; others have asked for specific information. For the benefit of each group, here are some addenda:

New York will put forward Representative Bertrand H. Snell of Potsdam, St. Lawrence County, minority leader of the House, for permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Snell was permanent chairman of the 1932 convention at Chicago and was a capable presiding officer.
With Christmas only one week away, the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases, which now totals $131,507.95, still is lagging behind last year's Fund at this date.

In other years gifts for the Neediest Cases have flowed in largely during the week before Christmas. It is necessary that they do so now if this year's Fund is to reach the total of 1934. It should really surpass it, with so many evidences that people have more money to spend and to give away than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Chairman Fletcher, after expressing "satisfaction" with the national committee's meeting, said he would go to New York tomorrow to confer with William B. Bell, head of the party's new finance committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A change in policy by which public works expenditures will be voted in the future by Congress as direct appropriations rather than be granted as allocations from a fund administered by the President was announced informally by Mr. Roosevelt today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Encouraged by what they regard as a "decided trend" against President Roosevelt over the nation, Republicans will open immediately a campaign to educate the voters by radio speeches and party literature, Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee announced today.

Plans for a campaign to raise $500,000 to aid Polish, German and other non-Russian Jews to settle in the recently created autonomous territory of Birobidjan in the Soviet Union were announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Bankers Club of the American committee for the settlement project.

Eight hundred nurses attended a closely contested debate last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania on the current proposal to amend the Nurse Practice Act, which has been effective in this State since 1921. Proposed changes would put in legislative form a definition of nursing and put all persons practicing nursing for hire under license.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 17. -The Elizabeth Town and Country Club defeated the Short Hills Club, 3 -- 2, today and continued unbeaten in the B division of the Women's New Jersey Squash Racquets League. In the other match played today, the Essex County Country Club defeated the Plainfield C.C., 3 -- 2, at West Orange to score its first victory of the season.

ATHENS, Dec. 17. -- The restoration of King George to the Greek throne was the result of Italian diplomacy, according to correspondence of Athens statesmen published in newspapers here. But instead of being pro-Italian, King George is definitely pro-British.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., vice chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, will become chairman of the committee on Jan. 1, succeeding William S. Filbert, who will retire under the corporation's pension plan, it was announced yesterday after a special meeting of the board of directors.
The first railroad to report for November, the Erie, showed yesterday a substantial gain in net operating income for the month. Its statement follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The War Department today awarded a contract for 100 attack planes to the Northrop Corporation of Inglewood, Calif. Spare parts sufficient for fifteen planes are included in the contract, which involves a total expenditure of $2,560,074.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- Liberal receipts of hogs here and a slow demand for fresh and cured products, as well as lard, continue to react strongly against the price of hogs. Sales today showed a decline of 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight compared with those on Monday, with heavy kinds leading the decline.

Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, has issued a warning to Christmas shoppers not to encourage beggars who are active around department stores, theatres, hotels and subways, "capitalizing on the good-will of the holiday season."

More than 500 "Grand Street boys and girls," ranging in age from 15 to 80 years, attended the installation of Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein as president of the Grand Street Boys Association at the association headquarters, 106 West Fiftyfifth Street, last night.

Political committees of whatever party abound in a rhetoric that is a happiness to the connoisseur. It has an unfailing imaginative sweep, a swing and ring of its own. The resolution of the Republican National Committee, inviting all and then some Americans to join the rescue party that is to save their liberty, might almost be called the organ voice of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation sold at public auction today fifty-eight issues of bonds which it had bought from the Public Works Administration at an average price of 104 1/4. Bonds with a face value of $12,614,300 brought $13,180,492.86, representing a net premium of $566,192.86, the corporation announced.

Pledges to maintain basic provisions of the industry's former codes will be sought from 1,200 cotton mills throughout the country before Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute.
Lucrezia Bori, for a quarter of a century one of the leading sopranos of the Metropolitan Opera, intends to retire from the lyric stage at the end of the current Metropolitan season.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- An act of faith in the government and its Ethiopian policy will be performed throughout Italy tomorrow, end of the first month of sanctions, by a donation of wedding rings to the State.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Negotiations between Consumers Research, Inc., and the Technical, Editorial and Office Assistants Union, representing the company's employes, leading up to the strike at its plant at Washington, N.J., last Sept. 4, were told by Miss Susan Jenkins, vice president of the union, at the continued hearing on the case before the National Labor Relations Board here today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 429 as against 544 in the previous week and 462 in the same period last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Only one of the four seeded players remained in the sixth annual Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship at the close of today's matches on the courts of Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -Faced with a heavy auto death toll despite intensive local drives to reduce accidents, traffic experts will meet here tomorrow to plan a cooperative movement for safer driving.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- The German Olympic Committee announced today that no German citizen living abroad will be allowed to compete as a German in the Olympic Games unless he becomes a member of the Nazi sports organization, the socalled Reich League for Athletics.
A team of dazzling dribbblers and accurate shooters, the St. Francis College basketball squad upset Columbia, 32 to 30, last night on the Morningside Heights court.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 17. -- The Canadian Tariff Board was told by the Ford Motor Company of Canada today that it had lost money on the cars it sold in the Dominion during the last four years.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 17. -- Verner W. Main, Republican, bearing the endorsement of the Townsend Old Age Pension organization, was elected representative of the Third Michigan Congressional District today by a two-toone majority over two opponents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight held the first of the state receptions of the season, entertaining in honor of the diplomatic corps.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The British plan for elimination of world-wide competitive naval building was laid before the five-power conference in full committee this afternoon by Viscount Monsell in his capacity as First Lord of the Admiralty, and it made a good impression.

While a near-capacity crowd of 600 persons looked on at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, James Caras of Wilmington, Del., clicked off a sensational run of 104 points in the sixth inning and then gathered 17 in the ninth to defeat Joe Procita of Gloversville, N.Y., 125 to 0, providing one of the most onesided, triumphs in world's professional pocket billiard championship play.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Dec. 17 (AP). -- A young practical nurse who, police said, confessed she killed a woman patient to end her suffering, was held without bail charged with murder pending determination of her mental condition.

PEIPING, Dec. 17. -- Sixty more Japanese soldiers were reported to have arrived today at Kalgan from Jehol. Their mission was not explained, but it is probably connected with the unconfirmed report of a Japanese demand that six eastern districts of Chahar be ceded to Jehol on the ground that the Chahar authorities are unable to maintain order along Jehol's western border.

Many dinners will be given in advance of the Christmas Song Festival and Dance of the People's Chorus of New York which will be held on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. One of the largest parties before the entertainment will be given by Miss Eleanor Wendell, acting chairman of the junior committee, at the York Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Another attack upon the constitutionality of a New Deal law was carried to the Supreme Court today when J. Edward Jones of New York, dealer in oil royalties, filed a petition seeking to upset the Securities Act of 1933.

Except at one point, the Federal Government continues to enjoy steadily rising revenues. Yesterday the Treasury noted that income tax payments due on the 15th of this month were nearly a third larger than those received a year ago. There have also been substantial gains in receipts from customs, from internal revenue taxes on liquor and tobacco, and from the various excise taxes imposed on the sale of automobiles, radios and other manufactured articles.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- A terse government communique told the nation today of the first admitted retreat of Italian soldiers invading Ethiopia. Tonight anxious groups awaited details of a battle in the north, which did not come. Scores were reported killed and wounded.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Dec. 17. -Mrs. Ella Hoover Thatcher, 86 years old, is of unsound mind and is incapable of looking after her own affairs, a jury decided here tonight after five and one-half hours' deliberation. Russell E. Conover, Judge of the Court of Common Pleas, will name a guardian to handle the affairs of the aged woman.

Three dogs, allegedly, by their barking at unusual hours disturbed the domestic tranquility of Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill's home at 20 East Sixty-fifth Street and caused him, though a member of the bar for forty years, to appear yesterday for the first time in Yorkville Court as a complainant.

Simplification of the Securities and Exchange Commission's accounting requirements for listed corporations was urged by C. Oliver Wellington of Scovell, Wellington Co. at the monthly meeting last night of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants.

The recent decline of more than $4 a bale developed more resistance in trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices recovered 6 to 17 points. Steadiness in Liverpool, where less cotton was reported at the decline, and a stronger stock market influenced professional sentiment, while trade price-fixing occurred below 11 cents a pound for the May delivery.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 17 (AP). -Martin Barton, A. G. Tarn's 4-yearold gelding, captured the Epsom Downs Handicap, stake feature of getaway day at the Downs today, closing with a rush to lead a fine field of distance horses by more than a length.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A study of waybills of representative railroads in all parts of the country has been undertaken by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to prove that all sections, the industrial East in particular, are benefiting from payments made to farmers from processing taxes.

Your editorial of Dec. 6 "Surplus Bank Reserves" encourages me to write you for the purpose of developing some aspects of the subject which it seems to me have been almost wholly neglected in the public discussion of the past few months.

Five women, including a granddaughter of Charles A. Dana, and three men were arrested yesterday in the Central Railroad of New Jersey Terminal in Jersey City for picketing against the shipment of a cargo of scrap iron to Italy aboard the Norwegian ship Spero.

City officials, lawyers, newspaper publishers, radio entertainers and virtually every one lucky enough to have had a low-numbered or distinctive automobile license plate last year have renewed the registration on their vehicles and thereby kept the insignia for another year, records at the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 155 Worth Street, revealed yesterday.

Counsel for Mrs. Etta Reisman made it clear during the second day of her trial for second-degree murder in Queens County Court yesterday that the defense would rest its case on a contention that the shooting of 23-year-old Virginia Seigh, her husband's secretary, was an accident.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 17. -Lanky Horton Smith of Oak Park, Ill., flashing form reminiscent of five years ago when he paraded to victory in one major golf tournament after another, came home the winner today in the sixth annual Miami Biltmore $10,000 open.

The directors of the American Smelting and Refining Company declared yesterday a dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Feb. 29 to stock of record of Jan. 31. This is the first dividend to be paid on the common stock since Feb. 1, 1932, when 12 1/2 cents a share was disbursed.

Mr. and Mrs. D. Basil O'Connor gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mr. and Mrs. George Tilley, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Tilley, the Misses Beryl and Yvonne Tilley and John Pierce, all of London; Mr. and Mrs. John Hopkins, Mrs. Stewart Hopps, Keith L. Morgan and Dudley C. Ferguson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- A contract for an $11,900,000 liner to replace the Leviathan was submitted today for approval by Secretary Roper, with an application for a 75 per cent loan to the United States Lines.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- Camille Chautemps, former Premier, who probably has suffered most in the mudslinging of the Stavisky trial, made an appeal for moral reform today at the thirty-third session of the trial. The court room was crowded with spectators, a large number of whom were his colleagues of the Paris bar.

The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico, conductor, gave its second concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night before a large and responsive audience. John Powell was the guest artist, appearing as piano soloist in Mozart's D minor Concerto and his own "Negro Rhapsody."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP) -Ernest O. Peters, the chauffeur who drove Thelma Todd home from a party which preceded her death, told the police tonight that the actress ordered him to drive at breakneck speed, fearing she might be kidnapped or slain by gangsters.

As the stacks of Christmas mail began to pile up yesterday, Santa Claus radioed an unusually urgent plea to "do your Christmas mailing early." The message was prompted by Postmaster Albert Goldman's prediction that the mail this year would far surpass that of any previous year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17. -Charles W. Williams, '38, of Pontiac, Mich., has been chosen business manager of the Princeton University Triangle Club for its 1936 production. The current show, "What a Relief," will be presented in New York tomorrow and Thursday before starting on a tour through the Midwest, which will include sixteen cities.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Securities on the London Stock exchange today were firmer than yesterday and prices generally were better, but business did not show much expansion. British funds recovered as a result of investment support.

Sixteen downcast members of Hook and Ladder Company 27 were considerably cheered last night when they arrived at the firehouse at 453 East 176th Street, the Bronx, and learned that the amount of their semi-monthly pay checks, missing with an absconding associate, would be made up by the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

Mrs. John Clarkson Jay gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 120 East Seventy-third Street, for a group of debutantes, who are conducting the sale of seats for the performance of "Victoria Regina," a new play with Helen Hayes in the leading role, to be given the night of Dec. 27 at the Broadhurst Theatre for the benefit of the Union Settlement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- John P. Frey, president of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor, warned affiliated metal trades councils in a letter today that John L. Lewis's committee for industrial organization was creating division within the labor movement by seeking to violate the decision of the last federation convention on the question of industrial unionism.

After putting up brilliant resistance in the first half, the Springfield College quintet faltered before Long Island University's high-scoring attack and lost, 42-32, last night at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

The New York City Charter Revision Commission, in a formal statement issued yesterday, characterized as "entirely unauthorized" and "inaccurate in many respects" published versions of the recommendations the commission plans to make for the revision of the city government.

Dr. Reginald Aldworth Daly, Sturgis-Hooper Professor in the Department of Geology at Harvard University, will receive the Penrose Medal of the Geological Society of America, one of the world's signal honors in the field of geology, it was announced here yesterday by the society.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 17 (AP). -Attacks by Ethiopian advance patrols on Italian outposts on the northern front led Italian officers to predict tonight that Emperor Halle Selassie's forces were preparing for a mass assault.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17. -- The finding Sunday of a thirty-pound nugget near the village of Polevski, in the Ural gold fields, has drawn attention to the widespread search for gold being conducted in the Soviet Union.

The Republican party must take a stand against management of business by a bureaucracy and against dictation to the Federal Government by groups seeking special privileges, Franklin Fort, former Representative from New Jersey, declared last night at a dinner at the National Republican Club.

JOE LOUIS has been proclaimed the outstanding athlete of 1935 by a jury of sports writers. Since there are no Pulitzer prizes for distinguished achievement in athletics the practice has grown up of polling the nation's best-known newspaper men in this field.

One of the oldest living inhabitants, "Personal Appearance," says a double-barreled good-bye today to Henry Miller's Theatre. There will be a special matinee, at a dollar top, and then the final performance -the 504th -- this evening. More statistics, fresh from the Pemberton office: Since the premiere on Oct. 17, 1934, the cast has given 5,544 performances, and of these only six have been missed.

PRAGUE, Dec. 17. -- At the close of a day, during which the bitter ness of the Presidential electoral campaign steadily increased, a sensational development tonight made it possible for Eduard Benes to obtain the necessary majority on the first balloting tomorrow.

David Schneider, a silk dealer, who lives at 327 Central Park West, testified yesterday in Federal court that an assistant purser of the Ward liner Morro Castle had refused to give up his life preserver, when requested to do so, as that vessel was burning off Asbury Park on Sept. 8, 1934.

ALBANY, Dec. 17. -- Republican members of the Legislature and a number of county chairmen gathered here tonight in preparation for the conference tomorrow at which the party's 1936 legislative program will be gone over and reshaped in a search for issues to be used in the election next November.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 17. -Coupling its decided physical advantage with capable reserve power, Princeton University's quintet continued along its unbeaten trail tonight at the Trenton Central High School court with a 25-to-19 triumph over a plucky Rider College quintet.

Replying to President Roosevelt's rejection of their appeal that the United States remonstrate against "persecution of religion by the Mexican Government," the Knights of Columbus yesterday, in a second letter to the President, restated their demand and denied they had asked for "intervention."

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- A declaration by Premier Pierre Laval in the French Chamber of Deputies today that he had "rallied to the British thesis" has materially added to the irritation of the Baldwin government with the French over the Ethiopian peace proposals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, mentioned for the Republication nomination for President, warned today in a statement that only "tragic disillusionment" could come out of the Townsend plan.

The two escaped prisoners of the Middlesex County jail at New Brunswick, N.J., fled last night from their second hold-up in two days as State, county and local police rushed to block all roads near Plainfield, the scene of the latest activities of the fugitives.
" The Perfect Gentleman," with Frank Morgan and Cicely Courtneidge, opens today at the Center Theatre.

Prohibiting of guaranteed mortgage certificates in this State, earlier this year, did not stop the public from buying certificates, according to testimony given to a legislative committee yesterday at the Bar Association by Earl Crabb, vice president of the Investors Syndicate Title Guarantee Company, 535 Fifth Avenue.

Between the soup and the salad, seven Albany legislators had a chance yesterday to chat with their hostesses at the State League of Women Voters during luncheon at 99 Park Avenue. Afterward they merely sat and listened as League chairmen, carrying into effect a new method of buttonholing the lawmakers, explained what measures would have their support in the next Legislature, and why.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Four armed young men held up executives, clerks and customers of the First National Bank of Ardsley at 10:40 A.M. today and escaped with $10,000. A policeman in a commandeered taxicab chased the robbers' automobile at a mile a minute down the Saw Mill River Parkway, but was outdistanced, and another patrolman, seeing the car in Yonkers, fired at it, but also was unable to halt the hold-up men.

The Board of Aldermen at its final meeting of the year yesterday received a report from its investigating committee dealing with minor irregularities in the office of Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's brilliant tennis comeback, bringing with it the Wimbledon championship for the seventh time, has earned for her a new title -- the outstanding woman athlete of 1935.

The Roosevelt committee for holders of defaulted bonds distributed by S. W. Straus Co., one of the groups under investigation by the Streit joint legislative committee, is willing to submit to broader court supervision, according to a letter from George E. Roosevelt, head of the committee, to Saul S. Streit, chairman of the legislative inquiry, which was made public yesterday at the latter's offices, 80 Center Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 17. -The geographical boundary between Ohio and Indiana today appears to mark a psychological border line in political sentiment. Whereas Ohio is in doubt whether to vote for or against President Roosevelt's reelection next year, with the chances at present favoring the Republicans, the situation here is almost the reverse.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17. -- Two gray geldings, Kievex and Scotch Gold, battled through the stretch to finish as named in the featured Coconut Grove Purse of five and a half furlongs at Tropical Park today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17. -Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger gave a luncheon for twelve persons today at Beau Rivage.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Carrying its overnight score from 80 for four wickets to 429, Australia today obtained a first innings lead of 181 over South Africa in the third day's play of the first test match between the two countries.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team scored a 4-1 victory over the New York A.C. yesterday in a Group I match of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association on the winner's court. J.C. Lyons, Winged Foot No. 1 player, was the only victor for his team, defeating J. Brascher, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11.
Continued activity in the midtown section was indicated by the business leases reported yesterday. Wholesale and retail firms were among the lessees, as follows:

Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System -Five months ended Nov. 30: Net income $1,921,044, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.76 a share earned on 735,664 no-par common shares, comparing with $2,188,737, or $2.12 a share, in corresponding period a year before.

In order to controvert erroneous conclusions drawn from pair production statistics, the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association yesterday issued a chart and data covering dollar volume, employment and weekly payrolls in the industry.

Agents for the Westchester County Liquor Dealers Association were enjoined yesterday from "molesting" Connecticut liquor dealers and from "congregating, loitering or lying in wait" in that State to detect New Yorkers purchasing liquor.

Promising that women "for once are going to get a break," Victor Ridder, WPA Administrator, said last night at a dinner of the Women's City Club at its clubhouse, 22 Park Avenue, that he proposed to have needy women given the same consideration as men in the appointment of relief work.

Judge Allen in General Sessions reserved decision yesterday on a motion of counsel for Miss Vera Stretz, slayer of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, German importer, for copies of letters and other papers of the couple seized by the police when he was found shot to death in his apartment in the Beekman Tower Hotel Nov. 12 last.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in a letter addressed yesterday to prominent New Yorkers interested in improving-social conditions for under-privileged boys and girls, asserted that settlement music schools serve as places "where young men and women may find an outlet for their energies and a constructive use of their leisure time."

After the first talesman had been called to the witness stand at the opening of his trial, Andrew Eichner, 44 years old, of 408 East Ninetyfourth Street pleaded guilty yesterday to the charge that he was a confederate of John Flaherty, who is in Sing Sing for a job-fixing conspiracy.

Polo's ten-goal rating, the top of the handicap list, which stood empty during the past year, is filled again with a familiar name. Thomas Hitchcock Jr., internationalist since 1921 and generally regarded as the greatest player in the world, was back at that figure in the 1936 handicap list announced yesterday by the United States Polo Association.

Robin Lee, 16-year-old men's national senior figure skating champion, will give his first New York performance of the season at the New York American Christmas and Relief Fund carnival at the Ice Club tonight. Lee's free-skating show, which has developed noticeably in power and assurance since last year, will be one of the major attractions among the fourteen numbers of the program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Prompted perhaps by the meeting here yesterday of the Republican National Committee, President Roosevelt laughingly described today to newspaper men at his press conference his approval of efforts to preserve specimens of the elephant lest it follow the buffalo into virtual extinction.
The Western Union Telegraph Company resumed dividends yesterday with a declaration of $2. The dividend, the first to be paid since April, 1932, received no designation. It will be drawn from surplus.

Aside from a moderate rally in the final hour when the ground lost the day before was regained, the share market moved sluggishly yesterday in the absence of news which might be counted on to break the present stalemate. The industrial reports continued favorable, after due allowance was made for seasonal considerations; corporation earnings and dividend announcements were encouraging; the French Cabinet has been sustained; retail trade is reported the best in years.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,869,050 barrels, compared with 2,785,300 in the preceding week, an increase of 83,750 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 45,950 and 11,600 barrels, respectively, in the daily average output of Oklahoma and Kanas were the important changes.

Air travel time will be cut 1 hour 15 minutes between New York and Boston by the newly formed Marine Airlines, Inc., according to an announcement made at the Yale Club yesterday. The line, which is headed by James M. Eaton, former president of the Ludington Air Lines, has ordered three Sikorsky S-43 planes, the largest amphibians yet produced.

The Treasury Department filed additional liens yesterday for $4,907,245 against the Associated Gas and Electric Company and one of its affiliates, bringing total income tax claims against the utility system built up by Howard C. Hopson, opponent of the New Deal's utility reform program, to $53,406,031.
William R. Conklin, City Hall reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, was elected president of the Inner Circle yesterday at its annual meeting in the Aldermanic chamber at City Hall.

VIENNA, Dec. 17. -- Information from Sofia says the trial by a military court of former Premier Damian Veltcheff, General Zaimoff and Major Stancheff on charges of plotting to overthrow the present Bulgarian Government will open tomorrow.
BERLIN, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 14 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A committee representing a substantial group of investment trusts of the management type will confer here on Friday with Commissioner Robert E. Healy of the Securities and Exchange Commission and his staff of experts in regard to the questionnaire that the commission is preparing in connection with a study of investment trusts.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Harvard's powerful varsity hockey team easily defeated Boston University, 12 to 1, in the Arena tonight for its second straight victory of the campaign. The Crimson scored three goals in the first period, added five in the second, and closed with a four-goal drive in the third session.

With an appeal to all business agencies, Charles E. Murphy, special representative of the City Department of Finance, last night started Controller Frank J. Taylor's drive to halt the flight of business from New York.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- The Boerse continued as inactive as ever today, with some signs of firmness, due to lack of offers. The report by I. G. Farben of increased export business had a somewhat buoying effect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Chairman O'Connor, Democrat, New York, reiterated today that the House rules committee's demands that Howard C. Hopson supply it with details of his income were unaffected by the filing of $50.962,163 in Federal tax liens against the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

Police Descend En Masse on Hotel Room to Find Neurotic Had Sent Out Alarm.Six police radio cars, an emergency squad and half a dozen detectives descended on the Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in response to a telephone message to police headquarters that there had been a "sack murder" in Room 1438.

Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, 40 years old, wife of the fugitive William F. Peterson, whose mythical stock transactions brought about her indictment and that of two men as his accomplices in grand larceny charges, took the witness stand in her defense yesterday in General Sessions.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 17. -- A deep depression is settling over the educational and intellectual circles of North China with the realization that there will be no liberty of action or expression under the new Japanese-influenced regime and that patriotic movements must be suppressed lest the Japanese use some trifling incident as an excuse for new demands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The fate of the Agricultural Adjustment Act rested with the Supreme Court tonight after lawyers for eight Louisiana rice millers and for the government argued before the court the legality of processing taxes imposed since Congress amended the law in August.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 17. -- While police hammered at the stories of alibi witnesses, preparations were completed late today for two eyewitnesses to the machine gun murder of Walter Liggett to testify on Friday before the grand jury which will be asked to indict Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld on a charge of first degree murder.

Fifteen properties were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Most of the parcels were five-story tenements. Several small loft structures and dwellings also were included.

Allegheny County, Pa., sold over the counter yesterday a new issue of $3,900,000 of park, airport and bridge bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., at 100.125 for 2 3/4s. No bids were submitted for the issue at the hour set for the formal award.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- When the Fascist Grand Council meets tomorrow night to consider the Italian reply to the Franco-British peace proposals, Premier Benito Mussolini, who will be presiding, will have to make one of the most difficult and possibly one of the most fateful decisions of his career, which has been full of occasions for swift, clear thinking.

Bruno Richard Hauptmann expects to have a "surprise witness" who will appear for him before the Court of Pardons. He is a lawyer whom the carpenter is said to have consulted, long before his arrest for the Lindbergh kidnapping, as to how he should dispose of the belongings of Isidor Fisch.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 17. -One hunter was killed, five or more injured and a number arrested for attempting to hunt illegally as the five-day deer-hunting season opened in New Jersey today. The number of injuries was large considering that almost all the hunters took the precaution of wearing red coats, hats or shorts.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt renounced personal requests for money from the estate of her 12year-old daughter, Gloria, asked only $191.10 for the entertainment of the child each week-end she is allowed to have her, and reserved the right to apply for expenses of running a Summer home in July.

College basketball will make its opening flourish of the season at Madison Square Garden tonight when the first of ten court doubleheaders is staged before a crowd that is expected to number 16,000. The University of California, best of the Pacific Coast teams, will meet New York University, victor in ten straight games over a twoyear span, in the feature, after St. John's and Westminster have opened the festivities at 8:15.

With selling orders for silver continuing to accumulate in London and the United States Treasury showing no disposition to take more than the daily 5 per cent of all offerings, which has been its practice for the last few days, the price of silver dropped still further yesterday.
