Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that he had received another $5,000,000 from the Federal Government for the financing of WPA work in this city. This brings the total to date to $123,000,000. Recently Mr. Ridder requested an additional allotment of $30,000,000, saying he would need the money for the period between Jan. 1 and Jan. 15.

A fire extinguished last Monday by a squad of firemen, who merely had to walk across the street to reach the blaze, resulted yesterday in the seizure of one of the largest illicit distilleries discovered since repeal and the arrest of four men accused of being its operators.

Magistrate Earl A. Smith in Night Court last night held Patrolman John Ross, 31 years old, married and living at 3,066 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, in $1,000 bail on a charge of felonious assault. The complainant was Mrs. Elizabeth Connolly of 2,800 University Avenue, the Bronx, the wife of Sergeant Timothy Connolly of the Kingsbridge station, where Ross is also assigned.

With only eighty-two infant deaths last week and but two and one-half more weeks to go officials of the Department of Health were confident yesterday that the infant mortality rate for this year would set an all-time low, probably several points under the previous record of 50.91 deaths per 1,000 live births set in 1932.

The intercompany merger considered for years by the Union Pacific Railroad is to become effective on Jan. 1 through the leasing of the Oregon Short Line Railroad, the Oregon-Washington Railroad and Navigation Company, the Los Angeles Salt Lake Railroad and the St. Joseph Grand Island Railway, subsidiaries, Carl R. Gray, president, announced yesterday.

A propaganda barrage sent out by representatives of Premier Mussolini showered on New York City school teachers yesterday at the same moment that Publicity Associates in the Empire State Building announced that Josef Israels 2d had been appointed "publications counsel" in New York for Emperor Haile Selassie.
In the twenty-sixth game of the recently concluded chess championship match in Holland between Dr. Max Euwe and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine, the latter resorted to the Dutch defense.

The minimum price for wheat and other important agricultural products recently established by the Argentine Government was not designed "to create artificial price levels or a false prosperity, but simply to keep the farmer in business and secure for him a decent subsistence," according to Ing. Luis Duhau, the Argentine Minister of Agriculture in a statement yesterday in Buenos Aires and released here through the Argentine Information Bureau.

By the light of 300 candles three choirs sang Christmas songs late yesterday afternoon in the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary. The occasion was the seminary's annual candlelight carol service.

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- Approval of France's stand at the London naval conference against an upper quantitative construction limit was obtained today by Minister of Marine Francois Pietri from the marine commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

The Yuletide spirit was rampant at the Christmas concert of the Down Town Glee Club given last night at Carnegie Hall with the assistance of the choir boys of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Traditional melodies of the holiday season played a large part in the program.

With three times last year's total already in hand and less than $300,000 more required to reach its goal of $2,000,000, the United Hospital Campaign will continue until Jan. 10, it was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the drive.

With the erection yesterday of a forty-foot Christmas tree in Broad Street almost directly in front of the entrance to the New York Stock Exchange, the financial community began preparations for its annual holiday festivities.

Remington Rand, Inc., reports for the eight months ended on Nov. 30 the largest net income for the period in the company's history except in 1929. It earned $1,453,454 after all charges and taxes, double that earned in eight months in 1934. This equaled, after eight months' dividend requirements on the preferred stocks, 44 cents a share on 1,378,684 common shares.

The reply of Mrs. Florence Brewer Boeckel to a recent letter of mine does not seem to me to make less grave the dangers involved in applying mandatory embargoes on war materials against the members of the League of Nations, should they be driven to use armed force to restrain an aggressor.

GENEVA, Dec. 18. -- The League of Nations Council, after having heard Anthony Eden of Great Britain, Premier Pierre Laval of France and Wolde Mariam of Ethiopia on the Hoare-Laval peace plan, adjourned this evening, ostensibly to await definite replies from the parties before discussing it.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America and leader of the advocates of industrial unionism, assailed last night the failure of the American Federation of Labor to establish the right to organize in the basic industries, and declared that he wanted "a labor movement equal in strength to those interests that have ruled and exploited this nation so long."
Buying of housing properties for renovating continued in scattered sections of the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Faced with sharp protests from within and without his official family over his order for a reduction in the personnel of the Civilian Conservation Corps and curtailment of the number of camps to establish a modified permanent organization, President Roosevelt today sought to harmonize the views of his advisers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP). -- Operation of "the Title Sweepstakes," a contest managed by the American Contest Corporation of 8 East Forty-first Street, New York City, for the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus, was halted here today by order of the chief of police, Henry T. Copenhagen.

An active player for more than three decades, Bennie Allen, Kansas City cue expert, came through with the greatest exhibition of his career last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania when he ran 125 points and out in his match with Joe Procita of Gloversville, N.Y., to win by 125 to 0, in the world's title pocket billiard tournament.

A recent letter to the editor of THE TIMES, written apparently with no thought of controversy, discussed the vagaries of pronunciation by New Yorkers of perfectly familiar words. The citation of numerous solecisms, some of them pretty glaring, has had the effect of rousing indignation among other writers to the editor.
The Franco-American contract bridge match passed its halfway mark at Essex House yesterday with the American Four Aces team leading the European champions by 6,390 points at the end of the 172d hand.

For the third time in eight days the United States Treasury yesterday forced a suspension of dealings in silver in the London market by refusing to make purchases there. In consequence, the price of silver here fell 3 cents to 55 3/4 cents an ounce, the lowest quotation since Feb. 26; silver futures in Montreal dropped 1 to 2 cents and dealing in the metal was suspended in Bombay until Sunday.

PRAGUE, Dec. 18. -- Dr. Eduard Benes, who throughout his politics life has been the closest collaborator of Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, today was elected to succeed the retiring President by 340 out of a total of 400 votes cast by the National Assembly.

Grace, comedy and the tango on skates composed the program of the sixth annual ice skating carnival staged last night at the Ice Club for the benefit of The New York American Christmas and relief fund before a crowd of almost 2,000.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP). -- Lawyers for fourteen of seventeen persons arrested in New York State's prosecution of fake racetrack tipster services challenged the validity today of the indictments against them.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18. -- Favorites continued to travel a rough road with the running of the third program of the Tropical Park meeting today. The fourth race, a six-furlong test for $2,500 platers, served as the best offering and also resulted in the biggest disappointment when A.C. Rose's four-time Maryland winner, Camino Real, failed to finish in the money.

The result of Tuesday's Congressional election in Michigan is hailed with enthusiasm by Dr. TOWNSEND and his fellow-advocates of the "Old Age Revolving Pension" plan. A Republican candidate in the Third District, pledged to the support of this panacea for depression, was elected to the House of Representatives by a two-to-one majority over a Democrat who challenged Dr. TOWNSEND'S economics.

The clergymen whose statement on birth control appears in THE NEW YORK TIMES fail to take into account the fact that contraceptive birth control alone cannot be relied upon to effect the adjustment of humanity to the industrial machine which they seem to regard as a paramount and compelling demand upon society.

TRENTON, Dec. 18. -- The State Relief Council, it was reported today, will suggest in its forthcoming report that a 20 per cent saving can be effected next year by a return to food orders and the abandonment of cash disbursements to relief clients.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- With the naval conference taking a twenty-four hour recess as far as joint discussions are concerned, the five delegations taking part in the parley concentrated today upon an individual study of the latest proposal laid before it -- the British suggestion of limitation through unilateral declarations of building programs covering a period of years.
The Food Machinery Corporation declared yesterday an initial quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the new common stock. The old stock, recently split two for one, was receiving 25 cents quarterly.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 18. -- Details of the greatest battle of the East African war, fought between Mai Timchet and Dembeguina Sunday, Monday and yesterday, were divulged by the high command of the Italian expeditionary force today.

Effective Feb. 1, Samuel W. Reyburn, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, will resign the presidency and become chairman of the board, a new post created yesterday at a meeting here of the board of directors.

One of the first things Hiram C. Todd will undertake as special prosecutor in the Druckman murder case in Brooklyn will be an effort to determine if evidence against Meyer Luckman and others allegedly involved in the crime was suppressed.

In an interview at Trenton yesterday, the second within twelve hours, Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey denied emphatically that he had expressed, either the night before or at any time, doubt as to the guilt of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.
Albany, Dec. 18. -- The statement of "Republican principles" adopted by the conference here today read as follows:

The American Chemical Society announced yesterday the election of Dr. Edward R. Weidlein, director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, Pittsburgh, to the presidency of the society for 1937. On Jan. 1 Professor Edward Bartow, head of the department of chemistry and chemical engineering in the State University of Iowa, who is now president-elect, will take office as president for 1936, succeeding Professor Roger Adams of the University of Illinois.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP). -- New York State's famous bobsled run on Mount Van Hoevenberg, on which numerous racing accidents have occurred, is being made safer in preparation for the opening of the bobsled season on Christmas Day.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 18. -- Harvard's quintet threw a scare into the ranks of Dartmouth rooters tonight, but the Big Green managed to subdue the Crimson, 37 -- 28, in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest of the season before 2,000 spectators.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- A special committee of the capital's Board of Education has found no evidence that communism is being taught in the schools here.

ROME, Dec. 18. -- Italy's so-called Day of Faith was a success exceeding all expectations of Fascist leaders, Italians of all classes turning out with remarkable unanimity to give their gold wedding rings to the State.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 18. -- Appraisals of the political significance of Verner W. Main's election Tuesday as Representative from the Third Michigan District varied widely today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- A combined cash farm income of $8,110,000,000 for 1935, or 12 per cent more than for last year, together with an increase of 41,000,000 acres in the total area harvested was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.

Prices of commodity futures held within a narrow trading range in the markets here yesterday. Wheat, corn, oats and rubber were higher in the cash markets with tin and cotton lower. Lard dropped to another new low price for the year.

With demand for better price sterling silver hollow and flat ware running far ahead of previous years, the industry this month is enjoying the best holiday season in five to six years, manufacturers said yesterday. Despite the lateness of the season, reorders for holiday goods are still being received in quantity for rush shipments. The purchasing is heaviest in flatware lines, producers said, but has shown a general increase in other divisions as well.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18, -- In honor of their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Ottley of New York, who are visiting for a few days at Brazilian Court on the way to Jamaica, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Howland Graham gave a tea for fifty persons today at their residence.

Henry Rogers Winthrop, senior partner in Winthrop, Mitchell Co. and a governing member of the New York Stock Exchange, was elected chairman of the Exchange's new standing committee on customers' men at the organization meeting of that body yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 18. -- Unable to check an outburst of violent attacks upon Premier Laval, which developed at a meeting of the Radical Socialist party's executive committee here, Edouard Herriot, Minister of State, resigned the presidency of the party tonight amid an indescribable uproar.

John C. (Blondy) Ryan has been sold by the Yankees to the Minneapolis Club of the American Association, it was announced yesterday by Ed Barrow, Yankee secretary. The price paid for Ryan, the infielder obtained by the New Yorkers from the Phillies late last season to replace the injured Frank Crosetti, was not disclosed.

The city of Providence, R.I., awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,500,000 of highway and bridge bonds to the Bank of the Manhattan Company at 100.193 for 2s. Thirteen bids were submitted. The bonds are dated Jan. 1, 1936, and will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1937 to 1951.

Miss Virginia Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Hyde of 935 Park Avenue, was selected as the typical American debutante of the season at a fashion show called the "Squirrel Silver Spectrum," held in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, yesterday afternoon.
Cardinal Hayes made public yesterday a statement replying to the thirteen non-Catholic clergymen who recently criticized his sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral on the subject of birth control.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18. -- For the first time since the introduction of five-year plans the Soviet Union's daily coal production has surpassed the schedule. The figures for this year up to Dec. 15, published today, show a total daily production of 370,900 tons, as against the schedule of 370,700.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Olga Steck, former Broadway musical comedy star, plunged twelve stories to her death today after a gay party, and her former husband later told police that he was convinced she jumped from his hotel window.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Frank C. Walker temporarily left his position with the New Deal again today when he resigned for the second time as executive director of the National Emergency Council.

MADISON, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Miss Emily Benedict McAlpin, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of Madison Avenue, and Miss Nancy Nickerson Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Cook of Ridgedale Avenue, were presented to society at a supper dance their parents gave this evening at the Morris County Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Delay in getting the work relief program started was an explanation advanced today for a drop of only 9.4 per cent in urban relief rolls between October and November. Expenditures for relief in the same period were reduced 20.4 per cent.

The Dessoff Choirs, directed by Margarete Dessoff, gave the first of two concerts at the Town Hall last night, presenting a program that was rewarding as well as un-hackneyed. Miss Dessoff's two organizations -- the Adesdi Chorus of women's voices and the A Cappella Singers of New York, mixed voices -- have always made their appearances the occasion of performance of rarely heard old and modern works.

SOFIA, Dec. 18. -- A military court sitting in a Sofia suburb began the trial today of former Premier Veltcheff, head of the Officers League, and twenty-eight other high officers, together with former Finance Minister Todoroff, on charges of plotting to overthrow the present Bulgarian regime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Holding that government construction of super liners of the Bremen-Normandie type is a question for Congress, Secretary Roper disclosed today that the Commerce Department is working on a new ship subsidy bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The producer of a play with an all-star cast has his troubles with temperament, but he can enforce a degree of teamwork through his control of the payroll. His director, lacking that control, is a man of many sorrows and defeats. Frank C. Walker, who today once again retired as the President's "coordinator," is the prototype of such a director.

After declaring that the war peril in Europe was based upon worry over the Suez Canal, Brig. Gen. Charles H. Sherrill, former Ambassador to Turkey, urged yesterday that the United States negotiate for European colonies in the Western Hemisphere, potential threats to the Panama Canal, in settlement of war debts.

BATON ROUGE, Dec. 18. -- After one of the strangest interludes in her rich and colorful history, one in which she threatened seriously to follow the loud pipings of one of her own citizens into a crusade against a century of political tradition, Louisiana appears destined to return to her former self.

New York's Jackson Day dinner, one of the nation-wide series of Democratic affairs on Jan. 8, will be held at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday. President Roosevelt, speaking from Washington, will greet the various gatherings in a radio address.

The Harvard, Princeton and Yale Club teams remained deadlocked for the lead among the Group One Class C combinations in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League as a result of 4-to-1 victories over rival squads.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, Dec. 18. -- Announcement of the appointment of Edward Markowski as head coach and the election of Cadet Douglas Marr of Kinderhook, N.Y., as captain of the 1936 team was made tonight at the annual football dinner at the New York Military Academy.

George W. Olvany Jr., 23-year-old son of the former judge and Tammany leader, died at 8 A.M. yesterday, eight days after he had shot himself twice in the head at Saranac Lake, where he had been staying for several months, recuperating from a nervous breakdown.

The Austin-Payne Corporation, W.F. Melhuish, president, has bought for investment a total of 200 lots in various parts of the 100-acre development of Bayside-Flushing Gardens, Inc., at Horace Harding and Bell Boulevards, Bayside. Alfred Lowett is head of the development firm, which acquired the property prior to the depression.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 18. -- The situation of Finnish Nazis because of alleged complicity in the attempted Nazi coup in Estonia became more serious today because of the arrest of an army major by the Finnish military authorities. The major's name was not divulged.

Judge Pecora's suggestion that a law which violates the Constitution should be valid if passed by the Congress over the decision of the Supreme Court, is one of the recurring crop of nostrums proposed by those lacking in enthusiasm for and understanding of our wise American plan of government.

Twelve outstanding foreign track and field stars have been invited by the Amateur Athletic Union for competition here during the coming indoor season, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer. Only one has definitely turned down the invitation.

ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- The Republican party of New York State, represented at a conference here today by about 125 legislators and county chairmen, put its hopes of carrying the State in the next election almost completely on national issues, which it intends to emphasize between the present time and next November.

No general project of the city in his experience ever has received such uniform support as the planned World's Fair of 1939, George McAneny, chairman of the fair committee, told members of the Bronx Board of Trade at its forty-first annual meeting and election at 349 East 149th Street, the Bronx, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Of securities with a face value of $289,771,988 which were released for sale in November under the Securities Act of 1935, utility companies registered $193,421,749, or 66.7 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Eben S. Abbott, chief engineer of the Ward liner Morro Castle, which burned off Asbury Park last Sept. 8 with a loss of 134 lives, found a place for himself in a lifeboat and then tore the bars and gold braid from his uniform, it was testified yesterday in Federal court.

The world has lost the grandpapa of all its dictators in the person of President GOMEZ of Venezuela. He ruled for nearly thirty years officially or through interim and thinly varnished puppets. Among the living heads of State only the democratic Kings of Sweden and Norway antedate him in accession to power.

The public received its first concrete idea of how the new $12,783,000 housing development in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will look when a model of the project, the first released from Washington, was placed on display yesterday at the Brooklyn Committee for Better Housing exhibition at the Brooklyn Savings Bank, Pierrepont and Clinton Streets.
Among the passengers due today from Southampton via Havre on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic are:

At 4 o'clock today the duck-hunting season comes to a close in the nineteen States which comprise the southern zone. These States are New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The greatest use of government credit to further President Roosevelt's dual purpose of reducing the cost of railroad financing and extending the use of sinking funds for debt retirement was undertaken today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in an offer to the Great Northern Railroad to underwrite $100,000,000 of new bonds on terms more favorable than could be obtained from the railroad company's own bankers.

TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 18. -- The inauguration in Peiping of General Sung Cheh-yuan's Autonomous Council for Hopei and Chahar Provinces today was overshadowed by evidence that Major Gen. Hayao Tada, commander of Japanese forces in North China, would adopt a dictatorial attitude toward the council.

The time is near for "a really great and sustained revival" in small home construction, and private industry must lead the way in bringing about "major reforms" in this field to meet the nation's needs, Eugene Meyer, publisher of The Washington Post and former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told 600 builders and realty experts at a luncheon-meeting of the New York Building Congress yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

Mayor La Guardia and Grover A. Whalen clashed again yesterday on the question whether the city's 2 per cent sales tax had affected retail trade here adversely, after the Mayor had sent a telegram to Mr. Whalen expressing his pleasure over a 10 per cent increase in Christmas sales.

Public Service Commissioner Maurice C. Burritt completed yesterday the taking of testimony in public hearings on rates charged by the Jamaica Water Supply Company. The hearing was left open, however, to permit cross-examination of company witnesses later by Charles Shankroff, self-described civic worker, who recently sued Mayor La Guardia for calling him a "bum" at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.
Seventy-six awards for participation in varsity and freshman athletics at Columbia were announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Thirty-nine persons were authenticated here today as the heirs to the estate of Mrs. Ellen Jane Ackerman, aged recluse who died Nov. 20 in her Westwood home. Assets of the estate total about $200,000, including cash and securities found tucked away in all corners of the house in which Mrs. Ackerman died, leaving no will.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- An unrestricted trust fund providing $900,000 was set up for Johns Hopkins Hospital by the will of Albert Marburg, retired tobacco manufacturer, filed for probate today. It will be known as "The Annie G. Marburg Memorial Fund," in memory of Mr. Marburg's wife, who died some years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Woodrow Wilson and Mrs. William Howard Taft, diplomats and high officials of the government and music lovers in all ranks of Washington society turned out this morning for the first of this season's musical mornings given by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- Maryland's State Board of Public Works has decided to sell on Jan. 22 the Northern Central Railway annuity, which produces $90,000 a year, it was announced today by Governor Nice after a session of the board. Sealed bids will be called for. The terms Will be cash.
The Fordham basketball team continued unbeaten last night, as St. Peter's College of Jersey City became the fifth consecutive victim of the Rams, 37 to 16.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- December wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade showed congestion in today's early trading and went to 3 3/4 cents premium over May, the widest difference of the season. The upturn brought in considerable profit-taking and the rise was lost, final trades being unchanged from yesterday, while the May and July were up 1/2 cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Duty reduction on seventeen commodities exported by the United States to Honduras and assurances against increases on twenty others are contained in a reciprocal trade agreement between the two countries signed at Tegucigalpa today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 18. -- With the second line of Pete Cook, Wilkes Covey and Jack Bissell leading the van, Princeton's hockey team rang up its fourth straight victory of the season tonight, downing the Colgate sextet, 10 -- 2, in the Hobey Baker Rink.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Dec. 18, 1935, will rank in British post-war politics as a day poignant with dramatic tension, for it witnessed the sudden downfall of a powerful minister already preparing for a triumph on the morrow.

Girls proved superior to boys as essayists yesterday when prizes were awarded by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York to more than 200 boys and girls of the public and parochial schools among 375,000 pupils who participated in the chamber's annual essay contest.

Caleb Milne 4th, 24-year-old actor and descendant of an old Philadelphia family, who disappeared last Saturday from his apartment at 157 East Thirty-seventh Street, this city, was found late last night, bound and gagged, semi-conscious and showing evidences of having been drugged, in a ditch near Doylestown, Pa.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- Recommendations that the trout season open the third Saturday in April and the deer season on Nov. 15 have been made by the State Advisory Council to Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne.

Five women and three men arrested Wednesday for picketing the Norwegian-American freighter Spero, which was being loaded at Pier 7 in the Central Railroad of New Jersey yards in Jersey City with scrap iron for Italy, were found guilty of disorderly conduct yesterday by Judge Botti in First Criminal Court, Jersey City. Sentence was suspended in each case.

The Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, and the Chesapeak Ohio, the second and third railways to report for November, showed gains in the month. The Alton's traffic continued to improve this month, with its ten daily trains between Chicago and St. Louis returning profits.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 18. -- The Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration's decision to start slum clearance in San Juan by constructing an apartment house housing 216 families has angered the Labor Federation, whose secretary, Rafael Alonzo, denounced the project as hygienically and socially unsound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- A new relief problem -- help for the jobless who are seeking relief this Winter for the first time -- brought forecasts today of a new demand for a return of the Federal dole.

The claque was a remunerative business before it was banished summarily from the Metropolitan Opera House with the opening of the new season this week, it was disclosed yesterday. Estimates of the weekly earnings of the masters of the claque were set conservatively at about $100, with a larger take possible if the singers were "cooperative."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Treasury was temporarily "in the black" for the first sixteen days of December for the first time in many months, but for the fiscal year so far the deficit was $26,672,118 greater than a year ago, and the public debt passed the $30,000,000,000 mark.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The German press featured today the inspection by Chancellor Adolf Hitler of his bodyguard, garrisoned in the former cadet school at Lichterfelde, a suburb of Berlin where occurred most of the executions during the party purge last year.

Declaring that performance bonds on city contracts had been a source of substantial revenue "to a small group of political brokers," Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, recommended to Mayor La Guardia yesterday that these bonds be abolished.

In 1908 Professor MASARYK, who had followed the journalistic work of EDUARD BENES in various parts of Europe, sent for him and suggested that he qualify for a university post in philosophy and sociology. This advice BENES followed, "hacking" his way, as he himself said, to "settled views" and being helped more by MASARYK and his books than by others.

The Associated Press filed yesterday its answer to the complaint of the National Labor Relations Board in the discharge of Morris Watson, a reporter and vice president of the American Newspaper Guild. The Associated Press denied the charges in the complaint and challenged the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act.

Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, finishing her testimony yesterday in the General Sessions trial of herself and two men on a grand larceny charge arising from the fake stock schemes of her fugitive husband, William F. Peterson, told of Peterson's disappearance last Nov. 12, two days before he was to go to trial with the trio.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 18. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles, his son-in-law, Fernando Torreblanca, and many other allies of the former President were expelled from the National Revolutionary party today. Among those expelled were the ousted Governors, Senators and Deputies, also the local Deputies of the States of Sonora, Sinaloa, Durango and Guanajuato, all of whom have formed a new party.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The year's last Cabinet session has come and gone without producing the long-heralded general law for new economic restrictions on Jews, designed to complete their segregation from the German people.

General Juan Vicente Gomez, called "El Benemerito" by act of Congress, will in the role of rehabilitator occupy a place second only to that of Simon Bolivar in the history of Venezuela. During the more than a quarter of a century that he held supreme power he regained for the country the full century of progress that had been lost through a perpetual reign of revolutionary terror.

A new form of cooperation between a book publisher and a motion picture company comes to light with the announcement by Random House and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer of a special editon of "Romeo and Juliet," which will include the complete text of the actual "shooting script" used in making the play into a talking picture.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

That expressions parallel to "C'mon seven" and "Get hot, baby" were used by Greeks and Persians in the pre-Christian era was shown yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University. An exhibit of statistical material that includes pictures of gambling devices of the past was opened this week by Dr. Helen M. Walker, Assistant Professor of Education.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The St. Paul's School hockey team of Concord, N.H., one of the tallest and heaviest hockey sextets in the school's history, will seek to avenge last year's 3 to 2 setback upon meeting the Princeton freshman combination in Madison Square Garden this afternoon. The game is to start at 3 o'clock.

William Gillette, who is remembered by generations of theatre-goers as the only possible Sherlock Holmes, is abandoning his placid retreat in order to return to the stage. At the age of 80 he is giving up his privately operated model railroad in Connecticut -- and that is about as famous as his characterization of the good gentleman of Baker Street -- in order to embark on just one more tour.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 18. -East Woods, a purchase acquired some years ago by the University of Vermont to preserve one of Burlington's most attractive stands of timber, is to become part of a new 750-acre game preserve which has been created on the outskirts of the city. The refuge is sponsored by Elliot Holt of New York and Burlington and includes "Fairholt," the f-Iolt country estate.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Prime Minister Baldwin underwent a hail of opposition questions in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal open market committee, composed of the governors of the Federal Reserve Banks, in a Joint statement tonight opposed immediate action to reduce excess reserve of member banks, adding, however, that the situation would be watched carefully and appropriate action taken if credit expansion developed which threatened public interest.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP). -- Six Tampa policemen were arrested tonight on affidavits signed by J.R. McLeod, Sheriff, and W.D. Bush, Detective Chief, in connection with the flogging to death of Joseph Shoemaker, a labor organizer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Twenty-five offering sheets of various oil interests were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the week ended on Dec. 14. The commission called attention to the fact that the act of filing did not indicate that it had passed upon the merits of the issue.

William Buechner won two events and Captain Matt Kelly triumphed in the 100-yard free style in the good time of 0:55.8 to feature the 47-to-24 victory registered by the Amherst College swimmers over the West Side Y. M. C. A. team in the latter's pool last night.

The offer by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to finance a forthcoming $100,000,000 maturity of the Great Northern Railway at a saving of millions of dollars compared with the terms offered by private bankers is expected in Wall Street to bring into the open the question whether the railways, which are holding expenditures to a minimum, should apply the same policy to their financial operations.

ROME, Dec. 18. -- A hostile attitude toward the France-British peace proposals was foreshadowed today in a speech delivered by Premier Benito Mussolini at the inauguration of Pontinia, the third town built on what was formerly a desolate waste of the Pontine marshes.

The performance of Wagner's "Walkuere" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House introduced to its audience a new, young and extremely gifted dramatic soprano, Marjorie Lawrence, who appeared as Bruennhilde. Miss Lawrence is fortunate in her appearance, her dramatic capacity, her voice.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 18. -- General Plutarco Elias Calles answered attempts by the followers of President Lazaro Cardenas to break the last vestige of his power by chal lenging the government tonight to expel him from the country by force.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18. -- Top weight of 130 pounds was asked of Discovery today for the Santa Anita $100,000 handicap, to be run here Feb. 22.

Charges of "persecution" by city officials in driving produce merchants out of the Harlem Market to the city-owned Bronx Terminal Market were met yesterday with counter-allegations by the city that the Harlem Market Company, Ltd., owner of the property, is trying to force the purchase of the market by the city.
The article in THE TIMES on "Federalism or States' Rights," by James Truslow Adams, is timely and interesting and should be widely read.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 18. -- It is highly probable that the directors of the Great Northern Railroad will accept the offer of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for its forthcoming $100,000,000 bond issue unless private underwriters can better the offer to finance the issue at 4 per cent with no underwriting charge, W.P. Kenney, president of the road, intimated today.

The Public Service Commission ordered the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday to make reductions in its electric rates which will save consumers about $1,225,000 a year as compared with the rates in effect in 1934. This saving would exceed by $675,000 those estimated in voluntary reductions made by the company, effective on Nov. 4.

With only six days remaining before Christmas -- the one day of the year when men most wish for peace on earth and good-will toward their fellow men -- the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases is still lagging behind the total on this date a year ago.

NORTH CREEK, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP). -- Between 10,000 and 15,000 toys will be distributed to needy children this Christmas by Samuel Coplon, the "Adirondack Santa Claus," despite poor health which curtails his activity of former years.
Eleven properties improved with fifteen buildings were offered for bidding at foreclosure auction sales in Manhattan yesterday. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Application of the Marine Parkway Authority of New York to construct a bridge across Rockaway Inlet between Brooklyn and Rockaway was approved today by the War Department.
PANAMA, R.P., Dec. 11 (By Mail). -- At least a dozen friends and enemies of General Juan Vicente Gomez have their eyes on the Presidency as eventual successors to the dictator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. (AP). -- A decision to drive for funds to give the nation an air force "second to none" emerged today from a conference between General Malin Craig, Army Chief of Staff, and Chairman McSwain of the House Military Committee.

A gathering of 18,000 jammed Madison Square Garden last night to watch New York University and the University of California battle for basketball supremacy. They remained instead to marvel at Violet artistry as N.Y.U., scoring at will against the vaunted Golden Bears, routed them, 41 to 26.

Nelson B. Clark, 63 years old, unsuccessful Bull Moose candidate for Governor of Massachusetts in 1915, was sentenced yesterday to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions. Clark was convicted recently as an accomplice of a gang of young gunmen in one of their hold-ups.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- For the second time within eight days a lawyer collapsed today while arguing before the Supreme Court.

GENEVA, Dec. 18. -- The Secretary-General of the League of Nations transmitted tonight to the members of the League on behalf of the committee for the coordination of measures under Article XVI of the covenant the following texts of speeches by Anthony Eden, British Minister for League Affairs, and Premier Pierre Laval of France:

Architects filed plans yesterday for a wide variety of new construction in the city. In Manhattan, plans were submitted for a four-story building in Cliff Street and two small garages in West Twenty-ninth Street, as well as various alterations to existing buildings.

" What a Relief," the forty-seventh annual production of the Princeton Triangle Club, made the first of its two New York appearances at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre last night before a top-hatted, ermine-caped audience which guffawed gleefully at its jests and departed humming its tunes.

After an early improvement which held for several hours yesterday, trading on the Cotton Exchange here became unsettled by developments in the silver market and reports that trading in the metal in Bombay had been suspended. Although comparatively few contracts appeared until the last hour, the approaching holidays and pending Supreme Court dicisions restricted new business to an extent that caused irregular fluctuations.
ROME, Dec. 18. -- Long after dark thousands of women stood in line here and in other large cities waiting to offer their wedding bands to the government.

The stoning of a retail liquor store in Greenwich, Conn., close to the New York State boundary, featured the controversy yesterday between Connecticut and New York liquor dealers. Joseph Piccone reported to the Greenwich police a large stone had been used to smash his show window during the night and one bottle of liquor also was missing from the display.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The Boerse was firmer today at the opening, but weakened slightly toward the close of the session, although activity was very limited, as usual. Heavy industrial shares started strong, but sagged later. Vereinigtestal losing 3/8 point.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 18. (AP). -- General Juan Vicente Gomez, who established a dictatorship in Venezuela long before the word became widely known in Europe, died last night -- still the ruler of his country despite his 78 years.
The RFC Mortgage Company, a branch of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has begun the purchase of mortgages covered by new dwellings in the New York area, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Sir Samuel Hoare resigned as British Foreign Secretary tonight under pressure of public indignation because of his agreement with Premier Pierre Laval of France on the proposal to dismember Ethiopia and also because he could not agree with his Cabinet colleagues that he should placate public opinion by expressing some regret in the speech that he was scheduled to make in Parliament tomorrow.

THIS department is in receipt of an inquiry from a returned traveler. J.B.K. Jr. writes to ask about a current phenomenon in the world of sports, a young man who has been talked of to a certain extent during recent weeks, Joe Louis.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 18 (Canadian Press). -- Australia gave South Africa a jolt today in the first of a series of five cricket tests between the two countries, winning by nine wickets. Only at one period of the encounter did the Springboks master the tricky spin bowling of the tourists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Word of the resignation of Sir Samuel Hoare as Foreign Secretary of Great Britain caused a sensation at the State Department, although officials declined to comment on what was in form and procedure a domestic question of another country.

HAVANA, Dec. 18. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez today was proclaimed the official candidate of the Liberal party nominated by the Presidential electors of that party at a meeting held under the recent Presidential decree that promulgated the formula presented by Professor Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, for the solution of the political impasse on the invitation of the Cuban Government.

Charges of lack of cooperation by the Police Department were made yesterday by Magistrate William O'Dwyer in his campaign on defaulting traffic violators. He asserted that of the 8,000 warrants outstanding, about 1,000 had fictitious addresses, and added that he would ask Commissioner Harnett to help to end this condition.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 18. -- Opponents of George S. Kemp and other directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation representing holders of the company's prior preference stock, tonight outvoted the Kemp faction and then proceeded, in a separate meeting, which was described as illegal by the management of the company, to oust eight of the preference directors and elect their successors.

MIAMI, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Conflicting statements from various sources today produced an air of considerable uncertainty as to whether Joe Louis will fight Isidoro Gastanaga in Havana Dec. 29. The promoter, Mike Jacobs, made it clear, however, that the fight has not yet been canceled.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- The market for hogs scored a sharp recovery here today, with weights under 200 pounds leading, while kinds over 275 pounds were inclined to drag. Prices were 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday's, with the top 10 cents higher at $9.60 and the day's average of $9.45 15 cents above Tuesday.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP). -- The 13 1/2 per cent tax imposed on non-complying coal companies by the Guffey Act is "frankly coercive," Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick held today, and he ordered the government not to collect the levy from two Philadelphia companies until the constitutionality of the law is determined.

Lured to a false sense of security by a police stratagem, Edward Metelski, safecracker and gunman, who escaped from jail at New Brunswick, N. J., last Saturday while awaiting trial for the murder of a State trooper, was surrounded and recaptured in Newark last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Twenty-two of the finest football players, picked from fourteen universities east of the Mississippi, headed for the Pacific Coast tonight to battle a picked team of Western stars at San Francisco on New Year's Day in the eleventh annual Shrine benefit game for crippled children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Despite the victory of Verner W. Main, Republican who supported the Townsend old-age pension plan, in the Third Congressional District in Michigan, leaders of the old line parties here refused today to regard it as a portent of victory for the third party movement which the Townsendites have said they will sponsor in the Presidential election next year.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 18 (AP). -- Pope Pius will confer red hats upon sixteen new Cardinals in a public consistory at St. Peter's tomorrow, bringing the Sacred College to its numerical full strength.

George Le Boutillier, who gives 30 per cent of his time to his duties as vice president of the Long Island Railroad and the other 70 per cent to his job as vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, revealed yesterday he alone made the decision on the proposed increase in commutation rates.

Twenty-three pairs are listed in the draw for the invitation pro-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament to be held at the Heights Casino starting tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock. The field includes a number of the leading players in this district.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 18. -- For the third straight year, Miss Anne Page, Philadelphia internationalist, is the winner of the Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship. She demonstrated her supremacy in the final round of the sixth annual tournament on the courts of Haddon Hall today and thereby gained permanent possession of the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Myer Bloom, Temple center, upset Georgetown in a thrill-packed overtime basketball game at the Tech Gym tonight. The score was 44 to 43.

Lieut. Col. Cyril Rocke, former British Army officer, denounced Ethiopia as the most uncivilized country in the world and attacked the League of Nations and its stand with regard to economic sanctions, in a speech yesterday at a luncheon of the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18. -- A new, strategically situated railroad through 1,365 miles of the Soviet Far East has been completed after two years of night and day work by convict labor, it was announced today.

A move that is looked upon by airline officials as the most concrete evidence yet presented of the safety of modern air transport was made yesterday when six of the largest casualty companies in the United States announced jointly that they would underwrite, beginning Jan. 1, a new form of insurance for commercial air travelers.

The possibility of reviving the drive for a reapportionment of Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts in the new Legislature was said yesterday to be under consideration by leaders of the Democratic party in Brooklyn and Queens.

The steamship operating company of Isbrandtsen-Moller, 24 Broadway, operating foreign flag tonnage to the Far East and other trades, became subject yesterday to a Federal fine of $100 a day for failure to file tariffs and rate information with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

Premier LAVAL warned the Chamber on Monday that he would not go to Geneva if the Deputies insisted upon "humiliating conditions." But he appeared there yesterday, along with Captain EDEN of the British Government, under conditions most humiliating which they had prepared for themselves.

The steamship operating company of Isbrandtsen-Moller, 24 Broadway, operating foreign flag tonnage to the Far East and other trades, became subject yesterday to a Federal fine of $100 a day for failure to file tariffs and rate information with the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

Premier LAVAL warned the Chamber on Monday that he would not go to Geneva if the Deputies insisted upon "humiliating conditions." But he appeared there yesterday, along with Captain EDEN of the British Government, under conditions most humiliating which they had prepared for themselves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- An application by the Middle West Corporation of Chicago with the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval to form and own the Middle West Service Company which would carry out management contracts with subsidiaries of the applicant, has raised a question as to the attitude that the SEC will take in administering provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 covering such activities.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 18. -- As investigation of the latest clues in the murder of Walter Liggett was pursued today, pressure was brought on the Legislature for a crime inquiry in this city.

James A. McGivney, veteran fireman who went out on Monday to cash $1,969 in checks for seventeen firemen and then disappeared, was arrested early yesterday morning with a brand-new automobile he had bought and $950 in his pockets.

Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, chief law enforcement officer of the Roosevelt administration, launched a vigorous counter-offensive last night against the Republican attack on the constitutionality of the New Deal.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP). -- A grand jury investigation of the death of Thelma Todd, movie actress, was ordered tonight after a coroner's jury, though agreeing that death seemed accidental, urged continued inquiry.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $2,000,000 of, 5 per cent debentures of the Carriers and General Corporation at 99 1/2 and accrued interest. The bonds are to mature on Nov. 1, 1950. The offering will be made by Calvin Bullock, as representative of the underwriters, including Eastman, Dillon Co.; Hemphill, Noyes Co.; G.M.P. Murphy Co.; Jackson Curtis, and Battles Co. of Philadelphia.

Outwardly impassive and unmoved until she reached the climactic finish of her version of the events immediately preceding the fatal shooting of her husband's secretary early on the morning of Aug. 14, Mrs. Etta Reisman took the witness stand for two hours and a quarter yesterday to testify in her own behalf in Queens County Court.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- A livelier and more cheerful atmosphere prevailed today on the London Stock Exchange as a result largely of the better overnight news from Wall Street.

It is the Masque, on Jan. 16, which is announced to receive Lynn Riggs's new play, "Russet Mantle," his first to reach Broadway since "Green Grow the Lilacs" in 1931. The play enters rehearsal today with John Beal heading a cast of eleven under Robert Ross's direction.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Two necklaces, formerly owned by the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick and valued once at close to $2,000,000, have been sold by the trustees of her estate for $600,000, it was disclosed today.

Our valued contemporary The London Telegraph, seeking to satisfy the intellectual curiosity of its readers about American statesmen, at present not so well known abroad as they deserve to be at home, is unintentionally unjust to Colonel FRANKLIN KNOX. It attributes to him a "candidatorial face." "Candidatorial" is a rich and rare word.

For a time yesterday the share market gave promise of reviving speculative confidence, giving rise to hopes that the deadlock of the last few days might be broken by a sustained advance; but as the day wore on and important sponsorship failed to develop, share prices resumed their drifting tendencies, moving within narrow limits to close irregular.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- President Roosevelt and his advisers concentrated today upon the shaping of a 1937 budget intended to check the rise of a public debt already exceeding $30,000,000,000.
The Detroit Tigers, world champions of baseball, have been chosen by the country's sports experts as the outstanding team of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission's charges against Michael J. Meehan that he manipulated Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock on the New York Curb Exchange dragged on today as counsel for the commission sought to learn from William F. Ingold, president of Hammons Co., Inc., co-underwriter with Mr. Meehan of an ill-fated Bellanca stock issue, all the details of the attempted financing.

A Winter program of work for the 18,000 WPA employes assigned to the Queens Borough Administration was outlined yesterday by Borough President Harvey after an inspection of the highway and sewer work in the borough on which the men are now detailed.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- Negotiations have been begun for the sale of the 35.000-ton liner Homeric, until recently one of the crack Cunard-White Star steamships, to a German firm.

" AFRICA DANCES," by Geoffrey Gorer (Knopf, $3.50), is the work of one of those young Englishmen whose aplomb is as amazing as it is infuriating. Quite casually, in the identical spirit of a man who says to himself: "What a nice day; I think I shall go for a walk in the country," Mr. Gorer decided one morning that he would go down and have a look at the Niger and adjacent territory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The American Federation of Labor, impelled by several militant craft unions, may ask Congress at the coming session to amend the Wagner National Labor Relations Act so as to assure to those unions the legal right to maintain the jurisdictions granted to them by the federation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The American Federation of Labor, impelled by several militant craft unions, may ask Congress at the coming session to amend the Wagner National Labor Relations Act so as to assure to those unions the legal right to maintain the jurisdictions granted to them by the federation.

A Christmas party for forty inmates of the Danish Home for the Aged, at 1,055 Forty-first Street, Brooklyn, was given yesterday afternoon by Svend Jorgenson, Swedish philanthropist, at the Wivel Restaurant, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Invading the Yale Club courts last night for its seventh match in the Metropolitan League Class A squash tennis championship race, the New York Athletic Club team scored a 5-0 shutout for its seventh victory and retained sole possession of first place.

The annual Christmas dinner and party, given by the Actors Fund Matinee Club for elderly actors and actresses, was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Actors Fund of America, at 1,619 Broadway, with more than 400 guests attending. It was the fifth party of the sort which the club has given.

The aim of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law is to serve "as a cushion against future depressions," rather than as "a cure for chronic unemployment," Joseph P. Craugh, assistant secretary of the New York State Department of Labor, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Twenty-third Street Association at the Gramercy Park Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- A nation-wide drive to cut the tolls of death and injury from accidents on land, at sea and in the air was started here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The "Title Sweepstakes" announced by the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus last week from its headquarters at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, is not a lottery within the meaning of the statute, and so permission has been granted to use the mails.
The story-book rise of James J. Braddock from a relief-roll job to the world heavyweight boxing championship has been labeled by sports experts as the greatest comeback of 1935.

The budget for maintenance of road and equipment of the Southern Pacific Company and its principal subsidiaries in 1936 will be $55,555,000, up $5,400,000 from 1935, Hale Holden, chairman, announced, yesterday. This sum does not include additions and betterments.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 20. -The mass demonstrations of student patriotism that have swept most of China in the last two weeks spread to Shanghai yesterday. More than 5,000 young men and women of local universities marched in converging groups to the Chinese city headquarters to present demands for the preservation of national sovereignty and territorial integrity, the punishment of traitors, the release of arrested Peiping students and protection of the student movement.
A team of Interclub Class yachts will renew its rivalry with the Bermuda one-designs in Bermuda next March, it was learned last night as the class held its annual meeting and dinner at the Yale Club.
With the approach of the yearend, many proposed realignments in the partnerships of memberfirms of the New York Stock Exchange are being revealed.
ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 19. -- The Ethiopian Government handed its reply to the Hoare-Laval peace proposals to the British and the French Legations here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Southwestern Gas and Electric Company of Louisiana, an operating subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, the first to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act of 1935, was authorized today to market $16,000,000 of 4 per cent mortgage bonds and $4,500,000 of serial debentures, the net proceeds from which will be used to redeem securities carrying a higher rate of interest.

" The decay of the New England village has been accompanied by the decay of public spirit," Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams College, declared in an address last night at the annual dinner of the New England Society in the City of New York at the Hotel Plaza.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 19 (AP). -Dedjasmatch Ayelu, commander of the Ethiopian forces on the west I bank of the strategic Takkaze River in the north, reported today that his army had defeated the Italians in a major battle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A quartet of stringed instruments by Antonio Stradivari has been given to the Library of Congress by Mrs. Matthew John Whittall of Worcester, Mass. It is believed to be the only quartet of stringed instruments made by the master artist in the possession of a public institution.

THERE has been a mysterious ceremony going on high up in the Hotel Pennsylvania for the last two weeks. Ten of the greatest pocket billiard players of the world have been competing with each other for the world championship. Tomorrow night it will be decided, if no ties result. This has taken place before. This year it is being done with all sorts of new trappings.

Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report to the trustees of the college, made public yesterday, said that government interference with private industry was a "symptom of a process of decay already in progress."

Several Wall Street institutions, including the Federal Reserve Bank, the National City Bank, the American Surety Company and the latter's affiliate, the New York Casualty Company, held their annual Christmas parties yesterday.

The doors of the new Rialto will swing open on or soon after Christmas Day, it was announced yesterday by Arthur L. Mayer, the operator. Rising from the ruins of the old Rialto, a Times Square landmark which the wreckers began demolishing seven months ago, the new house will offer Frank Buck's latest animal picture, "Fang and Claw," as its first attraction.

A vigilant Red Wing hockey team took advantage of every break to conquer the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. The speedy Detroit skaters jumped into the lead early, and though they were quickly tied, nevertheless moved forward to register a 3-to-1 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Dec. 14 to the general level of Nov. 30, following a slight rise for the week of Dec. 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index now stands at 80.8, based on 1926 averages, compared with 80.9 a week ago and 76.7 a year ago.
Four more men charged with usury entered pleas of guilty in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, and were held with a fifth, for sentence on the day after Christmas.

ASIARA, Eritrea, DeC. 19. -- Scattered Ethiopian forces in the region southwest of Makale, where heavy fighting took place lasting three days, were steadily bombed by Italian planes yesterday in six separate actions. It is believed they are now thoroughly dispersed and it only remains to conduct mopping up operations throughout that part of the Takkaze River district.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Two men, armed with pistols and with their faces painted red like Indians on the warpath, held up eleven persons in a barroom at 1,119 Madison Avenue here at 6 o'clock this evening and critically wounded Jacob White, 62 years old, the proprietor, when he resisted them.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 19. -- Attorneys for the National Labor Relations Board and Consumers Research, Inc., engaged in a heated dispute over which side introduced the "Red" issue in the current hearing before the board here today, and climaxed the debate with a fist fight during the noon recess.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- More than 80,000 Democrats, assembled at dinners throughout the country, will listen by radio to the speech of President Roosevelt at the Jackson Day dinner here on Jan. 8, party leaders estimated today.

The French franc, which on Wednesday had advanced above par for the first time in about four months, went down yesterday once more to a level at which gold imports from Paris may be resumed. The decline, which was based on fears of a government upset, carried the franc down to 6.59 1/2 cents and left it at 6.59 1/2 cents, off 3 5/8 points.

One of the things which SINCLAIR LEWIS a dozen years ago felt sure could never happen here was that Babbitt might be fond of music or painting. That name, in fact, has gone ringing down the grooves of time as the negation of the higher life.

In a conference which must have taken on something of the air of a Constitutional Convention, Republican county chairmen and members of the Legislature agreed upon a declaration of principles. Conscious that for some years the New York Republicans have had scant opportunity to point with pride, it was necessary to view with alarm.
More than 2,000 tourists will leave today for Christmas holiday cruises to the West Indies on the Kungsholm, Statendam and the Champlain and 650 more for Bermuda on the Monarch of Bermuda.

A proposal that the city postpone the relocation of the Queens Terminal of the Queens-Bronx municipal ferry until after the Triborough Bridge is opened was made by the executive committee of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.

Several New Jersey sportsmen have written to this column describing their experiences in the woods on the opening day of the deer-hunting season last Tuesday. The writers stressed the tremendous congestion of gunners and the dangers to life and limb to which they were exposed.

PEIPING, Dec. 19. -- Indicating either a divergence in the aims of high Japanese Army circles or deliberate obscurity Major Gen. Kenji Doihara of Japan outlined here today what he called the ultimate aims of the army on the Asiatic mainland.

George Le Boutillier, operating vice president of the Long Island Railroad, admitted yesterday at a joint hearing on the proposed increase in the commutation rates that the Pennsylvania Railroad had purchased five of the last seven shares of stock in the Long Island Railroad not held by the parent company at a 1,900 per cent profit to the owner.

The John B. Stetson Company announced yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on the $25-par 8 per cent preferred stock. Dividend accumulations on the preferred stock will amount to $2 a share after this payment. A disbursement of $1 a share on the preferred was made on July 1, 1935.

Relentlessly hammering away at the opposition's defense virtually throughout the encounter, Princeton University's freshman hockey team downed St. Paul's School of Concord, 4 to 1, before 2,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden yesterday for the fourth straight victory registered by a Tiger yearling combination over the New Hampshire schoolboys in as many seasons.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- There is a distinct note of moderation in the early German official and editorial comment on the retirement of Sir Samuel Hoare as British Foreign Secretary and the obvious speculations on its eventual repercussions on European politics and the Ethiopian situation.

WITH THE ITALIAN ARMY AT DOLO (by Courier to Mogadiscio, Italian Somaliland, Dee. 18). -- Three modernly armed African armies are moving stealthily down the rivers by night to engage the Italian southern troops in a major fight.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Dec. 19. -Federal agents sat at the bedside of Caleb Milne 4th in Doylestown Emergency Hospital tonight as the young actor told how he was kidnapped.
The names of eighty men, from which will be taken the twentythree who will make up the special grand jury which will investigate the murder of Samuel Druckman in Brooklyn, were drawn yesterday.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed a rise of 6 per cent for the week ended Dec. 14, the United Parcel Service announced yesterday. This figure represents a decline from the increase of 13 per cent noted for the previous week.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Princeton's quintet was humbled tonight by a strong-hearted Williams team which overcame a disadvantage of height and earlyseason awkwardness to win by 41 to 28.

One of the College Art Association's many traveling exhibitions this year is a show called "Genre Painting," which in the course of its itinerary has now reached New York and will be found installed at the Lilienfeld Galleries, 21 ]East Fifty-seventh Street.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
Both in number and in amount, gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund dropped yesterday, thus making the prospect of a happy Christmas dim for scores of the suffering who still wait for aid.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 19. -- The cases of five Mexican Senators removed from office for alleged seditious activity on behalf of former President Calles were turned over to the Attorney General this afternoon.

The city will ask Federal Judge Julian W. Mack today for permission to proceed in the State Supreme Court to condemn and remove the Sixth Avenue elevated line of the Interborough system. It has already asked the Transit Commission for permission to condemn the line, but hearings have been deferred because of the pending receiverships of the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Unperturbed by the disorganization of the silver markets in London and Bombay, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury had purchased silver "every day this week." He did not say in what quantities or where the purchases were made.

Importers, customs brokers and freight forwarders, meeting yesterday at the Merchants Association to decide whether or not to test the government's right to insist upon liquidated damages in instances where consular invoices are not produced on time, deferred decision until a committee to be named next week has had time to go over the problem.

Francis Hackett, the author and historical biographer, filed suit yesterday in United States District Court, charging that the English talking picture, "The Private Life of Henry VIII," in which Charles Laughton was starred, is based on his own interpretation of Henry's personal habits.

A violent explosion in the basement of the Rhinelander, an eleven-story apartment building on the east side of Lexington Avenue, from Eighty-eighth to Eighty-ninth Street, did considerable damage and rocked buildings a block away at 6 o'clock last night. No one was injured.

Statesmen should think of themselves as physicians who assist society rather than as engineers who plan and fabricate it. Walter Lippmann told the New York Academy of Medicine last night. Mr Lippmann delivered the anniversary discourse of the academy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Questions directed by justices of the Supreme Court to counsel during arguments today on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority were looked upon here as indicating a division in the court on this major New Deal case.
PARIS, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Latest returns in The Literary Digest poll revealed yesterday that twenty-three States were voting majorities against President Roosevelt and his New Deal. The new tabulation is contained in the forthcoming issue of the publication.

A privately owned mortgage bank, under strict State supervision, is to be recommended to the Legislature as the logical successor of guaranteed mortgage companies in New York, according to Louis S. Posner, a member of the State Mortgage Commission, now engaged in drafting a report to Governor Lehman.

Mrs. Anne Morrow Lindbergh, her sister, Constance Morrow, and her brother, Dwight W. Morrow Jr., have established an educational foundation for children, named for their late sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Reeve Morrow Morgan.

Dmitri Shostakovich's Piano Concerto was played for the first time in New York at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Otto Klemperer conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The work had an enthusiastic reception, deserved by the composer's skill and by an admirable performance of the young pianist Eugene List.
The attention of realty interests was focused on the upper West Side yesterday when brokers announced sales and leases of residential properties there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- WPA will spend more than the $1,140,000,000 allotted by President Roosevelt to continue its program in fullforce until next July 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, stated today. This revelation made it likely that other parts of the work-relief program, including some proposed permanent social developments, would have to be curtailed.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The following is the text of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's reply today to a question from the floor of the House of Commons regarding the government's stand on the HoareLaval peace proposals:

W. A. W. Stewart was elected successor to Junius S. Morgan as commodore of the New York Yacht Club last night at the club's annual meeting. The other flag officers named were E. Townsend Irvin, vice commodore, and George E. Roosevelt, rear commodore.

It was long ago laid down by an English writer that a British diplomat sent abroad should be not merely an agent but a spectacle. The meaning was that he should so bear himself in public as to show that he was a great personality representing a great nation.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 19. -- As Democratic leaders, headed by Vice President Garner and Speaker Byrns, returned to the capital today from their two-months' trip to the Orient, the question of early payment of the soldiers' bonus was widely discussed, and the consensus was that "it will be paid despite all objections."

The Coca-Cola Company has redeemed 127,820 shares of its Class A stock and has increased its holdings of common stock from 4,100 shares to 56,400, the report of the New York Stock Exchange on reacquired stocks reveals. The changes are in connection with its recent distribution of three shares for one held.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Internal Revenue Bureau figures for the first five months of the fiscal year, as completed by November's report, given today, show liquor tax receipts of $221,188,627, an increase of $42,270,028 over a year ago, and indicate that collections from this source will run to from $530,000,000 to $550,000,000, or possibly more by July 1.

While the home of J. Charles Laue in the Sunnyside Gardens community of Queens was being sold at a foreclosure sale at noon yesterday on the steps of the County Court House in Long Island City a group of residents of the community waving brooms and placards danced on the sidewalk in front of the court house as part of a demonstration protesting against the foreclosures.

Enthusiastic although not unanimous approval was registered yesterday for the "People's Mandate to Government," backed by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, in a conference of leaders of that organization at the Hotel Biltmore with representatives of other important groups of women whose combined membership totals millions.

Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, issued a statement yesterday on the answer filed by The Associated Press to the complaint issued by the National Labor Relations Board in the case of Morris Watson, vice president of the guild, who was discharged by the A. P. on Oct. 18.

The Long Island Lighting Company case, as reviewed by Chairman MALTBIE in his opinion, illustrates a number of the evils in the conduct of some utilities about which complaint has been made, both before the Public Service Commission and before the bar of public opinion.

While new business in wool goods has slackened off somewhat, due to the approach of the inventory period, mill activity continues at a high rate, with no sign of a let-up, according to the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Scattering orders for Spring lines have appeared, as well as some duplicate orders on goods still coming off the looms, the report says, but the total of these has been small.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Europe's statesmen may as well make up their minds that recent events in London and Paris have again widened the Atlantic, so far as Congress and the State Department are concerned. The department is realist enough to understand how such things can happen as Prime Minister Baldwin's turnabout on Sir Samuel Hoare, and to feel sufficiently confident in its own skill to continue to play the game with Europe.

Sixty awards for participation in Fall sports at Manhattan College were announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. Included in this number were twenty-seven major letters for football and ten major letters for cross-country.

The establishment on a permanent basis of the National Peace Conference to serve as the representative agency of thirty national organizations active in the promotion of better international relations and the prevention of war was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the new organization, 8 West Fortieth Street.

Erwin Rudolph advanced a step nearer his goal -- the world's pocket billiard championship -- when he subdued the youthful Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, 125 to 44, in fifteen innings last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

HAVANA, Dec. 19. -- The Joe Louis-Isadoro Gastanaga bout scheduled for Tropical Stadium Dec. 29, has been postponed to Feb. 2, according to Mike Jacobs, New York boxing promoter, who arrived today by plane from Miami.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 19 (AP). -H. B. Peterson, Minnesota Attorney General, disclosed tonight that an attempt was made last night to enter his office supposedly to steal records in the Walter Liggett assassination case.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- After a full morning of apparently profitless discussion, delegates to the fivepower naval conference had a little relaxation this evening when they were guests of the Pilgrims at a great dinner in the banqueting hall of the Hotel Victoria. All the dele-gates to the conference were present, and several hundred distin- ]guished Britishers welcomed them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19. -- Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, a social worker who is called "friend of the poor" in Japan, was technically held by the immigration authorities on his arrival here today, and American friends appealed to Washington for his release.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Two more New York University publications yesterday joined in the demand for better student seats at the Violet's basketball games in Madison Square Garden, urging a boycott of the contests unless more satisfactory arrangements are made.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, with 50,000 employes in the United States, will put into effect within the next few weeks a new thrift plan through which its employes will be able to supplement Federal old-age payments, according to an announcement by the company.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Prison gates will swing open for ten prisoners because of commutations granted today by Governor Lehman. Two are to he deported, one of them being a sufferer from an "abnormal mental condition." Herman Ebbers, convicted in New York County of first-degree robbery and sentenced to from fifteen to twenty years, is a German citizen.

After surrendering its place in the sun for the brief span of one season, the Harvard Club last night regained its laurels by winning the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Introduced by Ralph T. Crane, president of the Bond Club of New York, at a luncheon at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway yesterday, as "the only man I ever heard of who was able to get back a contribution to a political party after an election," Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, called for enactment by Congress of a "reasonable" public utility law "in place of the present destructive measures."
