CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- The wheat market on the Chicago Board of Trade fluctuated listlessly today within a range of around 1/2 cent a bushel until near the close, when scattered buying disclosed a lack of pressure. Prices were lifted about a cent a bushel from the early low mark and the close was at the top at net gains of 3/8 to 3/4 cent.

A further improvement in the heavy industries last month carried. The Annalist Index of Business Activity in the higest level since August, 1930, and to 1 point above the speculative peak of July, 1938. The preliminary index is 90.3, compared with 87.4 for October and 83.6 for September.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Wearing a smile as broad as the brim of his sombrero, Vice President Garner arrived here today in time to eat luncheon with President Roosevelt and regale him with stories of his trip to the Philippine Islands, where he attended the inauguration of the Commonwealth Government.

A young man who had been sought by the police for two days on a charge of attempted grand larceny hanged himself yesterday in a plunge from a metal tower supporting high tension wires above the embankment of the Connecting Railway, a few hundred feet south of Northern Boulevard, near Sixtyfourth Street, Queens.

ATHENS, Dec. 19. -- Anti-monarchists deported under the Kondylis dictatorial regency have begun a hunger strike. On the island of Amaphi 126 confined Communists refused food, demanding that the King accord them the same amnesty he granted the Venizelist rebels.

The Houston-Essex Street line of the city's Independent Subway will begin operation at noon on Jan. 1, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. Mayor La Guardia will open the new line to the public at the East Broadway station, where there will be brief ceremonies under the auspices of the Board of Transportation.

The Streit joint legislative committee investigating bondholders' protective committees at the State Building brought to light yesterday what was regarded as a glaring example of the "protection" afforded by such committees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Thomas D. Schall, blind Senator from Minnesota, suffered a compound fracture of the left leg, lacerations of the head and serious internal injuries when he was struck tonight by a hit-and-run driver at Cottage City, Md., about a mile outside the District of Columbia.

The stock market's inactivity is causing Wall Street to focus its attention on the European situation, unemployment, the Republican platform for next year and other old, debatable and far-off problems. Market letters distributed by brokers show little fear of a European war in the near future.

ROME, Dec. 19. -- The feeling of triumph that pervaded Italy when the terms of the Franco-British peace proposals were made public again has yielded to gloom. As late as yesterday the Italians still thought they had the whip hand over the situation and that the decision rested with them whether the solution of the Italo-Ethiopian controversy was reached by negotiation or war.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP). -- As a more searching inquiry into the Thelma Todd death began tonight, with police proposing to question three central figures, George W. Rochester, foreman of the Los Angeles County grand jury, declared that evidence he had gathered indicated strongly that the actress might have been a "monoxide murder victim."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19. -- Governor Harry W. Nice, slated to be Maryland's favorite-son candidate at the Republican National Convention, was confronted today with the prospect of a fight to win the State's delegation from Herbert Hoover.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 19. -- Securities, rights and credits of William Fox, film man, which had been posted with the All Continent Corporation as collateral, were sold at public auction here today by Paul N. Salsburg, president of the Atlantic County Bar Association.

ASMRA, Eritrea, Dec. 19 (AP. -Italian officers reported today that more than 1,000 bodies of fallen Italian and Ethiopian soldiers had been counted on the battle front along the Takkaze River front, where the invaders reported yesterday they had routed the Ethiopians after a fierce three-day battle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Applications by brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission totaled 5,608 today, and all but a relatively few will probably be permitted to become effective on Jan. 1, when supervision of these activities is inaugurated.

The printing of the recent comments of Cardinal Hayes on the subject of birth prevention, and the response of thirteen ministers, as well as the rejoinder of the Cardinal, has a news value of particular importance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- An interior decorator testified at the Securities Commission hearing today on the alleged manipulation of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock by Michael J. Meehan that he purchased 5,000 shares on Mr. Meekan's recommendation.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Striking evidence that intensive aircraft rearmament is world-wide is provided in "Jane's All the World's Aircraft for 1935."

DES MOINES, Dec. 19. -- People do not make fun of the New Deal's "alphabetical soup" here. The AAA means too much to them. It has raised, or at least it has been credited with a large share in bringing, Iowa from that unhappy depression period, when farmers burned their corn because it was so cheap, to their present relatively prosperous condition.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -Notices of liens for income tax deficiencies of $1,521,604, charged against Howard C. Hopson, utility official, and $3,898,029 against New Jersey subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, of which he is the head, were filed today by Charles V. Duffy Jr., Acting Collector of Internal Revenue here, on orders from Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Some of the Democratic chieftains at the Capitol today said that at the coming session of Congress, in addition to bonus, neutrality and NRA, the following legislative list was virtually certain to receive a going over:

Mayor La Guardia brought the Christmas season to New York officially yesterday afternoon when he pressed a switch which lighted a large Christmas tree in City Hall Park and illuminated trees in twenty-two other city parks at the same time.

At 3:30 o'clock this morning the fate of Mrs. Etta Reisman, indicted for second-degree murder in the slaying of her husband's 23-year-old secretary, remained in the hands of a jury. Judge Charles S. Colden completed his charge at 3:53 o'clock yesterday afternoon and the jurors retired for deliberation a few minutes later.

Declaring that opportunities for increasing income are available to employes in a large proportion of business concerns, the National Industrial Conference Board stated yesterday that the earning power of American wage-earners cannot be measured solely on the basis of hourly or weekly wages.

With less than three weeks remaining for the completion of his budget, the President is reported to have made no decision on the most important question which the budget raises for him. This is the problem of what policy to recommend to Congress in the matter of relief.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler handed down a decision yesterday refusing to approve a petition submitted by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent, permitting the compromise for $280,000 of two suits totaling $10,000,000 brought by the Insurance Department as liquidator of the State Title and Mortgage Company and the General Surety Company, a subsidiary, against former directors.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19. -- Invasion of the Mongolian People's Republic by 200 Japanese and Manchukuoan troops and the killing of a Mongolian officer and several soldiers were reported from Ulan Bator (Urga), Mongolia, to the official Tass News Agency tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The text of Sir Samuel Hoare's speech before the House of Commons today follows:

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The Reich Railway, the biggest single concern in the world, which Chancellor Adolf Hitler recently pronounced a model of "socialistic enterprise," announced today a public loan of 500,000,000 marks to cover a huge deficit and expenditures incurred in the service of the National Socialist "labor creation" program.

OTTAWA, Dec. 19 (Canadian Pres). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $1,509,816 in the week ended yesterday and deposits by chartered bank's decreased $2,853,264, the banks weekly statement today said.

The various charitable organizations sponsored by the Service Clubof St. Thomas Church were aidedby a dinner dance last night in theTrianon Room of the Ambassador.The proceeds will be devoted to theChurch Mission of Help, the HalseyDay Nursery, and to the childrenof needy parents in an isolatedparish in the mountains of Vermont.

The end of the long road that leads to the Metropolitan Opera House was reached by two young Americans in a performance of "Faust" last night. Charles Kullmann, tenor, came by way of the American Opera Company and a career abroad to make his debut in the title role of Gounod's opera.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19. -- Making her first appearance since a campaign in New England, F. W. Woodman's 3-year-old filly, Little Dinah, led home five other sprinters in the Matecumba Handicap, headliner on today's card at Tropical Park.

A delegation of seamen who quit the Norwegian freighter Spero when they discovered that she was taking on a cargo of iron for Italy appealed for aid yesterday to Rolf A. Christensen, Norwegian consul general. The ship left port Wednesday with a crew that had been signed in Jersey City, where she loaded.

When Admiral Nagano, Japanese delegate to the London Naval Conference, told American delegates that Japan's fear of attack from the United States withheld them from reducing their navy, there was opportunity for a snappy comeback.

Robert P. Levis, member of the Republican County Committee from the Eleventh Assembly District, opposed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCook a suit by Daniel J. Reisner for the removal of Levis as executive member for that district.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,498,000,000, an increase of $18,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $27,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1934.

Mayor La Guardia turned his office at City Hall yesterday noon into a court room and, acting in the triple capacity of judge, complainant and witness, fined John Nelson of 605 West 132d Street, a driver for the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, $2 for passing a red traffic light on the night of Dec. 5.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19. -The annual report of the treasurer of Yale University, issued today, showed a total expenditure of $6,919,740.44 by the university for the year 1934-35 for educational purposes.

The sale of high interest-bearing securities by railroads was seen in Wall Street yesterday as prevented by the offer of Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, to aid the Great Northern Railway in meeting a forthcoming maturity at a saving of more than $11,000,000, compared with the best arrangement that could be effected by the company's own bankers.

Both employers and employes came to the support yesterday of Controller Frank J. Taylor in his drive to halt the flight of business from New York. Mr. Taylor's campaign was announced this week by Charles E. Murphy, special representative of the City Department of Finance, who called for the cooperation of all large industries to stop an exodus which, Mr. Murphy said, may become a menace to the taxpayers at large.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A committee of forty educators and broadcasting officials has been named by the Federal Communications Commission to work out a plan to end controversy and misunderstanding between the radio industry and educators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The new form which corporations that registered their securities on the Stock Exchanges on Form 10 prescribed for seasoned companies, must use in making annual reports, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Although only small price changes occurred yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here, with closing quotations 1 point lower to 7 points higher, December established a 90point premium over October, the widest spread of the season. With only two full and two half-sessions before December goes off the board at noon next Tuesday, mill calling stiffened the spot month.

Long Island University's undefeated basketball team crushed Washington College of Chestertown, Md., 47 -- 22, last night for its seventh triumph. The contest was staged at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, sounded a warning last night against the Townsend plan, although she did not specify it by name. In a radio debate under the auspices of the League for Political Education and broadcast over a national network by the NBC from the Town Hall, 129 West Forty-third Street, she said it was the alternative to the President's social security plan.

ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Strong condemnation of practices of the Niagara Hudson System was voiced before the Mack utility investigating committee today by Walter Seymour, one of the committee's principal accountants.

May I reply to the letter criticizing the use of the term "common" for City Hall Park on one of the historical markers supplied by the State Education Department and erected by the New York City Department? The legends for this and other markers in Hanhattan and in Hudson Valley counties were supplied by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The smoldering, mountainous ash and rubbish heaps that form the greater part of Rikers Island outside Flushing Bay constitute a serious menace to the World's Fair, which will be held in Flushing Meadows, a tract stretching southward from the lower end of the bay.

After a down trend which had persisted for three successive weeks, a gain of more than $1,000,000,000 expanded bank clearings to the heaviest aggregate record since the period ended on Oct. 3. The total for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet's report, was $6,251,978,000, against $6,160,782,000 last year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 19. -- A presentment charging that the Works Progress Administration in Nassau County "is being grossly mismanaged and mishandled through inexperience and incompetence" was handed up today by the Nassau grand jury which has been investigating the administration of relief in the county for the last two weeks.

By rail, air and bus the annual rush of thousands toward family hearths for the Christmas holiday began yesterday on a scale unprecedented for many years. Estimates of the seasonal increase in travel ranged up to 40 per cent over last Christmas, with some transport lines reporting a heavier business than ever before.

Elmer Rice, playwright, in a letter made public yesterday, declined a recent invitation from Professor William Lyon Phelps to serve with him and Mrs. Padraic Colum on the Pulitzer Prize Play Committee for 1935-36. Mr. Rice's "Street Scene" received the prize in 1928-29.

Tributes to the late Mrs. Mary Harriman Rumsey as "a unique personality who has left a lasting impress upon the national movement to create a better life for all in this nation" were paid yesterday by leaders in many walks of life at a memorial service in her honor at the New York Junior League clubhouse. 221 East Seventy-first Street.

The Dodgers, having romped away with the Grapefruit League pennant in Florida last Spring, are making a repetition of that minor achievement next March more difficult, according to the training schedule announced yesterday by Secretary John Gorman.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 19. -- Although the Japanese army is probably actuated by a sincere desire to expand the territory of the Japanese Empire on the Asiatic mainland and to develop trade between North China areas bordering on Manchuria, the principal motive of the Japanese army in forcing autonomy upon Chahar and Hopei is far more imperative than territorial expansion or commercial greed could possibly be.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19. -- United States Circuit Judge Faris changed today the classification of the claim of J. P. Morgan Co for $5,850,000 balance due on loans made to the Missouri Pacific Railroad from a separate creditor's classification to the same classification in which are the claims of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for $23,134,800 and of the Railroad Credit Corporation for $3,775,000.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Political developments overshadowed every other factor today on the London Stock Exchange and prices at first fell sharply, although later they became steadier and firmer, with the volume of selling less than had been feared.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 19. -The five hold-up men found guilty of holding up thirty patrons of the Farm Rest, a road house near Monticello, early Labor Day morning, were sentenced today by County Judge George L. Cooke.

Christmas trade of department stores in the metropolitan area showed a decline of 2.8 per cent for the twelve shopping days from Dec. 2 to 14 as compared with the same number of days from Dec. 3 to 15 last years, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A declaration was made tonight by Senator Borah that he was willing to have liberal delegates from any State pledged to support him for the Republican nomination for the Presidency. This statement some observers interpreted as tantamount to a declaration of his candidacy.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 19. -- Students who on Wednesday night held up a train for Shanghai for nearly two hours while they insisted on free transportation to Nanking, Shanghai and Canton, in order that they might arouse students in other universities, announced today that they would walk to Nanking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP). -- A formal proposal by seven public utility companies for "two suits" to test the disputed Holding Company Act today found Attorney General Cummings reiterating his objections to all except one.

Many stage, screen and radio performers were among the 1,350 persons who attended yesterday the annual Christmas luncheon of the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers, Inc., in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. The proceeds will be contributed to the relief fund of The Film Daily, a trade publication.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 19. -Tributes to the character and achievements of the late Miss M. Carey Thomas, president emeritus of Bryn Mawr College, were paid at a memorial service this afternoon in Goodhart Hall, attended by about 900 persons.

The lead of the American Four Aces over their European contract bridge rivals, a team from Paris headed by Baron Robert De Nexon, was cut to 3,400 points yesterday after 204 hands of the 300-hand match had been played at Essex House.
The reply to Cardinal Hayes by a group of clergymen may easily seem to call for no rejoinder from him; but it certainly invites comment from others.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 20. -- There are many hints in London newspaper editorials today that Sir Samuel Hoare's return to the government may not be long delayed, although his position is a matter of speculation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A uniform traffic control code for all the States which would make possible a coast-to-coast automobile trip under a single set of regulations is expected to result from the Accident Prevention Conference called at the suggestion of President Roosevelt.

Reflecting the effects of the Treasury financing and tax-day operations last Monday, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $600,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday from the high record of $3,310,000,000 reported a week ago to $2,710,000,000, according to the weekly report of the Federal Reserve, published yesterday.

Eddie (Babe) Risko, holder of the world's middleweight championship, will engage Jock McAvoy, sturdy British boxer, in the feature bout of ten rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden. Although the battle will be held over the class limit of 160 pounds and will not involve Risko's title, it is expected to attract a crowd of about 10,000 persons.

GENEVA, Dec. 19. -- In two fiveminute meetings tonight the League of Nations Council and the Committee of Eighteen hastily adjourned to allow British and French delegations to rush home one day earlier to their governments groggy from the vain efforts to override the Council, the committee and the covenant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Army officers will not be allowed in the future to act as football coaches in civil colleges. This is provided, it was learned tonight, in an order issued by the War Department to become effective Jan. 1.

TOKYO, Friday, Dee. 20 (AP). -A War Office spokesman asserted today that the reported scene of a clash between Japanese-Manchukuoan troops and an Outer Mongolian detachment was in Manchukuoan territory. "Complaints by Outer Mongolia of any incident at that point is likely to bring further trouble," the Japanese officer said.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The Boerse again was virtually inactive throughout today's session. No price trend developed, and the market was characterized by slight variations and ended in lethargy. Talk in trading circles centered in the new Reich railway loan, although the market showed no response one way or the other.

A flag of the Cuban Republic was presented by Pablo Suarez, Consul General of Cuba, to Kermit Roosevelt, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, yesterday morning at Mr. Roosevelt's office at 1 Broadway. It was to have been presented to Mr. Roosevelt's mother, but she is confined to a hospital.

Gilbert Miller, who comes home from Mayfair occasionally to do something about Broadway, begins his New York season tonight. "Libel!" Edward Wooll's play set entirely in a court room, is this evening's item, and Henry Miller's Theatre is its home.

LONDON. Dec. 19. -- The Labor Opposition's motion of censure against the Baldwin government for its endorsement of the Hoare-Laval Ethiopian peace proposals was defeated tonight in the House of Commons by 397 to 165, a majority for the overnment of 232.

The share market failed yesterday to shake off the lethargy that has persisted these several days; resignation for the moment to the holiday and year-end influences appears to be general. With few exceptions, prices drifted aimlessly, closing firm at slightly lower levels.

The State should give adequate financial support to the Torrens Law so realty owners registering titles under the measure may have additional facilities to borrow money, witnesses said yesterday at the sixth public hearing of the joint legislative committee on guaranteed real estate mortgages in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19. -Mr. and Mrs. William Theodore Hoops gave a dinner and bridge tonight at Casa Eleda. Those present were Mr. and Mrs. Phil H. Sawyer, Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan D. Bill, Mrs. James H. Kennedy and Dr. Edmund Le Roy Dow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Bituminous Coal Commission tonight directed the Appalachian producers to fix minimum coal prices by Friday, Dec. 27.

There are more than 42,000 employable women on relief in this city, Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, revealed yesterday in disclosing the results of a study on the subject.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (AP). -Chickahominy, 7-year-old gelding owned by G. E. Ewins, kept intact a perfect record for 1935 today when he captured his fifth straight race in accounting for the sixfurlong top event at the Fair Grounds.

Thirteen bids on the contract for the construction of the Weehawken land sections and plaza of the new Midtown Hudson Tunnel were opened yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. Completion of this work by July 1, 1937, must be guaranteed so that schedules on other phases of the main contract can be met.

Prices of commodity futures generally were higher yesterday in quiet trading. Only cottonseed oil and copper were lower. On the cash markets, wheat, oats, cotton and rubber advanced, while corn, eggs, tin and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The first statement in its campaign for government ownership of railroads was made today by the Railway Labor Executives' Association in a letter to members of Congress summarizing some specific cases of financial abuses laid to the door of the carriers and financial groups.

Some facts speak for themselves. Once stated, they carry their own argument or appeal. This is notably true of the stories of the Neediest Cases in New York which THE TIMES has been printing since the first of the month, while it has been opening its columns for receipt of gifts for the benefit of these men and women and children in dire want.

Following an expansion of $94,000,000 in the previous three weeks brokers' loans declined $5,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly condition report of member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday.

Sir Arthur Willert, who recently resigned as head of the Press Department of Great Britain's Foreign Office, is coming here on Dec. 27 and will have a book published in mid-January by Putnam's, "What Next in Europe?"

A uniform fee payable by property owners to managing agents delegated to compile and report data in connection with the State Unemployment Insurance Law, effective Jan. 1, is being considered by the agents' subcommittee of the social security committee of the Real Estate Board of New York. J. H. N. Potter is chairman of the subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Speedy dissolution of the National Recovery Administration and distribution of the few functions it retains among regular government departments was announced informally by President Roosevelt today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- After eight days of fact-finding, the Securities and Exchange Commission adjourned today until Jan. 2 the hearing of its charges of stock manipulation against Michael J. Meehan after opposing counsel had engaged in loud contention.

The holiday season is at hand, new shows are arriving like robins in the Spring -- and New Year's Eve is just around the corner. Because it wishes to devote itself more extensively to the latter important subject, this column must perforce skip lightly over the schedule of events for the coming week, the record of recent happenings, Christmas greetings and all that.

Preserving the same unruffled composure she maintained during her four-day trial for second-degree murder, Mrs. Etta Reisman stood in Queens County Court a few minutes before 6 o'clock yesterday morning and heard a jury return a verdict against her of manslaughter in the first degree for the killing of Virginia Seigh, her husband's 23-year-old secretary.
TOKYO, Dec. 20. -- Manchukuo is prepared to meet force with force on the Mongolian border, said a Rengo News Agency dispatch today from Hsinking, capital of the Japanese-fostered State.

Your editorial "Bureaucratic Relief" repeats with apparent belief and approval Herbert Hoover's ideas about "local relief being shifted to a Federal bureaucracy," and "State and local relief administrations being dismissed or reduced to mere window dressing."

As the site for a gasoline station and auto parking place the entire square block bounded by Morris and Sheridan Avenues, 171st and 172d Streets, was leased by Vincent Astor to John Klinger. The lease was negotiated by the Oliver Lakin Company.

Only a little over a fortnight ago Controller TAYLOR announced that he had appointed Mr. CHARLES E. MURPHY, an advertising man, to conduct an investigation to find out whether it was true, as frequently alleged, that business was moving away from this city. If there was in fact an exodus, he wanted to know the reason for it, so that the city might do all in its power to stop it.
TIENTSIN, Dec. 20. -- "No matter how perfect our administration of Hopei and Chahar, the Japanese are certain to say the system does not work and to make excuses for further disturbances."

An attack upon the plan of the Fashion Originators Guild to extend its style protection principle to dresses wholesaling at $10.75 or cheaper was launched yesterday by a group of members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Association of Buying Offices, on the ground that extension of the plan "would create greater evils" and would prove "a menace to the successful operation of ready-towear departments in retail stores."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The lagging white-collar part of the work relief program was cut sharply today when Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, transferred $7,000,000, or almost one-quarter of the $27,000,000 allotment for the WPA arts program, to other sections of the work relief program.

The Columbia club's combination scored a 4-to-1 victory over the pace-setting Harvard club team yesterday in the Class B competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League. The Blue and White prevailed on its home courts in unexpectedly easy fashion.

Textile High went into undisputed possession of first place in the P.S. A.L. hockey tournament by vanquishing Manual Training, 2-0, in one of three league contests at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. It was Textile's second victory in as many starts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A national conference on conservation of wild life was called today by President Roosevelt to meet here Feb. 3-7.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Stock holders of the Great Northern Railroad accepted today an offer of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to absorb the surplus of a pending $100,000,000 bond issue carrying 4 per cent interest.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 20. -Harvard's hockey team remained undefeated by beating Brown, 3 to 0, tonight. The Crimson set a furious pace and concentrated on offense, while the Bruin centered its efforts on defense.

HAVANA, Dec. 20. -- In a radio broadcast tonight, opening the Cuban-American exposition of industrial products, President Jose Barnet attributed the economic improvement of Cuba to the reciprocity treaty signed last year by Cuba and the United States and expressed gratitude for United States cooperation.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Special agents of the Federal Housing Administration have opened a drive in New York on racketeers in the government housing loan field who are reported to have defrauded hundreds of uninformed persons seeking loans to repair or pay for homes.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Interest in Sir Samuel Hoare's resignation as Foreign Secretary and even in the selection of his successor waned somewhat tonight in the face of rumors that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin wished to retire as a result of his discomfiture over the Foreign Office blunder, which reached a climax in yesterday's debate in the House of Commons.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Inquiries made by the British Government to Mediterranean powers asking whether they had taken the necessary naval and military measures demanded by the application of sanctions and in view of the undertaking to give mutual assistance under Article XVI of the covenant of the League of Nations were not, it was stated here today, addressed to France but to Yugoslavia, Spain, Greece and Turkey.

Far off his usual form and a bit shaky at times, Erwin Rudolph, nevertheless, staggered through his important meeting with George Kelly of Philadelphia last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, turning back his rival in a twenty-seven inning encounter, 125 to 35, to assure himself of at least a tie for the world's pocket billiard championship.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 20. -- Colonel Damian Veltcheff, on trial with twenty-nine others on charges of attempting to overthrow the present government, continued today to furnish a military court with details of his activities in recent years, again denying all participation in any plots against King Boris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A union of railroad management and labor to terminate the office of Coordin ator of Transportation, now held by Joseph B. Eastman, appeared in the making today as a result of a decision by the Association of American Railroads to discuss with labor executives problems arising from displacement of workmen through coordination projects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Japanese Embassy cabled to Tokyo today a detailed report of the statement made in Las Vegas, N.M., yesterday by Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, attacking Japan.

GENEVA, Dec. 20. -- Professor Manley Ottmer Hudson of Harvard Law School was nominated to succeed Frank B. Kellogg on the World Court bench by the American group in the Permanent Court of Arbitration, the League of Nations announced today.

In order that all home relief families may have their food checks in time for Christmas, Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, announced yesterday that the checks will be distributed a day prior to the usual date of delivery.

GENEVA, Dec. 20. -- World trade in October reached the highest monthly total since the depression set in, according to provisional estimates, including final figures for nearly all the important countries, published in the monthly statistics bulletin of the League of Nations today.

Demolition of the city penitentiary on Welfare Island will clear the way for the construction of a large health center for the chronic sick. One of the most important projects of the La Guardia administration, the health center will provide not only for the better treatment and housing of those suffering from chronic diseases but also for the correlated scientific study of their diseases under the auspices of the city's medical institutions.

The sixty-second annual Christmastide performance of Handel's "Messiah," given by the Oratorio Society of New York last night in Carnegie Hall, under the direction of Albert Stoessel, was dedicated to the memory of Andrew Carnegie, president of the society from 1888 to 1918.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Conditions on the London Stock Exchange were brighter today following the outcome of last night's debate in Parliament, postponement of consideration of the oil sanctions at Geneva, continued encouraging industrial reports and improvement in Wall Street.

VIENNA, Dec. 20. -- Under a new departmental order signed by the Minister of Social Welfare, Professor Dobretsberger, State employes are warned, under threat of punishment, of their duty to take action against any members of their families who work against or merely take a hostile attitude toward the present Austrian regime.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The Westchester grand jury indicted today Joseph Ryan, 40 years old, of 756 Main Street, New Rochelle, for violation of the section of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control regulations which makes it a misdemeanor for individuals to transport liquor purchased in Connecticut into this State.

Six months ago a group of a half-dozen men sat in the fencing room of the New York Athletic Club watching a pair of foilsmen in action. When the match was over the spectators, all members of the club, chatted of this and that, mainly about sports.

The Western Long Island Sound fleet elected F. H. Van Winkle as delegate to the special meeting of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association last night with instructions to vote in the affirmative on three new resolutions affecting the world championship regatta.

Mr. HOOVER'S aide de camp, BEN ALLEN, says that the former President has been timed as requiring exactly seven minutes to get into full dress. The younger people around Mr. HOOVER need a fifteen-minute handicap for the same operation.
The American Four Aces were carefully protecting a 4,250-point lead over the invading French contract bridge team last night as the 300-hand international match neared its close at Essex House.

An exhibition of drawings by Degas opens today at the DurandRuel Galleries, 12 East Fiftyseventh Street, to remain until Jan. 15. These drawings, many of which are extremely fine, came out of the Degas sale held in Paris not long after the great French artist's death in 1917.

With the holiday week just ahead -- and it is generally regarded as one of the most profitable weeks of the year -- only one show will give up the struggle after this evening's performance. It is "Abide With Me," Clare Boothe Brokaw's play which, come to think of it, also gave up the struggle a week ago tonight and then was reprieved on Monday....

With the Christmas shopping season at its peak, reports from most districts of the country this week revealed the largest retail sales figures for any comparative period since 1930, while a few approached the 1929 totals, according to the survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The first "Aida" of the season was given last night in the Metropolitan Opera House with some important innovations in the cast. Gertrud Wettergren of the Royal Opera of Stockholm made her American debut as Amneris. John Charles Thomas appeared for the first time here as Amonasro.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20. -Mrs. Margaret Emerson entertained with a dinner for fifteen tonight at her villa, and gave earlier in the day a luncheon. The guests were Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick, Mrs. Arthur Somers Roche, Clyde Roche and Herbert Bayard Swope Jr., besides Mr. and Mrs. Askell Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Miss Dorothy de Milhau, Miss Gloria Baker, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Horace Kelland, members of her house party.

Eddie (Babe) Risko, Syracuse fighter, still is the world's middleweight champion only because his title wasn't at stake last night when he fought Jock McAvoy, Great Britain's champion, in Madison Square Garden.
New bond financing this week amounted to $68,480,000, against $205,536,000 last week and $80,728,032 in the week a year ago.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20. -- The JapaneseMongolian situation on the frontier of Outer Mongolia is being watched here with close attention and some disquietude.

" But isn't $200 a month a lot of money for an old person to spend?" asked Alice of the Queen of Spades, who was assiduously engaged in attempting to turn the page of her newspaper in spite of her lavender woolen gloves.
At least 2,400 more policemen are needed to stem the growing rate of crime in New York City, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday.

Last Spring the Bell System telephone companies extended their reduced rates on interstate toll service by advancing the period in which the lower night rates take effect from 8:30 in the evening to 7. The change was intended to stimulate social calls by permitting them to be made at a more convenient hour, and at the same time to level off the sharp traffic peak at 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Two attacks on the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Board Act were temporarily rebuffed by Justice Jesse C. Adkins in the District Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Senator Borah, by allowing his name to be put forward for President in the Wisconsin Republican primaries, has lost the support of the La Follette Progressive party and virtually assured its support for President Roosevelt in 1936, persons close to the Wisconsin political situation said today.

George Gordon Battle, member of the Pounds independent committee organized to protect bondholders in ninety-four S.W. Straus Co. real estate issues, yesterday accused the Continental Bank and Trust Company, trustee in most of the issues, of endeavoring to perpetuate its control of the properties for its own financial benefit and at the expense of bondholders.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt acted as Santa Claus yesterday afternoon for thirty-five children associated with the Women's Trade Union League at 247 Lexington Avenue. Originally, eleven years ago, invitations were sent out annually by Mrs. Roosevelt's sons, John and Franklin Jr., but more recently she herself has issued the invitations to the children, whose fathers have been the victims of industrial accidents or other disasters.

TRENTON, Dec. 20. -- Governor Hoffman suffered another rebuff at the hands of the anti-administration Republicans in the Legislature today when the Assembly majority caucus turned a deaf ear to his personal plea and elected officers for 1936 as desired by the Essex County "clean government" bloc.

The first city anthem to be made public in connection with Mayor La Guardia's official contest came to light yesterday when it was sung by the Girl Scout choir of the upper East Side as the climax of a carolsinging competition between Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts.

Followers of the share market were content yesterday to continue a policy of watchful waiting. Sporadic attempts were made to center attention on some groups, the petroleum shares in the late forenoon, the motors and steels later in the day, but the efforts at sponsorship were not quite successful, so that the best that may be said about the stock list was that final prices were steady and mixed.

Eben S. Abbott, chief engineer of the Morro Castle, who escaped in a lifeboat while that vessel was burning off Asbury Park on the morning of Sept. 8, 1934, knew then that criminal charges might be brought against him, according to testimony offered yesterday in Federal court.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Jones Humphrey of 580 Park Avenue and Ridgewood, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Scott Banks of 1,120 Fifth Avenue and Suffern, N.Y., gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society their respective daughters, Miss Mary Elizabeth Humphrey and Miss Marjory Albertine Banks.
A long-range, first-half attack enabled Columbia's basketball team to gain a 37-34 victory over Union last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The agenda of the inquiry which the Securities and Exchange Commission will make of investment trusts were discussed today at a conference between Commissioner Healy, a staff of SEC experts and a committee representing a group of investment trusts of the management type, of which Earle Bailie of the Tri-Continental Corporation is chairman.

The Westchester women's squash racquets team turned the tables on its New York rivals in the second of the triangular interteam series held at the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday, reversing the 4-3 defeat scored by the New York players earlier this month.

An exhibition contest marking Winston Guest's return to action indoors and the initial two Metropolitan Indoor Polo League games of the new season stand out on the sport's local schedule for tonight. Guest will play with Optimists against the First Division after Squadron A and Governors Island have met in a league match at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan.

Mrs. Marie Catherine Harris, 53 years old, a widow, of 55 Kingston Avenue, Yonkers, received a certified check for $10,000 last night in the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street, where it was announced she won first prize for the best slogan submitted in the contest conducted by the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is president.

Trailing for the first few minutes, New York University's court cannoneers dropped an 18-point barrage amid the startled Dartmouth quintet at the University Heights gymnasium last night, rolled up a substantial lead and coasted to a 54-29 victory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Cotton of this year's crop ginned prior to Dec. 13 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 9,757,680 running bales, counting 238,547 round as half bales and including 13,557 bales of AmericanEgyptian.

The city's anti-noise campaign was carried to the courts yesterday and some 250 drivers of automobiles were fined $540 for blowing their horns unnecessarily. In a few cases drivers were fined for having defective mufflers on their cars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a broad readjustment of freight rates on cotton, woolen and knitting factory products in all territory east of the Rocky Mountains.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Requirements relative to payroll records that must be kept by employers under the Social Security Act, effective on Jan. 1, were outlined in a Treasury decision today.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Dec. 20. -The ransom demanded for the release of Caleb Jones Milne 4th was $20,000 and it was not paid, Federal agents revealed here today.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 20. -- While Senator La Follette and his brother, Governor La Follette, withheld comment today on the announcement that Senator Borah had permitted his name to be entered in the Wisconsin Presidential primary as a "liberal Republican candidate," an idea of their probable reaction was seen in the statement of a leading Progressive spokesman, Thomas M. Duncan.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- Robert M. Washburn, president of the Roosevelt Club (named after President Theodore Roosevelt) announced today that he would put a slate of Borah-pledged delegates in the field for the Massachusetts primary in April.

Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion of the world and now part owner of a restaurant, was questioned yesterday, under a grand jury subpoena, on whether he had paid any "protection" money to racketeers in return for freedom from stench bombs and other depredations at his place of business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Twentyfour hours after he voluntarily appeared to "quash once and for all" the criticism of his dealings with the War Department, Joseph Silverman Jr New York dealer in surplus war materials, was indicted today by the District of Columbia grand jury on charges of conspiring to defraud the government.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Dec. 20 (Reuters). -- There is evidence on all sides here of the thorough precautions taken to guard Egypt against dangers arising from the international situation.
Your editorial "Social Security Cost" quotes Abraham Epstein as saying:

SANTOS, Brazil, Dec. 20. -- With a blast that shook a large part of the waterfront here, the steamship Britt Marie blew up at the dock where she was unloading this afternoon. She had been discharging a cargo of 3,500 tons of nitrate.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ames Hatch gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their daughter, Miss Barbara Hatch, and Dr. James T. Emert, who will be married this afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Among the other guests were:

Senator BORAH began his season early. Perhaps it was time for a change of bill. The absorbing problem play, "Will He, Won't He?" is taken off the boards. It is succeeded by "The Liberal Leader." Anywhere he can break into a fight for "liberal" delegates he will jump in.

That Italian hopes ran high when the Anglo-French proposals were made public, and that a spirit of gloom settled upon the Italian people when the plan broke down, dispatches from Rome passed by the censor have freely admitted. There is apparently a feeling in Italy that the Government missed a fine opportunity.
PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Despite the application of sanctions Nov. 18, French trade with Italy improved for that month, according to official figures obtained here today.

For the first time in twenty-seven years the United States will have a new chess champion when the national tournament, planned for early in March, is decided, it was learned yesterday. Frank J. Marshall, who has been American champion since he defeated J. W. Showalter of Kentucky in 1909, will step aside in order to afford opportunity to younger aspirants to show what they can do in that competition.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, through the Prussian Church Directorate today expelled from his pulpit one of the most distinguished and most widely known Confessional church pastors, the Rev. Gerhard Jacobi, chairman of the Berlin-Brandenburg Confessional Synod and Brotherhood Council.

Directors of the Gulf States Steel Company resumed payments on the company's senior stock with the declaration yesterday of $3.50 a share on the 7 per cent cumulative first preferred stock on account of accumulations. The last quarterly payment of $1.75 was made on April 1, 1931.

THE steady march of the seasons brings another one to the city tonight. Under the glare of arc lights a start is to be made in the indoor polo competition which leads to the national championships of the early Spring. League competition and a special match in which Winston Guest, the greatest of the indoor players, takes part form the excitement for this first evening of play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Reports to the Department of Commerce today told of quantities of silver smuggled from China to Japan and resold later in the world markets, which the Treasury recently abandoned as a source of its silver purchases.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack indicated yesterday that he would grant the city's application for permission to take the legal steps required to bring about immediate condemnation and removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line.
St. John's University conquered the Seton Hall College five, 56-31, last night in the De Gray gymnasium for its sixth consecutive triumph of the season.

Hearing on a show-cause order to determine why a bid of $250,000 should not be accepted by the trustees in bankruptcy of the American Type Founders Company, for the plant at 300 Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City, was adjourned yesterday by George R. Beach, referee in bankruptcy, when another bid offering $275,000 for the plant and $20,000 for adjoining property was made.
LILYPONS, Md., Dec. 20 (AP). -Christmas greetings, each bearing the postmark of the village named in her honor, were mailed here this week by Miss Lily Pons, the opera singer.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- It was learned tonight that Britain canvassed the Mediterranean powers a fortnight ago on whether they had taken any military precautions against hostilities that might grow out of the imposition of sanctions against Italy by the League of Nations.

On the ground that the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company defaulted on notes due on Oct. 1 last, Supreme Court Justice Walsh granted yesterday summary judgment in suits by two bondholders. The notes were dated Oct. 1, 1932, and matured in three years.

In the industrious little comedy at the Roxy Theatre, Roger Pryor, a newspaper man who has just lost both his job and his girl, finds his future depending on his ability to spend $1,000 a minute for twelve hours. One millionaire has wagered another that a spending orgy of such proportions is impossible, and Mr. Pryor is to receive $10,000 if he succeeds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Less than two hours were required today for the Labor Department to devise a formula for the admission to this country of Dr. Toyhiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian leader, after President Roosevelt took a personal interest in the case of the visitor, detained by immigration authorities at San Francisco because he suffered from trachoma, a disease of the eyes.

Distribution of approximately $5,000,000 as a 5 per cent dividend on the debentures of the International Match Corporation was made yesterday by the Irving Trust Company as trustee in bankruptcy. The payment was made pursuant to an order issued on Nov. 25 by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy.
Mr. and Mrs. Edmund P. Cassell of Providence gave a tea dance yesterday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria to introduce to society Mrs. Cassell's daughter, Miss Audrey Thomas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Interior Department has swung in behind Senator Wagner's $800,000,000 slum clearance and low-cost housing plan, it was learned today. Secretary Ickes, already pledged to the plan in principle, will go on record as personally in favor of the program, which represents a reversal of present housing policies.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 21. -(AP). -- For the first time since the nationalization of silver, a government official admitted today that direct shipments of silver were being made by Chinese Government banks to the United States.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Business institutions are translating profits into Christmas bonuses for workers this year at a greater rate than in any year since depression's pall blanketed industry.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- The British freighter Seven Seas Spray rammed and badly damaged the Boston lightship at about 9 A.M. today and was seized by the United States Government to satisfy a $20,000 damage claim.

Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt's application for an allowance of $197.10 for expenses in entertaining her 12year-old daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, on week-ends, was unopposed by George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist, general guardians of the child's estate. Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday directing them to pay the money.

A service of "International Goodwill" dealing especially with the relationship between Canada and the United States will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. It will commemorate the signing of the Treaty of Ghent on Christmas Eve, 1814, ending the War of 1812 between Canada and the United States and establishing 3,500 miles of unfortified frontier between the two nations.

Efforts to coordinate the work of independent agencies raising funds for relief in Ethiopia will be made during the next few months by Lij Tasfaye Zaphiro, first Secretary of the Ethiopian Legation in London, who arrived here Dec. 13. After presenting the case for Ethiopia at a number of meetings in New York and the vicinity, he will tour the country.

Under steady mill calling based on the December position, which will expire at noon on Tuesday, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday. At one time the list had gained about 15 points, but realizing near the close left quotations 5 to 10 points higher than on Thursday.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 21. -University and middle-school students converged on foot throughout the day yesterday on the Civic Center as youth demonstrations for the preservation of national rights continued here.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Prices on theBoerse, although trading remainedextremely quiet were slightly weaker today as a result of the tendencyon the part of the few traders still!interested in the official market toi liquidate their holdings before theChristmas holidays.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20. -The American premiere of "Murder in the Cathedral," poetic play by T. S. Eliot, the noted poet and critic, now living in England, was held tonight in the Yale Theatre before a group of prominent critics and invited guests.

After being out 11 hours and 15 minutes, a jury in General Sessions reported a disagreement last night as to a verdict in the trial of Mrs. Hilda M. Peterson, 40 years old, and two officers of the Isco Service Corporation on a theft indictment growing out of fake stock transactions by her fugitive husband, William F. Peterson.

Set three acts of a drama in a court room and it takes a devil of a fellow to keep it interesting. Yet that is what Edward Wooll has done in "Libel," which arrived at Henry Miller's last evening. He and the impeccable actors whom Gilbert Miller has gathered have rendered a perplexing trial scene into a skillfully told and dexterously acted stage entertainment.
The sports world warn inundated by a tidal wave of surprises this year, the greatest of which was the Chicago Cubs' twenty-one-game winning streak and drive to the National League pennant.

The fifteen-day meeting last October of the Empire City Racing Association, which concluded the sport for 1935 in New York, was the most successful ever conducted at the Yonkers track, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission.

A renewed flow of gold from Paris to New York became probable yesterday when the franc dropped once more below the gold-import point. Continuing to weaken on predictions that Premier Laval might be upset as a result of the collapse of the Italo-Ethiopian peace plan, the French currency dropped to 6.58 7/8 cents and closed there, off 5/8 point.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20. -- The Tamiami Purse, a one-mile test for 3-year-olds and upward, resulted in a Chicago triumph for Mrs. Emil Denemark when Brown Feathers, a $6.60-for-$2 chance, moved past the judges two lengths in front today at Tropical Park.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $7,247,133, and is represented by fifty-three loans. The sharp curtailment in activity reflects the holiday influence. The new financing compares with a revised total of $32,016,389 for this week.
LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The announcement to shipping agents today of the minimum fares for the Queen Mary indicates that the new Cunard White Star liner will be rated a cabin ship.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- Despite the complete failure of his projected plan for settlement of the ItaloEthiopian dispute, Premier Pierre Laval has not felt called on to follow the example of his British colleague, Sir Samuel Hoare, and resign.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Excepting independent strength in the December delivery from changing over hedges into the May future, trading in wheat was extremely dull today on the Chicago Board of Trade. At times the December acted tight and went to 3 1/4 cents premium on the May, at which difference it closed at a gain of 1/2 cent for the day, while May ended unchanged and July 1/4 cent lower.

Walter Kinsella, former world's squash tennis champion who retired undefeated after reigning supreme for eleven years, and his pupil, William E. Coyle, holder of the New York State title, made an impressive start yesterday in the opening matches of the invitation pro-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Inquiry into the death of Thelma Todd turned tonight to a suicide theory.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 20. -Identified as the slayer of Walter W. Liggett by two eye-witnesses, Isadore ("Kid Cann") Blumenfeld, sales manager of a liquor firm, was indicted today by the Hennepin County grand jury on a charge of first degree murder.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and the Netherlands, affecting Netherlands in Europe and the Netherlands Indies, Surinam and Curacao, was signed today by Secretary Hull and Arnold Theodoor Lamping, director of trade agreements of The Netherlands Government.

Pink and silver was the color scheme of the dinner dance given last night in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton by Mr. and Mrs. Herschel V. Williams of New Orleans to introduce their daughter, Miss Dorothy Pratt Williams, to their New York friends.

ASi~SARA, Eritrea, Dec. 20.--AnItalian eyewitness to the three-daybattle of the Takkaze related todaythat Ethiopian warriors, despitetheir reputed penchant for hand-to!hand fighting, fled in terror "wheni they came within cold steel fightingran ge."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

Te St. Ann's Academy quintet registered its second victory in as many circuit games by routing Cathedral Boys High, 32-17, on the latter's court in the only Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. contest played yesterday. After being held to a 12-8 margin at the intermission, the winners flashed a powerful offensive in the next two quarters to score handily.

A few minutes after George Le Boutillier, operating vice president of the Long Island Railroad, had finished defending the cut in maintenance costs yesterday morning, his interrogator, Maurice Hotchner, stopped abruptly and asked if he were aware that school children had just been killed in a grade crossing accident at Holbrook, L.I.

A man who recently had lost his job, and school children eager on the eve of Christmas to help children less fortunate than themselves, were among the 395 contributors who added $10,721.43 yesterday to the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases.
At the present time there are more than a quarter of a million pupils enrolled in the public high schools here, and of this number not even a score are studying Greek.

TOKYO, Dec. 20. -- Japanese dispatches from Hsinking, the capital of Manchukuo, assert the clash between Japanese-Manchukuoan and Outer Mongolian troops did not occur on Mongolian territory, as asserted in Moscow reports of the affair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- An enlarged wheat export quota, probably about 125,000,000 bushels annually, may be demanded by the United States at the forthcoming World Wheat Conference as this country's price for continued cooperation with the principal wheat producing nations toward maintaining prices for the staple at present profitable levels, agricultural officials said today.

Comparative fibres on Christmas trade in the metropolitan area made a better showing this week than that indicated in the Federal Reserve report for the first half of the month, reports from retail executives yesterday indicated. Increases over a year ago were noted, supporting the belief that the results for the entire holiday period will show a gain over 1934.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 20 (AP). -- A smartly played round of 65, that slashed three strokes from par figures, enabled Tom Creavy of Albany, N.Y., to take the early lead today in the annual $5,000 British Colonial open golf tournament.

One of the largest of many debutante parties yesterday was the supper dance given at the Ritz-Carlton by Mrs. E. J. Selby Tanner of this city and Wilton, Conn., to introduce her daughter, Miss M. Selby Tanner.

Five men armed with submachine guns and pistols robbed the First National Bank in Fort Lee, N.J., at 10 o'clock yesterday morning and escaped with $17,300 in a new sedan stolen the night before from a garage in Palisades Park.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 19 (Delayed). -- Following extensive air scouting in the northeast yesterday, five Italian reconnaissance planes flew over Lake Haik, twenty miles northeast of Dessye, near the Makale road at 8:30 this morning. After a survey of the area, which Emperor Selassie visited last week, they returned in the direction of Assab, Eritrea.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The FivePower Naval Conference, after a two-hour session today devoted chiefly to hearing Japanese criticism of the British proposal for limitation by a voluntary declaration of naval building programs, took adjournment until Jan. 6.

Proposals for tax limitation such as those presented as well as those expected to be presented to the New York Legislature at its next session have been found to be impractical, former State Senator Seabury C. Mastick, chairman of the New York State Commission on Revision of Tax Laws, told members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York yesterday at a luncheon in the Bankers Club.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Hans Kare Theodore Ludwig von Flotow, former diplomat, died here today at the age of 73. He entered the Foreign Service in 1892 and had occupied posts at Paris, Washington, The Hague and the Vatican.

Most commodity futures advanced moderately in light trading here yesterday. Coffee, rubber and cocoa futures declined. On the cash markets, all the grains, cotton, lard and silk advanced, while rubber declined.

Joseph McGinn of 45 Parade Place, Brooklyn, is still getting the $100 monthly wages he originally received as a CWA worker despite the fact that his wife, Mrs. Florence McGinn, receives $500 monthly from a trust fund, pays $95 a month rent and owns an automobile, it was disclosed yesterday in the City Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- An early determination of the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Control Act, another important phase of the New Deal program, was urged by the government upon the Supreme Court today while the nine justices were hearing closing arguments upon the Tennessee Valley Authority.

About 2,500 needy children of lower Manhattan were guests yesterday at the annual Christmas party and entertainment at the New York Curb Exchange. Santa Claus, impersonated by Otto Williams, was there with a well-filled bag and a generous hand.

MADISON, N.J., Dec. 20. -- Christmas decoration provided the background at Morris County Golf Club this evening for a supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Cook of Ridgedale Avenue and the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of Madison Avenue to introduce their daughters, Miss Nancy Nickerson Cook and Miss Emily Benedict McAlpin.

President ROOSEVELT told the newspaper correspondents yesterday that he is considering a plan to transfer what remains of the once mighty NRA to several established agencies of the Government. There they would rest at least until next April 1, when the law extending NRA in "skeleton" form expires.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- Interoffice communications, to which the Public Service Commission had no access, clearly proved the obsolescence of a gas plant belonging to the Syracuse Lighting Company of the Niagara Hudson system, according to testimony given before the Mack utility investigating committee by Walter H. Seymour, the committee's assistant chief accountant.

ROME, Dec. 20. -- The Grand Council of Fascism, which met tonight under the chairmanship of Premier Benito Mussolini to consider "the political situation that has been brought about by Great Britain's repudiation of the Paris peace proposals," issued after more than three hours discussion a communique in which no definite statement was made of the decisions taken.

Commercial nations in competition with the United States have placed a variety of handicaps in the way of American ship lines serving their ports, according to Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, shipping operators. Mr. Lee returned to his desk yesterday from a business trip to England, France, Germany, Norway, Poland and Sweden.

Manhattan College staved off a gallant second-half rally by a fighting St. Francis quintet to remain in the ranks of the unbeaten, prevailing by 36 to 28 in a fast contest before a near-capacity crowd of 1,200 persons at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 20. -- Police discovered early this morning an arsenal at the home of Luis Morones, near Tlalpam, Federal District, arresting two who were taking out guns in suitcases bearing the initials of Morones.

A high authority on land economics, Professor RICHARD T. ELY, tells of a recent personal experience which is pertinent at this season of New England Society celebrations of Forefathers' Day. In 1934 he with an associate made a little study of foreclosures up and down the Connecticut River, inquiring of the town clerks in the places visited.

For the eleventh year, the choristers of the Mount Holyoke College Glee Club appeared last night at the Town Hall, under the direction of its founder, Dr. William Churchill Hammond, head of the college's Music Department; and as in previous years, its members -- 123 voices -- joyously sang Christmas carol of many countries and of many centuries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Led by a continued advance in the durable goods industry, until recently laggard in the march toward recovery, factory employment and payrolls made the best showing in November for that month since 1925, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 20. -- In pursuance of its new policy to sell wheat at the world price rather than hold for a premium, the Canadian Wheat Board has sent a representative to Great Britain to promote good-will among British importers.

Floor members of the New York Stock Exchange, who since the inauguration of the many reports required by the Securities and Exchange Commission have found their day extended several hours on many occasions as a result, will be relieved today of some of their most burdensome tasks.

HOLBROOK, L.I., Dec. 20. -Three children were killed here at 8 A.M. today when a Long Island Railroad express train traveling between sixty and sixty-five miles an hour struck a school bus at the Broadway grade crossing. The crossing is unprotected except for a "Stop, Look and Listen" sign on the southwest corner.

GENEVA. Dec. 21. -- Information obtained from a well-informed source and confirmed in two reliable independent quarters -- all three of different nationalities -- throws serious new light on the Hoare-Laval peace plan, on the debate on it in the British Parliament and on the present diplomatic situation.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21. -- Completing a triple to take a commanding lead over Wayne Wright in their battle for riding honors on the American turf, Charley Stevenson of Boise, Idaho, today guided F. Ianni's Biff, 2-1 shot, to victory in the six-furlong handicap which topped the Fair Grounds program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Two expeditions were to start from regions on opposite sides Of Antarctica today to search for Lincoln Ellsworth, explorer, and his Canadian pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, who have not been heard from since they started a flight over the Antarctic last month.

POPLARVILLE, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP). -- The latchstring was out today on one of Mississippi's proudest mansions as United States Senator Theodore G. Bilbo opened his Juniper Grove "dream house" to hundreds of his friends.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Forty-four football stars, the pick of collegiate gridirons of 1935, assembled today to prepare for the annual East-West charity game on New Year's Day.

Although retail trade fell below expectations in several sections last week, most areas continued to report record-breaking totals. The wholesale markets showed some seasonal easing, but automobile sales continued to forge ahead, while new construction substantially exceeded 1934 figures.

IN his introduction Charles Francis Potter, outstanding exponent of the humanist philosophy, or religion, or way of life -- it seems to be any one of these or even a mixture of all three -- quotes from an article on the psychology of feeling in the Encyclopaedia Britannica this concluding sentence: "The true science of applied hedonics is not yet born," explaining that "applied hedonics" is "professorial slang for the art or technique of happiness."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 21. -- At the conclusion late this afternoon of a long and thorough test through the covers on land and in the turbulent waters of Long Island Sound, nine dogs were named for the second series of the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, to be started at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Director Robert Fechner said today the Civilian Conservation Corps had planted 222,000,000 trees this year in national forests, bringing to half a billion the number since the corps was founded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Under the supervision of the Census Bureau, about 35,000 enumerators recruited from white-collar relief rolls will begin a census of American business on Jan. 2. Twice before -- in the distribution census of 1929 and in the census of American business in 1933 -- the bureau has taken a similar census.

Final court decisions on appeal that turn upon questions which were not raised are uncommon to tax cases. The United States Supreme Court holds, in a recent decision, that where the Board of Tax Appeals rules upon an agreed statement of facts submitted by the parties to a proceeding the Circuit Court of Appeals must confine its review to the board's findings of fact and to the particular question presented to the board for determination.

I read with interest the difficulties encountered by Clifford Odets in his search for expression. The purpose of the musical reference was not quite clear. Is his citation of the forty-one symphonies another way of giving Mozart a Bronx cheer, or does he intimate that Beethoven is the greater for only having composed nine ;major works?

WITHOUT recourse to properties common to the mass of Westerns, in a tone singularly restrained, this novel tells the story of two Sierra gold-prospecting partners, Jule, an old stager nearing 70, and Arroyo Jones, younger by half those years, during the vicissitudes they share in conflict with a crooked East erner seeking by diverse shady means to trim them.

An increase of $818,995 in receipts from the State tax on alcoholic beverages for the first four months of the current fiscal year compared with the same period in 1934 is reported in the current ABC News, publication of the State Liquor Authority.
Al Smith dipped into his memory last week and pulled out this:

WALKING on country highways where automobiles speed has been recognized as a genuine hazard by those who are engaged in the campaign to reduce driving accidents. Among the remedies proposed is the building of footpaths and sidewalks along rural roads frequented by motorists.

IT is, of course, not only desirable but imperative that teachers should be loyal to the principles of government and of personal rights set forth in the Constitution of the United States and of the State in which they teach. It is, however, not only undesirable but extremely harmful to impose upon them such oaths as have lately been established by the Legislatures of several States.

Dolls made of wishbones, wood and mud from the Nile are included in a collection of more than 400 to go on display at 3 P.M. Friday for the benefit of the visiting nurse service of the Henry Street Settlement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Five elderly women, famous because their fathers fought in the Revolutionary War, are now receiving their annual Christmas-card shower from D.A.R. chapters.

PROGRESSIVE development of interest in an organization which functions primarily in the interest of safety and efficiency, the Air Line Maintenance Committee, was plainly manifest at its conference in Miami, held during the period of the annual air races. More than ninety persons attended the three days of meetings at that conference.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21. -- During the wedding of Miss Elizabeth Ross Duncan to Edward E. Yaggy Jr. of New York Saturday, jewels belonging to her, valued at $11,500, were stolen from Blythewood, home of her father, Alexander E. Duncan. There were 300 guests at the reception at the home which followed the wedding and two detectives were in the house all the time.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Many dances will be held in Westchester County this week for members of the younger set who have come home for the holidays from schools and colleges.
RADIO'S whirligig spins so fast at this season that only the outstanding events, the most brilliant broadcasts of the year, may be discerned through the blurred streaks of speed.

AMERICAN transcontinental highways are furnishing the inspiration for the first trans-European motor road from London and Calais to Istanbul, which is expected to be finished by 1938. Once it is completed, motorists will be able to cross Europe to Istanbul and return in a month, with ample time for sightseeing along the way.

Performances of "Victoria Regina," with Helen Hayes, at the Broadhurst Theatre, have been taken over to raise funds for various charitable organizations. Members of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Union Settlement have assumed the play for next Friday night. Mrs. Edwin M. Bulkley heads the benefit committee.

Stanley Galowin of the City A.C. and Albert E. Watt of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club advanced to the final, round yesterday in the second annual Long Island championship squash racquets tournament on the courts of the Bayside Tennis Club at Bayside, L.I.

ATHENS, Dec. 21. -- Through Sir Sidney Waterlow, her Minister here, Great Britain sounded Greece today to determine to what extent the present pro-British government would support armed measures against Italy.
Thirty-eight years ago, when a sympathetic editorial writer assured her that there was a Santa Claus, 8-year-old Laura Virginia O'Hanlon sighed with relief, believed him and thought no more about it.

Winter begins officially today. For thousands of shivering New Yorkers, however, there was no doubt of its unofficial presence yesterday. Sub-freezing temperatures throughout the day, made more uncomfortable by a biting northwest wind, gave the city its share of a cold spell that gripped other parts of the United States from the Middle West to the North Atlantic seaboard.
BERLIN. -- National Socialist Germany has resumed its effort to free itself from the dictatorship of Paris stylemakers.
BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- "The Children's Hour" is banned in Boston, and there has been plenty of irate comment but no mass meeting of protest.

LAST year, while J.B. Priestley was publishing a candid survey of depressed Britain called "English Journey," Sir Philip Gibbs was setting out to look at the Continent in a mellower spirit that resulted in a book he called "European Journey."

The New York State Department of Labor publicly confessed this week that it was wrestling with a Problem. Are boxers and wrestlers "manual workers"? The problem is not academic. For under the Byrne-Killgrew law only "non-manual" workers earning $50 a week or less are eligible for unemployment insurance, though "manual" workers are covered no matter how high their pay.
THE designation "Soldier of Fortune" is an ancient one. Captain Howard Hartman appears to have been a Sailor of Fortune.

ISTANBUL, Dec. 21. -- The new Turkish aim to make the country self-sufficient is slowly but surely being achieved. She has the necessary agricultural products and foodstuffs in abundance and here, mainly, it is a question of organization.

WHAT between red tape and copyright troubles, it has taken over five years for the History of Music, devised and edited by Percy Scholes for the English Columbia Company, to receive its final naturalization papers.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The ancient maxim that "the law allows a dog his first bite" is challenged by Judge Michael M. Musmanno.

Six American colleges in the Near East will be aided by a special performance of "Madame Butterfly," with Susanne Fisher, Richard Crooks and Richard Bonelli in the leading roles, Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The institutions that will be the beneficiaries of the performance are Robert College, the American University of Beirut, the American College of Sofia, Athens College, Istanbul Woman's College and International College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- New gargoyles are peeping out over the doorways of the Labor Department building, the Capitol has a new coat of paint, the statues on the Mall at the entrance to Capitol Park are fresh-bathed and luminous as snow creatures.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- The most colorful ceremony Madrid has seen since the advent of the republic occurred today when President Niceto Alcala Zamora, Premier Manuel Portela Valladares and all other members of the Cabinet as well as the entire diplomatic corps witnessed the presentation of the Red Hat of a Cardinal to Mgr. Flerico Tedeschini, Papal Nuncio, by Count Maximo Aluffi, a special Vatican envoy.
