JERUSALEM, Dec. 21. -- Sir Grenfell Wauchope, High Commissioner of Palestine, summoned Arab leaders today and presented to them a memorandum outlining the features of the proposed Legislative Council of Palestine. The preface to the memorandum states that in view of the fact that municipalities are now functioning smoothly the time is ripe for the establishment of the Council.

DALLAS, Dec. 21. -- Snow, sleet and biting temperatures, unlike the weather they expect in their Rose Bowl clash against Stanford's Indians on New Year's Day, drove Southern Methodist's Mustangs beneath the protecting shelter of the stadium today.

No serious break in municipal bond prices appears imminent, and it seems probable that these issues will stay close to their present levels for some time before easing off slowly. This is the gist of conclusions drawn by Derby Co., Inc. following a study of the price trend of State and municipal bonds since 1897.

Columbia and Seth Low met yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club in the fifth round for the championship of the New York City Intercollegiate Chess Association, Seth Low winning by the score of 3 -- 1.
AT St. Lawrence University students participate in every phase of radio broadcasting. The university's own radio station is used as a classroom to train students and develop radio technique.

The recent successful refunding operations, together with the reversion to old contract rates with farmers in July, 1938, will result in substantially increased earnings for the Federal Land Bank System, according to Judge Charles E. Lobdell of Lobdell Co., former farm loan commissioner.

A sharp about-face in form in the second half saved the City College quintet from an upset last night as the Lavender, riding high on the wings of a fourteen-point scoring splurge, conquered Dartmouth, 36 to 24, at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium.

NINETEEN hundred and many years ago, when shepherds watched their flocks by night, a glory shone around a little family, hovering about a new-born Babe lying in a manger in a mean stable. And bright in the sky above gleamed a star. Through many centuries since then lights have burned in the house at Christmastide for a sign and token of peace and good-will to men.

LONDON is devoting itself to pantomime and juvenile entertainments these days, the most important of which will open at the Palladium on Thursday. "Peter Pan," of course, with the 16-year-old Nova Pilbeam making her debut in place of Jean Forbes-Robertson.

WHAT the Fund can do for the Neediest of 1935 is indicated by the good that was accomplished for last year's cases. The records of the charitable organizations participating in the Appeal show that the majority of the Neediest of 1934, thanks to the aid given through the Fund, have been restored.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- How long Premier Pierre Laval can remain in office after the collapse of his Ethiopian peace plan will be answered within the next few days. His policy was a personal one. As he presented it, it got the support of the Paris press and of some large interests.

FLOWERING and fruiting plants that are used to adorn the home during the holidays bring a special problem to the indoor gardener. With proper attention their beauty and usefulness can be prolonged considerably. Some kinds can even be made to flourish in the house.

SOME one is always, as has been so accurately stated some time in the past, taking the joy out of life. There is more than passing significance in the word from Washington of a War Department ruling that in the future officers of the army assigned to R.O.T.C. (Reserve Officers Training Corps) duty in civil colleges will not be permitted to coach teams where that coaching interferes with their duties as R.O.T.C. officers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A recent speech by Senator Pittman at Las Vegas, N.M., in which he pictured war between Japan and the United States as a distinct possibility, was characterized today as "absurd" by Hirosi Saito, Japanese Ambassador.

OF all the wild-eyed, battered and thwarted geniuses that the world has scourged through wretched and unhappy lives devoted to its service the man whose story this book tells was surely the queerest, most ill-used, most absurd, most hampered and frustrated.

A decision blocking a hearing by the Court of Appeals on a ruling which permitted Harry Scott to be elected Mayor of New Rochelle by voters who wrote in his name on the ballots was made public yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department, in Brooklyn.

If the Republicans are to win the 1936 election they must state "without straddling or equivocation" what they propose to do when they return to power, declares Representative Theodore Christianson, three times Republican Governor of Minnesota, in an article entitled "A Program for Republicans," in January Current History.

With new records being set for travel to and from the city, and the season's spirit of gift-giving reflected in a last-minute rush of buying which must be crowded into the two remaining shopping days, the city's Christmas activities are fairly under way.

THE annual dispute about tickets is on again, the holidays giving it special emphasis. Reports sift in that the racketeering aspect of ticket speculation is back in town, with some brokers charging a premium of $2 or more per ticket.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Miss Edar von Lengerke Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Fleming, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert, F. Fleming, at their home in Edgemoor, Md.

CHESS has a new world's champion, and devotees of the game are discussing the upset of Dr. Alexander Alekhine by Dr. Max Euwe, in the recently concluded series of games in the Netherlands. "Surprising" is not too strong a word to apply to the outcome of the match.

PRAGUE, Dec. 21. -- Wednesday's election of Dr. Eduard Benes as President to succeed his mentor, Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, strikes an unusually calm and reassuring note amid the cacophony of the present unmelodious European concert.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 21. -- If allowed to vote for President of the United States today, a plurality of Rutgers University students would choose Franklin D. Roosevelt, it was indicated today by the results of a poll published in the Targum, undergraduate newspaper, this week.

WHEN one speaks by radio-phone into the emptiness of space he broadcasts into a world-wide whispering gallery in which he never knows who may be listening, how many are in tune or where his words may fall to earth.

IN his introduction to Smollett's "Adventures of Peregrine Pickle" (Limited Editions Club), G.K. Chesterton declares that so few moderns have read it that "it must now be introduced as a new rather than an old book."

A FEW weeks ago I leaned over the side of a ship off the coast of Ireland watching the fuguelike patterns woven in the air by gulls. As I tried to absorb the bewildering complexity of dip and twist and curve I found myself longing for some permanent record of these changing shapes, some photographs or moving pictures to which I could later turn.

Just 162 years ago today -- on Dec. 22, 1773 -- there clattered into New York a tall, travel-stained horseman who had made the 243-mile trip from Boston in five days, bearing an important message. The man was the Boston goldsmith, Paul Revere, and he carried to New York the first news of the Boston Tea Party.

CHINA is so remote and remained for so many centuries isolated from the rest of the world that we might expect its art to be difficult of approach and hard to appreciate. Its civilization has no common origin with Western civilization, and contacts have been few.
A Christmas cable message to the American people from General Evangeline Booth, international head of the Salvation Army, has been made public here by the Army. It follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A decision on some of the New Deal litigation argued in the last two weeks was generally believed tonight to have been reached by the Supreme Court.

Military reward came yesterday to two American World War veterans for deeds of heroism performed more than seventeen years ago. A colorful open-air ceremony in their honor was conducted at Governors Island.
Regarding the passage in John iii, 8, discussed by several correspondents in your paper:

Carrying out the traditions of the family, Mrs. Robert R. Livingston gave an old-fashioned reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 11 Washington Square North, to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Catherine L. Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howland S. Davis.

THE fate of Sir Walter Raleigh's lost colony in Virginia is something that has stimulated the imagination of more than one historical novelist; and it will probably go right on doing so, notwithstanding the scores of conjectures which have already been advanced. Clifford Wayne ( Continued on Page 14 )
An echo of pre-depression days rang through the sports world in 1935.

The joint statement issued in Washington last Wednesday by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve and the system's open-market committee, indicating that no immediate action to reduce excess bank reserves was contemplated, was regarded in Wall Street as the most important pronouncement of Federal Reserve policy in years.

There are different ways for an opera singer to say farewell. One is to say it and not retire, of which there have been various illustrious examples. It is to be feared that Miss LUCREZIA BORI means what she says, and that the present season at the Metropolitan Opera House will be her last.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- George N. Peek declared today in a radio address on a National Grange program that agriculture "is being asked to take the rap" in the reciprocal trade pact with Canada.

December business conditions were unchanged in the East this month but showed gains in all other sections, according to the report made public yesterday by the Business Survey Committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

" A penetrating analysis of the fears of young children" and means of overcoming those fears are included in a study published by Drs. Arthur T. Jersild and Frances B. Holmes of the Child Development Institute of Teachers College, Columbia University.

THE delightful old custom of associating holly and mistletoe and the yule log with Christmas is being broadened to admit other decorative items. This is the result of an increasing garden information, and especially of an improvement of taste in the use of ornamental living material.

Unmindful of his opponent's great reputation, 25-year-old James Caras of Wilmington, Del., fought his way back into the running for the world's pocket billiard championship last night by turning the tables on the veteran Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, 125 to 21, and bringing about a deadlock with the Middle Westerner for top honors as the regular tournament at the Hotel Pennsylvania came to a close.
WARWICK, R.I., Dec. 21 (AP). -- A mother and two daughters she tried to save died today as flames destroyed their home. Her husband was seriously burned in rescuing two sons.

WHEN Rosa Ponselle assumes the role of Carmen for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House next Friday evening, her audience will include a host of singers who were once Carmen themselves. There will be Maria Gay, who did the cigarette girl of Seville in the first season of Mr. Gatti-Casazza's regime in 1908-09.

THE essence of Christmas, that dual festival that Tennyson called both "human and divine," is a story -- a story told more often than any other in fact or fiction in the world. It is told at the bedsides of children, preached as sermon in the pulpit, sung in the streets in carols of joy and in the churches in majestic music of adoration.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Laborites made an unsuccessful attempt in the House of Commons yesterday, to have the House reassemble Jan. 21 instead of Feb. 4. They fear a coal strike called for Jan. 27 might start if negotiations fail.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Observers scanning this Fall's Supreme Court opinions for a possible "trend" in view of forthcoming New Deal decisions noted today that the justices had been divided in thirteen and unanimous in thirty-three.

Settlement of the difficulties which recently have threatened to cause a strike of 105,000 workers in the dress industry of New York City was predicted by spokesmen for manufacturers' groups yesterday while representatives of the union and the employers continued negotiations for a new agreement to take the place of the old one expiring Jan. 31.

AMONG the current exhibitions in New York that should on no account be missed is the one-man show of drawings by Eilshemius, which will be at the Valentine Gallery until Jan. 4. They are for the most part beautiful drawings, the subject matter chiefly landscape, although figures are frequently introduced and a few of the drawings concern themselves entirely with portraiture.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Dr. W.D. MacMillan, mathematical astronomer at the University of Chicago for thirty years, said today that science had no record of the Star of Bethlehem.

Traditional orthodox Judaism is in principle opposed to birth control, according to Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein of the Institutional Synagogue, in a statement issued yesterday in view of the pronouncements of the Protestant and Reformed Jewish clergy and of the Catholic Church on the subject.

Debutantes, headed by Miss Phyllis Konta, are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the recital by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, the night of Jan. 14 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the educational work of the Women's Trade Union League of New York. Serving with Miss Konta are:

WORK is progressing on the moving of concrete slabs on N.J. 26 to provide space for a safety island in the middle, as pictured above. On the left are the northbound lanes of the road which are carrying all traffic while operations are in progress.

The performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was the finest achievement of an uneven and very interesting opening week. Not every one in the cast attained the heights achieved, for example, by Mme. Lehmann and Mr. Melchior, but all the members of an uncommonly strong cast contributed with fine earnestness and sincerity to a common aim, inspired by real understanding and reverence for the composer-dramatist's purpose.

Brooklyn College bowed to Columbia's wrestling team yesterday in the Columbia gymnasium by a score of 16 to 14. Although each team won four bouts on decisions, the Lions registered two falls to one for the losers.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Frost, in some cases accompanied by fog, caused postponement of eight English league soccer games today and another was abandoned ten minutes before the end. All grounds were hard and slippery and the brand of football displayed suffered accordingly.

Bonds moved narrowly in typically dull week-end trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange. High-grade corporate issues, as well as United States Government loans, were virtually ignored, with the few that did exchange hands showing only minor price fluctuations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20. -- Just a year before repeal of prohibition the voters of California adopted a constitutional amendment on an if-and-when basis providing that liquor might be sold only with meals and placing control with the State Board of Equalization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A large-scale housing program in the United States will accomplish three major objectives. First and foremost, it will provide better living quarters for millions of our people who now dwell in dismal and unhealthful surroundings.

The majority of the season's debutantes and their young men friends, who had been at various dinner dances earlier in the evening, attended the annual interschool and college dance last night in the Cascades of the Biltmore.

THE usual pomp and parade accompanied the recent opening of the Barcelona opera season at the Gran Teatre del Liceu with a rehearing of Rimsky's "Invisible City of Kitej," a repertory favorite here. Michel Steiman got good results from the theatre's orchestra and a Russian troupe in which the tenor Possemkovsky, as Grishka, was outstanding.

This book may well be hailed as a blessing by teachers and parents who are urging young people in their teens through the dreary wastes of Caesar's Commentaries, for in this full-bodied tale of ample proportions Paul Anderson instills a vitality into the people and life of that period which will be astounding to bored young Latin students.

THE industry is awaiting with considerable interest the result of Walter Wanger's initial effort with outdoor color pictures. "The Trail of the Lonesome Pine" is being cut and should be ready for preview following the holidays.

In the death house of the New Jersey State Prison at Trenton, Bruno Richard Hauptmann is this week facing the last moves in his fight to escape the electric chair. Within the next ten days the Court of Pardons, for him the court of last resort, will listen to his petition for commutation of the death sentence.

SIXTY foreign-born women, most of them mothers, are launched this Winter on high school studies in the first classes of their kind ever organized in the United States and perhaps in the world. Each is a graduate of the Day Classes for Adults in English and Citizenship which were started twenty years ago with a half-dozen students and which have grown until the present registration is about 9,000 in 196 separate classes.
HE is George Westbrook -- the man whom Julian Dana names in his title "Samoa's greatest adventurer" -- and for sixty years he has been roaming the tropic islands of the Pacific.

Business corporations will no longer be permitted to place funds in so-called "savings accounts" of member-banks of the Federal Reserve System under regulations recently issued by the board of governors of the system. The new policy will become effective on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Stock Exchange here was closed today. The price of gold was lower at 141s 1/2d, with 90,000 of the metal sold. The silver market was closed. The money market was quiet, loans were in fair demand at one-half of 1 per cent.

W. Francklyn Paris gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza for his son and daughter-in-law. Mr. and Mrs. Francklyn Wynne Paris. Lady Butler, widow of Sir Geoffrey Butler, former Member of British Parliament, was to have assisted the host and his guests of honor in receiving, but was unable to be present owing to illness in her family.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- Pierce Brauen, master hand weaver who creates many exclusive fabrics for Paris couturiers, is preparing interesting novelties for the coming season. Scotch plaids have inspired him to make luxurious Summer travel rugs of pure silk.

THE papers comprising this volume represent the revised versions of a series of addresses, and in spite of Professor Cooper's efforts "to reduce the more obvious marks of oral delivery to a minimum," they are written with a conversational discursiveness that betrays the method of their origin.

THERE will be two "Eastern championship" tournaments in 1936, and both will be held in New York. Beginning on Tuesday, Jan. 28, the United States Bridge Association will hold its Eastern national tournament -- the "Atlantic" -- at the Park Central Hotel.

A DISCUSSION between Diego Rivera and Thomas Hart Benton on "Art and the Social Struggle" is a feature of The University Review, journal of the University of Kansas City, in the recently published Winter number.

Swimmers of De Witt Clinton High School shattered the season's interborough record for the 200-yard relay and the George Washington team scored a narrow victory over Evander Childs at the tenth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public Schools Athletic League, conducted yesterday in the 75-foot Clinton pool.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 21. -- Syracuse University's basketball team routed Harvard tonight, 40 to 20, before a crowd of about 500. It was the third defeat this week for the Crimson, which also bowed to Dartmouth and Cornell.

With thousands of shoppers crowding leading department, specialty and other stores in the metropolitan area, Christmas trade reached its peak here yesterday. In holiday mood, the crowds spent somewhat more freely than earlier in the month and store executives reported an improved demand for better merchandise.

ANADARKO, Okla., Dec. 21 (AP). -- An 18-year-old farm girl who resented paternal objections to her having a date with a boy friend was charged with murder today after her father, Harry Willis, 45, died of shotgun wounds. The farmer apparently was killed while asleep.

A benefit card party and raffle for Dorothea Antel, invalid actress known as the "Sunshine Girl," was given yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Al Goodman, wife of the orchestra conductor, at the Goodman apartment, 115 Central Park West. More than $800 was raised.

SALES of passenger cars in November in the New York metropolitan area increased by 6,535 over November of last year, representing a gain of approximately 150 per cent, according to a survey by Sherlock Arnold, Inc., made public last week by the Automobile Merchants Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Approval of thirty-one additional work relief projects calling for an expenditure of $871,958.78 was announced today by Lester W. Herzog, up-State Works Progress Administrator.

THE southlands have beckoned with a golden finger to golf professionals and they are away on the annual trek which leads from Florida to California. Tournaments with prizes totaling $50,000 and, incidentally, soft-rolling, sun-swept greens, are the lures which have called the swinging brigade away from snow- covered home links.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Following the New York-Connecticut liquor war, D. Frederick Burnett, Alcoholic Beverage Control Commissioner of New Jersey, issued a warning today that New Jersey limits the amount of liquor which may be brought into the State without obtaining a permit and payment of taxes and a fee.

The Drivers of Tomorrow. IT has often been remarked that whereas a locomotive engineer must pass through years of instruction and practice before he is entrusted with a train, any one able to grasp a few rudimentary ideas from a friend may obtain a license to drive an automobile.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Kelly Petillo, Italian driver from Huntington Park, Calif., who won the 1935 Indianapolis speedway race, is ranked No. 1 in the national automobile racing championship standings by the contest board of the American Automobile Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- In a long step toward building up the Army Air Corps with funds appropriated for the present fiscal year, the War Department today announced award of contracts for 103 of the most modern bombers known to the United States.
LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The naval conference prepared to adjourn for the Christmas holidays this week without having come remotely near an agreement but with some achievement, at least, to its credit.

A MERRY CHRISTMAS! Things are brighter, the depression shadows are lifting. The holidays in most homes will be more joyful than they have been in five long years, and the lights of Christmas will gleam more cheerily.
Caleb J. Milne 4th was moved from the Doylestown (Pa.) General Hospital to his mother's home in Woodstock, N.Y., yesterday with a guard of six Federal agents.

A raid by Secret Service men on the offices of the National Union Postage Stamp Corporation at 27 Beaver Street uncovered a headquarters for counterfeit and stolen stamps, Captain William B. Houghton, agent in charge of New York Secret Service, announced yesterday.

THE New Yorker's bards of fashion and of mirth are wreathed here in a poetical garland so fine it makes one feel a little less badly about the burning of the library at Alexandria. It is the pleasantest anthology of verse that has appeared in a long time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Current reports reveal a continuation in the first half of December of the recent favorable trend in trade, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of business. Industrial production has continued at a relatively high level, and retail sales reports stress the favorable trend of Christmas buying.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21.-- Political manoeuvring rather than sound business management is reflected by the proposed 1936 Westchester County gross budget of $10,671,263.50, the Westchester County Taxpayers Association, composed of 8,200 property owners, charged today in a request that action be deferred until reductions can be arranged.

IN his current exhibition of paintings by Americans, Henry Kleemann has juxtaposed the pictures he has selected in such a way as to produce some striking contrasts. The artists no longer living who are here represented are Eakins, Hassam, Ryder and Luks.

To a Summer of hope in Alberta a Winter of discontent succeeds. The Government of the Province was given to Mr. ABERHART, novice in politics, but thought a wonder-worker in finance. He was to pay every citizen of legal age "a basic dividend" of $25 a month. Boundless as the resources of Social Credit are, he didn't promise a too expectant people an instantaneous monthly rain.

AT this season of merry-making there is nothing more attractive for a woman at home than white or lame -- silver or gold. The colors seem to enter into the festive spirit symbolized by lighted candles.

LOS ANGELES. -- The Colorado River Aqueduct, which has been called the greatest domestic water supply system in the history of engineering, is this month entering its fourth year of construction and is 25 per cent completed. Water will probably start to flow out of the Colorado and into Southern California, defying gravitation and overcoming mountains and deserts, in December, 1938.

OUTNUMBERED but not overawed by machines, handworkers in arts and crafts show this season in many exhibitions how attractive and useful are the wares they produce. These workers in ceramics, metal, wood and textiles still set an artistic and technical standard for all the accessories which go into home decoration.

ON the eve of his seventieth birthday Vienna has at last heard a few notes of Sibelius. On Dec. 1, at the first of his two Philharmonic concerts, Toscanini conducted "En Saga" between the world premiere of a new Shakespearean overture by Castelnuovo-Tedesco and the "Tannhaeuser" bacchanale.

With, the opening of Christmas Week the appeal for New York's Neediest Cases is continued today in Section 9 of THE NEW YORK TIMES by the publication of typical cases from a third hundred whose stories have not been told previously.

THIS is a collection of essays by writers on their own particular fields of composition. A rather mixed group is represented: Herbert Agar tells us of the importance of books on economics, more particularly -- since these are personal essays -- of how he feels about his own books.

ARNOLD BENNETT has provided more jobs for lawyers since his death than he did during his lifetime. In May last I reported a libel action brought against the publishers, editors and printers of his post-humous "Journals."

Miss Elizabeth Pearsall Russell made her debut last night at a Christmastide dinner dance in the Waldorf-Astoria given by her aunt, Mrs. George Edwin Steel, with whom she makes her home. Silvered cedar trees formed the background for the floral decorations, with holly and red candles on the various tables arranged in the Jade Room.

CANBERRA, Dec. 20. -- Several factors, not the least important being the expansion of American sir service in the Pacific, which will eventually reach New Zealand, have stimulated the interest of Federal Cabinet ministers in improving the England-Australia service which is now limited to semi-weekly trips.

WHEN Puritan New England was looking down its austere nose at Christmas, New Amsterdam was hanging Yuletide lanterns in its doorways, beacons of good-will and good cheer. Had not the good St. Nicholas, protector of sailors, brought the early Dutch in safety across the sea by virtue of his effigy on the ship's prow, becoming thereby the city's patron saint?

SAYBROOK, Conn., Dec. 21. -- Competing in intensely cold weather, five of the eight dogs entered survived the first series in the Game in the Bag Stake, which marked the opening of the two-day gun dog variety field trials today.

PERHAPS the most difficult problem in film criticism arises out of the conflict between the esthetic and the ethical impulses during certain types of pictures. Lenin and the Russians were not alone in understanding and exploiting the enormous power of the cinema as a weapon of propaganda.

LARGE-scale operations in the deepening and widening of the fourteen-mile-long, toll-free Chesapeake and Delaware Canal were assured recently when 1,200 workers were taken off the home relief rolls to speed up this $12,500,000 Federal project.

THIS novel offers stout support to the theory that privacy is a commodity more generously supplied in big cities than in lonely country places. Willetts Lace and his young bride, Nancy, picked out an isolated cottage on the northeast coast as a likely spot for a two weeks' honeymoon of blissful solitude.

The distribution of approximately $70,000 among the music departments of seven women's colleges was announced yesterday by the officers of the Master School of Music of Brooklyn, which closed its career of thirty-one years on Dec. 13.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 21. -- Yin Jukeng's autonomous regime in Eastern Hopei will not merge with General Sung Cheh-yuan's Hopei-Chahar Political Council until an agreement has been reached on the use of provincial revenues, Major General Hayao Tada, Japanese commander in North China asserted here today.

THE increasing number of sales of cars that get their first highway tests under Winter weather has stirred both automobile manufacturers and dealers to give the utmost attention this year to the driving fitness of their models.

Miss Elsie Scheiding, secretary of the Alumnae Association of the Barnard School for Girls, is chairman of the dance under the auspices of the association which will be held Thursday evening at the Beekman Tower Hotel. Mrs. Theodore B. Morgan of New York, president of the organization, will head the receiving line.

An active wind-up of Christmas trade in many cities has brought volume to satisfactory levels, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. The extra two days' business before Christmas will further aid in establishing increases for most stores, the buying office notes.

ONCE again Christmas is here, with trees, Santa Claus, electric trains, Tiny Tim, Alexander Woollcott, turkey, Mickey Mouse lighters -- and special matinees in the Broadway theatres. For the holiday time also comes to Broadway and, filling its playhouses, brings to drama the most cheerful time of its year.

CONTRIBUTORS to the Fund for the Neediest write a living story of kindness year alter year in the letters that accompany their checks. Here are some characteristic expressions from this year's givers:

THE best operatic novelty lunched in Italy this Fall was the two-act lyric comedy of Marino Cremesini, "La Fiera," which had its premiere some days ago at the Teatro Verdi of this city. Luigi Bonelli's deftly versed libretto is based on the witty play of Giulio Bucciolini, "La Fiera dell'Impruneta," which is woven about the celebrated cattle fair of St. Luke's, held every October in L'Impruneta, the typical Tuscan hill village near Florence.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The appeal of Bruno Richard Hauptmann to the Court of Pardons for clemency probably will be filed here on Monday, it was said today by C. Lloyd Fisher of defense counsel.

THE coming week's concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will mark the final appearances of Otto Klemperer as conductor of the organization this season. Emanuel Feuermann, Viennese 'cellist, will be the soloist with the orchestra on Thursday and Friday in Schumann's concerto in A minor.

THE name of Franz Werfel, Austrian poet, is familiar to American ears because his novel "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" has taken the country by storm during the past year. Werfel has recently arrived in New York to help produce his new play, "The Eternal Road," under Max Reinhardt's direction.

Young women headed by the Misses Constance Looram and Barbara Field are in charge of arrangements for the annual tea dance under the auspices of the Junior Guild of New York on Thursday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Speedwell Society.
BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- Possible death or imprisonment was threatened today to farmers failing to observe Nazi milk marketing regulations.
CARDIFF, Wales, Dec. 21. -- Triumphant in a stirring battle between two great teams, Wales today gained its second international rugby triumph over New Zealand.
The letter of K. Sheridan Hayes does, of course, express the opinion of other writers to the press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission will hand down a decision in the near future drastically changing the basic railroad passenger fare structure throughout the United States, in its first major move to revive carrier earnings from that source, it was learned at that agency today.

ON the little fishing boats that go out to the fishing banks from Boston and Gloucester this is the season of ice in the rigging, cracked oilskins, frost- bitten fingers and toes, and rheumatism from sleeping in tightly shut quarters. It's all in the life of a deep-sea fisherman. Despite icebergs, gales and fogs, the little ships go out just the same.

Large industrial and individual gifts to the United Hospital Campaign were announced yesterday in the first list of contributors to be made public since the extension of the campaign until Jan. 10 to complete the raising of $2,000,000.

Dudley Field Malone, international lawyer and former Collector of the Port of New York, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the United States District Court. The petition, drawn by Arthur Stryker, his counsel, listed liabilities of $261,370.66 and assets of $62,500.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Here where their forefathers landed 315 years ago today to found New England's first permanent white settlement, Pilgrim descendants tonight invoked memories of that occasion at the traditional succotash banquet.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21. -- Congress approved this afternoon a measure declaring a state of war in the entire republic for ninety days.

HOLLY and evergreens wreathe the town. Christmas trees are on sale at the corner grocery, greetings are in the air and New York is ready again for the holiday menus. Good things for the Christmas feast come to New York from all over the world, a variety of traditional holiday fare ranging from gayly decorated gingerbread men to hang on the tree to the most potent of brandies to blaze from the Christmas pudding.

The city's public school children will have two extra days in their Christmas vacation this year, pursuant to a resolution adopted by the Board of Education adding tomorrow and Tuesday to the Yule holiday. Classes were dismissed on Friday and will not resume until Jan. 2.

When the national figure skating championships and Olympic team tryouts begin at the Ice Club Friday, interest will center on the junior skaters, whose rapid improvement in the last few months makes them serious contenders for Olympic berths.

WHEN Jim Jeffries encountered Jack Johnson to defend the heavyweight crown at Reno back in July, 1910, it was the next day in many cities before news of Johnson's victory spread through the populace. But that would not be true in 1935.

THE contributions of the University of North Carolina Press to the history of the South and to the social interpretation of that region as it is today have represented a notable service. The volumes which have issued from Chapel Hill have been marked by scholarship in their dealings with the past and by a courageous breadth of view in facing the social problems of the present.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 21. -- A top-flight field playing in the $5,000 British Colonial open discovered today there was still plenty of golf left in the angular frame of Willie Macfarlane.

CONSIDERABLE uncertainty seems to exist with respect to the precise meaning of the term "genre." Karl Lilienfeld, in the catalogue prepared for the College Art Association's traveling show of genre painting from the fifteenth century to the twentieth, which opened at the Lilienfeld Galleries, 21 East Fifty-seventh Street, last week, laments its having "so often been mistaken for 'illustrative painting.'"

VOTERS who succumb to the "share-the-wealth" theories of the newer brand of politician are more apt to be graduates of the sancrosanct "little red schoolhouse" than of the progressive school often criticized for its "fads and frills," according to Dean Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report made last week.

A closer union between the Socialist party and the trade union movement in formulating a militant labor program was urged yesterday afternoon by Norman Thomas, member of the national executive committee of the party, and eight other speakers at a meeting in the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street.

ONE of England's biggest and most famous railways, the Great Western, has been celebrating its centenary with a dignity befitting its age and importance, and incidents -- picturesque, dramatic and comic -- in its romantic history are being recalled.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- American newspapers were accused tonight by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, of conducting "an absurd and unfair" attack on President Roosevelt while their news columns herald a business revival which his "administration has brought about."

A gradual shift in the type of business being booked by steel companies is bringing operations of the plants of the United States Steel Corporation closer into line with that of the industry as a whole, according to steel executives.

MIAMI BEACH. -- Of outstanding interest among the many events scheduled at Christmas by the large Winter vacation throng now within the greater Miami area will be the singing of Handel's "Messiah" on Christmas night in Bay Front Park.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The Boerse closed quiet but firm today. Official commentators found increased activity, notably through the return of the banks to the floor. Harpener led the market with a rise of 2 1/4 points. Other heavy industrials were rather firm, Mannesmann and Mansfeld gaining 1/2 point each.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 21. -- According to messages received here, one of the strangest battles in the history of war was recently fought in the Takkaze River area. It is said airplanes proved useless, owing to the primitive methods of fighting.

Because of more stringent rules governing the giving of pups from its five shelters in the city as Christmas gifts, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, with headquarters at 50 Madison Avenue, announces that such gifts will not be so numerous this year.

IT is not always easy to find a Christmas gift to delight an adult. I want, therefore, to call your attention again to the albums called "Deutsche Kunst," of which brief mention was made here last Summer, and which are being brought out by the Angelsachsen Verlag of Bremen.

HOLLYWOOD. A FEW blocks from the boulevard the hills rise abruptly, their sage and scrub-oak covered sides clotted with holly trees. Some of the hills have been cleared of growth and mansions rise in the clearings.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- Unless the Conservative-Republican-Catholic leader, Jose Maria Gil Robles, overthrows the provisional interim Cabinet headed by Manuel Portela on the ground that it has no constitutional right to prolong the 1935 budget by decree, a general election will be held in Spain on Sunday, March 1, 1936.

Secretary of War Dern on landing at San Francisco is reported to have said: "The number of Japanese in the Philippines is increasing." The latest available reports give the total number of Japanese in the Philippines as 20,078 -- in a population of 12,000,000 Filipinos.

No quotations for silver were posted yesterday either here or in London, and indications were that the world silver market had gone on a five-day week basis for an indefinite period. The London market was closed because the developments of a week before had indicated that no purchases by the United States Treasury Department on Saturday could be looked for and, in the absence of such buying, quotations could, at best, be purely nominal.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 21. -- The lady chimpanzees of the Johns Hopkins Medical School got on the loose today and temporarily resumed primitive habits.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Trading in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade was slow today and prices held within narrow limits until near the close. Short covering in wheat then caused a mild flurry that lifted the December delivery to around 3 1/2 cent above the May, compared with 3 1/4 cents higher at yesterday's finish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A special study by the Census Bureau showed today that a person is less likely to be killed by some one else in New England and less likely to commit suicide in the South.

AROUND the white cliffs of England has grown up a sea tradition compact of the past. Customs hoary with age, customs that were yet old when England's mariners started their conquest of blue water, ballads that were sung in the days when Drake, the great freebooter, was singeing the whiskers of the proud King of Spain, are the common heritage of every Englishman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Whether the Labor Relations Board will appeal from Judge Merrill E. Otis's decision in Kansas City against the Wagner Labor Disputes Act is to be determined next week.
Four members of the 1934 All-National Football League first team retained their places on the 1935 eleven, according to the selections by coaches of the league.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- During the past week of bitter accusation and recrimination, of which the National Government of Great Britain had been the uncomfortable yet initially unyielding target, the question has been frequently asked: How much does British public opinion actually affect its government?

ROME, Dec. 20. -- Sir Samuel Hoare's resignation as British Foreign Secretary, Ethiopia's evident reluctance to negotiate on the basis suggested by France and Great Britain, the hostility with which the peace proposals have been received by the League and the Laval government's insecure position in France, all contribute to convince the Italians the Italo-Ethiopian controversy will ultimately be solved by generals, not by diplomats.

Announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity increased last week over the previous week. Municipal calls were the most numerous, although the largest redemptions were for public utility corporations. Except for a few small lots of municipal issues for this month, the refundings were all for the early part of next year.

After twenty-four hours of unbroken questioning, two men, suspected by the police of having taken part in a recent series of bank hold-ups and hijackings, were held in police headquarters last night on charges of homicide growing out of a chain-store hold-up in which a clerk was mortally wounded Nov. 27.

A NEW Sunday-afternoon half-hour program, "Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air," will be introduced today at 3:30 o'clock over WEAF for a run of thirteen weeks. Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan, will appear on each program and Wilfred Pelletier will direct the orchestra.

Accompanying the stronger efforts which department store and other retailers are putting forth to push their own brands in competition with national lines as a result of price-maintenance gains is a sharp increase in the higher standards and specifications which are being developed for the private brand goods.

W.A. Winterbottom, vice president of RCA Communications, called attention to the "mystery" signals a few days ago, saying that the source of the sound "is anybody's guess." He predicted it would be discovered that "they will turn out to have been set up by industries or hospitals using high-frequencies (short waves).

Hope for settlement of a problem that has hindered economies in the railroad business was expressed as a result of the announcement on Friday that the Association of American Railroads would confer with the Railway Labor Executives on the treatment of labor in moves for economy which might reduce employment.

With admirable persistence Secretary HULL continues to plug away at the task of reviving foreign trade by removing some of the barriers which have all but throttled it. Two new reciprocal tariff agreements were signed last week -- one with Honduras, the other, more important, with the Netherlands.

BOY SCOUTS are not usually thought of as Santa Claus's assistants, yet for many Yuletide seasons they have done a vast amount of work in repairing and distributing toys for poor children. This season, as always, the job got under way early in November. Then the Scouts started their house-to-house canvass and, aided by announcements in newspapers, in schools, in churches and in store windows, collected old and castoff toys.

IT seems that at last the general public has become genuinely alarmed at the continued increase in highway accidents. The 36,000 traffic fatalities in 1924 established an all-time high record. With an extension of safety laws and more thorough enforcement of traffic regulations, it was expected that there would be a decrease in motor-vehicle fatalities in 1935.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- Encouraged by the result of the plebiscite in Greece which restored the monarchy, Spanish royalists have begun preparations for an intensive campaign before the general election in March.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- With little business being done, the Bourse remained steady today near yesterday's low levels. There was a slight recovery in rentes, but the franc stays perilously near the gold-export point in respect to the dollar.
LONDON before long will have its first Hindu temple, and in its twelve-foot-square holy-of-holies a statue of Vishnu will be worshiped with rituals of flowers and foods.

SUCH great feats of transportation as those of the China Clippers in establishing the transpacific route have the effect of diminishing interest in lesser projects devoted to the common end of "getting there." The opening of new routes of mail or travel by air, bridge or motor road continues unabated throughout the world.
The Governors Island polo team defeated the Squadron A riders in the opening game of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League on the Squadron A tanbark last night, 9 1/2 to 7.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (by Wireless) -- What does England want? I do not think this is a difficult question. She wants, as far as possible, permanent universal peace, not only because war is futile, wasteful, cruel and horrible, but also because, in the hackneyed phrase, peace is the greatest of British interests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The navy, the motto of which is constant vigilance, has run down the "shadow" which has been interfering with radio reception.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20. -- Announcement by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the fourth largest steel producer in the country, of a $100,000,000 new financing program, $40,000,000 to be applied to plant expansion and improvements as soon as the expected approval of the stockholders is received, is generally commented on as one of the healthiest signs of economic recovery in the Pittsburgh district since 1929.

PAOTING, Hopei, China, Dec. 21. -- A belief that the Japanese Army has worked out a new method of extending its influence in China without bringing a great part of the army south of the Great Wall was expressed by General Shang Chen, who, for declining to join the autonomy movement, is being shifted from Governor of Hopei Province to Honan Province.

Christmas will be celebrated today in all the non-ritualistic Protestant churches and it will be celebrated Wednesday, Christmas Day, by all the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran congregations. Because the Feast of the Nativity this year comes so far after what is known as "Christmas Sunday" -- the Sunday before Christmas -- more denominational churches than ever before will hold services on Christmas Day itself.

The Nutley (N.J.) Woman's Club will sponsor community carol singing at 5 o'clock Christmas Eve, about a community Christmas tree in front of the Town Hall in Nutley. David Smith, tenor, who was born in the historic house now occupied by the Woman's Club, will conduct the singers, and Miss Margarette Litz will lead a group of trumpeters.

PARIS. PARIS couturiers are showing more beautiful and poetic evening gowns for Spring than is usual in the midseason, when the accent is usually placed on daytime clothes. This proves afresh that women are once more going places and doing things nearly every evening, and that when they go out they are dressing up.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 21. -- Judge Otis has handed down two previous decisions affecting New Deal legislation.

From Denmark -- The little town of Odense honors the memory of Hans Christian Andersen, famous teller of fairy tales, who was born there. Highlights of the program include a dramatization of Andersen's story, "The Little Match Girl"; a children's chorus singing, "In Denmark I Am Born"; J.P.E. Hartman's "Musical Miniatures"; a piano solo by Folmer Jensen and a soprano solo by Johanne Karstens entitled "The Dying Child"; WABC, 12:30 P.M.

Princeton's chess players, who a year ago made a bold bid for supremacy in the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League but were nosed out by Yale in a play-off, made an auspicious start yesterday by defeating Dartmouth, 3 -- 1, in the first round of the league's annual championship series at the Marshall Chess Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21. -- In order to make a short cut to a decision in a Wagner act case against the Mackay Radio Company of San Francisco the National Labor Relations Board at Washington today took direct charge of the proceeding, which will be completed at the national capital.

With the food industry sharply divided on the question of the proper procedure for attacking the problem of controlling demoralizing trade practices, manufacturers and distributors will enter the new year with competitive conditions in the struggle for sales throughout the country the most severe since the period of "profitless prosperity" in 1929.

The youngest competitor in the national figure-skating championships which start at the Ice Club at 8 o'clock next Friday morning and culminate in the sports show at Madison Square Garden the evening of Dec. 30 will be 16-year-old Polly Blodgett of Boston.

PHILIP GUEDALLA is at work on a book to be called "The Hundred Years," which Doubleday, Doran Co. expect to publish in the Fall of 1936. It is described as a panoramic history, picturing in a single volume the high-light events of the century beginning with 1837, when Queen Victoria ascended the throne.
All WPA workers in New York City will have half-holidays on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator.
A historic forerunner of the Townsend plan was discovered here yesterday in a document 142 years old. It was a product of the French Revolution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Sharp increases in November exports of the "sinews of war" to Italy said Italian Africa over November of last year were shown in figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Sir Thomas Beecham, English conductor, who will arrive here next Friday to conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will include a festival of English music and a little cycle of Mozart symphonies in his program, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society announces.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES Henry Ware Allen takes exception to Roger W. Babson's assumption that what is required to end the business depression is religion, which Mr. Allen defines as "any system of faith or worship."

The Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in November, published yesterday, compares with preceding months and years, with the three-year average of 1923-25 taken as 100, as follows:

Junior League groups in 129 cities contributed invaluable services to their local hospitals during the past twelve months, through volunteer workers or through financial aid supplied, according to a report issued yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund.

Many of Clifford Odets's severest critics score him on the ground that he is more like a mathematician than a dramatist in that he attempts to solve a problem rather than merely to state it. For me this is not so. He states the problems of his characters and only attempts to suggest a way out of their plight.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 20. -- Southern industry said "Me, too" here last Monday. Two hundred industrial leaders from twelve Southern States, assembled for the annual meeting of the Southern States Industrial Council, applauded speeches echoing anti-administration sentiments already expressed by big business in the North and East, and added new ones of their own.

WHEN Trudi Schoop and her "comic ballet" open their engagement of thirteen performances at the Majestic Theatre on Friday night New York will have its first glimpse of a dance company that has for the last five years set most of Europe laughing, on the testimony not alone of the professional critics of dancing, but of such artists in other lines as Thomas Mann.

IN 1932 the Yale North India Expedition unearthed in the Himalaya foothills relics of both manlike apes several million years old and of Stone Age men who lived during the Ice Age. Here was a promising field for exploration.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 21. -- Despite reports throughout the day that General Plutarco Elias Calles planned to leave Mexico, he was still at his home in the capital tonight, accompanied by Luis Morones and other close friends.

The coed varsity basketball team of the Savage School of Physical Education began its extensive program for this season by going down to a 28-20 defeat at the hands of the Savage alumnae sextet in the home gymnasium yesterday.

SINCE hundreds of persons have pledged support, the trustees of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival at a recent meeting in New York voted to proceed with their plans to have the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, present three concerts at the Hanna farm, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass., next Summer.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Whatever capitals lost in prestige during the past week's storm, Berlin certainly gained. Germany's seat on the fence has become the most comfortable and perhaps the most advantageous position in Europe. If any country ever enjoyed being neutral in time of conflict, that country is Germany today.

Between seven and eight hundred Girl Scouts of Manhattan are expected to gather this afternoon at their headquarters at 570 Lexington Avenue for a Christmas celebration that is one of the events of a busy week throughout the nation for the members. Magicians, a Punch and Judy show and refreshments of ice cream and cake will be on the program today.

Serious injuries resulting from football in high schools can be reduced to a minimum if five rules are observed, Dr. R. Arthur Fish told the members of the Osteopathic Society last night at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. Fish, who has been attending physician to the football team of Flushing High School for the past three years, made the following recommendations:
FORT NIAGARA, N.Y., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Colonel Charles H. Morrow, commandant of the regular army post here, died suddenly tonight of heart disease while reading in his library.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the premiere showing of the motion picture "The Rose of the Rancho," with Gladys Swarthout in the leading role, on the night of Jan. 7 at the Paramount Theatre for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Covering of December obligations because the spot month will expire at noon on Tuesday caused a sharp advance of a dollar a bale on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. In contrast with the rise in both near months, however, distant positions continued to lag, so that the list closed with irregular advances of 4 to 20 points.

When two boys start off on a holiday alone, without parental supervision, they are sure to see the world through different eyes. Mr. Strong, who is a distinguished novelist in the field of adult fiction, tells the story of such an adventure with as much freshness and gusto as if he himself had been a member of the expedition which took Jim and Walter to the Scottish Highlands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Predicting that Congress would remain in session much longer than the Democratic leaders expect and pledging his minority to "fight whenever there is an opportunity, whenever we have the chance," Representative Snell, the minority leader, today declared that he would follow and support any man the Republicans named to oppose President Roosevelt next Fall.

Reopening of a gold mine of Colonial days near Middletown, N.Y., by modern prospectors recalls an almost forgotten chapter in the history of American metallurgy. Throughout the Eastern United States are many shafts, long since abandoned, where gold and silver were obtained.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 21. -- Judge Otis's opinion upsetting the Wagner Labor Disputes Act was in substance as follows:

ROME, Dec. 21. -- The decent burial that Premier Mussolini was generally expected to give the France British peace proposals after yesterday's meeting of the Fascist Grand Council apparently is going to be denied them. They are to be left to rot, neglected and forgotten.

ESCANABA, Mich. -- The launching of the Florida canal project has revived hopes in some localities that the long-cherished dream of a waterway bisecting the Upper Peninsula of Michigan from Munising southward to Bay de Noquet at Rapid River might be realized.

THE most interesting part of this novel deals with the practical details of the life of a girl evangelist. When Camilla Dare, the orphan daughter of a preacher, agrees to take up a barnstorming career of preaching she finds ready helpers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Go through almost any farm neighborhood in the United States and you will notice that at least one out of every three or four farms differs considerably from most of the others. Perhaps lower residence value or surroundings account for the slightly depressing atmosphere of the place.

CHRISTMAS spirit manifests itself in two ways in the galleries of New York. There are the annual gift shows, with especially alluring prices affixed to works of art (and in this category should be placed that unique Christmas-card venture so successfully launched by the American Artists Group, Inc.).

Returns made public yesterday in the plebiscite on war and peace conducted by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches showed over-whelming votes in favor of a smaller army and navy, government control of the munitions industry and abolition of compulsory military training in schools and colleges.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Grover C. Talbot, former Speaker of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, was killed this morning in an automobile Collision in Drexel Hill, a suburb.

The boxing world was rocked yesterday with an unconfirmed report of the death of Joe Louis. The Detroit Bomber, the report said, had been killed in an automobile accident, and like wildfire the rumor went through the city, suburban communities and to some distant points.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- As a result of the continued shortage of butter, lard, eggs and various other foods, especially painful during the holiday season, General Hermann Goering today mobilized the Gestapo [secret police] to enforce compulsory milk delivery ordered sometime ago against "passive or open resistance of individual peasants and farmers."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during November at 101.1 per cent of capacity, on a single-shift basis, compared with 103.8 per cent in October this year and 94 per cent in November last year.

Registering a gain of more than 17 per cent, domestic consumption of burlap during the current year, based on official figures, will exceed 600,000,000 yards and will approach close to the 1931 total, according to estimates here yesterday by C.E. Rockstroh Co., Inc.

THERE is an impressive series of books in which "the history of civilization," Eastern and Western, ancient and modern, is broadly surveyed. To this encyclopedic enterprise Professor Guignebert contributes a treatise on the origin of Christianity.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Reports from Khabarovsk through official Soviet news channels early today said the Japanese Army in Manchuria was studying a plan for invading Outer Mongolia.

TO have a clear and thorough understanding of British naval operations in the World War, it is essential to read the memoirs of Sir Roger Keyes, an officer as much distinguished by his capacity to plan the execution of an effective Dover Patrol and the intricate blocking of Zeebrugge as by the inspiring quality of his leadership.

With the approach of the Christmas holidays, college basketball activity moves down almost to the vanishing point for the coming week, with only four local games scheduled besides the all-important double-header at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21. -- While preliminary reports of retail sales for the first half of December indicate that gains from comparable periods last year have been experienced, the increases have been somewhat smaller than were expected.

Committees of young people in society are being organized to assist with plans for the third annual Birthday Ball for President Roosevelt which will take place on the night of Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria. One of the newest groups to be formed is a debutante committee under the chairmanship of Miss Medora Roosevelt, who is related to the President.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 21. -- The Wagner National Labor Relations Act was held invalid in its entirety under the commerce clause of the Constitution by Judge Merrill E. Otis of the Federal District Court here tonight. The ruling was the first in the country on the law.

SOON deep snow, crisply crunching, will cover the hills to the north and skiers will flock to the railroad terminals bound for a ski outing in New England, the Poconos, the Catskills or the Adirondacks. Blood will tingle in the keen, invigorating air as they zoom down woodland trails, across the hills, or climb to mountain tops to thrill to the silent white panorama stretched below them.

IT is almost the night before Christmas and those who have not completed their lists of gifts must step lively. Even the foresighted, who do their shopping early, are certain to discover at the last moment that something -- or somebody -- has been forgotten.

MORE and more emphasis is being placed by the United States Army Air Corps and with it the War Department on the development of what is known as "attack" aviation. This differs from the other two combat wings, "pursuit" and "bombing," but at the same time combines some of the more deadly features of both.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Mrs. Butler arrived today at the Breakers for the holidays. Senator and Mrs. J.M. Wilson of Montreal and Mrs. Alfredo de Zayas, wife of the former President of Cuba, are recent guests there.

IN this book Mr. Verrill, who has perhaps written more books about more different subjects than any other author in this country, aims to tell the true story of the Indians of continental United States, excluding Alaska, whose Indians, he thinks, are more closely allied with Canadian than with our Indian stocks.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge announced today that Georgia had the money to pay her floating indebtedness, leaving her with only a funded debt of $4,187,000, brought over from Reconstruction days.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Wings flap, a hawk swoops, claws strike, and, in the revival of an ancient and kingly sport, the students and faculty of Cornell University have just become the latest devotees of falconry.
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Sir Donald Banks, Director-General of the Postoffice, returned today from a conference with Canadian and American authorities concerning a transatlantic air service.

By the abject failure of the Anglo-French effort to end the war in Africa, the whole question is necessarily thrown again into the hands of the League of Nations. At Geneva a new special committee has been appointed by it to strive to work out a plan for the peaceful settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian war.

Representatives of the Union, Essex, Rockaway Hunting and Princeton Clubs gained the semi-final round yesterday in the invitation pre-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The German military scored a momentous victory over the National Socialist party today when it was announced that all men who pass through the army -- that is, virtually the whole of German manhood -- would be organized in a non-political "Soldiers' League," the principal duty of which will be to cultivate the military tradition and maintain close comradeship among its members and with the active troops.

The fact that a majority of the ships of the American merchant marine are old and outmoded has added $5,000,000 annually to the cost of their operation for fuel oil alone, according to Alfred H. Haag, chief of the division of shipping research of the Shipping Board.

KEEPING an aquarium is a hobby that has grown rapidly during the past four or five years, and this year the Christmas scene in many homes will be enlivened by the appearance of gorgeously colored tropical fish swimming in aquaria of the latest modernistic design.

Gifts at this season of the year within the family or between friends are apt to take on something of a conventional air. They are the customary thing, meaning personal remembrance, of course, or keeping a friendship in repair, but not indicating or yielding the thrill which comes from a worthy charity, or to an individual in dire need, expecting nothing in return.

AROUND Christmas time the postoffice has a lot of things to think about that would seem to require more attention than a soiled envelope, carrying the inscription "Sandy Clause, the North Pole," written in an irregular hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- With government vaults rapidly filling with gold and silver, Treasury officials today were counting upon the completion of the huge "strongbox" in Kentucky to prevent any actual shortage of storage space. Gold worth $10,103,000,000 and silver valued at $1,900,000,000 are owned by the government.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Seventy-five representatives of up-State labor organizations voted tonight to call a statewide strike on all WPA projects employing skilled labor unless their demand for payment of the prevailing wage rate is met.

FOR the past six weeks the Bethlehem Bach Choir, directed by Bruce Carey, has been rehearsing for the 1936 Bach Festival in Bethlehem, Pa. While in Europe last Summer, Mr. Carey studied with Karl Strube, Bach's eleventh successor as cantor of the Thomas Church in Leipzig, and coached with Gunther Ramin of the Berlin Philharmonic organization.

Educational and collegiate topics will be discussed by the delegates to virtually all the conventions scheduled for the city during the Christmas holidays, according to the Merchants Association. Of thirty-nine conventions to be held, thirty-seven are tied up with education in one form or another.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 20. -- Northern Ohio Republicans are vitalized by the news that the national convention will be held here June 9. The Buckeye State, which went 70,000 for Roosevelt in 1932 and now is shown by polls to be veering away from the New Deal, may yet be a real battleground, but the first march has been stolen and the first big Ohio campaign enthusiasm will be strictly Republican.

After reading several of the reviews of "Paradise Lost" the impression I received was that something had missed the mark. A week later when I saw the play, exactly what it was that had missed instantly became apparent. It was the discernment of the critics.

Mr. and Mrs. Abram Vandermade of Montclair, N.J., introduced their daughter, Miss Ellenor Vandermade, last night at a dinner dance at Sherry's, in a setting of Christmas trees and poinsettias. Miss Vandermade wore a period frock of ivory taffeta, and carried a muff of red camellias.
SEASONAL NOTE: A twenty-foot balsam was sent last week from the Cherry Plain game refuge near Stephentown, Rensselaer County, N.Y., to the White House to be the Roosevelts' Christmas tree.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Anthony Eden called on Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today and on the strength of information he brought with him from Geneva last night, supplemented by even later diplomatic reports, was able to give assurances that Turkey, Greece, Rumania, Yugoslavia-and-Czechoslovakia would render military aid to Great Britain in the event of hostilities with Italy growing out the revived policy of checking instead of rewarding an aggressor.

MORE and more Christmas is becoming a season of pageants in schools throughout the country. Once the school Christmas celebration was intended mainly as a welcome release from classroom routine. Now it is more apt to be part and parcel of school life -- the culmination of weeks of historical, literary and artistic study.

Displaying its best form of the season, Columbia's basketball team defeated Williams, 35 -- 24, last night in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. It was the first setback of the year for the Purple five and marked the fourth victory in five starts for the Blue and White.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21. -- Entitled "The British Government Gives Way," an article by Karl Radek in today's Izvestia throws light not only on Soviet opinion regarding the recent events in London, Paris and Geneva but on the motives of the Soviet's own foreign policy.

THE royal babies of Callander, the Dionne quintuplets in their glassed-in haven amid high snowdrifts and frost-racked fir trees, will soon be celebrating their second Christmas, with Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe in the role of Santa Claus. On May 28 they will have their second birthday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- In the week before Christmas the mists over the Republican vista began to clear. A meeting of the national committee, which chose Cleveland, June 9, for the nominating convention; a smashing attack by Herbert Hoover on the President's Atlanta speech, and the agreement of Senator William E. Borah to stand for the Presidential nomination in the Wisconsin Republican primaries -- these events projected their force far into 1936.

IN connection with his forthcoming tour of this country in recitals devoted entirely to works by Beethoven and his seven such appearances to be made at Carnegie Hall this season, Artur Schnabel, the renowned German pianist, arranged with the publishing house of Simon Schuster of this city to bring out a reprint of his edition of the Beethoven piano sonatas.

LAK PLACID. -- High up in the Adirondack Mountains at this sports center the Winter season is already well under way. Ice skating on near-by ponds and skiing in the mountain passes have for several weeks attracted early season visitors.

More than 5,000 persons visited the Frick collection during the first week that it was open to the public. The notable collection of art bequeathed to the public by Henry Clay Frick was made available to the public last Monday morning at 10 o'clock. The entrance is at 1 East Seventieth Street.

CHICAGO. -- While national administration leaders are counting on unbroken Democratic support in Illinois in the 1936 elections, a steadily widening breach is developing between Mayor Edward J. Kelly and Thomas J. Courtney, Cook County's battling State's Attorney.

FRANCE is turning rapidly to the rail bus -- the automobile which travels on tracks -- for long as well as for short rides. Since 1930, when the first rail buses were commissioned, the range of these swift conveyances has been increased from ninety miles to 7,000 miles.

To introduce their daughter, Miss Dorothy Parsons Moore, Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Augustus Moore gave a dinner dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre. Pink and green was the color scheme of the floral decorations, Southern smilax entwined the stairway leading to the ballroom, where more smilax, cybotium ferns and pink lilies were massed in the balconies.

Last Tuesday, two days before the twenty-seventh anniversary of his assumption of the Presidency of Venezuela, General Juan Vicente Gomez died, at the age of 78. Long before Europe went in for dictatorships he had established one over his Latin-American republic, part of the territory freed from Spain by Simon Bolivar.

Reporting the oil industry's statistical position as the best in years, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in the current issue of its publication The Lamp, says that, taking the situation as a whole, the industry has more cause to feel optimistic than at any period since the depression began.

The average classroom in elementary schools has at least one pupil who is such an extremely "severe-behavior" problem as to require the attention of a psychiatrist or a physician, if he is to be saved from commitment to an institution because of crime or insanity, Dr. Julius Yourman, New York University instructor, declared yesterday.

TORONTO, Dec. 21. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs evened their season series with the Americans by defeating the New York team, 5 -- 3, tonight in a wide-open game of National League hockey. The triumph, with the Maroons' defeat of the Canadiens in Montreal, put the Leafs five points up on the Maroons and dropped the Americans to third place in the International Group.

Another of the debutante parties of yesterday was the tea dance given at the River Club by Mrs. Quentin F. Feitner, who returned from Palm Beach for the occasion, to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Lillian M. Feitner. Miss Feitner will return with her mother and brother to Palm Beach to spend the holidays with Mrs. John Vietor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Records of leading banks in New York and Chicago in the last few years indicate that institutions controlled and managed by a single family have weathered the depression more easily than banks whose ownership has been split among a large number of stockholders, no one of whom holds controlling interest.

From the standpoint of a Planned Order this whole business of Christmas has been sadly mismanaged. The chronology and geography are one big confusion. The scholars long ago figured out that the year of the Nativity must have been between 8 and 6 B.C., odd as that may sound.

LAREDO, Texas. -- Although the smuggling of aliens is less than it was a few years ago, when Chinese were brought into the United States from Mexico literally in carlots, the traffic has by no means ceased, according to immigration officials.

It has been many years since the European and world situation was as tangled as it is today. It is not only the peoples of the world who are confused by what is going on; even the diplomats, as the debacle of the Franco-British "peace plan" demonstrates, do not seem to know where they are heading for.

CHRISTMAS trade, taking the country as a whole, is ending favorably, with results probably the best since 1930. Last week, the National Retail Dry Goods Association reported an increase of 9.5 per cent over last year for the first half of this month.

It was more than a year ago when the public first began to hear of the plan of a Dr. Townsend in California for distributing pensions of $200 a month to persons over 60. Last April, in a standing vote in the House on an amendment to the Social Security Bill, though 206 Congressmen were against the plan, 56 voted in its favor.

Prospective visitors to Florida should not overlook the possibilities of the lower keys, says Ernest S. Wittnebel, chairman of the New York Athletic Club anglers' committee, who has just returned from a fishing trip in the Southland.

In the pink of health and feeling every whit as well as she had before she gave up stage dancing and its healthful discipline four years ago, Lady Charles Cavendish, the former Adele Astaire, dancer, returned yesterday to New York aboard the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- While the volume of holiday buying continues unabated, estimates of the gain in dollar totals over 1934 are being revised downward by the larger department stores. It now seems probable that the larger stores will show advances of not more than 5 per cent.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Nazi believers in the Teutonic conception of worship have started a fresh campaign against existing religions.

An agreement between District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, by which the latter is to direct that all prisoners captured in connection with Brooklyn murders, burglaries and other serious crimes be taken immediately after police line-ups to the office of Mr. Geoghan, was made at the crime conference held in Mr. Geoghan's office on Friday, the Brooklyn prosecutor announced yesterday.

THE Smith College Museum of Art has just announced the acquisition of a "Portrait of Rene de Gas," by Degas. The canvas, which measures thirty-six and one-half inches high by twenty-nine and one-half inches wide, shows Rene as a schoolboy with cap in hand and ink-pot at his side.

THE opening night of the Metropolitan Opera season demonstrated the value of the tried and proved system of opera performance in this country, plus a fresh spirit and an interpretive intent which carried the representation of one of the oldest chestnuts of the repertory to a brilliant victory.

A continued growth in inter-industry competition, with the textile field endeavoring to defend its share of the consumer purchasing power through various means, was predicted here yesterday by Scheuer Co., textile consultants and brokers, in their annual review of conditions in the cotton, rayon and silk field.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 21. -- Preparation for the 1936 Bach Festival by the Bethlehem Bach Choir has begun in earnest and twice a week for the last month and a half thorough instruction has been given the 273 members of the choir by Bruce Carey, director.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 21. -- The extensive Benjamin Franklin collection assembled by William Smith Mason of Evanston, Ill., including more than 10,000 volumes, many manuscripts and numerous portraits, prints, busts and statues has been acquired by Yale University from an anonymous donor.

THE lighting of Winter gardens, especially at Christmas time, is now widely practiced. There is more to this new vogue than just lighting a Yule tree or a doorway, attractive as that may be.
