For scenes of rarest beauty the entire garden is involved, with floodlights or colored lamps setting off choice areas and the merging of light and shadow completing the effect.

Santa Claus came to town yesterday, got lost temporarily in the Pennsylvania Station, registered finally at the Hotel Commodore and spent a comfortable afternoon talking about himself with a convincing Missouri twang even if he could not prove his title to his first name.

The proposal of the Interstate Commerce Commission to put into effect a 2-cents-a-mile day coach rate and a 3-cents-a-mile rate for Pullman service on railroads throughout the country will be the first nation-wide change since 1920, when the basic passenger rate was increased from 3 cents to 3.60 cents a mile.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Andrew Jackson would "turn over in his grave," Senator Harry S. Truman, Democrat of Missouri, asserted today, if dinners costing $10 a plate were given by Democrats on Jackson Day as suggested by Postmaster General Farley.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The "possibility of jealousy" and of "unrequited love or hatred" must be considered in the mystery death of Thelma Todd, film actress, Deputy District Attorney George Johnson said tonight.

LONDON, NOV. 29. SO eager is the theatre to exhibit new wares that I have been given no opportunity, since my return from abroad, to make a general survey of pieces that have appeared in my absence. I have been to five first nights consecutively, my assistants to nearly twice that number.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20. -- One of the most interesting things about the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is that it is dynamic and fluid. The Moscow of today is always a different city from the Moscow of three months ago.

UNDENIABLY Honey Jane, at the age of 12, was one of the "wild McCrearys." In spite of her Grandmother Miller, who hoped fervently and audibly that her lively granddaughter would grow up in the gentle ways becoming to the women of the oldest family in that section of the Tennessee mountains, Honey Jane was a tomboy with a secret preference for her father's people.
Francis X. Shields of New York displaced Sidney B. Wood as top-ranking player in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's listing for 1935, it was announced yesterday.

At the recent annual meeting in Chicago of the American Farm Bureau Federation resolutions were adopted endorsing AAA, opposing tariff cuts and requesting that "authority be extended for one year to raise and lower the price of gold and establish a definite policy of currency management to maintain suitable price levels in line with fixed costs from generation to generation."

IS Santa Claus a dramatic character? He is not a character in a stage play, like Falstaff and Peter Pan. But, like the figures in the commedia dell' arte, he wears a traditional costume, which identifies him with the Christmas masquerade.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Staging a determined scoring drive midway in the final period, the University of Rochester basketball team defeated a hard-fighting Cornell University five, 36 to 29, tonight.

Manhattan's basketball team completed its early season campaign with an unblemished record by turning back a fighting Cathedral College quintet of New York, 40 to 11, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. It was the sixth straight triumph for the undefeated Jaspers, who now will suspend activities until after the holidays.

The sororities of the Pan-Hellenic Association of Hunter College have completed plans for numerous dances and other activities during the Christmas holiday season, according to an announcement by Miss Selma Goldstone, chairman of the association.

Steps to take "militarism" out of the public schools and colleges and to end "racial discrimination" in relief jobs were urged yesterday at an all-day conference of the American League Against War and Fascism at Mecca Temple.
A gloomy citizen exclaimed the other day: "After all the taxpaying we do, we are still expected to give to charity!"

PHOENIX, Dec. 20. -- Arizona and adjoining States are stirred up over rumors that the practice of polygamy among members of a religious cult in this State and Utah may be more general than has been supposed.

Mayor La Guardia picked an executive committee of thirty-three men and women yesterday to set up rules and regulations for the $2,000 prize to be awarded for the composition of a city anthem. The committee also will name a jury to select the winning musical composition.

The lights go on early these short Winter days, and in many a Washington office, despite the holiday season, they stay on late. The reason: only twelve days remain before the opening of Congress. The committees must get their holdover legislation in some sort of shape, lobbyists must re-establish their contacts and President Roosevelt must make ready to present a budget.

SKEPTICISM over the abilities of the General Headquarters Air Force, created about a year ago, has been largely dispelled by its performance. Under the able command of Brig. Gen. Frank M. Andrews the force has given proof of its mettle under the handicap of a very limited equipment in really modern combat airplanes in the various categories.

A HUNDRED years ago some scattered frontiersmen were engaged in what appeared, at the time, to be a hopeless struggle against Mexico for independence. But their objective was won and the Republic of Texas was founded.

THE birth of the New York Film Critics, Unincorporated, must be rated one of the obstetrical marvels of 1935. Until the startling events of the last few weeks, no one who knew the breed would have believed it possible that they could agree on anything.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Dec. 21. -- The inquest into the death of three school children killed yesterday in the bus accident at the Broadway railroad crossing here has been postponed pending the outcome of the injuries received by three others. Eleanor Nagle, 17 years old, was reported in critical condition.

ANDERNACH, Germany, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The little group of former American doughboys who after the war married and settled down with German wives in the Rhineland will meet again this year for a Yuletide dinner and to talk over old times.

Decked with holly and mistletoe, fourteen centers of the Y.W.C.A. in the city are busy about their Christmas programs, which include dinners, parties and dances up to and including Jan. 5, the traditional "twelfth night." Mrs. William Hugh Coverdale, as chairman of the activities committee for the organization, has directed the planning of the numerous events.

Not the least interesting item in the National League official batting averages released today is the one showing Floyd (Arky) Vaughan, young Pirate shortstop, as the circuit's leading hitter for the 1934 season with a mark of .385 compiled in 137 games.

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- Following the formal opening of the Winter season at this resort, a special program of sports and social features is being planned to enliven the holiday season, when many collegians will be here with their families.

More than 1,500 persons, including I many public officials and ecclesias-I tic dignitaries, attended a solemnI requiem mass for the Rev. Jere-] miah J. Kent, rector for the last sixteen years of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Fourth~Avehue and Ninety-fifth Street, Brooklyn, in the church yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Hearings of the Securities and Exchange Commission's charges of stock manipulation against Michael J Meehan, which were adjourned yesterday until Jan. 2, probably will continue throughout that month, according to the best estimates available.
In reference to your editorial "Patent Reform," it appears to me that the lone inventor is the most truly worth-while of all the "forgotten men."

MY position with respect to the loyalty oath for teachers is this: I see no reason why any teacher should object to taking it and, indeed, I should think that teachers would look upon the opportunity to take it as an honor and a privilege.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 21. -- Early expansion of the Palmer Library at Connecticut College to meet educational needs is indicated by President Katharine Blunt in her annual report to the trustees. Plans are being studied for the library additions, using the fund given to the college by Mr. and Mrs George S. Palmer in 1931, with the understanding that it be kept until the need for wings to the library became pressing.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 21. -- Bennington College sent its 260 students out yesterday on the fourth annual field and reading period of two months in their chosen specialties. The young women will return Feb. 24 to report their findings and resume class, laboratory and studio work.

IT was in an old book shop that your correspondent recently waylaid Gian Francesco Malipiero for an interview on his new opera, "Giulio Cesare," which will have its premiere at the Teatro Carlo Felice of Genoa this season. The Venetian composer was hunting for a rare Goldoni edition; he was in Goldonian good humor and in communicative mood.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Rare Arabic manuscripts expressly composed or copied for Moslem rulers have been discovered during the cataloguing of the Garrett collection in the Princeton University library, Dr. Philip K. Hitti, Associate Professor of Semitic Literature on the Paton Foundation, who is supervising the work, announced today.

Loan shark racketeers were believed responsible last night for the kidnapping earlier in the day of a 23-year-old Brooklyn woman who escaped in Jersey City from three men who had gagged her after forcing her into an automobile two blocks from her home.

DALLAS, Dec. 21. -- Holiday buying in the Eleventh Reserve District continues to set new high levels as retailers report the largest dollar volume since 1929. Many merchants have been forced to employ the largest force of sales people since before the depression and even then have been hard pressed to care for the trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- United States exports in November, totaling $269,400,000, were 22 per cent larger than those in the preceding month and 38 per cent larger than in November, 1934. The gain was especially significant because there is a normal seasonal decline of 6 per cent in our exports at this time of the year.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 21. The Essex Country Club, which is playing its first season in the circuit, upset the Essex Club of Newark, which was leading in the New Jersey division of the metropolitan Class C Racquets League, 4 to 1, today.

In your criticism of Nov. 15, 1935, you comment upon the work of a conductor and say among other things: "This work was conducted, as everything else was, from memory and without score. This knowledge reflects much credit upon a young conductor's stubborness, but it is very questionable whether it is a help rather than a hindrance in interpretation. Mr. -- might be freer and more authoritative with a score than without one.

NOW that New York is tackling the noise problem in earnest, renewed interest attaches to what progress London has made in this direction. London has not so far succeeded in silencing all noise, but through the Anti-Noise League it has effectively silenced the defense of noise.

In his presidential address before the anniversary meeting of the Royal Society, Sir F. GOWLAND HOPKINS, whose fine study of vitamins won him the Nobel Prize, raised the question of the scientist's relation to society. To many, research has something unethical about it because of its disregard of human values.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- Abandonment by the American Philosophical Society of plans to build a $1,000,000 home on Philadelphia's parkway was disclosed this week by the introduction in the City Council of a bill providing for the return of the chosen parkway m plot to the city.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The New York Athletic Club, national and metropolitan indoor titleholder, met its first defeat in almost two years tonight against the Ridgewood Polo Club, New Jersey champion, by the score of 7 1/2 to 6 at the Essex Troop Armory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21. -- Reports from principal retail stores show a heavy increase in buying over last week. Individual stores reporting for the month to date show increases ranging from 6 to 38 per cent. Behind this optimistic picture is said to be a large amount of installment buying that may mean collection difficulties later, analysts declare.

National officials of the Daughters of the Defenders of the Republic, headed by Mrs. Amanda Shaw Hirsch, founder and president general, will attend the installation of Alexander Hamilton Chapter in Philadelphia Friday. Mayor Hampton J. Moore is scheduled to address the society at the ceremony in City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- With most of his family gathered around him at the White House, President Roosevelt today substituted the wrapping of gifts and like homely Christmas tasks for official work, closing his office and barring himself to all official callers.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- Charging the Jewish industrial firm of Simson Company in Suhl, Thuringia, with profiteering under the republic, the State forced it to surrender its works and turn over, for good measure, several million marks. The Voelkischer Beobachter, which reports the event sensationally as a great Nazi party accomplishment, describes the transaction as follows:

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 22. -- The immediate suppression of student demonstrations in Hankow was demanded yesterday by Yoshiake Miura, the Japanese Consul General, as a result of an alleged assault on a Japanese onlooker by parading Chinese youths, according to the Rengo (Japanese) News Agency.

Various organizations of women in Westchester County are making entertainment for the underprivileged boys and girls of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry a part of their holiday activities. Yesterday twenty boys of Howard Cottage were guests of the committee of 100 of the Scarsdale Women's Club, of which Mrs. Morton Gilde is chairman.

THE TIMES published an interview with Professor Julius Tandler, one-time Minister of Health of the former Austrian Republic and Commissioner of Health and Welfare of the city of Vienna, in which he asked why we do not have State-paid doctors on the same basis as judges and teachers.

Much information of value to prospective exhibitors is contained in the prize list of the Westminster Kennel Club for its sixtieth annual dog show to be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10, 11 and 12.

AMERICA, it should be no news, is a middle-class nation in outlook and aspiration. Exactly what that means you may not be sure, but you are safe in believing that it includes a desire that children shall go to college, that a new automobile be parked in front of the house, that homes be furnished in the approved fashion, that clothes, whatever else they are, shall be in style.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- John Bryerson of Chicago and Cooperstown, N.Y., is expected to defend his title in the thirty-third annual midwinter golf tournament, to be held on the No. 2 course at the Pinehurst Country Club, beginning on Friday.

Young persons with bad tempers or intractable dispositions are frequently transformed into "sweet and obedient" children as a result of diagnosis and treatment in the psychiatric clinic of the Babies Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, according to Dr. William S. Langford, director of the clinic.

ALTHOUGH the history of opera in the countries comprising the present Yugoslavia has been a continuous development in that form since 1870, the output is not generally known outside of that part of the world.

In their second strong comeback of the week, the visiting European contract bridge champions outplayed the Four Aces of the United States yesterday afternoon at Essex House as their 300-hand match approached its Madison Square Garden final session, cutting the Americans' lead to 2,370 points at the 272d hand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- President Roosevelt has made written charges against his military aide, Colonel E.M. Watson, accusing him of shooting "blind turkeys."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Misuse of Federal grants in aid to States for vocational training purposes are disclosed in a report made to Secretary Perkins and Dr. John W. Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, it was learned today.

By firming up during the final hour yesterday under the leadership of the aviation, automotive and petroleum stocks, the share market was able to close the week unchanged, according to the averages -- a week wherein trading was the slowest since the last week in September.

While shivering patrolmen of Police Emergency Squad 1 from the Ericsson Place station looked on at noon yesterday, Sergeant Irving Davies made a swift rescue of a cat that in some mysterious manner had imprisoned itself in a ventilator shaft of the I.R.T. subway at Seventeenth Street and Seventh Avenue.

With a fanfare of trumpets that went a little flat in the chill morning air, Mayor La Guardia opened war on food racketeers yesterday at the crack of dawn in Bronx Terminal Market by proclaiming a ban on the "sale, display and possession" of the thistly but delectable vegetable, known to the produce trade as the "small artichoke."

NEWARK, Dec. 21. -- The court action started here by Franklin Township and four individuals to prevent the Resettlement Administration from proceeding with the Bound Brook low-cost housing project for industrial workers has been transferred from this Federal court district to the District of Columbia.

MADRID, Dec. 21. -- While Foreign Minister Jose Martinez de Velasco tonight studies a British note asking what Spain is prepared and willing to do in case of Italian aggression against the British Fleet in the Mediterranean, it may be said on official authority that several Spanish warships in the Bay of Algeciras for several weeks have been almost a stone's throw from units of the British Home Fleet at Gibraltar.

THE first printing with movable metal types began in Germany around 1450. It was nearly a century later that the art reached America, and the initial press was established in Mexico City. Almost another hundred years went by before the territory of what is now the United States saw the light and Stephen Daye opened a shop in Cambridge in 1638.

HERE is the latest in a long line of attempts to revivify and interpret dramatically the early history of the Mormons. If a quiet New England village or an Iowa farm or a drooping, magnolia-scented Southern town can inspire novels of firm texture and good story-telling, why should not the dramatic and fantastic story of the Mormon pioneers inspire a fine American novel?

FOR the fourth Christmas Day King George will join what the broadcasters call "This Great Family" for an international broadcast covering the globe-girdling British Empire. His Majesty is scheduled to speak from Sandringham Palace at approximately 10 A.M., Eastern standard time.

NOW that the Winter vacation season is here, California and Florida will begin their traditional bidding for the nation's sun-seeking travelers. Zest is given to their ancient rivalry this year with the threat of certain Californians to leave their native State rather than pay the new income tax, and statisticians are sharpening their pencils to prove that, in the long run, taxes here are less than those in Eastern States.

Much of the authentic atmosphere of the Parisian Latin Quarter in the days of Alfred de Musset and Gautier of the scarlet waistcoats was captured in the pleasing, if not scintillant performance of Puccini's "La Boheme," billed at the Metropolitan last night as the first of this season's popular-priced productions.

The inmates of the Salvation Army Working Women's Home were guests at a party last night held by the Advertising Women of New York. It included entertainment, presents, a visit from Santa Claus, ice cream and cake, and the singing of carols and the old popular songs.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Star performers such as Lawson Little and Walter Hagen took a back seat today as Pat Abbott, 23, an actor by profession, shattered par by two strokes for a 68 and the 18-hole lead in Southern California's $3,000 open golf championship.

ATHENS, Dec. 21. -- Several business associations warn that the application of League of Nations sanctions against Italy has dangerously depressed the export side of Greece's already unfavorable trade balance.

The inmates of the Salvation Army Working Women's Home were guests at a party last night held by the Advertising Women of New York. It included entertainment, presents, a visit from Santa Claus, ice cream and cake, and the singing of carols and the old popular songs.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Star performers such as Lawson Little and Walter Hagen took a back seat today as Pat Abbott, 23, an actor by profession, shattered par by two strokes for a 68 and the 18-hole lead in Southern California's $3,000 open golf championship.

Fifteen uniformed Nazi sympathizers staged a dance hall putsch in Yorkville last night, but it failed to stop the Saturday night dance and beer party of the German Workers Club, Inc., an avowed anti-Nazi organization, with clubrooms on the first floor of 1,501 Third Avenue, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20. -- If there is dynamite in the Iowa unemployment situation, as L.S. Hill, Iowa State WPA administrator says, the fuse has been lighted.
Eighteen years of Democratic control of the Board of Education will come to an end next week with the seating of Mayor La Guardia's fourth appointee, giving the board a Fusion majority.

The seventy-fifth birthday of Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was observed yesterday by Jewish leaders in many parts of the world with one outstanding exception -- Miss Szold herself.

The revolutionary process that began in Mexico twenty-five years ago has again sharpened into open conflict. This conflict takes the form of a struggle between two men: General Plutarco Elias Calles, former President, and General Lazaro Cardenas, the President today.

THE demand for books on home decoration seems to be unceasing, but no matter how many such works are published each new volume has always its own distinctive value. This new one, for instance, is marked by its combination of practical quality and its inherent artistic appreciation -- the feeling displayed for line, color, harmony, balance, proportion.

Mobilization of trade groups and business interests favoring the foreign trade policy of the government was started late last week following reports from Washington that two new measures attacking reciprocal trade agreements will be introduced by protectionists as soon as Congress reconvenes Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Postoffice Department is handling its biggest Christmas business since 1929. Sales of mail-order houses, department stores and other retail establishments, running well above the 1934 levels according to many reports, are reflected in the amount of extra help required by postmasters all over the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Tax-paid withdrawals of whisky, rum, gin and brandy in November were to 9,044,520 tax gallons, which was 2,971,162 gallons, or 32.8 per cent more than in November last year, the Treasury said today.

HALCYON days are here again. The music season is on and promises to be a busy one. The opening bang came from the grands concerts -- as the French so euphoniously dub their symphonic manifestations -- the usual organizations holding forth in the usual places, the standard of performance akin to what it has been in preceding years, no better and, thank Heaven! no worse.

GENEVA, Dec. 20. -- It is a month since the main sanctions went into effect on Nov. 18. The first month has ended in considerable tumult but with sanctions going on about as expected here -- in fact, rather better than reasoned. The writer, after reporting on Nov. 15 the "fear that with elections over London.

Max Schorr, 21-year-old helper, of 379 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, was killed, and Max Chavin, 34, of 913 Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn, was injured critically in a collision at 2:30 P.M. yesterday at Ralph and Ditmas Avenues, Canarsie.

Indoor bicycle racing is to have its seasonal inaugural at the New York Coliseum tonight, when 200 of the world's leading professional and amateur competitors will whirl around the newly constructed seven-lap track in an interesting program of seven races.

NEARLY every beautiful idea and symbol used by the ancients in their rites and ceremonies has been adopted by the Christian world in some form. It is not surprising, therefore, to find laurel used for Christmas wreaths and ropes, though as a means of decoration it antedates written history.

One hundred orphans from Staten Island and 150 poor youngsters from the East Side yesterday afternoon attended the sixteenth annual Christmas party held at the Carroll Club, 120 Madison Avenue. The party was sponsored by members of the club, the Girl Scouts of America and the Catholic Day Nursery.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- The German press is engaged in a campaign to prove that the Vatican is opposed to Christmas trees and therefore to an old Germanic Custom. In itself the campaign is apparently only a minor incident in the general National Socialist anti-Catholic propaganda which has been characteristic of Chancellor Hitler's party since its earliest days.

DARRELL'S ISLAND in the Great Sound near Hamilton Harbor, once the site of a prison camp for Boer War captives, is rapidly being converted into a modern airport for a service which will bring Bermuda within four to six hours from New York and make it a port of call on the proposed twenty-six-hour transatlantic airway from America to England.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Joe Louis, scourge of the heavyweights, claimed front rank tonight as the individual the report of whose death is most frequently "exaggerated."
Does it constitute smuggling for a resident of New York State to bring across the border for his own consumption small lots of liquor purchased in another State?

WILSON MIZNER always behaved as though he had inherited the earth, and he got away with it. He appears td have had none of the familiar fears. He swore off work up in the Klondike in his early twenties, deciding that his wits were good enough to live on. From that time on he was consistently late to bed and late to rise, lazy, thriftless and hard drinking.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- Social calendars here have scheduled varied holiday entertainments for debutantes, those home from finishing schools, out-of-town guests and visiting relatives.

ORDAINED: She was 9 years old and riding on a street car in Southern California when the Lord spoke -- according to Uldine Utley's later testi mony -- and commanded her to preach His word. She began to study her Bible, brought revelation to her Baptist parents and her neighbors.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 21. -- With Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld indicted for first-degree murder, investigators in the Walter W. Liggett murder case today concentrated on a search for the unknown "John Doe" indicted with Cann as the second alleged assassin of the Minneapolis publisher and editor.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21. -- Scotch Gold, 6-year-old gelding, carried Miss Lillian C. White's colors to victory today in the Citrus Handicap, five-and-a-half-furlong feature race, before 12,000 at Tropical Park. He won by a head from Dancing Doll, which finished four lengths in front of Colonel Ed.

In spite of an automobile accident, marriage, the arrival of two children and the duties of a household, Mrs. William Freed of 700 Wrest 176th Street will be a candidate for the degree of Bachelor of Arts at the mid-term exercises in January at Hunter College, where she has been a student off and on for the past fourteen years.

PEIPING, Dec. 21. -- General Sung Cheh-yuan, chairman of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, refused today to submit to Japanese desires in matters of policy and administration in the new semi-autonomous regime. He insisted that he would not act without orders from Nanking.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Dec. 21. -- "The creed of our forefathers is now in graver peril than at any time since the Middle Ages," Dr. S. Parkes Cadman declared in an address on "The World at the Cross Roads" at the ninety-fourth annual Forefathers Day celebration at Middlebury last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21. -- An official of the Artichoke Farms Sales Association, who requested his identity be undisclosed as a matter of personal safety, heartily endorsed today the action of Mayor La Guardia of New York in banning the sale of small artichokes beginning next Thursday.

Mayor F.H. La Guardia, who spoke before several thousand persons attending the performance of "The Midnight Alarm" at Madison Square Garden last night, rebuked those firemen who brought court action to prevent the promotion of some of their fellow firemen on the grounds that war veterans should receive priority on the civil service lists.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- A full pardon was given today as a Christmas present by Governor Horner to Alfred Codman Jr., 33, Harvard graduate and member of a prominent Boston family. He was sentenced Jan. 5 to serve one to fourteen years in prison for manslaughter in connection with an automobile accident.

WOODCUTS at the Brooklyn Museum, contemporary and European. An interesting description of the development of the modern woodcut dedicated to making it "look like wood" came with the invitation to visit the group at the museum, and the statement was made therein that Felix Edouard Valloton was the originator of woodcuts that look like woodcuts.

ARRANGEMENTS are now being made for the Texas Centennial Exposition, which is to open in Dallas on June 6, to include an extensive showing of art works. The art exhibition will be held in the new building of the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts, now being pushed to completion for the opening of the exposition.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 21. -- Mrs. John Lovejoy is chairman of a committee arranging a junior subscription dance to be held at the Field Club Thursday for girls from 13 to 15 and boys from 13 to 16. The patronesses include:

Staging a four-goal rally in the last period with Frank Pfeiffer as the spearhead of the attack, Squadron C opened its Metropolitan Indoor Polo League schedule with an 8-to-6 triumph over Evergreen Farms at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Residential construction in the United States showed an increase of 129.9 per cent in November, as compared with November, 1934. The increase in construction costs was more than 20.7 per cent. On the other hand, non-residential construction in November showed an increase of 29.6 per cent over November, 1934, while the increase chargeable to additions, alterations and repairs was 10.9 per cent over November of last year.

As Congress prepares to reconvene, the relief problem and its twin, the budget problem, are among the most important and the most controversial with which Washington will have to deal this Winter. They are linked together because without the relief problem there would be no budget problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Virtually all sources of individual income, headed by wages and salaries -- the actual product of applied labor -- showed substantially higher yields in 1934 than in 1933, but still were substantially below the record levels of 1929, the Treasury announced today.
NOT every pieta is the work of sculptor, carver or painter; nor is it, necessarily, life-size. Here, for instance, in book form, is a twentieth century prose pieta in exquisite miniature.

CONCORD, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP). -- In a snug little shop of this quaint Colonial town a spry old man who once made shoes for Emerson, Hawthorne and Louisa May Alcott tips back in his rocking chair and recounts old days with "the literary great."

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- A friendly hint that the United States delegates are ready to stay here until next Summer or longer was dropped by Norman H. Davis and William H. Standley today during a brief courtesy call on Admiral Osamu Nagano and his colleagues of the Japanese delegation to the naval conference.

The a cappella choir of Lincoln Cathedral, Lincoln, Neb., which started yesterday on a national tour, will sing carols on the terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria on Christmas Day from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M. A group selected from the fifty-five mixed voices also will give a short program during the dinner hour in the Sert Room of the hotel.

Accounting for its eighth victory of the season, the undefeated Long Island University five overpowered the West Virginia State Teachers College team of Shepherdstown, 63 -- 18, last night. The game was played at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy Gymnasium.

SCIENTIFIC exploration avoids adventure as much as possible, we are told on the best authority. Well, this exploration of David Irwin's was the reverse of scientific. It accomplished nothing. It was of adventure all compact. Hair-raising adventure; stubborn and dare-devil adventure; adventure of which a large part was sheer physical torture, and which it seems to have been the millionth chance only that the 22-year-old protagonist survived.

NOW that "Jumbo" trumpets loud and clear at the Hippodrome, the veil of censorship, which obscured the dark and passionate doings which went on behind the scenes while that spectacular leviathan was in its prolonged travail, may be lifted and the claims of the Mad Mahout, Billy Rose, sifted and appraised.

All audience which filled every seat fairly rocked the walls of the auditorium with its applause for Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan soprano, who appeared in a recital last night as the fourth artist in the Town Hall's endowment series.

A group selected from the fifty-five mixed voices also will give a short program during the dinner hour in the Sert Room of the hotel.

It was of adventure all compact. Hair-raising adventure; stubborn and dare-devil adventure; adventure of which a large part was sheer physical torture, and which it seems to have been the millionth chance only that the 22-year-old protagonist survived.

NOW that "Jumbo" trumpets loud and clear at the Hippodrome, the veil of censorship, which obscured the dark and passionate doings which went on behind the scenes while that spectacular leviathan was in its prolonged travail, may be lifted and the claims of the Mad Mahout, Billy Rose, sifted and appraised.

All audience which filled every seat fairly rocked the walls of the auditorium with its applause for Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan soprano, who appeared in a recital last night as the fourth artist in the Town Hall's endowment series.

IN his introduction to this book Mr. Madden lets the late Conan Doyle tell in his own words the familiar story of how Sherlock Holmes came into being. In the chapters that follow, fifteen British writers of detective stories introduce us to their own brain-children and tell how they were born.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A voluntary agreement among Japanese exporters of textiles to hold shipments to the United States to "moderate" levels was reported to the State Department today.
Leaving the more staid Christmas programs to their elders, members of junior organizations in New Jersey are planning literally to dance their way through Christmas week.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Flashing an attack featured by fine team work and superior speed, Princeton's hockey team tonight scored its fifth straight triumph by turning back the St. Nicholas sextet, 4 to 3, at the Playland Rink. About 1,500 spectators watched the game and were given the thrill of an overtime battle.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 21. -- With almost 100 per cent of the students participating in one or more organized sports, the intramural program at Amherst College, designed to provide athletic training for all, has reached a new high.

Holiday festivities at the American Woman's Association will reach their climax tomorrow evening in the invasion of 250 children of the neighborhood for a Christmas romp around a tree in the ballroom, and a Santa Claus to distribute gifts. But they will neither begin nor end with the juvenile atmosphere.
NOT every pieta is the work of sculptor, carver or painter; nor is it, necessarily, life-size. Here, for instance, in book form, is a twentieth century prose pieta in exquisite miniature.

CONCORD, Mass., Dec. 21 (AP). -- In a snug little shop of this quaint Colonial town a spry old man who once made shoes for Emerson, Hawthorne and Louisa May Alcott tips back in his rocking chair and recounts old days with "the literary great."

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- A friendly hint that the United States delegates are ready to stay here until next Summer or longer was dropped by Norman H. Davis and William H. Standley today during a brief courtesy call on Admiral Osamu Nagano and his colleagues of the Japanese delegation to the naval conference.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21. -- Holiday buying of record proportions is reported throughout the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Large department stores have been jammed with buyers, and retailers report 10 to 15 per cent gains in sales over last year, with a good demand for the more expensive class of goods.

PALM BEACH. -- Except for snow and cold weather, from which they are geographically far removed, residents of Palm Beach will lack none of the traditional touches in observing the Christmas season. Gayety will be heightened by a round of house parties and entertaining for the younger set, converging here daily from colleges and schools, with family dinners the order for Christmas Day.
There seemed to be little news to talk over at President Roosevelt's press conference on Tuesday, and so the President summed up matters thus:

Accused of having struck two members of the German Workers Club, Inc., with a blackjack Saturday night, when twenty uniformed Nazi sympathizers invaded a weekly dance of the club in its quarters at 1,501 Third Avenue, near Eighty-fifth Street, Gustave Bagi, 35 years old, a furniture salesman of 4,039 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, was paroled in his own custody last night for trial in Special Sessions by Magistrate McKiniry in Night Court.

In THE TIMES of Dec. 19 appeared two completely separated statements which serve to emphasize the importance of the public service rendered by the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation in endowing at Harvard University a school of public administration.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has given up residence in the United States and is on his way to establish his home in England. With him are his wife and 3-year-old son, Jon.

Splendid teamwork by Junius A. Richards and his professional partner, John J. Smith, enabled the Rockaway Hunting Club pair to capture the first pro - amateur squash racquets doubles invitation tournament staged on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Judge Otis's Kansas City decision holding the National Labor Relations Board and its enabling Wagner act unconstitutional in its entirety will be appealed at once, officials of that body said tonight.

The New York Rangers snapped the string of successes run up by the Boston Bruins by defeating the Hub sextet at Madison Square Garden last night, 3 to 1. The visitors, led by the redoubtable Eddie Shore, waged a bitter struggle in their attempt to raise the flag of victory, but found the speedy New York skaters just a little too good for them.

Mayor F.H. La Guardia promised yesterday that his order prohibiting the sale of small artichokes in markets controlled by the city would be enforced rigidly, but he declined to say how this would be done. It would be time enough for the city to disclose its plans, he said, when the first violation occurred.

Captain Frank C. Bals, in charge of detectives of the Tenth Inspection District of Brooklyn, said last night that the local investigation of the reported kidnapping of Mrs. Constance Ritter of 7,107 Colonial Road, Brooklyn, had been closed. Mrs. Ritter reported to police in Jersey City Saturday that she had been kidnapped by three men near her home and taken to New Jersey.

International polo players of a new generation take their places in succession to the famous figures of the past in the announcement yesterday of the squad which has been picked to go abroad for the resumption of the international matches with England in June.

John Goss, English baritone, and his assisting male quartet, known as the London Singers, were heard yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall in the unusual and erudite type of program which has always aroused interest in their frequent appearances here.

Both the subway and elevated divisions of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company carried more passengers in November than they did during the same month in 1934, according to a report filed with Federal Judge Julian M. Mack by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver.

The charge that Mayor La Guardia has ignored their requests for a hearing since last April and has "given them the run around" whenever they sought to place before him their complaints against alleged inadequate wages and other grievances was made yesterday by employes on the city's Independent subway lines.

So the Charter Revision Commission wants to get us back into the same condition of stagnation we were in from 1898 through 1901? Centralization in Manhattan of all public works and city planning utterly stopped all progress then. Why repeat it?

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 (AP). -- The government issued a communique tonight proclaiming the establishment of a legislative council and entrusting to Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, High Commissioner, wide veto powers over the new Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The only man in the United States who reported an income of more than $5,000,000 for 1933 lived in Illinois, but twenty-two out of fifty in the country who acknowledged net incomes of $1,000,000 or more resided in New York State, according to final tax statistics for that year made public today by the Treasury Department.

St. Francis Prep captured the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. dual meet swimming championship for the third successive year by turning back Brooklyn Prep, 49 -- 26, in one of the two league engagements staged at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, pool in Brooklyn yesterday.

Believing that the present debt burden of cities in the United States is quite high enough for comfort and safety, Dun Bradstreet, in a survey of municipal debt, declares any general increase would mean gambling with an uncertain future. The survey covered 190 cities with populations of more than 50,000, and showed that the average community debt was $109 per capita.

Thirty voices from the Schola Cantorum under the direction of Hugh Ross gave a Christmas concert for members and friends of the American Woman's Association last night at the American Woman's Club. The assisting soloists included Dorothy Jung and Ruth Kenworthy, sopranos; Lorraine Eley, mezzo-soprano; Evelyn Gross, contralto; Alan Adair, tenor; Theodore Everett, baritone, and George Bennett, violinist.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures announced yesterday its selection of the ten best American-made and foreign produced films released here between Dec. 20, 1934, and Dec. 20, 1935. The list, arranged alphabetically, follows:

DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin announced this afternoon that 40,000 volunteer, unpaid organizers were working in communities throughout the country organizing groups of 100 to 250 supporters of Congressional candidates who will support the "nationalization of the currency."

TOKYO, Dec. 22. -- Statements by Japanese military authorities disclosed tonight that Japan's army in Manchuria, with or without the consent of the Tokyo Government, had embarked on a definite campaign of military pressure on Outer Mongolia.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- A stronger statistical situation in the world's wheat markets than at present has not existed in many years, as viewed by the closest observers here. Supplies are considered to be more closely adjusted to consumptive requirements and the price is said to be low in the light of all the factors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Grain fu ture prices had a good range in the Chicago market last week, with enough buying on the breaks to cause reactions. In wheat, net gains over the closing prices of the previous week were 3/8 cent on the July, 7/8 cent on the May, and 1 7/8 cents on the December.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 22. -- Leo Mallory, 24-year-old Noroton (Conn.) golf professional, won the $1,000 first prize in the annual $5,000 Nassau British colonial open today with a score of 271 for the seventy-two-hole grind.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 22. -- General Eustoquio Gomez, cousin of Venezuela's late dictator, was shot to death yesterday in an invasion of the Governor's office here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- While pageants and special musical services were being given in many churches throughout Westchester County this afternoon, a fanfare of trumpets from the roof of the County Center here echoed through the frosty air, a prelude to the ushering in of the Christmas season program in the auditorium of the Center where more than 2,500 people were gathered.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- A day of doldrums and fluky offshore breezes marred the regular Sunday dinghy regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today. In Class B. Cornelius Shields's Prudence led the fleet of eight boats by a margin of 6 points, while the Class X boats were deadlocked, Samuel Wetherill's Eaglet and Hugh Kilmer's Idlerkin both turning in a total of 36 points.

The principal staff members of the Regents' Inquiry Into the Character and Cost of Public Education in this State and the scope of their individual assignments were announced yesterday by Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the inquiry, at the first staff meeting held yesterday morning in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 56 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and down 1 point from the week before, the highest week of the year. The showing was partly fictitious, however, because mills intend to run as little as possible this week as the holiday break raises costs, and as producers turned out as much tonnage as possible last week.

R.W. Pressprich Co. will offer today $1,100,000 of Salt Lake County, Utah, tax-anticipation bonds and refunding tax-anticipation bonds due on Dec. 31, 1936, and $1,250,000 of Salt Lake City tax-anticipation bonds, also due on Dec. 31, 1936. Both blocks of bonds will bear interest at the rate of 0.30 per cent and are to be offered on a yield basis of 0.40 per cent.
HYDERABAD, India, Dec. 22. -- The Nizam of Hyderabad will celebrate his silver jubilee next month, so he has ordered that 1,000 oxen and 10,000 sheep be slaughtered and roasted for the fete.
The rumblings of war in Ethiopia and war talk in Europe found echo in Christmas sermons preached in New York City yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--Materials bought for the WPA program have cost the government $68,974,161 to date, it was revealed today by a Treasury procurement official, who remarked, "we've just started buying."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22. -- As the end of the year approaches, ship operators of the Pacific Coast are figuring the results of their work during the past twelve months.

The stress of the depression has made man less self-assured and has created a greater faith in the spiritual, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the thirty-fifth anniversary services of the founding of the Bedford Park Presbyterian Church, Bainbridge Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx. Dr. Coffin was the first minister of the church.

KURE, Japan, Monday, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Admiral of the Fleet, Prince Hiroyasu Fushimi, Chief of the Naval General Staff, presided today over the launching of a vessel considered the last word in aircraft carrier construction.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Hill gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 1,125 Fifth Avenue, for Sir Peter Morton-Griffiths, Bart., and Lady Norton-Griffiths, who returned recently from their wedding trip in Mexico and are at 1,120 Fifth Avenue for the Winter; and also for Gwladys, Lady Norton-Griffiths and Miss Phoebe Norton-Griffiths.

In last week's progressive decrease of activity, alike in trade and on the markets, the entirely familiar precedent for this time of year was followed. That production and distribution should diminish at this time means merely that the "Christmas trade" is practically over and the dull days of "inventory-taking" just ahead; it is too late for retailers even to send in "re-orders."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 22. -- Captain Henry W. Dreyer, "the grand old man of the traps," was given an open testimonial turkey birthday shoot over the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. Notwithstanding the cold, the largest field of the year participated, twenty-seven gunners being on the firing line for the 16-yard event and twenty competing in the skeet test.

When Stanley Baldwin formed his Cabinet on June 7, Anthony Eden was prominently mentioned for the post of Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. As Lord Privy Seal he had gained great experience in international affairs and had traveled to all parts of Continental Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The part Alfred E. Smith may play in the campaign against the re-election of President Roosevelt and for the overthrow of the New Deal may be revealed in an address the former Governor of New York is scheduled to make here Jan. 25 at a dinner of the American Liberty League.
" Annie Oakley," an RKO production with Barbara Stanwyck, Melvyn Douglas and Preston Foster, opens this morning at the Astor.

A thirty-five-piece band representing the Hebrew Orphan Asylum of New York won first award for the second time yesterday in the finals of the annual band-orchestra contest of the orphanages of New York, held in Mecca Temple. 130 West Fifty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Actual statistics to show the course of Christmas trade in Great Britain this season compared with previous years are virtually confined to the index of retail trade and the note circulation of the Bank of England. The former will not be available for another month or so, but the Bank's figures clearly indicate a very satisfactory expansion of the spending power.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.4 on Dec. 18, compared with 71.1 a fortnight before, 71.3 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Senator Borah is an actual and aggressive candidate for the Republican nomination for President, according to members of an advisory board consisting of Senators and progressive leaders which has been formed to further his candidacy.

The enactment of a law which would remove profits from war activities would be more of a protection to the United States than a standing army of 1,000,000 men, according to an article in the forthcoming January issue of The American Legion Monthly by Bernard M. Baruch, chairman of the War Industries Board during the World War.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- British hopes for a French repercussion to Sir Samuel Hoare's resignation that would leave his fellow peace negotiator, Premier Pierre Laval, outside the governmental breastworks and definitely align France beside Great Britain in a united front against Premier Benito Mussolini and for a strong League of Nations, are likely to be disappointed so far as immediate effects are concerned.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1935, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

New York's ninety-eight voluntary hospitals gave more than 3,795,000 days of hospital service free this year. David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, said yesterday in appealing for gifts to the United Hospital campaign.

PANAMA, R.P., Dec. 22. -- Foreign Secretary J.D. Arosemena was nominated for the Presidency by the Revolutionary Coalition party by acclamation at a convention held at Anton today. This is the fifth nomination for the Presidency by different groups of the Liberal party and so far only one nominee has withdrawn.

Bethlehem is the city of the greatest sacrifice the world has ever known as well as the city where a great miracle took place, the Rev. Walter Theodore Taylor, pastor of the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The United States traded off outright tariff cuts for concessions composed principally of reductions in quantitative restrictions in the reciprocal trade agreement signed Friday with the Netherlands, it was made clear in the detailed analysis of the pact which the State Department gave out today.

Lady Elizabeth Lindsay, niece of Sir Ronald G. Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, and Baron and Baroness Ino Dan are among the passengers due today from Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Majestic. Others coming on the ship are:

John E. Mack, counsel to the legislative committee investigating public utilities, has received $76,500 to date as his fee, it became known yesterday. This covers the sixteen months from July 1, 1934, when he began his work, to Nov. 2, 1935.

Ten million wedding rings are the Italian nation's contributions to Ethiopian war costs. Their value is estimated at $80,000,000. The donors are to receive iron rings as a memento of their patriotic sacrifices. But if the war should last long enough, even the iron in 10,000,000 finger rings may be conscripted. Pictures have been published of little Italian children bringing in scrap iron in the form of old beds and utensils.

Harper Brothers announce that at the December meeting of their board of directors Lee Foster Hartman, editor of Harper's Magazine, and Frank S. McGregor, head of the college department, were made vice presidents of the firm. At the same meeting Ordway Tead, head of the economic book department, was made a director to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John Larkin.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- Business men and financiers await the advent of Christmas with a somewhat chastened sentiment, although there is optimism in certain quarters that the holiday will provide a breathing spell in the European uncertainties. There is, however, a feeling here that Germany's judicious passivity in the Ethiopian complexities has materially improved her international standing.

Josephine Antoine, young American coloratura soprano, will make her debut at the Metropolitan Opera House in the role of Philine in "Mignon" on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 4, according to an announcement yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson of the program for the third week of the season.

The distribution of United States cotton has shown highly favorable comparisons with last year in the last few weeks, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. During the last four weeks forwardings to mills of the world have amounted to 1,220,000 bales, compared with only 935,000 in the corresponding period last year, while exports have aggregated 1,005,000, compared with only 535,000 a year ago.

TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 22. -- One man was burned to death and three other persons burned or injured here early this morning in a fire caused by the short-circuiting of Christmas tree lights, left burning through the night.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, is facing opposition from three sources, it was learned yesterday. From within the organization, there has developed dissatisfaction over the tentative slate for delegates-at-large to the Republican National Convention and the tentative slate for key positions in the State Assembly.

Louis S. Posner's advocacy, as reported in THE TIMES, of a formation of a mortgage bank in this State patterned after mortgage banks in foreign countries, apparently indicates a misconception of the fundamental reasons for the success of a few of these banks.

S. Parker Gilbert, in a letter to THE TIMES, presents a point of view on the excess reserves in our banking system that is, it seems to me, unwarranted by the facts and unjustified by economic logic. This is "that no action should be taken, certainly at this time, to raise member bank reserve requirements," in order to lessen the danger of inflation.

The average annual earnings for 1,546 Barnard College alumnae from classes of 1893 to 1933, were $1,962 last year, according to a report made public yesterday by Miss Katherine S. Doty, head of the occupational bureau. The maximum salary was $16,000.

In the decision of Federal Judge OTIS at Kansas City that the Wagner Labor Act is invalid the main point is clear. It is that Congress has no constitutional power to regulate labor relations, or anything else, in manufacturing. It can regulate commerce between the States, but it cannot go to a private employer within a State and tell him how he must conduct his business.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The official news agency confirmed tonight the acquisition by the State of Thuringia of a Jewish-owned industrial undertaking, the Simson Company in Suhl, one of the leading arms-making concerns in Germany.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that in the future architects for all municipal projects will be selected from a list of fifty architects and architectural firms having offices in New York City. In making public the list of names on the eligible list, the Mayor also gave out the names of the "jurymen" who selected the list and also those who had recommended the jurymen.

Public offering will be made today of 40,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of G.C. Murphy Company at par by a banking group composed of Lazard Freres Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers, Blyth Co., Inc., and Burr Co.

ISTANBUL, Dec. 22. -- Turkey's readiness in agreement with the other signatories of the Balkan Pact to abide by the terms of Article XVI of the League of Nations covenant and support Great Britain in the event of an Italian attack in the Mediterranean has greatly impressed and pleased the Turkish people.

Captain ANTHONY EDEN was long ago indicated as a coming British Foreign Secretary. It was only a question of time and of rival claims. When Mr. BALDWIN became Prime Minister again and formed his Government, Sir SAMUEL HOARE, on account of his skill in piloting the India Bill through Parliament, was preferred above Mr. EDEN.

Harvard's players defeated the Princeton and Dartmouth teams yesterday to take the lead from the Tigers in the annual tournament for the championship of the H.Y. P.D. College Chess League. The second and third rounds were contested at the Marshall Chess Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Livestock prices declined early last week on poor support and fairly liberal offerings. Toward the close of the week there was a moderate rally, but the undertone of the market was weak until the closing day, when buyers took hold more readily, absorbing all the good stock offered and creating a somewhat better tone.

ABOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 22 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp with the new Northrop airplane for the relief of Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, left Magallanes at 8 o'clock Eastern standard time tonight.

TOKYO, Dec. 22. -- The majority of Japanese newspapers did not publish Senator Pittman's speech. The only Tokyo paper taking notice of the Senator's Phoenix utterance on Saturday is Nichi Nichi whose Washington correspondent cables that fears that the failure of the silver policy will encounter the sneers of the public are causing Senator Pittman to try to distract attention to foreign affairs.

I have just found comforting evidence that rumors of war have not driven all thoughts of Christmas out of mind on the other side of the Atlantic. It is in the form of a report in The London Daily Telegraph, which runs as follows:

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- Wearing earmuffs, fur gloves, heavy sweaters and galoshes, six members of the James King Hand Walking Club, founded forty-two years ago, held their annual pre-Christmas hike today. According to their official timekeeper, they broke the club walking record for three and one-half miles plus sixty feet, which they covered in 2 hours 20 minutes and 52 seconds.

The New Dance League gave its first recital of the season at the Adelphi Theatre last night before a large audience. Ten young dancers, nine of whom are now or have been members of either Martha Graham's group or that of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, contributed solos and duets of their own composition.

An annual study of capital and disbursements of 123 American foundations privately subsidized for the public good, including the several Carnegie and Rockefeller organizations, was published yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Dec. 22. -- Sport, a little tricolor cocker spaniel owned and handled by C.S. Fuller of Manchester, N.H., proved that his size was no handicap as he turned in an exceptionally fine performance today to carry off the top award in the Game-in-the-Bag Stake, which marked the close of the novel gun-dog variety of field trials which started yesterday.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Giant airplanes were flying both ways across the Pacific tonight, carrying holiday cargo as well as mail between California and the Orient.

Birth control advocates again were criticised from Catholic pulpits yesterday while a Protestant clergyman suggested in his sermon that the controversy had disclosed "how much the pattern of thought of churchmen has actually changed in the last decade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Thomas D. Schall, blind Republican Senator from Minnesota, a vitriolic critic of the New Deal, died at 11:31 A.M. today after a sinking spell which began suddenly four hours earlier.

In The Saturday Review of Literature Mr. THOMAS WOLFE describes in part the gestation of "Of Time and the River," a work, if the majority vote of contemporary critics is the voice of the future, to endure for ages. The building of so grandiose a structure is a process of keen interest not only to literary contractors and manufacturers but to the whole guild of "creative artists."

EVERGLADES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Moving as silently as shadows, the Seminoles will emerge from the depths of the Everglades on Friday to participate in a Christmas party arranged for them by a missionary from Buffalo, N.Y.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Baseball's oldest old-timer, drawing a step nearer the 80-year age deadline he has set for himself in the diamond game, is looking at his gloomiest prospects in years with all the enthusiasm and confidence of a youngster.

A busy week's first new present is "The Season Changes," which will be unwrapped tonight at the Booth -- Arthur Richman's first Broadway play since "Heavy Traffic," back in 1928. Robert Milton produces and stages this one, with a cast which includes Phyllis Joyce, Eliot Cabot, Doris Dudley, Nicholas Joy, Zamah Cunningham, James Spottswood, Beatrice Hendricks and Hope Landin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Johnny Cooney, veteran Indianapolis outfielder, will carry the 1935 American Association batting championship along next Spring when he reports to the Brooklyn Dodgers for a major league trial.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,577,857,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
Unselfish and inspiring letters, rich with the spirit of Christmas, brought 336 contributions, totaling $8,086.36, to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday plans for combating excessive chartering of new banks in a statement by Robert V. Fleming, president of the association. Its statement accompanied a report of the history of bank-chartering policies in this country prepared by the economic policy commission of the association under the direction of Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--Secretary Roper sounded a cheerful note tonight in his annual report to Congress that "available evidence" indicates the nation's net business losses were "almost completely eliminated" in 1935.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22. -- A communique issued today by Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, High Commissioner, says that at separate meetings Arab and Jewish leaders both suggested that they receive time to study the proposals for a Palestine legislative council.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 22. -- President Lazaro Cardenas told 75,000 workers, massed before the National Palace here after parading, that former President Plutarco Elias Calles was "no problem for the government or for the workers."
AS a resident of College Point for many years I have naturally been interested in its transportation difficulties and how they blend with Greater New York's traffic movement.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The financial markets have experienced a trying week as a result of the City's reaction to the Cabinet crisis, the critical Parliamentary debate on the Anglo-French peace plan, the chaotic silver situation and the threat of a national coal strike.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Censorship was clamped down tonight on all Venezuelan newspapers and other news-distributing sources. It is reported to have coincided with widespread rioting and insurrection that began Saturday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 22. -- Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas is the only Republican who could carry this State, with its nine electoral votes, against President Roosevelt if the Presidential election were held today, it is believed by most political observers here.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- Twenty-nine gunners took part in the weekend shoot over the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. The best work was done by P.M. McHugh, who won the scratch trophy in the singles by finishing with 47 out of 50 targets, he handicap prize went to C.W. Deyo, who had a full card.
Real estate activity reported in the city over the week-end was confined chiefly to deals involving housing properties.

Both Eino Pentti and his Millrose A.A. teammates successfully defended their Metropolitan A.A.U. senior cross-country individual and team titles, respectively, in the annual championship run held yesterday in Forest Park, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Capitol Hill colleagues of Senator Schall mingled expressions of sorrow over the Minnesotan's death today with tribute to his lifetime victory over the handicap of blindness.
Mrs. John L. Montgomery gave a Sunday night buffet supper dance last night at the Sherry-Netherland for her debutante daughter, Miss Henrietta Wardwell. Spring flowers were used in the decorations.

Secretary ROPER'S annual report for 1934-35 covers a period more cheerful to write about than any fiscal year which has fallen to the lot of a Secretary of Commerce since 1929. Particularly during the latter part of this period there were marked gains in industrial production, in retail sales and in factory employment.

Del S. Harder, now on the staff of Thomas P. Arches, vice president of Fisher Body in charge of operations, will be transferred to Grand Rapids as resident manager of the new plant to be constructed for the Grand Rapids stamping division of General Motors.

With 175 riders competing, indoor bicycle and motor paced racing was inaugurated at the New York Coliseum last night. Seven events, witnessed by a crowd of 5,000 composed the program which was staged over the newly constructed seven-lap track.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Life secrets of Thelma Todd interested authorities today as a grand jury prepared to open its investigation tomorrow in an effort to solve the movie star's death.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The chaotic condition into which the London silver market was thrown by the virtual withdrawal of the United States as a buyer here, continues. Dealings still are being made only for cash, while the price of the metal has fallen 7d an ounce since the United States changed its purchasing procedure less than a fortnight ago.

The Jewish Education Association, engaged in the promotion of religious education for Jewish boys and girls in this city, observed the 2,100th anniversary of the Festival of Hanukkah last night with a dinner at the Hotel Astor, which was attended by more than 1,000 members and guests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Relief workers in Pennsylvania are compelled to pay political assessments to the Democratic organization. Republicans are denied work-relief unless they disavow their party and the WPA has been "degraded into a Democratic pie counter," former Governor Pinchot charged tonight in an open letter to President Roosevelt.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 22. -- The alleged reason for the recent deportation of Swedish Protestant missionaries from Italian Somaliland and Eritrea is that they were involved in political propaganda agitation against the government. But the deported missionaries, who have arrived in Sweden, maintain that the accusation is unfounded, for they have always kept perfectly neutral.
The following unsigned letter, one of those received with yesterday's contributions to the Neediest, explains graphically the "undiminished need for private charity":

N.Y.U. and St. John's gave impressive performances during the past week, as six of the leading college basketball teams in the Metropolitan district remained undefeated. Columbia was the only one to drop out of the unbeaten circle, while N.Y.U., St. John's, L.I.U., Manhattan, C.C.N.Y. and Fordham held to their winning pace.

The doctrine of racial purity "now vigorously preached in at least one modern land" is contrary to the testimony of history and anthropology, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared in his annual report to the university trustees, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- In line with the administration's efforts to make interest rates cheaper throughout the country, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, offered today to increase the Illinois Central's debt to his agency by $7,444,667 to $25,000,000 and to make the entire loan at 4 per cent.

The first of the community youth centers sponsored by Byrnes MacDonald, director of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, will be opened at Manhattan and Greenpoint Avenues, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, at 4:30 P.M. today.

LATTINGTOWN, L.I., Dec. 22. -- John E. Aldred, chairman of the board of the Gillette Razor Company and president of Aldred Co., bankers of New York, was elected Mayor of Lattingtown at a special meeting today of trustees of the municipality, to succeed the late Mayor William D. Guthrie, who held office from the time the village was incorporated.

CLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Eric Seavall of Viking ancestry showed today he knew something of the Scottish pastime of golf when he shot a 68, two strokes under par, to take the lead at the half-way mark in the Southern California $3,000 open championship.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22. -- The government's crop estimates indicate that Argentina will have only 64,000,000 bushels of wheat for export in 1936, compared with 143,000,000 exported to date this year. Argentina exported 172,000,000 bushels of wheat in 1934 and 142,000,000 in 1933.
The three American delegates to the International Labor Office Maritime Conference at Geneva returned yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines.

Foster mothers who raise homeless babies meet the responsibility with "normal or better" results, according to a three-year experimental survey conducted by the Home Bureau of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, made public yesterday.

Paul Graetz, a German stage and film actor and a former member of the Reinhardt stage in Berlin, who left Germany after Hitler came into power, has arrived here on a holiday visit. During the last two and one-half years he has made eleven films in London for British International Pictures, British Gaumont and Warner Brothers First National.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- The Nazi party and the German Nordic pagans celebrated tonight and last night an ancient pagan and modern Nazi festival of the Winter solstice. Hitler Special Guards, the backbone of the Nazi regime, were mobilized for the occasion.

Aground off Cape May, N.J., the steamship Iriona, managed by the United Fruit Company, furnished the first marine casualty of the Winter yesterday after the season had begun officially in the afternoon to the accompaniment of snow along the Atlantic Seaboard and in many parts of the United States.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 22. -- At the conclusion late today of the final series in the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, the awards were announced to a shivering gallery that stood on the sands of Lloyds Harbor, having gallantly braved the cold through two long sessions.

The new ten-story building of the Home of the Sons and Daughters of Israel was officially opened at 232-38 East Twelfth Street yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies included a parade, an address by Samuel Levy, President of the Borough of Manhattan, and the contribution of approximately $40,000 in small sums toward the maintenance of the home.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Princeton University conferred athletic awards upon 190 men for their participation in Fall sports, according to an announcement today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics The gridiron men head the list of those winning insignia, 129 on four squads being honored.

A goal by Clarie Shillington in the overtime period, scored so suddenly that players and spectators alike seemed stunned, enabled the New York Rovers to move into a tie for second place with Hershey in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League yesterday.

John Holley Clark Jr. and Thomas Keogh of counsel for the trustees for the Series Q certificate holders of the New Fork Title and Mortgage Company announced yesterday that they had begun a $6,000,000 damage action against the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

As an uncompromising critic of the New Deal and all its works Senator Schall gained nation-wide notice for his attacks not only upon the program of the Roosevelt administration but also upon the personalities of its members, including President Roosevelt himself.
Department of Justice agents carefully covered their activities yesterday as they inquired into the puzzling disappearance and return of Caleb Milne 4th of 159 East Thirty-seventh Street.

The United States Sugar Corporation, in its fourth annual report, covering the fiscal year ended on June 30, reports net earnings of $339,923 before Federal income tax, compared with $232,624 for the preceding twelve months. After provision for Federal taxes and preferred stock dividends, earnings were equivalent to 18 cents a share on the common stock.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.4, which compares with 84 the week before, 84.6 two weeks before, 84.5 three weeks before and 84.3 four weeks before.

MADRID, Dec. 22. -- The conclusion of a new trade treaty between Spain and France yesterday cleared the way for the early signature of a new commercial pact between the United States and this country.

The local wholesale markets continued very active last week, as last-minute orders for holiday items developed. Promotional goods for January sales, cruise and resort wear and regular Spring merchandise were also ordered, swelling the total volume of business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Plans to put another government radio program on the air were disclosed today with the announcement that President Roosevelt had allotted $1,983,000 of work relief funds to the Office of Education for five projects intended to provide 3,400 jobs.

Again last week it was the erratic movement of the French franc which gripped the attention of the traders in the foreign exchange market. At midweek the franc had risen to a premium against the dollar for the first time in months, but later reacted to close at a loss.

The United States Civil Service Commission, in its annual report to the President, renews its recommendation that those of the New Deal organizations destined to become permanent parts of the Government be brought within the scope of the Civil Service Law.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22 (AP). -- Uncle Sam's $30,000,000 Christmas gift to St. Louis -- the Thomas Jefferson Riverfront Memorial -- found a mixed welcome today.

Governor Lehman has been asked by the New York County July, 1934, grand jury to intervene to bring about a vigorous prosecution of the indictments in ten mortgage certificate cases which remain untried, Charles A. Richards, secretary of the grand jury, made known last evening.

The City Club, in a letter to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday, opposed rerouting of the College Point Ferry and establishing a new terminus for it in Chisholm Park, Queens, as proposed under a bill recently passed by the Municipal Assembly.

The gayest and happiest Christmas for many years was forecast yesterday from a number of pulpits in New York City. At the same time the clergy reminded their congregations of the serious obligations which should not be forgotten during the holiday season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- Oats had support here last week on the breaks from cereal interests, and the volume of business gained slightly, with the December covering a range of 1 1/2 cents a bushel, the other months showing about the same to a somewhat smaller range, the close being at net gains of 3/8 to 3/4 cent, the latter on December, which finished at 26 7/8 cents.

NORRIS, Tenn., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Quakers, Catholics, Methodists, Baptists and Presbyterians joined in a simple, feryent three-hour religious service in the Tennessee Valley Authority's model town of Norris today -- the town that has been called "Godless."

Scrooge should not be admitted to performances of the Yale Puppeteers. After a reputable experience in Hollywood and at least one season in their own showshop in Forty-sixth Street, they are now perched in the Nora Bayes Theatre, where they lifted the curtain last evening.

Trading was extremely mixed on the commodity futures markets here last week, with the volume declining in anticipation of the holidays. Price changes were about evenly divided between advances and declines. In the cash markets, all the grains, as well as cotton, wool tops, rubber and butter, gained ground, while eggs, lard, antimony, tin, silk and hides declined.

With entertainments and the distribution of gifts, Christmas week festivities begin today for thousands of the underprivileged children of the metropolis and for the shut-ins in the hospitals and other institutions of the city.

Joseph Urban, 49 years old, of 1,385 York Avenue, was killed yesterday morning when he was struck by an automobile while walking across First Avenue at Seventy-second Street.
