The driver of the car, John Hall, 27, of 645 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, failed to stop, according to the police, and was arrested ten blocks away after a chase.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses made public yesterday the plans for the playground he intends to build on the site of the Central Park Casino, when and if he wins his fight to oust the lessees of the 70-year-old structure. Since Mr. Moses brought his suit, control of the restaurant has passed from Sidney Solomon, the original lessee, to Angelo C. Scavullo and his associates.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Anthony Eden was appointed Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin here this afternoon and tonight there was an official announcement from Downing Street that the King had approved this selection of a successor to Sir Samuel Hoare.

The re-run of the 1906 dead heat between Eddie (Flash) McDermott of the West Side A.C. and Jack (King) Kelly of the Pastime A.C. in the Metropolitan A.A.U. half-mile championship did not take place yesterday as scheduled. Kelly was unable to make an appearance at Macombs Dam Park because of the illness of his wife.

The celebration of the seventy-fifth birthday of Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization, continued yesterday with a meeting of more than 1,000 women at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Two hundred and fifty-three members of the younger social set were routed out of bed before 1 P.M. yesterday to attend a hunt breakfast at the Hotel Lombardy for the benefit of the Big Brother movement.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Britain's "contemptible little army" will undergo sweeping modernization as a result of changes outlined in a War Office announcement tonight.

Margaret Flint of Bay St. Louis, Miss., has won the $10,000 prize for the best first novel in the Pictorial Review-Dodd, Mead contest, Herbert R. Mayes, editor of Pictorial Review, announced yesterday. Margaret Flint is the wife of an engineer and the mother of six children.
The Department of Agriculture yesterday made public the report submitted by J.N. Darling before his resignation as chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey.

If "Jesus the Jew" returned to a "Christian world," he would find it marred by a multitude of evils that violate every canon of His teachings, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise said yesterday in his annual pre-Christmas sermon in the Free Synagogue at Carnegie Hall.

President WILLKIE of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation made a speech before the Bond Club here last week which offers a challenge to Federal statesmanship. He began by a recital of the attempts which he and other forward-looking utility leaders made last Winter to reach a compromise with the anti-utility forces at Washington.

By breaking 95 out of 100 targets A.L. Burns captured the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The high handicap prize went to W.S. Pate, who had a card of 84, 27 -- 100, G.E. Churchill finishing next with 89, 9 -- 98.

VIENNA, Dec. 22. -- The charge against the mechanic Johann Kollitsch of having defrauded the Viennese mechanic Heinrich Schlitz, whose sculptor son Robert, it was stated, is now serving a life sentence for murder in Fort Leavenworth, Kan., was dropped in the Vienna courts yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- The improved New York Americans defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, in an overtime National Hockey League battle tonight before a crowd of 10,000 to go into a tie with the Montreal Maroons for second place in the International division.

Prices of cotton were generally steadier last week. After an early break of 22 to 25 points, quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange took on steadiness and final quotations on Saturday were 6 points lower to 29 points higher than at the close of the preceding week.

HOPEWELL, Va., Dec. 22. -- Fourteen persons met death in the icy waters of the Appomattox River here today when an Atlantic Greyhound bus plunged through an open drawbridge. None of those aboard was saved.

ETHIOPIAN ARMY HEADQUARTERS ON THE SOUTHERN FRONT, Jigija, Ethiopia, Dec. 2. -- One interesting lesson taught by the Italo-Ethiopian War is that the terror value of modern equipment such as tanks and airplanes is soon lost even on the most savage and ignorant troops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Tales of the activities of the government agents assigned to curb wholesale slaughter of ducks and other game came today from the pen of J.N. (Ding) Darling, cartoonist.

With the stroke of a master, 25-year-old James Caras of Wilmington, Del., ascended to the world's pocket billiard championship last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania by handing the veteran Cleveland expert, Erwin Rudolph, a decisive setback in the play-off game for the crown.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- The news that Anthony Eden has been appointed to succeed Sir Samuel Hoare as British Foreign Minister was learned in Rome with a feeling of intense dismay and apprehension. It is felt no worse choice could have been made.

TAIYUAN, Shansi Province, China, Dec. 22. -- If a fight on communism is to be the excuse, as has been intimated, for General Sung Cheh-yuan's autonomists to bring pressure on Shansi Province to join them, apparently it will not be the fault of Governor Yen Hsishan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A beautiful sky display for the sole benefit of a few penguins will be staged by the sun and moon over Antarctica on Christmas night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Publication in this morning's NEW YORK TIMES of the fact that the Department of Labor and the Office of Education have made a report on misuse of Federal grants to States in aid of vocation training, led today to the disclosure that the matter is under investigation by the subcommittee on appropriations for the Interior Department.

Gifts to the Neediest fell off sharply yesterday, and the fund for those in greatest need in all New York stands on Christmas Eve at $187,719.94, far from sufficient to care for all of those who most require help.

The marriage of Miss largaret Williams Lewis, daughter of the lev. Dr. and Irs. Frederick Wheeler Lewis, to the Rev. Camerdn David Lee Mosser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis O. Mosser of Perkasie, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon in the Throop Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, of which the bride's father is pastor.

Thirteen players were named yesterday to comprise the ice hockey squad which will represent the United States in the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, early next year. The announcement of the personnel of the group was made by Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee.
Harvard's chess team won the annual H.Y.P.D. League championship yesterday, holding Yale to a 2-2 tie in the final and finishing with a point score of 8 -- 4.

Casper Holstein, spectacular Harlem Negro who was kidnapped by white men for $50,000 ransom several years ago, was arrested last night on a charge of financing a policy racket. Another man and three women were arrested during the evening on charges of possessing policy slips.

The plan of presenting cash orders on any future performance of the Metropolitan Opera Association as Christmas gifts was adopted this season for the first time and has met with an immediate wide response, it was disclosed yesterday. The plan, long in use in shops throughout the town, has brought in about $1,000 in the last few days.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- A feeling of regret and sympathy pervaded the community in which the Charles A. Lindberghs have made their home since the birth of their second son, Jon, when residents learned today that they had departed for England.

Private detectives in the city have been nursing a grievance for some time against the police. They assert that the "cops" do not treat them with a proper respect, that they apparently do not realize that a private detective is a licensed professional and that a majority of patrolmen seem to think that their badges come from some junk or toy shop.

In volume of travel to and from the city, in the volume of last-minute shopping, in the gayety and spontaneity of the charitable activities ushering in the holiday week, New York appeared yesterday to be approaching one of the gayest Christmas celebrations since the beginning of the depression.
Mrs. H.A. Condon Barler gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Harriet Celia Durstine.
In an editorial you suggest that the Social Security Bill be revised to make it workable.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- A further example of the Laval government's lack of authority was given this afternoon when the Senate rejected the wording of the first article in the government-supported bill for the suppression of patriotic leagues and substituted its own phraseology.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Action of the Federal District Court for Eastern Wisconsin in quashing mail fraud-indictments against Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was permitted to stand today by the Supreme Court. The appeal was dismissed because of lack of jurisdiction.

Many of the letters sent to THE TIMES along with contributions to the Neediest Cases are of peculiar interest. Some of them testify to long-continued observation of this private charity. One recent communication revealed the fact that the donor had himself been, twenty-two years ago, on the list of Neediest Cases of that time.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 23. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted the 1936 county budget this afternoon. It was the largest in the history of the county with an 18-point rise in the tax rate. The board also received the annual tax apportionment table from the committee on tax equalization, and voted $75,000 as the county's share of more than $840,000 in approved WPA projects.

A spirited argument between Magistrate Charles Solomon, Socialist leader, and braham Kartzman, counsel for May's department store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, marked an all-day hearing yesterday in Bay Ridge Court of fifteen cases involving twenty-nine men and nine women charged with disorderly conduct for picketing in front of the store.

An admonition to help cope with the "menace of radicalism and communism" by maintaining the "principles of free government," coupled with a warning against "violent outbursts" in the court room, was delivered yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division to 182 new lawyers admitted to the New York State bar.

The Emergency Relief Bureau announced yesterday the dismissal of an additional 259 members of its staff as a result of the reduction of transient families now being cared for. The dismissed employes were given two weeks' notice.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake today approved the sale of the Jersey City plant of the American Type Founders Company to the Arvey Corporation, Inc., in Illinois, for $250,000.
Amelia Earhart voiced her discomfiture yesterday at having been forced to follow a political speaker at a dinner in her honor at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street, Sunday night.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday that it had earned its full preferred dividend in the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, the first twelve-month period in more than two years in which it had done so. Its net income was $9,048,112, equal to $6.03 a share on the 1,499,480 no-par shares of $6 preferred, on which the dividends have accumulated, compared with $8,236,104, or $5.49 a share, in the preceding year.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The City College Chess team, with a record of 5 1/2 points out of a possible 6, led the first session yesterday of the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League. All games were played at the Manhattan Chess Club.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23. -- Under the headline "Harvest Experts in Moscow'' the newspaper Izvestia describes on its front page the arrival in the Soviet capital of 426 presidents and "brigade leaders" of the most successful collective farms, 434 of the best tractor operators and 97 threshing-machine operators.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 23. -- Great satisfaction is felt here over the appointment of Anthony Eden as the British Foreign Secretary. It is taken as a sign that the League of Nations policy not only prevails in Great Britain but will be enforced elsewhere.

Publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the secret sailing for England of Colonel and Mrs. LINDBERGH and their child, in order to find there a safer residence than their own country can guarantee them, carries tragic implications which need not be dwelt upon.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The death of more than 600 Ethiopians and the wounding of 1,000 more were reported by the Italian high command tonight as a result of yesterday's fighting in the Tembien mountain region, which ended with an Ethiopian flight up the Tanqua Valley
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Two new points in the Thelma Todd death mystery were given a grand jury today as it opened an investigation. These were:
leat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.
A recently enacted law that abrogates a 104-year-old statute making imprisonment for debt impossible, was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 23 (AP) --- Mysterious "influences" which the prosecution asserted would "handicap investigation" of the Walter Liggett murder case were cited in District Court today in a successful move to block Isadore (Kid Cann) Blumenfeld's release on bail.

Mrs. Etta Reisman, 35-year-old Queens housewife who had been convicted of manslaughter in the first degree for the slaying of her husband's secretary, was freed yesterday by County Judge Charles S. Colden in the Queens County Court. He expressed hope that fate would deal more kindly with her in the future.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Federal Judge H.H. Watkins held today for the second time that the Public Works Administration had no legal right to make a $2,800,000 loan and grant to Greenwood County, S.C., for a publicly owned hydroelectric plant.

The members of the squash racquets team chosen by the United States Squash Racquets Association to invade England came home a few hours ahead of time yesterday because they had decided to sleep a bit longer of a morning in London.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Dec. 24. -- Comment in the German press on Colonel Lindbergh's decision to leave the United States is contained chiefly in such headlines as "Lindbergh Flees American Kidnappers"; "Lindbergh in Flight"; "Gangsters Force Lindbergh to Flee From America."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- While none of the experts of the Securities and Exchange Commission believes the policy of segregating the functions of broker and dealer on national securities exchanges should be put into effect at this time, some of them, it was learned tonight, have made suggestions to the commission for steps which, in their opinion, might make that course feasible eventually.

HOPEWELL, Va., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Police believed tonight they knew the identity of twelve victims of the bus accident here yesterday and had tentative identifications of the two others. The fourteen were killed when a Greyhound bus bound from Richmond to Raleigh, N.C., plunged through an open drawbridge into the Appomattox River yesterday morning.

MALONE, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Purchase by William A. Rockefeller from Bay Pond, Inc., of part of the Adirondack estate acquired by his grandfather early in the century was made known today with the recording of the deed in the County Clerk's office.

Mayor La Guardia has been chosen to receive the Pi Lamda Phi tolerance medal for 1935, an award given annually to the person in the world who best exemplifies the spirit of tolerance. The recipient of the medal last year was James G. MacDonald, High Commissioner for German Refugees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Published statements that the public debt rose $900,000,000 overnight, used in describing last week's Treasury operations, were criticized by President Roosevelt today as a deception of the people.
I am somewhat hazy in regard to the Borah "liberalism" now being heralded rather widely.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Walking home with a paper bag containing crullers in his hand, William E. Keer of 92 Walnut street, 60-year-old retired diamond merchant, was abducted by two gunmen in an automobile today, and robbed of $35 and a gold watch and chain.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Fate has ordained that the new Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, is not to have a quiet Christmas holiday. His first grave problem has already arrived. The ever-extending repercussions of the tension in the Mediterranean have brought Turkey into the orbit of world politics with a vengeance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The administration is disposed to await action by Congress on neutrality before developing its policy further with reference to exports to Italy and Ethiopia.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 23. -Stockholders of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation today mustered a quorum of all classes of stock and proceeded to achieve the objectives set forth in the call for the special meeting, which began here on Dec. 17.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Dissolution of the National Recovery Administration on Jan. 1 was decreed in an executive order issued today by President Roosevelt.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Dec. 24 (AP). -Demonstrating students opposed to North China autonomy clashed with policemen in busy Nanking Road, the remnants of the throng marching on to the city's large railroad terminal to reinforce more than 1,000 students who had seized the station.
John J. McElligott, Fire Commissioner, issued a reminder to motorists yesterday that the law required them to pull over to the curb and stop as soon as they hear the sirens of fire apparatus.
SAPULPA, Okla., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Two bodies, the last of five sought as victims of an itinerant oil field worker, were found today by squirrel hunters in a field west of here.
In contrast to the holiday activity, the real estate market was dull yesterday.

ON BOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 23. -- On her way to carry out the requirements laid down before Lincoln Ellsworth and Pilot Herbert Hollick-Kenyon left her, the Wyatt Earp is braving the dreaded Cockburn Channel -- a few miles north of Cape Horn and through which ships pass only in an emergency.

Business continued to show general improvement through November and the first half of December, according to the monthly survey by the National Industrial Conference Board. More-than-seasonal increases were made in November, compared with October, in motor vehicle production and sales, in steel production, electric power output and retail trade, the board reported yesterday.

What is the reason for present-day loafing by young men? Why are they seen congregated in cigar stores, poolrooms and drug stores? They have no jobs and no apparent interest in getting any. They simply sit back and wait. But what are they waiting for?

The State of Louisiana yesterday made the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of 4 1/2 per cent highway bonds to a group headed by the Chase National Bank at a price of 107.11. The bonds are dated Dec. 15, 1935, and mature serially from Dec. 15, 1939 to 1960.

Forgetting for a half hour their curiously divergent walks of life, some 500 persons paused on their way home from work yesterday afternoon to stand together around the forty-foot Christmas tree set up in the middle of Broad Street before the entrance to the New York Stock Exchange and sing Christmas carols while the rush-hour taxis and limousines had to detour or wait.
Commodity futures were irregular in light trading on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets wheat and rye advanced, while corn and tin declined.

Mrs. Stephen S. Wise, white-haired wife of the rabbi, joined a picket line yesterday morning to protest against the sale of German-made toys and novelties. For forty minutes, while an icy wind tore at the placard signs she carried, Mrs. Wise marched back and forth in front of the store of B. Shackman Co. at Thirty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The stock markets here were quiet today, with a small pre-holiday attendance. Industrials generally were better, but there was little buying The tone mostly was firm, helped by better week-end advices from New York. British funds were dull.
Homer C. Holland of Holland Co., 52 Broadway, was elected yesterday to membership in the New York Security Dealers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation was revealed today as drafting new recommendations for a broad reorganization of the Interstate Commerce Commission. The recommendations were reported to call for an increase in membership and a sharper division of duties to aid the handling of new transportation problems.

ROME, Dec. 23. -- After having thought things over for twenty-four hours the Italian press is inclined to take a less serious view of Anthony Eden's appointment as British Foreign Secretary than might have been expected.

Contributions to private charity total only 2.3 per cent of the national income, although the United States permits income tax deductions up to 15 per cent for this purpose, Charles V. Vickrey, executive secretary of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Answering questions at a press conference, President Roosevelt today limited the administration's relief commitment to caring for 3,500,000 employable unemployed persons in this fiscal year.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- California snapped the Temple quintet's winning streak by rallying in the closing minutes to gain a sensational 49-43 decision at the Arena tonight before 5,000 fans.

An estate of $1,341,576 net was left by Mrs. Blanche F. Wolf, philanthropist, when she died on Feb. 28, 1934, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The bulk of the estate goes to her husband, Frank Wolf, retired woolen merchant and former president of the Bruner Woolen Co.

Some formula which will limit imports of competitive cotton textiles from Japan to specific quantities in each of the various cotton fabric classifications and subclassifications, is called for in a statement made public yesterday by Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- The appointment of Anthony Eden as British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs has given rise to much guessing in Paris as to the future course of events, a great deal of which is far from being bounded by respect for facts or principles.

Mayor La Guardia opened yesterday the first of the community youth centers, sponsored by Byrnes MacDonald, director of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, at the Geenpoint Post, American Legion Building, Manhattan and Greenpoint Avenues, Brooklyn.

With the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group preparing to open negotiations today with representatives of the union, Louis Rubin, executive director of the organization, declared last night that the main objective to be sought in the writing of a new agreement will be definite assurance of uninterrupted production.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP). --The dropping of 521 employes from State payrolls was ordered tonight by Governor Albert B. Chandler, effective Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A suggestion that Postmaster General Farley may have violated the Corrupt Practices Act in sending invitations to the Jackson Day dinner to be held here Jan. 8 was made tonight in a radio speech by Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Step Miss, a 2-year-old filly that began her racing career in highly promising fashion in Florida last Winter, regained the form she left here almost a year ago when she led home a half dozen other juveniles in the fourth event at Tropical Park today.

VIENNA, Dec. 23. -- Joyous Christmas tidings for the workers of Austria were broadcast tonight by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, who announced unqualified amnesty for all except fourteen jailed after the civil war of February, 1934, which ended in the overthrow of the Socialists and of the democratic system by the Heimwehr and Clericals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- December wheat developed increased congestion on the Board of Trade today, and while there was some selling of the current month against purchases of the May credited to leading longs, the spread between the two deliveries widened to 4 3/4 cents a bushel at the close, compared with 3 1/4 cents on Saturday, while at the extreme the December was in new ground since Oct. 16.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Dec. 15 shows the following changes in paper pesos:

The United States Government, which recently filed liens for more than $50,000,000 against the Associated Gas Electric Company, representing its claim for income taxes for 1927 through 1933,, indicated yesterday that it would cooperate with creditors seeking reorganization of the company under the Bankruptcy Law.

Since tonight is devoted mainly to a happy, rotund little man with whiskers and a passion for sooty chimneys, the Broadway theatres will just accept their place as second-best attraction and will mark time. There are no openings, although "Squaring the Circle," "The Children's Hour," "Blind Alley," "Remember the Day" and "Mulatto" -- which took a vacation last night -- will return to the fold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The departure of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his family for England to find a haven of safety stirred Washington today and drew from Congressional sources the reaction that further legislation might be necessary to stamp out the gangster conditions that caused the famous aviator to forsake the United States.

Up to the closing decade of the last century, hunters in rural sections of the country were wont to work up enthusiasm for the Christmas Day festivities by engaging in organized shooting competitions, called "side hunts."

Katharine Cornell has offered again her best Christmas card to the city of New York, returning once more her production of "Romeo and Juliet" to the Martin Beck for the holiday time. It is still appreciated, for such changes she has made in the design have not detracted from the spirit nor from the beauty.

The first effect of Mayor F.H. La Guardia's order prohibiting the sale of small artichokes in city markets after Christmas was reflected yesterday in lowered retail prices for the delicacy, which the Mayor says is controlled by racketeers.

Consolidation of three wholly owned operating subsidiaries of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was announced yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president of the corporation. The subsidiaries are the McClintock-Marshall Corporation, the Pacific Coast Steel Corporation and the Kalman Steel Corporation.

Mr. J.F. ESSARY, at Washington the experienced and impartial watcher of the political scene for The Baltimore Sun, has been perambulating the Grass Roots States. He has conned their economic and political conditions. His observations are recorded in The Atlantic Monthly for January.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press). -- R.W. Breadner, former Commissioner of Customs for Canada, was internationally known as an expert on tariffs and taxation. At the time of his retirement early this year he was one of Canada's veteran civil servants with fifty years of service.

Police Commissioner Valentine, as he rode to work down Lafayette Street yesterday morning, blinked in amazement at a fifteen-foot sign near Police Headquarters that shrieked in fresh blue and gold paint:
Editorial comment on the departure of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh with his wife and son to take up permanent residence in England included the following:

Settlement of the remaining interest in December before trading ceases at noon today increased premiums on the spot month on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Contrasting with the urgent demand for near deliveries, October was under pressure, and the close was 7 points Up to 9 down.

Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the Federal Theatre Project, yesterday furnished the first picture thus far compiled of the attempt to resuscitate the stage in cities from Boston to San Francisco.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- Surrounded by members of his family, Connie Mack, veteran manager of the Athletics quietly celebrated his seventy-third birthday at his home in Germantown today. Telegrams and letters from friends in all parts of the country were spread before him wishing him continued health and baseball activity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 23. -- Plans of the Student League for Industrial Democracy and the National Student League were upset today when Dr. George W. Rightmire, president of Ohio State University, refused to permit the groups to meet in a campus building over the next week-end.
James Caras of Wilmington, Del., new world pocket billiard champion, will defend the title early next April in a 750-point challenge match with Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland.

IT is, of course, quite the usual thing to pin stories on a man when he doesn't happen to be around to deny or confirm them. Still, no great sympathy need be extended toward Mike Jacobs. For when a man sees fit to go gallavanting off to promote another fight in Cuba, where one fight more or less hardly is to be noticed, he should be expected to suffer the consequences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Never in his long career have words of Alfred E. Smith been waited for more anxiously by politicians than those he is scheduled to utter at the dinner of the American Liberty League in Washington on Jan. 25. The anxiety of the Republicans arises from hope, that of the Democrats from fear.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Justice Department was silent today on the disclosure that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had taken his family to England because of business and what friends said was growing apprehension over the safety of his 3-year-old son, Jon.
ROME, Dec. 23. -- By a strange circumstance France will be called on within a few days to solve the same political and moral problem under two different aspects:

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, who have provided the main scoring punch in the National Hockey League for many a season, are leading again this year. Last week they were paced by the veteran Buzz Boll, used in a utility role most of last season and now one of the team's main dynamos.
The best first baseman in the National League during 1935 wanted to retire to the business of bench managing in 1936.

The New York University quintet sprinted in the homestretch last night, after dawdling for most of the way, and finally staggered through to a 33-25 victory over Brooklyn College before a capacity crowd of 1,600 that had the rafters in the Heights gymnasium re-echoing to their frantic cheers.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23. -- Jockey Charley Stevenson, leading Wayne Wright in a close race for American riding honors this year, increased his advantage by scoring a consecutive triple at the Fair Grounds today. Stevenson now has 192 winners, five more than Wright, and with seven more days of racing i here before the end of'the year aas an excellent chance to reach 200.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP). -- The government of Outer Mongolia, press dispatches from Ulan Bator (Urga) said today, has taken a firm stand in face of an alleged threat of a Japanese-Manchukuoan invasion, telegraphing a peremptory demand to Manchukuo for an apology because of a border clash last week in which five Mongolian soldiers were killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The National Labor Relations Board will appeal as promptly as possible the ruling handed down by Judge Otis at Kansas City on Saturday holding the Labor Relations Act is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Senator Borah made known today in a conference with Colonel Frank Knox that he will not enter the Presidential primary in Illinois, despite the importunities of a group of liberal leaders in the home State of Colonel Knox, who is also seeking the Republican nomination.
DALLAS, Texas. Dec. 23. -- Southern Methodist is ready for Stanford with daring forwards, baffling laterals and a running game as solid as iron.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer entertained with a dinner to night at Capricho in compliment to Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- A picture of Westchester County trying to give streamlined governmental service under a horse and buggy system of government is painted by the Westchester Commission on Government in making public today the first of a series of reports on a factual survey of the county's government by the Institute of Public Administration.
The oddest happening of the year on any field of American sport was the volunteer appearance of a spectator as a "twelfth man" in Dartmouth's football line-up against Princeton.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Williams Steamship Corporation, reported yesterday for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 a net profit of $373,815 from operations against one of $527,894 for same period last year. After allowing for depreciation and after capital gains or losses, there was a net loss of $166,966, compared with a net loss of $470,595 last year.

Delay in the preliminary work for the 1939 World's Fair in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, will be "fatal" to the success of the fair, Park Commissioner Robert Moses warned yesterday in a report on the project to the World's Fair Committee of the Board of Estimate.

The Securities and Exchange Commission finished hearings yesterday on one of the many matters on which it must make recommendations to Congress on Jan. 3. Final testimony was taken by G.H. Dession of the SEC's legal staff in the regional office, 120 Broadway, in the matter of municipal-bond protective committee methods, a field which the commission's agents have explored from New Jersey to Florida.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 23. The Elizabeth Town and Country Club continued its march toward the Class B championship of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League today, when it defeated the Essex County Country Club, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- An organized effort to return to private agencies many banking functions now undertaken by the government was reported to President Roosevelt today by a spokesman for the nation's bankers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- A sharp advance in the price of fresh pork loins and decreased receipts of hogs today sent the prices of hogs soaring, with sales showing advances of 15 to 30 cents a hundred-weight compared with the limited trade on Saturday and steady to 15 cents higher than on Friday.

The will of Miss Julia E. Cullen, 74-year-old retired school teacher, who died in Saratoga Springs on July 30, which bequeathed most of her $150,000 estate to William McCarthy, manager of the Hotel Martha Washington, was rejected last night on the ground that the aged spinster had not been mentally fit to dispose of her estate.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Daniel Upthegrove, president of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway, testified in court here today that the Southern Pacific's withdrawal of financial support had forced his railroad to file a petition for reorganization under the amended Bankruptcy Law.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corporation filed yesterday a petition with the New York Public Service Commission for permission to consolidate ten operating utility companies, nine of which are subsidiaries of the corporation, into one company.

GENEVA, Dec. 23. -- Promotion of Anthony Eden, the world's first Minister for League of Nations Affairs, to British Secretary for Foreign Affairs is hailed here as setting a major precedent and as marking a sharp turn for the League as well as for Great Britain -- and 100 per cent to the good.

Directors of the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company declared yesterday a dividend of $6.15 a share on the second preferred stock, payable on March 1, 1936, to holders of record of Feb. 14, 1935. F.A. Hubbard, president, in a statement explains that this constituted a dividend at the rate of $5 a share annually from Dec. 6, 1934 to February, 1936.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 19. -- Criticism of the Bankhead Cotton Control Act and cross-current of charges of use of relief and work relief in the factional politics of the State are the only appreciable spots on an otherwise bright picture for the New Deal and New Dealers in Mississippi.

Pre-holiday quiet developed in the major Wholesale markets here yesterday, though mail orders for merchandise for January promotions showed an increase. Manufacturers in accessory and apparel lines expressed gratification over reports that Christmas trade has cut rather heavily into retail stocks and that substantial reorders will be required for merchandise for post-holiday sales events.

CONGRESS may pass a law, and the President may sign it, but that's not an end of the matter, as recent judicial decisions have made plain. In view of the contemporary squabbles attending the question of the constitutionality of much of the New Deal legislation, "Lawless Judges," by Louis P. Goldberg and Eleanore Levenson (Rand School Press, $2.50), has an enhanced importance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 18 shows increases for the week of $449,000,000 in total loans and investments and $253,000,000 in government deposits and decreases of $532,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $249,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $122,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.
Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. returned yesterday from Havana with the announcement that the proposed Joe Louis-Isadoro Gastanaga heavyweight bout there is definitely off.

Ar. and ]Firs. Sidney Vere-Smith gave a large supper dance last night in the Jade Room of the WaldorfAstoria for their daughter, liss Shirley Vere-Smith. Silvered fir and pine trees, clusters of pale green balloons, silver stars and flowers were used in the decorations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 23. -- A foolproof burglar detector which enmeshes an intruder in a network of radio waves from which he cannot move without giving an alarm has been designed by Thomas S. McCaleb, instructor in the Institute of Geographical Exploration of Harvard University.

BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- The Boerse continues to operate within narrow limits. The volume of business was small today, but gave the appearance of increased activity. Officially controlled or influenced groups were present on the floor, with small engagements. Real transactions in securities continue to be made entirely independently of the official Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Plans for the opening of Congress seem likely to be upset as a result of the death of Senator Thomas D. Schall.

With preoccupation in holiday activities general, the share market yesterday did little more than mark time. Aside from a continuation of the demand for automotive and aviation stocks, there were no very clearly defined preferences in the list; the closing was steady to firm, with prices irregularly higher.
Mr. and Mrs. George F. Breen gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador to celebrate the birthday of their cousin, Raymond DeVoe.

In a burst of eleventh-hour Christmas shopping large crowds jammed department, specialty and other stores here yesterday. The belated rush was credited by retail executives with bringing sales figures for the holiday period safely above the comparative totals for last year despite the handicap of the decrease noted by the stores in holiday trade for the first half of this month.

Last June Miss Irene Varga, 21-year-old Hungarian-American, of 338 East Eighty-second Street, won a popularity contest conducted by a newspaper and received as a prize a trip to Hungary and other parts of Europe for three and a half months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Transactions by which the Mid-America Corporation, a holding company for the Van Sweringen interests, took over securities of the Allegheny Corporation, held by the Vaness Company and Vested Shares, Inc., also Van Sweringen concerns, when the securities were placed on the auction block in New York City on Sept. 30, were shown today in reports of transactions in securities by officers and directors and principal stockholders of corporations.

Indian Hurtado, Panama lightweight who is being groomed as a contender for the world's title, knocked out Mickey Page of Providence, R.I., in the seventh round of their scheduled eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 23. -- Manchester gave a rapturous welcome tonight to Charles B. Cochran's 1936 revue "Follow the Sun" the biggest song-and-dance show he has ever staged and one which promises to excite London when it arrives there early in the new year.
Santa Claus, accompanied by more than a dozen troupes of radio entertainers from Station WHN, brought Christmas cheer to more than 150 crippled children in the wards of Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

Basketball followers who have been speculating on Purdue's chances of stopping the powerful quintet of N.Y.U. when they meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night will have something tangible to work on after Thursday.

If Mayor LA GUARDIA required any further evidence of the unwisdom of shunting the Queens terminal of the Clason Point Ferry to Chisholm Park on College Point, he obtained it at yesterday's hearing. As the speakers pointed out, the approach to the ferry would cut the park in two, destroying its usefulness.

Nearly 2,000 children of the old "Hell's Kitchen" neighborhood on Manhattan's West Side were the guests of honor yesterday afternoon at a pre-Christmas party sponsored by the Police Department and Uncle Robert, radio entertainer.

Germaine G. Glidden of Harvard, intercollegiate champion, progressed to the quarter-final round of the University Club's invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament by eliminating John Bevan of Yale in the second round yesterday.

ROME., Dec. 23. -- Despite the dangers of the international situation and despite sanctions -- the pinch of which is being increasingly felt -- Christmas this year will be not very different from any other, to judge from appearances.

Comparatively few people love artichokes and a good many people positively dislike them, so it is not to be expected that a great popular uprising will follow upon Mr. LA GUARDIA'S suppression of the artichoke traffic.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 23. -- Rioting with bloodshed has been under way in half a dozen Venezuelan cities in a struggle for the "rocking chair throne" of the dead dictator, General Juan Vicente Gomez, unofficial reports said today.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- C.R. Fairey, commodore of the Royal London Yacht Club, today discussed the prospects for future competition for the America's Cup. The interview cleared up the cup situation, which had been obscured by incorrect reports of Mr. Fairey's reasons for withdrawing his challenge.

A holiday armistice on criticism of President Roosevelt and the New Deal was declared yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, in a Christmas greeting issued at the headquarters of the Republican State Committee in the National Republican Club.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Scotland Yard is on the alert to provide for Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh the protection that, according to reports, it was impossible for his family to receive in the United States.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP). -- Pat Abbott, public links amateur who does bit work in motion pictures, won the Southern California open golf championship today from an impressive field with 281 strokes for seventy-two holes.

The celebration of the seventy-fifth birthday of Miss HENRIETTA SZOLD should not pass without mention of her translation, from the German manuscript, of the first and second volumes of "The Legends of the Jews," by LEWIS GINSBERG, -- a rich and proud collection of a "people's verdict upon history" welded into a glorious memory before which an actuality of suffering recedes.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 23. -- Mrs. Mary Louise Ginder, 70-year-old housekeeper of Haverford College, was shot and killed tonight as she presided over a family dinner in a private dining room of Founders' Hall on the college campus.

HAVANA, Dee. 23 (AP). -- The Cuban Tourist Commission today termed as "outrageous" a statement by Mike Jacobs, New York promoter, that two men carrying machine guns formed a part of the welcoming committee on his recent trip to Havana to arrange details for the Joe Louis-Isadoro Gastanaga fight.

Charging that this country has established a precedent in the Netherlands trade agreement by promising to notify the Netherlands Government before imposing any anti-dumping orders against goods from that nation, protectionists yesterday voiced protests against the most recent agreement concluded under President Roosevelt's reciprocal trade program.
LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Dec. 23. -- A sympathetically indignant "home town" learned today that its favorite son was en route to England -- perhaps never to return -- because of kidnappers' threats.

TOKYO, Dec. 23. -- Prince Teh, recently conspicuous in Mongolian autonomy agitation, proclaimed yesterday the independence of the western part of Inner Mongolia and summoned thirty-three chiefs to join him, according to press dispatches from Hsinking.

Having been away from the theatre for some time Arthur Richman needs to brush up. His "The Season Changes," which was put on at the Booth last evening, is placid to the point of being perplexing. No one interviewed by the correspondent knew what it was about.

Justices John F. Flood, Frederic Kernochan and James J. McInerney of Special Sessions upheld yesterday the interstate transportation feature of the State Liquor Authority's rules when they convicted a youth of hauling beer into this city from Connecticut without a license.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- A Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of the Guffey Coal Control Law within a short time was made possible when the court agreed today to pleas by the government and coal producers to pass upon the New Deal statute even before Circuit Courts hand down decisions.

Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Smith Richardson of 1 East End Avenue and Greens Farms, Conn., gave a supper dance last night at the River Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Keen Richardson. Christmas greens were used in the decorations.
The Christmas bonus total was swelled materially yesterday with announcements by financial houses and large corporations of gifts to employes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- An increase of 31 per cent in the Fall pig crop of 1935 over 1934 was forecast today by the Crop-Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, his wife and their 3-year-old son, Jon, driven into voluntary exile by threats against the child, were well on their way last night to England, where they expect to make their permanent home.

Let the cold facts of the matter explain what Edward J. Kavanagh laments -- the almost total disappearance of Greek as a subject of study in the high schools not only of New York but of most of the other cities in the metropolitan area.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 23. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann, under sentence of death for the murder of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., today signed a petition for clemency and cleared the way for consideration of his case by the Court of Pardons, possibly on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Christmas greetings were extended to the army today by President Roosevelt, who is Commander-in-Chief; Secretary Dern and General Malin D. Craig, Chief of Staff, in messages sent through Corps Area and Department commanders.

After being at large since their indictment on Nov. 26, Harry Luckman and Fred Hull surrendered yesterday morning to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan in Brooklyn on charges of murder in the first degree. Two others, Meyer and Morris Luckman, similarly accused, were arrested shortly after indictment.

In a decision bristling with denunciation of reluctant witnesses who impair the administration of the law Supreme Court Justice McCook sent a restaurant owner to the Tombs yesterday for thirty days for contempt in testifying falsely and evasively before him and before the extraordinary grand jury investigating rackets in New York County.

" Lakme" and Lily Pons made their re-entry into the Metropolitan Opera lists with the beginning of the second week of the season last night. Opera and singer are coupled advisedly, for without Miss Pons or a coloratura soprano of her caliber and charm Delibes's score could scarcely draw much more than a corporal's guard.

Six Manhattan parcels and nine Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Manhattan offerings included several apartment houses of six stories or less, a six-story loft structure and a dwelling.

The main floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, whose social life usually is restricted to the gatherings of shipping operators and freight forwarders for discussion of current trends in commerce, resounded yesterday to the voices of another group of shipping folk.

The Yale Club of New York today brings to an end its amateur art show for club members, which has proved so popular that it probably will be made an annual event. When the idea of the exhibition was broached there was considerable uncertainty as to the response.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Such unforgettable names as Ty Cobb, Christy Mathewson, Honus Wagner, Willie Keeler, Rube Waddell and Babe Ruth promise to supply the fuel for sports arguments once more as the gigantic task to select the immortals for baseball's Hall of Fame gets under way.

MADRID, Dec. 23 (AP). -- A Spanish-Portuguese mutual defense pact placing the entire Iberian peninsula under British protection in event of war was reported in reliable circles tonight to be under consideration.
Seven Jersey City policemen got a thorough wetting yesterday in rescuing an 8-year-old boy from an ice cake slowly floating into Newark Bay off the foot of Pearsall Avenue.

In a Madison Square Garden spectacle in which fifty-two ushers bearing seven-foot playing cards acted out the details of a contract bridge game with verve and accuracy, the Four Aces last night defeated the champions of Europe in the wind-up of their 300-hand match, winning a mythical world's title by 2,810 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Democratic chieftains reported today that the return of Representative Bankhead, House majority leader, had obviated any chance of opening Congress with an intra-party leadership scrap.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The changes outlined in yesterday's War Office announcement are the first really large step in army reorganization since the war, while also in a technical sense the most definite change that has taken place in the history of the British Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Although no offering of the securities is to be made other than to banks for investment purposes, the Dominion of Canada has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $40,000,000 of three-year 2 per cent notes due on Jan. 1, 1939, with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

After listening yesterday to ninety minutes of argument against the proposal to locate the Queens terminal of the College Point-Clason Point ferry in Chisholm Park, College Point, Mayor La Guardia said he would defer signing the permissive legislation until a thorough study has been made of the alternative Tallman's Island site.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Hearing on applications by the Middle West Corporation for the issuance of 3,310,757 shares of common stock in exchange for outstanding securities of the predecessor company, Middle West Utilities Company, and for the approval of a plan to form the Middle West Service Com pany was postponed today until Saturday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The filing of twelve registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 involving issues aggregating $16,184,102 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The list includes commercial and industrial issues, $2,800,125; investment trust issues, $13,320,000; oil and royalty interests, $114,000; voting trust certificates, $149,977.

Secretary HULL'S newest trade agreement, with the Netherlands, is an ingenious bargain. Dutch tariffs are relatively low, and have not constituted a serious barrier to commerce; but the Netherlands has an extensive system of "quotas" under which our trade has suffered.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Anthony Eden today went to Sandringham, where the royal family is spending Christmas, to receive the seals of office from the King. A special Privy Council was held there to confirm his appointment as Foreign Secretary.

All security and commodity Exchanges in the United States, Canada and Europe will be closed today in observance of Christmas Day. American Exchanges will be open for business as usual tomorrow. With the exception of the Paris Bourse all European markets and the Winnipeg Grain Exchange will remain closed tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Five questions on which it was said taxpayers might want enlightenment regarding the shifting of NRA employes to the Commerce Department were put today by the American Liberty League. The league asked:
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- The following is the official English summary of today's papal encyclical on the priesthood, as given out by the Vatican:

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday a letter to Park Commissioner Robert Moses protesting the plan of the Park Department to replace the Central Park Casino with a playground.

Master George White, it is, who will supply the only show for the Christmas night of 1935. For, after an odyssey greater than even most musical shows, his twelfth edition of the "Scandals" will open this evening at the New Amsterdam Theatre.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A proposal to wipe out the centuries-old tithe, or land tax, in one stroke by paying off Queen Anne's bounty -- a lump sum equivalent to $300,000,000 -- may write finis to England's oldest and most bitter feudal controversy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Further strength in fresh pork loins and the broadest shipping demand for light weight hogs in some time lifted prices of hogs 10 to 40 cents a hundredweight today to the highest level since Oct. 23. After allowing for the processing tax of $2.25 a hundred pounds the level was the best for any December since 1929.
The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies receives $2,500 under the will of Joseph Leeburger filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. Mr. Leeburger died on Friday.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday dropped well below the preceding week, but ran above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 218 arrivals were reported as against 429 in the previous week and 170 in the same period last year.

Making his first stop on what may prove to be a journey to England, the champion 3-year-old, Omaha, which carried the silks of William Woodward to victory in many leading American stakes during 1935, arrived here yesterday and was quartered at the Aqueduct race track.

DESSYE, Ethiopia, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Emperor Haile Selassie, in a Christmas message to America, prayed today that "the precious principles of peace, sanctified in the death of Christ, may again be restored to a distracted world."

Policemen in radio patrol cars listened attentively at 3:45 P.M. yesterday when they had heard the voice of their chief. For an instant they had visions of an alarm that would send them speeding to the scene of a crime.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Australian bowlers puzzled South African batsmen in the second cricket test match started today before a crowd of 8,000. The Springboks were dismissed for 157 runs, their opponents making 168 for the loss of three wickets when play closed.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24. -- Racing will return to Santa Anita tomorrow, with a program of eight events scheduled.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- New rules, designed for the most part to minimize the physical hazards of prep football, will be considered at the annual meeting of the rules committee of the National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations in Chicago, Jan. 10 and 11.

Engagements of $3,280,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $2,500,000 was taken in England and $780,000 in India. These engagements made a total of $831,000,000 gold taken abroad for shipment here since Sept. 9, of which $821,600,000 has been received.

BETHLEHEM, Wednesday, Dec. 25. -- An electric star of Bethlehem, blazing suddenly out of the darkness in the age-old Church of the Nativity, early today betokened the advent of Christmas day to thousands of pilgrims assembled in the Holy Land from many countries.

Spurred by the example of Samuel Levy, Manhattan Borough President, poets and slogan writers have come to the aid of the Police Street Safety Campaign, contributing jingles, some of them in doubtful verse, and slogans that will, if the police so decide, adorn safety signs at street intersections.

Funds for Christmas and other relief raised by newspapers in New York City through the generosity of their readers to aid the needy and to bring cheer to firesides that otherwise would be bleak have reached a total to date of about $389,000 this season.

HOPEWELL, Va., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Chief George Anderson of the Hopewell police said tonight that the identification of one of the fourteen victims of the Sunday bus tragedy as Miss Laura Davis of Meredithville, Va., is believed to be incorrect.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, which has at Manchester, N.H., the largest cotton textile plant of its kind in the world, filed a petition here today for reorganization Under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Christmas will be celebrated in Britain tomorrow as a welcome relaxation from recent public anxieties and a day of rejoicing over the nation's own continued steady recovery.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,850,050 barrels, compared with 2,869,050 in the preceding week, a drop of 19,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 20,100 and 11,400 barrels, respectively, in California and Oklahoma and a rise of 8,450 in Texas were the important changes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Operations in December wheat stood out in the trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, buying of the current month against sales of May and covering by belated shorts lifting the former to 6 cents premium above the distant position, the widest premium of the season.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 24 (AP). -- A court fight by power companies against the $37,500,000 Santee-Cooper power and navigation project was presaged today at a public hearing on the purchase of the site by the South Carolina State Authority from private interests.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- Entering the home of his estranged wife as she was trimming a Christmas tree, John W. dodgers, a former policeman, shot and killed her tonight, then killed his mother-in-law and two of his three young children, wounded the other child and killed himself.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- French children placed shoes beside their fireplaces tonight and went to bed hoping that Pere Noel (the French equivalent of Santa Claus) would leave a gift or two despite the hard times.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Dec. 24. -- A year ago all eyes were on the Saar because the hot campaign preceding the plebiscite caused as much international excitement last January as the Ethiopian campaign today. Now the Saar is forgotten amid larger troubles, yet no place more neatly fits into the present picture or throws more light on the German reaction to the European crisis and on the crisis itself.

The assembly room of the Union League Club on Park Avenue rang with the joyfulness of several hundred underprivileged children from the congested areas of lower Manhattan who were guests of the club yesterday at its annual Christmas party.

In a brief statement issued yesterday, Queens County Judge Charles S. Colden defended his action in releasing Mrs. Etta Reisman, who was convicted early last Friday for first-degree manslaughter in the killing of Virginia Seigh, her husband's 23-year-old secretary, who lived in their home at 14-37 Utopia Parkway, Beechhurst, Queens.

Martin C. Brooks's letter criticizing Louis S. Posner's suggestion for the creation of a mortgage bank on the lines of the old Credit Foncier de France contains certain matter which I would like to correct.
Burlington County, N.J., will sell on Jan. 23, an offering of $166,815 of refunding bonds carrying interest at a rate not exceeding 2 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- After a conference with Senator Borah, Representative Fish of New York today said he would call a conference of New York Republican leaders who favor the Idaho Senator's nomination for the Presidency with a view to electing delegates from New York to the Republican National Convention pledged to Senator Borah.

The traditional stillness of the waterfront on Christmas Day will be unbroken today. Only one commercial ship, the United Fruit liner Toloa, is scheduled to dock early this afternoon, and no departures are scheduled.

ALBANY, Dec. 24. -- Emergency nursery schools and parent education classes in up-State communities will be closed Thursday, Dr. J. Cayce Morrison, Assistant Commissioner for Elementary Education, told the school heads tonight. He said school and WPA officials had been unable, after six months' negotiation, to agree on the educational standards for supervision and teachers' salaries.
BERLIN, Dee. 24 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Dec. 21 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24. -- H.F. Carr's Character, a gelding that won in clock-like fashion in this sector two Winters ago, captured the featured fifth race, a five-and-a-half-furlong dash that drew seven sprinters at Tropical Park today. The 5-year-old son of Carlaris, first in his last two outings at Narragansett, greeted the judges two lengths clear in 1:05 1-5.

Alarmed at the smell of smoke while tucking two children into bed in a tenement flat on First Avenue after a Christmas celebration last night, a father carried them across a narrow hallway to a vacant flat, where they were trapped by the flames and burned to death.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- With many members absent, trading on the London Stock Exchange was very quiet today, business being at a preholiday minimum. The industrial list was again strong, shares of stores being particularly supported because of the excellent Christmas trading volume.
Led by seventy-five Girl Scouts in red and green hooded capes, more than 1,000 persons spent an hour singing carols yesterday afternoon in the plaza of Rockefeller Center.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Princeton University received $569,104 in gifts and bequests in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1935, according to a report issued today to the board of trustees of the university by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university.

The Friends of the New Germany, for three years the foremost partisans of Adolf Hitler in America, have been stripped by Hitler of the support of the Germans living in this country whom he considers still subject to his order.

All traffic was halted at Broadway and 155th Street at dusk yesterday while more than 1,000 children and adults, many hearing lanterns, filed from the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession and across Broadway to Trinity Cemetery in their annual pilgrimage to the graves of Dr. Clement Clarke Moore, author of "'Twas the Night Before Christmas," and Alfred Tennyson Dickens, son of Charles Dickens.

The recent letter of S. Parker Gilbert concerning the raising of member bank reserves in order to reduce excess reserves is a welcome comment. He is probably correct in holding that an emergency does not exist within the meaning of the Banking Act of 1935 and that we should proceed slowly in the use of a device with which we are unfamiliar.

A fellow can see the logic of getting up in the middle of the night in order to reach the Beaverkill before the warm Summer sun drives the trout to deep pools. And one does not question the necessity of an early start for the 100-mile spin to Greenport when the Peconic Bay weakfish run is on in the Spring. Those things are to be expected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Eleven companies manufacturing most of the zinc and copper plates used for engraving purposes and their trade association were accused today by the Federal Trade Commission of conspiracy to suppress competition in the sale of such plates to newspapers and photo-engravers.
Featured by a sharp increase in liquor buying and in last-minute gift purchasing by men, Christmas trade ended here yesterday in another sustained spurt of shopping.

Margaret Flint Jacobs, wife of the supervisor of the New Orleans-Ponchartrain toll bridge, came here yesterday to receive the $10,000 first prize in the Dodd, Mead-Pictorial Review first-novel contest for 1935. Mrs. Jacobs won the award with her novel. "The old Ashburn Place," which was selected as the best among 2,632 manuscripts submitted.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- The Senate this morning passed, 207 to 84, with some minor alterations, the government's bill for the suppression by governmental decree of those political, leagues that provoke armed manifestations in the streets or have the character of militia or fighting force or which aim at the overthrow by force of the republican form of government.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- Santa Claus rode clear skies today to brighten Christmas for lonely lighthouse keepers and their families standing guard over treacherous reefs and shoals along the northern New England coast.
LAS CRUCES, N.M., Dec. 24 (AP). -- A burst of gun fire today ended a smoldering dispute between a State official and a member of a college faculty.

Competition in the national figure skating championships and Olympic try-outs, which begin Friday morning at the Ice Club rink and close in Madison Square Garden next Monday night, is expected to be keenest in the men's division.

Nine Manhattan properties and six in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Small apartment structures and dwellings made up the bulk of the offerings. Two scheduled sales of Manhattan parcels, in Madison Avenue and East Seventy-fourth Street, were again postponed, the latter for the eighteenth time.

PAULSBORO, N.J., Dec. 24. -- An oil barge, loaded with 12,000 barrels of gasoline, set afire by an explosion which is believed to have killed its captain and his brother, drifted perilously close to the business section of this town this morning. Swept along by a flood tide, the blazing barge for hours endangered oil tanks, piers and chemical plants along the shore of Delaware River and Mantua Creek.

Net loss of the Aviation Corporation of Delaware and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $346,131 after interest, depreciation and portion of loss applicable to minority interest and including profit of $77,381 of a subsidiary which is being liquidated.

A collection of rare mathematical devices, assembled from all parts of the world in the last thirty-four years by David Eugene Smith, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Columbia University, has been presented by him to the university.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Former Senator James A. Reed, white-haired Democratic veteran, delivered a Christmas Eve blast on the national administration tonight as he called for a "return to constitutional Americanism."

Christmas Eve found the world, generally, far more cheerful and buoyant last night than it has been for years. Pealing church bells made mellow music and glowing trees lighted the way for millions of the devout in many countries. The air throbbed with holiday greetings and with Christmas carols.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- The decision of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to bring his wife and baby to safety in this country has made a profound impression upon England.

In an exchange telegrams yesterday with artichoke growers on the West Coast Mayor La Guardia indicated that his ban on sale of the vegetable in New York's public markets might be lifted if the growers could designate reputable consignees to receive their shipments here.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- Informal conversations were concluded here recently between representatives of the French Line and the Cunard White Star Line by which the Normandie and the Queen Mary will adopt the same rates during the coming season.

The contributions to the Neediest Cases announced this morning, led by an anonymous gift of $10,000 from a new source, carry the total this "Christmas Day in the morning" well beyond that of last year on the corresponding day. Again the lines of the old ballad are happily appropriate:

TRENTON, Dec. 24. -- Frederick A. Brodesser of Elizabeth, clerk of the New Jersey Assembly for ten years until reappointment was denied him a few days ago, was named State Purchase Commissioner today by Governor Hoffman. Mr. Brodesser gained today a $7,000 a year job in place of the $2,500 position he lost last week.

A prankish attempt by two occupants of a furnished-room flat on the top floor of a five-story building at 142 East Eighty-third Street to wake up a friend and make him join them in a Christmas toast resulted shortly after midnight in the death of one of the pair when a rope in which he was dangling from the roof snapped and he plunged to the bottom of an air shaft.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Although the Hurlingham Club, ruling body of British polo, has not yet completed plans for organization of the team that will oppose the United States for the Westchester Cup here next June, there has been no indication that Gerald Balding, the nine-goal Irish star, will be recruited for the matches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Further funds for developing the use of Diesel oil-burning motors for military planes and aviation purposes have been made available by the War Department, it was learned from authoritative sources today. Coincidentally, officials reported that progress is being made in this field.

DALLAS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Southern Methodist Mustangs drilled today on kick-off and punt formations. By noon most of the players, who live in or near Dallas, had departed to spend Christmas with the homefolk.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Martial law was reported by airplane travelers to be in effect today in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, and imminent for the rest of the South American republic as Provisional President Eleazar Lopez Contreras sought to put down widespread rioting.

The National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday that according to its estimates tax collections in the United States now represent about 20 per cent of the national income, a "substantially" larger percentage than in the pre-depressions years.

Two notorious gunmen were sentenced to long prison terms yesterday in General Sessions and four others pleaded guilty in the hold-up of an elderly woman social worker in her West Harlem home last month.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- More than 5,000 persons attended the Christmas Eve community pageant, the largest of several in Westchester County, here late today on a hillside near the Bronxville Village Square. Many of those present joined in the mass singing.

ONE evening last Summer the writer encountered Billy Stewart, the squat, broad-shouldered fellow who umpires ball games in the National League. This in itself is something unusual, for these umpires lead a singular existence.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP). -- George Rochester, foreman of the grand jury, muttered "Too many peculiar circumstances here" as the jury recessed tonight its hunt for possible murder clues in the death of Thelma Todd.

Relief pitching wasn't a lost art in the American League in 1935, although there were no rescue artists of the caliber of old Wilcy Moore and Fred Marberry to bring comfort to managers' hearts when their starting hurlers bogged down.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- On the eve of the Christmas holiday the Bourse today was quiet and little business was done. Prices, however, remained firm, the general expectation being that until the end of the year the political situation will be calm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Reformation of the American people, rather than passing new anti-crime laws, is essential to forestall such departures from the United States as that of the Lindberghs, Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska declared today.

VVASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A counterseasonal surge in home construction and repair was credited today with pushing net outstanding loans of the Federal Home Loan Bank System above the $100,000,000 mark. On Dec. 18 advances reached $100,056,000, compared with $95,817,641 in November and $88,121,544 a year ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP). -- First photographs ever taken showing five successive disintegrations of an atom of radium, resulting finally in transformation into lead, have been revealed by Dr. T. Russell Wilkins, Professor of Physics at the University of Rochester.

The Geological Society of America and three affiliated societies will hold their annual joint meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow, Friday and Saturday. The affiliated societies are the Palaeontological Society, Mineralogical Society of America and the Society of Economic Geologists.

Led by the umbrella section with a rise of 35.8 per cent, fifty-one out of sixty-six divisions in local department stores showed sales increases during November, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Stocks at the end of the month were lower in thirty-six departments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The request of the Federal Government for an order staying all proceedings involving the constitutionality of the Utility Holding Company Act was renewed today in a brief filed in District Supreme Court by Attorney General Cummings. The government asks a suspension of the pending cases until the Supreme Court of the United States decides the suit of the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Electric Bond and Share Company.

WATERVLIET, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Thirty "singing bells," to be installed in the new campanile on the du Pont estate, "Nemours," near Wilmington, Del., will receive their final tests in a program of Christmas carols.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24. -- It was learned today that within two weeks the Brazilian Government would denounce all trade treaties negotiated prior to 1934 in order to avoid disputes over the most-favored-nation clauses which would operate against the new Brazilian-American reciprocal trade agreement. Pacts with about forty nations are involved.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- There were no signs of Christmas in Moscow today and no "Christmas spirit" except among the handful of foreign residents.

Defeating Yeshiva and Brooklyn College in the third and fourth rounds, chess players representing New York University gained 6 1/2 points yesterday to take the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League. The games are being played at the Manhattan Chess Club in the Hotel Alamac.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- With brokers and dealers in over-the-counter securities continuing to register, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a new list of applicants for registration, including the following from New York City:

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 25. -- Martial law was declared here last night in four Chinese districts adjoining the International Settlement as clashes between demonstrating Chinese students and the police continued.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24. -- A large tea was given at their home today by Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry. At twilight, the Romany Quartet, directed by Clegg Monroe, sang Christmas carols in the patio, in which a large tree was illuminated with blue lights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Arthur J. (Dutch) Bergman, Catholic University football mentor, has decided a wide open game is the system for beating Mississippi U. in the Miami Orange Bowl football game New Year's Day.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

More than 8,000 persons, a capacity attendance, filled St. Patrick's Cathedral for the special midnight Christmas mass. A detail of police was forced to turn some 3,000 persons away, so great was the demand to attend the services.
About 150 pets of boys, girls and grownups attended yesterday afternoon the fourteenth annual Christmas party in their honor at the Humane Society of New York, 313 East Fifty-eighth Street.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Dr. Nancy G. Coryell, assistant to the principal and head of the English Department of Manual Training High School, Brooklyn, who lives at 25 Pilgrim Avenue in the Yonkers area adjoining this village, announced today her intention of entering the convent at the Corpus Christi Monastery, the Bronx, on Feb. 2, at the completion of her sabbatical leave.
An amateur hockey triple-header at Madison Square Garden tonight will send into action two teams in the Eastern League and four sextets in the Metropolitan League, starting at 7:30.

For Bobby, who at 9 is his blind father's "eyes"; for the old chef of Case 226; for Josie, the "little mother" of Case 232, and for scores of others of the Neediest, this Christmas will be a time of peace and security.
Caught in a burglary, a "model" 16-year-old boy was shot dead by a policeman early yesterday in a clothing store in Jamaica, Queens.

Four thousand packages of Christmas food were distributed to needy families of the Eleventh Assembly District yesterday by the James J. Hines regular Democratic organization of the district. The distribution followed a custom begun by Mr. Hines when he became leader of the district in 1912, when 400 baskets were considered a large number.

When the coaches and officials held their clinic recently, considerable attention was paid to the block rule. Just what was permissible and what was illegal was decided after various demonstrations. But a point which did not enter into the discussion was the handicap it places on the player who commits the block.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, suggested lower interest rates by both banks and insurance companies in a statement tonight commending the American Bankers Association's efforts to help its members resume their former financing functions.
