NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24. -- Clinton L. Bardo, who recently retired as president of the National Association of Manufacturers, was appointed today by Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court a trustee of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad.

More than 70,000 WPA workers and 15,000 home relief families scheduled to receive their checks on Christmas Day got them yesterday. Relief families that were to get their allowances yesterday had received them on Monday and those who were to have been paid Sunday received theirs on Saturday.
GROSS HERINGEN, Germany, Dec. 24. -- Twenty persons were killed and eighty injured here tonight when an express train rammed a local.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- With the capital's community Christmas tree shedding its multi-colored glow on the snow-covered expanse of Lafayette Square in front of the White House as dusk fell today, President Roosevelt wished "the American people, everywhere, a merry Christmas" in a greeting in which he emphasized that "the spirit of Christmas breathes an eternal message of peace and good will to all men."

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- The alarm with which the Vatican views the present European situation was reflected in an address delivered by Pope Pius today in reply to good wishes for Christmas and the New Year conveyed to him by the Sacred College of Cardinals, headed by its dean, Cardinal Granite di Belmonte.

The longest publishing project now under way in the world will inch a little further toward completion on Dec. 30 when Columbia University Press will publish Fascicle 2 of Volume II of the "Thesaurus Linguae Latinae Epigraphicae." This is the Olcott dictionary of Latin inscriptions, the first fascicle of which was published in Italy in 1904.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP). -- This is a happy Christmas on one of the loneliest islands of tragedy, adventure and romance in the Pacific.

Long Island University's undefeated basketball team is maintaining its average of 50 points per game, having scored 451 counters in nine contests this season. The Blackbirds set a record for L.I.U. teams last season with 1,411 markers for twenty-six clashes.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Kellogg of 1,021 Park Avenue gave a tea dance yesterday at the house of the National Society of Colonial Dames to introduce their daughter, Miss Nancy Kellogg. Evergreens in keeping with the Christmas season, mistletoe, holly, pine and smilax from the South were used in the decorations.

More cases of epidemic meningitis have occurred this year than for any year since 1929 and there have been more deaths from this disease than for any year since 1930, the Department of Health reported yesterday. Cases and deaths for the first fifty-one weeks of 1935 totaled 540 and 238, respectively.

Business failures declined in both the retail and wholesale divisions in the week ended Dec. 19, as compared with the previous week, but increased in the manufacturing branch, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company mills at Manchester, N.H., have made more than $50,000,000 profits in nearly thirty years. But after persistent depression losses, the mile-long string of brick mill buildings along the Merrimac River were shut June 30.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24. -- The New Jersey State Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control posted twenty agents today at bridges along the Delaware to prevent any illegal influx of cut rate holiday liquor from Pennsylvania.

To understand and be prepared for the many dispatches which will now begin to come from Washington quoting the majority and minority leaders of Congress on every subject, the latest often contradicting the previous one from the same source, it is necessary for newspaper readers to understand press conference etiquette on Capitol Hill.

BAKER'S MILLS, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Tired but determined to distribute the last of $10,000 worth of gifts before midnight, Samuel Coplon, Brooklyn toy salesman, stood in the midst of his packing cases today handing out presents to Adirondack Mountain folk.

Final trading in December contracts, combined with preparations for tomorrow's January notices, furnished a liberal volume of business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and the list ended with changes ranging from a gain of four to a loss of three points on the day.

With trade showing better than seasonal activity, stock prices were maintained without difficulty yesterday as dealings were diminished under holiday and year-end influences. The fact that trading on the Stock Exchange was able to aggregate as much as 1,705,000 shares, compared with 1,914,830 the day before, was probably due to the evening up of positions.
Operators' deals in two boroughs featured the urban housing transactions reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP). -- An increase in the pace of Germany's production of substitute raw materials was said in a report by the Berlin Chamber of Commerce and Industry, released today, to be the keynote of the nation's economic prospect for 1936.

Sunday evening, about midnight, while I was waiting at Thirty-fourth Street for the Seventh Avenue express, a panhandler on crutches asked me for money for a night's lodging. I suggested that he could get it by asking the nearest policeman, to which he respectfully suggested that I remove my glasses and he would "fix me up."

MELBOURNE, Dec. 24. -- The rescue ship Discovery II, which left for Antarctica today to aid in the search for Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, his pilot, carries two airplanes fitted with floats and it also carries several sledges. One of the sledges is one used by Sir Douglas Mawson in discovering parts of Antarctica in Australia's name.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- F.W. Green, a vice president of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad, testified today before United States District Judge C.B. Davis that control of the railroad by the Southern Pacific had been "beneficial" and had increased its volume of traffic.

A few days ago a dispatch from Geneva to THE TIMES reported that world trade, while still far below its 1929 level, had reached the highest monthly total since the depression set in. That is by no means the only indication that Christmas of 1935 finds most countries further along on the hard road to economic recovery than they were a year ago.

Dealings in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday were quiet, but prices were firm and a scattering of industrial issues advanced to new high prices for the year. Transactions were $11,144,000 compared with $13,048,400 on Monday; United States Government issues dealt in amounted to $651,000 against $1,953,900 the previous day.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 24. -- Motorists along the North Shore from Roslyn to Oyster Bay found brilliant evidences of the Christmas spirit along every highway and down every lane, where outdoor Christmas trees, illuminated hedgerows, midnight-blue wreaths on doorways, Moravian stars in holiday colors, greeted them as no Yuletide has ever done in the countryside here.

Several years ago (early in 1930) Dr. FREDERICK KEPPEL, president of the Carnegie Corporation, in a course of lectures on "Foundations," referred to the fear on the part of some lest these great privately managed funds might have too potent a part in determining public policies in education, or become a menace to the national wealth, or dry up the springs of individual philanthropy.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 24, -- Stanford's football players concluded practice on their home field today for the Rose Bowl game with Southern Methodist on New Year's Day.

Six of the first-run cinema houses in the local film sector will celebrate today with new pictures. They are "A Tale of Two Cities," at the Capitol; "The Bride Comes Home," at the Paramount; "If You Could Only Cook," at the Roxy; "Dangerous," at the Rivoli; "Ah, Wilderness!" at the Center; "Captain Blood," at the Strand, and "Fang and Claw," at the new Rialto, opening today.

The A Cappella Choir of Lincoln Cathedral, Lincoln, Neb., which is making a tour of the East, arrived here at 10:15 o'clock last night from Washington for a three-day stay, during which the fifty-five mixed voices will be heard in concerts at the Waldorf-Astoria and Carnegie Hall.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24. Soviet Russia, looking both to the Pacific and the Baltic, bluntly let Japan and Germany know today that she has quintupled her submarine and destroyer fleets in the last four years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Dick Skier, University of Kansas guard, playing for the Western team in the annual East-West charity football game here New Year's Day, became the first serious casualty of the training period when he suffered a "shoulder pointer" today.
The commodity futures markets were without particular feature in the two-hour session yesterday. In the cash market, wheat and lard were higher and cotton, corn and silk were lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The legal right of public utilities, which declined to register under the Holding Company Act, to attack other phases of the legislation was challenged today by the government in its brief in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.
CHICAGO. Dec. 24 (AP). -- Throughout the nation this Christmas Eve more than 1,400 convicts received Yule gifts in the form of pardons, paroles and commutations of sentences.

ROME, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The words "peace on earth" and "good-will to men" sound strangely today on this war-time day before Christmas as thoughts turned anxiously to the boys in Africa and the trials of the economic siege.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19. -- Kansas is for President Roosevelt, unless its native son, Governor Alf M. Landon, gets the Republican nomination, because the President has a farm program and the Republicans haven't.

Declaring that the circumstances that had forced Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his family virtually to flee the United States were an example of conditions prevailing in many parts of the country, Mayor La Guardia pledged yesterday a war of extermination against crime.
Dealings in business and residential properties in Westchester County, Jackson Heights and other parts of Long Island were reported by brokers yesterday.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The government announced today 700 Ethiopians were killed and more than 2,000 wounded in the battle Sunday at Abbi Addi in the Temblen region of Northern Ethiopia.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Search for two fugitive criminals who murdered their guard continued tonight as somber trappings of mourning displaced bright ornaments of Christmas in the home of the widow and six children of their victim.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The United States Employment Service found jobs for 2,781,732 persons in 1,300 private occupations and placed an additional 756,785 on work relief jobs in the fiscal year 1935, W. Frank Persons, chief of the service, reported to Secretary Perkins today.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 24. -- Here in Eritrea and Ethiopia there is to be witnessed tomorrow the sad parade of men celebrating peace on earth in the midst of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Moving to effect a more cohesive organization within the War Department, Secretary Dern announced today the promotion of three officers to the rank of chief of their respective branches and the elevation of several lesser officers to the General Staff command.

William F.X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, has informed his assistants that if they expect to be reappointed on Jan. 1 they must quit their private law practices, it was disclosed yesterday. It is understood that the sixteen assistants and four deputy assistants already have given their promises to carry out his order.

Holding that facial injuries affecting the prospects of a "favorable marriage" warranted extra damages, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora upheld yesterday the $90,000 verdict given by a Supreme Court jury to Miss Eileen Wenzel, former showgirl.

HONOLULU, Dec. 24. -- The possibility of an aerial bombardment to divert Mauna Loa's lava flow away from the source of water supply of the city of Hilo was seen yesterday when an army plane flew over the island of Hawaii, carrying personnel to survey the situation.

Patrolman James F. Dowling, 61 years old, of the East 126th Street Station, who recently succeeded in remaining in the department despite his age by passing a physical examination, was struck and killed last night by a truck that was making Christmas beer deliveries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Emphasizing the need for halting the mounting debt of Westchester County and its political subdivisions, which in 1931 surpassed the debt of any State in the nation except New York, the Institute of Public Administration in its report to the Westchester Commission on Government declared today this State "has made little or no progress in the direction of general laws governing the debts of local units."
TRENTON, Dec. 24. -- Factory employment in New Jersey during November reached the highest point since November, 1930, State Labor Commissioner Toohey reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- Charley Stevenson, 19-year-old Boise, (Idaho) apprentice, boosted his total winners for the year to 194 by scoring a double at the Fair Grounds today, while Wayne Wright, his more experienced rival from Rexburg, in the same State, dropped seven behind in the race for American riding honors as be failed to triumph in a single race at Miami.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- His study of "crank letters," said Dr. Harry R. Hoffman, director of the Cook County Behavior Clinic, today, convinced him that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has acted wisely.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A suggestion that the Interstate Commerce Commission's present investigation of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad embrace considerations whether the road should be consolidated with the Pennsylvania was on file today with the I.C.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Federal Prison Bureau has "condemned" 44 per cent of the local lock-ups which it investigated and is seeking to promote the better-jail cause by paying for prisoner's keep on a sliding scale. The better the jail the better the pay.

The possibility of a strike in hotels and restaurants on New Years Eve was threatened yesterday when delegates representing twenty-seven locals affiliated with the United Amusement, Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union met behind closed doors at a midtown hotel to discuss plans for a walkout.

CALLENDER, Ont., Dec. 24. -- Pebbles in this district jumped in value today. From all parts of the continent came requests from childless couples for the tiny stones as charms to bring babies into their homes. The nearer the pebbles were to the hospital home of the Dionne quintuplets, the more potent the charm, according to the belief of the applicants.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Netherlands West Indies, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Scores of Venezuelan refugees, arriving here on board a Venezuelan warship, reported tonight the death of about 150 persons in Maracaibo and other lake ports as the result of disorders following upon the death last week of President Gomez.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Franklyn Hobbs, business analyst, today termed the United States silver purchasing program virtually the only current means available for shoving into world trade part of the massive gold hoard of this country.
I concur most heartily with Martin C. Brooks's letter regarding "State Mortgage Bank."

At first glance it is not an exciting subject to which The London Times a fortnight ago dedicated a handsome centenary number in supplement form. It was to mark the anniversary of the Municipal Corporations Act of 1835, which constitutes the foundation of local government in England today.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- Hanns Kerrl, Reich Minister for Church Affairs, and the secret political police celebrated Christmas Eve by placing under arrest in his apartment Pastor Gerhard Jacobi, chairman of the Berlin Confessional Synod and Brotherhood Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A moratorium in banking legislation was proposed today by Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, as he explained his campaign to transfer government lending to private agencies.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 24. Sixty pigeons upon which a crippled youth based his hope of making a livelihood, were killed here tonight in a fire in his home at 58 Central Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Wilcy Moore, 38-year-old cast-off of the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox, was the pitching champion of the American Association on the basis of winning percentage in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Proposals for an expansion of existing neutrality legislation were sounded today on Capitol Hill, coupled with indications that Idaho's two Senators might tangle in the certain battle over such an action.

The continued improvement of the transatlantic passenger trade during the past year and the proposed entry of the new superliner Queen Mary into service this Spring justify the prediction in 1936 of record post-depression business, according to Harold P. Borer, general passenger manager of the Cunard White Star Line.

Eleven hundred seamen, most of whom have been "on the beach" for lack of a berth at sea for the last five years, were guests of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York at Christmas dinner yesterday at the institute building, 25 South Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Apprentice Jockey Charley Stevenson boosted his total of winners for 1935 to 196 today when he triumphed with Catwalk in the third race and Oican in the sixth at the Fair Grounds.

Most delinquent children brought before the courts of the city can be rehabilitated to a useful social life if they receive the opportunity to read good literature, Justice Jacob Panken of the Bronx Children's Court declared yesterday afternoon in an interview at his home, 44 West Seventy-seventh Street.
PARIS, Dec. 25. -- French courts are scheduled to decide Friday whether tennis tournaments should be included in the category of taxable public amusements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- With the purpose of ascertaining through personal conferences and statistical analyses of individual industries just how the government can best cooperate to increase employment and profits, the Department of Commerce is extending a project already successfully applied to the automobile and fisheries industries to all major business.

Some of Wall Street's professional stock market traders are showing increasing interest in facilities of distant exchanges for the expansion of their activities. In their inspections they have concentrated on the San Francisco Stock Exchange and on certain among the world markets abroad, looking for satisfactory emergency outlets for their speculative work, according to The Associated Press.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- King George, in his Christmas message to "this great and widespread family" of the British Empire, expressed the hope that the peace of his peoples might spread worldwide.

An appeal for reunion with the Roman Catholic Church, coupled with a scathing denunciation of Protestantism in this country as "bankrupt ethically, culturally, morally and religiously," has been made to the Protestant Episcopal ministry by a group of twenty-nine high churchmen, it became known yesterday.

Nine outstanding runners are scheduled to start in the 500-meter invitation race which will be a high spot in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, track and field meet to be held in the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, on Saturday, Jan. 4.

From twenty-two years in "savage" Africa one returns to America to read in THE TIMES Lauren D. Lyman's story of Colonel Lindbergh's third flight across the Atlantic, this time not alone as on his first, not just with Mrs. Lindbergh as on his second, but with a third life joining theirs, for whose sake they fly.

The United Hospital Campaign Committee will renew its effort this morning to carry the drive past its minimum goal of $2,000,000. Contributions announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, the campaign chairman, included one of $10,000 by Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.

Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, will break ground officially at 10:30 A.M., on Jan. 3, for the $12,500,000 Ten Eyck Houses in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the largest of the fifty PWA financed low-rental housing projects in the United States, according to an announcement made yesterday by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

A program that enables certain supervisory employes and executives to retire at fixed ages with incomes guaranteed for life has been adopted by the United States Freight Company, Frederic N. Melius, president, announced yesterday.

The forces of atheism and irreligion will shatter themselves against the "deep wells of steadiness and inspiration" which the world finds in those who have caught the spirit of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick told 1,100 persons at the Christmas morning service at Riverside Church.

Mayor La Guardia's artichoke prohibition faces its first test today. From the opening of business this morning until the grip of racketeers on the trade in small artichokes is broken, the Mayor has forbidden the sale of the small artichoke in public markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Developments of the late Summer and Fall in the United States were featured by the great increase in excess reserves of banks, heavier circulation of money to meet larger payrolls and volume of retail trade, and continued importation of gold from Europe, according to the December bulletin of the Federal Reserve Board, issued tonight.

Helen Hayes gets back to town this evening as the Queen of Laurence Housman's play, "Victoria Regina." From Washington comes word that it is all something pretty special, Mr. Miller (the producer) saying it is very great stuff, indeed, and Miss Hayes saying she won't tell any of the secrets of her make-up.

Despite an increase in sales, earnings of the Cudahy Packing Company decreased sharply in the period from Oct. 27, 1934, to Nov. 2, 1935, it was announced yesterday by E.A. Cudahy, chairman of the board. The net profit was $1,211,073, which was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $1.35 a share on 467,489 shares of common stock.

New York City Hall, which squats in weather-beaten antiquity among the tall skyscrapers of the downtown area, is to be restored to its former Colonial grandeur as the center of a newly refurbished City Hall Park, it became known yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 25. -- The Christmas festival in Bermuda combined many of the old English customs and local observances peculiar to the island. Governor-General Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt attended the morning service at the Garrison Church, Prospect Garrison, arriving in the official open carriage with red and blue liveried coachmen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Charging that the New Deal had "smothered" a "stop alien representation" amendment to the Constitution, three Methodist Bishops urged their ministers today to cooperate with the American Christian Alliance in an effort to defeat "alien conspiracies."
MELBOURNE, Dec. 25. -- The Melbourne Herald displays messages from overseas editors representing Britain, India, United States, France, Germany, Japan and Italy. THE NWE YORK TIMES says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Living costs in the United States increased four-tenths of 1 per cent between July 15 and Oct. 15, according to a report today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on figures from thirty-two large cities.

Reflecting holiday influences, the national rate of output of ingot steel has declined 7 points below that of a week ago to 48 1/2 per cent of capacity, The Iron Age says. Mill operations also have been sharply curtailed, the publication states, tin plate output having fallen to 40 per cent, or one-half the rate of a week ago, and sheet production to 45 per cent from 75.

Like a Christmas light the red bulb behind the Baltimore net shone time and time again last night at Madison Square Garden as the New York Rovers sent eight goals into the cords to crush the Orioles by the largest margin of victory in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game this season.
Wholesomeness is the foundation for the respect I have for your paper, and your clean references to the departure of the Lindberghs for England leave a lasting impression on my mind.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 25. -- Authoritative sources said today that they believed the problem of the Chaco war prisoners, which has been hampering the peace conference seeking to settle the recent conflict between Paraguay and Bolivia, had been virtually solved after parleys among neutral members of the peace commission.

MONTREAL, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The drive that reached its greatest momentum on the Montreal stock markets last month, sent at least thirty-four issues to new high records, better even than the peaks established in 1929.

The twelve leading news stories of the year, selected by editors of 128 newspapers and press associations of the country in a poll conducted by the Columbia Broadcasting System, with the United States Supreme Court rulings affecting the New Deal policy heading the list, were announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 25. -- Colonel Julio Sanguily, who was chief of staff of the Cuban Army under the administration of President Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, died at 6 o'clock tonight in the Medical Center in the suburb of Vedado from injuries received when he was struck by a street car last night. He was 57 years old.

As I begin to realize that the departure of the Lindbergh family is a fact, the gruesome details of which are printed in the manner that characterizes THE TIMES as a conservative and reliable news medium, I am stunned that such things can be in this our glorious land.

TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 25. -- A forecast of the effects of the autonomous government upon foreign business in North China was implicit in an interview given to the writer by Mayor Shiao Chen-ying of this city.
The committee which formulated the tentative redraft of the Neutrality Act, issued a detailed commentary on it which follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Senator Borah's committee of advisers, which includes several Senators, predicted today that he would enter the convention with more than 200 first-choice votes and would gain a powerful group of delegates from Eastern and Southern States when a break from uninstructed blocs occurred after early balloting.

PARIS, Dec. 25. -- War veterans of the National Union of Combatants warned Premier Pierre Laval today that they were unalterably opposed to war with Italy. It was in keeping with the uneasiness that seems to have been caused in some French circles since the defeat of the Hoare-Laval peace plan that Christmas Day was chosen for this demonstration.

Defeating Brooklyn by 3 1/2 -- 1/2 and gaining a 2-1 advantage over Columbia, with one game adjourned, the University of Pennsylvania chess team yesterday took the lead in the annual Intercollegiate Chess League championship play.
GROSS HERINGEN, Germany, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The bodies of thirty-six persons were removed today from the smashed coaches of a local train which was sidewiped by the Berlin-Basel express last night.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Cruising at 40,000 feet with a speed of nearly 300 miles an hour was forecast today by G.T.R. Hill, engineering professor at London University, as a possibility for airline travel in the near future.
The following text of a "Tentative Redraft of the Neutrality Act of Aug. 21, 1935" was made public here yesterday by the National Peace Conference:
An unidentified woman about 40 years old was killed by a hit-and-run driver at Avenue A and Twelfth Street soon after 4 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Speeding its program for strengthening the wings of the Army, the War Department is expected to award contracts for eighty-two additional pursuit planes by the end of this week.

At the Christmas dinners of many Democratic leaders there must have been a death's head at the feast in the shape of the specter of the coming Jackson Day dinners. Already a somewhat unpleasant odor has gathered around the latter. Objections are made to the expense of the entertainment -- in Washington, $50 a plate.
The toll of death from fires in Christmas trees mounted to five yesterday as a man and his wife died from burns in Bellevue Hospital at 4 A.M.

BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- The veteran Bill Cook tonight set the pace for the New York Rangers, who came from behind to gain their second triumph in four days over the Bruins, 3 -- 2, before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

The first arrest in what police believe to be a systematic attempt by several persons to defraud persons entirely dependent on home relief occurred last night when Peter Signor, 37 years old, of 243 Madison Street, was taken into custody for forging relief checks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 25 (AP). -- A middle-aged college professor and a middle-aged store manager swam and battled their way through the ice of Spa Creek here today to rescue a 6-year-old boy from drowning.

DETROIT, Dec. 25. -- "How to get rich in the boxing business," the unwritten story of Joe Louis's rise to wealth with a pair of boxing gloves, would be among the best sellers of 1936 if the Brown Bomber of Detroit should suddenly turn author.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Crisp, sunny weather attended the Holy Land's celebration of Christmas as thousands of pilgrims from all corners of the globe converged on this sacred spot to observe the birthday of Christ.

An air of Christmas cheer pervaded the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon despite the fact that the entire staff had to be called at short notice to spend part of the day in a dress rehearsal of "Carmen," which is to have a revival tomorrow evening with Rosa Ponselle in the title role.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- Zoe Akins's new play, "O Evening Star," had its world premiere here tonight at the Chestnut Street Opera House, where it is booked for a ten-day engagement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- President Roosevelt and his family, representing four generations, observed Christmas at the White House today in the simple fashion followed in countless American homes.

The annual discussions and action on problems affecting college athletics in general and football in particular start today with two events, forerunners of the National Collegiate Athletic Association meeting.
SANDRINGHAM, Norfolk, England, Dec. 25. -- Following is the text of the speech broadcast throughout the British Empire today by King George:
MATTOON, Ill., Dec. 25. -- While railroad officials searched for a law covering locomotive joyriding, Maurice Spurlin, 32, of Mattoon, was in jail for safekeeping today.

An attempt to get all the city's Santa Clauses under one roof by inviting them to a special Christmas dinner brought some disappointment to officials of the McAlpin Hotel yesterday, when only five of the invited guests appeared.

A Christmas dinner party that was to have been held yesterday afternoon at the home of the Rev. William Armstrong, 33 years old, Negro, at 402 Halladay Street, Jersey City, developed into an altercation, according to the police, with the result that the preacher is alleged to have drawn a revolver and shot his brother-in-law in the left arm.

Beginning at 10 o'clock this morning and continuing until 8 or later this evening the first rounds of the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships will be run off in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The meet, conducted by the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club under the auspices of the U.S.L.T.A., is the nineteenth annual for boys and the twenty-first for juniors.
A DELECTABLE honor seems to have fallen to the lot of the nation's baseball writers. At least, it appears so now, though even at this early date it promises a dubious outcome.

PARIS, Dec. 25. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's self-exile from the United States has given rise to much comment here, where his fame was made. It is generally said that the colonel's action is humiliating to the American national pride and admiration is expressed for the frankness with which this is admitted by the New York press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- A twelve-point program directed toward "constitutional recovery" and designed particularly "to encourage the legislative branch of the government to reassert its constitutional prerogatives and put the nation's house in order" was urged tonight by the American Liberty League.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 25. -- Forty persons fled to the street in their night clothes as fire damaged the McCrory apartments at New York Avenue and the Boardwalk, early this morning.

The proposed substitute for the present Neutrality Act, drafted by a committee of the National Peace Conference and published this morning, can best be approached by considering the scope of the law under which President ROOSEVELT is now acting in the case of Italy's war against Ethiopia.

The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared in his sermon there yesterday that one trouble with the world today lay in a widespread tendency of individuals to practice a "compromistic" version of Christianity.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 25. -- A gift of $500,000 to Harvard University from Thomas W. Lamont, New York banker, was announced today by President Conant.

Opportunity to relive one of the Christmas Days of happier times was provided yesterday afternoon at the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, for 200 aged men and women, many of whom were formerly well-to-do. They were guests at the club's eighth annual old folks Christmas party.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks, behind a stout defense which withstood a furious third-period attack, defeated the Red Wings, 2 -- 0, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 7,000 fans.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. Oliva Dionne said "Joyeux Noel" to their quintuplet daughters today by waving at them and talking through the glass window-panes of their nursery. The quintuplets were not allowed to have the family inside because of the possibility that cold germs might be brought in.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was filled at 11 A.M. yesterday for the pontifical Christmas mass. The celebrant was Cardinal Hayes, although the body of his foster-father, James Egan, lay in state in the archepiscopal residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

An expansion and re-equipment program without parallel since 1929 has been launched by manufacturing industries in the last six months, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Machine Tools Builders Association. A survey covering 500 companies in all parts of the country revealed that modernization and expansion projects costing $938,000,000 had been initiated by American industry in that period.

The season's second performance of Verdi's "Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House brought two changes in cast in important roles. Eide Norena was the Violetta and Charles Hackett the Alfredo. In the other principal part was Lawrence Tibbett, who was also in the opening night presentation of the opera last week.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Three Eritrean spies, charged by the Italian police with giving the Ethiopian Government information concerning the location of troops in Italy's colonies, were sentenced today to be shot in the back.

After a lay-off yesterday due to the holiday, N.Y.U. resumes practice today for its important intersectional contest with Purdue at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. The Violets were none too impressive against Brooklyn College on Monday night and Coach Howard Cann will drive them hard today and tomorrow in an attempt to smooth their play.

Organization of the Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conference was announced yesterday by Dabney T. Waring, traffic consultant, who has been named general manager. The group comprises motor operators in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, West Virginia, Virginia and the District of Columbia.

The Lindbergh departure is a national disgrace, and blame for the conditions that caused it should be laid squarely at the door of the American people themselves. Their too ready inclination to condone lawlessness and to fail to punish criminals adequately is where most of the trouble lies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Short-term loans to individual farmers through the Farm Credit Administration reached this year a record high mark of $517,000,000, W.I. Myers, governor of the administration, announced today. This compared with $446,000,000 in 1934.

ALBANY, Dec. 25. -- Retail stores in New York State increased their working forces 1.1 per cent and payrolls .8 per cent from mid-October to mid-November, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today on the basis of reports from 14,000 retail stores.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 (AP). -- If Temple University accepts any of several offers received from Pacific Coast schools, Pop Warner will return next year to the Far Western football wars he left four years ago.
Gleanings from notebook and mailbag:

TOKYO, Dec. 25. -- Armed clashes involving loss of life occurred yesterday between Outer Mongolian forces and Japanese-Manchurian troops near the border. A Japanese military communique issued today at Hsinking, Manchuria, reports:

ASMARA, Dec. 25. -- Christmas Day finds all Eritrea and the occupied regions of Ethiopia quiet and peaceful. There is not much celebration of the holiday, for there cannot be this far from home and comforts.

With the State Legislature about to convene once more, Democratic leaders in Brooklyn and Queens are reported to be discussing the possibility of reviving the attempt to bring about a reapportionment of Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts. Naturally no hint of any similar activity comes from the Democratic organization in Manhattan.

BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- Porter H. Adams, president of Norwich University, disclosed tonight that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh recently declined to serve on an important aviation research project, apparently because of his determination to leave the United States.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 26. -- Tang Yu-jen, Vice Minister of Railways, was assassinated last evening in the French Concession in the International Settlement by two unidentified Chinese. The assailants escaped.

Without the services of Tommy Anderson, the New York Americans six tonight will tackle the Montreal Maroons in Madison Square Garden in a struggle to determine second position in the International group of the National Hockey League.

About 175 homeless and transient boys were entertained at a Christmas dinner and party yesterday provided by Thomas W. Lamont, the banker, at the Brace Memorial Newsboys' House of the Children's Aid Society, at 244 William Street. Besides a turkey dinner, each boy received a white shirt, a necktie, a box of chocolates, an orange and a package of cigarettes.

In a literary career covering almost two generations PAUL BOURGET split sharply his personality as a writer, his thought, principles, philosophy, view of life. Brought up in the shadow of RENAN and TAINE, his novels from the Eighties to the first four or five years of the twentieth century indicate but little hope for happiness.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- Several railroads today reported sharply rising earnings in November and a continued volume of heavy traffic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Earnings of the 1,000,000 employed railroad workers are, on the average, 93 per cent as large as they were in 1929, while retail food prices are at approximately 80 per cent of the 1929 level, according to a statement issued today by L.H. Bean, economic adviser to the AAA.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- A blizzard blustered out of the north country today, crippling air, rail and highway traffic and spreading zero cold through the Middle West.
More than $500,000,000 will be invested in buying advertising space in newspapers and magazines in 1936, according to a prediction by Herbert L. Stephen in the current issue of Printers' Ink.

A new apparatus for obtaining samples from the bottom of the ocean, which has brought up cores eight feet in length from a depth of 7,200 feet, will be described today at the opening sessions of the annual meeting of the Geological Society of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

One hundred and fifty-three Protestant and Catholic leaders joined yesterday in an appeal "to the heart and conscience of Christian people" in this country to provide the funds needed for the relief and rehabilitation of German refugees of the Christian faith.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Emergency measures were taken tonight by the State Conservation Department to have the Olympic bobsled run ready for the official 1935 opening Sunday. Commissioner Lithgow Osborne set department workers to hauling snow from the top of Mount Van Hoevenberg to the run.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Al Ettore, promising Philadelphia heavyweight, outpointed Ford Smith, cowboy puncher from Montana, in ten rounds at the Arena today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Stanford's main football contingent headed for Pasadena tonight prepared either to break a Rose Bowl jinx with a victory over Southern Methodist or go down fighting the greatest New Year's Day battle of the last three seasons.
KNOXVILLE., Tenn., Dec. 25. -- Any attempt at this time to woo the ordinarily susceptible Tennessee away from the Democratic fold would be met readily with the answer: "The lady is busily engaged."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Representative George H. Tinkham of Massachusetts announced today that he would introduce a joint resolution in Congress to have the United States withdraw its participation in the Briand-Kellogg pact, which outlaws war as an instrument of national policy.
The hearty and generous Christmas response to the appeal for New York's Neediest Cases continued yesterday and the total for the day again exceeded last year's total for the corresponding day.

According to George White's strict system of bookkeeping, the "Scandals," which settled into the New Amsterdam last evening, is number twelve. On eleven previous occasions Mr. White has accustomed us to his appetizing style of showmanship and, to tell the truth, has taught us to expect a livelier evening.

Several hundred persons passing through Madison Square last night stopped to listen to the Gloria Trumpeters play Christmas carols near the base of the Tree of Light. Not a few remained to join in the singing led by Howard Wade Kimsey.

Production of electricity by the electric power and light companies in the United States amounted to 2,002,005,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended on Dec. 21, according to the Edison Electric Institute. This was another new high level for the year and also a new record for the industry.

BOONTON, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Five hundred and eighteen buck deer were killed in the five deer-hunting counties of Northern New Jersey during the five-day season which closed last Saturday, according to official tabulations of the game wardens received here today.

A motorman suffered a broken right foot and 200 passengers were frightened and shaken in a collision at 7:11 o'clock last night between two Long Island Railroad passenger trains, one of them empty, in the tunnel near the Brooklyn terminal of the line at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Inquiry into the death of Thelma Todd focused tonight on a report that the throat of the actress bore swellings or bruises such as might have been made by the jamming of a bottle neck or a pipe into her mouth.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- Walter T. Grosscup, chairman of the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board, commenting tonight on a report from Newark, N.J., that agents had been stationed at interstate bridges to prevent illegal influx of cut-rate holiday liquor from Penn sylvania, said the board had received complaints from package goods dealers in New Jersey.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25. -- Top Row raced before 45,000 fans to a record-breaking victory today in the Santa Anita Christmas Stakes, feature of the opening day's card, to increase the more than $100,000 in dividends he has paid A.A. Baroni, who claimed him in 1934 for $3,500.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 25 (AP). -- A woman guest in a Federal transient hotel was killed, and an undetermined number of persons were missing after the walls of a fire-ravaged theatre collapsed today on the adjoining hostelry.

CHENGTU, Szechwan Province, China, Dec. 25. -- Fragmentary reports from southern Szechwan Province told today of an earthquake Dec. 18 that shattered entire villages and caused a death toll that may reach thousands.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25. -- A large dinner dance was given this evening by Mrs. Margaret Emerson, her daughter, Miss Gloria Baker, and her son, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, at her villa.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Agents of the New Jersey Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control posted at Delaware River bridges because of complaints by package liquor dealers in the Trenton and Camden areas of competition from Pennsylvania cut-rate liquor were withdrawn early this morning by D. Frederick Burnett, commissioner of the department. He said he found the problem complained of to be negligible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -A slight improvement in the third quarter of 1935 in American farm exports, despite political unrest and trade restrictions abroad, was noted today in a foreign trade analysis by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
Mayor La Guardia, by proxy through the Police Department, played the role of Santa Claus to a starving Negro family in Brooklyn yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 25. -- Sanctions, the war's privations and anxieties, past hardships and fears for the future were forgotten by Italians for one day as they gathered in homes or in churches to celebrate Christmas according to the Italian tradition.

For some of his ideas Dr. TOWNSEND has gone back at least as far as the French Revolution. Dean WILLIAM F. RUSSELL of Teachers College, Columbia University, has called attention to a decree of the National Convention, June 28, 1793, setting up a system of relief for children, old persons and the indigent.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- Two far-reaching projects for the abolition of "Queen Anne's bounty" and to permit the State purchase of coal-mining royalties are hailed triumphantly by Socialists as "the forerunner of doom for England's feudal system."

The American Power and Light Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on Nov. 30 net income of $2,106,441 after charges and taxes, equal to $1.19 a share on the combined 1,772,025 preferred shares outstanding, compared with $1,200,275 or 67 cents a share in the same period last year.

Professor Andre Siegfried, the writer, is sailing today for Europe with his wife on the French liner Ile de France. Also sailing are Martin Egan of J.P. Morgan Co., with Mrs. Egan, who are en route to Cape Town; Helen Vinson, screen actress, who is the wife of Frederick Perry, the tennis player, and:

Columbia University will pay about $2,350,000 next year in taxes on real estate it controls in this city, President Nicholas Murray Butler's annual report indicates. The institution will have to pay taxes, either directly or indirectly through its tenants, on property having an aggregate assessed valuation of $86,595,000 during the coming year.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Lebanon Valley of Annville, Pa., today broke Tampa University's string of Christmas Day football victories by defeating the Spartans, 6 -- 0, in the third annual event. The visitors scored a touchdown in the first period, but neither side was able to cross the other's goal line thereafter.

A rare and savage goshawk, or goose hawk, was shot in the Bronx yesterday after three hours of hurling stones and shooting lifeline projectiles by members of a police emergency squad failed to dislodge the bird from a branch 75 feet up in a tree, where it had snagged a leather strap with which its owner had kept it tethered.

Somewhere in the mail on Christmas Eve was the Actors Equity Association's check for $100, and a private purse taken up among Equity's council. They were addressed to a former captain of bell boys at the Lambs Club. The Christmas spirit had something to do with it, of course, but not everything.

New Yorkers got a belated touch of white Christmas yesterday, while Chicago's streets were white with snowdrifts left by a blizzard, and rain swept across most of Europe. Snow started to fall in New York at 8:30 P.M., but was expected to stop before daybreak.

Charles Morgan, author of "The Fountain," has completed his first novel in several years. The Macmillan Company expect to publish it here this Spring. The title is "Sparkenbroke," and it concerns an English Lord who is a poet and novelist.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25. -- A threat by John W. Rodgers, a former policeman, that he would wipe out his entire family was fulfilled with the death this morning of his youngest child, Adele, 3 years old, in Mercy Hospital.

A revised Neutrality Act designed to enlarge and improve the resolution of the last Congress, was made public here yesterday by the National Peace Conference, a representative body recently established on a permanent basis by thirty national peace organizations.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Adverse weather conditions in many parts of the country did not materially hamper the Christmas Day English Soccer League program. In the four divisions only five games were postponed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Reports showing how widely the Justice Department's fingerprint files have been used in checking on applicants for work or enlistment in military service were made public today, and showed that in November, 11,008 fingerprints of applicants for private and public positions were forwarded for comparison with the more than 5,400,000 records on file, and 609 were found to have had criminal records.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25. -- Golden Rock II, in the pink and white silks of C.W. Muller, vice president of the Republic of Panama, caused a mild surprise at Tropical Park today by winning the one-mile Christmas Handicap by three lengths before 15,000 holiday fans.

Gross operating revenue of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiary companies for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 amounted to $107,596,748, compared with $104,525,220 the year before, a gain of 3 per cent. The statement includes all properties, irrespective of dates of acquisition, but does not include the New England Gas and Electric Association (and subsidiaries), which is not a subsidiary.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- L. W. Baldwin, president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad since 1923, resigned today as co-trustee in bankruptcy for the railroad because of disagreement with legal action impending over its purchase of terminal properties in 1930.

Dissolution of two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange and the formation of three new ones were announced yesterday by the Exchange. Those which are to dissolve are Gray Wilmerding and Hutton, Miller Co. The new firms will be Gray Wilmerding, William Morris Co. and Leonard Schafer Co.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a rise of 12 per cent over a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This period includes the peak day, Dec. 18. The increase is double that of the previous week, when a rise of 6 per cent was reported.

Hundreds of songs, including many of the theme melodies with which broadcast programs have been identified for years, will be deleted from the air offerings of the Columbia Broadcasting System, the National Broadcasting Company and nearly 100 independent stations scattered throughout the country beginning Jan. 1, it became known yesterday.

Are we to have the Battle of Fontenoy over again? French veterans have sent an appeal to Premier LAVAL not to make war upon Italy. They say that they could not bear the thought of fighting against their former allies. In response, Premier LAVAL has assured them that he would never think of attacking Italy, unless France were first attacked by her.

The subterranean caverns of the Hoersel and the heights of the Wartburg resounded with many an unfortunate display of vocalism at last night's first "Tannhaeuser" of the season at the Metropolitan. But the Wagner score, to make up for these deficiencies, was infused with new vigor.
It is difficult to understand the shallow thinking which prompts a critic to write to THE TIMES, "Mr. Roosevelt has given the greatest exemplification of shifting that any one possibly could give."

Modern scholars have been handicapped in their appreciation of the Greek poet Pindar because of a tendency to minimize his influence on later poets, according to Dr. David M. Robinson, a noted classical authority and professor of Archaeology at Johns Hopkins University.
Harvard had two winners, Yale one and Amherst one when the quarter-finals in the invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tourney at the University Club were completed yesterday.

The Lincoln Cathedral a capella choir of Lincoln, Neb., will give a concert tonight in Carnegie Hall, marking the climax of its visit to the city, which began Christmas morning. Diplomats, musicians, patrons of music and city officials are included among the boxholders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Federal Power Commission issued orders today requiring all companies owning facilities for the sale of electric energy in interstate commerce to file a schedule of rates.

WATERBURY, Vt., Dec. 26. -Four army officers were fatally burned and two others were seriously hurt today as fire swept a part of the officers' quarters at Camp Smith, war veteran's CCC camp here, in the bitter cold of early morning.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada increased in the week ended on Dec. 24 by $1,752,862, the bank reported today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $3,468,423. The statement follows:

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Receipt yesterday of a cable from Provisional President Eleazar Lopez Contreras of Venezuela approving "in principle" a set of "objectives" recently adopted by representatives of 3,000 political exiles from the South American country now living in New York, was announced here today by Dr. R. Ernest Lopez.

Contending that the recognition of football officials has not been commensurate with other developments of the game, William R. Crowley, retiring president of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials, yesterday suggested five steps toward improvement of the condition.

The first great cold wave this Winter was moving eastward last night in an extensive sweep from the Rocky Mountains to the Atlantic Coast and south almost to the Gulf Coast. It is expected to send the mercury here down to about 10 degrees above for the coldest day this Winter so far.

Shipping men expect the designation of first class as applied to transatlantic passenger ships to disappear from usage this Summer as a result of the plan of the Cunard White Star and French Lines to have their new super liners Queen Mary and Normandie designated cabin class ships by the North Atlantic Passenger Conference.

DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Manager Jack Adams of the Detroit Red Wings, his ire aroused by the unusual number of tie games his players have encountered this season, said tonight he had served notice on five National Hockey League squads they must play an offensive game here or the Wings will "cease to furnish entertainment" for their home game crowds.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ebling gave a dinner dance last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their daughter, Miss Doris Ebling. The other guests were the Misses Marian Fountain, Dorothy Babcock, Nancy Woodberry and Barbara Rinke; Robert Ebling Jr., Ross McKee, Stuart Spaulding, Clarence MacLean, Ralph Herrindeen and Harry Sohmer.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26. -- Plans are reported under way for the erection of a $35,000,000 plant at Clairton by the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation. Officers of the company declined to discuss the report, and it was indicated that an announcement would have to come from the parent company's offices in New York.
PERHAPS it was all a mistake and the writer should not have asked in the first place. He committed an egregious blunder right at the start by referring to it as "fancy skating."

Overseas telephone calls handled through the Bell Telephone Company's radio station over the Christmas holidays set a new record this year, it was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Giving an accounting of the state of advertising, H. B. Le Quatte, president of the Advertising Club of New York, denied yesterday it made for excessive profits and increased prices, but suggested it ultimately would prove to be the bridge between production and consumption leading to universal prosperity.

Following the Christmas holiday interruption of trading, real estate activity was resumed yesterday when real estate brokers and managing agents of buildings announced a large volume of new business space leasing. Some of the firms will occupy their new quarters after the first of the year.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 26. -- The Ethiopian Government's secret police pressed their intensive drive against suspected Italian spies today, expelling a Greek whose name was published as Dmitri Kiriakoulakis.

That touch of Paris in the heart of old Shubert Alley, the "Continental Varieties," has come back to town for a holiday week at the Masque. In it again is Lucienne Boyer, who used to be one of the reasons Americans went to France before she decided to simplify matters by coming to them.

Beginning on Sunday, the SkateSailing Association of America will stage an attractive program which will culminate in a series of three regattas for the national championships Feb. 9, 16 and 23, according to the card announced yesterday. The metropolitan division championships, also to be conducted on a three-regatta basis, will be held Jan. 1, 12 and 26.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- With the Bank of France's weekly statement showing an increase in gold of 385,000,000 francs, it was expected that the discount rate of 6 per cent would be lowered when the Bourse resumed operations today. This expectation was not realized, however, the regents of the bank evidently considering the franc still too close to the gold-export point in respect to the dollar to permit any reduction in its defense measures.

Dr. William Hallock Park, noted bacteriologist and hygienist, will retire on his seventy-second birthday anniversary Monday from active work as director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Department of Health, associates in the department said last night.

TOKYO, Dec. 26. -- Count Makino, who resigned today as Keeper of the Privy Seal, pleaded growing infirmities in yielding his post, but political authorities recalled that militarists have long agitated for his replacement, objecting to the presence of a statesman of Count Makino's liberal views so close to the throne.

Asking to be relieved of its onerous duties after nearly four months of service, the extraordinary grand jury empaneled by Governor Lehman last July to stamp out racketeering in New York County reported to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday that a dozen or more "major criminals" control the forces that extort millions each year from the city's business men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- A report that telephone companies of the Bell System had cut off teletypewriter service to some users while continuing it to others providing no more revenue was made public today by the Communications Commission.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 26. -- Archaeologists of the University of Cincinnati calculated tonight that a civilization lasting 3,200 years flourished on the site of Troy, the crossroads of the ancient world.

WISE, Va., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Haugeman Falin, 16-year-old youth, who was exonerated Dec. 9 on a charge of killing his father, has been jailed again on charges of drunkenness and attempting to kill his mother, who was his chief witness at the earlier hearing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Postal inspectors and other officers of the Postoffice Department were instructed, in an order made public by Postmaster General Farley tonight, to refuse to divulge records or information in their possession to any State court, "whether in answer to a subpoena duces tecum or otherwise," or in habeas corpus proceedings in a Federal court if the United States is not a party in interest.

To laymen, remembering what Mr. Justice Cardozo said for the unanimous Supreme Court in the Seelig milk pricefixing case in March, 1935, the efforts of New York and New Jersey local authorities to prevent or limit the importation of liquor from Connecticut and Pennsylvania respectively because it is sold cheaper in those States, seem violative of the court's reasoning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26. -Eighty thousand dollars has been raised toward the $150,000 regarded as one of the essentials to bring the Democratic National Convention here, according to an announcement today by Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the Chamber of Commerce convention committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- The State WPA is prepared to continue the emergency nursery schools and the parent education classes, which the State Department of Education ordered abandoned as of today in twenty-five up-State cities, Lester W. Herzog, State WPA administrator, said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26. -- This is the story of a light that did not fail. It is of the courage and loyalty of a lone woman, the wife of a lighthouse tender who fought to save his life and then kept his beacon burning.

The problem of the conduct of spectators at college sports events, particularly at football games, was brought into the open yesterday as the first guns were fired in the annual conventions of college sport officials which will take up the rest of the week.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- After five years with Tranmere Rovers, R. C. Bell, the Northern club's centre forward, has achieved the footballer's dream -- a goal-scoring record.

Indignant over a proffer of checks for $2.50 as a Christmas bonus, three editors of the publishing firm of E. P. Dutton Co., Inc., have resigned, it became known yesterday. They are Merton S. Yewdale, editor-in-chief; Louise T. Nicholl and Samuel Middlebrook, associate editors.

Martin Flavin essays Broadway again tonight with his second play of the season, "Tapestry in Gray," to be found at the Shubert Theatre at 8:30 o'clock. Fifty persons enact a multi-scened story, the four principals being Elissa Landi, Melvyn Douglas, Minor Watson and Arnold Korff -- the first three reclaimed from the films for the occasion.

Reports that Mayor La Guardia was planning a general reorganization of the city's public educational system and would force the resignation of two college presidents found little credence yesterday either at City Hall or among school and college officials.

A 20 per cent increase in gross revenues of the first eighteen railroads to report for November was translated into a rise of 74.5 per cent in net operating income. Returns to date indicate that the November earnings were the best for any like month since 1930.
New York University, by defeating Seth Low, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in the seventh round at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, gained the lead in the annual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved at one time yesterday in sympathy with a strong stock market, but hedge selling in the last hour cancelled the gain and left quotations with losses of 6 to 9 points.

The Dramatists Guild, whose membership includes every author who writes a play for Broadway, gave notice yesterday that the fiveyear minimum basic agreement between the guild and the managers would not be renewed in its present form after it expires on March 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Senator Harrison of Mississippi took up the cudgels today for the administration against the American Liberty League and attacked the 12-point plan for "constitutional recovery" which the league announced yesterday.

At a meeting of property owners last night in Christodora House, 147 Tompkins Square East, Miss Winifred Forsyth, acting head worker of the settlement house, criticized Park Commissioner Moses's plans for a new playground in Tompkins Square Park.
PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The continued dependence of business upon emergency spending of the government was characterized as "a unique and disturbing feature" of the economic recovery now in progress by Dr. Garfield V. Cox, Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago, in an address yesterday before the American Economic Association at the opening session of its forty-eighth annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Brig. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, promoted to that rank last Winter as commander of the General Headquarters Air Force, was made a temporary major general today upon the recommendation of Maj. Gen. Oscar Westover, Chief of the Air Corps.

Large apartment and loft buildings were among properties in Manhattan offered for sale at auctioneers' stands yesterday. The foreclosure list contained a dozen parcels, all of which were bought in by the plaintiffs in the proceedings.

Publicity, in its relationship to literature, was described as both a life-giving and a destroying angel by Christopher Morley in a symposium on literature and life at "America's Town Meeting of the Air," held at Town Hall last night.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 (AP). -Strengthened evidence of Benedict Arnold's resentment that "my character has been most cruelly and unjustly aspersed" which culminated in the Revolutionary War general's desertion to the British cause was believed found today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -Without waiting for possible moves to enact new NRA legislation, retail and wholesale druggist interests today shaped a drive in Congress to legalize interstate price-fixing contracts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Public Health Service recorded on its special honor roll today its first woman laboratory technician to die in the line of disease-research duty -- Anna Pabst, 39.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP). -- The validity of thirty-six indictments obtained by the State Law Department in its investigation of racetrack tipster services will be challenged in Supreme Court here tomorrow.

A total of $80,977 goes to charitable organizations from the estate of Ludwig Vogelstein, philanthropist and chairman of the American Metals Company, Ltd., according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Vogelstein, who died Sept. 23, 1934, left an estate appraised at $939,046 gross and $808,270 net.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Florida ship canal will not have an adverse effect upon municipal water supplies or impair the agricultural resources of that State, according to a report made to army engineers today by a special board of geologists and engineers appointed by the War Department corps of engineers to study geological conditions involved in the canal plan.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP). -- A sudden visit to the scene of Thelma Todd's mystery death was made today by investigators and was coupled immediately with reports of new evidence in the case.

The La Guardia administration will ask the next Congress to amend the bankruptcy laws so the city may acquire the Interborough and Manhattan Railway rapid transit properties without fear of long delays caused by the resistance of minority groups of security holders, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Production of durable goods continued to increase in November, offsetting reduced activity in most other industries, so that total production and employment, ordinarily declining from October to November, showed little change this year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly review.

Victorious in all her bouts, Miss Mildred Stewart of Hunter College took first honors in the Christmas tournament of the Women's Intercollegiate Fencing Association at the Brooklyn College gymnasium last night. Seventeen competitors, representing Brooklyn College, Hunter and New York University, competed in the event.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve-note circulation for the system as a whole and the ratio of reserve for the New York bank to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Acting on the theory that the pedagogic value of one live animal is equal to a museum of stuffed ones, or a gallery of animal pictures, the Ethical Culture Elementary School, at Sixty-third Street and Central Park West, has conferred upon two raccoons lifetime appointments as honorary members of the teaching staff in the Nature Department.
Ashley Egard Pidgeon will be admitted on Jan. 2 to Tobey Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, as a general partner. He has been with the firm since it was organized in 1932.

Conversion of the former quarters of the Manhattan Congregational Church into a motionpicture theatre will cost $10,000, according to plans filed yesterday. The space is in the Manhattan Towers Hotel at Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street.

MONTEVIDEO, Friday, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The Uruguayan Government, it was learned from an authoritative source early today, has decided to ask Alexander Minkin, the Soviet Minister, to leave the country. Officials have ordered precautionary measures because of rumors of a possible armed revolt.
Holiday in London. Tuesday's price of gold, 141s 1d per fine ounce.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The "new social order" was described as a myth by Dr. James S. Thomas, president of Clarkson College, tonight at the annual dinner of the Associated Academic Principals of the State of New York.
Indications yesterday were that the final Olympic track and field tryouts would be awarded to New York.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

They made a valiant effort, but the New York Americans could not beat the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's men fought desperately, kept charging their rivals almost every second, but when it was all over they had to skate off the ice on the short end of a 2-to-1 score.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Thirteen officers at the Supply and Civil Engineer Corps of the Navy were selected today for promotion on recommendations of selections' boards.

Stockholders of James Talcott, Inc., will vote on Thursday on a plan to increase the organization's capital stock from $3,500,000 to $6,000,000, according to a letter sent to them by J. Frederick Talcott. It is proposed to increase the number of authorized shares from 35,000 to 120,000 and to reduce their par value from $100 to $50, making the capitalization consist of 50,000 preferred shares, 18,500 Class A shares and 51,500 Class B shares.

Amid Yuletide decorations, silvered and green spruce trees and red poinsettias, Miss Harriet Morris Arthur was introduced yesterday afternoon by her parents at a tea dance at Sherry's. The party was in the ballroom and the guests, all young persons, included:

Thomas Williams, who died Dec. 21, will go down in those manifold unofficial records, the human memories of the people who loved him, but we -- who knew him through the fourteen years that he served on the council of the Charity Organization Society -- would also like to record a worded appreciation of him.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP). -Stanford came back to the Rose Bowl gridiron today for the third successive year -- resolved to break a New Year's Day losing streak at the expense of Southern Methodist.

Among the many debutante parties yesterday was the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spencer Childs in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Childs. The debutante is a granddaughter of the late Azel F. Hatch, Chicago corporation lawyer, and for many years president of the Bar Association, and of the late William Hamlin Childs, philanthropist.

Under pressure of labor unions and by public apathy, legislators are introducing a vast number of proposed laws that augur ill for the future of the railroads, E. E. Loomis, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroads, charged yesterday in a statement issued to the press.

A change in the new State Unemployment Insurance Law to obviate the necessity for detailed employe reports until 1937 will be sought in the Legislature next month if Governor Lehman accepts a recommendation which has been submitted to him by the Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council and Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.
ROME, Dec. 26. -- Premier Mussolini's navy, reliable sources reported tonight, is preparing for action, and about 13,000 naval specialists were understood to have been recalled for service.

A special matinee performance of Puccini's "Madame Butterfly," given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of various Eastern colleges, was the occasion of Susanne Fisher's debut in the title part.

President ROOSEVELT devoted a substantial part of the day yesterday to budget problems. Only a week now remains before Congress reconvenes, and the budget must be completed in time for that occasion. Routine departmental costs offer comparatively little difficulty.
MONTREAL, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, leaders of the International group of the National Hockey League, scored their third straight victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight, 2 to 0.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 26. -- Race tracks and race goers of Maryland paid a record sum into the State Treasury this year, data obtained from the Maryland Racing Commission, revealed today.

If Mr. BORAH'S advisers, among whom are deep-revolving Senators, are not mistaken, he is already sure of being the first choice of more than 200 delegates to the National Convention. If the delegates are counted long before they are elected, no proleptic exaggeration should be ascribed to the mathematics of Mr. BORAH'S managers.

The recently announced list of fifty architects chosen by the city for major contracts proved interesting reading from many angles. In the first place, the architects sponsoring the selection jury almost as a unit found favor in the eyes of that jury and were selected forthwith.
LONDON, Dec. 26. -- Of all the gifts which this Christmas has brought to men in public life let no one covet that which has fallen to the Right Hon. Anthony Eden.

The ninety-seventh annual meeting of the American Statistical Association will open today at the Hotel Commodore and continue for five days in conjunction with annual conventions of ten other organizations. Many notable in public life will speak or present papers bearing on current problems.

The first complete compilation of four of the American Winter sports teams which will represent the United States in the fourth Winter Olympic Games early next year was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee.

Just as pitchers point earnestly to their earned-run averages when those little salary discussions arise each Winter, so do the hitters call attention to number of runs they've batted in during a season. The leading attention-caller for 1935, according to the National League figures released yesterday, is Wally Berger of the Boston Braves.
A man, his wife and their 2-yearold son were found dead yesterday in the kitchen of their gas-filled five-room apartment at 319 East Ninetieth Street, all apparently victims of asphyxiation.

The use on human beings of the vaccine for immunity against infantile paralysis, developed at the Bureau of Laboratories of the New York City Department of Health, under direction of Dr. William H. Park, by Dr. Maurice Brodie of New York University, was discontinued about a week ago, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

A great need for further study of social sciences in the colleges of this country was indicated by delegates of the Pi Gamma Mu, national social science honor society, at their annual convention, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Renting agents added many names to the tenant rosters of apartment houses in the city yesterday. There was a good demand for suites in buildings on the East Side. One firm also reported signing up a number of families for rooms in houses in the Greenwich Village section.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League, questioned tonight whether Postmaster General Farley was not "indirectly" if not "directly" soliciting campaign funds in violation of the law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -Senator Pittman of Nevada served notice today he would discuss the Chino-Japanese situation in general and a remark attributed to the Japanese Ambassador in particular soon after Congress convenes.
Two hundred and sixty-one contributions added $4,664.08 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the grand total to $227,397.12.

Motor fuel stocks in the United States, including the amount of unfinished gasoline contained in naphtha distillates, at the end of last week amounted to 54,633,000 barrels, compared with 53,942,000 at the end of the preceding week, a gain of 691,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Holiday dullness in the grain markets was intensified today, as Winnipeg and Liverpool remained closed. In the trading on the Board of Trade here congestion increased in the December delivery. Short covering and buying of December against sales of May lifted the current month to 7 cents premium over the deferred position, the greatest difference on the crop.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The market for hogs here was unsettled today, early sales of weights under 225 pounds showing around 10 cents a hundredweight above Tuesday, but they lost the upturn later with some sales at the last being regarded as lower.
DALLAS, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Southern Methodist University football squad, in tiptop shape to a man, moved westward tonight for the Rose Bowl game with Stanford New Year's Day at Pasadena.

ROME, Dec. 26. -- Important events both in the military and in the political fields are believed to be imminent, for the present quiet brought about by the Christmas holidays is considered merely the lull before a storm.

I have just finished reading in your issue of Dec. 22 under the heading "Patent Reform" the letter of J. P. Hubbell about our patent system. I heartily agree with him that the personnel of the Patent Office is above reproach, but he is all wrong when he speaks of our present patent system as a "potpourri" and charges it with stifling the "lone inventor."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today to leave no stone unturned in its quest for the truth about the Midamerica Corporation, the holding company that was formed recently for the purpose of recovering from J. P. Morgan Co. actual control of the Van Sweringen railroad properties.
