RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 26 (AP). -Testimony that the Atlantic Greyhound bus was traveling at a "good speed" just before it crashed into a guard gate and plunged with its driver and thirteen passengers to icy death in the Appomattox River on Sunday was given at the coroner's inquest today.

Net income of the American Commercial Alcohol Corporation and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year was $939,466 after expenses, interest, depreciation and other charges but before Federal income tax. After providing $130,186 for taxes, there remained $809,280, which was equal to $3.10 a share on 260,901 shares.

In what some of the authorities present described as the "most important contribution in a decade to the knowledge of the tuberculosis problem in this country," Dr. Carl C. Dauer, Assistant Professor of Preventive Medicine at Tulane University, revealed yesterday that a county-to-county survey showed the Tennessee Valley region to be, for reasons that are yet mysterious, the center of high tuberculosis mortality in the southeastern part of the United States.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The women's division of the WPA was notified yesterday that a fund of $40,000 had been allotted to New York by the FERA to train domestic servants. Mrs. Sarah S. Dennen, director of the division, announced also that she would begin today selecting women from homerelief rolls for a WPA sewing project to be opened on Monday.

Otto Klemperer made his final Thursday night appearance this season as conductor of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He received a special welcome by the audience when he appeared on the stage, and after the "Eroica" symphony, which ended the program, there was a longer demonstration.

The injury that Frederick J. Perry of Great Britain sustained in his final round match with Wilmer Allison in the national tennis championship at Forest Hills, last September will keep him off the courts until the Spring.
With the arrival of the first real snowfall, the opportunity is at hand for every person who has the interests of wildlife at heart to become a practical conservationist.

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- The Cuban Boxing Commission today suspended Mike Jacobs, Joe Louis and Julian Black, one of Louis's managers, for six months for not complying with a contract signed for the Louis-Gastanaga fight on Dec. 29. The bout was recently canceled by Jacobs, New York promoter.
Holders of bonds of S. W. Straus Co., Inc., were told yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn that they might expect to recover not more than 15 cents on the dollar.

United States Government loans moved upward sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the heaviest trading of the month in those issues, the total reaching $2,661,000, compared with $651,000 on Tuesday. Gains were 1-32 to 9-32 point, with activity centered in the Treasury 2 7/8s, 2 8/4s and 3 1/8s and in Home Owners Loan 2 3/4s.

In the report to Judge McCook of the Extraordinary Grand Jury which has been investigating racketeering in this city, there is matter to make the ears of many supposedly reputable citizens tingle. They are the business men who have submitted to intimidation and extortion, yet who are unwilling to testify to the facts.

BOSTON, Dec. 26. -- Directors of the Amoskeag Company, investment holding concern, which has a substantial investment in the big Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, which recently filed a petition in Federal Court for permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act, declared dividends today for 1936 similar to those paid for two years.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- Although the general belief is that Premier Pierre Laval will survive tomorrow's debate on his foreign policy in the Chamber of Deputies, even his supporters anticipate a reduction in the already reduced majority of fifty-two that he had ten days ago before the resignation of Sir Samuel Hoare and the appointment of Anthony Eden as British Foreign Secretary.
A story of black magic, charms, midnight rendezvous in deserted places, and potent concoctions failed yesterday to raise the hair of Magistrate Charles Solomon in Bay Ridge court, Brooklyn.
RENO, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Katherine C. Hamilton obtained a divorce here today from Alexander Hamilton of New York on charges of cruelty.

Benson B. Sloan, banker and railroad director, of 41 East Sixtyfifth Street, was named in a summons for disorderly conduct issued yesterday in Yorkville Court on the complaint of his neighbor, Dr. David M. Bosworth of 58 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Yesterday's advance in stocks was the fifth consecutive rise. An additional net advance of 1.50 points during the four remaining sessions this year would cancel the decline of the first fortnight of the month and would make December the ninth consecutive month to register a rise in stocks.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 26. -- Unidentified groups last night attacked several buildings where the offices of workers' unions that have bitterly assailed former President Plutarco Elias Calles are located, captured black and red flags that had been raised since the start of the Italo-Ethiopian War as a protest "against Italian aggression," and left without injuring the watchmen.

With sugar, copper, rubber and hides stronger in light trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, other staples were erratic and dull. On the cash markets corn, rye, oats and rubber advanced, while cocoa, tin, cotton and silk declined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -The first checks for 1985 cotton subsidy payments will probably be mailed to farmers Jan. 15, AAA officials said today. It was originally planned to send them out in mid-December, but technical and clerical delays arose.
Factory deals featured the New Jersey realty items listed yesterday.

It may be that the municipal fathers of more than a hundred years ago who built our beautiful City Hall have all this time been the victims of a vile slander. Everybody knows that the front and sides of the City Hall are of marble and that the north side was left in plain sandstone.

One of the most original debutante parties of the season was the "circus party" and dance given last light by Campbell Locke in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for his daughter, Miss Faith Atherton Locke.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 26. -- Barry von La Salle, a German shepherd dog trained to lead the late Senator Thomas D. Schall, carried a wreath to the Senator's bier today. The dog was to have been a Christmas present to the Senator, who died in Washington Sunday after being struck by an automobile.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 27. -Chinese troops went into action today to block an anti-Japanese student demonstration as worried officials of the Chinese Republic sought to check the growing ChinoJapanese tension.

As its second production of the season the Artef Players Collective offers at its 48th Street Theatre a dramatization of Samuel Ornitz's novel of an East Side careerist, "Haunch, Paunch and Jowl." It took considerable authorship to shape so turbulent a work to the stage.

Stockholders having waived their pre-emptive rights, the Glidden Company will sell to a group of its officers and key employes 46,000 shares of common stock at $22 a share, it was disclosed yesterday when the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved the listing of the additional stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,519,000,000, an increase of $21,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $26,000,000 compared with corresponding week in 1934.
The national figure skating championships which will end with the selection of the Olympic team on Monday night start this morning at the Ice Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The neutrality legislation proposed by the National Peace Conference in New York appeared to officials today to be substantially in line in several of its points with views held in Congress at the last session and which may be followed to some extent when Congress at its coming session takes up the subject for further treatment.

The rocks which make up the Palisades are 150,000,000 years old, according to a scientific determination reported yesterday to more than 500 geologists, mineralogists and paleontologists in joint annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Viscount Makato Saito has long been regarded as one of Japan's outstanding liberals, an opponent of the military nationalist group, and in his new position as Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal, one of the leading advisers of the Emperor, he will be in a position to continue his opposition to the army.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP). -Al Krueger, former baseball pitcher from Beloit, Wis., hung up a 68, three strokes under par, to capture the lead in the first round of the fourth annual $4,000 Pasadena open golf tournament today.

Dr. and Mrs. James Herbert Lawson introduced their daughter, Miss Elsie Herbert Lawson, last night at a dinner dance in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The debutante, who attended the Brearley School and Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn., received with her mother in a bower of palms and ferns at the foot of the stairway leading to the Roof Garden.
Bird life in the North in Winter is on the increase, it was reported last night at the annual Christmas census of the Linnaean Society of New York at the Metropolitan Museum of Natural History.
A small, serious looking boy hurried out of a side door in Children's Court in the Bronx yesterday, freed of any charges growing out of the killing of a young friend last June.

Gold to the value of $2,867,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here -- $1,166,000 in England, $1,437,000 in India and $264,000 in Chile. These engagements made the total engaged abroad since Sept. 9, $833,900,000, of which $823,400,000 has been received.

Broad changes in Federal and State taxation methods to bring about a more equitable distribution of the cost of government were urged by educators and economists at the opening session of the third annual meeting of the Tax Policy League yesterday in the Town Hall Club.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26. -Charley Stevenson, 19-year-old Boise, Idaho, jockey who a year ago was almost unknown to the turf, virtually clinched 1935 riding honors today when he rode four winners at the Fair Grounds.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 26. -- Although there is a temporary cessation of spectacular developments in the student movement, Chinese Government leaders are not deceiving themselves, but say frankly they fear a grave crisis is ahead.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The Treasury approached the midpoint of the 1936 fiscal year today with receipts lagging far behind increasing expenditures to make a deficit of $1,785,000,000.

Higher prices for livestock and meats because of colder weather accounted largely for a 1.1 point recovery in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, which advanced to 129.6 on Tuesday from 128.5 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

Directors of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $1 and an extra dividend of $1 on the convertible preference stock, and the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents on the common shares. A similar extra dividend was paid on the convertible preference stock a year ago.

Violation of the National Labor Disputes Act by forming a company union and "restraining and coercing" its employes was charged against the Atlas Bag and Burlap Company of Brooklyn in an intermediate report to the National Labor Relations Board filed yesterday by Dr. John A. Lapp, trial examiner.

With Mayor La Guardia declaring that he had received promises of cooperation from Western growers of small artichokes in his ban on their sale in public markets here, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, said he thought it would take "only a few days" to drive the racketeers from the trade.

During the twenty business days of December that preceded Christmas American retail book buyers spent in the neighborhood of $400,000 for the two current non-fiction best sellers, publishers said yesterday. The list price of the copies of "The Woollcott Reader," edited by Alexander Woollcott, that Viking sent out to booksellers in those twenty days amounts to $258,827, the publishers said.

A report that the claque -- the body of paid applauders -- still existed on a semi-professional basis at the Metropolitan Opera House was vigorously denied yesterday afternoon by Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan. By way of proof, Mr. Johnson pointed to the spontaneous applause that had greeted the artists in their performances this season.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Laughing Sun, idle since his winning effort at Saratoga last August, returned to the races in top form today at Tropical Park and scored a hard-earned triumph in the Dinner Key Purse, a six-furlong dash that served as the feature on an off-day card.

The volume of money in circulation rose $89,000,000 in the week before Christmas to $5,991,000,000 on Tuesday, a gain of $368,000,000 over that of a year before, according to the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Dec. 26. -The South Jersey Transit Authority has voted to recommend that New Jersey buy all the railroad lines in the southern part of the State, modernize them and operate then publicly, it was announced here today by Colonel Clifford M. Elwell of Toms River, chairman of the Authority.

A Christmas supper dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Bartol last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Hester Gouverneur Bartol. Native white pine and balsam trees surrounded the ballroom and tall cedar trees trimmed with icicles were grouped about the columns of the room.

Miss Hayes, who has been dwelling among distant royalty for some time has now come close to present recollection. In Laurence Housman's "Victoria Regina," which held court at the Broadhurst last evening, she traverses the reign of England's doughtiest Queen from 1837 to 1897.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- An order by Comptroller General J. R. McCarl halted plans today for the Federal Surplus Commodity Corporation to buy surplus farm products for relief distribution.

A novelty will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight, when a boxing program in which all of the participants will be Negroes will be conducted. Ten bouts, each scheduled for four rounds, are listed, and James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at the Garden, has arranged five emergency matches besides, to insure the fans sufficient action in the event of short endings in the regular battles.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Recovering after a disastrous first innings South Africa is on even terms with Australia in the second cricket test match, which was started Tuesday and resumed today.

Eighty-five juniors and sixty-nine boys, all seeking the national indoor championships in their respective divisions, went into action yesterday on the pine board tennis courts at the Seventh Regiment Armory and after more than twelve hours of continuous warfare most of the favorites were still in the running.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP). -- Miss Virginia Hollinger, 18 year-old tennis star from Dayton, Ohio, today opened the defense of her girls' national indoor tennis title by defeating Miss Betty Albers of Brookline, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, in a secondround match on the Longwood indoor courts.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 26. -Twenty persons died victims of lynchings in the United States during 1935, the Department of Records and Research of the Tuskegee Institute reported today. This is five more than were listed last year but eight less than in 1933.

Two major developments in science's fight to control infantile paralysis were reported yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the Society of American Bacteriologists at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TOKYO, Dec. 26. -- One of the key posts in the unseen government of Japan changed hands today when former Premier Viscount Makato Saito was appointed Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal, succeeding Count Shinken Makino, who is suffering from neuritis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt secluded himself in the White House today and began the actual writing of his annual message to Congress. He had before him a fairly complete skeleton of the message made from notes jotted down during recent weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Rigid centralization of control over land uses, assessments and public debt must be effected in Westchester County if the taxpayer is to be protected against the high cost of premature real estate development, mounting tax arrears on unused lands, and uncertainties from the present complicated taxation and assessment system, according to the Institute of Public Administration in another report today to the County Commission on Government.
Houston, Texas, will be in the market on Jan. 15 with new bonds of the Independent School District aggregating $3,154,000. The bonds will mature from 1937 to 1965.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Final tryouts for places on the American Olympic boxing team will be held in the Chicago Stadium in May under the sponsorship of The Chicago Tribune.

The appeal of the Church Unity Octave Council in America to the Protestant Episcopal ministry for a reunion with the Roman Catholic Church was attacked yesterday as "disloyalty" by a spokesman for the evangelical or low church group and was assailed by clergymen of other sects throughout the nation.

Trading in the share market yesterday reflected the holiday cheerfulness and prices firmed up under the leadership of the aviation, public utility and various specialty stocks. As is usual after a holiday in midweek, the market was unusually active for these times, the volume on the Stock Exchange amounting to 2,336,000 shares, the heaviest since Dec. 10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The receipt by the Securities and Exchange Commission of fourteen offering sheets of various oil interests in the week ended on Dec. 21 was announced by that agency today as follows:

The present utterly confused condition of the silver market throws on our Government's Silver Purchase Law of 1934 a glaring light, historically as well as financially. What it means financially, the course of silver's price has shown. The Treasury, under the instructions of the law, had pursued the policy not only of buying up all the newly mined American silver but of making immensely heavy purchases for import on foreign markets.

The national public debt, about $30,000,000,000, at the end of the present fiscal year, will be double what it was five years ago, Professor Edwin Walter Kemmerer of Princeton University declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy at the Hotel New Yorker.

The drama will hike itself up to the Ritz Theatre this evening to offer there the saga of South Polar exploration called "Hell Freezes Over." It is the work of John Patrick, who normally writes stories for the Hollywood people, and playing its parts is a cast of seven.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 27. -- Expansion of the curriculum to meet the needs of the majority of students in secondary schools, "now crowded with non-essentials for 85 per cent of the students, was the keynote of the second day's sessions of the annual conference of Associated Academic Principals of New York State today.

The American Red Cross will receive $3,482,535 from the estate of Mrs. Clara A. Hapgood Higgins Smith, widow of Frank S. Smith, lawyer, and sister of the late Governor Frank W. Higgins. The exact sum was disclosed yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal was filed.

At noon you are standing in Kansas City and your breath blows out in thick clouds before you as you climb into the cockpit of the plane. You've had a hot drink to start the blood flowing in your veins and have stamped hastily across the icy ground of the airport.

St. John's University's undefeated basketball team won its seventh game in a row last night, defeating Brooklyn College, 27 -- 18, before a crowd of 1.300 at the De Gray gymnasium. The spectators occupied every seat in the place and overflowed on the court.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Validity of indictments obtained by New York State in its inquiry into fake racetrack tipster services was attacked again in Supreme Court here today as arguments on motions to quash the indictments were postponed until Jan. 6.

Most commodity futures were higher on the local Exchanges yesterday. Rubber and cottonseed oil were easier. Trading was heavy m some staples, particularly sugar and coffee. On the cash markets, corn, rye and dairy products advanced, while wheat, lard and silk declined.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Employers to the number of 150 came here today from several parts of the State to protest against individual employe records under the Unemployment Insurance Act. They were informed that no such records need be kept in 1936, but notwithstanding this they objected to the regulations which require them to furnish such data to the State.

Four piers on the North River waterfront were abustle last night as holiday cruise ships prepared to sail with about 4,500 passengers en route to warmer climes. On two others stores were being taken aboard for sailings today and tomorrow.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and Montgomery Waddell, co-executors of the estate of Mrs. Caroline W. Frame, who died in 1925, were ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division to restore about $232,000 to the estate.
A pair of Pirates led the National League pitchers in the important matter of allowing earned runs, the official 1935 averages, released today, reveal.

Mayor La Guardia defended the huge costs of relief administration and the Federal security program and appealed for "tolerance" toward public officials bearing these responsibilities last night when the Pi Lambda Phi awarded to him the medal it annually confers upon the man who best exemplifies the spirit of tolerance.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 27. -- Governor Olson today ordered National Guard troops to duty at the Strutwear Knitting Company plant in Minneapolis, where strike violence occurred yesterday. He said that he acted to "keep people from being killed or injured."
Fluctuations of prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a 10-point range yesterday, to end with a gain of 2 points to a loss of 1 point on the day.

President Roosevelt, faced by a national crisis and with the greatest opportunities for reform ever granted a President, has failed to meet the emergency and instead has resorted to "the usual game of putrid party politics," Dean Howard Lee McBain of the Graduate Faculties of Columbia University declared yesterday afternoon.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Geologists say that the Palisades on the other side of the Hudson are 150,000,000 years old. Some people will now ask if the engineers of the George Washington Bridge took into consideration the advanced age of the Palisades before tying up with them.

Frank Walter Nicolson, dean emeritus of Wesleyan University, yesterday outlined difficulties being encountered throughout the country by large and small colleges in the promotion of football games, and expressed the opinion that eventually the evils would be lessened through the continued fine work of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

At last, without any semblance of grief, I note that slowly but gradually American workers are learning what they may expect from the Wagner Labor Act and all the other misleading acts concocted by our present administration in Washington. The decision by Federal Judge Otis of Kansas City and the interpretations of the United States Supreme Court on several of the alphabetical arrangements have brought additional facts to the surface.

An all-Harvard final in the invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tourney at the University Club was assured last night when Germaine G. Glidden and Richard W. Gilder, both Crimson standard-bearers, emerged triumphant in the semi-finals.

Another building operation soon will be started in the Dyckman Street section of Manhattan as the result of a purchase by William Lippman. The latter has acquired a plot 100 by 100 feet on the east side of Cooper Street, 150 feet south of 204th Street, a block from Broadway.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- December wheat went off the Chicago Board of Trade blackboard today after one of the wildest price fluctuations witnessed in any delivery for many months. Short covering and buying of December against sales of May at 7 1/2 to 8 cents a bushel premium for the former continued persistently until near the close, when selling orders in the current delivery suddenly appeared from commission houses and disclosed a lack of support.
Is it fair to make a comparison between our criminal departments and Scotland Yard to the latter's advantage, when England's 'problem of hunting a criminal differs so vastly from ours?

A total entry of 152, an all-time record for the event, has been received for the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships which will be held at Newburgh on New Year's Day, it was announced yesterday.

In the ballroom of the Colony Club last night Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sillcocks gave a dinner dance to introduce their twin daughters, the Misses Margaret and Elizabeth Sillcocks. The ballroom was decorated with Christmas foliage and clusters of red balloons on the chandeliers.

The AAA and its methods were characterized as a justifiable but dangerous emergency makeshift requiring serious revision, in an address yesterday by Professor Frank D. Graham of Princeton University before the meeting of the American Economic Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
Auctioneers were kept busy again yesterday when they held a dozen forced sales of properties in Manhattan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- William Kilmartin, 53 years old, of 325 North Seventh Avenue, Mount Vernon, former business agent of Local 86, Plumbers and Steamfitters Union, and James P. Heelen, 48, of 412 Hancock Avenue, also Mount Vernon, former financial secretary of the local, were arraigned today before Judge Nolan in County Court here on charges of defrauding their union of $35,000 during the last ten years.

James C. Sheridan, Democratic County Leader of Queens, will start reprisals Jan. 1, 1936, against party executives who ousted him temporarily from the leadership last Summer, according to information obtained yesterday. It was learned that at least twenty-two attaches of the offices of Sheriff, Register and District Attorney of Queens who hold appointive posts were slated for dismissal in the new year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- President Roosevelt called attention to "injurious practices" on the Commodity Exchanges today, while officials of the Department of Agriculture announced a drive for corrective legislation when Congress convenes.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27. -- A real "messenger" from space outside the solar system reached the earth in the form of a brilliant meteor that was seen in broad daylight the afternoon of Oct. 22, flying across Connecticut at a speed of possibly 100 miles a second, Dr. Charles P. Olivier, director of the Flower Observatory of the University of Pennsylvania, told the members of the American Astronomical Society meeting here today.

With the firm conviction that his team will be able to snap New York University's thirteen-game winning streak, Coach Ward (Piggy) Lambert will bring his fast-moving Purdue quintet into Madison Square Garden tonight for the second of the season's college basketball double-headers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 27. -- The Bolivian reply to the proposal of the Chaco peace conference for the repatriation of war prisoners and a pact providing guarantees of non-aggression is being held up pending en explanation of certain terms of the proposal that are being subjected to varying interpretations here.

Business editors of the United States foresee a good year in almost all lines, according to a symposium of their views published in this week's issue of Editor Publisher, trade journal of the newspaper business.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- An order temporarily restraining the Securities and Exchange Commission from making public the salaries of officers and directors of the American Can Company was issued today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Amply fulfilling the expectations of its followers, the defending City College team captured the Intercollegiate Chess League championship at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. The victors also kept for another year the Harold M. Phillips Trophy, with a mark of six straight victories and a game score of 19 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Societa Italiana Pirelli (Pirelli Company of Italy) has filed on Form 21 for the permanent registration of $928,000 of 7 per cent convertible gold bonds due on May 1, 1952, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, at Milan, is engaged in the manufacture and sale of rubber, gutta-percha and asbestos, electric and submarine cables and similar products, either directly or through the participation of other companies.
OTTAWA, Dec. 27. -- The Canadian Government announced today settlement of the trade war with Japan which started in the closing days of the Bennett administration and was waged with surtaxes.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Stanford's football team took another hard workout on defense against Southern Methodist passes today at Brookside Park on a field made slippery by light rain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Senator Norris of Nebraska, father of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act and other new departures in government, will soon offer Congress a proposal vaster than all the rest.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Skillful pilot though he is, Premier Pierre Laval's government seems all but certain to crash tomorrow. Today it was buffeted and bruised in such a manner that even if it is kept afloat a few days longer for internal reasons it can have no authority and can steer no course.

Trudi Schoop and her "Comic Ballet" made their American debut last night at the Majestic Theatre in a program consisting of two long numbers, the first entitled "Want Ads" and the second and more famous called "Fridolin on the Road."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP). -- R. George Harvey, head of the Philadelphia Bureau of the Federal Investigation Division, announced his resignation from government service today. He will take a position as an attorney in the legal department of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. on Jan. 1.

New financing scheduled for the first week of 1936 by one State and fifty-five municipalities amounts to $9,777,266. This compares with a revised total of $9,117,133 offered to investment banking houses this week. In 1935 the weekly average of new offerings, not necessarily sales, by States and municipalities was $26,423,488, compared with $19,212,820 in 1934.

A celebration of the Holy Communion for the members of the Diocesan Auxiliary to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was held yesterday morning at the high altar of the cathedral by Bishop William T. Manning, assisted by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the cathedral, and the Rev. Robert F. Lau of the staff.

The right of the Actors Equity Association to close the play "The Right of Happiness" because of non-paymentt of salaries was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision reversing an award of damages made against Equity by a Supreme Court jury.

The first half of the competition for the women's national figure-skating title was concluded yesterday at the Ice Club with the present champion, Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, having a decided margin over the six other contestants.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The Foreign Office today denied a report emanating from French quarters to the effect that Sir Eric Phipps, the British Ambassador, paid a second pre-Christmas visit to the Chancellor in the course of which Chancellor Hitler proposed the conclusion of a bilateral air pact with Great Britain.

Keith Morgan, vice president of the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, established by President Roosevelt for the treatment of infantile paralysis sufferers, denied yesterday that the foundation had requested the discontinuance of the use on human beings of the vaccine for immunity against infantile paralysis developed at the bureau of laboratories of the New York City Department of Health.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, 18-year-old defending champion in the girls' national indoor tennis tournament at Longwood, today led the seeded list into the semi-final round.

PALM BEACH. Fla., Dec. 27. -Illumined by Japanese lanterns and decorated with a motif of blue and silver, the Palm Beach Private Schools provided the setting tonight for its fourth annual subscription dance, at which students and alumni, parents and friends were guests.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 27 (AP). -- A government communique said Ethiopian troops in the Tembien Mountain region, north and west of Makale, had routed Italian outposts on the Makale road, capturing eleven machine guns and quantities of rifles and ammunition.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Two more suits were filed here today contesting the right of Boston's Mayor and City Censor to ban from theatres such plays as they hold are improper. An equity action was instituted by Sidney S. Grant, counsel for the Children's Hour, Inc., of New York, against Mayor Frederick W. Mansfield and his Board of Censors to restrain them from banning the play "The Children's Hour."

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 27. -- The Civilian Conservation Corps contract for 1,000,000 pairs of cotton stocking-type socks today was awarded at the Quartermaster Depot to A.W. McLellan at 7.73 cents per pair, net. Leininger Knitting Company was awarded the contract for 500,000 woolen stocking-type socks at 15.74 cents per pair, net.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- A decision to enter Senator Borah in the Illinois Presidential primary against Frank Knox, publisher of that State, was announced today by Edgar J. Cook, Chicago attorney.
"One Way Ticket," with Walter Connolly, Lloyd Nolan and Peggy Conklin, opens with a preview showing tomorrow night at the Globe.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Par took a beating today when five golfers bettered 71 in the second day of the first round play in the Pasadena $4,000 open tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- After a study of probable price trends for the coming year, Donald E. Montgomery, consumers counsel for the AAA, reported today that the cost of leading meat and vegetable items and probably flour would be well on their way to lower levels by next November, and that a trend in this direction already had set in.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Soft coal producers expressed conflicting opinions before the Bituminous Coal Commission today at a hearing on the advisability of immediate price-fixing.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 27. -- Big Maurice Orr and his precious kicking foot, which produced 37 points in the first twelve games, punched footballs over the cross-bar from all angles today when Southern Methodist's Mustangs stopped here for a workout.

The unexpected rush of late Christmas buying, augmented by the abrupt rise in sales of Winter merchandise as the cold wave spread across the country, enabled the majority of retailers to end the most satisfactory holiday season in five years, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Committees representing noteholders and stockholders of Adolph Gobel, Inc., have approved a reorganization plan which the company has filed here in the United States District Court. The concern is being reorganized under Section1 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The fifty-third anniversary high mass of the Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society will be celebrated New Year's Day at 11 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Hayes will preside and impart his blessing to the members and their families.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The London Stock Exchange reopened quietly today after the holidays, but although little business was done the tone was firm. British Government stocks were steady, while in the foreign bond list few changes resulted.

Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, chairman of the joint legislative committee investigating bondholders' committees, issued yesterday a statement warning holders of S.W. Straus Co. bonds not to dispose of their securities at sacrifice prices. He said that in some cases Straus bondholders would realize eventually as much as 60, 70 and even 100 per cent on their holdings.

An improving market for farm lands in many parts of the country was noted in a report issued yesterday by the Farm Credit Administration showing that during the first ten months of 1935 more than 6,400 farms taken over by the Federal Land Banks because of mortgage defaults were sold to agriculturists and investors for an aggregate sum of $22,154,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The proposal that the country be split into ten or twelve districts for Federal activities tonight evoked a cordial word from Western Congressmen.

The proposed dissolution of Faroll Brothers, the formation of a new firm of the same name and the organization of Pflugfelder, Bampton Rust were among the year-end changes among its membership announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

With one exception in each division, all of the favorites in the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships came through with victories at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday to gain the fourth round as the second day of competition came to a close.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27. -- Mrs. Clyde Phillips's Wee Tune, an invader from New England, and Victor Emanuel's Lady Higloss finished so evenly in the Belle Glade Purse at Tropical Park today that many onlookers expected the judges to call it a dead heat.

A total of $7,534,750 of new bond financing this week was the smallest volume since the week ended on Feb. 15, when the amount was $5,537,000. Last week $68,480,000 in new issues was marketed, and in Christmas week last year $2,733,000.

The New York State Tax Commission on Revision of Tax Laws will report to the Legislature next month that there is no necessity for the imposition of new State taxes, former Senator Seabury C. Mastick announced yesterday after an all-day meeting of the commission in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27. -- Charley Stevenson of Boise, Idaho, leading in the race for American riding honors this year, held his lead of eleven winners over Wayne Wright of Rexburg, Idaho, by scoring a double at the Fair Grounds today, while his rival was achieving the same feat at Miami.

Tin horns will blare on Tuesday night, cow bells will rattle, paper streamers will go sizzling through the air and a new year will be born. In night clubs and hotel salons all over Manhattan, there will be noise and music, laughter and considerable spirited toasting, hilarious entertainment and, in a few isolated cases, free drinks.

Only a negligible change in the cold weather of the last three days may be expected in New York today, according to the Weather Bureau's forecast last night. Some time in the early morning the official temperature may fall as low as 15 degrees above zero, from which point it will climb later in the day to just below the freezing line of 32.

Yesterday's share market was, for the most part, uninteresting, with prices moving narrowly to close irregular. With 992 individual issues dealt in on the Stock Exchange, the market there was the broadest since Dec. 4, with total trading slightly lessened from the day before -- 2,139,000 shares, against 2,336,000.

ALIQUIPPA, Pa., Dec. 27 (AP). -- After-Christmas tragedy invaded six modest homes in this little steel town today where two women and four men, all neighbors, died in convulsions after drinking "moonshine" liquor.

Junior riders of the metropolitan district will compete this afternoon and evening in the ring of the Riding Club at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street in a dozen events, conditions and judging rules for which are unique. The matinee will start at 2 o'clock, with the first class of the evening to be called at 8 o'clock.

In an effort to solve the admittedly difficult problem of keeping Central Park an oasis of lawns and shrubbery without unduly curtailing recreational facilities for small children, Commissioner MOSES announced several weeks ago that he intended to lay out nineteen playgrounds around the rim of the park.

E.L. Phillips Co., the construction corporation controlled by Ellis L. Phillips, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, began business on a cash investment of $50,000 and paid total dividends of $5,082,219 in the twenty-year period from 1913 to 1933, according to testimony heard yesterday by the joint legislative committee investigating public utilities in this State.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27. -- Applicants for marriage licenses in this State will be required, starting today, to submit to blood tests under a new statute effective Jan. 1. By virtue of an existing law five days must elapse between the filing of the application and the issuance of the license.

CHICAG0, Dec. 27. -- Prices of hogs declined today and, while weights under 200 pounds sold at 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight lower, most offerings of hogs weighing 210 pounds and over dropped 25 to 50 cents, with occasional sales and late bids down 65 to 75 cents from the high point on Thursday.

The United States basketball entry in the 1936 Olympic Games will be selected after final elimination games in Madison Squire Garden next April 3, 4 and 5 or 6, Chairman Walter E. Meanwell of the Olympic basketball committee announced last night.
HONOLULU, T.H., Dec. 27. -- Mauna Loa's lava stream was attacked from the air today by army aviators, who dropped 6,000 pounds of bombs on the tough hide of the Pacific's second highest mountain.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- Ways to ease the tax burden in Westchester County for parks and parkways are discussed by the Institute of Public Administration in another of its reports to the Westchester Commission on Government.
The Neediest Cases Fund was increased to $231,772.87 yesterday by 248 contributions totaling $4,375.75.

Conflicting price trends characterized bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The sudden reversal of form in the market for United States Government loans was one of the interesting developments of the day as prices turned highly irregular on a turnover of only $575,900, compared with the $2,661,100 and buoyant tone on Thursday.

The Federal Reserve Board added yesterday fresh confirmation of the extent of the recovery recently achieved by American business. Its index of industrial production advanced last month to 97 per cent of the 1923-25 average. At this point it is at the highest level reached at any time during the last five years, except for a single month in 1933.

ROME, Dec. 27. -- Today's war bulletin which gives news of an engagement at Afaga Pass, indicates that military activity is still intense on the northern front. Although a comparatively small number of men is participating in these engagements, they nevertheless reveal an increased aggressiveness on the Ethiopian side that cannot but be disturbing to Italy.

A show-down on the fight of Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie Republican leader, against Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, will come at the caucus of the Republican members of the Assembly to be held in the State Capitol at Albany next Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Establishment of ten or twelve "little Washingtons" or Federal subcapitals to facilitate cooperation with States on regional problems has been recommended to President Roosevelt. The proposal was submitted by the National Resources Committee, which includes five members of the Cabinet and Harry L. Hopkins, head of the Works Progress Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- As the President continued the writing of his annual message to Congress today, the belief grew about the Capitol that Mr. Roosevelt would read the document to a joint session of the two houses, probably soon after the second session of the Seventy-fourth Congress convenes on next Friday noon.

As a sequel to two days of unofficial debate on the issues involved, a candid discussion of the Southeastern Conference's recent decision to subsidize athletes, especially football players, openly and under faculty control, is expected to feature today's thirtieth annual meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland married Mrs. Eleanor Davies Cheesborough, formerly of New York, this afternoon at the home of her mother, Mrs. Emlen Knight Davies, in Massachusetts Avenue.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27. -Radio Station WTIC, one of the most powerful and best equipped links in the National Broadcasting Company's chain, has been sold by the Travelers Insurance Company, its operators for ten years, and in a few months will be moved out of this State, according to reliable information here today.

Recent rumors of the presence of a wild panther in New York State have revived the hope of naturalists that this largest of North American unspotted cats may still survive in the wilderness areas of the Northeast.

Brilliant vocalism through the difficult medium of a cappella style delighted a highly responsive audience last night when the Lincoln Cathedral Choir, under the direction of John M. Rosborough, made its first appearance at Carnegie Hall in a recital of Christmas music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Wheeling Steel Corporation of Wheeling, W. Va., has filed an application under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $35,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due on Feb. 1, 1966.

IN this and age of high-pressure methods, infant prodigies are nothing very unusual. In fact, most any proud parent will tell you there is one tucked away upstairs, and if your luck runs out you probably will be favored before the evening is out with a rendition of "Three Blind Mice," whereupon you also will have to register profound admiration to the best of your ability.

The isolation for the first time in crystalline form of five pounds of the aucuba mosaic virus, a quantity more than sufficient to kill every tobacco plant in the world, was announced here yesterday at the annual convention of the Society of American Bacteriologists.

A gallery devoted exclusively to the work of artists employed by the WPA in the five boroughs was opened yesterday at 7 East Thirty-eighth Street. It is believed to be the first such gallery in the country arranged as a Federal art project.

The four children of the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick will share equally in the $10,000,000 trust fund set up for her by John D. Rockefeller Sr., the Appellate Division ruled yesterday. The court overruled the claim of Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard to a four-sevenths share, and the claim of assignees of Edward W. Krenn, Swiss architect, to a share.

Recent news dispatches in your columns indicate that certain Eastern leaders of large blocks of delegates from six States will go to the Republican National Convention uncommitted. Speaking for Pennsylvania, if this means that the Republicans of this State are to be tongue-tied and hand-tied in expressing their preferences, the plan will fail.

The long, swift decline in silver was turned yesterday when the price in London rose 1/8d to 21d an ounce, and the quotation here was posted unchanged, for the third successive business day, at 49 3/4 cents. London's price was equal to about 46.66 cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Brig. Gen. Henry H. Arnold was named today as assistant chief of the Air Corps.

Marking a further unification with the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, Edward W. Scheer was elected yesterday as president of the Reading Company and of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. A former general superintendent of the B. O., Mr. Scheer succeeds the late Charles H. Ewing as head of the two controlled lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Despite the opposition of counsel representing power companies in four suits attacking the right of PWA to allocate funds for the construction of municipally owned power plants in Alabama and Texas, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia remanded the cases to the District Supreme Court today so that the record could be revised to meet a change in the situation which furnishes the background for the litigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Wholesale prices declined slightly in the week ended on Dec. 21, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average, fell to 80.4 from 80.8 the preceding week, and compared with 80.6 a month ago and 76.7 a year ago.

Frederick P. Condit, former executive vice president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, and three other former officers of the two concerns were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for alleged mail fraud and conspiracy.

Members of the New York State Planning Council, appointed recently by Governor Lehman to study coordination of the work of various State departments and to unify improvements of a State-wide character, met yesterday in the offices of Gilmore D. Clarke at 101 Park Avenue to map out their program for the coming year.
ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Terms on which Emperor Haile Selassie's delegation to Geneva is authorized to discuss peace with Italy were disclosed in reliable quarters here today.

Charging that William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, used the "fish racket" in 1933 to further his political ambitions to the detriment of the business he headed, minority stockholders of the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday for an accounting and recovery of the sums allegedly lost to the company.

Governor Lehman will issue today an order for another special grand jury to succeed the body that for several months has been investigating rackets in New York County and now has asked to be relieved. It is possible, too, that to meet technical routine, the Governor may name a new extraordinary term of the Supreme Court with Justice McCook again presiding.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 27. -- Student troubles broke out at a new place today, completely interrupting train traffic on two trunk railways when more than 2,000 middle school pupils occupied the railway station at Hsuchow in Northern Kiangsu.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Preparing to hold a hearing on Feb. 4 on the Van Sweringen plan for reorganization of the Missouri Pacific, the Interstate Commerce Commission received today testimony favorable to the plan in another proceeding.

Voicing the optimism he said prevails within the radio industry, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, in a survey of radio in 1935 issued yesterday said the manner in which the industry last year emerged "from a period which has been trying to all business endeavor," proves it still retains "the youthful outlook and vitality" exhibited in the decade following 1920.

TOKYO, Dec. 27. -- Eiji Amau, spokesman of the Japanese Foreign Office, charged today that American missionary schools were leading the anti-Japanese student agitation in China. He said the schools had undertaken to repress the movement, so he did not disclose the names of the missions involved.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press). -- Requiring 314 runs for victory in the second cricket test match with South Africa, the touring Australians, with nine wickets to fall, face a difficult task tomorrow.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 27. -- Ten players representing the United States, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Belgium and England began play this evening in the international masters' tournament at the annual Christmas Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club at the White lock Pavilion.

Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a dance last night at their home, 7 East Ninety-first Street, for Mrs. Astor's debutante sister, Miss Virginia French, daughter of Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr. and of Francis Ormond French.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 27. -Miss Doris Bainbridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Marcellus Bainbridge of this place, was introduced to society today at a tea given at the home of her parents. The debutante, who received with her mother, was gowned in white pleated chiffon and carried yellow roses and blue lace flowers.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt added three of her dolls to the exhibition of "The Dolls of the World" which started yesterday at B. Altman Co., Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, to continue daily through Tuesday for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service, administered by the Henry Street Settlement.

The Federal Government must start transferring funds by next April to extend the relief program to the end of the fiscal year, June 30, 1936, it was declared yesterday by Jacob Baker, Assistant Works Progress administrator, when he arrived from Washington to take part in the opening of the Federal art project gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Following widespread criticism, especially in "low church" circles, of its recent proposal to the Protestant Episcopal ministry for a reunion with the Roman Catholic Church, the Church Unity Octave Council of high churchmen asserted yesterday that its sole purpose was "the stirring up as many as may be to pray very earnestly for the reunion of all Christians."
The value of the dollar on the social foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spencer Childs's supper dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Childs, took place last night in the ballroom of the Pierre in a red and gold setting. Gilded smilax entwined the pillars of the ballroom land vases of red poinsettias were in the corners.

A special Federal grand jury, which for the last three months has been investigating the affairs of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, the huge utility system built up by Howard C. Hopson, was discharged yesterday by Federal Judge Coxe.

The growing complexity of the world of atoms and of molecules and the high lights of the stratosphere flight on Nov. 11 of the balloon Explorer II were described yesterday before 1,500 honor students in science, members of the student science clubs of the American Institute at the second day's sessions of its science congress and Christmas lectures at the American Museum of Natural History.

Transcontinental motor freight service became a reality yesterday with the arrival in New York City of the first motorized caravan to span the continent in the history of transportation. Completing the run in six days, 23 hours and 46 minutes after leaving Los Angeles, the four huge tractor trucks, drawing as many trailers, pulled into the city with 72,000 pounds of freight.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP). -- American bobsled teams to compete in the Olympic Games in Berlin were announced today as preparations were completed for the official opening of the Winter sports season here tomorrow night.

Sir Arthur Willert, for fourteen years head of the press department of the British Foreign Office, arrives here today at noon, and a reception for him will be held at the British Empire Exhibition on Monday afternoon. His book, "What Next in Europe?" will be published Jan. 15 by Putnam.

Sir Arthur Willert, for fourteen years head of the press department of the British Foreign Office, arrives here today at noon, and a reception for him will be held at the British Empire Exhibition on Monday afternoon. His book, "What Next in Europe?" will be published Jan. 15 by Putnam.

An entirely unauthorized transaction whereby Jack, a chow dog owned by John E. Biggins, Brooklyn bank president, acquired twenty-five shares of stock of the Bank of Suffolk County on Christmas Eve, was in effect set aside by the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27. -- The Uruguayan Government severed diplomatic relations with Soviet Russia this morning, sending their passports to Alexander Minkin, the Soviet Minister, and other members of the Legation in Montevideo.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- With the near approach of the American Importer, which is bringing the Lindbergh family to England, the British press is taking greater account of what The London Daily Mirror calls "a victory for crime such as never before occurred in the modern world."

Metering of all water used in New York City was urged yesterday by Harold Reigelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, as the only means of averting a future water shortage pending the construction of the $273,000,000 Delaware River water system.

Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been retained by the Radio Corporation of America to make a study of the problems relating to the company's capital structure, it was announced by David Sarnoff, president, following the regular meeting of the board of directors yesterday.

Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Nicoll introduced their daughter, Miss Jean Nicoll, last night at a dinner dance at Sherry's, where silvered and white smilax was the theme of the decorations in the ballroom. The hostess and her daughter received in a bower of palms, smilax and lilies.

Delegates attending the opening sessions yesterday of the annual convention of the American Association of Teachers of Spanish, in the Harkness Academic Theatre at Columbia University, heard Professor Walter V. Kaulfers of Stanford University attack the stereotyped foreign language course in secondary schools as being "an educational monstrosity."
An increasing vote against the New Deal is shown by the tabulation of nearly one million votes in the sixth instalment in the Literary Digest's poll, published in the current issue of that magazine.

With State Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin playing the role of Santa Claus, some 750 children were entertained yesterday afternoon at the belated sixteenth annual Christmas party of the Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 27 (AP). -- Suit to recover $3,200,000, already paid the Van Sweringen interests by the Missouri Pacific Railroad in a deal involving a purchase price in excess of $20,000,000, was filed here in Circuit Court late today by Guy A. Thompson, trustee for the railroad.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Further exchanges between the German and British Governments, it can now be stated, have followed the remarkable and revealing interview between Chancellor Hitler and Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to Berlin, on the pregnant date of Friday the thirteenth of December.
PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Following is the text of the speech by Premier Pierre Laval today opening the debate on his foreign policy in the Chamber of Deputies:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Louisiana State University, referred to by the late Senator Long as "my school," was censured today by the Association of American Law Schools for "far-reaching political influence" attributed to Mr. Long's rule.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The Boerse was almost totally inactive today with the addition of the holiday indifference to the prevailing neglect of the market. The floor was nearly deserted. Some weakness appeared as a result of the absence of buyers.
HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Fighting planes bombed the erupting volcano Mauna Loa today in an attempt to divert a gigantic lava flow from the city of Hilo and its water supply.

The City Commissioner of Licenses has no power to revoke the license of a theatre for indecent performances unless there has been a conviction under the Penal Law, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in a three-to-two decision. Reversing the lower court, the Appellate Division granted a temporary injunction to restrain Commissioner Paul Moss from revoking the license of the Republic Theatre, home of Billy Minsky's burlesque.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Minnesota's Farmer-Labor party obtained a second place in the United States Senate today with the appointment of Elmer A. Benson, State Banking Commissioner, to the vacancy created by the death of the Republican Senator, Thomas D. Schall.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27. -- Eighteen "worthless" paintings left by John Kane, house-painter artist and three-time exhibitor in the Carnegie International, enriched his widow by $3,560 today.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Former Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, who holds office of Lord President of the Council in the new government without a seat in Parliament, has accepted an invitation to run as a government candidate for a vacancy in the representation of the Scottish universities caused by the death of Noel Skelton.

A new low in professional fight attendances was experienced last night in Madison Square Garden for a ring novelty. About 3,000 fans turned out for an all-Negro carnival, which brought together an assortment of fighters of varying weights and ability.

Enough borax to supply the United States for a hundred years has been located in the Mohave Desert in Southern California, according to a report presented here yesterday at the annual convention of the Geological Society of America and associated societies at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

By the gorgeousness of her voice and the perfection of her artistry, Enid Szantho, leading contralto of the Vienna State Opera, scored a sensational success at her recital yesterday evening in the Town Hall. Miss Szantho had been heard here for the first time last week when she appeared as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Second symphony of Mahler.

It is probable that Bizet's "Carmen," performed last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, is the most popular opera in existence. The greatness of Bizet and the skill of his librettist are attested by the fact that no matter how this work is performed, it is such a good show that the audience has a good time.

Low temperatures yesterday and Thursday stimulated consumer response to clearances of Winter apparel and furs in local stores and merchants reported yesterday these promotions have gotten off to a good start. In view of the spurt in last-minute Christmas shopping, confidence was expressed that sales for the month as a whole will show a gain over last December of from 4 to 5 per cent.

Christmas holiday trade ended well, with sales the best in several years, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by NcGreevey, Werring Howell Company. This was especially the case in accessories, and the wholesale markets are now practically clean of merchandise.

Because of a divergence of demands of contractors and the Dressmakers Union the manufacturers and wholesalers see no prospect of negotiating a new agreement before the old contract expires, Jan. 31, it was declared yesterday by Barnett Joseph, chairman of the Labor Conference Committee of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Inc.

It is hard to write about housing without emptying the ink bottle. All the more credit to Mr. JOHN IHLDER of Washington for having compressed a sprawling subject into these few inches of type in the columns of The American City for December:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Officials made known today that the Home Owners Loan Corporation was winding up its lending activities in five States and that the agency is likely to complete operations in most of the others by April 1.
The 1935 polo season in the United States was outstanding for the success of the major tournaments and for the developments in international play.

The Seventy-fourth Congress next Friday will assemble in Washington for its final session after an absence of four months, during which the popularity of the President and the New Deal have been definitely on the downgrade. Because of this fact, which has encouraged to boldness Democratic discontent with administration policies and stimulated to great activity the Republican opposition, the session is not likely to be as brief as the President desires.

John F. Condon of 2,974 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, the "Jafsie" of the Lindbergh kidnapping case and one of the principal prosecution witnesses in the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann growing out of the kidnapping; has sent the following communication, which was rcceived yesterday, to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The possibility of concerted action by American nations on the United States Government's silver-buying program was seen today by Senator Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, when it was announced that a conference with a representative of the Mexican Finance Ministry would be held here on next Wednesday night.

SO breathless is the pace of modern science, so numerous are the discoveries made in a few months that nothing short of a whole Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES could possibly do justice to the achievements of chemistry, physics, biology and astronomy in 1935.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Although there is doubt in the mind of D. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey alcoholic beverage commissioner, and also in the mind of Deputy Erwin B. Hock, as to the wisdom of having a bar in a firehouse, the North Haledon fire company will be permitted to have one.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Blackmur has long been recognized as one of our most intelligent critics, his work has, hitherto, appeared only in such "high-brow" magazines as Hound and Horn and Direction. This, his first book, gives us the first opportunity to gauge his critical position.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP). -- The aerial circus came to town today.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- New Year's resolutions are as traditionally suspect with reference to nations as to persons. Still, they are kept sometimes by individuals who have been chastened sufficiently or who find virtue less uncomfortable than its opposite.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- According to advance reservations for dances at the country clubs, Westchester will usher in a gay New Year. One of the largest parties will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye. More than 800 persons are expected to attend the dinner dance in the main clubhouse, and members of the younger set will celebrate in the Sports House.
THE year 1935 was an interesting one in contract bridge, and profitable for those who make bridge their business. It was the best year, commercially, since 1932.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade held within narrow limits today until near the close of the session, when buying of the July against sales of the May enlivened the dull pit operations. The result was a narrowing in the spread to 9 1/2 cents, compared with 10 1/4 cents at yesterday's close.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- It is unusual for a Lord Chief Justice of England to discuss publicly any political question that is a matter of current controversy. However, Lord Hewart, the present incumbent of that highest judicial office, is of a different type from many of his predecessors.

WHEN Dr. Francis E. Townsend, who thought up the plan to give everybody 60 and over $200 a month provided everybody spent it within the month and also quit work, was asked the other day what he would do if he elected a Townsend Congress and President he denied any desire to be a part of the government.

"What the Townsendites forget," says Henry Hazlitt in the course of his excellent article in THE TIMES, "is that no matter what form of tax is chosen, it must eventually come out of the incomes of those who pay it."
What is the outlook for world peace in 1936? Well, perhaps one reason for not feeling too down-hearted about things is that there are so many Sore Spots on the map of the world.

The main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton was the setting for a large tea dance given yesterday afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Jacques Halle to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anne Halle. Cybotium ferns and tall palm trees were arranged about the ballroom.

MAJOR GREY, V.C., herculean ace of the British-Indian secret service, while big game hunting in the Himalayas on a six-month furlough with his wife Diana, receives orders from Simla to proceed into a valley region of the frontier where sinister mutinous events portend a widespread outbreak of the warlike native tribesmen.

Spaced over the eight days and nights of the National Motor Boat Show next month will be as many as twenty-three meetings of one kind or another for yachtsmen and for those concerned with either the sport or the industry of power boating.

SKI enthusiasts, lovers of all outdoor Winter sports, those who enjoy unusual photographs, will find this book especially made for them. And all the skiers, from amateurs to experts, will take particular delight in it, for they will find in it such a rounding up of all manner of information about their favorite sport as they have long wanted.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- An end by next June to the need for Federal aid for unemployed musicians was predicted today by Dr. Nicolai Sokoloff, director of the WPA Federal music project, in addressing the annual meeting of the Music Teachers National Association.

The rise of 25-year-old James Caras of Wilmington, Del., to the world's professional pocket billiard championship climaxed the 1935 cue campaign. He triumphed over the veteran Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland in a play-off game to become the youngest player to reach the top since Ralph Greenleaf, at the age of 19, accomplished the feat in 1919.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Dec. 28. -- Judge Albert Levitt, who succeeded Judge J. Webber Wilson on the bench of the United States District Court here today held, in an opinion, that native women had equal rights with men to vote for members of local Councils and candidates for other electoral offices.

For the first time within memory at any production of Wagner's "Lohengrin," Telramund became the dominating figure of that opera in last night's performance at the Metropolitan. The honor of lifting this role to such eminence was Eduard Habich's, the veteran Wagnerian baritone, whose interpretation of the part was masterly, whether viewed from the vocal or the histrionic angle.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 28. -- Coal gas escaping from a broken furnace pipe in the cold hours of dawn took five lives here today, wiping out an entire family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The idea of levying sales taxes on luxuries to support the New Deal's social security program was suggested today by Chairman Buchanan of the House Appropriations Committee.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C. THE phrase "of the people, for the people, by the people" has taken on added meaning in North Carolina. Here, in the Institute of Government citizens and officials of the State have united to organize their own school of government, with laboratories and classes from which new officials and private persons alike may draw on the accumulated experience of past officers in the administration of public affairs.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- Increasing its defense appropriation by 2,084,893 ($8,114,478 at the present rate for the Australian pound), Australia plans a general strengthening of all defenses. Further mechanization of the army, maintenance of the navy at effective strength, and rearmament and improvement of coastal defenses are provided by the program, which calls for an expenditure of 7,352,399 ($28,968,452).

The share market ended yesterday the last full week of the year, with prices displaying a sagging tendency. Trading on the Stock Exchange was 1,140,000 shares, against 1,097,000 the Saturday before. Traders had their last day in which to deal "in the regular way" (at least two full days are required for clearing) if the transactions were to be made for 1935 tax purposes, and it appeared that many availed themselves of this eleventh-hour opportunity.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Rain caused abandonment of the second cricket test match between South Africa and Australia as a draw today at a point when the tourists seemed sure of victory.

WITH the appointment of Major Gen. Oscar Westover as Chief of the Air Corps, announced on Christmas Day, that service is assured of the leadership of an officer of wide popularity and varied experience. He holds four aeronautical ratings, having earned those of Airship Pilot and Balloon Observer in addition to those of Airplane Pilot and Aerial Observer.

WHEN the library of the late Ogden Goelet was sold at auction here a year ago, what was probably the last great private collection of Americana was dispersed. This significant fact was only imperfectly perceived except by the few whose business or hobby it is to watch for the appearances of the vanishing race.

LAKE PLACID, -- Tomorrow morning the fifteenth annual College Week ski competitions open at the Lake Placid Club, with teams entered from thirteen colleges in the United States and Canada. About 100 athletes the largest representation in several years, are here from Dartmouth, University of New Hampshire, Cornell, Williams, Princeton, Bowdoin, Harvard, Yale, Ottawa, St. Patrick's, Toronto, McGill and the University of Georgia.

Since the middle of March the Yale-Cambridge India Expedition has been conducting a scientific study of the geologic and archaeologic prehistory of India's Northwest Punjab. Entombed here in the Siwalik formation, which forms part of the foothills of the Himalayas, is a tremendous wealth of petrified animal remains.

THE little red school house and the generations of American children who studied in it are recalled in a current exhibition of old American school books, prints of early school scenes and other school-room accessories at the Newark Public Library.

HONOLULU, Dec. 28. -- Wreathed in the smoke and flame of burning trees, Mauna Loa's crawling lava flow progressed today through timber land on the flank of the volcano and continued its march toward Hilo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Work on a Federal budget is again under way. Subcommittees of the House Appropriations Committee for three weeks have been asking representatives of the Departments of the Treasury, Postoffice, Interior and War to justify the expenditures recommended by the Budget Bureau for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, 1936.

SIGMUND FREUD'S theories have caused more bitter battles among scientists than those of any other innovator since Darwin's thesis of man's descent from monkeys made him anathema to the Fundamentalists. The orthodox were also vastly exasperated when Freud enunciated his idea that religion was merely a universal obsessional neurosis, the rationalized residue, persisting in our subconscious selves, of our prehistoric ancestors' totem worship.

DUBLIN, Dec. 28. -- The year just closing has seen still further advances in the policy of industrializing the Irish Free State. Secondary industries for the production of such goods as electrical bulbs and equipment, metal goods of various kinds including aluminum ware, and pottery, to mention but a few, have been successfully established.

IN the fields of civil and of military aeronautics the year which draws to a close marked strides in technical development which have hardly been excelled in any year since the Wright brothers gave powered flight to man on the sands of Kitty Hawk more than three decades ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Mrs. ]Joseph Leiter gave a ball tonight at her home on Dupont Circle for her daughter, Nancy, who vas presented to society soon after the opening of the Washington season, after a preliminary dbut some months ago at Edgewater, Summer home of the Leiters at Beverly Parms, Mass.
Motor boating was in transition during 1935. It was a curious year, a year of contradictions and yet, withal, a phenomenal year.
TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 28. -- McIntyre-Porcupine Mines, Ltd., will proceed immediately to bring its Mud Lake property in Quebec to a producing basis, it is authoritatively reported.

SINCE Geraldine Farrar left the Metropolitan Opera, the company has been in constant search of a Carmen who would realize both on the possibilities of Bizet's imagining and on the large public in New York that the opera has drawn to itself. The Metropolitan seems now to be twice-blest -- there are, from all reports, two Carmens on hand to do justice to Bizet's masterpiece.

Miss Theresa Schey of New York City was the outstanding performer in the junior equestrian competition yesterday at the Riding Club, winning the equitation championship in a field of nine. This event concluded a program of eleven events judged during the afternoon and evening sessions.

LIGHTHOUSES and lightships -- the commas, periods and exclamation points of sea travel -- are undergoing remarkable changes at present. The nature of the change is indicated by the fact that while the number of major lights operated by the United States Lighthouse Service along our continental and insular shores was increasing from 2,436 to 2,678 between 1931 and 1935, the number of keepers decreased by 154.

Formation of the Eastern Rugby Union of the United States was the outstanding event of a year which saw rugby continue to grow in popular appeal. This organization, composed of most of the leading clubs and colleges in the East, plans to supervise the game much on the style of the parent body in England.

ATLANTA, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The Republican party was warned by Dr. Charles A. Beard today that in the event of a victory next year it would "find itself cabined, cribbed and confined by forces more powerful than its campaign speeches and promises."
SOME years ago, when Vsevolod Ivanov was asked to furnish one of those single-page autobiographies which are the fashion in Russia, he said among other things:

FAMOUS musicians will appear in an "Undignified Entertainment by Dignified Artists" at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 5. There will be an amateur hour for professionals only, a very little symphony orchestra and "a million dollars' worth of three pianists' fingers on one keyboard."

An unusual horse show season reached a colorful climax in the annual exhibition of the National Horse Show Association in Madison Square Garden. That event was one of the most successful in many years, not only in point of attendance and financial returns, but in the size and quality of the entry and the featured numbers that added variety and sparkle to the programs.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Autumn and early Winter weather has been most favorable for hunting, and the hunt clubs in this vicinity have taken full advantage of it.
