For the last two months the dates of the Warrenton, Piedmont, Orange County, Middleburg, Old Dominion and Cobbler Hunts have given lovers of sport the opportunity of going out every day and of choosing among several hunts.

Two of the veteran pier superintendents of the North River waterfront are retiring at the end of this year and will receive pensions from the International Mercantile Marine Company. They are Henry Willie of Pier 59 and John Nevins of Piers 61 and 62.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- The report in the foreign press of Anglo-German diplomatic exchanges and assertions that the Reich offered Britain a bilateral air pact drew more fire in German official quarters as well as in the Nazi party press, today.

NEW YEAR'S, in this latitude at least, is probably the moment when we have the purest, most typical Winter conditions. There is not a trace of Autumn left, not a hint of Spring in the air. The old country houses hunch themselves down into the drifts; the cities, for the moment, seem newly purified, even the slums made lovely by the first blanket of snow.

Blinding speed set the tempo for track and field in 1935 as Jesse Owens and Eulace Peacock, sprinters extraordinary, engaged in a series of magnificent duels on straightways and in jumping pits. After long years of dominance by the milers, track turned to the dash men for its most thrilling and startling performances.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- New York State's New Year celebration will be the biggest and happiest since the depression, on the basis of advance registration of merrymakers reported today by managers of leading hotels, clubs and restaurants in key cities.
The race for the men's national figure skating crown developed some keen competition at the Ice Club yesterday.

Miss Lucy Gilbert Hutchinson was presented to society last night at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, at the River Club. A holiday setting for the dance was created by an arrangement of cedar trees, poinsettias, silver heather, smilax, ferns and whitened evergreen branches.

PARIS. CABARETS and night clubs have superseded, in the social life of young Parisiennes, the more stilted home dinners and receptions that delighted our grandmothers. Now that the Paris season is in full swing, every evening Maxim's, the Cafe de Paris, Monte Cristo, the Boeuf sur le Toit, chez Florence or Casanova are filled with smart young couples dancing away the hours from 9 till daybreak.

Public interest in photography seems steadily on the increase. When the New York season is in progress, exhibitions abound. New textbooks on the myriad details of technical procedure appear at frequent intervals, and annually we have volumes composed of carefully selected examples of photography produced both in this country and abroad.

DUE to his strenuous activities on the radio and for the screen, Lowell Thomas is perhaps better known to most of us as a disseminator of news rather than as a writer on history and travel. In "The Untold Story of Exploration" he has succeeded in combining his talents for history and reporting in one volume.

ONE of the finest of small trees for use in the garden is the American Hornbeam or Ironwood. In small gardens where large trees would take up too much space Ironwoods are appropriate. They are not shrublike, but are real trees in form and seldom grow over 30 to 35 feet in height.

Consents having been received representing approximately two-thirds of the capital amount required, the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York announced yesterday that the reorganization of Series C-2 guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was assured.

THE WPA will open a factory in New York on Jan. 1 for the manufacture of "talking-book" machines for the blind. There 200 relief workers will assemble 5,000 specially devised portable phonographs which will be distributed without charge through the Library of Congress among the sightless, together with records embracing a wide variety of literary works.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Labor turnover, the status of the older worker in industry, housing and other important problems of wage earners will be subjects of special study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics during the coming year, according to the report of Isador Lubin, Commissioner, to Secretary Perkins.

TOPEKA, Dec. 27. -- Enthusiastic supporters of Governor Alf M. Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination are not discouraged over the big play Senator William E. Borah has been getting since the Idahoan agreed to allow his name to be used in the Wisconsin primaries.

Our good friends, who in this Yuletide are discouraged by war and rumors of war, should be stimulated by the evident fact that today there are more people anxious to be right, and do right, than ever before in the world's history.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- As a commentary on the plea of the Church Unity Octave Council of high-church Episcopalians for union with the Church of Rome, the Rev. Dr. Alexander Griswold Cummins, rector of Christ Church here and editor of the Protestant Episcopal publication, The Chronicle, made public today the text of a telegram he had received from the Very Rev. Charles E. McAllister, dean of St. John's Cathedral, Spokane, Wash.

"WORK with him was easy and efficient. There was little need to talk. Politically and historically he was so well trained that a word was enough. He thought out and executed plans in detail * * * he had great initiative and was an untiring worker."

SEA ISLAND, Ga. -- The coming of the New Year will be celebrated at the New Year's Eve supper dance to be held in the Cloister dining room, assembling guests and Sea Island residents. Favors and decorations will reflect the festive spirit, and supper will be served shortly before midnight.

During the last season field hockey activity indicated that the game is fast establishing its position as one of the country's leading sports for women. Besides a marked increase in school and college interest, many clubs joined the United States Field Hockey Association, bringing the total number of active clubs to over 100 and spreading membership over thirty-eight States.

In essaying a survey of the year's activities in fishing and hunting we are reminded of the two old fishing cronies who, meeting at a New Year's Eve party several seasons back, passed the hours exchanging reminiscences of the previous Summer's sport and, instead of emphasizing their respective successes, dwelt mainly on the big ones that got away.

WHAT with Mr. Wells deserting to the fleshpots of Hollywood and the Nailbiters' Club devoting itself to mysteries only, it seemed quite fitting and proper that a new writer of scientific romances should come on the scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The day the Supreme Court handed down the Schechter case decision the National Recovery Administration ceased to function. Control of wages, hours, prices and production by codes came to an end. When the Supreme Court hands down its decisions next month on the three cases testing the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, the control of farm production through some Federal device will continue regardless of what the decisions say.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- A "cheesy story" is the Soviet answer to Uruguay's rupture of relations.
GENEVA, Dec. 28. -- This year ends as did 1934 with renewed hope in the world for the League of Nations after twelve months of alternative hope and despair.

GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- No live student of social problems could have gone through the two months' session of the Hobart College Police School, which closed Dec. 3, without being stimulated by the enthusiasm of the officers in attendance and thrilled with the possibilities of police training.

A summons obtained by Dr. David M. Bosworth of 58 East Sixty-fifth Street for Benson B. Sloan, a broker living at 41 East Sixty-fifth Street, charging violation of the section of the Penal Code dealing with willful damage to an automobile, was dismissed in the Yorkville Court yesterday by Magistrate Renaud.

The Townsend plan was assailed yesterday afternoon as a "scheme of complete absurdity, cruelly mischievous, crassly unworkable and filled with possibilities of wreckage" by Dr. Stuart A. Rice, acting chairman of the Central Statistical Board, United States Bureau of the Census.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 28.--A huge Ethiopian army under Ras Mulugheta was reported engaged in fierce battle today with Italy's invaders in the North. The warriors were encountering strong opposition, and many had been slain on both sides, it was announced.

January is anticipated as a peak month for the New York League of the Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, which has set a record this season for impressive programs at its luncheons in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The next, scheduled for Jan. 13, will present a coterie of distinguished men and women from various countries in an international program.
On the last Sunday of the year, the 1935 appeal for the Neediest Cases of all New York reached a grand total of $233,339.66 today, after receipt of 117 contributions yesterday, totaling $1,566.79.

A new extraordinary term of Supreme Court and a new grand jury to continue the special investigation of racketeering, vice and possibly political corruption, directed by Thomas E. Dewey, was authorized yesterday by Governor Lehman.

TOPEKA, Kan. -- Political opinion in the Middle West is in a state of flux. It has not solidified definitely either for or against the New Deal. Everywhere are contradictions. On one matter sentiment is revealed as dominantly favorable to the New Deal; on another matter, it is equally dominantly opposed, even though the same people are involved.

Fear that opponents of the administration's reciprocal trade treaty program will succeed in manoeuvring a bill requiring Senate approval of trade treaties through the coming session of Congress prompted adherents of the reciprocal treaty program to call a meeting to be held here Friday to lay plans for circumventing such action.

A 51-year-old railroad conductor, J.B. Royall of Tallahassee, Fla., attended his first Grand American trapshoot competition this year, richest and most important of all trapshooting events, and walked off with the sport's highest honors, the Grand American Handicap.

DALLAS, Dec. 28. -- With the Christmas buying over, merchants throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District have found time to survey business during the last few weeks. In many respects the holiday buying has been the most satisfactory since 1929, and this includes dollar volume as well as number of sales made and quality of merchandise sold.

Unanimous endorsement of American participation in the Olympic Games and opposition to the recent action of the Southeastern Conference in the matter of subsidizing athletes were the high lights of the closing meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MISS LAWRENCE knows how to turn home economics into effective fiction. Her "Years Are So Long," published last year, was a thoughtful, sympathetic, and appallingly accurate study in the liabilities of old age. The present novel is less grim.

As the New Year swings westward next Wednesday morning it will mark the first decisive step in America's first nation-wide program of social security. The Federal unemployment insurance plan, going into operation at that time, is something new in our history.

A WEEK ago these pages carried a note by Mr. Morgan regarding the State Society's production of Elmer Rice's "Not for Children." From out Eighth Avenue way, where the author is now battling as the local head of the WPA theatre projects, comes word of what else happened that night after Mr. Morgan went to his office and started writing.

Outdoor skating races, dramatics and several acts of "a traveling circus" provided amusement and excitement yesterday as part of the Christmas week program conducted at the Roosevelt Park playground, along Forsythe and Chrystie Streets, by Park Department officials.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28. -- Few official reports on the extent of the gain in holiday trade are available, but it is indicated from scattered preliminary estimates that statements will be highly satisfactory. One important chain department store with coast-wide ramifications increased its common stock dividend 50 per cent, an action taken as an excellent indication of what final compilations will show.

BUFFALO, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Specific charges of alleged illegal voting and registration in Erie County's November election were made today in a letter sent by Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican County chairman, to District Attorney Newcomb, Governor Lehman and Attorney General Bennett.

HARRISON SMITH ROBERT HAAS announce a series of biographies of the leading figures in the Russian Revolution by William C. White, author of "These Russians" and "Made in Russia." The general title of the series will be "Makers of the Revolution."
Only two champions retained their crowns in cycling during the year 1935, which saw eight new titleholders arise in the ten standard divisions of the sport.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- Far-Eastern tension has been considerably heightened in recent weeks by a series of raids upon the eastern frontier of Outer Mongolia. The fact that the raids are inspired and conducted by Japanese officers combined with the other fact of a peculiarly close relationship between Outer Mongolia and the U.S.S.R. prompts the question whether Japan is not deliberately -- if indirectly -- seeking to provoke a conflict with Russia.

THE new White House kitchens, 1935 model, illustrate vividly the change that has come over the American scene since the early days of the Republic, when Presidential fare, like that of humbler citizens, was cooked on cranes and spits hanging over open fireplaces and Andrew Jackson kept a cow in a lean-to so that he could be assured of a steady supply of milk and butter.

An important realty deal involving a change in ownership and a new lease on a part of the property occupied by the Saks-Fifth Avenue store building in the Fifth Avenue blockfront between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets was reported yesterday.
A committee for creditors of the Lawyers Mortgage Company filed a plan of reorganization for the company with Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in the Supreme Court yesterday.

Adolescent boys are less anxious to travel than formerly, according to George Hallwachs, director of the Boys Bureau, 105 East Twenty-second Street. The bureau, a joint activity of the Charity Organization Society and the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, was established four years ago to give special aid to homeless, destitute adolescent boys.

Rudolph Potratz, 31 years old, of 140 East Eighty-third Street, and Johann Braeuter, 25, of 26 East Eighty-eighth Street, were held in bail of $250 each by Magistrate Renaud in Yorkville Court yesterday and a hearing on charges of petit larceny was adjourned to Tuesday.

Additional engagements of $1,946,000 gold abroad for import to this country were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank. Of this amount $1,000,000 was taken in England, $346,000 in Ecuador and $600,000 in India. These engagements brought the total taken since Sept. 9 to $838,700,000, of which $823,400,000 has been received.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the application of the Middle West Corporation to acquire the securities of the Middle West Service Company, which will thus be a wholly owned subsidiary formed to carry out management contracts with other subsidiaries in the former Insull group. The commission's action had been awaited with interest here in view of its potential importance in setting a precedent for future service companies.

The question which Zona Gale recently asked and attempted to answer in the Sunday TIMES, "When does propaganda (in the theatre) cease to be propaganda?" seems to me to be simply another variation on an ancient theme: Is a zebra black with white stripes, or white with black stripes?

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28. -- Staging one of the most courageous and spectacular stretch drives observed this season, the Odessa Farms' 2-year-old gelding Don Creole swept to a head victory in the featured Sarasota Purse before more than 10,000 spectators at Tropical Park today.

THE five stars overslept. So director, camera men, sound engineers and fellow-players waited patiently to go to work. On another occasion production was shut down to allow two of the stars to cut new teeth. And those were but two of the novel situations confronting Director Henry King when he and a company of thirty actors and technicians went "on location" at Callander, Ont., to film the cinema's latest stellar players, the Dionne Quintuplets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Nineteen thirty-five has been a boom year for the business of government. From the AAA to the WPA the record is one of unprecedented activity by the largest peacetime army of men and women on Federal payrolls.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt gave a barn dance at Oakland Farm last evening. Preceding the dance there were a number of dinner parties. Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt had guests at Oakland, Mr. and Mrs. Gurnee Dyer at Farmlands.

Returning to the heights she enjoyed during an uninterrupted reign of six years, until she allowed the title to go undefended in 1934, Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, who regained the women's national figure skating championship, produced one of the highlights of 1935 in this popular ice sport.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Continuing gayety initiated last with the round of Christmas entertaining are many events of this week, centering around New Year's festivities. Several clubs, unofficially available for several weeks, will make their formal debuts.

The nation was shocked and shamed last week by the departure for England of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who left their homeland because they feared that their second son, 3-year-old Jon, might be kidnapped, and because they wished to find for him and for themselves an opportunity to live a normal life.

Discussing the commercial and financial policy of Germany under the Hitler regime, Dr. Ernst Wagemann, president of the Institute for Business Research, Berlin, said last week that the fear of inflation in Germany was great and that the question of obtaining raw materials was one of the most serious problems in that country.

Dr. GOEBBELS, drill sergeant of German public opinion, has made the discovery that international scientific conventions are regularly attended by the leaders of German science. With a few exceptions these gatherings have been conducted with a laudable objectivity and solely for the advancement of science.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Advances made by proposals for unification of Protestant denominations were reported today to young people gathered here for the National Conference of Theological Students and the quadrennial convention of the Student Volunteer Movement.

PARTICULARLY in its final quarter -- the months elapsing since local activity was resumed at the end of the Summer -- 193 has witnessed a noticeable improvement on the material side in the art field. For one thing, more new galleries have opened than in any previous period since the economic lepression began.

BEARDED and fur-clad primitives, staring southward across the icy fens and forests where the pines bent under the burden of snow, thousands of years before calendars were invented, recognized at last a day when the curved trail of the sun reached its lowest point in the horizon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- To provide technical instruction for Uncle Sam's future housing managers, the National Association of Housing Officials, with the cooperation of the Public Works and the Rural Resettlement Administrations, has opened a new "school" in Washington.

A NUMBER of foreign critics who visited London recently at the invitation of the Foreign Relations Council were given opportunities to hear our three orchestras and some of our best choirs. No special program had been arranged, however, and of the three novelties offered to Londoners recently they heard but one -- the new symphony of Arnold Bax.

FOR years past it has been usual on New Year's Eve for the British Broadcasting Corporation to broadcast a retrospect of the previous twelve months. On Dec. 31, however, a new experiment will be attempted with a program entitled "Chimes at Midnight."

The chess world saw the end of an eight-year reign shortly before the year's activities in the game came to a close. In a match lasting more than two months Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris relinquished his title to Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam.
The Emergency Relief Bureau will drop 2,000 of its staff employes next month, it was announced yesterday at the offices of Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the bureau.

The fifteenth annual meeting of the American Football Coaches Association closed at the Pennsylvania Hotel last night with the annual dinner following a full day of committee reports and technical discussions.

Prodded by the necessity of cutting production costs to take care of new taxes and still maintain old price levels, manufacturers will spend in 1936 25 to 30 per cent more than originally planned for plant rehabilitation, executives in durable goods lines said yesterday.

THIS is a competent, painstaking and fair biography of the most abused man in American public life. Roger Taney was in many respects a great man, but in the two major acts of his career, the destruction of the United States Bank and the decision in the Dred Scott case, he fell far short of attaining sound statesmanship.

The cross-country pendulum continued to swing toward the Midwest this year, as that section gained domination of the sport for the third straight season. Led by J. Edward Bechtold, its captain, Michigan State romped off with the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championship for the third time.

With the police preparing to handle the largest New Year's Eve crowds in recent history, it became apparent last night that New Yorkers would pay their farewell respects to a year that has been kinder to most of them than many of its predecessors by rushing it out the back door with a lustier shove than the city has accorded any other post-prosperity year.

ON Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, Sir Thomas Beecham will begin his third visit to this country. As guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra he will lead a series of eleven concerts within three weeks.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Political passions run so high in France now that even the dead are not exempt from insult. On Christmas Eve in the quiet village of Pacy-sur-Eure an attempt was made by some young partisans with ghoulish instincts to saw through the bronze feet of the statue of Aristide Briand and throw it off its pedestal.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM will begin a three weeks' guest engagement as conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony Thursday evening. The first half of his opening program will consist of the American premiere of the dance from Delius's "Koanga," the first New York performances of the overture to Ethel Smyth's opera.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 28. -- Statements that President Wilson was "eager for war" with Germany in 1916, was urged to such a course by Secretary Lansing and was deterred by opposition of three members of Congress, were made today at the convention of the American Historical Association.

When the American Kennel Club, in celebration of its fiftieth anniversary, established a large fund for the payment of valuable cash prizes for winning American-bred dogs at member shows it did more to encourage the breeding industry in this country than any single step in the history of the governing body.

Pastors will preach today on lessons to be drawn from the old year and will give their advice for the new year. In virtually every church the special programs of Christmas music will be repeated. In many edifices there will be in the afternoon or evening a pageant, candlelight service, a cantata or Christmas oratorio.
SIR PHILIP SIDNEY, one of the perennially alluring figures of the Elizabethan era, has always been regarded primarily as a man of action rather than as an accomplished litterateur.

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 28. -- Two Maine fishermen, adrift in a disabled motor boat in bitter Winter weather since Christmas morning, were rescued tonight, alive and well, through the efforts of Coast Guard fliers from the Winter Island station here.

THE public symphonic season of the "E.I.A.R." (Italian Broadcasting Corporation), held every Winter before a packed house in the Teatro di Torino under conductors of repute -- Turin's major concert attraction, shared by European radio listeners -- was inaugurated some days ago with a Respighi program, under the composer's direction.

HERBERT READ secured a wide circle of readers in this country with his previous volume, "Art Now," published in 1934. The new work undertakes to explain how the same principles operative in the realm of modern painting apply in the creation of objects designed for everyday use.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- Nikolai Lenin's famous saying exactly fifteen years ago that "electrification in Russia plus Soviet power equals communism," was the text of a speech by G.K. Ordjonikidze, Commissar for Heavy Industry, at a recent session of the Central Committee of the Communist party.
The ten Neediest Cases published on these pages are typical tragedies of distress selected from many cases which still await relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A movement to establish a new system of safety signals and barricades at all approaches to drawbridges and railroad crossings and to require interstate motor carriers to follow schedules which will permit sufficient rest periods between trips for drivers was started today by Senator Lonergan of Connecticut.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28. -- Herbert Hoover recalled tonight his boyhood days in a short address, "because if I speak longer I might refer to some things going on in the country today and that might darken a happy holiday."

New Year's day will be marked at the American Woman's Association clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street by the opening of an exhibit of American Provincial paintings. The canvases shown, which will be hung in the club art gallery through January, are a loan from the Whitney Museum of American Art, where they form part of the permanent collection.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- Former Governor Pinchot's attack upon the administration of work relief in Pennsylvania, contained in his letter to President Roosevelt several days ago, followed public disclosure of an undercover feud over relief problems within the Earle administration.

The United States Building and Loan League, a national organization for 11,000 institutions, has announced that dividends totaling $130,000,000 will be paid to members of savings and loan associations for the second half of 1935, the distribution to be completed by Dec. 31.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Besides the unusually extensive golf program, New Year's week in Pinehurst will see a number of activities, mostly informal, in other fields. One formal affair, the New Year's Eve ball at the Carolina, will bring together not only the guests staying at all the Pinehurst hotels for the holidays but the entire cottage colony and house guests.

Delegates from all over the United States are expected to attend the tenth annual convention of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, which will open Jan. 11 in Washington. There are more than 5,000 women in the various chapters, participating in the work of the group, which is an integral part of the orthodox faction of the Zionist movement.

Two of the season's best-played indoor polo matches at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn resulted in victories last night for Winston Guest's Optimists and the Squadron C entry in the annual Metropolitan League competition.

Evidence of the widening of the breach between President Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, two old-time friends and political associates, was furnished yesterday by disclosure that Mr. Smith will decline an invitation to be an overnight guest at the White House when he goes to Washington to speak at a dinner of the American Liberty League Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The Bituminous Coal Commission directed producers today to fix minimum sales prices as speedily as possible, without regard to court tests of the Guffey act's constitutionality.

With New York schools on the short end of the count in two of the three contests, scholastic basketball made its debut in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon before 4,000 fans. The triple-header opened an eleven-game school program, the first of its kind ever to be arranged for the Eighth Avenue arena.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 27. -- As the old year dies Tuesday night 8,500 employes of the State of Kentucky will end their official life, dropped from the payroll by Governor A.B. Chandler since he assumed office Dec. 10, and the places of many of them will never he filled.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Virtually on the eve of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's arrival in England to escape prying publicity in the United States the entire British press was busily arranging today to report his landing, discover his hiding place and, if possible, to photograph members of his family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Laughter and shouts of happy children swept away White House formality today at the annual party for friends of the Roosevelt grandchildren. From the President and Mrs. Roosevelt to cooks and coat-checkers, the Executive Mansion's staff put forth every effort for the young guests.

For the first time in fully five years, coat and suit manufacturers will probably be required to increase prices on reorder numbers, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

OCEAN BAY PARK, L.I., Dec. 28. -- Coast Guardsmen from Point of Woods station here fought fire and ice for eight hours last night and early this morning to save the life of George Michellett, a shell-shocked World War veteran known to Summer residents here as "The Hermit of Fire Island."
Leap year will return at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday and persons born on Feb. 29 will be on the threshold of an actual birthday.

With continued cold weather and probably snow predicted for today and tomorrow, little hope was entertained for a return to normal temperatures before the new year appears on the calendar. Although early reports yesterday from the Weather Bureau indicated that the cold wave was about to abate, the temperatures began dropping instead until 13 degrees, the low for the Winter, was reached.

OMAHA, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, predicted in an interview today that a group of veteran Democratic Senators would lead a fight "to curtail excessive expenditures of the Federal Government at the forthcoming session of Congress."

That New York University winning streak was stretched to the breaking point last night but it did not snap. In a spectacular, up-hill battle that left a crowd of 18,000 limp with excitement, the Violet staged a magnificent rally in the second half to turn back Purdue, 43 to 41, at Madison Square Garden.

THE automobile industry is writing across the face of its New Year's greetings to the nation the promise of unbroken production and the continued distribution of generous payrolls to its thousands of workers in Detroit as well as elsewhere.

THOUSANDS of Americans are off again for the Winter or a long holiday in Nassau or Bermuda. A fortunate few are departing for their own houses or even for islands of their own in these once distant British colonies, today near and familiar American playgrounds.

VIENNA, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Reports circulated in diplomatic quarters today that the Balkan Entente (Greece, Rumania, Turkey and Yugoslavia) had expressed concern over a possible restoration of the Hapsburg monarchy. The fear of these nations, it was declared, was expressed by Tewfik Rushdu Aras, Turkish Foreign Minister, who stopped off in Vienna for a long conference with the Austrian Foreign Minister, Baron Egon Berger-Waldenegg.

THE likes and dislikes of the radio audience seem to shift with the years, for the surveys at this year-end reveal that the popularity line-up of performers has been altered considerably within twelve months.

LONDON, Dec. 6. THE outstanding event of the present season is without question the vast commercial success of "Romeo and Juliet." The New Theatre is a big place and it is packed for eight performances a week.

More than 100,000 persons have visited the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, to see the exhibition of paintings and drawings by Vincent van Gogh, since it was opened Nov. 5. The show will continue through Jan. 5.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 29 (AP). -- A Manchukuoan army thrust forward today into Chahar Province of Northern China, according to a Chinese report. Escorted by Japanese airplanes roaring overhead, the army was reported to be attempting to sever an area as large as the State of Maine from control of the Chinese Government.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Dec. 29. -- The widely publicized possibility of an early and amicable settlement of all critical Chino-Japanese problems is deemed not only unlikely but actually impossible by the Japanese Government, it was disclosed last evening by one of the most authoritative and best informed Japanese officials assigned to China.

Sir Thomas Beecham, English composer, conductor and impresario of Covent Garden Opera House, arrived last night from London on the New York of the Hamburg-American Line. This is his third visit to this country. He will conduct eleven concerts with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in three weeks, his first appearance being on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall.
To the marksmen of America, probably the most interesting development in a year of exciting competition was the resumption of the national rifle and pistol matches.

THIS riches-to-rags and back-to-riches story is cast in an antiquated mold. It is neither important nor significant, but embodies the ingratiating qualities of quaint sweetness, sincerity and lack of pretension.

The Reliable Stores Corporation has declared a dividend of $10.50 a share on the first preferred stock. This includes the regular semi-annual dividend of $3.50 a share for the six months ended Dec. 31, 1935, and $7 a share in full payment of all accumulated dividends to July 31, 1935.
Ernie Riedel of New York came back into the national canoeing championship picture during 1935 by winning the national one-man double-paddle title.
OMAHA, Dec. 27. -- The Corn Belt States have prepared to take over the relief of unemployables and those who have failed to find jobs with WPA or PWA, but with misgivings.
GLANCING over the current hockey standings one is struck rather forcibly with something that may mean nothing yet portend a great deal.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and Joseph C. Rovensky, vice president of the Chase National Bank, will sail for Europe on the Majestic on Jan. 22 to represent American banks in the sixth annual "standstill" conference among creditor banks of eight nations and German debtor banks, which will open in Berlin on Feb. 3.

IN the waning hours of 1935 it is perhaps not without interest to indulge the seasonal urge and glance back over the record in search of tendencies and trends. Occasional failures and disappointments nothwithstanding, the year has been a full one, teeming with promise for the future. A few specific items will serve to reveal the directions and the extent of its accomplishment.

AS these columns were moving toward the press, show business had just acquired a new producer. The name is James Donahue, young scion of the Woolworth family, who, it will be remembered, had one previous but fleeting experience with the stage.

THE British celebrations of the Mark Twain centenary have naturally been on a smaller scale than the American, but the occasion has by no means been overlooked. Every important newspaper has published an editorial and a special article on Mark Twain's life and work, and several Englishmen who had the good luck to meet him have contributed anecdotal reminiscences.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- A gay round of New Year's parties and dances will inaugurate the Winter social season here. The biggest event of the holiday week will be the Dragon Club invitation dance on New Year's Eve at the Vinoy Park Hotel.

Reports submitted by sixty-one cities in twenty-three States, all with a population of 50,000 or more, showed that in the first ten months of 1935 fifty-five cities in the United States collected a larger percentage of their current taxes than during the corresponding period of 1934, according to a nation-wide survey just completed by Frank H. Morse of Lehman Brothers.

MR. GROSS does not mean by the "gold" in his title merely the precious metal or the wealth it symbolizes, but uses the word to include all the values that man prizes, both material and spiritual. Similarly by "backyard" he means both the environment of the individual and the general American scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Recent manoeuvres of the army's general headquarters air force in Florida demonstrated that this spearhead of the new national defense plan is seriously handicapped more by lack of ground facilities than by its inadequate airplanes, the War Department said in a statement today.

THE resumption of the Congressional deliberations next Friday calls attention once more to that ever-changing group of individualists who make up the inner council of advisers to the President. As the session progresses, more of their brain children will be born and quietly deposited on the steps of the Capitol, in the hope that a kindly Legislature will receive them into its home and give them a good name:

Debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in the sale of tickets for the premiere showing of "Rose of the Rancho," with Gladys Swarthout in the leading role, which will take place the night of Jan. 7 at the Paramount Theatre for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Fund.

BOMBAY. -- The Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court has decided against the Ford Motor Company of India, Ltd., in an appeal brought by the company against a lower court decision on the manner of assessing customs duty on Ford cars imported into India.

Aided by favorable snow conditions, skiing enjoyed the best year of its history in the United States during the 1934-35 season. This was particularly true in the East, where an unusually long Winter permitted the extensive program arranged by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association to be carried out in full.

Lacrosse continued its slow but steady progress during the year, despite the fact that the sport was dropped from the Olympic program as a demonstration event. The East still is the stronghold, with the game established on a firm basis in more than thirty colleges.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Townsend National Weekly, official organ of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., listed today thirty-nine members of the House who are said to have promised, in answering a questionnaire, to vote for the $200 a month old-age pension plan at the coming session.

A.L. Burns and T.H. Lewis each finished with 95 out of a possible 100 targets in the contest for the scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the shoot-off Burns added another triumph to his season's performances by breaking 24 out of 25.

Attainment of his goal -- five miles a minute on land -- by Sir Malcolm Campbell of Great Britain was the principal achievement in automobile racing during 1935. Twice within seven months Sir Malcolm shattered the world's automobile speed record over a measured mile, but it was only the second of these feats that quenched the Briton's desire for records.

Mayor La Guardia's war against the "small artichoke" racket ended in victory yesterday when the five companies which import the commodity from California signed an agreement in his office at City Hall pledging themselves to sell directly to retailers and market dealers.

Mayor La Guardia's war against unnecessary noise now goes into its fifth month, having achieved what military strategists would call "preliminary advances" preparatory to a general, smashing attack. Reports from City Hall, headquarters for the campaign, indicate that a major offensive will be launched on the heels of the usual New Year's Eve revelries.
MANILA, Dec. 28. -- The dual issue involved in the Philippines' chrome shipments to Italy is being pushed toward a decision by both civilian and official sources here.

PROBABLY the anonymous master-builders who raised these six mansions in pre-Revolutionary days before the Colonies could boast of a single professional architect had little idea that their work would today be dedicated as monuments to America's history.

The war against diphtheria will be carried on in the future more successfully than ever before as the result of the isolation of the poison which causes the disease in the purest and most potent state ever achieved, it was announced yesterday at the closing session of the annual congress of the Society of American Bacteriologists, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

IT is the unique quality of the city of Boston that it has defied its legend without deserving it. Three-fourths of the citizens who make their way along Tremont Street are of foreign stock, and the voices are mostly Irish that echo in the corridors of the City Hall; yet Boston's tradition of Anglo-Saxon Puritanism survives, and many of the names that signed the Cambridge agreement in 1629 are important in Boston still.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The new year in Nassau will be ushered in with the "John Canoe" parade, when all street regulations are waived and the population is permitted to indulge in a wild exhibition of joy. Folk in fantastic costumes throng the streets, blowing horns, ringing bells, setting off firecrackers, beating tom-toms and singing.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 28. -- Uniform standards of education as set up in the old days deprived a majority of pupils of liberty and the pursuit of happiness in later life and served to contribute to a wave of juvenile crime, Dr. Max McConn, dean of Lehigh University, told the Associated Academic Principals of New York today at their final session.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 28. -- A ship bearing the Charles A. Lindberghs away from their native America approached the British Isles today and an airplane waited under sealed orders near here.

To introduce to society her daughter, Miss Yvonne Johnstone, Mrs. James T. Johnstone gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre. The d6butante and her mother received in the foyer of the ballroom, which was decorated with palms and silvered smilax.

The heavyweight wrestling situation was considerably cleared up in 1935, with the advent of Dan O'Mahoney of the Irish Free State. The young Irish grappler, who arrived in this country in December, 1934, after having purchased his release from the Free State Army, went into action almost immediately on his arrival and performed with success so consistent as to earn for him the world championship.

Mayor La Guardia's ban on the sale of small artichokes, in an effort to end racketeering in the product, has focused attention on a delicacy little known to the public at large, but consumed in large quantities by Italians in New York City.

College rowing had for its climax during the year one of the most hotly contested Poughkeepsie varsity races in the history of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. California's remarkable crew coming East to defend its championship, just managed to retain the laurels after a bitter struggle.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A blast believed by officials to have originated in a broken gas line, early today ripped from its foundation a three-story brick office and laboratory of the American Rolling Mill Company, badly damaged an adjoining structure, splintered windows nearly a mile away and caused a loss estimated by Charles R. Hook, president, at $75,000.

BOSTON, Dec 27. -- Townsend plan converts are multiplying more rapidly in Massachusetts than in any other State. In the five days ending Dec. 13 the certified gains were 2,535, bringing the total membership close to 30,000.

Twenty-four hours after Santa Claus paid his proverbial annual visit, the stork called at the Bronx Zoo and left an unusual baby, a solenodon. It should be explained at once that the solenodon is a small fur-bearing mammal related to the shrew.

ROME, Dec. 27. -- Now that the Christmas holidays are over the thoughts of all Italians after a brief interlude of carefree revelry have again come to grips with the stern realities of the international situation. The picture that unfolds before them is not very bright.

BEFORE 1926 I was a painter. I had not yet achieved any great mastery, but I was profoundly persuaded that within ten or twelve years, about the year 1938 or 1940, I should have succeeded in becoming a master. That was at Kharkov.

Within the past few months the bankers of the country have been agitated by a problem which, although highly technical in character, is so deeply "affected" with public interest as to have engaged widespread attention. The problem is what to do about the mounting total of excess bank reserves and the possibility of a credit inflation which they entail.

Fire, which police believe was started by children playing with matches, drove nineteen families out of an apartment house at 2,143 Eighty-second Street, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock last night.

THREE hundred years ago this October the first German expedition went to Persia. An amazing, fantastic undertaking for that time. Vast sums were expended on luxurious equipment for the journey to an entirely unknown country. The purpose of the expedition was to bring Indian products to Germany via Persia.

THE history of the cinema year which is just fading into limbo was distinguished by no such sensation as the decency crusade of 1934. It was a well-behaved twelve-month and Hollywood cautiously pulled its ears in. Double bills became the order of the day and there was polite argument over the relative merits of one good film as against two mediocre ones.

ATHENS, Dec. 28. -- One hundred and thirty anti-monarchists, released from concentration camps by King George's amnesty decree, today visited the palace to present a petition on behalf of about 200 hunger-striking anti-monarchists still detained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota predicted today that a "rising swell" of sentiment in Congress for strict neutrality soon would force the administration to embargo oil shipments to the African war zone.

FOR the last eight years the axe has been poised above the Adelphi, that fine old terrace of houses overlooking the Thames. Built by the Adam brothers in the eighteenth century, it is today the most eighteenth-century thing left in London.

A gift of $10,000 from the Friedsam Foundation and two individual gifts, each for $2,000, from William Nelson Cromwell and Josephine Clews Wrightson, to the United Hospital Campaign were announced yesterday by the campaign committee in its latest listing of contributors to the fund.

In one of the speediest and best-played matches seen on a New York court this season, Germain G. Glidden, Harvard University senior, yesterday defeated his Harvard classmate, Richard W. Gilder, to win the University Club's first invitation squash racquets tournament.

Bonds moved irregularly lower yesterday in the largest turnover for a two-hour session since Nov. 23. While no severe pressure developed in any one section, a scarcity of near-by bids caused prices, with a few notable exceptions, to drift toward moderately lower levels.

MONTREAL, -- Dates for some of the principal Winter sports and other attractions in Montreal and district have now been fixed. The annual Fete de Nuit is set for Feb. 8. It takes place in the western slope of Mount Royal, near the toboggan slide, and is featured by an immense bonfire and a display of fireworks.

HOLLYWOOD. THE controversy between the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the two guilds -- Screen Writers and Screen Actors -- will come to a climax in February with the annual academy awards for outstanding pictures, direction, performances and writing, it was indicated this week by charges and threats from the two factions.
SOME notable speed and distance flights marked the year 1935. On Jan. 11-12 Amelia Earhart flew solo in her Wasp-powered Lockheed Vega from Honolulu to Oakland, Calif., in 18 hours 16 minutes.

A display of military colors and a diversified program of entertainment will mark the Military and Naval Ball to be held on Jan. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York is to benefit from the event, which is being sponsored by many men and women of distinction in society, military, diplomatic and political circles.

WITH record-breaking snow mantling the Sierra Nevada Mountains between Mount Lassen and Yosemite National Parks, skiers and Winters sports enthusiasts from California and Nevada have already begun their trips to this Winter playground.

HAVANA, Cuba. -- The Cuban Government and resort centers are making every effort to revive the tourist trade, and Cuba is looking forward to what, it is believed, will be the best Winter season in years. Numerous events of interest to tourists have been scheduled.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Harry Cooper, Chicago professional, shattered par by five strokes, equaled the course record and took a commanding lead in the first round of the $4,000 Pasadena open golf tournament today.

In Greece a decree was issued a little time before Christmas by the new Minister of Agriculture making any one found in possession of a Christmas tree "liable to prosecution." The reason was not one of hostility to the religious observance of the Christmas season.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japan's "holy man of the machine age," came here today with praise for President Roosevelt, a challenge to American youth to spread the Christian gospel and a plea for cooperative farming as a solution for agricutural ills.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- To the accompaniment of shrilling harbor whistles the Eastern Steamship Lines steamer Belfast arrived here this morning ending a service of many years to Maine ports along Penebscot Bay and River to Bangor.

From the threshold of 1936, even a brief look backward at what transpired during the last twelve months discloses that, from several perspectives, 1935 was of more than average importance to the far-flung organizations of women in this country.

One of the first and most important duties of the Fusion-controlled Board of Education and a function which will serve to test the judgment of Mayor La Guardia's appointees, all avowed advocates of the merit system, will be the action in approving or rejecting appointments to seventeen vacancies in the administrative and supervisory staff of the schools.
CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Nineteen months old today, the Dionne quintuplets faced the new year with "a healthy and happy 1936," meaning more than just the season's wish.

Numerically, the year 1935 stood out as the greatest one in the history in American yachting. All records were broken in the size of the fleets that participated in the sailing races, and there were more contests than ever before.

As the fields in both divisions of the junior and boys' national indoor tennis championships narrowed down to the quarter finals at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday all of the favorites, save one, accomplished what was expected of them as the competition passed the half-way mark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The State Department, with the approval of President Roosevelt, has called on the army for engineering and architectural assistance in the maintenance of its diplomatic and consular properties abroad.

MABEL LEIGH HUNT, whose "Lucinda, a Little Girl of Long Ago" was one of last year's most delightful children's books, has written a second story with authentic American background, genuine understanding of children and likable, convincing characters.

DUBLIN, Dec. 7. ELMER RICE'S "Not for Children" was given a production here this week by the Gate Theatre. The organization maintained just that pace so essential in a play of ideas of this kind to preserve its verve and brilliance. Added to good production the casting was admirable.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28. -- Governor Landon took under consideration today an invitation to speak in New York City.

MUNSEY is most famous as the man who butchered newspapers to make Munsey mastheads. But he also had that string of magazines, a collection of banks, a hotel, an umbrella factory and a chain of New England grocery stores.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The whereabouts of Leopold III, King of the Belgians, became a first-class political mystery today following his unexpected arrival at Dover yesterday on a so-called "private visit" to England.

Soccer was distinctly on the upgrade during the past year and has made a wholly satisfying start on the new season. Much of the credit was due to the visit of the picked team from the Scottish Football Association.

On a snow-swept Detroit gridiron the championship of the National Football League passed from the hands of the New York Giants to the Detroit Lions for the standout development of the year in professional football. Once again the sport showed an advance in general interest and spectator appeal and the campaign was one of the best and most progressive in its history.

George F. Warren, Professor of Agricultural Economics at Cornell University, author of the New Deal gold purchasing plan and one of President Roosevelt's former monetary advisers, attacked last night the underlying economic principles of the government AAA program at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, former Assistant Secretary of Labor, and now a member of the Social Security Board headed by John J. Winant, said tonight that the reason no provision for health insurance was included in the Social Security Act was because the technical committee, of which he was chairman, had reached no conclusion on which to base recommendations to Congress on the subject.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The overwhelming question in Europe still is whether it will be possible to maintain peace and thus preserve what is left of European civilization and to this question the year 1935 has supplied no conclusive answer.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- Creation of the Soldiers League under command of General Werner von Fritsch, commander-in-chief of the army, is rated as a decisive victory for the military organization in the stubbornly fought battle for the leadership of ex-soldiers.

The methods and figures used by the American Appraisal Company in estimating the value of the Ambassador Hotels here and in Atlantic City in 1927 were "clear and accurate," and reports criticizing these appraisals have been misleading, according to Lyle H. Olson, vice president of the company.

European diplomacy is showing signs of unwonted activity again. One might have supposed that its recent blunders and defeats would have kept it quiescent for a time. But as it has been said that the cure for the evils of democracy is more democracy, so the diplomats have apparently decided that a sick diplomacy must be ordered to quit its bed and go vigorously to work again.

HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 28.--Lava flowed from Mauna Loa volcano at a sharply reduced pace tonight following yesterday's aerial bombing of the molten stream in an attempt to divert it from Hilo's water reservoirs. Experts were unprepared to say whether the bombing was responsible.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The thousands of Scotchmen -- and others -- accustomed to assemble before the steps of St. Paul's Cathedral to "see the New Year in" this year will be encouraged to participate in organized community singing.

Price advances, ranging from minor rises to sharp increases, will be made on the important lines of textiles which will be opened next month for Fall, 1936, according to predictions yesterday in the primary market. The three major ranges of heavy goods include blankets, outing flannels and cotton and woolen underwear.

CITY planners have finally doomed the Trocadero, that great structure built for the Exposition of 1878 by the architects Davioud and Bourdals. It has disappeared to make room for a new building around which the next great Parisian exposition, that of 1937, will take place.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Death revealed tonight the blighted romance of a Boston girl who spent her life virtually entombed in a seventeen-room house because of sacred Victorian traditions.

CHICAGO.--A detailed plan for the licensing of bankers, under which those qualified would receive certificates as certified public bankers from Federal or State government, is proposed by Professor S.P. Meech of the School of Business of the University of Chicago and R.O. Byerrum, vice president of the University State Bank of Chicago, in an article in the university's Journal of Business.

Largely because of his flashing victory in the Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, N.Y., on Aug. 14, the gray gelding Greyhound, 2:00, closed the light harness racing season as the leading money-winning trotter of the year with a total of $26,731.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The United States has refused a request of the Austrian Government for postponement of payment of its annuity of $495,000, due Jan. 1, on account of the relief credit loan of $24,000,000 extended by this government on Sept. 4, 1920.

THE icy winds that blow about our 40 degrees north latitude are too much for some people, who feel they must leave after the first of the year for climates where the sun is warm. It is for them that shop windows have been filled with those bathing suits and cruise clothes that look so chilly to the pedestrian caught in swirls of snow.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27. -- The main provisions of the new Canadian-American trade treaty will go into effect next Wednesday. Meanwhile, Canadian industry has been taking full advantage of the fact that under the agreement Canada has retained her right to raise her intermediate tariff on all except eighty-eight items specifically enumerated.

FOR many years T.S. Stribling has concentrated on those sore spots of the South which he knows thoroughly, and he has written novels about them that are like social histories. He has shown high ability to dig toward tragic truths and to place his findings in fiction that is readable and enlivened by a gift for irony.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Sugar consumption requirements for the continental United States for 1936 were estimated at 6,434,088 short tons today by Secretary Wallace, with import quotas set at 4,624,088 short tons. Basic quotas for domestic production under the Jones-Costigan Act are fixed at 1,550,000 short tons of beet and 260,000 tons of cane.

RADIO, in all its branches from high-speed international communication to home-broadcasting, from trans-oceanic picturegrams to ultra-short-wave television, made remarkable advances in 1935, abetted by the application of engineering refinements evolved during the depression years.

LOVE being the interesting subject it is, Allene Corliss has generously packed half a dozen romances -- all interestingly bent, broken or slightly chipped -- into her latest novel. Primarily, it is the love story of Vicky Kent, a wholesome, confident, attractive girl of 19, who came down from Vermont to spend the Winter with her married sister in Westport, Conn.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 28. -- At least two of the mysterious fadeouts noticed in short-wave radio transmission by scientists at the National Bureau of Standards in recent months occurred at the same time as sudden eruptions of hydrogen on the sun, it was reported this afternoon at the session of the American Astronomical Society at Princeton University.

A group of up-State Republican Assemblymen took steps yesterday to meet the threat of Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County chairman, to try to block the Assembly slate favored by State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton by sending a telegram to all Republican Assemblymen and Assemblymen-elect urging the election of Irving M. Ives as Speaker and advocating the leaving of Assembly appointments entirely to him.

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES a while ago that John Studebaker wished to establish twenty adult forums in this country at a cost of over a million dollars. It seems to me that if the Federal Government considered spending that sum on only twenty adult forums it could consider spending perhaps $250,000 to establish more than one thousand youth forums.

HARAR, Ethiopia, Nov. 28 (By Air Mail). -- General Wehib Pasha, late defender of the Dardanelles, now divides his time between the best cooking in Ethiopia, as furnished by Ras Nasibu's chef and the worst, which is struck off al fresco by the Somalis guarding the acrid brush before Daggah Bur.

ITALIAN CASUALTY: The Official Spokesman was banished last week by the Italian Ministry of Press and Propaganda. In the past newspaper correspondents have credited information received from the ministry to the Official Spokesman. In the future they will have to use Authoritative Sources or some similar phrase; apparently the reason for the new rule was that Official Spokesman sounded too official.

ON BOARD MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 28. -- Hurrying to the relief of Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon, who were last heard from when on a flight to the Ross Sea over Antarctica on Nov. 23, the Wyatt Earp has reached within sixty miles of Charcot Island.
SYDNEY. -- Water has been uses as currency during the recent drought in the goldfields at Tennant's Creek, Central Australia.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 27. -- First of the potential Presidential candidates to bid publicly for Wisconsin's delegation to the Republican National Convention, Senator William E. Borah of Idaho has a head start. While Republicans are not rushing to his colors, there is genuine interest in him and the early reaction to his candidacy would be considerable favorable.

In Venezuela, where death vacated the post of dictator, there is political confusion. Henchmen of the late ruler, President Juan Vicente Gomez, are already being shot. The army is threatening mutiny. There is rioting in the streets of Valentia, Merida, Cumana, and Caracas.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, sailed yesterday with Mrs. Davison on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, on their way to India for both a vacation trip and a search for specimens for the museum.

GENEVA, Dec. 28. -- Striking contrast between American and British handling of their investments in long-term foreign bonds is drawn in the League of Nations year book on balances of payments in 1934, which has just come out.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- A complete reorganization of the Socialist party in New York State was being mapped here tonight as delegates from twenty-seven cities rallied around Norman Thomas.

WHEN conservationists meet in Washington, D.C., in February at the call of the President to consider more effective means of preserving the nation's wild life, no group will be more eager to cooperate than the Boy Scouts of America.

The Squadron A polo team defeated the Fort Hamilton riders in a Metropolitan Indoor League contest at the Squadron A Armory last night, 15 1/2 to 6 1/2. In an exhibition Boulder Brook halted a Squadron C outfit by 13 -- 8.

VOLLARD, in one of his volumes of reminiscence, mentions Degas's having confessed that "if he had let himself follow his own taste in the matter he would never have done anything but black and white."

A NEW ALTAR: Ten years ago the parish priest of Royal Oak, Detroit suburb, found himself and his work at a crisis. His flock numbered about 200 persons; he had difficulty raising funds to pay for his little wooden church.

The cricket season was enlivened by a visit of a team representing the Bermuda Athletic Association, which toured Eastern Canada, New York and Providence, playing nineteen games, of which the tourists won eleven, lost four and drew four. Their captain, W.F. Hayward, headed both the batting and bowling averages and scored a century in the match at Huntington against the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 28. -- Reuben Fine of New York, representing the United States in the international chess masters tournament under the auspices of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, registered his second straight victory today and held first place in the field of ten players.
COMMENTING on the new art consciousness of America, Felix Payant, editor of Design, writes in the current number of that publication:

Cardinal Hayes and former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Mrs. Smith were guests of honor yesterday at a program of plays presented by the children of the New York Foundling Hospital at 175 East Sixty-eighth Street. Following the plays, Cardinal Hayes and Mr. Smith attended a Christmas party at the hospital and presented toys to the 300 children.
THE need for greater protection for the motorist at grade crossings and for the eventual elimination of all such crossings has been emphasized by recent motor bus fatalities.
The roof garden of the Pierre was the scene last night of the coming-out party of Miss Margaret Flook, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Flook, gave a dinner-dance for her there.

Faced with the necessity of setting up a reserve of millions of dollars against unrealized profts on securities, executives of several investment companies are discussing plans for applying for a change in the Federal income tax which will grant their companies partial or total exemption from the tax on capital gains.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Men's dress is to be gayer!

Having been connected with the Department of Commerce for less than a year, but having been in active business for almost thirty years, I hope that I may express my views, not so much as a government official but as a business man intensely interested in the many problems of industry which have confronted us during these most difficult times.

With the ascendancy of Anthony Eden in Britain's affairs foreign foreshadowing the end of the policy of conciliation and firmer measures toward Italy, there again rises the possibility of a clash between the two countries and speculation is renewed as to the form such a conflict would take.

THERE are not enough good prospective husbands in America to go around. Other nations have long faced a like situation. It is not new in the United States, but here it has remained obscured because of an impression that the unbalance existing in pioneer times more or less persists.

NONE of us who went to school with Sibelius at the Musical Institute in Helsingfors would have believed in those days that he would reach the biblical age. He did not seem to dwell on this earth. His was a delicate, impressionable nature, with a sensitive imagination which found outlet in music at the slightest incitement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27. -- California has been aroused by public action of a Commonwealth Club report showing that its half-billion-dollar-a-year agricultural industry rests upon an army of 150,000 migratory laborers who live in squatters' camps, under wretched sanitary conditions, and with no educational facilities for their children.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28. -- Charley Stevenson, who has all but clinched jockey honors on the American turf for 1935, went on another riding spree today as he brought home three winners, including B. Hernandez's Indiantown in the feature race at the Fair Grounds.

HERE is a book that makes a comprehensive survey of strike-breaking by professional strike-breakers in this country since that method began to be used about sixty years ago. As labor editor of The New York Evening Post Mr. Levinson has long been a student of labor problems.

IT was Louis Sullivan's fate to be slowed down in mid-career by a depression and by the unwillingness or inability of his own contemporaries to make use of his talents. He lived through years of obscurity, during which his buildings were not constructed nor his writings published, and not long after recognition began to come to him he died.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Duncan gave a reception with dancing to introduce their daughter, Miss Christine S. Duncan, yesterday afternoon at their home, 1 East Eighty-seventh Street. The rooms given over to entertaining were decorated with Christmas greens and flowers.

The collection of Near Eastern and early Mediterranean art belonging to the estate of the late Emile Tabbagh of Paris and New York will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Senator Borah will enter the fight for New York delegates to the National Republican Convention in Cleveland in June. Representative Hamilton Fish of New York said today that he had been authorized by Senator Borah to "organize the entire State."

ESCANABA, Mich., Dec. 27. -- Michigan Republicans now are certain their junior United States Senator, Arthur H. Vandenberg, will be in the forefront in one role or another at the party's national convention to be held in Cleveland next June.

THE Austrian Tyrol is preparing for one of its most active Winter seasons in many years. The proximity of the Tyrolean resorts and Garmisch-Partenkirchen, scene of the Olympic tryouts, has prompted the directors of the former to expand their regular programs.

A fundamental principle of the Neediest Cases Fund is that all of the money contributed shall go toward the necessities of life and toward the permanent rehabilitation of the unfortunate, and not be dissipated on trivialities.

Pointing toward the Olympic games, American fencers made great gains in dexterity and experience during the past year. The most significant development of the season was the return to the strips of Joseph C. Levis after a year's absence to reclaim the national foils championship that he had been forced to let go by default in 1934.

TOKYO, Dec. 28. -- The progress on Japan's three naval replacement building programs now under way has been so satisfactory that the newspaper Hochi, in giving figures, maintains that if a naval race starts in 1936 Japan will be able to meet it.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- A sensation has been caused here by a widespread report that Russia, which was not among the five countries questioned by Britain regarding the support they would render in the event of an Italian attack upon the British fleet, had voluntarily offered to place her air fleet at Britain's disposal in such an event.

Once again death took its toll of outstanding figures in the world of sport during 1935. Among the notables to pass on were football's immortal Ted Coy, court tennis's unforgettable Jay Gould and baseball's stalwart Frank J Navin, president of the Detroit Tigers.

AMONG the many original and interesting ideas which the Japanese have passed on to us none is more intriguing than that of the miniature fruit tree, bearing perfectly good apples, pears or plums, growing in a pot small enough to be placed on a dinner table.

Two of the most sensational matches tennis has provided in years overshadowed all else in 1935, including England's successful defense of the Davis Cup and the fifth successive Wightman Cup victory of the United States.

Omaha was the year's leading money-winning thoroughbred and as definite a 3-year-old champion as was his sire, Gallant Fox, in 1930. Discovery was a standout in the handicap division, performing as a 4-year-old in a manner to rival the showing of Equipoise at the same age, although this star had no such juvenile records as Equipoise's.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Several inches of snow covered the Pocono Mountains and a safe thickness of ice covered the lakes and skating rinks of the playgrounds of Pennsylvania as preparations were being made to entertain the New Year's crowd coming to the Poconos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- In its most important move in recent years to reduce the cost of railroad financing, the Interstate Commerce Commission today told the New York Central Railroad that it could pay no more than 5 per cent interest on a $75,000,000 issue of short-term promissory notes which the road had sought to market at 6 per cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Glendhu, the 5-year-old chestnut mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Stephen Gilbert, captured the blue ribbon in the featured open jumpers' sweepstake at the indoor horse show staged by the Saxon Woods Hunt Club today. In a stellar performance, this handsome entrant, under a fine ride by Johnny Hicks, had little trouble coming through to victory.

A plan of reorganization providing for the formation of a new corporation to take over the assets of the present company has been submitted to the creditors and stockholders of the American Encaustic Tiling Company, Inc. The new corporation would have an authorized capitalization of 310,000 shares of $1-par stock.

The tennis matches to be played by world's ranking professionals on the night of Jan. 11 at Madison Square Garden have drawn a large advance subscription from members of society, many of whom are actively interested in the work of the Frontier Nursing Service, which is to benefit from the occasion.

ACOLONIAL desk always contributes a charming decorative note to a room; even two though a century or may have passed since it made, it is still a most useful piece of furniture. Of the several types found in early American households, the slant-top desk or scrutoir was very popular and was made in a great variety of woods and ornamentation, ranging from simple pine to ornate mahogany enriched with carving and elaborate brasses.
Before a hushed House of Commons July 30, 1934, Stanley Baldwin, then the Acting Prime Minister, made this statement:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28. -- The ninety-seventh annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science will open here Monday and will continue through Saturday with a vast program, covering all the major branches of science, from astronomy to zoology.

A general upheaval among titleholders, spectacular comebacks, a cluster of record-smashing performances and a wave of public enthusiasm that sent turnstiles clicking merrily on practically all fronts combined to make 1935 the most notable year in sport since 1929.
Thirty deaths attributed to football injuries were reported in the United States during the 1935 season up to Dec. 19, the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday.

THE standard of music maintained at Wells College, Aurora, N.Y., may be gleaned by a perusal of the recently published list of compositions performed in 1935 by the institution's Department of Music. Particularly imposing is the long catalogue of choral music sung at the Sunday vespers.

Program chairmen of New Jersey clubs have scheduled events for the January calendar that reflect even more diversity than usual. Some of these functions represent a departure for the sake of novelty. Others are customary programs, recurring each year at some time during the holiday season.
The holiday season, which has already produced a Missouri farmer named Santa Claus and real snow, turned up another delightful improbability yesterday.

"Rigoletto" was the opera yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, with Lawrence Tibbett appearing for the first time in the title role. The opera was welcome and thrice welcome, for, though interlarded with certain conventionalities, it is a thrilling work of genius, instinctively prophetic of things that were to occur in the supreme masterpieces of Verdi's later period.
New champions in every event were crowned during the past year in bowling. The sport in general continued to show steady gains.

ALBANY, Dec. 28. -- Syndicates and pools are taxable as partnerships when engaged in a trade, business or occupation, the State Tax Commission announced today in a ruling on the new, unincorporated business income tax law.

Basketball moved out of the cramped confines of college gymnasiums into the "big time" atmosphere of Madison Square Garden during 1935 and the sport, taking its tempo from the shift in scene in New York, went on to the greatest season in its history.

ONE type of gardening can be enjoyed even in the most inclement weather, and no matter how short the days. And yet its delights are comparatively little known to many planters and tillers who work strenuously from early Spring to late Fall.
THE pilots and other employee who accompany Pan American Clipper ships to and from the Far East will soon be able to greet the native Chinese in his native tongue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A nationwide reorganization of the Works Progress Administration for efficiency, now that its program has reached the purely operating stage, has been ordered by Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, a high authority revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The struggle over a cash compensation for American veterans of the World War, which has featured every session of Congress for the past eighteen years, will come to the legislative front as soon as both houses settle down to business after they convene on Jan. 3.

This little book has the charm one finds in sensitive and unself-conscious children. A little German girl spent many Summers in Italy with her mother. Here she began her diary when she was so young that the record was kept by pictures with one or two printed letters for text, and, as she grew older, she continued to make notes of what she saw and did and thought.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The sum of $736,916 has been allotted to the National Park Service by the WPA for the administration of forty-four transient camps in seventeen States, including New York, whose enrollees are engaged in carrying out projects in State, county and municipal parks, Secretary Ickes said today.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Faith in Father Divine led three Negroes to spurn rescue in a fire following an explosion in a two-story frame house at 18 Barclay Street here this afternoon, but it could not save their lives.

FIFTEEN violin concertos will be played by Mischa Elman in a series of five concerts in collaboration with Leon Barzin and the orchestra of the National Orchestral Association. The series, to be concerned with the development of violin literature will be given Saturday afternoons at Carnegie Hall, beginning this week. The opening program will consist of the following concertos: the Bach in E major, the Mozart in A major and the Beethoven.

ACCORDING to all the reference books, Rudyard Kipling will be 70 tomorrow.
