If this is true (and all the books of reference can't be wrong), it disposes once and for all of the theory that Mr. Kipling is a myth, that he does not exist and never has existed. There used to be several variants of this once popular theory.

In London Sir Samuel Hoare was obliged to resign as Foreign Secretary after he had espoused a plan for settlement of the Italo-Ethiopian war which the British public construed as going back on the League of Nations effort to force Italy, through sanctions, to give up her effort at conquest in Eastern Africa.

A collection of choice early Greek and Roman silver coins collected by the late F. Munroe Endicott during the many years he was in the diplomatic service of the United States was recently presented as a memorial to the American Numismatic Society at Broadway and 156th Street and it has just been placed on exhibition in that building.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- Department store sales in Boston for December, up to Christmas, were about 3 per cent ahead of the same period a year ago. The first week of December was well ahead of last year, the second week was below 1934, while the third week was slightly ahead of last year.

Athletes of New Utrecht and Textile provided most of the outstanding achievements among city P.S. A.L. senior high school teams during the last year, as each captured three important crowns. New Utrecht continued its track reign, both indoors and outdoors, and took the soccer title, while Textile retained the baseball laurels, regained the fencing honors and added the basketball championship.

BE chic when you play on Southern beaches this Winter! This is the admonition of expert stylists. You'll want a lot of dresses, long ones and short ones, to wear over your bathing or play suits. It looks as though it were going to be an undercover season and as if skins would be exposed to the sun only during hours devoted to intensive tanning.

PARIS, Dec. 25. -- Fernand Aubry is launching turbans entirely made of human hair worked into ostrich plume or palm-leaf motifs. These are novelties in evening coiffures. They are definitely hats and not wigs; they may match the wearer's own hair or be dyed in bright colors.

TORONTO, Dec. 28. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs routed the New York Ranger sextet, 9 to 3, in the highest scoring game of the season tonight. The Rangers presented a weak defense in front of Goalie Dave Kerr. A crowd of 11,000 saw the game.

THE third concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra series, for Bennington College, will be given Monday evening, Jan. 6, at the Town Hall. It will be devoted to compositions of the "classical period" of the eighth century.

OCCASIONALLY, not too often, we find an artist, or any one else, who is flexible. Christian Rohlfs is one. He was 52 years old when he went to Hagen to teach. Within the next few years he became familiar with the epoch-making work of Daumier, Cezanne and Van Gogh.
The greatest year it has enjoyed since the boom days of the Jack Dempsey-Tex Rickard era came to boxing in 1935.

LAST year when "Awake and Sing!" was produced Clifford Odets compelled the town to prick up its ears. This year he has put it on its ear with the production of "Paradise Lost." The general newspaper verdict has been against his new play, which is criticized for its frowsy characterization, its random form and its inchoate material.

THE career of the famous French demagogue, guillotined in the Year II of the First Republic, makes a truly capital subject of biography. This is especially true for the general reader who often makes the same error as some of Danton's contemporaries, and imagines that Danton -- with the cruel Marat and the spinsterlike Robespierre -- formed, at a given moment, a triumvirate of supreme power.

The spectacular world series triumph of Mickey Cochrane's Tigers, giving Detroit its first world championship since the inception of the American League, preceded by another nerve-throbbing pennant race in the National circuit, provided the highlights of the 1935 baseball campaign in a manner to give the past season a ranking among the standout years in the game's history.

VIOLATION of traffic regulations and common-sense driving rules results in so many "set-ups" or stage settings for motor-car accidents that there is little mystery as to why the accident rate is so high.

If you were a resident of Newcastle County, Del., for the next two years, you would have to pay the County Commissioners a tax on your income. You would also have to pay the State of Delaware a tax on your income. When that was finished, the Federal Government would step up to ask for a share, too.

The Federal revenue legislation of 1935 was criticized and President Roosevelt's tax program to redistribute wealth was characterized as impractical and illusory by Professor Harley L. Lutz of Princeton University in an address yesterday at the closing session of the American Economic Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 28. (AP). -- Fourteen-year-old Miss Helen Bernhard of New York and Miss Virginia Hollinger of Dayton, Ohio, the defending champion, will meet tomorrow for the girls' national indoor tennis championship.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--With his majority reduced to twenty--it was fifty-two ten days ago--Premier Pierre Laval has survived these two feverish days of turbulent debate on his foreign policy. The vote today was 296 to 276. That Mr. Laval did survive was due entirely to his great ability in presenting his own case and in turning difficult corners to his advantage.

Representative THEODORE CHRISTIANSON, Governor of Minnesota from 1925 to 1931, sketches in Current History for January "A Program for Republicans." They are in Sore need of one. Mr. CHRISTIANSON may be thought to know the mind of the Minnesotan the Northwestern, farmer.

A practical use for seismic or earthquake waves was reported yesterday by Dr. Maurice Ewing at the closing session of the annual conference of the Geological Society of America and associated societies in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Football definitely turned the corner in 1935 with the most prosperous and satisfactory season it has enjoyed since the depression set in.

With next year's program for the department of tropical research of the New York Zoological Society completed, Dr. William Beebe, marine explorer and naturalist, sailed with Mrs. Beebe aboard the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda for a brief vacation before starting a long period of activity in deep sea studies.

PRINCIPALS of elementary and junior high schools are now busily interviewing boys and girls of the 8B grade who have shown talent in music or the fine arts and who may wish to enter the city's new high school of music and arts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Seventy-five of the foremost skiers in American and Canadian college ranks were busily occupied today in waxing their wooden runners and adjusting steel edges for the fifteenth annual college Winter sports program, which the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds will stage starting on Monday and ending New Year's Day.

ISTANBUL -- The news that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is making a film of "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh," which relates Turkish maltreatment of Armenians during the Great War, lately has roused among Turkish citizens storms of protest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A further continuation of the recent favorable trend of business activity was noted today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly survey.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, the afternoon of Jan. 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House which has been taken over to raise funds for the Florence Crittenton League.

THE romance of railroading continues to grip the popular imagination, as evidenced recently by the hundreds of sightseers who journeyed to the West Albany freight yards in the New York Central's "wonder train." The trek was planned to give a behind-the-scenes glimpse of water scoops, automatic stokers and other devices of modern railroading.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The advisory committee of the New York State Mayors Conference recommended today that the State share equally with cities the cost of home relief after Jan. 1, 1937. Municipalities now pay 60 per cent and the State the remainder.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Members of the Adirondack Winter colony jammed the Olympic Arena from ringside to roof tonight to witness the coronation of the king and queen of Winter. This elaborate ceremony officially ushered in the Winter season at this resort.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A charge that publicity seekers were hindering the Thelma Todd death inquiry was made tonight by Deputy District Attorney George Johnson.

One hundred delegates to the council meeting of the General Federation at Miami next Spring will leave the convention city on May 1, at the close of the sessions, for a good-will tour which will set a precedent in the organization. Led by Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson, president of the federation, the party will spend eleven days visiting affiliated clubs in Havana, Puerto Rico and the Canal Zone.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A newly formed American Student Union answered an American Legion protest tonight with a decision to close its convention a day early, and then reversed its stand.

Forty-seven members of America's Winter sports team will sail Friday for Garmisch-Partenkirchen and the fourth Olympic Winter Games. They are scheduled to leave on the S.S. Manhattan of the United States Lines. Others already are in Europe, while a handful more will depart a fortnight later on the S.S. Washington.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Continuation of its effort to gear its program of study to the needs of the individual student, to give the undergraduate greater independence and to place more responsibility upon him marked the year for Princeton University.

PHOENIX. -- Arizona has entered the final phase of its decade-long campaign for power and Water from Boulder Dam, but finds itself arrayed not only against California but against all six of the Colorado River Basin States and perhaps before the fight is over against the Reclamation Bureau, which is not at all desired.

Two gunmen bound and gagged Mrs. Liza Solomon, 52 years old, in her combination antique shop and rooming house at 125 West Fifteenth Street at 12:30 P.M. yesterday. After ransacking the place they fled with $75 cash and jewelry worth several hundred dollars.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Sports and social clubs of Orlando's Winter residents have completed preparations for an influx of visitors next week, coming to attend the first Orlando Olympic stars aquatic meet and the Florida State Education Association convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Years of economic conflict have shown that Woodrow Wilson was right in his view that peace, to be lasting, must rest upon the removal, so far as possible, of economic barriers, Francis B. Sayre told the Democratic Women's Luncheon Club of Pennsylvania here today.

The Maroons of Montreal brought the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's professional hockey championship, back to the Canadian metropolis last April. Under the guidance of Manager Tommy Gorman, the Maroons contributed one of the greatest upsets in the history of the National Hockey League by turning back the heavily favored Toronto Maple Leafs in three straight games to capture the title.

A dinner dance was given jointly by Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Gibbons and Mr. and Mrs. Wharton Poor last night at Sherry's to introduce their respective daughters, Miss M. Thayer Gibbons and Miss Ella Marie Poor. The decorations for the party were confined to silver and various shades of green.

While retailers have held down price advances throughout most of the Fall season, with retail quotations out of line with those in the wholesale markets, it is expected that the early Spring will see a more general increase. Currently, retail prices are averaging about 1 per cent above the corresponding period of 1935, but it is estimated that the first half of this year may see a further gain of 2 per cent or more.

Scattered liquidation and hedge selling marked yesterday's short session on the Cotton Exchange, but after declining to bottom levels of the week, a closing rally left quotations 2 points lower to 4 points higher than on Friday.

The Twentieth Amendment to the Constitution brought an end to "lame duck" Congresses, but, paradoxically, it made possible "lame duck" Presidents. Although attention was called to this contingency when the proposed amendment was under discussion in Congress, little has been said about it since.
LONDON. -- People in the British Isles agree that 1935 has been in many respects a satisfactory year.
I have read with deep interest your editorial under the caption of "Excluding Our Own Sons," also the contributions of correspondents under the composite caption "The Lindbergh Exile."

A broad-scale campaign to facilitate international commerce by simplification and unification of the laws in various countries, by elimination of red tape and by speeding up legal procedure will be started by the Federal Bar Association, it was made known here yesterday by Edward A. Alexander, chairman of a subcommittee of the organization, recently created to handle the campaign.

Slight gains and losses were fairly evenly distributed between staples traded in on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with no outstanding developments in seasonably desultory trading. On the cash markets, all the grains, dairy products and rubber advanced, with no declines reported.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 28. -- Plans of the trustees of Williams College to enlarge the college's musical facilities and to offer more courses in this field have given considerable impetus to the Glee Club, directed by Charles L. Safford, which is carrying out one of its most ambitious programs to make space available to house the Paul Whiteman collection of instruments, orchestrations, scripts and records, tracing the history of American music.

A SYMPOSIUM on the car of the future will be presented at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers in Detroit during the week of Jan. 13. Those scheduled to participate in it are William B. Stout, president of the organization; Walter Dorwin Teague, designer; A.M. Wolf, automotive consultant; Herbert Chase, consulting engineer, and John Tjaarda and A.E. Northup, both of whom have made contributions to advanced car design.

PARIS, Dec. 1. THE spate of Autumn theatrical productions in Paris is nearly always in two parts, an interval between the two. The first part finished three weeks ago. We are now in the second. In the last few days there have been new works by Jean Giraudoux, Edouard Bourdet and that promising young author Armand Salacrou, to say nothing of productions by such practiced theatrical carpenters as Charles Mere and Louis Verneuil.

A reception for members of the junior and debutante committees of the third annual Birthday Ball for the President will be held on Thursday in the Jansen suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball, one of the largest of about 5,000 to be held simultaneously throughout the country on President Roosevelt's birthday, will take place on Jan. 30 at the Waldorf.

LOS ANGELES, newest and most modern of cities, has had a long and colorful history. Harry Carr, author of "Old Mother Mexico" and "The West Is Still Wild," here tells the story of its early days, and of the modern city as he has known it through forty years as a newspaper writer -- years that have witnessed changes as sweeping and dramatic as any in the past.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 28. -- High Commissioner Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, who now is entering his fifth year of administration of the Holy Land as the representative of the mandatory power, has, since he took over the reins of government, cherished two ideals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A three-cornered race to head the "Borah for President" movement in New York developed today with a newly entered faction expressing hope all would cooperate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Senator Arthur Capper plans a new campaign when Congress convenes for his proposed constitutional amendment to eliminate "aliens from representation" in Congress.

The American system of taxation is one of expediency and, as such, sales taxes, utilized as emergency measures, are likely to be continued, Alfred G. Buehler, Professor of Public Finance at the University of Vermont, told members of the Tax Policy League at a luncheon at the National Arts Club yesterday.

With a substantial burst of shopping featuring the close of Christmas trade with cold weather stimulating consumer response to clearance offerings of Winter merchandise, retailers in the metropolitan area are in a fairly optimistic mood as the year draws to its close.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 28. -- Secretary of Finance Eduardo Suarez and his wife unexpectedly departed by airplane today for the United States by way of Brownsville.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Albert H. Lenart, 38 years old, of 1,711 East Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, was held in $1,000 bail at the Essex County jail here today on a charge of false swearing because he was reluctant to admit he had been married eight times.

LONDON, Ky., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Charging illegal imprisonment, former Kentucky coal miners today sued Circuit Judge James M. Gilbert of Pinevilie and Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton of Harlan for damages totaling $350,000 in Federal District Court here.

THE phenomena of industrial expansion in the South have given us recently so many novels of social unrest, all in more or less the same vein, that it is probably just as well to be reminded here of another side to the picture. "Quality House" is also, in its way, a novel of social unrest as it afflicts certain inhabitants of a mill town in Georgia.

THIS, says Will James in his preface, "is the story of a regular ranch and cow outfit and of regular range folks and cowboys." And that is what he has really done in the book -- portrayed in his always vividly lifelike and convincing way, and in his always rough and ready English, the day-by-day life and work and feeling of a big-range owner, his family, his cowboys and other assistants and his undesired visitors.

The 1935 season in court tennis and racquets found the younger generation of players holding forth successfully in almost every instance. In court tennis, the campaign was almost a repetition of the one before, with Ogden Phipps of New York dominating the game.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 28. -- The newspaper was pictured by Edgar E. Robinson of Stanford University tonight as the historian's surest and most nearly eternal source of information.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn affirmed unanimously yesterday a recommendation of Referee Joseph Morschauser awarding the custody of 10-year-old Constance Brock to her maternal grandparents, Samuel and Libby Starr of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

THE automobile industry is about to put 1935 behind it and enter the year 1936 with the feeling, among its executives, that it has turned the corner around which prosperity evasively lurked for so long. In the middle of December the Automobile Manufacturers Association estimated that the year's production of passenger cars and trucks would total 4,150,000 units in the United States and Canada.

The season is at hand for summaries of the financial and business progress made during 1925 and for estimates of the possibilities for the next twelvemonth. A glance at the prophecies made a year ago reveals that the improvement scored in many lines far exceeded expectations.

SLIGHTLY more than a year having passed since England began seriously to compete with Hollywood for American film trade, it might not be amiss to present a brief historical footnote on one of the leading factors in the British campaign.
Boys and girls from 8 to 10 will find "The Lotus Mark" thoroughly good reading, for along with its description of a fascinating country there are a well-knit plot and a dramatic ending.

WHAT is termed "the most important show of paintings by Rembrandt and the members of his circle ever held in America" opened on Thursday and will continue till Sunday evening, Jan. 19, at the Art Institute of Chicago, in the East Wing galleries.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Miami's Roosevelt Birthday Ball in observance of the President's birthday and in aid of the fight against infantile paralysis will this season be staged on the night of Jan. 30 in the Royal Palm Club, the use of which has been given by Arthur Childers, club president, to the Miami President Roosevelt Birthday Ball Committee, of which Roddy B. Burdine is chairman.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With the round of social and sport events here getting under way with the New Year, an affair anticipated by members of the Winter colony is a buffet supper and dance on New Year's Eve at the Pine Needles Inn to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Emmett E. Boone of West Hampton Beach.
SCENARIO writers of children's programs must adhere to the following formula if the broadcasts are to be on the approved list of the Women's National Radio Committee:
ROME, Dec. 28. -- Premier Pierre Laval's victory in the French Chamber of Deputies today pleased Italy but did not succeed in dissipating the gloom with which the people here view the future.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Among the undue costs and duplicated services imposed upon the taxpayers of Westchester County by ancient laws and too many units of government is a costly and complicated system of inferior courts, the Institute of Public Administration has reported to the Westchester Commission on government.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 27. -- Two weeks after the machine gun murder of Walter Liggett, editor of The Mid-West American of Minneapolis, the case is already becoming merely yesterday's sensation.

MANILA. -- What was at first merely a minor matter of personality has rapidly developed in the Philippines into what promises to be one of the first real structural issues in the new government. It concerns the powers and prerogatives of the Speaker of the National Assembly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28. -- Pacific steamship operators were interested this week in the report that a new "intercoastal conference" to unite lines in coast-to-coast trade in a working agreement is in the making. The new conference will take the place of a similar organization which broke up with the withdrawal of its principal members last July.

For the last forty years a movement has been afoot to raze the old Federal Building. Articles have been published in newspapers ever since 1928 predicting its demolition "within two years." People have called it "Mullett's Monstrosity."
Snow flurries and not the one long and two short toots of sirens will summon men on home relief to duty as emergency snow workers this Winter, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- The Christmas tree is barred in Russia, but it has been decided to go in for the "New Year's tree" in a big way this year.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28 (AP). -- President Agustin Justo and his Finance Minister, Federico Pinedo, by virtue of a budgetary surplus of 20,000,000 pesos have announced a program of relief for income taxpayers, shopkeepers and professional men.

DISCLOSURE last week of two stamp counterfeiting plots throws light on a hazard to which the unwary or inexperienced collector is frequently subjected. Dozens of similar frauds have been reported in recent years, some of them involving issues having high collectors' values.

The makings of an amusing parlor game were supplied last week by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The editors of 128 newspapers and press associations were asked to select the twelve leading news stories of 1935. The selections were far from unanimous.

THIS book, covering many decades, is a generous Broadway omnibus of anecdote and reminiscence from the dean of American theatrical producers, one who did as much as anybody else now alive to mold and advance the native stage.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Despite the feverishness of the political situation, the Bourse was calm today. There was some hesitation at first and rentes weakened, but toward the close of the market the position was reversed: rentes strengthened and international securities fell slightly.

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 28 (AP).--The Soviet Minister, Alexander Minkin, who already has been handed his passport by the Uruguayan Government, in a note tonight categorically denied all charges made against his government as reasons for severing relations with Russia.

THE plan for a uniform traffic code for the nation, as outlined at the Accident Prevention Conference in Washington a few days ago, indicates a growing realization of the importance of harmonious motor laws in the larger program of highway accident reduction.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Soon Over, Greentree Stables' 4-year-old colt, won the $2,500 Santa Maria Handicap at Santa Anita Park today before a crowd of 20,000 persons.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28. -- While zero weather has retarded some lines of business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week, it has also spurred sales of Winter wear, coal and fuel oil and added zest to extensive Christmas shopping.
If there's any single palm to be awarded for outstanding performance on the links during 1935, it must by all means go to W. Lawson Little Jr. of California.

La Argentina ended her sixth American season with another of her enchanting programs at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Three dances from other seasons were revived for the occasion, namely, the brilliant "Jota" to music by de Falla, the lovely "Almeria" of Albeniz, and the "Malaguena" which allows the elegance of the dancer to be submerged under the surface of a fish-wife.

ROME, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The destruction of two Italian airplanes beyond the front lines by pilots who escaped to their own forces under cover of an aerial bombardment was described tonight in communique.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The Supreme Court has the privilege of sending its mail free, but buys stamps for most of its letters because it does not consider them to be government business.

Colonel Lindbergh's decision to leave the United States and to take up residence in Britain has brought dramatically into public debate, first, the crime problem in this country and, second, the issue of privacy.
BUFFALO, Dec. 28. -- The Young Republican organization of the State demanded the right today to name a "fair share" of the delegates to the State and national conventions of the party.

THIS little book is a familiar study of an author who once bulked largely in the reading consciousness of our forbears. Probably few houses today contain a copy of Thomas Fuller's "Worthies of England." But many of our ancestors fed upon this work with only less avidity than they fed upon the Bible itself.

Atlantic storms and holiday travel have combined in the past week to keep the passenger and pier staffs of the Hapag Lloyd Line working at double speed. The additional labor will continue today, and resume on Thursday, when new arrivals and sailings are due.

Basing their expectation on further industrial recovery and increased consumer purchasing, retail merchants throughout the country expect continued gains in retail trade next year, according to a telegraphic survey made by THE TIMES last week.

The surprising victory of the United States women's team over the English in the third international squash racquets match for the Wolfe-Noel Cup stood out as the major achievement of a season that saw more play among both the men and women than ever before.

HOLIDAY trade for the country as a whole ran substantially above the volume of a year ago, but the increases in many sections fell short of expectations, according to reports received here. The average gain was probably around 7 or 8 per cent, whereas retailers were looking for an increase of between 10 and 15 per cent.

On one important point the Washington dispatches are impressively silent as Congress prepares to reconvene. There is little talk of new currency legislation. To be sure, Congress will vote on the soldiers' bonus, and one of the plans for paying it calls for the printing of paper money.

There are only two ways in which criminal laws are enforced. One way is by common consent of the governed; the other by brute force. It may seem like begging the question to speak of a law as being "enforced" by common consent of the governed, for a law that is obeyed voluntarily by an individual does not require any formal legal process or machinery of enforcement so far as that individual is concerned.

A plan to establish air-conditioning equipment standards on the railroads was announced yesterday by J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. This was considered possibly the most prompt action of its kind taken by the railroads as a group.

Three men were wounded, one critically, about 6 o'clock last night when a detective encountered two gunmen fleeing from the Nonpareil Billiard Academy, a basement pool room at 600 Fifth Street at Avenue B. where the thugs had just staged a hold-up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- In honor of Hawaii a new memorial stone, the first in many years, will soon be placed in the Washington Monument. The memorial of coral sandstone recently reached the capital. The National Park Service, as custodian, has awarded the contract for setting the stone and dedication ceremonies will be held in January or February.

Caleb J. Milne 4th, grandson of a wealthy retired Pennsylvania textile manufacturer, confessed at 4 o'clock yesterday morning that his so-called kidnapping on Dec. 14 was a hoax engineered by him in an attempt to obtain money and publicity so he could get a job on the stage or in moving pictures.

CAPTAIN BLOOD was trapped at luncheon in the Ritz. A half-dozen oysters appeared before him and, almost as quickly, disappeared within him. "I was always being sacked at school," he was saying. Just then his wife flew in.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Premier Pierre Laval, in a speech liberally filled with the "danger of war with Italy" if he were overthrown, convinced the Deputies today that they should let him remain in office.

Because of the Christmas holidays, the announcements last week of bonds called for payment before maturity were less than in the last several weeks. The calls were almost all for next year, only one small lot of municipal bonds being added for this month and raising the total for December to $408,044,200, against $219,529,000 last month and $27,391,000 in December, 1934, in the respective corresponding weeks.

AS snowy begins to blow across the ridges of the high Sierras, the California State Highway Department prepares for another Winter-long battle to keep some 4,500 miles of the State's roads open to traffic, despite often almost insurmountable difficulties.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Municipal plants and private utility companies in New York State effected rate reductions totaling $14,617,000 in 1935, nearly three times more than the previous three years, the joint legislative utility investigating committee reported today.

Forty per cent of the 2,600 graduate students at Columbia University last year had full-time outside jobs and an additional 17 per cent were engaged in part-time employment, Dean Howard Lee McBain of the Graduate Faculties disclosed yesterday in a report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

THE cinema rarely looks back. While others appraise the work of the past, Hollywood concerns itself with adjectives about the year to come. The epic of epics may have been made in January; by December the profits are all in and the effort forgotten. In this town it is better to survey the news of the year, to interpret it and speculate on its influence on this lively segment of the American scene.

Cockeyed, which has been in the dictionary a long time, got into the White House vocabulary last week. President Roosevelt and a group of reporters were talking about the budget. There was mention of a report that Mr. Roosevelt intended to present to Congress early next month a $7,000,000,000 budget, involving a $1,500,000,000 deficit.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Mexican officials said today that any threat of a revolution brought about by the return from exile of General Plutarco Elias Calles, onetime strong man and President, had definitely passed.

AS 1935 passes into educational history, set it down as youth's year. For the first time perhaps since the founding of Latin schools in early New England, the child has been eclipsed by the adolescent in the view of educators.
The highlight in water sports during 1935 was a keenly contested international swimming meet between Japan and the United States at Tokyo.

According to figures announced yesterday by the American Kennel Club, more than a million fanciers of the thoroughbred dog attended the all-breed and specialty shows, matches and field trials conducted under the rules of the governing body during 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- When Congress meets in January it will have before it a recommendation by the Civil Service Commission, of which Harry B. Mitchell is head, for legislation to extend the provisions of the Civil Service Law and rules to New Deal agencies placed by law outside the competitive classified service "to the extent that it is determined that such agencies are to become established branches of the government."

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP). -- An eightpoint program to correlate the State's social security program with that of the Federal Government probably will be recommended to the 1936 Legislature, it was indicated in Capitol circles tonight.

N.Y.U., St. John's and Long Island U. continued unbeaten, while C.C.N.Y. lost in a week in which activities in basketball circles were considerably curtailed on account of the Christmas holidays. It was City College's first defeat.

Stocks of United States cotton throughout the world at the end of November, including the unpicked portion of the crop and governmentfinanced stocks, amounted to 15,531,000 bales, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

Legislation enabling the State to guarantee real estate titles under the Torrens law was suggested yesterday by Edward Polak, former Register of the Bronx, in a letter addressed to State Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the joint legislative committee on guaranteed mortgages.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin called on his followers today for a million votes of confidence to bulwark his nationalization of money campaign as the climax of an address attacking industrialists opposed to government regulation as "thick-headed" and "welchers."

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Supreme Court Justice Ellis J. Staley has dismissed the $100,000 action brought by Mrs. Catherine Farmer Vanderbilt of Greenville against Mrs. Lizzie Vanderbilt Hegeman of New York, half-sister of the plaintiff's husband, George V. Vanderbilt.

A heavy snowfall, which by 3 A.M. had reached an average depth of three and one-half inches, began blanketing the city last night while high northeast winds whipped up drifts that delayed traffic and threatened to disrupt railroad and bus service.

BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The economic year has been a subdued one in the Reich with official and press utterances warning against exaggerated expectations of any prosperity in the future. The year, it is conceded, saw a distinct slackening of industrial activity and a disappointingly small decline in unemployment.

Dr. Erich Schmidt, field director of the Oriental Institute of Chicago, who has been conducting excavations since last April at Persepolis among the ruins of the palaces of the ancient Persian Kings, returned Saturday night on the liner New York of the Hamburg-American Line, bringing news of an important discovery of eight stone tablets inscribed in cuneiform characters with the records of the Iranian Kings.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP). -A severe cold and sore throat sent all-America Bobby Grayson to bed as Stanford drilled in the rain today for the New Year's Day Rose Bowl game with Southern Methodist.

GEORGE F. WARREN, the professor who thought up our gold purchasing program and helped to give us a 59-cent dollar, now emerges as another of the New Dealers who have turned against the New Deal. Criticizing the AAA, he advances the interesting theory that if the Supreme Court should throw out the processing taxes and production control, and if the whole AAA program were forthwith abandoned, it would not necessarily hurt the farmers.

The results of the unsuccessful attempt to oust James C. Sheridan as Democratic Leader of Queens County at the last primaries will be seen on Wednesday when new appointees, all Sheridan adherents, will supplant several office-holders in patronage positions.

The fight over organization of the Assembly by the Republicans showed no signs of settlement yesterday and adjustment of the various issues involved awaited the result of the caucus of the Republican Assemblymen in the State Capitol at Albany tomorrow night.

Rafael Quendo, 19 years old, of 247 West 116th Street, who has spent all but nineteen days of his five months in this country in the workhouse on a narcotic charge, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Smith in Washington Heights Court on a charge of burglary.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- The favorites, Alex Hurd of Sudbury, Ont., and Miss Kit Klein of Buffalo, took full charge of the ice today and slipped ahead of a brilliant field to win principal honors in the annual silver skates carnival before 13,500 spectators.

Henry Fisher, oldest executive in point of years of service in the employ of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will retire from active business life on Wednesday. He is 78 years old and has been continuously with Socony-Vacuum and its predecessor companies since 1871.
I read with considerable interest your article headed "Safety Paths for Highways," which takes into consideration one use to which individuals put the rural highways even in the suburbs of New York.

The New York State Conservation Department has published in pamphlet form the address delivered recently by Commissioner Lithgow Osborne before the annual convention of the Conservation Council. Entitled "Better Hunting and Fishing? -- It's Up to You," the booklet is being distributed to sportsmen's groups throughout the State.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 29. -Representative students from hundreds of campuses of the United States and Canada this afternoon had a pre-view of a still distant United Christian Church, described as now beginning to emerge in college and university classrooms in nearly every nation.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 29. -- According to the Atlantic Transport Line, the American Importer, which is now said to be taking the Southern route around the south coast of Ireland, is due to arrive in the Mersey at 2 A.M. on Tuesday. But whether Colonel Lindbergh and his family will still be aboard then apparently only Colonel Lindbergh himself knows.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- Of the 1,592 law students who took the examination in October for admission to the bar, 748 passed, it was announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners. The board is composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- J. Kenneth Bradley, director of the Young Republican division of the party's national committee, said tonight that replies to a recent questionnaire indicated the Young Republicans considered the farm problem and government cost the outstanding political issues.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The year-end stringency in Lombard Street is developing along lines that indicate it will be greater than in several years. There is, however, cause for satisfaction in this pressure which arises from increasing prosperity throughout the country.

The National Bureau for Blind Artists will be the beneficiary of a holiday tea dance today at Sherry's. Exhibition dancing and dancing contests in which the guests will participate will be features of the entertainment. The funds realized will further the work of the National Bureau for Blind Artists which is maintained in order that blind musicians may obtain engagements throughout the country.

Who can doubt that the Republican party of this State has been rejuvenated? If there were not a multitude of Republicans how could there be so many brands of them? The quarrel about offices at Albany has evoked bad temper and loud words, but a question of high principle is involved.

No Christian has the right to attack the idols of the unconverted, the Rev. Herbert Lockyer, evangelist of Liverpool, England, said yesterday morning at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- If one of the wonderful machines imagined by H. G. Wells really existed to demonstrate the depth of private anxiety among European statesmen just now the lull that seems to have succeeded the political storm of three weeks ago would bear a different aspect.

Members of the American Sociological Society, meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore, planned to form an organization with headquarters at the University of Kansas that will collect and correlate research work dealing with the character and influence of newspapers.

ON BOARD MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 29. -- By cruising slowly along the edge of the pack ice the Wyatt Earp has approached within fifty-five miles of Charcot Island, but such proximity is of no avail yet in the attempt to lay a depot at Mount Monique for Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,577,856,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

The cotton futures market last week was largely a typical one for the year-end holiday period. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated narrowly and ended the week with net declines of only 3 to 13 points.

In his letter, published today, resigning as High Commissioner for Refugees Coming from Germany, Mr. JAMES G. MCDONALD outlines the work that has been done during his slightly more than two years of office. His duty was, as defined by the Council of the League, to seek to bring about and to make effective the "international collaboration" necessary to solve the problem of German refugees.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Traders in corn on the Board of Trade here are not disposed to take hold of the market on the buying side except in a moderate way on breaks, while bulges bring out profit-taking and purchases made at lower-price levels and some short selling.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Low temperatures in the soft Winter wheat district, with the wheat plant lacking snow covering, suggested to traders last week possibilities of damage to next year's crop. A large percentage of the hard Winter wheat acreage had light snow, however.

Georgia Graves, American contralto, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, proved herself to be a young artist of commendable accomplishments and exceptional promise. In a program that embraced music by Cesti, Handel, Rossi, Dvorak, Brahms, Strauss and Scandinavian and English groups the various facets of the singer's art were put to the test, and Miss Graves was not found wanting in the essentials.

The competitors who will participate tonight at Madison Square Garden in the final trials for the United States Olympic team were named yesterday at the conclusion of the national figure skating championships.

Consideration of the subject of minimum wage legislation for women cannot be complete without the viewpoint of the women workers who are affected by it. Representing a large number of wage-earning members of our organization, I should like to present their views on the subject.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29. -A galaxy of America's best aquatic stars shattered five national and one world swimming record today as the three-day Miami Biltmore aquatic show opened.
PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Money remains scarce in the market here. Call money is hard to find at less than the official rate of 6 per cent and there are few offers of longerterm loans.

BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- The Voelkischer Beobachter and the Angriff, published by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's own publishing house, have adopted a new method of promoting circulation which does indeed differ from any available to the disparaged "commercial press."
ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- Cancer mortality in New York State in 1934 was the highest ever recorded, the State Department of Health reported tonight.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Several thousand dollars worth of skyrockets, Roman candles and other fireworks exploded at 11:40 o'clock this morning on the Jersey meadows during a fire that destroyed the corrugated iron warehouse in which they were stored.

A schedule of twenty-eight games, including one encounter with the Cubs, National League champions, has been arranged for the Yankees' 1936 Spring training activities, according to announcement yesterday by Business Manager Ed Barrow.

The death rate in proportion to the number of automobile accidents has increased nearly 7 per cent this year, although the number of deaths from such accidents has remained virtually unchanged at 36,000, according to a survey by the Travelers Insurance Company.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 29. -Liscom C. Case, a member of the jury that convicted Bruno Richard Hauptmann of the crime for which he now awaits execution, died at his home in Hamden, near here, today. He was 65 years old.

A medal symbolic of the rank of commander of the Carlos Manuel de Cespedes National Order of Merit was bestowed yesterday morning by Cayetano de Quesada, acting Consul General of Cuba in New York, upon Edwin R. A. Seligman, Professor Emeritus of Political Economy at Columbia University, for his services as financial adviser of the Cuban Government.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 28. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 84.1, which compares with 84.4 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 84.6 three weeks before and 84.5 four weeks before.

Seasonally slow last week, the local wholesale markets prepared for the arrival of a large number of buyers after the first of the year. The cold weather spurred the demand for some Winter items, promotional goods were bought for January sales and the South placed some orders on Spring goods but the total volume was restricted.
Statements of results of operations issued by industrial corporations for various periods, follow:
Life must change if it is to remain the same, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

A real threat to the health of the residents of New York exists today in the fact that malaria once more may become epidemic in this area, Dr. C. H. Curran of the Entomological Department of the American Museum of Natural History said yesterday in reporting on recent studies of this fever.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- The most efficient apparatus so far developed by man for the direct conversion of the rays of the sun into useful mechanical energy was demonstrated here today at the scientific exhibit of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opens its annual Winter meeting tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP). -- Perspiring in 75 degree weather, the Catholic University football squad arrived this afternoon to complete training for its Orange Bowl game with Mississippi on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -- A group of prominent educators made public today a protest to President Roosevelt against criticism in the annual report of Secretary Dern of opposition to compulsory military training in schools.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- An electric eye which can see events of the past was announced by agents of the Department of Justice here today as new equipment in their fight on crime. It is operated by use of the spectograph.

CLARA WEATHERWAX'S "Marching! Marching!" (John Day-Reynal Hitchcock, $1.90) won the prize in the contest conducted jointly by The New Masses and the John Day Company for the best submitted novel on an American working-class theme. And doubly to honor it, the Book Union has made "Marching! Marching!" its January choice.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 29. -- Safe from starvation and towering seas, Lamont and Frank Sinnett, father and son who drifted four days off the Maine coast in a 30-foot power boat, rested in port today.

With a united front as its objective, the American Olympic Committee took steps yesterday to remove from its membership all not in sympathy with its policies and purposes. It unanimously voted at a meeting at the New York A.C. to make a canvass of its personnel and either obtain a promise of vigorous support from each individual or a letter of resignation.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Prime Minister Gen-dun of Outer Mongolia, visiting Moscow with other Mongolian officials, accused Japan tonight of preparing to convert his country into "a second Manchukuo."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 29 (AP). -The American Student Union closed its convention tonight with a resolution aimed at "certain elements" of the American Legion, "student Americaneers" and the Hearst press.

Japanese newspapers have been requested by the Home Office to refrain from publishing caricatures of foreign chiefs of State. Tokyo newspapers say the step is in response to a protest by the German Embassy against cartoons of HITLER.

To the man on Mars, providing his binoculars are of sufficient strength and his receiving set is in good working order, some of our antics in a year of merry sport must appear rather perplexing, not to say downright confusing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Business operation of the Postoffice Department during the fiscal year ending last June 30 was claimed today by Postmaster General Farley in his annual report.
Establishment of a chemical research fund totaling $52,600 at the University of Notre Dame was announced here yesterday by the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of the institution.

Joe Louis, the Brown Bomber of Detroit, whose unbroken series of triumphs in 1935 lifted boxing from the depths, was placed at the head of the world's heavyweight list in the annual rankings published by The Ring, boxing magazine, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

With reference to the article that appeared in your issue of Nov. 17, it would appear that your reporter has incorrectly reported my interview with him on the Ile de France. I informed him that the Irish Transatlantic Corporation, Ltd., had an option on over 600 acres at Londonderry, at the nearest point to the area in Lough Foyle approved by the Air Ministry for a seaplane base.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Sales in November on the twenty-three registered securities Exchanges of the United States amounted to $2,546,935,909, according to a report issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and were the largest since the commission began compiling figures on this basis in October, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Senator Arthur Vandenberg of Michigan, prominently mentioned as a possible Republican "dark horse" nominee at Cleveland next June, proclaimed his opposition today to any plan or movement the purpose of which is to tie any American neutrality program to the Kellogg peace pact.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29. -- An East Orange police captain refused here today to accept the diagnosis of a police surgeon and ordered the arrest of a Montclair woman on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The resignation of James G. McDonald as High Commissioner for Refugees (Jewish and Others) and his final report are featured prominently today in most British newspapers. Several newspapers comment editorially on the problem thus presented to the world.

It has often happened under Parliamentary Government that a Prime Minister lives on by sufferance. His opponents are strong enough to oust him, but for one reason or another decide to let him continue for a time. Meanwhile they exact from him concessions which he would not grant if he were strong enough to resist the pressure.

Steel operations this week will average 48 per cent of capacity, the same as last week, according to the weekly summary of the magazine Steel. A year ago the rate was 39 per cent. Rapid gains are looked for beginning next week, the magazine says.

The popularity of the mediumpriced quarters on transatlantic ships has increased beyond that of the cheapest or most expensive, according to reports prepared by the Atlantic Passenger Conference on traffic eastbound during the first eleven months of the current year.

More than the ordinary amount of interest was excited by the singing of Bidu Sayao, young Brazilian coloratura soprano, who made her first American appearance in a recital last evening in the Town Hall. Though previously unknown here, Miss Sayao has sung extensively in Europe and South America, having appeared at the Opera Comique in Paris, La Scala and many other leading opera houses.

To John Golden, in association with Joseph Schildkraut, falls the duty of presenting the last new Broadway attraction of 1935 -- "Tomorrow's a Holiday," opening tonight at the Golden Theatre. Leo Perutz and Hans Adler wrote the original, or Viennese, version, which Romney Brent has adapted, with George S. Kaufman supervising the script revisions and looking after the direction.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Prices for wheat futures on the Board of Trade advanced sharply several times last week but finished 3/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel net lower, except for December, which was unchanged.

A Harlem housing property that was bought in at foreclosure auction on Friday has been resold by the bidder, it was learned yesterday. The property, a six-story elevator apartment building at 251-255 West 129th Street, known as Lafayette Court, was taken over by the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, at an auction conducted by James R. Murphy.

BLOOMSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29. -David Shaffer, a paroled convict who had been hunted for more than two months on a murder charge, was captured early today by a village doctor at Benton, twenty miles north of this city.

A large audience braved the blizzard last night to see Carola Goya in her season's first recital of Spanish dances at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. It is pleasant to note that Miss Goya becomes a better artist each season.

UTICA, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Under the leadership of Norman Thomas an emergency convention of "Left Wing" Socialists broke from the "Old Guard" party leaders, elected their own State committee and moved for recognition as the official New York State organization by the National Executive Committee at the continuation of their conference here today.

Two more literary fellowships of $1,000 each are offered by Houghton Mifflin for 1936. The fellowships may be given for any book project, fiction or non-fiction, and the awards are entirely in addition to and apart from subsequent royalties.

The Rev. Gordon Wadhams has been elected rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection to succeed the Rev. E. Russell Bourne, who resigned because of ill health. The announcement was made yesterday morning by Ernest F. Eidlitz, senior warden, at services at the church, 115 East Seventyfourth Street.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 29. -Charm of Oakledge, chestnut mare, owned by Roger A. Young of Bronxville, N.Y., was awarded the championship of the annual Winter horse show of the Boulder Brook Club, held today in the club ring. She was also the only winner of two events, taking the open saddle class and also the test for ladies' saddle horses, in which she was ridden by Mrs. Walter Brundage.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- The question of easing Constitutional restrictions in view of economic changes will be debated at the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, which will be held in New York City on Jan. 23, 24 and 25.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Boston's hard-skating Bruins defeated the Red Wings coming from behind in 10,000 fans. Bill Cowley's overtime goal decided a fast match.
ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 29. -- According to advices received here from the front, the Ethiopian offensive in Tigre continues against the weak Italian right flank in the north.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Larger supplies of hogs were responsible last week for declines of 65 to 75 cents a hundredweight. The top was reached on Thursday with $10.20, while the average on that day was $9.85.

The first change in program under the new regime headed by Edward Johnson will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House this week when "Tannhaeuser" replaces "Carmen" as the Wednesday evening bill. The shift was made upon the advice of Rosa Ponselle's physician.

Red Dutton proved the leader of the New York Americans in fact as well as in name last night. The playing manager of the Star-Spangled sextet took the most prominent part in his team's 5-to-1 victory over the Canadiens of Montreal, a triumph which enabled the Americans to go into a tie with the Maroons for second place in the International division of the National Hockey League.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP). -The New Orleans Sugar Bowl sports program fell victim to the weather again today, frigid blasts from the North, which followed a torrential rain, causing postponement of the open golf tournament and the regatta.

There is a great need today of men who manifest convictions, just as the shepherds did upon their return from Bethlehem, declared the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Farber, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue at Ninety-first Street.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- In a rebellious mood and with its demand for an international charter as an industrial union still unanswered by the American Federation of Labor, the Radio Workers and Allied Trades Union ended its convention today.

The old year is ending, in business and on the markets, as old years usually end -- with financial attention pretty much diverted from what is going on just now to discussion of what has happened in the expiring year and what is likely to happen in the next one.

The world will not become better until men realize that they are "adopted sons of God and participators in His divine nature," the Rev. Walter J. Sullivan declared in a sermon at high mass yesterday morning, at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and 59th Street.

Another attempt has been made to discourage men from invading the Antarctic. In "Hell Freezes Over," which was staged at the Ritz Saturday evening, John Patrick reveals as hopefully as possible the degradation of the human spirit under the wreck of a dirigible somewhere on the Polar Plateau.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Sentiment in the world's wheat markets leans more toward an advance of prices, but those who are in favor of this trend report that they are not getting the support that would make a natural bull market. The trade appears to have an impression that there is a strong statistical position the world over, with supplies closely adjusted to requirements for the next six months or more.

James G. McDonald announced yesterday his resignation, effective tomorrow, as High Commissioner of the League of Nations for Refugees (Jewish and Others) Coming from Germany. He has served in that post a little more than two years.

HILO, Hawaii, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A fiery river of molten lava rolled slowly but relentlessly on tonight toward Hilo's municipal reservoir, despite the bombs that army airmen men dropped Friday to divert its course. The lava ceased flowing last night within three miles of the reservoir, source of this city's water supply, and residents had hoped the menace was past.

Mayor La Guardia will open the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee at 62 West Fifty-third Street next Monday, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, chairman of the committee. The first exhibition will consist of work by ten sculptors and thirtysix painters.
BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, the "fighting submarine pastor," was held under arrest in his apartment today by secret political police to prevent his preaching.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Commenting on Premier Pierre Laval's victory in the French Chamber, The London Times says that the pursuing within the framework of the League of the task of restoring peace by conciliation is unquestionably one of the two main duties of the League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -In a New Year's statement to the country, Secretary Roper predicted today that the "broadening of the recovery process" in 1935 had provided a basis "for further encouraging economic gains in 1936."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The first nine months of this year were marked by a larger comparative increase in United States import trade than for any corresponding period since 1920, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith has been named chairman of the United Hospital Fund Distribution Committee to allot funds being raised in the campaign, now in progress among the eighty-one participating hospitals, it was announced yesterday.

Accused of having threatened the family of his former employer with death unless his job was restored, Frank Wagner, 35 years old, a WPA worker, of 645 East Twelfth Street was arrested Saturday night by detectives who traced a telephone call he was making to a restaurant at 84 Third Avenue, near Twelfth Street.

The Guaranty Trust Company, in its monthly publication The Guaranty Survey, issued today, takes its stand with those bankers who doubt the wisdom of immediate action by the Federal Reserve authorities to reduce excess bank reserves.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 50 per cent of capacity for a week of five working days, down 6 points from the rate of the two weeks preceding. Only necessary production took place, units being kept off where possible because the break by the holiday increased costs.

The New Jersey Court of Pardons meets today in Trenton, N.J., and may take summary action on Bruno Richard Hauptmann's petition for clemency on his conviction as the murderer of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. It is believed likely, however, that it will do no more than fix a date for hearing of argument on the appeal and decide whether to examine the condemned man in person.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Scoring impressive victories in their semi-final matches today, James H. Van Alen and Ogden Phipps gained the right to meet for the Gold Racquet in the final of the sixteenth annual court tennis fixture at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club on New Year's morning.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County declared yesterday that the appointment of assistants to his office would be "entirely" free from the influence of Democratic County leader Frank V. Kelly.

The Authors League of America, supported by other organizations, yesterday addressed a letter to President Roosevelt protesting against what the letter characterized as the virtual collapse of the WPA program for the relief of needy writers.

James G. McDonald's letter of resignation as High Commissioner for Refugees (Jewish and Others) Coming from Germany was accompanied by an "Annex," containing a comprehensive analysis of Nazi legislation against "non-Aryans," administrative decrees and judicial decisions that have carried out this legislation, and their combined effects upon the refugee problem.

The Boys' Bureau, which provides special care for homeless and destitute boys between the ages of 16 and 21, will be aided by the performance of "Victoria Regina" with Helen Hayes in the leading role tonight at the Broadhurst Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Governor Landon of Kansas and Senator Vandenberg of Michigan are now regarded by Eastern leaders as the most formidable contenders for the Republican nomination for President.
Sixteen scientists and students of population problems joined forces yesterday with the Protestant and Jewish clergymen who recently attacked the views on birth control expressed by Cardinal Hayes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -Speaker Byrns will support proposals in Congress for a stronger air force, an Alaskan aviation base and strengthened fortifications for Hawaii.

ON THE ITALIAN FRONT LINES AT GABRE DARRE (North of Gorahai), Ethiopia, Dec. 25 (Delayed). -- War guns are quiet on the Dolo and Ogaden fronts, while the Italians await slowly advancing Ethiopian armies.

Postmaster General FARLEY is the only member of the Cabinet who can show both a surplus and a deficit for the same fiscal year. His surplus for 1934-35 amounts in round numbers to $5,000,000; his deficit to $65,000,000. Both figures appear in the annual report which he publishes this morning.
Following is the text of James G. McDonald's letter to the Secretary General of the League of Nations, resigning his post as High Commissioner for Refugees (Jewish and Others) Coming From Germany:

A 3-year-old boy, dropped from a fourth-floor window to the arms of a neighbor on the roof of a second-floor extension, was taken to Metropolitan Hospital yesterday suffering from shock and possibly a skull fracture after a rooming house fire at 111 East 103d Street.

The departure of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh from the United States was the topic of many sermons in New York churches yesterday. Preachers deplored it, found it pointing to a bad state of crime and disrespect for personal liberty and argued that it should be a warning for the future.

Compilation of the numerous trade customs and practices governing the buying and selling of cotton textiles into a booklet form, titled "Worth Street Rules," was announced here yesterday by a joint committee representing eleven manufacturing and buying associations.

Price trends in the commodity futures markets here last week were largely insignificant, partly because of holiday trading apathy and partly because of the indeterminate statistical position of certain more active staples. On the cash markets, wheat, cotton, lard, silk, antimony and tin were lower, while corn, rye, oats, dairy products, hides, wool tops, cocoa and rubber advanced.

Samuel Strauss, 74 years old, a wealthy wholesale butcher, was injured critically last night during an assault in which he was robbed of $1,700 in cash and a gold watch as he opened the door to his threeroom suite on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Alden, 225 Central Park West, near Eighty-third Street.

In a discordant world the calendar, as has been said, is a "miracle of unanimity." All the peoples of the earth, whatever their local customs of reckoning, have to bring themselves in their relations with one another to the same planetary calculator and "common arbitrator."
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The Rangers staged a savage battle on the Stadium ice tonight, but faltered in the final period to take a 3-to-1 beating from the Black Hawks before 15,500 spectators.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 30. -- As the Lindberghs, aboard the American Importer, near these shores, the newspaper space devoted to them is increasing enormously. That is, in all newspapers except The London Times, which has only a small Dublin dispatch about the Irish interest in the matter on one of the back pages.

President Roosevelt will be on the firing line in the campaign for his re-election, according to the present plans of his supporters, it was learned yesterday, and will personally take the stump in defense of his policies and in an appeal for the support of the voters of the nation.

Certainly both Greek and German should he studied in our high schools, and the neglect of these languages at the present time is a serious reflection on American education. Exception should be taken, moreover, to several of the points made by Dr. Stephen G. Rich in his letter to THE TIMES.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Statistics are lackin from many directions to give a detailed picture of the state of trade in 1935, but the Board of Trade index of industrial production for the first nine months of the year clearly indicates the progressive nature of the recovery.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 29. -- The Federation of Electrical Workers' Unions voted today for the second time to strike on Jan. 18 unless General Plutarco Elias Calles, former "iron man" of Mexico, left the country.

A goal by Sammy Babcock scored midway through the final chapter proved the deciding factor in giving the New York Rovers a 3-to-2 triumph over the fast-skating Atlantic City Sea Gulls at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A record of its work in placing the security Exchanges of the country under Federal control and the assertion that the Securities Act of 1933 had been so administered that many of the original objections to its severity were eliminated, with hundreds of millions of dollars of issues marketed, were presented in the first annual report to Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public today.

The WPA is emancipating boys and girls -- and grown-ups, too -- from the tyranny of spinach, it was revealed yesterday. By the joint efforts of the Department of Public Markets and a group of WPA research workers employed under its sponsorship, cardoon, seaweeds and yantia are being introduced as tasty substitutes for the healthful but much-hated vegetable.

Instead of making the world safe for democracy, which he called "a dream, anyway," we should endeavor to make the world safe for the persons who live in it, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of the St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eightysixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

On the glassy, steel-gray surface of the frozen Van Cortlandt Park Lake, the first Winter Sports Carnival of the Bronx was held yesterday afternoon, despite a biting wind and a temperature that was well below the comfort point.

William Ziegler Jr., chairman of the Progressive Republican State Committee, made formal announcement yesterday that the campaign in this State for the election of delegates favorable to the nomination of Senator William E. Borah of Idaho for President would be opened on Jan. 28, when Senator Borah will speak at Kismet Temple, Brooklyn.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29. -A little more than twenty-four hours after the death here of Miss Elizabeth A. Clare at the age of 92, her sister, Mrs. Amelia R. Lockwood, with whom she had lived for thirty years, died tonight at her home, 162 Park Avenue. Mrs. Lockwood was 81.

VIENNA, Dec. 29. -- A change is taking place in the type of material published in the Austrian press about Italy which, in view of the complete government control of the press, seems suggestive of a forthcoming change in Austrian policy.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The financial markets here at the year-end are cheerfully facing many problems confronting them. These difficulties are mainly international, therefore less easy of assessment and approach than the purely domestic affairs calling for settlement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A Ship Subsidy Bill embodying the recommendations of President Roosevelt in his message of March 4 will be introduced by Senator Copeland immediately after the convening of Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (AP). -College football stars of the 1935 season, who will clash here New Year's Day in the annual East-West charity game, dug their cleats into the turf today in final intensive workouts.

The Living Church, a weekly periodical published in Milwaukee, takes issue with the American Committee of the Church Unity Octave Council which sent circular letters to 1,500 Protestant Episcopal clergymen urging a union with the Roman Catholic Church.
Sixty-four gifts, totaling $436.80, were received for the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 29. -Only two games were completed in the third round of the international masters tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club today. Three others were adjourned and will be played off later.

"Blessed are the meek, for they shall possess the land." Happy are the slum dwellers, for a way has been found to house them in apartments costing $2,243 a room, for which they need only pay between $6 and $7 a month.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29. -- Every form of production in Russia today, from galoshes to locomotives, is at a startlingly high level, with one important exception: vodka. Short of caviar, there is nothing so Russian as vodka -- except perhaps the Volga boat song -- and vodka production is dropping.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, Tracy H. Lewis captured the highover-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Four gunners, each with a full card, tied for the handicap prize, E. B. Horwath taking the extra string.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The hog shortage last Summer changed the nation's meat-eating habits this year, William W. Woods, president of the Institute of American Meat Packers, declared in his review of the packing industry today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29. -The American bobsled team engaged in its final workout today prior to its departure on Friday for the fourth Olympic Winter Games on the snow slopes of the Bavarian Alps next February. Although the tricky Mount Van Hoevenberg slide, the Olympic run in 1932, was open only from the halfway mark, it was in speedy condition and provided a true test.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The Potato Act of 1935 was branded as "flagrantly unconstitutional" by the national lawyers' committee of the American Liberty League in a report issued today.

A racket that cost automobile owners in this State more than $2,500,000 in the last three years, according to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., was ended with the arrest of six men and a woman at 6 o'clock yesterday morning at their homes here on charges of fraudulent sale of insurance and memberships in fake automobile clubs.

That the morale of the nation is being destroyed, that people do not know how to order their lives because they do not know what to expect from the government, and that all of this can be traced directly back to a lack of faith in religion, was the substance of the sermon given yesterday by the Rev. George J. Russell, pastor, in the Second Presbyterian Church at Ninety-sixth Street near Central Park West.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Albert J. (Al) Prignano, State Representative of the Seventeenth district and Democratic committeeman of the Twentieth Ward here, known as the "Bloody Twentieth," was shot to death late tonight by three gunmen on the doorstep of his home as he returned with his family from a party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A workers' insurance bill, which, if enacted, would call for an immediate appropriation of $5,000,000,000, will be introduced in the Senate by Senator Frazier, Progressive Republican, of North Dakota.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29. -- With scores of eminent professors of philosophy in attendance, the Eastern division of the American Philosophical Association met here today under the auspices of Johns Hopkins University.

The Willard Gibbs Medal of the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society for 1936 has been awarded Professor Roger Adams, head of the chemistry department at the University of Illinois, it was announced yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Play in the junior and boys' national indoor tennis championships will be continued this morning at the Seventh Regiment Armory with the singles quarter-finals in both divisions as the feature attractions on today's schedule.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- "The reign of law" in labor relations between the railroads and most of their million employes is responsible for the lack of strikes in that industry, according to the first annual report of the National Mediation Board.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- No League of Nations document since the report of its Manchurian committee has attracted so much attention in Britain as that regarding the condition of Jews in Germany which came yesterday from James G. McDonald as his final blast on giving up his post as High Commissioner for Refugees.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30. -Harry Cooper, aided by four birdies, added a par 71 to his 66 of the first round to hold the lead today through the second round of the Pasadena $4,000 open golf tournament.

Nine Manhattan properties and fourteen Bronx parcels were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Two scheduled Manhattan sales were adjourned and a Bronx offering was withdrawn. Apartment houses, dwellings and business buildings were among the properties put on the block. Thirteen banks were among the plaintiffs.
Capitalism has "grown middle-aged," Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, declared in an address here yesterday.
Local Republican leaders took steps yesterday to check the movement to elect delegates in this State favorable to the nomination of Senator William E. Borah, of Idaho.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Following the advice of Congressional leaders, President Roosevelt was planning tonight to deliver his annual message to Congress Saturday and his message on the budget on Monday, thus starting the session off with a rush which they hoped might set the pace toward a Spring adjournment.

The share market completed the final day of the year but one in a cheerful mood. Prices moved substantially higher, particularly in the last hour when nearly one-third of the day's business was done. A large percentage of the day's transactions consisted of cash sales to establish records for income-tax purposes.

Low temperatures bolstered the demand for Winter goods in the local stores yesterday and held the usual between-holiday reaction down to a minimum. Clearance events received good consumer attention and the general report on store stocks was that they were in notably clean shape.

Contradictory trends are disclosed by a review of the electric light and power industry for 1935, according to Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Edison Electric Institute and of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey.

New York City's light bill, having already been cut $2,000,000 below the 1934 total, will show a further saving of $165,000 next year, it was said yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- There are many more important things in the world than the proffer and refusal of the White House invitation to Alfred E. Smith to be a guest of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt while, on ,,Jan. 25, he is here conspicuously lending aid and comfort to the enemy.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Balls for debutantes, festivities at clubs and celebrations at hotels will mark the coming of a new year in this city.
BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- Activity on the Boerse today was, as usual, limited. Such quotations as were made, however, mostly showed firmness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A national plan of unemployment compensation for the transportation industry capable of raising $72,000,000 annually for average benefit payments of $140 to at least 470,000 claimants by 1938 is being drafted in the office of Joseph B. Eastman, Coordinator of Transportation, for presentation to Congress.
