ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A major Ethiopian offensive leading to the most severe fighting since the Italo-Ethiopian war broke out was predicted during the week by officials here today.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- Three young Negro children, all under the age of 6 years, were burned to death here tonight in a fire which destroyed their home and caused the burning or injury of two other children.

The fitness of Lamar Hardy for the post of United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to which he recently was appointed by President Roosevelt will be challenged before a special meeting of the 1,500 members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on Thursday evening.

For over a century physicists have been measuring the amount of heat with which the sun bathes the earth. About 5,000 horsepower beats upon each acre. All the energy now generated by coal, oil and falling water in the country is only half what Arizona might furnish if there were engines of but 10 per cent efficiency.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30. -- Beaurivage was the setting today for a large tea dance which Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger gave for the younger set in honor of her daughter, Miss Dana Maher. Guests included the Misses Shirley Bell, Althea Tevander, Emmaline Moody, Harriet and Marion Morgan, Katherine Wait, Clara Floyer Giover, Gracia Florence and Dorothy Underhill.

Bo Sheppard was both athletic director and basketball coach at North Carolina a year ago and he found the double job a bit onerous. So Sheppard, the athletic director, fired Sheppard, the coach, and now he wanders around the country with no other court concern than acting as scout.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The Metropolitan Opera Association will give its third performance here Jan. 21, when it presents Puccini's "Madame Butterfly" at the Mosque Theatre. The announcement was made today by L. Bamberger Co., which is underwriting the production.

Rufus Daniel Isaacs, first Marquess of Reading, had one of the most varied and distinguished careers in the history of British law, State and diplomacy. By sheer ability, personality and energy he rose to heights in national and international spheres attained by few.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Although Westchester pays more than most other comparable communities in the country for police and fire protection, and has manpower in these departments equivalent to that of the most advanced municipalities, it is not receiving a proper return for its investment and at some points the protection is far from what it should be, according to the Institute of Public Administration.

ROME, Dec. 30. -- Premier Benito Mussolini tried today to calm the growing impatience with which Italians contemplate the inactivity of their army in East Africa, which has remained in its present position for almost two months.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30. -- President Agustin P. Justo announced today that he had accepted the resignations of three Cabinet Ministers, including Federico Pinedo, Finance Minister. The others are Luis Duhau, Minister of Agriculture, and Manuel De Iriondo, Minister of Justice and Public Instruction.

Fusion control of the city school system became an accomplished fact at 6:25 P.M. yesterday, when Ellsworth B. Buck, Mayor La Guardia's fourth appointee to the Board of Education, took his seat at a special meeting of the board at 500 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The filing of thirteen additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1932, involving issues amounting to $33,833,824 was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Among the issues were seven by industrial of commercial concerns, aggregating $7,528,750.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Rufus Daniel Isaacs, the Marquess of Reading, a cabin boy who rose to become Lord Chief Justice of England and Viceroy of India, died peacefully at his London home this afternoon at the age of 75.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- If the Court of Pardons finds Bruno Richard Hauptmann "completely guilty" of the kidnap-murder of the Lindbergh baby, he will not, in the opinion of Governor Harold G. Hoffman, be entitled to mercy. Under the State Constitution, the Governor must vote with a majority of the court in order to set aside a death sentence.
Mr. and Mrs. Morrill Goddard gave a dinner dance in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre last night to introduce their daughter, Miss Rowena Goddard. Spring flowers were used in the decorations.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The tone was firm today on the Stock Exchange here, although the volume of business was slight. British Government securities closed strong, while French bonds rose sharply on Premier Laval's victory on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- "More time to think" is all that Mrs. Roosevelt asks of the New Year. It does not amount to a resolution, rather a hope, voiced somewhat hesitantly, in response to a question asked at her press conference today.

For the eighth time, Miss Maribel Y. Vinson of the Skating Club of Boston became the women's figure skating champion of the United States, when the results of the competition were announced last night at the Winter sports carnival at Madison Square Garden.

If any one asks for evidence that Great Britain keeps a career open for talents, it will be necessary only to point him to the life of Lord READING, who died yesterday. From the humblest beginnings he rose to the highest positions, and did it by sheer native ability, unflinching industry and force of character.

Let it be said at the outset Marian Anderson has returned to her native land one of the great singers of our time. The Negro contralto who has been abroad for four years established herself in her concert at the Town Hall last night as the possessor of an excelling voice and art.

Reorganization of the Board of Aldermen for the next two years proceeded yesterday with the selection of leaders by the Democratic members and the selection of important administrative officials of the board.

A nation hasn't any better idea of what it can accomplish in several years than an individual has of what he can do in the next twenty-four hours, according to Dr. P.A. Sorokin, Professor of Sociology at Harvard University.

HAROLD RIEGELMAN, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, has signalized his return to New York from a brief sojourn among the alphabetical agencies at Washington by showing how the city can save no less than $3,000,000 a year, or an aggregate of $45,000,000 during the next fifteen years, by properly conserving its water supply.

Lester Patrick's New York Rangers ring down the curtain on the old year tonight in Madison Square Garden with a chance to gain undisputed possession of first place in the American division of the National Hockey League.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 30. -- Subsidization of college athletes was condemned today by a committee of the National Student Federation in convention here.
" Strike Me Pink," Eddie Cantor's sixth annual musical film for Samuel Goldwyn, will have its premiere on Thursday, Jan. 16, at Radio City Music Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Dec. 24 shows decreases for the week of $31,000,000 in total loans and investments, $58,000,000 in demand deposits (adjusted), and $26,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $15,000,000 in time deposits.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs led the heaviest scoring week-end in the National Hockey League this season, when thirty-eight goals were fired home in five matches, and the Leafs' feat of getting nine goals in one game was fully reflected tonight in the league's weekly scoring statistics.

A toll of two dead and many persons hurt was claimed yesterday by the five-inch snowfall that ended at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, leaving the city in the grip of freezing weather that promised, according to the Weather Bureau, a fair and cold New Year's Eve.

The Truline Realty Corporation, Irving Smith, attorney, has sold to Frances Greenaway a brownstone dwelling at 5 East 128th Street for a reported price of $7,200, the buyer paying $1,500 cash. A first mortgage is held by the Harlem Savings Bank.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30. -- Instantaneous relief from angina pectoris, the most painful form of heart disease, by the simple and assertedly harmless method of inhaling a chloroformlike drug, was reported today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

New York City's credit, measured by the percentage of unpaid taxes and reduction in both the short-term and the funded debt, is better now than it has been at any time in the last five years, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday.

Reports of earnings in November which have been issued to date by the railroads indicate that the carriers had a net income of $8,200,000 in that month, against one of $32,000,000 in October and against net losses of $12,124,848 in November, 1934, and $5,116,463 in November, 1933.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith denounced as unqualifiedly "false" yesterday a press report ascribed to a "spokesman for the President" asserting that Mr. Smith had declined other invitations to be an overnight guest at the White House before he refused to accept a bid in connection with his visit to Washington on Jan. 25 to address the American Liberty League.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Hickory Lad, a 4-year-old gelding good enough to win eight of his thirty-two starts last year, came through with his first victory of 1935 today when he carried the silks of the Saddle Spur Stable to the front in the one and one-sixteenth mile feature at the Fair Grounds.

A gift of $50,000 from Felix M. Warburg over a period of ten years to the Corporation of the American Schools of Oriental Research was announced last night by Dr. Millar Burrows of Yale University, president of the board of trustees of the corporation.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- With the New York Legislature preparing to enter upon one of its most momentous sessions of recent years, there is widespread speculation and keen curiosity here regarding the coming annual message of Governor Lehman.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- The growing tension between Germany and Lithuania has caused so much anxiety in London that today the British Government felt it necessary to intervene in Berlin.
THE snow was falling steadily outside and the apple logs were burning brisky in the big open fireplace. Herr Frisch of the St. Louis Cardinals tipped back in his chair and said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Of the $12,456,262,000 net income for the 1934 calendar year taxable by the government, only .001 per cent of the returns reflected incomes of $1,000,000 or over, while but .45 per cent of net income was reported by those in the million-income class, an analysis by the Treasury showed today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Making a strong showing in the tricky slalom race, the Dartmouth College skiers gained a slim edge over their perennial rivals from McGill University in the competition for the President Harding Trophy, emblematic of the team prize, as the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds fifteenth annual intercollegiate Winter sports carnival got under way today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30. -- More than 150 men and women philosophers heard Dr. Morris E. Cohen of the College of the City of New York use the rolling dice and tossed penny today to prove his contention on absolutism. He was speaking at the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Association's Eastern division.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A warning to all motor carriers, common and contract, that they must apply by Feb. 12 next for certificates of public convenience and necessity or lose valuable rights and risk heavy fines for operating without them, was issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

While the American Olympic Committee is undergoing a "house-cleaning" to rid the organization of any members not in full sympathy with United States participation in the 1936 games at Berlin, a new counter movement to keep Uncle Sam's athletes out of the international sports carnival was started yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Boston tonight welcomed the hard-hitting, home-run king of the American League, Jimmy Foxx, the new, high-priced, pennant hope of the Red Sox.

Three thousand children from twenty-one orphanages in Greater New York attended their second annual "year-end" theatre party at the Roxy yesterday morning as guests of Mr. and Mrs. I.J. Fox. The young guests, chosen for the party by the Welfare Council of New York, were conveyed to the theatre in a fleet of fifty-seven motor buses.
Article V of the Constitution sets no limitation on the power of Congress to propose amendments after 1808, except that no State can be deprived, without its consent, of equal suffrage in the Senate.

Transferring from Washington to this city its hearings into the activities of committees for holders of foreign bonds, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday pressed its inquiry into the Colombian Government bond issues. A second session will be held today at the New York offices of the commission, 120 Broadway.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Rainy weather, looming for the East-West football game here New Year's Day, will aid the Eastern cause, in the opinion of Coach Andy Kerr.

Automobile manufacturers in the United States produced cars and trucks to the wholesale value of $2,186,400,000 in 1935, according to a report, "Preliminary Facts and Figures About the Automobile Industry During 1935," issued yesterday by Alfred Reeves, vice president and general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

Herbert A. Burgtorf, 45 years old, of 45 Fifth Avenue, Pelham, N.Y., one of the two men indicted last Friday by the New York County grand jury on charges of grand larceny of $11,400 from six job applicants, was arrested yesterday at the Y.M.C.A. in Mount Vernon by Detective Louis Decker of Attorney General Bennett's Bureau of Securities.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A carnival atmosphere gripped New Orleans today as one Sugar Bowl football team arrived on the scene and the other put on finishing touches for the New Year's Day classic at its home camp in Baton Rouge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The crisis between the Maritime Federation of the Pacific, steering group of four marine unions dominated by Harry Bridges, left wing longshoremen's leader, and Pacific Coast shipowners has reached such a point that Department of Labor officials feared today three new possibilities, namely:

The Theatre Guild has now settled the matter of its last production of the year. It will offer, in mid-March and after a brief tour, "Idiot's Delight," a new play by Robert E. Sherwood. In it will be Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne and the former is to direct.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Europe's first strike of air mail pilots threatens to cripple the service of the Royal Dutch Airline next Wednesday, it was learned here tonight, unless an eleventh-hour settlement can be patched up.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The Stacy-Trent Hotel here decided today to prosecute Caleb Milne 4th for failure to pay a bill of $15.80. New Jersey law fixes a penalty of one to three years in prison, a fine not to exceed $1,000, or both, for defrauding a hotel.

After a heated argument bristling with charges of unconstitutionality and "amazing insolence," Supreme Court Justice William Harmon Black reserved decision yesterday in the suit to restrain Mayor La Guardia and other city officials from enforcing the artichoke ban against the Union Pacific Produce Company.

ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Rulings affecting the new unincorporated business income tax were issued today by the State Tax Commission. Computation of gross income is generally parallel to that of the present personal income tax only to the extent that it is derived from a trade, business or occupation.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 30. -- Daggah Bur was again bombed today, four Italian planes dropping explosives for eight hours. Official reports indicated no loss of life, merely stating that nine bombs failed to explode.

A three-months provisional contract, permitting the use in radio programs of music controlled by the Warner group of publishing firms, has been sent to independent broadcasters, it was announced yesterday. The group of firms, which controls the music of Victor Herbert, Jerome Kern, George Gershwin and other composers, recently withdrew from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, because of dissatisfaction over royalties received from radio stations.

BERLIN, Dec. 30. -- One of the many veils shielding the creation of the new German war fleet has been lifted with publication of the German Naval Manual, carrying pictures and some details of a new type of naval fighting craft, the first of which was put into commission this month.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Harvard's fast-skating hockey team went on a scoring rampage tonight in defeating Clarkson Tech, 5-1, at the Olympic Arena to bring about a 1 -- all tie in their three-game series, which is part of the college week sports program at Lake Placid.

Wagner's sovereign tone-poem, "Tristan und Isolde," returned to the repertory last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. An immense audience, which had purchased the seating capacity of the theatre days in advance of the event, listened absorbed to the miraculous music.

A new wage contract to replace that which has been effective in the last year for sailors on merchant ships operating from Atlantic Coast ports was submitted yesterday afernoon by a committee of the International Seamen's Union to the American Steamship Owners Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Postmaster General Farley declared tonight that neither Hoover nor Borah can win the Republican nomination for President, and suggested that the "political lightweights" of the "minority party shake dice or shoot craps" for it.

American shipyards will start the news year in a stronger position than they have had in the last five years, according to the annual survey completed by Marine Engineering and Shipping Review. Under construction today is 459,671 tons, 65 per cent more than the tonnage reported under way a year ago.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday made the award of two new issues of serial bonds, aggregating $3,650,000, to separate banking groups. A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and including Brown Harriman Co., Inc. Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and F. S. Moseley Co. won the award of the issue of $2,000,000 of emergency public works bonds, maturin. from 1936 to 1945, on a bid of 1,. 714 for ls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- A personal letter has been sent by President Roosevelt to Gifford Pinchot in reply to the former Pennsylvania Governor's charge that Federal Work Relief in Pennsylvania "has been sold into political bondage."

The Roessler Hasslacher Chemical Company, now out of existence, must pay Zimmerman Forshay, foreign exchange bankers, $332,812 for not carrying out a contract for German marks made in 1917 but which could not be fulfilled until after the war, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

The Transit Commission, before which the City of New York must apply for permission to carry out its plan to raze the Sixth Avenue elevated line, expressed itself yesterday through its counsel, John J. Curtin, as being opposed to such a move.

Mrs. Edith Hoadley Durkee, widow of Richard P.H. Durkee, member of a prominent New York family, left an estate valued at $1,148,541 gross and $1,054,301 net, according to a non-resident transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Durkee, who died on July 17, 1934, left $160,000 to charitable and religious organizations.

Closer cooperation by large trade groups in support of current social legislation may prevent more drastic legislation in the future, according to Glenn B. Bowers, director of unemployment insurance in this State, who discussed various phases of this topic yesterday at a luncheon of the Trade Association Executives held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- A suspect was halted tonight by gunfire as he fled detectives raiding his home in their search for the killers of State Representative Albert J. Prignano. The suspect, Angelo Lazzia, fell and wrenched his knee as a police bullet knocked his hat off and he was caught outside his door.

With a holiday tomorrow and decisions from the United States Supreme Court expected on next Monday, narrow trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange held fluctuations within a few points. The close was unchanged to a gain of 4 points. Steadiness in Liverpool and strength of the stock market imparted a firm undertone, with limited pressure and ample purchasing power for all the contracts offered.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP).-New York State may rival New England and Europe this year as a Winter sports center, it was indicated tonight by Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner. Miles of new ski trails in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains now are ready, he announced, after intensive work by Civilian Conservation Corps and Conservation Department workers.

LIVERPOOL, Tuesday, Dec. 31 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his family arrived off Gladstone Dock here on board the steamer American Importer at 7:30 o'clock this morning (2:30 A.M. New York time). For some unexplained reason the vessel missed the tide after having waited in midstream off New Brighton all night for its change, and hence she will be unable to reach the dock before 11 A.M.

New York's WPA theatre program drew nearer to its first premiere yesterday when Elmer Rice, regional director, announced that he had arranged to lease the Biltmore Theatre, in West Forty-seventh Street, and Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre.
ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A tense feeling that big events are impending was apparent tonight after a month of the sharpest fighting since the start of the Italo-Ethiopian war.

Declaring that about 10,000 wild ducks are facing death from starvation as a result of the complete freeze-up in Great South Bay, John Miles Flynn, president of the Nassau Chapter of the Izaak Walton League, yesterday issued a plea to sportsmen and other wildlife enthusiasts to help feed the birds through the critical period.

BUFFALO, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Roland E. Markell, a Rochester messenger of 21, today confessed the authorship of letters demanding $250,000 from Frank E. Gannett, the publisher of a group of newspapers, and Louis A. Wehle, a Rochester brewer.

The azure wings of Osbert, Central Park's foundling peacock, will be clipped soon in an effort to counteract the wanderlust which periodically takes him on a sight-seeing tour over the rooftops of Central Park South.

As a sort of sentimental gesture at the close of an alert year John Golden has taken an old plot out of mothballs and put it on the stage of his own theatre. "Tomorrow's a Holiday!" is the exclamatory title chosen; Leo Perutz, who once wrote "A Trip to Pressburg," and Hans Adler are the authors; our own mischievous Romney Brent adapted it, and the whole thing was cautiously unveiled last evening.
Confirmation by the United States District Court of the plan of reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation was announced yesterday by Stuart Hedden, chairman of the reorganization committee.

Covering the court with a swiftness and agility that his favored opponent was unable to match, Robert L. Madden, a junior at the University of Pittsburgh, eliminated Marvin Wachman of Northwestern University, the second seeded player in the junior singles, to provide the lone upset in the national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.
Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets in New York County, revealed yesterday that eighteen convicted loan sharks had filed appeals. All are serving terms.

A happy new year was assured yesterday for two of the Neediest Cases that still awaited help when two large gifts provided the amounts needed for Cases 412, "Too Good," and 417, "All They Once Had Is Gone," which were published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday.

Construction work on ten new schools, all being built with PWA money, has been tied up by a strike of seventy-five electricians called by the Electrical Workers Union. The projects involve an expenditure of $14,000,000. Several hundred workers have been compelled to stop work because of the walkout.

MADRID, Dec. 30. -- Governments form and fall frequently under the second Spanish Republic. The Cabinet of Manuel Portela, organized sixteen days ago, resigned today, making the sixth crisis this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- A sharp advance in the price of fresh pork loins imparted considerable strength to offerings of lightweight hogs here today. Prices were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher compared with Saturday's levels, but hogs weighing over 250 pounds were inclined to drag and generally showed slight losses compared with Saturday and were around 25 cents lower compared with Friday's average.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Great Britain's industrial revival on the eve of the new year is shown in the December figures of the Ministry of Labor, announced tonight. The number of unemployed dropped by 49,997 to 1,868,565, while the insured persons employed increased 62,000 to 10,599,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Leading all the way in a thrilling game, Temple University defeated the Purdue quintet at the Arena tonight, 54 to 39, before 5,500 fans.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- To see well in the dark one should eat plenty of carrots and tomatoes, Dr. Marston T. Bogert, Professor of Organic Chemistry at Columbia University, said today.

Generally firmer prices in active trading were the rule on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Cocoa and copper were easier. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, rubber, silk and raw sugar advanced, while lard made a new low.

ATHENS, Dec. 30. -- Italian forces nearly equal to those held by Great Britain in Egypt have been quietly concentrated in the Dodecanese Islands this month, it is learned here by secret courier from the islands.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 30. -- The city hereafter will put out municipal scrip with no interest, according to a decision today by the City Commission.

Luigi Lucioni is not a frequent one-man exhibitor. His show at the Ferargil Galleries, which opened yesterday, is the first in two or three seasons, although of course examples of his work have been included in many of the large group exhibitions since last he gave a solo performance.

An innovation in aldermanic practices was introduced yesterday by James J. Paretti, Alderman-elect of the Long Island City district, when he hung on the wall of his clubhouse at 38-62 Eleventh Street, Ravenswood, Queens, a large gold-lettered sign that read:

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 30. -- Four of the five games an the fourth round, in addition to two adjourned games from the third, were decided in the international masters tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club today.

" DEAR ANNE HIRST." "Dear Dorothy Dix." "Dear Miss Lonelihearts." Day by day the baskets marked "incoming mall" on the desks of these bland Mother Confessors to the American public are filled with plaintive bleats from people who don't want help so much as they want a sympathetic pat on the head. Josephine Lawrence, household editor of The Newark Sunday Call, has seen her fair share of these piteous missives.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30. -- The fifth race headed today's card at Tropical Park and resulted in a surprise triumph for the Texas invader Red Roamer, Jockey Jimmy Lynch, who recently arrived from the Lone Star State, completed a double astride the $14.80-for-$2 shot, which scored with ease by two lengths over J.E. Smallman's heavily favored Ilchester.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- New methods for artificially accelerating the evolution of plants were discussed here today at the opening session of the thirty-third annual meeting of the American Society of Zoologists at Princeton University, Other recent scientific developments also were discussed before the 300 zoologists, geneticists and cellular physiologists from all sections of the country attending the three-day convention.
The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent for the common stock of the White Motor Company.

A country-wide police search was started yesterday for ten members of the gang of nineteen indicted in Manhattan and Queens on charges of having obtained $2,500,000 from motorists in this State by the fraudulent sale of insurance and memberships in fake automobile clubs.

In a setting of Spring flowers, ferns and palms, Count and Countess Alphonso P. Villa of 18 East Seventy-second Street and Fairholme, Newport, gave a dinner dance last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for their debutante daughter, Miss Elena Villa.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 30. -- The Canadian National Railways, Canada's largest industry, with $2,000,000,000 in physical assets, and one of the largest railway systems in the world, is to be reorganized by the Mackenzie King government. An objection to "remote control" of an organization to whose deficits the Canadian Government annually contributes $50,000,000 from the public treasury was registered recently by the new Minister of Transportation, C.D. Howe.
Despite the periodical public effort to reduce the number of automobile accidents, can any considerable result be achieved so long as the tap-dance method of speed control prevails?

MINEOLA, L.I, Dec. 30. -- A charter revision report, recommending the creation of several new county departments and the establishment of a new district court system to replace village justices of the peace, was submitted to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today by the Committee on Governmental Revision.

PARIS, Dec. 30. -- Premier Pierre Laval's statement during his speech to the Chamber of Deputies Saturday that consultations had taken place between the British and the French general staffs regarding measures that should be taken in fulfillment of Article XVI of the Covenant of the League of Nations in case British vessels were attacked by Italy left a widespread impression that a full agreement had been reached.

Americans may be a bit hasty in distributing epithets like Communist and Red, but we are not really so bad as some of our British visitors imagine. One well-known English critic, arriving here to deliver a series of lectures in the colleges, told the ship reporters that the Left Wing of the Conservative party is now dominant in England.

Ding Palmer and Mike Baldwin will not play on the American Olympic hockey team in the fourth Winter Olympic games at Garmisch-Partenkirchen in February, it was announced by Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP). -- A "harmony conference," designed to replace the bitter competition between railroad and motor carriers with peaceful cooperation was held here today under the auspices of Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator.

On page 223 of "The Greatest Pages of Charles Dickens," by Stephen Leacock, I read: "He spoke in the greater cities of the East * * * in Brooklyn they lay out all night on mattresses waiting for a chance to buy tickets."
Proposals to change the name of the Sharon Steel Hoop Company to the Sharon Steel Corporation and to revise its capitalization will be voted upon by the shareholders on Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to commit itself on the course pursued by the Western Pacific Railroad in authorizing the purchase of $3,900,000 of equipment without providing definitely for the financing of the transaction.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30. -- The Princeton University hockey team fell before the University of Minnesota tonight, 3 to 1. Last-minute goals in the first and third periods were fatal to the cause of the Eastern team, which put up a stubborn fight.

Julius F. Newman, Ex-President of Association, Disciplined for Retaining a Client's Money. Julius F. Newman, former president of the Queens County Bar Association, has been suspended for six months by the Appellate Division in a ruling made known yesterday. The court's opinion, written by Presiding Justice Francis Martin, held Mr. Newman had failed to "safely keep" moneys collected for the account of a client. The moneys have now been paid in full to the client.

In order to assure a "united front," the American Olympic Committee has just decided to get rid of every member who does not agree with the majority. A canvass of the membership is to be made, demanding hearty support of the committee's policies, or else a letter of resignation.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 30. -- The part liver plays in the unseen manufacture of red blood cells that dispel anemia was described tonight by Dr. George H. Whipple, dean of the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, to the 500 chemists gathered here for a three-day organic chemistry symposium.
With the worst behind them -- even in the weather -- New Yorkers prepared yesterday for their most expansive New Year's Eve celebration since the carefree days when "whoopee" was a common word.

Effectively screened from passersby by a frost-covered window, two armed robbers looted a jewelry store at 200 West Forty-ninth Street at 10:30 A.M. yesterday. They escaped with merchandise pawned for about $20,000 and having a retail value of at least three times that.

Joey Ferrando, Jersey City light-weight, did a lot of fighting against Steve Halaiko, Buffalo, in his Manhattan debut last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, but after the final bell he learned his willing work was all in vain.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP). -- Cinder path stars competing in the first Sugar Bowl track and field meet today in near-freezing temperatures hung up five new Southern records in a brilliant display of speed before 3,500 shivering fans.

Nearly 900 children had an opportunity to try out their school fire drills about 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when they were forced to hurry out of a Bronx moving picture theatre when smoke from a fire in an adjoining building filled the place. Their orderly exodus was nearly spoiled, however, when some of the more mercenary of them thought to stop at the boxoffice to try and get their money back.

The preliminary draft of a constitution for the permanent organization of the Investment Bankers Conference Committee was discussed yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the group's executive committee presided over by B. Howell Griswold Jr., chairman. The draft was referred to a subcommittee to effect some of the changes suggested at the meeting.

The letter of MacDonald Peters in defense of the aliens in this country is of interest, as it evidently gives the views of an alien who has been here for ten years enjoying the protection of our laws and making a living or he would have returned long ago to his own country, although under our kindly laws he could be on relief.

ON BOARD THE MOTOR SHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 30 (by Wireless). -- It now seems impossible to lay a depot at Charcot Island before proceeding to the Ross Sea in search off Lincoln Ellsworth and his pilot, Herbert Hollick-Kenyon.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30. -- A psychological analysis of what may be termed the "American soul," through a critical study of what the American people buy with their income, was presented here tonight at the opening general session of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in the presidential address of Dr. Edward L. Thorndike of Teachers College, Columbia University, retiring president of the association.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30. -- Southern Methodist and Stanford football players kept a weather eye on the skies today. There was a threat of rain in the air for their intersectional clash at the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

In coming to the last day of the old year and approaching the first day of the new there should be a moment for every one in which to think of what one would do in the inner man if it were the last day of life, and another moment in which to behold the world as if one had come in maturity to see it and its heavens for the first time.

A special panel of eighty talesmen for the Druckman case will meet in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, Monday morning. From them will be selected the twenty-three members of the special grand jury to investigate the circumstances surrounding the murder of Samuel Druckman, garage worker, and the murder itself.

A Special Statutory Court composed of Federal Judges Martin S. Manton, Augustus N. Hand and John C. Knox signed yesterday an order temporarily restraining the Federal Communications Commission from forcing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and other telephone companies from putting into effect tomorrow a new system of accounting as ordered by the commission.

With Congress about to reconvene, and the stage set for the President's budget message, the Treasury's statements reveal the salient facts in the fiscal position of the Government at the year's end. It will close its books tonight on the six months' period July-to-December with a deficit of about $1,550,000,000, exclusive of debt reduction.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, at the urging of Governor Lehman, sent a request last night to the Board of Estimate for a special $50,000 appropriation with which to retain an outside "skilled prosecutor" to try the remaining indictments against officers or directors of four defunct title mortgage companies on charges that they violated the State Insurance Laws.

Details of a 1,000 per cent write-up in the value of a power plant owned by the Rockland Light and Power Company were spread upon the record of the Mack utility investigating committee yesterday at a hearing at the committee's headquarters, 10 East Fortieth Street.

In spite of the "unwritten" if not unbroken law or rule of political etiquette which restrains an aspirant to the nomination for President from poaching on the preserves of a Favorite Son, Mr. BORAH is being taken into Colonel FRANKLIN KNOX'S home "territory."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Senator Borah agreed today to enter the primaries in Ohio on May 12 as a Republican Presidential candidate if the political situation in that State makes it advisable.

Mayor La Guardia vetoed the city ordinance compelling display of the American flag at indoor gatherings of fifteen or more persons yesterday, with the declaration that patriotism must be "spontaneous and not legislated."
The Board of Estimate voted $8,930,000 yesterday for relief in January at the request of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The registration of 5,088 over-the-counter brokers and dealers having about 7,400 offices and 85,000 employes throughout the country will become effective on Wednesday, and of the flood of applications received only thirty-six have been denied by the commission after investigation or withdrawn while under investigation, James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, must wrestle with an international situation which Sir Samuel Hoare's resignation has done nothing to solve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Charges by the Republican Congressional Committee that Kentucky was "flooded with $42,000,000 in relief money ten days before the last November election" are refuted by the record, said Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky today in a statement issued through the Democratic National Committee.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP). -- Splashing through the water of the Miami Biltmore pool to surpass four national records today, young swimming stars again bolstered Uncle Sam's hopes for aquatic supremacy at the 1936 Olympics.

Unless THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks registers a gain of .77 point today, December will go into the record books as the month that ended the longest string of consecutive monthly advances in more than twenty-five years. The market has advanced since March and put together a string of eight successive gains.

Mayor La Guardia differed sharply yesterday with representatives of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies on what actually happened last Saturday night when six relief workers met him at his home, 1,274 Fifth Avenue.

William F.X. Geoghan will be sworn in for a second four-year term as Kings County District Attorney today at noon in his office in the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Because of the illness of County Clerk John N. Harman, his first deputy, James A. Kelly, will administer the oath.

The world silver market made further progress toward normal conditions yesterday, following its severe decline earlier in the month. In new York the quotation was unchanged at 49 3/4 cents for the fourth successive business day, while in London bar silver rose 11-16d to 22 1-16d an ounce, which was equivalent to about 49 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. -- Federal aid for American composers of serious music was advocated today by A. Walter Kramer of New York, editor of Musical America, as a means of enabling musical creation to flourish in this country.

Most of the churches, including all of the large edifices in midtown Manhattan, will hold watch-night services tonight. And in the majority of Protestant Episcopal congregations the service will be a midnight celebration of the Holy Communion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Eduardo Suarez, Mexican Secretary of the Treasury, arrived in Washington today for a conference with Secretary Morgenthau on the international silver situation. Mr. Suarez arrived later than he had planned because the storm had grounded his plane, and neither he nor Mr. Morgenthau would discuss details of the coming conversations.

The directors of the Holly Sugar Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $7 a share on the preferred stock. This payment will clear up the arrears of $5.25 a share on this issue and also provide for the current quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share due on Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Charges that the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was being dominated by powerful banking interests in New York through H.A. Scandrett, its president, were rejected today by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a decision confirming his appointment together with those of Walter J. Cummings and George I. Haight as trustees for the road in reorganization.

Several debutante parties marked the festivities of last night. Among them was the large supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. James Perin Kineon in the Roof Garden of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Charmion Vira Kineon. In a bower of white daisies combined with smilax and ferns, a contrast to the wintry scene outside, the debutante received with her mother.

Amid decorations in keeping with the holiday season -- red berries, evergreens, gilded eucalyptus and white heather -- Miss Elizabeth Mason was introduced to society at a dinner dance given last night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Waterman Mason in the ballroom of the Pierre.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- Commenting on the "stubborn resistance" of the Westchester Lighting Company to the efforts of the Public Service Commission to effect lower lighting rates in this county, the Board of Supervisors today urged the various municipali ties within the county to consider the building of public-owned power plants to obtain lower rates.

Bonds called for redemption last month before maturity made the largest total since July and greatly exceeded the amount retired in December, 1934. Last month's total of $404,044,200 compared with $219,529,000 the month before, $443,769,000 for last July and $27,391,000 for December of 1934.

Seventeen of the town's twenty-six plays will have matinees today, and so will five of the seven musicals. Some of them have their midweek matinee on Wednesday anyhow, and so the occasion can hardly be termed special. Others are moving the regular matinee day up from Thursday and omitting the usual performance tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Applications for the issuance of $3,141,811,917 of securities were filed with the Securities and Exchange mission under the Securities Act 1933 in the twelve months ended tonight. Of these, on the basis of detlled figures through Nov. 30. $2,474,517,850 became effective and were released for sale.

While predicting that today would be partly cloudy and slightly warmer, with the possibility that the temperature would rise above the freezing point for the first time since Dec. 19, the Weather Bureau made public last night some of the meteorological records of 1935.

In observance of New Year's Day all domestic, Canadian and European markets will be closed today. Banks will likewise be shut. All Canadian security exchanges and the Montreal silver market operated only a half day yesterday, while the early closing was observed here by the Coffee and Sugar, Cocoa and the Commodities Exchanges.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Lloyd Pan, Alexander Pantages's promising 2-year-old colt, was piloted home in front by three-quarters of a length at Santa Anita today in the $10,000 California Breeders' Championship Stakes of a mile.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Prime Minister Baldwin's authority as leader of the Conservative party was defied today when the local organization of that party in the Scottish constituency of Ross and Cromarty voted unanimously to disregard orders from Conservative headquarters in London to accept Malcolm MacDonald as their Parliamentary candidate in a by-election to fill a vacancy.

NINETEEN HUNDRED AND THIRTY-FIVE will long be remembered as a year witnessing unusual strides in the development of our National Aerial Defense System. Reorganization of many of our air units, more intensive training of our flying personfuel, phenomenal advancement in the performance of our equipment land the development of new air tactics made possible by this new L equipment combine to mark our progress.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31. -- Asserting that a more general interest is being taken in philosophy than the world has known before, Dr. Moritz A. Geiger of Vassar College told the Eastern Division of the American Philosophical Association today that three positive attempts are being made to solve problems confronting modern philosophies. He enumerated them as follows:
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31. -- Horton Smith, ranking golf professional from Chicago, won the annual Pasadena $4,000 open tournament today with a card of 279 for 78 holes.

THE United States Department of Labor held a series of regional conferences and one national gathering during the year on matters of labor legislation. The exchange of views between Federal and State officials and representatives of organized labor and of leading national organizations was helpful in bringing about improved conditions for wage-earners.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP). -- East and West meet on the football field tomorrow in the eleventh intersectional game played for charity -- one that will see the Eastern forces line up as 2 to 1 favorites.

The revenues collected at the Port of New York in the last year totaled $161,358,108.03, an increase of $267,683.67 over the total for 1934, according to a report issued yesterday by Henry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.
The Department of Health reported yesterday a rise of twenty-three cases of scarlet fever last week over the preceding seven days. The increase was a little more than seasonal.

Thousands of men and women in evening garb bade farewell to 1935 last night in the brilliant settings of the leading hotels and restaurants. Reservations showed it to be one of the largest New Year's Eve celebrations in recent years, far ahead of many pre-depression festivities, with champagne and liquors flowing freely.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Reports from Paris today that the British and French Governments were about to make a joint approach to Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany on the question of limitation of land and air armaments were denied by the British Foreign Office.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The National Student Federation today urged American youth not to bear arms outside the United States, adopting, at the final session of delegates from 160 American colleges and universities, a resolution offered by Columbia University delegates.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 31 (AP). -- A special investigating committee may have to be appointed to determine whether Northwestern defeated Notre Dame, 20 to 19, or the Wildcats and Ramblers battled to a 20-to-20 tie in their annual New Year's Eve basketball game.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31. -- A new "earthquake machine," which makes it possible to reproduce in the laboratory for the first time all the intricate motions of destructive earthquakes hundreds of miles below the surface of the earth was described here today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The steel industry will continue to feel the restraining effect of holiday influences until the end of this week, according to the Iron Age's weekly summary, issued yesterday. The output of finished steel has recovered somewhat from last week's rate, but steel ingot production has receded to 47 1/2 per cent of capacity, compared with 48 1/2 per cent last week, it was estimated.

TBuAlcohol Tax Unit of the reau of Internal Revenue is committed to the rigid enforcement of the laws relating to the production and tax payment of liquors to the end that the rvenue is protected, letimate dealers safeguarded, and the public assured it hat the liquor Is genuine and taxi paid.

Perhaps the sixteen gentlemen mentioned in your item headed "Scientists Appeal for Birth Control" did not all claim to be scientists: and, possibly, the summary as printed does not do full justice to their statement. For if the summary be correct, the statement is grossly unscientific.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31. -- Pasadena put the finishing touches tonight on its preparations for staging the Rose Bowl's most picturesque gridiron drama in history when Stanford for the third successive year represents the Coast Conference tomorrow, this time against Southern Methodist from Dallas, Texas.
Isidor J. Kresel, the attorney, married Mrs. Adele B. Gans, formerly of Philadelphia, in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Plans for dismissal of 1,662 more staff employes by Feb. 1 were announced yesterday by the Emergency Relief Bureau, bringing the total of staff curtailments to 4,762. The number of ERB staff employes by February will be 13,313 as compared with 18,075 on Nov. 1.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP). -- A dispute over the motion picture rights to tomorrow's Rose Bowl football game brought a threat by newsreel concerns today to boycott the game and the rose parade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The Republic of Panama has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for the permanent registration of its bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The issues covered were $3,865,000 of thirty-year 5 1/2 per cent external secured sinking fund gold bonds of 1923, due in 1953, and $11,356,000 of thirty-five year external secured sinking fund 5 per cent gold bonds, series A, of 1928, due in 1963.

New Yorkers let themselves go last night in one of the most delirious welcomes to a New Year that even the most hard-bitten Broadway veterans could recall. Happier faces, more spontaneous shouting and clamoring with noise devices, heavier spending in night clubs, hotels and barrooms seemed to reflect, beyond all doubt, a definite return of mass confidence.

The Continental Motors Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a net loss of $910,961 after depreciation, taxes and other deductions. In the preceding year the net loss was $1,977,620 after similar deductions.

Added distinction was conferred yesterday on W. Lawson Little Jr. of California, king of the amateur golfing domain, when the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States named the two-time winner of British and American links championships the outstanding athlete and sportsman for 1935.

Plans for the N.C.A.A. competition to determine representatives for the finals of the tournament at Madison Square Garden in April to select the American Olympic basketball team were announced yesterday by A.A. Schabinger, director of intercollegiate Olympic tournaments.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The Supreme Court made another surrender today to a modern demand by appointing a "press contact man," the tribunal's first in the 146 years of its existence.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The arrival of the New Year found many of the popular melodies of the day missing from the elaborate dance programs planned by the network broadcasters as their salute to 1936, since no agreement had been reached between the radio chains and the Warner Brothers, who control a string of music-publishing houses.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31. -- Baron and Baroness Jan Carel van Eck gave a large tea dance at their home, Bellora Villa, on Lake Avenue, today to present to society their daughter, Miss Agnes van Eck. Decorations in silver made an attractive setting for the dance room.

Headed by the five members of the American Olympic team and one or more of the Canadian color-bearers, more than 150 speed-skating stars will participate in the seventeenth annual Middle Atlantic outdoor championships today at Newburgh, N.Y.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP). -- Two world and five American swimming marks fell today, final day of the fourth annual Miami- Biltmore meet, with young Adolph Kiefer of Chicago and Miss Erna Kompa of New York's famed Kompa sisters sharing honors.

Largely because of pay cuts and enforced retirements at the age of 70, the first two years of the La Guardia administration showed as many employes retired as had retired in the preceding twelve years combined, the New York City Employes' Retirement system reports.

The first phase of the ambitious program of social security sponsored by the Roosevelt Administration becomes effective this morning, with a tax of 1 per cent on payrolls. This tax is intended to raise the initial funds for an unemployment insurance plan which will be put into operation two years hence.

The strength of the United States is reasserting itself unmistakably and characteristically, Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said in response to requests for his views on business prospects for the new year.

The directors of the Advance Rumley Company declared yesterday a liquidating dividend of $1 in cash and half a share of Allis-Chalmers stock on each share of Rumley capital stock outstanding. The payment will be made beginning on Jan. 14. Shareholders must send or present their stock to the New York Trust Company to obtain the dividend since the stock must be stamped with the amount i of the liquidating dividend.

State law forbids the use of the American flag in advertising or on business letterheads. The flag may not be placed in pawn. It may not be defaced or defiled, nor may contempt be cast upon it by either word or act. It must be displayed on or near every school, and, when the Legislature is in session, on the Capitol at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Indications became apparent today that the Packers' Consent Decree of 1920, under which the five largest packing groups in the country were required to withdraw from allied industries, may be reopened in the District Supreme Court.

The lack of a definite government policy toward the merchant marine has handicapped the shipbuilding industry as well as American shipping in competition with foreign nations, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this district received notice yesterday from the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, through J.H. Case, Federal Reserve agent here, that, pending action by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on its regulations relating to the payment of interest on deposits by insured non-member banks, the effective date of Subsection f of Section 1 of revised regulation Q has been suspended.
PWA'S outstanding accomplishments in 1935 were bringing the first public works program to substantial completion and getting its second program under way in record time.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Dec. 31. -- With a fireworks display in Munich and a series of radio broadcasts, Germany today greeted the coming year as "the Olympian year."
LONDON Wednesday, Jan. 1 (Reuters). -- Conflicting reports reached London today regarding the number of casualties in the bombing of a Swedish Red Cross unit in Southern Ethiopia by Italian planes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- The consolidation of all independent public health services with the Westchester County Department of Health was urged by the Institute of Public Administration in another report today to the Westchester Commission on Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Spokesmen for government, business and organized labor, speaking optimistically in general, welcomed the New Year with suggestions for carrying forward the recovery gains of 1935.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- Although not so successful in today's two events as its keen rival, McGill University, the Dartmouth Ski Squad nevertheless continued to hold first place in the race for the team prize as the second day of competition in the fifteenth annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds intercollegiate Winter games ended.

A goal by Lynn Patrick sent the New York Rangers into first place in the American division of the National Hockey League last night. The tally by the son of the Blue Shirts' manager was the only one registered in the battle between the Rangers and the Montreal Maroons, but it served the purpose.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stock from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- United States foreign trade for 1935 will attain a value of $4,300,000,000, compared with $3,768,000,000 last year, according to estimates of experts in and out of the government based on actual results for the first eleven months this year and past monthly averages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- (AP). -- The Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal Church said today in a report that drinking at football games was "very general" last season, with the worst conditions noted at Eastern contests.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31. -- A warning against an "insidious illness" the germs of which were "carried by the mechanization of music" was voiced today by Hans Kindler, conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, Washington, at the convention of the Music Teachers National Association.

La Guardia Prefers Hollandaise With His, but Butter Sauce Also Has Its Devotees. Artichoke dealers in the metropolitan market were rejoicing yesterday in a greatly increased demand for the vegetable that came largely from persons impelled to try it because of Mayor La Guardia's recent drive on artichoke racketeers.
On the first day of a new year which will mean hope renewed and brighter lives for many of the Neediest Cases of New York, the fund's grand total stands at $241,714.73.

TOKYO, Dec. 31. -- Japan closes a successful year in a mood of complacency and confidence to which a variety of causes contribute. The continued properity is shown by the all-time record for the export trade which was up 16 per cent compared with last year and 130 per cent compared with 1931.

" How strange a thing is man," said a doctor-saint of centuries ago. "But half a cubit of him [his head] "yet a universe of material things will "not satisfy him." This view has statistical support in the address of Dr. E.L. THORNDIKE as president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 31. -- Defeating Sir George Thomas, champion of the City of London, in the fifth round, Reuben Fine of New York slightly increased his lead today in the annual masters tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- A comprehensive neutrality bill embracing both mandatory and discretionary features was agreed upon for submission to Congress at a White House conference this afternoon.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 31. -- Princeton's hockey team launched a spirited drive in the final periods tonight to overcome a three-goal handicap and defeat Minnesota, 4 to 3 in an overtime game at the Auditorium. The victory enabled the Tigers to break even in the two-game series between the teams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Charging the government with an "arbitrary and high-handed attempt" to deprive the North American Company and the American Waterworks and Electric Company of their lawful rights, those utility holding companies filed a rebuttal brief in the District Supreme Court today asking denial of motion made to stay the suits they brought to restrain the government from enforcing the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Jerry May, 15-year-old schoolboy whose only plea was that "things went black" when he could not get money to buy his mother a present, was held last night in Union City, N.J., for the murder of a 6-year-old cousin and the stabbing of his uncle earlier in the day.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 31. -- Morris Rosner, appointed soon after the kidnapping of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr. as an intermediary with the underworld in the search for the baby, was dismissed without explanation here today as Police Chief of Long Beach.
Increased construction and realty buying activity during 1936 was predicted yesterday on the basis of sales, rising rentals, building costs and mortgage financing during the year just ended.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31. -- Miss Katharine Torrey of Clinton, N.Y., was found dead this morning at the home of her sister, Mrs. Jeanette Rose.

Bond issues publicly offered here in December, although the most numerous for any month since April, 1931, were for smaller face values than those offered in November. Stock flotations, on the other hand, were in number and amount the largest since October.
MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 31. -- President Lazaro Cardenas this evening issued New Year's greetings to Mexican workers, the army and State Governors. To the workers he said:

NEWPORT, Dec. 31. -- Chief among the New Year's Eve parties in or about Newport was that given by Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren at Gray Craig, their Middletown home. They had eighty for dinner, including their holiday party, who are remaining over the week-end, and about 100 more came in from other dinner parties for the dancing and supper and for the official welcoming of the New Year.

New York City broke five of its health records in 1935, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia. A sixth record, of which he expressed concern, was the establishment of a new low of 13.2 births per 1,000 of population.

PARIS, Dec. 31. -- Deputy Paul Reynaud made a vigorous reply today to former Premier Andre Tardieu's letter of yesterday in the controversy whether France was acting wisely in seeming lukewarm toward Great Britain and favorable to Italy at the moment when British public opinion had for the first time rallied to the idea of collective security and application of the League of Nations covenant in a dispute between two League members.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 31. -- The year that ends today has been more crowded with history than any year this part of Africa has seen since the Queen of Sheba visited King Solomon. And now a new year begins that may well settle issues hanging in the balance between Italy, Ethiopia and Great Britain.

The State of West Virginia will enter the market on Jan. 9 with a new issue of $1,000,000 of road bonds, carrying a 4 per cent coupon. They will be date Sept. 1, 1935, and will mature from Sept. 1, 1936 to 1960.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Form players met with a stunning setback in the fourth race, six-furlong feature at Tropical Park today. A bad start saw the recent winner and favorite, Jake Blieden, last away, while Wizard, also well backed, broke next to last with scant chance.
Deals involving business and residential properties in various parts of Manhattan were announced by brokers yesterday as the year ended.

The Metropolitan Opera celebrated New Year's Eve in a cheerful frame of mind with the second sold-out house of the week on hand to greet the season's first performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor." If the tale this opera tells is somewhat lugubrious, there was no sign that it depressed the capacity audience.

Santiago, Chile, Dec. 31. -- Seven members of the governing body of the International Labor Organization and twenty-seven officials and experts of its permanent secretariat in Geneva arrived here today for the labor conference of American States, which will open Thursday in the Chilean Congress Building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Secretary Ickes has become involved in another struggle here by seeking to acquire the site at Constitution and Virginia Avenues, already voted by Congress to the Pan American Union for construction of a new Pan American Building.

Trapped by the police in an apartment on the top floor of a five-story apartment building at 204 East Eighty-second Street about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a youthful burglar refused to heed a patrolman's command to surrender, climbed out a bathroom window, hung suspended by his hands a moment, then lost his hold and plunged to the rear courtyard.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Here are some of the Federal enactments just becoming effective at midnight:

Fourteen Manhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Among the parcels were an eleven-story loft structure in West Twentieth Street, a seven-story hotel in West Forty-fourth Street and a group of four five-story flats in East Ninety-sixth Street. The results were as follows:

MONTEVIDEO, Dec. 31. -- Alexander Minkin, until last week Soviet Minister here, sent a second note to the Foreign Office today, reiterating his previous denial of the Uruguayan Government's charges that the Soviet legation aided and abetted the recent revolt in Brazil.
Tribute to the performance of their employes in 1935 was paid yesterday by two trunk-line presidents.

A proposed addition to the trans-pacific air mail and passenger service, long considered by the officials of Pan American Airways, was outlined yesterday. The route would be between Honolulu, Hawaii, and Auckland, New Zealand. It is expected to connect with a proposed extension of the Imperial Airways from Australia to New Zealand to complete a round-the-world air mail line.

DURING the year 1935 the navy has made steady progress toward the full strength allowed in the various categories by the treaties of Washington and London and has resumed recruiting and training enlisted personnel for the new vessels which are being completed and which will join the fleet during the coming twelve months. The more than 300 vessels in commission have completed their operating schedules successfully and fulfilled their assigned missions.

THE year 1935 is a landmark in the history of labor legislation. Besides the far-reaching program adopted by Congress, every one of the forty-four States holding regular legislative sessions this year enacted at least some new legislation for the protection of the safety, health or security of labor.

ASTROPHYSICS and archaeology have each had an outstanding year at the Smithsonian Institution. Two years ago a station for observing the intensity of the sun's radiation was set up on Mount St. Katherine near Mount Sinai, in Egypt.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 31. -- The attempt of Congress to control the bituminous coal industry through the Guffey Act was declared unconstitutional by a Federal court here today because the tax levied on non-conformers to the Coal Code is "a penalty to coerce the plaintiffs to submit" to regulation.
ROME, Dec. 31. -- Italians face 1936 with mingled apprehension and hope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- As the new year dawns, the year of the national election, a septuagenarian who is an inflationist, a silverite, a rigid prohibitionist, an enemy of industrial bigness, an isolationist in foreign policy, a potato controllist and a Townsend plan sympathist, is upsetting the hopes and plans of a great political party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- In an effort to extend his control over marine unions to regions other than the Pacific Coast, Harry Bridges, left-wing San Francisco longshoremen 's leader who directed the 1934 general strike in that city, has arranged to hold a convention in Houston on Jan. 6 to organize the "Maritime Federation of the Gulf," it was learned here today.

In the three years' hubbub concerning the relief situation, along with its alphabetical agencies, there has been one sour, discordant note -- the treatment of civil service eligibles. Years of active, aggressive effort spent in building up the merit system are now in danger of being wasted.

The estate of Sarah E. Bruce, who died Oct. 6, 1933, was valued at $5,301,101 gross and $5,030,597 net, in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Miss Bruce was the daughter of the late Robert and Margaret T. Bruce, and with her brother, the late Robert M. Bruce, she gave some years ago to Greenwich, Conn., the town hall and the Bruce Memorial Museum and Park.

Owners of eight moving picture theatres, all members of the Independent Theatre Owners Association Inc., brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday against Local 306, Moving Picture Machine Operators' Union, charging damage to their business from picketing and other union activities.

In December directors of 1,334 companies declared dividends of $343,593,916, the largest amount for any December since 1931, when $363,572,932 was voted by 1,730 companies. The total compared with $401,523,897 in the preceding month, when 827 corporations voted payments and with S270,043,068 for 1,253 companies in December, 1934.

The hearings being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission in its inquiry on the activities of foreign bondholders' protective committees continued yesterday at the New York offices of the commission, 120 Broadway.

New Year's Eve or not, the only woman blacksmith in New York worked until midnight yesterday attaching snow-clips to the shoes of Manhattan's few surviving horses. The Vulcanian matron was Mrs. Martha Drew Smith, 24 years old, and beside her, at an identical anvil, labored her husband, George, who married her eight years ago.
Omaha, the 1935 champion 3-year-old which carried the silks of William Woodward to the triple American crown during the past year, definitely will race in England in 1936, it was announced yesterday.

How have democratic institutions fared throughout the world during the year just ended ? On the whole, they have stood up with courage and credit. They have had no lack of troubles. They have had to face fierce storms. Rumors or threats of sweeping changes or outright revolution have beaten upon them.

Following the four days of tests that comprised the national championship and Olympic tryouts, the members of the United States figure skating team, chosen at Madison Square Garden Monday evening, are now looking forward to the voyage that will end in the international competition at Garmisch-Partenkirchen.

Writing as a life-long enrolled, but independent Republican, who cast his first vote for William McKinley, and who is intensely interested in the rehabilitation of the party, also the substitution of sound economic and constitutional government for its present antithesis the New Deal, I wish to take issue with David M. Newbold, who under the caption of "Delegates in Blocks" advises sending pledged delegations.

Warming up to its task in a sensational second half, the undefeated Long Island University quintet battered Geneva College, 44-17, last night for its tenth triumph of the season. The game was played in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Formulation of a definite and uniform procedure for the examination of applicants for citizenship was announced today by Colonel D.W. MacCormack, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. The examination is designed to reflect the basic naturalization law rather than the personal views of examiners and to test the actual qualifications for good citizenship of the alien instead of his ability to answer questions of a technical or even "tricky" character.

Prices of commodity futures held within a narrow range in the pre-holiday half-session on the local markets yesterday. Gains and losses were about evenly distributed and the undertone was firm in most staples. Eggs alone declined on the cash markets. Wheat, corn, flour, cotton, butter, raw sugar, wool tops, rubber and silk advanced.

Buyers' Arrivals Higher. An increase in the number of visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the preceding week. However, the total was well below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

ISEiD you the following information concerning lynchins for the year 1935: I find, according to the records compiled in the Department of Records and Research of the Tuskegee Institute, that there were twenty persons lynched in 1935.

THERE has been a steady increase in the business of the Postoffice Department for many, many months. Since July 1, 1934, there have been only two weeks during all that period when the business of the department was less than in the corresponding weeks of the previous year.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- The Times publishes the following from its Berlin correspondent:

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- With the six Republican Assemblymen from Erie County ready to take their fight over organization of the Assembly to the House floor at the opening of the Legislature tomorrow, the Republican Assembly caucus took a recess at 11:30 this evening until 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

Predicting that two major strikes would almost certainly result early in the new year, James J. Bambrick, president of local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, disclosed last night the demands his organization will present tomorrow to the real estate interests of the city.

A statement attacking the Italians for "barbaric and inhuman actions" was issued yesterday by Lij Tasfaye Zaphiro, First Secretary of the Ethiopian legation in London, who is in this country to coordinate relief work and fund-raising among American sympathizers with Ethiopia.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in December dropped below the activity of the preceding month, which was the largest turnover of any month since July, 1933. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 45,590,420 shares last month, compared with 57,462,895 shares in November and 23,587,502 in December, 1934.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- Christabel Pankhurst was made a Dame of the British Empire by King George tonight in belated recognition for her long uphill struggle to win the vote for women. Her name appeared far down in the annual list of New Year's honors issued from Buckingham Palace tonight with the explanation that her new title -- equivalent to knighthood for a man -- had been given to her "for public and social services."

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- Amid a near-riot in Venezuela's Congress, War Minister Eleazar Lopez Contreras was elected President of the republic today in succession to General Juan Vicente Gomez, according to word received here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Lightweight hogs, which have been showing the most strength in recent market sessions, developed a reactionary tendency here today and, while an early top of $9.75 was quoted, $9.60 was the best that could be secured late. The general market was 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than on Monday, with heavy butcher hogs off the least.

Dr. Paul S. Martin has been appointed curator of the department of anthropology at Field Museum of Natural History, according to an announcement made by Stephen C. Simms, director of the Chicago institution. Dr. Martin is the choice of the museum's board of trustees to fill the vacancy caused by the death late in 1934 of Dr. Berthold Laufer, former curator and noted scholar on Orientalia.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 31. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and their son Jon are secluded tonight in a suite in a Liverpool hotel and no one has been permitted to violate their wish for privacy. Tomorrow, it is understood, they intend to go to South Wales, where they will remain temporarily with relatives of Mrs. Lindbergh before deciding upon their future course.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The Nazis' official greetings to 1936, broadcast tonight, speed the dying year as a period that witnessed the rebirth of the Reich's freedom to build up its defenses, and they admonish the army the navy and the air forces to renewed mindfulness of their duty to the people and the Reich.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The Horned Frogs of Texas Christian and the Tigers of Louisiana State -- two of the nation's ranking football teams -- were even-money choices tonight on the eve of the second annual Sugar Bowl gridiron classic.

Comparing the nation with a steamboat kept running by boilers stoked with its own beams, Leonard P. Ayres, economist and vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, told members of the American Statistical Association here yesterday that a continuation of the government's policy of large expenditures exceeding income, if continued for four years, would lead to real inflation.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Celebrations gayer than for many years marked the entrance of 1936, hotels, clubs and villas providing settings for numerous large affairs. Gladioluses and other exotic flowers adorned tables for the dinner dance, attended by four hundred colonists, that marked the Everglades Club's formal welcome to the season.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Control of the Braves was formally turned over to Bob Quinn today after that veteran baseball executive rejected a belated offer of financial support made by a group of minority stockholders.

WISE, Va., Dec. 31 -- (AP). -- Judge H.A.W. Skeen took under advisement today a second petition for a new trial for Edith Maxwell, under 25-year sentence for killing her father, and asked attorneys to submit briefs on constitutional questions raised.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 31. -- Public anger and consternation over the reported destruction by Italian bombing planes of a Swedish Red Cross ambulance unit in Ethiopia exceeds anything seen here since the death of the international swindler, Ivar Kreuger.

Faced by opposition from Robert Moses. Park Commissioner and the Park Association, Mayor La Guardia decided yesterday to withhold his signature from the local law which would place the Queens terminal of the College Point-Clason Point Ferry in Chishlom Park, Col Point.
