Call and time money rates remained stationary in December at quotations similar to those prevailing in the preceding month. Loans against securities increased, although stock market activity was less than in November.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP). -- Soviet Russia formally protested to the League of Nations tonight that Uruguay had violated the League covenant by breaking off diplomatic relations with Moscow.

ONE way of starting the New Year right is to clear up the mail. Here's a card decorated with bright green holly leaves bringing "Season's Greetings" from Brownsdale. Meaning Bill Brown, the lively Boxing Commissioner, whose Irish ancestry has left him with a fondness for green in general. But nobody around the ring ever saw any green in his eye.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Increasing strength in the world's cash wheat situation was again a factor in the market today, and with a lack of aggressive selling the May delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade advanced 1 cent a bushel to $1.01 3/4, the best figure since Oct. 18. The close was at a net gain of 7/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Quotations to show that Senator Long sought to restrict the freedom of the press when he drove through the Louisiana Legislature a law imposing a 2 per cent tax on the gross advertising revenue of newspapers with weekly circulation of more than 20,000 were contained in a brief presented to the Supreme Court today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 1. -- The old year went out in a burst of revelry and lavish spending such as London has not seen in recent years, testifying more than anything else to Great Britain's recovery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation of Ithaca, a part of the Associated Gas and Electric System, has filed with the Securities Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $17,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series due in 1965, the proceeds of which are to be used for refunding or in exchange for outstanding bonds of affiliates.

Stanley M. Rinehart Jr. of Farrar Rinehart is slated to become president of the National Association of Book Publishers at the annual luncheon and business meeting of that organization, which will be held at the St. Regis on Wednesday, Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- A prelude to possible concerted international action in regard to world silver prices was the interpretation placed today by some observers here on the conference held between Secretary Morgenthau and his aides and Eduardo Suarez, Secretary of the Treasury of Mexico, who likewise was attended by members of the staff of the Mexican Embassy here.

THE American people, in common with other peoples of the world, have during the past twelve months come to a growing realization of the necessity for international economic cooperation as the best guarantee of prosperity and peace. By the negotiation of reciprocal trade agreements, the Department of State has actively exerted itself to remove indefensible barriers to trade and restore a reasonably free flow of commerce.

Substitution of a utilitarian for a moral code as advocated by sponsors of the birth-control movement would provide justification for "mercy killings" of the sick, the aged and the unemployed and unemployable, a prominent spokesman for the Catholic Church declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The secret political police rearrested Pastor Gerhard Jacobi, chairman of the Berlin-Brandenburg Confessional Synod, today and will keep him under arrest over New Year's to prevent his preaching. He was also kept under arrest in his apartment over Christmas. He was scheduled to preach at a New Year's Eve service at 11 o'clock tonight in his church.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The Hupp Motor Car Corporation, the oldest in the industry, has suspended production, officials said today, because of inadequate working capital.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31. -- Two good, soundly coached football teams were fit and ready tonight for tomorrow's Orange Bowl game.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 31. -- The New Year was greeted tonight at various country clubs near here with dinner dances. The Stamford Yacht Club, the Woodway Country Club and the Riverside Yacht Club united in a large New Year's Eve party.
Dipping into our grab-bag of memories of the year 1935, we come up wtih yarns of four days and of four fish -- a native trout, a rainbow, a tuna and a swordfish. . . .

THE outstanding feature-of the year 1935 in Latin America has bewail the progress made in the settlement of two major international controversies, one of which actually resulted in war and another which brought two States to I the verge of armed strife.
BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 31 (AP). -- His knack for "booting home the winner" placed 103-pound Charles Stevenson at the top among the nation's jockeys tonight.

When Bill Bonthron announced with great finality last June that he was through with track forever, he apparently neglected to add the word "positively." For Bonny is returning to the footracing wars with a place on the Olympic team as his great objective.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 1. -- The British destroyer Brilliant reported early today it had discovered the wreckage of the Imperial Airways liner City of Khartoum in the Mediterranean Sea, but had found only one member of the crew and none of the passengers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The deadline was reached today for filing suits to compel payment of government obligations in gold or $1.69 for each dollar and litigants rushed to the courts with cases whose outcome may affect more than $8,000,000,000 in government securities.

ROME, Dec. 31. -- The idea of another Winter's war in Africa is already accepted as inevitable by the Italian people at large as well as by political and military circles. It is said, indeed, that work has already begun in the occupied parts of Ethiopia on barracks and other buildings that will be necessary for troops through the rainy season.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- In years to come the British people will remember 1935 not so much for the political events but for the simple and sentimental fact that it was a year of Jubilee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- On Capitol Hill, where both majority and minority leaders met in Vice President Garner's office to discuss the arrangements for President Roosevelt's appearance Friday night, it was understood that the suggestion originated at the White House.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 31. -- Edward Schwahl, 31 years old, of 47 Thomas Street, a former policeman, was placed under arrest early today when he came to police headquarters to inquire if his common-law wife was being held there. A woman who had come to report a hold-up at her husband's store saw Schwahl at headquarters and told police she recognized him as the man who had committed the holdup.
The New Year was ushered in with devotions by thousands of New Yorkers who attended "watch night" services in churches of various denominations throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP). -- The pre-session Congressional campaign for immediate cash payment of the bonus was marked today by a new overture intended to align powerful service men's organizations behind a single bill, and by continued emphasis on the inflation element.

Interests having obligations in near months became nervous yesterday over the announcement that the producers' pool still held contracts for 80,000 bales of cotton for delivery in January, and quotations advanced $1 a bale from the resultant covering on the Cotton Exchange.

Plans for a 1,000-foot tower designed to be one of the outstanding structures at the 1939 World's Fair in Queens were announced yesterday following the signing by Supreme Court Justice Miller of a certificate of incorporation for the group of sponsors to be known as "Memorial Beacon Tower to the Presidents of the United States Committee."

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- Material relief for small enterprises was announced today by the State Tax Commission in the payment of the new unincorporated business income tax. First, a salary allowance of not more than $5,000, and, second, a flat exemption of $5,000 may remove as much as $10,000 of net income from tax liability in the case of an individually owned business.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Dec. 31. -- New Year's will find the Wyatt Earp well on her way from Charcot Island to the Ross Sea, where it is hoped she will be joined by Lincoln Ellsworth and Herbert Hollick-Kenyon.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31. -- Soviet historians are already listing 1935 as a banner year in the short but checkered life of Soviet Russia.

In the hands of the Secretary of State for Scotland is a petition that discloses another and a grievous wrong done to the Northern by the Southern partner. The St. Andrew's Society of Glasgow and the St. Andrew's Society of London view with alarm violations by certain Government departments of the Treaty of Union of 1707.

An amateur hockey triple-header will be staged at Madison Square Garden tonight, in which five local teams and one from Boston will be seen in action. The program will start at 7:15 o'clock and is expected to attract a crowd of about 10,000.

Offhand one would say it is a day late for discussing New Year's resolutions. The vows for 1936 have already been uttered and registered. But the subjoined proposal is so startling in its nature that perhaps a year's consideration is not too much before putting it in force on Jan. 1, 1937.

Trading in silver futures will be resumed on the Commodity Exchange of New York if and when a free market for silver is again feasible in this country, says Jerome Lewine, president of the Exchange, in his annual report. Meanwhile the silver contract remains on the Exchange's books.
Donald Leavens, Northwestern University star, justified his rating yesterday by advancing to the last round in the national junior championship tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing divisions, but showed no change in the wholesale branch, in the five business days ended Dec. 26, as compared with the previous week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31. -- The 600 delegates, representing thirty-nine countries, to the tenth international Congress of Surgeons had an unexpectedly boisterous reception at the inaugural session here this morning.

BERLIN, Dec. 31. -- The Boerse closed the year in the same state of semi-paralysis that has afflicted it for months, or ever since the National Socialist policies made its quotations mere window dressing for prestige and drove real transactions off its board.

ADDIS ABABA, Dec. 31. -- A radiogram received here this morning from the headquarters of Ras Desta Demtu at Nogheilli in southernmost Sidamo Province reported that a Swedish Red Cross unit near Dolo, on the Ethiopian-Italian Somaliland frontier, had been destroyed by Italian bombing planes yesterday morning.

Sir Thomas Beecham, who is artistic director of the Covent Garden Opera Company in London, will spend part of his time during his present visit to this country in holding auditions for the London opera. He will begin a three-weeks' period as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra tomorrow evening.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, by a decision in the United States District Court here yesterday, paved the way for the early substitution of buses for trolleys on the remaining trolley lines of the New York Railways system.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,810,800 barrels, compared with 2,850,050 in the preceding week, a drop of 39,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 270,600 barrels in excess of the calculations of 2,540,200 barrels daily by the Department of Interior for December.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- In a sudden change of plans for the opening of Congress President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders of both major parties agreed tonight to arrange a joint meeting of the Senate and House on Friday night to hear a personal delivery by the President of his annual message on "the state of the Union."

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hunt Tilford Dickinson of Locust Valley gave a large dinner tonight at the Nassau Country Club before the New Year's Eve dance. Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Maxwell and Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Brooks were hosts at another of the larger dinners at the club. Others who had parties were:
Continuing the upward trend started in 1934, thoroughbred horse racing poured more than $7,000,000 into State treasuries during 1935.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 31. -- Thirty - five charitable organizations, hospitals, relatives and friends are beneficiaries under the terms of the will of Lewis Straus, philanthropist, which was filed for probate here today. Mr. Straus, who made his home here, died on Dec. 18.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- How science has supplanted the civit cat and the musk deer as sources of the bases for fine perfumery was told by Dr. Wallace H. Carothers at the National Symposium of Organic Chemistry today.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31. -- The American Association of University Professors, composed of 13,000 members of the faculties of the country's universities, voted unanimously today to put the University of Pittsburgh on its ineligible list of institutions of learning.
The hand-organ went out of official existence last midnight, but along 105th Street, east of Second Avenue, where the last handful of licensed players live, nobody really believed it.

Charles Corbett, the detective who told his superiors that a bribe had been offered to him to "forget about" the Druckman murder case, is a patient in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday. He has been on sick leave from the Police Department since Dec. 17.
ATLANTA, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Eugene Talmadge today joined Alfred E. Smith in declining a White House invitation, reporting that her cotton plantation demanded attention.

The declaration last week by twenty-nine high-church Episcopalian ministers that Protestantism was "bankrupt ethically, culturally, morally and religiously" was contradicted yesterday morning by Protestant ministers who were guest speakers at services held at the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A new standard of correct light for reading in home or office has been found by Miles A. Tinker of the University of Minnesota Psychology Department.

The National Academy of Design announces that it will open tomorrow in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, an exhibition of work by portrait members of the venerable institution. This represents a new activity, since hitherto the National Academy has for the most part confined its efforts to the putting on of general group exhibitions each year.

The progress of the Negro race since the freeing of the slaves was termed "truly remarkable" by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in a message read yesterday at a meeting celebrating the seventy-third anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Governor Lehman in his annual message to the Legislature, delivered in person at the opening session today, gave unqualified endorsement to the Federal Social Security program which remains as the high spot of President Roosevelt's New Deal policies.

One happy result of the release of the Supreme Court from its old confined quarters is the ability to provide the press with ampler and speedier means for the communication of its decisions. Under the New Deal the court's essential task of keeping straight under the Constitution the relations between the Federal Government and the several States has been greatly, if temporarily, increased.

Supreme Court's decision, Feb. 18, on constitutionality of government's repudiation of gold payment on its bonds. Court unanimous that government had exceeded its constitutional powers, but decided, 5 to 4, that no recovery by bondholders was possible.

Although profits in the food industry were smaller in the first nine months of 1935, the trend was upward in the last quarter of the year, according to C.M. Chester, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation. He described the industry as optimistic in its outlook for the next few months.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1. -- Mars is more earth-like than astronomers have been willing to admit. Vast, bright clouds covering hundreds of thousands of square miles, light snowfalls that blanket areas as large as continents, and great storms that sweep rapidly from equator to poles were reported to astronomers of the American Association for the Advancement of Science here today by Dr. E.C. Slipher of the Lowell Observatory.

Alfred L. Jarvis, lanky Williams College freshman, became one of the first new champions crowned in 1936 when he won the national junior indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Four men who have occupied executive positions with Paine, Webber Co. have been admitted to general partnership in the firm, it was announced yesterday. They are Frank H. Brown, Maurice M. Wheeler, Glenn G. Munn and Don M. Craft.

ROME, Jan. 1. -- Charges of Ethiopian atrocities were made in a statement issued in Rome today. It said two Italian aviators, seized after a forced landing near Daggah Bur, were beheaded and their heads were paraded before the populace at Harar.

Reflecting the improvement in business conditions throughout the country that started early in 1935, earnings of the various industries, as revealed by financial reports for the first nine months of 1935, produced favorable comparisons with the corresponding period of 1934.

Retail distribution has come to the end of 1935 with a record of progress and a promise of further improvement, according to Paul H. Nystrom, professor of marketing, Columbia University, and president of Limited Price Variety Stores Association.

The sale of railroad securities was established on a more stable basis in 1935. Borrowings from governmental agencies to meet outstanding obligations declined from the nominal figure at which they had stood in 1934 and, simultaneously, the marketing of new issues adjusted comfortably to the usages of the Securities and Securities and Exchange Acts.

A woman was fatally injured and three other persons were hurt in a fire of undetermined cause that did $10,000 damage to a three-story, four-family frame apartment and store building at 446 West Side Avenue, Jersey City, about 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1. -- A biological paradox which promises to take rank alongside the famous ancient paradoxes of Zeno has been brought to the attention of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. David Causey, Professor of Biology at the University of Arkansas.

Operation of the new Houston-Essex Street line of the city's independent subway system began at noon yesterday. Mayor La Guardia, heading an official inspection party, opened the $17,300,000 link of the city's rapid transit network to the public by cutting a red, white and blue cord which barred access to the turnstiles on the mezzanine of the cavernous station at East Broadway and Rutgers Street.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan, 1 (AP). -- The breaks, overanxiousness and an "off day" in their aerial bombing cost Southern Methodist the chance for a Rose Bowl victory today, in the opinion of Coach Matty Bell.

Railroad executives were generally optimistic in their predictions for 1936. Virtually all of them who expressed their views on the outlook at this time noted a steady improvement in 1935 and expressed the belief that the trend would continue into 1936.

The season's second performance of "Tannhaeuser" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with several changes in cast, notably the appearance of Kirsten Flagstad in the role of Elisabeth. Margaret Halstead was the Venus and Emanuel List the Landgraf Hermann.
In the passing of Lord Reading, nature can truly stand up and say to all the world: "This was a man."

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Thanks to the absence of six Democratic members of the Assembly the rebelling Republican Assemblymen from Erie and Suffolk Counties were defeated today in their efforts to block organization of the lower house. Irving M. Ives was elected Speaker.

The year 1935 marked the adoption of the highest Federal rates of income and estate taxes ever enacted by any Congress in peace times. To cushion the shock of these extreme measures they were, considerately, not made effective retroactively.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1. -- The Loyola basketball team conquered the Yale Bulldogs, 40 to 27, tonight. Before the final whistle blew, three members of the home team had been ejected from the rough battle on personal fouls, and twice the threat of flying fists had been turned aside.

Beethoven's only opera, "Fidelio," will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera House during the latter half of next month, with Kirsten Flagstad, the Norwegian soprano, in the role of Leonore, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- In the face of a disclosure by Governor Lehman in his annual message that he would submit soon his own detailed program of anti-crime legislation, the Senate Democrats moved today toward early action on a series of their own measures.

A heartening recovery has taken place in the men's clothing business throughout the year 1935, William Goldman, president of Cohen, Goldman Co., said. Sales of men's clothing in department stores have run steadily ahead of the stores' general average for other departments, he pointed out.

In a troubled world filled with uncertainty we give more than customary expression to hopes for peace and progress, according to George A. Sloan, president of George A. Sloan Co., Inc., and chairman of the Consumers Goods Industries Committee.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- The fourth anniversary of frostbite dinghy sailing was observed at the Larchmont Yacht Club today with a series of races in the harbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- President Roosevelt's plan to deliver his annual message to Congress at a joint session in the House chamber Friday night was attacked as a political move tonight by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

At this season the commentator is torn between two desires: to review the year just completed and to contemplate the future. The first is comparatively easy of accomplishment -- the record is there -- while the latter involves guesswork.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Fists flew tonight as the Detroit Red Wings. displaying probably their best offensive of the season, routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2, to go into a first place tie with the New York Rangers in the American Division of the National Hockey League.
The improvement in steel operations recorded in 1935 should be extended this year, according to leaders of the steel industry.

General trends in life insurance were favorable last year, with the exception of the downward movement in interest rates, Thomas A. Buckner, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, says in his annual review of the insurance field.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (AP). -- New Year's revelers going home today may later report seeing a lion "or something" and, according to Sheriff George A. Lutz, they may not be wrong.

In the following columns the financial history of 1935 is told in such way as to recall chronologically the year's outstanding occurrences. The narrative sketches concisely, in the introduction to each month, salient occurrences and the course of finance and industry in that month.

In the opinion of Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, while the nation enters the new year still faced by uncertainty as to the course of government, there is considerably more justification for optimism in business today than there was at the beginning of 1935.
Mrs. Richard P. Worrall gave an afternoon reception with dancing in keeping with the holiday yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland for her debutante daughter, Miss Renee Worrall.

Reflecting the sharp increase in the demand for its product, the copper-mining industry finished 1935 in the best position in several years. Earnings of the leading companies generally were satisfactory and probably at the best levels since 1930.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- A bombproof defense for magazines, machinery, spaces for inflammable stores and all vital control stations, according to Hector C. Bywater of The London Daily Telegraph, will be a feature of the new British battleships that, according to present plans, will be laid down a year hence.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- Recovery during the past year in Great Britain has been steadily maintained, and there seems to be no reason to look for any serious setback, or, indeed, for any retrograde movement at all whatever. Nearly all signs point to continued betterment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- The traffic fatality record of eighty-six major American cities, considered as a whole, was reported by the Department of Commerce today to have improved slightly in 1935.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Baby talk came in for some hard words today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Forty-five thousand persons jammed in Santa Anita Park today saw H.C. Hatch's Ariel Cross win the $5,000 New Year Stakes by a length from Soon Over of the Greentree Stable.

[ The changes in the average price of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Dec. 1 of three i years, according to figures compiled by that institution, are given in the following classified table:

ETANG DU NORD, Magdalen Islands, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press Cable). -- Although pronounced dead eight days ago, Didier Fougere, a 71-year-old fishery officer, still lies unburied in his home here in this Gulf of St. Lawrence group of islands tonight because his relatives believe he shows signs of life.

PEIPING, Jan. 1. -- The beginning of the new year finds Japan's policy of domination of the Orient from the Arctic Ocean southward gradually emerging from guarded archives. Recalling General Shigeru Honjo's assertion in 1931 that Japan must occupy the Peiping-Suiyan railway as well as Manchuria and expect a struggle with Russia over the Siberian Coast provinces, events are gradually shaping to that end.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- James Hagan, author of the comedy. "One Sunday Afternoon," has written a grim little drama, "Mid-West," which opened last night at the Shubert. It concerns the drought-ridden farmers of the Western wheat belt. Mr. Hagan has written in homely, earnest, down-to-earth fashion, with obvious sincerity and a good deal of feeling.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 1. -- Prince Carl, president of the Swedish Red Cross, who will return to Stockholm tomorrow from his residence at Fridhem, issued a communique late tonight saying, "The latest press information seems to indicate that the attack on the Swedish ambulance by Italian bombing planes was of another nature than we at first hoped and believed.

Retail trade in the New York Federal Reserve area during the year just closed lagged consistently behind the increases shown for other major industrial centers and the agricultural regions. For the year, the reported sales increase was 1 1/2 per cent, compared with an average rise of 6.4 per cent for 1934.
A brief review of the banking situation for the year just past, from a supervisory standpoint, shows the national banking system to be on a sound basis.

The sharpest reversal of conditions in its history was experienced by the cotton-textile industry in the second half of 1935, with the knit goods and rayon fields also going through a period of extremes.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 1. -- Two Norwalk High School students were killed this morning when an automobile operated by Philip Sherwood, a patrolman, struck their car in West Avenue. The dead were Robert Munsell, 19, of Harbor View Beach and Miss Eileen McGuire, 18, of Byington Place.

DENVER, Colo., Jan. 1. -- The Detroit Lions, National Football League champions, added a post-season triumph to their record today by scoring a 33-to-0 exhibition victory over a team picked from their league opponents.

William H. Pflugfelder, Benjamin Bampton, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and Adolf H. Rust have formed a copartnership under the name of Pflugfelder, Bampton Rust, with offices at 61 Broadway.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1. -- Coming from behind twice, the Jacksonville All-Stars, composed of gridiron players from three local senior high schools, earned a 13-13 tie with the Marblehead (Mass.) High School eleven here today.

The American merchant marine is more competently organized and strongly entrenched in the trade routes of the world than at the start of the depression, according to R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners' Association.

While further improvement in railway equipment was seen in 1935, this largely reflected orders placed in 1934, and there was a decrease in purchases of all classes of rolling stock. The surplus of equipment in service continued ample for the demands of traffic, although the opinion expressed by manufacturers for several years that any sizable increase in traffic would bring a greater demand for equipment was repeated in 1935.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Avenging his setback of a year ago, Ogden Phipps of New York scored a crushing triumph over James H. Van Alen of New York in the final of the sixteenth annual Gold Racquet tournament at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club today.

Passage by Congress of a Soldiers' Bonus Bill at its coming session, its veto by President Roosevelt and passage over the President's veto are predicted by Raymond Moley, original member of the Roosevelt "brain trust" and editor of Today, in the current issue of that magazine.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- In regard to the officially denied report from Paris that the latest conversation between Premier Laval and Sir George Clerk, British Ambassador, concerned the possibility of inviting Germany to re-examine the question of limiting land and air armaments, it was said here today nothing whatever had been decided on this point.

The communications business continued its comeback in 1935 to an extent which improved the earnings of telephone and telegraph companies to an important degree, but the improvement was not enough to prevent the second largest telegraph system from going into bankruptcy, nor was the rate of improvement equal to that experienced in the years immediately preceding the depression.
The dealings in stocks and bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in 1935 compare as follows with the preceding years:

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 1. -- Retail sales in 1935, boosted by last-quarter auto sales and spirited Christmas trade, were 9 per cent above 1934. Recovery in the Ninth District was featured by higher farm prices, increased sales volume and a marked revival in building.
Prohibition did wrong by us in numerous ways not generally mentioned by those who rejoice over its passing.

Passage of the Banking Act of 1935 on Aug. 23 completed, in the opinion of leading bankers, the reform of the banking system that had been regarded as necessary following the temporary collapse of that system in the banking holiday of 1933.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 1. -- Successful against William Winter of London, the British champion, in the sixth round, Reuben Fine of New York, with a total of 5 1/2 points out of 6 to his credit, held his place today at the head of the list of ten competitors in the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonard's Chess Club.

Electrical development covered a wide range in 1935, according to a survey by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company made on the threshold of its golden anniversary, which it will observe early this year. New records were established in 1935 in the size and power of electrical units put into service, greater efficiencies were achieved in the general distribution and application of electrical service and research continued to develop new products and wider horizons.

DALLAS, Jan. 1. -- The Eleventh Federal Reserve District ended 1935 with a whirlwind retail business that surpassed 1934's record-breaking Christmas shopping season by more than 15 per cent, thus maintaining the year's 15 per cent increase ratio.

Even farmers believe that the Department of Agriculture is primarily concerned with the practical aspects of crops and livestock. To Secretary WALLACE research is one of the department's chief functions. In an article which appears in the January issue of The Scientific Monthly he tells us that at least 6,700 "specific lines of research are going on at the present time" in the various bureaus.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The successful transplanting of the heart of one animal into the body of another animal, with the transplanted heart living in its new environment as long as its adopted body lived, was described here today before the meeting at Princeton University of the Zoological Society of America by Dr. H.H. Collins and Dr. W.H. Wright of the University of Pittsburgh.
One favorite gained a decisive triumph and another was the victim in an upset last night in two games of an amateur hockey triple-header in Madison Square Garden.

The curious fact about present year-end surveys is that, although every responsible business body recognizes genuine industrial recovery, nevertheless there exists reluctance to predict its unbroken continuance. Reasons for the contrasting viewpoint can be set forth best by reciting dispassionately, in the usual method of this annual picture, the contentions, favorable and unfavorable, which are heard in every quarter of the business community. First for the hopeful judgments:

With the Home Owners Loan Corporation nearing the end of its emergency relief undertaking and with its lending operations more than 95 per cent finished, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, declares the permanent institutions operating through the board are a sound means of correcting evils in the present mortgage system.

Revenues of the manufactured and natural gas public utility industry in 1935 aggregated $726,306,000, a gain of 3.4 per cent compared with 1934, according to Alexander Forward, managing director of the American Gas Association.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 1. -- Rodolfo (Babe) Casanova, Mexico's boxing idol, decisively defeated Freddie Miller of Cincinnati, recognized by the National Boxing Association as world featherweight champion, in a 10-round non-title bout before 30,000 persons today in the bull ring.

Substantial improvement was shown in retail trade last year over 1934, according to Percy S. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc. A fair estimate of the increase would be, perhaps, 6 or 7 per cent and, if we include retail sales of automobiles and some other lines, the aggregate gain may approximate 10 per cent, he said.
Several West Side apartment structures and an East Side dwelling were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Putting up a desperate battle to avoid relegation to the second division of the English Football League, Aston Villa featured the abbreviated New Year's Day schedule by defeating Sunderland, league leader, 3 -- 1, at Roker Park.

The durable goods industry expects an increase in production volume this year that will materially exceed the gain made in 1935, according to John F. Gowen, executive secretary of the Producers' Council, Inc. He asserts that manufacturers of building materials and equipment are making preparations for a volume of business in the next twelve months of as much as 50 per cent above the 1935 totals.

Fundamental economic factors indicate that the improvement in business recorded last year should continue this year, according to Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Dismissal of all non-residents on the staff of the Emergency Relief Bureau and all those not in need was recommended yesterday in a report to the Board of Estimate by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, who at the request of Mayor La Guardia investigated the staff of the ERB and its disbursements.
High school debaters in eleven States will devote their 1936 speaking schedules to discussion of socialized medicine, the current issue of the State Journal of Medicine discloses.

Gross expenditures for construction in the electric utility field in 1935, exclusive of Federal and municipal projects, were less than $200,000,000, according to G.O. Muhlfeld, president of Stone Webster, Inc. It was the first year since 1930, the peak year, however, in which utility construction has shown a gain over the previous year.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Jenny Csontos, 25-year-old beauty parlor operator, and her mother, Mrs. Julia Csontos, died today from gunshot wounds said by police to have been inflicted by a rejected suitor of the daughter, after he had led musicians in a New Year serenade in front of her home.

RENO, Nev., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Unhappily married couples from two States on opposite sides of the nation -- New York and California -- filed more than half the 3,088 divorce suits instituted here during 1935.

BUFFALO, Jan, 1 (AP). -An explosion which wrecked a four-story tenement and shook a large part of the city today killed five persons and injdred another so seriously that she was not expected to live.

Despite the progress which was made last year by municipalities in improving budgetary methods, which carried prices of municipal bonds to the highest levels in thirty years, there is a serious need for more effective control of public debt and public expenditures, which is illustrated by the agitation for a tax limitation on real property, according to John S. Linen, second vice president of the Chase National Bank.

The city's health in 1935 was very good, but the city's birth rate continued to go down, and this greatly disturbs Health Commissioner RICE. Fewer children and a longer life span mean a nation of more old people and fewer young folks to look after them.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- Retail trade in New England in 1935 was about 10 per cent over 1934. A survey of representative retail organizations indicates a general expectation that 1936 will show about the same percentage of gain over 1935.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The American Red Cross begins the new year with a membership of more than 4,000,000, as against 3,837,941 last year, according to Admiral Cary T. Grayson, national chairman.

Dr. James E. West, who completes today twenty-five years of service as Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, attributes his success in rounding out a wide program of boys' work to his persistence in carrying out a project for which he was engaged temporarily.

At the end of 1935, life insurance in force in all the legal-reserve companies amounted to $101,000,000,000, according to Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The gain in 1935 is estimated at $2,500,000,000, the greatest increase made in any single year since 1930.

After moving in a narrow range two years, the stock market in 1935 staged the longest sustained advance in more than twenty-five years. Reflecting continued improvement in industry, prices of shares rose steadily more than nine months.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1. -- In an intersectional football game filled with thrills, Catholic University's big Red Cardinals defeated the lighter, late-rallying University of Mississippi eleven today by 20 to 19.

" We look forward to 1936 with great confidence from the retail viewpoint," John Block of Kirby, Block Co., president, Association of Buying Offices, said. "What the public lacks in earning power, due to continued unemployment, as compared to our recent boom years, it seems to be making up from two other sources:
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Discovery of a new germ was announced today by three University of Chicago doctors.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Cincinnati became a city without a mayor today as a follower of Father Coughlin deadlocked a councilmanic election for the office.
Office, loft and store leases are increasing, with rental activity in midtown decidedly above its normal season level, M. Errol Mapes, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27. -- The South's outlook for the coming year is considered distinctly favorable. As a result of the higher prices maintained for cotton, all branches of wholesale and retail trade have been stimulated during 1935.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- The highest prices for a Jan. 1 in six years were paid today for cattle and lambs at the Chicago stockyards, while hogs brought the best prices in nine years. The markets were erratic, however, with trends in some classes lower on the final rounds.

IMPERIAL ETHIOPIAN HEADQUARTERS, DESSYE, Jan. 1. -- Emperor Haile Selassie called Italy brusquely to account before the League of Nations today for alleged poison gas warfare and the destruction of a Swedish ambulance by war planes on the southern battlefront.

BERLIN, Jan. 1. -- Thousands of German girls and women under 35 years face destitution this New Year's Day because they have been compelled to give up their jobs and their homes in Jewish households with the year-end as provided by the Nuremberg "ghetto laws."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Outplaying its rivals throughout, the speedy Harvard University hockey team routed the Lake Placid A.C., 6 -- 2, at the Olympic Arena today in a rough contest. The triumph was the fifth this season for the collegians, who gained a 2-0 lead in the first period and then added to it as the game progressed.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1. -- Stanford's football team made its third successive Rose Bowl appearance today and stepped to the heights by defeating Southern Methodist University, 7 -- 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. -- Cardinal Dougherty, speaking at his New Year's reception to representatives of the Catholic diocesan societies, criticized young women who drink intoxicants and mothers who encourage it as a means of enhancing their daughters' chances in society.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Massachusetts Legislators had before them tonight a long list of recommendations from Governor Curley for laws which he said he believed desirable to advance the Commonwealth's social and economic welfare.

LONDON, Jan 1. -- Crane-equipped tugs worked in thirteen fathoms of water off Alexandria, Egypt, tonight attempting to raise the Imperial Airways liner City of Khartoum and find the bodies of ten of the twelve victims of the New Year's Eve tragedy.

A field of forty-six gunners competed in a champagne shoot at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The program consisted of one event at 100 targets, in which there were offered twelve scratch and sixteen handicap prizes.

Gradual improvement is expected by the steel construction industry this year, according to V.G. Iden, secretary of the American Institute of Steel Construction. No great increase in volume is indicated, he said, but the industry has a greater degree of confidence and hope.

PARIS, Jan. 1. -- At 8:25 this morning, after having journeyed back and forth between Senate and Chamber five times during the night, the French budget was finally approved and the parliamentary session adjourned until Jan. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Automobile deaths fluctuate in number with the nation's gasoline consumption rather than its use of alcohol, and so far as records are obtainable more traffic accidents in which alcohol figured occurred under prohibition than since repeal, Captain W.H. Stayton, executive director of Repeal Associates, declared today.

A contribution of $20,000 from William Hale Harkness to the United Hospital Campaign Committee in its efforts to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 was announced yesterday by Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the campaign. Announcement also was made of a gift of $7,733 by R.H. Macy Co. and the employes.

A trend on the part of the public toward fewer but better garments in 1936 may bring about a slight decrease in number of units, but a rise in the monetary value of the output of the apparel trades, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and founder of the Council of Apparel Trade Association Executives.

DETROIT, Jan. 1. -- The people of the United States are fed up with idleness and are going back to work. This is the solid base on which the country will get onto an even level of prosperity, according to Henry Ford.

District Attorney Dodge, reporting on the work of his prosecuting staff in General Sessions in 1935 in a range of crime from murder down to unlawful entry, shows that his aides disposed of 3,798 eases in the courts, 1,033 fewer than in 1934.

The general recovery in business has brought a substantial improvement in banking conditions, according to the annual report of the Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York, issued yesterday. Deposits in State banks and trust companies rose more than $500,000,000 in the year ended on June 30 last, the report says.

John Macrae, president of E.P. Dutton Co., announces that George Morbey Acklom will head his editorial staff beginning today. Mr. Ackloin served as editor-in-chief for E.P. Dutton Co. for eighteen years, resigning in 1927 to enter business for himself.

THE TIMES publishes today, as it has done at this time during many past years, its "financial review" and "financial forecast." It is made up, not of the retrospective or anticipative judgments of THE TIMES itself, but of opinions gathered from a great number of competent individuals in this country and from a body of experienced financial correspondents throughout the United States and Europe.

In looking back over 1935, officials of the New York Stock Exchange, its members and their partners are inclined to agree that the year was an eventful and significant one which, happily, ended much better than it had begun. This opinion is based upon a quick comparison of conditions affecting the Exchange today with those prevailing a twelvemonth ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Phelan Beale gave a supper dance last night at the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Edith Bouvier Beale. The debutante received under a bower of cybotium ferns and smilax and was assisted by Miss Lucy Blow Jeffcott and Miss Margaret Louise Kelsey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The three powerful veterans' organizations united tonight behind a cash-payment bonus bill which they promised to introduce when Congress convenes on Friday and to press with all their strength to a final vote.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The induction into office here today of Dr. Charles H. Erdman Jr., former Professor of Politics at Princeton University, as Mayor of the borough of Princeton, indicated the emergence of a "municipal brain trust" to conduct borough affairs, I as several Princeton University i gaduates and faculty members were named to important administrative posts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The sustained forward movement in trade during the last half of the year, followed by the extraordinary cleanup of all kinds of merchandise at the year-end, is taken by trade leaders here to mean distinct change of sentiment on the part of consumers in general and as indicating the necessity of manufacturers increasing their output, not only of general merchandise, but of durable goods.
Sixty-six contributors added $2,950.30 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the grand total to date to $244,665.03.

The oil industry ended 1935 in excellent condition, according to William R. Boyd Jr., vice president of the American Petroleum Institute, who believes that if the degree of self-restraint is exercised over production, refining and distributing facilities, that prudent business judgment dictates, the petroleum picture in 1936 will be decidedly good for all concerned.

The depression has hit the brisk trade in mailing lists, an industry which supplies lists of "good names" to business men and others (such as persons seeking a roster of wealthy widows), according to Edgar J. Williams, president of Boyd's City Dispatch, one of the oldest mailing-list concerns in the country.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- A tale of thermometric mercury which fell so fast and hard that it killed a rat today won for Jim Jordan of Chicago the 1936 grand championship of all liars.

The year 1935 was one of progress for the railroads, according to J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. In his annual review, he notes that increases in both passenger and freight traffic brought net operating income of the carriers to the highest level since 1931 and 8.1 per cent higher than in 1934.

With commerce and industry recording substantial progress during 1935, all branches of business throughout the nation are entering the New Year with the prospects for further widespread gains the brightest in several years. Reports wired to THE TIMES yesterday from all of the Federal Reserve Districts were optimistic in tone, with indications that manufacturers and distributors are confident over the outlook, despite the possibility of some uncertainties.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP). -- They needed rubber walls in the Stanford dressing room tonight. Compressed human joy, generated but never released over a three-year period, boomed and echoed through the locker aisles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The resignation of Franklin C. Hoyt as Federal Alcohol Administrator was officially announced at the White House today. President Roosevelt accepted it, effective as of yesterday, expressing his regret at the throat ailment which Mr. Hoyt said was the cause of his resignation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- The reign of supremacy that Dartmouth has enjoyed in the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds annual intercollegiate skiing competition will continue for another year as the Green squad carried off the team prize in the fifteenth games, which ended today.

The Italian people are now officially warned to expect a prolonged war in Ethiopia. Military opinion is convinced that the conquest cannot be completed before the rainy season. Accordingly, it is stated, barracks for the comfort of the Italian troops during the rains are now being constructed at various posts.

It was a champagne New Year, the hotel and restaurant men reported yesterday as they smashed thousands upon thousands of empty reminders of New Year's Eve gayety, in conformity with Federal regulations. They asserted that free spending had reached heights not known in more than half a decade.
LONDON, Jan. 1. -- The Cunard White Star Line has given notice of withdrawal from the North Atlantic Passenger Conference, which fixes passenger fares, according to Lloyd's.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 1. -- For the first time in Brazilian history a President addressed the country over a nation-wide radio hook-up early today, President Getulio Vargas reviewing the accomplishments of his administration for 1935. Amplifiers were placed in convenient places in all cities.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP). -- History which reached from the death of Will Rogers back into the centuries was told by flower-decked floats in the annual Tournament of Roses today.

Savings banking has come to find itself deeply interested in the course of general business as it affects investments, Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Williamsburg Savings Bank, says in a year-end statement outlining the chief problems confronting savings bankers.

Engineering awards in the United States last month totaled $235,506,000, the highest monthly total since April, 1931, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday. Heavy public works awards, with State and municipal work predominating, were said to be responsible for the record.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Prospects for a settlement of the coal miners' wage demands in Great Britian are no brighter as the new year begins.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- East conquered West on the football field today with a 19-to-3 score that turned the final quarter of the eleventh intersectional charity classic into a Western rout.

Improvements in the last year have brought the oil industry to its best position since 1929. Maintenance of crude oil production within consumption needs and heavy increases in the use of gasoline and other oil products were important factors in the improvement.

Outside of coffee futures, which declined sharply, commodity futures were steady or materially firmer at the end of 1935 than at the start of the year. The gains appeared in sugar, hides, wool tops and silk. Cottonseed oil, rubber and cocoa were virtually unchanged for the year as a whole.

The recovery of advertising in 1935, while not spectacular, was sound and substantial, about in line with the upturn in general business, L.D.H. Weld, director of research, McCann-Erickson, Inc., stated yesterday. For the first ten months of the year, advertising activity showed a pick-up of about 5 per cent over the corresponding period of 1934, he added.

GLASGOW, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Seventy thousand spectators at Parkhead today saw the Glasgow Rangers make a great second-half recovery to defeat Celtic by 4 -- 3 in their annual New Year's Day fixture. The victory put the Scottish Football League champions and cup-holders within one point of the second-place Celts and three points behind the leagueleading Dons of Aberdeen who drew 2 -- 2 at Dundee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- Agriculture, petroleum and lumber products enjoyed an excellent year compared with depression lows and since these three constitute the lifeblood of the Pacific Coast area, long strides toward better times are being made.

Stabilization of the entire liquor industry along sound, ethical lines and coordination of the commercial interests of the industry with the social interests of the State are among the important problems liquor dealers face in the New Year, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, president of the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, Inc., said yesterday.
Three deaths and numerous injuries resulting from automobile accidents were reported yesterday in the metropolitan area.

The gradual withdrawal of the government, largest customer for the textile industry during 1935, from this field of operation will create the necessity for adjustment in 1936, presenting to the industry a major problem, Sidney H. Scheuer, head of Scheuer Co., textile consultants and brokers, said.

A system for determining the profit or loss to be expected from any sales volume, developed by Professor Walter Rautenstrauch, head of the Department of Industrial Engineering of Columbia University, was announced yesterday, with a statement that its general use would cut business losses in the United States by nearly $5,000,000 a day.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 1. -- President Arturo Alessandri of Chile will attend the opening session of the Labor Conference of American States, members of the International Labor Organization, when it convenes tomorrow. The speech of welcome to the delegates will be made by Foreign Minister Miguel Cruchagua.

A mild thaw, brought about by the rise of the thermometer above the freezing point of 32 degrees, appeared to have ended the recent cold spell in the city, the Weather Bureau reported last night. The forecast for today is partly cloudy, with the probability of light snow or rain.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Agriculture, wholesale and retail sales, and with them manufacturing industry, had in the past twelve months the best year that has been witnessed since 1929. Labor was more fully employed during 1935 than in any of the four preceding years.
ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Salient proposals of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today were:

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- German industry improved somewhat during 1935, but its development was determined by credit-financed rearmament and by public works. Substantial progress was confined to steel, cement and certain engineering branches, general manufacturing stagnated, and in some directions declined.

The key to Governor LEHMAN'S fourth annual message is to be found in the passage in which, after referring to the arduous days behind and the somewhat brighter present outlook, he declares that "now we have reached a "point in our progress where we can "undertake, with a reasonable perspec"tive of the distressing events of the "past, to project a more permanent "policy for the State."

While the course of the investment security business, as well as general business, during 1936 looks promising from the viewpoint of business economics, the extent to which the improvement shown in 1935 will be continued this year depends largely upon the policies of the Federal Government and their effects upon such businesses, according to Orrin G. Wood of Estabrook Co., president of the Investment Bankers Association of America.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- The Chicago metropolitan area faces 1936 with confidence, despite possible election year influences and local merchandising uncertainties.
BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- Communism was denounced today by Cardinal O'Connell as "the breeder of class warfare, world revolution and international atheism."

Plans for another Eastern concert tour of the Lincoln Cathedral Choir, a cappella, of Lincoln, Neb., during Easter Week were discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the choir's committee at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The ensemble of fifty-five mixed voices, under the direction of its organizer and conductor, John M. Rosborough, met with notable success in their first appearance at Carnegie Hall last Friday night.
Improvement is proceeding in the steel industry in response to natural forces of recovery, according to Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 1. -- All hope of rescuing twelve of the thirteen occupants of the Imperial Airways flying boat City of Khartoum, which was lost in the Mediterranean off Alexandria yesterday evening, was given up this afternoon after the wreck had been located and a floating crane had been towed to the spot in order that the hull might be raised.

Records are in danger of being smashed Saturday night at the tenth annual indoor meet of the Columbus Council, K. of C., in the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, if the field runs according to form in the "great American sprint series."

Peter J. McGuinness, the Greenpoint Democratic boss who forecast two years ago as he was swept out of his appointive post by the Fusion administration when it took over Brooklyn Borough Hall that eventually he would be the Sheriff of Kings County, was inducted into that office yesterday.

Judging from the preliminary figures 1935 will prove to have been the beginning of the end of the depression for the importing trade, unless unforeseen complications arise, according to James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern Stiner Co., Inc. For example, he pointed out, imports during September, 1935, as compared with the same month of 1934, measured by volume, increased slightly more than 10 per cent.

Jan. 1, 1936, will be a memorable day in the naturalization history of the United States. The order of the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization issuing on that day inaugurates a new procedure for the examination of applicants for citizenship. The purpose of the new instructions, which have the force of law, is first of all to give effect to the provision of the Constitution that there shall be a "uniform rule of naturalization."

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 1. -- No official announcement has been made of the details of the Italian bombing of the Swedish Red Cross unit, which Ras Desta Demtu was asked last night to send, but it is understood the original fear that all of the staff had been killed proved unfounded.

Spokesmen for the Columbia and National Broadcasting Companies said here last night that no decision has been taken as yet on the request of Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee, for radio time in which to reply to the address which President Roosevelt is to deliver at a joint session of Congress tomorrow night.

A group of thirty men and women, representing ten States, attended yesterday morning a New Year's Day ceremony on Bedloe's Island to mark the first day of the fiftieth anniversary year of the erection of the Statue of Liberty, dedicated in 1886.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Striking flat-glass workers in four States added a "closed shop" demand today to the conditions under which they will return to work.

LIMA, Peru, Jan, 1. -- In accordance with the customary procedure, President Oscar P. Benavides, accompanied by the members of the Cabinet and his military staff, held a New Year's reception at noon today at the Presidential palace, all the members of the diplomatic corps, Congressmen, officials, clergymen, the chiefs of the army, navy and air force, prominent business men and other private citizens paying their respects.

Four Queens officials elected last November were inducted into office yesterday in the County Court House in Long Island City. The officials were County Judge Charles S. Colden, District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan, Sheriff William F. Brunner and Register Bernard M. Patten.

While the food manufacturing industry has enjoyed an increase in sales during 1935, net profits have not kept pace with the rise in volume, according to a survey made by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

Business is improving for companies in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, as it is for other utilities, but because of higher operating costs and taxes, net earnings are only slightly better, says John J. O'Brien, president of the company, in a review for 1935.

The over-the-counter market here was active and substantially stronger in all major departments last year, according to a review of 1935 by Howard S. Hoit of Hoit, Rose Troster, New York bank stocks appreciated sharply in November and December, while insurance issues moved quietly but steadily higher throughout the year, he said.

RICHMOND, Jan. 1. -- In the Fifth Reserve District the year just closed continued the upward trend in commerce, industry and agriculture noted in 1934 and indications point to further progress in 1936.

Closely paralleling, as usual, the volume of transactions in stocks, the price of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange fluctuated widely in 1935. In the Spring, when trading was at a low ebb, seats sold for less than half the sums they brought at the end of the year, when the turnover on the Exchanges had increased more than 100 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- In France the past year's most salient event, from the financial viewpoint, was the heavy loss of gold suffered by the bank. This exodus of gold occurred during two crises of extremely violent character, separated by a period of calm.

A substantial rise in the price of convertible bond issues was a feature of the higher-grade bond market in 1935, in the opinion of the Fitch Investors Service, which reports that new offerings carrying conversion privileges advanced materially above their original prices.

ROME, Dec. 27. -- Along with undoubted resentment over the application of "sanctions" by other nations, the feeling of financial Italy at the year-end is that even full application of sanctions would reduce very greatly Italy's unfavorable balance of international payments, and would consequently limit to a bare minimum the outflow of gold.

The country's leading public-utility systems began at the end of November multiple court actions against the Public Utility Act of 1935 to have it declared unconstitutional. A fight throughout 1936 is expected.

The last year will be notable in the history of silver. As a result of the operations of the United States silver policy violent fluctuations in the price of the metal occurred, leading to disturbances in the silver-using countries, the widespread demonetization of the metal and, at the close of the year, to unprecedented demoralization of the world silver market.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Leo Freisinger, 19-year-old high school boy from Chicago, upon whom America will pin its hopes in the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen next month, today became the new Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating champion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- If, through parliamentary devices, a stubborn Representative should attempt to block the President's plan to deliver his annual message to Congress at a night session on Friday, he probably would not succeed. But if, because of the well-known timidity of the House Democratic organization, he should accomplish his purpose, he would advertise more greatly the message whenever delivered, though robbing it of some of its dramatic setting.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. -- Outstanding events and personalities of 1935, both local and international, were lampooned here today by followers of Momus, whirling and dancing for three hours along a five-mile route banked by one of the largest crowds in the 102-year history of the Mummers Parade.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 1. -- If time were rolled backward some thousands of years the garage man would find his motor oil changed into green growing things.

A suggestion that the New Testament precede the Old Testament in the Bible is embodied in an open letter addressed to the president and managers of the American Bible Society by the Rev. Robert H. Kelley, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Hartsdale, N.Y.

Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford of 24 West Fifty-second Street and Woodland, Tuxedo Park, gave a dinner dance last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce her debutante granddaughter, Miss Eve Mortimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grafton Mortimer.

Based on statistics for the first ten months of 1935, the world consumption of nickel for the year was estimated by Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., as the largest in the history of the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Published reports that Rexford Guy Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture and Rural Resettlement Administrator, and Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, had offered their resignations to President Roosevelt in the last two or three days, only to have the Chief Executive decline them, were discounted by friends of both officials today.
Official of the government quarantine station on Staten Island do not wish to appear inhospitable, but they are beginning to wonder when one of their week-end guests is going to depart.

Research and development work of the last five years, coupled with the employment of new capital to finance construction embodying the improvements in products and in manufacturing methods, will make 1936 a year of pronounced industrial progress, according to O.C. Huffman, president of the Continental Can Company.
ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- The text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature was as follows:

In recent years the expression, "upsetting the balance of nature," has appeared with increasing frequency in the fish and game columns of newspapers, in the pages of outdoor magazines and in treatises by game technicians.

Business is responding cautiously to such reassurances as it has received, but needs "additional encouragement if we are to have a soundly based recovery," Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. He named as prerequisites of recovery "equitable taxation, prudent management of our fiscal affairs and a stable currency policy."

Power output in the United States in 1935 set a new high record of 92,500,000,000 kilowatt-hours, based on estimates for the full year gained from an analysis of figures compiled monthly by the Edison Electric Institute. This is an increase of about 9 per cent over the 84,930,882,000 kilowatt-hours produced in 1934.

Firm prices, a rapidly expanding market and reawakened consumer interest in home requirements are a few of the encouraging factors confronting manufacturers of home furnishings as they prepare for Spring trade shows this month.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 1. -- President Lazaro Cardenas broadcast tonight a good-will message to the Mexican people containing a general review of governmental activities during the last year. He appealed to all patriots to consecrate their energies during 1936 to constructive labor.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 1. -- Spurred by the far-reaching demand brought about by the automobile industry, business in the Cleveland area this year ran substantially ahead of 1934 in many lines. Automotive parts plants in many cases operated with two or three shifts throughout the year.

Following an average increase in sales of the electrical manufacturing industry of about 20 per cent for 1935 over 1934, it is anticipated that the 1936 volume of business of the electrical manufacturing industry will be, conservatively, 10 to 15 per cent above 1935, according to W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

MADRID, Jan. 1. -- Spain entered the new year with its internal political situation in complete chaos. President Niceto Alcala Zamora today is faced with the choice of dissolving Parliament or suspending its sessions till the end of the month.

Pointing out that few developments in the field of retail distribution have attracted more widespread interest than the establishment by retailers of new liberal credit policies during the last few months, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, sounds a note of warning of possible "unsatisfactory and costly experiences for many retail stores."
Active woolen mills operated at a higher percentage of capacity in 1935 than at any time since 1923, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, declared.

The reopening of the investment market to corporations, made possible largely by the simplified form of registration statement published by the Securities and Exchange Commission and stimulated by money rates unusually favorable for refunding operations, was the outstanding development in the investment security business in 1935.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- One hundred years after the first publication of the "Pickwick Papers" there vanished from British life today one of those glaring injustices that Dickens fought again and again throughout his busy career.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1. -- Lynx Eye, former member of the C.V. Whitney establishment which Robert Robertson acquired for a song and won many a race with, regained his best form to capture the second running of the E. Phocion Howard Memorial Handicap at Tropical Park today.
The first phase of New York State's new Unemployment Insurance Act went into effect yesterday coincidentally with the inauguration of the Federal job-insurance plan.

Like many of the plans that appear perfect in construction and working order as visualized from the capital, but when put into practice fail because they are hampered by red tape and rules, so the National Youth Administration appears in danger of becoming another firecracker that did not go off.

A well-sustained and increasing tendency toward thrift is shown by the records of deposits in mutual savings banks and the growth in the number of their depositors, Robert C. Glazier, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, declared in a statement reviewing the savings-bank situation at the close of the year.

WARSAW, Jan. 1. -- The year of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's death was a sad year for Poland, Warsaw newspapers stress in their reviews of 1935. They say it will be a memorable year for generations to come because it placed on the shoulders of the present generation the great responsibility for carrying on the work to which Marshal Pilsudski devoted his life.

The recently organized New York Film Critics, representing all but one of the leading metropolitan newspapers, announced yesterday the results of their balloting on the best picture, performances and direction of 1935.

Downtown Traffic Court disposed of 100,190 cases in 1935, the greatest number since the establishment of the uptown branch, which was founded to relieve pressure on the older court. The court took in $130,032 in fines.

The seventeen plays and five musicals which gave New Year's Day matinees did, on the whole, an excellent business. To note a few which were personally inspected, "Pride and Prejudice" played to thirty-three standees; "First Lady," twenty-eight standees; "Jubilee," thirty-eight standees; "Scandals," 108 standees (as clocked by George White and George Morley, box-office treasurer).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A prediction that a third party candidate would be put forward under the auspices of the American Liberty League, with a view to dividing New York's vote and thus defeating President Roosevelt next year, was made today by Senator Lewis, retiring chairman of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Overshadowing other leading events pivoting on the Federal Government since the midsummer adjournment of Congress was the transfer of the New Deal spotlight to the Supreme Court of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Twenty-three picked policemen were called today to attend the Justice Department's "Little Red School House," the government's laboratory of crime detection and prevention.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1. -- In accordance with their custom of many years, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained today with a large reception at Casa del Pastor, in dual celebration of the new year and of Mr. Shepard's seventy-ninth birthday tomorrow.

If advancing prices, due to higher costs of raw materials, do not outstrip the public's capacity to pay, the resulting business should be better than at any time since the depression began, Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation, asserted in a survey of prospects for 1936.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- The old year ended with the publication of Treasury returns, covering the first three-quarters of the financial year, that proved Great Britain's business and financial recovery was moving along without a hitch.

Estimating the proved crude-oil reserves of the country at more than 12,000,000,000 barrels, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said 1935 "developed the comforting assurance that there are, within the confines of the United States, sufficient petroleum reserves to meet the needs of generations, if not centuries."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1. -- An accurate place kick by Taldon Manton, held steadily by the nimble hands of Sam Baugh, provided the victory margin of a battle won in the rain today by the Horned Frogs of Texas Christian University over the Tigers of Louisiana State by the score of 3 to 2.

Business, prices and profits are comparatively satisfactory in most lines and most sections, according to George A. Renard of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. In some instances we approximate boom conditions, with shortages of skilled labor and delayed deliveries of necessary materials to contend with in any further expansion, Mr. Renard added.

AT first glance it appeared that the esteemed president of the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs, Ford Christopher Frick, was frothing at the mouth. At his own New Year's party, too. It was true that he had some reason to feel disturbed and upset. One of his guests had just mentioned that the National League would be lucky to elect two representatives to the all-star team for the Baseball Hall of Fame.

A release from the restraints that hamper long-term confidence is the "need of the hour" in the bond market, as elsewhere, T.E. Hough, vice president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., says in his review of the bond market of 1935.

Youthful executives of Camp Fire Girls from twenty-four States gathered yesterday at the Hotel Astor for the opening of a six-day national convention to consider problems and plans of this movement for the current year.

High praise for Secretary of State Hull for his reciprocal trade program and a prediction of increased export business for American interests in the coming year are contained in a statement on foreign trade prospects made yesterday by James D. Mooney, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, in charge of overseas operations, and president of the American Manufacturers Export Association.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Seventh Heaven, a little brown 3-year-old filly, captured the $1,200 New Year's Day inaugural handicap today as Alamo Downs opened its forty-six-day race meeting. Approximately 12,000 persons turned out under clouded skies to watch the program on a heavy track.

An average increase of about 6 per cent in carloadings in the first three months of 1936 is forecast by the thirteen shippers' regional advisory boards. New England is the only region in which a decrease is expected.

Friends of Lamar Hardy, it was revealed yesterday, have urged him to withdraw as United States Attorney before his name is sent to the Senate for confirmation of his appointment by President Roosevelt.

Bankruptcies in the Southern District of New York have been decreasing slowly but steadily since the record year 1933, when 2,874 voluntary and involuntary petitions were filed, it is revealed by the entries in the office of the clerk of the Federal Court.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A packed crowd of 15,000 persons that welcomed the Boston Bruins on their return from their sensational road trip saw their favorites hit a new hockey low by dropping a 2 to 0 game to the Canadiens tonight.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1. -- It is estimated that general business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District gained 16 per cent over 1934 in the last year, as measured by debit to individual accounts.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1. -- Evolution, model 1936, which brings Darwin up-to-the-minute and extends the picture of the origin of life and consciousness far back into its beginning from inanimate matter, by sunlight's action on water, carbon dioxide, sugar, nitrogen and similar inorganic substances, was presented tonight before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- Westchester political leaders celebrated today their successes at the polls in November and the victors prepared to enter office tomorrow.

The automobile industry, which took 21 per cent of steel production in 1934 increased its proportion to 25 per cent in 1935, while the railroad proportion declined, according to Iron Age's annual survey. The railroads took only 6 1/2 per cent of the 1935 output of finished steel, against 10 1/2 per cent in 1934.

Rush orders for foreign distilled gins went forward early this week from scores of importers anxious to have stocks on hand when provisions of the trade treaty with the Netherlands become effective Feb. 1. Under the agreement, duty rates on gin from the Netherlands and from countries enjoying most-favored-nation treatment are reduced 50 per cent.

ATLANTA, Jan. 1. -- Substantial commercial and industrial progress was recorded in the Sixth Federal Reserve District during 1935 and continued widespread gains during the New Year were indicated in views of business executives and announcements of plans for expansion.
