SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (AP). -- The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association made a new high record for deposits, earnings and resources in 1935, A.P. Giannini, chairman of the directorate, said today.

After advocating a life of self-discipline based on religious guidance in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Dr. Philip J. Furlong, Professor of History at Cathedral College, urged 3,000 members of the Holy Name Society to shun newspapers which feature crime news and theatres pandering to low tastes.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 1. -- Increased production of grain and hogs form the basis of a further recovery of buying power and general improvement in business in the Tenth District for 1936. The Winter wheat acreage for Kansas exceeds 14,000,000, an all-time high record for the State.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP). -- A heavy New Year's Day toll of lives on highways touched off today a five-year national campaign to check the huge death list rolled up annually.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 30. -- There are, as usual, two sides to the end-of-the-year position in the Farm Belt. Holiday trade has been substantially above last year, and some industrial plants have been moving West, taking up surplus labor, and there are indications of an old-time wheat crop.

The general improvement in the nation's business in 1935 was reflected on the New York Curb Exchange where securities of 1,200 corporations, representing most of the major divisions of industry, are traded, according to Fred C. Moffatt, president of the Exchange.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1. -- A cancer garden where roses and other common plants contract human and animal cancer was reported to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Hogs continued in good demand here today, and prices were steady to as much as 15 cents a hundredweight higher, the general market being up 5 to 10 cents compared with Wednesday. Heavy-weight hogs, which recently were in slow demand, led the upturn, and the shipping demand was inclined to favor them also, compared with previous takings of the light kinds.

An organization aided by Marshall Field, banker, has been incorporated by seven psychiatrists and two social workers to undertake a scientific investigation of the motives and impulses that lead to suicide, and to study self-destruction as a preventable disease, it became known yesterday.

The New York Academy of Medicine is constantly making important contributions to the welfare of the community, both directly and indirectly, Dr. Eugene H. Pool, its president, said last night in his address at the annual meeting of the organization at its building, 2 East 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Broader use of silver as a standard of monetary value on a coordinated basis with gold and more effective stabilization of silver values for the benefit of producing countries was regarded today as a possible development from discussions between the United States and Mexico.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2.--Eugene Ormandy, whose virtuosity was credited generally with giving the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra a greater artistic authority, looked forward tonight to leadership of the Philadelphia Orchestra, ranked among the world's finest.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2. -- The Russian people for the first time since the revolution have had a really happy New Year's Day.

Leo Newman, theatre ticket broker of 1,502 Broadway, who died on Dec. 24, named Bernard H. Sandler of 44 West Seventy-seventh Street executor of his estate in his will filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, and directed him to form a corporation of his ticket business.

Although 1936 is a Presidential election year, it is believed generally that improvement in business will continue, according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, investment company. The expected rise in the price of securities this year should be reflected, Mr. Odlum said, in the asset values of the common stocks of investment companies.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Deposis of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended on Dec. 31 decreased $16,636,045, according to the bank's weekly statement, issued today. Deposits by chartered banks increased $1,370,344.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- In the past few days French and foreign newspapers have been so filled with comment and conjecture about the future of Franco-British collaboration under Article XVI of the League of Nations covenant the I thought it useful to have the exact character of the accords concluded and under discussion specified by the most competent authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The first registration statement for the issuance of a large volume of securities under the Securities Act of 1933 received by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the new year was filed today by the Inland Steel Company of Chicago.

Mail orders here yesterday were fairly numerous, but the apparel and accessory markets for the most part continued to await the heavy arrivals of buyers expected here in person next week. Cold weather in many sections of the country last week made further inroads into already depleted retail stocks, tending to confirm previous reports that buying of Winter goods for promotions during the next four to five weeks will be of substantial proportions.

Lou Ambers and Frankie Klick, a pair of persistent challengers for the world's lightweight championship now held by Tony Canzoneri, will meet in a ten-round battle at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout tops a well-balanced card of lightweight contests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Liquidation of stock holdings of considerable volume and numerous gifts of stocks, presumably to escape the higher gift taxes that became effective yesterday, were disclosed in the official summary for November of stock transactions and holdings of officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations, which contained also data for some previous months made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Control of the newly formed Southern Natural Gas Company, which has 1,250 miles of transmission lines in the Southeast, is now vested in the Federal Water Service Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

It is the season of the year when in the principal hotel lobbies of the United States it would be impossible to throw a brick without hitting an archaeologist or a geologist or a microbiologist or a philologist or a sociologist or a zoopathologist.

The income statement of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., for the year ended on Sept. 30 last shows total income of $10,771,429, compared with $9,816,710 for the preceding year. Net income after expenses, taxes and charges was $2,630,034, against $1,316,310.
Trading at the opening session of the new year on the Cotton Exchange was in increased volume and at an 8 to 14 point final improvement.

BRIDGEVILLE, Del., Jan. 2 (AP). -- Three end cars on the Pennsylvania Railroad's Delmarva express left the rails at a point one-quarter mile south of Bridgeville late today, causing injury to five passengers. None was seriously hurt.

A jodhpur-clad deputation of riding academy proprietors will call on Mayor La Guardia on a date to be announced later to seek the removal of bridle path obstructions preventing equestrians in the lower end of the park from riding north of Seventy-ninth Street.

Earnings of the Federal Reserve System transferred to surplus, after all expenses, dividends and reserves, amounted last year to $879,000, compared with $6,510, 071 in 1934 and contrasted with a deficit of $916,855 in 1935. The extent of last year's earnings was disclosed in the weekly statement of the Reserve System as of Dec. 31, published yesterday, which gave effect to the usual year-old adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The first challenge of the constitutionality of authority given to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Securities Act of 1934 to compel the registration with it of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets was brought today in the District Supreme Court by J. Edward Jones of New York, a dealer in oil securities.

MADRID, Jan. 2. -- A petition drawn up by monarchist Deputies and supported by some Conservative, Catholic and Republican members of the Chamber today sought to impeach President Alcala Zamora but failed to obtain even half of the required number of signatures.

Five candidates for two places on the United States women's squash racquets team which will meet Great Britain's players in the Wolfe-Noel Cup matches in England next month took the courts at the Junior League yesterday in the first of the preliminary tryouts.

It would seem that both the usual statistics of business trends and the more subtle psychological influences and economic forces are all looking in the direction of gradual business recovery, Ordway Tead, president, Society for the Advancement of Management, formerly the Taylor Society, declared yesterday. "
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had received applications to list the securities of six corporations. The concerns and their issues were:

The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority re-elected Frank C. Ferguson and Howard S. Cullman chairman and vice chairman, respectively, at their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Combined net assets of $36,950,438 on Dec. 31, 1935, before reserves for taxes on unrealized profits, were reported yesterday by three investment companies in the National Investors group -- the Second, the Third and the Fourth National Investors Corporations.

An inter-faith manifesto declaring that slum conditions in New York City constitute an "awful offense against the sanctity of human life" was made public yesterday. It bears the signatures of fifty clergymen and social workers, representatives of the Roman Catholic, Jewish, and Protestant faiths.

The improvement of American flag shipping services to South America as a means of developing freight trade and encouraging passenger travel was urged yesterday by Dr. Alexander V. Dye, newly appointed acting director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.
BERLIN, Jan. 2. -Thw Boerse opened the first trading session of the new year today with a flurry of strength, but prices sagged later into weakness and stagnation.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP). -- New York City's Board of Education today told the State Education Department that granting of the appeal of Miss Rose Freistater, school teacher, who in 1931 was denied a license to teach in New York because of overweight, would set a technical precedent which would "seriously hamper the educational system" in that city.

The threefold combination of rain, fog and temperatures hovering around the freezing mark caused the closing of the main New Jersey highways between the Holland Tunnel and Newark yesterday because of danger to traffic from ice formed by the rain.

Interest payments have been resumed in full on all Austrian dollar bonds in this country, according to a bulletin to be issued today by John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.
ThursTuesWeek Year day. day. Ago. Ago. The value of the dollar on the BELGIUm -- Par 16.95 cents per belga. local foreign exchange market, Demand .

WARSAW, Jan. 2. -- Death sentences for three of the twelve Ukrainian terrorists who have been on trial in a Warsaw court for participation in the assassination of Minister of the Interior Bronislaw Pieracki in June, 1934, was demanded by Prosecuting Attorney Zelenski today at the end of his indictment speech, which took up three days.

PARIS, Jan. 2. -- The proposed permanent neutrality act that is to come before the United States Congress formed the principal topic of conversation in an interview today between Premier Pierre Laval and Under-Secretary William Phillips of the Washington State Department, who is in Paris during the recess of the London Naval Conference.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- The German public received its first intimation of the existence of the scathing report of James G. McDonald and his letter of resignation as League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees from Germany in a short dispatch of the official German news service from Geneva today.

For the second time within a year, Armando Cestola, 31 years old, a taxi driver of 5 Van Dam Street, appeared in Homicide Court yesterday on a charge of homicide resulting from the death of a pedestrian struck by his cab. Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio set bail at $500 for a hearing Jan. 9.

Lack of sympathy for disowned pets and continued cruelty on the part of owners were noted at the sixty-ninth annual meeting yesterday of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, at 50 Madison Avenue.

Business conditions in the United States in 1935 were better than those of a year before, and the outlook is for a moderate but sustained gain in 1936, according to W.S. Farish, chairman of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. Mr. Farish said the petroleum industry had a satisfactory year and that its position was improved.

Republican leaders at Washington seem to be keeping themselves in a state of hyperesthesia. They are taking offense where none was intended. They are ready at an instant's notice, or without any notice at all, to emit cries of pain and protest against the dark ways and vain tricks of the Administration.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Donahue introduced their daughter, Miss Julia Donahue, last night at a supper dance in the Roof Garden of the Pierre, which for the night represented a formal moonlit garden of greens of begonias. Miss Donahue, who attended the Spence School, wore a frock of ice blue lace and net and carried gardenias and spray orchids, while her mother's gown was of all-over beaded fuchsia satin.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2. -- While lawyers for Bruno Richard Hauptmann were completing plans today for the hearing on his petition to the Court of Pardons, State prison officials went ahead with their preparation for his execution.

Full credit for the $9,000,000 electric rate reduction granted to consumers in the city last year by local utility companies was claimed for his department yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Suppose Chairman Fletcher of the Republican National Committee gets free from some broadcasting company the equal time he has demanded for a party answer to the President's annual message. Suppose NBC follows CBS in refusing to give Mr. Fletcher the time, and he decides to pay for it.

It is Lew Brown who has the honor of announcing the season's first new project. Not so new, perhaps, for once again he has on his mind the musical comedy called "Yokel Boy Makes Good," with book and lyrics by himself and score by Harry Akst. Mr. Brown first planned it for last season, then gave it up in favor of "Calling All Stars."

Oscar Rosner, an attorney of 30 Broad Street, took exception yesterday to a statement published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 27, quoting Edmund Van Voorhis, counsel for the receiver of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., as saying that investigators had been unable to locate Straus assets in Philadelphia, Montreal and other places.
MANILA, Jan. 2. -- Philippine constabulary officers disclosed today that a daring mass murder plot had been thwarted with the killing of the bandit chieftain Teodoro Asedillo and two of his aides.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2. -- Dr. Edwin Grant Conklin, Princeton biologist, was elected today to become president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science next December. He will succeed Dr. Karl T. Compton, who took office at the present convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The expenditures of the Republican and Democratic National Committees and the American Liberty League in 1935 totaled $1,092,028.32, according to accounts filed today with the clerk of the House. Contributions to the three organizations totaled more than $1,400,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Bids on fifty-four issues of municipal, county and school-district bonds with an aggregate principal of $5,867,171.92 were asked today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Bids will be opened here at noon on Jan. 16.

Bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation for the five-day week ended on Dec. 31 amounted to $4,991,801,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was a gain of 8.8 per cent over the amount of $4,590,050,000 shown in the previous five-day week, and an increase of 6 per cent over last year's figure of $4,709,221,000.

The outstanding reason for early unification of all rapid transit lines is the conservation of the city's "last shot in the locker," its unexpended margin of $170,000,000 of borrowing power within the constitutional debt limit, City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. said yesterday at a regular meeting of the New York State Chamber of Commerce.

William A. Dalton was renominated yesterday for the presidency of the New York Athletic Club, which will hold its annual election on Jan. 14. At present there is no opposition ticket and, according to officials of the nation's oldest athletic organization, there will be none.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Kent Jr. gave a party this afternoon at their home on Peruvian Avenue in honor of Mr. and Mrs. W. Scott Blanchard of Hewlett, L.I., who have come from Miami to be their house guests. Other guests included:

Warning that the United States is facing "a growing threat of mob rule by pressure groups," Donald A. Hobart, National Commander of the American Veterans Association, appealed yesterday to the forty Senators who sustained President Roosevelt's veto of the Patman Bonus Bill last year to hold the "last defensive trench" at all costs.

Organization of the Furniture Trade Committee, representing most of the big retail furniture merchants in the city and many of the smaller ones, to wage a campaign against alleged deceitful practices on the fringes of the trade, was announced yesterday by Alexander Spear, head of Spear Co., as chairman of the committee.

The New York Americans finally beat the Rangers in the current National Hockey League race. The star-spangled crew led by Red Dutton handed a 6-to-3 defeat to their city rivals at Madison Square Garden last night in a thrilling battle that attracted a crowd of 14,000 cheering spectators.

Signal honors are bestowed on the skeet shooters of New Jersey in general and of the Roseland Community Gun Club in particular in the selection of the 1935 All-America teams, announced yesterday by the National Skeet Shooting Association.

The New York University A squad of Theodore Gold, Murray Steyer and Norman Lewis swept aside three rivals after drawing a bye in the preliminary round to capture the national junior foils team championship for the second year in a row at the Fencers Club last night.

A tentative allotment of $58,365,000 for the construction of the proposed vehicular tunnel under the East River, linking Manhattan with Queens and Brooklyn, was made yesterday by Harold A. Ickes, Federal PWA Administrator, with the approval of President Roosevelt.

Mrs. Charles Miller Billings gave a dinner dance last night in the grill of the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Kenneth Clinton. The debutante and her mother received in a bower of cybotium ferns and Southern smilax.

INSTEAD of telling us all about the wonders that science has achieved since an inventive savage first beat a piece of glowing ore into the semblance of a knife, C.C. Furnas, Associate Professor of Chemical Engineering at Yale, has written a book to demonstrate just how little we know in comparison to what is still to be discovered.
Seventy-six contributors added $705.10 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the Fund's total to date to $245,370.13.

Statements of condition as of Dec. 31, published yesterday by leading banks and trust companies, disclosed large gains in deposits and total resources, carrying the figures in the case of many institutions to the highest levels in their histories.

Directing officials of the Institute of International Finance were examined closely yesterday as the Securities and Exchange Commission, in its local offices, 120 Broadway, ended the inquiry into the activities of foreign bondholders' protective committees.

A refunding plan for the township of North Bergen, N.J., involving approximately $16,000,000 of bonds and notes now in default, has been proposed by the conciliation committee appointed recently at a general meeting of the township's creditors.

Slightly more than 60 per cent of the ballots tabulated thus far in The Literary Digest poll on the New Deal answer "no" to the question, "Do you now approve the acts and policies of the Roosevelt New Deal to date," according to the current issue of the Digest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- A visit to New York City by President Roosevelt on Jan. 19 and a later trip planned to embrace absence from Washington for almost a week in the latter part of February were announced tentatively by the White House today.

The Washington String Quartet, composed of youthful members of the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C., made its first New York appearance yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Organized five years ago, the group, coached by Louis Persinger and Alphonse Onnou, has given concerts in the South.

The year 1935 closed with business at the highest levels in more than five years, and with signs of recovery more widespread than at any time since the turn of the depression was reached in 1932, says the National City Bank in its January bulletin, published yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Leopold Stokowski, who has long felt that a symphony orchestra should be heard and not seen, made the experiment tonight.

Larger volume but unsatisfactory prices in many instances characterized the men's furnishings fields during 1935. Numerous novelties were introduced and caught popular favor and these in their initial stages helped to offset the low quotations on staple items.

The hope of making the ideals of Scouting "a more vigorous and militant force" in meeting the problems facing the country, was expressed yesterday by Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America, when he received the congratulations of leading executives of the nations and his associates upon the completion of twenty-five years of service.

Tenders will be considered by officials of Alamance County, N.C., on Jan. 14 for a new issue of $809,000 of refunding bonds. They will be dated Dec. 1, 1935, and mature from Dec. 1, 1937, to 1950. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

Extension of the Federal music project to give employment to 17,000 idle musicians all over the country was announced yesterday by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, director of the project. The extended program will add 4,000 musicians to the number now employed.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2. -- The scarlet, white and black silks of Joseph E. Widener, making their first appearance of the season at Tropical Park today, were borne to victory in the two races in which the Philadelphia sportsman was represented.

CAPE TOWN, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Xenophen Balaskas, the South African team's young Greek spin bowler, heralded his return to test cricket today by stopping Australia's crack batsmen at a point when it appeared certain they would run up a big score in the third international encounter between the two countries.

With the $123,000,000 allotted by Washington for WPA expenditures in this city nearing exhaustion, Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, returned from the capital yesterday after a conference with Federal relief officials, bringing with him another $5,000,000.

Effects of social-security legislation upon retailers, the government's housing program, the manufacturers' fair-trade practices which have been submitted to the Federal Trade Commission and the report of members' attitude toward the program of the Fashion Originators Guild will be among the major subjects to be discussed or acted upon at the forthcoming silver anniversary convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held from Jan. 20 to 24 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The gold-bloc currencies began the year with renewed weakness yesterday, influenced by news of banking difficulties in Switzerland. The Swiss franc fell 5 1/2 points to 32.51 1/2 cents, the French franc was down 7/8 point to 6.61 5/8 cents and the guilder lost 7 points to 67.96 cents.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Motor vehicle fatalities reached a new high record of about 36,400 in 1935, the National Safety Council reported tonight.

In blaze of extravagant splendor, Verdi's "Aida" reached its second performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Gazed upon merely as a spectacle it conveyed constant pleasure to the eye, not only by its sumptuous scenic investiture, but also because of the glowing color combinations afforded by the fresh, new costumes provided with a lavish hand for this production.

Declaring that the people of New York would either end the 2 per cent sales tax or end the administration responsible for it, the City Affairs Committee urged Mayor La Guardia yesterday to forego his plan for extending the tax through the whole of this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner tonight in honor of the Vice President and Mrs. Garner, the company including leaders of the Senate and House, the Ambassador to Mexico and Mrs. Josephus Daniels; the Mayor of New York and Mrs. La Guardia, and Sir Arthur and Lady Willert, who arrived this afternoon from New York and are overnight guests at the White House.
PARIS, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 2. -- Reports today that only two Swedes had been wounded in the Italian air bombardment near Polo in Ethiopia were received with relief in Stockholm, but anger is still prevalent as the Swedes become more convinced that the attack was deliberate.

The demand of Republican National Chairman Henry P. Fletcher that the radio broadcasting systems afford to the Republicans an opportunity to answer President Roosevelt's address of tonight was acceded to by the National Broadcasting System yesterday.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- An explosion, believed to have been caused by illuminating gas, wrecked the two-story building of the Elmira Savings Bank, of which former Lieut. Gov. Seymour Lowman is president, at 8:17 o'clock tonight, causing damage tentatively estimated at $100,000.

The champion colt, Omaha, owned by William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, will be shipped to England next Wednesday aboard the Aquitania of the Cunard White Star Line, according to an announcement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The American Federation of Labor and the international union chiefs of the Longshoremen and Seamen's Unions will make efforts here to cope with what they regard as a threat of Harry Bridges, left wing San Francisco marine union leader, to dominate both the licensed and unlicensed personnel among sailors, and to control the longshoremen and other marine union members in all ports.

Paine, Webber Co. will offer publicly today 20,900 shares of 7 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, of $25 par value, of Stokely Brothers Co., at par. The shares were purchased by the bankers from a stockholder and the offering does not represent any new financing for the company. Stokely Brothers Co. are canners of vegetables.

ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 2. -- Ethiopian information is that the Italians on the northern front are consolidating their lines along the Adigrat-Makale road and withdrawing exposed detachments in the Gheralta area and further east.
A trip to Europe, planned forty-two years ago and never taken, has created a problem in the offices of Thomas Cook Son-Wagon-Lits, Inc., international tourist agency.

Although Dr. Alexandre Alekhine made a great bid to tie the score in the final stages of his recent match for the world's championship with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the new champion, he found the defense of the latter too powerful to be overcome in the twenty-eighth and twenty-ninth games.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- The London Stock Exchange began the new trading year generally cheerful today, with prices better in virtually all sections. The firm tone was laid to the good news regarding employment and trade.

The first suit based on claims for damages as a result of the administration's gold policy was filed yesterday in Federal court. The plaintiff was the British-American Tobacco Company, Ltd., distributer of tobacco products here and abroad.

Two girl employes from the John Wanamaker store climbed four flights to the top floor rear apartment at 43 West Eighth Street during the lunch hour yesterday to learn why Mrs. Patsy Ann Lifford, one of the buyers, had not come to work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--Plans were completed tonight to throw the neutrality fight into both houses of Congress as soon as that body reaches a business stage of the session that opens tomorrow.

Mayor La Guardia and Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx accused each other of being headline hunters yesterday as an aftermath of Mr. Lyons' report on the Emergency Relief Bureau, which recommended dropping 7,000 relief employes and cutting the bureau's administrative costs.

The decoration of Commander of the Order of Orange Nassau has been conferred on James G. McDonald by the Queen of the Netherlands in recognition of his work as High Commissioner for Refugees From Germany, it was learned yesterday.

The letter of Miss Esther M. Brink in your issue of this morning urging the erection of the central building for the Brooklyn Public Library should command the gratitude of all who are interested in the intellectual opportunities of Brooklyn.

The city campaign to vacate and raze the worst of the firetrap tenements got under way yesterday when Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, sent a staff of 125 inspectors to make a survey of slum areas in four boroughs.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2.--A new electron tube which virtually supplies man with a "third eye" and literally sees the heretofore invisible and includes the infra-red and the ultra-violet for the first time in man's range of vision, was given its first demonstration today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 2. -- Representatives of nineteen States of North, Central and South America assembled this morning at the inaugural session of the labor conference, which is being held in the Chilean Congress Building.

The Glidden Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $2,645,590 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equal, after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent prior preference stock, to $3.23 a share on 678,883 no-par shares of common stock outstanding (average) during the year, and $2.91 a share on 758,881 outstanding at the end of the year.

With outstanding quartets from the New York Curb Exchange, Manhattan College, New York University, Columbia and the New York Athletic Club among the fifty-eight relay teams entered in three races, the baton-passing events promise to be among the most attractive features of the annual track and field meet of the Columbus Council K. of C. at the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, tomorrow night.
The money market was as quiet and uneventful in the first session of the new year as the preceding markets. The demand for money was light, and quotations unchanged for all classifications.

The white flag with its five interlocking circles that waved at Chamonix, St. Moritz and Lake Placid will be run up to the masthead of the S.S. Manhattan this morning as the main group of the American Olympic Winter sports team sails for Garmisch-Partenkirchen and the fourth Olympic Winter Games.

Sasha Siemel, veteran of more than a quarter of a century of big game hunting in South America with such hunters as the late Theodore Roosevelt and his sons, returned to New York yesterday aboard the Munson liner Pan America.

Irregularity developed on local markets yesterday. Coffee, cocoa, wool tops and cottonseed oil futures were higher and other staples were steady or weak. On the cash markets tin sagged, while gains were made by all the grains, cotton, wool tops and cocoa.

In the Vanderbilt, Center and South galleries of the American Fine Arts Building the American Water-Color Society has installed its sixty-ninth annual exhibition, which opens with a private view from 8:30 to 11 o'clock this evening, while in the academy room (once playfully known as the morgue) the National Academy is holding an exhibition of portraits by contemporary artists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Early and favorable action on the proposed equal rights amendment sponsored by the National Woman's Party will be urged at the coming session of Congress by an active group in both houses, led by Senator Townsend of Delaware and Representative Ludlow of Indiana, and including more than a hundred of their colleagues.

The United States liner Manhattan sails today for Hamburg and other European ports. Her passengers will include fifty athletes, comprising the official party of those who will represent the United States in the Winter Olympics at Garmisch-Partenkirchen next month.

A large part of the excess reserves held by banks in this city is in reality idle funds belonging to their correspondent banks in other localities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in a discussion of recent fluctuations in reserve balances contained in the January review of the bank, published yesterday.

Henry Lasky, 43-year-old founder of the Lasky Motor Car Company of Williamsburg and a leader in civic and charitable organizations, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning at 6 o'clock last evening in the garage of his home at 990 East Twenty-third Street, at Avenue J, in the East Midwood district of Flatbush.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 2. -- Gaining his sixth victory at the expense of H. Golombek of London, member of the British international team, in the seventh round at the White Rock Pavilion today, Reuben Fine of New York added to his lead in the masters' Tournament at the annual Christmas Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club.

Business in the year 1936 will have the difficult problem of keeping one eye on the possibility of realizing profits from the recovery and keeping the other eye on the ground over which it must travel in the attainment of a "safe and sane" recovery, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 31, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks was $2,488,000,000, a decrease of $31,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $20,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

The actual count of sales made by Baker Taylor, book wholesalers, for the month Nov. 18 to Dec. 16 shows that "Valiant Is the Word for Carrie," by Barry Benefield, was the best-selling novel throughout the country for that period. "It Can't Happen Here," by Sinclair Lewis, was second, and "Silas Crockett," by Mary Ellen Chase, was third.

TRENTON, Jan. 2. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman urged the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce today to move without delay the further proposals to establish a free port on the New Jersey side of the New York Harbor. A zone in which foreign goods might be reshipped without duty payments would offer mutual advantages to foreign commercial interests and New Jersey business, the Governor said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Excerpts from the article which will appear in the current issue of the Red Book Magazine were released for publication today by Senator Borah.

Chandler A. Mackey, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, said yesterday that the exchange entered its fifty-fifth year of trading with confidence. Uncertainties always would handicap business, he added, referring to legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- A New York Jeweler testified today at the Securities and Exchange Commission hearing into alleged stock manipulation by Michael J. Meehan of New York that he had Mr. Meehan buy him 2,000 shares of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation stock which Mr. Meehan is accused of rigging.

In THE TIMES of Dec. 28 there appeared a dispatch from your Tokyo correspondent reporting the statement of the Japanese Foreign Office spokesman that the patriotic demonstrations of Chinese students were led by the missionary institutions and agitated by the American missionaries.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2. -- America's Olympic hockey team was hard-pressed to beat the Princeton six in a contest in the Hobey Baker Rink tonight, finally coming out on top by a 2-1 count in a fast and well-played contest.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 2. -- The Italian bombing of a Swedish ambulance unit is arousing much comment here, the general feeling being that what has happened to the Swedes may well happen tomorrow to the Netherland Red Cross ambulance unit that has just arrived in Ethiopia.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted to be at the lowest point of the year. The ratio of reserve for the New York Bank reached a new high figure for the year.

The Building Service Employes Union announced yesterday that it had served demands upon owners representing more than 10,000 apartment buildings, hotels, department stores and loft and office structures in the city calling for wage increases, reductions in hours and a closed shop.

Brokers and renting agents of buildings in Manhattan reported a large volume of business space rentals yesterday. The demand for office, showroom and store quarters was featured by contracts for several entire floors.

ROME, Jan. 2. -- Reported atrocities of the Ethiopians against Italian aviators are apparently to be used as a reason for carrying on the war in a severer and more ruthless manner than hitherto. The feeling is widespread throughout Italy that too much velvet glove and not enough mailed fist has been evident in the way the campaign has been carried on so far.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Sitting for the first time since the operation of the Money Payments (Justice Procedure) Act designed to save minor offenders and debtors from prison, Magistrate Harold McKenna in the Marylebone Police Court had before him today a ship steward charged with drunkenness who asked "the favor of being jailed."

Basing her observation upon a three months' sojourn in Great Britain and writing under the caption "England Also Has Her Crimes," Gertrude Hills endeavors to convey the impression that England is as prolific in crime as the United States, and by implication that the Lindberghs would have been as safe at home.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2. -- Harvard College Observatory, in collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is planning to send a joint expedition to Soviet Russia to observe the total eclipse of the sun, June 19 of this year, it was stated here tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Anthony Eden, M.C., M.P., member of the King's Privy Council and now at 38 His Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, came down to London from Yorkshire today and took up his job. A British writer the other day called it one of the biggest and hardest jobs there are in the present state of the world, and that is true.

Thanks to the absence of six Democrats, two of whom were ill, the Republicans were able to organize the Assembly. Doubtless the other four were victims of absence of mind, though their leader, Mr. STEINGUT, had ordered all his force to report for duty. It is easy to forgive a fault of memory that made the Assembly ready for business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Striking out at demands for restrictions on Supreme Court power, Senator Borah declared today that efforts at further "centralization of leadership" in the Presidency smacked of a drive for fascism.
ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Senate Democrats changed their minds today about pushing their own anti-crime bills in advance of the program to be submitted later by Governor Lehman.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

An additional twenty-four independent radio stations throughout the nation have signified their intention of accepting the provisional three months' contract offered by Warner Brothers, permitting them to use music published by the Warner-owned firms which withdrew from the American Society of Authors, Composers and Musicians in November, the film company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Leaders of the three major veterans' associations, seeing eye to eye for the first time since the bonus question became an issue, completed today the draft of the new Legion-Vinson measure calling for a cash outlay of about $1,000,000,000.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 9 (AP). -- George W. Norris, grocer, who in 1930 attempted to oppose Senator George W. Norris in his campaign for re-election, today was sentenced to three months in jail and fined $100 for perjury in connection with his testimony before a United States Senate investigating committee.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo handed down yesterday an opinion reaffirming an injunction he granted last year against picketing of a Bronx department store, but modifying the basis of his decision. He held that his original decision was not affected by a subsequent Court of Appeals ruling.
Alfred Miller, an anti-Nazi German, who arrived here as a quota immigrant in 1929, faces deportation from the United States on Jan. 22, unless a writ of habeas corpus in him behalf prevents it.

In his transit talk before the Chamber of Commerce yesterday Chamberlain BERLE shifted the base of the conventional unification argument somewhat. Unification, we have been told by earlier laborers in the vineyard, would result in large savings in interest and overhead.

Members of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association, following their annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker, announced yesterday they would hold their thirteenth annual dinner, frolic and minstrel show on Feb. 2 in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- The world's wheat markets advanced today into new high ground on the current movement as the result of a broad overseas demand for grain. The May delivery on the Board of Trade here at the top was 1 1/4 cents a bushel above Tuesday's finish, and it touched $1.02 7/8, or within 4 1/8 cents of the best figure of the season, established early in October.

The first of the monthly index numbers of average commodity prices, that of Dun's Review, was given out yesterday. It figures an increase during December of two-tenths of 1 per cent. The net increase for the full year 1935 was slightly less than 3 per cent, but the present index number is the highest reported at the beginning of any year since 1930.

Your editorial "The Silver Purchase Mess" is accurate and conservative in statement. You might have gone further. You recall that President Roosevelt sent Professor Rogers of Yale to the Orient to make a report on the implications of our purchase of silver on Eastern economy.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--On the heels of a plea for harmony by Governor Lehman, the Republicans in the Legislature gave evidence today that they intended to fight the Governor and the New Deal tooth and nail, opening fire on the Chief Executive on several fronts.

The right of the city's thirty-two "locality Mayors" to vie with Mayor La Guardia in displaying metal symbols of their office on their automobiles was upheld yesterday by Magistrate Alexander Brough in the Tombs Court.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alexander P. Gray of Paterson and New York gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Essex County Country Club here to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Caroline Hobart Gray. The debutante and her mother were assisted in receiving by the Misses Betty Bowne Strange of South Orange, Katherine Fiske of Providence, R.I.; Jane Wiske of Bronxville, N.Y., and Jane Randall of Paterson.

An offering to the public will be made today of a new issue of $8,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and Hiram Walker Sons Distilleries, Inc., by an underwriting group in Canada and the United States headed by Hornblower Weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- Westchester County is a "patchwork" of school districts, resulting in inequalities of educational facilities and taxation among the four cities of the county, according to another report of the Institute of Public Administration made public today by the Westchester County Commission on Government.

After demurring yesterday on the request of District Attorney William C. Dodge for an additional $50,000 to prosecute bond and mortgage cases, Mayor La Guardia asked his colleagues on the Board of Estimate to establish a policy on special prosecutors and their expenses.

Real estate activity in this city yesterday was featured by the sale of an apartment house on a Madison Avenue corner and deals for multi-family buildings in other sections of Manhattan and in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Figures to show the millions which Irving Wexler (Waxey Gordon) made through his "racket" as a beer baron are set forth in a brief presented by the government to the Supreme Court today asking the court to uphold Wexler's ten-year sentence for evading income tax laws.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- All bids received for eighty-two new army pursuit planes were set aside today by Harry H. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, who reported that the planes thus far developed were not considered satisfactory. New bids have been requested and the opening date set for April 15. An official statement declared:

In addition to an expansion in factors' volume during 1935, the use of these organizations, confined chiefly in previous years to textiles, spread rapidly to other industries, according to leading executives in the field. Among the new industries which adopted this method more widely were electrical appliances, petroleum, clothing, paper, furniture, automotive and hardware accessories and tires.

MONTREAL, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons crushed their bitterest National Hockey League rivals, the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 2, tonight in a game that wound up with one of the season's most spectacular fist fights and a collection of penalties that looked like a record.
ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- A bill designed to permit New York City to pave the way for the world's fair there in 1939 was introduced today by Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr., Manhattan Republican.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2. -- The Southern Methodist Mustangs took an intentional sightseeing ride today to Hollywood's movie studios. And Stanford's football Cardinals shouted to the four winds how they rode the Mustangs to defeat, 7 -- 0, in the Rose Bowl yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- With the air surcharged with partisanship over President Roosevelt's decision to address a spectacular joint session tomorrow night, Washington tonight was awaiting the convening of the final session of the Seventy-fourth Congress convinced that it would be productive of more political strategy than legislation.

The results of City College elections were announced yesterday by Bernard Kanerek, chairman of the elections committee. The Independent Student Rights party won all but three positions to retain control.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The law gained a victory in a race with death today with the capture of Tommy Touhy, last of the "terrible Touhy" gang, said to be doomed by illness.

In a quiet holiday week The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.5 point to 129.4 on Tuesday from 129.9 (revised) on the Tuesday previous. Most of the grains were higher, but hogs and cattle were lower.

Miss Elsa Maxwell gave a ball last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for several hundred of her friends. Miss Maxwell is internationally known for her entertainments -- those she has given as private parties and others arranged in behalf of charity -- and last night's ball, fitting the former classification, was one of the most unusual and colorful fetes given here in many years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra for twenty-three years, has turned down a new three-year contract to devote his attention to "research work" in music.

Last night in Carnegie Hall an audience listened to a man who is in the second place a conductor and in the first a true musician -- in fact, when he is in the mood of last night, a very great musician -- Sir Thomas Beecham, who then made his first appearance of the season as guest leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

New York University's varsity basketball team continued all three of its winning streaks as it went on a rampage at the expense of Princeton's five last night before a capacity gathering in the University Heights gymnasium. The score was 60 to 34, with Coach Howard G. Cann sending every one of his nineteen men into the contest before the final gun sounded.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, president of Antioch College, Yellow Springs, Ohio, and chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said yesterday that there is "nothing in sight" that would so quickly restore economic welfare in this country as the establishment of universal low-price power rates similar to those prevailing in the TVA development area.

Governor Lehman's recommendation to the Legislature that his proposed social service program be financed by a "moderate" increase in the tax on alcoholic beverages evoked an immediate and antagonistic reaction yesterday both from the liquor industry and from authorities on the liquor problem.
LONDON. Jan. 2. -- Legislation for the protection of the British investing public was recommended tonight by a Stock Exchange committee which for a year has been investigating "fixed trusts."
Mr. and Mrs. John Gerdes gave a large dinner party last night at their home, 830 Park Avenue, for their daughter, Miss Janet Gerdes, who will make her debut next season. Among the guests were:

Lower rates for charitable institutions or voluntary hospitals, representing an annual saving of $100,000, were filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday by the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company system. They will apply to institutions supported wholly or in part by public subscription and not conducted for profit.
The Fund for New York's Neediest Cases was increased to $246,081.63 yesterday by sixty-five contributions, totaling $711.50.

In preparation for the annual election of officers on Feb. 10, the nominating committee of the New York Curb Exchange submitted yesterday its slate of candidates for the governing committee and trustees of the Exchange's gratuity fund.

While trading on the floor of the Stock Exchange proceeded yesterday at a pace closely approaching 3,000,000 shares for the day, announcement was made of the first proposed sale of a membership in 1936. The price was $149,000, representing a gain of $4,000 over the last previous transfer, on Dec. 30, and a rise of $14,000 within little more than a week.

The Mayor's special Queens bus committee met yesterday in the office of the Franchise Bureau of the Board of Estimate and interviewed bus operators in the Long Island City area of Queens. It was announced later the area would be taken over under the four-zone bus franchise plan by the Tri-Boro Coach Company which bought out four other operators in the zone.

WARSAW, Jan. 3. -- The gates of Polish prisons were opened this morning to release nearly 27,000 inmates under the amnesty voted by Parliament shortly before Christmas to commemorate the new Polish Constitution.

Declaring that universities in the totalitarian States of Russia, Germany and Italy were "dead except as names," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, yesterday called on the leaders of scholarship in the other Western countries to get "on the firing line" and furnish "disinterested, constant, liberal-minded, forward-looking leadership toward liberty."

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP). -- "Technological developments and increased efficiency in production methods" were the reasons given tonight by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, for the failure of employment to keep pace with business recovery in 1935.

While the usual Christmas aftermath lowered retail sales in all districts this week, wholesalers in most of the leading markets gave their attention to the largest volume of orders received at this season in four years, according to the survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Loans to member firms on securities increased $92,328,515 in December, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The loan total at the end of the month was $938,441,652, compared with $846,113,137 at the close of November.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- Count Konrad Preysing, recently appointed Catholic Bishop of Berlin, who was installed in his new position in the capital and removed from his country diocese in order that he might deal with the government, has arranged a renewed temporary truce.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- The Polish Embassy estimates the number of Polish Jews expelled from the Reich last year at approximately fifty. The embassy does not claim to have exact statistics and has issued no official report on the subject.

Lester F. Scott, national secretary of the Camp Fire Girls, announced last night the names of twelve Camp Fire executives who won the 1935 executive honor awards. The announcement was made in the Hotel Astor, where almost 100 persons attended the dinner of the national executives' conference.

Now that New Year's Eve has come and gone, the holiday season all but sped and the sizable sums of money which changed hands during the interlude safely banked, the beaming nocturnal nabobs are leaning back in their chairs, lighting big black cigars and regarding the immediate future benignly.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Heminway, who will return to New York this week-end after a visit at Villa del Sarmiento, were honored by Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien with a dinner tonight for eighteen persons and a luncheon today for ten.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- The American Federation of Labor tallied up its own November employment figures today and decided that "although business has now recovered half its depression loss, only 30 per cent of the depression unemployed have been put to work."

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S message to Congress last evening was couched in vigorous language. His defense of his own Administration was, as had been indicated in advance, a challenge to his political enemies and a rallying summons to his supporters. This was fully expected after his Atlanta speech, also tn a fighting vein.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- First impressions of President Roosevelt's message to Congress here are that it will make the British Government less disposed to press for an oil embargo in Geneva and at the same time will strengthen the hands of those in the Cabinet who believe that existing sanctions are severe enough.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The members of the Governor's commission which reported on unemployment relief are as follows:

The price-fixing provisions of the New York State Milk Control Law, which expires April 1, are no longer necessary to sustain the market in the opinion of many members of the New York and New Jersey Milk Institute who attended a closed meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Ten golfers shattered par today as two Easterners took a first-round lead in the Riverside $3,000 open tournament.

A stockholders' suit for an accounting and return of assets allegedly wasted was filed in Supreme Court yesterday against the Long Island Lighting Company, Ellis L. Phillips, its president, and twenty-eight present and former directors of the company. The complaint charged that the directors "grossly mismanaged" the company and wasted its assets for the benefit of a few.

The Associated Press went to Federal court yesterday in its fight with the Newspaper Guild over the dismissal of Morris Watson, one of its New York reporters, who is vice-president of the guild's national organization.

Negotiations between the trustees in bankruptcy of the Western Pacific Railroad and the company's bondholders have reached a point where it is hope to come to an agreement on a reorganization by the end of the month, it was disclosed yesterday in financial circles.

Elmer J. Willets, 37 years old, a former boxer; his wife, Kate, 31, and their only child, Dolores, 7, were found dead of illuminating gas yesterday morning in their small flat on the top floor of a three-story frame building at 644 Fourth Avenue, near Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- American rights to ship directly or indirectly as much essential war materials as belligerents may wish to buy; to travel under government protection on vessels of warring nations; and to extend to such nations broad, financial credits or to sell and acquire their securities are permanently abandoned in the new Neutrality Bill endorsed by the administration.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Setting the pace for a field of 143 starters, Jules Huot of Quebec, Canadian P.G.A. champion, took the lead by a stroke today for the first eighteen holes of the $2,500 Miami open golf tourney at the Miami Springs Country Club.

The new Soldiers' Bonus Bill was formally introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday, and an examination of its text reveals that it is fully as bad as advance accounts of it forecast. Not only does it provide for immediate cash payment of every bonus certificate upon presentation to the Government.

Police of the Morrisania station were puzzled last night when they broke into a flat at 764 Home Street, the Bronx, and found an elderly woman dead and an elderly man unconscious, both apparently the victims of exposure and starvation, although there was plenty of fuel for the kitchen stove and plenty of food on the shelves.

There will be racing of the twelve-meter one-design class on Long Island Sound next Summer for the first time in several years. The three new owners of the "twelves" have banded to form a division which assures fine racing, it was learned yesterday.

Despite the fact that followers of the share market were quite as much in the dark as anybody else yesterday as to what points would be stressed in President Roosevelt's message to Congress, stocks had their biggest day, from the standpoint of volume, since Dec. 4; transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 2,831,000 shares.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3. -- The Soviet Union has already begun the New Year with certain novelties as revealed in today's newspapers.

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 3. -- Lieut. Col. Herbert E. Marshburn, United States military attache here, was decorated with the Mexican Medal of Honor in a ceremony at the military college today. The decoration was conferred by General Salvador Sanchez, representing President Lazaro Cardenas and the Minister of War.

Borough President James J. Lyons again characterized Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a "top-notcher and expert" on gathering headlines for himself. Mr. Lyons's latest statement on his investigation of the Emergency Relief Bureau repeated substantially what he had said before.

Gus Sonnenberg of Boston was declared the winner over Joe Savoldi, Three Oaks, Mich., in 36 minutes of the finish wrestling match by Referee Joe Boyle at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night, when the former Notre Dame star butted Sonnenberg to the floor while the latter was outside the ropes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Chief Justice Alfred A. Wheat, in the District of Columbia Supreme Court, today ordered dismissal of the suit brought by the township of Franklin, N.J., and four property owners, to restrain Rexford Guy Tugwell, Rural Resettlement Administrator, from establishing a "model community" there.
Delegates to the annual meeting of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, assembled at the Hotel Vanderbilt last night, heard the welcome news of returning prosperity.

With Robert Jordan contributing 18 points, the Poly Prep quintet launched its campaign by crushing Trinity School of Manhattan, 38 -- 9, in an Eastern Private Schools League game at the Poly gymnasium in Brooklyn. The contest, which marked the opening of the league competition, was one of the features of the scholastic basketball program yesterday.

By beating the Princeton Club in a hard-fought match at the resumption of the playing-schedule last night, the Columbia Club Class B squash tennis team enhanced its chances of giving the Harvard Club a race for honors in the metropolitan league.

WASHINGTON, Jan 3. -- A permanent neutrality policy for the United States, intended to keep this country clear of military or economic entanglements which might drag it into war, was offered to Congress today as the first business desired by administration forces on both sides of the Capitol.

Uncertainty over the United States Supreme Court's decisions which are expected on Monday, overshadowed trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, causing liquidation that brought net losses of 5 to 9 points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- An analysis of the administration's Permanent Neutrality Bill, made public today by Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and co-author of the measure, is as follows:

In connection with the specimens of solenodons in the Bronx Zoo it may be of interest to note that I was the first person to secure specimens of these strange creatures after they had been completely lost to science for over seventy years.

Viola Mitchell, the talented young violinist from Pittsburgh, who was heard here last season as soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, gave her first New York recital last night in the Town Hall. Her program, an imposing and exacting one, included the Vitali "Chaconne, in G minor," the Brahms D minor sonata, the Malipiero concerto, and shorter items by Ysaye, Debussy and Ravel.
Most commodity futures were higher on the local markets yesterday, with trading more active. On the cash markets wheat, rye, lard and silk declined, while corn, oats and rubber advanced.

An appetite for candy, whetted by more than two weeks of panhandling on the Bowery, was the undoing early yesterday of two youths who escaped from the Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, Dec. 16 and started another foray into crime in St. George, S.I.
BERLIN, Jan. 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for Dec. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- President Roosevelt divided his message to Congress between a discussion of world affairs and American neutrality and an attack on the opposition to the New Deal. A topical summary follows:
New State and municipal bond issues scheduled for effering next week total $18,894,847 in sixty-three separate loans, against a revised total of $10,362,266 this week.
R.G.B.'s letter is a very important sidelight on our ever-increasing automobile accident rate.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 3. -- Corridors of apartment houses at 363 and 357 Lincoln Avenue, here, were thrown into wild confusion this afternoon when Thomas Neilan, 26 years old, an escaped inmate of Overbrook Hospital, ran through the buildings screaming and brandishing a pruning knife and a hatchet.
Frankie Klick's title hopes crashed against the unorthodox style of Lou Ambers last night in the feature of a lightweight card at Madison Square Garden that drew 8,000 fight fans, of whom 7,817 paid.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Virtually discarding the theory that gas leakage caused the blast which wrecked the three-story Elmira Savings Bank building last night, investigators today awaited the arrival of an explosive expert from the New York City Police Department.

In the presence of Supreme Court Justices McCook and Black, Frederick O'Byrne, Commissioner of Jurors, drew a special panel of 100 names yesterday afternoon. From these will be chosen on Jan. 24 the twenty-three members of the new grand jury that will succeed the grand jury which has been investigating rackets in New York County.
ADDIS ABABA, Jan. 3. -- A threatened revolt in Gojjam Province added to the difficulties today of the Ethiopian Government, already fighting Italian invasions on two borders.

The post-holiday letdown in retail trade in the metropolitan area was not excessively pronounced, with stores here finding fairly good response to clearances and special promotions of Winter merchandise. Furs, domestics and white goods, lingerie and liquors gave a good account of themselves in the course of the week.

MANILA, Jan. 3. -- President Manuel Quezon at a press conference today unleashed a frontal attack on Manila newspapers, declaring that unless the accuracy in political reporting improved he would take over the radio station and give out his own information.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Asserting the right to lower the price of milk in New York City, the Borden's Farm Products Company, Inc., told the Supreme Court today that the State Milk Control Act would lead to "political intrigue" and "oppression."

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Renovation of America's home furnishings will be a big accomplishment of 1936, manufacturers, gathering for the industry's annual Winter show, agreed today. And from kitchen to front hall the new domestic scenery for the American family will be on modernistic lines. Walnut is the favored wood.

More than 2,000 members of the Building Service Employes Union met in the Star Casino, 105 East 107th Street, last night and voted approval of the new wage and employment demands which were served by officers of their union upon apartment, hotel, department store and office building owners of the city last Wednesday.

Friction between the Department of Parks and the local Works Progress Administration such as developed when General Hugh S. Johnson was WPA Administrator here has recurred under the latter's successor in the post, Victor F. Ridder.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, criticized President Roosevelt's address, shortly after it was delivered last night, in a speech at a mass meeting in Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue. The meeting was held in connection with the national executive committee meeting of the Socialist party to be held today and tomorrow in Philadelphia.

The first all-metropolitan bill will be offered in Madison Square Garden tonight when the third of the college basketball double-headers is staged before another large crowd. New York University, riding on the crest of a fifteen-game streak, will play unbeaten Fordham in the feature, while St. John's, winner of seven straight, will attempt to halt City College in the preliminary scheduled for 8:15 P.M.

The renewed decline in the price of silver in London, which began on Thursday, was accelerated yesterday when the spot quotation dropped 7/8d to 21 1/2d an ounce. This price was equal to about 47.73 cents an ounce and represented a recession of 1d, or nearly 2 cents, from the best quotation reached on the recovery.

The protective committee for holders of National Public Service Corporation 5 per cent debentures has informed holders of the debentures that it has been negotiating for six months with important public utility interests which have been seeking control of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

Winning the last event of the program, the 400-yard relay, City College's varsity swimming team defeated the Manhattan College team, 40 -- 31, in a hotly contested dual meet at the C.C.N.Y. pool last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Westchester's administration of public welfare, heretofore regarded as far above the average, was criticized by the Institute of Public Administration in another of its reports to the Westchester Commission on Government made public today.

Organization of the New York State Section of the National Committee for Reciprocal Trade was effected at a luncheon and conference held here yesterday. The section will cooperate with similar groups in other States. B.C. Budd was elected chairman of the New York group and Clifford L. Webster will serve as secretary.

The second of the Junior Assemblies for this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, drawing an attendance of several hundred young persons, including most of the debutantes and many of their young men friends.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 3. -- About fifty men and women guests fled into a driving rain when fire, discovered shortly after 2 A.M. today, destroyed the five-story brick and frame Hotel Biltmore, at Rhode Island and Oriental Avenues, a block from the Boardwalk, here. The loss was estimated at $150,000.

Banks and trust companies of this city continued yesterday to issue statements of conditions as of the year-end, disclosing large increases in deposits and total resources, in most cases to new high figures.

DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 3. -- Edsel B. Ford, president of Ford Motor Company, announced hers today that a new $25-a-month-plan for financing retail purchases of new Ford V-8 automobiles will be effective immediately in the United States.

An Eighth Avenue property that has been held in one ownership for more than half a century passed to new control yesterday when Wright estate sold a corner a few blocks north of Madison Square Garden.

New methods of furnishing the American home in modern fashion will be demonstrated to the public beginning next Monday in Forward House 1936, an interpretation of recent trends in interior decoration, at R.H. Macy Co.

The maternity ward of Lincoln Hospital, in the Bronx, was ordered closed last night by Dr. Mark L. Fleming, general medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals, immediately after a conference of thirteen obstetricians and pediatricians of city hospitals to determine a preventive for an unknown form of dysentery that took more than forty infant lives during 1935 and recently appeared in Lincoln Hospital.

The thaw following the cold spell caused flooded streets and cellars throughout the city yesterday as the temperature rose to 51 degrees, a difference of 19 degrees from normal. The twenty-four-hour precipitation ended at noon was 1.71 inches.

The American General Corporation, formed recently through the merger of several units in the United Founders group of investment companies, reported yesterday its opening balance sheet for Nov. 23, showing total assets of $52,757,464.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The first organized movement in New York State to block election of delegates to the Republican national convention favorable to the nomination of Senator William E. Borah has been started in the Third Judicial District after a secret meeting here of the seven Republican leaders in the territory.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The text of the "united front" Bonus Bill, introduced in the House today by Representative Vinson of Kentucky, follows:

The shipping house of Isbrandtsen, Moller, Inc., 24 Broadway, operators of ships throughout the world, obtained yesterday an injunction against the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce, which has ordered it to file its freight rates on all services operating to and from American ports.

The new year started this week with the public offering of $11,650,000 in new bond issues, represented by one industrial loan and two flotations by Massachusetts. This compares with only $7,534,750 last week, and $4,310,000 in the corresponding period of last year.

Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, who is directing the WPA theatre project, spoke to 450 members of Actors Equity Association yesterday afternoon at a discussion-meeting at the Astor. She explained the work of the project, saying that about 6,000 persons are now enrolled in the scheme, and asked Equity and other organizations and individuals interested in the theatre to give the WPA a period of grace in which to get playing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--Bonus legislation, which was hailed yesterday by the combined leadership of the three major veterans' organizations as certain of early passage, was in a snarl tonight, which threatened to delay final action on it for weeks.

Brooklyn building activity tripled last year as compared with 1934, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Edwin H. Thatcher, Brooklyn Building Commissioner. Some of the increase, it was said, was attributed to owners who had received Federal loans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The Republican Congressional Committee, of which Robert V. Fleming is treasurer, received $55,534.41 and spent $28,788.92 in 1935, according to a report filed today with the Clerk of the House. The receipts of the Republican Senatorial and Congressional Committee, of which Perry K. Heath is treasurer, were $18,084.82, and expenditures $18,975.40.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 3. -- The Protestant theological faculty of the University of Bonn issued an appeal to the public today which reveals the low estate to which the State-controlled theological faculties in Germany have fallen and the extent to which they have been replaced by "catacomb seminaries."

PEIPING, Jan. 3. -- With six important districts along the Jehol-Chahar border becoming virtually autonomous over the year's end, 400 Northern university and middle school students have launched a pilgrimage afoot to Nanking with the avowed purpose of arousing the masses into action against the recent changes and against further changes in North China.
BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- Prices on the Boerse were mixed again today in generally inactive trading. No changes of any real significance were recorded.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The report of Governor Lehman's Commission on Unemployment Relief submitted today, after a year of preparation, its fifth since its creation on Aug. 15, 1934, deals with organization for permanent public relief services in New York State and localities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Government attorneys said today that they would call William Wigmore of the New York Curb Exchange to testify before the Securities Commission on Monday in their effort to establish that Michael J. Meehan, Wall Street operator, rigged Bellanca Aircraft stock last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The fighting speech which was President Roosevelt's annual message to the final session of the Seventy-fourth Congress was received by the overwhelming Democratic majority of both houses tonight in the challenging spirit in which it was delivered.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens announced yesterday the dismissal of four assistants on his staff and the promotion of three others. He refused to make any statement or comment on his action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Apparently expecting an examination of some length before the special Senate committee investigating the munitions industry, J.P. Morgan and his staff have taken twenty or more rooms at the Shoreham.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The text of President Roosevelt's annual message to Congress was as follows:

Lady Armstrong, representative in England of the International Council of the Federation of Catholic Alumnae, will be the guest at a luncheon to be given today at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Mrs. Philip A. Brennan, president of the council.

Kenneth S. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, announced last night that he and Warren B. Ashmead, Queens County chairman, and Sheriff John Timlin, Richmond County chairman, would attend the conference called for this afternoon at the National Republican Club by Hamilton Fish Jr., who has undertaken to organize the State for Senator William E. Borah, candidate for the Republican nomination for President.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Four national long course swimming records were bettered today as a field of speedsters opened the two-day Orlando Olympic stars' aquatic meet.

Plans to provide for the religious and social needs of Jewish patients in hospitals and homes on Welfare Island were discussed yesterday at a meeting of a special committee of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women held at the home of Mrs. Sidney B. Erlanger, chairman, at 1,100 Park Avenue.

The five borough presidents joined yesterday to fight against any revision of the city charter that, in their opinion, would harm the autonomy of their boroughs. The decision was reached at a private luncheon in the City Club.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 3. -- The total income of the three Travelers insurance companies for 1935 exceeded $218,955,000, the largest in the history of the organization, according to preliminary annual figures announced here today. It was more than $8,593,000 greater than for 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Reaction among Republicans generally was that the President's message to Congress tonight was a dramatic political speech and the opening of his campaign for re-election. Opinion of Democrats was that, while the President failed to recommend much legislation, his message was intended only as a prelude and that specific recommendations would follow.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 3. -- The eighth and semi-final round in the international chess masters' tournament at the White Rock Pavilion today brought together Reuben Fine of New York, the leader, and Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland, the only two of the ten competitors who have not yet met with defeat.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- British Government securities were adversely affected today by the appearance of the big Australian conversion loan although the market appeared confident of the success of the flotation. Elsewhere the business transacted was smaller than that of yesterday in spite of the number of firm features among the industrials.

With the sailor's good luck omen of rain signalizing its departure, the main body of the American Olympic Winter sports squad -- forty-five strong -- departed on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday for Garmisch-Partenkirchen and the fourth Olympic Winter Games.

BUDAPEST, Jan. 3. -- The problem of what is to happen to Hungary in case of the death of Regent Horthy -- a question hitherto taboo for every politician -- was raised by the leader of the oppositional Farmers' party, Dr. Tibor Eckhardt, in a speech answering New Year's wishes from his supporters.

Coal merchants along the East River in Yorkville and Harlem expressed relief yesterday in Special Sessions when Mollie P. Jones, 30 years old, a Negro motor-truck owner, was found guilty of the theft of five tons of coal in the snowstorm on Christmas night from a barge moored at East Ninety-ninth Street.

Christmas trees are frowned upon in Soviet Russia, but New Year's fir trees are good Communist doctrine. Rumor says that such a tree with candles and decorations has been set up in the Kremlin. Santa Claus is, of course, bourgeois, if not actually kulak; he owns no less than eight reindeer -- Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Ponder, Blitzen.
