Varying opinions are being voiced why living here has become such a perilous matter that a distinguished and valued citizen feels he must establish a domicile far removed from his own country. Among the countless theories and panaceas being advanced is the following, spoken from a New York pulpit by the Rev. Minot Simons:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- In the midst of a formal session devoted to organization, the Senate paused today to extend birthday greetings to Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, who was born seventy-eight years ago tomorrow.

ROME, Jan. 3. -- The Tribuna this evening prints an impassioned appeal by its editor. Senator Forges d'Avanzati, to America not to become a victim of British propaganda when the moment comes to frame a new neutrality law and to reflect at length on the consequences America's interpretation of neutrality may have on the course of European events.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- Publication of the French tax returns for the first eleven months of 1935 and the revelation that there was a deficit on estimates of more than 4,500,000,000 francs from indirect taxation was one of the causes of the sudden collapse of prices on the Bourse today.
Contracts for the sale of several housing properties in the Bronx were reported by brokers yesterday. A deal for a site to be improved with a new building also was announced.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 3. -- A new Italian threat has developed on the Southern Ethiopian front, the invaders being reported at Badu Danan, half-way between the Fafan and Webbe Shibeli Rivers. This place is on a road leading eastward to Gabredarre and another leading northward to Dagaha Modo.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 (AP). -- The New York State Department of Education ended its disagreement with the Works Progress Administration over salaries paid in emergency nursery schools today and announced it would resume operation of forty-five such schools and parent education classes in twenty-five up-State communities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Dr. Silber C. Peacock, prominent pediatrician, was found slain tonight in his automobile on the North Side, less than twenty-four hours after he was decoyed to his death by a telephoned plea to attend "a sick child."

General agreement with the preliminary findings of the joint legislative committee investigating real estate bondholders' committees was expressed in a letter from Lewis H. Pounds made public yesterday by Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, chairman of the committee.

Special educational attention for young people who are hard of hearing was urged last night at a dinner meeting celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing. About 200 persons attended the dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3. -- Princeton's hockey team had little trouble downing Williams College in the Hobey Baker Rink today, scoring three goals in both the first and third periods to win, 6 -- 1.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday a letter to Park Commissioner Robert Moses reiterating its objection to the construction of a playground on the Central Park Casino site.

The Greenwich Savings Bank yesterday bought in on a bid of $500,000 the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street, three buildings known as 660-666 Eighth Avenue and 261 West Forty-second Street. The bank acquired the realty at an auction sale conducted at 18 Vesey Street by I. Lincoln Seide, auctioner, in an action against the Perlned Corporation.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Governor Lehman said today that he was "amused and most gratified" by the Republican statements charging him with "helping himself" in his annual message to parts of the Republican legislative agenda.
LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The biggest profits since 1931 were reported today by Barclays Bank, Ltd., the largest bank in the country and the first of the "Big Five" to issue its 1935 balance sheet.

Last evening the National Academy of Design opened with a reception its all-portrait show, the canvases painted by full-fledged N.A.'s and associate members. Fifty-three artists are represented by one portrait each.

The three-story Ploughchester Building at Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, has been sold to an investor through Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co. The structure, representing an investment of $300,000, contains seven stoes with offices above. It was erected in 1930 by the Bache Construction Company for the Ploughchester Realty Company (Leonard A. Davidow and Allan A. Plough).
OVERSEXED and theme-ridden, "Men and Brethren" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50) is likely to widen James Gould Cozzens's reputation, but unlikely to strengthen it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Although only one bill, the Pittman neutrality measure, was introduced at the opening session of the Senate today, a flood of measures went into the House hopper.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 3. -- As an aftermath of the escape by two desperadoes from the Middlesex County jail here Dec. 14, the grand jury indicted today Alfred H. Puerschner of 211 Rutgers Street, suspended warden, for malfeasance and made recommendations for correcting the "woefully inefficient" management of the jail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly in the week ended on Dec. 28, but retail food prices for the two weeks ended on Dec. 17 remained unchanged, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Jointly occupying the cabin of a steam shovel, Mayor La Guardia and Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, launched the $12,500,000 Ten Eyck housing project in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, yesterday before 3,000 persons who braved the rain to look on.

Federal Judge Caffey, acting yesterday on a motion by John J. Burns, general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, set aside the service of subpoenas upon members of the commission in suits brought by the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, the United Corporation and other public utility companies.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 3. -- The establishment of a connection between the League of Nations and the Pan American Union was suggested this morning by Jose Antuna, Uruguayan Government delegate, in an address before the labor conference of nineteen American nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The atmosphere of the White House today reflected none of the excitement with which the capital awaited President Roosevelt's message. He worked on it for several hours during the day, completing it just before 4 o'clock this afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The attention of this correspondent has been drawn to the fact that a dispatch he sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Munich on Nov. 8, describing the impressive anniversary ceremony with which the dead of the Nazi putsch of 1923 were then honored, contained an erroneous statement. The dispatch said:

Bob Healy's goal in 7:28 of the second period broke a 1 -- 1 deadlock and enabled the pace-setting Textile High School team to turn back Brooklyn Tech, 2 -- 1, in the feature game of a P.S.A.L. hockey tripleheader at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- Moderate receipts of hogs here today lifted prices 10 to 20 cents a hundred-weight over yesterday's level, but part of the advance was lost. Shipping demand was aggressive early, with heavier weights generally favored.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- An indefinite extension of the unlisted trading privileges on national securities Exchanges while it gradually works out a broad policy to obtain adequate information for investors from all corporations and other issuers of substantial size whose issues are not now registered under the provisions of the Securities Act of 1934, was recommended to Congress today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- As a preliminary step toward carrying into effect proposals to place the State administration of unemployment relief on a permanent basis as an agency within the State Department of Social Welfare, Governor Lehman transmitted to the Senate and Assembly today a report submitted by his Commission on Unemployment Relief, following a survey conducted during the last eighteen months.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 3. -- While the Estonian dictatorial regime is still engaged in rounding up participants in the recent futile Fascist revolt, Premier Konstantin Paets in a New Year message foreshadows at least a partial return to constitutional rule.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- In his opening message to the second session of the Seventy-fourth Congress, delivered personally at an unprecedented joint session in the House chamber tonight, and broadcast by radio to millions of listeners throughout the world, President Roosevelt threw down a challenge to critics of the New Deal to come out into the open at once and fight in Congress, the people's forum, for repeal of the administration's measures.
Beginning at 6 P.M. today, the Globe will show "Navy Wife," by Kathleen Norris. Made by Twentieth Century-Fox, the film features Claire Trevor, Ben Lyon and Ralph Bellamy.

NOT only is college basketball whooping along to unprecedented prosperity in this area but the approaching clash between Fordham and N.Y.U. on the Madison Square Garden floor carries an added bit of flavor because of the late Fall battle on the gridiron. Once again the Maroon has a chance to spoil a great record by a Violet team.
ROME, Jan. 3 -- The whole Italian press continues to demand most insistently that the war in East Africa be prosecuted with greater vigor and greater sternness.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- A crisis in the relief situation in Illinois, where 300,000 families have been fed from Federal funds which have ceased, approached the boiling point today. The Governor and the Mayor of Chicago are at swords' points over the spending of funds collected from the State's 3 per cent sales tax. The present relief funds will be exhausted Jan. 15.

Lower liquor prices resulting from tariff reductions under the Canadian-American trade pact spurred purchases yesterday in local stores despite weather conditions that ordinarily would have decreased buying. In some instances department store executives declared the additional sales were sufficient to bring the total dollar-volume of business above that of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- There were some hints today that the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill would seek to obtain Senate action first on the bonus in an attempt to get a bill that would be less objectionable to the administration than some others.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 3. -- Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler struck out tonight at war in an address before the third United States Congress Against War and Fascism.

At the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Horse Show Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Alfred B. Maclay of New York City and Milbrook, N.Y., tendered his resignation after ten years of service as president.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 3. -- The first experimental evidence of the existence of another fundamental particle of matter, which scientists have been hunting for the past few years in the primordial atomic jungle without success, was reported today before the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Professor Kenneth T. Bainbridge and Dr. Edward B. Jordan of the Research Laboratory of Physics, Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Closing the first half of the 1936 fiscal year with a deficit of $1,879,651,192 and a gross public debt of $30,557,324,062, the government registered heavier receipts despite the large slump in processing taxes, and greater expenditures than during the corresponding period of last year, the Treasury announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The text of the Administration's new neutrality bill, introduced today in the Senate by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada and in the House by Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee, follows:

CHICAGO, Jan, 3. -- Declaring that the Guffey Coal Act is unconstitutional in his opinion, Federal Judge John P. Barnes today granted a temporary injunction to the Truax-Traer Company restraining Federal officials from collecting part of the taxes imposed under the act.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Following are the twenty-one major recommendations regarding State and local welfare organization and policy made by Governor Lehman's Commission on Unemployment Relief in its report to him:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

Charging that prison-made articles are on the whole inferior to those produced in private industry and that they are in most cases more expensive, Russell Forbes, New York City Commissioner of Purchase, defied the State Department of Correction yesterday in placing private orders totaling $25,000 to the lowest bidders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- John J. Brosnan Jr. of 715 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, was designated by the War Department today from the Fifth New York Congressional District for the entrance examination on March 3, with a view to admission to the United States Military Academy at the term beginning July 1.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Members of the county grand jury split tonight on the question of how and why Thelma Todd came to her death, after an all-day survey of the place where the screen actress lived and near which she was found dead.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The text of the Administration's new neutrality bill, introduced today in the Senate by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada and in the House by Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee, follows:

CHICAGO, Jan, 3. -- Declaring that the Guffey Coal Act is unconstitutional in his opinion, Federal Judge John P. Barnes today granted a temporary injunction to the Truax-Traer Company restraining Federal officials from collecting part of the taxes imposed under the act.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Following are the twenty-one major recommendations regarding State and local welfare organization and policy made by Governor Lehman's Commission on Unemployment Relief in its report to him:

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Custody of Catherine Hegeman Vanderbilt, 4, was awarded to her mother, Mrs. Catherine Farmer Vanderbilt of Greenville, in a decision filed in the Supreme Court here today by Justice Pierce H. Russell. The child's father, George V. Vanderbilt, had sought custody of his daughter in a habeas corpus proceeding.

The final plan for reorganization of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation, providing for forgiveness of a $3,511,523 indebtedness to the landlord and cancellation of $2,189,785 in accrued interest, was made public yesterday in the report of George Brokaw Compton as special master in the reorganization proceedings.

With three national champions, Glenn Cunningham, Eulace Peacock and Joe McCluskey, as well as many other spiked-shoe luminaries included in an entry of more than 600, the 1936 track and field campaign will get under way tonight with the tenth annual Columbus Council, K. of C. meet at the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn.

Sharp disagreement with Governor Lehman's proposal to regulate private employment agencies, contained in his recent message to the Legislature, was expressed yesterday by Karl M. Wehinger, publicity chairman of the New York Association of Commercial Employment Bureaus and head of Wehinger Service, a firm of employment consultants.

New building plans filed with the Department of Buildings in Manhattan during 1935 totaled $24,930,865, or about 38 per cent more than the figure for the previous year, which was $18,055,610, according to figures compiled yesterday.
Fusion employes of the Aldermanic President's office were quietly informed yesterday that their resignations would be in order before Monday's meeting of the new Board of Aldermen.

HONOLULU, Jan. 3. -- Prospects of a maritime strike settlement appeared somewhat brighter this afternoon as three Hilo stevedores were reinstated by the Matson line. A spokesman for the line said here that the crew of the liner Malolo had agreed to work the ship pending further advices from the San Francisco headquarters of the Maritime Union.
GENEVA, Jan. 3. -- For the second successive year registered unemployment in the world showed a decline in 1935, according to the International Labor Office quarterly report, out today.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, will come to the Capitol tomorrow for a conference with Speaker Irving M. Ives and Ansley B. Borkowski, clerk of the Assembly, in connection with the distribution of $250,000 of House patronage to the party faithful, it was disclosed tonight.
Should brown trout be introduced in speckled trout areas?

The eleventh annual exhibition of the New York Society of Women Artists opened with a reception yesterday afternoon on the thirty-third floor art galleries of the Squibb Building. The paintings and sculpture will remain on view there through Jan. 18.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Francis J. Heafy took action today to establish himself as the duly appointed City Clerk of Yonkers. Meanwhile William McCabe, holdover City Clerk, continued to occupy the offices and refused to relinquish the position.

Two boys who, the police said, admitted they did it for a thrill, were arrested yesterday afternoon for setting fire to a four-story brick tenement house at 166 South Fourth Street, near Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. The boys are Roger Petz, 18 years old, of 164 South Fourth Street, and David Klinger, 15, of 101 South Eighth Street.

Dr. Anderson believes it is imperative that we immediately reduce excess reserves of the Federal Reserve System. Mr. Gilbert, on the other hand, believes it is not yet the time. Both, however, agree on the problem -- their difference is only one of timing.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 (London Times Dispatch). -- The German public continues to be instructed on the colonial question in preparation, it is supposed, for demands that the German Government is expected to make when a suitable moment arrives.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Don Creole, consistent son of Crack Brigade, representing the Detroit-owned Odessa Farms, defeated seven other 3-year-olds over the one-mile distance of the San Blas Purse today at Tropical Park. The gelding, making his local record three victories and a second in four starts, skipped home by four lengths to give favorite players their first score in five races.

Isidore Lazarowitz, 56-year-old janitor of a tenement at 90 Ludlow Street, died last night from injuries he received when he attempted to capture two men whom he surprised robbing the cellar of the five-story building. One of the pair escaped but the second was captured and turned over to the police.

A complete investigation by city authorities of the administration of home relief in the city, with special reference to the percentage of relief money expended for administrative costs, is in progress, it was learned yesterday.

CRITICISM is at best so near to self-reproduction that it is very difficult to be objective. In Ireland, where life and letters are so much of a compact, cozy, intimate fellowship where every one knows every one else, this is particularly true.

ROME, Jan. 4. -- It was rather with a sense of relief than otherwise that Italians read the terms of the proposed new American Neutrality Law. From all they had heard of the general trend of public opinion in the United States and the temper of the White House they had been led to expect far worse.

More than 2,000 women have received invitations to a tea at the Hotel Astor on Thursday afternoon honoring Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of the Hadassah organization, which is sponsoring the function. At this time Miss Szold, whose seventy-fifth anniversary is being celebrated throughout the country by Jewish groups, will make her first and possibly her only public address during her current visit to this country from Palestine.

When the world's ranking professional tennis players meet in competition on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, they will be performing the double service of providing an interesting sports exhibition and at the same time contributing to a widely known philanthropic organization.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 3. -- William Aberhart, Alberta's Prime Minister and head of her Social Credit government, is not surprised that the Townsend plan is receiving wide attention in the United States and is likely to become an issue in the coming national elections.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 4. -- After two years of work training deaf and mute boys in scouting, Hermon L. Toof, Brown University junior, looks forward today toward his third year in charge of one of the most unusual of the special welfare projects sponsored by the Brown Christian Association.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 4. -Harper Sibley of Rochester, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, raised doubts tonight about the "no new taxes" part of President Roosevelt's address to Congress.

Under the direction of a committee headed by Mrs. Marjorie M. Wise as chairman, plans for the annual ball of the Criterion Society at the Hotel Plaza on Thursday evening will include a spectacular decorative background in black and white.

A buoyant tone in domestic corporate issues was the feature of bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The combined price average for that section again established a new high, on a gain of 0.25 point, while the turnover in the category was the largest for a Saturday in more than ten years, or since Dec. 19, 1925.

RETAIL trade held up unexpectedly well after Christmas, according to reports from a number of sections of the country. Volume ran 3 or 4 per cent above a year ago. New Year's expenditures for the record celebration may affect merchandise business but before the holiday undoubtedly furnished some expansion of apparel and accessory demand.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- "Let them propose to this Congress the complete repeal of these measures. The way is open to such a proposal."

The number of employes in the steel industry last November was 438,370, a gain of 15 per cent over the 381,663 in November, 1934, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. In October, 1935, the industry had 436,554 employes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The nation's death rate from all causes as indicated today in reports from eighty-six cities to the Department of Commerce remained unchanged in 1935 as compared with 1934.
A fire in Harlem last night in which twenty-four firemen were overcome brought Mayor La Guardia to the sceen from his Fifth Avenue apartment.

FEW men have had better opportunities than Dr. Charles Franklin Thwing to learn about higher education in America, and few have made as assiduous use of them. For thirty-one years, until his retirement with the title of president emeritus in 1921, Dr. Thwing was president of Western Reserve University and Adelbert College.

TO a superficial judgment the difference between poetical drama and dramatic poetry might not seem any greater than that between bluish green and greenish blue, or between Tweedledum and Tweedledee; yet the distinction is valid and real, and connotes a fundamental variance of approach, method and final effect.

Witty and delightful drawings, in color, of cities, ancient, modern and legendary, one for each letter of the alphabet; thus J stands for Jerusalem, with a group of crusaders in the foreground, I for Ilium, with its imposing wooden horse, X for Xanadu, and there is a castle (C is for Carcassonne); and a lighthouse (E is for Eddystone), thrown in for good measure.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were more numerous and diversified than in the preceding week, despite the New Year's Day holiday. The calls, the largest of which were in the public utility and industrial fields, were nearly all for future months, only four being for January.

Objective teaching methods as opposed to abstract forms of instruction will receive special attention in the public schools this year, with activities already under way to provide materials and techniques which will give reality to the printed word.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3. -- The blacklisting blow, long threatened by the American Association of University Professors against the University of Pittsburgh, was delivered this week, from the convention of the organization in St. Louis, and Chancellor John G. Bowman's laconic comment, "What of it?" gives a pretty good line on the community cleavage.

Notwithstanding its several failures, the end of attempts at international sugar control is not in sight, according to Earl D. Babst, chairman of the board of directors of the American Sugar Refining Company, who foresees a world sugar conference under the auspices of Great Britain and encouraged by the United States and the Soviet Union.

There appears to be a general impression in the United States and abroad that the United States Government assumed certain obligations and commitments under the Pact of Paris which, in fact, were not assumed.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 4. -- Col. Greene, a 4-year-old gelding that raced consistently in New England, outfooted four rivals to win the sixth event, a handicap at a mile and a sixteenth that topped an eight-race card at Tropical Park today.
CAMDEN, S.C. -- The Kirkwood, Camden's largest resort hotel, of which Karl P. Abbott is owner, opened yesterday with more than a hundred early reservations made, forty of them by new visitors.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 4. -- The appointment of four outstanding leaders in education, the theatre, science and sociology as honorary fellows of Union College, was announced tonight by President Fox before he departed for the annual tour of alumni associations in Buffalo, Erie, Cleveland, Detroit and Chicago.

Is it so certain that Mr. ROOSEVELT scored an enormous advantage by addressing Congress at 9 P.M. instead of approximately 12 noon? If he had chosen to address Congress at noon on Friday or shortly after that hour, he would have had an enormous radio audience.

FROM landscapes in festive colors to abstractions and semi-abstractions with humor is the jump Oliver Chaffee has negotiated in the course of his development. His present show at the Morton Galleries (to Jan. 13) consists of work in the later vein.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- The German Government has just issued a decree further restricting the amount of property emigrants may take out of Germany and dispose of abroad. This new order applies to all emigrants except those to Palestine, for whom special new regulations are to be issued soon.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- This city ended 1935 with a budget deficit estimated $4,500,000, compared with $9,300,000 for 1934 and $11,500,000 for two years ago. Receipts from real estate and personal property taxes and water rents all exceeded the official estimates.
WHAT is the big news in the latest styles?" the writer recently asked an authority who spends her time between Paris and New York. With no hesitation the authority replied: "Fabrics."

The European gold-standard currencies continued to decline yesterday in the foreign exchange market. The franc fell to 6.59 1/4 cents, only a small fraction above the price at which gold exports from Paris to this country can be resumed, and it closed at 6.59 3/8 cents, reflecting a loss of 1/2 point for the day, but a net gain of 5/8 point for last week.

Now that the annual reviews of the business and financial progress in 1935 and the forecasts for 1936 have been scanned, the financial community is facing the future with some degree of confidence. President Roosevelt's address at the second session of the Seventy-fourth Congress did not shake this confidence.
Three days before President Roosevelt addressed Congress on the state of the nation, Governor Lehman presented to the New York Legislature his annual message on the condition of the State.

Marking the 110th anniversary of the Old Guard of the City of New York, a Blue and Gray Ball will be given by the organization on Jan. 31 at the Commodore. The ball, dedicated to Civil War veterans of both the North and South, is expected to draw an attendance of nearly 5,000 persons, according to Colonel Edward Havemeyer Snyder, who has commanded the organization for eighteen years.
ATLANTA, Jan. 4. -- A decline in retail trade was recorded in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP). -- In defense of a section of the New York Milk Control Act, which permits dealers without a well-advertised trade name to sell their product in New York City at 1 cent a quart below well-known concerns, John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, told the Supreme Court today that elimination of the differential would produce "strikes, riots and danger of the loss of the milk supply."

DURING the first week of February there will meet at Washington the North American Wild Life Conference. Unprecedented in size and scope, it will include public and private representatives from all the States and, it is hoped, from Canada and Mexico as well.

The events of the story take place at the time of the World War and during the Russian Revolution in the country east of Lake Baikal. Peter, who has figured in other books by this author ("Siberian Gold," "Kubrik the Outlaw," "His Excellency and Peter"), is now in the army, where he is arrested for striking an officer, an act for which, incidentally, there were other reasons than that of insubordination.

WHEN you innocently inquire, "Why ten?" you neatly expose the totally unreasonable, absurdly dogmatic and cruelly arbitrary nature of the annual best-ten lists. Reviewers are bad enough when they are abruptly distributing their huzzahs and damns for the day-to-day cinema.

GENEVA, Jan. 3. -- What are the prospects of peace in the world as the new year opens? One answer on which all here seem agreed is that the future is now much harder than usual to foresee. Most persons also seem to agree that the situation is so complicated and uncertain that it is as hopeless to try to prophesy.

THE new wallpapers, appearing for the first time this month, are important contributions to the modern decorative arts. Gone are the more or less uninteresting and unrelated designs of recent decades which, we know now, had much to do with a temporary decline in the use of wallpaper.

ESPECIALLY when an artist adopts the excellent plan of holding a show not oftener than once in two years, the public approaches his demonstration in a mood that is quizzical as well as eager. Much can have happened in the interim.

SANTIAGO, Chile. MANY years ago an Indian miner prospecting in the hills back of Copiapo, from which so many of Chile's big fortunes have come, unearthed a rudely carved image of the Virgin of the Candles.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Aston Villa's $150,000 venture into the player market is being justified. The five football players obtained, three of them internationalists, are gradually becoming acclimatized at Birmingham and the fortunes of the famous Villans, for weeks in danger of losing their place in the first division of the English League, have taken a definite upward slant since the turn of the year.

GRACE ADAMS maintains a lucid and charming style, yet her brief book overdresses interesting but somewhat skimpy subject-matter. In her introductory chapter she discuses the force of fear. She skims over the pages of history and points to the celebrities of the past who because of shivers and qualms either did or refrained from doing great things.

Twelve blocks of "decrepit dwelling houses, leaning crazily one against another," replaced by a "modern community of bright, sunny homes" -- such, in the language of Secretary ICKES, is the $13,000,000 Federal housing project which he launched in Brooklyn last Friday.

M'SIEU LESTAIRRE PATRICK was seated at his desk discoursing of current hockey affairs between short telephone conversations and the signing of letters having to do with affairs of the Rangers and their farm products. There arose the question as to whether or not he was in favor of letting his stalwart son, Murray Patrick, carry the family chin into the professional prize ring.

BERLIN, Jan. 4. -- President Roosevelt's indictment in his message to Congress of "foreign dictators who enslave their people and drive them into war" created a profound impression in Germany and led to the immediate mobilization of the entire German propaganda apparatus to answer this indictment in so far as it might be applied to Germany.

DETROIT, Jan. 4. -- The next race for the Harmsworth Trophy, emblem of the world's speedboat championship held by Gar Wood, may be run in the Detroit River under revised rules agreed upon by the Yachtsmen's Association of America and the Royal Motor Yacht Club of England.

THE name Tartarian Maple (Acer tartaricum) is one seldom mentioned in landscape literature or by landscape architects, but why this little gem is so neglected is difficult to understand. It needs, to be sure, a formal introduction into the annals of easy-to-grow trees.

BUREAU of Air Commerce figures for 1935 are even more encouraging than year-end estimates would have led one to expect. Subject to slight modifications for final returns for the month of December, Mr. Vidal said last week that the total for passengers on the domestic and foreign (Pan American) air transport systems for the year was 860,000.

If in any human breast hope springs eternal, it is in that of a Congressional leader, arrived in Washington at the beginning of a new session, optimism fairly radiating from him. It will be a short session. The President is known to desire one, and the country will be pleased by an early adjournment.

HAVANA. -- The opening of the second week of the new year finds Havana taking on an appearance of gayety unrivaled for several years. Visitors arriving daily by passenger ships, airplanes and cruise vessels are constantly increasing the vacation throngs in tourist centers.

AIKEN, S.C. -- With the new year begun, Aiken's Winter sports program is ready to get under way. All hunting seasons, with the exception of that for quail, will soon be closed and members of the resort colony will be turning their attention to other fields of entertainment and diversion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4. -- The prospect of another decisive struggle between shipowners and shipworkers confronts the Pacific Coast today. If the break develops, the struggle is certain to present difficult problems for the national administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Beyond attempting to minimize Presidential discretion throughout the bill and to make action mandatory at the outbreak of war, members of Congress who were expected to oppose the administration neutrality proposal indicated today that they would offer little obstruction to its passage.

There is certainly room for a difference of opinion as to the relative merits of the two proposed plans for modernizing our present calendar. Though the State Chamber of Commerce has advocated the adoption of the equal quarters calendar, twenty-five or more chambers of commerce in other parts of the country have been just as emphatic in recommending the adoption of the thirteen equal months plan.

Unless the Municipal Assembly enacts and Mayor La Guardia signs a local law providing for deferred collection of substantial amounts of accrued and future real estate and franchise taxes on the Interborough and Manhattan Railway Company properties, the Federal receivers for those companies will be free to oppose condemnation and removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line.

A little account that has rankled in New York University breasts since Thanksgiving Day was settled at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 18,000 intensely partisan Violet supporters roared its acclaim, an N.Y.U. team that had far from forgotten the upset to its Rose Bowl football hopes in November utterly routed Fordham in the third of the college basketball double-headers.

Responding to an urge which he was unable to explain to the satisfaction of the police, Walter E. Kasin sent pedestrians scurrying for shelter in an effort to dodge the chairs, lamps and other furniture Kasin threw from his ninth-floor room in the Hotel Roosevelt shortly afternoon yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Highway Department said today that more than 200 men have been hired to survey the old South Penn right-of-way, the $10,000,000 "relic" of an old railroad struggle, for a proposed all-weather super-highway between Harrisburg and Pittsburgh.
IT promises to be a year marked by augmented communal developments, whether these be carried on under the auspices of our government or of the municipality.

Predicting that the costs of city hospitals would rise steadily in the future, "if present economic conditions continue," Mayor La Guardia dedicated yesterday the new Women's Pavilion of Harlem Hospital, in West 137th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues.

Although wholesale and retail trade experienced the usual seasonal decline last week, the volume throughout the country continued to run somewhat ahead of that of a year ago. Store volume was about 3 to 5 per cent greater than the corresponding week of last year, while wholesale totals registered gains up to 10 per cent.

With the first closing date set for one week from tomorrow, entries for the sixtieth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Feb. 10, 11 and 12 are pouring into the club's offices, 381 Fourth Avenue.
PARIS, Jan. 4. -- French rentes opened hesitant today and weakened slightly, while in unofficial trading, dollars and sterling again moved against the franc.

A scheduled appearance of Dr. John F. (Jafsie) Condon, important witness aganst Bruno Richard Hauptmann, at a Plainfield, N.J., theatre was protested yesterday in a resolution adopted by a group of twenty-five ministers who condemned it as "exploitation of human tragedy."

Activity in Shorters Court, London, which during the depression dwindled to a mere shadow of its former self, has returned. To the initiated this means that the British again are purchasing securities on the Stock Exchanges here.

MADRID, Dec. 20, 1935. THE Madrid music season opened with the first concert of the fifteenth annual series offered by the Asociacion de Cultura Musical, presenting the first local appearance of the 26-year-old Austrian pianist, Kurt Engel, a winner in the 1932 Warsaw concert.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 4. -- A pre-school group for children from 2 to 5 years of age, known as the Pre-School Group of Smith College, is being held this year at the People's Institute in Northampton. The group meets five mornings a week during the college year and the children may enjoy the special quarters and large outdoor playground provided for them without charge.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 4. -- David Williams, 14-year-old Greenwich boy, today captured the first competition of the new year for the Maclay Cup in jumping. He scored in a field of twenty at the sixth annual indoor horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

A net lose of $3,976,920 for the Illinois Central Railroad in 1935 is estimated in a statement filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. This was based on returns for the first ten months of the year and calculated net incomes of $355,000 in November and $92,100 in December.

WHEN Arizona was a frontier Territory there was undying enmity between Painted Post, county seat of Indian County and metropolis of the surrounding ranch country, and Los Pasos, nest of El Scorpio and his gang of rustlers and murderers and of numerous other scoundrelly knaves in both high and low estate.

Relief workers on WPA payrolls are refusing to take jobs in private industry, it was disclosed yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator. The problem of what to do with them is becoming acute and Mr. Ridder is seeking a solution.

Packard Motor Car Company resumed yesterday the payment of dividends on the common stock with a declaration by the board of directors of a disbursement of 10 cents a share payable on Feb. 11 to stock of record Jan. 15. The last payment, which also was 10 cents a share, was made on Dec. 12, 1931.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Retail trade got off to an auspicious start, with sales of the larger stores after Christmas running 3 to 4 per cent ahead of a year earlier, and the volume of gift exchanges and refunds less than usual. House furnishings and white goods were in demand, as were rugs advertised in a special odd-lots sale of one of the stores.

WITH the opening of Congress, Washington again is in full swing as the national Riviera of politics and patriotic sightseeing. The apartment hotels have hung out their "no vacancy" signs; the 111 transient hotels have tidied up their remotest corners and alcoves for a peak demand on sleeping space; the night clubs have spiced up their programs with new numbers sprinkled with political allusions.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 4. -- Secretary Ickes denounced here today the policies of taxation which he declared were being advocated by many of those "screaming" against the Roosevelt program. He asserted that the ideal of taxation according to the ability to pay and the benefits derived had been accepted as basic for more than 1,000 years and that it was in antithesis to the clamor for "soaking the poor."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4. -- Memories of a night at the height of the August storm of 1933, which laid waste long stretches of the Atlantic Coast, were recalled with the presentation of the Congressional medal for heroism to Thomas J. Steinhise, 57-year-old keeper of the lighthouse at Seven-Foot Knoll.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 30, 1935. A MUSICIAN under the baton of Sir Arthur Sullivan, Johann Strauss, the great Arthur Nikisch and many other celebrated conductors, a trombone teacher of the composer Henry Hadley, and one of the two living charter members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra marked his eighty-second birthday here last Nov. 23 -- and he is still an active musician!

St. Michael's High of Union City scored an impressive 30-26 triumph over St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn in the final game of the interscholastic basketball triple-header yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 4,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- The development by Temple University in physical growth and academic attainment is revealed in a "ten-years-of-progress" survey, made public today in connection with the closing of the tenth year of the administration of Dr. Charles E. Beury, as president.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The Montclair Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club shared the lead in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets League as a result of victories today.

Pageantry, customs, and amusements borrowed from the holiday known in Northern Europe and old England as Twelfth Night or "Little Christmas" will entertain more than 750 members of the Schoolwomen's Club of Newark tomorrow night, when they gather at the Essex House there with their husbands and guests.

In one highly important respect the Neutrality Bill introduced in Congress with the support of the Administration proposes to increase the authority of the President. The existing law, as officially interpreted, gives him power to place an embargo only upon weapons of war.

Members of the younger set, headed by Miss Mary de Mumm, are taking an active interest in the premiere showing of the motion picture, "Rose of the Rancho," with Gladys Swarthout in the leading role, which will take place on Tuesday night at the Paramount Theatre for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador. -- Divorce under the new "quick-and-easy" law threatens to reach the proportions of a popular fad, although the administering officials have succeeded in effecting reconciliations in a number of cases by using tactful methods.

Always an exceedingly restless organization when it comes to mapping out Spring training campaigns. Colonel Bill Terry and his New York Giants will be moving strictly along traditional lines this year, according to the 1936 exhibition schedule announced yesterday by Secretary Jim Tierney.

Reminiscence will be the order of the day tomorrow afternoon at Passaic, N.J., as the Monday Afternoon Club, largest federated group of women in the community, celebrates the forty-fifth anniversary of its founding. Commodore Herbert Hartley, U.S.N.R., former commander of the Leviathan, will pay his respects to the members and make the principal address.

The debate concerning the study of Greek in our schools raises an issue of vital importance to modern education. For if one accept, as a mere convenient yardstick, Arnold's dictum that liberal education should be a symposium of the best that has been thought and done in the world, then it is appalling to notice how high school students come up to the universities with little or no first-hand knowledge of the ancients.

A city-wide drive to prevent unescorted children under 16 years of age from attending motion-picture theatres was launched yesterday by members of the Police Department's Juvenile Aid Bureau, headed by Byrnes MacDonald.

Why sanctions, boycotts, threats of war against Italy? She has no quarrel with the League of Nations. She merely wants breathing space for her closely packed population. But England refuses! She imagines her supremacy in Africa and on the Mediterranean imperiled.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Many sports and social events will be provided for this city's Winter visitors, now that the season is in full swing. Golfers, recruited from the resort hotel colony, will begin their first tournament today, a mixed foursome at the Pasadena Course.
